<poems>
  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1784</date>
    <title>To the South Downs (Elegiac Sonnets)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, hills beloved! where once, a happy child,</line>
      <line>Your beechen shades, ‘your turf, your flowers among’,</line>
      <line>I wove your bluebells into garlands wild,</line>
      <line>And woke your echoes with my artless song –</line>
      <line>Ah, hills beloved! your turf, your flowers, remain,</line>
      <line>But can they peace to this sad breast restore –</line>
      <line>For one poor moment soothe the sense of pain,</line>
      <line>And teach a breaking heart to throb no more?</line>
      <line>And you, Aruna, in the vale below,</line>
      <line>O As to the sea your limpid waves you bear,</line>
      <line>Can you one kind Lethean cup bestow</line>
      <line>To drink a long oblivion to my care?</line>
      <line>Ah no! when all, e’en hope’s last ray, is gone,</line>
      <line>There’s no oblivion – but in death alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1786</date>
    <title>To a Mountain Daisy, on Turning One Down with the Plough</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wee, modest, crimson-tippéd flower,</line>
      <line>Thou’s met me in an evil hour;</line>
      <line>For I maun crush amang the stoure</line>
      <line>Thy slender stem:</line>
      <line>To spare thee now is past my power,</line>
      <line>Thou bonnie gem.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas! It’s no thy neebor sweet,</line>
      <line>The bonnie lark, companion meet,</line>
      <line>Bending thee ’mang the dewy weet,</line>
      <line>O Wi’ spreckled breast,</line>
      <line>When upward-springing, blythe, to greet</line>
      <line>The purpling east.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cauld blew the bitter-biting north</line>
      <line>Upon thy early, humble birth;</line>
      <line> Yet cheerfully thou glinted forth</line>
      <line>Amid the storm,</line>
      <line>Scarce reared above the parent-earth</line>
      <line>Thy tender form.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The flaunting flowers our gardens yield,</line>
      <line>O High sheltering woods and wa’s maun shield;</line>
      <line>But thou, beneath the random bield</line>
      <line>O’ clod or stane,</line>
      <line>Adorns the histie stibble-field,</line>
      <line>Unseen, alane.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There, in thy scanty mantle clad,</line>
      <line>Thy snawie bosom sun-ward spread,</line>
      <line>Thou lifts thy unassuming head</line>
      <line>In humble guise;</line>
      <line>But now the share uptears thy bed,</line>
      <line>O And low thou lies!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such is the fate of artless maid,</line>
      <line>Sweet floweret of the rural shade,</line>
      <line>By love’s simplicity betrayed,</line>
      <line>And guileless trust;</line>
      <line>Till she, like thee, all soiled, is laid</line>
      <line>Low i’ the dust.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such is the fate of simple bard,</line>
      <line>On Life’s rough ocean luckless starred!</line>
      <line>Unskilful he to note the card</line>
      <line>O Of prudent lore,</line>
      <line>Till billows rage, and gales blow hard,</line>
      <line>And whelm him o’er!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such fate to suffering Worth is given,</line>
      <line>Who long with wants and woes has striven,</line>
      <line>By human pride or cunning driven</line>
      <line>To misery’s brink;</line>
      <line>Till, wrenched of every stay but Heaven,</line>
      <line>He, ruined, sink!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Even thou who mournst the Daisy’s fate,</line>
      <line>O That fate is thine – no distant date –</line>
      <line>Stern Ruin’s plough-share drives elate,</line>
      <line>Full on thy bloom,</line>
      <line>Till crushed beneath the furrow’s weight</line>
      <line>Shall be thy doom!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1794</date>
    <title>A London Summer Morning</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who has not waked to list the busy sounds</line>
      <line>Of summer morning in the sultry smoke</line>
      <line>Of noisy London? On the pavement hot</line>
      <line>The sooty chimney-boy, with dingy face</line>
      <line>And tattered covering, shrilly hawks his trade,</line>
      <line>Rousing the sleepy housemaid. At the door</line>
      <line>The milk-pail rattles, and the tinkling bell</line>
      <line>Proclaims the dustman’s office, while the street</line>
      <line>Is lost in clouds impervious. Now begins</line>
      <line>O The din of hackney coaches, wagons, carts;</line>
      <line>While tin-men’s shops, and noisy trunk-makers,</line>
      <line>Knife-grinders, coopers, squealing cork-cutters,</line>
      <line>Fruit-barrows, and the hunger-giving cries</line>
      <line>Of vegetable vendors, fill the air.</line>
      <line>Now every shop displays its varied trade,</line>
      <line>And the fresh-sprinkled pavement cools the feet</line>
      <line>Of early walkers. At the private door</line>
      <line>The ruddy housemaid twirls the busy mop,</line>
      <line>Annoying the smart ’prentice, or neat girl</line>
      <line>O Tripping with bandbox lightly. Now the sun</line>
      <line>Darts burning splendour on the glittering pane,</line>
      <line>Save where the canvas awning throws a shade</line>
      <line>On the gay merchandise. Now spruce and trim</line>
      <line>In shops where beauty smiles with industry,</line>
      <line> Sits the smart damsel, while the passenger</line>
      <line>Peeps through the window, watching every charm.</line>
      <line>Now pastry dainties catch the eyes minute</line>
      <line>Of hummy insects, while the slimy snare</line>
      <line>Waits to enthral them. Now the lamp-lighter</line>
      <line>O Mounts the slight ladder, nimbly venturous,</line>
      <line>To trim the half-filled lamp, while at his feet</line>
      <line>The pot-boy yells discordant. All along</line>
      <line>The sultry pavement, the old-clothes man cries</line>
      <line>In tone monotonous, and sidelong views</line>
      <line>The area for his traffic. Now the bag</line>
      <line>Is slily opened, and the half-worn suit</line>
      <line>(Sometimes the pilfered treasure of the base</line>
      <line>Domestic spoiler) for one half its worth</line>
      <line>Sinks in the green abyss. The porter now</line>
      <line>O Bears his huge load along the burning way,</line>
      <line>And the poor poet wakes from busy dreams</line>
      <line>To paint the summer morning.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>Kubla Khan</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Xanadu did Kubla Khan</line>
      <line>A stately pleasure-dome decree,</line>
      <line>Where Alph the sacred river ran</line>
      <line>Through caverns measureless to man</line>
      <line>Down to a sunless sea.</line>
      <line>So twice five miles of fertile ground</line>
      <line>With walls and towers were girdled round –</line>
      <line>And there were gardens bright with sinuous rills,</line>
      <line>Where blossomed many an incense-bearing tree;</line>
      <line>O And here were forests ancient as the hills,</line>
      <line>Enfolding sunny spots of greenery.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But oh, that deep romantic chasm, which slanted</line>
      <line>Down the green hill athwart a cedarn cover!</line>
      <line>A savage place, as holy and enchanted</line>
      <line> As e’er beneath a waning moon was haunted</line>
      <line>By woman wailing for her demon lover!</line>
      <line>And from this chasm, with ceaseless turmoil seething</line>
      <line>As if this earth in fast thick pants were breathing,</line>
      <line>A mighty fountain momently was forced,</line>
      <line>O Amid whose swift half-intermitted burst</line>
      <line>Huge fragments vaulted, like rebounding hail</line>
      <line>Or chaffy grain beneath the thresher’s flail;</line>
      <line>And mid these dancing rocks, at once and ever,</line>
      <line>It flung up momently the sacred river.</line>
      <line> Five miles meandering with a mazy motion</line>
      <line>Through wood and dale the sacred river ran,</line>
      <line>Then reached the caverns measureless to man</line>
      <line>And sank in tumult to a lifeless ocean –</line>
      <line>And mid this tumult Kubla heard from far</line>
      <line>O Ancestral voices prophesying war!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shadow of the dome of pleasure</line>
      <line>Floated midway on the waves,</line>
      <line>Where was heard the mingled measure</line>
      <line>From the fountain and the caves.</line>
      <line> It was a miracle of rare device –</line>
      <line>A sunny pleasure-dome with caves of ice!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A damsel with a dulcimer</line>
      <line>In a vision once I saw:</line>
      <line>It was an Abyssinian maid,</line>
      <line>O And on her dulcimer she played</line>
      <line>Singing of Mount Abora.</line>
      <line>Could I revive within me</line>
      <line>Her symphony and song,</line>
      <line>To such a deep delight ’twould win me,</line>
      <line>That with music loud and long</line>
      <line>I would build that dome in air –</line>
      <line>That sunny dome, those caves of ice!</line>
      <line>And all who heard should see them there,</line>
      <line>And all should cry ‘Beware! Beware!’</line>
      <line>O His flashing eyes, his floating hair!</line>
      <line>Weave a circle round him thrice,</line>
      <line>And close your eyes with holy dread,</line>
      <line>For he on honey-dew hath fed</line>
      <line>And drunk the milk of Paradise.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLES LAMB</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Old Familiar Faces</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where are they gone, the old familiar faces?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I had a mother, but she died, and left me,</line>
      <line>Died prematurely in a day of horrors –</line>
      <line>All, all are gone, the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I have had playmates, I have had companions,</line>
      <line>In my days of childhood, in my joyful schooldays –</line>
      <line>All, all are gone, the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have been laughing, I have been carousing,</line>
      <line>Drinking late, sitting late, with my bosom cronies;</line>
      <line>O All, all are gone, the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loved a love once, fairest among women;</line>
      <line>Closed are her doors on me, I must not see her –</line>
      <line>All, all are gone, the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have a friend, a kinder friend has no man;</line>
      <line> Like an ingrate, I left my friend abruptly,</line>
      <line>Left him, to muse on the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ghost-like, I paced round the haunts of my childhood.</line>
      <line>Earth seemed a desert I was bound to traverse,</line>
      <line>Seeking to find the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Friend of my bosom, thou more than a brother,</line>
      <line>Why wert not thou born in my father’s dwelling?</line>
      <line>So might we talk of the old familiar faces –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How some they have died, and some they have left me,</line>
      <line>And some are taken from me – all are departed –</line>
      <line>All, all are gone, the old familiar faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Lucy Gray</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oft had I heard of Lucy Gray,</line>
      <line>And when I crossed the wild</line>
      <line>I chanced to see at break of day</line>
      <line>The solitary child.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> No mate, no comrade, Lucy knew:</line>
      <line>She dwelt on a wild moor,</line>
      <line>The sweetest thing that ever grew</line>
      <line>Beside a human door!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet you may spy the fawn at play,</line>
      <line>O The hare upon the green,</line>
      <line>But the sweet face of Lucy Gray</line>
      <line>Will never more be seen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Tonight will be a stormy night,</line>
      <line>You to the town must go,</line>
      <line> And take a lantern, child, to light</line>
      <line>Your mother through the snow.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘That, father, will I gladly do,</line>
      <line>’Tis scarcely afternoon!</line>
      <line>The minster-clock has just struck two,</line>
      <line>O And yonder is the moon.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At this the father raised his hook</line>
      <line>And snapped a faggot-band;</line>
      <line>He plied his work, and Lucy took</line>
      <line>The lantern in her hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Not blither is the mountain-roe:</line>
      <line>With many a wanton stroke</line>
      <line>Her feet disperse the powdery snow</line>
      <line>That rises up like smoke.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The storm came on before its time;</line>
      <line>O She wandered up and down,</line>
      <line>And many a hill did Lucy climb</line>
      <line>But never reached the town.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wretched parents all that night</line>
      <line>Went shouting far and wide,</line>
      <line> But there was neither sound nor sight</line>
      <line>To serve them for a guide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At daybreak on a hill they stood</line>
      <line>That overlooked the moor,</line>
      <line>And thence they saw the bridge of wood</line>
      <line>O A furlong from their door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now they homeward turned, and cried,</line>
      <line>‘In Heaven we all shall meet’ –</line>
      <line>When in the snow the mother spied</line>
      <line>The print of Lucy’s feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then downward from the steep hill’s edge</line>
      <line>They tracked the footmarks small,</line>
      <line>And through the broken hawthorn-hedge,</line>
      <line>And by the long stone wall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then an open field they crossed –</line>
      <line>O The marks were still the same –</line>
      <line>They tracked them on, nor ever lost,</line>
      <line>And to the bridge they came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They followed from the snowy bank</line>
      <line>The footmarks one by one,</line>
      <line> Into the middle of the plank,</line>
      <line>And further there were none.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet some maintain that to this day</line>
      <line>She is a living child,</line>
      <line>That you may see sweet Lucy Gray</line>
      <line>O Upon the lonesome wild.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O’er rough and smooth she trips along</line>
      <line>And never looks behind,</line>
      <line>And sings a solitary song</line>
      <line>That whistles in the wind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Strange Fits of Passion I Have Known</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Strange fits of passion I have known,</line>
      <line>And I will dare to tell</line>
      <line>But in the lover’s ear alone</line>
      <line>What once to me befell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> When she I loved was strong and gay</line>
      <line>And like a rose in June,</line>
      <line>I to her cottage bent my way</line>
      <line>Beneath the evening moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upon the moon I fixed my eye</line>
      <line>O All over the wide lea;</line>
      <line>My horse trudged on, and we drew nigh</line>
      <line>Those paths so dear to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now we reached the orchard-plot,</line>
      <line>And as we climbed the hill</line>
      <line> Towards the roof of Lucy’s cot</line>
      <line>The moon descended still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In one of those sweet dreams I slept,</line>
      <line>Kind Nature’s gentlest boon,</line>
      <line>And all the while my eyes I kept</line>
      <line>O On the descending moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My horse moved on – hoof after hoof</line>
      <line>He raised and never stopped –</line>
      <line>When down behind the cottage-roof</line>
      <line>At once the planet dropped.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> What fond and wayward thoughts will slide</line>
      <line>Into a lover’s head:</line>
      <line>‘Oh mercy’, to myself I cried,</line>
      <line>‘If Lucy should be dead!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>She Dwelt Among the Untrodden Ways</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She dwelt among the untrodden ways</line>
      <line>Beside the springs of Dove,</line>
      <line>A maid whom there were none to praise</line>
      <line>And very few to love –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A violet by a mossy stone</line>
      <line>Half-hidden from the eye,</line>
      <line>Fair as a star when only one</line>
      <line>Is shining in the sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She lived unknown, and few could know</line>
      <line>O When Lucy ceased to be;</line>
      <line>But she is in her grave, and oh,</line>
      <line>The difference to me!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>A Slumber Did My Spirit Seal</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A slumber did my spirit seal –</line>
      <line>I had no human fears –</line>
      <line>She seemed a thing that could not feel</line>
      <line>The touch of earthly years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> No motion has she now, no force,</line>
      <line>She neither hears nor sees,</line>
      <line>Rolled round in Earth’s diurnal course</line>
      <line>With rocks and stones and trees.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>Three Years She Grew</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Three years she grew in sun and shower,</line>
      <line>Then Nature said: ‘A lovelier flower</line>
      <line>On earth was never sown –</line>
      <line>This child I to myself will take,</line>
      <line> She shall be mine, and I will make</line>
      <line>A lady of my own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Myself will to my darling be</line>
      <line>Both law and impulse, and with me</line>
      <line>The girl – in rock and plain,</line>
      <line>O In earth and heaven, in glade and bower –</line>
      <line>Shall feel an overseeing power</line>
      <line>To kindle or restrain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She shall be sportive as the fawn</line>
      <line>That wild with glee across the lawn</line>
      <line> Or up the mountain springs;</line>
      <line>And hers shall be the breathing balm,</line>
      <line>And hers the silence and the calm,</line>
      <line>Of mute insensate things.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The floating clouds their state shall lend</line>
      <line>O To her, for her the willow bend;</line>
      <line>Nor shall she fail to see</line>
      <line>Even in the motions of the storm</line>
      <line>Grace that shall mould the maiden’s form</line>
      <line>By silent sympathy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The stars of midnight shall be dear</line>
      <line>To her, and she shall lean her ear</line>
      <line>In many a secret place</line>
      <line>Where rivulets dance their wayward round,</line>
      <line>And beauty born of murmuring sound</line>
      <line>O Shall pass into her face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And vital feelings of delight</line>
      <line>Shall rear her form to stately height,</line>
      <line>Her virgin bosom swell –</line>
      <line>Such thoughts to Lucy I will give</line>
      <line> While she and I together live</line>
      <line>Here in this happy dell.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus Nature spake: the work was done.</line>
      <line>How soon my Lucy’s race was run!</line>
      <line>She died – and left to me</line>
      <line>O This heath, this calm and quiet scene,</line>
      <line>The memory of what has been</line>
      <line>And never more will be.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS CAMPBELL</author>
    <date>1801</date>
    <title>Hohenlinden</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>On Linden, when the sun was low,</line>
      <line>All bloodless lay the untrodden snow,</line>
      <line>And dark as winter was the flow</line>
      <line>Of Iser, rolling rapidly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But Linden saw another sight</line>
      <line>When the drum beat at dead of night,</line>
      <line>Commanding fires of death to light</line>
      <line>The darkness of her scenery.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By torch and trumpet fast arrayed,</line>
      <line>O Each horseman drew his battle-blade,</line>
      <line>And furious every charger neighed</line>
      <line>To join the dreadful revelry!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then shook the hills with thunder riven,</line>
      <line>Then rushed the steed to battle driven,</line>
      <line> And louder than the bolts of heaven</line>
      <line>Far flashed the red artillery!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But redder yet that light shall glow</line>
      <line>On Linden’s hills of stainéd snow,</line>
      <line>And bloodier yet the torrent flow</line>
      <line>Of Iser, rolling rapidly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis morn, but scarce yon level sun</line>
      <line>Can pierce the war clouds, rolling dun,</line>
      <line>Where furious Frank and fiery Hun</line>
      <line>Shout in their sulphurous canopy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The combat deepens. On, ye brave,</line>
      <line>Who rush to glory, or the grave!</line>
      <line>Wave, Munich, all thy banners wave!</line>
      <line>And charge with all thy chivalry!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Few, few shall part where many meet!</line>
      <line>O The snow shall be their winding-sheet,</line>
      <line>And every turf beneath their feet</line>
      <line>Shall be a soldier’s sepulchre.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1803</date>
    <title>The Inchcape Rock</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No stir in the air, no stir in the sea,</line>
      <line>The ship was still as she could be,</line>
      <line>Her sails from heaven received no motion,</line>
      <line>Her keel was steady in the ocean.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Without either sign or sound of their shock</line>
      <line>The waves flowed over the Inchcape Rock:</line>
      <line>So little they rose, so little they fell,</line>
      <line>They did not move the Inchcape Bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Abbot of Aberbrothok</line>
      <line>O Had placed that bell on the Inchcape Rock –</line>
      <line>On a buoy in the storm it floated and swung,</line>
      <line>And over the waves its warning rung.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the Rock was hid by the surge’s swell</line>
      <line>The mariners heard the warning bell;</line>
      <line> And then they knew the perilous Rock,</line>
      <line>And blest the Abbot of Aberbrothok.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun in heaven was shining gay,</line>
      <line>All things were joyful on that day:</line>
      <line>The sea-birds screamed as they wheeled around,</line>
      <line>O And there was joyance in their sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The buoy of the Inchcape Rock was seen,</line>
      <line>A darker speck on the ocean green;</line>
      <line>Sir Ralph the Rover walked his deck,</line>
      <line>And he fixed his eye on the darker speck.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He felt the cheering power of spring,</line>
      <line>It made him whistle, it made him sing;</line>
      <line>His heart was mirthful to excess,</line>
      <line>But the Rover’s mirth was wickedness!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His eye was on the Inchcape float –</line>
      <line>O Quoth he, ‘My men, put out the boat,</line>
      <line>And row me to the Inchcape Rock,</line>
      <line>And I’ll plague the Abbot of Aberbrothok!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The boat is lowered, the boatmen row,</line>
      <line>And to the Inchcape Rock they go;</line>
      <line> Sir Ralph bent over from the boat,</line>
      <line>And he cut the Bell from the Inchcape float!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down sunk the Bell with a gurgling sound,</line>
      <line>The bubbles rose and burst around;</line>
      <line>Quoth Sir Ralph, ‘The next who comes to the Rock</line>
      <line>O Won’t bless the Abbot of Aberbrothok!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sir Ralph the Rover sailed away,</line>
      <line>He scoured the seas for many a day;</line>
      <line>And now, grown rich with plundered store,</line>
      <line>He steers his course for Scotland’s shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> So thick a haze o’erspreads the sky</line>
      <line>They cannot see the sun on high;</line>
      <line>The wind hath blown a gale all day,</line>
      <line>At evening it hath died away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the deck the Rover takes his stand,</line>
      <line>O So dark it is they see no land;</line>
      <line>Quoth Sir Ralph, ‘It will be lighter soon,</line>
      <line>For there is the dawn of the rising moon.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Canst hear’, said one, ‘the breakers roar?</line>
      <line>For methinks we should be near the shore.’</line>
      <line> ‘Now where we are I cannot tell,</line>
      <line>But I wish I could hear the Inchcape Bell.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They hear no sound, the swell is strong,</line>
      <line>Though the wind hath fallen, they drift along,</line>
      <line>Till the vessel strikes with a shivering shock –</line>
      <line>O ‘Oh Christ! it is the Inchcape Rock!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sir Ralph the Rover tore his hair –</line>
      <line>He cursed himself in his despair –</line>
      <line>The waves rush in on every side,</line>
      <line>The ship is sinking beneath the tide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But even in his dying fear</line>
      <line>One dreadful sound could the Rover hear,</line>
      <line>A sound as if with the Inchcape Bell</line>
      <line>The Devil below was ringing his knell!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>And Did Those Feet</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And did those feet in ancient time</line>
      <line>Walk upon England’s mountains green?</line>
      <line>And was the holy Lamb of God</line>
      <line>On England’s pleasant pastures seen?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And did the Countenance Divine</line>
      <line>Shine forth upon our clouded hills?</line>
      <line>And was Jerusalem builded here</line>
      <line>Among these dark satanic mills?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bring me my bow of burning gold!</line>
      <line>O Bring me my arrows of desire!</line>
      <line>Bring me my spear – oh clouds unfold!</line>
      <line>Bring me my chariot of fire!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I will not cease from mental fight,</line>
      <line>Nor shall my sword sleep in my hand,</line>
      <line> Till we have built Jerusalem,</line>
      <line>In England’s green and pleasant land.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WALTER SCOTT</author>
    <date>1808</date>
    <title>Lochinvar</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh young Lochinvar is come out of the west,</line>
      <line>Through all the wide Border his steed was the best,</line>
      <line>And save his good broadsword, he weapons had none –</line>
      <line>He rode all unarmed, and he rode all alone.</line>
      <line> So faithful in love, and so dauntless in war,</line>
      <line>There never was knight like the young Lochinvar!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stayed not for brake, and he stopped not for stone,</line>
      <line>He swam the Esk river where ford there was none;</line>
      <line>But ere he alighted at Netherby gate,</line>
      <line>O The bride had consented – the gallant came late!</line>
      <line>For a laggard in love, and a dastard in war,</line>
      <line>Was to wed the fair Ellen of brave Lochinvar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So boldly he entered the Netherby Hall,</line>
      <line>Among bride’s-men, and kinsmen, and brothers, and all;</line>
      <line> Then spoke the bride’s father, his hand on his sword</line>
      <line>(For the poor craven bridegroom said never a word),</line>
      <line>‘Oh come ye in peace here, or come ye in war,</line>
      <line>Or to dance at our bridal, young Lord Lochinvar?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I long wooed your daughter – my suit you denied –</line>
      <line>O Love swells like the Solway, but ebbs like its tide,</line>
      <line>And now am I come, with this lost love of mine</line>
      <line>To lead but one measure, drink one cup of wine.</line>
      <line>There are maidens in Scotland more lovely by far,</line>
      <line>That would gladly be bride to the young Lochinvar.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The bride kissed the goblet, the knight took it up –</line>
      <line>He quaffed off the wine, and he threw down the cup.</line>
      <line>She looked down to blush, and she looked up to sigh,</line>
      <line>With a smile on her lips, and a tear in her eye.</line>
      <line>He took her soft hand, ere her mother could bar –</line>
      <line>O ‘Now tread we a measure!’ said young Lochinvar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So stately his form, and so lovely her face,</line>
      <line>That never a hall such a galliard did grace –</line>
      <line>While her mother did fret, and her father did fume,</line>
      <line>And the bridegroom stood dangling his bonnet and plume;</line>
      <line> And the bride-maidens whispered, ‘’Twere better by far</line>
      <line>To have matched our fair cousin with young Lochinvar.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One touch to her hand, and one word in her ear,</line>
      <line>When they reached the hall-door, and the charger stood near;</line>
      <line>So light to the croup the fair lady he swung,</line>
      <line>O So light to the saddle before her he sprung!</line>
      <line>‘She is won! We are gone, over bank, bush, and scar –</line>
      <line>They’ll have fleet steeds that follow!’ quoth young Lochinvar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was mounting ’mong Graemes of the Netherby clan;</line>
      <line>Forsters, Fenwicks, and Musgraves, they rode and they ran;</line>
      <line> There was racing and chasing on Cannobie Lee,</line>
      <line>But the lost bride of Netherby ne’er did they see –</line>
      <line>So daring in love, and so dauntless in war,</line>
      <line>Have ye e’er heard of gallant like young Lochinvar?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>


  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS MOORE</author>
    <date>1810</date>
    <title>Oh! Blame Not the Bard</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh! blame not the bard, if he fly to the bowers</line>
      <line>Where Pleasure lies carelessly smiling at Fame;</line>
      <line>He was born for much more, and in happier hours</line>
      <line>His soul might have burned with a holier flame.</line>
      <line> The string that now languishes loose o’er the lyre</line>
      <line>Might have bent a proud bow to the warrior’s dart,</line>
      <line>And the lip which now breathes but the song of desire</line>
      <line>Might have poured the full tide of a patriot’s heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But alas for his country! Her pride is gone by,</line>
      <line>O And that spirit is broken which never would bend;</line>
      <line>O’er the ruin her children in secret must sigh,</line>
      <line>For ’tis treason to love her, and death to defend!</line>
      <line>Unprized are her sons, till they’ve learned to betray;</line>
      <line>Undistinguished they live, if they shame not their sires;</line>
      <line> And the torch that would light them through dignity’s way</line>
      <line>Must be caught from the pile where their country expires.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then blame not the bard, if in passion’s soft dream</line>
      <line>He should try to forget what he never can heal:</line>
      <line>Oh, give but a hope – let a vista but gleam</line>
      <line>O Through the gloom of his country – and mark how he’ll feel!</line>
      <line>That instant his heart at her shrine would lay down</line>
      <line>Every passion it nursed, every bliss it adored;</line>
      <line>While the myrtle, now idly entwined with his crown,</line>
      <line>Like the wreath of Harmodius, should cover his sword.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But though glory be gone, and though hope fade away,</line>
      <line>Thy name, loved Erin, shall live in his songs:</line>
      <line>Not e’en in the hour when his heart is most gay</line>
      <line>Will he lose the remembrance of thee and thy wrongs!</line>
      <line>The stranger shall hear thy lament on his plains;</line>
      <line>O The sigh of thy harp shall be sent o’er the deep –</line>
      <line>Till thy masters themselves, as they rivet thy chains,</line>
      <line>Shall pause at the song of thy captive and weep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>‘Revelry by Night’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Self-exiled Harold wanders forth again,</line>
      <line>With nought of hope left – but with less of gloom.</line>
      <line>The very knowledge that he lived in vain,</line>
      <line>That all was over on this side the tomb,</line>
      <line>O Had made despair a smilingness assume,</line>
      <line>Which, though ’twere wild (as on the plundered wreck</line>
      <line>When mariners would madly meet their doom</line>
      <line>With draughts intemperate on the sinking deck),</line>
      <line>Did yet inspire a cheer, which he forbore to check.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Stop! for thy tread is on an Empire’s dust!</line>
      <line>An earthquake’s spoil is sepulchred below!</line>
      <line>Is the spot marked with no colossal bust?</line>
      <line>Nor column trophied for triumphal show?</line>
      <line>None. But the moral’s truth tells simpler so –</line>
      <line>O As the ground was before, thus let it be!</line>
      <line>How that red rain hath made the harvest grow!</line>
      <line>And is this all the world has gained by thee,</line>
      <line>Thou first and last of fields – king-making victory?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Harold stands upon this place of skulls,</line>
      <line> The grave of France, the deadly Waterloo!</line>
      <line>How in an hour the power which gave annuls</line>
      <line>Its gifts, transferring fame as fleeting too!</line>
      <line>In ‘pride of place’ here last the Eagle flew,</line>
      <line>Then tore with bloody talon the rent plain,</line>
      <line>O Pierced by the shaft of banded nations through;</line>
      <line>Ambition’s life and labours all were vain –</line>
      <line>He wears the shattered links of the World’s broken chain...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a sound of revelry by night,</line>
      <line>And Belgium’s capital had gathered then</line>
      <line>Her beauty and her chivalry – and bright</line>
      <line>The lamps shone o’er fair women and brave men.</line>
      <line> A thousand hearts beat happily, and when</line>
      <line>Music arose with its voluptuous swell,</line>
      <line>Soft eyes looked love to eyes which spake again,</line>
      <line>And all went merry as a marriage-bell –</line>
      <line>But hush, hark, a deep sound strikes like a rising knell!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Did ye not hear it? No – ’twas but the wind,</line>
      <line>Or the car rattling o’er the stony street –</line>
      <line>On with the dance! Let joy be unconfined!</line>
      <line>No sleep till morn, when youth and pleasure meet</line>
      <line>To chase the glowing hours with flying feet –</line>
      <line> But hark! that heavy sound breaks in once more</line>
      <line>As if the clouds its echo would repeat,</line>
      <line>And nearer, clearer, deadlier, than before.</line>
      <line>Arm! Arm! It is, it is, the cannon’s opening roar!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within a windowed niche of that high hall</line>
      <line>OO Sat Brunswick’s fated Chieftain; he did hear</line>
      <line>That sound the first amidst the festival,</line>
      <line>And caught its tone with death’s prophetic ear –</line>
      <line>And when they smiled because he deemed it near,</line>
      <line>His heart more truly knew that peal too well</line>
      <line>O Which stretched his father on a bloody bier,</line>
      <line>And roused the vengeance blood alone could quell:</line>
      <line>He rushed into the field, and, foremost fighting, fell!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! then and there was hurrying to and fro,</line>
      <line>And gathering tears, and tremblings of distress,</line>
      <line>O And cheeks all pale which but an hour ago</line>
      <line>Blushed at the praise of their own loveliness –</line>
      <line>And there were sudden partings, such as press</line>
      <line>The life from out young hearts, and choking sighs</line>
      <line>Which ne’er might be repeated. Who could guess</line>
      <line> If ever more should meet those mutual eyes,</line>
      <line>Since upon night so sweet such awful morn could rise!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And there was mounting in hot haste! The steed,</line>
      <line>The mustering squadron, and the clattering car,</line>
      <line>Went pouring forward, with impetuous speed</line>
      <line>O And swiftly forming in the ranks of war –</line>
      <line>And the deep thunder, peal on peal, afar;</line>
      <line>And near, the beat of the alarming drum</line>
      <line>Roused up the soldier ere the morning star;</line>
      <line>While thronged the citizens, with terror dumb,</line>
      <line> Or whispering, with white lips: ‘The foe! They come! they come!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And wild and high the Cameron’s Gathering rose –</line>
      <line>The war-note of Lochiel, which Albyn’s hills</line>
      <line>Have heard, and heard too have her Saxon foes.</line>
      <line>How in the noon of night that pibroch thrills,</line>
      <line>O Savage and shrill! But with the breath which fills</line>
      <line>Their mountain-pipe, so fill the mountaineers</line>
      <line>With the fierce native daring which instils</line>
      <line>The stirring memory of a thousand years –</line>
      <line>And Evan’s, Donald’s, fame rings in each clansman’s ears!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And Ardennes waves above them her green leaves,</line>
      <line>Dewy with Nature’s tear-drops, as they pass,</line>
      <line>Grieving, if aught inanimate e’er grieves,</line>
      <line>Over the unreturning brave – alas,</line>
      <line>Ere evening to be trodden like the grass</line>
      <line>O Which now beneath them, but above shall grow</line>
      <line>In its next verdure, when this fiery mass</line>
      <line>Of living valour, rolling on the foe</line>
      <line>And burning with high hope, shall moulder cold and low.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Last noon beheld them full of lusty life,</line>
      <line> Last eve in Beauty’s circle proudly gay,</line>
      <line>The midnight brought the signal-sound of strife,</line>
      <line>The morn the marshalling in arms – the day,</line>
      <line>Battle’s magnificently-stern array!</line>
      <line>The thunder-clouds close o’er it, which, when rent,</line>
      <line>O The earth is covered thick with other clay</line>
      <line>Which her own clay shall cover, heaped and pent,</line>
      <line>Rider and horse – friend, foe – in one red burial blent!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>To Autumn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Season of mists and mellow fruitfulness,</line>
      <line>Close bosom-friend of the maturing sun,</line>
      <line>Conspiring with him how to load and bless</line>
      <line>With fruit the vines that round the thatch-eaves run –</line>
      <line> To bend with apples the mossed cottage-trees,</line>
      <line>And fill all fruit with ripeness to the core;</line>
      <line>To swell the gourd, and plump the hazel-shells</line>
      <line>With a sweet kernel; to set budding more,</line>
      <line>And still more, later flowers for the bees,</line>
      <line>O Until they think warm days will never cease,</line>
      <line>For Summer has o’erbrimmed their clammy cells.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who hath not seen thee oft amid thy store?</line>
      <line>Sometimes whoever seeks abroad may find</line>
      <line>Thee sitting careless on a granary floor,</line>
      <line> Thy hair soft-lifted by the winnowing wind;</line>
      <line>Or on a half-reaped furrow, sound asleep,</line>
      <line>Drowsed with the fume of poppies, while thy hook</line>
      <line>Spares the next swath and all its twinéd flowers;</line>
      <line>And sometimes like a gleaner thou dost keep</line>
      <line>O Steady thy laden head across a brook,</line>
      <line>Or by a cider-press, with patient look,</line>
      <line>Thou watchest the last oozings hours by hours.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where are the songs of Spring? Aye, where are they?</line>
      <line>Think not of them, thou hast thy music too –</line>
      <line> While barred clouds bloom the soft-dying day,</line>
      <line>And touch the stubble-plains with rosy hue.</line>
      <line>Then in a wailful choir the small gnats mourn</line>
      <line>Among the river sallows, borne aloft</line>
      <line>Or sinking as the light wind lives or dies;</line>
      <line>O And full-grown lambs loud-bleat from hilly bourn;</line>
      <line>Hedge-crickets sing; and now, with treble soft,</line>
      <line>The redbreast whistles from a garden-croft,</line>
      <line>And gathering swallows twitter in the skies.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>To a Skylark</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hail to thee, blithe spirit,</line>
      <line>Bird thou never wert</line>
      <line>That from heaven, or near it,</line>
      <line>Pourest thy full heart</line>
      <line> In profuse strains of unpremeditated art!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Higher still and higher</line>
      <line>From the earth thou springest</line>
      <line>Like a cloud of fire;</line>
      <line>The blue deep thou wingest,</line>
      <line>And singing still dost soar, and soaring ever singest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the golden lightning</line>
      <line>Of the sunken sun</line>
      <line>O’er which clouds are brightning,</line>
      <line>Thou dost float and run;</line>
      <line> Like an unbodied joy whose race is just begun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pale purple even</line>
      <line>Melts around thy flight;</line>
      <line>Like a star of heaven</line>
      <line>In the broad daylight</line>
      <line>Thou art unseen, but yet I hear thy shrill delight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Keen as are the arrows</line>
      <line>Of that silver sphere,</line>
      <line>Whose intense lamp narrows</line>
      <line>In the white dawn clear,</line>
      <line> Until we hardly see – we feel that it is there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All the earth and air</line>
      <line>With thy voice is loud,</line>
      <line>As, when night is bare,</line>
      <line>From one lonely cloud</line>
      <line>The moon rains out her beams, and heaven is overflowed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What thou art we know not –</line>
      <line>What is most like thee?</line>
      <line>From rainbow clouds there flow not</line>
      <line>Drops so bright to see</line>
      <line> As from thy presence showers a rain of melody.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like a poet hidden</line>
      <line>In the light of thought,</line>
      <line>Singing hymns unbidden</line>
      <line>Till the world is wrought</line>
      <line>To sympathy with hopes and fears it heeded not;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like a high-born maiden</line>
      <line>In a palace tower,</line>
      <line>Soothing her love-laden</line>
      <line>Soul in secret hour</line>
      <line> With music sweet as love, which overflows her bower;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like a glow-worm golden</line>
      <line>In a dell of dew,</line>
      <line>Scattering unbeholden</line>
      <line>In aërial hue</line>
      <line>Among the flowers and grass, which screen it from the view;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like a rose embowered</line>
      <line>In its own green leaves,</line>
      <line>By warm winds deflowered,</line>
      <line>Till the scent it gives</line>
      <line> Makes faint with too much sweet those heavy-wingéd thieves –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sound of vernal showers</line>
      <line>On the twinkling grass,</line>
      <line>Rain-awakened flowers –</line>
      <line>All that ever was</line>
      <line>Joyous, and clear, and fresh, thy music doth surpass!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Teach us, sprite, or bird,</line>
      <line>What sweet thoughts are thine;</line>
      <line>I have never heard</line>
      <line>Praise of love or wine</line>
      <line> That panted forth a flood of rapture so divine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Chorus hymeneal,</line>
      <line>Or triumphal chant,</line>
      <line>Matched with thine would be all</line>
      <line>But an empty vaunt,</line>
      <line>A thing wherein we feel there is some hidden want.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What objects are the fountains</line>
      <line>Of thy happy strain?</line>
      <line>What fields, or waves, or mountains?</line>
      <line>What shapes of sky or plain?</line>
      <line> What love of thine own kind? What ignorance of pain?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With thy clear keen joyance</line>
      <line>Languor cannot be;</line>
      <line>Shadow of annoyance</line>
      <line>Never came near thee!</line>
      <line>Thou lovest – but ne’er knew love’s sad satiety.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Waking or asleep,</line>
      <line>Thou of death must deem</line>
      <line>Things more true and deep</line>
      <line>Than we mortals dream,</line>
      <line>Or how could thy notes flow in such a crystal stream?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We look before and after,</line>
      <line>And pine for what is not:</line>
      <line>Our sincerest laughter</line>
      <line>With some pain is fraught –</line>
      <line>Our sweetest songs are those that tell of saddest thought.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet if we could scorn</line>
      <line>Hate, and pride, and fear;</line>
      <line>If we were things born</line>
      <line>Not to shed a tear,</line>
      <line> I know not how thy joy we ever should come near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Better than all measures</line>
      <line>Of delightful sound</line>
      <line>Better than all treasures</line>
      <line>That in books are found,</line>
      <line>Thy skill to poet were, thou scorner of the ground!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Teach me half the gladness</line>
      <line>That thy brain must know,</line>
      <line>Such harmonious madness</line>
      <line>From my lips would flow,</line>
      <line>The world should listen then, as I am listening now.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JAMES HOGG</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>When the Kye Comes Hame</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come all ye jolly shepherds that whistle thro’ the glen,</line>
      <line>I’ll tell ye of a secret that courtiers dinna ken.</line>
      <line>What is the greatest bliss that the tongue of man can name?</line>
      <line>’Tis to woo a bonny lassie when the kye comes hame.</line>
      <line> When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis not beneath the burgonet, nor yet beneath the crown,</line>
      <line>’Tis not on couch of velvet, nor yet in bed of down –</line>
      <line>’Tis beneath the spreading birch, in the dell without a name,</line>
      <line>Wi’ a bonny, bonny lassie, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There the blackbird bigs his nest for the mate he lo’es to see,</line>
      <line>And up upon the topmost bough, oh, a happy bird is he!</line>
      <line> There he pours his melting ditty, and love ’tis a’ the theme,</line>
      <line>And he’ll woo his bonny lassie when the kye cames hame.</line>
      <line>When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the bluart bears a pearl, and the daisy turns a pea,</line>
      <line>And the bonny lucken gowan has fouldit up his ee,</line>
      <line>Then the lavrock frae the blue lift drops down, and thinks nae shame</line>
      <line>To woo his bonnie lassie when the kye comes hame.</line>
      <line>When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then the eye shines sae bright, the hale soul to beguile,</line>
      <line>There’s love in every whisper, and joy in every smile:</line>
      <line>O wha wad choose a crown, wi’ its perils and its fame,</line>
      <line>And miss a bonny lassie when the kye comes hame?</line>
      <line>When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>See yonder pawky shepherd, that lingers on the hill,</line>
      <line>His ewes are in the fauld, and his lambs are lying still;</line>
      <line>Yet he downa gang to bed, for his heart is in a flame,</line>
      <line>To meet his bonny lassie when the kye comes hame.</line>
      <line> When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away wi’ fame and fortune, what comfort can they gie?</line>
      <line>And a’ the arts that prey on man’s life and liberty:</line>
      <line>Gie me the highest joy that the heart o’ man can frame,</line>
      <line>My bonny, bonny lassie, when the kye comes hame.</line>
      <line>When the kye comes hame, when the kye comes hame,</line>
      <line>’Tween the gloaming an’ the mirk, when the kye comes hame.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>The Shepherd’s Calendar</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Loud is the Summer’s busy song,</line>
      <line>The smallest breeze can find a tongue,</line>
      <line>While insects of each tiny size</line>
      <line>Grow teasing with their melodies,</line>
      <line>Till noon burns with its blistering breath</line>
      <line> Around, and day dies still as death.</line>
      <line>The busy noise of man and brute</line>
      <line>Is on a sudden lost and mute;</line>
      <line>Even the brook that leaps along</line>
      <line>Seems weary of its bubbling song,</line>
      <line>And, so soft its waters creep,</line>
      <line>Tired silence sinks in sounder sleep.</line>
      <line>The cricket on its banks is dumb,</line>
      <line>The very flies forget to hum;</line>
      <line>And, save the wagon rocking round,</line>
      <line>The landscape sleeps without a sound.</line>
      <line>The breeze is stopped, the lazy bough</line>
      <line>Hath not a leaf that dances now;</line>
      <line>The tottergrass upon the hill,</line>
      <line>And spiders’ threads, are standing still;</line>
      <line>The feathers dropped from moorhen’s wing,</line>
      <line>Which to the water’s surface cling,</line>
      <line>Are steadfast, and as heavy seem</line>
      <line>As stones beneath them in the stream;</line>
      <line>Hawkweed and groundsel’s fanning downs</line>
      <line> Unruffled keep their seedy crowns;</line>
      <line>And in the oven-heated air,</line>
      <line>Not one light thing is floating there,</line>
      <line>Save that to the earnest eye</line>
      <line>The restless heat seems twittering by!</line>
      <line>Noon swoons beneath the heat it made,</line>
      <line>And flowers e’en wither in the shade,</line>
      <line>Until the sun slopes in the west,</line>
      <line>Like weary traveller, glad to rest,</line>
      <line>On pillowed clouds of many hues;</line>
      <line> Then Nature’s voice its joy renews,</line>
      <line>And chequered field and grassy plain</line>
      <line>Hum, with their summer songs again,</line>
      <line>A requiem to the day’s decline,</line>
      <line>Whose setting sunbeams coolly shine,</line>
      <line>As welcome to day’s feeble powers</line>
      <line>As falling dews to thirsty flowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1826</date>
    <title>I Remember, I Remember</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I remember, I remember,</line>
      <line>The house where I was born,</line>
      <line>The little window where the sun</line>
      <line>Came peeping in at morn;</line>
      <line> He never came a wink too soon,</line>
      <line>Nor brought too long a day;</line>
      <line>But now, I often wish the night</line>
      <line>Had borne my breath away!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I remember, I remember,</line>
      <line>The roses, red and white,</line>
      <line>The violets, and the lily-cups,</line>
      <line>Those flowers made of light!</line>
      <line>The lilacs where the robin built,</line>
      <line>And where my brother set</line>
      <line> The laburnum on his birth-day –</line>
      <line>The tree is living yet!</line>
      <line>I remember, I remember</line>
      <line>Where I was used to swing,</line>
      <line>And thought the air must rush as fresh</line>
      <line>To swallows on the wing;</line>
      <line>My spirit flew in feathers then,</line>
      <line>That is so heavy now,</line>
      <line>And summer-pools could hardly cool</line>
      <line>The fever on my brow!</line>
      <line> I remember, I remember</line>
      <line>The fir-trees dark and high;</line>
      <line>I used to think their slender tops</line>
      <line>Were close against the sky:</line>
      <line>It was a childish ignorance,</line>
      <line>But now ’tis little joy</line>
      <line>To know I’m farther off from heaven</line>
      <line>Than when I was a boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>Casabianca</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The boy stood on the burning deck</line>
      <line>Whence all but he had fled;</line>
      <line>The flame that lit the battle’s wreck,</line>
      <line>Shone round him o’er the dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet beautiful and bright he stood,</line>
      <line>As born to rule the storm –</line>
      <line>A creature of heroic blood,</line>
      <line>A proud, though childlike form!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The flames rolled on! He would not go</line>
      <line>Without his father’s word –</line>
      <line>That father, faint in death below,</line>
      <line>His voice no longer heard.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He called aloud: ‘Say, Father, say</line>
      <line>If yet my task is done?’</line>
      <line> He knew not that the chieftain lay</line>
      <line>Unconscious of his son.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Speak, Father!’ once again he cried,</line>
      <line>‘If I may yet be gone!’ –</line>
      <line>And but the booming shots replied,</line>
      <line>And fast the flames rolled on.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upon his brow he felt their breath,</line>
      <line>And in his waving hair,</line>
      <line>And looked from that lone post of death,</line>
      <line>In still, yet brave despair –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And shouted but once more aloud,</line>
      <line>‘My Father! must I stay?’</line>
      <line>While o’er him fast, through sail and shroud,</line>
      <line>The wreathing fires made way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They wrapt the ship in splendour wild,</line>
      <line>They caught the flag on high,</line>
      <line>And streamed above the gallant child</line>
      <line>Like banners in the sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There came a burst of thunder-sound –</line>
      <line>The boy – oh! where was he?</line>
      <line> Ask of the winds that far around</line>
      <line>With fragments strewed the sea:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With mast, and helm, and pennon fair,</line>
      <line>That well had borne their part –</line>
      <line>But the noblest thing which perished there</line>
      <line>Was that young faithful heart!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1829</date>
    <title>Lines of Life</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, read my cheek, and watch my eye –</line>
      <line>Too strictly schooled are they</line>
      <line>One secret of my soul to show,</line>
      <line>One hidden thought betray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I never knew the time my heart</line>
      <line>Looked freely from my brow:</line>
      <line>It once was checked by timidness,</line>
      <line>’Tis taught by caution now.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I live among the cold, the false,</line>
      <line>And I must seem like them –</line>
      <line>And such I am, for I am false</line>
      <line>As those I most condemn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I teach my lip its sweetest smile,</line>
      <line>My tongue its softest tone;</line>
      <line> I borrow others’ likeness, till</line>
      <line>Almost I lose my own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I pass through flattery’s gilded sieve</line>
      <line>Whatever I would say;</line>
      <line>In social life, all, like the blind,</line>
      <line>Must learn to feel their way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I check my thoughts like curbéd steeds</line>
      <line>That struggle with the rein;</line>
      <line>I bid my feelings sleep, like wrecks</line>
      <line>In the unfathomed main.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I hear them speak of love, the deep,</line>
      <line>The true, and mock the name –</line>
      <line>Mock at all high and early truth –</line>
      <line>And I too do the same.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hear them tell some touching tale,</line>
      <line>I swallow down the tear;</line>
      <line>I hear them name some generous deed,</line>
      <line>And I have learnt to sneer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hear the spiritual, the kind,</line>
      <line>The pure, but named in mirth;</line>
      <line> Till all of good, aye, even hope,</line>
      <line>Seems exiled from our earth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And one fear, withering ridicule,</line>
      <line>Is all that I can dread;</line>
      <line>A sword hung by a single hair</line>
      <line>For ever o’er the head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We bow to a most servile faith,</line>
      <line>In a most servile fear,</line>
      <line>While none among us dares to say</line>
      <line>What none will choose to hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And if we dream of loftier thoughts,</line>
      <line>In weakness they are gone,</line>
      <line>And indolence and vanity</line>
      <line>Rivet our fetters on.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Surely I was not born for this!</line>
      <line>I feel a loftier mood</line>
      <line>Of generous impulse, high resolve,</line>
      <line>Steal o’er my solitude!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I gaze upon the thousand stars</line>
      <line>That fill the midnight sky;</line>
      <line>And wish, so passionately wish,</line>
      <line> A light like theirs on high.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have such eagerness of hope</line>
      <line>To benefit my kind,</line>
      <line>And feel as if immortal power</line>
      <line>Were given to my mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I think on that eternal fame,</line>
      <line>The sun of earthly gloom,</line>
      <line>Which makes the gloriousness of death</line>
      <line>The future of the tomb –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> That earthly future, the faint sign</line>
      <line>Of a more heavenly one:</line>
      <line>A step, a word, a voice, a look –</line>
      <line>Alas! my dream is done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Earth, and Earth’s debasing stain,</line>
      <line>Again is on my soul;</line>
      <line>And I am but a nameless part</line>
      <line>Of a most worthless whole.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why write I this? because my heart</line>
      <line>Towards the future springs,</line>
      <line> That future where it loves to soar</line>
      <line>On more than eagle wings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The present, it is but a speck</line>
      <line>In that eternal time,</line>
      <line>In which my lost hopes find a home,</line>
      <line>My spirit knows its clime.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh! not myself – for what am I? –</line>
      <line>The worthless and the weak,</line>
      <line>Whose every thought of self should raise</line>
      <line>A blush to burn my cheek?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But song has touched my lips with fire,</line>
      <line>And made my heart a shrine;</line>
      <line>For what, although alloyed, debased,</line>
      <line>Is in itself divine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am myself but a vile link</line>
      <line>Amid life’s weary chain;</line>
      <line>But I have spoken hallowed words –</line>
      <line>Oh do not say in vain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My first, my last, my only wish,</line>
      <line>Say will my charméd chords</line>
      <line> Wake to the morning-light of fame,</line>
      <line>And breathe again my words?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will the young maiden, when her tears</line>
      <line>Alone in moonlight shine –</line>
      <line>Tears for the absent and the loved –</line>
      <line>Murmur some song of mine?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will the pale youth by his dim lamp,</line>
      <line>Himself a dying flame,</line>
      <line>From many an antique scroll beside,</line>
      <line>Choose that which bears my name?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let music make less terrible</line>
      <line>The silence of the dead;</line>
      <line>I care not, so my spirit last</line>
      <line>Long after life has fled.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>My Arab Steed</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My beautiful, my beautiful, that standest meekly by</line>
      <line>With thy proudly arched and glossy neck, and dark and fiery eye,</line>
      <line>Fret not to roam the desert now, with all thy wingéd speed –</line>
      <line>I may not mount on thee again – thou’rt sold, my arab steed!</line>
      <line> Fret not with that impatient hoof – snuff not the breezy wind!</line>
      <line>The further that thou fliest now, so far am I behind!</line>
      <line>The stranger hath thy bridle-rein – thy master hath his gold –</line>
      <line>Fleet-limbed and beautiful, farewell! Thou’rt sold, my steed, thou’rt sold!</line>
      <line>Farewell! Those free untiréd limbs full many a mile must roam</line>
      <line>To reach the chill and wintry sky which clouds the stranger’s home;</line>
      <line>Some other hand, less fond, must now thy corn and bed prepare;</line>
      <line>The silky mane I braided once, must be another’s care!</line>
      <line>The morning sun shall dawn again, but never more with thee</line>
      <line>Shall I gallop through the desert-paths, where we were wont to be:</line>
      <line> Evening shall darken on the earth, and o’er the sandy plain</line>
      <line>Some other steed, with slower step, shall bear me home again.</line>
      <line>Yes, thou must go! The wild free breeze, the brilliant sun and sky,</line>
      <line>The master’s home – from all of these, my exiled one must fly!</line>
      <line>Thy proud dark eye will grow less proud, thy step become less fleet,</line>
      <line>And vainly shalt thou arch thy neck thy master’s hand to meet.</line>
      <line>Only in sleep shall I behold that dark eye glancing bright,</line>
      <line>Only in sleep shall hear again that step so firm and light;</line>
      <line>And when I raise my dreaming arm to check or cheer thy speed,</line>
      <line>Then must I, starting, wake, to feel – thou’rt sold, my arab steed!</line>
      <line> Ah, rudely then (unseen by me) some cruel hand may chide,</line>
      <line>Till foam-wreaths lie, like crested waves, along thy panting side;</line>
      <line>And the rich blood that is in thee swells, in thy indignant pain,</line>
      <line>Till careless eyes which rest on thee may count each started vein.</line>
      <line>Will they ill-use thee? If I thought – but no, it cannot be! –</line>
      <line>Thou art so swift, yet easy curbed; so gentle, yet so free.</line>
      <line>And yet if haply when thou’rt gone my lonely heart should yearn,</line>
      <line>Can the hand which casts thee from it now, command thee to return?</line>
      <line>Return! Alas, my arab steed, what shall thy master do</line>
      <line>When thou, who wert his all of joy, hast vanished from his view –</line>
      <line>When the dim distance cheats mine eye, and through the gathering tears</line>
      <line>Thy bright form, for a moment, like the false mirage appears?</line>
      <line>Slow and unmounted will I roam with weary foot, alone,</line>
      <line>Where with fleet step, and joyous bound, thou oft hast borne me on;</line>
      <line>And, sitting down by that green well, I’ll pause and sadly think,</line>
      <line>‘It was here he bowed his glossy neck, when last I saw him drink!’</line>
      <line>When last I saw thee drink! Away – the fevered dream is o’er! –</line>
      <line>I could not live a day, and know that we should meet no more!</line>
      <line>They tempted me, my beautiful, for hunger’s power is strong –</line>
      <line>They tempted me, my beautiful, but I have loved too long!</line>
      <line> Who said that I had given thee up? Who said that thou wert sold?</line>
      <line>’Tis false – ’tis false, my arab steed! I fling them back their gold!</line>
      <line>Thus, thus, I leap upon thy back, and scour the distant plains –</line>
      <line>Away! Who overtakes us now, shall claim thee for his pains!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1834</date>
    <title>Abou Ben Adhem</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Abou Ben Adhem – may his tribe increase –</line>
      <line>Awoke one night from a deep dream of peace,</line>
      <line>And saw, within the moonlight in his room,</line>
      <line>Making it rich, and like a lily in bloom,</line>
      <line> An angel writing in a book of gold.</line>
      <line>Exceeding peace had made Ben Adhem bold,</line>
      <line>And to the presence in the room he said:</line>
      <line>‘What writest thou?’ The vision raised its head</line>
      <line>And with a look made all of sweet accord,</line>
      <line>Answered, ‘The names of those who love the Lord.’</line>
      <line>‘And is mine one?’ said Abou. ‘Nay, not so’,</line>
      <line>Replied the angel. Abou spoke more low,</line>
      <line>But cheerly still, and said, ‘I pray thee, then,</line>
      <line>Write me as one who loves his fellow men.’</line>
      <line> The angel wrote, and vanished. The next night</line>
      <line>It came again, with a great wakening light,</line>
      <line>And showed the names whom love of God had blest,</line>
      <line>And lo! Ben Adhem’s name led all the rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Sonnet Introductory</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Favoured by Heaven are those, ordained to taste</line>
      <line>The bliss supreme that kindles fancy’s fire;</line>
      <line>Whose magic fingers sweep the muse’s lyre</line>
      <line>In varying cadence, eloquently chaste!</line>
      <line> Well may the mind, with tuneful numbers graced,</line>
      <line>To fame’s immortal attributes aspire,</line>
      <line>Above the treacherous spells of low desire</line>
      <line>That wound the sense, by vulgar joys debased.</line>
      <line>For thou, blest Poesy, with godlike powers</line>
      <line>To calm the miseries of man, wert given;</line>
      <line>When passion rends, and hopeless love devours,</line>
      <line>By memory goaded and by frenzy driven,</line>
      <line>’Tis thine to guide him midst Elysian bowers</line>
      <line>And show his fainting soul – a glimpse of Heaven.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Temple of Chastity</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> High on a rock, coëval with the skies,</line>
      <line>A temple stands, reared by immortal powers</line>
      <line>To chastity divine! Ambrosial flowers,</line>
      <line>Twining round icicles, in columns rise,</line>
      <line>Mingling with pendent gems of orient dyes!</line>
      <line>Piercing the air, a golden crescent towers,</line>
      <line>Veiled by transparent clouds; while smiling Hours</line>
      <line>Shake from their varying wings – celestial joys!</line>
      <line>The steps of spotless marble, scattered o’er</line>
      <line>With deathless roses, armed with many a thorn,</line>
      <line> Lead to the altar. On the frozen floor,</line>
      <line>Studded with tear-drops petrified by scorn,</line>
      <line>Pale vestals kneel the goddess to adore,</line>
      <line>While Love, his arrows broke, retires forlorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>The Bower of Pleasure</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Turn to yon vale beneath, whose tangled shade</line>
      <line>Excludes the blazing torch of noonday light:</line>
      <line>Where sportive fawns and dimpled loves invite,</line>
      <line>The bower of pleasure opens to the glade.</line>
      <line>Lulled by soft flutes, on leaves of violets laid,</line>
      <line>There witching beauty greets the ravished sight,</line>
      <line> More gentle than the arbitress of night</line>
      <line>In all her silvery panoply arrayed!</line>
      <line>The birds breathe bliss, light zephyrs kiss the ground</line>
      <line>Stealing the hyacinth’s divine perfume;</line>
      <line>While from pellucid fountains glittering round,</line>
      <line>Small tinkling rills bid rival flowerets bloom!</line>
      <line>Here, laughing cupids bathe the bosom’s wound;</line>
      <line>There, tyrant passion finds a glorious tomb!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Sappho Discovers her Passion</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why, when I gaze on Phaon’s beauteous eyes,</line>
      <line>Why does each thought in wild disorder stray?</line>
      <line> Why does each fainting faculty decay,</line>
      <line>And my chilled breast in throbbing tumults rise?</line>
      <line>Mute on the ground my lyre neglected lies,</line>
      <line>The Muse forgot, and lost the melting lay;</line>
      <line>My down-cast looks, my faltering lips, betray</line>
      <line>That stung by hopeless passion Sappho dies!</line>
      <line>Now on a bank of cypress let me rest –</line>
      <line>Come, tuneful maids, ye pupils of my care,</line>
      <line>Come, with your dulcet numbers sooth my breast,</line>
      <line>And, as the soft vibrations float on air,</line>
      <line> Let pity waft my spirit to the blest,</line>
      <line>To mock the barbarous triumphs of despair!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Condemns its Power</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh how can love exulting reason quell?</line>
      <line>How fades each nobler passion from his gaze –</line>
      <line>E’en fame, that cherishes the poet’s lays,</line>
      <line>That fame ill-fated Sappho loved so well?</line>
      <line>Lost is the wretch, who in his fatal spell</line>
      <line>Wastes the short summer of delicious days,</line>
      <line>And from the tranquil path of wisdom strays</line>
      <line>In passion’s thorny wild forlorn to dwell.</line>
      <line>Oh ye who in that sacred temple smile</line>
      <line> Where holy innocence resides enshrined,</line>
      <line>Who fear not sorrow, and who know not guile</line>
      <line>(Each thought composed, and every wish resigned),</line>
      <line>Tempt not the path where pleasure’s flowery wile</line>
      <line>In sweet, but poisonous, fetters holds the mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Describes the Characteristics of Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it to love, to fix the tender gaze,</line>
      <line>To hide the timid blush, and steal away –</line>
      <line>To shun the busy world, and waste the day</line>
      <line>In some rude mountain’s solitary maze?</line>
      <line> Is it to chant one name in ceaseless lays,</line>
      <line>To hear no words that other tongues can say,</line>
      <line>To watch the pale moon’s melancholy ray,</line>
      <line>To chide in fondness, and in folly praise?</line>
      <line>Is it to pour the involuntary sigh,</line>
      <line>To dream of bliss, and wake new pangs to prove –</line>
      <line>To talk, in fancy, with the speaking eye,</line>
      <line>Then start with jealousy, and wildly rove?</line>
      <line>Is it to loath the light, and wish to die?</line>
      <line>For these I feel – and feel that they are love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Invokes Reason</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> Come, Reason, come! Each nerve rebellious bind,</line>
      <line>Lull the fierce tempest of my feverish soul –</line>
      <line>Come, with the magic of thy meek control,</line>
      <line>And check the wayward wanderings of my mind:</line>
      <line>Estranged from thee, no solace can I find.</line>
      <line>O’er my rapt brain, where pensive visions stole,</line>
      <line>Now Passion reigns and stormy tumults roll:</line>
      <line>So the smooth sea obeys the furious wind!</line>
      <line>In vain, Philosophy unfolds her store –</line>
      <line>O’erwhelmed is every source of pure delight;</line>
      <line> Dim is the golden page of Wisdom’s lore;</line>
      <line>All nature fades before my sickening sight:</line>
      <line>For what bright scene can fancy’s eye explore</line>
      <line>Midst dreary labyrinths of mental night?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Her Passion Increases</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why, through each aching vein, with lazy pace</line>
      <line>Thus steals the languid fountain of my heart,</line>
      <line>While from its source each wild convulsive start</line>
      <line>Tears the scorched roses from my burning face?</line>
