      <line>In vain, oh Lesbian vales, your charms I trace –</line>
      <line>Vain is the poet’s theme, the sculptor’s art!</line>
      <line>No more the lyre its magic can impart,</line>
      <line>Though waked to sound with more than mortal grace.</line>
      <line>Go, tuneful maids, go bid my Phaon prove</line>
      <line>That passion mocks the empty boast of fame –</line>
      <line>Tell him no joys are sweet, but joys of love,</line>
      <line>Melting the soul, and thrilling all the frame!</line>
      <line>Oh may the ecstatic thought his bosom move,</line>
      <line>And sighs of rapture fan the blush of shame!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Laments the Volatility of Phaon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye, who in alleys green and leafy bowers</line>
      <line>Sport, the rude children of fantastic birth;</line>
      <line> Where frolic nymphs, and shaggy tribes of mirth,</line>
      <line>In clamorous revels waste the midnight hours –</line>
      <line>Who, linked in flaunting bands of mountain-flowers,</line>
      <line>Weave your wild mazes o’er the dewy earth,</line>
      <line>Ere the fierce lord of lustre rushes forth</line>
      <line>And o’er the world his beamy radiance pours!</line>
      <line>Oft has your clanking cymbal’s maddening strain,</line>
      <line>Loud-ringing through the torch-illumined grove,</line>
      <line>Lured my loved Phaon from the youthful train,</line>
      <line>Through rugged dells, o’er craggy rocks to rove –</line>
      <line> Then how can she his vagrant heart detain,</line>
      <line>Whose lyre throbs only to the touch of love?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Describes Phaon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dangerous to hear is that melodious tongue,</line>
      <line>And fatal to the sense those murderous eyes,</line>
      <line>Where in a sapphire sheath love’s arrow lies,</line>
      <line>Himself concealed the crystal haunts among!</line>
      <line>Oft o’er that form, enamoured, have I hung,</line>
      <line>On that smooth cheek to mark the deepening dyes,</line>
      <line>While from that lip the fragrant breath would rise,</line>
      <line>That lip, like Cupid’s bow, with rubies strung!</line>
      <line> Still let me gaze upon that polished brow,</line>
      <line>O’er which the golden hair luxuriant plays;</line>
      <line>So, on the modest lily’s leaves of snow</line>
      <line>The proud sun revels in resplendent rays!</line>
      <line>Warm as his beams this sensate heart shall glow,</line>
      <line>Till life’s last hour with Phaon’s self decays!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Rejects the Influence of Reason</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Reason, vaunted sovereign of the mind –</line>
      <line>Thou pompous vision with a sounding name!</line>
      <line>Canst thou the soul’s rebellious passions tame?</line>
      <line>Canst thou in spells the vagrant fancy bind?</line>
      <line> Ah no, capricious as the wavering wind</line>
      <line>Are sighs of love that dim thy boasted flame,</line>
      <line>While Folly’s torch consumes the wreath of fame,</line>
      <line>And Pleasure’s hands the sheaves of truth unbind.</line>
      <line>Pressed by the storms of fate, hope shrinks and dies;</line>
      <line>Frenzy darts forth in mightiest ills arrayed;</line>
      <line>Around thy throne destructive tumults rise,</line>
      <line>And Hell-fraught jealousies thy rights invade!</line>
      <line>Then, what art thou, oh idol of the wise? –</line>
      <line>A visionary theme! A gorgeous shade!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Previous to her Interview with Phaon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> Now, o’er the tesselated pavement strew</line>
      <line>Fresh saffron, steeped in essence of the rose,</line>
      <line>While down yon agate column gently flows</line>
      <line>A glittering streamlet of ambrosial dew!</line>
      <line>My Phaon smiles! The rich carnation’s hue,</line>
      <line>On his flushed cheek in conscious lustre glows,</line>
      <line>While o’er his breast enamoured Venus throws</line>
      <line>Her starry mantle of celestial blue!</line>
      <line>Breathe soft, ye dulcet flutes, among the trees</line>
      <line>Where clustering boughs with golden citrons twine;</line>
      <line> While slow vibrations, dying on the breeze,</line>
      <line>Shall soothe his soul with harmony divine.</line>
      <line>Then let my form his yielding fancy seize,</line>
      <line>And all his fondest wishes blend with mine!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>She Endeavours to Fascinate Him</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bring, bring, to deck my brow, ye sylvan girls,</line>
      <line>A roseate wreath – nor for my waving hair</line>
      <line>The costly band of studded gems prepare,</line>
      <line>Of sparkling chrysolite, or orient pearls!</line>
      <line>Love o’er my head his canopy unfurls,</line>
      <line>His purple pinions fan the whispering air;</line>
      <line> Mocking the golden sandal, rich and rare,</line>
      <line>Beneath my feet the fragrant woodbine curls.</line>
      <line>Bring the thin robe, to fold about my breast,</line>
      <line>White as the downy swan; while round my waist</line>
      <line>Let leaves of glossy myrtle bind the vest,</line>
      <line>Not idly gay, but elegantly chaste!</line>
      <line>Love scorns the nymph in wanton trappings dressed;</line>
      <line>And charms the most concealed, are doubly graced.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>To the Eolian Harp</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, soft Eolian harp, while zephyr plays</line>
      <line>Along the meek vibration of thy strings,</line>
      <line> As Twilight’s hand her modest mantle brings,</line>
      <line>Blending with sober grey the western blaze!</line>
      <line>Oh prompt my Phaon’s dreams with tenderest lays,</line>
      <line>Ere night o’ershade thee with its humid wings,</line>
      <line>While the lorn philomel his sorrow sings</line>
      <line>In leafy cradle, red with parting rays!</line>
      <line>Slow let thy dulcet tones on ether glide –</line>
      <line>So steals the murmur of the amorous dove;</line>
      <line>The mazy legions swarm on every side,</line>
      <line>To lulling sounds the sunny people move!</line>
      <line> Let not the wise their little world deride,</line>
      <line>The smallest sting can wound the breast of love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Phaon Awakes</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now round my favoured grot let roses rise,</line>
      <line>To strew the bank where Phaon wakes from rest!</line>
      <line>Oh happy buds, to kiss his burning breast,</line>
      <line>And die beneath the lustre of his eyes!</line>
      <line>Now let the timbrels echo to the skies,</line>
      <line>Now damsels sprinkle cassia on his vest,</line>
      <line>With odorous wreaths of constant myrtle dressed,</line>
      <line>And flowers, deep tinted with the rainbow’s dyes!</line>
      <line>From cups of porphyry let nectar flow,</line>
      <line>Rich as the perfume of Phoenicia’s vine!</line>
      <line>Now let his dimpling cheek with rapture glow,</line>
      <line>While round his heart love’s mystic fetters twine;</line>
      <line>And let the Grecian lyre its aid bestow,</line>
      <line>O In songs of triumph to proclaim him mine!...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Reproaches Phaon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What means the mist opaque that veils these eyes?</line>
      <line>Why does yon threatening tempest shroud the day?</line>
      <line>Why does thy altar, Venus, fade away,</line>
      <line>And on my breast the dews of horror rise?</line>
      <line>Phaon is false! Be dim, ye orient skies,</line>
      <line>And let black Erebus succeed your ray!</line>
      <line>Let clashing thunders roll, and lightnings play –</line>
      <line>Phaon is false! and hopeless Sappho dies!</line>
      <line> ‘Farewell, my Lesbian love’, you might have said</line>
      <line>(Such sweet remembrance had some pity proved),</line>
      <line>Or coldly thus, ‘Farewell, oh Lesbian maid’ –</line>
      <line>No task severe for one so fondly loved!</line>
      <line>The gentle thought had soothed my wandering shade,</line>
      <line>From life’s dark valley, and its thorns, removed!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Her Confirmed Despair</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lead me, Sicilian maids, to haunted bowers,</line>
      <line>While yon pale moon displays her faintest beams</line>
      <line>O’er fading woodlands, and enchanted streams</line>
      <line>Whose banks infect the breeze with poisonous flowers.</line>
      <line> Ah, lead me where the barren mountain towers,</line>
      <line>Where no sounds echo, but the night-owl’s screams;</line>
      <line>Where some lone spirit of the desert gleams,</line>
      <line>And lurid horrors wing the fateful hours!</line>
      <line>Now goaded frenzy grasps my shrinking brain,</line>
      <line>OO Her touch absorbs the crystal fount of woe!</line>
      <line>My blood rolls burning through each bursting vein:</line>
      <line>Away, lost lyre – unless thou canst bestow</line>
      <line>A charm to lull that agonising pain</line>
      <line>Which those who never loved can never know!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Foresees Her Death</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When, in the gloomy mansion of the dead,</line>
      <line>This withering heart, this faded form shall sleep;</line>
      <line>When these fond eyes at length shall cease to weep,</line>
      <line>And earth’s cold lap receive this feverish head –</line>
      <line>Envy shall turn away, a tear to shed,</line>
      <line>And Time’s obliterating pinions sweep</line>
      <line>The spot where poets shall their vigils keep</line>
      <line>To mourn and wander near my freezing bed!</line>
      <line>Then my pale ghost upon the Elysian shore</line>
      <line>Shall smile, released from every mortal care,</line>
      <line> While (doomed love’s victim to repine no more)</line>
      <line>My breast shall bathe in endless rapture there –</line>
      <line>Ah no, my restless shade would still deplore,</line>
      <line>Nor taste that bliss, which Phaon did not share!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>To a Sigh</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh sigh, thou stealest (the herald of the breast)</line>
      <line>The lover’s fears, the lover’s pangs, to tell;</line>
      <line>Thou bidst with timid grace the bosom swell,</line>
      <line>Cheating the day of joy, the night of rest!</line>
      <line>Oh lucid tears, with eloquence confessed,</line>
      <line>Why on my fading cheek unheeded dwell,</line>
      <line> Meek as the dew-drops on the flowret’s bell</line>
      <line>By ruthless tempests to the green-sod pressed.</line>
      <line>Fond sigh, be hushed! Congeal, oh slighted tear –</line>
      <line>Thy feeble powers the busy Fates control!</line>
      <line>Or if thy crystal streams again appear,</line>
      <line>Let them, like Lethe’s, to oblivion roll –</line>
      <line>For love the tyrant plays when hope is near,</line>
      <line>And she who flies the lover, chains the soul!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>To the Muses</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Prepare your wreaths, Aonian maids divine,</line>
      <line>To strew the tranquil bed where I shall sleep;</line>
      <line> In tears, the myrtle and the laurel steep,</line>
      <line>And let Erato’s hand the trophies twine.</line>
      <line>No Parian marble there, with laboured line</line>
      <line>Shall bid the wandering lover stay to weep;</line>
      <line>There holy silence shall her vigils keep</line>
      <line>Save when the nightingale such woes as mine</line>
      <line>Shall sadly sing; as twilight’s curtains spread,</line>
      <line>There shall the branching lotus widely wave,</line>
      <line>Sprinkling soft showers upon the lily’s head,</line>
      <line>Sweet drooping emblem for a lover’s grave!</line>
      <line> And there shall Phaon pearls of pity shed</line>
      <line>To gem the vanquished heart he scorned to save!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Visions Appear to Her in a Dream</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the low margin of a murmuring stream,</line>
      <line>As rapt in meditation’s arms I lay,</line>
      <line>Each aching sense in slumbers stole away,</line>
      <line>While potent fancy formed a soothing dream.</line>
      <line>O’er the Leucadian deep, a dazzling beam</line>
      <line>Shed the bland light of empyrean day –</line>
      <line>But soon transparent shadows veiled each ray,</line>
      <line>While mystic visions sprang athwart the gleam!</line>
      <line> Now to the heaving gulf they seemed to bend,</line>
      <line>And now across the sphery regions glide;</line>
      <line>Now in mid-air their dulcet voices blend:</line>
      <line>‘Awake! awake!’ the restless phalanx cried,</line>
      <line>‘See ocean yawns the lover’s woes to end;</line>
      <line>Plunge the green wave, and bid thy griefs subside!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Resolves to Take the Leap of Leucata</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, I will go, where circling whirlwinds rise,</line>
      <line>Where threatening clouds in sable grandeur lour;</line>
      <line>Where the blast yells, the liquid columns pour,</line>
      <line>And maddening billows combat with the skies!</line>
      <line> There, while the Demon of the Tempest flies</line>
      <line>On growing pinions through the troublous hour,</line>
      <line>The wild waves gasp impatient to devour,</line>
      <line>And on the rock the wakened vulture cries!</line>
      <line>Oh! dreadful solace to the stormy mind –</line>
      <line>To me, more pleasing than the valley’s rest,</line>
      <line>The woodland songsters, or the sportive kind</line>
      <line>That nip the turf, or prune the painted crest;</line>
      <line>For in despair alone, the wretched find</line>
      <line>That unction sweet, which lulls the bleeding breast!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Her Last Appeal to Phaon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh! canst thou bear to see this faded frame</line>
      <line>Deformed and mangled by the rocky deep?</line>
      <line>Wilt thou remember, and forbear to weep,</line>
      <line>My fatal fondness and my peerless fame?</line>
      <line>Soon o’er this heart, now warm with passion’s flame,</line>
      <line>The howling winds and foamy waves shall sweep –</line>
      <line>These eyes be ever closed in death’s cold sleep,</line>
      <line>And all of Sappho perish, but her name!</line>
      <line>Yet, if the Fates suspend their barbarous ire,</line>
      <line>If days less mournful, Heaven designs for me,</line>
      <line> If rocks grow kind, and winds and waves conspire</line>
      <line>To bear me softly on the swelling sea –</line>
      <line>To Phoebus only will I tune my lyre,</line>
      <line>‘What suits with Sappho, Phoebus, suits with thee!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Her Reflections on the Leucadian Rock Before She Perishes</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>While from the dizzy precipice I gaze,</line>
      <line>The world receding from my pensive eyes,</line>
      <line>High o’er my head the tyrant eagle flies,</line>
      <line>Clothed in the sinking sun’s transcendent blaze!</line>
      <line>The meek-eyed moon, midst clouds of amber plays,</line>
      <line>As o’er the purpling plains of light she hies,</line>
      <line> Till the last stream of living lustre dies,</line>
      <line>And the cool concave owns her tempered rays!</line>
      <line>So shall this glowing, palpitating soul,</line>
      <line>Welcome returning reason’s placid beam,</line>
      <line>While o’er my breast the waves Lethean roll,</line>
      <line>To calm rebellious fancy’s feverish dream.</line>
      <line>Then shall my lyre disdain love’s dread control,</line>
      <line>And loftier passions prompt the loftier theme!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Sonnet Conclusive</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here droops the Muse! while from her glowing mind,</line>
      <line>Celestial Sympathy, with humid eye,</line>
      <line>Bids the light sylph (capricious Fancy) fly,</line>
      <line>Time’s restless wings with transient flowers to bind!</line>
      <line>For now, with folded arms and head inclined,</line>
      <line>Reflection pours the deep and frequent sigh</line>
      <line>O’er the dark scroll of human destiny,</line>
      <line>Where gaudy buds and wounding thorns are twined.</line>
      <line>Oh, sky-born Virtue! sacred is thy name –</line>
      <line>And though mysterious Fate, with frown severe,</line>
      <line>Oft decorates thy brows with wreaths of fame</line>
      <line>Bespangled o’er with Sorrow’s chilling tear,</line>
      <line> Yet shalt thou more than mortal raptures claim,</line>
      <line>The brightest planet of the eternal sphere!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Ruined Cottage</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas summer and the sun was mounted high;</line>
      <line>Along the south the uplands feebly glared</line>
      <line>Through a pale steam, and all the northern downs,</line>
      <line>In clearer air ascending, showed far off</line>
      <line> Their surfaces with shadows dappled o’er</line>
      <line>Of deep embattled clouds. Far as the sight</line>
      <line>Could reach those many shadows lay in spots</line>
      <line>Determined and unmoved, with steady beams</line>
      <line>Of clear and pleasant sunshine interposed –</line>
      <line>Pleasant to him who on the soft cool moss</line>
      <line>Extends his careless limbs beside the root</line>
      <line>Of some huge oak whose agéd branches make</line>
      <line>A twilight of their own, a dewy shade</line>
      <line>Where the wren warbles while the dreaming man,</line>
      <line> Half-conscious of that soothing melody,</line>
      <line>With sidelong eye looks out upon the scene,</line>
      <line>By those impending branches made more soft,</line>
      <line>More soft and distant.</line>
      <line>Other lot was mine.</line>
      <line>Across a bare wide common I had toiled</line>
      <line>With languid feet which by the slippery ground</line>
      <line>Were baffled still; and when I stretched myself</line>
      <line>On the brown earth my limbs from very heat</line>
      <line>Could find no rest, nor my weak arm disperse</line>
      <line>The insect host which gathered round my face</line>
      <line> And joined their murmurs to the tedious noise</line>
      <line>Of seeds of bursting gorse that crackled round.</line>
      <line>I rose and turned towards a group of trees</line>
      <line>Which midway in that level stood alone;</line>
      <line>And thither come at length, beneath a shade</line>
      <line>Of clustering elms that sprang from the same root</line>
      <line>I found a ruined house, four naked walls</line>
      <line>That stared upon each other. I looked round,</line>
      <line>And near the door I saw an agéd man</line>
      <line>Alone and stretched upon the cottage bench;</line>
      <line> An iron-pointed staff lay at his side.</line>
      <line>With instantaneous joy I recognized</line>
      <line>That pride of Nature and of lowly life,</line>
      <line>The venerable Armytage, a friend</line>
      <line>As dear to me as is the setting sun.</line>
      <line>Two days before</line>
      <line>We had been fellow-travellers. I knew</line>
      <line>That he was in this neighbourhood, and now</line>
      <line>Delighted found him here in the cool shade.</line>
      <line>He lay, his pack of rustic merchandise</line>
      <line> Pillowing his head. I guess he had no thought</line>
      <line>Of his way-wandering life. His eyes were shut,</line>
      <line>The shadows of the breezy elms above</line>
      <line>Dappled his face. With thirsty heat oppressed</line>
      <line>At length I hailed him, glad to see his hat</line>
      <line>Bedewed with water-drops, as if the brim</line>
      <line>Had newly scooped a running stream. He rose</line>
      <line>And pointing to a sun-flower, bade me climb</line>
      <line>The broken wall where that same gaudy flower</line>
      <line>Looked out upon the road.</line>
      <line>It was a plot</line>
      <line> Of garden-ground now wild, its matted weeds</line>
      <line>Marked with the steps of those whom as they passed,</line>
      <line>The gooseberry-trees that shot in long lank slips,</line>
      <line>Or currants hanging from their leafless stems</line>
      <line>In scanty strings, had tempted to o’erleap</line>
      <line>The broken wall. Within that cheerless spot,</line>
      <line>Where two tall hedgerows of thick alder boughs</line>
      <line>Joined in a damp cold nook, I found a well</line>
      <line>Half covered up with willow-flowers and grass.</line>
      <line>I slaked my thirst and to the shady bench</line>
      <line> Returned, and while I stood unbonneted</line>
      <line>To catch the motion of the cooler air</line>
      <line>The old man said, ‘I see around me here</line>
      <line>Things which you cannot see. We die, my friend,</line>
      <line>Nor we alone, but that which each man loved</line>
      <line>O And prized in his peculiar nook of earth</line>
      <line>Dies with him, or is changed, and very soon</line>
      <line>Even of the good is no memorial left.</line>
      <line>The poets, in their elegies and songs</line>
      <line>Lamenting the departed, call the groves,</line>
      <line> They call upon the hills and streams to mourn,</line>
      <line>And senseless rocks – nor idly, for they speak</line>
      <line>In these their invocations with a voice</line>
      <line>Obedient to the strong creative power</line>
      <line>Of human passion. Sympathies there are</line>
      <line>More tranquil, yet perhaps of kindred birth,</line>
      <line>That steal upon the meditative mind</line>
      <line>And grow with thought. Beside yon spring I stood,</line>
      <line>And eyed its waters till we seemed to feel</line>
      <line>One sadness, they and I. For them a bond</line>
      <line> Of brotherhood is broken: time has been</line>
      <line>When every day the touch of human hand</line>
      <line>Disturbed their stillness, and they ministered</line>
      <line>To human comfort. When I stooped to drink</line>
      <line>A spider’s web hung to the water’s edge,</line>
      <line>And on the wet and slimy foot-stone lay</line>
      <line>The useless fragment of a wooden bowl.</line>
      <line>It moved my very heart.</line>
      <line>The day has been</line>
      <line>When I could never pass this road but she</line>
      <line>Who lived within these walls, when I appeared,</line>
      <line> A daughter’s welcome gave me, and I loved her</line>
      <line>As my own child. Oh sir, the good die first,</line>
      <line>And they whose hearts are dry as summer dust</line>
      <line>Burn to the socket. Many a passenger</line>
      <line>Has blest poor Margaret for her gentle looks</line>
      <line>When she upheld the cool refreshment drawn</line>
      <line>From that forsaken spring, and no one came</line>
      <line>But he was welcome, no one went away</line>
      <line>But that it seemed she loved him. She is dead,</line>
      <line>The worm is on her cheek, and this poor hut,</line>
      <line>Stripped of its outward garb of household-flowers,</line>
      <line>Of rose and sweetbriar, offers to the wind</line>
      <line>A cold bare wall whose earthy top is tricked</line>
      <line>With weeds and the rank speargrass. She is dead,</line>
      <line>And nettles rot and adders sun themselves</line>
      <line>O Where we have sat together while she nursed</line>
      <line>Her infant at her breast. The unshod colt,</line>
      <line>The wandering heifer and the potter’s ass,</line>
      <line>Find shelter now within the chimney-wall</line>
      <line>Where I have seen her evening hearthstone blaze</line>
      <line> And through the window spread upon the road</line>
      <line>Its cheerful light. You will forgive me, sir,</line>
      <line>But often on this cottage do I muse</line>
      <line>As on a picture, till my wiser mind</line>
      <line>Sinks, yielding to the foolishness of grief.</line>
      <line>She had a husband, an industrious man,</line>
      <line>Sober and steady. I have heard her say</line>
      <line>That he was up and busy at his loom</line>
      <line>In summer ere the mower’s scythe had swept</line>
      <line>The dewy grass, and in the early spring</line>
      <line> Ere the last star had vanished. They who passed</line>
      <line>At evening, from behind the garden-fence</line>
      <line>Might hear his busy spade, which he would ply</line>
      <line>After his daily work till the daylight</line>
      <line>Was gone, and every leaf and flower were lost</line>
      <line>In the dark hedges. So they passed their days</line>
      <line>In peace and comfort, and two pretty babes</line>
      <line>Were their best hope next to the God in Heaven.</line>
      <line>You may remember, now some ten years gone,</line>
      <line>Two blighting seasons when the fields were left</line>
      <line> With half a harvest. It pleased Heaven to add</line>
      <line>A worse affliction in the plague of war;</line>
      <line>A happy land was stricken to the heart –</line>
      <line>’Twas a sad time of sorrow and distress.</line>
      <line>A wanderer among the cottages,</line>
      <line>I with my pack of winter raiment saw</line>
      <line>The hardships of that season. Many rich</line>
      <line>Sunk down as in a dream among the poor,</line>
      <line>And of the poor did many cease to be,</line>
      <line>And their place knew them not. Meanwhile, abridged</line>
      <line> Of daily comforts, gladly reconciled</line>
      <line>To numerous self-denials, Margaret</line>
      <line>Went struggling on through those calamitous years</line>
      <line>With cheerful hope. But ere the second autumn,</line>
      <line>A fever seized her husband. In disease</line>
      <line>He lingered long, and when his strength returned</line>
      <line>He found the little he had stored to meet</line>
      <line>The hour of accident, or crippling age,</line>
      <line>Was all consumed. As I have said, ’twas now</line>
      <line>A time of trouble: shoals of artisans</line>
      <line> Were from their daily labour turned away</line>
      <line>To hang for bread on parish charity,</line>
      <line>They and their wives and children – happier far</line>
      <line>Could they have lived as do the little birds</line>
      <line>That peck along the hedges, or the kite</line>
      <line>That makes her dwelling in the mountain rocks.</line>
      <line>Ill fared it now with Robert, he who dwelt</line>
      <line>In this poor cottage. At his door he stood</line>
      <line>And whistled many a snatch of merry tunes</line>
      <line>That had no mirth in them, or with his knife</line>
      <line> Carved uncouth figures on the heads of sticks;</line>
      <line>Then idly sought about through every nook</line>
      <line>Of house or garden any casual task</line>
      <line>Of use or ornament, and with a strange</line>
      <line>Amusing but uneasy novelty</line>
      <line>He blended where he might the various tasks</line>
      <line>Of summer, autumn, winter, and of spring.</line>
      <line>But this endured not, his good humour soon</line>
      <line>Became a weight in which no pleasure was,</line>
      <line>And poverty brought on a petted mood</line>
      <line> And a sore temper. Day by day he drooped,</line>
      <line>And he would leave his home, and to the town</line>
      <line>Without an errand would he turn his steps,</line>
      <line>Or wander here and there among the fields.</line>
      <line>One while he would speak lightly of his babes</line>
      <line>And with a cruel tongue, at other times</line>
      <line>He played with them wild freaks of merriment,</line>
      <line>And ’twas a piteous thing to see the looks</line>
      <line>Of the poor innocent children. ‘Every smile’,</line>
      <line>Said Margaret to me here beneath these trees,</line>
      <line>‘Made my heart bleed.’</line>
      <line> At this the old man paused,</line>
      <line>And looking up to those enormous elms</line>
      <line>He said, ‘’Tis now the hour of deepest noon.</line>
      <line>At this still season of repose and peace,</line>
      <line>This hour when all things which are not at rest</line>
      <line>Are cheerful, while this multitude of flies</line>
      <line>Fills all the air with happy melody,</line>
      <line>Why should a tear be in an old man’s eye?</line>
      <line>Why should we thus with an untoward mind,</line>
      <line>And in the weakness of humanity,</line>
      <line> From natural wisdom turn our hearts away,</line>
      <line>To natural comfort shut our eyes and ears,</line>
      <line>And, feeding on disquiet, thus disturb</line>
      <line>The calm of Nature with our restless thoughts?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He spake with somewhat of a solemn tone,</line>
      <line>But when he ended there was in his face</line>
      <line>Such easy cheerfulness, a look so mild,</line>
      <line>That for a little time it stole away</line>
      <line>All recollection, and that simple tale</line>
      <line>Passed from my mind like a forgotten sound.</line>
      <line>A while on trivial things we held discourse,</line>
      <line>To me soon tasteless. In my own despite</line>
      <line>I thought of that poor woman as of one</line>
      <line>Whom I had known and loved. He had rehearsed</line>
      <line>Her homely tale with such familiar power,</line>
      <line>With such an active countenance, an eye</line>
      <line>So busy, that the things of which he spake</line>
      <line>Seemed present, and, attention now relaxed,</line>
      <line>There was a heartfelt chillness in my veins.</line>
      <line>I rose, and turning from that breezy shade</line>
      <line> Went out into the open air, and stood</line>
      <line>To drink the comfort of the warmer sun.</line>
      <line>Long time I had not stayed ere, looking round</line>
      <line>Upon that tranquil ruin, I returned</line>
      <line>And begged of the old man that for my sake</line>
      <line>He would resume his story.</line>
      <line>He replied,</line>
      <line>‘It were a wantonness, and would demand</line>
      <line>Severe reproof, if we were men whose hearts</line>
      <line>Could hold vain dalliance with the misery</line>
      <line>Even of the dead, contented thence to draw</line>
      <line> A momentary pleasure, never marked</line>
      <line>By reason, barren of all future good.</line>
      <line>But we have known that there is often found</line>
      <line>In mournful thoughts, and always might be found,</line>
      <line>A power to virtue friendly; were’t not so</line>
      <line>I am a dreamer among men, indeed</line>
      <line>An idle dreamer. ’Tis a common tale</line>
      <line>By moving accidents uncharactered,</line>
      <line>A tale of silent suffering, hardly clothed</line>
      <line>In bodily form, and to the grosser sense</line>
      <line> But ill adapted – scarcely palpable</line>
      <line>To him who does not think. But at your bidding</line>
      <line>I will proceed.</line>
      <line>While thus it fared with them</line>
      <line>To whom this cottage till that hapless year</line>
      <line>Had been a blesséd home, it was my chance</line>
      <line>To travel in a country far remote;</line>
      <line>And glad I was when, halting by yon gate</line>
      <line>That leads from the green lane, again I saw</line>
      <line>These lofty elm-trees. Long I did not rest –</line>
      <line>With many pleasant thoughts I cheered my way</line>
      <line> O’er the flat common. At the door arrived,</line>
      <line>I knocked, and when I entered, with the hope</line>
      <line>Of usual greeting, Margaret looked at me</line>
      <line>A little while, then turned her head away</line>
      <line>Speechless, and sitting down upon a chair</line>
      <line>Wept bitterly. I wist not what to do,</line>
      <line>Or how to speak to her. Poor wretch, at last</line>
      <line>She rose from off her seat, and then, oh sir,</line>
      <line>I cannot tell how she pronounced my name.</line>
      <line>With fervent love, and with a face of grief</line>
      <line> Unutterably helpless, and a look</line>
      <line>That seemed to cling upon me, she enquired</line>
      <line>If I had seen her husband. As she spake</line>
      <line>A strange surprise and fear came to my heart,</line>
      <line>Nor had I power to answer ere she told</line>
      <line>That he had disappeared – just two months gone,</line>
      <line>He left his house. Two wretched days had passed,</line>
      <line>And on the third by the first break of light,</line>
      <line>Within her casement full in view she saw</line>
      <line>A purse of gold. “I trembled at the sight”,</line>
      <line> Said Margaret, “for I knew it was his hand</line>
      <line>That placed it there. And on that very day</line>
      <line>By one, a stranger, from my husband sent,</line>
      <line>The tidings came that he had joined a troop</line>
      <line>Of soldiers going to a distant land.</line>
      <line>He left me thus. Poor man, he had not heart</line>
      <line>To take a farewell of me, and he feared</line>
      <line>That I should follow with my babes, and sink</line>
      <line>Beneath the misery of a soldier’s life.”</line>
      <line>This tale did Margaret tell with many tears,</line>
      <line> And when she ended I had little power</line>
      <line>To give her comfort, and was glad to take</line>
      <line>Such words of hope from her own mouth as served</line>
      <line>To cheer us both. But long we had not talked</line>
      <line>Ere we built up a pile of better thoughts,</line>
      <line>And with a brighter eye she looked around</line>
      <line>As if she had been shedding tears of joy.</line>
      <line>We parted. It was then the early spring;</line>
      <line>I left her busy with her garden-tools,</line>
      <line>And well remember, o’er that fence she looked,</line>
      <line> And, while I paced along the foot-way path,</line>
      <line>Called out and sent a blessing after me,</line>
      <line>With tender cheerfulness, and with a voice</line>
      <line>That seemed the very sound of happy thoughts.</line>
      <line>I roved o’er many a hill and many a dale</line>
      <line>With this my weary load, in heat and cold,</line>
      <line>Through many a wood and many an open ground,</line>
      <line>In sunshine or in shade, in wet or fair,</line>
      <line>Now blithe, now drooping, as it might befall;</line>
      <line>My best companions now the driving winds</line>
      <line> And now the “trotting brooks” and whispering trees,</line>
      <line>And now the music of my own sad steps,</line>
      <line>With many a short-lived thought that passed between</line>
      <line>And disappeared.</line>
      <line>I came this way again</line>
      <line>Towards the wane of summer, when the wheat</line>
      <line>Was yellow, and the soft and bladed grass</line>
      <line>Sprang up afresh and o’er the hayfield spread</line>
      <line>Its tender green. When I had reached the door</line>
      <line>I found that she was absent. In the shade,</line>
      <line>Where we now sit, I waited her return.</line>
      <line>Her cottage in its outward look appeared</line>
      <line>As cheerful as before, in any show</line>
      <line>Of neatness little changed – but that I thought</line>
      <line>The honeysuckle crowded round the door</line>
      <line>And from the wall hung down in heavier tufts,</line>
      <line>And knots of worthless stonecrop started out</line>
      <line>Along the window’s edge, and grew like weeds</line>
      <line>Against the lower panes. I turned aside</line>
      <line>And strolled into her garden. It was changed.</line>
      <line>The unprofitable bindweed spread his bells</line>
      <line> From side to side, and with unwieldy wreathes</line>
      <line>Had dragged the rose from its sustaining wall</line>
      <line>And bent it down to earth. The border tufts,</line>
      <line>Daisy, and thrift, and lowly camomile,</line>
      <line>And thyme, had straggled out into the paths</line>
      <line>Which they were used to deck.</line>
      <line>Ere this an hour</line>
      <line>Was wasted. Back I turned my restless steps,</line>
      <line>And as I walked before the door it chanced</line>
      <line>A stranger passed, and guessing whom I sought,</line>
      <line>He said that she was used to ramble far.</line>
      <line> The sun was sinking in the west, and now</line>
      <line>I sat with sad impatience. From within</line>
      <line>Her solitary infant cried aloud.</line>
      <line>The spot though fair seemed very desolate –</line>
      <line>The longer I remained more desolate –</line>
      <line>And looking round I saw the corner-stones,</line>
      <line>Till then unmarked, on either side the door</line>
      <line>With dull red stains discoloured, and stuck o’er</line>
      <line>With tufts and hairs of wool, as if the sheep</line>
      <line>That feed upon the commons thither came</line>
      <line> Familiarly, and found a couching-place</line>
      <line>Even at her threshold.</line>
      <line>The house-clock struck eight:</line>
      <line>I turned and saw her distant a few steps.</line>
      <line>Her face was pale and thin, her figure too</line>
      <line>Was changed. As she unlocked the door she said,</line>
      <line>“It grieves me you have waited here so long,</line>
      <line>But in good truth I’ve wandered much of late,</line>
      <line>And sometimes – to my shame I speak – have need</line>
      <line>Of my best prayers to bring me back again.”</line>
      <line>While on the board she spread our evening meal</line>
      <line> She told me she had lost her elder child,</line>
      <line>That he for months had been a serving-boy,</line>
      <line>Apprenticed by the parish. “I perceive</line>
      <line>You look at me, and you have cause. Today</line>
      <line>I have been travelling far, and many days</line>
      <line>About the fields I wander, knowing this</line>
      <line>Only, that what I seek I cannot find.</line>
      <line>And so I waste my time: for I am changed,</line>
      <line>And to myself”, said she, “have done much wrong,</line>
      <line>And to this helpless infant. I have slept</line>
      <line> Weeping, and weeping I have waked. My tears</line>
      <line>Have flowed as if my body were not such</line>
      <line>As others are, and I could never die.</line>
      <line>But I am now in mind and in my heart</line>
      <line>More easy, and I hope”, said she, “that Heaven</line>
      <line>Will give me patience to endure the things</line>
      <line>Which I behold at home.”</line>
      <line>It would have grieved</line>
      <line>Your very soul to see her. Sir, I feel</line>
      <line>The story linger in my heart. I fear</line>
      <line>’Tis long and tedious, but my spirit clings</line>
      <line> To that poor woman. So familiarly</line>
      <line>Do I perceive her manner and her look</line>
      <line>And presence, and so deeply do I feel</line>
      <line>Her goodness, that not seldom in my walks</line>
      <line>A momentary trance comes over me</line>
      <line>And to myself I seem to muse on one</line>
      <line>By sorrow laid asleep or borne away,</line>
      <line>A human being destined to awake</line>
      <line>To human life, or something very near</line>
      <line>To human life, when he shall come again</line>
      <line> For whom she suffered. Sir, it would have grieved</line>
      <line>Your very soul to see her: evermore</line>
      <line>Her eyelids drooped, her eyes were downward cast,</line>
      <line>And when she at her table gave me food</line>
      <line>She did not look at me. Her voice was low,</line>
      <line>Her body was subdued. In every act</line>
      <line>Pertaining to her house-affairs appeared</line>
      <line>The careless stillness which a thinking mind</line>
      <line>Gives to an idle matter. Still she sighed,</line>
      <line>But yet no motion of the breast was seen,</line>
      <line> No heaving of the heart. While by the fire</line>
      <line>We sat together, sighs came on my ear –</line>
      <line>I knew not how, and hardly whence, they came.</line>
      <line>I took my staff, and when I kissed her babe</line>
      <line>The tears stood in her eyes. I left her then</line>
      <line>With the best hope and comfort I could give:</line>
      <line>She thanked me for my will, but for my hope</line>
      <line>It seemed she did not thank me.</line>
      <line>I returned</line>
      <line>And took my rounds along this road again</line>
      <line>Ere on its sunny bank the primrose flower</line>
      <line> Had chronicled the earliest day of spring.</line>
      <line>I found her sad and drooping. She had learned</line>
      <line>No tidings of her husband. If he lived,</line>
      <line>She knew not that he lived: if he were dead,</line>
      <line>She knew not he was dead. She seemed the same</line>
      <line>In person or appearance, but her house</line>
      <line>Bespoke a sleepy hand of negligence.</line>
      <line>The floor was neither dry nor neat, the hearth</line>
      <line>Was comfortless,</line>
      <line>The windows too were dim, and her few books,</line>
      <line>Which one upon the other heretofore</line>
      <line>Had been piled up against the corner-panes</line>
      <line>In seemly order, now with straggling leaves</line>
      <line>Lay scattered here and there, open or shut,</line>
      <line>As they had chanced to fall. Her infant babe</line>
      <line>Had from its mother caught the trick of grief,</line>
      <line>And sighed among its playthings. Once again</line>
      <line>I turned towards the garden-gate, and saw</line>
      <line>More plainly still that poverty and grief</line>
      <line>Were now come nearer to her. The earth was hard,</line>
      <line> With weeds defaced and knots of withered grass;</line>
      <line>No ridges there appeared of clear black mould,</line>
      <line>No winter greenness. Of her herbs and flowers</line>
      <line>It seemed the better part were gnawed away</line>
      <line>Or trampled on the earth. A chain of straw,</line>
      <line>Which had been twisted round the tender stem</line>
      <line>Of a young apple-tree, lay at its root;</line>
      <line>The bark was nibbled round by truant sheep.</line>
      <line>Margaret stood near, her infant in her arms,</line>
      <line>And, seeing that my eye was on the tree,</line>
      <line> She said, “I fear it will be dead and gone</line>
      <line>Ere Robert come again.”</line>
      <line>Towards the house</line>
      <line>Together we returned, and she enquired</line>
      <line>If I had any hope. But for her babe,</line>
      <line>And for her little friendless boy, she said,</line>
      <line>She had no wish to live – that she must die</line>
      <line>Of sorrow. Yet I saw the idle loom</line>
      <line>Still in its place. His Sunday garments hung</line>
      <line>Upon the self-same nail, his very staff</line>
      <line>Stood undisturbed behind the door. And when</line>
      <line> I passed this way beaten by autumn winds,</line>
      <line>She told me that her little babe was dead</line>
      <line>And she was left alone. That very time,</line>
      <line>I yet remember, through the miry lane</line>
      <line>She walked with me a mile, when the bare trees</line>
      <line>Trickled with foggy damps, and in such sort</line>
      <line>That any heart had ached to hear her, begged</line>
      <line>That wheresoe’er I went I still would ask</line>
      <line>For him whom she had lost. We parted then,</line>
      <line>Our final parting; for from that time forth</line>
      <line> Did many seasons pass ere I returned</line>
      <line>Into this tract again.</line>
      <line>Five tedious years</line>
      <line>She lingered in unquiet widowhood,</line>
      <line>A wife and widow. Needs must it have been</line>
      <line>A sore heart-wasting. I have heard, my friend,</line>
      <line>That in that broken arbour she would sit</line>
      <line>The idle length of half a sabbath-day –</line>
      <line>There, where you see the toadstool’s lazy head –</line>
      <line>And when a dog passed by she still would quit</line>
      <line>The shade and look abroad. On this old bench</line>
      <line> For hours she sat, and evermore her eye</line>
      <line>Was busy in the distance, shaping things</line>
      <line>Which made her heart beat quick. Seest thou that path?</line>
      <line>The green-sward now has broken its grey line –</line>
      <line>There to and fro she paced through many a day</line>
      <line>Of the warm summer, from a belt of flax</line>
      <line>That girt her waist, spinning the long-drawn thread</line>
      <line>With backward steps. Yet ever as there passed</line>
      <line>A man whose garments showed the soldier’s red,</line>
      <line>Or crippled mendicant in sailor’s garb,</line>
      <line> The little child who sat to turn the wheel</line>
      <line>Ceased from his toil, and she, with faltering voice,</line>
      <line>Expecting still to learn her husband’s fate,</line>
      <line>Made many a fond enquiry; and when they</line>
      <line>Whose presence gave no comfort, were gone by,</line>
      <line>Her heart was still more sad. And by yon gate,</line>
      <line>Which bars the traveller’s road, she often stood</line>
      <line>And, when a stranger horseman came, the latch</line>
      <line>Would lift, and in his face look wistfully,</line>
      <line>Most happy if from aught discovered there</line>
      <line> Of tender feeling she might dare repeat</line>
      <line>The same sad question.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile her poor hut</line>
      <line>Sunk to decay; for he was gone, whose hand</line>
      <line>At the first nippings of October frost</line>
      <line>Closed up each chink, and with fresh bands of straw</line>
      <line>Chequered the green-grown thatch. And so she lived</line>
      <line>Through the long winter, reckless and alone,</line>
      <line>Till this reft house, by frost, and thaw, and rain,</line>
      <line>Was sapped; and when she slept, the nightly damps</line>
      <line>Did chill her breast, and in the stormy day</line>
      <line> Her tattered clothes were ruffled by the wind</line>
      <line>Even at the side of her own fire. Yet still</line>
      <line>She loved this wretched spot, nor would for worlds</line>
      <line>Have parted hence; and still that length of road,</line>
      <line>And this rude bench, one torturing hope endeared,</line>
      <line>Fast rooted at her heart. And here, my friend,</line>
      <line>In sickness she remained; and here she died,</line>
      <line>Last human tenant of these ruined walls.’</line>
      <line>The old man ceased; he saw that I was moved.</line>
      <line>From that low bench rising instinctively</line>
      <line> I turned aside in weakness, nor had power</line>
      <line>To thank him for the tale which he had told.</line>
      <line>I stood, and leaning o’er the garden gate</line>
      <line>Reviewed that woman’s sufferings; and it seemed</line>
      <line>To comfort me while with a brother’s love</line>
      <line>I blest her in the impotence of grief.</line>
      <line>At length towards the cottage I returned</line>
      <line>Fondly, and traced with milder interest</line>
      <line>That secret spirit of humanity</line>
      <line>Which, mid the calm oblivious tendencies</line>
      <line>Of Nature, mid her plants, her weeds and flowers,</line>
      <line>And silent overgrowings, still survived.</line>
      <line>The old man seeing this resumed, and said,</line>
      <line>‘My friend, enough to sorrow have you given,</line>
      <line>The purposes of wisdom ask no more:</line>
      <line>Be wise and cheerful, and no longer read</line>
      <line>The forms of things with an unworthy eye.</line>
      <line>She sleeps in the calm earth, and peace is here.</line>
      <line>I well remember that those very plumes</line>
      <line>Those weeds, and the high spear-grass on that wall,</line>
      <line> By mist and silent raindrops silvered o’er,</line>
      <line>As once I passed did to my mind convey</line>
      <line>So still an image of tranquillity,</line>
      <line>So calm and still, and looked so beautiful</line>
      <line>Amid the uneasy thoughts which filled my mind,</line>
      <line>That what we feel of sorrow and despair</line>
      <line>From ruin and from change, and all the grief</line>
      <line>The passing shows of being leave behind,</line>
      <line>Appeared an idle dream that could not live</line>
      <line>Where meditation was. I turned away,</line>
      <line> And walked along my road in happiness.’</line>
      <line>He ceased. By this the sun declining shot</line>
      <line>A slant and mellow radiance, which began</line>
      <line>To fall upon us where beneath the trees</line>
      <line>We sat on that low bench. And now we felt,</line>
      <line>Admonished thus, the sweet hour coming on:</line>
      <line>A linnet warbled from those lofty elms,</line>
      <line>A thrush sang loud, and other melodies</line>
      <line>At distance heard peopled the milder air.</line>
      <line>The old man rose and hoisted up his load;</line>
      <line> Together casting then a farewell look</line>
      <line>Upon those silent walls, we left the shade,</line>
      <line>And ere the stars were visible attained</line>
      <line>A rustic inn, our evening resting-place.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All thoughts, all passions, all delights,</line>
      <line>Whatever stirs this mortal frame,</line>
      <line>All are but ministers of Love,</line>
      <line>And feed his sacred flame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oft in my waking dreams do I</line>
      <line>Live o’er again that happy hour,</line>
      <line>When midway on the mount I lay</line>
      <line>Beside the ruined tower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moonshine, stealing o’er the scene,</line>
      <line>Had blended with the lights of eve,</line>
      <line>And she was there, my hope, my joy,</line>
      <line>My own dear Genevieve!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She leant against the arméd man,</line>
      <line>The statue of the arméd knight –</line>
      <line> She stood and listened to my lay,</line>
      <line>Amid the lingering light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Few sorrows hath she of her own,</line>
      <line>My hope! my joy! my Genevieve!</line>
      <line>She loves me best whene’er I sing</line>
      <line>The songs that make her grieve.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I played a soft and doleful air,</line>
      <line>I sang an old and moving story –</line>
      <line>An old rude song, that suited well</line>
      <line>That ruin wild and hoary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She listened with a flitting blush,</line>
      <line>With downcast eyes and modest grace,</line>
      <line>For well she knew I could not choose</line>
      <line>But gaze upon her face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I told her of the Knight that wore</line>
      <line>Upon his shield a burning brand,</line>
      <line>And that for ten long years he wooed</line>
      <line>The Lady of the Land.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I told her how he pined – and ah!</line>
      <line>The deep, the low, the pleading tone</line>
      <line> With which I sang another’s love,</line>
      <line>Interpreted my own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She listened with a flitting blush,</line>
      <line>With downcast eyes, and modest grace,</line>
      <line>And she forgave me that I gazed</line>
      <line>Too fondly on her face!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when I told the cruel scorn</line>
      <line>That crazed that bold and lovely Knight,</line>
      <line>And that he crossed the mountain-woods,</line>
      <line>Nor rested day nor night;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> That sometimes from the savage den,</line>
      <line>And sometimes from the darksome shade,</line>
      <line>And sometimes starting up at once</line>
      <line>In green and sunny glade,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There came and looked him in the face</line>
      <line>An angel beautiful and bright;</line>
      <line>And that he knew it was a fiend,</line>
      <line>This miserable Knight!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that unknowing what he did,</line>
      <line>He leaped amid a murderous band,</line>
      <line> And saved from outrage worse than death</line>
      <line>The Lady of the Land!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And how she wept, and clasped his knees;</line>
      <line>And how she tended him in vain,</line>
      <line>And ever strove to expiate</line>
      <line>The scorn that crazed his brain –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that she nursed him in a cave,</line>
      <line>And how his madness went away</line>
      <line>When on the yellow forest-leaves</line>
      <line>A dying man he lay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> His dying words – but when I reached</line>
      <line>That tenderest strain of all the ditty,</line>
      <line>My faltering voice and pausing harp</line>
      <line>Disturbed her soul with pity!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All impulses of soul and sense</line>
      <line>Had thrilled my guileless Genevieve –</line>
      <line>The music and the doleful tale,</line>
      <line>The rich and balmy eve –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And hopes, and fears that kindle hope,</line>
      <line>An undistinguishable throng,</line>
      <line> And gentle wishes long subdued,</line>
      <line>Subdued and cherished long!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She wept with pity and delight,</line>
      <line>She blushed with love and virgin-shame,</line>
      <line>And like the murmur of a dream</line>
      <line>I heard her breathe my name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her bosom heaved, she stepped aside –</line>
      <line>As conscious of my look she stepped –</line>
      <line>Then suddenly, with timorous eye,</line>
      <line>She fled to me and wept.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She half enclosed me with her arms,</line>
      <line>She pressed me with a meek embrace,</line>
      <line>And, bending back her head, looked up</line>
      <line>And gazed upon my face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas partly love, and partly fear,</line>
      <line>And partly ’twas a bashful art,</line>
      <line>That I might rather feel, than see,</line>
      <line>The swelling of her heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I calmed her fears, and she was calm,</line>
      <line>And told her love with virgin pride –</line>
      <line> And so I won my Genevieve,</line>
      <line>My bright and beauteous bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1803</date>
    <title>The Crystal Cabinet</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The maiden caught me in the wild</line>
      <line>Where I was dancing merrily;</line>
      <line>She put me into her cabinet</line>
      <line>And locked me up with a golden key.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> This cabinet is formed of gold</line>
      <line>And pearl and crystal shining bright,</line>
      <line>And within it opens into a world</line>
      <line>And a little lovely moony night!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Another England there I saw,</line>
      <line>Another London with its Tower,</line>
      <line>Another Thames and other hills,</line>
      <line>And another pleasant Surrey bower,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Another maiden like herself,</line>
      <line>Translucent, lovely, shining clear,</line>
      <line> Threefold each in the other closed –</line>
      <line>Oh what a pleasant trembling fear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh what a smile, a threefold-smile,</line>
      <line>Filled me, that like a flame I burned!</line>
      <line>I bent to kiss the lovely maid,</line>
      <line>And found a threefold-kiss returned;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I strove to seize the inmost form</line>
      <line>With ardour fierce and hands of flame,</line>
      <line>But burst the crystal cabinet</line>
      <line>And like a weeping babe became!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A weeping babe upon the wild</line>
      <line>And weeping woman pale reclined –</line>
      <line>And in the outward air again</line>
      <line>I filled with woes the passing wind!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1803</date>
    <title>The Mental Traveller</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I travelled through a land of men,</line>
      <line>A land of men, and women too –</line>
      <line>And heard and saw such dreadful things</line>
      <line>As cold-earth wanderers never knew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For there the babe is born in joy</line>
      <line>That was begotten in dire woe,</line>
      <line>Just as we reap in joy the fruit</line>
      <line>Which we in bitter tears did sow;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if the babe is born a boy,</line>
      <line>He’s given to a woman old</line>
      <line>Who nails him down upon a rock,</line>
      <line>Catches his shrieks in cups of gold –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She binds iron thorns around his head,</line>
      <line>She pierces both his hands and feet,</line>
      <line> She cuts his heart out at his side</line>
      <line>To make it feel both cold and heat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her fingers number every nerve</line>
      <line>Just as a miser counts his gold,</line>
      <line>She lives upon his shrieks and cries</line>
      <line>And she grows young as he grows old;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till he becomes a bleeding youth</line>
      <line>And she becomes a virgin bright,</line>
      <line>Then he rends up his manacles</line>
      <line>And binds her down for his delight –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He plants himself in all her nerves</line>
      <line>Just as a husbandman his mould,</line>
      <line>And she becomes his dwelling place</line>
      <line>And garden fruitful seventy-fold!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An agéd shadow soon he fades</line>
      <line>Wandering round an earthly cot,</line>
      <line>Full filled all with gems and gold</line>
      <line>Which he by industry had got –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And these are the gems of the human soul:</line>
      <line>The rubies and pearls of a lovesick eye,</line>
      <line> The countless gold of the aching heart,</line>
      <line>The martyr’s groan and the lover’s sigh.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They are his meat, they are his drink;</line>
      <line>He feeds the beggar and the poor</line>
      <line>And the wayfaring traveller –</line>
      <line>For ever open is his door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His grief is their eternal joy:</line>
      <line>They make the roofs and walls to ring,</line>
      <line>Till from the fire on the hearth</line>
      <line>A little female babe does spring!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And she is all of solid fire</line>
      <line>And gems and gold, that none his hand</line>
      <line>Dares stretch to touch her baby form,</line>
      <line>Or wrap her in his swaddling-band.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But she comes to the man she loves,</line>
      <line>If young or old or rich or poor,</line>
      <line>They soon drive out the agéd host,</line>
      <line>A beggar at another’s door –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He wanders weeping far away</line>
      <line>Until some other take him in,</line>
      <line> Oft blind and age-bent, sore distressed,</line>
      <line>Until he can a maiden win;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And to allay his freezing age</line>
      <line>The poor man takes her in his arms –</line>
      <line>The cottage fades before his sight,</line>
      <line>The garden and its lovely charms!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The guests are scattered through the land,</line>
      <line>For the eye, altering, alters all!</line>
      <line>The senses roll themselves in fear</line>
      <line>And the flat earth becomes a ball;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The stars, sun, moon all shrink away,</line>
      <line>A desert vast without a bound,</line>
      <line>And nothing left to eat or drink</line>
      <line>And a dark desert all around.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The honey of her infant lips,</line>
      <line>The bread and wine of her sweet smile,</line>
      <line>The wild game of her roving eye,</line>
      <line>Does him to infancy beguile –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For as he eats and drinks he grows</line>
      <line>Younger and younger every day,</line>
      <line> And on the desert wild they both</line>
      <line>Wander in terror and dismay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like the wild stag she flees away</line>
      <line>(Her fear plants many a thicket wild)</line>
      <line>While he pursues her night and day</line>
      <line>By various arts of love beguiled –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By various arts of love and hate;</line>
      <line>Till the wide desert planted o’er</line>
      <line>With labyrinths of wayward love</line>
      <line>Where roams the lion, wolf, and boar;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Till he becomes a wayward babe</line>
      <line>And she a weeping woman old!</line>
      <line>Then many a lover wanders here</line>
      <line>The sun and stars are nearer rolled,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The trees bring forth sweet ecstasy</line>
      <line>To all who in the desert roam,</line>
      <line>Till many a city there is built</line>
      <line>And many a pleasant shepherd’s home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when they find the frowning babe</line>
      <line>Terror strikes through the region wide,</line>
      <line> They cry, ‘The babe, the babe is born!’</line>
      <line>And flee away on every side –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For who dare touch the frowning form</line>
      <line>His arm is withered to its root;</line>
      <line>Lions, boars, wolves, all howling flee,</line>
      <line>OAnd every tree does shed its fruit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And none can touch that frowning form,</line>
      <line>Except it be a woman old –</line>
      <line>She nails him down upon the rock,</line>
      <line>And all is done as I have told.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY TIGHE</author>
    <date>1803</date>
    <title>‘A Glimpse of Love’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mid the blue waves, by circling seas embraced,</line>
      <line>A chosen spot of fairest land was seen,</line>
      <line>For there with favouring hand had Nature placed</line>
      <line>All that could lovely make the varied scene:</line>
      <line>Eternal Spring there spread her mantle green;</line>
      <line>There high surrounding hills deep-wooded rose</line>
      <line>O’er placid lakes; while marble rocks between</line>
      <line>The fragrant shrubs their pointed heads disclose,</line>
      <line>And balmy breathes each gale which o’er the island blows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Pleasure had called the fertile lawns her own,</line>
      <line>And thickly strewed them with her choicest flowers;</line>
      <line>Amid the quiet glade her golden throne</line>
      <line>Bright shone with lustre through o’erarching bowers:</line>
      <line>There her fair train, the ever-downy Hours</line>
      <line>Sport on light wing with the young Joys entwined;</line>
      <line>While Hope, delighted, from her full lap showers</line>
      <line>Blossoms, whose fragrance can the ravished mind</line>
      <line>Inebriate with dreams of rapture unconfined.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in the grassy centre of the isle,</line>
      <line> Where the thick verdure spreads a damper shade,</line>
      <line>Amid their native rocks concealed awhile,</line>
      <line>Then o’er the plains in devious streams displayed,</line>
      <line>Two gushing fountains rise; and thence conveyed,</line>
      <line>Their waters through the woods and valleys play,</line>
      <line>Visit each green recess and secret glade,</line>
      <line>With still unmingled, still meandering way,</line>
      <line>Nor widely wandering far, can each from other stray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But of strange contrast are their virtues found,</line>
      <line>And oft the lady of that isle has tried</line>
      <line> In rocky dens and caverns under ground,</line>
      <line>The black deforméd stream in vain to hide –</line>
      <line>Bursting all bounds her labours it defied!</line>
      <line>Yet many a flowery sod its course conceals</line>
      <line>Through plains where deep its silent waters glide,</line>
      <line>Till secret ruin, all corroding, steals,</line>
      <line>And every treacherous arch the hideous gulf reveals.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forbidding every kindly prosperous growth,</line>
      <line>Where’er it ran, a channel bleak it wore;</line>
      <line>The gaping banks receded, as though loth</line>
      <line> To touch the poison which disgraced their shore:</line>
      <line>There deadly anguish pours unmixed his store</line>
      <line>Of all the ills which sting the human breast,</line>
      <line>The hopeless tears which past delights deplore,</line>
      <line>Heart-gnawing jealousy which knows no rest,</line>
      <line>And self-upbraiding shame, by stern remorse opprest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, how unlike the pure transparent stream</line>
      <line>Which near it bubbles o’er its golden sands!</line>
      <line>The impeding stones with pleasant music seem</line>
      <line>Its progress to detain from other lands;</line>
      <line> And all its banks, enwreathed with flowery bands,</line>
      <line>Ambrosial fragrance shed in grateful dew.</line>
      <line>There young Desire enchanted ever stands,</line>
      <line>Breathing delight and fragrance ever new,</line>
      <line>And bathed in constant joys of fond affection true.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But not to mortals is it e’er allowed</line>
      <line>To drink unmingled of that current bright.</line>
      <line>Scarce can they taste the pleasurable flood,</line>
      <line>Defiled by angry Fortune’s envious spite,</line>
      <line>Who from the cup of amorous delight</line>
      <line> Dashes the sparkling draught of brilliant joy,</line>
      <line>Till, with dull sorrow’s stream despoiléd quite,</line>
      <line>No more it cheers the soul nor charms the eye,</line>
      <line>But mid the poisoned bowl distrust and anguish lie.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here Cupid tempers his unerring darts,</line>
      <line>And in the fount of bliss delights to play;</line>
      <line>Here mingles balmy sighs and pleasing smarts,</line>
      <line>And here the honied draught will oft allay</line>
      <line>With that black poison’s all-polluting sway,</line>
      <line>For wretched man. Hither, as Venus willed,</line>
      <line>For Psyche’s punishment he bent his way;</line>
      <line>From either stream his amber vase he filled –</line>
      <line>For her were meant the drops which grief alone distilled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His quiver, sparkling bright with gems and gold,</line>
      <line>From his fair pluméd shoulder graceful hung,</line>
      <line>And from its top in brilliant chords enrolled,</line>
      <line>Each little vase resplendently was slung.</line>
      <line>Still as he flew, around him sportive clung</line>
      <line>His frolic train of wingéd zephyrs light,</line>
      <line>Wafting the fragrance which his tresses flung;</line>
      <line> While odours dropped from every ringlet bright,</line>
      <line>And from his blue eyes beamed ineffable delight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wrapt in a cloud unseen by mortal eye,</line>
      <line>He sought the chamber of the royal maid;</line>
      <line>There, lulled by careless soft security,</line>
      <line>Of the impending mischief nought afraid,</line>
      <line>Upon her purple couch was Psyche laid,</line>
      <line>Her radiant eyes a downy slumber sealed;</line>
      <line>In light transparent veil alone arrayed,</line>
      <line>Her bosom’s opening charms were half revealed,</line>
      <line> And scarce the lucid folds her polished limbs concealed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A placid smile plays o’er each roseate lip!</line>
      <line>Sweet severed lips, while thus your pearls disclose</line>
      <line>That slumbering thus unconscious she may sip</line>
      <line>The cruel presage of her future woes.</line>
      <line>Lightly, as fall the dews upon the rose,</line>
      <line>Upon the coral gates of that sweet cell</line>
      <line>The fatal drops he pours; nor yet he knows</line>
      <line>(Nor, though a god, can he presaging tell)</line>
      <line>How he himself shall mourn the ills of that sad spell!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Nor yet content, he from his quiver drew,</line>
      <line>Sharpened with skill divine, a shining dart.</line>
      <line>No need had he for bow, since thus too true</line>
      <line>His hand might wound her all-exposéd heart,</line>
      <line>Yet her fair side he touched with gentlest art,</line>
      <line>And half relenting on her beauties gazed!</line>
      <line>Just then, awaking with a sudden start,</line>
      <line>Her opening eye in humid lustre blazed –</line>
      <line>Unseen he still remained, enchanted and amazed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dart which in his hand now trembling stood,</line>
      <line> As o’er the couch he bent with ravished eye,</line>
      <line>Drew with its daring point celestial blood</line>
      <line>From his smooth neck’s unblemished ivory.</line>
      <line>Heedless of this, but with a pitying sigh</line>
      <line>(The evil done now anxious to repair),</line>
      <line>He shed in haste the balmy drops of joy</line>
      <line>O’er all the silky ringlets of her hair;</line>
      <line>Then stretched his plumes divine, and breathed celestial air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unhappy Psyche! Soon the latent wound</line>
      <line>The fading roses of her cheek confess,</line>
      <line> Her eyes’ bright beams, in swimming sorrows drowned,</line>
      <line>Sparkle no more with life and happiness</line>
      <line>Her parents’ fond exulting heart to bless.</line>
      <line>She shuns adoring crowds, and seeks to hide</line>
      <line>The pining sorrows which her soul oppress,</line>
      <line>Till to her mother’s tears no more denied,</line>
      <line>The secret grief she owns, for which she lingering sighed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A dream of mingled terror and delight</line>
      <line>Still heavy hangs upon her troubled soul,</line>
      <line>An angry form still swims before her sight,</line>
      <line> And still the vengeful thunders seem to roll –</line>
      <line>Still crushed to earth she feels the stern control</line>
      <line>Of Venus unrelenting, unappeased.</line>
      <line>The dream returns, she feels the fancied dole:</line>
      <line>Once more the furies on her heart have seized,</line>
      <line>But still she views the youth who all her sufferings eased.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of wondrous beauty did the vision seem,</line>
      <line>And in the freshest prime of youthful years –</line>
      <line>Such at the close of her distressful dream</line>
      <line>A graceful champion to her eyes appears!</line>
      <line> Her loved deliverer from her foes and fears</line>
      <line>She seems in grateful transport still to press;</line>
      <line>Still his soft voice sounds in her ravished ears.</line>
      <line>Dissolved in fondest tears of tenderness</line>
      <line>His form she oft invokes her waking eyes to bless.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor was it quite a dream, for as she woke,</line>
      <line>Ere heavenly mists concealed him from her eye,</line>
      <line>One sudden transitory view she took</line>
      <line>Of Love’s most radiant bright divinity.</line>
      <line>From the fair image never can she fly,</line>
      <line> As still consumed with vain desire she pines;</line>
      <line>While her fond parents heave the anxious sigh,</line>
      <line>And to avert her fate seek holy shrines</line>
      <line>The threatened ills to learn by auguries and signs.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS CAMPBEL</author>
    <date>1809</date>
    <title>Gertrude of Wyoming II</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A valley, from the river-shore withdrawn,</line>
      <line>Was Albert’s home, two quiet woods between</line>
      <line>Whose lofty verdure overlooked his lawn;</line>
      <line>And waters to their resting-place serene</line>
      <line> Came freshening, and reflecting all the scene –</line>
      <line>A mirror in the depth of flowery shelves!</line>
      <line>So sweet a spot of earth you might (I ween)</line>
      <line>Have guessed some congregation of the elves</line>
      <line>To sport by summer moons had shaped it for themselves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet wanted not the eye far scope to muse,</line>
      <line>Nor vistas opened by the wandering stream;</line>
      <line>Both where at evening Allegany views,</line>
      <line>Through ridges burning in her western beam,</line>
      <line>Lake after lake interminably gleam –</line>
      <line> And past those settlers’ haunts the eye might roam,</line>
      <line>Where earth’s unliving silence all would seem,</line>
      <line>Save where on rocks the beaver built his dome</line>
      <line>Or buffalo remote lowed far from human home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But silent not that adverse eastern path</line>
      <line>Which saw Aurora’s hills the horizon crown:</line>
      <line>There was the river heard, in bed of wrath</line>
      <line>(A precipice of foam from mountains brown),</line>
      <line>Like tumults heard from some far distant town –</line>
      <line>But, softening in approach, he left his gloom</line>
      <line> And murmured pleasantly, and laid him down</line>
      <line>To kiss those easy curving banks of bloom</line>
      <line>That lent the windward air an exquisite perfume.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It seemed as if those scenes sweet influence had</line>
      <line>On Gertrude’s soul, and kindness like their own</line>
      <line>Inspired those eyes affectionate and glad,</line>
      <line>That seemed to love whate’er they looked upon.</line>
      <line>Whether with Hebe’s mirth her features shone,</line>
      <line>Or if a shade more pleasing them o’ercast</line>
      <line>(As if for heavenly musing meant alone),</line>
      <line> Yet so becomingly the expression past</line>
      <line>That each succeeding look was lovelier than the last.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor, guess I, was that Pennsylvanian home,</line>
      <line>With all its picturesque and balmy grace,</line>
      <line>And fields that were a luxury to roam,</line>
      <line>Lost on the soul that looked from such a face!</line>
      <line>Enthusiast of the woods, when years apace</line>
      <line>Had bound thy lovely waist with woman’s zone,</line>
      <line>The sunrise-path at morn I see thee trace</line>
      <line>To hills with high magnolia overgrown,</line>
      <line> And joy to breathe the groves, romantic and alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
