      <line>The sunrise drew her thoughts to Europe forth</line>
      <line>That thus apostrophized its viewless scene:</line>
      <line>‘Land of my father’s love, my mother’s birth!</line>
      <line>The home of kindred I have never seen!</line>
      <line>We know not other – oceans are between –</line>
      <line>Yet say! far friendly hearts from whence we came,</line>
      <line>Of us does oft remembrance intervene?</line>
      <line>My mother sure, my sire, a thought may claim,</line>
      <line>But Gertrude is to you an unregarded name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And yet, loved England! when thy name I trace</line>
      <line>In many a pilgrim’s tale and poet’s song,</line>
      <line>How can I choose but wish for one embrace</line>
      <line>Of them, the dear unknown, to whom belong</line>
      <line>My mother’s looks – perhaps her likeness strong?</line>
      <line>Oh parent! with what reverential awe,</line>
      <line>From features of thine own related throng,</line>
      <line>An image of thy face my soul could draw –</line>
      <line>And see thee once again whom I too shortly saw!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet deem not Gertrude sighed for foreign joy –</line>
      <line> To soothe a father’s couch her only care,</line>
      <line>And keep his reverend head from all annoy.</line>
      <line>For this, methinks, her homeward steps repair</line>
      <line>Soon as the morning-wreath had bound her hair,</line>
      <line>While yet the wild deer trod in spangling dew,</line>
      <line>While boatman carolled to the fresh-blown air,</line>
      <line>And woods a horizontal shadow threw,</line>
      <line>And early fox appeared in momentary view.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At times there was a deep untrodden grot,</line>
      <line>Where of the reading-hours sweet Gertrude wore;</line>
      <line> Tradition had not named its lonely spot,</line>
      <line>But here, methinks, India’s sons explore</line>
      <line>Their father’s dust, or lift, perchance, of yore,</line>
      <line>Their voice to the Great Spirit – rocks sublime</line>
      <line>To human art a sportive semblance wore,</line>
      <line>And yellow lichens coloured all the clime</line>
      <line>Like moonlight battlements, and towers decayed by time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But high, in amphitheatre above,</line>
      <line>His arms the everlasting aloes threw –</line>
      <line>Breathed but an air of Heaven, and all the grove</line>
      <line> As if with instinct living spirit grew,</line>
      <line>Rolling its verdant gulfs of every hue.</line>
      <line>And now suspended was the pleasing din,</line>
      <line>Now from a murmur faint it swelled anew –</line>
      <line>Like the first note of organ heard within</line>
      <line>Cathedral aisles, ere yet its symphony begin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was in this lone valley she would charm</line>
      <line>The lingering noon, where flowers a couch had strewn,</line>
      <line>Her cheek reclining, and her snowy arm</line>
      <line>On hillock by the palm-tree half o’ergrown –</line>
      <line> And aye that volume on her lap is thrown</line>
      <line>Which every heart of human mould endears:</line>
      <line>With Shakespeare’s self she speaks and smiles alone,</line>
      <line>And no intruding visitation fears</line>
      <line>To shame the unconscious laugh, or stop her sweetest tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For, save her presence, scarce an ear had heard</line>
      <line>The stock-dove plaining through its gloom profound,</line>
      <line>Or winglet of the fairy humming-bird</line>
      <line>Like atoms of the rainbow fluttering round,</line>
      <line>Till chance had ushered to its inmost ground</line>
      <line>The stranger-guest of many a distant clime.</line>
      <line>He was (to weet) for eastern mountains bound,</line>
      <line>But late the equator suns his cheek had tanned,</line>
      <line>And California’s gales his roving bosom fanned.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A steed, whose rein hung loosely o’er his arm,</line>
      <line>He led dismounted; ere his leisure pace</line>
      <line>Amid the brown leaves could her ear alarm</line>
      <line>Close he had come, and worshipped for a space</line>
      <line>Those downcast features – she her lovely face</line>
      <line>Uplift on one whose lineaments and frame</line>
      <line> Wore youth and manhood’s intermingled grace:</line>
      <line>Iberian seemed his boot, his robe the same,</line>
      <line>And well the Spanish plume his lofty looks became.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For Albert’s home he sought – her finger fair</line>
      <line>Has pointed where the father’s mansion stood.</line>
      <line>Returning from the copse, he soon was there;</line>
      <line>And soon has Gertrude hied from dark green wood,</line>
      <line>Nor joyless, by the converse, understood,</line>
      <line>Between the man of age and pilgrim young –</line>
      <line>That gay congeniality of mood</line>
      <line> And early liking from acquaintance sprung.</line>
      <line>Full fluently conversed their guest in England’s tongue,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And well could he his pilgrimage of taste</line>
      <line>Unfold, and much they loved his fervid strain</line>
      <line>While he each fair variety retraced</line>
      <line>Of climes, and manners, o’er the eastern main:</line>
      <line>Now happy Switzer’s hills, romantic Spain,</line>
      <line>Gay lilied fields of France, or, more refined,</line>
      <line>The soft Ausonia’s monumental reign –</line>
      <line>Nor less each rural image he designed</line>
      <line> Than all the city’s pomp, and home of human kind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Anon some wilder portraiture he draws:</line>
      <line>Of Nature’s savage glories he would speak –</line>
      <line>The loneliness of Earth that overawes</line>
      <line>Where, resting by some tomb of old cacique,</line>
      <line>The lama-driver on Peruvia’s peak</line>
      <line>Nor voice, nor living motion, marks around,</line>
      <line>But storks that to the boundless forest shriek,</line>
      <line>Or wild-cane arch high flung o’er gulf profound,</line>
      <line>That fluctuates when the storms of El Dorado sound!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Pleased with his guest, the good man still would ply</line>
      <line>Each earnest question, and his converse court;</line>
      <line>But Gertrude, as she eyed him, knew not why</line>
      <line>A strange and troubling wonder stopped her short.</line>
      <line>‘In England thou hast been, and by report</line>
      <line>An orphan’s name’, quoth Albert, ‘mayst have known.</line>
      <line>Sad tale! When latest fell our frontier-fort</line>
      <line>One innocent, one soldier’s child, alone</line>
      <line>Was spared, and brought to me, who loved him as my own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Young Henry Waldegrave – three delightful years</line>
      <line> These very walls his infant sports did see –</line>
      <line>But most I loved him when his parting tears</line>
      <line>Alternately bedewed my child and me.</line>
      <line>His sorest parting, Gertrude, was from thee –</line>
      <line>Nor half his grief his little heart could hold!</line>
      <line>By kindred he was sent for o’er the sea,</line>
      <line>They tore him from us when but twelve years old,</line>
      <line>And scarcely for his loss have I been yet consoled.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His face the wanderer hid, but could not hide</line>
      <line>A tear, a smile, upon his cheek that dwell.</line>
      <line> ‘And speak, mysterious stranger!’ Gertrude cried,</line>
      <line>‘It is – it is – I knew – I knew him well!</line>
      <line>’Tis Waldegrave’s self, of Waldegrave come to tell!’</line>
      <line>A burst of joy the father’s lips declare,</line>
      <line>But Gertrude speechless on his bosom fell:</line>
      <line>At once his open arms embraced the pair –</line>
      <line>Was never group more blest in this wide world of care!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And will ye pardon then’, replied the youth,</line>
      <line>‘Your Waldegrave’s feignéd name, and false attire?</line>
      <line>I durst not in the neighbourhood, in truth,</line>
      <line> The very fortunes of your house inquire,</line>
      <line>Lest one that knew me might some tidings dire</line>
      <line>Impart, and I my weakness all betray;</line>
      <line>For had I lost my Gertrude, and my sire,</line>
      <line>I meant but o’er your tombs to weep a day –</line>
      <line>Unknown I meant to weep, unknown to pass away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But here ye live, ye bloom! In each dear face</line>
      <line>The changing hand of time I may not blame:</line>
      <line>For there it hath but shed more reverend grace,</line>
      <line>And here, of beauty perfected the frame –</line>
      <line> And well I know your hearts are still the same!</line>
      <line>They could not change – ye look the very way</line>
      <line>As when an orphan first to you I came!</line>
      <line>And have ye heard of my poor guide, I pray –</line>
      <line>Nay, wherefore weep we, friends, on such a joyous day?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And art thou here – or is it but a dream?</line>
      <line>And wilt thou, Waldegrave, wilt thou leave us more?’</line>
      <line>‘No, never! Thou that yet dost lovelier seem</line>
      <line>Than aught on earth – than even thyself of yore –</line>
      <line>I will not part thee from thy father’s shore,</line>
      <line> But we shall cherish him with mutual arms,</line>
      <line>And hand-in-hand again the path explore</line>
      <line>Which every ray of young remembrance warms,</line>
      <line>While thou shalt be my own with all thy truth and charms!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At morn, as if beneath a galaxy</line>
      <line>Of over-arching groves in blossoms white</line>
      <line>(Where all was odorous scent and harmony,</line>
      <line>And gladness to the heart, nerve, ear and sight),</line>
      <line>There if, oh gentle love, I read aright</line>
      <line>The utterance that sealed thy sacred bond,</line>
      <line>’Twas – listening to these accents of delight –</line>
      <line>She hid upon his breast those eyes beyond</line>
      <line>Expression’s power to paint, all languishingly fond.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Flower of my life, so lovely and so lone!</line>
      <line>Whom I would rather in this desert meet,</line>
      <line>Scorning (and scorned by) Fortune’s power, than own</line>
      <line>Her pomp and splendours lavished at my feet!</line>
      <line>Turn not from me thy breath, more exquisite</line>
      <line>Than odours cast on Heaven’s own shrine – to please –</line>
      <line>Give me thy love, than luxury more sweet,</line>
      <line> And more than all the wealth that loads the breeze</line>
      <line>When Coromandel’s ships return form Indian seas!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then would the home admit them – happier far</line>
      <line>Than grandeur’s most magnificent saloon –</line>
      <line>While here and there a solitary star</line>
      <line>Flushed in the darkening firmament of June,</line>
      <line>And silence brought the soul-felt hour, full soon,</line>
      <line>Ineffable, which I may not portray –</line>
      <line>For never did the Hymenean moon</line>
      <line>A paradise of hearts more sacred sway</line>
      <line> In all that slept beneath her soft voluptuous ray!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1814</date>
    <title>The Bride of Abydos</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Zuleika mute and motionless</line>
      <line>Stood, like that statue of distress</line>
      <line>When (her last hope forever gone)</line>
      <line>The mother hardened into stone –</line>
      <line> All in the maid that eye could see</line>
      <line>Was but a younger Niobe!</line>
      <line>But ere her lip, or even her eye,</line>
      <line>Essayed to speak or look reply,</line>
      <line>Beneath the garden’s wicket-porch</line>
      <line>Far flashed on high a blazing torch –</line>
      <line>Another – and another – and another!</line>
      <line>‘Oh fly – no more, yet now my more than brother!’</line>
      <line>Far, wide, through every thicket spread,</line>
      <line>The fearful lights are gleaming red –</line>
      <line>Nor these alone, for each right hand</line>
      <line>Is ready with a sheathless brand.</line>
      <line>They part, pursue, return and wheel,</line>
      <line>With searching flambeau, shining steel;</line>
      <line>And last of all, his sabre waving,</line>
      <line>Stern Giaffir in his fury raving!</line>
      <line>And now almost they touch the cave –</line>
      <line>Oh, must that grot be Selim’s grave?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dauntless he stood – ‘’Tis come – soon past –</line>
      <line>One kiss, Zuleika – ’tis my last!</line>
      <line> But yet my band, not far from shore,</line>
      <line>May hear this signal, see the flash –</line>
      <line>Yet now too few, the attempt were rash –</line>
      <line>No matter – yet one effort more!’</line>
      <line>Forth to the cavern-mouth he stepped –</line>
      <line>His pistol’s echo rang on high –</line>
      <line>Zuleika started not, nor wept,</line>
      <line>Despair benumbed her breast and eye.</line>
      <line>‘They hear me not! Or if they ply</line>
      <line>Their oars, ’tis but to see me die!</line>
      <line> That sound hath drawn my foes more nigh –</line>
      <line>Then forth my father’s scimitar –</line>
      <line>Thou ne’er hast seen less equal war!</line>
      <line>Farewell, Zuleika! Sweet, retire –</line>
      <line>Yet stay within – here linger, safe –</line>
      <line>At thee his rage will only chafe.</line>
      <line>Stir not, lest even to thee perchance</line>
      <line>Some erring blade or ball should glance.</line>
      <line>Fearst thou for him? May I expire</line>
      <line>If in this strife I seek thy sire!</line>
      <line> No – though by him that poison poured!</line>
      <line>No – though he called me coward!</line>
      <line>But tamely shall I meet their steel?</line>
      <line>No – as each crest, save his, may feel!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One bound he made, and gained the sand:</line>
      <line>Already at his feet hath sunk</line>
      <line>The foremost of the prying band,</line>
      <line>A gasping head, a quivering trunk!</line>
      <line>Another falls – but round him close</line>
      <line>A swarming circle of his foes.</line>
      <line> From right to left his path he cleft,</line>
      <line>And almost met the meeting wave!</line>
      <line>His boat appears – not five oars’ length –</line>
      <line>His comrades strain with desperate strength!</line>
      <line>Oh, are they yet in time to save?</line>
      <line>His feet the foremost breakers lave,</line>
      <line>His band are plunging in the bay –</line>
      <line>Their sabres glitter through the spray –</line>
      <line>Wet, wild, unwearied, to the strand</line>
      <line>They struggle – now they touch the land!</line>
      <line> They come – ’tis but to add to slaughter –</line>
      <line>His heart’s best blood is on the water.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Escaped from shot, unharmed by steel,</line>
      <line>Or scarcely grazed its force to feel,</line>
      <line>Had Selim won – betrayed, beset –</line>
      <line>To where the strand and billows met.</line>
      <line>There, as his last step left the land,</line>
      <line>And the last death-blow dealt his hand,</line>
      <line>Ah, wherefore did he turn to look</line>
      <line>For her his eye but sought in vain?</line>
      <line> That pause, that fatal gaze he took,</line>
      <line>Hath doomed his death, or fixed his chain.</line>
      <line>Sad proof, in peril and in pain</line>
      <line>How late will lover’s hope remain!</line>
      <line>His back was to the dashing spray –</line>
      <line>Behind, but close, his comrades lay –</line>
      <line>When, at the instant, hissed the ball:</line>
      <line>‘So may the foes of Giaffir fall!’</line>
      <line>Whose voice is heard? Whose carbine rang?</line>
      <line>Whose bullet through the night-air sang</line>
      <line> Too nearly, deadly, aimed to err?</line>
      <line>’Tis thine, Abdallah’s murderer!</line>
      <line>The father slowly rued thy hate,</line>
      <line>The son hath found a quicker fate:</line>
      <line>Fast from his breast the blood is bubbling,</line>
      <line>The whiteness of the sea-foam troubling –</line>
      <line>If aught his lips essayed to groan,</line>
      <line>The rushing billows choked the tone!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Morn slowly rolls the clouds away,</line>
      <line>Few trophies of the fight are there.</line>
      <line> The shouts that shook the midnight-bay</line>
      <line>Are silent; but some signs of fray</line>
      <line>That strand of strife may bear,</line>
      <line>And fragments of each shivered brand;</line>
      <line>Steps stamped; and, dashed into the sand,</line>
      <line>The print of many a struggling hand</line>
      <line>May there be marked – nor far remote</line>
      <line>A broken torch, an oarless boat.</line>
      <line>And, tangled on the weeds that heap</line>
      <line>The beach where shelving to the deep,</line>
      <line> There lies a white capote!</line>
      <line>’Tis rent in twain – one dark-red stain</line>
      <line>The wave yet ripples o’er in vain –</line>
      <line>But where is he who wore?</line>
      <line>Ye, who would o’er his relics weep,</line>
      <line>Go, seek them where the surges sweep</line>
      <line>Their burden round Sigaeum’s steep</line>
      <line>And cast on Lemnos’ shore.</line>
      <line>The sea-birds shriek above the prey,</line>
      <line>O’er which their hungry beaks delay,</line>
      <line>As shaken on his restless pillow</line>
      <line>His head heaves with the heaving billow.</line>
      <line>That hand, whose motion is not life,</line>
      <line>Yet freely seems to menace strife,</line>
      <line>Flung by the tossing tide on high,</line>
      <line>Then levelled with the wave –</line>
      <line>What recks it, though that corse shall lie</line>
      <line>Within a living grave?</line>
      <line>The bird that tears that prostrate form</line>
      <line>Hath only robbed the meaner worm!</line>
      <line> The only heart, the only eye,</line>
      <line>Had bled or wept to see him die,</line>
      <line>Had seen those scattered limbs composed,</line>
      <line>And mourned above his turban-stone –</line>
      <line>That heart hath burst, that eye was closed,</line>
      <line>Yea – closed before his own!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By Helle’s stream there is a voice of wail!</line>
      <line>And woman’s eye is wet, man’s cheek is pale.</line>
      <line>Zuleika – last of Giaffir’s race –</line>
      <line>Thy destined lord is come too late:</line>
      <line> He sees not, ne’er shall see, thy face!</line>
      <line>Can he not hear</line>
      <line>The loud wull-wulley warn his distant ear?</line>
      <line>Thy handmaids weeping at the gate,</line>
      <line>The Koran-chanters of the hymn of fate,</line>
      <line>The silent slaves with folded arms that wait,</line>
      <line>Sighs in the hall, and shrieks upon the gale,</line>
      <line>Tell him thy tale.</line>
      <line>Thou didst not view thy Selim fall:</line>
      <line>That fearful moment when he left the cave</line>
      <line> Thy heart grew chill!</line>
      <line>He was thy hope, thy joy, thy love, thine all,</line>
      <line>And that last thought on him thou couldst not save</line>
      <line>Sufficed to kill –</line>
      <line>Burst forth in one wild cry, and all was still!</line>
      <line>Peace to thy broken heart and virgin grave!</line>
      <line>Ah happy, but of life to lose the worst –</line>
      <line>That grief, though deep, though fatal, was thy first!</line>
      <line>Thrice happy, ne’er to feel or fear the force</line>
      <line>Of absence, shame, pride, hate, revenge, remorse,</line>
      <line> And oh, that pang where more than madness lies –</line>
      <line>The worm that will not sleep, and never dies –</line>
      <line>Thought of the gloomy day and ghastly night,</line>
      <line>That dreads the darkness, and yet loathes the light,</line>
      <line>That winds around, and tears, the quivering heart!</line>
      <line>Ah, wherefore not consume it, and depart?</line>
      <line>Woe to thee, rash and unrelenting chief!</line>
      <line>Vainly thou heapst the dust upon thy head,</line>
      <line>Vainly the sackcloth o’er thy limbs dost spread –</line>
      <line>By that same hand Abdallah, Selim, bled!</line>
      <line> Now let it tear thy beard in idle grief:</line>
      <line>Thy pride of heart, thy bride for Osman’s bed,</line>
      <line>She whom thy Sultan had but seen to wed,</line>
      <line>Thy daughter’s dead!</line>
      <line>Hope of thine age, thy twilight’s lonely beam,</line>
      <line>The star hath set that shone on Helle’s stream –</line>
      <line>What quenched its ray? The blood that thou hast shed.</line>
      <line>Hark to the hurried question of despair:</line>
      <line>‘Where is my child?’ An echo answers, ‘Where!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Alastor</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Poet wandering on, through Araby</line>
      <line>And Persia, and the wild Carmanian waste,</line>
      <line>And o’er the aerial mountains which pour down</line>
      <line>Indus and Oxus from their icy caves,</line>
      <line>In joy and exultation held his way,</line>
      <line> Till in the vale of Cashmire, far within</line>
      <line>Its loneliest dell, where odorous plants entwine</line>
      <line>Beneath the hollow rocks a natural bower,</line>
      <line>Beside a sparkling rivulet he stretched</line>
      <line>His languid limbs.</line>
      <line>A vision on his sleep</line>
      <line>There came – a dream of hopes that never yet</line>
      <line>Had flushed his cheek. He dreamed a veiléd maid</line>
      <line>Sat near him, talking in low tones.</line>
      <line>Her voice was like the voice of his own soul</line>
      <line>Heard in the calm of thought: its music long,</line>
      <line> Like woven sounds of streams and breezes, held</line>
      <line>His inmost sense suspended in its web</line>
      <line>Of many-coloured woof and shifting hues.</line>
      <line>Knowledge and truth and virtue were her theme,</line>
      <line>And lofty hopes of divine liberty</line>
      <line>(The thoughts most dear to him), and poesy –</line>
      <line>Herself a poet. Soon the solemn mood</line>
      <line>Of her pure mind kindled through all her frame</line>
      <line>A permeating fire: wild numbers then</line>
      <line>She raised, with voice stifled in tremulous sobs</line>
      <line> Subdued by its own pathos. Her fair hands</line>
      <line>Were bare alone, sweeping from strange harp</line>
      <line>Strange symphony, and in their branching veins</line>
      <line>The eloquent blood told an ineffable tale.</line>
      <line>The beating of her heart was heard to fill</line>
      <line>The pauses of her music, and her breath</line>
      <line>Tumultuously accorded with those fits</line>
      <line>Of intermitted song.</line>
      <line>Sudden she rose,</line>
      <line>As if her heart impatiently endured</line>
      <line>Its bursting burden. At the sound he turned,</line>
      <line> And saw by the warm light of their own life</line>
      <line>Her glowing limbs beneath the sinuous veil</line>
      <line>Of woven wind, her outspread arms now bare,</line>
      <line>Her dark locks floating in the breath of night,</line>
      <line>Her beamy bending eyes, her parted lips</line>
      <line>Outstretched and pale, and quivering eagerly.</line>
      <line>His strong heart sank and sickened with excess</line>
      <line>Of love. He reared his shuddering limbs and quelled</line>
      <line>His gasping breath, and spread his arms to meet</line>
      <line>Her panting bosom. She drew back a while,</line>
      <line> Then, yielding to the irresistible joy,</line>
      <line>With frantic gesture and short breathless cry</line>
      <line>Folded his frame in her dissolving arms.</line>
      <line>Now blackness veiled his dizzy eyes, and night</line>
      <line>Involved and swallowed up the vision; sleep,</line>
      <line>Like a dark flood suspended in its course,</line>
      <line>Rolled back its impulse on his vacant brain.</line>
      <line>Roused by the shock, he started from his trance –</line>
      <line>The cold white light of morning, the blue moon</line>
      <line>Low in the west, the clear and garish hills,</line>
      <line> The distinct valley and the vacant woods,</line>
      <line>Spread round him where he stood. Whither have fled</line>
      <line>The hues of heaven that canopied his bower</line>
      <line>Of yesternight, the sounds that soothed his sleep,</line>
      <line>The mystery and the majesty of Earth,</line>
      <line>The joy and exultation? His wan eyes</line>
      <line>Gaze on the empty scene as vacantly</line>
      <line>As Ocean’s moon looks on the moon in heaven.</line>
      <line>The spirit of sweet human love has sent</line>
      <line>A vision to the sleep of him who spurned</line>
      <line>Her choicest gifts.</line>
      <line>He eagerly pursues</line>
      <line>Beyond the realms of dream that fleeting shade –</line>
      <line>He overleaps the bounds! Alas, alas,</line>
      <line>Were limbs, and breath, and being, intertwined</line>
      <line>Thus treacherously? Lost, lost, for ever lost,</line>
      <line>In the wide pathless desert of deep sleep,</line>
      <line>That beautiful shape! Does the dark gate of Death</line>
      <line>Conduct to thy mysterious paradise,</line>
      <line>Oh Sleep? Does the bright arch of rainbow clouds,</line>
      <line>And pendent mountains seen in the calm lake,</line>
      <line> Lead only to a black and watery depth,</line>
      <line>While Death’s blue vault, with loathliest vapours hung</line>
      <line>(Where every shade which the foul grave exhales</line>
      <line>Hides its dead eye from the detested day),</line>
      <line>Conduct, oh Sleep, to thy delightful realms?</line>
      <line>This doubt, with sudden tide, flowed on his heart;</line>
      <line>The insatiate hope which it awakened stung</line>
      <line>His brain even like despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Paulo and Francesca</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All the green garden, flower-bed, shade, and plot,</line>
      <line>Francesca loved but most of all this spot:</line>
      <line>Whenever she walked forth, wherever went</line>
      <line> About the grounds, to this at last she bent.</line>
      <line>Here she had brought a lute and a few books;</line>
      <line>Here would she lie for hours, with grateful looks,</line>
      <line>Thanking at heart the sunshine and the leaves,</line>
      <line>The summer rain-drops counting from the eaves,</line>
      <line>And all that promising, calm smile we see</line>
      <line>In Nature’s face, when we look patiently.</line>
      <line>Then would she think of Heaven; and you might hear</line>
      <line>Sometimes, when everything was hushed and clear,</line>
      <line>Her gentle voice from out those shades emerging,</line>
      <line> Singing the evening anthem to the Virgin.</line>
      <line>The gardeners and the rest, who served the place</line>
      <line>And blest – whenever they beheld – her face,</line>
      <line>Knelt when they heard it, bowing and uncovered,</line>
      <line>And felt as if in air some sainted beauty hovered.</line>
      <line>One day – ’twas on a summer afternoon,</line>
      <line>When airs and gurgling brooks are best in tune,</line>
      <line>And grasshoppers are loud, and day-work done,</line>
      <line>And shades have heavy outlines in the sun –</line>
      <line>The princess came to her accustomed bower</line>
      <line>To get her, if she could, a soothing hour,</line>
      <line>Trying, as she was used, to leave her cares</line>
      <line>Without, and slumberously enjoy the airs</line>
      <line>And the low-talking leaves, and that cool light</line>
      <line>The vines let in, and all that hushing sight</line>
      <line>Of closing wood seen through the opening door,</line>
      <line>And distant plash of waters tumbling o’er,</line>
      <line>And smell of citron blooms – and fifty luxuries more!</line>
      <line>She tried, as usual, for the trial’s sake –</line>
      <line>For even that diminished her heartache,</line>
      <line> And never yet (how ill soe’er at ease)</line>
      <line>Came she for nothing midst the flowers and trees.</line>
      <line>Yet somehow or another, on that day,</line>
      <line>She seemed to feel too lightly borne away –</line>
      <line>Too much relieved – too much inclined to draw</line>
      <line>A careless joy from everything she saw;</line>
      <line>And looking round her with a new-born eye,</line>
      <line>As if some tree of knowledge had been nigh,</line>
      <line>To taste of Nature, primitive and free,</line>
      <line>And bask at ease in her heart’s liberty.</line>
      <line> Painfully clear those rising thoughts appeared,</line>
      <line>With something dark at bottom that she feared;</line>
      <line>And snatching from the fields her thoughtful look,</line>
      <line>She reached o’er-head, and took her down a book,</line>
      <line>And fell to reading with as fixed an air,</line>
      <line>As though she had been wrapt since morning there.</line>
      <line>’Twas Launcelot of the Lake, a bright romance,</line>
      <line>That like a trumpet made young pulses dance,</line>
      <line>Yet had a softer note that shook still more.</line>
      <line>She had begun it but the day before,</line>
      <line> And read with a full heart, half sweet, half sad,</line>
      <line>How old King Ban was spoiled of all he had</line>
      <line>But one fair castle – how one summer’s day</line>
      <line>With his fair queen and child he went away</line>
      <line>To ask the great King Arthur for assistance;</line>
      <line>How, reaching by himself a hill at distance,</line>
      <line>He turned to give his castle a last look,</line>
      <line>And saw its far white face – and how a smoke,</line>
      <line>As he was looking, burst in volumes forth,</line>
      <line>And good King Ban saw all that he was worth,</line>
      <line> And his fair castle, burning to the ground,</line>
      <line>So that his wearied pulse felt over-wound,</line>
      <line>And he lay down, and said a prayer apart</line>
      <line>For those he loved, and broke his poor old heart.</line>
      <line>Then read she of the Queen with her young child,</line>
      <line>How she came up, and nearly had gone wild,</line>
      <line>And how, in journeying on in her despair,</line>
      <line>She reached a lake and met a lady there</line>
      <line>Who pitied her, and took the baby sweet</line>
      <line>Into her arms, when lo, with closing feet</line>
      <line> She sprang up all at once, like bird from brake,</line>
      <line>And vanished with him underneath the lake!</line>
      <line>The mother’s feelings we as well may pass –</line>
      <line>The fairy of the place that lady was,</line>
      <line>And Launcelot (so the boy was called) became</line>
      <line>Her inmate, till in search of knightly fame</line>
      <line>He went to Arthur’s court, and played his part</line>
      <line>So rarely, and displayed so frank a heart,</line>
      <line>That what with all his charms of look and limb,</line>
      <line>The Queen Genevra fell in love with him.</line>
      <line> And here, with growing interest in her reading,</line>
      <line>The princess, doubly fixed, was now proceeding.</line>
      <line>Ready she sat with one hand to turn o’er</line>
      <line>The leaf, to which her thoughts ran on before,</line>
      <line>The other propping her white brow, and throwing</line>
      <line>Its ringlets out, under the sky-light glowing.</line>
      <line>So sat she fixed; and so observed was she</line>
      <line>Of one, who at the door stood tenderly –</line>
      <line>Paulo – who, from a window seeing her</line>
      <line>Go straight across the lawn, and guessing where,</line>
      <line> Had thought she was in tears, and found, that day,</line>
      <line>His usual efforts vain to keep away.</line>
      <line>‘May I come in?’ said he. It made her start,</line>
      <line>That smiling voice – she coloured, pressed her heart</line>
      <line>A moment (as for breath), and then with free</line>
      <line>And usual tone said ‘Oh yes, certainly!’</line>
      <line>There’s apt to be, at conscious times like these,</line>
      <line>An affectation of a bright-eyed ease,</line>
      <line>An air of something quite serene and sure,</line>
      <line>As if to seem so, was to be, secure:</line>
      <line> With this the lovers met, with this they spoke,</line>
      <line>With this they sat down to the self-same book,</line>
      <line>And Paulo, by degrees, gently embraced</line>
      <line>With one permitted arm her lovely waist;</line>
      <line>And both their cheeks, like peaches on a tree,</line>
      <line>Leaned with a touch together, thrillingly;</line>
      <line>And o’er the book they hung, and nothing said,</line>
      <line>And every lingering page grew longer as they read.</line>
      <line>As thus they sat, and felt with leaps of heart</line>
      <line>Their colour change, they came upon the part</line>
      <line> Where fond Genevra, with her flame long nurst,</line>
      <line>Smiled upon Launcelot when he kissed her first!</line>
      <line>That touch, at last, through every fibre slid,</line>
      <line>And Paulo turned, scarce knowing what he did,</line>
      <line>Only he felt he could no more dissemble,</line>
      <line>And kissed her, mouth to mouth, all in a tremble.</line>
      <line>Sad were those hearts, and sweet was that long kiss:</line>
      <line>Sacred be love from sight, whate’er it is!</line>
      <line>The world was all forgot, the struggle o’er –</line>
      <line>Desperate the joy! That day they read no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS MOORE</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>The Fire-Worshippers</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She loves – but knows not whom she loves,</line>
      <line>Nor what his race, nor whence he came –</line>
      <line>Like one who meets, in Indian groves,</line>
      <line>Some beauteous bird, without a name,</line>
      <line>Brought by the last ambrosial breeze</line>
      <line>From isles in the undiscovered seas</line>
      <line>To show his plumage for a day</line>
      <line>To wondering eyes, and wing away!</line>
      <line>Will he thus fly – her nameless lover?</line>
      <line>Allah forbid! ’Twas by a moon</line>
      <line>As fair as this, while singing over</line>
      <line>Some ditty to her soft kanoon,</line>
      <line>Alone, at this same witching-hour,</line>
      <line>She first beheld his radiant eyes</line>
      <line> Gleam through the lattice of the bower</line>
      <line>Where nightly now they mix their sighs,</line>
      <line>And thought some spirit of the air</line>
      <line>(For what could waft a mortal there?)</line>
      <line>Was pausing on his moonlight way</line>
      <line>To listen to her lonely lay!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This fancy ne’er hath left her mind,</line>
      <line>And though, when terror’s swoon had passed,</line>
      <line>She saw a youth of mortal kind</line>
      <line>Before her in obeisance cast,</line>
      <line> Yet often since, when he has spoken</line>
      <line>Strange, awful words, and gleams have broken</line>
      <line>From his dark eyes too bright to bear,</line>
      <line>Oh, she hath feared her soul was given</line>
      <line>To some unhallowed child of air,</line>
      <line>Some erring spirit, cast from Heaven,</line>
      <line>Like those angelic youths of old,</line>
      <line>Who burned for maids of mortal mould,</line>
      <line>Bewildered left the glorious skies,</line>
      <line>And lost their Heaven for woman’s eyes!</line>
      <line> Fond girl – nor fiend nor angel he,</line>
      <line>Who woos thy young simplicity,</line>
      <line>But one of Earth’s impassioned sons</line>
      <line>As warm in love, as fierce in ire,</line>
      <line>As the best here whose current runs</line>
      <line>Full of the Day-God’s living fire!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But quenched tonight that ardour seems,</line>
      <line>And pale his cheek, and sunk his brow.</line>
      <line>Never before, but in her dreams,</line>
      <line>Had she beheld him pale as now –</line>
      <line> And those were dreams of troubled sleep</line>
      <line>From which ’twas joy to wake and weep,</line>
      <line>Visions that will not be forgot</line>
      <line>But sadden every waking scene</line>
      <line>Like warning ghosts, that leave the spot</line>
      <line>All withered where they once have been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How sweetly’, said the trembling maid,</line>
      <line>Of her own gentle voice afraid</line>
      <line>(So long had they in silence stood,</line>
      <line>Looking upon that moonlight flood) –</line>
      <line> ‘How sweetly does the moonbeam smile</line>
      <line>Tonight upon yon leafy isle!</line>
      <line>I’ve wished that little isle had wings,</line>
      <line>And we, within its fairy-bowers,</line>
      <line>Were wafted off to seas unknown</line>
      <line>Where not a pulse should beat but ours</line>
      <line>And we might live, love, die, alone,</line>
      <line>Far from the cruel and the cold,</line>
      <line>Where the bright eyes of angels only</line>
      <line>Should come around us to behold</line>
      <line> A paradise so pure and lonely!</line>
      <line>Would this be world enough for thee?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Playful she turned, that he might see</line>
      <line>The passing smile her cheek put on;</line>
      <line>But when she marked how mournfully</line>
      <line>His eyes met hers, that smile was gone,</line>
      <line>And, bursting into heart-felt tears,</line>
      <line>‘Yes, yes’, she cried, ‘my hourly fears,</line>
      <line>My dreams, have boded all too right –</line>
      <line>We part, for ever part, tonight!</line>
      <line> I knew, I knew, it could not last –</line>
      <line>’Twas bright, ’twas heavenly, but ’tis past!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh ever thus, from childhood’s hour,</line>
      <line>I’ve seen my fondest hopes decay –</line>
      <line>I never loved a tree or flower,</line>
      <line>But ’twas the first to fade away!</line>
      <line>I never nursed a dear gazelle,</line>
      <line>To glad me with its soft black eye,</line>
      <line>But when it came to know me well,</line>
      <line>And love me, it was sure to die!</line>
      <line> Now too, the joy most like divine</line>
      <line>Of all I ever dreamed or knew,</line>
      <line>To see thee, hear thee, call thee mine –</line>
      <line>Oh misery! must I lose that too?</line>
      <line>Yet go! On peril’s brink we meet:</line>
      <line>Those frightful rocks, that treacherous sea –</line>
      <line>No, never come again – though sweet,</line>
      <line>Though heaven, it may be death to thee!</line>
      <line>Farewell, and blessings on thy way</line>
      <line>Where’er thou goest, belovéd stranger!</line>
      <line> Better to sit and watch that ray,</line>
      <line>And think thee safe, though far away,</line>
      <line>Than have thee near me and in danger!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Danger – oh tempt me not to boast!’</line>
      <line>The youth exclaimed, ‘Thou little knowest</line>
      <line>What he can brave, who, born and nursed</line>
      <line>In Danger’s paths, has dared the worst –</line>
      <line>Upon whose ear the signal-word</line>
      <line>Of strife and death is hourly breaking,</line>
      <line>Who sleeps with head upon the sword</line>
      <line>His fevered hand must grasp in waking!</line>
      <line>Danger!’</line>
      <line>‘Say on! Thou fearest not then,</line>
      <line>And we may meet – oft meet again?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh look not so! Beneath the skies</line>
      <line>I now fear nothing but those eyes.</line>
      <line>If aught on earth could charm or force</line>
      <line>My spirit from its destined course –</line>
      <line>If aught could make this soul forget</line>
      <line>The bond to which its seal is set,</line>
      <line>’Twould be those eyes – they, only they,</line>
      <line> Could melt that sacred seal away!</line>
      <line>But no – ’tis fixed – my awful doom</line>
      <line>Is fixed! On this side of the tomb</line>
      <line>We meet no more – why, why, did Heaven</line>
      <line>Mingle two souls that Earth has riven,</line>
      <line>Has rent asunder, wide as ours?</line>
      <line>Oh arab maid – as soon the powers</line>
      <line>Of light and darkness may combine</line>
      <line>As I be linked with thee, or thine!</line>
      <line>Thy father –’</line>
      <line>‘Holy Allah save</line>
      <line> His gray head from that lightning glance!</line>
      <line>Thou knowest him not – he loves the brave,</line>
      <line>Nor lives their under heaven’s expanse</line>
      <line>One who would prize, would worship thee</line>
      <line>And thy bold spirit, more than he!</line>
      <line>Oft when in childhood I have played</line>
      <line>With the bright falchion by his side,</line>
      <line>I’ve heard him swear his lisping maid</line>
      <line>In time should be a warrior’s bride.</line>
      <line>And still, whene’er at haram-hours,</line>
      <line> I take him cool sherbets and flowers,</line>
      <line>He tells me (when in playful mood)</line>
      <line>A hero shall my bridegroom be –</line>
      <line>Since maids are best in battle wooed,</line>
      <line>And won mid shouts of victory!</line>
      <line>Nay, turn not from me – thou alone</line>
      <line>Art formed to make both hearts thy own!</line>
      <line>Go, join his sacred ranks – thou knowest</line>
      <line>The unholy strife these Persians wage –</line>
      <line>Good Heaven, that frown! Even now thou glowest</line>
      <line> With more than mortal warrior’s rage!</line>
      <line>Haste to the camp by morning’s light,</line>
      <line>And when that sword is raised in fight</line>
      <line>Oh still remember love and I</line>
      <line>Beneath its shadow trembling lie!</line>
      <line>One victory o’er those slaves of fire –</line>
      <line>Those impious Ghebers, whom my sire</line>
      <line>Abhors –’</line>
      <line>‘Hold, hold – thy words are death!’</line>
      <line>The stranger cried, as wild he flung</line>
      <line>His mantle back, and showed beneath</line>
      <line> The Gheber belt that round him clung:</line>
      <line>‘Here, maiden, look – weep – blush, to see</line>
      <line>All that thy sire abhors in me!</line>
      <line>Yes! I am of that impious race –</line>
      <line>Those ‘slaves of fire’ who, morn and even,</line>
      <line>Hail their Creator’s dwelling-place</line>
      <line>Among the living lights of Heaven!</line>
      <line>Yes! I am of that outcast few,</line>
      <line>To Iran and to vengeance true,</line>
      <line>Who curse the hour your arabs came</line>
      <line> To desolate our shrines of flame –</line>
      <line>And swear, before God’s burning eye,</line>
      <line>To break our country’s chains, or die!</line>
      <line>Thy bigot sire – nay, tremble not –</line>
      <line>He who gave birth to those dear eyes</line>
      <line>With me is sacred as the spot</line>
      <line>From which our fires of worship rise!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But know, ’twas he I sought that night</line>
      <line>When from my watch-boat on the sea</line>
      <line>I caught this turret’s glimmering light,</line>
      <line> And up the rude rocks desperately</line>
      <line>Rushed to my prey! Thou knowest the rest –</line>
      <line>I climbed the gory vulture’s nest,</line>
      <line>And found a trembling dove within!</line>
      <line>Thine, thine, the victory – thine the sin –</line>
      <line>If Love has made one thought his own</line>
      <line>Which Vengeance claims first – last – alone!</line>
      <line>Oh, had we never, never met,</line>
      <line>Or could this heart even now forget</line>
      <line>How linked, how blest, we might have been,</line>
      <line> Had Fate not frowned so dark between!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hadst thou been born a Persian maid,</line>
      <line>In neighbouring valleys had we dwelt,</line>
      <line>Through the same fields in childhood played,</line>
      <line>At the same kindling altar knelt,</line>
      <line>While all those nameless ties</line>
      <line>In which the charm of Country lies</line>
      <line>Had round our hearts been hourly spun,</line>
      <line>Till Iran’s cause and thine were one –</line>
      <line>While in thy lute’s awakening sigh</line>
      <line> I heard the voice of days gone by</line>
      <line>And saw in every smile of thine</line>
      <line>Returning hours of glory shine –</line>
      <line>While the wronged spirit of our land</line>
      <line>Lived, looked and spoke, her wrongs through thee!</line>
      <line>God! who could then this sword withstand?</line>
      <line>Its very flash were victory!</line>
      <line>But now, estranged, divorced for ever</line>
      <line>Far as the grasp of Fate can sever,</line>
      <line>Our only ties what love has wove</line>
      <line>(Faith, friends, and country, sundered wide),</line>
      <line>And then, then only, true to love,</line>
      <line>When false to all that’s dear beside;</line>
      <line>Thy father Iran’s deadliest foe,</line>
      <line>Thyself perhaps even now – but no!</line>
      <line>Hate never looked so lovely yet!</line>
      <line>No – sacred to thy soul will be</line>
      <line>The land of him who could forget</line>
      <line>All but that bleeding land for thee!</line>
      <line>When other eyes shall see, unmoved,</line>
      <line> Her widows mourn, her warriors fall,</line>
      <line>Thou’lt think how well one Gheber loved,</line>
      <line>And for his sake thou’lt weep for all.</line>
      <line>But look!’</line>
      <line>With sudden start he turned</line>
      <line>And pointed to the distant wave</line>
      <line>Where lights, like charnel meteors, burned</line>
      <line>Bluely, as o’er some seaman’s grave,</line>
      <line>And fiery darts at intervals</line>
      <line>Flew up all sparkling from the main,</line>
      <line>As if each star that nightly falls</line>
      <line> Were shooting back to heaven again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My signal-lights! I must away –</line>
      <line>Both, both, are ruined if I stay.</line>
      <line>Farewell, sweet life – thou clingst in vain –</line>
      <line>Now, Vengeance, I am thine again !’</line>
      <line>Fiercely he broke away, nor stopped,</line>
      <line>Nor looked, but from the lattice dropped</line>
      <line>Down mid the pointed crags beneath,</line>
      <line>As if he fled from life to death –</line>
      <line>While pale and mute young Hinda stood,</line>
      <line> Nor moved, till in the silent flood</line>
      <line>A momentary plunge below</line>
      <line>Startled her from her trance of woe.</line>
      <line>Shrieking, she to the lattice flew:</line>
      <line>‘I come, I come – if in that tide</line>
      <line>Thou sleepst tonight, I’ll sleep there too,</line>
      <line>In death’s cold wedlock by thy side.</line>
      <line>Oh, I would ask no happier bed</line>
      <line>Than the chill wave my love lies under –</line>
      <line>Sweeter to rest together dead,</line>
      <line> Far sweeter, than to live asunder!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But no, their hour is not yet come:</line>
      <line>Again she sees his pinnace fly,</line>
      <line>Wafting him fleetly to his home</line>
      <line>(Where’er that ill-starred home may lie),</line>
      <line>And calm and smooth it seemed to win</line>
      <line>Its moonlight way before the wind,</line>
      <line>As if it bore all peace within</line>
      <line>Nor left one breaking heart behind!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date><1819/date>
    <title>The Eve of St Agnes</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>St. Agnes’ Eve – ah, bitter chill it was!</line>
      <line>The owl, for all his feathers, was a-cold;</line>
      <line>The hare limped trembling through the frozen grass,</line>
      <line>And silent was the flock in woolly fold;</line>
      <line> Numb were the Beadsman’s fingers, while he told</line>
      <line>His rosary, and while his frosted breath,</line>
      <line>Like pious incense from a censer old,</line>
      <line>Seemed taking flight for Heaven, without a death,</line>
      <line>Past the sweet Virgin’s picture, while his prayer he saith.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His prayer he saith, this patient holy man;</line>
      <line>Then takes his lamp, and riseth from his knees,</line>
      <line>And back returneth, meagre, barefoot, wan,</line>
      <line>Along the chapel-aisle by slow degrees.</line>
      <line>The sculptured dead, on each side, seem to freeze,</line>
      <line> Imprisoned in black, purgatorial rails:</line>
      <line>Knights, ladies, praying in dumb oratories,</line>
      <line>He passeth by, and his weak spirit fails</line>
      <line>To think how they may ache in icy hoods and mails.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Northward he turneth through a little door,</line>
      <line>And scarce three steps, ere music’s golden tongue</line>
      <line>Flattered to tears this agéd man and poor;</line>
      <line>But no – already had his deathbell rung;</line>
      <line>The joys of all his life were said and sung –</line>
      <line>His was harsh penance on St Agnes’ Eve!</line>
      <line> Another way he went, and soon among</line>
      <line>Rough ashes sat he for his soul’s reprieve,</line>
      <line>And all night kept awake, for sinners’ sake to grieve.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That ancient Beadsman heard the prelude soft –</line>
      <line>And so it chanced, for many a door was wide</line>
      <line>From hurry to and fro. Soon, up aloft,</line>
      <line>The silver snarling trumpets gan to chide;</line>
      <line>The level chambers, ready with their pride,</line>
      <line>Were glowing to receive a thousand guests;</line>
      <line>The carvéd angels, ever eager-eyed,</line>
      <line> Stared, where upon their heads the cornice rests,</line>
      <line>With hair blown back, and wings put cross-wise on their breasts.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length burst in the argent revelry,</line>
      <line>With plume, tiara, and all rich array,</line>
      <line>Numerous as shadows haunting fairily</line>
      <line>The brain, new stuffed in youth with triumphs gay</line>
      <line>Of old romance. These let us wish away,</line>
      <line>And turn, sole-thoughted, to one lady there,</line>
      <line>Whose heart had brooded all that wintry day</line>
      <line>On love, and winged St Agnes’ saintly care –</line>
      <line> As she had heard old dames full many times declare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They told her how upon St Agnes’ Eve</line>
      <line>Young virgins might have visions of delight,</line>
      <line>And soft adorings from their loves receive</line>
      <line>Upon the honeyed middle of the night,</line>
      <line>If ceremonies due they did aright –</line>
      <line>As, supperless to bed they must retire,</line>
      <line>And couch supine their beauties, lily white;</line>
      <line>Nor look behind, nor sideways, but require</line>
      <line>Of Heaven with upward eyes for all that they desire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Full of this whim was thoughtful Madeline:</line>
      <line>The music, yearning like a god in pain,</line>
      <line>She scarcely heard; her maiden eyes divine,</line>
      <line>Fixed on the floor, saw many a sweeping train</line>
      <line>Pass by – she heeded not at all. In vain</line>
      <line>Came many a tiptoe amorous cavalier,</line>
      <line>And back retired – not cooled by high disdain,</line>
      <line>But she saw not. Her heart was otherwhere:</line>
      <line>She sighed for Agnes’ dreams, the sweetest of the year.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She danced along with vague regardless eyes,</line>
      <line> Anxious her lips, her breathing quick and short.</line>
      <line>The hallowed hour was near at hand – she sighs</line>
      <line>Amid the timbrels, and the thronged resort</line>
      <line>Of whisperers in anger, or in sport,</line>
      <line>Mid looks of love, defiance, hate, and scorn,</line>
      <line>Hoodwinked with faery fancy – all amort,</line>
      <line>Save to St Agnes and her lambs unshorn,</line>
      <line>And all the bliss to be before tomorrow morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, purposing each moment to retire,</line>
      <line>She lingered still. Meantime, across the moors</line>
      <line> Had come young Porphyro, with heart on fire</line>
      <line>For Madeline. Beside the portal-doors,</line>
      <line>Buttressed from moonlight, stands he and implores</line>
      <line>All saints to give him sight of Madeline</line>
      <line>But for one moment in the tedious hours,</line>
      <line>That he might gaze and worship all unseen –</line>
      <line>Perchance speak, kneel, touch, kiss! In sooth such things have been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He ventures in! Let no buzzed whisper tell –</line>
      <line>All eyes be muffled, or a hundred swords</line>
      <line>Will storm his heart, love’s feverous citadel.</line>
      <line> For him, those chambers held barbarian hordes,</line>
      <line>Hyena foemen and hot-blooded lords,</line>
      <line>Whose very dogs would execrations howl</line>
      <line>Against his lineage. Not one breast affords</line>
      <line>Him any mercy in that mansion foul,</line>
      <line>Save one old beldame, weak in body and in soul.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, happy chance – the agéd creature came,</line>
      <line>Shuffling along with ivory-headed wand,</line>
      <line>To where he stood, hid from the torch’s flame</line>
      <line>Behind a broad hall-pillar, far beyond</line>
      <line> The sound of merriment and chorus bland.</line>
      <line>He startled her; but soon she knew his face</line>
      <line>And grasped his fingers in her palsied hand,</line>
      <line>Saying, ‘Mercy, Porphyro! Hie thee from this place –</line>
      <line>They are all here to-night, the whole bloodthirsty race!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Get hence! Get hence! There’s dwarfish Hildebrand;</line>
      <line>He had a fever late, and in the fit</line>
      <line>He curséd thee and thine, both house and land –</line>
      <line>Then there’s that old Lord Maurice, not a whit</line>
      <line>More tame for his grey hairs! Alas me, flit!</line>
      <line>Flit like a ghost away!’ ‘Ah, Gossip dear,</line>
      <line>We’re safe enough – here in this armchair sit,</line>
      <line>And tell me how –’ ‘Good saints not here, not here!</line>
      <line>Follow me, child, or else these stones will be thy bier.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He followed through a lowly archéd way,</line>
      <line>O Brushing the cobwebs with his lofty plume,</line>
      <line>And as she muttered, ‘Well-a – well-a-day!’</line>
      <line>He found him in a little moonlight room,</line>
      <line>Pale, latticed, chill, and silent as a tomb.</line>
      <line>‘Now tell me where is Madeline’, said he,</line>
      <line> ‘Oh tell me, Angela, by the holy loom</line>
      <line>Which none but secret sisterhood may see,</line>
      <line>When they St Agnes’ wool are weaving piously.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘St Agnes? Ah, it is St Agnes’ Eve –</line>
      <line>Yet men will murder upon holy days:</line>
      <line>Thou must hold water in a witch’s sieve,</line>
      <line>And be liege-lord of all the elves and fays,</line>
      <line>To venture so! It fills me with amaze</line>
      <line>To see thee, Porphyro! St Agnes’ Eve!</line>
      <line>God’s help! My lady fair the conjuror plays</line>
      <line> This very night – good angels her deceive!</line>
      <line>But let me laugh awhile, I’ve mickle time to grieve.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Feebly she laugheth in the languid moon,</line>
      <line>While Porphyro upon her face doth look,</line>
      <line>Like puzzled urchin on an agéd crone</line>
      <line>Who keepeth closed a wondrous riddle-book,</line>
      <line>As spectacled she sits in chimney nook.</line>
      <line>But soon his eyes grew brilliant, when she told</line>
      <line>His lady’s purpose; and he scarce could brook</line>
      <line>Tears at the thought of those enchantments cold,</line>
      <line> And Madeline asleep in lap of legends old.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sudden a thought came like a full-blown rose,</line>
      <line>Flushing his brow, and in his painéd heart</line>
      <line>Made purple riot. Then doth he propose</line>
      <line>A stratagem that makes the beldame start:</line>
      <line>‘A cruel man and impious thou art!</line>
      <line>Sweet lady, let her pray, and sleep, and dream</line>
      <line>Alone with her good angels, far apart</line>
      <line>From wicked men like thee. Go, go! – I deem</line>
      <line>Thou canst not surely be the same that thou didst seem.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘I will not harm her, by all saints I swear’,</line>
      <line>Quoth Porphyro. ‘Oh may I ne’er find grace</line>
      <line>When my weak voice shall whisper its last prayer,</line>
      <line>If one of her soft ringlets I displace,</line>
      <line>Or look with ruffian passion in her face!</line>
      <line>Good Angela, believe me by these tears;</line>
      <line>Or I will, even in a moment’s space,</line>
      <line>Awake, with horrid shout, my foemen’s ears,</line>
      <line>And beard them, though they be more fanged than wolves and bears.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Ah, why wilt thou affright a feeble soul –</line>
      <line> A poor, weak, palsy-stricken, churchyard thing,</line>
      <line>Whose passing-bell may ere the midnight toll,</line>
      <line>Whose prayers for thee each morn and evening</line>
      <line>Were never missed?’ Thus plaining, doth she bring</line>
      <line>A gentler speech from burning Porphyro,</line>
      <line>So woeful, and of such deep sorrowing,</line>
      <line>That Angela gives promise she will do</line>
      <line>Whatever he shall wish, betide her weal or woe –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Which was, to lead him in close secrecy</line>
      <line>Even to Madeline’s chamber, and there hide</line>
      <line> Him in a closet of such privacy</line>
      <line>That he might see her beauty unespied,</line>
      <line>And win perhaps that night a peerless bride,</line>
      <line>While legioned fairies paced the coverlet</line>
      <line>And pale enchantment held her sleepy-eyed.</line>
      <line>Never on such a night have lovers met,</line>
      <line>Since Merlin paid his demon all the monstrous debt!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It shall be as thou wishest’, said the dame,</line>
      <line>All cates and dainties shall be storéd there</line>
      <line>Quickly on this feast-night – by the tambour-frame</line>
      <line> Her own lute thou wilt see – no time to spare</line>
      <line>For I am slow and feeble, and scarce dare</line>
      <line>On such a catering trust my dizzy head!</line>
      <line>Wait here, my child, with patience; kneel in prayer</line>
      <line>The while. Ah! thou must needs the lady wed,</line>
      <line>Or may I never leave my grave among the dead!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So saying, she hobbled off with busy fear.</line>
      <line>The lover’s endless minutes slowly passed;</line>
      <line>The dame returned, and whispered in his ear</line>
      <line>To follow her – with agéd eyes aghast</line>
      <line> From fright of dim espial. Safe at last,</line>
      <line>Through many a dusky gallery, they gain</line>
      <line>The maiden’s chamber, silken, hushed, and chaste;</line>
      <line>Where Porphyro took covert, pleased amain –</line>
      <line>His poor guide hurried back with agues in her brain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her faltering hand upon the balustrade,</line>
      <line>Old Angela was feeling for the stair,</line>
      <line>When Madeline, St Agnes’ charméd maid,</line>
      <line>Rose, like a missioned spirit, unaware.</line>
      <line>With silver taper’s light, and pious care,</line>
      <line> She turned, and down the agéd gossip led</line>
      <line>To a safe level matting. Now prepare,</line>
      <line>Young Porphyro, for gazing on that bed –</line>
      <line>She comes, she comes again, like ring-dove frayed and fled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Out went the taper as she hurried in –</line>
      <line>Its little smoke in pallid moonshine died –</line>
      <line>She closed the door, she panted, all akin</line>
      <line>To spirits of the air, and visions wide.</line>
      <line>No uttered syllable (or, woe betide!)</line>
      <line>But to her heart, her heart was voluble,</line>
      <line>Paining with eloquence her balmy side,</line>
      <line>As though a tongueless nightingale should swell</line>
      <line>Her throat in vain, and die, heart-stifled, in her dell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A casement high and triple-arched there was,</line>
      <line>All garlanded with carven imageries</line>
      <line>Of fruits, and flowers, and bunches of knot-grass,</line>
      <line>And diamonded with panes of quaint device,</line>
      <line>Innumerable of stains and splendid dyes</line>
      <line>As are the tiger-moth’s deep-damasked wings;</line>
      <line>And in the midst, ’mong thousand heraldries,</line>
      <line> And twilight saints, and dim emblazonings,</line>
      <line>A shielded scutcheon blushed with blood of queens and kings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full on this casement shone the wintry moon,</line>
      <line>And threw warm gules on Madeline’s fair breast</line>
      <line>As down she knelt for Heaven’s grace and boon;</line>
      <line>Rose-bloom fell on her hands, together prest,</line>
      <line>And on her silver cross soft amethyst,</line>
      <line>And on her hair a glory, like a saint:</line>
      <line>She seemed a splendid angel, newly drest,</line>
      <line>Save wings, for Heaven – Porphyro grew faint:</line>
      <line> She knelt, so pure a thing, so free from mortal taint.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Anon his heart revives. Her vespers done,</line>
      <line>Of all its wreathéd pearls her hair she frees,</line>
      <line>Unclasps her warméd jewels one by one,</line>
      <line>Loosens her fragrant bodice – by degrees</line>
      <line>Her rich attire creeps rustling to her knees.</line>
      <line>Half-hidden, like a mermaid in sea-weed,</line>
      <line>Pensive awhile she dreams awake, and sees,</line>
      <line>In fancy, fair St Agnes in her bed,</line>
      <line>But dares not look behind, or all the charm is fled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Soon, trembling in her soft and chilly nest,</line>
      <line>In sort of wakeful swoon, perplexed she lay,</line>
      <line>Until the poppied warmth of sleep oppressed</line>
      <line>Her soothéd limbs, and soul fatigued away –</line>
      <line>Flown, like a thought, until the morrow-day;</line>
      <line>Blissfully havened both from joy and pain;</line>
      <line>Clasped like a missal where swart Paynims pray;</line>
      <line>Blinded alike from sunshine and from rain,</line>
      <line>As though a rose should shut, and be a bud again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Stolen to this paradise, and so entranced,</line>
      <line> Porphyro gazed upon her empty dress</line>
      <line>And listened to her breathing, if it chanced</line>
      <line>To wake into a slumberous tenderness –</line>
      <line>Which when he heard, that minute did he bless,</line>
      <line>And breathed himself; then from the closet crept,</line>
      <line>Noiseless as fear in a wide wilderness,</line>
      <line>And over the hushed carpet, silent, stepped</line>
      <line>And ’tween the curtains peeped, where, lo – how fast she slept!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then by the bedside, where the faded moon</line>
      <line>Made a dim silver twilight, soft he set</line>
      <line> A table, and, half anguished, threw thereon</line>
      <line>A cloth of woven crimson, gold, and jet –</line>
      <line>Oh for some drowsy Morphean amulet!</line>
      <line>The boisterous, midnight, festive clarion,</line>
      <line>The kettle-drum and far-heard clarionet,</line>
      <line>Affray his ears, though but in dying tone:</line>
      <line>The hall door shuts again, and all the noise is gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And still she slept an azure-liddéd sleep,</line>
      <line>In blanchéd linen, smooth and lavendered,</line>
      <line>While he from forth the closet brought a heap</line>
      <line> Of candied apple, quince, and plum, and gourd;</line>
      <line>With jellies soother than the creamy curd,</line>
      <line>And lucent syrops, tinct with cinnamon;</line>
      <line>Manna and dates, in argosy transferred</line>
      <line>From Fez; and spicéd dainties, every one,</line>
      <line>From silken Samarcand to cedared Lebanon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>These delicates he heaped with glowing hand</line>
      <line>On golden dishes and in baskets bright</line>
      <line>Of wreathéd silver – sumptuous they stand</line>
      <line>In the retiréd quiet of the night,</line>
      <line> Filling the chilly room with perfume light:</line>
      <line>‘And now, my love, my seraph fair, awake!</line>
      <line>Thou art my Heaven, and I thine eremite!</line>
      <line>Open thine eyes, for meek St Agnes’ sake,</line>
      <line>Or I shall drowse beside thee, so my soul doth ache.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus whispering, his warm, unnervéd arm</line>
      <line>Sank in her pillow. Shaded was her dream</line>
      <line>By the dusk curtains – ’twas a midnight charm</line>
      <line>Impossible to melt as icéd stream!</line>
      <line>The lustrous salvers in the moonlight gleam;</line>
      <line> Broad golden fringe upon the carpet lies:</line>
      <line>It seemed he never, never could redeem</line>
      <line>From such a stedfast spell his lady’s eyes,</line>
      <line>So mused awhile, entoiled in wooféd fantasies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Awakening up, he took her hollow lute</line>
      <line>Tumultuous, and, in chords that tenderest be,</line>
      <line>He played an ancient ditty, long since mute,</line>
      <line>In Provence called La Belle Dame Sans Mercy,</line>
      <line>Close to her ear touching the melody.</line>
      <line>Wherewith disturbed, she uttered a soft moan –</line>
      <line> He ceased – she panted quick – and suddenly</line>
      <line>Her blue affrayéd eyes wide open shone:</line>
      <line>Upon his knees he sank, pale as smooth-sculptured stone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her eyes were open, but she still beheld,</line>
      <line>Now wide awake, the vision of her sleep.</line>
      <line>There was a painful change, that nigh expelled</line>
      <line>The blisses of her dream so pure and deep –</line>
      <line>At which fair Madeline began to weep,</line>
      <line>And moan forth witless words with many a sigh,</line>
      <line>While still her gaze on Porphyro would keep;</line>
      <line>Who knelt, with joinéd hands and piteous eye,</line>
      <line>Fearing to move or speak, she looked so dreamingly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Ah, Porphyro!’ said she, ‘but even now</line>
      <line>Thy voice was at sweet tremble in mine ear,</line>
      <line>Made tuneable with every sweetest vow,</line>
      <line>And those sad eyes were spiritual and clear.</line>
      <line>How changed thou art! How pallid, chill, and drear!</line>
      <line>Give me that voice again, my Porphyro,</line>
      <line>Those looks immortal, those complainings dear –</line>
      <line>Oh leave me not in this eternal woe,</line>
      <line> For if thou diest, my love, I know not where to go.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beyond a mortal man impassioned far</line>
      <line>At these voluptuous accents, he arose,</line>
      <line>Ethereal, flushed, and, like a throbbing star</line>
      <line>Seen mid the sapphire heaven’s deep repose,</line>
      <line>Into her dream he melted, as the rose</line>
      <line>Blendeth its odour with the violet –</line>
      <line>Solution sweet! Meantime the frost-wind blows</line>
      <line>Like love’s alarum pattering the sharp sleet</line>
      <line>Against the window-panes. St Agnes’ moon hath set.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ’Tis dark – quick pattereth the flaw-blown sleet:</line>
      <line>‘This is no dream, my bride, my Madeline!’</line>
      <line>’Tis dark – the icéd gusts still rave and beat:</line>
      <line>‘No dream, alas! alas! and woe is mine!</line>
      <line>Porphyro will leave me here to fade and pine –</line>
      <line>Cruel! What traitor could thee hither bring?</line>
      <line>I curse not, for my heart is lost in thine,</line>
      <line>Though thou forsakest a deceivéd thing,</line>
      <line>A dove forlorn and lost with sick unprunéd wing.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My Madeline! Sweet dreamer! Lovely bride!</line>
      <line> Say, may I be for aye thy vassal blest –</line>
      <line>Thy beauty’s shield, heart-shaped and vermeil dyed?</line>
      <line>Ah, silver shrine, here will I take my rest</line>
      <line>After so many hours of toil and quest,</line>
      <line>A famished pilgrim saved by miracle!</line>
      <line>Though I have found, I will not rob thy nest,</line>
      <line>Saving of thy sweet self – if thou thinkst well</line>
      <line>To trust, fair Madeline, to no rude infidel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hark! ’Tis an elfin-storm from faery land,</line>
      <line>Of haggard seeming, but a boon indeed!</line>
      <line> Arise, arise! The morning is at hand –</line>
      <line>The bloated wassaillers will never heed –</line>
      <line>Let us away, my love, with happy speed!</line>
      <line>There are no ears to hear, or eyes to see,</line>
      <line>Drowned all in Rhenish and the sleepy mead.</line>
      <line>Awake! Arise, my love, and fearless be,</line>
      <line>For o’er the southern moors I have a home for thee!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She hurried at his words, beset with fears,</line>
      <line>For there were sleeping dragons all around,</line>
      <line>At glaring watch, perhaps with ready spears;</line>
      <line> Down the wide stairs a darkling way they found.</line>
      <line>In all the house was heard no human sound:</line>
      <line>A chain-drooped lamp was flickering by each door;</line>
      <line>The arras, rich with horseman, hawk, and hound,</line>
      <line>Fluttered in the besieging wind’s uproar;</line>
      <line>And the long carpets rose along the gusty floor.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They glide, like phantoms, into the wide hall –</line>
      <line>Like phantoms, to the iron porch, they glide –</line>
      <line>Where lay the porter, in uneasy sprawl,</line>
      <line>With a huge empty flagon by his side!</line>
      <line> The wakeful bloodhound rose, and shook his hide,</line>
      <line>But his sagacious eye an inmate owns;</line>
      <line>By one, and one, the bolts full easy slide,</line>
      <line>The chains lie silent on the footworn stones;</line>
      <line>The key turns, and the door upon its hinges groans,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And they are gone – aye, ages long ago</line>
      <line>These lovers fled away into the storm!</line>
      <line>That night the Baron dreamt of many a woe,</line>
      <line>And all his warrior-guests, with shade and form</line>
      <line>Of witch, and demon, and large coffin-worm,</line>
      <line> Were long be-nightmared. Angela the old</line>
      <line>Died palsy-twitched, with meagre face deform;</line>
      <line>The Beadsman, after thousand avés told,</line>
      <line>For aye unsought for, slept among his ashes cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1821</date>
    <title>Juan and Haidee (from Don Jual II-IV)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How long in his damp trance young Juan lay</line>
      <line>He knew not, for the earth was gone for him,</line>
      <line>And Time had nothing more of night nor day</line>
      <line>For his congealing blood, and senses dim;</line>
      <line> And how this heavy faintness passed away</line>
      <line>He knew not, till each painful pulse and limb,</line>
      <line>And tingling vein, seemed throbbing back to life,</line>
      <line>For Death, though vanquished, still retired with strife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His eyes he opened, shut, again unclosed,</line>
      <line>For all was doubt and dizziness; he thought</line>
      <line>He still was in the boat, and had but dozed,</line>
      <line>And felt again with his despair o’erwrought,</line>
      <line>And wished it death in which he had reposed,</line>
      <line>And then once more his feelings back were brought,</line>
      <line> And slowly by his swimming eyes was seen</line>
      <line>A lovely female face of seventeen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas bending close o’er his, and the small mouth</line>
      <line>Seemed almost prying into his for breath;</line>
      <line>And chafing him, the soft warm hand of youth</line>
      <line>Recalled his answering spirits back from death;</line>
      <line>And, bathing his chill temples, tried to soothe</line>
      <line>Each pulse to animation, till beneath</line>
      <line>Its gentle touch and trembling care, a sigh</line>
      <line>To these kind efforts made a low reply.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then was the cordial poured, and mantle flung</line>
      <line>Around his scarce-clad limbs; and the fair arm</line>
      <line>Raised higher the faint head which o’er it hung,</line>
      <line>And her transparent cheek (all pure and warm)</line>
      <line>Pillowed his death-like forehead. Then she wrung</line>
      <line>His dewy curls, long drenched by every storm,</line>
      <line>And watched with eagerness each throb that drew</line>
      <line>A sigh from his heaved bosom – and hers, too.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lifting him with care into the cave,</line>
      <line>The gentle girl, and her attendant (one</line>
      <line> Young, yet her elder, and of brow less grave,</line>
      <line>And more robust of figure), then begun</line>
      <line>To kindle fire, and as the new flames gave</line>
      <line>Light to the rocks that roofed them, which the sun</line>
      <line>Had never seen, the maid, or whatsoe’er</line>
      <line>She was, appeared distinct, and tall, and fair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her brow was overhung with coins of gold</line>
      <line>That sparkled o’er the auburn of her hair –</line>
      <line>Her clustering hair, whose longer locks were rolled</line>
      <line>In braids behind – and though her stature were</line>
      <line> Even of the highest for a female mould,</line>
      <line>They nearly reached her heel; and in her air</line>
      <line>There was a something which bespoke command,</line>
      <line>As one who was a lady in the land…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I’ll tell you who they were, this female pair,</line>
      <line>Lest they should seem princesses in disguise;</line>
      <line>Besides, I hate all mystery, and that air</line>
      <line>Of clap-trap, which your recent poets prize!</line>
      <line>And so, in short, the girls they really were</line>
      <line>They shall appear before your curious eyes –</line>
      <line>Mistress and maid – the first was only daughter</line>
      <line>Of an old man, who lived upon the water.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fisherman he had been in his youth,</line>
      <line>And still a sort of fisherman was he;</line>
      <line> But other speculations were, in sooth,</line>
      <line>Added to his connection with the sea,</line>
      <line>Perhaps not so respectable, in truth:</line>
      <line>A little smuggling, and some piracy,</line>
      <line>Left him, at last, the sole of many masters</line>
      <line>Of an ill-gotten million of piastres.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fisher, therefore, was he – though of men,</line>
      <line>Like Peter the Apostle, – and he fished</line>
      <line>For wandering merchant-vessels, now and then,</line>
      <line>And sometimes caught as many as he wished.</line>
