      <line>The cargoes he confiscated, and gain</line>
      <line>He sought in the slave-market too, and dished</line>
      <line>Full many a morsel for that Turkish trade,</line>
      <line>By which, no doubt, a good deal may be made.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He was a Greek, and on his isle had built</line>
      <line>(One of the wild and smaller Cyclades)</line>
      <line>A very handsome house from out his guilt,</line>
      <line>And there he lived exceedingly at ease;</line>
      <line>Heaven knows what cash he got, or blood he spilt –</line>
      <line>A sad old fellow was he, if you please –</line>
      <line>But this I know, it was a spacious building,</line>
      <line>Full of barbaric carving, paint, and gilding.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had an only daughter, called Haidee,</line>
      <line>The greatest heiress of the Eastern Isles;</line>
      <line>Besides, so very beautiful was she,</line>
      <line>Her dowry was as nothing to her smiles!</line>
      <line>Still in her teens, and like a lovely tree,</line>
      <line>She grew to womanhood, and between whiles</line>
      <line>Rejected several suitors, just to learn</line>
      <line>How to accept a better in his turn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And walking out upon the beach, below</line>
      <line>The cliff, towards sunset, on that day she found,</line>
      <line>Insensible – not dead, but nearly so –</line>
      <line>Don Juan, almost famished, and half drowned;</line>
      <line>But being naked, she was shocked, you know,</line>
      <line>Yet deemed herself in common pity bound,</line>
      <line>As far as in her lay to ‘take him in’ –</line>
      <line>‘A stranger’ dying, with so white a skin!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But taking him into her father’s house</line>
      <line>Was not exactly the best way to save,</line>
      <line>But like conveying to the cat the mouse,</line>
      <line>Or people in a trance into their grave;</line>
      <line>Because the good old man had so much nous</line>
      <line>Unlike the honest arab thieves so brave,</line>
      <line>He would have hospitably cured the stranger,</line>
      <line>And sold him instantly when out of danger.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And therefore, with her maid, she thought it best –</line>
      <line>A virgin always on her maid relies –</line>
      <line>To place him in the cave for present rest.</line>
      <line>And when, at last, he opened his black eyes</line>
      <line>Their charity increased about their guest,</line>
      <line>And their compassion grew to such a size</line>
      <line>It opened half the turnpike-gates to Heaven</line>
      <line>(St Paul says ’tis the toll which must be given).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They made a fire, but such a fire as they</line>
      <line>Upon the moment could contrive with such</line>
      <line>Materials as were cast up round the bay –</line>
      <line>Some broken planks, and oars, that to the touch</line>
      <line>Were nearly tinder, since so long they lay</line>
      <line>A mast was almost crumbled to a crutch –</line>
      <line>But, by God’s grace, here wrecks were in such plenty,</line>
      <line>That there was fuel to have furnished twenty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had a bed of furs, and a pelisse,</line>
      <line>For Haidee stripped her sables off to make</line>
      <line>His couch; and, that he might be more at ease,</line>
      <line>And warm, in case by chance he should awake,</line>
      <line>They also gave a petticoat apiece,</line>
      <line>She and her maid, and promised by daybreak</line>
      <line>To pay him a fresh visit, with a dish</line>
      <line>For breakfast, of eggs, coffee, bread, and fish.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus they left him to his lone repose:</line>
      <line>Juan slept like a top – or like the dead,</line>
      <line>Who sleep at last, perhaps (God only knows) –</line>
      <line>Just for the present, and in his lulled head</line>
      <line>Not even a vision of his former woes</line>
      <line>Throbbed in accurséd dreams, which sometimes spread</line>
      <line>Unwelcome visions of our former years,</line>
      <line>Till the eye, cheated, opens thick with tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Young Juan slept all dreamless – but the maid</line>
      <line>Who smoothed his pillow, as she left the den</line>
      <line>Looked back upon him, and a moment stayed,</line>
      <line>And turned, believing that he called again.</line>
      <line>He slumbered; yet she thought, at least she said</line>
      <line>(The heart will slip even as the tongue and pen),</line>
      <line>He had pronounced her name-but she forgot</line>
      <line>That at this moment Juan knew it not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And pensive to her father’s house she went,</line>
      <line>Enjoining silence strict to Zoë, who</line>
      <line>Better than her knew what in fact she meant,</line>
      <line>She being wiser by a year or two –</line>
      <line>A year or two’s an age when rightly spent,</line>
      <line>And Zoë spent hers, as most women do,</line>
      <line>In gaining all that useful sort of knowledge</line>
      <line>Which is acquired in Nature’s good old college.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The morn broke, and found Juan slumbering still</line>
      <line>Fast in his cave, and nothing clashed upon</line>
      <line>His rest; the rushing of the neighbouring rill,</line>
      <line>And the young beams of the excluded sun,</line>
      <line>Troubled him not, and he might sleep his fill;</line>
      <line>And need he had of slumber yet, for none</line>
      <line>Had suffered more – his hardships were comparative</line>
      <line>To those related in my grand-dad’s Narrative.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not so Haidee; she sadly tossed and tumbled,</line>
      <line>And started from her sleep, and, turning o’er,</line>
      <line>Dreamed of a thousand wrecks, o’er which she stumbled,</line>
      <line>And handsome corpses strewed upon the shore;</line>
      <line>And woke her maid so early that she grumbled,</line>
      <line>And called her father’s old slaves up, who swore</line>
      <line>In several oaths – Armenian, Turk, and Greek –</line>
      <line>They knew not what to think of such a freak.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But up she got, and up she made them get,</line>
      <line>With some pretence about the sun, that makes</line>
      <line>Sweet skies just when he rises, or is set –</line>
      <line>And ’tis, no doubt, a sight to see, when breaks</line>
      <line>Bright Phoebus, while the mountains still are wet</line>
      <line>With mist and every bird with him awakes,</line>
      <line>And night is flung off like a mourning-suit</line>
      <line>Worn for a husband, or some other brute.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I say, the sun is a most glorious sight,</line>
      <line>I’ve seen him rise full oft, indeed of late</line>
      <line> I have sat up on purpose all the night,</line>
      <line>Which hastens, as physicians say, one’s fate –</line>
      <line>And so all ye, who would be in the right</line>
      <line>In health and purse, begin your day to date</line>
      <line>From daybreak, and when coffined at fourscore,</line>
      <line>Engrave upon the plate, you rose at four.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Haidee met the morning face to face!</line>
      <line>Her own was freshest, though a feverish flush</line>
      <line>Had dyed it with the headlong blood, whose race</line>
      <line>From heart to cheek is curbed into a blush,</line>
      <line> Like to a torrent which a mountain’s base,</line>
      <line>That overpowers some alpine river’s rush,</line>
      <line>Checks to a lake, whose waves in circles spread –</line>
      <line>Or the Red Sea (but the sea is not red).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And down the cliff the island virgin came,</line>
      <line>And near the cave her quick light footsteps drew,</line>
      <line>While the sun smiled on her with his first flame,</line>
      <line>And young Aurora kissed her lips with dew,</line>
      <line>Taking her for a sister – just the same</line>
      <line>Mistake you would have made on seeing the two,</line>
      <line> Although the mortal, quite as fresh and fair,</line>
      <line>Had all the advantage too of not being air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when into the cavern Haidee stepped</line>
      <line>All timidly, yet rapidly, she saw</line>
      <line>That like an infant Juan sweetly slept;</line>
      <line>And then she stopped, and stood as if in awe</line>
      <line>(For sleep is awful) and on tiptoe crept</line>
      <line>And wrapped him closer, lest the air, too raw,</line>
      <line>Should reach his blood – then o’er him still as death</line>
      <line>Bent, with hushed lips, that drank his scarce-drawn breath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And thus like to an angel o’er the dying</line>
      <line>Who die in righteousness, she leaned; and there</line>
      <line>All tranquilly the shipwrecked boy was lying,</line>
      <line>As o’er him lay the calm and stirless air;</line>
      <line>But Zoë the meantime some eggs was frying,</line>
      <line>Since, after all, no doubt the youthful pair</line>
      <line>Must breakfast, and betimes-lest they should ask it,</line>
      <line>She drew out her provision from the basket.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She knew that the best feelings must have victual,</line>
      <line>And that a shipwrecked youth would hungry be;</line>
      <line> Besides, being less in love, she yawned a little,</line>
      <line>And felt her veins chilled by the neighbouring sea;</line>
      <line>And so, she cooked their breakfast to a tittle;</line>
      <line>I can’t say that she gave them any tea,</line>
      <line>But there were eggs, fruit, coffee, bread, fish, honey,</line>
      <line>With Scio wine – and all for love, not money!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Zoë, when the eggs were ready, and</line>
      <line>The coffee made, would fain have wakened Juan;</line>
      <line>But Haidee stopped her with her quick small hand,</line>
      <line>And without word, a sign her finger drew on</line>
      <line> Her lip, which Zoë needs must understand,</line>
      <line>And, the first breakfast spoilt, prepared a new one,</line>
      <line>Because her mistress would not let her break</line>
      <line>That sleep which seemed as it would ne’er awake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For still he lay, and on his thin worn cheek</line>
      <line>A purple hectic played like dying day</line>
      <line>On the snow-tops of distant hills; the streak</line>
      <line>Of sufferance yet upon his forehead lay,</line>
      <line>Where the blue veins looked shadowy, shrunk and weak;</line>
      <line>And his black curls were dewy with the spray</line>
      <line> Which weighed upon them yet, all damp and salt,</line>
      <line>Mixed with the stony vapours of the vault.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And she bent o’er him, and he lay beneath</line>
      <line>Hushed as the babe upon its mother’s breast,</line>
      <line>Drooped as the willow when no winds can breathe,</line>
      <line>Lulled like the depth of ocean when at rest,</line>
      <line>Fair as the crowning rose of the whole wreath,</line>
      <line>Soft as the callow cygnet in its nest –</line>
      <line>In short, he was a very pretty fellow,</line>
      <line>Although his woes had turned him rather yellow!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He woke and gazed, and would have slept again,</line>
      <line>But the fair face which met his eyes forbade</line>
      <line>Those eyes to close (though weariness and pain</line>
      <line>Had further sleep a further pleasure made),</line>
      <line>For woman’s face was never formed in vain</line>
      <line>For Juan, so that even when he prayed</line>
      <line>He turned from grisly saints, and martyrs hairy,</line>
      <line>To the sweet portraits of the Virgin Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus upon his elbow he arose</line>
      <line>And looked upon the lady, in whose cheek</line>
      <line> The pale contended with the purple rose,</line>
      <line>As with an effort she began to speak –</line>
      <line>Her eyes were eloquent, her words would pose,</line>
      <line>Although she told him, in good modern Greek,</line>
      <line>With an Ionian accent, low and sweet,</line>
      <line>That he was faint, and must not talk, but eat…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And every day by daybreak – rather early</line>
      <line>For Juan, who was somewhat fond of rest –</line>
      <line>She came into the cave, but it was merely</line>
      <line>To see her bird reposing in his nest;</line>
      <line>And she would softly stir his locks so curly,</line>
      <line>Without disturbing her yet slumbering guest,</line>
      <line>Breathing all gently o’er his cheek and mouth,</line>
      <line>As o’er a bed of roses the sweet south.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And every morn his colour freshlier came,</line>
      <line>And every day helped on his convalescence.</line>
      <line>’Twas well, because health in the human frame</line>
      <line>Is pleasant, besides being true love’s essence,</line>
      <line>For health and idleness to passion’s flame</line>
      <line>Are oil and gunpowder – and some good lessons</line>
      <line>Are also learnt from Ceres and from Bacchus,</line>
      <line>Without whom Venus will not long attack us.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While Venus fills the heart (without heart really</line>
      <line>Love, though good always, is not quite so good)</line>
      <line> Ceres presents a plate of vermicelli –</line>
      <line>For love must be sustained like flesh and blood –</line>
      <line>While Bacchus pours out wine, or hands a jelly:</line>
      <line>Eggs, oysters too, are amatory food;</line>
      <line>But who is their purveyor from above</line>
      <line>Heaven knows – it may be Neptune, Pan, or Jove.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When Juan woke he found some good things ready:</line>
      <line>A bath, a breakfast, and the finest eyes</line>
      <line>That ever made a youthful heart less steady –</line>
      <line>Besides her maid’s, as pretty for their size –</line>
      <line> But I have spoken of all this already</line>
      <line>(And repetition’s tiresome and unwise),</line>
      <line>Well – Juan, after bathing in the sea,</line>
      <line>Came always back to coffee and Haidee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Both were so young, and one so innocent,</line>
      <line>That bathing passed for nothing: Juan seemed</line>
      <line>To her (as ’twere) the kind of being sent,</line>
      <line>Of whom these two years she had nightly dreamed,</line>
      <line>A something to be loved, a creature meant</line>
      <line>To be her happiness, and whom she deemed</line>
      <line> To render happy. All who joy would win,</line>
      <line>Must share it – happiness was born a twin!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was such pleasure to behold him, such</line>
      <line>Enlargement of existence to partake</line>
      <line>Nature with him, to thrill beneath his touch,</line>
      <line>To watch him slumbering, and to see him wake.</line>
      <line>To live with him for ever were too much;</line>
      <line>But then the thought of parting made her quake!</line>
      <line>He was her own, her ocean-treasure, cast</line>
      <line>Like a rich wreck – her first love, and her last.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And thus a moon rolled on, and fair Haidee</line>
      <line>Paid daily visits to her boy, and took</line>
      <line>Such plentiful precautions, that still he</line>
      <line>Remained unknown within his craggy nook;</line>
      <line>At last her father’s prows put out to sea,</line>
      <line>For certain merchantmen upon the look,</line>
      <line>Not as of yore to carry off an Io,</line>
      <line>But three Ragusan vessels, bound for Scio.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then came her freedom, for she had no mother,</line>
      <line>So that, her father being at sea, she was</line>
      <line> Free as a married woman, or such other</line>
      <line>Female, as where she likes may freely pass,</line>
      <line>Without even the incumbrance of a brother –</line>
      <line>The freest she that ever gazed on glass</line>
      <line>(I speak of Christian lands in this comparison,</line>
      <line>Where wives, at least, are seldom kept in garrison.)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now she prolonged her visits and her talk</line>
      <line>(For they must talk), and he had learnt to say</line>
      <line>So much as to propose to take a walk –</line>
      <line>For little had he wandered since the day</line>
      <line>On which, like a young flower snapped from the stalk,</line>
      <line>Drooping and dewy on the beach he lay –</line>
      <line>And thus they walked out in the afternoon,</line>
      <line>And saw the sun set opposite the moon…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They looked up to the sky, whose floating glow</line>
      <line>Spread like a rosy ocean, vast and bright;</line>
      <line> They gazed upon the glittering sea below,</line>
      <line>Whence the broad moon rose circling into sight;</line>
      <line>They heard the wave’s splash, and the wind so low,</line>
      <line>And saw each other’s dark eyes darting light</line>
      <line>Into each other, and, beholding this,</line>
      <line>Their lips drew near, and clung into a kiss –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A long, long kiss, a kiss of youth and love</line>
      <line>And beauty, all concentrating like rays</line>
      <line>Into one focus, kindled from above –</line>
      <line>Such kisses as belong to early days,</line>
      <line> Where heart, and soul, and sense, in concert move,</line>
      <line>And the blood’s lava, and the pulse a blaze,</line>
      <line>Each kiss a heart-quake (for a kiss’s strength,</line>
      <line>I think, it must be reckoned by its length).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By length I mean duration; theirs endured</line>
      <line>Heaven knows how long – no doubt they never reckoned;</line>
      <line>And if they had, they could not have secured</line>
      <line>The sum of their sensations to a second.</line>
      <line>They had not spoken; but they felt allured,</line>
      <line>As if their souls and lips each other beckoned,</line>
      <line> Which, being joined, like swarming bees they clung –</line>
      <line>Their hearts the flowers from whence the honey sprung.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They were alone, but not alone as they</line>
      <line>Who shut in chambers think it loneliness:</line>
      <line>The silent ocean, and the starlight bay,</line>
      <line>The twilight glow, which momently grew less,</line>
      <line>The voiceless sands, and dropping caves, that lay</line>
      <line>Around them, made them to each other press,</line>
      <line>As if there were no life beneath the sky</line>
      <line>Save theirs, and that their life could never die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They feared no eyes nor ears on that lone beach,</line>
      <line>They felt no terrors from the night, they were</line>
      <line>All in all to each other: though their speech</line>
      <line>Was broken words, they thought a language there –</line>
      <line>And all the burning tongues the passions teach</line>
      <line>Found in one sigh the best interpreter</line>
      <line>Of Nature’s oracle – first love – that all</line>
      <line>Which Eve has left her daughters since her fall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Haidee spoke not of scruples, asked no vows,</line>
      <line>Nor offered any; she had never heard</line>
      <line> Of plight and promises to be a spouse,</line>
      <line>Or perils by a loving maid incurred;</line>
      <line>She was all which pure ignorance allows,</line>
      <line>And flew to her young mate like a young bird –</line>
      <line>And, never having dreamt of falsehood, she</line>
      <line>Had not one word to say of constancy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She loved, and was beloved – she adored,</line>
      <line>And she was worshipped; after Nature’s fashion</line>
      <line>Their intense souls, into each other poured,</line>
      <line>If souls could die, had perished in that passion;</line>
      <line> But by degrees their senses were restored,</line>
      <line>Again to be o’ercome, again to dash on –</line>
      <line>And, beating ’gainst his bosom, Haidee’s heart</line>
      <line>Felt as if never more to beat apart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas! they were so young, so beautiful,</line>
      <line>So lonely, loving, helpless, and the hour</line>
      <line>Was that in which the heart is always full,</line>
      <line>And, having o’er itself no further power,</line>
      <line>Prompts deeds eternity can not annul,</line>
      <line>But pays off moments in an endless shower</line>
      <line> Of hell-fire – all prepared for people giving</line>
      <line>Pleasure or pain to one another living.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas! for Juan and Haidee! they were</line>
      <line>So loving and so lovely – till then never,</line>
      <line>Excepting our first parents, such a pair</line>
      <line>Had run the risk of being damned for ever;</line>
      <line>And Haidee, being devout as well as fair,</line>
      <line>Had, doubtless heard about the Stygian river,</line>
      <line>And Hell and Purgatory – but forgot</line>
      <line>Just in the very crisis she should not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> They look upon each other, and their eyes</line>
      <line>Gleam in the moonlight; and her white arm clasps</line>
      <line>Round Juan’s head, and his around hers lies</line>
      <line>Half buried in the tresses which it grasps;</line>
      <line>She sits upon his knee, and drinks his sighs,</line>
      <line>He hers, until they end in broken gasps;</line>
      <line>And thus they form a group that’s quite antique,</line>
      <line>Half naked, loving, natural, and Greek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when those deep and burning moments passed,</line>
      <line>And Juan sunk to sleep within her arms,</line>
      <line> She slept not, but all tenderly, though fast,</line>
      <line>Sustained his head upon her bosom’s charms;</line>
      <line>And now and then her eye to heaven is cast,</line>
      <line>And then on the pale cheek her breast now warms,</line>
      <line>Pillowed on her o’erflowing heart, which pants</line>
      <line>With all it granted, and with all it grants…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Haidee and Juan were not married, but</line>
      <line>The fault was theirs, not mine. It is not fair,</line>
      <line>Chaste reader, then, in any way to put</line>
      <line>The blame on me, unless you wish they were –</line>
      <line>Then, if you’d have them wedded, please to shut</line>
      <line>The book which treats of this erroneous pair,</line>
      <line> Before the consequences grow too awful!</line>
      <line>’Tis dangerous to read of loves unlawful.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet they were happy, happy in the illicit</line>
      <line>Indulgence of their innocent desires;</line>
      <line>But more imprudent grown with every visit,</line>
      <line>Haidee forgot the island was her sire’s</line>
      <line>(When we have what we like, ’tis hard to miss it,</line>
      <line>At least in the beginning, ere one tires),</line>
      <line>Thus she came often, not a moment losing,</line>
      <line>Whilst her piratical papa was cruising…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now pillowed cheek to cheek, in loving sleep,</line>
      <line>Haidee and Juan their siesta took,</line>
      <line>A gentle slumber, but it was not deep,</line>
      <line>For ever and anon a something shook</line>
      <line>Juan, and shuddering o’er his frame would creep;</line>
      <line>And Haidee’s sweet lips murmured like a brook</line>
      <line>A wordless music, and her face so fair</line>
      <line>Stirred with her dream as rose-leaves with the air;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or as the stirring of a deep clear stream</line>
      <line>Within an Alpine hollow, when the wind</line>
      <line> Walks o’er it, was she shaken by the dream,</line>
      <line>The mystical usurper of the mind –</line>
      <line>O’erpowering us to be whate’er may seem</line>
      <line>Good to the soul which we no more can bind.</line>
      <line>Strange state of being (for ’tis still to be),</line>
      <line>Senseless to feel, and with sealed eyes to see!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She dreamed of being alone on the sea-shore,</line>
      <line>Chained to a rock; she knew not how, but stir</line>
      <line>She could not from the spot, and the loud roar</line>
      <line>Grew, and each wave rose roughly, threatening her;</line>
      <line> And o’er her upper lip they seemed to pour</line>
      <line>Until she sobbed for breath, and soon they were</line>
      <line>Foaming o’er her lone head, so fierce and high</line>
      <line>Each broke to drown her, yet she could not die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Anon she was released, and then she strayed</line>
      <line>O’er the sharp shingles with her bleeding feet,</line>
      <line>And stumbled almost every step she made;</line>
      <line>And something rolled before her in a sheet,</line>
      <line>Which she must still pursue howe’er afraid –</line>
      <line>’Twas white and indistinct, nor stopped to meet</line>
      <line> Her glance nor grasp, for still she gazed and grasped</line>
      <line>And ran, but it escaped her as she clasped.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dream changed: in a cave she stood, its walls</line>
      <line>Were hung with marble icicles (the work</line>
      <line>Of ages on its water-fretted halls,</line>
      <line>Where waves might wash, and seals might breed and lurk),</line>
      <line>Her hair was dripping, and the very balls</line>
      <line>Of her black eyes seemed turned to tears, and murk</line>
      <line>The sharp rocks looked below each drop they caught,</line>
      <line>Which froze to marble as it fell, she thought.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And wet, and cold, and lifeless at her feet,</line>
      <line>Pale as the foam that frothed on his dead brow,</line>
      <line>Which she essayed in vain to clear (how sweet</line>
      <line>Were once her cares, how idle seemed they now!)</line>
      <line>Lay Juan, nor could aught renew the beat</line>
      <line>Of his quenched heart; and the sea dirges low</line>
      <line>Rang in her sad ears like a mermaid’s song –</line>
      <line>And that brief dream appeared a life too long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And gazing on the dead, she thought his face</line>
      <line>Faded, or altered into something new,</line>
      <line> Like to her father’s features, till each trace</line>
      <line>More like and like to Lambro’s aspect grew,</line>
      <line>With all his keen worn look and Grecian grace –</line>
      <line>And starting, she awoke. And what to view?</line>
      <line>Oh, Powers of Heaven! what dark eye meets she there?</line>
      <line>’Tis – ’tis her father’s – fixed upon the pair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then shrieking she arose, and shrieking fell,</line>
      <line>With joy and sorrow, hope and fear, to see</line>
      <line>Him whom she deemed a habitant where dwell</line>
      <line>The ocean-buried, risen from death, to be</line>
      <line> Perchance the death of one she loved too well:</line>
      <line>Dear as her father had been to Haidee,</line>
      <line>It was a moment of that awful kind –</line>
      <line>I have seen such, but must not call to mind!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up Juan sprung to Haidee’s bitter shriek,</line>
      <line>And caught her falling, and from off the wall</line>
      <line>Snatched down his sabre, in hot haste to wreak</line>
      <line>Vengeance on him who was the cause of all:</line>
      <line>Then Lambro, who till now forbore to speak,</line>
      <line>Smiled scornfully, and said, ‘Within my call,</line>
      <line> A thousand scimitars await the word –</line>
      <line>Put up, young man, put up your silly sword!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Haidee clung around him: ‘Juan, ’tis –</line>
      <line>’Tis Lambro – ’tis my father! Kneel with me –</line>
      <line>He will forgive us – yes – it must be – yes!</line>
      <line>Oh dearest father! in this agony</line>
      <line>Of pleasure and of pain – even while I kiss</line>
      <line>Thy garment’s hem with transport, can it be</line>
      <line>That doubt should mingle with my filial joy?</line>
      <line>Deal with me as thou wilt, but spare this boy!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>High and inscrutable the old man stood,</line>
      <line>Calm in his voice, and calm within his eye</line>
      <line>(Not always signs with him of calmest mood);</line>
      <line>He looked upon her, but gave no reply,</line>
      <line>Then turned to Juan, in whose cheek the blood</line>
      <line>Oft came and went, as there resolved to die –</line>
      <line>In arms at least he stood, in act to spring</line>
      <line>On the first foe whom Lambro’s call might bring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Young man, your sword!’ so Lambro once more said:</line>
      <line>Juan replied, ‘Not while this arm is free!’</line>
      <line> The old man’s cheek grew pale, but not with dread,</line>
      <line>And drawing from his belt a pistol, he</line>
      <line>Replied, ‘Your blood be then on your own head!’</line>
      <line>Then looked close at the flint, as if to see</line>
      <line>’Twas fresh (for he had lately used the lock),</line>
      <line>And next proceeded quietly to cock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It has a strange quick jar upon the ear,</line>
      <line>That cocking of a pistol, when you know</line>
      <line>A moment more will bring the sight to bear</line>
      <line>Upon your person, twelve yards off, or so</line>
      <line> (A gentlemanly distance, not too near,</line>
      <line>If you have got a former friend for foe),</line>
      <line>But after being fired at once or twice,</line>
      <line>The ear becomes more Irish, and less nice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lambro presented, and one instant more</line>
      <line>Had stopped this Canto, and Don Juan’s breath,</line>
      <line>When Haidee threw herself her boy before;</line>
      <line>Stern as her sire, ‘On me’, she cried, ‘let death</line>
      <line>Descend! The fault is mine. This fatal shore</line>
      <line>He found – but sought not. I have pledged my faith;</line>
      <line> I love him – I will die with him. I knew</line>
      <line>Your nature’s firmness – know your daughter’s too!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A minute past, and she had been all tears,</line>
      <line>And tenderness, and infancy; but now</line>
      <line>She stood as one who championed human fears –</line>
      <line>Pale, statue-like, and stern, she wooed the blow;</line>
      <line>And tall beyond her sex, and their compeers,</line>
      <line>She drew up to her height, as if to show</line>
      <line>A fairer mark, and with a fixed eye scanned</line>
      <line>Her father’s face – but never stopped his hand!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He gazed on her, and she on him – ’twas strange</line>
      <line>How like they looked! The expression was the same:</line>
      <line>Serenely savage, with a little change</line>
      <line>In the large dark eye’s mutual-darted flame;</line>
      <line>For she too was as one who could avenge,</line>
      <line>If cause should be – a lioness, though tame!</line>
      <line>Her father’s blood before her father’s face</line>
      <line>Boiled up, and proved her truly of his race.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said they were alike, their features and</line>
      <line>Their stature differing but in sex and years;</line>
      <line> Even to the delicacy of their hand</line>
      <line>There was resemblance, such as true blood wears;</line>
      <line>And now to see them, thus divided, stand</line>
      <line>In fixed ferocity (when joyous tears,</line>
      <line>And sweet sensations, should have welcomed both)</line>
      <line>Shows what the passions are in their full growth!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The father paused a moment, then withdrew</line>
      <line>His weapon, and replaced it; but stood still,</line>
      <line>And looking on her, as to look her through,</line>
      <line>‘Not I’, he said, ‘have sought this stranger’s ill –</line>
      <line> Not I have made this desolation. Few</line>
      <line>Would bear such outrage, and forbear to kill –</line>
      <line>But I must do my duty. How thou hast</line>
      <line>Done thine, the present vouches for the past!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Let him disarm; or, by my father’s head,</line>
      <line>His own shall roll before you like a ball!’</line>
      <line>He raised his whistle, as the word he said,</line>
      <line>And blew; another answered to the call,</line>
      <line>And, rushing in, disorderly, though led</line>
      <line>(And armed from boot to turban, one and all),</line>
      <line> Some twenty of his train came, rank on rank.</line>
      <line>He gave the word, ‘Arrest or slay the Frank!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, with a sudden movement, he withdrew</line>
      <line>His daughter; while compressed within his clasp,</line>
      <line>’Twixt her and Juan interposed the crew –</line>
      <line>In vain she struggled in her father’s grasp,</line>
      <line>His arms were like a serpent’s coil! Then flew</line>
      <line>Upon their prey, as darts an angry asp,</line>
      <line>The file of pirates – save the foremost, who</line>
      <line>Had fallen, with his right shoulder half cut through.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The second had his cheek laid open; but</line>
      <line>The third (a wary, cool old sworder) took</line>
      <line>The blows upon his cutlass, and then put</line>
      <line>His own well in – so well, ere you could look,</line>
      <line>His man was floored, and helpless at his foot,</line>
      <line>With the blood running like a little brook</line>
      <line>From two smart sabre gashes, deep and red,</line>
      <line>One on the arm, the other on the head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then they bound him where he fell, and bore</line>
      <line>Juan from the apartment: with a sign</line>
      <line> Old Lambro bade them take him to the shore,</line>
      <line>Where lay some ships which were to sail at nine.</line>
      <line>They laid him in a boat, and plied the oar</line>
      <line>Until they reached some galliots, placed in line;</line>
      <line>On board of one of these, and under hatches,</line>
      <line>They stowed him, with strict orders to the watches.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world is full of strange vicissitudes,</line>
      <line>And here was one exceedingly unpleasant:</line>
      <line>A gentleman, so rich in the world’s goods,</line>
      <line>Handsome and young, enjoying all the present,</line>
      <line>Just at the very time when he least broods</line>
      <line>On such a thing, is suddenly to sea sent,</line>
      <line>Wounded and chained, so that he cannot move –</line>
      <line>And all because a lady fell in love!…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The last sight which she saw was Juan’s gore,</line>
      <line>And he himself o’ermastered and cut down</line>
      <line>(His blood was running on the very floor</line>
      <line>Where late he trod, her beautiful, her own) –</line>
      <line>Thus much she viewed an instant and no more –</line>
      <line>Her struggles ceased with one convulsive groan.</line>
      <line>On her sire’s arm, which until now scarce held</line>
      <line>Her writhing, fell she like a cedar felled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A vein had burst, and her sweet lips’ pure dyes</line>
      <line>Were dabbled with the deep blood which ran o’er;</line>
      <line>And her head drooped as when the lily lies</line>
      <line>O’ercharged with rain. Her summoned handmaids bore</line>
      <line>Their lady to her couch with gushing eyes;</line>
      <line>Of herbs and cordials they produced their store,</line>
      <line>But she defied all means they could employ,</line>
      <line>Like one life could not hold, nor death destroy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Days lay she in that state unchanged (though chill,</line>
      <line>With nothing livid – still her lips were red);</line>
      <line> She had no pulse, but death seemed absent still.</line>
      <line>No hideous sign proclaimed her surely dead –</line>
      <line>Corruption came not, in each mind to kill</line>
      <line>All hope – to look upon her sweet face bred</line>
      <line>New thoughts of life, for it seemed full of soul:</line>
      <line>She had so much, earth could not claim the whole…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Twelve days and nights she withered thus. At last,</line>
      <line>Without a groan, or sigh, or glance, to show</line>
      <line>A parting pang, the spirit from her past;</line>
      <line>And they who watched her nearest could not know</line>
      <line>The very instant, till the change that cast</line>
      <line>Her sweet face into shadow, dull and slow,</line>
      <line>Glazed o’er her eyes – the beautiful, the black –</line>
      <line>Oh, to possess such lustre – and then lack!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She died, but not alone: she held within</line>
      <line>A second principle of life, which might</line>
      <line> Have dawned a fair and sinless child of sin,</line>
      <line>But closed its little being without light,</line>
      <line>And went down to the grave unborn, wherein</line>
      <line>Blossom and bough lie withered with one blight;</line>
      <line>In vain the dews of heaven descend above</line>
      <line>The bleeding flower, and blasted fruit, of love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus lived, thus died, she. Never more on her</line>
      <line>Shall sorrow light, or shame. She was not made</line>
      <line>Through years, or moons, the inner weight to bear</line>
      <line>Which colder hearts endure till they are laid</line>
      <line> By age in earth; her days and pleasures were</line>
      <line>Brief, but delightful – such as had not stayed</line>
      <line>Long with her destiny; but she sleeps well</line>
      <line>By the sea-shore, whereon she loved to dwell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That isle is now all desolate and bare,</line>
      <line>Its dwellings down, its tenants past away.</line>
      <line>None but her own and father’s grave is there,</line>
      <line>And nothing outward tells of human clay:</line>
      <line>Ye could not know where lies a thing so fair –</line>
      <line>No stone is there to show, no tongue to say,</line>
      <line> What was – no dirge, except the hollow sea’s,</line>
      <line>Mourns o’er the Beauty of the Cyclades.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>The Indian Bride</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She has lighted her lamp, and crowned it with flowers,</line>
      <line>The sweetest that breathed of the summer hours,</line>
      <line>Red and white roses linked in a band</line>
      <line>Like a maiden’s blush, or a maiden’s hand;</line>
      <line> Jasmines – some like silver spray,</line>
      <line>Some like gold in the morning ray –</line>
      <line>Fragrant stars, and favourites they,</line>
      <line>When Indian girls on a festival-day</line>
      <line>Braid their dark tresses, and all over weaves</line>
      <line>The rosy-bower of lotus leaves –</line>
      <line>Canopy suiting the lamp-lighted bark,</line>
      <line>Love’s own flowers, and Love’s own ark.</line>
      <line>She watched the sky, the sunset grew dim;</line>
      <line>She raised to Camdeo her evening hymn.</line>
      <line> The scent of the night-flowers came on the air;</line>
      <line>And then, like a bird escaped from the snare,</line>
      <line>She flew to the river (no moon was bright,</line>
      <line>But the stars and the fire-flies gave her their light);</line>
      <line>She stood beneath the mangos’ shade,</line>
      <line>Half delighted and half afraid;</line>
      <line>She trimmed her lamp, and breathed on each bloom</line>
      <line>(Oh, that breath was sweeter than all their perfume!)</line>
      <line>Threw spices and oil on the spire of flame,</line>
      <line>Called thrice on her absent lover’s name –</line>
      <line> And every pulse throbbed as she gave</line>
      <line>Her little boat to the Ganges’ wave…</line>
      <line>Zaide watched her flower-built vessel glide,</line>
      <line>Mirrored beneath on the deep-blue tide;</line>
      <line> Lovely and lonely, scented and bright,</line>
      <line>Like Hope’s own bark, all bloom and light.</line>
      <line>There’s not one breath of wind on the air,</line>
      <line>The heavens are cloudless, the waters are fair,</line>
      <line>No dew is falling, yet woe to that shade –</line>
      <line>The maiden is weeping, her lamp has decayed!</line>
      <line>Hark to the ring of the scimitar –</line>
      <line>It tells that the soldier returns from afar.</line>
      <line>Down from the mountains the warriors come:</line>
      <line>Hark to the thunder-roll of the drum!</line>
      <line> To the startling voice of the trumpet’s call!</line>
      <line>To the cymbal’s clash – to the atabal!</line>
      <line>The banners of crimson float in the sun;</line>
      <line>The warfare is ended, the battle is won.</line>
      <line>The mother hath taken the child from her breast</line>
      <line>And raised it to look on its father’s crest.</line>
      <line>The pathway is lined, as the bands pass along,</line>
      <line>With maidens, who meet them with flowers and song.</line>
      <line>And Zaide hath forgotten in Azim’s arms</line>
      <line>All her so false lamp’s falser alarms.</line>
      <line> This looks not a bridal – the singers are mute,</line>
      <line>Still is the mandore, and breathless the lute;</line>
      <line>Yet there the bride sits. Her dark hair is bound,</line>
      <line>And the robe of her marriage floats white on the ground.</line>
      <line>Oh, where is her lover, the bridegroom – oh, where?</line>
      <line>Look under yon black pall – the bridegroom is there!</line>
      <line>Yet the guests are all bidden, the feast is the same,</line>
      <line>The bride plights her troth amid smoke and mid flame!</line>
      <line>They have raised the death-pyre of sweet scented wood,</line>
      <line>And sprinkled it o’er with the sacred flood</line>
      <line> Of the Ganges. The priests are assembled – their song</line>
      <line>Sinks deep on the ear as they bear her along,</line>
      <line>The bride of the dead. Aye, is this not love –</line>
      <line>That one pure, wild feeling all others above,</line>
      <line>Vowed to the living, and kept to the tomb –</line>
      <line>The same in its blight as it was in its bloom!</line>
      <line>With no tear in her eye, and no change in her smile,</line>
      <line>Young Zaide had come nigh to the funeral pile.</line>
      <line>The bells of the dancing ceased from their sound;</line>
      <line>Silent they stood by that holiest mound.</line>
      <line> From a crowd like the sea-waves there came not a breath,</line>
      <line>When the maiden stood by the place of death!</line>
      <line>One moment was given, the last she might spare,</line>
      <line>To the mother who stood in her weeping there.</line>
      <line>She took the jewels that shone on her hand;</line>
      <line>She took from her dark hair its flowery band,</line>
      <line>And scattered them round. At once they raise</line>
      <line>The hymn of rejoicing and love in her praise.</line>
      <line>A prayer is muttered, a blessing said,</line>
      <line>Her torch is raised – she is by the dead.</line>
      <line> She has fired the pile! At once there came</line>
      <line>A mingled rush of smoke and flame,</line>
      <line>Though the wind swept it off. They saw the bride –</line>
      <line>Laid by her Azim, side by side.</line>
      <line>The breeze had spread the long curls of her hair:</line>
      <line>Like a banner of fire they played on the air.</line>
      <line>The smoke and the flame gathered round as before,</line>
      <line>Then cleared – but the bride was seen no more!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>Arabella Stuart</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas but a dream! – I saw the stag leap free</line>
      <line>Under the boughs where early birds were singing,</line>
      <line>I stood o’ershadowed by the greenwood-tree,</line>
      <line>And heard, it seemed, a sudden bugle ringing</line>
      <line> Far through a royal forest: then the fawn</line>
      <line>Shot, like a gleam of light, from grassy lawn</line>
      <line>To secret covert; and the smooth turf shook</line>
      <line>And lilies quivered by the glade’s lone brook,</line>
      <line>And young leaves trembled, as, in fleet career,</line>
      <line>A princely band, with horn, and hound, and spear,</line>
      <line>Like a rich masque swept forth. I saw the dance</line>
      <line>Of their white plumes, that bore a silvery glance</line>
      <line>Into the deep wood’s heart; and all passed by,</line>
      <line>Save one – I met the smile of one clear eye,</line>
      <line> Flashing out joy to mine. Yes, thou wert there.</line>
      <line>Seymour, a soft wind blew the clustering hair</line>
      <line>Back from thy gallant brow, as thou didst rein</line>
      <line>Thy courser, turning from that gorgeous train,</line>
      <line>And fling, methought, thy hunting-spear away,</line>
      <line>And, lightly graceful in thy green array,</line>
      <line>Bound to my side; and we, that met and parted,</line>
      <line>Ever in dread of some dark watchful power,</line>
      <line>Won back to childhood’s trust, and fearless-hearted,</line>
      <line>Blent the glad fullness of our thoughts that hour,</line>
      <line> Even like the mingling of sweet streams, beneath</line>
      <line>Dim woven leaves, and midst the floating breath</line>
      <line>Of hidden forest-flowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis past! – I wake,</line>
      <line>A captive, and alone, and far from thee,</line>
      <line>My love and friend – yet fostering for thy sake</line>
      <line>A quenchless hope of happiness to be,</line>
      <line>And feeling still my woman-spirit strong,</line>
      <line>In the deep faith which lifts from earthly wrong</line>
      <line>A Heavenward glance. I know, I know our love</line>
      <line>Shall yet call gentle angels from above,</line>
      <line> By its undying fervour, and prevail –</line>
      <line>Sending a breath, as of the spring’s first gale,</line>
      <line>Through hearts now cold; and, raising its bright face</line>
      <line>With a free gush of sunny tears, erase</line>
      <line>The characters of anguish. In this trust</line>
      <line>I bear, I strive, I bow not to the dust,</line>
      <line>That I may bring thee back no faded form,</line>
      <line>No bosom chilled and blighted by the storm,</line>
      <line>But all my youth’s first treasures, when we meet,</line>
      <line>Making past sorrow, by communion, sweet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thou too art in bonds! – yet droop thou not,</line>
      <line>Oh my beloved – there is one hopeless lot,</line>
      <line>But one, and that not ours. Beside the dead</line>
      <line>There sits the grief that mantles up its head,</line>
      <line>Loathing the laughter and proud pomp of light,</line>
      <line>When darkness, from the vainly doting sight</line>
      <line>Covers its beautiful! If thou wert gone</line>
      <line>To the grave’s bosom, with thy radiant brow;</line>
      <line>If thy deep-thrilling voice, with that low tone</line>
      <line>Of earnest tenderness, which now, even now</line>
      <line>Seems floating through my soul, were music taken</line>
      <line>For ever from this world – oh! thus forsaken,</line>
      <line>Could I bear on? Thou livest, thou livest, thou’rt mine!</line>
      <line>With this glad thought I make my heart a shrine,</line>
      <line>And by the lamp which quenchless there shall burn,</line>
      <line>Sit a lone watcher for the day’s return.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lo, the joy that cometh with the morning,</line>
      <line>Brightly victorious o’er the hours of care!</line>
      <line>I have not watched in vain, serenely scorning</line>
      <line>The wild and busy whispers of despair!</line>
      <line>Thou hast sent tidings, as of Heaven – I wait</line>
      <line>The hour, the sign, for blesséd flight to thee.</line>
      <line>Oh for the skylark’s wing that seeks its mate</line>
      <line>As a star shoots! – but on the breezy sea</line>
      <line>We shall meet soon. To think of such an hour!</line>
      <line>Will not my heart, o’erburdened by its bliss,</line>
      <line>Faint and give way within me, as a flower</line>
      <line>Borne down and perishing by noontide’s kiss?</line>
      <line>Yet shall I fear that lot – the perfect rest,</line>
      <line>The full deep joy of dying on thy breast,</line>
      <line> After long suffering won? So rich a close</line>
      <line>Too seldom crowns with peace affection’s woes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sunset! – I tell each moment – from the skies</line>
      <line>The last red splendour floats along my wall,</line>
      <line>Like a king’s banner! Now it melts, it dies!</line>
      <line>I see one star – I hear – ’twas not the call,</line>
      <line>The expected voice; my quick heart throbbed too soon.</line>
      <line>I must keep vigil till yon rising moon</line>
      <line>Shower down less golden light. Beneath her beam</line>
      <line>Through my lone lattice poured, I sit and dream</line>
      <line> Of summer-lands afar, where holy love,</line>
      <line>Under the vine or in the citron grove,</line>
      <line>May breathe from terror.</line>
      <line>Now the night grows deep,</line>
      <line>And silent as its clouds, and full of sleep.</line>
      <line>I hear my veins beat. Hark! a bell’s slow chime!</line>
      <line>My heart strikes with it. Yet again – ’tis time!</line>
      <line>A step! – a voice! – or but a rising breeze?</line>
      <line>Hark! – haste! – I come, to meet thee on the seas.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now never more, oh! never, in the worth</line>
      <line>Of its pure cause, let sorrowing love on earth</line>
      <line> Trust fondly – never more! The hope is crushed</line>
      <line>That lit my life, the voice within me hushed</line>
      <line>That spoke sweet oracles; and I return</line>
      <line>To lay my youth, as in a burial urn,</line>
      <line>Where sunshine may not find it. All is lost!</line>
      <line>No tempest met our barks – no billow tossed –</line>
      <line>Yet were they severed, even as we must be,</line>
      <line>That so have loved, so striven our hearts to free</line>
      <line>From their close-coiling fate! In vain – in vain!</line>
      <line>The dark links meet, and clasp themselves again,</line>
      <line>And press out life. Upon the deck I stood,</line>
      <line>And a white sail came gliding o’er the flood,</line>
      <line>Like some proud bird of ocean; then mine eye</line>
      <line>Strained out, one moment earlier to descry</line>
      <line>The form it ached for, and the bark’s career</line>
      <line>Seemed slow to that fond yearning. It drew near,</line>
      <line>Fraught with our foes! What boots it to recall</line>
      <line>The strife, the tears? Once more a prison-wall</line>
      <line>Shuts the green hills and woodlands from my sight,</line>
      <line>And joyous glance of waters to the light,</line>
      <line> And thee, my Seymour, thee!</line>
      <line>I will not sink!</line>
      <line>Thou, thou hast rent the heavy chain that bound thee!</line>
      <line>And this shall be my strength – the joy to think</line>
      <line>That thou mayst wander with heaven’s breath around thee,</line>
      <line>And all the laughing sky! This thought shall yet</line>
      <line>Shine o’er my heart a radiant amulet,</line>
      <line>Guarding it from despair. Thy bonds are broken,</line>
      <line>And unto me, I know, thy true love’s token</line>
      <line>Shall one day be deliverance, though the years</line>
      <line>Lie dim between, o’erhung with mists of tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> My friend! my friend! where art thou? Day by day,</line>
      <line>Gliding like some dark mournful stream away,</line>
      <line>My silent youth flows from me. Spring, the while,</line>
      <line>Comes and rains beauty on the kindling boughs</line>
      <line>Round hall and hamlet; Summer with her smile,</line>
      <line>Fills the green forest; young hearts breathe their vows;</line>
      <line>Brothers long parted meet; fair children rise</line>
      <line>Round the glad board; Hope laughs from loving eyes –</line>
      <line>All this is in the world! These joys lie sown,</line>
      <line>The dew of every path. On one alone</line>
      <line> Their freshness may not fall – the stricken deer</line>
      <line>Dying of thirst with all the waters near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye are (from dingle and fresh glade) ye flowers</line>
      <line>By some kind hand to cheer my dungeon sent;</line>
      <line>O’er you the oak shed down the summer showers,</line>
      <line>And the lark’s nest was where your bright cups bent,</line>
      <line>Quivering to breeze and raindrop, like the sheen</line>
      <line>Of twilight stars. On you heaven’s eye hath been,</line>
      <line>Through the leaves, pouring its dark sultry blue</line>
      <line>Into your glowing hearts; the bee to you</line>
      <line> Hath murmured, and the rill. My soul grows faint</line>
      <line>With passionate yearning, as its quick dreams paint</line>
      <line>Your haunts by dell and stream – the green, the free,</line>
      <line>The full of all sweet sound – the shut from me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There went a swift bird singing past my cell –</line>
      <line>Oh love and freedom, ye are lovely things!</line>
      <line>With you the peasant on the hills may dwell,</line>
      <line>And by the streams; but I – the blood of kings,</line>
      <line>A proud unmingling river, through my veins</line>
      <line>Flows in lone brightness, and its gifts are chains!</line>
      <line> Kings! – I had silent visions of deep bliss,</line>
      <line>Leaving their thrones far distant, and for this</line>
      <line>I am cast under their triumphal car,</line>
      <line>An insect to be crushed! Oh! Heaven is far –</line>
      <line>Earth pitiless!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dost thou forget me, Seymour? I am proved</line>
      <line>So long, so sternly! Seymour, my beloved!</line>
      <line>There are such tales of holy marvels done</line>
      <line>By strong affection, of deliverance won</line>
      <line>Through its prevailing power! Are these things told</line>
      <line> Till the young weep with rapture, and the old</line>
      <line>Wonder, yet dare not doubt; and thou! oh, thou!</line>
      <line>Dost thou forget me in my hope’s decay? –</line>
      <line>Thou canst not! – through the silent night, even now,</line>
      <line>I, that need prayer so much, awake and pray</line>
      <line>Still first for thee. Oh gentle, gentle friend!</line>
      <line>How shall I bear this anguish to the end?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Aid! – comes there yet no aid? The voice of blood</line>
      <line>Passes Heaven’s gate, even ere the crimson flood</line>
      <line>Sinks through the greensward! Is there not a cry</line>
      <line> From the wrung heart, of power, through agony,</line>
      <line>To pierce the clouds? Hear, Mercy! – hear me! None</line>
      <line>That bleed and weep beneath the smiling sun</line>
      <line>Have heavier cause! – yet hear! – my soul grows dark –</line>
      <line>Who hears the last shriek from the sinking bark</line>
      <line>On the mid-seas, and with the storm alone,</line>
      <line>And bearing to the abyss, unseen, unknown,</line>
      <line>Its freight of human hearts? The o’ermastering wave –</line>
      <line>Who shall tell how it rushed – and none to save?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou hast forsaken me! I feel, I know,</line>
      <line> There would be rescue if this were not so.</line>
      <line>Thou’rt at the chase, thou’rt at the festive board,</line>
      <line>Thou’rt where the red wine free and high is poured,</line>
      <line>Thou’rt where the dancers meet! – a magic glass</line>
      <line>Is set within my soul, and proud shapes pass,</line>
      <line>Flushing it o’er with pomp from bower and hall;</line>
      <line>I see one shadow, stateliest there of all –</line>
      <line>Thine! What dost thou amidst the bright and fair,</line>
      <line>Whispering light words, and mocking my despair?</line>
      <line>It is not well of thee! My love was more</line>
      <line> Than fiery song may breathe, deep thought explore –</line>
      <line>And there thou smilest, while my heart is dying,</line>
      <line>With all its blighted hopes around it lying;</line>
      <line>Even thou, on whom they hung their last green leaf.</line>
      <line>Yet smile, smile on! Too bright art thou for grief.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Death – what? Is death a locked and treasured thing,</line>
      <line>Guarded by swords of fire – a hidden spring,</line>
      <line>A fabled fruit – that I should thus endure,</line>
      <line>As if the world within me held no cure?</line>
      <line>Wherefore not spread free wings? Heaven, Heaven control</line>
      <line>These thoughts – they rush – I look into my soul</line>
      <line>As down a gulf, and tremble at the array</line>
      <line>Of fierce forms crowding it! Give strength to pray,</line>
      <line>So shall their dark host pass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The storm is stilled.</line>
      <line>Father in Heaven! thou, only thou, canst sound</line>
      <line>The heart’s great deep, with floods of anguish filled,</line>
      <line>For human line too fearfully profound.</line>
      <line>Therefore forgive, my Father! if thy child,</line>
      <line>Rocked on its heaving darkness, hath grown wild</line>
      <line>And sinned in her despair! It well may be,</line>
      <line> That thou wouldst lead my spirit back to thee –</line>
      <line>By the crushed hope too long on this world poured,</line>
      <line>The stricken love which hath perchance adored</line>
      <line>A mortal in thy place! Now let me strive</line>
      <line>With thy strong arm no more! Forgive, forgive!</line>
      <line>Take me to peace!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And peace at last is nigh.</line>
      <line>A sign is on my brow, a token sent</line>
      <line>The o’erwearied dust from home; no breeze flits by</line>
      <line>But calls me with a strange sweet whisper, blent</line>
      <line>Of many mysteries.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hark! the warning tone</line>
      <line> Deepens – its word is Death! Alone, alone,</line>
      <line>And sad in youth, but chastened, I depart,</line>
      <line>Bowing to Heaven. Yet, yet my woman’s heart</line>
      <line>Shall wake a spirit and a power to bless,</line>
      <line>Even in this hour’s o’ershadowing fearfulness,</line>
      <line>Thee, its first love! Oh! tender still, and true –</line>
      <line>Be it forgotten if mine anguish threw</line>
      <line>Drops from its bitter fountain on thy name,</line>
      <line>Though but a moment.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, with fainting frame,</line>
      <line>With soul just lingering on the flight begun,</line>
      <line> To bind for thee its last dim thoughts in one,</line>
      <line>I bless thee! Peace be on thy noble head,</line>
      <line>Years of bright fame, when I am with the dead!</line>
      <line>I bid this prayer survive me, and retain</line>
      <line>Its might, again to bless thee, and again!</line>
      <line>Thou hast been gathered into my dark fate</line>
      <line>Too much; too long, for my sake, desolate</line>
      <line>Hath been thine exiled youth; but now take back,</line>
      <line>From dying hands, thy freedom, and retrack</line>
      <line>(After a few kind tears for her whose days</line>
      <line> Went out in dreams of thee) the sunny ways</line>
      <line>Of hope, and find thou happiness! Yet send,</line>
      <line>Even then, in silent hours, a thought, dear friend!</line>
      <line>Down to my voiceless chamber; for thy love</line>
      <line>Hath been to me all gifts of earth above,</line>
      <line>Though bought with burning tears! It is the sting</line>
      <line>Of death to leave that vainly-precious thing</line>
      <line>In this cold world! What were it then, if thou,</line>
      <line>With thy fond eyes, wert gazing on me now?</line>
      <line>Too keen a pang! Farewell! and yet once more,</line>
      <line> Farewell! – the passion of long years I pour</line>
      <line>Into that word. Thou hearest not, but the woe</line>
      <line>And fervour of its tones may one day flow</line>
      <line>To thy heart’s holy place – there let them dwell.</line>
      <line>We shall o’ersweep the grave to meet – Farewell!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>The Faithless Knight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lady she sat in her bower alone,</line>
      <line>And she gazed from the lattice-window high</line>
      <line>Where a white steed’s hoofs were ringing on,</line>
      <line>With a beating heart, and a smothered sigh.</line>
      <line> Why doth she gaze through the sunset-rays?</line>
      <line>Why doth she watch that white steed’s track,</line>
      <line>While a quivering smile on her red lip plays?</line>
      <line>’Tis her own dear knight – will he not look back?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The steed flew fast, and the rider passed –</line>
      <line>Nor paused he to gaze at the lady’s bower –</line>
      <line>The smile from her lip is gone at last!</line>
      <line>There are tears on her cheek, like the dew on a flower!</line>
      <line>And ‘Plague on these foolish tears’, she said,</line>
      <line>‘Which have dimmed the view of my young love’s track!</line>
      <line> For oh, I am sure, while I bent my head,</line>
      <line>It was then – it was then – that my knight looked back!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On flew that steed with an arrow’s speed –</line>
      <line>He is gone, and the green boughs wave between –</line>
      <line>And she sighs, as the sweet breeze sighs through a reed,</line>
      <line>As she watches the spot where he last has been.</line>
      <line>Oh, many a sun shall rise and set,</line>
      <line>And many an hour may she watch in vain,</line>
      <line>And many a tear shall that soft cheek wet,</line>
      <line>Ere that steed and its rider return again!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM COWPER</author>
    <date>1785</date>
    <title>Crazy Kate (Task)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There often wanders one, whom better days</line>
      <line> Saw better clad, in cloak of satin trimmed</line>
      <line>With lace, and hat with splendid ribband bound.</line>
      <line>A serving-maid was she, and fell in love</line>
      <line>With one who left her, went to sea and died.</line>
      <line>Her fancy followed him through foaming waves</line>
      <line>To distant shores, and she would sit and weep</line>
      <line>At what a sailor suffers; fancy too,</line>
      <line>Delusive most where warmest wishes are,</line>
      <line>Would oft anticipate his glad return,</line>
      <line>And dream of transports she was not to know.</line>
      <line> She heard the doleful tidings of his death,</line>
      <line>And never smiled again. And now she roams</line>
      <line>The dreary waste – there spends the livelong day,</line>
      <line>And there (unless when charity forbids)</line>
      <line>The livelong night. A tattered apron hides,</line>
      <line>Worn as a cloak – and hardly hides – a gown</line>
      <line>More tattered still! And both but ill conceal</line>
      <line>A bosom heaved with never-ceasing sighs.</line>
      <line>She begs an idle pin of all she meets,</line>
      <line>And hoards them in her sleeve; but needful food,</line>
      <line> Though pressed with hunger oft, or comelier clothes,</line>
      <line>Though pinched with cold, asks never – Kate is crazed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOANNA BAILLIE</author>
    <date>1790</date>
    <title>The Storm-Beat Maid: Somewhat after the Style of Our Old English Ballads</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All shrouded in the winter snow</line>
      <line>The maiden held her way;</line>
      <line>Nor chilly winds that roughly blow,</line>
      <line>Nor dark night could her stay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> O’er hill and dale, through bush and briar,</line>
      <line>She on her journey kept;</line>
      <line>Save often, when she gan to tire,</line>
      <line>She stopped awhile and wept.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wild creatures left their caverns drear,</line>
      <line>To raise their nightly yell;</line>
      <line>But little does the bosom fear</line>
      <line>Where inward troubles dwell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No watch-light from the distant spire</line>
      <line>To cheer the gloom so deep,</line>
      <line> Nor twinkling star, nor cottage fire,</line>
      <line>Did through the darkness peep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet heedless still she held her way,</line>
      <line>Nor feared she crag, nor dell,</line>
      <line>Like ghost that through the gloom to stray</line>
      <line>Wakes with the midnight bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now night through her dark watches ran,</line>
      <line>Which lock the peaceful mind,</line>
      <line>And through the neighbouring hamlets ’gan</line>
      <line>To wake the yawning hind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet bark of dog, nor village cock,</line>
      <line>That spoke the morning near,</line>
      <line>Nor gray light trembling on the rock,</line>
      <line>Her ’nighted mind could cheer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The whirling flail, and clacking mill,</line>
      <line>Wake early with the day;</line>
      <line>And careless children, loud and shrill,</line>
      <line>With new-made snowballs play,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And as she passed each cottage-door</line>
      <line>They did their gambols cease;</line>
      <line> And old men shook their locks so hoar</line>
      <line>And wished her spirit peace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For sometimes slow, and sometimes fast,</line>
      <line>She held her wavering pace,</line>
      <line>Like early spring’s inconstant blast</line>
      <line>That ruffles evening’s face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length with weary feet she came</line>
      <line>Where in a sheltering wood,</line>
      <line>Whose master bore no humble name,</line>
      <line>A stately castle stood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The open gate and smoking fires,</line>
      <line>Which cloud the air so thin,</line>
      <line>And shrill bell tinkling from the spires,</line>
      <line>Bespoke a feast within.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With busy looks, and hasty tread,</line>
      <line>The servants cross the hall,</line>
      <line>And many a page in buskins red</line>
      <line>Await the master’s call.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair streaming bows of bridal white</line>
      <line>On every shoulder played,</line>
      <line> And clean, in lily kerchief dight,</line>
      <line>Tripped every household maid.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She asked for neither lord nor dame,</line>
      <line>Nor who the mansion owned,</line>
      <line>But straight into the hall she came</line>
      <line>And sat her on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The busy crew all crowded nigh,</line>
      <line>And round the stranger stared;</line>
      <line>But still she rolled her wandering eye,</line>
      <line>Nor for their questions cared.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘What dost thou want, thou storm-beat maid,</line>
      <line>That thou these portals passed?</line>
      <line>Ill suiteth here thy looks dismayed –</line>
      <line>Thou art no bidden guest.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh chide not’, said a gentle page,</line>
      <line>And wiped his tear-wet cheek,</line>
      <line>‘Who would not shun the winter’s rage? –</line>
      <line>The wind is cold and bleak!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her robe is stiff with drizzly snow,</line>
      <line>And rent her mantle grey –</line>
      <line> None ever bade the wretched go</line>
      <line>Upon his wedding-day!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then to his lord he hied him straight,</line>
      <line>(Where round on silken seat</line>
      <line>Sat many a courteous dame and knight</line>
      <line>And made obeisance meet:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is a stranger in your hall</line>
      <line>Who wears no common mien;</line>
      <line>Hard were the heart, as flinty wall,</line>
      <line>That would not take her in.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A fairer dame in hall or bower</line>
      <line>Mine eyes did ne’er behold;</line>
      <line>Though sheltered in no father’s tower,</line>
      <line>And turned out to the cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her face is like an early morn,</line>
      <line>Dimmed with the nightly dew;</line>
      <line>Her skin is like the sheeted thorn,</line>
      <line>Her eyes are watery blue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And tall and slender is her form,</line>
      <line>Like willow o’er the brook;</line>
      <line> But on her brow there broods a storm,</line>
      <line>And restless is her look.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And well her troubled motions show</line>
      <line>The tempest of her mind,</line>
      <line>Like the unsheltered sapling-bough</line>
      <line>Vexed with the wintry wind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her head droops on her ungirt breast,</line>
      <line>And scattered is her hair;</line>
      <line>Yet lady braced in courtly vest</line>
      <line>Was never half so fair!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Reverse, and cold, the turning blood</line>
      <line>The bridegroom’s cheek forsook:</line>
      <line>He shook and staggered as he stood,</line>
      <line>And faltered as he spoke.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘So soft and fair I know a maid,</line>
      <line>There is but only she;</line>
      <line>A wretched man her love betrayed –</line>
      <line>And wretched let him be!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Deep frowning turned the bride’s dark eye,</line>
      <line>For bridal morn unmeet:</line>
      <line> With trembling steps her lord did hie</line>
      <line>The stranger fair to greet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though loose in scattered weeds arrayed,</line>
      <line>And ruffled by the storm,</line>
      <line>Like lambkin from its fellows strayed</line>
      <line>He knew her graceful form.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when he spied her sunken eye,</line>
      <line>And features sharp and wan,</line>
      <line>He heaved a deep and heavy sigh</line>
      <line>And down the big tears ran.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Why droops thy head, thou lovely maid,</line>
      <line>Upon thy hand of snow?</line>
      <line>Is it because thy love’s betrayed</line>
      <line>That thou art brought so low?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Quick from her eye the keen glance came,</line>
      <line>Who questioned her to see,</line>
      <line>And oft she muttered o’er his name –</line>
      <line>And wist not it was he.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full hard against his writhing brows</line>
      <line>His clenchéd hands he prest;</line>
      <line> Full high his labouring bosom rose,</line>
      <line>And rent its silken vest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh curséd be the golden price</line>
      <line>That did my baseness prove!</line>
      <line>And curséd be my friends’ advice,</line>
      <line>That willed me from thy love!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And curséd be the woman’s art</line>
      <line>That lured me to her snare!</line>
      <line>And curséd be the faithless heart</line>
      <line>That left thee to despair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet now I’ll hold thee to my side,</line>
      <line>Though worthless I have been:</line>
      <line>Nor friends, nor wealth, nor dizened bride,</line>
      <line>Shall ever stand between.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When thou art weary and depressed</line>
      <line>I’ll lull thee to thy sleep,</line>
      <line>And when dark fancies vex thy breast</line>
      <line>I’ll sit by thee and weep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll tend thee like a restless child</line>
      <line>Where’er thy rovings be;</line>
      <line> Nor gesture keen, nor eyeball wild,</line>
      <line>Shall turn my love from thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Night shall not hang cold o’er thy head,</line>
      <line>And I securely lie;</line>
      <line>Nor drizzly clouds upon thee shed,</line>
      <line>And I in covert dry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll share the cold blast on the heath,</line>
      <line>I’ll share thy wants and pain:</line>
      <line>Nor friend nor foe, nor life nor death,</line>
      <line>Shall ever make us twain.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Female Exile</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>November’s chill blast on the rough beach is howling,</line>
      <line>The surge breaks afar, and then foams to the shore,</line>
      <line>Dark clouds o’er the sea gather heavy and scowling,</line>
      <line>And the white cliffs re-echo the wild wintry roar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Beneath that chalk rock, a fair stranger reclining,</line>
      <line>Has found on damp sea-weed a cold lonely seat;</line>
      <line>Her eyes filled with tears, and her heart with repining,</line>
      <line>She starts at the billows that burst at her feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There, day after day, with an anxious heart heaving,</line>
      <line>She watches the waves where they mingle with air;</line>
      <line>For the sail which, alas! all her fond hopes deceiving,</line>
      <line>May bring only tidings to add to her care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Loose stream to wild winds those fair flowing tresses,</line>
      <line>Once woven with garlands of gay summer flowers;</line>
      <line> Her dress unregarded bespeaks her distresses,</line>
      <line>And beauty is blighted by grief’s heavy hours.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her innocent children, unconscious of sorrow,</line>
      <line>To seek the glossed shell, or the crimson weed stray;</line>
      <line>Amused with the present, they heed not tomorrow,</line>
      <line>Nor think of the storm that is gathering today.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The gilt, fairy ship, with its ribbon-sail spreading,</line>
      <line>They launch on the salt pool the tide left behind;</line>
      <line>Ah victims – for whom their sad mother is dreading</line>
      <line>The multiplied miseries that wait on mankind!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> To fair fortune born, she beholds them with anguish,</line>
      <line>Now wanderers with her on a once hostile soil,</line>
      <line>Perhaps doomed for life in chill penury to languish,</line>
      <line>Or abject dependence, or soul-crushing toil.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the sea-boat, her hopes and her terrors renewing,</line>
      <line>O’er the dim grey horizon now faintly appears;</line>
      <line>She flies to the quay, dreading tidings of ruin,</line>
      <line>All breathless with haste, half expiring with fears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor mourner – I would that my fortune had left me</line>
      <line>The means to alleviate the woes I deplore;</line>
      <line> But like thine my hard fate has of affluence bereft me,</line>
      <line>I can warm the cold heart of the wretched no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
