  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1793</date>
    <title>Visions of the Daughters of Albion</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loved Theotormon</line>
      <line>And I was not ashamed,</line>
      <line>I trembled in my virgin fears</line>
      <line>And I hid in Leutha’s vale –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I plucked Leutha’s flower,</line>
      <line>And I rose up from the vale;</line>
      <line>But the terrible thunders tore</line>
      <line>My virgin mantle in twain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Enslaved, the Daughters of Albion weep – a trembling lamentation</line>
      <line>Upon their mountains, in their valleys sighs toward America.</line>
      <line>For the soft soul of America, Oothoon, wandered in woe</line>
      <line>Along the vales of Leutha, seeking flowers to comfort her,</line>
      <line> And thus she spoke to the bright Marygold of Leutha’s vale:</line>
      <line>‘Art thou a flower? Art thou a nymph? I see thee now a flower,</line>
      <line>Now a nymph! I dare not pluck thee from thy dewy bed.’</line>
      <line>The golden nymph replied: ‘Pluck thou my flower, Oothoon the mild.</line>
      <line>Another flower shall spring, because the soul of sweet delight</line>
      <line>Can never pass away.’ She ceased and closed her golden shrine.</line>
      <line>Then Oothoon plucked the flower saying, ‘I pluck thee from thy bed,</line>
      <line>Sweet flower, and put thee here to glow between my breasts,</line>
      <line>And thus I turn my face to where my whole soul seeks.’</line>
      <line>Over the waves she went in winged exulting swift delight,</line>
      <line> And over Theotormon’s reign, took her impetuous course.</line>
      <line>Bromion rent her with his thunders. On his stormy bed</line>
      <line>Lay the faint maid, and soon her woes appalled his thunders hoarse.</line>
      <line>Bromion spoke: ‘Behold this harlot here on Bromion’s bed,</line>
      <line>And let the jealous dolphins sport around the lovely maid!</line>
      <line>Thy soft American plains are mine, and mine thy north and south.</line>
      <line>Stamped with my signet are the swarthy children of the sun –</line>
      <line>They are obedient, they resist not, they obey the scourge,</line>
      <line>Their daughters worship terrors and obey the violent!</line>
      <line>Now thou mayst marry Bromion’s harlot and protect the child</line>
      <line> Of Bromion’s rage that Oothoon shall put forth in nine moons time.’</line>
      <line>Then storms rent Theotormon’s limbs; he rolled his waves around</line>
      <line>And folded his black jealous waters round the adulterate pair.</line>
      <line>Bound back to back in Bromion’s caves, terror and meekness dwell;</line>
      <line>At entrance Theotormon sits, wearing the threshold hard</line>
      <line>With secret tears. Beneath him sound like waves on a desert-shore</line>
      <line>The voice of slaves beneath the sun, and children bought with money</line>
      <line>That shiver in religious caves beneath the burning fires</line>
      <line>Of lust that belch incessant, from the summits of the earth.</line>
      <line>Oothoon weeps not. She cannot weep – her tears are locked up –</line>
      <line> But she can howl incessant writhing her soft snowy limbs</line>
      <line>And calling Theotormon’s eagles to prey upon her flesh:</line>
      <line>‘I call with holy voice, kings of the sounding air!</line>
      <line>Rend away this defiled bosom that I may reflect</line>
      <line>The image of Theotormon on my pure transparent breast.’</line>
      <line>The eagles at her call descend and rend their bleeding prey;</line>
      <line>Theotormon severely smiles. Her soul reflects the smile,</line>
      <line>As the clear spring, muddied with feet of beasts, grows pure and smiles.</line>
      <line>The Daughters of Albion hear her woes, and echo back her sighs.</line>
      <line>‘Why does my Theotormon sit weeping upon the threshold</line>
      <line> And Oothoon hovers by his side, persuading him in vain?</line>
      <line>I cry “arise”, oh Theotormon, for the village dog</line>
      <line>Barks at the breaking day, the nightingale has done lamenting,</line>
      <line>The lark does rustle in the ripe corn, and the eagle returns</line>
      <line>From nightly prey and lifts his golden beak to the pure east,</line>
      <line>Shaking the dust from his immortal pinions to awake</line>
      <line>The sun that sleeps too long. Arise, my Theotormon, I am pure –</line>
      <line>Because the night is gone that closed me in its deadly black.</line>
      <line>They told me that the night and day were all that I could see,</line>
      <line>They told me that I had five senses to inclose me up,</line>
      <line> And they inclosed my infinite brain into a narrow circle</line>
      <line>And sunk my heart into the abyss, a red round globe hot burning –</line>
      <line>Till all from life I was obliterated and erased.</line>
      <line>Instead of morn arises a bright shadow like an eye</line>
      <line>In the eastern cloud, instead of night a sickly charnel-house,</line>
      <line>That Theotormon hears me not! To him the night and morn</line>
      <line>Are both alike – a night of sighs, a morning of fresh tears –</line>
      <line>And none but Bromion can hear my lamentations.</line>
      <line>With what sense is it that the chicken shuns the ravenous hawk?</line>
      <line>With what sense does the tame pigeon measure out the expanse?</line>
      <line>With what sense does the bee form cells? Have not the mouse and frog</line>
      <line>Eyes and ears and sense of touch – yet are their habitations</line>
      <line>And their pursuits as different as their forms and as their joys?</line>
      <line>Ask the wild ass why he refuses burdens, and the meek camel</line>
      <line>Why he loves man. Is it because of eye, ear, mouth, or skin,</line>
      <line>Or breathing nostrils? No, for these the wolf and tiger have.</line>
      <line>Ask the blind worm the secrets of the grave, and why her spires</line>
      <line>Love to curl round the bones of death, and ask the ravenous snake</line>
      <line>Where she gets poison, and the winged eagle why he loves the sun –</line>
      <line>And then tell me the thoughts of man, that have been hid of old.</line>
      <line> Silent I hover all the night, and all day could be silent</line>
      <line>If Theotormon once would turn his loved eyes upon me.</line>
      <line>How can I be defiled when I reflect thy image pure?</line>
      <line>Sweetest the fruit that the worm feeds on, and the soul preyed on by woe,</line>
      <line>The new-washed lamb tinged with the village smoke, and the bright swan</line>
      <line>By the red earth of our immortal river. I bathe my wings,</line>
      <line>And I am white and pure to hover round Theotormon’s breast.’</line>
      <line>Then Theotormon broke his silence, and he answered:</line>
      <line>‘Tell me what is the night or day to one o’erflowed with woe!</line>
      <line>Tell me what is a thought, and of what substance is it made!</line>
      <line> Tell me what is a joy, and in what gardens do joys grow!</line>
      <line>And in what rivers swim the sorrows, and upon what mountains</line>
      <line>Wave shadows of discontent, and in what houses dwell the wretched</line>
      <line>Drunken with woe, forgotten and shut up from cold despair?</line>
      <line>Tell me where dwell the thoughts forgotten till thou call them forth!</line>
      <line>Tell me where dwell the joys of old, and where the ancient loves,</line>
      <line>And when will they renew again, and the night of oblivion past –</line>
      <line>That I might traverse times and spaces far remote and bring</line>
      <line>Comforts into a present sorrow, and a night of pain.</line>
      <line>Where goest thou, oh thought, to what remote land is thy flight?</line>
      <line> If thou returnest to the present moment of affliction</line>
      <line>Wilt thou bring comforts on thy wings, and dews and honey and balm,</line>
      <line>Or poison from the desert wilds, from the eyes of the envier?’</line>
      <line>Then Bromion said, and shook the cavern with his lamentation:</line>
      <line>‘Thou knowest that the ancient trees seen by thine eyes have fruit,</line>
      <line>But knowest thou that trees and fruits flourish upon the earth</line>
      <line>To gratify senses unknown – trees, beasts and birds, unknown –</line>
      <line>Unknown not unperceived, spread in the infinite microscope</line>
      <line>In places yet unvisited by the voyager, and in worlds</line>
      <line>Over another kind of seas, and in atmospheres unknown?</line>
      <line>Ah, are there other wars beside the wars of sword and fire?</line>
      <line>And are there other sorrows beside the sorrows of poverty?</line>
      <line>And are there other joys beside the joys of riches and ease?</line>
      <line>And is there not one law for both the lion and the ox?</line>
      <line>And is there not eternal fire, and eternal chains,</line>
      <line>To bind the phantoms of existence from eternal life?’</line>
      <line>Then Oothoon waited silent all the day and all the night,</line>
      <line>But when the morn arose, her lamentation renewed.</line>
      <line>The Daughters of Albion hear her woes, and echo back her sighs.</line>
      <line>‘Oh Urizen, creator of men, mistaken demon of Heaven,</line>
      <line> Thy joys are tears, thy labour vain to form men to thine image!</line>
      <line>How can one joy absorb another? Are not different joys</line>
      <line>Holy, eternal, infinite? – and each joy is a love.</line>
      <line>Does not the great mouth laugh at a gift, and the narrow eyelids mock</line>
      <line>At the labour that is above payment – and wilt thou take the ape</line>
      <line>For thy councilor, or the dog for a schoolmaster to thy children?</line>
      <line>Does he who condemns poverty, and he who turns with abhorrence</line>
      <line>From usury, feel the same passion, or are they moved alike?</line>
      <line>How can the giver of gifts experience the delights of the merchant,</line>
      <line>How the industrious citizen the pains of the husbandman?</line>
      <line> How different far the fat-fed hireling with hollow drum,</line>
      <line>Who buys whole cornfields into wastes, and sings upon the heath –</line>
      <line>How different their eye and ear, how different the world to them!</line>
      <line>With what sense does the parson claim the labour of the farmer?</line>
      <line>What are his nets and gins and traps, and how does he surround him</line>
      <line>With cold floods of abstraction and with forests of solitude,</line>
      <line>To build him castles and high spires where kings and priests may dwell,</line>
      <line>Till she who burns with youth and knows no fixed lot is bound</line>
      <line>In spells of law to one she loathes? And must she drag the chain</line>
      <line>Of life in weary lust? Must chilling murderous thoughts obscure</line>
      <line> The clear heaven of her eternal spring – to bear the wintry rage</line>
      <line>Of a harsh terror, driven to madness, bound to hold a rod</line>
      <line>Over her shrinking shoulders all the day, and all the night</line>
      <line>To turn the wheel of false desire, and longings that wake her womb</line>
      <line>To the abhorréd birth of cherubs in the human form</line>
      <line>That live a pestilence, and die a meteor, and are no more –</line>
      <line>Till the child dwell with one he hates, and do the deed he loathes,</line>
      <line>And the impure scourge force his seed into its unripe birth</line>
      <line>E’er yet his eyelids can behold the arrows of the day.</line>
      <line>Does the whale worship at thy footsteps as the hungry dog,</line>
      <line> Or does he scent the mountain prey because his nostrils wide</line>
      <line>Draw in the ocean? Does his eye discern the flying cloud</line>
      <line>As the raven’s eye, or does he measure the expanse like the vulture?</line>
      <line>Does the still spider view the cliffs where eagles hide their young,</line>
      <line>Or does the fly rejoice because the harvest is brought in?</line>
      <line>Does not the eagle scorn the earth and despise the treasures beneath –</line>
      <line>But the mole knoweth what is there, and the worm shall tell it thee.</line>
      <line>Does not the worm erect a pillar in the mouldering churchyard,</line>
      <line>And a place of eternity in the jaws of the hungry grave?</line>
      <line>Over his porch these words are written: “Take thy bliss oh man,</line>
      <line> And sweet shall be thy taste and sweet thy infant joys renew.”</line>
      <line>Infancy, fearless, lustful, happy, nestling for delight</line>
      <line>In laps of pleasure! Innocence, honest, open, seeking</line>
      <line>The vigorous joys of morning-light, open to virgin bliss!</line>
      <line>Who taught thee modesty, subtle modesty, child of night and sleep?</line>
      <line>When thou awakest wilt thou dissemble all thy secret joys,</line>
      <line>Or wert thou not awake when all this mystery was disclosed?</line>
      <line>Then comest thou forth a modest virgin, knowing to dissemble,</line>
      <line>With nets found under thy night-pillow to catch virgin joy,</line>
      <line>And brand it with the name of whore and sell it in the night</line>
      <line> In silence, even without a whisper, and in seeming sleep.</line>
      <line>Religious dreams and holy vespers light thy smoky fires:</line>
      <line>Once were thy fires lighted by the eyes of honest morn.</line>
      <line>And does my Theotormon seek this hypocrite modesty –</line>
      <line>This knowing, artful, secret, fearful, cautious, trembling hypocrite?</line>
      <line>Then is Oothoon a whore indeed, and all the virgin joys</line>
      <line>Of life are harlots, and Theotormon is a sick man’s dream,</line>
      <line>And Oothoon is the crafty slave of selfish holiness!</line>
      <line>But Oothoon is not so – a virgin filled with virgin fancies</line>
      <line>Open to joy and to delight wherever beauty appears!</line>
      <line> If in the morning sun I find it, there my eyes are fixed</line>
      <line>In happy copulation; if in evening mild, wearied with work,</line>
      <line>Sit on a bank and draw the pleasures of this free-born joy.</line>
      <line>The moment of desire! The moment of desire! The virgin</line>
      <line>That pines for man shall awaken her womb to enormous joys</line>
      <line>In the secret shadows of her chamber. The youth shut up from</line>
      <line>The lustful joy shall forget to generate, and create an amorous image</line>
      <line>In the shadows of his curtains, and in the folds of his silent pillow.</line>
      <line>Are not these the places of religion, the rewards of continence,</line>
      <line>The self-enjoyings of self-denial? Why dost thou seek religion?</line>
      <line> Is it because acts are not lovely that thou seekest solitude,</line>
      <line>Where the horrible darkness is impressed with reflections of desire?</line>
      <line>Father of Jealousy, be thou accurséd from the earth!</line>
      <line>Why hast thou taught my Theotormon this accurséd thing?</line>
      <line>Till beauty fades from off my shoulders, darkened and cast out,</line>
      <line>A solitary shadow wailing on the margin of non-entity.</line>
      <line>I cry, love! love! love! Happy, happy love, free as the mountain wind!</line>
      <line>Can that be love that drinks another as a sponge drinks water –</line>
      <line>That clouds with jealousy his nights, with weepings all the day,</line>
      <line>To spin a web of age around him, grey and hoary, dark,</line>
      <line> Till his eyes sicken at the fruit that hangs before his sight?</line>
      <line>Such is self-love that envies all, a creeping skeleton</line>
      <line>With lamplike eyes watching around the frozen marriage-bed.</line>
      <line>But silken nets and traps of adamant will Oothoon spread,</line>
      <line>And catch for thee girls of mild silver, or of furious gold!</line>
      <line>I’ll lie beside thee on a bank and view their wanton play</line>
      <line>In lovely copulation, bliss on bliss with Theotormon.</line>
      <line>Red as the rosy morning, lustful as the first-born beam,</line>
      <line>Oothoon shall view his dear delight, nor e’er with jealous cloud</line>
      <line>Come in the heaven of generous love, nor selfish blightings bring.</line>
      <line>Does the sun walk in glorious raiment on the secret floor</line>
      <line>Where the cold miser spreads his gold? Or does the bright cloud drop</line>
      <line>On his stone threshold? Does his eye behold the beam that brings</line>
      <line>Expansion to the eye of pity? Or will he bind himself</line>
      <line>Beside the ox to thy hard furrow? Does not that mild beam blot</line>
      <line>The bat, the owl, the glowing tiger, and the king of night?</line>
      <line>The sea-fowl takes the wintry blast for a covering to her limbs,</line>
      <line>And the wild snake the pestilence to adorn him with gems and gold –</line>
      <line>And trees and birds and beasts and men behold their eternal joy.</line>
      <line>Arise you little glancing wings, and sing your infant joy!</line>
      <line> Arise and drink your bliss, for every thing that lives is holy!’</line>
      <line>Thus every morning wails Oothoon. But Theotormon sits</line>
      <line>Upon the margined ocean conversing with shadows dire.</line>
      <line>The Daughters of Albion hear her woes, and echo back her sighs.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>Mary the Maid of the Inn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who is she, the poor maniac, whose wildly-fixed eyes</line>
      <line>Seem a heart overcharged to express?</line>
      <line>She weeps not, yet often and deeply she sighs;</line>
      <line>She never complains, but her silence implies</line>
      <line> The composure of settled distress.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No aid, no compassion, the maniac will seek –</line>
      <line>Cold and hunger awake not her care.</line>
      <line>Through her rags do the winds of the winter blow bleak</line>
      <line>On her poor withered bosom, half bare, and her cheek</line>
      <line>Hath the deathy pale hue of despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet cheerful and happy – nor distant the day –</line>
      <line>Poor Mary the Maniac has been:</line>
      <line>The traveller remembers, who journeyed this way,</line>
      <line>No damsel so lovely, no damsel so gay,</line>
      <line> As Mary the Maid of the Inn!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her cheerful address filled the guests with delight</line>
      <line>As she welcomed them in with a smile;</line>
      <line>Her heart was a stranger to childish affright,</line>
      <line>And Mary would walk by the Abbey at night</line>
      <line>When the wind whistled down the dark aisle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She loved – and young Richard had settled the day,</line>
      <line>And she hoped to be happy for life –</line>
      <line>But Richard was idle, and worthless, and they</line>
      <line>Who knew him would pity poor Mary, and say</line>
      <line> That she was too good for his wife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas in autumn, and stormy and dark was the night,</line>
      <line>And fast were the windows and door;</line>
      <line>Two guests sat enjoying the fire that burnt bright,</line>
      <line>And, smoking in silence with tranquil delight,</line>
      <line>They listened to hear the wind roar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘’Tis pleasant’, cried one, ‘seated by the fireside,</line>
      <line>To hear the wind whistle without.’</line>
      <line>‘A fine night for the Abbey!’ his comrade replied,</line>
      <line>‘Methinks a man’s courage would now be well tried</line>
      <line> Who should wander the ruins about.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I myself, like a schoolboy, should tremble to hear</line>
      <line>The hoarse ivy shake over my head,</line>
      <line>And could fancy I saw, half persuaded by fear,</line>
      <line>Some ugly old Abbot’s white spirit appear –</line>
      <line>For this wind might awaken the dead!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I’ll wager a dinner’, the other one cried,</line>
      <line>‘That Mary would venture there now!’</line>
      <line>‘Then wager, and lose!’ with a sneer he replied,</line>
      <line>‘I’ll warrant she’d fancy a ghost by her side,</line>
      <line> And faint if she saw a white cow!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Will Mary this charge on her courage allow?’</line>
      <line>His companion exclaimed with a smile –</line>
      <line>‘I shall win, for I know she will venture there now,</line>
      <line>And earn a new bonnet by bringing a bough</line>
      <line>From the elder that grows in the aisle.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With fearless good humour did Mary comply,</line>
      <line>And her way to the Abbey she bent;</line>
      <line>The night was dark, and the wind was high,</line>
      <line>And as hollowly howling it swept through the sky</line>
      <line> She shivered with cold as she went,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O’er the path so well-known still proceeded the Maid</line>
      <line>Where the Abbey rose dim on the sight;</line>
      <line>Through the gateway she entered – she felt not afraid,</line>
      <line>Yet the ruins were lonely and wild, and their shade</line>
      <line>Seemed to deepen the gloom of the night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All around her was silent, save when the rude blast</line>
      <line>Howled dismally round the old pile;</line>
      <line>Over weed-covered fragments still fearless she passed,</line>
      <line>And arrived in the innermost ruin at last</line>
      <line> Where the elder-tree grew in the aisle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well pleased did she reach it, and quickly drew near,</line>
      <line>And hastily gathered the bough –</line>
      <line>When the sound of a voice seemed to rise on her ear;</line>
      <line>She paused, and she listened, all eager to hear,</line>
      <line>And her heart panted painfully now.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wind blew, the hoarse ivy shook over her head;</line>
      <line>She listened – nought else could she hear!</line>
      <line>The wind ceased – her heart sunk in her bosom with dread,</line>
      <line>For she heard in the ruins distinctly the tread</line>
      <line> Of footsteps approaching her near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Behind a wide column, half breathless with fear</line>
      <line>She crept to conceal herself there;</line>
      <line>That instant the moon o’er a dark cloud shone clear,</line>
      <line>And she saw in the moonlight two ruffians appear,</line>
      <line>And between them a corpse did they bear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Mary could feel her heart-blood curdle cold;</line>
      <line>Again the rough wind hurried by:</line>
      <line>It blew off the hat of the one – and behold</line>
      <line>Even close to the feet of poor Mary it rolled!</line>
      <line> She felt, and expected to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Curse the hat!’ he exclaims. ‘Nay, come on and first hide</line>
      <line>The dead body’, his comrade replies.</line>
      <line>She beheld them in safety pass on by her side,</line>
      <line>She seizes the hat – fear her courage supplied –</line>
      <line>And fast through the Abbey she flies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She ran with wild speed, she rushed in at the door,</line>
      <line>She gazed horribly eager around;</line>
      <line>Then her limbs could support their faint burden no more,</line>
      <line>And exhausted and breathless she sunk on the floor,</line>
      <line> Unable to utter a sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ere yet her pale lips could the story impart,</line>
      <line>For a moment the hat met her view;</line>
      <line>Her eyes from that object convulsively start,</line>
      <line>For – oh God – what cold horror then thrilled through her heart</line>
      <line>When the name of her Richard she knew!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where the old Abbey stands, on the common hard by,</line>
      <line>His gibbet is now to be seen –</line>
      <line>Not far from the road it engages the eye –</line>
      <line>The traveller beholds it, and thinks with a sigh</line>
      <line>Of poor Mary, the Maid of the Inn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>Old Man Travelling</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The little hedgerow-birds</line>
      <line>That peck along the road, regard him not;</line>
      <line>He travels on, and in his face, his step,</line>
      <line>His gait, is one expression. Every limb,</line>
      <line> His look and bending figure, all bespeak</line>
      <line>A man who does not move with pain, but moves</line>
      <line>With thought. He is insensibly subdued</line>
      <line>To settled quiet, he is one by whom</line>
      <line>All effort seems forgotten – one to whom</line>
      <line>O Long patience hath such mild composure given</line>
      <line>That patience now doth seem a thing of which</line>
      <line>He hath no need. He is by Nature led</line>
      <line>To peace so perfect that the young behold</line>
      <line>With envy what the old man hardly feels.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Discharged Soldier</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love to walk</line>
      <line>Along the public way when, for the night</line>
      <line>Deserted in its silence, it assumes</line>
      <line>A character of deeper quietness</line>
      <line> Than pathless solitudes. At such a time</line>
      <line>I slowly mounted up a steep ascent</line>
      <line>Where the road’s watery surface to the ridge</line>
      <line>Of that sharp rising glittered in the moon,</line>
      <line>And seemed before my eyes another stream</line>
      <line>Stealing with silent lapse to join the brook</line>
      <line>That murmured in the valley. On I passed</line>
      <line>Tranquil, receiving in my own despite</line>
      <line>Amusement, as I slowly passed along,</line>
      <line>From such near objects as from time to time</line>
      <line> Perforce disturbed the slumber of the sense</line>
      <line>Quiescent and disposed to sympathy –</line>
      <line>With an exhausted mind worn out by toil</line>
      <line>And all unworthy of the deeper joy</line>
      <line>Which waits on distant prospect, cliff or sea,</line>
      <line>The dark blue vault, and universe of stars.</line>
      <line>Thus did I steal along that silent road,</line>
      <line>My body from the stillness drinking in</line>
      <line>A restoration like the calm of sleep</line>
      <line>But sweeter far. Above, before, behind,</line>
      <line> Around me, all was peace and solitude:</line>
      <line>I looked not round, nor did the solitude</line>
      <line>Speak to my eye, but it was heard and felt.</line>
      <line>Oh happy state – what beauteous pictures now</line>
      <line>Rose in harmonious imagery! They rose</line>
      <line>As from some distant region of my soul</line>
      <line>And came along like dreams – yet such as left</line>
      <line>Obscurely mingled with their passing forms</line>
      <line>A consciousness of animal delight,</line>
      <line>A self-possession felt in every pause</line>
      <line> And every gentle movement of my frame.</line>
      <line>While thus I wandered, step by step led on,</line>
      <line>It chanced a sudden turning of the road</line>
      <line>Presented to my view an uncouth shape</line>
      <line>So near that, stepping back into the shade</line>
      <line>Of a thick hawthorn, I could mark him well,</line>
      <line>Myself unseen. He was of stature tall,</line>
      <line>A foot above man’s common measure tall,</line>
      <line>And lank, and upright. There was in his form</line>
      <line>A meagre stiffness – you might almost think</line>
      <line> That his bones wounded him. His legs were long,</line>
      <line>So long and shapeless that I looked at them</line>
      <line>Forgetful of the body they sustained.</line>
      <line>His arms were long and lean; his hands were bare;</line>
      <line>His visage, wasted though it seemed, was large</line>
      <line>In feature; his cheeks sunken; and his mouth</line>
      <line>Showed ghastly in the moonlight. From behind,</line>
      <line>A milestone propped him, and his figure seemed</line>
      <line>Half-sitting and half-standing. I could mark</line>
      <line>That he was clad in military garb,</line>
      <line> Though faded yet entire. His face was turned</line>
      <line>Towards the road, yet not as if he sought</line>
      <line>For any living thing. He appeared</line>
      <line>Forlorn and desolate, a man cut off</line>
      <line>From all his kind, and more than half-detached</line>
      <line>From his own nature.</line>
      <line>He was alone,</line>
      <line>Had no attendant, neither dog, nor staff,</line>
      <line>Nor knapsack – in his very dress appeared</line>
      <line>A desolation, a simplicity,</line>
      <line>That appertained to solitude: I think</line>
      <line> If but a glove had dangled in his hand</line>
      <line>It would have made him more akin to man.</line>
      <line>Long time I scanned him, with a mingled sense</line>
      <line>Of fear and sorrow. From his lips meanwhile</line>
      <line>There issued murmuring sounds as if of pain</line>
      <line>Or of uneasy thought; yet still his form</line>
      <line>Kept the same fearful steadiness. His shadow</line>
      <line>Lay at his feet and moved not.</line>
      <line>In a glen</line>
      <line>Hard by, a village stood, whose silent doors</line>
      <line>Were visible among the scattered trees,</line>
      <line> Scarce distant from the spot an arrow’s flight.</line>
      <line>I wished to see him move, but he remained</line>
      <line>Fixed to his place, and still from time to time</line>
      <line>Sent forth a murmuring voice of dead complaint,</line>
      <line>A groan scarce audible. Yet all the while</line>
      <line>The chained mastiff in his wooden house</line>
      <line>Was vexed, and from among the village trees</line>
      <line>Howled never ceasing. Not without reproach</line>
      <line>Had I prolonged my watch, and now confirmed,</line>
      <line>And my heart’s specious cowardice subdued,</line>
      <line> I left the shady nook where I had stood</line>
      <line>And hailed the stranger.</line>
      <line>From his resting-place</line>
      <line>He rose, and, with his lean and wasted arm</line>
      <line>In measured gesture lifted to his head,</line>
      <line>Returned my salutation. A short while</line>
      <line>I held discourse on things indifferent</line>
      <line>And casual matter. He meanwhile had ceased</line>
      <line>From all complaint – his station had resumed,</line>
      <line>Propped by the milestone as before. And when erelong</line>
      <line>I asked his history, he in reply</line>
      <line> Was neither slow nor eager, but unmoved,</line>
      <line>And with a quiet uncomplaining voice,</line>
      <line>A stately air of mild indifference,</line>
      <line>He told a simple fact: that he had been</line>
      <line>A soldier, to the Tropic Isles had gone,</line>
      <line>Whence he had landed now some ten days past;</line>
      <line>That on his landing he had been dismissed,</line>
      <line>And with the little strength he yet had left</line>
      <line>Was travelling to regain his native home.</line>
      <line>At this I turned, and through the trees looked down</line>
      <line>Into the village – all were gone to rest:</line>
      <line>Nor smoke nor any taper-light appeared,</line>
      <line>But every silent window to the moon</line>
      <line>Shone with a yellow glitter. ‘No one there’,</line>
      <line>Said I, ‘is waking; we must measure back</line>
      <line>The way which we have come. Behind yon wood</line>
      <line>A labourer dwells, an honest man and kind;</line>
      <line>He will not murmur should we break his rest,</line>
      <line>And he will give you food if food you need,</line>
      <line>And lodging for the night.’ At this he stooped,</line>
      <line> And from the ground took up an oaken staff</line>
      <line>By me yet unobserved, a traveller’s staff,</line>
      <line>Which I suppose from his slack hand had dropped,</line>
      <line>And (such the languor of the weary man)</line>
      <line>Had lain till now neglected in the grass,</line>
      <line>But not forgotten.</line>
      <line>Back we turned and shaped</line>
      <line>Our course toward the cottage. He appeared</line>
      <line>To travel without pain, and I beheld</line>
      <line>With ill-suppressed astonishment his tall</line>
      <line>And ghostly figure moving at my side.</line>
      <line> As we advanced I asked him for what cause</line>
      <line>He tarried there, nor had demanded rest</line>
      <line>At inn or cottage. He replied, ‘In truth</line>
      <line>My weakness made me loath to move, and here</line>
      <line>I felt myself at ease and much relieved –</line>
      <line>But that the village mastiff fretted me,</line>
      <line>And every second moment rang a peal</line>
      <line>Felt at my very heart. There was no noise,</line>
      <line>Nor any foot abroad; I do not know</line>
      <line>What ailed him, but it seemed as if the dog</line>
      <line> Were howling to the murmur of the stream.’</line>
      <line>While thus we travelled on I did not fail</line>
      <line>To question him of what he had endured</line>
      <line>From war and battle and the pestilence.</line>
      <line>He all the while was in demeanour calm,</line>
      <line>Concise in answer: solemn and sublime</line>
      <line>He might have seemed, but that in all he said</line>
      <line>There was a strange half-absence and a tone</line>
      <line>Of weakness and indifference, as of one</line>
      <line>Remembering the importance of his theme,</line>
      <line> But feeling it no longer. We advanced</line>
      <line>Slowly, and ere we to the wood were come</line>
      <line>Discourse had ceased. Together on we passed</line>
      <line>In silence through the shades gloomy and dark,</line>
      <line>Then turning up along an open field</line>
      <line>We gained the cottage.</line>
      <line>At the door I knocked,</line>
      <line>And called aloud, ‘My friend, here is a man</line>
      <line>By sickness overcome; beneath your roof</line>
      <line>This night let him find rest, and give him food –</line>
      <line>The service if need be I will requite.’</line>
      <line> Assured that now my comrade would repose</line>
      <line>In comfort, I entreated that henceforth</line>
      <line>He would not linger in the public ways</line>
      <line>But at the door of cottage or of inn</line>
      <line>Demand the succour which his state required,</line>
      <line>And told him, feeble as he was, ’twere fit</line>
      <line>He asked relief or alms. At this reproof,</line>
      <line>With the same ghastly mildness in his look,</line>
      <line>He said, ‘My trust is in the God of Heaven,</line>
      <line>And in the eye of him that passes me.’</line>
      <line> By this the labourer had unlocked the door,</line>
      <line>And now my comrade touched his hat again</line>
      <line>With his lean hand, and, in a voice that seemed</line>
      <line>To speak with a reviving interest</line>
      <line>Till then unfelt, he thanked me. I returned</line>
      <line>The blessing of the poor unhappy man,</line>
      <line>And so we parted.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Mad Mother</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her eyes are wild, her head is bare,</line>
      <line>The sun has burnt her coal-black hair,</line>
      <line>Her eyebrows have a rusty stain,</line>
      <line>And she came far from over the main.</line>
      <line> She has a baby on her arm,</line>
      <line>Or else she were alone;</line>
      <line>And underneath the haystack warm,</line>
      <line>And on the greenwood stone,</line>
      <line>She talked and sung the woods among,</line>
      <line>And it was in the English tongue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sweet babe, they say that I am mad,</line>
      <line>But nay, my heart is far too glad,</line>
      <line>And I am happy when I sing</line>
      <line>Full many a sad and doleful thing!</line>
      <line> Then, lovely baby, do not fear –</line>
      <line>I pray thee have no fear of me –</line>
      <line>But, safe as in a cradle, here,</line>
      <line>My lovely baby, thou shalt be.</line>
      <line>To thee I know too much I owe;</line>
      <line>I cannot work thee any woe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fire was once within my brain,</line>
      <line>And in my head a dull dull pain,</line>
      <line>And fiendish faces one, two, three,</line>
      <line>Hung at my breasts, and pulled at me.</line>
      <line> But then there came a sight of joy</line>
      <line>(It came at once to do me good),</line>
      <line>I waked and saw my little boy,</line>
      <line>My little boy of flesh and blood –</line>
      <line>Oh joy for me that sight to see</line>
      <line>For he was here, and only he!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Suck, little babe, oh suck again –</line>
      <line>It cools my blood, it cools my brain!</line>
      <line>Thy lips I feel them, baby, they</line>
      <line>Draw from my heart the pain away.</line>
      <line> Oh press me with thy little hand,</line>
      <line>It loosens something at my chest –</line>
      <line>About that tight and deadly band</line>
      <line>I feel thy little fingers pressed.</line>
      <line>The breeze I see is in the tree;</line>
      <line>It comes to cool my babe and me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh love me, love me, little boy,</line>
      <line>Thou art thy mother’s only joy,</line>
      <line>And do not dread the waves below,</line>
      <line>When o’er the sea-rock’s edge we go.</line>
      <line> The high crag cannot work me harm,</line>
      <line>Nor leaping torrents when they howl:</line>
      <line>The babe I carry on my arm,</line>
      <line>He saves for me my precious soul!</line>
      <line>Then happy lie, for blest am I –</line>
      <line>Without me my sweet babe would die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then do not fear, my boy, for thee</line>
      <line>Bold as a lion I will be;</line>
      <line>And I will always be thy guide,</line>
      <line>Through hollow snows and rivers wide.</line>
      <line> I’ll build an Indian bower, I know</line>
      <line>The leaves that make the softest bed;</line>
      <line>And if from me thou wilt not go,</line>
      <line>But still be true till I am dead,</line>
      <line>My pretty thing, then thou shalt sing,</line>
      <line>As merry as the birds in spring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy father cares not for my breast –</line>
      <line>’Tis thine, sweet baby, there to rest,</line>
      <line>’Tis all thy own, and if its hue</line>
      <line>Be changed, that was so fair to view,</line>
      <line> ’Tis fair enough for thee, my dove!</line>
      <line>My beauty, little child, is flown,</line>
      <line>But thou wilt live with me in love –</line>
      <line>And what if my poor cheek be brown?</line>
      <line>’Tis well for me: thou canst not see</line>
      <line>How pale and wan it else would be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dread not their taunts, my little life,</line>
      <line>I am thy father’s wedded wife,</line>
      <line>And underneath the spreading tree</line>
      <line>We two will live in honesty.</line>
      <line> If his sweet boy he could forsake,</line>
      <line>With me he never would have stayed.</line>
      <line>From him no harm my babe can take;</line>
      <line>But he, poor man, is wretched made,</line>
      <line>And every day we two will pray</line>
      <line>For him that’s gone and far away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll teach my boy the sweetest things;</line>
      <line>I’ll teach him how the owlet sings.</line>
      <line>My little babe, thy lips are still,</line>
      <line>And thou hast almost sucked thy fill –</line>
      <line> Where art thou gone, my own dear child?</line>
      <line>What wicked looks are those I see?</line>
      <line>Alas, alas, that look so wild,</line>
      <line>It never, never came from me!</line>
      <line>If thou art mad, my pretty lad,</line>
      <line>Then I must be for ever sad.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh smile on me, my little lamb,</line>
      <line>For I thy own dear mother am!</line>
      <line>My love for thee has well been tried –</line>
      <line>I’ve sought thy father far and wide.</line>
      <line> I know the poisons of the shade,</line>
      <line>I know the earth-nuts fit for food;</line>
      <line>Then, pretty dear, be not afraid;</line>
      <line>We’ll find thy father in the wood.</line>
      <line>Now laugh and be gay, to the woods away,</line>
      <line>And there, my babe, we’ll live for aye!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Complaint of a Forsaken Indian Woman</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Before I see another day,</line>
      <line>Oh let my body die away!</line>
      <line>In sleep I heard the northern gleams,</line>
      <line>The stars they were among my dreams;</line>
      <line> In sleep did I behold the skies –</line>
      <line>I saw the crackling flashes drive,</line>
      <line>And yet they are upon my eyes,</line>
      <line>And yet I am alive.</line>
      <line>Before I see another day,</line>
      <line>Oh let my body die away!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My fire is dead – it knew no pain;</line>
      <line>Yet is it dead, and I remain.</line>
      <line>All stiff with ice the ashes lie;</line>
      <line>And they are dead, and I will die.</line>
      <line> When I was well I wished to live,</line>
      <line>For clothes, for warmth, for food, and fire;</line>
      <line>But they to me no joy can give,</line>
      <line>No pleasure now, and no desire.</line>
      <line>Then here contented will I lie –</line>
      <line>Alone I cannot fear to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas, you might have dragged me on</line>
      <line>Another day, a single one!</line>
      <line>Too soon despair o’er me prevailed,</line>
      <line>Too soon my heartless spirit failed;</line>
      <line> When you were gone my limbs were stronger,</line>
      <line>And oh how grievously I rue</line>
      <line>That afterwards, a little longer,</line>
      <line>My friends, I did not follow you!</line>
      <line>For strong and without pain I lay,</line>
      <line>My friends, when you were gone away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My child, they gave thee to another,</line>
      <line>A woman who was not thy mother!</line>
      <line>When from my arms my babe they took,</line>
      <line>On me how strangely did he look:</line>
      <line> Through his whole body something ran,</line>
      <line>A most strange something did I see,</line>
      <line>As if he strove to be a man</line>
      <line>That he might pull the sledge for me!</line>
      <line>And then he stretched his arms, how wild –</line>
      <line>Oh mercy, like a little child!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My little joy! my little pride!</line>
      <line>In two days more I must have died –</line>
      <line>Then do not weep and grieve for me,</line>
      <line>I feel I must have died with thee!</line>
      <line> Oh wind that o’er my head art flying</line>
      <line>The way my friends their course did bend,</line>
      <line>I should not feel the pain of dying</line>
      <line>Could I with thee a message send.</line>
      <line>Too soon, my friends, you went away,</line>
      <line>For I had many things to say.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll follow you across the snow –</line>
      <line>You travel heavily and slow –</line>
      <line>In spite of all my weary pain,</line>
      <line>I’ll look upon your tents again!</line>
      <line> My fire is dead, and snowy white</line>
      <line>The water which beside it stood;</line>
      <line>The wolf has come to me tonight,</line>
      <line>And he has stolen away my food –</line>
      <line>For ever left alone am I,</line>
      <line>Then wherefore should I fear to die?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My journey will be shortly run,</line>
      <line>I shall not see another sun –</line>
      <line>I cannot lift my limbs to know</line>
      <line>If they have any life or no.</line>
      <line> My poor forsaken child, if I</line>
      <line>For once could have thee close to me,</line>
      <line>With happy heart I then would die,</line>
      <line>And my last thoughts would happy be!</line>
      <line>I feel my body die away,</line>
      <line>I shall not see another day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1800</date>
    <title>Michael (lines 217-490)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>While this good household thus were living on</line>
      <line>From day to day, to Michael’s ear there came</line>
      <line>Distressful tidings. Long before the time</line>
      <line>Of which I speak, the shepherd had been bound</line>
      <line>In surety for his brother’s son, a man</line>
      <line>Of an industrious life and ample means,</line>
      <line>But unforeseen misfortunes suddenly</line>
      <line>Had pressed upon him, and old Michael now</line>
      <line> Was summoned to discharge the forfeiture –</line>
      <line>A grievous penalty, but little less</line>
      <line>Than half his substance. This unlooked-for claim,</line>
      <line>At the first hearing, for a moment took</line>
      <line>More hope out of his life than he supposed</line>
      <line>That any old man ever could have lost.</line>
      <line>As soon as he had gathered so much strength</line>
      <line>That he could look his trouble in the face,</line>
      <line>It seemed that his sole refuge was to sell</line>
      <line>A portion of his patrimonial fields.</line>
      <line> Such was his first resolve; he thought again,</line>
      <line>And his heart failed him.</line>
      <line>‘Isabel’, said he,</line>
      <line>Two evenings after he had heard the news,</line>
      <line>‘I have been toiling more than seventy years,</line>
      <line>And in the open sunshine of God’s love</line>
      <line>Have we all lived, yet if these fields of ours</line>
      <line>Should pass into a stranger’s hands, I think</line>
      <line>That I could not lie quiet in my grave.</line>
      <line>Our lot is a hard lot; the sun itself</line>
      <line>Has scarcely been more diligent than I,</line>
      <line> And I have lived to be a fool at last</line>
      <line>To my own family. An evil man</line>
      <line>That was, and made an evil choice, if he</line>
      <line>Were false to us; and if he were not false,</line>
      <line>There are ten thousand to whom loss like this</line>
      <line>Had been no sorrow. I forgive him – but</line>
      <line>’Twere better to be dumb than to talk thus!</line>
      <line>When I began, my purpose was to speak</line>
      <line>Of remedies and of a cheerful hope.</line>
      <line>Our Luke shall leave us, Isabel; the land</line>
      <line> Shall not go from us, and it shall be free –</line>
      <line>He shall possess it, free as is the wind</line>
      <line>That passes over it. We have, thou knowest,</line>
      <line>Another kinsman; he will be our friend</line>
      <line>In this distress. He is a prosperous man,</line>
      <line>Thriving in trade, and Luke to him shall go</line>
      <line>And with his kinsman’s help and his own thrift</line>
      <line>He quickly will repair this loss, and then</line>
      <line>May come again to us. If here he stay,</line>
      <line>What can be gained?’</line>
      <line>At this the old man paused,</line>
      <line> And Isabel sat silent, for her mind</line>
      <line>Was busy looking back into past times:</line>
      <line>‘There’s Richard Bateman’, thought she to herself,</line>
      <line>‘He was a parish-boy – at the church-door</line>
      <line>They made a gathering for him, shillings, pence</line>
      <line>And halfpennies, wherewith the neighbours bought</line>
      <line>A basket, which they filled with pedlar’s wares,</line>
      <line>And with this basket on his arm the lad</line>
      <line>Went up to London, found a master there,</line>
      <line>Who out of many chose the trusty boy</line>
      <line> To go and overlook his merchandise</line>
      <line>Beyond the seas, where he grew wondrous rich</line>
      <line>And left estates and moneys to the poor,</line>
      <line>And at his birthplace built a chapel, floored</line>
      <line>With marble which he sent from foreign lands.’</line>
      <line>These thoughts, and many others of like sort,</line>
      <line>Passed quickly through the mind of Isabel,</line>
      <line>And her face brightened. The old man was glad,</line>
      <line>And thus resumed: ‘Well, Isabel, this scheme</line>
      <line>These two days has been meat and drink to me:</line>
      <line> Far more than we have lost is left us yet.</line>
      <line>We have enough – I wish indeed that I</line>
      <line>Were younger, but this hope is a good hope.</line>
      <line>Make ready Luke’s best garments; of the best</line>
      <line>Buy for him more, and let us send him forth</line>
      <line>Tomorrow, or the next day, or tonight –</line>
      <line>If he could go, the boy should go tonight!’</line>
      <line>Here Michael ceased, and to the fields went forth</line>
      <line>With a light heart. The housewife for five days</line>
      <line>Was restless morn and night, and all day long</line>
      <line> Wrought on with her best fingers to prepare</line>
      <line>Things needful for the journey of her son.</line>
      <line>But Isabel was glad when Sunday came</line>
      <line>To stop her in her work; for when she lay</line>
      <line>By Michael’s side, she for the two last nights</line>
      <line>Heard him, how he was troubled in his sleep;</line>
      <line>And when they rose at morning she could see</line>
      <line>That all his hopes were gone. That day at noon</line>
      <line>She said to Luke, while they two by themselves</line>
      <line>Were sitting at the door: ‘Thou must not go,</line>
      <line>We have no other child but thee to lose,</line>
      <line>None to remember – do not go away,</line>
      <line>For if thou leave thy father he will die.’</line>
      <line>The lad made answer with a jocund voice,</line>
      <line>And Isabel, when she had told her fears,</line>
      <line>Recovered heart. That evening her best fare</line>
      <line>Did she bring forth, and all together sat</line>
      <line>Like happy people round a Christmas fire.</line>
      <line>Next morning Isabel resumed her work,</line>
      <line>And all the ensuing week the house appeared</line>
      <line> As cheerful as a grove in spring. At length</line>
      <line>The expected letter from their kinsman came,</line>
      <line>With kind assurances that he would do</line>
      <line>His utmost for the welfare of the boy –</line>
      <line>To which requests were added that forthwith</line>
      <line>He might be sent to him. Ten times or more</line>
      <line>The letter was read over; Isabel</line>
      <line>Went forth to show it to the neighbours round;</line>
      <line>Nor was there at that time on English land</line>
      <line>A prouder heart than Luke’s. When Isabel</line>
      <line> Had to her house returned the old man said,</line>
      <line>‘He shall depart tomorrow.’ To this word</line>
      <line>The housewife answered, talking much of things</line>
      <line>Which, if at such short notice he should go,</line>
      <line>Would surely be forgotten – but at length</line>
      <line>She gave consent, and Michael was at ease.</line>
      <line>Near the tumultuous brook of Greenhead Gill</line>
      <line>In that deep valley, Michael had designed</line>
      <line>To build a sheepfold, and before he heard</line>
      <line>The tidings of his melancholy loss</line>
      <line> For this same purpose he had gathered up</line>
      <line>A heap of stones, which close to the brook-side</line>
      <line>Lay thrown together, ready for the work.</line>
      <line>With Luke that evening thitherward he walked,</line>
      <line>And soon as they had reached the place he stopped,</line>
      <line>And thus the old man spake to him: ‘My son,</line>
      <line>Tomorrow thou wilt leave me. With full heart</line>
      <line>I look upon thee, for thou art the same</line>
      <line>That wert a promise to me ere thy birth,</line>
      <line>And all thy life hast been my daily joy.</line>
      <line> I will relate to thee some little part</line>
      <line>Of our two histories – ’twill do thee good</line>
      <line>When thou art from me, even if I should speak</line>
      <line>Of things thou canst not know of.</line>
      <line>After thou</line>
      <line>First camest into the world, as it befalls</line>
      <line>To newborn infants, thou didst sleep away</line>
      <line>Two days, and blessings from thy father’s tongue</line>
      <line>Then fell upon thee. Day by day passed on,</line>
      <line>And still I loved thee with increasing love.</line>
      <line>Never to living ear came sweeter sounds</line>
      <line> Than when I heard thee by our own fireside</line>
      <line>First uttering without words a natural tune –</line>
      <line>When thou, a feeding babe, didst in thy joy</line>
      <line>Sing at thy mother’s breast. Month followed month,</line>
      <line>And in the open fields my life was passed,</line>
      <line>And in the mountains, else I think that thou</line>
      <line>Hadst been brought up upon thy father’s knees!</line>
      <line>But we were playmates, Luke: among these hills,</line>
      <line>As well thou knowest, in us the old and young</line>
      <line>Have played together! – nor with me didst thou</line>
      <line> Lack any pleasure which a boy can know.’</line>
      <line>Luke had a manly heart; but at these words</line>
      <line>He sobbed aloud. The old man grasped his hand,</line>
      <line>And said, ‘Nay, do not take it so – I see</line>
      <line>That these are things of which I need not speak.</line>
      <line>Even to the utmost have I been to thee</line>
      <line>A kind and a good father; and herein</line>
      <line>I but repay a gift which I myself</line>
      <line>Received at others’ hands, for though now old</line>
      <line>Beyond the common life of man I still</line>
      <line> Remember them who loved me in my youth.</line>
      <line>Both of them sleep together – here they lived</line>
      <line>As all their forefathers had done; and when</line>
      <line>At length their time was come, they were not loath</line>
      <line>To give their bodies to the family mould.</line>
      <line>I wished that thou shouldst live the life they lived;</line>
      <line>But ’tis a long time to look back, my son,</line>
      <line>And see so little gain from sixty years.</line>
      <line>These fields were burdened when they came to me:</line>
      <line>Till I was forty years of age, not more</line>
      <line> Than half of my inheritance was mine.</line>
      <line>I toiled and toiled – God blest me in my work,</line>
      <line>And till these three weeks past the land was free.</line>
      <line>It looks as if it never could endure</line>
      <line>Another master! Heaven forgive me, Luke,</line>
      <line>If I judge ill for thee, but it seems good</line>
      <line>That thou shouldst go.’</line>
      <line>At this the old man paused,</line>
      <line>Then, pointing to the stones near which they stood,</line>
      <line>Thus after a short silence he resumed:</line>
      <line>‘This was a work for us, and now, my son,</line>
      <line> It is a work for me! But, lay one stone –</line>
      <line>Here, lay it for me, Luke, with thine own hands –</line>
      <line>I for the purpose brought thee to this place.</line>
      <line>Nay, boy, be of good hope, we both may live</line>
      <line>To see a better day! At eighty-four</line>
      <line>I still am strong and stout: do thou thy part,</line>
      <line>I will do mine. I will begin again</line>
      <line>With many tasks that were resigned to thee:</line>
      <line>Up to the heights, and in among the storms,</line>
      <line>Will I without thee go again, and do</line>
      <line>All works which I was wont to do alone</line>
      <line>Before I knew thy face.</line>
      <line>Heaven bless thee,</line>
      <line>Thy heart these two weeks has been beating fast</line>
      <line>With many hopes. It should be so – yes, yes –</line>
      <line>I knew that thou couldst never have a wish</line>
      <line>To leave me, Luke. Thou hast been bound to me</line>
      <line>Only by links of love! When thou art gone</line>
      <line>What will be left to us? – but I forget</line>
      <line>My purposes. Lay now the corner-stone</line>
      <line>As I requested, and hereafter, Luke,</line>
      <line> When thou art gone away, should evil men</line>
      <line>Be thy companions, let this sheepfold be</line>
      <line>Thy anchor and thy shield. Amid all fear,</line>
      <line>And all temptation, let it be to thee</line>
      <line>An emblem of the life thy fathers lived,</line>
      <line>Who, being innocent, did for that cause</line>
      <line>Bestir them in good deeds. Now, fare thee well.</line>
      <line>When thou returnst, thou in this place wilt see</line>
      <line>A work which is not here. A covenant</line>
      <line>’Twill be between us – but whatever fate</line>
      <line> Befall thee, I shall love thee to the last,</line>
      <line>And bear thy memory with me to the grave.’</line>
      <line>The shepherd ended here, and Luke stooped down</line>
      <line>And, as his father had requested, laid</line>
      <line>The first stone of the sheepfold. At the sight</line>
      <line>The old man’s grief broke from him. To his heart</line>
      <line>He pressed his son; he kissed him and he wept,</line>
      <line>And to the house together they returned.</line>
      <line>Next morning, as had been resolved, the boy</line>
      <line>Began his journey; and when he had reached</line>
      <line> The public way he put on a bold face,</line>
      <line>And all the neighbours as he passed their doors</line>
      <line>Came forth with wishes and with farewell prayers</line>
      <line>That followed him till he was out of sight.</line>
      <line>A good report did from their kinsman come</line>
      <line>Of Luke and his well-doing; and the boy</line>
      <line>Wrote loving letters, full of wondrous news,</line>
      <line>Which, as the housewife phrased it, were throughout</line>
      <line>The prettiest letters that were ever seen!</line>
      <line>Both parents read them with rejoicing hearts.</line>
      <line> So many months passed on, and once again</line>
      <line>The shepherd went about his daily work</line>
      <line>With confident and cheerful thoughts; and now</line>
      <line>Sometimes when he could find a leisure hour</line>
      <line>He to that valley took his way, and there</line>
      <line>Wrought at the sheepfold. Meantime Luke began</line>
      <line>To slacken in his duty, and at length</line>
      <line>He in the dissolute city gave himself</line>
      <line>To evil courses. Ignominy and shame</line>
      <line>Fell on him, so that he was driven at last</line>
      <line> To seek a hiding-place beyond the seas.</line>
      <line>There is a comfort in the strength of love,</line>
      <line>’Twill make a thing endurable which else</line>
      <line>Would break the heart – old Michael found it so.</line>
      <line>I have conversed with more than one who well</line>
      <line>Remember the old man, and what he was</line>
      <line>Years after he had heard this heavy news.</line>
      <line>His bodily frame had been from youth to age</line>
      <line>Of an unusual strength. Among the rocks</line>
      <line>He went, and still looked up upon the sun</line>
      <line> And listened to the wind, and, as before,</line>
      <line>Performed all kinds of labour for his sheep</line>
      <line>And for the land, his small inheritance.</line>
      <line>And to that hollow dell from time to time</line>
      <line>Did he repair, to build the fold of which</line>
      <line>His flock had need. ’Tis not forgotten yet</line>
      <line>The pity which was then in every heart</line>
      <line>For the old man, and ’tis believed by all</line>
      <line>That many and many a day he thither went,</line>
      <line>And never lifted up a single stone.</line>
      <line> There by the sheepfold sometimes was he seen</line>
      <line>Sitting alone, with that his faithful dog</line>
      <line>(Then old) beside him, lying at his feet.</line>
      <line>The length of full seven years from time to time</line>
      <line>He at the building of this sheepfold wrought,</line>
      <line>And left the work unfinished when he died.</line>
      <line>Three years, or little more, did Isabel</line>
      <line>Survive her husband; at her death the estate</line>
      <line>Was sold, and went into a stranger’s hand.</line>
      <line>The cottage which was named the Evening Star</line>
      <line> Is gone; the ploughshare has been through the ground</line>
      <line>On which it stood. Great changes have been wrought</line>
      <line>In all the neighbourhood; yet the oak is left</line>
      <line>That grew beside their door, and the remains</line>
      <line>Of the unfinished sheepfold may be seen</line>
      <line>Beside the boisterous brook of Greenhead Gill.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Leech-Gatherer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a roaring in the wind all night,</line>
      <line>The rain came heavily and fell in floods,</line>
      <line>But now the sun is rising calm and bright,</line>
      <line>The birds are singing in the distant woods,</line>
      <line> Over his own sweet voice the stock-dove broods,</line>
      <line>The jay makes answer as the magpie chatters,</line>
      <line>And all the air is filled with pleasant noise of waters.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All things that love the sun are out of doors,</line>
      <line>The sky rejoices in the morning’s birth,</line>
      <line>The grass is bright with raindrops; on the moors</line>
      <line>The hare is running races in her mirth,</line>
      <line>And with her feet she from the plashy earth</line>
      <line>Raises a mist which, glittering in the sun,</line>
      <line>Runs with her all the way, wherever she doth run.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I was a traveller then upon the moor:</line>
      <line>I saw the hare that raced about with joy,</line>
      <line>I heard the woods and distant waters roar –</line>
      <line>Or heard them not – as happy as a boy;</line>
      <line>The pleasant season did my heart employ;</line>
      <line>My old remembrances went from me wholly,</line>
      <line>And all the ways of men, so vain and melancholy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, as it sometimes chanceth – from the might</line>
      <line>Of joy in minds that can no farther go –</line>
      <line>As high as we have mounted in delight</line>
      <line> In our dejection do we sink as low.</line>
      <line>To me that morning did it happen so,</line>
      <line>And fears and fancies thick upon me came:</line>
      <line>Dim sadness, and blind thoughts I knew not, nor could name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I heard the skylark singing in the sky</line>
      <line>And I bethought me of the playful hare:</line>
      <line>‘Even such a happy child of earth am I –</line>
      <line>Even as these blissful creatures do I fare!</line>
      <line>Far from the world I walk, and from all care;</line>
      <line>But there may come another day to me</line>
      <line> Solitude, pain of heart, distress and poverty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My whole life have I lived in pleasant thought</line>
      <line>As if life’s business were a summer mood,</line>
      <line>As if all needful things would come unsought</line>
      <line>To genial faith, still rich in genial good –</line>
      <line>But how can he expect that others should</line>
      <line>Build for him, sow for him, and at his call</line>
      <line>Love him, who for himself will take no heed at all?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I thought of Chatterton – the marvellous boy,</line>
      <line>The sleepless soul that perished in its pride –</line>
      <line> Of him who walked in glory and in joy</line>
      <line>Behind his plough upon the mountain’s side.</line>
      <line>By our own spirits are we deified!</line>
      <line>We poets in our youth begin in gladness,</line>
      <line>But thereof comes in the end despondency and madness.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, whether it were by peculiar grace</line>
      <line>(A leading from above, a something given),</line>
      <line>Yet it befell that in this lonely place</line>
      <line>When up and down my fancy thus was driven,</line>
      <line>And I with these untoward thoughts had striven,</line>
      <line> I saw a man before me unawares;</line>
      <line>The oldest man he seemed that ever wore grey hairs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My course I stopped as soon as I espied</line>
      <line>The old man in that naked wilderness;</line>
      <line>Close by a pond – upon the further side –</line>
      <line>He stood alone a minute’s space, I guess.</line>
      <line>I watched him, he continuing motionless;</line>
      <line>To the pool’s further margin then I drew,</line>
      <line>He being all the while before me full in view.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As a huge stone is sometimes seen to lie</line>
      <line> Couched on the bald top of an eminence</line>
      <line>(Wonder to all who do the same espy</line>
      <line>By what means it could thither come, and whence)</line>
      <line>So that it seems a thing endued with sense,</line>
      <line>Like a sea-beast crawled forth, which on a shelf</line>
      <line>Of rock or sand reposeth, there to sun itself–</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such seemed this man, not all alive nor dead,</line>
      <line>Nor all asleep, in his extreme old age.</line>
      <line>His body was bent double, feet and head</line>
      <line>Coming together in their pilgrimage</line>
      <line> As if some dire constraint of pain, or rage</line>
      <line>Of sickness, felt by him in times long past,</line>
      <line>A more than human weight upon his frame had cast.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Himself he propped – his body, limbs, and face –</line>
      <line>Upon a long grey staff of shaven wood;</line>
      <line>And still, as I drew near with gentle pace,</line>
      <line>Beside the little pond or moorish flood</line>
      <line>Motionless as a cloud the old man stood,</line>
      <line>That heareth not the loud winds when they call,</line>
      <line>And moveth altogether, if it move at all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> At length – himself unsettling – he the pond</line>
      <line>Stirred with his staff, and fixedly did look</line>
      <line>Upon the muddy water which he conned</line>
      <line>As if he had been reading in a book;</line>
      <line>And now such freedom as I could I took</line>
      <line>And, drawing to his side, to him did say,</line>
      <line>‘This morning gives us promise of a glorious day.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A gentle answer did the old man make</line>
      <line>In courteous speech which forth he slowly drew,</line>
      <line>And him with further words I thus bespake:</line>
      <line> ‘What kind of work is that which you pursue? –</line>
      <line>This is a lonesome place for one like you.’</line>
      <line>He answered me with pleasure and surprise,</line>
      <line>And there was, while he spake, a fire about his eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His words came feebly from a feeble chest,</line>
      <line>Yet each in solemn order followed each</line>
      <line>With something of a lofty utterance dressed –</line>
      <line>Choice word and measured phrase, above the reach</line>
      <line>Of ordinary men – a stately speech</line>
      <line>Such as grave livers do in Scotland use,</line>
      <line>Religious men, who give to God and man their dues.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He told me that he to this pond had come</line>
      <line>To gather leeches, being old and poor</line>
      <line>(Employment hazardous and wearisome!)</line>
      <line>And he had many hardships to endure.</line>
      <line>From pond to pond he roamed, from moor to moor,</line>
      <line>Housing, with God’s good help, by choice or chance;</line>
      <line>And in this way he gained an honest maintenance.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The old man still stood talking at my side,</line>
      <line>But now his voice to me was like a stream</line>
      <line> Scarce heard – nor word from word could I divide –</line>
      <line>And the whole body of the man did seem</line>
      <line>Like one whom I had met with in a dream,</line>
      <line>Or like a man from some far region sent</line>
      <line>To give me human strength, and strong admonishment.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My former thoughts returned: the fear that kills,</line>
      <line>The hope that is unwilling to be fed –</line>
      <line>Cold, pain, and labour, and all fleshly ills,</line>
      <line>And mighty poets in their misery dead.</line>
      <line>And now, not knowing what the old man had said,</line>
      <line> My question eagerly did I renew:</line>
      <line>‘How is it that you live, and what is it you do?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He with a smile did then his words repeat,</line>
      <line>And said that, gathering leeches far and wide</line>
      <line>He travelled, stirring thus about his feet</line>
      <line>The waters of the ponds where they abide:</line>
      <line>‘Once I could meet with them on every side,</line>
      <line>But they have dwindled long by slow decay;</line>
      <line>Yet still I persevere, and find them where I may.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While he was talking thus, the lonely place,</line>
      <line> The old man’s shape and speech, all troubled me;</line>
      <line>In my mind’s eye I seemed to see him pace</line>
      <line>About the weary moors continually,</line>
      <line>Wandering about alone and silently.</line>
      <line>While I these thoughts within myself pursued,</line>
      <line>He, having made a pause, the same discourse renewed,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And soon with this he other matter blended –</line>
      <line>Cheerfully uttered, with demeanour kind,</line>
      <line>But stately in the main – and when he ended</line>
      <line>I could have laughed myself to scorn to find</line>
      <line> In that decrepit man so firm a mind.</line>
      <line>‘God’, said I, ‘be my help and stay secure,</line>
      <line>I’ll think of the leech-gatherer on the lonely moor!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>The London Beggar</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How often in the overflowing streets</line>
      <line> Have I gone forwards with the crowd, and said</line>
      <line>Unto myself ‘The face of everyone</line>
      <line>That passes by me is a mystery!’</line>
      <line>Thus have I looked, nor ceased to look, oppressed</line>
      <line>By thoughts of what and whither, when and how,</line>
      <line>Until the shapes before my eyes became</line>
      <line>A second-sight procession such as glides</line>
      <line>Over still mountains, or appears in dreams,</line>
      <line>And all the ballast of familiar life</line>
      <line>(The present and the past, hope, fear, all stays –</line>
      <line>All laws – of acting, thinking, speaking man)</line>
      <line>Went from me, neither knowing me, nor known.</line>
      <line>And once, far travelled in such mood, beyond</line>
      <line>The reach of common indications, lost</line>
      <line>Amid the moving pageant, ’twas my chance</line>
      <line>Abruptly to be smitten with the view</line>
      <line>Of a blind beggar, who, with upright face,</line>
      <line>Stood propped against a wall, upon his chest</line>
      <line>Wearing a written paper to explain</line>
      <line>The story of the man, and who he was.</line>
      <line> My mind did at this spectacle turn round</line>
      <line>As with the might of waters, and it seemed</line>
      <line>To me that in this label was a type</line>
      <line>Or emblem of the utmost that we know</line>
      <line>Both of ourselves and of the universe.</line>
      <line>And on the shape of this unmoving man,</line>
      <line>His fixéd face and sightless eyes, I looked</line>
      <line>As if admonished from another world.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Rime of the Ancyent Marinere, In Seven Parts</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is an ancyent Marinere,</line>
      <line>And he stoppeth one of three:</line>
      <line>‘By thy long grey beard and thy glittering eye</line>
      <line>Now wherefore stoppest me?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The Bridegroom’s doors are opened wide</line>
      <line>And I am next of kin;</line>
      <line>The Guests are met, the Feast is set –</line>
      <line>May’st hear the merry din.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But still he holds the wedding-guest –</line>
      <line>'There was a Ship’, quoth he –</line>
      <line>‘Nay, if thou’st got a laughsome tale,</line>
      <line>Marinere! come with me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He holds him with his skinny hand,</line>
      <line>Quoth he, ‘There was a Ship’ –</line>
      <line> ‘Now get thee hence, thou grey-beard Loon!</line>
      <line>Or my Staff shall make thee skip.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He holds him with his glittering eye –</line>
      <line>The wedding guest stood still</line>
      <line>And listens like a three year’s child;</line>
      <line>The Marinere hath his will.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wedding-guest sate on a stone,</line>
      <line>He cannot chuse but hear –</line>
      <line>And thus spake on that ancyent man,</line>
      <line>The bright-eyed Marinere:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘The Ship was cheered, the Harbour cleared –</line>
      <line>Merrily did we drop</line>
      <line>Below the Kirk, below the Hill,</line>
      <line>Below the Light-house top.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Sun came up upon the left,</line>
      <line>Out of the Sea came he;</line>
      <line>And he shone bright, and on the right</line>
      <line>Went down into the Sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Higher and higher every day,</line>
      <line>Till over the mast at noon’ –</line>
      <line> The wedding-guest here beat his breast,</line>
      <line>For he heard the loud bassoon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Bride hath paced into the Hall,</line>
      <line>Red as a rose is she;</line>
      <line>Nodding their heads before her goes</line>
      <line>The merry Minstralsy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wedding-guest he beat his breast,</line>
      <line>Yet he cannot chuse but hear –</line>
      <line>And thus spake on that ancyent Man,</line>
      <line>The bright-eyed Marinere:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Listen, Stranger! Storm and Wind,</line>
      <line>A Wind and Tempest strong!</line>
      <line>For days and weeks it played us freaks –</line>
      <line>Like Chaff we drove along.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Listen, Stranger! Mist and Snow,</line>
      <line>And it grew wondrous cauld:</line>
      <line>And Ice mast-high came floating by</line>
      <line>As green as Emerauld.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And through the drifts the snowy clifts</line>
      <line>Did send a dismal sheen;</line>
      <line> Ne shapes of men ne beasts we ken –</line>
      <line>The Ice was all between.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Ice was here, the Ice was there,</line>
      <line>The Ice was all around:</line>
      <line>It cracked and growled, and roared and howled –</line>
      <line>Like noises of a swound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length did cross an Albatross,</line>
      <line>Thorough the Fog it came;</line>
      <line>And an it were a Christian Soul,</line>
      <line>We hailed it in God’s name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The Marineres gave it biscuit-worms,</line>
      <line>And round and round it flew;</line>
      <line>The Ice did split with a Thunder-fit,</line>
      <line>The Helmsman steered us through.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
