      <line>And a good south wind sprung up behind,</line>
      <line>The Albatross did follow,</line>
      <line>And every day for food or play</line>
      <line>Came to the Marinere’s hollo!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In mist or cloud on mast or shroud</line>
      <line>It perched for vespers nine,</line>
      <line> Whiles all the night through fog smoke-white</line>
      <line>Glimmered the white moon-shine.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘God save thee, ancyent Marinere!</line>
      <line>From the fiends that plague thee thus –</line>
      <line>Why look’st thou so?’ ‘With my cross-bow</line>
      <line>I shot the Albatross.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Sun came up upon the right,</line>
      <line>Out of the Sea came he;</line>
      <line>And broad as a weft upon the left</line>
      <line>Went down into the Sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And the good south wind still blew behind,</line>
      <line>But no sweet Bird did follow</line>
      <line>Ne any day for food or play</line>
      <line>Came to the Marinere’s hollo!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I had done an hellish thing</line>
      <line>And it would work ’em woe:</line>
      <line>For all averred, I had killed the Bird</line>
      <line>That made the Breeze to blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ne dim ne red, like God’s own head,</line>
      <line>The glorious Sun uprist;</line>
      <line> Then all averred, I had killed the Bird</line>
      <line>That brought the fog and mist.</line>
      <line>’Twas right, said they, such birds to slay</line>
      <line>That bring the fog and mist.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The breezes blew, the white foam flew,</line>
      <line>The furrow followed free:</line>
      <line>We were the first that ever burst</line>
      <line>Into that silent Sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down dropt the breeze, the Sails dropt down,</line>
      <line>’Twas sad as sad could be</line>
      <line>And we did speak only to break</line>
      <line>The silence of the Sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All in a hot and copper sky</line>
      <line>The bloody sun at noon,</line>
      <line>Right up above the mast did stand,</line>
      <line>No bigger than the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Day after day, day after day,</line>
      <line>We stuck, ne breath ne motion,</line>
      <line>As idle as a painted Ship</line>
      <line>Upon a painted Ocean.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Water, water, every where</line>
      <line>And all the boards did shrink;</line>
      <line>Water, water, every where,</line>
      <line>Ne any drop to drink.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The very deeps did rot: O Christ!</line>
      <line>That ever this should be!</line>
      <line>Yea, slimy things did crawl with legs</line>
      <line>Upon the slimy Sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>About, about, in reel and rout</line>
      <line>The Death-fires danced at night;</line>
      <line> The water, like a witch’s oils,</line>
      <line>Burnt green and blue and white.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And some in dreams assuréd were</line>
      <line>Of the Spirit that plagued us so:</line>
      <line>Nine fathom deep he had followed us</line>
      <line>From the Land of Mist and Snow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And every tongue through utter drouth</line>
      <line>Was withered at the root;</line>
      <line>We could not speak – no more than if</line>
      <line>We had been choked with soot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ah wel-a-day! what evil looks</line>
      <line>Had I from old and young;</line>
      <line>Instead of the Cross the Albatross</line>
      <line>About my neck was hung.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw a something in the Sky</line>
      <line>No bigger than my fist;</line>
      <line>At first it seemed a little speck</line>
      <line>And then it seemed a mist:</line>
      <line>It moved and moved, and took at last</line>
      <line>A certain shape, I wist.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A speck, a mist, a shape, I wist!</line>
      <line>And still it nered and nered;</line>
      <line>And, an it dodged a water-sprite,</line>
      <line>It plunged and tacked and veered.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With throat unslacked with black lips baked</line>
      <line>Ne could we laugh, ne wail:</line>
      <line>Then while through drouth all dumb they stood</line>
      <line>I bit my arm and sucked the blood</line>
      <line>And cryed, “A sail! a sail!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With throat unslacked, with black lips baked</line>
      <line> Agape they heared me call:</line>
      <line>Gramercy! they for joy did grin</line>
      <line>And all at once their breath drew in</line>
      <line>As they were drinking all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She doth not tack from side to side –</line>
      <line>Hither to work us weal</line>
      <line>Withouten wind, withouten tide</line>
      <line>She steddies with upright keel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The western wave was all a flame,</line>
      <line>The day was well nigh done!</line>
      <line> Almost upon the western wave</line>
      <line>Rested the broad bright Sun,</line>
      <line>When that strange shape drove suddenly</line>
      <line>Betwixt us and the Sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And strait the Sun was flecked with bars</line>
      <line>(Heaven’s mother send us grace)</line>
      <line>As if through a dungeon grate he peered</line>
      <line>With broad and burning face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas! (thought I, and my heart beat loud)</line>
      <line>How fast she neres and neres!</line>
      <line> Are those her Sails that glance in the Sun</line>
      <line>Like restless gossameres?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Are these her naked ribs, which flecked</line>
      <line>The sun that did behind them peer?</line>
      <line>And are these two all, all the crew,</line>
      <line>That woman and her fleshless Pheere?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His bones were black with many a crack,</line>
      <line>All black and bare, I ween;</line>
      <line>Jet-black and bare, save where with rust</line>
      <line>Of mouldy damps and charnel crust</line>
      <line> They’re patched with purple and green.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her lips are red, her looks are free,</line>
      <line>Her locks are yellow as gold:</line>
      <line>Her skin is as white as leprosy,</line>
      <line>And she is far liker Death than he;</line>
      <line>Her flesh makes the still air cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The naked Hulk alongside came</line>
      <line>And the Twain were playing dice;</line>
      <line>“The Game is done! I’ve won, I’ve won!”</line>
      <line>Quoth she, and whistled thrice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A gust of wind sterte up behind</line>
      <line>And whistled through his bones –</line>
      <line>Through the holes of his eyes and the hole of his mouth</line>
      <line>Half-whistles and half-groans.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With never a whisper in the Sea</line>
      <line>Off darts the Spectre-ship;</line>
      <line>While clombe above the Eastern bar</line>
      <line>The hornéd Moon, with one bright Star</line>
      <line>Almost atween the tips.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One after one by the hornéd Moon</line>
      <line>(Listen, O Stranger! to me)</line>
      <line>Each turned his face with a ghastly pang</line>
      <line>And cursed me with his ee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Four times fifty living men,</line>
      <line>With never a sigh or groan,</line>
      <line>With heavy thump, a lifeless lump</line>
      <line>They dropped down one by one.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their souls did from their bodies fly –</line>
      <line>They fled to bliss or woe –</line>
      <line>And every soul it passed me by,</line>
      <line> Like the whiz of my Cross-bow.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I fear thee, ancyent Marinere!</line>
      <line>I fear thy skinny hand;</line>
      <line>And thou art long and lank and brown</line>
      <line>As is the ribbed Sea-sand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I fear thee and thy glittering eye</line>
      <line>And thy skinny hand so brown’ –</line>
      <line>‘Fear not, fear not, thou wedding guest!</line>
      <line>This body dropt not down.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alone, alone, all all alone</line>
      <line> Alone on the wide wide Sea;</line>
      <line>And Christ would take no pity on</line>
      <line>My soul in agony.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The many men so beautiful,</line>
      <line>And they all dead did lie!</line>
      <line>And a million million slimy things</line>
      <line>Lived on – and so did I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I looked upon the rotting Sea,</line>
      <line>And drew my eyes away;</line>
      <line>I looked upon the eldritch deck,</line>
      <line> And there the dead men lay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I looked to Heaven, and tryed to pray;</line>
      <line>But or ever a prayer had gusht,</line>
      <line>A wicked whisper came and made</line>
      <line>My heart as dry as dust.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I closed my lids and kept them close,</line>
      <line>Till the balls like pulses beat;</line>
      <line>For the sky and the sea, and the sea and the sky</line>
      <line>Lay like a load on my weary eye,</line>
      <line>And the dead were at my feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The cold sweat melted from their limbs,</line>
      <line>Ne rot, ne reek did they;</line>
      <line>The look with which they looked on me,</line>
      <line>Had never passed away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An orphan’s curse would drag to Hell</line>
      <line>A spirit from on high:</line>
      <line>But O! more horrible than that</line>
      <line>Is the curse in a dead man’s eye!</line>
      <line>Seven days, seven nights I saw that curse,</line>
      <line>And yet I could not die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The moving Moon went up the sky</line>
      <line>And no where did abide:</line>
      <line>Softly she was going up</line>
      <line>And a star or two beside –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her beams bemocked the sultry main</line>
      <line>Like morning frosts yspread;</line>
      <line>But where the ship’s huge shadow lay,</line>
      <line>The charméd water burnt alway</line>
      <line>A still and awful red.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beyond the shadow of the ship</line>
      <line> I watched the water-snakes:</line>
      <line>They moved in tracks of shining white;</line>
      <line>And when they reared, the elfish light</line>
      <line>Fell off in hoary flakes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within the shadow of the ship</line>
      <line>I watched their rich attire:</line>
      <line>Blue, glossy green, and velvet black</line>
      <line>They coiled and swam; and every track</line>
      <line>Was a flash of golden fire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O happy living things! no tongue</line>
      <line> Their beauty might declare:</line>
      <line>A spring of love gusht from my heart,</line>
      <line>And I blest them unaware!</line>
      <line>Sure my kind saint took pity on me,</line>
      <line>And I blest them unaware.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The self-same moment I could pray;</line>
      <line>And from my neck so free</line>
      <line>The Albatross fell off, and sank</line>
      <line>Like lead into the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O sleep, it is a gentle thing</line>
      <line> Beloved from pole to pole!</line>
      <line>To Mary-queen the praise be yeven</line>
      <line>She sent the gentle sleep from heaven</line>
      <line>That slid into my soul.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The silly buckets on the deck</line>
      <line>That had so long remained,</line>
      <line>I dreamt that they were filled with dew</line>
      <line>And when I awoke it rained.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My lips were wet, my throat was cold,</line>
      <line>My garments all were dank;</line>
      <line> Sure I had drunken in my dreams</line>
      <line>And still my body drank.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I moved and could not feel my limbs,</line>
      <line>I was so light, almost</line>
      <line>I thought that I had died in sleep,</line>
      <line>And was a blesséd Ghost.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The roaring wind! it roared far off,</line>
      <line>It did not come anear;</line>
      <line>But with its sound it shook the sails</line>
      <line>That were so thin and sere.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The upper air bursts into life,</line>
      <line>And a hundred fire-flags sheen</line>
      <line>To and fro they are hurried about;</line>
      <line>And to and fro, and in and out</line>
      <line>The stars dance on between.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The coming wind doth roar more loud;</line>
      <line>The sails do sigh, like sedge:</line>
      <line>The rain pours down from one black cloud</line>
      <line>And the Moon is at its edge.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hark! hark! the thick black cloud is cleft,</line>
      <line> And the Moon is at its side:</line>
      <line>Like waters shot from some high crag,</line>
      <line>The lightning falls with never a jag,</line>
      <line>A river steep and wide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The strong wind reached the ship: it roared</line>
      <line>And dropped down, like a stone!</line>
      <line>Beneath the lightning and the moon</line>
      <line>The dead men gave a groan.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They groaned, they stirred, they all uprose,</line>
      <line>Ne spake, ne moved their eyes:</line>
      <line> It had been strange, even in a dream</line>
      <line>To have seen those dead men rise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The helmsman steered, the ship moved on;</line>
      <line>Yet never a breeze up-blew;</line>
      <line>The Marineres all ’gan work the ropes,</line>
      <line>Where they were wont to do:</line>
      <line>They raised their limbs like lifeless tools –</line>
      <line>We were a ghastly crew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The body of my brother’s son</line>
      <line>Stood by me knee to knee:</line>
      <line> The body and I pulled at one rope,</line>
      <line>But he said nought to me –</line>
      <line>And I quaked to think of my own voice</line>
      <line>How frightful it would be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The day-light dawned – they dropped their arms,</line>
      <line>And clustered round the mast:</line>
      <line>Sweet sounds rose slowly through their mouths</line>
      <line>And from their bodies passed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Around, around, flew each sweet sound,</line>
      <line>Then darted to the sun:</line>
      <line> Slowly the sounds came back again</line>
      <line>Now mixed, now one by one.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sometimes a-dropping from the sky</line>
      <line>I heard the Lavrock sing;</line>
      <line>Sometimes all little birds that are</line>
      <line>How they seemed to fill the sea and air</line>
      <line>With their sweet jargoning,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now ’twas like all instruments,</line>
      <line>Now like a lonely flute;</line>
      <line>And now it is an angel’s song</line>
      <line> That makes the heavens be mute.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It ceased: yet still the sails made on</line>
      <line>A pleasant noise till noon,</line>
      <line>A noise like of a hidden brook</line>
      <line>In the leafy month of June,</line>
      <line>That to the sleeping woods all night</line>
      <line>Singeth a quiet tune.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Listen, O listen, thou Wedding-guest!’</line>
      <line>‘Marinere! thou hast thy will;</line>
      <line>For that, which comes out of thine eye, doth make</line>
      <line> My body and soul to be still.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Never sadder tale was told</line>
      <line>To a man of woman born:</line>
      <line>Sadder and wiser thou wedding-guest!</line>
      <line>Thou’lt rise to morrow morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Never sadder tale was heard</line>
      <line>By a man of woman born:</line>
      <line>The Marineres all returned to work</line>
      <line>As silent as beforne.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Marineres all ’gan pull the ropes,</line>
      <line> But look at me they n’old:</line>
      <line>Thought I, I am as thin as air –</line>
      <line>They cannot me behold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till noon we silently sailed on</line>
      <line>Yet never a breeze did breathe:</line>
      <line>Slowly and smoothly went the ship</line>
      <line>Moved onward from beneath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Under the keel nine fathom deep</line>
      <line>From the land of mist and snow</line>
      <line>The spirit slid: and it was He</line>
      <line> That made the Ship to go.</line>
      <line>The sails at noon left off their tune</line>
      <line>And the Ship stood still also.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun right up above the mast</line>
      <line>Had fixed her to the ocean:</line>
      <line>But in a minute she ’gan stir</line>
      <line>With a short uneasy motion –</line>
      <line>Backwards and forwards half her length</line>
      <line>With a short uneasy motion.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, like a pawing horse let go,</line>
      <line> She made a sudden bound;</line>
      <line>It flung the blood into my head,</line>
      <line>And I fell into a swound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How long in that same fit I lay,</line>
      <line>I have not to declare;</line>
      <line>But ere my living life returned,</line>
      <line>I heard and in my soul discerned</line>
      <line>Two voices in the air,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“Is it he?” quoth one, “Is this the man?</line>
      <line>By him who died on cross,</line>
      <line>With his cruel bow he layed full low</line>
      <line>The harmless Albatross.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The spirit who bideth by himself</line>
      <line>In the land of mist and snow,</line>
      <line>He loved the bird that loved the man</line>
      <line>Who shot him with his bow.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The other was a softer voice,</line>
      <line>As soft as honey-dew;</line>
      <line>Quoth he, “The man hath penance done,</line>
      <line>And penance more will do.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> “But tell me, tell me! speak again,</line>
      <line>Thy soft response renewing –</line>
      <line>What makes that ship drive on so fast?</line>
      <line>What is the Ocean doing?”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“Still as a Slave before his Lord,</line>
      <line>The Ocean hath no blast:</line>
      <line>His great bright eye most silently</line>
      <line>Up to the moon is cast</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If he may know which way to go,</line>
      <line>For she guides him smooth or grim.</line>
      <line> See, brother, see! how graciously</line>
      <line>She looketh down on him.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“But why drives on that ship so fast</line>
      <line>Withouten wave or wind?”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“The air is cut away before,</line>
      <line>And closes from behind.</line>
      <line>Fly, brother, fly! more high, more high,</line>
      <line>Or we shall be belated;</line>
      <line>For slow and slow that ship will go,</line>
      <line>When the Marinere’s trance is abated.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I woke, and we were sailing on</line>
      <line>As in a gentle weather:</line>
      <line>’Twas night, calm night, the moon was high;</line>
      <line>The dead men stood together.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All stood together on the deck,</line>
      <line>For a charnel-dungeon fitter;</line>
      <line>All fixed on me their stony eyes</line>
      <line>That in the moon did glitter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pang, the curse, with which they died,</line>
      <line>Had never passed away:</line>
      <line> I could not draw my een from theirs</line>
      <line>Ne turn them up to pray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in its time the spell was snapt,</line>
      <line>And I could move my een:</line>
      <line>I looked far-forth, but little saw</line>
      <line>Of what might else be seen,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like one that on a lonely road</line>
      <line>Doth walk in fear and dread,</line>
      <line>And having once turned round, walks on</line>
      <line>And turns no more his head</line>
      <line> Because he knows, a frightful fiend</line>
      <line>Doth close behind him tread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But soon there breathed a wind on me,</line>
      <line>Ne sound ne motion made:</line>
      <line>Its path was not upon the sea</line>
      <line>In ripple or in shade.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It raised my hair, it fanned my cheek,</line>
      <line>Like a meadow-gale of spring –</line>
      <line>It mingled strangely with my fears,</line>
      <line>Yet it felt like a welcoming.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Swiftly, swiftly flew the ship,</line>
      <line>Yet she sailed softly too:</line>
      <line>Sweetly, sweetly blew the breeze –</line>
      <line>On me alone it blew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O dream of joy! is this indeed</line>
      <line>The light-house top I see?</line>
      <line>Is this the Hill? Is this the Kirk?</line>
      <line>Is this mine own countree?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We drifted o’er the Harbour-bar,</line>
      <line>And I with sobs did pray –</line>
      <line> “O let me be awake, my God!</line>
      <line>Or let me sleep alway!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The harbour-bay was clear as glass,</line>
      <line>So smoothly it was strewn!</line>
      <line>And on the bay the moonlight lay,</line>
      <line>And the shadow of the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moonlight bay was white all o’er,</line>
      <line>Till rising from the same,</line>
      <line>Full many shapes, that shadows were,</line>
      <line>Like as of torches came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A little distance from the prow</line>
      <line>Those dark-red shadows were;</line>
      <line>But soon I saw that my own flesh</line>
      <line>Was red as in a glare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I turned my head in fear and dread,</line>
      <line>And by the holy rood,</line>
      <line>The bodies had advanced, and now</line>
      <line>Before the mast they stood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They lifted up their stiff right arms,</line>
      <line>They held them strait and tight;</line>
      <line> And each right-arm burnt like a torch,</line>
      <line>A torch that’s borne upright.</line>
      <line>Their stony eye-balls glittered on</line>
      <line>In the red and smoky light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I prayed and turned my head away</line>
      <line>Forth looking as before.</line>
      <line>There was no breeze upon the bay,</line>
      <line>No wave against the shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The rock shone bright, the kirk no less</line>
      <line>That stands above the rock;</line>
      <line>The moonlight steeped in silentness</line>
      <line>The steady weathercock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the bay was white with silent light,</line>
      <line>Till rising from the same</line>
      <line>Full many shapes, that shadows were,</line>
      <line>In crimson colours came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little distance from the prow</line>
      <line>Those crimson shadows were:</line>
      <line>I turned my eyes upon the deck –</line>
      <line>O Christ! what saw I there?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Each corse lay flat, lifeless and flat;</line>
      <line>And by the Holy rood</line>
      <line>A man all light, a seraph-man,</line>
      <line>On every corse there stood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This seraph-band, each waved his hand –</line>
      <line>It was a heavenly sight –</line>
      <line>They stood as signals to the land,</line>
      <line>Each one a lovely light:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This seraph-band, each waved his hand,</line>
      <line>No voice did they impart –</line>
      <line> No voice; but O! the silence sank,</line>
      <line>Like music on my heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Eftsones I heard the dash of oars,</line>
      <line>I heard the pilot’s cheer;</line>
      <line>My head was turned perforce away</line>
      <line>And I saw a boat appear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then vanished all the lovely lights;</line>
      <line>The bodies rose anew:</line>
      <line>With silent pace, each to his place,</line>
      <line>Came back the ghastly crew.</line>
      <line> The wind, that shade nor motion made,</line>
      <line>On me alone it blew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pilot, and the pilot’s boy</line>
      <line>I heard them coming fast:</line>
      <line>Dear Lord in Heaven! it was a joy,</line>
      <line>The dead men could not blast.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw a third – I heard his voice:</line>
      <line>It is the Hermit good!</line>
      <line>He singeth loud his godly hymns</line>
      <line>That he makes in the wood.</line>
      <line> He’ll shrieve my soul, he’ll wash away</line>
      <line>The Albatross’s blood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This Hermit good lives in that wood</line>
      <line>Which slopes down to the Sea.</line>
      <line>How loudly his sweet voice he rears!</line>
      <line>He loves to talk with Marineres</line>
      <line>That come from a far Countree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He kneels at morn and noon and eve –</line>
      <line>He hath a cushion plump:</line>
      <line>It is the moss, that wholly hides</line>
      <line> The rotted old Oak-stump.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Skiff-boat neerd, I heard them talk:</line>
      <line>“Why, this is strange, I trow!</line>
      <line>Where are those lights so many and fair</line>
      <line>That signal made but now?”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“Strange, by my faith!” the Hermit said –</line>
      <line>“And they answered not our cheer.</line>
      <line>The planks look warped, and see those sails</line>
      <line>How thin they are and sere!</line>
      <line>I never saw aught like to them</line>
      <line> Unless perchance it were</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The skeletons of leaves that lag</line>
      <line>My forest brook along:</line>
      <line>When the Ivy-tod is heavy with snow,</line>
      <line>And the Owlet whoops to the wolf below</line>
      <line>That eats the she-wolf’s young.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“Dear Lord! it has a fiendish look”,</line>
      <line>The Pilot made reply,</line>
      <line>“I am a-feared.” “Push on, push on!”</line>
      <line>Said the Hermit cheerily.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The Boat came closer to the Ship,</line>
      <line>But I ne spake ne stirred!</line>
      <line>The Boat came close beneath the Ship,</line>
      <line>And strait a sound was heard!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Under the water it rumbled on,</line>
      <line>Still louder and more dread:</line>
      <line>It reached the Ship, it split the bay;</line>
      <line>The Ship went down like lead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Stunned by that loud and dreadful sound,</line>
      <line>Which sky and ocean smote,</line>
      <line> Like one that hath been seven days drowned</line>
      <line>My body lay afloat,</line>
      <line>But, swift as dreams, myself I found</line>
      <line>Within the Pilot’s boat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upon the whirl, where sank the Ship,</line>
      <line>The boat spun round and round;</line>
      <line>And all was still, save that the hill</line>
      <line>Was telling of the sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I moved my lips; the Pilot shrieked</line>
      <line>And fell down in a fit;</line>
      <line> The Holy Hermit raised his eyes</line>
      <line>And prayed where he did sit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took the oars – the Pilot’s boy,</line>
      <line>Who now doth crazy go,</line>
      <line>Laughed loud and long, and all the while</line>
      <line>His eyes went to and fro:</line>
      <line>“Ha! ha!” quoth he “full plain I see</line>
      <line>The devil knows how to row.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now all in mine own Countree</line>
      <line>I stood on the firm land!</line>
      <line>The Hermit stepped forth from the boat,</line>
      <line>And scarcely he could stand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>“O shrieve me, shrieve me, holy Man!”</line>
      <line>The Hermit crossed his brow –</line>
      <line>“Say quick”, quoth he, “I bid thee say</line>
      <line>What manner of man art thou?”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forthwith this frame of mine was wrenched</line>
      <line>With a woeful agony,</line>
      <line>Which forced me to begin my tale</line>
      <line>And then it left me free.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Since then at an uncertain hour,</line>
      <line>Now oftimes and now fewer,</line>
      <line>That anguish comes and makes me tell</line>
      <line>My ghastly aventure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I pass, like night, from land to land;</line>
      <line>I have strange power of speech;</line>
      <line>The moment that his face I see</line>
      <line>I know the man that must hear me –</line>
      <line>To him my tale I teach.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What loud uproar bursts from that door!</line>
      <line> The Wedding-guests are there,</line>
      <line>But in the Garden-bower the Bride</line>
      <line>And Bride-maids singing are –</line>
      <line>And hark the little Vesper-bell</line>
      <line>Which biddeth me to prayer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Wedding-guest! this soul hath been</line>
      <line>Alone on a wide wide sea:</line>
      <line>So lonely ’twas, that God himself</line>
      <line>Scarce seeméd there to be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O sweeter than the Marriage-feast,</line>
      <line> ’Tis sweeter far to me</line>
      <line>To walk together to the Kirk</line>
      <line>With a goodly company.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To walk together to the Kirk</line>
      <line>And all together pray,</line>
      <line>While each to his great father bends,</line>
      <line>Old men, and babes, and loving friends,</line>
      <line>And Youths, and Maidens gay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell, farewell! but this I tell</line>
      <line> To thee, thou Wedding-guest!</line>
      <line>He prayeth well who loveth well</line>
      <line>Both man and bird and beast.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He prayeth best who loveth best,</line>
      <line>All things both great and small:</line>
      <line>For the dear God, who loveth us,</line>
      <line>He made and loveth all.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Marinere, whose eye is bright,</line>
      <line>Whose beard with age is hoar,</line>
      <line>Is gone; and now the Wedding-guest</line>
      <line> Turned from the bridegroom’s door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He went, like one that hath been stunned</line>
      <line>And is of sense forlorn:</line>
      <line>A sadder and a wiser man</line>
      <line>He rose the morrow morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1803</date>
    <title>Pains of Sleep</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ere on my bed my limbs I lay,</line>
      <line>It hath not been my use to pray</line>
      <line>With moving lips or bended knees;</line>
      <line>But silently, by slow degrees,</line>
      <line> My spirit I to love compose,</line>
      <line>In humble trust mine eyelids close</line>
      <line>With reverential resignation,</line>
      <line>No wish conceived, no thought expressed,</line>
      <line>Only a sense of supplication –</line>
      <line>A sense o’er all my soul impressed</line>
      <line>That I am weak, yet not unblest,</line>
      <line>Since in me, round me, everywhere</line>
      <line>Eternal Strength and Wisdom are.</line>
      <line>But yester-night I prayed aloud</line>
      <line> In anguish and in agony,</line>
      <line>Upstarting from the fiendish crowd</line>
      <line>Of shapes and thoughts that tortured me:</line>
      <line>A lurid light, a trampling throng,</line>
      <line>Sense of intolerable wrong,</line>
      <line>And whom I scorned, those only strong –</line>
      <line>Thirst of revenge, the powerless will</line>
      <line>Still baffled, and yet burning still!</line>
      <line>Desire with loathing strangely mixed</line>
      <line>On wild or hateful objects fixed!</line>
      <line> Fantastic passions! maddening brawl!</line>
      <line>And shame and terror over all!</line>
      <line>Deeds to be hid which were not hid,</line>
      <line>Which all confused I could not know</line>
      <line>Whether I suffered, or I did;</line>
      <line>For all seemed guilt, remorse or woe –</line>
      <line>My own or others’ – still the same</line>
      <line>Life-stifling fear, soul-stifling shame!</line>
      <line>So two nights passed. The night’s dismay</line>
      <line>Saddened and stunned the coming day:</line>
      <line> Sleep, the wide blessing, seemed to me</line>
      <line>Distemper’s worst calamity.</line>
      <line>The third night, when my own loud scream</line>
      <line>Had waked me from the fiendish dream,</line>
      <line>O’ercome with sufferings strange and wild</line>
      <line>I wept as I had been a child;</line>
      <line>And having thus by tears subdued</line>
      <line>My anguish to a milder mood,</line>
      <line>Such punishments, I said, were due</line>
      <line>To natures deepliest stained with sin</line>
      <line> (For aye entempesting anew</line>
      <line>The unfathomable Hell within),</line>
      <line>The horror of their deeds to view,</line>
      <line>To know and loathe, yet wish and do!</line>
      <line>Such griefs with such men well agree,</line>
      <line>But wherefore, wherefore fall on me?</line>
      <line>To be beloved is all I need,</line>
      <line>And whom I love, I love indeed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS CAMPBELL</author>
    <date>1809</date>
    <title>Lord Ullin’s Daughter</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A chieftain to the Highlands bound</line>
      <line>Cries, ‘Boatman, do not tarry!</line>
      <line>And I’ll give thee a silver pound</line>
      <line>To row us o’er the ferry.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Now who be ye would cross Lochgyle,</line>
      <line>This dark and stormy water?’</line>
      <line>‘Oh, I’m the chief of Ulva’s isle,</line>
      <line>And this Lord Ullin’s daughter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And fast before her father’s men</line>
      <line>Three days we’ve fled together,</line>
      <line>For should he find us in the glen</line>
      <line>My blood would stain the heather!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His horsemen hard behind us ride;</line>
      <line>Should they our steps discover,</line>
      <line> Then who will cheer my bonny bride</line>
      <line>When they have slain her lover?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Outspoke the hardy Highland wight,</line>
      <line>‘I’ll go, my chief! I’m ready –</line>
      <line>It is not for your silver bright,</line>
      <line>But for your winsome lady!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, by my word! the bonny bird</line>
      <line>In danger shall not tarry;</line>
      <line>So, though the waves are raging white,</line>
      <line>I’ll row you o’er the ferry!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> By this the storm grew loud apace,</line>
      <line>The water-wraith was shrieking;</line>
      <line>And in the scowl of heaven each face</line>
      <line>Grew dark as they were speaking.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But still, as wilder blew the wind,</line>
      <line>And as the night grew drearer,</line>
      <line>Adown the glen rode arméd men,</line>
      <line>Their trampling sounded nearer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O haste thee, haste!’ the lady cries,</line>
      <line>‘Though tempests round us gather,</line>
      <line> I’ll meet the raging of the skies</line>
      <line>But not an angry father!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The boat has left a stormy land,</line>
      <line>A stormy sea before her,</line>
      <line>When, oh! too strong for human hand,</line>
      <line>The tempest gathered o’er her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And still they rowed amidst the roar</line>
      <line>Of waters fast prevailing:</line>
      <line>Lord Ullin reached that fatal shore,</line>
      <line>His wrath was changed to wailing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For sore dismayed, through storm and shade,</line>
      <line>His child he did discover:</line>
      <line>One lovely hand she stretched for aid,</line>
      <line>And one was round her lover.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Come back! come back!’ he cried in grief</line>
      <line>Across the stormy water,</line>
      <line>‘And I’ll forgive your Highland chief,</line>
      <line>My daughter! oh my daughter!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas vain – the loud waves lashed the shore,</line>
      <line>Return or aid preventing;</line>
      <line> The waters wild went o’er his child,</line>
      <line>And he was left lamenting.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY BRYAN</author>
    <date>1815</date>
    <title>The Visit</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Here’, said my guide,</line>
      <line>‘The poor crazed inmates of yon mansion stray;</line>
      <line>Their keepers watch their moody wanderings,</line>
      <line>Yet oft in these wild heights unseen they lurk</line>
      <line>Eluding all research.’ I trembled at the tale –</line>
      <line>Oh frightful haunts! – lest a strange form,</line>
      <line>With sudden rage and demon strength possessed,</line>
      <line>Swift from yon jutting crag with fell intent</line>
      <line>And horrid yell might rush, and hurl me down</line>
      <line>The immense below. Urged by these terrors, soon</line>
      <line> We gained the sullen dwelling – drear retreat!</line>
      <line>The massy doors, the iron-grated lights,</line>
      <line>Appalled with very strength – I trembled there</line>
      <line>E’en in the terrible security.</line>
      <line>Then fearful wrecks of storms I ill endured</line>
      <line>Unmeet to greet a sympathizing guest:</line>
      <line>The shriek, the long loud laugh, the desperate din</line>
      <line>I scarce forbore to join. I clasped my dewy brows</line>
      <line>Insensate of the pressure, chilling cold.</line>
      <line>I thought, ‘Or death, or madness, soon will seize</line>
      <line> My trembling frame, and I shall never more</line>
      <line>Behold aught fair, or good, or blest, or dear.’</line>
      <line>Instant I clasped them all! Oh, what a change</line>
      <line>To love, and hope, and joy, one tender look –</line>
      <line>One precious word of recognition – gave!</line>
      <line>Now, all her own sweet self in loveliness</line>
      <line>(Restored by kindest care, and medicinal aid),</line>
      <line>I saw my gentle friend – mutual surprise</line>
      <line>Of unexpected bliss! Enquiry o’er,</line>
      <line>And calmed the sudden joy, ‘’Tis years’, she said,</line>
      <line> ‘Dark years, since we have met – dark years of grief –</line>
      <line>And dark the future too – but these will pass,</line>
      <line>These too will pass, and so we’ll meet in Heaven.</line>
      <line>Nay, here we’ll meet if, kind, my soon return</line>
      <line>Thou’lt wait amongst our native bowers – shelters</line>
      <line>From many a storm, when, rambling far, we saw</line>
      <line>The gathering clouds with fear – fond maids! – nor shunned</line>
      <line>The darker storms that early whelmed us o’er.</line>
      <line>One more request, and we will say farewell</line>
      <line>Lest night o’ertake thee.</line>
      <line>Dost thou remember,</line>
      <line> Six years ago (past a few warmer suns</line>
      <line>To give the summer ripeness) one evening</line>
      <line>We lingered in the copse, plucking wild flowers</line>
      <line>To weave us wreathes beseeming more, we said,</line>
      <line>The brows of simple maids, than garden flowers</line>
      <line>Flaunting so proud in artificial hues.</line>
      <line>Capricious idlers! so we moralized,</line>
      <line>‘And this, for one afar!’ you cried, bending</line>
      <line>A pliant branch, on whose high top you hung</line>
      <line>A varied garland. Withdrawn the gentle force,</line>
      <line> Upsprung in air it waved its modest tints</line>
      <line>So prettily, we, smiling, marked the while</line>
      <line>’Till, roused by distant sounds threatening and rude,</line>
      <line>We turned, and, through the mazy thicket</line>
      <line>(Every repelling branch or bent, or torn),</line>
      <line>Heedless of hurt, a tattered creature, wild,</line>
      <line>Haggard and wan, pressed on to where we stood</line>
      <line>Silent and still with fear – nor time for flight!</line>
      <line>In wrathful mood mad Kattern hailed us loud,</line>
      <line>Then you, with feigned composure, forward stepped:</line>
      <line>“This to Kate – sweet flowers for her! Does any</line>
      <line>Harm poor Kate – aught ail her?” Relenting, pleased,</line>
      <line>She took the fragrant gift, muttered and passed.</line>
      <line>Poor Kate, rude boys had worried her to rage –</line>
      <line>Harmless else, and sometimes happy too, for</line>
      <line>Kate had long forgotten him who wronged her.</line>
      <line>Blest forgetfulness! Oh falsest man,</line>
      <line>Forgetting thee!’</line>
      <line>Then in those softest eyes</line>
      <line>Gleamed wandering fires – fires not their own – but soon</line>
      <line>To tears they changed. ‘How much’, she said, ‘in fond</line>
      <line> And idle talk I, wandering, lose myself,</line>
      <line>Detaining thee. Tomorrow at this hour</line>
      <line>Cross that low copse, and climb the ascent beyond,</line>
      <line>So gay with yellow broom and purple heath;</line>
      <line>I to yon sullen heights will bend my way,</line>
      <line>And, if the day is fair, I have a glass</line>
      <line>Will show thee there – thy white kerchief waving.</line>
      <line>Though indistinct thy form I see, this sign</line>
      <line>Will mark it thine – sweet consciousness! Again</line>
      <line>Each day, return – the dearest hour I’ll know</line>
      <line> Till that I meet thee there! Farewell, farewell!’</line>
      <line>‘Each word of thine is treasured – oh, farewell!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>The Prisoner of Chillon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My hair is grey, but not with years –</line>
      <line>Nor grew it white</line>
      <line>In a single night,</line>
      <line>As men’s have grown from sudden fears;</line>
      <line> My limbs are bowed, though not with toil</line>
      <line>But rusted with a vile repose,</line>
      <line>For they have been a dungeon’s spoil,</line>
      <line>And mine has been the fate of those</line>
      <line>To whom the goodly earth and air</line>
      <line>Are banned, and barred – forbidden fare!</line>
      <line>But this was for my father’s faith</line>
      <line>I suffered chains and courted death –</line>
      <line>That father perished at the stake</line>
      <line>For tenets he would not forsake,</line>
      <line> And for the same his lineal race</line>
      <line>In darkness found a dwelling place!</line>
      <line>We were seven, who now are one:</line>
      <line>Six in youth, and one in age,</line>
      <line>Finished as they had begun,</line>
      <line>Proud of Persecution’s rage.</line>
      <line>One in fire, and two in field,</line>
      <line>Their belief with blood have sealed,</line>
      <line>Dying as their father died,</line>
      <line>For the God their foes denied;</line>
      <line> Three were in a dungeon cast,</line>
      <line>Of whom this wreck is left the last!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There are seven pillars of gothic mould</line>
      <line>In Chillon’s dungeons deep and old,</line>
      <line>There are seven columns, massy and grey,</line>
      <line>Dim with a dull imprisoned ray</line>
      <line>(A sunbeam which hath lost its way,</line>
      <line>And through the crevice and the cleft</line>
      <line>Of the thick wall is fallen and left,</line>
      <line>Creeping o’er the floor so damp,</line>
      <line> Like a marsh’s meteor lamp),</line>
      <line>And in each pillar there is a ring,</line>
      <line>And in each ring there is a chain –</line>
      <line>That iron is a cankering thing,</line>
      <line>For in these limbs its teeth remain,</line>
      <line>With marks that will not wear away,</line>
      <line>Till I have done with this new day,</line>
      <line>Which now is painful to these eyes</line>
      <line>Which have not seen the sun so rise</line>
      <line>For years – I cannot count them o’er,</line>
      <line> I lost their long and heavy score</line>
      <line>When my last brother drooped and died,</line>
      <line>And I lay living by his side.</line>
      <line>They chained us each to a column-stone,</line>
      <line>And we were three – yet, each alone!</line>
      <line>We could not move a single pace,</line>
      <line>We could not see each other’s face</line>
      <line>But with that pale and livid light</line>
      <line>That made us strangers in our sight:</line>
      <line>And thus together – yet apart –</line>
      <line> Fettered in hand but joined in heart,</line>
      <line>’Twas still some solace in the dearth</line>
      <line>Of the pure elements of earth,</line>
      <line>To hearken to each other’s speech,</line>
      <line>And each turn comforter to each</line>
      <line>With some new hope, or legend old,</line>
      <line>Or song heroically bold –</line>
      <line>But even these at length grew cold.</line>
      <line>Our voices took a dreary tone,</line>
      <line>An echo of the dungeon-stone,</line>
      <line> A grating sound, not full and free</line>
      <line>As they of yore were wont to be –</line>
      <line>It might be fancy, but to me</line>
      <line>They never sounded like our own!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I was the eldest of the three,</line>
      <line>And to uphold and cheer the rest</line>
      <line>I ought to do – and did my best –</line>
      <line>And each did well in his degree.</line>
      <line>The youngest, whom my father loved,</line>
      <line>Because our mother’s brow was given</line>
      <line> To him, with eyes as blue as heaven –</line>
      <line>For him my soul was sorely moved.</line>
      <line>And truly might it be distressed</line>
      <line>To see such bird in such a nest;</line>
      <line>For he was beautiful as day –</line>
      <line>When day was beautiful to me</line>
      <line>As to young eagles, being free –</line>
      <line>A polar day, which will not see</line>
      <line>A sunset till its summer’s gone,</line>
      <line>Its sleepless summer of long light,</line>
      <line> The snow-clad offspring of the sun!</line>
      <line>And thus he was as pure and bright,</line>
      <line>And in his natural spirit gay,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With tears for nought but others’ ills –</line>
      <line>And then they flowed like mountain-rills,</line>
      <line>Unless he could assuage the woe</line>
      <line>Which he abhorred to view below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The other was as pure of mind,</line>
      <line>But formed to combat with his kind:</line>
      <line>Strong in his frame, and of a mood</line>
      <line> Which ’gainst the world in war had stood,</line>
      <line>And perished in the foremost rank</line>
      <line>With joy – but not in chains to pine!</line>
      <line>His spirit withered with their clank,</line>
      <line>I saw it silently decline</line>
      <line>(And so perchance in sooth did mine,</line>
      <line>But yet I forced it on to cheer</line>
      <line>Those relics of a home so dear).</line>
      <line>He was a hunter of the hills,</line>
      <line>Had followed there the deer and wolf;</line>
      <line>To him this dungeon was a gulf,</line>
      <line>And fettered feet the worst of ills.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lake Leman lies by Chillon’s walls:</line>
      <line>A thousand feet in depth below</line>
      <line>Its massy waters meet and flow –</line>
      <line>Thus much the fathom-line was sent</line>
      <line>From Chillon’s snow-white battlement,</line>
      <line>Which round about the wave enthralls!</line>
      <line>A double dungeon wall and wave</line>
      <line>Have made – and like a living grave.</line>
      <line> Below the surface of the lake</line>
      <line>The dark vault lies wherein we lay –</line>
      <line>We heard it ripple night and day –</line>
      <line>Sounding o’er our heads it knocked,</line>
      <line>And I have felt the winter’s spray</line>
      <line>Wash through the bars when winds were high</line>
      <line>And wanton in the happy sky;</line>
      <line>And then the very rock hath rocked,</line>
      <line>And I have felt it shake, unshocked,</line>
      <line>Because I could have smiled to see</line>
      <line> The death that would have set me free.</line>
      <line>I said my nearer brother pined,</line>
      <line>I said his mighty heart declined,</line>
      <line>He loathed and put away his food –</line>
      <line>It was not that ’twas coarse and rude,</line>
      <line>For we were used to hunter’s fare</line>
      <line>And for the like had little care:</line>
      <line>The milk drawn from the mountain-goat</line>
      <line>Was changed for water from the moat,</line>
      <line>Our bread was such as captives’ tears</line>
      <line> Have moistened many a thousand years</line>
      <line>Since man first pent his fellow men</line>
      <line>Like brutes within an iron den –</line>
      <line>But what were these to us or him?</line>
      <line>These wasted not his heart or limb!</line>
      <line>My brother’s soul was of that mould</line>
      <line>Which in a palace had grown cold</line>
      <line>Had his free breathing been denied</line>
      <line>The range of the steep mountain’s side –</line>
      <line>But why delay the truth? He died.</line>
      <line> I saw, and could not hold his head,</line>
      <line>Nor reach his dying hand – nor dead,</line>
      <line>Though hard I strove (but strove in vain)</line>
      <line>To rend and gnash my bonds in twain.</line>
      <line>He died – and they unlocked his chain</line>
      <line>And scooped for him a shallow grave</line>
      <line>Even from the cold earth of our cave.</line>
      <line>I begged them, as a boon, to lay</line>
      <line>His corse in dust whereon the day</line>
      <line>Might shine – it was a foolish thought,</line>
      <line> But then within my brain it wrought</line>
      <line>That even in death his freeborn breast</line>
      <line>In such a dungeon could not rest.</line>
      <line>I might have spared my idle prayer –</line>
      <line>They coldly laughed, and laid him there:</line>
      <line>The flat and turfless earth above</line>
      <line>The being we so much did love.</line>
      <line>His empty chain above it leant –</line>
      <line>Such murder’s fitting monument!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But he, the favourite and the flower,</line>
      <line> Most cherished since his natal hour,</line>
      <line>His mother’s image in fair face,</line>
      <line>The infant love of all his race,</line>
      <line>His martyred father’s dearest thought,</line>
      <line>My latest care (for whom I sought</line>
      <line>To hoard my life, that his might be</line>
      <line>Less wretched now, and one day free) –</line>
      <line>He, too, who yet had held untired</line>
      <line>A spirit natural or inspired –</line>
      <line>He, too, was struck, and day by day</line>
      <line> Was withered on the stalk away.</line>
      <line>Oh, God! it is a fearful thing</line>
      <line>To see the human soul take wing</line>
      <line>In any shape, in any mood:</line>
      <line>I’ve seen it rushing forth in blood,</line>
      <line>I’ve seen it on the breaking ocean</line>
      <line>Strive with a swoln convulsive motion,</line>
      <line>I’ve seen the sick and ghastly bed</line>
      <line>Of sin, delirious with its dread.</line>
      <line>But these were horrors – this was woe</line>
      <line> Unmixed with such – but sure and slow.</line>
      <line>He faded, and so calm and meek,</line>
      <line>So softly worn, so sweetly weak,</line>
      <line>So tearless, yet so tender – kind,</line>
      <line>And grieved for those he left behind;</line>
      <line>With all the while a cheek whose bloom</line>
      <line>Was as a mockery of the tomb,</line>
      <line>Whose tints as gently sunk away</line>
      <line>As a departing rainbow’s ray;</line>
      <line>An eye of most transparent light,</line>
      <line> That almost made the dungeon bright;</line>
      <line>And not a word of murmur, not</line>
      <line>A groan o’er his untimely lot –</line>
      <line>A little talk of better days,</line>
      <line>A little hope my own to raise,</line>
      <line>For I was sunk in silence, lost</line>
      <line>In this last loss, of all the most.</line>
      <line>And then the sighs he would suppress</line>
      <line>Of fainting Nature’s feebleness,</line>
      <line>More slowly drawn, grew less and less:</line>
      <line>I listened, but I could not hear;</line>
      <line>I called, for I was wild with fear;</line>
      <line>I knew ’twas hopeless, but my dread</line>
      <line>Would not be thus admonishéd.</line>
      <line>I called, and thought I heard a sound –</line>
      <line>I burst my chain with one strong bound,</line>
      <line>And rushed to him! I found him not!</line>
      <line>I only stirred in this black spot,</line>
      <line>I only lived, I only drew</line>
      <line>The accurséd breath of dungeon-dew –</line>
      <line> The last, the sole, the dearest link</line>
      <line>Between me and the eternal brink,</line>
      <line>Which bound me to my failing race,</line>
      <line>Was broken in this fatal place.</line>
      <line>One on the earth, and one beneath –</line>
      <line>My brothers – both had ceased to breathe.</line>
      <line>I took that hand which lay so still</line>
      <line>(Alas, my own was full as chill),</line>
      <line>I had not strength to stir, or strive,</line>
      <line>But felt that I was still alive –</line>
      <line> A frantic feeling, when we know</line>
      <line>That what we love shall ne’er be so.</line>
      <line>I know not why</line>
      <line>I could not die;</line>
      <line>I had no earthly hope – but faith,</line>
      <line>And that forbade a selfish death.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What next befell me then and there</line>
      <line>I know not well – I never knew –</line>
      <line>First came the loss of light, and air,</line>
      <line>And then of darkness too!</line>
      <line> I had no thought, no feeling – none –</line>
      <line>Among the stones I stood a stone,</line>
      <line>And was (scarce conscious what I wist)</line>
      <line>As shrubless crags within the mist.</line>
      <line>For all was blank, and bleak, and grey:</line>
      <line>It was not night – it was not day,</line>
      <line>It was not even the dungeon-light,</line>
      <line>So hateful to my heavy sight,</line>
      <line>But vacancy absorbing space,</line>
      <line>And fixédness, without a place!</line>
      <line> There were no stars, no earth, no time,</line>
      <line>No check, no change, no good, no crime –</line>
      <line>But silence, and a stirless breath</line>
      <line>Which neither was of life nor death:</line>
      <line>A sea of stagnant idleness,</line>
      <line>Blind, boundless, mute, and motionless!</line>
      <line>A light broke in upon my brain,</line>
      <line>It was the carol of a bird –</line>
      <line>It ceased, and then it came again,</line>
      <line>The sweetest song ear ever heard,</line>
      <line> And mine was thankful till my eyes</line>
      <line>Ran over with the glad surprise,</line>
      <line>And they that moment could not see</line>
      <line>I was the mate of misery!</line>
      <line>But then by dull degrees came back</line>
      <line>My senses to their wonted track;</line>
      <line>I saw the dungeon-walls and floor</line>
      <line>Close slowly round me as before;</line>
      <line>I saw the glimmer of the sun</line>
      <line>Creeping as it before had done,</line>
      <line> But through the crevice where it came</line>
      <line>That bird was perched, as fond and tame,</line>
      <line>And tamer than upon the tree –</line>
      <line>A lovely bird, with azure wings</line>
      <line>And song that said a thousand things,</line>
      <line>And seemed to say them all for me!</line>
      <line>I never saw its like before,</line>
      <line>I ne’er shall see its likeness more:</line>
      <line>It seemed like me to want a mate,</line>
      <line>But was not half so desolate,</line>
      <line> And it was come to love me when</line>
      <line>None lived to love me so again,</line>
      <line>And cheering from my dungeon’s brink,</line>
      <line>Had brought me back to feel and think.</line>
      <line>I know not if it late were free,</line>
      <line>Or broke its cage to perch on mine,</line>
      <line>But knowing well captivity,</line>
      <line>Sweet bird, I could not wish for thine!</line>
      <line>Or if it were, in wingéd guise,</line>
      <line>A visitant from Paradise;</line>
      <line> For (Heaven forgive that thought, the while</line>
      <line>Which made me both to weep and smile)</line>
      <line>I sometimes deemed that it might be</line>
      <line>My brother’s soul come down to me!</line>
      <line>But then at last away it flew,</line>
      <line>And then ’twas mortal well I knew,</line>
      <line>For he would never thus have flown</line>
      <line>And left me twice so doubly lone –</line>
      <line>Lone as the corse within its shroud,</line>
      <line>Lone as a solitary cloud,</line>
      <line> A single cloud on a sunny day,</line>
      <line>While all the rest of heaven is clear,</line>
      <line>A frown upon the atmosphere</line>
      <line>That hath no business to appear</line>
      <line>When skies are blue, and earth is gay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A kind of change came in my fate,</line>
      <line>My keepers grew compassionate;</line>
      <line>I know not what had made them so</line>
      <line>(They were inured to sights of woe),</line>
      <line>But so it was – my broken chain</line>
      <line>With links unfastened did remain,</line>
      <line>And it was liberty to stride</line>
      <line>Along my cell from side to side,</line>
      <line>And up and down, and then athwart,</line>
      <line>And tread it over every part;</line>
      <line>And round the pillars one by one,</line>
      <line>Returning where my walk begun,</line>
      <line>Avoiding only, as I trod,</line>
      <line>My brothers’ graves without a sod;</line>
      <line>For if I thought with heedless tread</line>
      <line> My step profaned their lowly bed,</line>
      <line>My breath came gaspingly and thick,</line>
      <line>And my crushed heart felt blind and sick.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I made a footing in the wall –</line>
      <line>It was not therefrom to escape,</line>
      <line>For I had buried one and all</line>
      <line>Who loved me in a human shape,</line>
      <line>And the whole earth would henceforth be</line>
      <line>A wider prison unto me!</line>
      <line>No child, no sire, no kin had I,</line>
      <line> No partner in my misery;</line>
      <line>I thought of this, and I was glad,</line>
      <line>For thought of them had made me mad;</line>
      <line>But I was curious to ascend</line>
      <line>To my barred windows, and to bend</line>
      <line>Once more, upon the mountains high,</line>
      <line>The quiet of a loving eye.</line>
      <line>I saw them – and they were the same,</line>
      <line>They were not changed like me in frame;</line>
      <line>I saw their thousand years of snow</line>
      <line> On high – their wide long lake below,</line>
      <line>And the blue Rhone in fullest flow!</line>
      <line>I heard the torrents leap and gush</line>
      <line>O’er channelled rock and broken bush;</line>
      <line>I saw the white-walled distant town,</line>
      <line>And whiter sails go skimming down;</line>
      <line>And then there was a little isle,</line>
      <line>Which in my very face did smile,</line>
      <line>The only one in view –</line>
      <line>A small green isle, it seemed no more,</line>
      <line> Scarce broader than my dungeon floor,</line>
      <line>But in it there were three tall trees,</line>
      <line>And o’er it blew the mountain-breeze,</line>
      <line>And by it there were waters flowing,</line>
      <line>And on it there were young flowers growing,</line>
      <line>Of gentle breath and hue.</line>
      <line>The fish swam by the castle wall,</line>
      <line>And they seemed joyous each and all;</line>
      <line>The eagle rode the rising blast,</line>
      <line>Methought he never flew so fast</line>
      <line> As then to me he seemed to fly!</line>
      <line>And then new tears came in my eye,</line>
      <line>And I felt troubled – and would fain</line>
      <line>I had not left my recent chain;</line>
      <line>And when I did descend again,</line>
      <line>The darkness of my dim abode</line>
      <line>Fell on me as a heavy load.</line>
      <line>It was as is a new-dug grave,</line>
      <line>Closing o’er one we sought to save –</line>
      <line>And yet my glance, too much opprest,</line>
      <line> Had almost need of such a rest.</line>
      <line>It might be months, or years, or days</line>
      <line>(I kept no count, I took no note,</line>
      <line>I had no hope my eyes to raise,</line>
      <line>And clear them of their dreary mote),</line>
      <line>At last men came to set me free.</line>
      <line>I asked not why, and recked not where;</line>
      <line>It was at length the same to me,</line>
      <line>Fettered or fetterless to be –</line>
      <line>I learned to love despair!</line>
      <line> And thus when they appeared at last,</line>
      <line>And all my bonds aside were cast,</line>
      <line>These heavy walls to me had grown</line>
      <line>A hermitage – and all my own!</line>
      <line>And half I felt as they were come</line>
      <line>To tear me from a second home:</line>
      <line>With spiders I had friendship made,</line>
      <line>And watched them in their sullen trade,</line>
      <line>Had seen the mice by moonlight play,</line>
      <line>And why should I feel less than they?</line>
      <line> We were all inmates of one place,</line>
      <line>And I, the monarch of each race,</line>
      <line>Had power to kill – yet, strange to tell</line>
      <line>In quiet we had learned to dwell.</line>
      <line>My very chains and I grew friends,</line>
      <line>So much a long communion tends</line>
      <line>To make us what we are – even, I</line>
      <line>Regained my freedom with a sigh.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>from Isabella, or The Pot of Basil</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the mid-days of autumn, on their eves,</line>
      <line>The breath of Winter comes from far away,</line>
      <line>And the sick west continually bereaves</line>
      <line>Of some bold tinge, and plays a roundelay</line>
      <line>Of death among the bushes and the leaves,</line>
      <line>To make all bare before he dares to stray</line>
      <line> From his north cavern. So sweet Isabel</line>
      <line>By gradual decay from beauty fell,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Because Lorenzo came not. Oftentimes</line>
      <line>She asked her brothers, with an eye all pale,</line>
      <line>Striving to be itself, what dungeon-climes</line>
      <line>Could keep him off so long? They spake a tale</line>
      <line>Time after time, to quiet her. Their crimes</line>
      <line>Came on them, like a smoke from Hinnom’s vale;</line>
      <line>And every night in dreams they groaned aloud,</line>
      <line>To see their sister in her snowy shroud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And she had died in drowsy ignorance,</line>
      <line>But for a thing more deadly dark than all –</line>
      <line>It came like a fierce potion, drunk by chance,</line>
      <line>Which saves a sick man from the feathered pall</line>
      <line>For some few gasping moments – like a lance,</line>
      <line>Waking an Indian from his cloudy hall</line>
      <line>With cruel pierce, and bringing him again</line>
      <line>Sense of the gnawing fire at heart and brain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was a vision: in the drowsy gloom,</line>
      <line>The dull of midnight, at her couch’s foot</line>
      <line> Lorenzo stood, and wept. The forest tomb</line>
      <line>Had marred his glossy hair which once could shoot</line>
      <line>Lustre into the sun, and put cold doom</line>
      <line>Upon his lips, and taken the soft lute</line>
      <line>From his lorn voice, and past his loaméd ears</line>
      <line>Had made a miry channel for his tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Strange sound it was when the pale shadow spake,</line>
      <line>For there was striving in its piteous tongue</line>
      <line>To speak as when on earth it was awake –</line>
      <line>And Isabella on its music hung.</line>
      <line> Languor there was in it, and tremulous shake,</line>
      <line>As in a palsied Druid’s harp unstrung;</line>
      <line>And through it moaned a ghostly under-song,</line>
      <line>Like hoarse night-gusts sepulchral briars among.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Its eyes, though wild, were still all dewy bright</line>
      <line>With love, and kept all phantom fear aloof</line>
      <line>From the poor girl by magic of their light,</line>
      <line>The while it did unthread the horrid woof</line>
      <line>Of the late darkened time – the murderous spite</line>
      <line>Of pride and avarice – the dark pine roof</line>
      <line> In the forest – and the sodden turféd-dell,</line>
      <line>Where, without any word, from stabs he fell –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Saying moreover, ‘Isabel, my sweet!</line>
      <line>Red whortle-berries droop above my head,</line>
      <line>And a large flint-stone weighs upon my feet;</line>
      <line>Around me beeches and high chestnuts shed</line>
      <line>Their leaves and prickly nuts; a sheepfold-bleat</line>
      <line>Comes from beyond the river to my bed –</line>
      <line>Go, shed one tear upon my heather-bloom,</line>
      <line>And it shall comfort me within the tomb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am a shadow now, alas! alas!</line>
      <line>Upon the skirts of human-nature dwelling</line>
      <line>Alone. I chant alone the holy mass,</line>
      <line>While little sounds of life are round me knelling,</line>
      <line>And glossy bees at noon do fieldward pass,</line>
      <line>And many a chapel-bell the hour is telling,</line>
      <line>Paining me through! Those sounds grow strange to me,</line>
      <line>And thou art distant in humanity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know what was, I feel full well what is –</line>
      <line>And I should rage, if spirits could go mad!</line>
      <line> Though I forget the taste of earthly bliss,</line>
      <line>That paleness warms my grave, as though I had</line>
      <line>A seraph chosen from the bright abyss</line>
      <line>To be my spouse. Thy paleness makes me glad;</line>
      <line>Thy beauty grows upon me, and I feel</line>
      <line>A greater love through all my essence steal.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The spirit mourned ‘Adieu’, dissolved, and left</line>
      <line>The atom-darkness in a slow turmoil –</line>
      <line>As when, of healthful midnight-sleep bereft,</line>
      <line>Thinking on ruggéd hours and fruitless toil,</line>
      <line> We put our eyes into a pillowy cleft,</line>
      <line>And see the spangly gloom froth up and boil!</line>
      <line>It made sad Isabella’s eyelids ache,</line>
      <line>And in the dawn she started up awake –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Ha! ha!’ said she, ‘I knew not this hard life,</line>
      <line>I thought the worst was simple misery;</line>
      <line>I thought some fate with pleasure or with strife</line>
      <line>Portioned us – happy days, or else to die.</line>
      <line>But there is crime: a brother’s bloody knife!</line>
      <line>Sweet spirit, thou hast schooled my infancy:</line>
      <line> I’ll visit thee for this, and kiss thine eyes,</line>
      <line>And greet thee morn and even in the skies.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the full morning came, she had devised</line>
      <line>How she might secret to the forest hie;</line>
      <line>How she might find the clay, so dearly prized,</line>
      <line>And sing to it one latest lullaby;</line>
      <line>How her short absence might be unsurmised,</line>
      <line>While she the inmost of the dream would try.</line>
      <line>Resolved, she took with her an agéd nurse,</line>
      <line>And went into that dismal forest-hearse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> See, as they creep along the river-side,</line>
      <line>How she doth whisper to that agéd dame,</line>
      <line>And, after looking round the champaign wide,</line>
      <line>Shows her a knife. ‘What feverous hectic flame</line>
      <line>Burns in thee, child? What good can thee betide,</line>
      <line>That thou shouldst smile again?’ The evening came,</line>
      <line>And they had found Lorenzo’s earthy bed:</line>
      <line>The flint was there, the berries at his head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who hath not loitered in a green churchyard,</line>
      <line>And let his spirit, like a demon-mole,</line>
      <line> Work through the clayey soil and gravel hard,</line>
      <line>To see skull, coffined bones, and funeral-stole;</line>
      <line>Pitying each form that hungry Death hath marred,</line>
      <line>And filling it once more with human soul?</line>
      <line>Ah, this is holiday to what was felt</line>
      <line>When Isabella by Lorenzo knelt!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She gazed into the fresh-thrown mould, as though</line>
      <line>One glance did fully all its secrets tell.</line>
      <line>Clearly she saw, as other eyes would know</line>
      <line>Pale limbs at bottom of a crystal well.</line>
      <line> Upon the murderous spot she seemed to grow,</line>
      <line>Like to a native lily of the dell –</line>
      <line>Then with her knife, all sudden, she began</line>
      <line>To dig more fervently than misers can.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Soon she turned up a soiléd glove, whereon</line>
      <line>Her silk had played in purple fantasies –</line>
      <line>She kissed it with a lip more chill than stone,</line>
      <line>And put it in her bosom, where it dries</line>
      <line>And freezes utterly unto the bone</line>
      <line>Those dainties made to still an infant’s cries!</line>
      <line> Then ’gan she work again – nor stayed her care,</line>
      <line>But to throw back at times her veiling hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That old nurse stood beside her wondering,</line>
      <line>Until her heart felt pity to the core</line>
      <line>At sight of such a dismal labouring,</line>
      <line>And so she kneeléd, with her locks all hoar,</line>
      <line>And put her lean hands to the horrid thing.</line>
      <line>Three hours they laboured at this travail sore;</line>
      <line>At last they felt the kernel of the grave,</line>
      <line>And Isabella did not stamp and rave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ah, wherefore all this wormy circumstance?</line>
      <line>Why linger at the yawning tomb so long?</line>
      <line>Oh for the gentleness of old romance,</line>
      <line>The simple plaining of a minstrel’s song!</line>
      <line>Fair reader, at the old tale take a glance,</line>
      <line>For here, in truth, it doth not well belong</line>
      <line>To speak – oh turn thee to the very tale,</line>
      <line>And taste the music of that vision pale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With duller steel than the Perséan sword</line>
      <line>They cut away no formless monster’s head,</line>
      <line> But one whose gentleness did well accord</line>
      <line>With death, as life. The ancient harps have said</line>
      <line>Love never dies, but lives, immortal Lord.</line>
      <line>If Love impersonate was ever dead,</line>
      <line>Pale Isabella kissed it, and low moaned.</line>
      <line>’Twas Love, cold – dead indeed – but not dethroned.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In anxious secrecy they took it home,</line>
      <line>And then the prize was all for Isabel!</line>
      <line>She calmed its wild hair with a golden comb,</line>
      <line>And all around each eye’s sepulchral cell</line>
      <line>Pointed each fringéd lash. The smearéd loam</line>
      <line>With tears as chilly as a dripping well</line>
      <line>She drenched away – and still she combed, and kept</line>
      <line>Sighing all day – and still she kissed, and wept.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then in a silken scarf – sweet with the dews</line>
      <line>Of precious flowers plucked in Araby,</line>
      <line>And divine liquids come with odorous ooze</line>
      <line>Through the cold serpent-pipe refreshfully –</line>
      <line>She wrapped it up, and for its tomb did choose</line>
      <line>A garden-pot, wherein she laid it by</line>
      <line> And covered it with mould, and o’er it set</line>
      <line>Sweet basil, which her tears kept ever wet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And she forgot the stars, the moon, and sun,</line>
      <line>And she forgot the blue above the trees,</line>
      <line>And she forgot the dells where waters run,</line>
      <line>And she forgot the chilly autumn breeze –</line>
      <line>She had no knowledge when the day was done,</line>
      <line>And the new morn she saw not, but in peace</line>
      <line>Hung over her sweet basil evermore,</line>
      <line>And moistened it with tears unto the core.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And so she ever fed it with thin tears,</line>
      <line>Whence thick, and green, and beautiful it grew,</line>
      <line>So that it smelt more balmy than its peers</line>
      <line>Of basil-tufts in Florence; for it drew</line>
      <line>Nurture besides, and life, from human fears –</line>
      <line>From the fast-mouldering head there shut from view –</line>
      <line>So that the jewel, safely casketed,</line>
      <line>Came forth, and in perfuméd leafits spread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Melancholy, linger here awhile!</line>
      <line>Oh Music, Music, breathe despondingly!</line>
      <line> Oh Echo, Echo, from some sombre isle</line>
      <line>Unknown, Lethean, sigh to us, oh sigh!</line>
      <line>Spirits in grief, lift up your heads, and smile –</line>
      <line>Lift up your heads, sweet spirits, heavily,</line>
      <line>And make a pale light in your cypress-glooms,</line>
      <line>Tinting with silver wan your marble tombs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Moan hither, all ye syllables of woe,</line>
      <line>From the deep throat of sad Melpomene!</line>
      <line>Through bronzéd lyre in tragic order go,</line>
      <line>And touch the strings into a mystery!</line>
      <line> Sound mournfully upon the winds and low,</line>
      <line>For simple Isabel is soon to be</line>
      <line>Among the dead. She withers, like a palm</line>
      <line>Cut by an Indian for its juicy balm.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
