      <line>Oh leave the palm to wither by itself,</line>
      <line>Let not quick winter chill its dying hour!</line>
      <line>It may not be – those Baälites of pelf,</line>
      <line>Her brethren, noted the continual shower</line>
      <line>From her dead eyes; and many a curious elf,</line>
      <line>Among her kindred, wondered that such dower</line>
      <line> Of youth and beauty should be thrown aside</line>
      <line>By one marked out to be a noble’s bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, furthermore, her brethren wondered much</line>
      <line>Why she sat drooping by the basil green,</line>
      <line>And why it flourished, as by magic touch –</line>
      <line>Greatly they wondered what the thing might mean.</line>
      <line>They could not surely give belief that such</line>
      <line>A very nothing would have power to wean</line>
      <line>Her from her own fair youth and pleasures gay –</line>
      <line>And even remembrance of her love’s delay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Therefore they watched a time when they might sift</line>
      <line>This hidden whim – and long they watched in vain,</line>
      <line>For seldom did she go to chapel-shrift,</line>
      <line>And seldom felt she any hunger-pain;</line>
      <line>And when she left, she hurried back, as swift</line>
      <line>As bird on wing to breast its eggs again,</line>
      <line>And, patient as a hen-bird, sat her there</line>
      <line>Beside her basil, weeping through her hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet they contrived to steal the basil-pot,</line>
      <line>And to examine it in secret place.</line>
      <line> The thing was vile with green and livid spot,</line>
      <line>And yet they knew it was Lorenzo’s face –</line>
      <line>The guerdon of their murder they had got,</line>
      <line>And so left Florence in a moment’s space,</line>
      <line>Never to turn again. Away they went,</line>
      <line>With blood upon their heads, to banishment!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Melancholy, turn thine eyes away!</line>
      <line>Oh Music, Music, breathe despondingly!</line>
      <line>Oh Echo, Echo, on some other day,</line>
      <line>From isles Lethean, sigh to us, oh sigh!</line>
      <line> Spirits of grief, sing not your ‘Well-a-way!’</line>
      <line>For Isabel, sweet Isabel, will die –</line>
      <line>Will die a death too lone and incomplete,</line>
      <line>Now they have ta’en away her basil sweet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Piteous, she looked on dead and senseless things,</line>
      <line>Asking for her lost basil amorously;</line>
      <line>And with melodious chuckle in the strings</line>
      <line>Of her lorn voice, she oftentimes would cry</line>
      <line>After the pilgrim in his wanderings</line>
      <line>To ask him where her basil was, and why</line>
      <line> ’Twas hid from her. ‘For cruel ’tis’, said she,</line>
      <line>‘To steal my basil-pot away from me!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so she pined, and so she died forlorn,</line>
      <line>Imploring for her basil to the last.</line>
      <line>No heart was there in Florence but did mourn</line>
      <line>In pity of her love, so overcast;</line>
      <line>And a sad ditty, of this story born,</line>
      <line>From mouth to mouth through all the country passed.</line>
      <line>Still is the burden sung: ‘Oh cruelty,</line>
      <line>To steal my basil-pot away from me!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>The Shipwreck (from Don Juan II)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>At half-past eight o’clock, booms, hencoops, spars,</line>
      <line>And all things, for a chance, had been cast loose</line>
      <line>That still could keep afloat the struggling tars –</line>
      <line>For yet they strove, although of no great use:</line>
      <line>There was no light in heaven but a few stars,</line>
      <line>The boats put off o’ercrowded with their crews;</line>
      <line>She gave a heel, and then a lurch to port,</line>
      <line>And, going down head foremost – sunk, in short.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then rose from sea to sky the wild farewell,</line>
      <line>Then shrieked the timid, and stood still the brave;</line>
      <line>Then some leaped overboard with dreadful yell,</line>
      <line>As eager to anticipate their grave;</line>
      <line>And the sea yawned around her like a hell,</line>
      <line>And down she sucked with her the whirling wave,</line>
      <line> Like one who grapples with his enemy,</line>
      <line>And strives to strangle him before he die…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Juan got into the long-boat, and there</line>
      <line>Contrived to help Pedrillo to a place.</line>
      <line>It seemed as if they had exchanged their care,</line>
      <line>For Juan wore the magisterial face</line>
      <line> Which courage gives, while poor Pedrillo’s pair</line>
      <line>Of eyes were crying for their owner’s case:</line>
      <line>Battista, though (a name called shortly ‘Tita’)</line>
      <line>Was lost by getting at some aqua-vita.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pedro, his valet, too, he tried to save,</line>
      <line>But the same cause, conducive to his loss,</line>
      <line>Left him so drunk, he jumped into the wave</line>
      <line>As o’er the cutter’s edge he tried to cross,</line>
      <line>And so he found a wine-and-watery grave;</line>
      <line>They could not rescue him although so close,</line>
      <line> Because the sea ran higher every minute,</line>
      <line>And for the boat – the crew kept crowding in it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A small old spaniel, which had been Don Jóse’s</line>
      <line>(His father’s), whom he loved, as ye may think,</line>
      <line>For on such things the memory reposes</line>
      <line>With tenderness, stood howling on the brink,</line>
      <line>Knowing – dogs have such intellectual noses! –</line>
      <line>No doubt, the vessel was about to sink,</line>
      <line>And Juan caught him up, and ere he stepped</line>
      <line>Off, threw him in, then after him he leapt…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis said that persons living on annuities</line>
      <line>Are longer-lived than others – God knows why,</line>
      <line> Unless to plague the grantors – yet so true it is</line>
      <line>That some, I really think, do never die!</line>
      <line>Of any creditors the worst a Jew it is,</line>
      <line>And that’s their mode of furnishing supply:</line>
      <line>In my young days they lent me cash that way,</line>
      <line>Which I found very troublesome to pay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis thus with people in an open boat,</line>
      <line>They live upon the love of life, and bear</line>
      <line>More than can be believed, or even thought,</line>
      <line>And stand like rocks the tempest’s wear and tear;</line>
      <line> And hardship still has been the sailor’s lot,</line>
      <line>Since Noah’s ark went cruising here and there –</line>
      <line>She had a curious crew as well as cargo,</line>
      <line>Like the first old Greek privateer, the Argo.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But man is a carnivorous production</line>
      <line>And must have meals, at least one meal a day;</line>
      <line>He cannot live, like woodcocks, upon suction,</line>
      <line>But, like the shark and tiger, must have prey –</line>
      <line>Although his anatomical construction</line>
      <line>Bears vegetables in a grumbling way,</line>
      <line> Your labouring-people think beyond all question,</line>
      <line>Beef, veal, and mutton, better for digestion.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus it was with this our hapless crew,</line>
      <line>For on the third day there came on a calm,</line>
      <line>And though at first their strength it might renew</line>
      <line>(And lying on their weariness like balm,</line>
      <line>Lulled them like turtles sleeping on the blue</line>
      <line>Of ocean), when they woke they felt a qualm</line>
      <line>And fell all ravenously on their provision,</line>
      <line>Instead of hoarding it with due precision.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The consequence was easily foreseen –</line>
      <line>They ate up all they had, and drank their wine,</line>
      <line>In spite of all remonstrances, and then</line>
      <line>On what, in fact, next day were they to dine?</line>
      <line>They hoped the wind would rise, these foolish men!</line>
      <line>And carry them to shore – these hopes were fine,</line>
      <line>But as they had but one oar, and that brittle,</line>
      <line>It would have been more wise to save their victual!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fourth day came, but not a breath of air,</line>
      <line>And Ocean slumbered like an unweaned child:</line>
      <line> The fifth day, and their boat lay floating there –</line>
      <line>The sea and sky were blue, and clear, and mild –</line>
      <line>With their one oar (I wish they had had a pair)</line>
      <line>What could they do? And hunger’s rage grew wild!</line>
      <line>So Juan’s spaniel, spite of his entreating,</line>
      <line>Was killed, and portioned out for present eating.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the sixth day they fed upon his hide,</line>
      <line>And Juan, who had still refused, because</line>
      <line>The creature was his father’s dog that died,</line>
      <line>Now feeling all the vulture in his jaws,</line>
      <line> With some remorse received (though first denied)</line>
      <line>As a great favour one of the forepaws,</line>
      <line>Which he divided with Pedrillo, who</line>
      <line>Devoured it, longing for the other too.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The seventh day, and no wind – the burning sun</line>
      <line>Blistered and scorched, and, stagnant on the sea,</line>
      <line>They lay like carcasses; and hope was none,</line>
      <line>Save in the breeze that came not! Savagely</line>
      <line>They glared upon each other – all was done,</line>
      <line>Water, and wine, and food – and you might see</line>
      <line> The longings of the cannibal arise</line>
      <line>(Although they spoke not) in their wolfish eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length one whispered his companion, who</line>
      <line>Whispered another, and thus it went round,</line>
      <line>And then into a hoarser murmur grew</line>
      <line>(An ominous, and wild, and desperate sound),</line>
      <line>And when his comrade’s thought each sufferer knew,</line>
      <line>’Twas but his own, suppressed till now, he found –</line>
      <line>And out they spoke of lots for flesh and blood,</line>
      <line>And who should die to be his fellow’s food.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But ere they came to this, they that day shared</line>
      <line>Some leathern caps, and what remained of shoes;</line>
      <line>And then they looked around them, and despaired,</line>
      <line>And none to be the sacrifice would choose:</line>
      <line>At length the lots were torn up, and prepared,</line>
      <line>But of materials that much shock the Muse –</line>
      <line>Having no paper, for the want of better,</line>
      <line>They took by force from Juan, Julia’s letter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lots were made, and marked, and mixed, and handed,</line>
      <line>In silent horror, and their distribution</line>
      <line> Lulled even the savage hunger which demanded,</line>
      <line>Like the Promethean vulture, this pollution.</line>
      <line>None in particular had sought or planned it,</line>
      <line>’Twas Nature gnawed them to this resolution,</line>
      <line>By which none were permitted to be neuter –</line>
      <line>And the lot fell on Juan’s luckless tutor.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He but requested to be bled to death:</line>
      <line>The surgeon had his instruments, and bled</line>
      <line>Pedrillo, and so gently ebbed his breath</line>
      <line>You hardly could perceive when he was dead.</line>
      <line>He died as born, a Catholic in faith,</line>
      <line>Like most in the belief in which they’re bred,</line>
      <line>And first a little crucifix he kissed,</line>
      <line>And then held out his jugular and wrist.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The surgeon, as there was no other fee,</line>
      <line>Had his first choice of morsels for his pains;</line>
      <line>But being thirstiest at the moment, he</line>
      <line>Preferred a draught from the fast-flowing veins.</line>
      <line>Part was divided, part thrown in the sea,</line>
      <line>And such things as the entrails and the brains</line>
      <line> Regaled two sharks, who followed o’er the billow –</line>
      <line>The sailors ate the rest of poor Pedrillo.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sailors ate him, all save three or four</line>
      <line>Who were not quite so fond of animal food;</line>
      <line>To these was added Juan who, before,</line>
      <line>Refusing his own spaniel, hardly could</line>
      <line>Feel now his appetite increased much more –</line>
      <line>’Twas not to be expected that he should,</line>
      <line>Even in extremity of their disaster,</line>
      <line>Dine with them on his pastor and his master.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ’Twas better that he did not; for, in fact,</line>
      <line>The consequence was awful in the extreme:</line>
      <line>For they, who were most ravenous in the act,</line>
      <line>Went raging mad. Lord! how they did blaspheme,</line>
      <line>And foam and roll, with strange convulsions racked,</line>
      <line>Drinking salt-water like a mountain-stream,</line>
      <line>Tearing, and grinning, howling, screeching, swearing,</line>
      <line>And, with hyaena-laughter, died despairing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their numbers were much thinned by this infliction,</line>
      <line>And all the rest were thin enough, Heaven knows;</line>
      <line> And some of them had lost their recollection,</line>
      <line>Happier than they who still perceived their woes;</line>
      <line>But others pondered on a new dissection,</line>
      <line>As if not warned sufficiently by those</line>
      <line>Who had already perished, suffering madly,</line>
      <line>For having used their appetites so sadly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And next they thought upon the master’s mate,</line>
      <line>As fattest; but he saved himself, because,</line>
      <line>Besides being much averse from such a fate,</line>
      <line>There were some other reasons: the first was,</line>
      <line> He had been rather indisposed of late –</line>
      <line>And that which chiefly proved his saving clause,</line>
      <line>Was a small present made to him at Cadiz,</line>
      <line>By general subscription of the ladies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of poor Pedrillo something still remained,</line>
      <line>But was used sparingly – some were afraid,</line>
      <line>And others still their appetites constrained,</line>
      <line>Or but at times a little supper made –</line>
      <line>All except Juan, who throughout abstained,</line>
      <line>Chewing a piece of bamboo, and some lead</line>
      <line> At length they caught two boobies, and a noddy,</line>
      <line>And then they left off eating the dead body.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if Pedrillo’s fate should shocking be,</line>
      <line>Remember Ugolino condescends</line>
      <line>To eat the head of his arch-enemy</line>
      <line>The moment after he politely ends</line>
      <line>His tale; if foes be food in Hell, at sea</line>
      <line>’Tis surely fair to dine upon our friends,</line>
      <line>When shipwreck’s short allowance grows too scanty,</line>
      <line>Without being much more horrible than Dante.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1826</date>
    <title>The Dream of Eugene Aram</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas in the prime of summer-time,</line>
      <line>An evening calm and cool,</line>
      <line>And four-and-twenty happy boys</line>
      <line>Came bounding out of school:</line>
      <line> There were some that ran, and some that leapt</line>
      <line>Like troutlets in a pool.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away they sped with gamesome minds,</line>
      <line>And souls untouched by sin –</line>
      <line>To a level mead they came, and there</line>
      <line>They drove the wickets in;</line>
      <line>Pleasantly shone the setting sun</line>
      <line>Over the town of Lynn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like sportive deer they coursed about,</line>
      <line>And shouted as they ran –</line>
      <line> Turning to mirth all things of earth,</line>
      <line>As only boyhood can;</line>
      <line>But the Usher sat remote from all,</line>
      <line>A melancholy man.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His hat was off, his vest apart,</line>
      <line>To catch Heaven’s blesséd breeze,</line>
      <line>For a burning thought was in his brow,</line>
      <line>And his bosom ill at ease –</line>
      <line>So he leaned his head on his hands, and read</line>
      <line>The book between his knees.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Leaf after leaf he turned it o’er,</line>
      <line>Nor ever glanced aside;</line>
      <line>For the peace of his soul he read that book</line>
      <line>In the golden eventide –</line>
      <line>Much study had made him very lean,</line>
      <line>And pale, and leaden-eyed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At last he shut the ponderous tome –</line>
      <line>With a fast and fervent grasp</line>
      <line>He strained the dusky covers close,</line>
      <line>And fixed the brazen hasp:</line>
      <line> ‘Oh God, could I so close my mind,</line>
      <line>And clasp it with a clasp!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then leaping on his feet upright,</line>
      <line>Some moody turns he took –</line>
      <line>Now up the mead, then down the mead,</line>
      <line>And past a shady nook –</line>
      <line>And lo, he saw a little boy</line>
      <line>That pored upon a book.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My gentle lad, what is’t you read –</line>
      <line>Romance or fairy-fable?</line>
      <line> Or is it some historic page</line>
      <line>Of kings and crowns unstable?’</line>
      <line>The young boy gave an upward glance:</line>
      <line>‘It is The Death of Abel.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Usher took six hasty strides,</line>
      <line>As smit with sudden pain –</line>
      <line>Six hasty strides beyond the place,</line>
      <line>Then slowly back again –</line>
      <line>And down he sat beside the lad,</line>
      <line>And talked with him of Cain,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And (long since then) of bloody men</line>
      <line>Whose deeds tradition saves:</line>
      <line>Of lonely folk cut off unseen,</line>
      <line>And hid in sudden graves;</line>
      <line>Of horrid stabs, in groves forlorn,</line>
      <line>And murders done in caves;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And how the sprites of injured men</line>
      <line>Shriek upward from the sod,</line>
      <line>Aye, how the ghostly hand will point</line>
      <line>To show the burial-clod,</line>
      <line> And unknown facts of guilty acts</line>
      <line>Are seen in dreams from God!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He told how murderers walk the earth</line>
      <line>Beneath the curse of Cain,</line>
      <line>With crimson clouds before their eyes,</line>
      <line>And flames about their brain –</line>
      <line>For blood has left upon their souls</line>
      <line>Its everlasting stain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And well’ quoth he, ‘I know, for truth,</line>
      <line>Their pangs must be extreme –</line>
      <line> Woe, woe, unutterable woe –</line>
      <line>Who spill life’s sacred stream!</line>
      <line>For why? Methought, last night, I wrought</line>
      <line>A murder in a dream:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One that had never done me wrong</line>
      <line>(A feeble man, and old),</line>
      <line>I led him to a lonely field –</line>
      <line>The moon shone clear and cold –</line>
      <line>Now here, said I, this man shall die,</line>
      <line>And I will have his gold!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Two sudden blows with a ragged stick,</line>
      <line>And one with a heavy stone,</line>
      <line>One hurried gash with a hasty knife –</line>
      <line>And then the deed was done!</line>
      <line>There was nothing lying at my foot</line>
      <line>But lifeless flesh and bone –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nothing but lifeless flesh and bone,</line>
      <line>That could not do me ill,</line>
      <line>And yet I feared him all the more</line>
      <line>For lying there so still:</line>
      <line> There was a manhood in his look</line>
      <line>That murder could not kill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lo, the universal air</line>
      <line>Seemed lit with ghastly flame –</line>
      <line>Ten thousand, thousand dreadful eyes</line>
      <line>Were looking down in blame:</line>
      <line>I took the dead man by his hand,</line>
      <line>And called upon his name!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh God, it made me quake to see</line>
      <line>Such sense within the slain;</line>
      <line>But when I touched the lifeless clay</line>
      <line>The blood gushed out amain –</line>
      <line>For every clot, a burning spot</line>
      <line>Was scorching in my brain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My head was like an ardent coal,</line>
      <line>My heart as solid ice;</line>
      <line>My wretched, wretched soul, I knew,</line>
      <line>Was at the Devil’s price!</line>
      <line>A dozen times I groaned – the Dead</line>
      <line>Had never groaned but twice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And now, from forth the frowning sky,</line>
      <line>From the Heaven’s topmost height,</line>
      <line>I heard a voice – the awful voice</line>
      <line>Of the blood-avenging sprite:</line>
      <line>“Thou guilty man, take up thy dead</line>
      <line>And hide it from my sight!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took the dreary body up,</line>
      <line>And cast it in a stream,</line>
      <line>A sluggish water, black as ink,</line>
      <line>Its depth was so extreme –</line>
      <line> My dearest boy, remember this</line>
      <line>Is nothing but a dream!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down went the corse with hollow plunge</line>
      <line>And vanished in the pool;</line>
      <line>Anon I cleansed my bloody hands,</line>
      <line>And washed my forehead cool –</line>
      <line>And sat among the urchins young</line>
      <line>That evening in the School!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Heaven, to think of their white souls,</line>
      <line>And mine so black and grim!</line>
      <line> I could not share in childish prayer,</line>
      <line>Nor join in evening hymn –</line>
      <line>Like a devil of the pit I seemed,</line>
      <line>Mid holy cherubim!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And peace went with them, one and all,</line>
      <line>And each calm pillow spread,</line>
      <line>But Guilt was my grim chamberlain</line>
      <line>That lighted me to bed,</line>
      <line>And drew my midnight-curtains round</line>
      <line>With fingers bloody red!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> All night I lay in agony,</line>
      <line>In anguish dark and deep;</line>
      <line>My fevered eyes I dared not close,</line>
      <line>But stared aghast at Sleep –</line>
      <line>For Sin had rendered unto her</line>
      <line>The keys of Hell to keep!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All night I lay in agony,</line>
      <line>From weary chime to chime,</line>
      <line>With one besetting horrid hint</line>
      <line>That racked me all the time –</line>
      <line> A mighty yearning, like the first</line>
      <line>Fierce impulse unto crime!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One stern tyrannic thought, that made</line>
      <line>All other thoughts its slave –</line>
      <line>Stronger and stronger every pulse</line>
      <line>Did that temptation crave,</line>
      <line>Still urging me to go and see</line>
      <line>The dead man in his grave!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Heavily I rose up, as soon</line>
      <line>As light was in the sky,</line>
      <line> And sought the black accursed pool</line>
      <line>With a wild misgiving eye –</line>
      <line>And saw the Dead in the river bed,</line>
      <line>For the faithless stream was dry!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Merrily rose the lark, and shook</line>
      <line>The dewdrop from its wing –</line>
      <line>But I never marked its morning-flight,</line>
      <line>I never heard it sing,</line>
      <line>For I was stooping once again</line>
      <line>Under the horrid thing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> With breathless speed, like a soul in chase,</line>
      <line>I took him up and ran –</line>
      <line>There was no time to dig a grave</line>
      <line>Before the day began:</line>
      <line>In a lonesome wood, with heaps of leaves,</line>
      <line>I hid the murdered man.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all that day I read in school,</line>
      <line>But my thought was other-where –</line>
      <line>As soon as the midday task was done,</line>
      <line>In secret I was there:</line>
      <line> And a mighty wind had swept the leaves,</line>
      <line>And still the corse was bare!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then down I cast me on my face,</line>
      <line>And first began to weep,</line>
      <line>For I knew my secret then was one</line>
      <line>The earth refused to keep –</line>
      <line>Or land or sea, though he should be</line>
      <line>Ten thousand fathoms deep!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So wills the fierce avenging sprite,</line>
      <line>Till blood for blood atones!</line>
      <line> Aye, though he’s buried in a cave,</line>
      <line>And trodden down with stones,</line>
      <line>And years have rotted off his flesh –</line>
      <line>The world shall see his bones!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh God, that horrid, horrid dream</line>
      <line>Besets me, now awake:</line>
      <line>Again, again, with dizzy brain,</line>
      <line>The human life I take –</line>
      <line>And my red right hand grows raging hot</line>
      <line>Like Cranmer’s at the stake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And still no peace for the restless clay</line>
      <line>Will wave or mound allow;</line>
      <line>The horrid thing pursues my soul –</line>
      <line>It stands before me now!’</line>
      <line>The fearful boy looked up and saw</line>
      <line>Huge drops upon his brow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That very night, while gentle sleep</line>
      <line>The urchin’s eyelids kissed,</line>
      <line>Two stern-faced men set out from Lynn</line>
      <line>Through the cold and heavy mist;</line>
      <line> And Eugene Aram walked between,</line>
      <line>With gyves upon his wrist.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>Indian Woman’s Death Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down a broad river of the western wilds,</line>
      <line>Piercing thick forest-glooms, a light canoe</line>
      <line>Swept with the current. Fearful was the speed</line>
      <line>Of the frail bark, as by a tempest’s wing</line>
      <line> Borne leaf-like on to where the mist of spray</line>
      <line>Rose with the cataract’s thunder. Yet within,</line>
      <line>Proudly, and dauntlessly, and all alone,</line>
      <line>Save that a babe lay sleeping at her breast,</line>
      <line>A woman stood. Upon her Indian brow</line>
      <line>Sat a strange gladness, and her dark hair waved</line>
      <line>As if triumphantly! She pressed her child</line>
      <line>In its bright slumber to her beating heart,</line>
      <line>And lifted her sweet voice, that rose awhile</line>
      <line>Above the sound of waters, high and clear,</line>
      <line> Wafting a wild proud strain – a song of death:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Roll swiftly to the spirit’s land, thou mighty stream and free!</line>
      <line>Father of ancient waters, roll – and bear our lives with thee!</line>
      <line>The weary bird that storms have tossed would seek the sunshine’s calm,</line>
      <line>And the deer that hath the arrow’s hurt flies to the woods of balm.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Roll on! My warrior’s eye hath looked upon another’s face,</line>
      <line>And mine hath faded from his soul, as fades a moonbeam’s trace:</line>
      <line>My shadow comes not o’er his path, my whisper to his dream,</line>
      <line>He flings away the broken reed – roll swifter yet, thou stream!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The voice that spoke of other days is hushed within his breast,</line>
      <line> But mine its lonely music haunts, and will not let me rest:</line>
      <line>It sings a low and mournful song of gladness that is gone,</line>
      <line>I cannot live without that light – father of waves, roll on!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will he not miss the bounding step that met him from the chase,</line>
      <line>The heart of love that made his home an ever-sunny place,</line>
      <line>The hand that spread the hunter’s board, and decked his couch of yore?</line>
      <line>He will not! Roll, dark foaming stream, on to the better shore!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some blesséd fount amidst the woods of that bright land must flow,</line>
      <line>Whose waters from my soul may lave the memory of this woe;</line>
      <line>Some gentle wind must whisper there, whose breath may waft away</line>
      <line> The burden of the heavy night, the sadness of the day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thou, my babe! though born like me for woman’s weary lot,</line>
      <line>Smile! To that wasting of the heart, my own! I leave thee not –</line>
      <line>Too bright a thing art thou to pine in aching love away –</line>
      <line>Thy mother bears thee far, young fawn! from sorrow and decay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She bears thee to the glorious bowers where none are heard to weep,</line>
      <line>And where the unkind one hath no power again to trouble sleep,</line>
      <line>And where the soul shall find its youth, as wakening from a dream –</line>
      <line>One moment, and that realm is ours! On, on, dark rolling stream!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>She Sat Alone Beside Her Hearth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She sat alone beside her hearth –</line>
      <line>For many nights alone –</line>
      <line>She slept not on the pleasant couch</line>
      <line>Where fragrant herbs were strown.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> At first she bound her raven hair</line>
      <line>With feather and with shell –</line>
      <line>But then she hoped! – at length, like night,</line>
      <line>Around her neck it fell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They saw her wandering mid the woods,</line>
      <line>Lone, with the cheerless dawn,</line>
      <line>And then they said, ‘Can this be her</line>
      <line>We called the Startled Fawn?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her heart was in her large sad eyes,</line>
      <line>Half sunshine and half shade,</line>
      <line> And love – as love first springs to life –</line>
      <line>Of every thing afraid.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The red leaf far more heavily</line>
      <line>Fell down to autumn earth</line>
      <line>Than her light feet, which seemed to move</line>
      <line>To music and to mirth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With the light feet of early youth,</line>
      <line>What hopes and joys depart –</line>
      <line>Ah, nothing like the heavy step</line>
      <line>Betrays the heavy heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> It is a usual history</line>
      <line>That Indian girl could tell:</line>
      <line>Fate sets apart one common doom</line>
      <line>For all who love too well.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The proud, the shy, the sensitive –</line>
      <line>Life has not many such –</line>
      <line>They dearly buy their happiness,</line>
      <line>By feeling it too much.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A stranger to her forest home,</line>
      <line>That fair young stranger came;</line>
      <line> They raised for him the funeral song –</line>
      <line>For him the funeral flame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love sprang from pity, and her arms</line>
      <line>Around his arms she threw;</line>
      <line>She told her father, ‘If he dies,</line>
      <line>Your daughter dieth too!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For her sweet sake they set him free –</line>
      <line>He lingered at her side;</line>
      <line>And many a native song yet tells</line>
      <line>Of that pale stranger’s bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Two years have passed – how much two years</line>
      <line>Have taken in their flight!</line>
      <line>They’ve taken from the lip its smile,</line>
      <line>And from the eye its light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor child! – she was a child in years,</line>
      <line>So timid and so young –</line>
      <line>With what a fond and earnest faith</line>
      <line>To desperate hope she clung!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His eyes grew cold, his voice grew strange</line>
      <line>(They only grew more dear)</line>
      <line> She served him meekly, anxiously,</line>
      <line>With love – half faith, half fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And can a fond and faithful heart</line>
      <line>Be worthless in those eyes</line>
      <line>For which it beats? Ah, woe to those</line>
      <line>Who such a heart despise!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor child! what lonely days she passed,</line>
      <line>With nothing to recall</line>
      <line>But bitter taunts, and careless words,</line>
      <line>And looks more cold than all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Alas for love that sits at home,</line>
      <line>Forsaken, and yet fond –</line>
      <line>The grief that sits beside the hearth,</line>
      <line>Life has no grief beyond!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He left her, but she followed him –</line>
      <line>She thought he could not bear,</line>
      <line>When she had left her home for him,</line>
      <line>To look on her despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Adown the strange and mighty stream</line>
      <line>She took her lonely way:</line>
      <line> The stars at night her pilots were,</line>
      <line>As was the sun by day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet mournfully – how mournfully –</line>
      <line>The Indian looked behind</line>
      <line>When the last sound of voice or step</line>
      <line>Died on the midnight wind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet still adown the gloomy stream</line>
      <line>She plied her weary oar –</line>
      <line>Her husband, he had left their home,</line>
      <line>And it was home no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She found him – but she found in vain –</line>
      <line>He spurned her from his side;</line>
      <line>He said her brow was all too dark</line>
      <line>For her to be his bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She grasped his hands – her own were cold –</line>
      <line>And silent turned away,</line>
      <line>As she had not a tear to shed</line>
      <line>And not a word to say.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And pale as death she reached her boat,</line>
      <line>And guided it along;</line>
      <line> With broken voice she strove to raise</line>
      <line>A melancholy song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>None watched the lonely Indian girl –</line>
      <line>She passed unmarked of all –</line>
      <line>Until they saw her slight canoe</line>
      <line>OApproach the mighty Fall!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upright within that slender boat</line>
      <line>They saw the pale girl stand,</line>
      <line>Her dark hair streaming far behind,</line>
      <line>Upraised her desperate hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The air is filled with shriek and shout:</line>
      <line>They call, but call in vain!</line>
      <line>The boat amid the waters dashed –</line>
      <line>’Twas never seen again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANNA LAETITIA BARBAULD</author>
    <date>1773</date>
    <title>The Mouse’s Petition to Dr Priestley, Found in the Trap where he had been Confined all Night</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, hear a pensive captive’s prayer,</line>
      <line>For liberty that sighs,</line>
      <line>And never let thine heart be shut</line>
      <line>Against the prisoner’s cries!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For here forlorn and sad I sit,</line>
      <line>Within the wiry grate,</line>
      <line>And tremble at the approaching morn</line>
      <line>Which brings impending fate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If e’er thy breast with freedom glowed,</line>
      <line>O And spurned a tyrant’s chain,</line>
      <line>Let not thy strong oppressive force</line>
      <line>A free-born mouse detain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, do not stain with guiltless blood</line>
      <line>Thy hospitable hearth,</line>
      <line> Nor triumph that thy wiles betrayed</line>
      <line>A prize so little worth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The scattered gleanings of a feast</line>
      <line>My scanty meals supply –</line>
      <line>But if thine unrelenting heart</line>
      <line>O That slender boon deny,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cheerful light, the vital air,</line>
      <line>Are blessings widely given;</line>
      <line>Let Nature’s commoners enjoy</line>
      <line>The common gifts of Heaven.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The well-taught philosophic mind</line>
      <line>To all compassion gives;</line>
      <line>Casts round the world an equal eye,</line>
      <line>And feels for all that lives.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If mind, as ancient sages taught,</line>
      <line>O A never-dying flame,</line>
      <line>Still shifts through matter’s varying forms,</line>
      <line>In every form the same,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beware, lest in the worm you crush</line>
      <line>A brother’s soul you find;</line>
      <line> And tremble lest thy luckless hand</line>
      <line>Dislodge a kindred mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or, if this transient gleam of day</line>
      <line>Be all of life we share,</line>
      <line>Let pity plead within thy breast</line>
      <line>O That little all to spare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So may thy hospitable board</line>
      <line>With health and peace be crowned,</line>
      <line>And every charm of heartfelt ease</line>
      <line>Beneath thy roof be found.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> So, when unseen destruction lurks,</line>
      <line>Which mice like men may share,</line>
      <line>May some kind angel clear thy path,</line>
      <line>And break the hidden snare.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANNA LAETITIA BARBAULD</author>
    <date>1773</date>
    <title>from A Summer’s Evening’s Meditation</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis now the hour</line>
      <line>When Contemplation from her sunless haunts</line>
      <line>(The cool damp grotto or the lonely depth</line>
      <line>Of unpierced woods), where, wrapped in solid shade,</line>
      <line>She mused away the gaudy hours of noon</line>
      <line>And fed on thoughts unripened by the sun,</line>
      <line>Moves forward, and with radiant finger points</line>
      <line>To yon blue concave swelled by breath divine,</line>
      <line> Where, one by one, the living eyes of Heaven</line>
      <line>Awake, quick-kindling o’er the face of ether</line>
      <line>One boundless blaze – ten thousand trembling fires</line>
      <line>And dancing lustres – where the unsteady eye,</line>
      <line>Restless and dazzled, wanders unconfined</line>
      <line>O’er all this field of glories! Spacious field,</line>
      <line>And worthy of the Master – he whose hand</line>
      <line>With hieroglyphics older than the Nile</line>
      <line>Inscribed the mystic tablet hung on high</line>
      <line>To public gaze, and said, ‘Adore, oh man,</line>
      <line>The finger of thy God!’</line>
      <line> From what pure wells</line>
      <line>Of milky light, what soft o’erflowing urn,</line>
      <line>Are all these lamps so filled – these friendly lamps</line>
      <line>For ever streaming o’er the azure deep</line>
      <line>To point our path and light us to our home?</line>
      <line>How soft they slide along their lucid spheres,</line>
      <line>And, silent as the foot of time, fulfil</line>
      <line>Their destined courses! Nature’s self is hushed</line>
      <line>And, but a scattered leaf which rustles through</line>
      <line>The thick-wove foliage, not a sound is heard</line>
      <line> To break the midnight air – though the raised ear,</line>
      <line>Intensely listening, drinks in every breath.</line>
      <line>How deep the silence, yet how loud the praise!</line>
      <line>But are they silent all? Or is there not</line>
      <line>A tongue in every star that talks with man</line>
      <line>And woos him to be wise – nor woos in vain?</line>
      <line>This dead of midnight is the noon of thought,</line>
      <line>And wisdom mounts her zenith with the stars.</line>
      <line>At this still hour the self-collected soul</line>
      <line>Turns inward, and beholds a stranger there</line>
      <line> Of high descent, and more than mortal rank:</line>
      <line>An embryo God, a spark of fire divine</line>
      <line>Which must burn on for ages, when the sun</line>
      <line>(Fair transitory creature of a day)</line>
      <line>Has closed his golden eye and, wrapped in shades,</line>
      <line>Forgets his wonted journey through the east.</line>
      <line>Ye citadels of light and seats of gods –</line>
      <line>Perhaps my future home! – from whence the soul,</line>
      <line>Revolving periods past, may oft look back</line>
      <line>With recollected tenderness on all</line>
      <line> The various busy scenes she left below</line>
      <line>(Its deep-laid projects and its strange events),</line>
      <line>As on some fond and doting tale that soothed</line>
      <line>Her infant hours. Oh be it lawful now</line>
      <line>To tread the hallowed circle of your courts,</line>
      <line>And with mute wonder and delighted awe</line>
      <line>Approach your burning confines!</line>
      <line>Seized in thought,</line>
      <line>On fancy’s wild and roving wing I sail,</line>
      <line>From the green borders of the peopled earth</line>
      <line>And the pale moon, her duteous fair attendant;</line>
      <line> From solitary Mars; from the vast orb</line>
      <line>Of Jupiter, whose huge gigantic bulk</line>
      <line>Dances in ether like the lightest leaf –</line>
      <line>To the dim verge, the suburbs of the system,</line>
      <line>Where cheerless Saturn midst her watery moons,</line>
      <line>Girt with a lucid zone, majestic sits</line>
      <line>In gloomy grandeur, like an exiled queen</line>
      <line>Amongst her weeping handmaids.</line>
      <line>Fearless thence</line>
      <line>I launch into the trackless deeps of space</line>
      <line>Where, burning round, ten thousand suns appear</line>
      <line> Of elder beam, which ask no leave to shine</line>
      <line>Of our terrestrial star, nor borrow light</line>
      <line>From the proud regent of our scanty day –</line>
      <line>Sons of the morning, first-born of Creation,</line>
      <line>And only less than Him who marks their track</line>
      <line>And guides their fiery wheels. Here must I stop,</line>
      <line>Or is there aught beyond? What hand unseen</line>
      <line>Impels me onward through the glowing orbs</line>
      <line>Of habitable Nature far remote,</line>
      <line>To the dread confines of eternal night,</line>
      <line> To solitudes of vast unpeopled space,</line>
      <line>The deserts of Creation, wide and wild,</line>
      <line>Where embryo systems and unkindled suns</line>
      <line>Sleep in the womb of chaos?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM COWPER</author>
    <date>1785</date>
    <title>The Winter Evening (Task IV)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Just when our drawing-rooms begin to blaze</line>
      <line>With lights, by clear reflection multiplied</line>
      <line>From many a mirror – in which he of Gath,</line>
      <line>Goliath, might have seen his giant bulk</line>
      <line>Whole, without stooping, towering crest and all –</line>
      <line>My pleasures, too, begin. But me perhaps,</line>
      <line>The glowing hearth may satisfy awhile</line>
      <line>With faint illumination, that uplifts</line>
      <line> The shadow to the ceiling, there by fits</line>
      <line>Dancing uncouthly to the quivering flame.</line>
      <line>Not undelightful is an hour to me</line>
      <line>So spent in parlour-twilight: such a gloom</line>
      <line>Suits well the thoughtful or unthinking mind,</line>
      <line>The mind contemplative, with some new theme</line>
      <line>Pregnant, or indisposed alike to all.</line>
      <line>Laugh ye, who boast your more mercurial powers –</line>
      <line>That never feel a stupor, know no pause,</line>
      <line>Nor need one – I am conscious, and confess,</line>
      <line> Fearless, a soul that does not always think.</line>
      <line>Me oft has fancy, ludicrous and wild,</line>
      <line>Soothed with a waking dream of houses, towers,</line>
      <line>Trees, churches, and strange visages, expressed</line>
      <line>In the red cinders, while with poring eye</line>
      <line>I gazed, myself creating what I saw.</line>
      <line>Nor less amused have I quiescent watched</line>
      <line>The sooty films that play upon the bars,</line>
      <line>Pendulous, and foreboding, in the view</line>
      <line>Of superstition – prophesying still,</line>
      <line> Though still deceived – some stranger’s near approach.</line>
      <line>’Tis thus the understanding takes repose</line>
      <line>In indolent vacuity of thought,</line>
      <line>And sleeps and is refreshed. Meanwhile the face</line>
      <line>Conceals the mood lethargic with a mask</line>
      <line>Of deep deliberation, as the man</line>
      <line>Were tasked to his full strength, absorbed and lost.</line>
      <line>Thus oft, reclined at ease, I lose an hour</line>
      <line>At evening, till at length the freezing blast,</line>
      <line>That sweeps the bolted shutter, summons home</line>
      <line>The recollected powers, and, snapping short</line>
      <line>The glassy threads with which the fancy weaves</line>
      <line>Her brittle toys, restores me to myself.</line>
      <line>How calm is my recess – and how the frost,</line>
      <line>Raging abroad, and the rough wind, endear</line>
      <line>The silence and the warmth within!</line>
      <line>I saw the woods and fields, at close of day,</line>
      <line>A variegated show: the meadows green,</line>
      <line>Though faded; and the lands where lately waved</line>
      <line>The golden harvest, of a mellow brown,</line>
      <line> Upturned so lately by the forceful share.</line>
      <line>I saw far off the weedy fallows smile</line>
      <line>With verdure not unprofitable, grazed</line>
      <line>By flocks, fast feeding and selecting each</line>
      <line>His favourite herb – while all the leafless groves</line>
      <line>That skirt the horizon wore a sable hue,</line>
      <line>Scarce noticed in the kindred dusk of eve.</line>
      <line>Tomorrow brings a change, a total change!</line>
      <line>Which even now – though silently performed,</line>
      <line>And slowly, and by most unfelt – the face</line>
      <line> Of universal Nature undergoes.</line>
      <line>Fast falls a fleecy shower: the downy flakes,</line>
      <line>Descending, and with never-ceasing lapse</line>
      <line>Softly alighting upon all below,</line>
      <line>Assimilate all objects. Earth receives</line>
      <line>Gladly the thickening mantle, and the green</line>
      <line>And tender blade that feared the chilling blast</line>
      <line>Escapes unhurt beneath so warm a veil.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1785</date>
    <title>To a Mouse, On Turning Her Up in Her Nest with the Plough</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wee, sleeket, cowran’, tim’rous beastie,</line>
      <line>O, what a panic’s in thy breastie!</line>
      <line>Thou need na start awa sae hasty</line>
      <line>Wi’ bickering brattle –</line>
      <line> I wad be laith to rin an’ chase thee</line>
      <line>Wi’ murd’ring pattle!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’m truly sorry man’s dominion</line>
      <line>Has broken Nature’s social union,</line>
      <line>An’ justifies that ill opinion</line>
      <line>Which makes thee startle</line>
      <line>At me, thy poor earth-born companion</line>
      <line>An’ fellow-mortal!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I doubt na, whyles, but thou may thieve –</line>
      <line>What then? poor beastie, thou maun live!</line>
      <line> A daimen-icker in a thrave</line>
      <line>’S a sma’ request;</line>
      <line>I’ll get a blessin’ wi’ the lave,</line>
      <line>An’ never miss’t!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy wee-bit housie, too, in ruin –</line>
      <line>Its silly wa’s the win’s are strewin’ –</line>
      <line>An’ naething, now, to big a new ane</line>
      <line>O’ foggage green!</line>
      <line>An’ bleak December’s winds ensuin’,</line>
      <line>Baith snell an’ keen!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thou saw the fields laid bare an’ wast,</line>
      <line>An’ weary winter comin’ fast,</line>
      <line>An’ cozie here, beneath the blast,</line>
      <line>Thou thought to dwell –</line>
      <line>Till crash! the cruel coulter past</line>
      <line>Out thro’ thy cell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That wee-bit heap o’ leaves an’ stibble,</line>
      <line>Has cost thee monie a weary nibble!</line>
      <line>Now thou’s turn’d out, for a’ thy trouble,</line>
      <line>But house or hald,</line>
      <line> To thole the winter’s sleety dribble</line>
      <line>An’ cranreuch cauld!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Mousie, thou art no thy-lane</line>
      <line>In proving foresight may be vain:</line>
      <line>The best laid schemes o’ mice an’ men</line>
      <line>Gang aft agley,</line>
      <line>An’ lea’e us nought but grief an’ pain,</line>
      <line>For promis’d joy!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still, thou art blest compar’d wi’ me:</line>
      <line>The present only toucheth thee,</line>
      <line> But och! I backward cast my e’e</line>
      <line>On prospects drear –</line>
      <line>An’ forward, though I canna see,</line>
      <line>I guess an’ fear!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1795</date>
    <title>The Eolian Harp</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My pensive Sara! – thy soft cheek reclined</line>
      <line>Thus on mine arm, most soothing sweet it is</line>
      <line>To sit beside our cot, our cot o’ergrown</line>
      <line>With white-flowered jasmine and the broad-leaved myrtle</line>
      <line> (Meet emblems they of innocence and love),</line>
      <line>And watch the clouds, that late were rich with light,</line>
      <line>Slow saddening round, and mark the Star of Eve</line>
      <line>Serenely brilliant (such should wisdom be)</line>
      <line>Shine opposite. How exquisite the scents</line>
      <line>Snatched from yon bean-field – and the world so hushed!</line>
      <line>The stilly murmur of the distant sea</line>
      <line>Tells us of silence.</line>
      <line>And that simplest lute,</line>
      <line>Placed lengthways in the clasping casement – hark</line>
      <line>How, by the desultory breeze caressed</line>
      <line> Like some coy maid half yielding to her lover,</line>
      <line>It pours such sweet upbraiding as must needs</line>
      <line>Tempt to repeat the wrong! And now, its strings</line>
      <line>Boldlier swept, the long sequacious notes</line>
      <line>Over delicious surges sink and rise –</line>
      <line>Such a soft floating witchery of sound</line>
      <line>As twilight elfins make, when they at eve</line>
      <line>Voyage on gentle gales from Faery Land,</line>
      <line>Where melodies round honey-dropping flowers</line>
      <line>(Footless and wild, like birds of Paradise)</line>
      <line> Nor pause, nor perch, hovering on untamed wing!</line>
      <line>And thus, my love, as on the midway slope</line>
      <line>Of yonder hill I stretch my limbs at noon,</line>
      <line>Whilst through my half-closed eyelids I behold</line>
      <line>The sunbeams dance like diamonds on the main,</line>
      <line>And tranquil muse upon tranquillity,</line>
      <line>Full many a thought uncalled and undetained,</line>
      <line>And many idle flitting fantasies,</line>
      <line>Traverse my indolent and passive brain –</line>
      <line>As wild and various as the random gales</line>
      <line> That swell and flutter on this subject lute!</line>
      <line>And what if all of animated Nature</line>
      <line>Be but organic harps, diversely framed,</line>
      <line>That tremble into thought as o’er them sweeps,</line>
      <line>Plastic and vast, one intellectual breeze,</line>
      <line>At once the soul of each, and God of all?</line>
      <line>But thy more serious eye a mild reproof</line>
      <line>Darts, oh belovéd woman – nor such thoughts,</line>
      <line>Dim and unhallowed, dost thou not reject –</line>
      <line>And biddest me walk humbly with my God.</line>
      <line> Meek daughter in the family of Christ,</line>
      <line>Well hast thou said – and holily dispraised</line>
      <line>These shapings of the unregenerate mind,</line>
      <line>Bubbles that glitter as they rise and break</line>
      <line>On vain Philosophy’s aye-babbling spring!</line>
      <line>For never guiltless may I speak of him,</line>
      <line>The Incomprehensible, save when with awe</line>
      <line>I praise him, and with faith that inly feels,</line>
      <line>Who with his saving mercies healéd me,</line>
      <line>A sinful and most miserable man,</line>
      <line> Wildered and dark, and gave me to possess</line>
      <line>Peace, and this cot, and thee, heart-honoured maid!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>This Lime-Tree Bower, My Prison</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, they are gone, and here must I remain,</line>
      <line>This lime-tree bower my prison! I have lost</line>
      <line>Such beauties and such feelings as had been</line>
      <line>Most sweet to have remembered, even when age</line>
      <line> Had dimmed my eyes to blindness! They, meanwhile,</line>
      <line>My friends, whom I may never meet again,</line>
      <line>On springy heath along the hilltop edge</line>
      <line>Wander in gladness, and wind down, perchance,</line>
      <line>To that still roaring dell of which I told</line>
      <line>(The roaring dell, o’erwooded, narrow, deep,</line>
      <line>And only speckled by the mid-day sun),</line>
      <line>Where its slim trunk the ash from rock to rock</line>
      <line>Flings arching like a bridge – that branchless ash,</line>
      <line>Unsunned and damp, whose few poor yellow leaves</line>
      <line> Ne’er tremble in the gale, yet tremble still,</line>
      <line>Fanned by the waterfall! And there my friends</line>
      <line>Behold the dark-green file of long lank weeds,</line>
      <line>That all at once – a most fantastic sight! –</line>
      <line>Still nod and drip beneath the dripping edge</line>
      <line>Of the dim clay-stone.</line>
      <line>Now my friends emerge</line>
      <line>Beneath the wide wide heaven, and view again</line>
      <line>The many-steepled tract magnificent</line>
      <line>Of hilly fields and meadows, and the sea,</line>
      <line>With some fair bark, perhaps, which lightly touches</line>
      <line> The slip of smooth clear blue betwixt two isles</line>
      <line>Of purple shadow! Yes, they wander on</line>
      <line>In gladness all; but thou, methinks, most glad,</line>
      <line>My gentle-hearted Charles! For thou hast pined</line>
      <line>And hungered after Nature many a year</line>
      <line>In the great city pent, winning thy way</line>
      <line>With sad yet patient soul, through evil and pain</line>
      <line>And strange calamity! Ah, slowly sink</line>
      <line>Behind the western ridge, thou glorious sun!</line>
      <line>Shine in the slant beams of the sinking orb,</line>
      <line> Ye purple heath-flowers! Richlier burn, ye clouds!</line>
      <line>Live in the yellow light, ye distant groves!</line>
      <line>And kindle, thou blue ocean! So my friend</line>
      <line>Struck with deep joy may stand, as I have stood,</line>
      <line>Silent with swimming sense; yea, gazing round</line>
      <line>On the wide landscape, gaze till all doth seem</line>
      <line>Less gross than bodily; a living thing</line>
      <line>Which acts upon the mind – and with such hues</line>
      <line>As clothe the Almighty Spirit when he makes</line>
      <line>Spirits perceive his presence.</line>
      <line>A delight</line>
      <line> Comes sudden on my heart, and I am glad</line>
      <line>As I myself were there! Nor in this bower,</line>
      <line>This little lime-tree bower, have I not marked</line>
      <line>Much that has soothed me. Pale beneath the blaze</line>
      <line>Hung the transparent foliage, and I watched</line>
      <line>Some broad and sunny leaf, and loved to see</line>
      <line>The shadow of the leaf and stem above</line>
      <line>Dappling its sunshine! And that walnut-tree</line>
      <line>Was richly tinged, and a deep radiance lay</line>
      <line>Full on the ancient ivy, which usurps</line>
      <line> Those fronting elms – and now, with blackest mass,</line>
      <line>Makes their dark branches gleam a lighter hue</line>
      <line>Through the late twilight. And though now the bat</line>
      <line>Wheels silent by, and not a swallow twitters,</line>
      <line>Yet still the solitary humble-bee</line>
      <line>Sings in the bean-flower!</line>
      <line>Henceforth I shall know</line>
      <line>That Nature ne’er deserts the wise and pure –</line>
      <line>No scene so narrow but may well employ</line>
      <line>Each faculty of sense, and keep the heart</line>
      <line>Awake to love and beauty! And sometimes</line>
      <line> ’Tis well to be bereft of promised good,</line>
      <line>That we may lift the soul, and contemplate</line>
      <line>With lively joy the joys we cannot share.</line>
      <line>My gentle-hearted Charles, when the last rook</line>
      <line>Beat its straight path along the dusky air</line>
      <line>Homewards, I blest it! – deeming its black wing</line>
      <line>(Now a dim speck, now vanishing in light)</line>
      <line>Had crossed the mighty orb’s dilated glory</line>
      <line>While thou stoodst gazing; or, when all was still,</line>
      <line>Flew creeking o’er thy head, and had a charm</line>
      <line> For thee, my gentle-hearted Charles, to whom</line>
      <line>No sound is dissonant which tells of life.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Frost at Midnight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The frost performs its secret ministry,</line>
      <line>Unhelped by any wind. The owlet’s cry</line>
      <line>Came loud – and hark, again – loud as before!</line>
      <line>The inmates of my cottage, all at rest,</line>
      <line> Have left me to that solitude which suits</line>
      <line>Abstruser musings – save that at my side</line>
      <line>My cradled infant slumbers peacefully.</line>
      <line>’Tis calm indeed – so calm that it disturbs</line>
      <line>And vexes meditation with its strange</line>
      <line>And extreme silentness. Sea, hill, and wood,</line>
      <line>This populous village – sea, and hill, and wood,</line>
      <line>With all the numberless goings-on of life,</line>
      <line>Inaudible as dreams! The thin blue flame</line>
      <line>Lies on my low-burnt fire, and quivers not.</line>
      <line> Only that film, which fluttered on the grate,</line>
      <line>Still flutters there, the sole unquiet thing!</line>
      <line>Methinks, its motion in this hush of Nature</line>
      <line>Gives it dim sympathies with me who live,</line>
      <line>Making it a companionable form,</line>
      <line>With which I can hold commune. Idle thought!</line>
      <line>But still the living spirit in our frame,</line>
      <line>That loves not to behold a lifeless thing,</line>
      <line>Transfuses into all its own delights,</line>
      <line>Its own volition, sometimes with deep faith,</line>
      <line> And sometimes with fantastic playfulness.</line>
      <line>Ah me! amused by no such curious toys,</line>
      <line>How often in my early schoolboy days,</line>
      <line>With most believing superstitious wish</line>
      <line>Presageful, have I gazed upon the bars</line>
      <line>To watch the stranger there!</line>
      <line>And oft, belike,</line>
      <line>With unclosed lids, already had I dreamt</line>
      <line>Of my sweet birth-place, and the old church-tower,</line>
      <line>Whose bells, the poor man’s only music, rang</line>
      <line>From morn to evening, all the hot Fair-day,</line>
      <line> So sweetly, that they stirred and haunted me</line>
      <line>With a wild pleasure, falling on mine ear</line>
      <line>Most like articulate sounds of things to come.</line>
      <line>So gazed I, till the soothing things I dreamt</line>
      <line>Lulled me to sleep, and sleep prolonged my dreams!</line>
      <line>And so I brooded all the following morn,</line>
      <line>Awed by the stern preceptor’s face, mine eye</line>
      <line>Fixed with mock study on my swimming book;</line>
      <line>Save if the door half opened, and I snatched</line>
      <line>A hasty glance – and still my heart leapt up,</line>
      <line> For still I hoped to see the stranger’s face,</line>
      <line>Townsman, or aunt, or sister more beloved,</line>
      <line>My play-mate when we both were clothed alike!</line>
      <line>Dear babe, that sleepest cradled by my side,</line>
      <line>Whose gentle breathings, heard in this dead calm,</line>
      <line>Fill up the interspersed vacancies</line>
      <line>And momentary pauses of the thought!</line>
      <line>My babe so beautiful, it thrills my heart</line>
      <line>With tender gladness, thus to look at thee,</line>
      <line> And think that thou shalt learn far other lore,</line>
      <line>And in far other scenes! For I was reared</line>
      <line>In the great city, pent mid cloisters dim,</line>
      <line>And saw nought lovely but the sky and stars.</line>
      <line>But thou, my babe, shalt wander like a breeze</line>
      <line>By lakes and sandy shores, beneath the crags</line>
      <line>Of ancient mountain, and beneath the clouds,</line>
      <line>Which image in their bulk both lakes and shores</line>
      <line>And mountain-crags. So shalt thou see and hear</line>
      <line>The lovely shapes and sounds intelligible</line>
      <line> Of that eternal language which thy God</line>
      <line>Utters, who from eternity doth teach</line>
      <line>Himself in all, and all things in himself.</line>
      <line>Great universal Teacher – he shall mould</line>
      <line>Thy spirit, and by giving make it ask!</line>
      <line>Therefore all seasons shall be sweet to thee,</line>
      <line>Whether the summer clothe the general earth</line>
      <line>With greenness, or the redbreast sit and sing</line>
      <line>Betwixt the tufts of snow on the bare branch</line>
      <line>Of mossy apple-tree, while all the thatch</line>
      <line> Smokes in the sun-thaw; whether the eave-drops fall</line>
      <line>Heard only in the trances of the blast,</line>
      <line>Or whether the secret ministry of cold</line>
      <line>Shall hang them up in silent icicles,</line>
      <line>Quietly shining to the quiet moon –</line>
      <line>Like those, my babe, which, ere tomorrow’s warmth</line>
      <line>Have capped their sharp keen points with pendulous drops,</line>
      <line>Will catch thine eye, and with their novelty</line>
      <line>Suspend thy little soul, then make thee shout</line>
      <line>And stretch and flutter from thy mother’s arms</line>
      <line> As thou wouldst fly for very eagerness.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Nightingale</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No cloud, no relic of the sunken day,</line>
      <line>Distinguishes the west, no long thin slip</line>
      <line>Of sullen light, no obscure trembling hues.</line>
      <line>Come, we will rest on this old mossy bridge!</line>
      <line> You see the glimmer of the stream beneath,</line>
      <line>But hear no murmuring: it flows silently</line>
      <line>O’er its soft bed of verdure. All is still,</line>
      <line>A balmy night! And though the stars be dim,</line>
      <line>Yet let us think upon the vernal showers</line>
      <line>That gladden the green earth, and we shall find</line>
      <line>A pleasure in the dimness of the stars.</line>
      <line>And hark, the nightingale begins its song,</line>
      <line>‘Most musical, most melancholy’!</line>
      <line>A melancholy bird? Oh idle thought:</line>
      <line> In Nature there is nothing melancholy.</line>
      <line>But some night-wandering man, whose heart was pierced</line>
      <line>With the remembrance of a grievous wrong,</line>
      <line>Or slow distemper, or neglected love,</line>
      <line>And so, poor wretch! filled all things with himself</line>
      <line>And made all gentle sounds tell back the tale</line>
      <line>Of his own sorrows – he, and such as he,</line>
      <line>First named these notes a melancholy strain,</line>
      <line>And many a poet echoes the conceit,</line>
      <line>Poet, who hath been building up the rhyme</line>
      <line> When he had better far have stretched his limbs</line>
      <line>Beside a brook in mossy forest-dell</line>
      <line>By sun or moonlight, to the influxes</line>
      <line>Of shapes and sounds and shifting elements</line>
      <line>Surrendering his whole spirit, of his song</line>
      <line>And of his fame forgetful! So his fame</line>
      <line>Should share in Nature’s immortality –</line>
      <line>A venerable thing – and so his song</line>
      <line>Should make all Nature lovelier, and itself</line>
      <line>Be loved, like Nature. But ’twill not be so;</line>
      <line> And youths and maidens most poetical</line>
      <line>Who lose the deepening twilights of the spring</line>
      <line>In ball-rooms and hot theatres, they still</line>
      <line>(Full of meek sympathy) must heave their sighs</line>
      <line>O’er Philomela’s pity-pleading strains!</line>
      <line>My friend, and my friend’s sister! we have learnt</line>
      <line>A different lore: we may not thus profane</line>
      <line>Nature’s sweet voices, always full of love</line>
      <line>And joyance! ’Tis the merry nightingale</line>
      <line>That crowds, and hurries, and precipitates,</line>
      <line> With fast thick warble, his delicious notes,</line>
      <line>As he were fearful, that an April night</line>
      <line>Would be too short for him to utter forth</line>
      <line>His love-chant, and disburden his full soul</line>
      <line>Of all its music! And I know a grove</line>
      <line>Of large extent, hard by a castle huge</line>
      <line>Which the great lord inhabits not; and so</line>
      <line>This grove is wild with tangling underwood,</line>
      <line>And the trim walks are broken up, and grass,</line>
      <line>Thin grass and king-cups, grow within the paths –</line>
      <line> But never elsewhere in one place I knew</line>
      <line>So many nightingales! And far and near,</line>
      <line>In wood and thicket, over the wide grove</line>
      <line>They answer and provoke each other’s songs</line>
      <line>With skirmish and capricious passagings,</line>
      <line>And murmurs musical, and swift jug jug,</line>
      <line>And one low piping sound more sweet than all,</line>
      <line>Stirring the air with such an harmony</line>
      <line>That, should you close your eyes, you might almost</line>
      <line>Forget it was not day! On moonlight bushes,</line>
      <line> Whose dewy leafits are but half disclosed,</line>
      <line>You may perchance behold them on the twigs,</line>
      <line>Their bright, bright eyes – their eyes both bright and full –</line>
      <line>Glistening, while many a glow-worm in the shade</line>
      <line>Lights up her love-torch.</line>
      <line>A most gentle maid</line>
      <line>Who dwelleth in her hospitable home</line>
      <line>Hard by the Castle, and at latest eve</line>
      <line>(Even like a lady vowed and dedicate</line>
      <line>To something more than Nature in the grove)</line>
      <line>Glides through the pathways. She knows all their notes,</line>
      <line> That gentle maid! and oft, a moment’s space,</line>
      <line>What time the moon was lost behind a cloud,</line>
      <line>Hath heard a pause of silence – till the moon,</line>
      <line>Emerging, hath awakened earth and sky</line>
      <line>With one sensation, and those wakeful birds</line>
      <line>Have all burst forth in choral minstrelsy,</line>
      <line>As if one quick and sudden gale had swept</line>
      <line>An hundred airy harps! And she hath watched</line>
      <line>Many a nightingale perch giddily</line>
      <line>On blossomy twig still swinging from the breeze,</line>
      <line> And to that motion tune his wanton song</line>
      <line>Like tipsy joy that reels with tossing head.</line>
      <line>Farewell, oh warbler, till tomorrow eve!</line>
      <line>And you, my friends, farewell – a short farewell!</line>
      <line>We have been loitering long and pleasantly,</line>
      <line>And now for our dear homes. That strain again –</line>
      <line>Full fain it would delay me! My dear babe,</line>
      <line>Who, capable of no articulate sound,</line>
      <line>Mars all things with his imitative lisp,</line>
      <line>How he would place his hand beside his ear</line>
      <line> (His little hand), the small forefinger up,</line>
      <line>And bid us listen! And I deem it wise</line>
      <line>To make him Nature’s playmate. He knows well</line>
      <line>The evening star – and once when he awoke</line>
      <line>In most distressful mood (some inward pain</line>
      <line>Had made up that strange thing, an infant’s dream)</line>
      <line>I hurried with him to our orchard-plot,</line>
      <line>And he beholds the moon, and, hushed at once,</line>
      <line>Suspends his sobs, and laughs most silently,</line>
      <line>While his fair eyes that swam with undropt tears</line>
      <line>Did glitter in the yellow moon-beam!</line>
      <line>Well,</line>
      <line>It is a father’s tale. But if that Heaven</line>
      <line>Should give me life, his childhood shall grow up</line>
      <line>Familiar with these songs, that with the night</line>
      <line>He may associate joy! Once more farewell,</line>
      <line>Sweet nightingale! Once more, my friends, farewell!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Tintern Abbey</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Five years have passed, five summers, with the length</line>
      <line>Of five long winters, and again I hear</line>
      <line>These waters, rolling from their mountain-springs</line>
      <line>With a sweet inland murmur. Once again</line>
      <line> Do I behold these steep and lofty cliffs,</line>
      <line>Which on a wild secluded scene impress</line>
      <line>Thoughts of more deep seclusion, and connect</line>
      <line>The landscape with the quiet of the sky.</line>
      <line>The day is come when I again repose</line>
      <line>Here, under this dark sycamore, and view</line>
      <line>These plots of cottage-ground, these orchard-tufts</line>
      <line>Which at this season, with their unripe fruits,</line>
      <line>Among the woods and copses lose themselves,</line>
      <line>Nor with their green and simple hue disturb</line>
      <line> The wild green landscape. Once again I see</line>
      <line>These hedgerows – hardly hedgerows, little lines</line>
      <line>Of sportive wood run wild – these pastoral farms</line>
      <line>Green to the very door, and wreaths of smoke</line>
      <line>Sent up, in silence, from among the trees</line>
      <line>With some uncertain notice, as might seem</line>
      <line>Of vagrant dwellers in the houseless woods,</line>
      <line>Or of some hermit’s cave, where by his fire</line>
      <line>The hermit sits alone.</line>
      <line>Though absent long,</line>
      <line>These forms of beauty have not been to me</line>
      <line> As is a landscape to a blind man’s eye;</line>
      <line>But oft, in lonely rooms, and mid the din</line>
      <line>Of towns and cities, I have owed to them,</line>
      <line>In hours of weariness, sensations sweet</line>
      <line>Felt in the blood, and felt along the heart,</line>
      <line>And passing even into my purer mind</line>
      <line>With tranquil restoration – feelings too</line>
      <line>Of unremembered pleasure; such, perhaps,</line>
      <line>As may have had no trivial influence</line>
      <line>On that best portion of a good man’s life,</line>
      <line> His little nameless unremembered acts</line>
      <line>Of kindness and of love. Nor less, I trust,</line>
      <line>To them I may have owed another gift,</line>
      <line>Of aspect more sublime: that blesséd mood</line>
      <line>In which the burden of the mystery,</line>
      <line>In which the heavy and the weary weight</line>
      <line>Of all this unintelligible world,</line>
      <line>Is lightened – that serene and blesséd mood</line>
      <line>In which the affections gently lead us on,</line>
      <line>Until, the breath of this corporeal frame</line>
      <line> And even the motion of our human blood</line>
      <line>Almost suspended, we are laid asleep</line>
      <line>In body, and become a living soul,</line>
      <line>While, with an eye made quiet by the power</line>
      <line>Of harmony, and the deep power of joy,</line>
      <line>We see into the life of things.</line>
      <line>If this</line>
      <line>Be but a vain belief, yet oh, how oft,</line>
      <line>In darkness, and amid the many shapes</line>
      <line>Of joyless daylight, when the fretful stir</line>
      <line>Unprofitable and the fever of the world</line>
      <line> Have hung upon the beatings of my heart,</line>
      <line>How oft in spirit have I turned to thee</line>
      <line>Oh sylvan Wye, thou wanderer through the woods –</line>
      <line>How often has my spirit turned to thee!</line>
      <line>And now, with gleams of half-extinguished thought,</line>
      <line>With many recognitions dim and faint,</line>
      <line>And somewhat of a sad perplexity,</line>
      <line>The picture of the mind revives again,</line>
      <line>While here I stand, not only with the sense</line>
      <line>Of present pleasure, but with pleasing thoughts</line>
      <line> That in this moment there is life and food</line>
      <line>For future years. And so I dare to hope</line>
      <line>Though changed, no doubt, from what I was when first</line>
      <line>I came among these hills, when like a roe</line>
      <line>I bounded o’er the mountains, by the sides</line>
      <line>Of the deep rivers and the lonely streams,</line>
      <line>Wherever Nature led – more like a man</line>
      <line>Flying from something that he dreads, than one</line>
      <line>Who sought the thing he loved. For Nature then</line>
      <line>(The coarser pleasures of my boyish days,</line>
      <line> And their glad animal movements, all gone by)</line>
      <line>To me was all in all. I cannot paint</line>
      <line>What then I was. The sounding cataract</line>
      <line>Haunted me like a passion; the tall rock,</line>
