      <line>The mountain, and the deep and gloomy wood,</line>
      <line>Their colours and their forms, were then to me</line>
      <line>An appetite – a feeling and a love</line>
      <line>That had no need of a remoter charm</line>
      <line>By thought supplied, or any interest</line>
      <line>Unborrowed from the eye.</line>
      <line>That time is past,</line>
      <line> And all its aching joys are now no more,</line>
      <line>And all its dizzy raptures. Not for this</line>
      <line>Faint I, nor mourn, nor murmur: other gifts</line>
      <line>Have followed, for such loss, I would believe,</line>
      <line>Abundant recompense. For I have learned</line>
      <line>To look on Nature, not as in the hour</line>
      <line>Of thoughtless youth, but hearing oftentimes</line>
      <line>The still, sad music of humanity,</line>
      <line>Nor harsh, nor grating, though of ample power</line>
      <line>To chasten and subdue. And I have felt</line>
      <line> A presence that disturbs me with the joy</line>
      <line>Of elevated thoughts, a sense sublime</line>
      <line>Of something far more deeply interfused,</line>
      <line>Whose dwelling is the light of setting suns,</line>
      <line>And the round ocean, and the living air,</line>
      <line>And the blue sky, and in the mind of man –</line>
      <line>A motion and a spirit that impels</line>
      <line>All thinking things, all objects of all thought,</line>
      <line>And rolls through all things. Therefore am I still</line>
      <line>A lover of the meadows and the woods</line>
      <line>And mountains, and of all that we behold</line>
      <line>From this green earth – of all the mighty world</line>
      <line>Of eye and ear, both what they half-create,</line>
      <line>And what perceive – well pleased to recognize</line>
      <line>In Nature and the language of the sense</line>
      <line>The anchor of my purest thoughts, the nurse,</line>
      <line>The guide, the guardian of my heart, and soul</line>
      <line>Of all my moral being.</line>
      <line>Nor perchance</line>
      <line>If I were not thus taught, should I the more</line>
      <line>Suffer my genial spirits to decay;</line>
      <line> For thou art with me, here, upon the banks</line>
      <line>Of this fair river – thou, my dearest friend,</line>
      <line>My dear, dear friend – and in thy voice I catch</line>
      <line>The language of my former heart, and read</line>
      <line>My former pleasures in the shooting lights</line>
      <line>Of thy wild eyes. Oh, yet a little while</line>
      <line>May I behold in thee what I was once,</line>
      <line>My dear, dear sister. And this prayer I make,</line>
      <line>Knowing that Nature never did betray</line>
      <line>The heart that loved her: ’tis her privilege</line>
      <line> Through all the years of this our life to lead</line>
      <line>From joy to joy. For she can so inform</line>
      <line>The mind that is within us, so impress</line>
      <line>With quietness and beauty, and so feed</line>
      <line>With lofty thoughts, that neither evil tongues,</line>
      <line>Rash judgments, nor the sneers of selfish men,</line>
      <line>Nor greetings where no kindness is, nor all</line>
      <line>The dreary intercourse of daily life,</line>
      <line>Shall e’er prevail against us, or disturb</line>
      <line>Our cheerful faith that all which we behold</line>
      <line> Is full of blessings. Therefore let the moon</line>
      <line>Shine on thee in thy solitary walk,</line>
      <line>And let the misty mountain winds be free</line>
      <line>To blow against thee; and in after years,</line>
      <line>When these wild ecstasies shall be matured</line>
      <line>Into a sober pleasure, when thy mind</line>
      <line>Shall be a mansion for all lovely forms,</line>
      <line>Thy memory be as a dwelling-place</line>
      <line>For all sweet sounds and harmonies – oh, then</line>
      <line>If solitude, or fear, or pain, or grief,</line>
      <line> Should be thy portion, with what healing thoughts</line>
      <line>Of tender joy wilt thou remember me</line>
      <line>And these my exhortations!</line>
      <line>Nor perchance</line>
      <line>If I should be where I no more can hear</line>
      <line>Thy voice, nor catch from thy wild eyes these gleams</line>
      <line>Of past existence, wilt thou then forget</line>
      <line>That on the banks of this delightful stream</line>
      <line>We stood together, and that I, so long</line>
      <line>A worshipper of Nature, hither came</line>
      <line>Unwearied in that service – rather say</line>
      <line> With warmer love, oh, with far deeper zeal</line>
      <line>Of holier love! Nor wilt thou then forget</line>
      <line>That after many wanderings, many years</line>
      <line>Of absence, these steep woods and lofty cliffs,</line>
      <line>And this green pastoral landscape, were to me</line>
      <line>More dear, both for themselves, and for thy sake.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>There Was a Boy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a boy – ye knew him well, ye cliffs</line>
      <line>And islands of Winander – many a time</line>
      <line>At evening, when the stars had just begun</line>
      <line>To move along the edges of the hills,</line>
      <line> Rising or setting, would he stand alone</line>
      <line>Beneath the trees or by the glimmering lake,</line>
      <line>And there, with fingers interwoven, both hands</line>
      <line>Pressed closely palm to palm and to his mouth</line>
      <line>Uplifted, he, as through an instrument,</line>
      <line>Blew mimic hootings to the silent owls,</line>
      <line>That they might answer him. And they would shout</line>
      <line>Across the watery vale, and shout again,</line>
      <line>Responsive to his call, with quivering peals,</line>
      <line>And long halloos, and screams, and echoes loud,</line>
      <line> Redoubled and redoubled – a wild scene</line>
      <line>Of mirth and jocund din. And when it chanced</line>
      <line>That pauses of deep silence mocked his skill,</line>
      <line>Then sometimes in that silence, while he hung</line>
      <line>Listening, a gentle shock of mild surprise</line>
      <line>Has carried far into his heart the voice</line>
      <line>Of mountain torrents; or the visible scene</line>
      <line>Would enter unawares into his mind</line>
      <line>With all its solemn imagery – its rocks,</line>
      <line>Its woods, and that uncertain heaven – received</line>
      <line> Into the bosom of the steady lake.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>The Two-Part Prelude</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Was it for this</line>
      <line>That one, the fairest of all rivers, loved</line>
      <line>To blend his murmurs with my nurse’s song,</line>
      <line>And from his alder shades and rocky falls,</line>
      <line> And from his fords and shallows, sent a voice</line>
      <line>That flowed along my dreams? For this didst thou,</line>
      <line>Oh Derwent, travelling over the green plains</line>
      <line>Near my ‘sweet birthplace’, didst thou, beauteous stream,</line>
      <line>Make ceaseless music through the night and day,</line>
      <line>Which with its steady cadence tempering</line>
      <line>Our human waywardness, composed my thoughts</line>
      <line>To more than infant softness, giving me</line>
      <line>Among the fretful dwellings of mankind</line>
      <line>A knowledge, a dim earnest, of the calm</line>
      <line> Which Nature breathes among the fields and groves?</line>
      <line>Belovéd Derwent, fairest of all streams,</line>
      <line>Was it for this that I, a four years’ child,</line>
      <line>A naked boy, among thy silent pools</line>
      <line>Made one long bathing of a summer’s day,</line>
      <line>Basked in the sun, or plunged into thy streams,</line>
      <line>Alternate, all a summer’s day, or coursed</line>
      <line>Over the sandy fields, and dashed the flowers</line>
      <line>Of yellow groundsel – or, when crag and hill,</line>
      <line>The woods, and distant Skiddaw’s lofty height,</line>
      <line> Were bronzed with a deep radiance, stood alone</line>
      <line>A naked savage in the thunder-shower?</line>
      <line>And afterwards (’twas in a later day,</line>
      <line>Though early), when upon the mountain-slope</line>
      <line>The frost and breath of frosty wind had snapped</line>
      <line>The last autumnal crocus, ’twas my joy</line>
      <line>To wander half the night among the cliffs</line>
      <line>And the smooth hollows where the woodcocks ran</line>
      <line>Along the moonlight turf. In thought and wish</line>
      <line>That time, my shoulder all with springes hung,</line>
      <line> I was a fell destroyer. Gentle powers,</line>
      <line>Who give us happiness and call it peace,</line>
      <line>When scudding on from snare to snare I plied</line>
      <line>My anxious visitation, hurrying on,</line>
      <line>Still hurrying, hurrying onward, how my heart</line>
      <line>Panted! – among the scattered yew-trees and the crags</line>
      <line>That looked upon me, how my bosom beat</line>
      <line>With expectation! Sometimes strong desire</line>
      <line>Resistless overpowered me, and the bird</line>
      <line>Which was the captive of another’s toils</line>
      <line> Became my prey; and when the deed was done</line>
      <line>I heard among the solitary hills</line>
      <line>Low breathings coming after me, and sounds</line>
      <line>Of undistinguishable motion, steps</line>
      <line>Almost as silent as the turf they trod.</line>
      <line>Nor less in springtime, when on southern banks</line>
      <line>The shining sun had from his knot of leaves</line>
      <line>Decoyed the primrose flower, and when the vales</line>
      <line>And woods were warm, was I a rover then</line>
      <line>In the high places, on the lonesome peaks,</line>
      <line> Among the mountains and the winds. Though mean</line>
      <line>And though inglorious were my views, the end</line>
      <line>Was not ignoble. Oh, when I have hung</line>
      <line>Above the raven’s nest, by knots of grass</line>
      <line>Or half-inch fissures in the slippery rock</line>
      <line>But ill sustained, and almost, as it seemed,</line>
      <line>Suspended by the blast which blew amain</line>
      <line>Shouldering the naked crag, oh, at that time,</line>
      <line>While on the perilous ridge I hung alone,</line>
      <line>With what strange utterance did the loud dry wind</line>
      <line> Blow through my ears; the sky seemed not a sky</line>
      <line>Of earth, and with what motion moved the clouds!</line>
      <line>The mind of man is fashioned and built up</line>
      <line>Even as a strain of music. I believe</line>
      <line>That there are spirits which, when they would form</line>
      <line>A favoured being, from his very dawn</line>
      <line>Of infancy do open out the clouds</line>
      <line>As at the touch of lightning, seeking him</line>
      <line>With gentle visitation – quiet powers,</line>
      <line>Retired, and seldom recognized, yet kind,</line>
      <line> And to the very meanest not unknown –</line>
      <line>With me, though, rarely in my boyish days</line>
      <line>They communed. Others too there are, who use,</line>
      <line>Yet haply aiming at the self-same end,</line>
      <line>Severer interventions, ministry</line>
      <line>More palpable – and of their school was I.</line>
      <line>They guided me: one evening led by them</line>
      <line>I went alone into a shepherd’s boat,</line>
      <line>A skiff, that to a willow-tree was tied</line>
      <line>Within a rocky cave, its usual home.</line>
      <line> The moon was up, the lake was shining clear</line>
      <line>Among the hoary mountains; from the shore</line>
      <line>I pushed, and struck the oars, and struck again</line>
      <line>In cadence, and my little boat moved on</line>
      <line>Just like a man who walks with stately step</line>
      <line>Though bent on speed. It was an act of stealth</line>
      <line>And troubled pleasure. Not without the voice</line>
      <line>Of mountain echoes did my boat move on,</line>
      <line>Leaving behind her still on either side</line>
      <line>Small circles glittering idly in the moon,</line>
      <line> Until they melted all into one track</line>
      <line>Of sparkling light.</line>
      <line>A rocky steep uprose</line>
      <line>Above the cavern of the willow-tree,</line>
      <line>And now, as suited one who proudly rowed</line>
      <line>With his best skill, I fixed a steady view</line>
      <line>Upon the top of that same craggy ridge,</line>
      <line>The bound of the horizon – for behind</line>
      <line>Was nothing but the stars and the grey sky.</line>
      <line>She was an elfin pinnace; twenty times</line>
      <line>I dipped my oars into the silent lake,</line>
      <line>And as I rose upon the stroke my boat</line>
      <line>Went heaving through the water like a swan –</line>
      <line>When from behind that rocky steep, till then</line>
      <line>The bound of the horizon, a huge cliff,</line>
      <line>As if with voluntary power instinct,</line>
      <line>Upreared its head. I struck, and struck again,</line>
      <line>And, growing still in stature, the huge cliff</line>
      <line>Rose up between me and the stars, and still,</line>
      <line>With measured motion, like a living thing</line>
      <line>Strode after me. With trembling hands I turned,</line>
      <line> And through the silent water stole my way</line>
      <line>Back to the cavern of the willow-tree.</line>
      <line>There in her mooring-place I left my bark,</line>
      <line>And through the meadows homeward went with grave</line>
      <line>And serious thoughts; and after I had seen</line>
      <line>That spectacle, for many days my brain</line>
      <line>Worked with a dim and undetermined sense</line>
      <line>Of unknown modes of being. In my thoughts</line>
      <line>There was a darkness – call it solitude,</line>
      <line>Or blank desertion – no familiar shapes</line>
      <line> Of hourly objects, images of trees,</line>
      <line>Of sea or sky, no colours of green fields,</line>
      <line>But huge and mighty forms that do not live</line>
      <line>Like living men moved slowly through my mind</line>
      <line>By day, and were the trouble of my dreams.</line>
      <line>Ah, not in vain ye beings of the hills,</line>
      <line>And ye that walk the woods and open heaths</line>
      <line>By moon or starlight, thus, from my first dawn</line>
      <line>Of childhood, did ye love to intertwine</line>
      <line>The passions that build up our human soul</line>
      <line> Not with the mean and vulgar works of man,</line>
      <line>But with high objects, with eternal things,</line>
      <line>With life and Nature, purifying thus</line>
      <line>The elements of feeling and of thought,</line>
      <line>And sanctifying by such discipline</line>
      <line>Both pain and fear, until we recognize</line>
      <line>A grandeur in the beatings of the heart.</line>
      <line>Nor was this fellowship vouchsafed to me</line>
      <line>With stinted kindness. In November days,</line>
      <line>When vapours rolling down the valleys made</line>
      <line> A lonely scene more lonesome, among woods</line>
      <line>At noon, and mid the calm of summer nights</line>
      <line>When by the margin of the trembling lake</line>
      <line>Beneath the gloomy hills I homeward went</line>
      <line>In solitude, such intercourse was mine.</line>
      <line>And in the frosty season, when the sun</line>
      <line>Was set, and visible for many a mile</line>
      <line>The cottage windows through the twilight blazed,</line>
      <line>I heeded not the summons. Clear and loud</line>
      <line>The village-clock tolled six; I wheeled about</line>
      <line> Proud and exulting, like an untired horse</line>
      <line>That cares not for its home. All shod with steel</line>
      <line>We hissed along the polished ice in games</line>
      <line>Confederate, imitative of the chase</line>
      <line>And woodland pleasures, the resounding horn,</line>
      <line>The pack loud bellowing, and the hunted hare.</line>
      <line>So through the darkness and the cold we flew,</line>
      <line>And not a voice was idle. With the din,</line>
      <line>Meanwhile, the precipices rang aloud;</line>
      <line>The leafless trees and every icy crag</line>
      <line> Tinkled like iron; while the distant hills</line>
      <line>Into the tumult sent an alien sound</line>
      <line>Of melancholy, not unnoticed; while the stars,</line>
      <line>Eastward, were sparkling clear, and in the west</line>
      <line>The orange sky of evening died away.</line>
      <line>Not seldom from the uproar I retired</line>
      <line>Into a silent bay, or sportively</line>
      <line>Glanced sideway, leaving the tumultuous throng,</line>
      <line>To cut across the shadow of a star</line>
      <line>That gleamed upon the ice. And oftentimes</line>
      <line> When we had given our bodies to the wind</line>
      <line>And all the shadowy banks on either side</line>
      <line>Came sweeping through the darkness, spinning still</line>
      <line>The rapid line of motion, then at once</line>
      <line>Have I, reclining back upon my heels,</line>
      <line>Stopped short – yet still the solitary cliffs</line>
      <line>Wheeled by me, even as if the earth had rolled</line>
      <line>With visible motion her diurnal round.</line>
      <line>Behind me did they stretch in solemn train,</line>
      <line>Feebler and feebler, and I stood and watched</line>
      <line> Till all was tranquil as a summer sea.</line>
      <line>Ye powers of earth, ye genii of the springs,</line>
      <line>And ye that have your voices in the clouds,</line>
      <line>And ye that are familiars of the lakes</line>
      <line>And of the standing pools, I may not think</line>
      <line>A vulgar hope was yours when ye employed</line>
      <line>Such ministry – when ye through many a year</line>
      <line>Thus by the agency of boyish sports,</line>
      <line>On caves and trees, upon the woods and hills,</line>
      <line>Impressed upon all forms the characters</line>
      <line> Of danger or desire, and thus did make</line>
      <line>The surface of the universal earth</line>
      <line>With meanings of delight, of hope and fear,</line>
      <line>Work like a sea.</line>
      <line>Not uselessly employed,</line>
      <line>I might pursue this theme through every change</line>
      <line>Of exercise and sport to which the year</line>
      <line>Did summon us in its delightful round.</line>
      <line>We were a noisy crew; the sun in heaven</line>
      <line>Beheld not vales more beautiful than ours,</line>
      <line>Nor saw a race in happiness and joy</line>
      <line>More worthy of the fields where they were sown.</line>
      <line>I would record with no reluctant voice</line>
      <line>Our home amusements by the warm peat fire</line>
      <line>At evening, when with pencil and with slate,</line>
      <line>In square divisions parcelled out, and all</line>
      <line>With crosses and with cyphers scribbled o’er,</line>
      <line>We schemed and puzzled, head opposed to head,</line>
      <line>In strife too humble to be named in verse;</line>
      <line>Or round the naked table, snow-white deal,</line>
      <line>Cherry, or maple, sat in close array,</line>
      <line> And to the combat – loo or whist – led on</line>
      <line>A thick-ribbed army, not as in the world</line>
      <line>Discarded and ungratefully thrown by</line>
      <line>Even for the very service they had wrought,</line>
      <line>But husbanded through many a long campaign.</line>
      <line>Oh, with what echoes on the board they fell –</line>
      <line>Ironic diamonds, hearts of sable hue,</line>
      <line>Queens gleaming through their splendour’s last decay,</line>
      <line>Knaves wrapped in one assimilating gloom,</line>
      <line>And kings indignant at the shame incurred</line>
      <line> By royal visages. Meanwhile abroad</line>
      <line>The heavy rain was falling, or the frost</line>
      <line>Raged bitterly with keen and silent tooth,</line>
      <line>And, interrupting the impassioned game,</line>
      <line>Oft from the neighbouring lake the splitting ice,</line>
      <line>While it sank down towards the water, sent</line>
      <line>Among the meadows and the hills its long</line>
      <line>And frequent yellings, imitative some</line>
      <line>Of wolves that howl along the Bothnic main.</line>
      <line>Nor with less willing heart would I rehearse</line>
      <line> The woods of autumn, and their hidden bowers</line>
      <line>With milk-white clusters hung; the rod and line –</line>
      <line>True symbol of the foolishness of hope –</line>
      <line>Which with its strong enchantment led me on</line>
      <line>By rocks and pools, where never summer star</line>
      <line>Impressed its shadow, to forlorn cascades</line>
      <line>Among the windings of the mountain-brooks;</line>
      <line>The kite in sultry calms from some high hill</line>
      <line>Sent up, ascending thence till it was lost</line>
      <line>Among the fleecy clouds – in gusty days</line>
      <line> Launched from the lower grounds, and suddenly</line>
      <line>Dashed headlong and rejected by the storm.</line>
      <line>All these, and more, with rival claims demand</line>
      <line>Grateful acknowledgement. It were a song</line>
      <line>Venial, and such as (if I rightly judge)</line>
      <line>I might protract unblamed, but I perceive</line>
      <line>That much is overlooked, and we should ill</line>
      <line>Attain our object if, from delicate fears</line>
      <line>Of breaking in upon the unity</line>
      <line>Of this my argument, I should omit</line>
      <line> To speak of such effects as cannot here</line>
      <line>Be regularly classed, yet tend no less</line>
      <line>To the same point – the growth of mental power</line>
      <line>And love of Nature’s works.</line>
      <line>Ere I had seen</line>
      <line>Eight summers (and ’twas in the very week</line>
      <line>When I was first transplanted to thy vale,</line>
      <line>Belovéd Hawkshead! – when thy paths, thy shores</line>
      <line>And brooks, were like a dream of novelty</line>
      <line>To my half-infant mind), I chanced to cross</line>
      <line>One of those open fields which, shaped like ears,</line>
      <line> Make green peninsulas on Esthwaite’s lake.</line>
      <line>Twilight was coming on, yet through the gloom</line>
      <line>I saw distinctly on the opposite shore,</line>
      <line>Beneath a tree and close by the lake side,</line>
      <line>A heap of garments, as if left by one</line>
      <line>Who there was bathing. Half an hour I watched</line>
      <line>And no one owned them; meanwhile the calm lake</line>
      <line>Grew dark with all the shadows on its breast,</line>
      <line>And now and then a leaping fish disturbed</line>
      <line>The breathless stillness.</line>
      <line>The succeeding day</line>
      <line> There came a company, and in their boat</line>
      <line>Sounded with iron hooks and with long poles.</line>
      <line>At length the dead man, mid that beauteous scene</line>
      <line>Of trees and hills and water, bolt upright</line>
      <line>Rose with his ghastly face. I might advert</line>
      <line>To numerous accidents in flood or field,</line>
      <line>Quarry or moor, or mid the winter snows,</line>
      <line>Distresses and disasters, tragic facts</line>
      <line>Of rural history that impressed my mind</line>
      <line>With images to which in following years</line>
      <line> Far other feelings were attached – with forms</line>
      <line>That yet exist with independent life,</line>
      <line>And, like their archetypes, know no decay.</line>
      <line>There are in our existence spots of time</line>
      <line>Which with distinct preeminence retain</line>
      <line>A fructifying virtue, whence, depressed</line>
      <line>By trivial occupations and the round</line>
      <line>Of ordinary intercourse, our minds –</line>
      <line>Especially the imaginative power –</line>
      <line>Are nourished and invisibly repaired.</line>
      <line> Such moments chiefly seem to have their date</line>
      <line>In our first childhood.</line>
      <line>I remember well</line>
      <line>(’Tis of an early season that I speak,</line>
      <line>The twilight of rememberable life),</line>
      <line>While I was yet an urchin, one who scarce</line>
      <line>Could hold a bridle, with ambitious hopes</line>
      <line>I mounted, and we rode towards the hills.</line>
      <line>We were a pair of horsemen: honest James</line>
      <line>Was with me, my encourager and guide.</line>
      <line>We had not travelled long ere some mischance</line>
      <line>Disjoined me from my comrade, and, through fear</line>
      <line>Dismounting, down the rough and stony moor</line>
      <line>I led my horse, and stumbling on, at length</line>
      <line>Came to a bottom where in former times</line>
      <line>A man, the murderer of his wife, was hung</line>
      <line>In irons. Mouldered was the gibbet-mast;</line>
      <line>The bones were gone, the iron and the wood;</line>
      <line>Only a long green ridge of turf remained</line>
      <line>Whose shape was like a grave. I left the spot,</line>
      <line>And reascending the bare slope I saw</line>
      <line> A naked pool that lay beneath the hills,</line>
      <line>The beacon on the summit, and more near</line>
      <line>A girl who bore a pitcher on her head</line>
      <line>And seemed with difficult steps to force her way</line>
      <line>Against the blowing wind. It was in truth</line>
      <line>An ordinary sight, but I should need</line>
      <line>Colours and words that are unknown to man</line>
      <line>To paint the visionary dreariness</line>
      <line>Which, while I looked all round for my lost guide,</line>
      <line>Did at that time invest the naked pool,</line>
      <line> The beacon on the lonely eminence,</line>
      <line>The woman and her garments vexed and tossed</line>
      <line>By the strong wind.</line>
      <line>Nor less I recollect –</line>
      <line>Long after, though my childhood had not ceased –</line>
      <line>Another scene which left a kindred power</line>
      <line>Implanted in my mind. One Christmas-time,</line>
      <line>The day before the holidays began,</line>
      <line>Feverish, and tired, and restless, I went forth</line>
      <line>Into the fields, impatient for the sight</line>
      <line>Of those three horses which should bear us home,</line>
      <line> My brothers and myself. There was a crag,</line>
      <line>An eminence, which from the meeting-point</line>
      <line>Of two highways ascending overlooked</line>
      <line>At least a long half-mile of those two roads,</line>
      <line>By each of which the expected steeds might come –</line>
      <line>The choice uncertain. Thither I repaired</line>
      <line>Up to the highest summit. ’Twas a day</line>
      <line>Stormy, and rough, and wild, and on the grass</line>
      <line>I sat half sheltered by a naked wall.</line>
      <line>Upon my right hand was a single sheep,</line>
      <line> A whistling hawthorn on my left, and there,</line>
      <line>Those two companions at my side, I watched</line>
      <line>With eyes intensely straining, as the mist</line>
      <line>Gave intermitting prospects of the wood</line>
      <line>And plain beneath.</line>
      <line>Ere I to school returned</line>
      <line>That dreary time, ere I had been ten days</line>
      <line>A dweller in my father’s house, he died,</line>
      <line>And I and my two brothers, orphans then,</line>
      <line>Followed his body to the grave. The event,</line>
      <line>With all the sorrow which it brought, appeared</line>
      <line> A chastisement; and when I called to mind</line>
      <line>That day so lately passed, when from the crag</line>
      <line>I looked in such anxiety of hope,</line>
      <line>With trite reflections of morality,</line>
      <line>Yet with the deepest passion, I bowed low</line>
      <line>To God who thus corrected my desires.</line>
      <line>And afterwards the wind and sleety rain,</line>
      <line>And all the business of the elements,</line>
      <line>The single sheep, and the one blasted tree,</line>
      <line>And the bleak music of that old stone wall,</line>
      <line> The noise of wood and water, and the mist</line>
      <line>Which on the line of each of those two roads</line>
      <line>Advanced in such indisputable shapes –</line>
      <line>All these were spectacles and sounds to which</line>
      <line>I often would repair, and thence would drink</line>
      <line>As at a fountain. And I do not doubt</line>
      <line>That in this later time, when storm and rain</line>
      <line>Beat on my roof at midnight, or by day</line>
      <line>When I am in the woods, unknown to me</line>
      <line>The workings of my spirit thence are brought.</line>
      <line> Nor, sedulous as I have been to trace</line>
      <line>How Nature by collateral interest,</line>
      <line>And by extrinsic passion, peopled first</line>
      <line>My mind with forms or beautiful or grand</line>
      <line>And made me love them, may I well forget</line>
      <line>How other pleasures have been mine, and joys</line>
      <line>Of subtler origin – how I have felt</line>
      <line>Not seldom, even in that tempestuous time,</line>
      <line>Those hallowed and pure motions of the sense</line>
      <line>Which seem in their simplicity to own</line>
      <line> An intellectual charm, that calm delight</line>
      <line>Which, if I err not, surely must belong</line>
      <line>To those first-born affinities that fit</line>
      <line>Our new existence to existing things,</line>
      <line>And, in our dawn of being, constitute</line>
      <line>The bond of union betwixt life and joy.</line>
      <line>Yes, I remember when the changeful earth</line>
      <line>And twice five seasons on my mind had stamped</line>
      <line>The faces of the moving year, even then,</line>
      <line>A child, I held unconscious intercourse</line>
      <line> With the eternal beauty, drinking in</line>
      <line>A pure organic pleasure from the lines</line>
      <line>Of curling mist, or from the level plain</line>
      <line>Of waters coloured by the steady clouds.</line>
      <line>The sands of Westmorland, the creeks and bays</line>
      <line>Of Cumbria’s rocky limits, they can tell</line>
      <line>How when the sea threw off his evening shade</line>
      <line>And to the shepherd’s hut beneath the crags</line>
      <line>Did send sweet notice of the rising moon,</line>
      <line>How I have stood, to images like these</line>
      <line>A stranger, linking with the spectacle</line>
      <line>No body of associated forms,</line>
      <line>And bringing with me no peculiar sense</line>
      <line>Of quietness or peace – yet I have stood</line>
      <line>Even while my eye has moved o’er three long leagues</line>
      <line>Of shining water, gathering, as it seemed,</line>
      <line>Through the wide surface of that field of light</line>
      <line>New pleasure, like a bee among the flowers.</line>
      <line>Thus often in those fits of vulgar joy</line>
      <line>Which through all seasons on a child’s pursuits</line>
      <line> Are prompt attendants, mid that giddy bliss</line>
      <line>Which like a tempest works along the blood</line>
      <line>And is forgotten, even then I felt</line>
      <line>Gleams like the flashing of a shield. The earth</line>
      <line>And common face of Nature spake to me</line>
      <line>Rememberable things – sometimes, ’tis true,</line>
      <line>By quaint associations, yet not vain</line>
      <line>Nor profitless, if haply they impressed</line>
      <line>Collateral objects and appearances,</line>
      <line>Albeit lifeless then, and doomed to sleep</line>
      <line> Until maturer seasons called them forth</line>
      <line>To impregnate and to elevate the mind.</line>
      <line>And if the vulgar joy by its own weight</line>
      <line>Wearied itself out of the memory,</line>
      <line>The scenes which were a witness of that joy</line>
      <line>Remained, in their substantial lineaments</line>
      <line>Depicted on the brain, and to the eye</line>
      <line>Were visible, a daily sight. And thus</line>
      <line>By the impressive agency of fear,</line>
      <line>By pleasure and repeated happiness –</line>
      <line> So frequently repeated – and by force</line>
      <line>Of obscure feelings representative</line>
      <line>Of joys that were forgotten, these same scenes,</line>
      <line>So beauteous and majestic in themselves,</line>
      <line>Though yet the day was distant, did at length</line>
      <line>Become habitually dear, and all</line>
      <line>Their hues and forms were by invisible links</line>
      <line>Allied to the affections.</line>
      <line>I began</line>
      <line>My story early, feeling, as I fear,</line>
      <line>The weakness of a human love for days</line>
      <line> Disowned by memory – ere the birth of spring</line>
      <line>Planting my snowdrops among winter snows.</line>
      <line>Nor will it seem to thee, my friend, so prompt</line>
      <line>In sympathy, that I have lengthened out</line>
      <line>With fond and feeble tongue a tedious tale.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile my hope has been that I might fetch</line>
      <line>Reproaches from my former years, whose power</line>
      <line>May spur me on, in manhood now mature,</line>
      <line>To honourable toil. Yet should it be</line>
      <line>That this is but an impotent desire –</line>
      <line> That I by such inquiry am not taught</line>
      <line>To understand myself, nor thou to know</line>
      <line>With better knowledge how the heart was framed</line>
      <line>Of him thou lovest – need I dread from thee</line>
      <line>Harsh judgements if I am so loath to quit</line>
      <line>Those recollected hours that have the charm</line>
      <line>Of visionary things, and lovely forms</line>
      <line>And sweet sensations, that throw back our life</line>
      <line>And make our infancy a visible scene</line>
      <line>On which the sun is shining?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus far, my friend, have we retraced the way</line>
      <line>Through which I travelled when I first began</line>
      <line>To love the woods and fields. The passion yet</line>
      <line>Was in its birth, sustained, as might befall,</line>
      <line> By nourishment that came unsought – for still</line>
      <line>From week to week, from month to month, we lived</line>
      <line>A round of tumult. Duly were our games</line>
      <line>Prolonged in summer till the daylight failed:</line>
      <line>No chair remained before the doors, the bench</line>
      <line>And threshold-steps were empty, fast asleep</line>
      <line>The labourer and the old man who had sat</line>
      <line>A later lingerer, yet the revelry</line>
      <line>Continued and the loud uproar. At last,</line>
      <line>When all the ground was dark and the huge clouds</line>
      <line> Were edged with twinkling stars, to bed we went</line>
      <line>With weary joints and with a beating mind.</line>
      <line>Ah, is there one, who ever has been young</line>
      <line>And needs a monitory voice to tame</line>
      <line>The pride of virtue and of intellect?</line>
      <line>And is there one, the wisest and the best</line>
      <line>Of all mankind, who does not sometimes wish</line>
      <line>For things which cannot be, who would not give,</line>
      <line>If so he might, to duty and to truth</line>
      <line>The eagerness of infantine desire?</line>
      <line> A tranquillizing spirit presses now</line>
      <line>On my corporeal frame, so wide appears</line>
      <line>The vacancy between me and those days,</line>
      <line>Which yet have such self-presence in my heart</line>
      <line>That sometimes when I think of them I seem</line>
      <line>Two consciousnesses – conscious of myself,</line>
      <line>And of some other being.</line>
      <line>A grey stone</line>
      <line>Of native rock, left midway in the square</line>
      <line>Of our small market-village, was the home</line>
      <line>And centre of these joys; and when, returned</line>
      <line> After long absence, thither I repaired,</line>
      <line>I found that it was split and gone to build</line>
      <line>A smart assembly-room that perked and flared</line>
      <line>With wash and rough-cast, elbowing the ground</line>
      <line>Which had been ours. But let the fiddle scream,</line>
      <line>And be ye happy! Yet I know, my friends,</line>
      <line>That more than one of you will think with me</line>
      <line>Of those soft starry nights, and that old dame</line>
      <line>From whom the stone was named, who there had sat</line>
      <line>And watched her table with its huckster’s wares,</line>
      <line> Assiduous, for the length of sixty years.</line>
      <line>We ran a boisterous race, the year spun round</line>
      <line>With giddy motion; but the time approached</line>
      <line>That brought with it a regular desire</line>
      <line>For calmer pleasures – when the beauteous scenes</line>
      <line>Of Nature were collaterally attached</line>
      <line>To every scheme of holiday delight,</line>
      <line>And every boyish sport, less grateful else</line>
      <line>And languidly pursued. When summer came</line>
      <line>It was the pastime of our afternoons</line>
      <line> To beat along the plain of Windermere</line>
      <line>With rival oars; and the selected bourne</line>
      <line>Was now an island musical with birds</line>
      <line>That sang for ever, now a sister isle</line>
      <line>Beneath the oak’s umbrageous covert, sown</line>
      <line>With lilies-of-the-valley like a field,</line>
      <line>And now a third small island where remained</line>
      <line>An old stone table and one mouldered cave –</line>
      <line>A hermit’s history. In such a race,</line>
      <line>So ended, disappointment could be none,</line>
      <line> Uneasiness, or pain, or jealousy;</line>
      <line>We rested in the shade, all pleased alike,</line>
      <line>Conquered or conqueror. Thus our selfishness</line>
      <line>Was mellowed down, and thus the pride of strength</line>
      <line>And the vainglory of superior skill</line>
      <line>Were interfused with objects which subdued</line>
      <line>And tempered them, and gradually produced</line>
      <line>A quiet independence of the heart.</line>
      <line>And to my friend who knows me I may add,</line>
      <line>Unapprehensive of reproof, that hence</line>
      <line> Ensued a diffidence and modesty,</line>
      <line>And I was taught to feel – perhaps too much –</line>
      <line>The self-sufficing power of solitude.</line>
      <line>No delicate viands sapped our bodily strength:</line>
      <line>More than we wished we knew the blessing then</line>
      <line>Of vigorous hunger, for our daily meals</line>
      <line>Were frugal, Sabine fare – and then, exclude</line>
      <line>A little weekly stipend, and we lived</line>
      <line>Through three divisions of the quartered year</line>
      <line>In penniless poverty. But now, to school</line>
      <line> Returned from the half-yearly holidays,</line>
      <line>We came with purses more profusely filled,</line>
      <line>Allowance which abundantly sufficed</line>
      <line>To gratify the palate with repasts</line>
      <line>More costly than the dame of whom I spake,</line>
      <line>That ancient woman, and her board, supplied.</line>
      <line>Hence inroads into distant vales, and long</line>
      <line>Excursions far away among the hills,</line>
      <line>Hence rustic dinners on the cool green ground –</line>
      <line>Or in the woods, or by a river-side</line>
      <line> Or fountain – festive banquets, that provoked</line>
      <line>The languid action of a natural scene</line>
      <line>By pleasure of corporeal appetite.</line>
      <line>Nor is my aim neglected if I tell</line>
      <line>How twice in the long length of those half-years</line>
      <line>We from our funds perhaps with bolder hand</line>
      <line>Drew largely, anxious for one day at least</line>
      <line>To feel the motion of the galloping steed;</line>
      <line>And with the good old innkeeper, in truth,</line>
      <line>I needs must say that sometimes we have used</line>
      <line>Sly subterfuge, for the intended bound</line>
      <line>Of the day’s journey was too distant far</line>
      <line>For any cautious man: a structure famed</line>
      <line>Beyond its neighbourhood, the antique walls</line>
      <line>Of a large abbey, with its fractured arch,</line>
      <line>Belfry, and images, and living trees –</line>
      <line>A holy scene. Along the smooth green turf</line>
      <line>Our horses grazed. In more than inland peace,</line>
      <line>Left by the winds that overpass the vale,</line>
      <line>In that sequestered ruin trees and towers –</line>
      <line> Both silent and both motionless alike –</line>
      <line>Hear all day long the murmuring sea that beats</line>
      <line>Incessantly upon a craggy shore.</line>
      <line>Our steeds remounted, and the summons given,</line>
      <line>With whip and spur we by the chantry flew</line>
      <line>In uncouth race, and left the cross-legged knight</line>
      <line>And the stone abbot, and that single wren</line>
      <line>Which one day sang so sweetly in the nave</line>
      <line>Of the old church that, though from recent showers</line>
      <line>The earth was comfortless, and, touched by faint</line>
      <line> Internal breezes, from the roofless walls</line>
      <line>The shuddering ivy dripped large drops, yet still</line>
      <line>So sweetly mid the gloom the invisible bird</line>
      <line>Sang to itself that there I could have made</line>
      <line>My dwelling-place, and lived for ever there,</line>
      <line>To hear such music. Through the walls we flew</line>
      <line>And down the valley, and, a circuit made</line>
      <line>In wantonness of heart, through rough and smooth</line>
      <line>We scampered homeward. Oh, ye rocks and streams,</line>
      <line>And that still spirit of the evening air,</line>
      <line> Even in this joyous time I sometimes felt</line>
      <line>Your presence, when, with slackened step, we breathed</line>
      <line>Along the sides of the steep hills, or when,</line>
      <line>Lightened by gleams of moonlight from the sea,</line>
      <line>We beat with thundering hoofs the level sand.</line>
      <line>There was a row of ancient trees, since fallen,</line>
      <line>That on the margin of a jutting land</line>
      <line>Stood near the lake of Coniston, and made,</line>
      <line>With its long boughs above the water stretched,</line>
      <line>A gloom through which a boat might sail along</line>
      <line> As in a cloister. An old hall was near,</line>
      <line>Grotesque and beautiful, its gavel-end</line>
      <line>And huge round chimneys to the top o’ergrown</line>
      <line>With fields of ivy. Thither we repaired –</line>
      <line>’Twas even a custom with us – to the shore,</line>
      <line>And to that cool piazza. They who dwelt</line>
      <line>In the neglected mansion-house supplied</line>
      <line>Fresh butter, tea-kettle and earthenware,</line>
      <line>And chafing-dish with smoking coals; and so</line>
      <line>Beneath the trees we sat in our small boat,</line>
      <line> And in the covert ate our delicate meal</line>
      <line>Upon the calm smooth lake.</line>
      <line>It was a joy</line>
      <line>Worthy the heart of one who is full-grown</line>
      <line>To rest beneath those horizontal boughs</line>
      <line>And mark the radiance of the setting sun,</line>
      <line>Himself unseen, reposing on the top</line>
      <line>Of the high eastern hills. And there I said,</line>
      <line>That beauteous sight before me, there I said</line>
      <line>(Then first beginning in my thoughts to mark</line>
      <line>That sense of dim similitude which links</line>
      <line> Our moral feelings with external forms)</line>
      <line>That in whatever region I should close</line>
      <line>My mortal life I would remember you,</line>
      <line>Fair scenes – that dying I would think on you,</line>
      <line>My soul would send a longing look to you,</line>
      <line>Even as that setting sun, while all the vale</line>
      <line>Could nowhere catch one faint memorial gleam,</line>
      <line>Yet with the last remains of his last light</line>
      <line>Still lingered, and a farewell lustre threw</line>
      <line>On the dear mountain-tops where first he rose.</line>
      <line> ’Twas then my fourteenth summer, and these words</line>
      <line>Were uttered in a casual access</line>
      <line>Of sentiment, a momentary trance</line>
      <line>That far outran the habit of my mind.</line>
      <line>Upon the eastern shore of Windermere</line>
      <line>Above the crescent of a pleasant bay</line>
      <line>There was an inn, no homely-featured shed,</line>
      <line>Brother of the surrounding cottages,</line>
      <line>But ’twas a splendid place, the door beset</line>
      <line>With chaises, grooms, and liveries, and within</line>
      <line> Decanters, glasses and the blood-red wine.</line>
      <line>In ancient times, or ere the hall was built</line>
      <line>On the large island, had the dwelling been</line>
      <line>More worthy of a poet’s love, a hut</line>
      <line>Proud of its one bright fire and sycamore shade;</line>
      <line>But though the rhymes were gone which once inscribed</line>
      <line>The threshold, and large golden characters</line>
      <line>On the blue-frosted signboard had usurped</line>
      <line>The place of the old lion, in contempt</line>
      <line>And mockery of the rustic painter’s hand,</line>
      <line> Yet to this hour the spot to me is dear</line>
      <line>With all its foolish pomp. The garden lay</line>
      <line>Upon a slope surmounted by the plain</line>
      <line>Of a small bowling-green; beneath us stood</line>
      <line>A grove, with gleams of water through the trees</line>
      <line>And over the tree-tops – nor did we want</line>
      <line>Refreshment, strawberries and mellow cream –</line>
      <line>And there through half an afternoon we played</line>
      <line>On the smooth platform, and the shouts we sent</line>
      <line>Made all the mountains ring.</line>
      <line>But ere the fall</line>
      <line>Of night, when in our pinnace we returned</line>
      <line>Over the dusky lake, and to the beach</line>
      <line>Of some small island steered our course, with one,</line>
      <line>The minstrel of our troop, and left him there,</line>
      <line>And rowed off gently, while he blew his flute</line>
      <line>Alone upon the rock, oh, then the calm</line>
      <line>And dead still water lay upon my mind</line>
      <line>Even with a weight of pleasure, and the sky,</line>
      <line>Never before so beautiful, sank down</line>
      <line>Into my heart and held me like a dream.</line>
      <line> Thus day by day my sympathies increased,</line>
      <line>And thus the common range of visible things</line>
      <line>Grew dear to me. Already I began</line>
      <line>To love the sun – a boy I loved the sun</line>
      <line>Not as I since have loved him (as a pledge</line>
      <line>And surety of my earthly life, a light</line>
      <line>Which while I view I feel I am alive),</line>
      <line>But for this cause, that I had seen him lay</line>
      <line>His beauty on the morning hills, had seen</line>
      <line>The western mountain touch his setting orb</line>
      <line> In many a thoughtless hour, when from excess</line>
      <line>Of happiness my blood appeared to flow</line>
      <line>With its own pleasure, and I breathed with joy.</line>
      <line>And from like feelings, humble though intense,</line>
      <line>To patriotic and domestic love</line>
      <line>Analogous, the moon to me was dear:</line>
      <line>For I would dream away my purposes</line>
      <line>Standing to look upon her, while she hung</line>
      <line>Midway between the hills as if she knew</line>
      <line>No other region but belonged to thee,</line>
      <line> Yea appertained by a peculiar right</line>
      <line>To thee and thy grey huts, my native vale.</line>
      <line>Those incidental charms which first attached</line>
      <line>My heart to rural objects, day by day</line>
      <line>Grew weaker, and I hasten on to tell</line>
      <line>How Nature, intervenient till this time</line>
      <line>And secondary, now at length was sought</line>
      <line>For her own sake. But who shall parcel out</line>
      <line>His intellect by geometric rules</line>
      <line>Split like a province into round and square?</line>
      <line> Who knows the individual hour in which</line>
      <line>His habits were first sown even as a seed?</line>
      <line>Who that shall point as with a wand, and say</line>
      <line>‘This portion of the river of my mind</line>
      <line>Came from yon fountain’? Thou, my friend, art one</line>
      <line>More deeply read in thy own thoughts, no slave</line>
      <line>Of that false secondary power by which</line>
      <line>In weakness we create distinctions, then</line>
      <line>Believe our puny boundaries are things</line>
      <line>Which we perceive, and not which we have made.</line>
      <line> To thee, unblinded by these outward shows,</line>
      <line>The unity of all has been revealed;</line>
      <line>And thou wilt doubt with me, less aptly skilled</line>
      <line>Than many are to class the cabinet</line>
      <line>Of their sensations, and in voluble phrase</line>
      <line>Run through the history and birth of each</line>
      <line>As of a single independent thing.</line>
      <line>Hard task to analyze a soul, in which</line>
      <line>Not only general habits and desires,</line>
      <line>But each most obvious and particular thought –</line>
      <line> Not in a mystical and idle sense,</line>
      <line>But in the words of reason deeply weighed –</line>
      <line>Hath no beginning.</line>
      <line>Blest the infant babe –</line>
      <line>For with my best conjectures I would trace</line>
      <line>The progress of our being – blest the babe</line>
      <line>Nursed in his mother’s arms, the babe who sleeps</line>
      <line>Upon his mother’s breast, who, when his soul</line>
      <line>Claims manifest kindred with an earthly soul,</line>
      <line>Doth gather passion from his mother’s eye.</line>
      <line>Such feelings pass into his torpid life</line>
      <line> Like an awakening breeze, and hence his mind,</line>
      <line>Even in the first trial of its powers,</line>
      <line>Is prompt and watchful, eager to combine</line>
      <line>In one appearance all the elements</line>
      <line>And parts of the same object, else detached</line>
      <line>And loath to coalesce. Thus day by day,</line>
      <line>Subjected to the discipline of love,</line>
      <line>His organs and recipient faculties</line>
      <line>Are quickened, are more vigorous; his mind spreads,</line>
      <line>Tenacious of the forms which it receives.</line>
      <line> In one belovéd presence – nay and more,</line>
      <line>In that most apprehensive habitude</line>
      <line>And those sensations which have been derived</line>
      <line>From this belovéd presence – there exists</line>
      <line>A virtue which irradiates and exalts</line>
      <line>All objects through all intercourse of sense.</line>
      <line>No outcast he, bewildered and depressed;</line>
      <line>Along his infant veins are interfused</line>
      <line>The gravitation and the filial bond</line>
      <line>Of Nature that connect him with the world.</line>
      <line> Emphatically such a being lives,</line>
      <line>An inmate of this active universe.</line>
      <line>From Nature largely he receives, nor so</line>
      <line>Is satisfied, but largely gives again;</line>
      <line>For feeling has to him imparted strength,</line>
      <line>And – powerful in all sentiments of grief,</line>
      <line>Of exultation, fear and joy – his mind,</line>
      <line>Even as an agent of the one great mind,</line>
      <line>Creates, creator and receiver both,</line>
      <line>Working but in alliance with the works</line>
      <line>Which it beholds. Such, verily, is the first</line>
      <line>Poetic spirit of our human life –</line>
      <line>By uniform control of after-years</line>
      <line>In most abated and suppressed, in some</line>
      <line>Through every change of growth or of decay</line>
      <line>Pre-eminent till death.</line>
      <line>From early days,</line>
      <line>Beginning not long after that first time</line>
      <line>In which, a babe, by intercourse of touch</line>
      <line>I held mute dialogues with my mother’s heart,</line>
      <line>I have endeavoured to display the means</line>
      <line> Whereby this infant sensibility,</line>
      <line>Great birthright of our being, was in me</line>
      <line>Augmented and sustained. Yet is a path</line>
      <line>More difficult before me, and I fear</line>
      <line>That in its broken windings we shall need</line>
      <line>The chamois’ sinews and the eagle’s wing.</line>
      <line>For now a trouble came into my mind</line>
      <line>From obscure causes. I was left alone</line>
      <line>Seeking this visible world, nor knowing why:</line>
      <line>The props of my affections were removed,</line>
      <line> And yet the building stood, as if sustained</line>
      <line>By its own spirit. All that I beheld</line>
      <line>Was dear to me, and from this cause it came</line>
      <line>That now to Nature’s finer influxes</line>
      <line>My mind lay open – to that more exact</line>
      <line>And intimate communion which our hearts</line>
      <line>Maintain with the minuter properties</line>
      <line>Of objects which already are beloved,</line>
      <line>And of those only.</line>
      <line>Many are the joys</line>
      <line>Of youth, but oh, what happiness to live</line>
      <line> When every hour brings palpable access</line>
      <line>Of knowledge, when all knowledge is delight,</line>
      <line>And sorrow is not there. The seasons came,</line>
      <line>And every season brought a countless store</line>
      <line>Of modes and temporary qualities</line>
      <line>Which but for this most watchful power of love</line>
      <line>Had been neglected – left a register</line>
      <line>Of permanent relations, else unknown.</line>
      <line>Hence life and change and beauty, solitude</line>
      <line>More active even than ‘best society’,</line>
      <line> Society made sweet as solitude</line>
      <line>By silent inobtrusive sympathies,</line>
      <line>And gentle agitations of the mind</line>
      <line>From manifold distinctions (difference</line>
      <line>Perceived in things where to the common eye</line>
      <line>No difference is) – and hence, from the same source,</line>
      <line>Sublimer joy.</line>
      <line>For I would walk alone</line>
      <line>In storm and tempest, or in starlight nights</line>
      <line>Beneath the quiet heavens, and at that time</line>
      <line>Would feel whate’er there is of power in sound</line>
      <line> To breathe an elevated mood, by form</line>
      <line>Or image unprofaned; and I would stand</line>
      <line>Beneath some rock, listening to sounds that are</line>
      <line>The ghostly language of the ancient earth,</line>
      <line>Or make their dim abode in distant winds.</line>
      <line>Thence did I drink the visionary power.</line>
      <line>I deem not profitless these fleeting moods</line>
      <line>Of shadowy exaltation; not for this,</line>
      <line>That they are kindred to our purer mind</line>
      <line>And intellectual life, but that the soul –</line>
      <line> Remembering how she felt, but what she felt</line>
      <line>Remembering not – retains an obscure sense</line>
      <line>Of possible sublimity, to which</line>
      <line>With growing faculties she doth aspire,</line>
      <line>With faculties still growing, feeling still</line>
      <line>That whatsoever point they gain they still</line>
      <line>Have something to pursue.</line>
      <line>And not alone</line>
      <line>In grandeur and in tumult, but no less</line>
      <line>In tranquil scenes, that universal power</line>
      <line>And fitness in the latent qualities</line>
      <line> And essences of things, by which the mind</line>
      <line>Is moved with feelings of delight, to me</line>
      <line>Came strengthened with a superadded soul,</line>
      <line>A virtue not its own. My morning walks</line>
      <line>Were early: oft before the hours of school</line>
      <line>I travelled round our little lake, five miles</line>
      <line>Of pleasant wandering – happy time, more dear</line>
      <line>For this, that one was by my side, a friend</line>
      <line>Then passionately loved. With heart how full</line>
      <line>Will he peruse these lines, this page (perhaps</line>
      <line> A blank to other men); for many years</line>
      <line>Have since flowed in between us, and, our minds</line>
      <line>Both silent to each other, at this time</line>
      <line>We live as if those hours had never been.</line>
      <line>Nor seldom did I lift our cottage latch</line>
      <line>Far earlier, and before the vernal thrush</line>
      <line>Was audible, among the hills I sat</line>
      <line>Alone upon some jutting eminence</line>
      <line>At the first hour of morning, when the vale</line>
      <line>Lay quiet in an utter solitude.</line>
      <line> How shall I trace the history, where seek</line>
      <line>The origin of what I then have felt?</line>
      <line>Oft in those moments such a holy calm</line>
      <line>Did overspread my soul that I forgot</line>
      <line>The agency of sight, and what I saw</line>
      <line>Appeared like something in myself, a dream,</line>
      <line>A prospect in my mind.</line>
      <line>’Twere long to tell</line>
      <line>What spring and autumn, what the winter snows,</line>
      <line>And what the summer shade, what day and night,</line>
      <line>The evening and the morning, what my dreams</line>
      <line>And what my waking thoughts, supplied to nurse</line>
      <line>That spirit of religious love in which</line>
      <line>I walked with Nature. But let this at least</line>
      <line>Be not forgotten, that I still retained</line>
      <line>My first creative sensibility,</line>
      <line>That by the regular action of the world</line>
      <line>My soul was unsubdued. A plastic power</line>
      <line>Abode with me, a forming hand, at times</line>
      <line>Rebellious, acting in a devious mood,</line>
      <line>A local spirit of its own, at war</line>
      <line> With general tendency, but for the most</line>
      <line>Subservient strictly to the external things</line>
      <line>With which it communed. An auxiliar light</line>
      <line>Came from my mind, which on the setting sun</line>
      <line>Bestowed new splendour; the melodious birds,</line>
      <line>The gentle breezes, fountains that ran on</line>
      <line>Murmuring so sweetly in themselves, obeyed</line>
      <line>A like dominion, and the midnight storm</line>
      <line>Grew darker in the presence of my eye.</line>
      <line>Hence my obeisance, my devotion hence,</line>
      <line>And hence my transport.</line>
      <line> Nor should this, perchance,</line>
      <line>Pass unrecorded, that I still had loved</line>
      <line>The exercise and produce of a toil</line>
      <line>Than analytic industry to me</line>
      <line>More pleasing, and whose character I deem</line>
      <line>Is more poetic, as resembling more</line>
      <line>Creative agency – I mean to speak</line>
      <line>Of that interminable building reared</line>
      <line>By observation of affinities</line>
      <line>In objects where no brotherhood exists</line>
      <line> To common minds. My seventeenth year was come,</line>
      <line>And, whether (from this habit rooted now</line>
      <line>So deeply in my mind, or from excess</line>
      <line>Of the great social principle of life</line>
      <line>Coercing all things into sympathy)</line>
      <line>To unorganic natures I transferred</line>
      <line>My own enjoyments, or (the power of truth</line>
      <line>Coming in revelation) I conversed</line>
      <line>With things that really are, I at this time</line>
      <line>Saw blessings spread around me like a sea.</line>
      <line> Thus did my days pass on, and now at length</line>
      <line>From Nature and her overflowing soul</line>
      <line>I had received so much that all my thoughts</line>
      <line>Were steeped in feeling.</line>
      <line>I was only then</line>
      <line>Contented when with bliss ineffable</line>
      <line>I felt the sentiment of being, spread</line>
      <line>O’er all that moves and all that seemeth still,</line>
      <line>O’er all that, lost beyond the reach of thought</line>
      <line>And human knowledge, to the human eye</line>
      <line>Invisible, yet liveth to the heart,</line>
      <line> O’er all that leaps, and runs, and shouts, and sings,</line>
      <line>Or beats the gladsome air, o’er all that glides</line>
      <line>Beneath the wave, yea, in the wave itself</line>
      <line>And mighty depth of waters. Wonder not</line>
      <line>If such my transports were, for in all things</line>
      <line>I saw one life, and felt that it was joy;</line>
      <line>One song they sang and it was audible –</line>
      <line>Most audible then when the fleshly ear,</line>
      <line>O’ercome by grosser prelude of that strain,</line>
      <line>Forgot its functions and slept undisturbed.</line>
      <line> If this be error, and another faith</line>
      <line>Find easier access to the pious mind,</line>
      <line>Yet were I grossly destitute of all</line>
      <line>Those human sentiments which make this earth</line>
      <line>So dear if I should fail with grateful voice</line>
      <line>To speak of you, ye mountains, and ye lakes</line>
      <line>And sounding cataracts, ye mists and winds</line>
      <line>That dwell among the hills where I was born.</line>
      <line>If in my youth I have been pure in heart,</line>
      <line>If, mingling with the world, I am content</line>
      <line> With my own modest pleasures, and have lived</line>
      <line>With God and Nature communing, removed</line>
      <line>From little enmities and low desires,</line>
      <line>The gift is yours! If, in these times of fear,</line>
      <line>This melancholy waste of hopes overthrown,</line>
      <line>If, mid indifference and apathy</line>
      <line>And wicked exultation, when good men</line>
      <line>On every side fall off we know not how</line>
      <line>To selfishness (disguised in gentle names</line>
      <line>Of peace and quiet and domestic love,</line>
      <line> Yet mingled, not unwillingly, with sneers</line>
      <line>On visionary minds) – if, in this time</line>
      <line>Of dereliction and dismay, I yet</line>
      <line>Despair not of our nature, but retain</line>
      <line>A more than Roman confidence, a faith</line>
      <line>That fails not, in all sorrow my support,</line>
      <line>The blessing of my life, the gift is yours</line>
      <line>Ye mountains, thine oh Nature! Thou hast fed</line>
      <line>My lofty speculations, and in thee,</line>
      <line>For this uneasy heart of ours, I find</line>
      <line> A never-failing principle of joy</line>
      <line>And purest passion.</line>
      <line>Thou, my friend, wast reared</line>
      <line>In the great city, mid far other scenes,</line>
      <line>But we by different roads at length have gained</line>
      <line>The self-same bourne. And from this cause to thee</line>
      <line>I speak unapprehensive of contempt,</line>
      <line>The insinuated scoff of coward tongues,</line>
      <line>And all that silent language which so oft</line>
      <line>In conversation betwixt man and man</line>
      <line>Blots from the human countenance all trace</line>
      <line>Of beauty and of love. For thou hast sought</line>
      <line>The truth in solitude, and thou art one</line>
      <line>The most intense of Nature’s worshippers,</line>
      <line>In many things my brother, chiefly here</line>
      <line>In this my deep devotion.</line>
      <line>Fare thee well!</line>
      <line>Health and the quiet of a healthful mind</line>
      <line>Attend thee, seeking oft the haunts of men –</line>
      <line>But yet more often living with thyself,</line>
      <line>And for thyself – so haply shall thy days</line>
      <line>Be many, and a blessing to mankind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>Statue Horse</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>One evening, walking in the public way,</line>
      <line>A peasant of the valley where I dwelt</line>
      <line>Being my chance companion, he stopped short</line>
      <line>And pointed to an object full in view</line>
      <line> At a small distance. ’Twas a horse, that stood</line>
      <line>Alone upon a little breast of ground</line>
      <line>With a clear silver moonlight sky behind.</line>
      <line>With one leg from the ground the creature stood,</line>
      <line>Insensible and still: breath, motion, gone –</line>
      <line>Hairs, colour, all but shape and substance, gone –</line>
      <line>Mane, ears, and tail, as lifeless as the trunk</line>
      <line>That had no stir of breath! We paused awhile</line>
      <line>In pleasure of the sight, and left him there,</line>
      <line>With all his functions silently sealed up,</line>
      <line> Like an amphibious work of Nature’s hand,</line>
      <line>A borderer dwelling betwixt life and death,</line>
      <line>A living statue or a statued life.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>Climbing of Snowdon (Prelude XIII)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was a summer’s night, a close warm night,</line>
      <line>Wan, dull and glaring, with a dripping mist</line>
      <line>Low-hung and thick that covered all the sky</line>
      <line>Half threatening storm and rain; but on we went</line>
      <line>Unchecked, being full of heart and having faith</line>
      <line> In our tried pilot. Little could we see</line>
      <line>Hemmed round on every side with fog and damp,</line>
      <line>And, after ordinary travellers’ chat</line>
      <line>With our conductor, silently we sank</line>
      <line>Each into commerce with his private thoughts.</line>
      <line>Thus did we breast the ascent, and by myself</line>
      <line>Was nothing either seen or heard the while</line>
      <line>Which took me from my musings, save that once</line>
      <line>The shepherd’s cur did to his own great joy</line>
      <line>Unearth a hedgehog in the mountain crags</line>
      <line> Round which he made a barking turbulent.</line>
      <line>This small adventure (for even such it seemed</line>
      <line>In that wild place and at the dead of night)</line>
      <line>Being over and forgotten, on we wound</line>
      <line>In silence as before.</line>
      <line>With forehead bent</line>
      <line>Earthward, as if in opposition set</line>
      <line>Against an enemy, I panted up</line>
      <line>With eager pace, and no less eager thoughts.</line>
      <line>Thus might we wear perhaps an hour away,</line>
      <line>Ascending at loose distance each from each,</line>
      <line> And I, as chanced, the foremost of the band –</line>
      <line>When at my feet the ground appeared to brighten,</line>
      <line>And with a step or two seemed brighter still;</line>
      <line>Nor had I time to ask the cause of this,</line>
      <line>For instantly a light upon the turf</line>
      <line>Fell like a flash! I looked about, and lo,</line>
      <line>The moon stood naked in the heavens at height</line>
      <line>Immense above my head, and on the shore</line>
      <line>I found myself of a huge sea of mist,</line>
      <line>Which meek and silent rested at my feet.</line>
      <line> A hundred hills their dusky backs upheaved</line>
      <line>All over this still ocean; and beyond,</line>
      <line>Far, far beyond, the vapours shot themselves</line>
      <line>In headlands, tongues, and promontory shapes,</line>
      <line>Into the sea – the real sea, that seemed</line>
      <line>To dwindle and give up its majesty,</line>
      <line>Usurped upon as far as sight could reach.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile, the moon looked down upon this show</line>
      <line>In single glory, and we stood, the mist</line>
      <line>Touching our very feet.</line>
      <line>And from the shore</line>
      <line> At distance not the third part of a mile</line>
      <line>Was a blue chasm, a fracture in the vapour,</line>
      <line>A deep and gloomy breathing-place through which</line>
      <line>Mounted the roar of waters, torrents, streams</line>
      <line>Innumerable, roaring with one voice!</line>
      <line>The universal spectacle throughout</line>
      <line>Was shaped for admiration and delight,</line>
      <line>Grand in itself alone, but in that breach</line>
      <line>Through which the homeless voice of waters rose,</line>
      <line>That dark deep thoroughfare, had Nature lodged</line>
      <line> The soul, the imagination of the whole.</line>
      <line>A meditation rose in me that night</line>
      <line>Upon the lonely mountain when the scene</line>
      <line>Had passed away, and it appeared to me</line>
      <line>The perfect image of a mighty mind,</line>
      <line>Of one that feeds upon infinity,</line>
      <line>That is exalted by an underpresence,</line>
      <line>The sense of God, or whatso’er is dim</line>
      <line>Or vast in its own being.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>Crossing the Alps (Prelude VI)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upturning with a band</line>
      <line> Of travellers, from the Valais we had clomb</line>
      <line>Along the road that leads to Italy;</line>
      <line>A length of hours, making of these our guides</line>
      <line>Did we advance, and having reached an inn</line>
      <line>Among the mountains, we together ate</line>
      <line>Our noon’s repast, from which the travellers rose</line>
      <line>Leaving us at the board. Erelong we followed,</line>
      <line>Descending by the beaten road that led</line>
      <line>Right to a rivulet’s edge, and there broke off.</line>
      <line>The only track now visible was one</line>
      <line>Upon the further side, right opposite,</line>
      <line>And up a lofty mountain. This we took</line>
      <line>After a little scruple, and short pause,</line>
      <line>And climbed with eagerness, though not at length</line>
      <line>Without surprise and some anxiety</line>
      <line>On finding that we did not overtake</line>
      <line>Our comrades gone before. By fortunate chance,</line>
      <line>While every moment now increased our doubts,</line>
      <line>A peasant met us, and from him we learned</line>
      <line>That to the place which had perplexed us first</line>
      <line> We must descend, and there should find the road,</line>
      <line>Which in the stony channel of the stream</line>
      <line>Lay a few steps, and then along its banks –</line>
      <line>And further, that thenceforward all our course</line>
      <line>Was downwards with the current of that stream.</line>
      <line>Hard of belief, we questioned him again,</line>
      <line>And all the answers which the man returned</line>
      <line>To our inquiries – in their sense and substance,</line>
      <line>Translated by the feelings which we had –</line>
      <line>Ended in this, that we had crossed the Alps!</line>
      <line> Imagination – lifting up itself</line>
      <line>Before the eye and progress of my song</line>
      <line>Like an unfathered vapour, here that power,</line>
      <line>In all the might of its endowments, came</line>
      <line>Athwart me! I was lost as in a cloud,</line>
      <line>Halted without a struggle to break through;</line>
      <line>And now, recovering, to my soul I say</line>
      <line>‘I recognize thy glory.’ In such strength</line>
      <line>Of usurpation, in such visitings</line>
      <line>Of awful promise, when the light of sense</line>
      <line> Goes out in flashes that have shown to us</line>
      <line>The invisible world, does greatness make abode –</line>
      <line>There harbours whether we be young or old.</line>
      <line>Our destiny, our nature, and our home,</line>
      <line>Is with infinitude, and only there –</line>
      <line>With hope it is, hope that can never die,</line>
      <line>Effort, and expectation, and desire,</line>
      <line>And something evermore about to be.</line>
      <line>The mind beneath such banners militant</line>
      <line>Thinks not of spoils or trophies, nor of aught</line>
      <line> That may attest its prowess, blest in thoughts</line>
      <line>That are their own perfection and reward –</line>
      <line>Strong in itself, and in the access of joy</line>
      <line>Which hides it like the overflowing Nile.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dull and heavy slackening which ensued</line>
      <line>Upon those tidings by the peasant given</line>
      <line>Was soon dislodged. Downwards we hurried fast,</line>
      <line>And entered with the road which we had missed</line>
      <line>Into a narrow chasm. The brook and road</line>
      <line>Were fellow-travellers in this gloomy pass,</line>
      <line> And with them did we journey several hours</line>
      <line>At a slow step. The immeasurable height</line>
      <line>Of woods decaying, never to be decayed,</line>
      <line>The stationary blasts of waterfalls,</line>
      <line>And everywhere along the hollow rent</line>
      <line>Winds thwarting winds, bewildered and forlorn,</line>
      <line>The torrents shooting from the clear blue sky,</line>
      <line>The rocks that muttered close upon our ears,</line>
      <line>Black drizzling crags that spake by the wayside</line>
      <line>As if a voice were in them, the sick sight</line>
      <line> And giddy prospect of the raving stream,</line>
      <line>The unfettered clouds and region of the heavens,</line>
      <line>Tumult and peace, the darkness and the light –</line>
      <line>Were all like workings of one mind, the features</line>
      <line>Of the same face, blossoms upon one tree,</line>
      <line>Characters of the great apocalypse,</line>
      <line>The types and symbols of eternity,</line>
      <line>Of first, and last, and midst, and without end.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM LISLE BOWLES</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>from Coombe Ellen</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Call the strange spirit that abides unseen</line>
      <line>In wilds and wastes and shaggy solitudes,</line>
      <line>And bid his dim hand lead thee through these scenes</line>
      <line>That burst immense around – by mountains, glens,</line>
      <line> And solitary cataracts that dash</line>
      <line>Through dark ravines, and trees whose wreathéd roots</line>
      <line>O’erhang the torrent’s channelled course, and streams</line>
      <line>That far below, along the narrow vale,</line>
      <line>Upon their rocky way wind musical!</line>
      <line>Stranger, if Nature charm thee – if thou lovest</line>
      <line>To trace her awful steps, in glade or glen,</line>
      <line>Or under covert of the rocking wood</line>
      <line>That sways its murmuring and mossy boughs</line>
      <line>Above thy head – now, when the wind at times</line>
      <line> Stirs its deep silence round thee, and the shower</line>
      <line>Falls on the sighing foliage, hail her here</line>
      <line>In these her haunts, and, wrapt in musings high,</line>
      <line>Think that thou holdest converse with some power</line>
      <line>Invisible and strange…</line>
      <line>Here Melancholy, on the pale crags laid,</line>
      <line>Might muse herself to sleep; or Fancy come,</line>
      <line>Witching the mind with tender cozenage,</line>
      <line>And shaping things that are not – here all day</line>
      <line>Might Meditation listen to the lapse</line>
      <line>Of the white waters flashing through the cleft,</line>
      <line>And, gazing on the many shadowing trees,</line>
      <line>Mingle a pensive moral as she gazed.</line>
      <line>High o’er thy head, amidst the shivered slate,</line>
      <line> Behold (a sapling yet) the wild ash bend,</line>
      <line>Its dark red berries clustering, as if it wished</line>
      <line>In the clear liquid mirror, ere it fell,</line>
      <line>To trace its beauties. O’er the prone cascade,</line>
      <line>Airy, and light, and elegant, the birch</line>
      <line>Displays its glossy stem amidst the gloom</line>
      <line>Of alders and jagg’d fern, as she wooed</line>
      <line>The passing gale to whisper flatteries!</line>
      <line>Upon the adverse bank, withered, and stripped</line>
      <line>Of all its pleasant leaves, a scathéd oak</line>
      <line>Hangs desolate…</line>
      <line>Now wind we up the glen, and hear below</line>
      <line>The dashing torrent, in deep woods concealed –</line>
      <line>And now, again, white water flashing on the view</line>
      <line>O’er the huge craggy fragments! Ancient stream,</line>
