      <line>That murmurest through the mountain-solitudes,</line>
      <line>The time has been when no eye marked thy course</line>
      <line>Save his who made the world. Fancy might dream</line>
      <line>She saw thee thus bound on from age to age</line>
      <line>Unseen of man, whilst awful Nature sat</line>
      <line> On the rent rocks, and said: ‘These haunts be mine!’</line>
      <line>Now Taste has marked thy features, here and there</line>
      <line>Touching with tender hand, but injuring not,</line>
      <line>Thy beauties – whilst along thy woody verge</line>
      <line>Ascends the winding pathway, and the eye</line>
      <line>Catches at intervals thy varied falls.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>From Beachy Head</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>An early worshipper at Nature’s shrine,</line>
      <line>I loved her rudest scenes – warrens, and heaths,</line>
      <line>And yellow commons, and birch-shaded hollows,</line>
      <line>And hedgerows bordering unfrequented lanes,</line>
      <line>Bowered with wild roses and the clasping woodbine,</line>
      <line>Where purple tassels of the tangling vetch</line>
      <line>With bittersweet and bryony inweave,</line>
      <line>And the dew fills the silver bindweed’s cups.</line>
      <line>I loved to trace the brooks whose humid banks</line>
      <line> Nourish the harebell and the freckled pagil,</line>
      <line>And stroll among o’ershadowing woods of beech,</line>
      <line>Lending in summer from the heats of noon</line>
      <line>A whispering shade; while haply there reclines</line>
      <line>Some pensive lover of uncultured flowers</line>
      <line>Who, from the tumps with bright green mosses clad,</line>
      <line>Plucks the wood-sorrel with its light thin leaves,</line>
      <line>Heart-shaped and triply-folded, and its root</line>
      <line>Creeping like beaded coral – or who there</line>
      <line>Gathers (the copse’s pride) anemones,</line>
      <line> With rays like golden studs on ivory laid</line>
      <line>Most delicate, but touched with purple clouds,</line>
      <line>Fit crown for April’s fair but changeful brow.</line>
      <line>Ah, hills so early loved! In fancy still</line>
      <line>I breathe your pure keen air and still behold</line>
      <line>Those widely spreading views, mocking alike</line>
      <line>The poet and the painter’s utmost art –</line>
      <line>And still (observing objects more minute)</line>
      <line>Wondering remark the strange and foreign forms</line>
      <line>Of seashells, with the pale calcareous soil</line>
      <line> Mingled, and seeming of resembling substance –</line>
      <line>Though surely the blue ocean (from the heights</line>
      <line>Where the downs westward tend, but dimly seen)</line>
      <line>Here never rolled its surge? Does Nature then</line>
      <line>Mimic, in wanton mood, fantastic shapes</line>
      <line>Of bivalves, and inwreathed volutes, that cling</line>
      <line>To the dark sea-rock of the watery world?</line>
      <line>Or did this range of chalky mountains once</line>
      <line>Form a vast basin, where the ocean-waves</line>
      <line>Swelled fathomless, what time these fossil shells,</line>
      <line> Buoyed on their native element, were thrown</line>
      <line>Among the imbedding calx when the huge hill</line>
      <line>Its giant bulk heaved, and in strange ferment</line>
      <line>Grew up a guardian-barrier ’twixt the sea</line>
      <line>And the green level of the sylvan weald?</line>
      <line>Ah, very vain is Science’ proudest boast,</line>
      <line>And but a little light its flame yet lends</line>
      <line>To its most ardent votaries; since from whence</line>
      <line>These fossil forms are seen is but conjecture,</line>
      <line>Food for vague theories, or vain dispute –</line>
      <line> While to his daily task the peasant goes</line>
      <line>Unheeding such inquiry, with no care</line>
      <line>But that kindly change of sun and shower</line>
      <line>Fit for his toil the earth he cultivates.</line>
      <line>As little recks the herdsman of the hill</line>
      <line>(Who on some turfy knoll, idly reclined,</line>
      <line>Watches his wether-flock) that deep beneath</line>
      <line>Rest the remains of men of whom is left</line>
      <line>No traces in the records of mankind,</line>
      <line>Save what these half-obliterated mounds</line>
      <line>And half-filled trenches doubtfully impart…</line>
      <line>Near where a richer tract of cultured land</line>
      <line>Slopes to the south, and (burnished by the sun)</line>
      <line>Bend in the gale of August floods of corn;</line>
      <line>The guardian of the flock, with watchful care,</line>
      <line>Repels by voice and dog the encroaching sheep –</line>
      <line>While his boy visits every wiréd trap</line>
      <line>That scars the turf; and from the pit-falls takes</line>
      <line>The timid migrants, who, from distant wilds,</line>
      <line>Warrens and stone-quarries, are destined thus</line>
      <line> To lose their short existence. But unsought</line>
      <line>By Luxury yet, the shepherd still protects</line>
      <line>The social bird, who from his native haunts</line>
      <line>Of willowy current, or the rushy pool,</line>
      <line>Follows the fleecy crowd, and flirts and skims,</line>
      <line>In fellowship among them.</line>
      <line>Where the knoll</line>
      <line>More elevated takes the changeful winds,</line>
      <line>The windmill rears its vanes; and thitherward</line>
      <line>With his white load, the master travelling</line>
      <line>Scares the rooks rising slow on whispering wings,</line>
      <line> While o’er his head (before the summer sun</line>
      <line>Lights up the blue expanse), heard more than seen,</line>
      <line>The lark sings matins, and, above the clouds</line>
      <line>Floating, embathes his spotted breast in dew.</line>
      <line>Beneath the shadow of a gnarléd thorn</line>
      <line>Bent by the sea blast, from a seat of turf</line>
      <line>With fairy nosegays strewn, how wide the view!</line>
      <line>Till in the distant north it melts away</line>
      <line>And mingles indiscriminate with clouds –</line>
      <line>But if the eye could reach so far, the mart</line>
      <line> Of England’s capital, its domes and spires,</line>
      <line>Might be perceived! Yet hence the distant range</line>
      <line>Of Kentish hills appear in purple haze,</line>
      <line>And nearer, undulate the wooded heights</line>
      <line>And airy summits that above the mole</line>
      <line>Rise in green beauty, and the beaconed ridge</line>
      <line>Of Black Down shagged with heath, and, swelling rude</line>
      <line>Like a dark island from the vale, its brow</line>
      <line>Catching the last rays of the evening sun</line>
      <line>That gleam between the nearer park’s old oaks,</line>
      <line> Then lighten up the river, and make prominent</line>
      <line>The portal, and the ruined battlements</line>
      <line>Of that dismantled fortress, raised what time</line>
      <line>The Conqueror’s successors fiercely fought,</line>
      <line>Tearing with civil feuds the desolate land.</line>
      <line>But now a tiller of the soil dwells there,</line>
      <line>And of the turret’s looped and raftered halls</line>
      <line>Has made an humbler homestead – where he sees,</line>
      <line>Instead of arméd foemen, herds that graze</line>
      <line>Along his yellow meadows, or his flocks</line>
      <line>At evening from the upland driven to fold.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>AMELIA OPIE</author>
    <date>1808</date>
    <title>Stanzas Written Under Aeolus’ Harp</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come ye, whose hearts the tyrant sorrows wound,</line>
      <line>Come ye, whose breasts the tyrant passions tear,</line>
      <line>And seek this harp in whose still varying sound</line>
      <line>Each woe its own appropriate plaint may hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Solemn and slow yon murmuring cadence rolls</line>
      <line>Till on the attentive ear it dies away,</line>
      <line>To your fond griefs responsive – ye whose souls,</line>
      <line>O’er loved lost friends, regret’s sad tribute pay!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But hark, in regular progression move</line>
      <line>Yon silver sounds, and mingle as they fall!</line>
      <line>Do they not wake thy trembling nerves, oh Love,</line>
      <line>And into warmer life thy feelings call?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Again it speaks, but, shrill and swift, the tones</line>
      <line>In wild disorder strike upon the ear!</line>
      <line> Pale Frenzy listens, kindred wildness owns,</line>
      <line>And starts – appalled the well-known sounds to hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lo, e’en the gay, the giddy and the vain,</line>
      <line>In deep delight these vocal wires attend –</line>
      <line>Silent and breathless watch the varying strain</line>
      <line>And, pleased, the vacant toils of mirth suspend.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So when the lute on Memnon’s statue hung</line>
      <line>(At day’s first rising) strains melodious poured</line>
      <line>Untouched by mortal hands, the gathering throng</line>
      <line>In silent wonder listened and adored.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But the wild cadence of these trembling strings</line>
      <line>The enchantress Fancy with most rapture hears –</line>
      <line>At the sweet sound to grasp her wand she springs,</line>
      <line>And lo, her band of airy shapes appears!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She (rapt enthusiast) thinks the melting strains</line>
      <line>A choir of angels breathe, in bright array</line>
      <line>Bearing on radiant clouds to yon blue plains</line>
      <line>A soul just parted from its silent clay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And oft at eve her wild creative eye</line>
      <line>Sees to the gale their silken pinions stream,</line>
      <line> While in the quivering trees soft zephyrs sigh,</line>
      <line>And through the leaves disclose the moon’s pale beam.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, breathing instrument, be ever near</line>
      <line>While to the pensive muse my vows I pay;</line>
      <line>Thy softest call the inmost soul can hear,</line>
      <line>Thy faintest breath can Fancy’s pinions play.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when art’s laboured strains my feelings tire,</line>
      <line>To seek thy simple music shall be mine;</line>
      <line>I’ll strive to win its graces to my lyre,</line>
      <line>And make my plaintive lays enchant like thine!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ISABELLA LICKBARROW</author>
    <date>1814</date>
    <title>On Esthwaite Water</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O’er Esthwaite’s lake, serene and still,</line>
      <line>At sunset’s silent peaceful hour</line>
      <line>Scarce moved the zephyr’s softest breath,</line>
      <line>Or sighed along its reedy shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The lovely landscape on its sides,</line>
      <line>With evening’s softening hues impressed,</line>
      <line>Shared in the general calm, and gave</line>
      <line>Sweet visions of repose and rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Inverted on the waveless flood,</line>
      <line>A spotless mirror smooth and clear,</line>
      <line>Each fair surrounding object shone</line>
      <line>In softer beauty imaged there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Brown hills and woods of various shades,</line>
      <line>Orchards and sloping meadows green,</line>
      <line> Sweet rural seats and sheltered farms,</line>
      <line>Were in the bright reflector seen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>E’en lofty Tilberthwaite from far</line>
      <line>His giant shadow boldly threw,</line>
      <line>His ruggéd, dark, high-towering head</line>
      <line>On Esthwaite’s tranquil breast to view.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Struck with the beauty of the scene,</line>
      <line>I cried, ‘Oh may my yielding breast</line>
      <line>Retain but images of peace</line>
      <line>Like those, sweet lake, on thine impressed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ne’er may it feel a ruder gale</line>
      <line>Than that which o’er thy surface spreads,</line>
      <line>When sportive zephyrs briskly play,</line>
      <line>And whisper through thy bordering reeds –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When, dancing in the solar beam,</line>
      <line>Thy silvery waves the margin seek</line>
      <line>With gently undulating flow,</line>
      <line>And there in softest murmurs break.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Vain wish – o’er Esthwaite’s tranquil lake</line>
      <line>A stronger gale full frequent blows,</line>
      <line> The soothing prospect disappears,</line>
      <line>The lovely visions of repose!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Lake Leman (from Childe Harold III)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lake Leman woos me with its crystal face,</line>
      <line>The mirror where the stars and mountains view</line>
      <line>The stillness of their aspect in each trace</line>
      <line>Its clear depth yields of their far height and hue.</line>
      <line>There is too much of man here, to look through</line>
      <line>With a fit mind the might which I behold;</line>
      <line>But soon in me shall loneliness renew</line>
      <line>Thoughts hid, but not less cherished than of old,</line>
      <line>Ere mingling with the herd had penned me in their fold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To fly from, need not be to hate, mankind:</line>
      <line>All are not fit with them to stir and toil,</line>
      <line> Nor is it discontent to keep the mind</line>
      <line>Deep in its fountain, lest it over-boil</line>
      <line>In the hot throng, where we become the spoil</line>
      <line>Of our infection, till too late and long</line>
      <line>We may deplore and struggle with the coil,</line>
      <line>In wretched interchange of wrong for wrong</line>
      <line>Midst a contentious world, striving where none are strong.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There, in a moment, we may plunge our years</line>
      <line>In fatal penitence, and in the blight</line>
      <line>Of our own soul turn all our blood to tears,</line>
      <line> And colour things to come with hues of night!</line>
      <line>The race of life becomes a hopeless flight</line>
      <line>To those that walk in darkness – on the sea</line>
      <line>The boldest steer but where their ports invite –</line>
      <line>But there are wanderers o’er eternity</line>
      <line>Whose bark drives on and on, and anchored ne’er shall be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it not better, then, to be alone,</line>
      <line>And love Earth only for its earthly sake –</line>
      <line>By the blue rushing of the arrowy Rhone,</line>
      <line>Or the pure bosom of its nursing Lake</line>
      <line> Which feeds it as a mother who doth make</line>
      <line>A fair but froward infant her own care,</line>
      <line>Kissing its cries away as these awake –</line>
      <line>Is it not better thus our lives to wear,</line>
      <line>Than join the crushing crowd, doomed to inflict or bear?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I live not in myself, but I become</line>
      <line>Portion of that around me, and to me</line>
      <line>High mountains are a feeling, but the hum</line>
      <line>Of human cities torture! I can see</line>
      <line>Nothing to loathe in Nature, save to be</line>
      <line> A link reluctant in a fleshly chain,</line>
      <line>Classed among creatures, when the soul can flee,</line>
      <line>And with the sky, the peak, the heaving plain</line>
      <line>Of ocean, or the stars, mingle – and not in vain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus I am absorbed, and this is life:</line>
      <line>I look upon the peopled desert past,</line>
      <line>As on a place of agony and strife,</line>
      <line>Where, for some sin, to sorrow I was cast,</line>
      <line>To act and suffer, but remount at last</line>
      <line>With a fresh pinion – which I feel to spring,</line>
      <line> Though young, yet waxing vigorous as the blast</line>
      <line>Which it would cope with, on delighted wing</line>
      <line>Spurning the clay-cold bonds which round our being cling.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when, at length, the mind shall be all free</line>
      <line>From what it hates in this degraded form,</line>
      <line>Reft of its carnal life, save what shall be</line>
      <line>Existent happier in the fly and worm –</line>
      <line>When elements to elements conform</line>
      <line>And dust is as it should be, shall I not</line>
      <line>Feel all I see less dazzling but more warm?</line>
      <line> The bodiless thought? The spirit of each spot,</line>
      <line>Of which, even now, I share at times the immortal lot?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Are not the mountains, waves, and skies, a part</line>
      <line>Of me and of my soul, as I of them?</line>
      <line>Is not the love of these deep in my heart</line>
      <line>With a pure passion? Should I not contemn</line>
      <line>All objects, if compared with these – and stem</line>
      <line>A tide of suffering, rather than forego</line>
      <line>Such feelings for the hard and worldly phlegm</line>
      <line>Of those whose eyes are only turned below,</line>
      <line> Gazing upon the ground with thoughts which dare not glow?…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Clear, placid Leman! thy contrasted lake,</line>
      <line>With the wild world I dwelt in, is a thing</line>
      <line>Which warns me, with its stillness, to forsake</line>
      <line>Earth’s troubled waters for a purer spring.</line>
      <line>This quiet sail is as a noiseless wing</line>
      <line>To waft me from distraction. Once I loved</line>
      <line>Torn ocean’s roar, but thy soft murmuring</line>
      <line>Sounds sweet as if a sister’s voice reproved</line>
      <line> That I with stern delights should e’er have been so moved.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is the hush of night, and all between</line>
      <line>Thy margin and the mountains, dusk, yet clear</line>
      <line>(Mellowed and mingling, yet distinctly seen),</line>
      <line>Save darkened Jura, whose capped heights appear</line>
      <line>Precipitously steep – and drawing near,</line>
      <line>There breathes a living fragrance from the shore,</line>
      <line>Of flowers yet fresh with childhood; on the ear</line>
      <line>Drops the light drip of the suspended oar,</line>
      <line>Or chirps the grasshopper one good-night carol more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He is an evening reveller, who makes</line>
      <line>His life an infancy, and sings his fill!</line>
      <line>At intervals, some bird from out the brakes</line>
      <line>Starts into voice a moment, then is still.</line>
      <line>There seems a floating whisper on the hill –</line>
      <line>But that is fancy! – for the starlight-dews</line>
      <line>All silently their tears of love instill,</line>
      <line>Weeping themselves away, till they infuse</line>
      <line>Deep into Nature’s breast the spirit of her hues.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye stars, which are the poetry of Heaven!</line>
      <line> If in your bright leaves we would read the fate</line>
      <line>Of men and empires, ’tis to be forgiven</line>
      <line>That in our aspirations to be great,</line>
      <line>Our destinies o’erleap their mortal state,</line>
      <line>And claim a kindred with you – for ye are</line>
      <line>A beauty and a mystery, and create</line>
      <line>In us such love and reverence from afar</line>
      <line>That fortune, fame, power, life, have named themselves a star.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All Heaven and Earth are still – though not in sleep,</line>
      <line>But breathless, as we grow when feeling most,</line>
      <line> And silent, as we stand in thoughts too deep –</line>
      <line>All Heaven and Earth are still! From the high host</line>
      <line>Of stars, to the lulled lake and mountain-coast,</line>
      <line>All is concentred in a life intense</line>
      <line>Where not a beam, nor air, nor leaf is lost,</line>
      <line>But hath a part of being, and a sense</line>
      <line>Of that which is of all creator and defense.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then stirs the feeling infinite, so felt</line>
      <line>In solitude, where we are least alone –</line>
      <line>A truth which through our being then doth melt,</line>
      <line>And purifies from self: it is a tone,</line>
      <line>The soul and source of music, which makes known</line>
      <line>Eternal harmony…</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date><1816/date>
    <title>Epistle to Augusta</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My sister! my sweet sister! if a name</line>
      <line>Dearer and purer were, it should be thine.</line>
      <line>Mountains and seas divide us, but I claim</line>
      <line>No tears but tenderness to answer mine:</line>
      <line> Go where I will, to me thou art the same –</line>
      <line>A loved regret which I would not resign!</line>
      <line>There yet are two things in my destiny:</line>
      <line>A world to roam through, and a home with thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The first were nothing, had I still the last!</line>
      <line>It were the haven of my happiness –</line>
      <line>But other claims and other ties thou hast,</line>
      <line>And mine is not the wish to make them less.</line>
      <line>A strange doom is thy father’s son’s, and past</line>
      <line>Recalling, as it lies beyond redress –</line>
      <line> Reversed for him our grandsire’s fate of yore:</line>
      <line>He had no rest at sea, nor I on shore!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If my inheritance of storms hath been</line>
      <line>In other elements, and on the rocks</line>
      <line>Of perils, overlooked or unforeseen,</line>
      <line>I have sustained my share of worldly shocks,</line>
      <line>The fault was mine – nor do I seek to screen</line>
      <line>My errors with defensive paradox –</line>
      <line>I have been cunning in mine overthrow,</line>
      <line>The careful pilot of my proper woe!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mine were my faults, and mine be their reward.</line>
      <line>My whole life was a contest, since the day</line>
      <line>That gave me being gave me that which marred</line>
      <line>The gift – a fate, or will – that walked astray!</line>
      <line>And I at times have found the struggle hard,</line>
      <line>And thought of shaking off my bonds of clay,</line>
      <line>But now I fain would for a time survive,</line>
      <line>If but to see what next can well arrive.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Kingdoms and Empires in my little day</line>
      <line>I have outlived, and yet I am not old!</line>
      <line> And when I look on this, the petty spray</line>
      <line>Of my own years of troubles (which have rolled</line>
      <line>Like a wild bay of breakers) melts away.</line>
      <line>Something – I know not what – does still uphold</line>
      <line>A spirit of slight patience: not in vain,</line>
      <line>Even for its own sake, do we purchase pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perhaps the workings of defiance stir</line>
      <line>Within me – or, perhaps, a cold despair</line>
      <line>Brought on when ills habitually recur –</line>
      <line>Perhaps a kinder clime, or purer air</line>
      <line> (For even to this may change of soul refer,</line>
      <line>And with light armour we may learn to bear),</line>
      <line>Have taught me a strange quiet, which was not</line>
      <line>The chief companion of a calmer lot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I feel almost at times as I have felt</line>
      <line>In happy childhood: trees, and flowers, and brooks,</line>
      <line>Which do remember me of where I dwelt</line>
      <line>Ere my young mind was sacrificed to books,</line>
      <line>Come as of yore upon me, and can melt</line>
      <line>My heart with recognition of their looks –</line>
      <line> And even at moments I could think I see</line>
      <line>Some living thing to love – but none like thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here are the Alpine landscapes which create</line>
      <line>A fund for contemplation – to admire</line>
      <line>Is a brief feeling of a trivial date,</line>
      <line>But something worthier do such scenes inspire.</line>
      <line>Here to be lonely is not desolate,</line>
      <line>For much I view which I could most desire,</line>
      <line>And (above all) a lake I can behold,</line>
      <line>Lovelier – not dearer – than our own of old!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh that thou wert but with me – but I grow</line>
      <line>The fool of my own wishes, and forget</line>
      <line>The solitude which I have vaunted so</line>
      <line>Has lost its praise in this but one regret.</line>
      <line>There may be others which I less may show:</line>
      <line>I am not of the plaintive mood, and yet</line>
      <line>I feel an ebb in my philosophy,</line>
      <line>And the tide rising in my altered eye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I did remind thee of our own dear Lake,</line>
      <line>By the old Hall which may be mine no more.</line>
      <line> Leman’s is fair, but think not I forsake</line>
      <line>The sweet remembrance of a dearer shore –</line>
      <line>Sad havoc time must with my memory make</line>
      <line>Ere that or thou can fade these eyes before,</line>
      <line>Though (like all things which I have loved) they are</line>
      <line>Resigned for ever, or divided far.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world is all before me! I but ask</line>
      <line>Of Nature that with which she will comply –</line>
      <line>It is but in her summer’s sun to bask,</line>
      <line>To mingle with the quiet of her sky,</line>
      <line> To see her gentle face without a mask,</line>
      <line>And never gaze on it with apathy.</line>
      <line>She was my early friend, and now shall be</line>
      <line>My sister – till I look again on thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I can reduce all feelings but this one –</line>
      <line>And that I would not! For at length I see</line>
      <line>Such scenes as those wherein my life begun:</line>
      <line>The earliest – even the only – paths for me.</line>
      <line>Had I but sooner learnt the crowd to shun,</line>
      <line>I had been better than I now can be –</line>
      <line> The passions which have torn me would have slept:</line>
      <line>I had not suffered, and thou hadst not wept!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With false ambition what had I to do?</line>
      <line>Little with love, and least of all with fame!</line>
      <line>And yet they came unsought, and with me grew,</line>
      <line>And made me all which they can make, a name!</line>
      <line>Yet this was not the end I did pursue –</line>
      <line>Surely I once beheld a nobler aim –</line>
      <line>But all is over. I am one the more</line>
      <line>To baffled millions which have gone before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And for the future, this world’s future may</line>
      <line>From me demand but little of my care –</line>
      <line>I have outlived myself by many a day,</line>
      <line>Having survived so many things that were!</line>
      <line>My years have been no slumber, but the prey</line>
      <line>Of ceaseless vigils; for I had the share</line>
      <line>Of life which might have filled a century,</line>
      <line>Before its fourth in time had passed me by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And for the remnant which may be to come</line>
      <line>I am content – and for the past I feel</line>
      <line>Not thankless – for within the crowded sum</line>
      <line>Of struggles, happiness at times would steal!</line>
      <line>And for the present, I would not benumb</line>
      <line>My feelings farther – nor shall I conceal</line>
      <line>That with all this I still can look around,</line>
      <line>And worship Nature with a thought profound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For thee, my own sweet sister, in thy heart</line>
      <line>I know myself secure, as thou in mine.</line>
      <line>We were and are – I am, even as thou art –</line>
      <line>Beings who ne’er each other can resign.</line>
      <line> It is the same, together or apart!</line>
      <line>From life’s commencement to its slow decline</line>
      <line>We are entwined – let death come slow or fast,</line>
      <line>The tie which bound the first endures the last!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Mont Blanc: Lines Written in the Vale of Chamouni</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The everlasting universe of things</line>
      <line>Flows through the mind, and rolls its rapid waves,</line>
      <line>Now dark, now glittering, now reflecting gloom,</line>
      <line>Now lending splendour, where from secret springs</line>
      <line> The source of human thought its tribute brings</line>
      <line>Of waters – with a sound but half its own,</line>
      <line>Such as a feeble brook will oft assume</line>
      <line>In the wild woods, among the mountains lone,</line>
      <line>Where waterfalls around it leap for ever,</line>
      <line>Where woods and winds contend, and a vast river</line>
      <line>Over its rocks ceaselessly bursts and raves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus thou, Ravine of Arve – dark, deep Ravine –</line>
      <line>Thou many-coloured, many-voicéd vale,</line>
      <line>Over whose pines, and crags, and caverns sail</line>
      <line> Fast cloud-shadows and sunbeams. Awful scene,</line>
      <line>Where Power in likeness of the Arve comes down</line>
      <line>From the ice-gulfs that gird his secret throne,</line>
      <line>Bursting through these dark mountains like the flame</line>
      <line>Of lightning through the tempest! Thou dost lie,</line>
      <line>Thy giant brood of pines around thee clinging</line>
      <line>(Children of elder time, in whose devotion</line>
      <line>The chainless winds still come and ever came</line>
      <line>To drink their odours, and their mighty swinging</line>
      <line>To hear: an old and solemn harmony),</line>
      <line> Thine earthly rainbows stretched across the sweep</line>
      <line>Of the aethereal waterfall, whose veil</line>
      <line>Robes some unsculptured image – the strange sleep</line>
      <line>Which when the voices of the desert fail</line>
      <line>Wraps all in its own deep eternity –</line>
      <line>Thy caverns echoing to the Arve’s commotion,</line>
      <line>A loud, lone sound no other sound can tame!</line>
      <line>Thou art pervaded with that ceaseless motion,</line>
      <line>Thou art the path of that unresting sound,</line>
      <line>Dizzy Ravine! and when I gaze on thee</line>
      <line> I seem as in a trance sublime and strange</line>
      <line>To muse on my own separate fantasy,</line>
      <line>My own, my human mind, which passively</line>
      <line>Now renders and receives fast influencings,</line>
      <line>Holding an unremitting interchange</line>
      <line>With the clear universe of things around –</line>
      <line>One legion of wild thoughts, whose wandering wings</line>
      <line>Now float above thy darkness, and now rest</line>
      <line>Where that, or thou, art no unbidden guest,</line>
      <line>In the still cave of the witch Poesy,</line>
      <line> Seeking among the shadows that pass by</line>
      <line>(Ghosts of all things that are) some shade of thee,</line>
      <line>Some phantom, some faint image. Till the breast</line>
      <line>From which they fled recalls them, thou art there!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some say that gleams of a remoter world</line>
      <line>Visit the soul in sleep – that death is slumber,</line>
      <line>And that its shapes the busy thoughts outnumber</line>
      <line>Of those who wake and live. I look on high:</line>
      <line>Has some unknown omnipotence unfurled</line>
      <line>The veil of life and death? Or do I lie</line>
      <line> In dream, and does the mightier world of sleep</line>
      <line>Spread far around and inaccessibly</line>
      <line>Its circles? For the very spirit fails,</line>
      <line>Driven like a homeless cloud from steep to steep</line>
      <line>That vanishes among the viewless gales!</line>
      <line>Far, far above, piercing the infinite sky,</line>
      <line>Mont Blanc appears, still, snowy, and serene.</line>
      <line>Its subject mountains their unearthly forms</line>
      <line>Pile around it, ice and rock – broad vales between</line>
      <line>Of frozen floods, unfathomable deeps,</line>
      <line> Blue as the overhanging heaven, that spread</line>
      <line>And wind among the accumulated steeps –</line>
      <line>A desert peopled by the storms alone,</line>
      <line>Save when the eagle brings some hunter’s bone,</line>
      <line>And the wolf tracks her there! How hideously</line>
      <line>Its shapes are heaped around – rude, bare, and high,</line>
      <line>Ghastly, and scarred, and riven! Is this the scene</line>
      <line>Where the old Earthquake-Demon taught her young</line>
      <line>Ruin? Were these their toys? Or did a sea</line>
      <line>Of fire envelop once this silent snow?</line>
      <line> None can reply – all seems eternal now.</line>
      <line>The wilderness has a mysterious tongue</line>
      <line>Which teaches awful doubt, or faith so mild,</line>
      <line>So solemn, so serene, that man may be,</line>
      <line>But for such faith, with Nature reconciled.</line>
      <line>Thou hast a voice, great Mountain, to repeal</line>
      <line>Large codes of fraud and woe – not understood</line>
      <line>By all, but which the wise, and great, and good</line>
      <line>Interpret, or make felt, or deeply feel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fields, the lakes, the forests, and the streams,</line>
      <line> Ocean, and all the living things that dwell</line>
      <line>Within the daedal earth; lightning and rain,</line>
      <line>Earthquake and fiery flood, and hurricane;</line>
      <line>The torpor of the year when feeble dreams</line>
      <line>Visit the hidden buds, or dreamless sleep</line>
      <line>Holds every future leaf and flower; the bound</line>
      <line>With which from that detested trance they leap;</line>
      <line>The works and ways of man, their death and birth,</line>
      <line>And that of him and all that his may be;</line>
      <line>All things that move and breathe with toil and sound</line>
      <line> Are born and die; revolve, subside, and swell.</line>
      <line>Power dwells apart in its tranquillity,</line>
      <line>Remote, serene and inaccessible,</line>
      <line>And this the naked countenance of earth</line>
      <line>On which I gaze, even these primeval mountains,</line>
      <line>Teach the adverting mind. The glaciers creep</line>
      <line>Like snakes that watch their prey, from their far fountains</line>
      <line>Slow rolling on. There, many a precipice</line>
      <line>Frost and the sun, in scorn of mortal power,</line>
      <line>Have piled: dome, pyramid, and pinnacle –</line>
      <line>A city of death, distinct with many a tower</line>
      <line>And wall impregnable of beaming ice.</line>
      <line>Yet not a city, but a flood of ruin</line>
      <line>Is there, that from the boundaries of the sky</line>
      <line>Rolls its perpetual stream: Vast pines are strewing</line>
      <line>Its destined path, or in the mangled soil</line>
      <line>Branchless and shattered stand.</line>
      <line>The rocks, drawn down</line>
      <line>From yon remotest waste, have overthrown</line>
      <line>The limits of the dead and living world,</line>
      <line>Never to be reclaimed. The dwelling-place</line>
      <line> Of insects, beasts and birds, becomes its spoil;</line>
      <line>Their food and their retreat for ever gone,</line>
      <line>So much of life and joy is lost. The race</line>
      <line>Of man flies far in dread; his work and dwelling</line>
      <line>Vanish like smoke before the tempest’s stream,</line>
      <line>And their place is not known. Below, vast caves</line>
      <line>Shine in the rushing torrents’ restless gleam,</line>
      <line>Which from those secret chasms in tumult welling</line>
      <line>Meet in the vale, and one majestic river,</line>
      <line>The breath and blood of distant lands, for ever</line>
      <line> Rolls its loud waters to the ocean-waves,</line>
      <line>Breathes its swift vapours to the circling air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mont Blanc yet gleams on high – the power is there,</line>
      <line>The still and solemn power of many sights,</line>
      <line>And many sounds, and much of life and death.</line>
      <line>In the calm darkness of the moonless nights,</line>
      <line>In the lone glare of day, the snows descend</line>
      <line>Upon that Mountain; none beholds them there,</line>
      <line>Nor when the flakes burn in the sinking sun,</line>
      <line>Or the star-beams dart through them. Winds contend</line>
      <line> Silently there, and heap the snow with breath</line>
      <line>Rapid and strong, but silently! Its home</line>
      <line>The voiceless lightning in these solitudes</line>
      <line>Keeps innocently, and like vapour broods</line>
      <line>Over the snow. The secret Strength of Things</line>
      <line>Which governs thought, and to the infinite dome</line>
      <line>Of heaven is as a law, inhabits thee!</line>
      <line>And what were thou, and earth, and stars, and sea,</line>
      <line>If to the human mind’s imaginings</line>
      <line>Silence and solitude were vacancy?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>To Jane: The Invitation</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Best and brightest, come away –</line>
      <line>Fairer far than this fair day,</line>
      <line>Which, like thee to those in sorrow,</line>
      <line>Comes to bid a sweet good-morrow</line>
      <line> To the rough year just awake</line>
      <line>In its cradle on the brake.</line>
      <line>The brightest hour of unborn spring,</line>
      <line>Through the winter wandering,</line>
      <line>Found, it seems, this halcyon morn</line>
      <line>To hoar February born –</line>
      <line>Bending from heaven, in azure mirth,</line>
      <line>It kissed the forehead of the Earth,</line>
      <line>And smiled upon the silent sea,</line>
      <line>And bade the frozen streams be free,</line>
      <line> And waked to music all their fountains,</line>
      <line>And breathed upon the frozen mountains,</line>
      <line>And like a prophetess of May</line>
      <line>Strewed flowers upon the barren way,</line>
      <line>Making the wintry world appear</line>
      <line>Like one on whom thou smilest, dear.</line>
      <line>Away, away, from men and towns</line>
      <line>To the wild wood and the downs,</line>
      <line>To the silent wilderness</line>
      <line>Where the soul need not repress</line>
      <line> Its music lest it should not find</line>
      <line>An echo in another’s mind,</line>
      <line>While the touch of Nature’s art</line>
      <line>Harmonizes heart to heart.</line>
      <line>I leave this notice on my door</line>
      <line>For each accustomed visitor:</line>
      <line>‘I am gone into the fields</line>
      <line>To take what this sweet hour yields!</line>
      <line>Reflection, you may come tomorrow,</line>
      <line>Sit by the fireside with Sorrow –</line>
      <line> You with the unpaid bill, Despair,</line>
      <line>You, tiresome verse-reciter, Care!</line>
      <line>I will pay you in the grave –</line>
      <line>Death will listen to your stave!</line>
      <line>Expectation too, be off –</line>
      <line>Today is for itself enough!</line>
      <line>Hope, in pity mock not Woe</line>
      <line>With smiles, nor follow where I go.</line>
      <line>Long having lived on thy sweet food,</line>
      <line>At length I find one moment’s good</line>
      <line> After long pain – with all your love,</line>
      <line>This you never told me of!’</line>
      <line>Radiant sister of the day,</line>
      <line>Awake, arise, and come away!</line>
      <line>To the wild woods and the plains,</line>
      <line>And the pools where winter-rains</line>
      <line>Image all their roof of leaves,</line>
      <line>Where the pine its garland weaves</line>
      <line>Of sapless green and ivy dun</line>
      <line>Round stems that never kiss the sun –</line>
      <line> Where the lawns and pastures be,</line>
      <line>And the sandhills of the sea –</line>
      <line>Where the melting hoar-frost wets</line>
      <line>The daisy-star that never sets,</line>
      <line>And wind-flowers, and violets,</line>
      <line>Which yet join not scent to hue,</line>
      <line>Crown the pale year weak and new;</line>
      <line>When the night is left behind</line>
      <line>In the deep east, dun and blind,</line>
      <line>And the blue noon is over us,</line>
      <line> And the multitudinous</line>
      <line>Billows murmur at our feet,</line>
      <line>Where the earth and ocean meet,</line>
      <line>And all things seem only one</line>
      <line>In the universal sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>To Jane: A Recollection</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now the last day of many days,</line>
      <line>All beautiful and bright as thou,</line>
      <line>The loveliest and the last, is dead –</line>
      <line>Rise, Memory, and write its praise!</line>
      <line> Up, to thy wonted work! Come, trace</line>
      <line>The epitaph of glory fled;</line>
      <line>For now the Earth has changed its face,</line>
      <line>A frown is on the Heaven’s brow.</line>
      <line>We wandered to the pine forest</line>
      <line>That skirts the ocean-foam,</line>
      <line>The lightest wind was in its nest,</line>
      <line>The tempest in its home.</line>
      <line>The whispering waves were half asleep,</line>
      <line>The clouds were gone to play,</line>
      <line> And on the bosom of the deep</line>
      <line>The smile of Heaven lay –</line>
      <line>It seemed as if the hour were one</line>
      <line>Sent from beyond the skies,</line>
      <line>Which scattered from above the sun</line>
      <line>A light of Paradise!</line>
      <line>We paused amid the pines that stood</line>
      <line>The giants of the waste,</line>
      <line>Tortured by storms to shapes as rude</line>
      <line>As serpents interlaced,</line>
      <line> And soothed by every azure breath,</line>
      <line>That under Heaven is blown,</line>
      <line>To harmonies and hues beneath,</line>
      <line>As tender as its own –</line>
      <line>Now all the tree-tops lay asleep,</line>
      <line>Like green waves on the sea,</line>
      <line>As still as in the silent deep</line>
      <line>The ocean-woods may be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How calm it was – the silence there</line>
      <line>By such a chain was bound</line>
      <line> That even the busy woodpecker</line>
      <line>Made stiller by her sound</line>
      <line>The inviolable quietness!</line>
      <line>The breath of peace we drew,</line>
      <line>With its soft motion, made not less</line>
      <line>The calm that round us grew.</line>
      <line>There seemed from the remotest seat</line>
      <line>Of the white mountain-waste,</line>
      <line>To the soft flower beneath our feet,</line>
      <line>A magic circle traced –</line>
      <line> A spirit interfused around,</line>
      <line>A thrilling, silent life!</line>
      <line>To momentary peace it bound</line>
      <line>Our mortal nature’s strife –</line>
      <line>And still I felt the centre of</line>
      <line>The magic circle there</line>
      <line>Was one fair form that filled with love</line>
      <line>The lifeless atmosphere.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We paused beside the pools that lie</line>
      <line>Under the forest bough:</line>
      <line> Each seemed as ’twere a little sky</line>
      <line>Gulfed in a world below –</line>
      <line>A firmament of purple light</line>
      <line>Which in the dark earth lay,</line>
      <line>More boundless than the depth of night,</line>
      <line>And purer than the day!</line>
      <line>In which the lovely forests grew,</line>
      <line>As in the upper air,</line>
      <line>More perfect both in shape and hue</line>
      <line>Than any spreading there.</line>
      <line> There lay the glade and neighbouring lawn,</line>
      <line>And through the dark green wood</line>
      <line>The white sun twinkling like the dawn</line>
      <line>Out of a speckled cloud.</line>
      <line>Sweet views, which in our world above</line>
      <line>Can never well be seen,</line>
      <line>Were imaged by the water’s love</line>
      <line>Of that fair forest green.</line>
      <line>And all was interfused beneath</line>
      <line>With an Elysian glow,</line>
      <line> An atmosphere without a breath,</line>
      <line>A softer day below.</line>
      <line>Like one beloved the scene had lent</line>
      <line>To the dark water’s breast,</line>
      <line>Its every leaf and lineament</line>
      <line>With more than truth exprest –</line>
      <line>Until an envious wind crept by,</line>
      <line>Like an unwelcome thought,</line>
      <line>Which from the mind’s too faithful eye</line>
      <line>Blots one dear image out.</line>
      <line> Though thou art ever fair and kind,</line>
      <line>The forests ever green,</line>
      <line>Less oft is peace in Shelley’s mind,</line>
      <line>Than calm in waters, seen!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>From Endymion (I)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wherein lies happiness? In that which becks</line>
      <line>Our ready minds to fellowship divine,</line>
      <line>A fellowship with essence, till we shine</line>
      <line>Full alchemized, and free of space. Behold</line>
      <line>The clear religion of Heaven! Fold</line>
      <line>A roseleaf round thy finger’s taperness</line>
      <line>And soothe thy lips. Hist, when the airy stress</line>
      <line>Of music’s kiss impregnates the free winds,</line>
      <line> And with a sympathetic touch unbinds</line>
      <line>Eolian magic from their lucid wombs –</line>
      <line>Then old songs waken from enclouded tombs,</line>
      <line>Old ditties sigh above their father’s grave,</line>
      <line>Ghosts of melodious prophesyings rave</line>
      <line>Round every spot where trod Apollo’s foot;</line>
      <line>Bronze clarions awake and faintly bruit</line>
      <line>Where long ago a giant-battle was;</line>
      <line>And, from the turf, a lullaby doth pass</line>
      <line>In every place where infant Orpheus slept.</line>
      <line> Feel we these things? That moment have we stepped</line>
      <line>Into a sort of oneness, and our state</line>
      <line>Is like a floating spirit’s. But there are</line>
      <line>Richer entanglements, enthralments far</line>
      <line>More self-destroying, leading, by degrees,</line>
      <line>To the chief intensity: the crown of these</line>
      <line>Is made of love and friendship, and sits high</line>
      <line>Upon the forehead of humanity.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>from Epistle to J. H. Reynolds</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is a flaw</line>
      <line>In happiness to see beyond our bourne –</line>
      <line>It forces us in summer skies to mourn;</line>
      <line> It spoils the singing of the nightingale.</line>
      <line>Dear Reynolds, I have a mysterious tale</line>
      <line>And cannot speak it. The first page I read</line>
      <line>Upon a limpit-rock of green sea-weed</line>
      <line>Among the breakers. ’Twas a quiet eve;</line>
      <line>The rocks were silent; the wide sea did weave</line>
      <line>An untumultuous fringe of silver foam</line>
      <line>Along the flat brown sand. I was at home,</line>
      <line>And should have been most happy, but I saw</line>
      <line>Too far into the sea, where every maw,</line>
      <line> The greater on the less, feeds evermore –</line>
      <line>But I saw too distinct into the core</line>
      <line>Of an eternal fierce destruction,</line>
      <line>And so from happiness I far was gone.</line>
      <line>Still am I sick of it; and though today</line>
      <line>I’ve gathered young spring-leaves, and flowers gay</line>
      <line>Of periwinkle and wild strawberry,</line>
      <line>Still do I that most fierce destruction see:</line>
      <line>The shark at savage prey, the hawk at pounce,</line>
      <line>The gentle robin, like a pard or ounce,</line>
      <line>Ravening a worm.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL PALMER</author>
    <date>1827</date>
    <title>Twilight Time</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now the trembling light</line>
      <line>Glimmers behind the little hills and corn,</line>
      <line>Lingering as loath to part. Yet part thou must,</line>
      <line>And though than open day far pleasing more</line>
      <line> (Ere yet the fields, and pearléd cups of flowers</line>
      <line>Twinkle in the parting light),</line>
      <line>Thee night shall hide, sweet visionary gleam</line>
      <line>That softly lookest through the rising dew –</line>
      <line>Till, all like silver bright,</line>
      <line>The Faithful Witness, pure and white,</line>
      <line>Shall look o’er yonder grassy hill</line>
      <line>At this village, safe, and still.</line>
      <line>All is safe, and all is still,</line>
      <line>Save what noise the watch-dog makes</line>
      <line> Or the shrill cock the silence breaks</line>
      <line>Now and then –</line>
      <line>And now and then.</line>
      <line>Hark! once again,</line>
      <line>The wether’s bell to us doth tell</line>
      <line>Some little stirring in the fold.</line>
      <line>Methinks the lingering, dying ray</line>
      <line>Of twilight time doth seem more fair,</line>
      <line>And lights the soul up more than day,</line>
      <line>When wide-spread, sultry sunshines are...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>This Leaning Tree with Ivy Overhung</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This leaning tree with ivy overhung,</line>
      <line>This crooked brook o’er which is rudely flung</line>
      <line>A slender plank that bends beneath the feet,</line>
      <line>And that small hill the shepherd’s summer seat,</line>
      <line> Make up a picture to the mind and wear</line>
      <line>A nobler gild than palace-walls can heir.</line>
      <line>To me the wild wind dashes o’er the scene</line>
      <line>Enchantment’s shades of vivifying green:</line>
      <line>I see her, sketchy pencil in her hand,</line>
      <line>Painting the moving scene to fairy land!</line>
      <line>That blackbird’s music from the hazel bower</line>
      <line>Turns into golden drops this summer shower –</line>
      <line>To think the rain that wets his sooty wing</line>
      <line>Should wake the gushes of his soul to sing!</line>
      <line> Hark at the melody, how rich and loud</line>
      <line>(Like daylight breaking through the morning cloud),</line>
      <line>How luscious through that sea of green it floats!</line>
      <line>Knowst thou of music breathed from sweeter notes</line>
      <line>Than that wild minstrel of the summer shower</line>
      <line>Breathes at this moment from that hazel-bower?</line>
      <line>To me the anthem of a thousand tongues</line>
      <line>Were poor and idle to the simple songs</line>
      <line>Of that high-toned and edifying bird</line>
      <line>That sings to Nature, by itself, unheard.</line>
      <line> There is a language wrote on earth and sky</line>
      <line>By God’s own pen in silent majesty;</line>
      <line>There is a voice that’s heard and felt and seen</line>
      <line>In spring’s young shades and summer’s endless green;</line>
      <line>There is a book of poesy and spells</line>
      <line>In which that voice in sunny splendour dwells;</line>
      <line>There is a page in which that voice aloud</line>
      <line>Speaks music to the few, and not the crowd!</line>
      <line>Though no romantic scenes my feet hath trod,</line>
      <line>The voice of Nature, as the voice of God,</line>
      <line> Appeals to me in every tree and flower,</line>
      <line>Breathing his glory, magnitude and power.</line>
      <line>In Nature’s open book I read, and see</line>
      <line>Beauty’s rich lesson in this seeming pea.</line>
      <line>Crowds see no magic in this trifling thing –</line>
      <line>‘Pshaw, ’tis a weed, and millions come with spring!’</line>
      <line>I hear rich music whereso’er I look,</line>
      <line>But heedless worldlings chide the brawling brook.</line>
      <line>And that small lark between me and the sky</line>
      <line>Breathes sweetest strains of morning’s melody –</line>
      <line> Yet by the heedless crowd ’tis only heard</line>
      <line>As the small warbling of a common bird</line>
      <line>That o’er the plough-teams hails the morning-sun.</line>
      <line>They see no music from such magic won;</line>
      <line>Yet I see melody in Nature’s laws –</line>
      <line>Or do I dream? Still wonder bids me pause.</line>
      <line>I pause and hear a voice that speaks aloud:</line>
      <line>‘’Tis not on earth, nor in the thunder-cloud!</line>
      <line>The many look for sound, ’tis silence speaks –</line>
      <line>And song, like sunshine, from her rapture breaks.’</line>
      <line> I hear it in my bosom, ever near,</line>
      <line>’Tis in these winds, and they are everywhere –</line>
      <line>It casts around my vision magic spells,</line>
      <line>And makes earth Heaven, where poor fancy dwells!</line>
      <line>I read its speech, and its speech is joy!</line>
      <line>So, without teaching, when a lonely boy,</line>
      <line>Each weed to me did happy tidings bring</line>
      <line>(Plain as the daisy wrote the name of spring),</line>
      <line>And God’s own language, unto Nature given,</line>
      <line>Seemed universal as the light of Heaven</line>
      <line> And common as the grass upon the plain</line>
      <line>That all may read and meet with joy again –</line>
      <line>Save the unheeding heart, who, like the tomb,</line>
      <line>Shuts joy in darkness, and forbids its bloom.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>Remembrance of Nature</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Nature thou didst rear me for thine own,</line>
      <line>With thy free singing-birds and mountain-brooks,</line>
      <line>Feeding my thoughts in primrose-haunted nooks</line>
      <line>With fairy fantasies and wood-dreams lone;</line>
      <line> And thou didst teach me every wandering tone</line>
      <line>Drawn from thy many-whispering trees and waves,</line>
      <line>And guide my steps to founts and sparry caves,</line>
      <line>And where bright mosses wove thee a rich throne</line>
      <line>Midst the green hills. And now that, far estranged</line>
      <line>O From all sweet sounds and odours of thy breath,</line>
      <line>Fading I lie, within my heart unchanged</line>
      <line>So glows the love of thee that not for death</line>
      <line>Seems that pure passion’s fervour, but ordained</line>
      <line>To meet on brighter shores thy majesty unstained.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1836</date>
    <title>Scale Force, Cumberland</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It sweeps, as sweeps an army</line>
      <line>Adown the mountain-side,</line>
      <line>With the voice of many thunders</line>
      <line>Like the battle’s sounding tide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet the sky is blue above it,</line>
      <line>And the dashing of the spray</line>
      <line>Wears the colour of the rainbow</line>
      <line>Upon an April day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It rejoices in the sunshine</line>
      <line>When after heavy rain</line>
      <line>It gathers the far waters</line>
      <line>To dash upon the plain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is terrible yet lovely</line>
      <line>Beneath the morning rays,</line>
      <line> Like a dream of strength and beauty</line>
      <line>It haunted those who gaze.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We feel that it is glorious –</line>
      <line>Its power is on the soul –</line>
      <line>And lofty thoughts within us</line>
      <line>Acknowledge its control.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A generous inspiration</line>
      <line>Is on the outward world –</line>
      <line>It waketh thoughts and feelings</line>
      <line>In careless coldness furled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> To love and to admire</line>
      <line>Seems natural to the heart;</line>
      <line>Life’s small and selfish interests</line>
      <line>From such a scene depart!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1836</date>
    <title>Fountains Abbey</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Never more, when the day is o’er,</line>
      <line>Will the lonely vespers sound;</line>
      <line>No bells are ringing – no monks are singing –</line>
      <line>When the moonlight falls around.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A few pale flowers, which in other hours</line>
      <line>May have cheered the dreary mood;</line>
      <line>When the votary turned to the world he had spurned,</line>
      <line>And repined at the solitude.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still do they blow mid the ruins below,</line>
      <line>For fallen are fane and shrine,</line>
      <line>And the moss has grown o’er the sculptured stone</line>
      <line>Of an altar no more divine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still on the walls where the sunshine falls,</line>
      <line>The ancient fruit-tree grows;</line>
      <line> And o’er tablet and tomb, extends the bloom</line>
      <line>Of many a wilding rose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair though they be, yet they seemed to me</line>
      <line>To mock the wreck below;</line>
      <line>For mighty the tower, where the fragile flower</line>
      <line>May now as in triumph blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, foolish the thought, that my fancy brought;</line>
      <line>More true and more wise to say,</line>
      <line>That still thus doth spring, some gentle thing,</line>
      <line>With its beauty to cheer decay.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1786</date>
    <title>Despondency, An Ode</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oppressed with grief, oppressed with care,</line>
      <line>A burden more than I can bear,</line>
      <line>I set me down and sigh;</line>
      <line>Oh life! thou art a galling load,</line>
      <line> Along a rough, a weary road,</line>
      <line>To wretches such as I!</line>
      <line>Dim-backward as I cast my view,</line>
      <line>What sickening scenes appear –</line>
      <line>What sorrows yet may pierce me through,</line>
      <line>Too justly I may fear!</line>
      <line>Still caring, despairing,</line>
      <line>Must be my bitter doom;</line>
      <line>My woes here shall close ne’er</line>
      <line>But with the closing tomb!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Happy ye sons of busy life</line>
      <line>Who, equal to the bustling strife,</line>
      <line>No other view regard</line>
      <line>(Even when the wishéd end’s denied,</line>
      <line>Yet while the busy means are plied,</line>
      <line>They bring their own reward);</line>
      <line>Whilst I, a hope-abandoned wight,</line>
      <line>Unfitted with an aim,</line>
      <line>Meet every sad returning night</line>
      <line>And joyless morn the same.</line>
      <line> You, bustling and justling,</line>
      <line>Forget each grief and pain;</line>
      <line>I, listless yet restless,</line>
      <line>Find every prospect vain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How blest the solitary’s lot,</line>
      <line>Who, all-forgetting, all-forgot,</line>
      <line>Within his humble cell –</line>
      <line>The cavern wild with tangling roots –</line>
      <line>Sits o’er his newly-gathered fruits,</line>
      <line>Beside his crystal well!</line>
      <line> Or haply to his evening thought,</line>
      <line>By unfrequented stream,</line>
      <line>The ways of men are distant brought,</line>
      <line>A faint-collected dream;</line>
      <line>While praising, and raising</line>
      <line>His thoughts to Heaven on high,</line>
      <line>As wandering, meandering,</line>
      <line>He views the solemn sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Than I, no lonely hermit, placed</line>
      <line>Where never human footstep traced,</line>
      <line> Less fit to play the part:</line>
      <line>The lucky moment to improve,</line>
      <line>And just to stop, and just to move,</line>
      <line>With self-respecting art.</line>
      <line>But ah, those pleasures, loves, and joys,</line>
      <line>Which I too keenly taste,</line>
      <line>The solitary can despise –</line>
      <line>Can want and yet be blest!</line>
      <line>He needs not, he heeds not</line>
      <line>Or human love, or hate;</line>
      <line> Whilst I here must cry here</line>
      <line>At perfidy ingrate!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh enviable early days,</line>
      <line>When dancing thoughtless pleasure’s maze,</line>
      <line>To care, to guilt unknown –</line>
      <line>How ill exchanged for riper times,</line>
      <line>To feel the follies or the crimes</line>
      <line>Of others, or my own!</line>
      <line>Ye tiny elves that guiltless sport,</line>
      <line>Like linnets in the bush,</line>
      <line> Ye little know the ills ye court,</line>
      <line>When manhood is your wish!</line>
      <line>The losses, the crosses</line>
      <line>That active man engage;</line>
      <line>The fears all, the tears all</line>
      <line>Of dim declining age!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Immortality Ode</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a time when meadow, grove, and stream,</line>
      <line>The earth and every common sight</line>
      <line>To me did seem</line>
      <line>Apparelled in celestial light –</line>
      <line> The glory and the freshness of a dream.</line>
      <line>It is not now as it has been of yore;</line>
      <line>Turn wheresoe’er I may,</line>
      <line>By night or day,</line>
      <line>The things which I have seen I now can see no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The rainbow comes and goes,</line>
      <line>And lovely is the rose;</line>
      <line>The moon doth with delight</line>
      <line>Look round her when the heavens are bare;</line>
      <line>Waters on a starry night</line>
      <line> Are beautiful and fair;</line>
      <line>The sunshine is a glorious birth –</line>
      <line>But yet I know, where’er I go,</line>
      <line>That there hath passed away a glory from the earth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, while the birds thus sing a joyous song,</line>
      <line>And while the young lambs bound</line>
      <line>As to the tabor’s sound,</line>
      <line>To me alone there came a thought of grief.</line>
      <line>A timely utterance gave that thought relief,</line>
      <line>And I again am strong!</line>
      <line> The cataracts blow their trumpets from the steep</line>
      <line>(No more shall grief of mine the season wrong),</line>
      <line>I hear the echoes through the mountains throng;</line>
      <line>The winds come to me from the fields of sleep,</line>
      <line>And all the earth is gay;</line>
      <line>Land and sea</line>
      <line>Give themselves up to jollity,</line>
      <line>And with the heart of May</line>
      <line>Doth every beast keep holiday;</line>
      <line>Thou child of joy,</line>
      <line>Shout round me – let me hear thy shouts, thou happy</line>
      <line> shepherd-boy!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye blesséd creatures I have heard the call</line>
      <line>Ye to each other make; I see</line>
      <line>The heavens laugh with you in your jubilee;</line>
      <line>My heart is at your festival,</line>
      <line>My head hath its coronal,</line>
      <line>The fullness of your bliss, I feel – I feel it all!</line>
      <line>Oh evil day, if I were sullen</line>
      <line>While the Earth herself is adorning</line>
      <line>This sweet May-morning,</line>
      <line> And the children are pulling</line>
      <line>On every side</line>
      <line>In a thousand valleys far and wide</line>
      <line>Fresh flowers; while the sun shines warm,</line>
      <line>And the babe leaps up on his mother’s arm.</line>
      <line>I hear, I hear, with joy I hear!</line>
      <line>But there’s a tree, of many one,</line>
      <line>A single field which I have looked upon –</line>
      <line>Both of them speak of something that is gone.</line>
      <line>The pansy at my feet</line>
      <line> Doth the same tale repeat:</line>
      <line>Whither is fled the visionary gleam?</line>
      <line>Where is it gone, the glory and the dream?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our birth is but a sleep and a forgetting:</line>
      <line>The soul that rises with us, our life’s star,</line>
      <line>Hath had elsewhere its setting</line>
      <line>And cometh from afar.</line>
      <line>Not in entire forgetfulness,</line>
      <line>And not in utter nakedness,</line>
      <line>But trailing clouds of glory do we come</line>
      <line> From God who is our home.</line>
      <line>Heaven lies about us in our infancy –</line>
      <line>Shades of the prison-house begin to close</line>
      <line>Upon the growing boy,</line>
      <line>But he beholds the light and whence it flows,</line>
      <line>He sees it in his joy.</line>
      <line>The youth, who daily farther from the east</line>
      <line>Must travel, still is Nature’s priest</line>
      <line>And by the vision splendid</line>
      <line>Is on his way attended;</line>
      <line> At length the man perceives it die away</line>
      <line>And fade into the light of common day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Earth fills her lap with pleasures of her own:</line>
      <line>Yearnings she hath in her own natural kind,</line>
      <line>And even with something of a mother’s mind</line>
      <line>And no unworthy aim</line>
      <line>The homely nurse doth all she can</line>
      <line>To make her foster-child, her inmate, man,</line>
      <line>Forget the glories he hath known,</line>
      <line>And that imperial palace whence he came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Behold the child among his new-born blisses,</line>
      <line>A four years’ darling of a pigmy size –</line>
      <line>See where, mid work of his own hand, he lies,</line>
      <line>Fretted by sallies of his mother’s kisses,</line>
      <line>With light upon him from his father’s eyes!</line>
      <line>See at his feet some little plan or chart,</line>
      <line>Some fragment from his dream of human life</line>
      <line>Shaped by himself with newly-learnéd art</line>
      <line>(A wedding or a festival,</line>
      <line>A mourning or a funeral),</line>
      <line> And this hath now his heart,</line>
      <line>And unto this he frames his song.</line>
      <line>Then he will fit his tongue</line>
      <line>To dialogues of business, love or strife;</line>
      <line>But it will not be long</line>
      <line>Ere this be thrown aside,</line>
      <line>And with new joy and pride</line>
      <line>The little actor cons another part,</line>
      <line>Filling from time to time his ‘humourous stage’</line>
      <line>With all the persons down to palsied age</line>
      <line>That life brings with her in her equipage–</line>
      <line>As if his whole vocation</line>
      <line>Were endless imitation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou whose exterior semblance doth belie</line>
      <line>Thy soul’s immensity,</line>
      <line>Thou best philosopher, who yet dost keep</line>
      <line>Thy heritage – thou eye among the blind</line>
      <line>That, deaf and silent, readst the eternal deep,</line>
      <line>Haunted for ever by the eternal mind;</line>
      <line>Mighty prophet, seer blest,</line>
      <line> On whom those truths do rest</line>
      <line>Which we are toiling all our lives to find!</line>
      <line>Thou over whom thy immortality</line>
      <line>Broods like the day, a master o’er a slave –</line>
      <line>A presence which is not to be put by –</line>
      <line>To whom the grave</line>
      <line>Is but a lonely bed without the sense or sight</line>
      <line>Of day or the warm light,</line>
      <line>A place of thought where we in waiting lie;</line>
      <line>Thou little child, yet glorious in the might</line>
      <line> Of untamed pleasures, on thy being’s height</line>
      <line>Why with such earnest pains dost thou provoke</line>
      <line>The years to bring the inevitable yoke,</line>
      <line>Thus blindly with thy blessedness at strife?</line>
      <line>Full soon thy soul shall have her earthly freight,</line>
      <line>And custom lie upon thee with a weight</line>
      <line>Heavy as frost and deep almost as life!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh joy that in our embers</line>
      <line>Is something that doth live,</line>
      <line>That nature yet remembers</line>
      <line> What was so fugitive!</line>
      <line>The thought of our past years in me doth breed</line>
      <line>Perpetual benedictions; not indeed</line>
      <line>For that which is most worthy to be blest –</line>
      <line>Delight and liberty, the simple creed</line>
      <line>Of childhood, whether fluttering or at rest,</line>
      <line>With new-born hope for ever in his breast –</line>
      <line>Not for these I raise</line>
      <line>The song of thanks and praise,</line>
      <line>But for those obstinate questionings</line>
      <line> Of sense and outward things,</line>
      <line>Fallings from us, vanishings,</line>
      <line>Blank misgivings of a creature</line>
      <line>Moving about in worlds not realized,</line>
      <line>High instincts, before which our mortal nature</line>
      <line>Did tremble like a guilty thing surprised –</line>
      <line>But for those first affections,</line>
      <line>Those shadowy recollections</line>
      <line>Which be they what they may</line>
      <line>Are yet the fountain-light of all our day,</line>
      <line> Are yet the master-light of all our seeing;</line>
      <line>Uphold us, cherish us, and make</line>
      <line>Our noisy years seem moments in the being</line>
      <line>Of the eternal silence – truths that wake</line>
      <line>To perish never,</line>
      <line>Which neither listlessness, nor mad endeavour,</line>
      <line>Nor man nor boy,</line>
      <line>Nor all that is at enmity with joy,</line>
      <line>Can utterly abolish or destroy!</line>
      <line>Hence in a season of calm weather,</line>
      <line> Though inland far we be,</line>
      <line>Our souls have sight of that immortal sea</line>
      <line>Which brought us hither,</line>
      <line>Can in a moment travel thither</line>
      <line>And see the children sport upon the shore,</line>
      <line>And hear the mighty waters rolling evermore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then sing ye birds, sing, sing a joyous song,</line>
      <line>And let the young lambs bound</line>
      <line>As to the tabor’s sound!</line>
      <line>We in thought will join your throng –</line>
      <line> Ye that pipe and ye that play,</line>
      <line>Ye that through your hearts today</line>
      <line>Feel the gladness of the May!</line>
      <line>What though the radiance which was once so bright</line>
      <line>Be now forever taken from my sight,</line>
      <line>Though nothing can bring back the hour</line>
      <line>Of splendour in the grass, of glory in the flower,</line>
      <line>We will grieve not, rather find</line>
      <line>Strength in what remains behind:</line>
      <line>In the primal sympathy</line>
      <line> Which having been must ever be,</line>
      <line>In the soothing thoughts that spring</line>
      <line>Out of human suffering,</line>
      <line>In the faith that looks through death,</line>
      <line>In years that bring the philosophic mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And oh ye fountains, meadows, hills, and groves,</line>
      <line>Think not of any severing of our loves;</line>
      <line>Yet in my heart of hearts I feel your might –</line>
      <line>I only have relinquished one delight</line>
      <line>To live beneath your more habitual sway!</line>
      <line> I love the brooks which down their channels fret,</line>
      <line>Even more than when I tripped lightly as they;</line>
      <line>The innocent brightness of a new-born day</line>
      <line>Is lovely yet;</line>
      <line>The clouds that gather round the setting sun</line>
      <line>Do take a sober colouring from an eye</line>
      <line>That hath kept watch o’er man’s mortality;</line>
      <line>Another race hath been, and other palms are won.</line>
      <line>Thanks to the human heart by which we live –</line>
      <line>Thanks to its tenderness, its joys, and fears –</line>
      <line>To me the meanest flower that blows can give</line>
      <line>Thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Dejection: An Ode</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, if the bard was weather-wise, who made</line>
      <line>The grand old ballad of Sir Patrick Spens,</line>
      <line>This night, so tranquil now, will not go hence</line>
      <line>Unroused by winds, that ply a busier trade</line>
      <line> Than those which mould yon cloud in lazy flakes,</line>
      <line>Or the dull sobbing draught, that drones and rakes</line>
      <line>Upon the strings of this Eolian lute,</line>
      <line>Which better far were mute.</line>
      <line>For lo! the new moon, winter-bright</line>
      <line>And overspread with phantom light –</line>
      <line>With swimming phantom light o’erspread,</line>
      <line>But rimmed and circled by a silver thread –</line>
      <line>I see the old moon in her lap, foretelling</line>
      <line>The coming-on of rain and squally blast.</line>
      <line> And oh, that even now the gust were swelling,</line>
      <line>And the slant night-shower driving loud and fast!</line>
      <line>Those sounds which oft have raised me, while they awed,</line>
      <line>And sent my soul abroad,</line>
      <line>Might now perhaps their wonted impulse give,</line>
      <line>Might startle this dull pain, and make it move and live!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A grief without a pang, void, dark, and drear,</line>
      <line>A stifled, drowsy, unimpassioned grief,</line>
      <line>Which finds no natural outlet, no relief,</line>
      <line>In word, or sigh, or tear –</line>
      <line> Oh Edmund, in this wan and heartless mood,</line>
      <line>To other thoughts by yonder throstle wooed,</line>
      <line>All this long eve, so balmy and serene,</line>
      <line>Have I been gazing on the western sky,</line>
      <line>And its peculiar tint of yellow-green –</line>
      <line>And still I gaze – and with how blank an eye!</line>
      <line>And those thin clouds above, in flakes and bars,</line>
      <line>That give away their motion to the stars;</line>
      <line>Those stars, that glide behind them or between,</line>
      <line>Now sparkling, now bedimmed, but always seen;</line>
      <line> Yon crescent moon, as fixed as if it grew</line>
      <line>In its own cloudless, starless lake of blue –</line>
      <line>A boat becalmed, a lovely sky-canoe!</line>
      <line>I see them all, so excellently fair,</line>
      <line>I see, not feel, how beautiful they are!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My genial spirits fail;</line>
      <line>And what can these avail</line>
      <line>To lift the smothering weight from off my breast?</line>
      <line>It were a vain endeavour,</line>
      <line>Though I should gaze for ever</line>
      <line> On that green light that lingers in the west:</line>
      <line>I may not hope from outward forms to win</line>
