      <line>The passion and the life, whose fountains are within.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Edmund, we receive but what we give,</line>
      <line>And in our life alone does Nature live:</line>
      <line>Ours is her wedding garment, ours her shroud!</line>
      <line>And would we aught behold of higher worth</line>
      <line>Than that inanimate cold world allowed</line>
      <line>To the poor loveless ever-anxious crowd,</line>
      <line>Ah! from the soul itself must issue forth</line>
      <line> A light, a glory, a fair luminous cloud</line>
      <line>Enveloping the earth –</line>
      <line>And from the soul itself must there be sent</line>
      <line>A sweet and potent voice, of its own birth,</line>
      <line>Of all sweet sounds the life and element.</line>
      <line>Oh pure of heart, thou needst not ask of me</line>
      <line>What this strong music in the soul may be –</line>
      <line>What, and wherein it doth exist,</line>
      <line>This light, this glory, this fair luminous mist,</line>
      <line>This beautiful and beauty-making power.</line>
      <line> Joy, virtuous Edmund – joy that ne’er was given,</line>
      <line>Save to the pure, and in their purest hour –</line>
      <line>Joy, Edmund, is the spirit and the power</line>
      <line>Which, wedding Nature to us, gives in dower</line>
      <line>A new Earth and new Heaven,</line>
      <line>Undreamt of by the sensual and the proud!</line>
      <line>Joy is the sweet voice, joy the luminous cloud –</line>
      <line>We, we ourselves, rejoice!</line>
      <line>And thence flows all that charms or ear or sight –</line>
      <line>All melodies the echoes of that voice,</line>
      <line> All colours a suffusion from that light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, dearest Edmund, yes,</line>
      <line>There was a time when, though my path was rough,</line>
      <line>This joy within me dallied with distress,</line>
      <line>And all misfortunes were but as the stuff</line>
      <line>Whence fancy made me dreams of happiness;</line>
      <line>For hope grew round me like the twining vine,</line>
      <line>And fruits and foliage not my own, seemed mine!</line>
      <line>But now afflictions bow me down to earth –</line>
      <line>Nor care I that they rob me of my mirth,</line>
      <line> But oh, each visitation</line>
      <line>Suspends what Nature gave me at my birth,</line>
      <line>My shaping spirit of imagination!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, wherefore did I let it haunt my mind,</line>
      <line>This dark distressful dream?</line>
      <line>I turn from it and listen to the wind,</line>
      <line>Which long has raved unnoticed. What a scream</line>
      <line>Of agony, by torture lengthened out,</line>
      <line>That lute sent forth! Thou wind, that ravest without!</line>
      <line>Bare crag, or mountain-tairn, or blasted tree,</line>
      <line> Or pine-grove whither woodman never clomb,</line>
      <line>Or lonely house, long held the witches’ home,</line>
      <line>Methinks were fitter instruments for thee,</line>
      <line>Mad lutanist, who in this month of showers,</line>
      <line>Of dark-brown gardens, and of peeping flowers,</line>
      <line>Makest devils’ yule, with worse than wintry song</line>
      <line>The blossoms, buds, and timorous leaves among.</line>
      <line>Thou actor, perfect in all tragic sounds!</line>
      <line>Thou mighty poet, even to frenzy bold!</line>
      <line>What tellest thou now about?</line>
      <line>’Tis of the rushing of an host in rout,</line>
      <line>With many groans of men with smarting wounds –</line>
      <line>At once they groan with pain, and shudder with the cold!</line>
      <line>But hush, there is a pause of deepest silence!</line>
      <line>And all that noise, as of a rushing crowd,</line>
      <line>With groans and tremulous shudderings – all is over!</line>
      <line>It tells another tale, with sounds less deep and loud,</line>
      <line>A tale of less affright</line>
      <line>And tempered with delight,</line>
      <line>As Edmund’s self had framed the tender lay.</line>
      <line> ’Tis of a little child</line>
      <line>Upon a lonesome wild</line>
      <line>Not far from home, but she has lost her way</line>
      <line>And now moans low in utter grief and fear,</line>
      <line>And now screams loud, and hopes to make her mother hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis midnight, and small thoughts have I of sleep –</line>
      <line>Full seldom may my friend such vigils keep!</line>
      <line>Visit him, gentle sleep, with wings of healing,</line>
      <line>And may this storm be but a mountain-birth,</line>
      <line>May all the stars hang bright above his dwelling,</line>
      <line> Silent as though they watched the sleeping Earth!</line>
      <line>With light heart may he rise,</line>
      <line>Gay fancy, cheerful eyes,</line>
      <line>And sing his lofty song, and teach me to rejoice!</line>
      <line>Oh Edmund, friend of my devoutest choice,</line>
      <line>Oh, raised from anxious dread and busy care</line>
      <line>By the immenseness of the good and fair</line>
      <line>Which thou seest everywhere –</line>
      <line>Joy lifts thy spirit, joy attunes thy voice;</line>
      <line>To thee do all things live, from pole to pole,</line>
      <line> Their life the eddying of thy living soul!</line>
      <line>Oh simple spirit, guided from above;</line>
      <line>Oh lofty poet, full of light and love;</line>
      <line>Brother and friend of my devoutest of my choice,</line>
      <line>Thus mayst thou ever, evermore rejoice!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Hymn to Intellectual Beauty</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The awful shadow of some unseen power</line>
      <line>Floats, though unseen, among us – visiting</line>
      <line>This various world with as inconstant wing</line>
      <line>As summer winds that creep from flower to flower.</line>
      <line> Like moonbeams that behind some piny mountain-shower,</line>
      <line>It visits with inconstant glance</line>
      <line>Each human heart and countenance:</line>
      <line>Like hues and harmonies of evening,</line>
      <line>Like clouds in starlight widely spread,</line>
      <line>Like memory of music fled –</line>
      <line>Like aught that for its grace may be</line>
      <line>Dear, and yet dearer for its mystery.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spirit of Beauty – that dost consecrate</line>
      <line>With thine own hues all thou dost shine upon</line>
      <line> Of human thought or form – where art thou gone?</line>
      <line>Why dost thou pass away and leave our state,</line>
      <line>This dim vast vale of tears, vacant and desolate?</line>
      <line>Ask why the sunlight not for ever</line>
      <line>Weaves rainbows o’er yon mountain-river,</line>
      <line>Why aught should fail and fade that once is shown,</line>
      <line>Why fear and dream and death and birth</line>
      <line>Cast on the daylight of this earth</line>
      <line>Such gloom – why man has such a scope</line>
      <line>For love and hate, despondency and hope?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> No voice from some sublimer world hath ever</line>
      <line>To sage or poet these responses given,</line>
      <line>Therefore the names of Demon, Ghost, and Heaven,</line>
      <line>Remain the records of their vain endeavour –</line>
      <line>Frail spells, whose uttered charm might not avail to sever,</line>
      <line>From all we hear and all we see,</line>
      <line>Doubt, chance, and mutability.</line>
      <line>Thy light alone – like mist o’er mountains driven,</line>
      <line>Or music by the night-wind sent</line>
      <line>Through strings of some still instrument,</line>
      <line> Or moonlight on a midnight stream –</line>
      <line>Gives grace and truth to life’s unquiet dream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love, hope, and self-esteem, like clouds depart</line>
      <line>And come, for some uncertain moments lent.</line>
      <line>Man were immortal, and omnipotent,</line>
      <line>Didst thou, unknown and awful as thou art,</line>
      <line>Keep with thy glorious train firm state within his heart!</line>
      <line>Thou messenger of sympathies,</line>
      <line>That wax and wane in lovers’ eyes,</line>
      <line>Thou that to human thought art nourishment</line>
      <line> Like darkness to a dying flame,</line>
      <line>Depart not as thy shadow came –</line>
      <line>Depart not, lest the grave should be,</line>
      <line>Like life and fear, a dark reality.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While yet a boy I sought for ghosts, and sped</line>
      <line>Through many a listening chamber, cave and ruin,</line>
      <line>And starlight wood, with fearful steps pursuing</line>
      <line>Hopes of high talk with the departed dead.</line>
      <line>I called on poisonous names with which our youth is fed –</line>
      <line>I was not heard! I saw them not!</line>
      <line> When musing deeply on the lot</line>
      <line>Of life, at that sweet time when winds are wooing</line>
      <line>All vital things that wake to bring</line>
      <line>News of birds and blossoming,</line>
      <line>Sudden thy shadow fell on me –</line>
      <line>I shrieked, and clasped my hands in ecstasy!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I vowed that I would dedicate my powers</line>
      <line>To thee and thine – have I not kept the vow?</line>
      <line>With beating heart and streaming eyes, even now</line>
      <line>I call the phantoms of a thousand hours</line>
      <line> Each from his voiceless grave! They have in visioned bowers</line>
      <line>Of studious zeal, or love’s delight,</line>
      <line>Outwatched with me the envious night –</line>
      <line>They know that never joy illumed my brow</line>
      <line>Unlinked with hope that thou wouldst free</line>
      <line>This world from its dark slavery,</line>
      <line>That thou, oh awful Loveliness,</line>
      <line>Wouldst give whate’er these words cannot express.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The day becomes more solemn and serene</line>
      <line>When noon is past; there is a harmony</line>
      <line> In autumn, and a lustre in its sky,</line>
      <line>Which through the summer is not heard or seen –</line>
      <line>As if it could not be, as if it had not been!</line>
      <line>Thus let thy power, which like the truth</line>
      <line>Of Nature on my passive youth</line>
      <line>Descended, to my onward life supply</line>
      <line>Its calm – to one who worships thee,</line>
      <line>And every form containing thee,</line>
      <line>Whom, Spirit fair, thy spells did bind</line>
      <line>To fear himself, and love all human kind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Ode to Psyche</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Goddess, hear these tuneless numbers, wrung</line>
      <line>By sweet enforcement and remembrance dear,</line>
      <line>And pardon that thy secrets should be sung</line>
      <line>Even into thine own soft-conchéd ear!</line>
      <line> Surely I dreamt to-day, or did I see</line>
      <line>The wingéd Psyche with awakened eyes?</line>
      <line>I wandered in a forest thoughtlessly,</line>
      <line>And, on the sudden, fainting with surprise,</line>
      <line>Saw two fair creatures, couchéd side by side</line>
      <line>In deepest grass, beneath the whispering roof</line>
      <line>Of leaves and trembled blossoms, where there ran</line>
      <line>A brooklet, scarce espied.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mid hushed, cool-rooted flowers, fragrant-eyed,</line>
      <line>Blue, silver-white, and budded Tyrian,</line>
      <line> They lay calm-breathing on the bedded grass.</line>
      <line>Their arms embracéd, and their pinions too;</line>
      <line>Their lips touched not, but had not bade adieu,</line>
      <line>As if disjoinéd by soft-handed slumber,</line>
      <line>And ready still past kisses to outnumber</line>
      <line>At tender eye-dawn of aurorean love:</line>
      <line>The wingéd boy I knew –</line>
      <line>But who wast thou, oh happy, happy dove?</line>
      <line>His Psyche true!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh latest born and loveliest vision far</line>
      <line> Of all Olympus’ faded hierarchy!</line>
      <line>Fairer than Phoebe’s sapphire-regioned star,</line>
      <line>Or Vesper, amorous glow-worm of the sky –</line>
      <line>Fairer than these, though temple thou hast none,</line>
      <line>Nor altar heaped with flowers;</line>
      <line>Nor virgin-choir to make delicious moan</line>
      <line>Upon the midnight hours –</line>
      <line>No voice, no lute, no pipe, no incense sweet</line>
      <line>From chain-swung censer teeming;</line>
      <line>No shrine, no grove, no oracle, no heat</line>
      <line> Of pale-mouthed prophet dreaming.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh brightest, though too late for antique vows!</line>
      <line>Too, too late for the fond believing lyre,</line>
      <line>When holy were the haunted forest-boughs,</line>
      <line>Holy the air, the water, and the fire.</line>
      <line>Yet even in these days, so far retired</line>
      <line>From happy pieties, thy lucent fans,</line>
      <line>Fluttering among the faint Olympians,</line>
      <line>I see, and sing, by my own eyes inspired.</line>
      <line>So let me be thy choir, and make a moan</line>
      <line> Upon the midnight hours –</line>
      <line>Thy voice, thy lute, thy pipe, thy incense sweet</line>
      <line>From swingéd censer teeming;</line>
      <line>Thy shrine, thy grove, thy oracle, thy heat</line>
      <line>Of pale-mouthed prophet dreaming.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, I will be thy priest, and build a fane</line>
      <line>In some untrodden region of my mind,</line>
      <line>Where branchéd thoughts, new grown with pleasant pain,</line>
      <line>Instead of pines shall murmur in the wind.</line>
      <line>Far, far around shall those dark-clustered trees</line>
      <line> Fledge the wild-ridgéd mountains steep by steep;</line>
      <line>And there by zephyrs, streams, and birds, and bees,</line>
      <line>The moss-lain dryads shall be lulled to sleep.</line>
      <line>And in the midst of this wide quietness</line>
      <line>A rosy sanctuary will I dress</line>
      <line>With the wreathed trellis of a working brain,</line>
      <line>With buds, and bells, and stars without a name –</line>
      <line>With all the gardener Fancy e’er could feign,</line>
      <line>Who, breeding flowers, will never breed the same.</line>
      <line>And there shall be for thee all soft delight</line>
      <line> That shadowy thought can win,</line>
      <line>A bright torch, and a casement ope at night,</line>
      <line>To let the warm Love in!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Ode to a Nightingale</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains</line>
      <line>My sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk,</line>
      <line>Or emptied some dull opiate to the drains</line>
      <line>One minute past, and Lethe-wards had sunk.</line>
      <line> ’Tis not through envy of thy happy lot,</line>
      <line>But being too happy in thine happiness –</line>
      <line>That thou, light-wingéd dryad of the trees,</line>
      <line>In some melodious plot</line>
      <line>Of beechen green, and shadows numberless,</line>
      <line>Singest of summer in full-throated ease.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, for a draught of vintage that hath been</line>
      <line>Cooled a long age in the deep-delvéd earth,</line>
      <line>Tasting of Flora and the country green,</line>
      <line>Dance, and Provençal song, and sunburnt mirth!</line>
      <line> Oh for a beaker full of the warm South,</line>
      <line>Full of the true, the blushful Hippocrene,</line>
      <line>With beaded bubbles winking at the brim,</line>
      <line>And purple-stainéd mouth;</line>
      <line>That I might drink, and leave the world unseen,</line>
      <line>And with thee fade away into the forest dim –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fade far away, dissolve, and quite forget</line>
      <line>What thou among the leaves hast never known,</line>
      <line>The weariness, the fever, and the fret</line>
      <line>Here, where men sit and hear each other groan –</line>
      <line> Where palsy shakes a few, sad, last, grey hairs,</line>
      <line>Where youth grows pale, and spectre-thin, and dies;</line>
      <line>Where but to think is to be full of sorrow</line>
      <line>And leaden-eyed despairs,</line>
      <line>Where beauty cannot keep her lustrous eyes</line>
      <line>Or new love pine at them beyond tomorrow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away! Away! For I will fly to thee,</line>
      <line>Not charioted by Bacchus and his pards,</line>
      <line>But on the viewless wings of poesy,</line>
      <line>Though the dull brain perplexes and retards.</line>
      <line> Already with thee! Tender is the night,</line>
      <line>And haply the Queen-Moon is on her throne,</line>
      <line>Clustered around by all her starry fays;</line>
      <line>But here there is no light,</line>
      <line>Save what from heaven is with the breezes blown</line>
      <line>Through verdurous glooms and winding mossy ways.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot see what flowers are at my feet,</line>
      <line>Nor what soft incense hangs upon the boughs,</line>
      <line>But, in embalméd darkness, guess each sweet</line>
      <line>Wherewith the seasonable month endows</line>
      <line> The grass, the thicket, and the fruit-tree wild;</line>
      <line>White hawthorn, and the pastoral eglantine;</line>
      <line>Fast fading violets covered up in leaves;</line>
      <line>And mid-May’s eldest child,</line>
      <line>The coming musk-rose, full of dewy wine,</line>
      <line>The murmurous haunt of flies on summer eves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Darkling I listen, and for many a time</line>
      <line>I have been half in love with easeful death,</line>
      <line>Called him soft names in many a muséd rhyme,</line>
      <line>To take into the air my quiet breath.</line>
      <line> Now more than ever seems it rich to die,</line>
      <line>To cease upon the midnight with no pain,</line>
      <line>While thou art pouring forth thy soul abroad</line>
      <line>In such an ecstasy!</line>
      <line>Still wouldst thou sing, and I have ears in vain –</line>
      <line>To thy high requiem become a sod.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou wast not born for death, immortal bird!</line>
      <line>No hungry generations tread thee down;</line>
      <line>The voice I hear this passing night was heard</line>
      <line>In ancient days by emperor and clown –</line>
      <line> Perhaps the self-same song that found a path</line>
      <line>Through the sad heart of Ruth, when, sick for home,</line>
      <line>She stood in tears amid the alien corn;</line>
      <line>The same that oft-times hath</line>
      <line>Charmed magic casements, opening on the foam</line>
      <line>Of perilous seas, in fairy lands forlorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forlorn – the very word is like a bell</line>
      <line>To toll me back from thee to my sole self!</line>
      <line>Adieu! The fancy cannot cheat so well</line>
      <line>As she is famed to do, deceiving elf!</line>
      <line> Adieu! adieu! Thy plaintive anthem fades</line>
      <line>Past the near meadows, over the still stream,</line>
      <line>Up the hillside; and now ’tis buried deep</line>
      <line>In the next valley-glades:</line>
      <line>Was it a vision, or a waking dream?</line>
      <line>Fled is that music! Do I wake or sleep?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Ode on a Grecian Urn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou still unravished bride of quietness,</line>
      <line>Thou foster-child of silence and slow time,</line>
      <line>Sylvan historian, who canst thus express</line>
      <line>A flowery tale more sweetly than our rhyme!</line>
      <line> What leaf-fringed legend haunts about thy shape,</line>
      <line>Of deities or mortals, or of both,</line>
      <line>In Tempe or the dales of Arcady?</line>
      <line>What men or gods are these? What maidens loath?</line>
      <line>What mad pursuit? What struggle to escape?</line>
      <line>What pipes and timbrels? What wild ecstasy?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Heard melodies are sweet, but those unheard</line>
      <line>Are sweeter; therefore, ye soft pipes, play on –</line>
      <line>Not to the sensual ear, but, more endeared,</line>
      <line>Pipe to the spirit ditties of no tone.</line>
      <line> Fair youth, beneath the trees, thou canst not leave</line>
      <line>Thy song, nor ever can those trees be bare;</line>
      <line>Bold lover, never, never canst thou kiss,</line>
      <line>Though winning near the goal – yet, do not grieve:</line>
      <line>She cannot fade, though thou hast not thy bliss,</line>
      <line>For ever wilt thou love, and she be fair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, happy, happy boughs! that cannot shed</line>
      <line>Your leaves, nor ever bid the spring adieu;</line>
      <line>And, happy melodist, unweariéd,</line>
      <line>For ever piping songs for ever new!</line>
      <line> More happy love! more happy, happy love!</line>
      <line>For ever warm and still to be enjoyed,</line>
      <line>For ever panting, and for ever young –</line>
      <line>All breathing human passion far above,</line>
      <line>That leaves a heart high-sorrowful and cloyed,</line>
      <line>A burning forehead, and a parching tongue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who are these coming to the sacrifice?</line>
      <line>To what green altar, oh mysterious priest,</line>
      <line>Leadst thou that heifer lowing at the skies,</line>
      <line>And all her silken flanks with garlands drest?</line>
      <line> What little town by river or sea shore,</line>
      <line>Or mountain-built with peaceful citadel,</line>
      <line>Is emptied of this folk, this pious morn?</line>
      <line>And, little town, thy streets for evermore</line>
      <line>Will silent be; and not a soul to tell</line>
      <line>Why thou art desolate, can e’er return.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Attic shape! Fair attitude! with brede</line>
      <line>Of marble men and maidens overwrought,</line>
      <line>With forest branches and the trodden weed –</line>
      <line>Thou, silent form, dost tease us out of thought</line>
      <line> As doth eternity. Cold pastoral!</line>
      <line>When old age shall this generation waste</line>
      <line>Thou shalt remain, in midst of other woe</line>
      <line>Than ours, a friend to man, to whom thou sayst,</line>
      <line>‘Beauty is truth, truth beauty – that is all</line>
      <line>Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Ode on Melancholy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, no, go not to Lethe, neither twist</line>
      <line>Wolf’s-bane, tight-rooted, for its poisonous wine;</line>
      <line>Nor suffer thy pale forehead to be kissed</line>
      <line>By nightshade, ruby grape of Proserpine.</line>
      <line> Make not your rosary of yew-berries,</line>
      <line>Nor let the beetle, nor the death-moth, be</line>
      <line>Your mournful Psyche, nor the downy owl</line>
      <line>A partner in your sorrow’s mysteries;</line>
      <line>For shade to shade will come too drowsily,</line>
      <line>And drown the wakeful anguish of the soul.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when the melancholy fit shall fall</line>
      <line>Sudden from heaven like a weeping cloud</line>
      <line>That fosters the droop-headed flowers all</line>
      <line>And hides the green hill in an April shroud,</line>
      <line> Then glut thy sorrow on a morning rose,</line>
      <line>Or on the rainbow of the salt sand-wave,</line>
      <line>Or on the wealth of globéd peonies –</line>
      <line>Or, if thy mistress some rich anger shows,</line>
      <line>Emprison her soft hand and let her rave,</line>
      <line>And feed deep, deep upon her peerless eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She dwells with Beauty – Beauty that must die;</line>
      <line>And Joy, whose hand is ever at his lips</line>
      <line>Bidding adieu; and aching Pleasure, nigh,</line>
      <line>Turning to poison while the bee-mouth sips.</line>
      <line> Ay, in the very temple of Delight</line>
      <line>Veiled Melancholy has her sovran shrine,</line>
      <line>Though seen of none save him whose strenuous tongue</line>
      <line>Can burst Joy’s grape against his palate fine –</line>
      <line>His soul shall taste the sadness of her might,</line>
      <line>And be among her cloudy trophies hung.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Ode on Indolence</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>One morn before me were three figures seen,</line>
      <line>With bowéd necks and joinéd hands, side-faced,</line>
      <line>And one behind the other stepped serene,</line>
      <line>In placid sandals and in white robes graced.</line>
      <line> They passed, like figures on a marble urn</line>
      <line>When shifted round to see the other side;</line>
      <line>They came again – as when the urn once more</line>
      <line>Is shifted round the first-seen shades return –</line>
      <line>And they were strange to me, as may betide</line>
      <line>With vases, to one deep in Phidian lore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How is it, Shadows, that I knew ye not?</line>
      <line>How came ye muffled in so hush a masque?</line>
      <line>Was it a silent deep-disguiséd plot</line>
      <line>To steal away, and leave without a task</line>
      <line> My idle days? Ripe was the drowsy hour;</line>
      <line>The blissful cloud of summer-indolence</line>
      <line>Benumbed my eyes; my pulse grew less and less;</line>
      <line>Pain had no sting, and pleasure’s wreath no flower!</line>
      <line>Oh, why did ye not melt, and leave my sense</line>
      <line>Unhaunted quite of all, but – nothingness?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A third time passed they by – and, passing, turned</line>
      <line>Each one the face a moment-whiles to me –</line>
      <line>Then faded, and to follow them I burned,</line>
      <line>And ached for wings, because I knew the three.</line>
      <line> The first was a fair maid, and Love her name;</line>
      <line>The second was Ambition, pale of cheek,</line>
      <line>And ever watchful with fatiguéd eye;</line>
      <line>The last, whom I love more, the more of blame</line>
      <line>Is heaped upon her (maiden most unmeek),</line>
      <line>I knew to be my demon Poesy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They faded, and, forsooth, I wanted wings!</line>
      <line>Oh folly! What is love, and where is it? –</line>
      <line>And, for that poor ambition! It springs</line>
      <line>From a man’s little heart’s short fever-fit!</line>
      <line> For Poesy! No, she has not a joy</line>
      <line>(At least for me) so sweet as drowsy noons,</line>
      <line>And evenings steeped in honeyed indolence!</line>
      <line>Oh, for an age so sheltered from annoy,</line>
      <line>That I may never know how change the moons,</line>
      <line>Or hear the voice of busy common-sense!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And once more came they by. Alas, wherefore?</line>
      <line>My sleep had been embroidered with dim dreams;</line>
      <line>My soul had been a lawn besprinkled o’er</line>
      <line>With flowers, and stirring shades, and baffled beams.</line>
      <line> The morn was clouded, but no shower fell,</line>
      <line>Though in her lids hung the sweet tears of May;</line>
      <line>The open casement pressed a new-leaved vine,</line>
      <line>Let in the budding warmth and throstle’s lay:</line>
      <line>‘Oh Shadows, ’twas a time to bid farewell!</line>
      <line>Upon your skirts had fallen no tears of mine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, ye three Ghosts, adieu! Ye cannot raise</line>
      <line>My head cool-bedded in the flowery grass;</line>
      <line>For I would not be dieted with praise –</line>
      <line>A pet-lamb in a sentimental farce!</line>
      <line> Fade softly from my eyes, and be once more</line>
      <line>In masque-like figures on the dreamy urn.</line>
      <line>Farewell! I yet have visions for the night,</line>
      <line>And for the day faint visions there is store –</line>
      <line>Vanish, ye Phantoms, from my idle sprite</line>
      <line>Into the clouds, and never more return!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Ode to the West Wind</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh wild West Wind, thou breath of autumn’s being,</line>
      <line>Thou, from whose unseen presence the leaves dead</line>
      <line>Are driven, like ghosts from an enchanter fleeing,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yellow, and black, and pale, and hectic red –</line>
      <line> Pestilence-stricken multitudes! Oh thou,</line>
      <line>Who chariotest to their dark wintry bed</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wingéd seeds, where they lie cold and low,</line>
      <line>Each like a corpse within its grave, until</line>
      <line>Thine azure sister of the spring shall blow</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her clarion o’er the dreaming earth, and fill</line>
      <line>(Driving sweet buds like flocks to feed in air)</line>
      <line>With living hues and odours plain and hill:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wild Spirit, which art moving everywhere –</line>
      <line>Destroyer and preserver – hear, oh, hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thou on whose stream, mid the steep sky’s commotion,</line>
      <line>Loose clouds like earth’s decaying leaves are shed,</line>
      <line>Shook from the tangled boughs of Heaven and Ocean,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Angels of rain and lightning – there are spread</line>
      <line>On the blue surface of thine airy surge,</line>
      <line>Like the bright hair uplifted from the head</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of some fierce Maenad, even from the dim verge</line>
      <line>Of the horizon to the zenith’s height,</line>
      <line>The locks of the approaching storm. Thou dirge</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of the dying year, to which this closing night</line>
      <line> Will be the dome of a vast sepulchre,</line>
      <line>Vaulted with all thy congregated might</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of vapours, from whose solid atmosphere</line>
      <line>Black rain, and fire, and hail will burst – oh, hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou who didst waken from his summer dreams</line>
      <line>The blue Mediterranean, where he lay,</line>
      <line>Lulled by the coil of his crystalline streams,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beside a pumice isle in Baiae’s bay,</line>
      <line>And saw in sleep old palaces and towers</line>
      <line>Quivering within the wave’s intenser day,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> All overgrown with azure moss and flowers</line>
      <line>So sweet, the sense faints picturing them! Thou</line>
      <line>For whose path the Atlantic’s level powers</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cleave themselves into chasms, while far below</line>
      <line>The sea-blooms and the oozy woods which wear</line>
      <line>The sapless foliage of the ocean, know</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy voice, and suddenly grow grey with fear,</line>
      <line>And tremble and despoil themselves – oh, hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If I were a dead leaf thou mightest bear,</line>
      <line>If I were a swift cloud to fly with thee,</line>
      <line> A wave to pant beneath thy power, and share</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The impulse of thy strength, only less free</line>
      <line>Than thou, oh uncontrollable! – if even</line>
      <line>I were as in my boyhood, and could be</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The comrade of thy wanderings over heaven,</line>
      <line>As then, when to outstrip thy skiey speed</line>
      <line>Scarce seemed a vision – I would ne’er have striven</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As thus with thee in prayer in my sore need.</line>
      <line>Oh, lift me as a wave, a leaf, a cloud!</line>
      <line>I fall upon the thorns of life! I bleed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A heavy weight of hours has chained and bowed</line>
      <line>One too like thee, tameless, and swift, and proud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Make me thy lyre, even as the forest is –</line>
      <line>What if my leaves are falling like its own? –</line>
      <line>The tumult of thy mighty harmonies</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will take from both a deep autumnal tone,</line>
      <line>Sweet though in sadness. Be thou, Spirit fierce,</line>
      <line>My spirit! Be thou me, impetuous one!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Drive my dead thoughts over the universe</line>
      <line>Like withered leaves to quicken a new birth!</line>
      <line> And, by the incantation of this verse,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Scatter, as from an unextinguished hearth</line>
      <line>Ashes and sparks, my words among mankind!</line>
      <line>Be through my lips to unawakened earth</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The trumpet of a prophecy! Oh, Wind,</line>
      <line>If winter comes, can spring be far behind?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1783</date>
    <title>Song (‘How sweet I roamed’)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How sweet I roamed from field to field</line>
      <line>And tasted all the summer’s pride,</line>
      <line>Till I the Prince of Love beheld,</line>
      <line>Who in the sunny beams did glide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He showed me lilies for my hair,</line>
      <line>And blushing roses for my brow;</line>
      <line>He led me through his gardens fair,</line>
      <line>Where all his golden pleasures grow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With sweet May dews my wings were wet,</line>
      <line>And Phoebus fired my vocal rage.</line>
      <line>He caught me in his silken net,</line>
      <line>And shut me in his golden cage.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He loves to sit and hear me sing,</line>
      <line>Then laughing sports and plays with me –</line>
      <line> Then stretches out my golden wing,</line>
      <line>And mocks my loss of liberty.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1786</date>
    <title>It Was upon a Lammas Night</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was upon a Lammas night</line>
      <line>When corn rigs are bonnie,</line>
      <line>Beneath the moon’s unclouded light,</line>
      <line>I held awa to Annie;</line>
      <line> The time flew by wi’ tentless heed,</line>
      <line>Till, ’tween the late and early,</line>
      <line>Wi’ sma’ persuasion she agreed,</line>
      <line>To see me thro’ the barley.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Corn rigs, an’ barley rigs,</line>
      <line>An’ corn rigs are bonnie</line>
      <line>I’ll ne’er forget that happy night,</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs wi’ Annie!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sky was blue, the wind was still,</line>
      <line>The moon was shining clearly,</line>
      <line> I set her down, wi’ right good will,</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs o’ barley.</line>
      <line>I ken’t her heart was a’ my ain,</line>
      <line>I loved her most sincerely,</line>
      <line>I kissed her owre and owre again</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs o’ barley.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Corn rigs, an’ barley rigs,</line>
      <line>An’ corn rigs are bonnie</line>
      <line>I’ll ne’er forget that happy night,</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs wi’ Annie!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I locked her in my fond embrace</line>
      <line>(Her heart was beating rarely),</line>
      <line>My blessings on that happy place</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs o’ barley –</line>
      <line>But by the moon and stars so bright,</line>
      <line>She ay shall bless that happy night,</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs o’ barley!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Corn rigs, an’ barley rigs,</line>
      <line>An’ corn rigs are bonnie</line>
      <line>I’ll ne’er forget that happy night,</line>
      <line> Amang the rigs wi’ Annie!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hae been blythe wi’ comrades dear,</line>
      <line>I hae been merry drinking,</line>
      <line>I hae been joyfu’ gath’rin gear,</line>
      <line>I hae been happy thinking –</line>
      <line>But a’ the pleasures e’er I saw,</line>
      <line>Tho’ three times doubl’d fairly,</line>
      <line>That happy night was worth them a’,</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs o’ barley.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Corn rigs, an’ barley rigs,</line>
      <line> An’ corn rigs are bonnie</line>
      <line>I’ll ne’er forget that happy night,</line>
      <line>Amang the rigs wi’ Annie!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1791</date>
    <title>The Banks o’ Doon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye flowery banks o’ bonnie Doon</line>
      <line>How can ye blume sae fair,</line>
      <line>How can ye chant, ye little birds,</line>
      <line>And I sae fu’ o’care?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thou’ll break my heart, thou bonnie bird</line>
      <line>That sings upon the bough,</line>
      <line>Thou minds me o’ the happy days</line>
      <line>When my fause luve was true.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou’ll break my heart, thou bonnie bird</line>
      <line>That sings beside thy mate,</line>
      <line>For sae I sat, and sae I sang,</line>
      <line>And wist na o’ my fate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Aft hae I roved by bonnie Doon</line>
      <line>To see the woodbine twine,</line>
      <line> And ilka bird sang o’ its love,</line>
      <line>And sae did I o’ mine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wi’ lightsome heart I pu’d a rose</line>
      <line>Frae aff its thorny tree,</line>
      <line>And my fause luver staw the rose,</line>
      <line>But left the thorn wi’ me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wi’ lightsome heart I pu’d a rose</line>
      <line>Upon a morn in June,</line>
      <line>And sae I flourished on the morn,</line>
      <line>And sae was pu’d or noon!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1793</date>
    <title>A Red Red Rose</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O my luve’s like a red, red rose,</line>
      <line>That’s newly sprung in June;</line>
      <line>O my luve’s like the melodie</line>
      <line>That’s sweetly played in tune:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> As fair art thou, my bonnie lass,</line>
      <line>So deep in luve am I;</line>
      <line>And I will love thee still, my dear,</line>
      <line>Till a’ the seas gang dry –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till a’ the seas gang dry, my dear,</line>
      <line>And the rocks melt wi’ the sun –</line>
      <line>I will love thee still, my dear,</line>
      <line>While the sands o’ life shall run!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And fare thee weel, my only luve,</line>
      <line>And fare thee weel, a while –</line>
      <line> And I will come again, my luve,</line>
      <line>Tho’ it were ten thousand mile!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>Introduction</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Piping down the valleys wild,</line>
      <line>Piping songs of pleasant glee,</line>
      <line>On a cloud I saw a child</line>
      <line>And he laughing said to me:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Pipe a song about a lamb.’</line>
      <line>So I piped with merry cheer –</line>
      <line>‘Piper, pipe that song again!’</line>
      <line>So I piped; he wept to hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Drop thy pipe, thy happy pipe,</line>
      <line>Sing thy songs of happy cheer.’</line>
      <line>So I sung the same again,</line>
      <line>While he wept with joy to hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Piper, sit thee down and write,</line>
      <line>In a book that all may read.’</line>
      <line> So he vanished from my sight,</line>
      <line>And I plucked a hollow reed,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I made a rural pen,</line>
      <line>And I stained the water clear,</line>
      <line>And I wrote my happy songs</line>
      <line>Every child may joy to hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>The Shepherd</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How sweet is the shepherd’s sweet lot,</line>
      <line>From the morn to the evening he strays:</line>
      <line>He shall follow his sheep all the day</line>
      <line>And his tongue shall be filled with praise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For he hears the lamb’s innocent call,</line>
      <line>And he hears the ewe’s tender reply;</line>
      <line>He is watchful while they are in peace,</line>
      <line>For they know when their shepherd is nigh.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>Infant Joy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I have no name,</line>
      <line>I am but two days old!’</line>
      <line>‘What shall I call thee?’</line>
      <line>‘I happy am,</line>
      <line> Joy is my name –</line>
      <line>Sweet joy befall thee!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Pretty joy,</line>
      <line>Sweet joy but two days old –</line>
      <line>Sweet joy I call thee!</line>
      <line>Thou dost smile,</line>
      <line>I sing the while –</line>
      <line>Sweet joy befall thee!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>The Echoing Green</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun does arise,</line>
      <line>And make happy the skies.</line>
      <line>The merry bells ring</line>
      <line>To welcome the spring.</line>
      <line> The skylark and thrush,</line>
      <line>The birds of the bush,</line>
      <line>Sing louder around</line>
      <line>To the bells’ cheerful sound,</line>
      <line>While our sports shall be seen</line>
      <line>On the echoing green.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old John with white hair</line>
      <line>Does laugh away care,</line>
      <line>Sitting under the oak</line>
      <line>Among the old folk.</line>
      <line> They laugh at our play,</line>
      <line>And soon they all say:</line>
      <line>‘Such, such were the joys</line>
      <line>When we all, girls and boys,</line>
      <line>In our youth-time were seen</line>
      <line>On the echoing green.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till the little ones weary</line>
      <line>No more can be merry,</line>
      <line>The sun does descend</line>
      <line>And our sports have an end.</line>
      <line> Round the laps of their mothers</line>
      <line>Many sisters and brothers,</line>
      <line>Like birds in their nest,</line>
      <line>Are ready for rest,</line>
      <line>And sport no more seen,</line>
      <line>On the darkening green.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>Laughing Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the green woods laugh with the voice of joy</line>
      <line>And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,</line>
      <line>When the air does laugh with our merry wit</line>
      <line>And the green hill laughs with the noise of it,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> When the meadows laugh with lively green</line>
      <line>And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,</line>
      <line>When Mary and Susan and Emily</line>
      <line>With their sweet round mouths sing ‘ha, ha, he!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the painted birds laugh in the shade</line>
      <line>Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread,</line>
      <line>Come live and be merry and join with me,</line>
      <line>To sing the sweet chorus of ‘ha, ha, he!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>Nurse’s Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the voices of children are heard on the green</line>
      <line>And laughing is heard on the hill,</line>
      <line>My heart is at rest within my breast</line>
      <line>And everything else is still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Then come home my children, the sun is gone down</line>
      <line>And the dews of night arise;</line>
      <line>Come, come, leave off play, and let us away</line>
      <line>Till the morning appears in the skies!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘No, no, let us play, for it is yet day,</line>
      <line>And we cannot go to sleep;</line>
      <line>Besides, in the sky the little birds fly,</line>
      <line>And the hills are all covered with sheep!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Well, well, go and play, till the light fades away,</line>
      <line>And then go home to bed.’</line>
      <line> The little ones leaped and shouted and laughed,</line>
      <line>And all the hills echoéd.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>Holy Thursday</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas on a Holy Thursday – their innocent faces clean –</line>
      <line>The children walking two and two in red and blue and green;</line>
      <line>Grey-headed beadles walked before with wands as white as snow</line>
      <line>Till into the high dome of Paul’s they like Thames waters flow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh what a multitude they seemed, these flowers of London town!</line>
      <line>Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own!</line>
      <line>The hum of multitudes was there, but multitudes of lambs –</line>
      <line>Thousands of little boys and girls raising their innocent hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, like a mighty wind they raise to Heaven the voice of song,</line>
      <line>Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of Heaven among.</line>
      <line>Beneath them sit the agéd men, wise guardians of the poor –</line>
      <line>Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>The Lamb</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Little lamb who made thee?</line>
      <line>Dost thou know who made thee,</line>
      <line>Gave thee life and bid thee feed</line>
      <line>By the stream and o’er the mead,</line>
      <line> Gave thee clothing of delight,</line>
      <line>Softest clothing woolly bright,</line>
      <line>Gave thee such a tender voice,</line>
      <line>Making all the vales rejoice!</line>
      <line>Little lamb who made thee,</line>
      <line>Dost thou know who made thee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Little lamb I’ll tell thee,</line>
      <line>Little lamb I’ll tell thee!</line>
      <line>He is calléd by thy name,</line>
      <line>For He calls himself a lamb;</line>
      <line> He is meek and He is mild,</line>
      <line>He became a little child.</line>
      <line>I a child and thou a lamb,</line>
      <line>We are calléd by his name –</line>
      <line>Little lamb God bless thee,</line>
      <line>Little lamb God bless thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>The Chimney Sweeper</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When my mother died I was very young,</line>
      <line>And my father sold me while yet my tongue</line>
      <line>Could scarcely cry ‘weep, weep, weep, weep!’</line>
      <line>So your chimneys I sweep and in soot I sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> There’s little Tom Dacre, who cried when his head</line>
      <line>That curled like a lamb’s back was shaved, so I said,</line>
      <line>‘Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head’s bare,</line>
      <line>You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so he was quiet, and that very night</line>
      <line>As Tom was a-sleeping he had such a sight,</line>
      <line>That thousands of sweepers Dick, Joe, Ned, and Jack,</line>
      <line>Were all of them locked up in coffins of black,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And by came an angel who had a bright key,</line>
      <line>And he opened the coffins and set them all free.</line>
      <line> Then down a green plain leaping, laughing they run</line>
      <line>And wash in a river and shine in the sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then naked and white, all their bags left behind,</line>
      <line>They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.</line>
      <line>And the angel told Tom if he’d be a good boy,</line>
      <line>He’d have God for his father and never want joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark</line>
      <line>And got with our bags and our brushes to work.</line>
      <line>Though the morning was cold, Tom was happy and warm –</line>
      <line>So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>The Divine Image</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>To Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,</line>
      <line>All pray in their distress,</line>
      <line>And to these virtues of delight</line>
      <line>Return their thankfulness.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,</line>
      <line>Is God our father dear,</line>
      <line>And Mercy, Pity, Peace, and Love,</line>
      <line>Is man, his child and care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For Mercy has a human heart,</line>
      <line>Pity, a human face,</line>
      <line>And Love, the human form divine,</line>
      <line>And Peace, the human dress.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then every man of every clime</line>
      <line>That prays in his distress,</line>
      <line> Prays to the human form divine</line>
      <line>Love, Mercy, Pity, Peace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all must love the human form,</line>
      <line>In heathen, Turk or Jew:</line>
      <line>Where Mercy, Love, and Pity dwell</line>
      <line>There God is dwelling too.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SUSANNA BLAMIRE</author>
    <date>1790</date>
    <title>The Siller Croun</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And ye shall walk in silk attire,</line>
      <line>And siller hae to spare,</line>
      <line>Gin ye’ll consent to be his bride,</line>
      <line>Nor think o’ Donald mair.’</line>
      <line> ‘O wha wad buy a silken goun</line>
      <line>Wi’ a poor broken heart!</line>
      <line>Or what’s to me a siller croun,</line>
      <line>Gin frae my love I part!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mind wha’s every wish is pure</line>
      <line>Far dearer is to me;</line>
      <line>And ere I’m forced to break my faith</line>
      <line>I’ll lay me doun an’ dee!</line>
      <line>For I hae pledged my virgin troth</line>
      <line>Brave Donald’s fate to share;</line>
      <line> And he has gi’en to me his heart,</line>
      <line>Wi’ a’ its virtues rare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His gentle manners wan my heart,</line>
      <line>He gratefu’ took the gift;</line>
      <line>Could I but think to seek it back</line>
      <line>It wad be waur than theft!</line>
      <line>For langest life can ne’er repay</line>
      <line>The love he bears to me;</line>
      <line>And ere I’m forced to break my troth</line>
      <line>I’ll lay me doun an’ dee.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SUSANNA BLAMIRE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Oh Bid Me Not to Wander</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh urge me not to wander,</line>
      <line>And quit my pleasant native shore;</line>
      <line>Oh let me still meander</line>
      <line>On those sweet banks I loved before!</line>
      <line> The heart when filled with sorrow</line>
      <line>Can find no joy in change of scene,</line>
      <line>Nor can that cheat, tomorrow,</line>
      <line>Be aught but what today has been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If pleasure e’er o’ertakes me,</line>
      <line>’Tis when I tread the wonted round</line>
      <line>Where former joy awakes me,</line>
      <line>And strews its relics o’er the ground.</line>
      <line>There’s not a shrub or flower</line>
      <line>But tells some dear loved tale to me,</line>
      <line> And paints some happy hour</line>
      <line>Which I, alas, no more shall see.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Introduction</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hear the voice of the bard</line>
      <line>Who present, past, and future sees,</line>
      <line>Whose ears have heard</line>
      <line>The Holy Word</line>
      <line> That walked among the ancient trees</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Calling the lapséd soul,</line>
      <line>And weeping in the evening dew –</line>
      <line>That might control</line>
      <line>The starry pole,</line>
      <line>And fallen, fallen, light renew!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Earth, oh Earth return,</line>
      <line>Arise from out the dewy grass!</line>
      <line>Night is worn,</line>
      <line>And the morn</line>
      <line> Rises from the slumberous mass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Turn away no more –</line>
      <line>Why wilt thou turn away?</line>
      <line>The starry floor,</line>
      <line>The watery shore,</line>
      <line>Is given thee till the break of day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Earth’s Answer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Earth raised up her head</line>
      <line>From the darkness dread and drear:</line>
      <line>Her light fled,</line>
      <line>Stony dread!</line>
      <line> And her locks covered with grey despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Prisoned on watery shore,</line>
      <line>Starry Jealousy does keep my den;</line>
      <line>Cold and hoar,</line>
      <line>Weeping o’er,</line>
      <line>I hear the father of the ancient men,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Selfish father of men –</line>
      <line>Cruel, jealous, selfish fear!</line>
      <line>Can delight</line>
      <line>Chained in night</line>
      <line> The virgins of youth and morning bear?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Does spring hide its joy</line>
      <line>When buds and blossoms grow?</line>
      <line>Does the sower</line>
      <line>Sow by night,</line>
      <line>Or the ploughman in darkness plough?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Break this heavy chain</line>
      <line>That does freeze my bones around –</line>
      <line>Selfish, vain,</line>
      <line>Eternal bane,</line>
      <line> That free Love with bondage bound!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>My Pretty Rose Tree</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A flower was offered to me –</line>
      <line>Such a flower as May never bore –</line>
      <line>But I said, ‘I’ve a pretty rose-tree’,</line>
      <line>And I passed the sweet flower o’er.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then I went to my pretty rose-tree,</line>
      <line>To tend her by day and by night;</line>
      <line>But my rose turned away with jealousy</line>
      <line>And her thorns were my only delight!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Clod and the Pebble</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Love seeketh not itself to please,</line>
      <line>Nor for itself hath any care,</line>
      <line>But for another gives its ease,</line>
      <line>And builds a Heaven in Hell’s despair.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> So sang a little clod of clay,</line>
      <line>Trodden with the cattle’s feet,</line>
      <line>But a pebble of the brook</line>
      <line>Warbled out these metres meet:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Love seeketh only self to please,</line>
      <line>To bind another to its delight –</line>
      <line>Joys in another’s loss of ease,</line>
      <line>And builds a Hell in Heaven’s despite.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Garden of Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I went to the Garden of Love,</line>
      <line>And saw what I never had seen:</line>
      <line>A chapel was built in the midst</line>
      <line>Where I used to play on the green.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And the gates of this chapel were shut,</line>
      <line>And ‘Thou shalt not’ writ over the door;</line>
      <line>So I turned to the Garden of Love</line>
      <line>That so many sweet flowers bore,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I saw it was filled with graves,</line>
      <line>And tomb-stones where flowers should be,</line>
      <line>And priests in black gowns, were walking their rounds,</line>
      <line>And binding with briars my joys and desires.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>A Poison Tree</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I was angry with my friend –</line>
      <line>I told my wrath, my wrath did end.</line>
      <line>I was angry with my foe –</line>
      <line>I told it not, my wrath did grow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And I watered it in fears,</line>
      <line>Night and morning with my tears;</line>
      <line>And I sunnéd it with smiles,</line>
      <line>And with soft deceitful wiles.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And it grew both day and night</line>
      <line>Till it bore an apple bright,</line>
      <line>And my foe beheld it shine,</line>
      <line>And he knew that it was mine,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And into my garden stole,</line>
      <line>When the night had veiled the pole;</line>
      <line> In the morning glad I see</line>
      <line>My foe outstretched beneath the tree.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Infant Sorrow</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My mother groaned, my father wept,</line>
      <line>Into the dangerous world I leapt –</line>
      <line>Helpless, naked, piping loud,</line>
      <line>Like a fiend hid in a cloud!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Struggling in my father’s hands,</line>
      <line>Striving against my swadling bands,</line>
      <line>Bound and weary I thought best</line>
      <line>To sulk upon my mother’s breast.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>London</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wander through each chartered street,</line>
      <line>Near where the chartered Thames does flow,</line>
      <line>And mark in every face I meet</line>
      <line>Marks of weakness, marks of woe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> In every cry of every man,</line>
      <line>In every infant’s cry of fear,</line>
      <line>In every voice, in every ban,</line>
      <line>The mind-forged manacles I hear:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How the chimney-sweeper’s cry</line>
      <line>Every blackening church appals,</line>
      <line>And the hapless soldier’s sigh</line>
      <line>Runs in blood down palace walls;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But most through midnight streets I hear</line>
      <line>How the youthful harlot’s curse</line>
      <line> Blasts the new-born infant’s tear</line>
      <line>And blights with plagues the marriage-hearse.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Nurse’s Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the voices of children are heard on the green</line>
      <line>And whisperings are in the dale</line>
      <line>The days of my youth rise fresh in my mind,</line>
      <line>My face turns green and pale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Then come home my children, the sun is gone down</line>
      <line>And the dews of night arise.</line>
      <line>Your spring and your day are wasted in play</line>
      <line>And your winter and night in disguise.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Tyger</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tyger, tyger, burning bright</line>
      <line>In the forests of the night,</line>
      <line>What immortal hand or eye</line>
      <line>Could frame thy fearful symmetry?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> In what distant deeps or skies</line>
      <line>Burnt the fire of thine eyes?</line>
      <line>On what wings dare he aspire?</line>
      <line>What the hand dare seize the fire?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And what shoulder, and what art,</line>
      <line>Could twist the sinews of thy heart?</line>
      <line>And when thy heart began to beat,</line>
      <line>What dread hand? And what dread feet?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What the hammer? What the chain?</line>
      <line>In what furnace was thy brain?</line>
      <line> What the anvil? What dread grasp</line>
      <line>Dare its deadly terrors clasp?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the stars threw down their spears,</line>
      <line>And watered heaven with their tears,</line>
      <line>Did he smile his work to see?</line>
      <line>Did he who made the lamb make thee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tyger, tyger burning bright</line>
      <line>In the forests of the night,</line>
      <line>What immortal hand or eye</line>
      <line>Dare frame thy fearful symmetry?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Human Abstract</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pity would be no more</line>
      <line>If we did not make somebody poor;</line>
      <line>And mercy no more could be,</line>
      <line>If all were as happy as we;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And mutual fear brings peace</line>
      <line>Till the selfish loves increase,</line>
      <line>Then Cruelty knits a snare</line>
      <line>And spreads his baits with care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sits down with holy fears</line>
      <line>And waters the ground with tears,</line>
      <line>Then Humility takes its root</line>
      <line>Underneath his foot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Soon spreads the dismal shade</line>
      <line>Of mystery over his head;</line>
      <line> And the caterpillar and fly</line>
      <line>Feed on the mystery,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And it bears the fruit of deceit,</line>
      <line>Ruddy and sweet to eat;</line>
      <line>And the raven his nest has made</line>
      <line>In its thickest shade.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The gods of the earth and sea</line>
      <line>Sought through nature to find this tree,</line>
      <line>But their search was all in vain –</line>
      <line>There grows one in the human brain!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Sick Rose</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh rose thou art sick!</line>
      <line>The invisible worm</line>
      <line>That flies in the night</line>
      <line>In the howling storm</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Has found out thy bed</line>
      <line>Of crimson joy</line>
      <line>And his dark secret love</line>
      <line>Does thy life destroy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Chimney Sweeper</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little black thing among the snow</line>
      <line>Crying ‘weep, weep’, in notes of woe!</line>
      <line>‘Where are thy father and mother, say?’</line>
      <line>‘They are both gone up to the church to pray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Because I was happy upon the heath</line>
      <line>And smiled among the winter’s snow,</line>
      <line>They clothed me in the clothes of death</line>
      <line>And taught me to sing the notes of woe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And because I am happy, and dance, and sing,</line>
      <line>They think they have done me no injury,</line>
      <line>And are gone to praise God and his priest and king,</line>
      <line>Who make up a Heaven of our misery!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Holy Thursday</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is this a holy thing to see,</line>
      <line>In a rich and fruitful land,</line>
      <line>Babes reduced to misery,</line>
      <line>Fed with cold and usurous hand?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Is that trembling cry a song?</line>
      <line>Can it be a song of joy?</line>
      <line>And so many children poor?</line>
      <line>It is a land of poverty!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And their sun does never shine.</line>
      <line>And their fields are bleak and bare.</line>
      <line>And their ways are filled with thorns.</line>
      <line>It is eternal winter there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For where’er the sun does shine,</line>
      <line>And where’er the rain does fall,</line>
      <line> Babe can never hunger there,</line>
      <line>Nor poverty the mind appal.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>The Fly</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Little fly,</line>
      <line>Thy summer’s play</line>
      <line>My thoughtless hand</line>
      <line>Has brushed away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Am not I</line>
      <line>A fly like thee?</line>
      <line>Or art not thou</line>
      <line>A man like me?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For I dance</line>
      <line>And drink and sing;</line>
      <line>Till some blind hand</line>
      <line>Shall brush my wing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If thought is life</line>
      <line>And strength and breath;</line>
      <line> And the want</line>
      <line>Of thought is death;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then am I</line>
      <line>A happy fly,</line>
      <line>If I live,</line>
      <line>Or if I die!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Ah! Sun-Flower</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! sun-flower, weary of time,</line>
      <line>Who countest the steps of the sun,</line>
      <line>Seeking after that sweet golden clime</line>
      <line>Where the traveller’s journey is done,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Where the youth pined away with desire,</line>
      <line>And the pale virgin shrouded in snow,</line>
      <line>Arise from their graves and aspire,</line>
      <line>Where my sun-flower wishes to go.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANN BATTEN CRISTAL</author>
    <date>1795</date>
    <title>Through Springtime Walks</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Through springtime walks, with flowers perfumed,</line>
      <line>I chased a wild capricious fair,</line>
      <line>Where hyacinths and jonquils bloomed,</line>
      <line>Chanting gay sonnets through the air;</line>
      <line>Hid amid a briary dell</line>
      <line> Or ’neath a hawthorn-tree,</line>
      <line>Her sweet enchantments led me on</line>
      <line>And still deluded me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While summer’s ’splendent glory smiles</line>
      <line>My ardent love in vain essayed,</line>
      <line>I strove to win her heart by wiles,</line>
      <line>But still a thousand pranks she played;</line>
      <line>Still o’er each sunburnt furzy hill,</line>
      <line>Wild, playful, gay, and free,</line>
      <line> She laughed and scorned; I chased her still,</line>
      <line>And still she bantered me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When autumn waves her golden ears</line>
      <line>And wafts o’er fruits her pregnant breath,</line>
      <line>The sprightly lark its pinions rears;</line>
      <line>I chased her o’er the daisied heath,</line>
      <line>And all around was glee –</line>
      <line>Still, wanton as the timid hart,</line>
      <line>She swiftly flew from me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now winter lights its cheerful fire,</line>
      <line> While jests with frolic mirth resound</line>
      <line>And draws the wandering beauty nigher,</line>
      <line>’Tis now too cold to rove around;</line>
      <line>The Christmas-game, the playful dance,</line>
      <line>Incline her heart to glee –</line>
      <line>Mutual we glow, and kindling love</line>
      <line>Draws every wish to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>A Thousand Torments</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A thousand torments wait on love –</line>
      <line>The sigh, the tear, the anguished groan –</line>
      <line>But he who never learnt to prove</line>
      <line>A jealous pang has nothing known!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For jealousy, supreme of woe,</line>
      <line>Nursed by distorted fancy’s power,</line>
      <line>Can round the heart bid misery grow,</line>
      <line>Which darkens with the lingering hour,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While shadows, blanks to reason’s orb,</line>
      <line>In dread succession haunt the brain,</line>
      <line>And pangs, that every pang absorb,</line>
      <line>In wild, convulsive tumults reign.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At morn, at eve, the fever burns,</line>
      <line>While phantoms tear the aching breast;</line>
      <line> Day brings no calm, and night returns</line>
      <line>To mark no soothing hour of rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor, when the bosom’s wasted fires</line>
      <line>Are all extinct, is anguish o’er;</line>
      <line>For jealousy, that ne’er expires,</line>
      <line>Still wounds, when passion lives no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS CAMPBELL</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Written on Visiting a Scene in Argyleshire</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>At the silence of twilight’s contemplative hour</line>
      <line>I have mused in a sorrowful mood</line>
      <line>On the wind-shaken reeds that embosom the bower</line>
      <line>Where the home of my forefathers stood.</line>
      <line> All ruined and wild is their roofless abode,</line>
      <line>And lonely the dark raven’s sheltering tree –</line>
      <line>And travelled by few is the grass-covered road</line>
      <line>Where the hunter of deer and the warrior trod</line>
      <line>To his hills that encircle the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet, wandering, I found on my ruinous walk,</line>
      <line>By the dial-stone agéd and green,</line>
      <line>One rose of the wilderness left on its stalk</line>
      <line>To mark where a garden had been.</line>
      <line>Like a brotherless hermit, the last of his race,</line>
      <line> All wild in the silence of Nature it drew</line>
      <line>From each wandering sunbeam a lonely embrace –</line>
      <line>For the night-weed and thorn overshadowed the place</line>
      <line>Where the flower of my forefathers grew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet bud of the wilderness, emblem of all</line>
      <line>That remains in this desolate heart!</line>
      <line>The fabric of bliss to its centre may fall,</line>
      <line>But patience shall never depart</line>
      <line>Though the wilds of enchantment, all vernal and bright</line>
      <line>In the days of delusion, by fancy combined</line>
      <line> With the vanishing phantoms of love and delight,</line>
      <line>Abandon my soul like a dream of the night</line>
      <line>And leave but a desert behind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be hushed, my dark spirit, for wisdom condemns</line>
      <line>When the faint and the feeble deplore –</line>
      <line>Be strong as the rock of the ocean, that stems</line>
      <line>A thousand wild waves on the shore!</line>
      <line>Through the perils of chance and the scowl of disdain</line>
      <line>May thy front be unaltered, thy courage elate!</line>
      <line>Yea, even the name I have worshipped in vain</line>
      <line> Shall awake not the sigh of remembrance again:</line>
      <line>To bear is to conquer our fate.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Lines Written in Early Spring</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I heard a thousand blended notes</line>
      <line>While in a grove I sat reclined,</line>
      <line>In that sweet mood when pleasant thoughts</line>
      <line>Bring sad thoughts to the mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> To her fair works did Nature link</line>
      <line>The human soul that through me ran,</line>
      <line>And much it grieved my heart to think</line>
      <line>What man has made of man.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Through primrose-tufts, in that sweet bower,</line>
      <line>The periwinkle trailed its wreathes;</line>
      <line>And ’tis my faith that every flower</line>
      <line>Enjoys the air it breathes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The birds around me hopped and played,</line>
      <line>Their thoughts I cannot measure,</line>
      <line> But the least motion which they made,</line>
      <line>It seemed a thrill of pleasure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The budding twigs spread out their fan,</line>
      <line>To catch the breezy air;</line>
      <line>And I must think – do all I can –</line>
      <line>That there was pleasure there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If I these thoughts may not prevent,</line>
      <line>If such be of my creed the plan,</line>
      <line>Have I not reason to lament</line>
      <line>What man has made of man?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>Two April Mornings</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We walked along while bright and red</line>
      <line>Uprose the morning sun,</line>
      <line>And Matthew stopped – he looked, and said</line>
      <line>‘The will of God be done!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A village schoolmaster was he</line>
      <line>With hair of glittering grey,</line>
      <line>As blithe a man as you could see</line>
      <line>On a spring holiday.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And on that morning, through the grass</line>
      <line>And by the steaming rills,</line>
      <line>We travelled merrily to pass</line>
      <line>A day among the hills.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Our work’, said I, ‘was well begun –</line>
      <line>Then, from thy breast what thought,</line>
      <line> Beneath so beautiful a sun,</line>
      <line>So sad a sigh has brought?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A second time did Matthew stop</line>
      <line>And, fixing still his eye</line>
      <line>Upon the eastern mountain-top,</line>
      <line>To me he made reply:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Yon cloud with that long purple cleft</line>
      <line>Brings fresh into my mind</line>
      <line>A day like this which I have left</line>
      <line>Full thirty years behind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And on that slope of springing corn</line>
