      <line>The self-same crimson hue</line>
      <line>Fell from the sky that April morn –</line>
      <line>The same which now I view.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With rod and line my silent sport</line>
      <line>I plied by Derwent’s wave,</line>
      <line>And, coming to the church, stopped short</line>
      <line>Beside my daughter’s grave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nine summers had she scarcely seen,</line>
      <line>The pride of all the vale!</line>
      <line> And then she sang – she would have been</line>
      <line>A very nightingale!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Six feet in earth my Emma lay,</line>
      <line>And yet I loved her more</line>
      <line>(For so it seemed) than till that day</line>
      <line>I e’er had loved before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, turning from her grave, I met</line>
      <line>Beside the churchyard-yew</line>
      <line>A blooming girl, whose hair was wet</line>
      <line>With points of morning dew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A basket on her head she bare,</line>
      <line>Her brow was smooth and white;</line>
      <line>To see a child so very fair,</line>
      <line>It was a pure delight!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No fountain from its rocky cave</line>
      <line>E’er tripped with foot so free;</line>
      <line>She seemed as happy as a wave</line>
      <line>That dances on the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There came from me a sigh of pain</line>
      <line>Which I could ill confine;</line>
      <line> I looked at her, and looked again –</line>
      <line>And did not wish her mine.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Matthew is in his grave, yet now</line>
      <line>Methinks I see him stand,</line>
      <line>As at that moment, with his bough</line>
      <line>Of wilding in his hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>The Fountain</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We talked with open heart, and tongue</line>
      <line>Affectionate and true –</line>
      <line>A pair of friends, though I was young,</line>
      <line>And Matthew seventy-two.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> We lay beneath a spreading oak,</line>
      <line>Beside a mossy seat,</line>
      <line>And from the turf a fountain broke</line>
      <line>And gurgled at our feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Now, Matthew, let us try to match</line>
      <line>This water’s pleasant tune</line>
      <line>With some old Border song or catch</line>
      <line>That suits a summer’s noon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or of the church-clock and the chimes</line>
      <line>Sing here beneath the shade</line>
      <line> That half-mad thing of witty rhymes</line>
      <line>Which you last April made!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In silence Matthew lay, and eyed</line>
      <line>The spring beneath the tree;</line>
      <line>And thus the dear old man replied,</line>
      <line>The grey-haired man of glee:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Down to the vale this water steers –</line>
      <line>How merrily it goes! –</line>
      <line>’Twill murmur on a thousand years,</line>
      <line>And flow as now it flows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And here, on this delightful day,</line>
      <line>I cannot choose but think</line>
      <line>How oft, a vigorous man, I lay</line>
      <line>Beside this fountain’s brink.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My eyes are dim with childish tears,</line>
      <line>My heart is idly stirred,</line>
      <line>For the same sound is in my ears</line>
      <line>Which in those days I heard.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus fares it still in our decay;</line>
      <line>And yet the wiser mind</line>
      <line> Mourns less for what age takes away</line>
      <line>Than what it leaves behind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The blackbird in the summer trees,</line>
      <line>The lark upon the hill,</line>
      <line>Let loose their carols when they please,</line>
      <line>Are quiet when they will.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With Nature never do they wage</line>
      <line>A foolish strife; they see</line>
      <line>A happy youth, and their old age</line>
      <line>Is beautiful and free.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But we are pressed by heavy laws,</line>
      <line>And often – glad no more –</line>
      <line>We wear a face of joy, because</line>
      <line>We have been glad of yore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If there is one who need bemoan</line>
      <line>His kindred laid in earth,</line>
      <line>The household-hearts that were his own,</line>
      <line>It is the man of mirth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My days, my friend, are almost gone,</line>
      <line>My life has been approved,</line>
      <line> And many love me, but by none</line>
      <line>Am I enough beloved.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Now both himself and me he wrongs,</line>
      <line>The man who thus complains!</line>
      <line>I live and sing my idle songs</line>
      <line>Upon these happy plains –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, Matthew, for thy children dead</line>
      <line>I’ll be a son to thee!’</line>
      <line>At this he grasped his hands, and said</line>
      <line>‘Alas, that cannot be!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> We rose up from the fountain-side,</line>
      <line>And down the smooth descent</line>
      <line>Of the green sheep-track did we glide,</line>
      <line>And through the wood we went,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, ere we came to Leonard’s Rock,</line>
      <line>He sang those witty rhymes</line>
      <line>About the crazy old church-clock</line>
      <line>And the bewildered chimes.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>To the Cuckoo</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh blithe new-comer, I have heard,</line>
      <line>I hear, thee and rejoice –</line>
      <line>Oh cuckoo, shall I call thee bird,</line>
      <line>Or but a wandering voice?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> While I am lying on the grass</line>
      <line>I hear thy restless shout;</line>
      <line>From hill to hill it seems to pass</line>
      <line>About and all about.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To me, no babbler with a tale</line>
      <line>Of sunshine and of showers,</line>
      <line>Thou tellest – cuckoo in the vale –</line>
      <line>Of visionary hours.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thrice welcome darling of the spring!</line>
      <line>Even yet thou art to me</line>
      <line> No bird, but an invisible thing,</line>
      <line>A voice, a mystery,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The same whom in my schoolboy days,</line>
      <line>I listened to – that cry</line>
      <line>Which made me look a thousand ways</line>
      <line>In bush, and tree, and sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To seek thee did I often rove</line>
      <line>Through woods and on the green,</line>
      <line>And thou wert still a hope, a love –</line>
      <line>Still longed for, never seen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And I can listen to thee yet,</line>
      <line>Can lie upon the plain,</line>
      <line>And listen till I do beget</line>
      <line>That golden time again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh blesséd bird, the earth we pace</line>
      <line>Again appears to be</line>
      <line>An unsubstantial fairy place</line>
      <line>That is fit home for thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Rainbow</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My heart leaps up when I behold</line>
      <line>A rainbow in the sky:</line>
      <line>So was it when my life began,</line>
      <line>So is it now I am a man,</line>
      <line> So be it when I shall grow old,</line>
      <line>Or let me die!</line>
      <line>The child is father of the man;</line>
      <line>And I could wish my days to be</line>
      <line>Bound each to each by natural piety.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>To H. C., Six Years Old</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh thou whose fancies from afar are brought,</line>
      <line>Who of thy words dost make a mock apparel,</line>
      <line>And fittest to unutterable thought</line>
      <line>The breeze-like motion and the self-born carol;</line>
      <line> Thou fairy voyager, that dost float</line>
      <line>In such clear water, that thy boat</line>
      <line>May rather seem</line>
      <line>To brood on air that on an earthly stream –</line>
      <line>Suspended in a stream as clear as sky,</line>
      <line>Where earth and heaven do make one imagery.</line>
      <line>Oh blesséd vision, happy child,</line>
      <line>That art so exquisitely wild,</line>
      <line>I think of thee with many fears</line>
      <line>For what may be thy lot in future years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I thought of times when Pain might be thy guest,</line>
      <line>Lord of thy house and hospitality;</line>
      <line>And Grief – uneasy Lover – never rest</line>
      <line>But when she sat within the touch of thee.</line>
      <line>Oh too industrious folly!</line>
      <line>Oh vain and causeless melancholy!</line>
      <line>Nature will either end thee quite,</line>
      <line>Or, lengthening out thy season of delight</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Preserve for thee, by individual right,</line>
      <line>A young lamb’s heart among the full-grown flocks.</line>
      <line> What hast thou to do with sorrow,</line>
      <line>Or the injuries of tomorrow?</line>
      <line>Thou art a dew-drop which the morn brings forth,</line>
      <line>Not doomed to jostle with unkindly shocks</line>
      <line>Or to be trailed along the soiling earth –</line>
      <line>A gem that glitters while it lives,</line>
      <line>And no forewarning gives,</line>
      <line>But, at the touch of wrong, without a strife,</line>
      <line>Slips in a moment out of life.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Cock Is Crowing</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cock is crowing,</line>
      <line>The stream is flowing,</line>
      <line>The small birds twitter,</line>
      <line>The lake doth glitter,</line>
      <line> The green field sleeps in the sun;</line>
      <line>The oldest and youngest</line>
      <line>Are at work with the strongest;</line>
      <line>The cattle are grazing,</line>
      <line>Their heads never raising –</line>
      <line>There are forty feeding like one!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like an army defeated</line>
      <line>The snow hath retreated</line>
      <line>And now doth fare ill</line>
      <line>On the top of the bare hill;</line>
      <line> The ploughboy is whooping, anon, anon –</line>
      <line>There’s joy in the mountains,</line>
      <line>There’s life in the fountains,</line>
      <line>Small clouds are sailing,</line>
      <line>Blue sky prevailing,</line>
      <line>The rain is over and gone!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>To a Butterfly</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve watched you now a full half-hour</line>
      <line>Self-poised upon that yellow flower,</line>
      <line>And little butterfly indeed</line>
      <line>I know not if you sleep or feed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> How motionless! Not frozen seas</line>
      <line>More motionless – and then,</line>
      <line>What joy awaits you, when the breeze</line>
      <line>Hath found you out among the trees</line>
      <line>And calls you forth again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This plot of orchard ground is ours</line>
      <line>(My trees they are, my sister’s flowers),</line>
      <line>Stop here whenever you are weary</line>
      <line>And rest as in a sanctuary.</line>
      <line>Come often to us – fear no wrong –</line>
      <line> Sit near us on the bough!</line>
      <line>We’ll talk of sunshine and of song,</line>
      <line>And summer days when we were young –</line>
      <line>Sweet childish days that were as long</line>
      <line>As twenty days are now.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>I Have Thoughts that Are Fed by the Sun</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have thoughts that are fed by the sun:</line>
      <line>The things which I see</line>
      <line>Are welcome to me,</line>
      <line>Welcome every one –</line>
      <line> I do not wish to lie</line>
      <line>Dead, dead,</line>
      <line>Dead, without any company.</line>
      <line>Here alone on my bed</line>
      <line>With thoughts that are fed by the sun,</line>
      <line>And hopes that are welcome every one,</line>
      <line>Happy am I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh life there is about thee</line>
      <line>A deep delicious peace;</line>
      <line>I would not be without thee,</line>
      <line> Stay, oh stay!</line>
      <line>Yet be thou ever as now –</line>
      <line>Sweetness and breath, with the quiet of death –</line>
      <line>Be but thou ever as now,</line>
      <line>Peace, peace, peace.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Sun Has Long Been Set</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun has long been set:</line>
      <line>The stars are out by twos and threes;</line>
      <line>The little birds are piping yet</line>
      <line>Among the bushes and trees;</line>
      <line> There’s a cuckoo, and one or two thrushes,</line>
      <line>And a noise of wind that rushes,</line>
      <line>With a noise of water that gushes,</line>
      <line>And the cuckoo’s sovereign cry</line>
      <line>Fills all the hollow of the sky!</line>
      <line>Who would go ‘parading’</line>
      <line>In London, and ‘masquerading’,</line>
      <line>On such a night of June,</line>
      <line>With that beautiful soft half-moon</line>
      <line>And all those innocent blisses –</line>
      <line> On such a night as this is?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>Daffodils</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wandered lonely as a cloud</line>
      <line>That floats on high o’er vales and hills,</line>
      <line>When all at once I saw a crowd,</line>
      <line>A host, of golden daffodils;</line>
      <line> Beside the lake, beneath the trees,</line>
      <line>Fluttering and dancing in the breeze.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Continuous as the stars that shine</line>
      <line>And twinkle on the Milky Way,</line>
      <line>They stretched in never-ending line</line>
      <line>Along the margin of a bay:</line>
      <line>Ten thousand saw I at a glance,</line>
      <line>Tossing their heads in sprightly dance.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The waves beside them danced; but they</line>
      <line>Out-did the sparkling waves in glee:</line>
      <line> A poet could not but be gay,</line>
      <line>In such a jocund company:</line>
      <line>I gazed, and gazed, but little thought</line>
      <line>What wealth the show to me had brought –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For oft, when on my couch I lie</line>
      <line>In vacant or in pensive mood,</line>
      <line>They flash upon that inward eye</line>
      <line>Which is the bliss of solitude;</line>
      <line>And then my heart with pleasure fills,</line>
      <line>And dances with the daffodils.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>Stepping Westward</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What, you are stepping westward?’ ‘Yea.’</line>
      <line>’Twould be a wildish destiny</line>
      <line>If we, who thus together roam</line>
      <line>In a strange land, and far from home,</line>
      <line> Were in this place the guests of Chance.</line>
      <line>Yet who would stop, or fear to advance,</line>
      <line>Though home or shelter he had none,</line>
      <line>With such a sky to lead him on?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dewy ground was dark and cold –</line>
      <line>Behind, all gloomy to behold –</line>
      <line>And stepping westward seemed to be</line>
      <line>A kind of heavenly destiny.</line>
      <line>I liked the greeting! ’Twas a sound</line>
      <line>Of something without place or bound,</line>
      <line> And seemed to give me spiritual right</line>
      <line>To travel through that region bright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The voice was soft, and she who spake</line>
      <line>Was walking by her native lake;</line>
      <line>The salutation had to me</line>
      <line>The very sound of courtesy.</line>
      <line>Its power was felt – and while my eye</line>
      <line>Was fixed upon the glowing sky,</line>
      <line>The echo of the voice inwrought</line>
      <line>A human sweetness with the thought</line>
      <line> Of travelling through the world that lay</line>
      <line>Before me in my endless way.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>The Solitary Reaper</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Behold her, single in the field,</line>
      <line>Yon solitary highland lass,</line>
      <line>Reaping and singing by herself –</line>
      <line>Stop here, or gently pass!</line>
      <line> Alone she cuts and binds the grain,</line>
      <line>And sings a melancholy strain:</line>
      <line>Oh listen, for the vale profound</line>
      <line>Is overflowing with the sound!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No nightingale did ever chant</line>
      <line>So sweetly to reposing bands</line>
      <line>Of travellers in some shady haunt</line>
      <line>Among Arabian sands;</line>
      <line>No sweeter voice was ever heard</line>
      <line>In springtime from the cuckoo-bird,</line>
      <line> Breaking the silence of the seas</line>
      <line>Among the farthest Hebrides.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will no one tell me what she sings?</line>
      <line>Perhaps the plaintive numbers flow</line>
      <line>For old, unhappy, far-off things,</line>
      <line>And battles long ago;</line>
      <line>Or is it some more humble lay,</line>
      <line>Familiar matter of today –</line>
      <line>Some natural sorrow, loss, or pain,</line>
      <line>That has been, and may be again?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Whate’er the theme, the maiden sang</line>
      <line>As if her song could have no ending;</line>
      <line>I saw her singing at her work</line>
      <line>And o’er the sickle bending;</line>
      <line>I listened till I had my fill,</line>
      <line>And as I mounted up the hill</line>
      <line>The music in my heart I bore</line>
      <line>Long after it was heard no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>Something Childish, but Very Natural</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>If I had but two little wings,</line>
      <line>And were a little feathery bird,</line>
      <line>To you I’d fly, my dear!</line>
      <line>But thoughts like these are idle things,</line>
      <line> And I stay here.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But in my sleep to you I fly –</line>
      <line>I’m always with you in my sleep –</line>
      <line>The world is all one’s own!</line>
      <line>But then one wakes, and where am I?</line>
      <line>All, all alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep stays not, though a monarch bids,</line>
      <line>So I love to wake ere break of day;</line>
      <line>For though my sleep be gone,</line>
      <line>Yet while ’tis dark one shuts one’s lids –</line>
      <line> And still dreams on.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Keepsake</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The tedded hay, the first fruits of the soil –</line>
      <line>The tedded hay and corn-sheaves in one field –</line>
      <line>Show summer gone, ere come. The foxglove tall</line>
      <line>Sheds its loose purple bells, or in the gust,</line>
      <line> Or when it bends beneath the up-springing lark</line>
      <line>Or mountain-finch alighting. And the rose</line>
      <line>(In vain the darling of successful love)</line>
      <line>Stands, like some boasted beauty of past years,</line>
      <line>The thorns remaining, and the flowers all gone.</line>
      <line>Nor can I find, amid my lonely walk</line>
      <line>By rivulet, or spring, or wet roadside,</line>
      <line>That blue and bright-eyed floweret of the brook,</line>
      <line>Hope’s gentle gem, the sweet forget-me-not!</line>
      <line>So will not fade the flowers which Emmeline</line>
      <line> With delicate fingers on the snow-white silk</line>
      <line>Has worked (the flowers which most she knew I loved),</line>
      <line>And, more beloved than they, her auburn hair.</line>
      <line>In the cool morning twilight, early waked</line>
      <line>By her full bosom’s joyous restlessness,</line>
      <line>Softly she rose, and lightly stole along</line>
      <line>Down the slope-coppice to the woodbine-bower,</line>
      <line>Whose rich flowers, swinging in the morning breeze,</line>
      <line>Over their dim fast-moving shadows hung,</line>
      <line>Making a quiet image of disquiet</line>
      <line> In the smooth, scarcely moving river-pool.</line>
      <line>There, in that bower where first she owned her love</line>
      <line>And let me kiss my own warm tear of joy</line>
      <line>From off her glowing cheek, she sat and stretched</line>
      <line>The silk upon the frame, and worked her name</line>
      <line>Between the moss-rose and forget-me-not –</line>
      <line>Her own dear name, with her own auburn hair! –</line>
      <line>That, forced to wander till sweet spring return,</line>
      <line>I yet might ne’er forget her smile, her look,</line>
      <line>Her voice (that even in her mirthful mood</line>
      <line> Has made me wish to steal away and weep),</line>
      <line>Nor yet the entrancement of that maiden-kiss</line>
      <line>With which she promised that, when spring returned,</line>
      <line>She would resign one half of that dear name,</line>
      <line>And own thenceforth no other name but mine!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Answer to a Child’s Question</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you ask what the birds say? The sparrow, the dove,</line>
      <line>The linnet and thrush, say, ‘I love and I love!’</line>
      <line>In the winter they’re silent, the wind is so strong –</line>
      <line>What it says, I don’t know, but it sings a loud song –</line>
      <line> But green leaves, and blossoms, and sunny warm weather,</line>
      <line>And singing, and loving, all come back together!</line>
      <line>But the lark is so brimful of gladness and love</line>
      <line>(The green fields below him, the blue sky above)</line>
      <line>That he sings, and he sings, and forever sings he:</line>
      <line>‘I love my love, and my love loves me!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS MOORE</author>
    <date>1801</date>
    <title>Away with this Pouting</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away with this pouting and sadness!</line>
      <line>Sweet girl, will you never give o’er?</line>
      <line>I love you, by Heaven, to madness –</line>
      <line>And what can I swear to you more?</line>
      <line> Believe not the old women’s fable</line>
      <line>That oaths are as short as a kiss,</line>
      <line>I’ll love you as long as I’m able,</line>
      <line>And swear for no longer than this.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then waste not the time with professions,</line>
      <line>For not to be blest when we can</line>
      <line>Is one of the darkest trangressions</line>
      <line>That happen ’twixt woman and man.</line>
      <line>Pretty moralist, why thus beginning</line>
      <line>My innocent warmth to reprove?</line>
      <line> Heaven knows that I never loved sinning,</line>
      <line>Except little sinnings of love!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If swearing, however, will do it,</line>
      <line>Come, bring me the calendar, pray –</line>
      <line>I vow, by that lip, I’ll go through it,</line>
      <line>And not miss a saint on my way!</line>
      <line>The angels shall help me to wheedle,</line>
      <line>I’ll swear upon every one</line>
      <line>That e’er danced on the point of a needle,</line>
      <line>Or rode on a beam of the sun!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh! why should Platonic control, love,</line>
      <line>Enchain an emotion so free?</line>
      <line>Your soul, though a very sweet soul, love,</line>
      <line>Will ne’er by sufficient for me.</line>
      <line>If you think by this coldness and scorning</line>
      <line>To seem more angelic and bright,</line>
      <line>Be an angel, my love, in the morning,</line>
      <line>But, oh, be a woman tonight!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>A Walk by the Water</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us walk where reeds are growing,</line>
      <line>By the alders in the mead;</line>
      <line>Where the crystal streams are flowing,</line>
      <line>In whose waves the fishes feed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> There the golden carp is laving,</line>
      <line>With the trout, the perch, and bream;</line>
      <line>Mark! their flexile fins are waving,</line>
      <line>As they glance along the stream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now they sink in deeper billows,</line>
      <line>Now upon the surface rise;</line>
      <line>Or from under roots of willows,</line>
      <line>Dart to catch the water-flies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Midst the reeds and pebbles hiding,</line>
      <line>See the minnow and the roach –</line>
      <line> Or by water-lilies gliding,</line>
      <line>Shun with fear our near approach.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do not dread us, timid fishes,</line>
      <line>We have neither net nor hook;</line>
      <line>Wanderers we, whose only wishes</line>
      <line>Are to read in Nature’s book.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY TIGHE</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>Address to My Harp</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, my loved harp! companion dear!</line>
      <line>Sweet soother of my secret grief,</line>
      <line>No more thy sounds my soul must cheer,</line>
      <line>No more afford a soft relief.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> When anxious cares my heart oppressed,</line>
      <line>When doubts distracting tore my soul,</line>
      <line>The pains which heaved my swelling breast</line>
      <line>Thy gentle sway could oft control.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each well remembered, practised strain,</line>
      <line>The cheerful dance, the tender song,</line>
      <line>Recalled with pensive, pleasing pain</line>
      <line>Some image loved and cherished long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where joy sat smiling o’er my fate,</line>
      <line>And marked each bright and happy day,</line>
      <line> When partial friends around me sat,</line>
      <line>And taught my lips the simple lay;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when by disappointment grieved</line>
      <line>I saw some darling hope o’erthrown,</line>
      <line>Thou hast my secret pain relieved;</line>
      <line>O’er thee I wept, unseen, alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh! must I leave thee, must we part,</line>
      <line>Dear partner of my happiest days?</line>
      <line>I may forget thy much-loved art,</line>
      <line>Unused thy melody to raise,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But ne’er can memory cease to love</line>
      <line>Those scenes where I thy charms have felt,</line>
      <line>Though I no more thy power may prove,</line>
      <line>Which taught my softened heart to melt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forced to forego with thee this spot,</line>
      <line>Endeared by many a tender tie,</line>
      <line>When rosy pleasure blessed my lot,</line>
      <line>And sparkled in my cheated eye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet still thy strings, in Fancy’s ear,</line>
      <line>With soothing melody shall play;</line>
      <line> Thy silver sounds I oft shall hear,</line>
      <line>To pensive gloom a silent prey.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>DOROTHY WORDSWORTH</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>A Cottage in Grasmere Vale</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Peaceful our valley, fair and green,</line>
      <line>And beautiful her cottages,</line>
      <line>Each in its nook, its sheltered hold,</line>
      <line>Or guarded by its tuft of trees.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Many and beautiful they are,</line>
      <line>But there is one that I love best,</line>
      <line>A lowly shed in truth it is,</line>
      <line>A brother of the rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet when I sit on rock or hill,</line>
      <line>Down-looking on the valley fair,</line>
      <line>That cottage with its clustering trees</line>
      <line>Summons my heart – it settles there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Others there are whose small domain</line>
      <line>Of fertile fields and hedgerows green</line>
      <line> Might more entice a wanderer’s mind</line>
      <line>To wish that there his home had been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such wish be his, I blame him not –</line>
      <line>My fancy is unfettered, wild –</line>
      <line>I love that house because it is</line>
      <line>The very mountains’ child!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fields hath it of its own, green fields,</line>
      <line>But they are craggy, steep and bare;</line>
      <line>Their fence is of the mountain-stone</line>
      <line>And moss and lichen flourish there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And when the storm comes from the north</line>
      <line>It lingers near that pastoral spot,</line>
      <line>And piping through the mossy walls,</line>
      <line>It seems delighted with its lot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And let it take its own delight,</line>
      <line>And let it range the pastures bare,</line>
      <line>Until it reach that group of trees –</line>
      <line>It may not enter there!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A green unfading grove it is,</line>
      <line>Skirted with many a lesser tree –</line>
      <line> Hazel and holly, beech and oak –</line>
      <line>A bright and flourishing company!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Precious the shelter of those trees,</line>
      <line>They screen the cottage that I love;</line>
      <line>The sunshine pierces to the roof</line>
      <line>And the tall pine-trees tower above.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JANE TAYLOR</author>
    <date>1806</date>
    <title>The Star</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Twinkle, twinkle, little star,</line>
      <line>How I wonder what you are!</line>
      <line>Up above the world so high,</line>
      <line>Like a diamond in the sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> When the blazing sun is gone,</line>
      <line>When he nothing shines upon,</line>
      <line>Then you show your little light,</line>
      <line>Twinkle, twinkle, all the night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the traveller in the dark,</line>
      <line>Thanks you for your tiny spark!</line>
      <line>He could not see which way to go,</line>
      <line>If you did not twinkle so.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the dark blue sky you keep,</line>
      <line>And often through my curtains peep,</line>
      <line> For you never shut your eye</line>
      <line>Till the sun is in the sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As your bright and tiny spark</line>
      <line>Lights the traveller in the dark,</line>
      <line>Though I know not what you are,</line>
      <line>Twinkle, twinkle, little star.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1810</date>
    <title>The Maid of Athens</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Maid of Athens, ere we part,</line>
      <line>Give, oh give me back, my heart!</line>
      <line>Or, since that has left my breast,</line>
      <line>Keep it now – and take the rest!</line>
      <line> Hear my vow, before I go:</line>
      <line>My life, I love you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By those tresses unconfined,</line>
      <line>Wooed by each Aegean wind;</line>
      <line>By those lids whose jetty fringe</line>
      <line>Kiss thy soft cheeks’ blooming tinge;</line>
      <line>By those wild eyes like the roe –</line>
      <line>My life, I love you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By that lip I long to taste;</line>
      <line>By that zone-encircled waist;</line>
      <line> By all the token-flowers that tell</line>
      <line>What words can never speak so well;</line>
      <line>By love’s alternate joy and woe –</line>
      <line>My life, I love you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Maid of Athens, I am gone!</line>
      <line>Think of me, sweet, when alone –</line>
      <line>Though I fly to Istamboul,</line>
      <line>Athens holds my heart and soul!</line>
      <line>Can I cease to love thee? No!</line>
      <line> My life, I love you.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1814</date>
    <title>She Walks in Beauty</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She walks in beauty, like the night</line>
      <line>Of cloudless climes and starry skies,</line>
      <line>And all that’s best of dark and bright</line>
      <line>Meet in her aspect and her eyes –</line>
      <line> Thus mellowed to that tender light</line>
      <line>Which Heaven to gaudy day denies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One shade the more, one ray the less,</line>
      <line>Had half impaired the nameless grace</line>
      <line>Which waves in every raven tress,</line>
      <line>Or softly lightens o’er her face,</line>
      <line>Where thoughts serenely sweet express</line>
      <line>How pure, how dear, their dwelling-place.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And on that cheek, and o’er that brow,</line>
      <line>So soft, so calm, yet eloquent,</line>
      <line> The smiles that win, the tints that glow,</line>
      <line>But tell of days in goodness spent,</line>
      <line>A mind at peace with all below,</line>
      <line>A heart whose love is innocent.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Stanzas for Music</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There be none of Beauty’s daughters</line>
      <line>With a magic like to thee,</line>
      <line>And like music on the waters</line>
      <line>Is thy sweet voice to me,</line>
      <line> When, as if its sound were causing</line>
      <line>The charméd ocean’s pausing,</line>
      <line>The waves lie still and gleaming,</line>
      <line>And the lulled winds seem dreaming,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the midnight-moon is weaving</line>
      <line>Her bright chain o’er the deep,</line>
      <line>Whose breast is gently heaving</line>
      <line>Like an infant’s asleep –</line>
      <line>So the spirit bows before thee</line>
      <line> To listen and adore thee,</line>
      <line>With a full but soft emotion</line>
      <line>Like the swell of summer’s ocean.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Stanzas for Music</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s not a joy the world can give like that it takes away</line>
      <line>When the glow of early thought declines in feeling’s dull decay:</line>
      <line>’Tis not on youth’s smooth cheek the blush alone which fades so fast,</line>
      <line>But the tender bloom of heart is gone ere youth itself be past.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then the few whose spirits float above the wreck of happiness</line>
      <line>Are driven o’er the shores of guilt, or ocean of excess –</line>
      <line>The magnet of their course is gone, or only points in vain</line>
      <line>The shore to which their shivered sail shall never stretch again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the mortal coldness of the soul like death itself comes down</line>
      <line>(It cannot feel for others’ woes, it dare not dream its own):</line>
      <line>That heavy chill has frozen o’er the fountain of our tears –</line>
      <line>And though the eye may sparkle still, ’tis where the ice appears!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though wit may flash from fluent lips, and mirth distract the breast,</line>
      <line>Through midnight hours that yield no more their former hope of rest,</line>
      <line> ’Tis but as ivy-leaves around the ruined turret wreathe,</line>
      <line>All green and wildly fresh without, but worn and grey beneath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh could I feel what I have felt, or be what I have been,</line>
      <line>Or weep as I could once have wept o’er many a vanished scene –</line>
      <line>As springs in desert found seem sweet, all brackish though they be,</line>
      <line>So, midst the withered waste of life, those tears would flow for O me!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>We’ll Go No More A-Roving</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>So we’ll go no more a-roving</line>
      <line>So late into the night,</line>
      <line>Though the heart be still as loving,</line>
      <line>And the moon be still as bright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For the sword outwears its sheath,</line>
      <line>And the soul wears out the breast,</line>
      <line>And the heart must pause to breathe,</line>
      <line>And love itself have rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the night was made for loving,</line>
      <line>And the day returns too soon,</line>
      <line>Yet we’ll go no more a-roving</line>
      <line>By the light of the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1821</date>
    <title>The Isles of Greece (Don Juan, Canto III)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The isles of Greece, the isles of Greece!</line>
      <line>Where burning Sappho loved and sung,</line>
      <line>Where grew the arts of war and peace,</line>
      <line>Where Delos rose, and Phoebus sprung –</line>
      <line> Eternal summer gilds them yet,</line>
      <line>But all, except their sun, is set.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Scian and the Telan muse –</line>
      <line>The hero’s harp, the lover’s lute –</line>
      <line>Have found the fame your shores refuse;</line>
      <line>Their place of birth alone is mute</line>
      <line>To sounds which echo further west</line>
      <line>Than your sires’ Islands of the Blest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mountains look on Marathon,</line>
      <line>And Marathon looks on the sea;</line>
      <line> And musing there an hour alone,</line>
      <line>I dreamed that Greece might still be free –</line>
      <line>For, standing on the Persians’ grave,</line>
      <line>I could not deem myself a slave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A King sat on the rocky brow</line>
      <line>Which looks o’er sea-born Salamis;</line>
      <line>And ships, by thousands, lay below,</line>
      <line>And men in nations – all were his!</line>
      <line>He counted them at break of day –</line>
      <line>And when the sun set, where were they?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And where are they? And where art thou,</line>
      <line>My country? On thy voiceless shore</line>
      <line>The heroic lay is tuneless now,</line>
      <line>The heroic bosom beats no more!</line>
      <line>And must thy lyre, so long divine,</line>
      <line>Degenerate into hands like mine?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis something, in the dearth of fame,</line>
      <line>Though linked among a fettered race,</line>
      <line>To feel at least a patriot’s shame,</line>
      <line>Even as I sing, suffuse my face.</line>
      <line> For what is left the poet here?</line>
      <line>For Greeks a blush – for Greece a tear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Must we but weep o’er days more blest?</line>
      <line>Must we but blush? Our fathers bled!</line>
      <line>Earth, render back from out thy breast</line>
      <line>A remnant of our Spartan dead!</line>
      <line>Of the three hundred grant but three,</line>
      <line>To make a new Thermopylae!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What, silent still – and silent all?</line>
      <line>Ah, no! The voices of the dead</line>
      <line> Sound like a distant torrent’s fall,</line>
      <line>And answer, ‘Let one living head,</line>
      <line>But one, arise – we come, we come!’</line>
      <line>’Tis but the living who are dumb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In vain – in vain! Strike other chords –</line>
      <line>Fill high the cup with Samian wine!</line>
      <line>Leave battles to the Turkish hordes,</line>
      <line>And shed the blood of Scio’s vine!</line>
      <line>Hark – rising to the ignoble call,</line>
      <line>How answers each bold Bacchanal!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> You have the Pyrrhic dance as yet,</line>
      <line>Where is the Pyrrhic phalanx gone?</line>
      <line>Of two such lessons, why forget</line>
      <line>The nobler and the manlier one?</line>
      <line>You have the letters Cadmus gave –</line>
      <line>Think ye he meant them for a slave?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fill high the bowl with Samian wine –</line>
      <line>We will not think of themes like these!</line>
      <line>It made Anacreon’s song divine:</line>
      <line>He served, but served Polycrates,</line>
      <line> A tyrant – but our masters then</line>
      <line>Were still, at least, our countrymen!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Tyrant of the Chersonese</line>
      <line>Was freedom’s best and bravest friend;</line>
      <line>That tyrant was Miltiades!</line>
      <line>Oh, that the present hour would lend</line>
      <line>Another despot of the kind –</line>
      <line>Such chains as his were sure to bind!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fill high the bowl with Samian wine!</line>
      <line>On Suli’s rock, and Parga’s shore,</line>
      <line> Exists the remnants of a line</line>
      <line>Such as the Doric mothers bore;</line>
      <line>And there, perhaps, some seed is sown,</line>
      <line>The Heracleidan blood might own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Trust not for freedom to the Franks,</line>
      <line>They have a King who buys and sells!</line>
      <line>In native swords, and native ranks,</line>
      <line>The only hope of courage dwells –</line>
      <line>But Turkish force, and Latin fraud,</line>
      <line>Would break your shield, however broad.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Fill high the bowl with Samian wine!</line>
      <line>Our virgins dance beneath the shade –</line>
      <line>I see their glorious black eyes shine –</line>
      <line>But gazing on each glowing maid,</line>
      <line>My own the burning tear-drop laves,</line>
      <line>To think such breasts must suckle slaves!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Place me on Sunium’s marbled steep,</line>
      <line>Where nothing, save the waves and I,</line>
      <line>May hear our mutual murmurs sweep;</line>
      <line>There, swan-like, let me sing and die!</line>
      <line> A land of slaves shall ne’er be mine –</line>
      <line>Dash down yon cup of Samian wine!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>On This Day I Complete My Thirty-Sixth Year</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis time this heart should be unmoved,</line>
      <line>Since others it hath ceased to move –</line>
      <line>Yet, though I cannot be beloved,</line>
      <line>Still let me love!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> My days are in the yellow leaf;</line>
      <line>The flowers and fruits of love are gone;</line>
      <line>The worm, the canker, and the grief</line>
      <line>Are mine alone!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fire that on my bosom preys</line>
      <line>Is lone as some volcanic isle;</line>
      <line>No torch is kindled at its blaze –</line>
      <line>A funeral pile!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The hope, the fear, the jealous care,</line>
      <line>The exalted portion of the pain</line>
      <line> And power of love, I cannot share,</line>
      <line>But wear the chain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But ’tis not thus – and ’tis not here –</line>
      <line>Such thoughts should shake my soul – nor now,</line>
      <line>Where glory decks the hero’s bier,</line>
      <line>Or binds his brow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sword, the banner, and the field,</line>
      <line>Glory and Greece, around me see!</line>
      <line>The Spartan, borne upon his shield,</line>
      <line>Was not more free.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Awake! – not Greece, she is awake! –</line>
      <line>Awake, my spirit! Think through whom</line>
      <line>Thy life-blood tracks its parent lake,</line>
      <line>And then strike home!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tread those reviving passions down,</line>
      <line>Unworthy manhood! Unto thee</line>
      <line>Indifferent should the smile or frown</line>
      <line>Of Beauty be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If thou regretst thy youth, why live?</line>
      <line>The land of honourable death</line>
      <line> Is here! Up to the field, and give</line>
      <line>Away thy breath!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Seek out – less often sought than found –</line>
      <line>A soldier’s grave (for thee the best);</line>
      <line>Then look around, and choose thy ground,</line>
      <line>And take thy rest</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>To Constantia, Singing</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy voice, slow rising like a spirit, lingers</line>
      <line>O’ershadowing me with soft and lulling wings;</line>
      <line>The blood and life within thy snowy fingers</line>
      <line>Teach witchcraft to the instrumental strings!</line>
      <line> My brain is wild, my breath comes quick,</line>
      <line>The blood is listening in my frame,</line>
      <line>And thronging shadows fast and thick</line>
      <line>Fall on my overflowing eyes,</line>
      <line>My heart is quivering like a flame –</line>
      <line>As morning-dew that in the sunbeam dies</line>
      <line>I am dissolved in these consuming ecstasies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have no life, Constantia, but in thee,</line>
      <line>Whilst, like the world-surrounding air, thy song</line>
      <line>Flows on, and fills all things with melody!</line>
      <line> Now is thy voice a tempest swift and strong</line>
      <line>On which, as one in trance upborne,</line>
      <line>Secure o’er woods and waves I sweep</line>
      <line>Rejoicing like a cloud of morn –</line>
      <line>Now ’tis the breath of summer’s night</line>
      <line>Which, where the starry waters sleep</line>
      <line>Round western isles with incense-blossoms bright,</line>
      <line>Lingering suspends my soul in its voluptuous flight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A deep and breathless awe (like the swift change</line>
      <line>Of dreams unseen, but felt, in youthful slumbers),</line>
      <line> Wild, sweet, yet incommunicably strange,</line>
      <line>Thou breathest now, in fast-ascending numbers.</line>
      <line>The cope of Heaven seems rent and cloven</line>
      <line>By the enchantment of thy strain,</line>
      <line>And o’er my shoulders wings are woven</line>
      <line>To follow its sublime career</line>
      <line>Beyond the mighty moons that wane</line>
      <line>Upon the verge of Nature’s utmost sphere,</line>
      <line>Till the world’s shadowy walls are past, and disappear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cease, cease, for such wild lessons madmen learn!</line>
      <line> Long thus to sink, thus to be lost and die,</line>
      <line>Perhaps is death indeed – Constantia turn!</line>
      <line>Yes, in thine eyes a power like light doth lie</line>
      <line>Even though the sounds – its voice – that were</line>
      <line>Between thy lips are laid to sleep,</line>
      <line>Within thy breath and on thy hair</line>
      <line>Like odour it is lingering yet,</line>
      <line>And from thy touch like fire doth leap!</line>
      <line>Even while I write my burning cheeks are wet –</line>
      <line>Such things the heart can feel and learn, but not forget!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>Stanzas Written in Dejection</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun is warm, the sky is clear,</line>
      <line>The waves are dancing fast and bright,</line>
      <line>Blue isles and snowy mountains wear</line>
      <line>The purple noon’s transparent might,</line>
      <line> The breath of the moist earth is light,</line>
      <line>Around its unexpanded buds;</line>
      <line>Like many a voice of one delight,</line>
      <line>The winds, the birds, the ocean floods,</line>
      <line>The City’s voice itself, is soft like solitude’s.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I see the deep’s untrampled floor</line>
      <line>With green and purple seaweeds strown;</line>
      <line>I see the waves upon the shore,</line>
      <line>Like light dissolved in star-showers, thrown;</line>
      <line>I sit upon the sands alone.</line>
      <line> The lightning of the noontide ocean</line>
      <line>Is flashing round me, and a tone</line>
      <line>Arises from its measured motion,</line>
      <line>How sweet – did any heart now share in my emotion!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas, I have nor hope, nor health,</line>
      <line>Nor peace within, nor calm around,</line>
      <line>Nor that content surpassing wealth</line>
      <line>The sage in meditation found,</line>
      <line>And walked with inward glory crowned –</line>
      <line>Nor fame, nor power, nor love, nor leisure.</line>
      <line> Others I see whom these surround,</line>
      <line>Smiling they live, and call life pleasure –</line>
      <line>To me that cup has been dealt in another measure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet now despair itself is mild,</line>
      <line>Even as the winds and waters are;</line>
      <line>I could lie down like a tired child,</line>
      <line>And weep away the life of care</line>
      <line>Which I have borne and yet must bear,</line>
      <line>Till death like sleep might steal on me</line>
      <line>And I might feel in the warm air</line>
      <line> My cheek grow cold, and hear the sea</line>
      <line>Breathe o’er my dying brain its last monotony.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some might lament that I were cold –</line>
      <line>As I, when this sweet day is gone</line>
      <line>(Which my lost heart, too soon grown old,</line>
      <line>Insults with this untimely moan),</line>
      <line>They might lament – for I am one</line>
      <line>Whom men love not, and yet regret;</line>
      <line>Unlike this day, which, when the sun</line>
      <line>Shall on its stainless glory set,</line>
      <line> Will linger, though enjoyed, like joy in memory yet.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>The Cloud</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I bring fresh showers for the thirsting flowers</line>
      <line>From the seas and the streams,</line>
      <line>I bear light shade for the leaves when laid</line>
      <line>In their noonday dreams.</line>
      <line> From my wings are shaken the dews that waken</line>
      <line>The sweet buds every one,</line>
      <line>When rocked to rest on their Mother’s breast,</line>
      <line>As she dances about the sun.</line>
      <line>I wield the flail of the lashing hail,</line>
      <line>And whiten the green plains under,</line>
      <line>And then again I dissolve it in rain,</line>
      <line>And laugh as I pass in thunder.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I sift the snow on the mountains below,</line>
      <line>And their great pines groan aghast;</line>
      <line> And all the night ’tis my pillow white,</line>
      <line>While I sleep in the arms of the blast.</line>
      <line>Sublime on the towers of my skiey bowers,</line>
      <line>Lightning my pilot sits;</line>
      <line>In a cavern under is fettered the thunder,</line>
      <line>It struggles and howls at fits;</line>
      <line>Over earth and ocean, with gentle motion,</line>
      <line>This pilot is guiding me,</line>
      <line>Lured by the love of the genii that move</line>
      <line>In the depths of the purple sea;</line>
      <line> Over the rills, and the crags, and the hills,</line>
      <line>Over the lakes and the plains,</line>
      <line>Wherever he dream, under mountain or stream,</line>
      <line>The spirit he loves remains;</line>
      <line>And I all the while bask in Heaven’s blue smile,</line>
      <line>Whilst he is dissolving in rains.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sanguine Sunrise, with his meteor-eyes,</line>
      <line>And his burning plumes outspread,</line>
      <line>Leaps on the back of my sailing rack</line>
      <line>When the morning-star shines dead –</line>
      <line> As on the jag of a mountain-crag,</line>
      <line>Which an earthquake rocks and swings,</line>
      <line>An eagle alit one moment may sit</line>
      <line>In the light of its golden wings.</line>
      <line>And when Sunset may breathe, from the lit sea beneath,</line>
      <line>Its ardours of rest and of love,</line>
      <line>And the crimson pall of eve may fall</line>
      <line>From the depth of Heaven above,</line>
      <line>With wings folded I rest, on mine airy nest,</line>
      <line>As still as a brooding dove.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> That orbéd maiden with white fire laden,</line>
      <line>Whom mortals call the Moon,</line>
      <line>Glides glimmering o’er my fleece-like floor,</line>
      <line>By the midnight breezes strewn;</line>
      <line>And wherever the beat of her unseen feet,</line>
      <line>Which only the angels hear,</line>
      <line>May have broken the woof of my tent’s thin roof,</line>
      <line>The stars peep behind her and peer.</line>
      <line>And I laugh to see them whirl and flee,</line>
      <line>Like a swarm of golden bees,</line>
      <line> When I widen the rent in my wind-built tent,</line>
      <line>Till the calm rivers, lakes, and seas,</line>
      <line>Like strips of the sky fallen through me on high,</line>
      <line>Are each paved with the moon and these.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I bind the Sun’s throne with a burning zone,</line>
      <line>And the Moon’s with a girdle of pearl;</line>
      <line>The volcanoes are dim, and the stars reel and swim,</line>
      <line>When the whirlwinds my banner unfurl.</line>
      <line>From cape to cape, with a bridge-like shape,</line>
      <line>Over a torrent sea,</line>
      <line> Sunbeam-proof, I hang like a roof –</line>
      <line>The mountains its columns be!</line>
      <line>The triumphal arch through which I march</line>
      <line>With hurricane, fire, and snow,</line>
      <line>When the Powers of the Air are chained to my chair,</line>
      <line>Is the million-coloured bow;</line>
      <line>The sphere-fire above its soft colours wove,</line>
      <line>While the moist Earth was laughing below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am the daughter of Earth and Water,</line>
      <line>And the nursling of the Sky;</line>
      <line> I pass through the pores of the ocean and shores;</line>
      <line>I change, but I cannot die.</line>
      <line>For after the rain when with never a stain</line>
      <line>The pavilion of Heaven is bare,</line>
      <line>And the winds and sunbeams with their convex gleams</line>
      <line>Build up the blue dome of air,</line>
      <line>I silently laugh at my own cenotaph,</line>
      <line>And out of the caverns of rain,</line>
      <line>Like a child from the womb, like a ghost from the tomb,</line>
      <line>I arise and unbuild it again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1821</date>
    <title>Hellas: The Last Chorus</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world’s great age begins anew,</line>
      <line>The golden years return,</line>
      <line>The earth doth like a snake renew</line>
      <line>Her winter weeds outworn;</line>
      <line>Heaven smiles, and faiths and empires gleam</line>
      <line>Like wrecks of a dissolving dream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A brighter Hellas rears its mountains</line>
      <line>From waves serener far,</line>
      <line>A new Peneus rolls his fountains</line>
      <line>Against the morning-star</line>
      <line>Where fairer Tempes bloom; there sleep</line>
      <line>Young Cycladson a sunnier deep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A loftier Argo cleaves the main,</line>
      <line>Fraught with a later prize;</line>
      <line>Another Orpheus sings again,</line>
      <line>And loves, and weeps, and dies;</line>
      <line>A new Ulysses leaves once more</line>
      <line>Calypso for his native shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh write no more the tale of Troy,</line>
      <line>If earth Death’s scroll must be!</line>
      <line>Nor mix with Laian rage the joy</line>
      <line>Which dawns upon the free;</line>
      <line>Although a subtler Sphinx renew</line>
      <line>Riddles of death Thebes never knew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Another Athens shall arise,</line>
      <line>And to remoter time</line>
      <line>Bequeath, like sunset to the skies,</line>
      <line>The splendour of its prime,</line>
      <line>And leave, if nought so bright may live,</line>
      <line>All earth can take or Heaven give.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Saturn and Love their long repose</line>
      <line>Shall burst, more bright and good</line>
      <line>Than all who fell, than one who rose,</line>
      <line>Than many unsubdued;</line>
      <line>Not gold, not blood their altar dowers</line>
      <line>But votive tears and symbol flowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh cease! must hate and death return?</line>
      <line>Cease! must men kill and die?</line>
      <line>Cease! drain not to its dregs the urn</line>
      <line>Of bitter prophecy.</line>
      <line>The world is weary of the past,</line>
      <line>Oh might it die or rest and last!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1821</date>
    <title>Music, When Soft Voices Die</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Music, when soft voices die,</line>
      <line>Vibrates in the memory;</line>
      <line>Odours, when sweet violets sicken,</line>
      <line>Live within the sense they quicken.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Rose leaves, when the rose is dead,</line>
      <line>Are heaped for the belovéd’s bed;</line>
      <line>And so thy thoughts, when thou art gone,</line>
      <line>Love itself shall slumber on.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>Where Be Ye Going</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where be ye going, you Devon maid?</line>
      <line>And what have you there in the basket?</line>
      <line>Ye tight little fairy, just fresh from the dairy,</line>
      <line>Will ye give me some cream if I ask it?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I love your meads, and I love your flowers,</line>
      <line>And I love your junkets mainly,</line>
      <line>But ‘hind the door I love kissing more,</line>
      <line>Oh look not so disdainly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love your hills and I love your dales,</line>
      <line>And I love your flocks a-bleating –</line>
      <line>But oh, on the heather to lie together</line>
      <line>With both our hearts a-beating!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll put your basket all safe in a nook,</line>
      <line>Your shawl I hang on this willow,</line>
      <line> And we will sigh in the daisy’s eye</line>
      <line>And kiss on a grass-green pillow.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>The Witching Time</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis the ‘witching time of night’,</line>
      <line>Orbéd is the moon and bright,</line>
      <line>And the stars, they glisten, glisten,</line>
      <line>Seeming with bright eyes to listen!</line>
      <line> For what listen they?</line>
      <line>For a song and for a charm –</line>
      <line>See they glisten in alarm,</line>
      <line>And the moon is waxing warm</line>
      <line>To hear what I shall say!</line>
      <line>Moon, keep wide thy golden ears!</line>
      <line>Hearken stars, and hearken spheres!</line>
      <line>Hearken thou eternal sky!</line>
      <line>I sing an infant’s lullaby,</line>
      <line>A pretty lullaby.</line>
      <line> Listen, listen, listen, listen,</line>
      <line>Glisten, glisten, glisten, glisten,</line>
      <line>And hear my lullaby!</line>
      <line>Though the rushes that will make</line>
      <line>Its cradle still are in the lake;</line>
      <line>Though the linen that will make</line>
      <line>Its swathe is on the cotton-tree;</line>
      <line>Though the woollen that will keep</line>
      <line>It warm is on the silly sheep;</line>
      <line>Listen stars-light, listen, listen,</line>
      <line> Glisten, glisten, glisten, glisten,</line>
      <line>And hear my lullaby.</line>
      <line>Child, I see thee! Child, I’ve found thee</line>
      <line>Midst of the quiet all around thee!</line>
      <line>Child, I see thee! Child, I spy thee!</line>
      <line>And thy mother sweet is nigh thee!</line>
      <line>Child, I know thee – child no more,</line>
      <line>But a poet evermore!</line>
      <line>See, see, the lyre, the lyre</line>
      <line>In a flame of fire,</line>
      <line> Upon the little cradle’s top</line>
      <line>Flaring, flaring, flaring,</line>
      <line>Past the eyesight’s bearing –</line>
      <line>Awake it from its sleep,</line>
      <line>And see if it can keep</line>
      <line>Its eyes upon the blaze.</line>
      <line>Amaze, amaze!</line>
      <line>It stares, it stares, it stares –</line>
      <line>It dares what no one dares!</line>
      <line>It lifts its little hand into the flame</line>
      <line> Unharmed, and on the strings</line>
      <line>Paddles a little tune, and sings</line>
      <line>With dumb endeavour, sweetly!</line>
      <line>Bard art thou completely,</line>
      <line>Little child</line>
      <line>O’ the western wild,</line>
      <line>Bard art thou completely:</line>
      <line>Sweetly, with dumb endeavour,</line>
      <line>A poet now or never!</line>
      <line>Little child</line>
      <line> O’ the western wild,</line>
      <line>A poet now or never!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date1818></date>
    <title>I Had a Dove</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I had a dove, and the sweet dove died,</line>
      <line>And I have thought it died of grieving.</line>
      <line>Oh, what could it grieve for? Its feet were tied</line>
      <line>With a silken thread of my own hand’s weaving.</line>
      <line> Sweet little red feet! Why should you die –</line>
      <line>Why would you leave me, sweet dove, why?</line>
      <line>You lived alone on the forest-tree,</line>
      <line>Why, pretty thing, could you not live with me?</line>
      <line>I kissed you oft, and gave you white peas –</line>
      <line>Why not live sweetly, as in the green trees?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>Hush, Hush! Tread Softly</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hush, hush! Tread softly! Hush, hush, my dear!</line>
      <line>All the house is asleep, but we know very well</line>
      <line>That the jealous, the jealous old bald-pate may hear –</line>
      <line>Though you’ve padded his nightcap, oh sweet Isabel!</line>
      <line> Though your feet are more light than a fairy’s feet,</line>
      <line>Who dances on bubbles where brooklets meet.</line>
      <line>Hush, hush! Soft tiptoe! Hush, hush, my dear!</line>
      <line>For less than a nothing the jealous can hear.</line>
      <line>No leaf doth tremble, no ripple is there</line>
      <line>On the river; all’s still, and the night’s sleepy eye</line>
      <line>Closes up and forgets all its Lethean care,</line>
      <line>Charmed to death by the drone of the humming mayfly –</line>
      <line>And the moon, whether prudish or complaisant,</line>
      <line>Has fled to her bower, well knowing I want</line>
      <line> No light in the dusk, no torch in the gloom,</line>
      <line>Than my Isabel’s eyes, and her lips pulped with bloom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lift the latch! Ah, gently! Ah, tenderly, sweet!</line>
      <line>We are dead if that latchet gives one little clink –</line>
      <line>Well done – now those lips, and a flowery seat!</line>
      <line>The old man may sleep and the planets may wink,</line>
      <line>The shut rose shall dream of our loves, and awake</line>
      <line>Full-blown, and such warmth for the morning’s take;</line>
      <line>The stock-dove shall hatch her soft brace, and shall coo,</line>
      <line>While I kiss to the melody, aching all through.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>This Living Hand</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This living hand, now warm and capable</line>
      <line>Of earnest grasping, would, if it were cold</line>
      <line>And in the icy silence of the tomb,</line>
      <line>So haunt thy days and chill thy dreaming nights</line>
      <line> That thou wouldst wish thine own heart dry of blood</line>
      <line>So in my veins red life might stream again,</line>
      <line>And thou be conscience-calmed. See, here it is –</line>
      <line>I hold it towards you.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sad was the day when my Willie did leave me,</line>
      <line>Sad was the moments that winged him away,</line>
      <line>And oh most distressing and most it did grieve me</line>
      <line>To witness his looks when I pressed him to stay!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> It hurt him to think that in vain was my crying,</line>
      <line>Which I couldn’t help though I knew it so too –</line>
      <line>The trumpets all sounding the colours all flying</line>
      <line>A soldier my Willie he couldn’t but go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The youths never heeding tomorrow and danger</line>
      <line>Were laughing and toasting their girls o’er their beer,</line>
      <line>But oh my poor Willie just like a lost stranger</line>
      <line>Stood speechless among them half-dead as it were!</line>
      <line>He kissed me – ’twas all – not a word when he started,</line>
      <line>And oh in his silence too much I could see:</line>
      <line> He knew for a truth, and he knew broken-hearted,</line>
      <line>That kiss was the last he should ever give me!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1827</date>
    <title>Ruth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She stood breast high amid the corn</line>
      <line>Clasped by the golden light of morn,</line>
      <line>Like the sweetheart of the sun</line>
      <line>Who many a glowing kiss had won.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> On her cheek an autumn flush</line>
      <line>Deeply ripened – such a blush</line>
      <line>In the midst of brown was born,</line>
      <line>Like red poppies grown with corn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Round her eyes her tresses fell,</line>
      <line>Which were blackest none could tell,</line>
      <line>But long lashes veiled a light</line>
      <line>That had else been all too bright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And her hat, with shady brim,</line>
      <line>Made her tressy forehead dim;</line>
      <line> Thus she stood amid the stooks</line>
      <line>Praising God with sweetest looks –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sure, I said, Heaven did not mean</line>
      <line>Where I reap thou shouldst but glean,</line>
      <line>Lay thy sheaf adown and come,</line>
      <line>Share my harvest and my home.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLES LAMB</author>
    <date>1827</date>
    <title>To Louisa Martin, Whom I Used to Call ‘Monkey’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Louisa, serious grown and mild,</line>
      <line>I knew you once a romping child,</line>
      <line>Obstreperous much and very wild.</line>
      <line>Then you would clamber up my knees,</line>
      <line> And strive with every art to tease,</line>
      <line>When every art of yours could please.</line>
      <line>Those things would scarce be proper now.</line>
      <line>But they are gone, I know not how,</line>
      <line>And woman’s written on your brow.</line>
      <line>O Time draws his finger o’er the scene,</line>
      <line>But I cannot forget between</line>
      <line>The thing to me you once have been:</line>
      <line>Each sportive sally, wild escape –</line>
      <line>The scoff, the banter, and the jape –</line>
      <line> And antics of my gamesome Ape.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLES LAMB</author>
    <date>1829</date>
    <title>In My Own Album</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fresh clad from Heaven in robes of white,</line>
      <line>A young probationer of light,</line>
      <line>Thou wert, my soul, an album bright –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A spotless leaf! But thought, and care,</line>
      <line> And friends, and foes, in foul or fair,</line>
      <line>Have ‘written strange defeature’ there;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Time, with heaviest hand of all,</line>
      <line>Like that fierce writing on the wall,</line>
      <line>Hath stamped sad dates, he can’t recall;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Error, gilding worst designs</line>
      <line>(Like speckled snake that strays and shines),</line>
      <line>Betrays his path by crooked lines;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Vice hath left his ugly blot,</line>
      <line>And good resolves, a moment hot –</line>
      <line> Fairly begun, but finished not;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And fruitless Late Remorse doth trace</line>
      <line>(Like Hebrew lore) a backward pace,</line>
      <line>Her irrecoverable race.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Disjointed numbers, sense unknit,</line>
      <line>Huge reams of folly, shreds of wit,</line>
      <line>Compose the mingled mass of it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My scalded eyes no longer brook</line>
      <line>Upon this ink-blurred thing to look –</line>
      <line>Go, shut the leaves, and clasp the book.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1827</date>
    <title>Song (‘My heart is like the failing hearth’)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My heart is like the failing hearth</line>
      <line>Now by my side,</line>
      <line>One by one its bursts of flame</line>
      <line>Have burnt and died;</line>
      <line> There are none to watch the sinking blaze,</line>
      <line>And none to care,</line>
      <line>Or if it kindle into strength,</line>
      <line>Or waste in air.</line>
      <line>My fate is as yon faded wreath</line>
      <line>Of summer flowers:</line>
      <line>They’ve spent their store of fragrant health</line>
      <line>In sunny hours,</line>
      <line>Which recked them not, which heeded not</line>
      <line>When they were dead –</line>
      <line> Other flowers, unwarned by them,</line>
      <line>Will spring instead.</line>
      <line>And my own heart is as the lute</line>
      <line>I am now waking;</line>
      <line>Wound to too fine and high a pitch,</line>
      <line>They both are breaking.</line>
      <line>And of their song what memory</line>
      <line>Will stay behind?</line>
      <line>An echo, like a passing thought,</line>
      <line>Upon the wind.</line>
      <line> Silence, forgetfulness, and rust,</line>
      <line>Lute, are for thee –</line>
      <line>And such my lot – neglect, the grave,</line>
      <line>These are for me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>The Graves of a Household</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They grew in beauty, side by side,</line>
      <line>They filled one home with glee –</line>
      <line>Their graves are severed, far and wide,</line>
      <line>By mount, and stream, and sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The same fond mother bent at night</line>
      <line>O’er each fair sleeping brow;</line>
      <line>She had each folded flower in sight –</line>
      <line>Where are those dreamers now?</line>
      <line>One, midst the forests of the west,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By a dark stream is laid –</line>
      <line>The Indian knows his place of rest,</line>
      <line>Far in the cedar-shade.</line>
      <line>The sea, the blue lone sea, hath one,</line>
      <line>He lies where pearls lie deep:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He was the loved of all, yet none</line>
      <line>O’er his low bed may weep!</line>
      <line>One sleeps where southern vines are dressed</line>
      <line>Above the noble slain:</line>
      <line>He wrapped his colours round his breast,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On a blood-red field of Spain.</line>
      <line>And one – o’er her the myrtle showers</line>
      <line>Its leaves, by soft winds fanned –</line>
      <line>She faded midst Italian flowers</line>
      <line>The last of that bright band.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And parted thus they rest, who played</line>
      <line>Beneath the same green tree;</line>
      <line>Whose voices mingled as they prayed</line>
      <line>Around one parent knee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They that with smiles lit up the hall,</line>
      <line>And cheered with song the hearth –</line>
      <line>Alas for love, if thou wert all,</line>
      <line>And nought beyond, oh Earth!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>A Parting Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When will ye think of me, my friends?</line>
      <line>When will ye think of me?</line>
      <line>When the last red light, the farewell of day,</line>
      <line>From the rock and the river is passing away –</line>
      <line> When the air with a deepening hush is fraught,</line>
      <line>And the heart grows tender with burdened thought –</line>
      <line>Then let it be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When will ye think of me, kind friends?</line>
      <line>When will ye think of me?</line>
      <line>When the rose of the rich midsummer-time</line>
      <line>Is filled with the hues of its glorious prime –</line>
      <line>When ye gather its bloom, as in bright hours fled,</line>
      <line>From the walks where my footsteps no more may tread –</line>
      <line>Then let it be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> When will ye think of me, sweet friends?</line>
      <line>When will ye think of me?</line>
