      <line>When the sudden tears o’erflow your eye</line>
      <line>At the sound of some olden melody –</line>
      <line>When ye hear the voice of a mountain-stream,</line>
      <line>When ye feel the charm of a poet’s dream –</line>
      <line>Then let it be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus let my memory be with you, friends!</line>
      <line>Thus ever think of me!</line>
      <line>Kindly and gently, but as of one</line>
      <line> For whom ’tis well to be fled and gone –</line>
      <line>As of a bird from a chain unbound,</line>
      <line>As of a wanderer whose home is found –</line>
      <line>So let it be.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>Dreams</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Surely I heard a voice – surely my name</line>
      <line>Was breathed in tones familiar to my heart?</line>
      <line>I listened, and the low wind stealing came,</line>
      <line>In darkness and in silence to depart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Surely I saw a form, a proud bright form,</line>
      <line>Standing beside my couch? I raised mine eyes –</line>
      <line>’Twas but a dim cloud, herald of a storm,</line>
      <line>That floated through the grey and twilight skies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Surely the brightness of the summer-hour</line>
      <line>Hath suddenly burst upon the circling gloom?</line>
      <line>I dream – ’twas but the perfume of a flower,</line>
      <line>Which the breeze wafted through the silent room.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Surely a hand clasped mine with greetings fond?</line>
      <line>A name is murmured by my lips with pain!</line>
      <line> Woe for that sound – woe for love’s broken bond!</line>
      <line>I start, I wake, I am alone again!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JAMES HOGG</author>
    <date>1831</date>
    <title>When Maggy Gangs Away</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh what will a’ the lads do</line>
      <line>When Maggy gangs away?</line>
      <line>Oh what will a’ the lads do</line>
      <line>When Maggy gangs away?</line>
      <line> There’s no a heart in a’ the glen</line>
      <line>That disna dread the day!</line>
      <line>Oh what will a’ the lads do</line>
      <line>When Maggy gangs away?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Young Jock has ta’en the hill for’t –</line>
      <line>A waefu’ wight is he –</line>
      <line>Poor Harry’s ta’en the bed for’t,</line>
      <line>An’ laid him down to dee;</line>
      <line>An’ Sandy’s gane unto the kirk,</line>
      <line>An learnin’ fast to pray!</line>
      <line> And, oh, what will the lads do</line>
      <line>When Maggy gangs away?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The young laird o’ the Lang-Shaw</line>
      <line>Has drunk her health in wine;</line>
      <line>The priest has said (in confidence)</line>
      <line>The lassie was divine –</line>
      <line>And that is mair in maiden’s praise</line>
      <line>Than ony priest should say!</line>
      <line>But, oh, what will the lads do</line>
      <line>When Maggy gangs away?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The wailing in our green glen</line>
      <line>That day will quaver high,</line>
      <line>’Twill draw the redbreast frae the wood,</line>
      <line>The laverock frae the sky;</line>
      <line>The fairies frae their beds o’ dew</line>
      <line>Will rise an’ join the lay:</line>
      <line>An’ hey, what a day will be</line>
      <line>When Maggy gangs away!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS WARTON</author>
    <date>1777</date>
    <title>To the River Loden</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! what a weary race my feet have run</line>
      <line>Since first I trod thy banks with alders crowned,</line>
      <line>And thought my way was all through fairy-ground</line>
      <line>Beneath thy azure sky and golden sun,</line>
      <line> Where first my Muse to lisp her notes begun!</line>
      <line>While pensive Memory traces back the round</line>
      <line>Which fills the varied interval between,</line>
      <line>Much pleasure – more of sorrow – marks the scene.</line>
      <line>Sweet native stream, those skies and suns so pure</line>
      <line>No more return to cheer my evening road!</line>
      <line>Yet still one joy remains: that not obscure,</line>
      <line>Nor useless, all my vacant days have flowed,</line>
      <line>From youth’s gay dawn to manhood’s prime mature –</line>
      <line>Nor with the Muse’s laurel unbestowed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1784</date>
    <title>The Partial Muse (I)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The partial Muse has from my earliest hours</line>
      <line>Smiled on the ruggéd path I’m doomed to tread,</line>
      <line>And still, with sportive hand, has snatched wild flowers</line>
      <line>To weave fantastic garlands for my head;</line>
      <line> But far, far happier is the lot of those</line>
      <line>Who never learned her dear delusive art,</line>
      <line>Which, while it decks the head with many a rose,</line>
      <line>Reserves the thorn to fester in the heart.</line>
      <line>For still she bids soft Pity’s melting eye</line>
      <line>Stream o’er the hills she knows not to remove –</line>
      <line>Points every pang, and deepens every sigh</line>
      <line>Of mourning friendship, or unhappy love.</line>
      <line>Ah, then how dear the Muse’s favours cost</line>
      <line>If those paint sorrow best, who feel it most!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1784</date>
    <title>Should the Lone Wanderer (XXXVI)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Should the lone wanderer, fainting on his way,</line>
      <line>Rest for a moment of the sultry hours,</line>
      <line>And though his path through thorns and roughness lay,</line>
      <line>Pluck the wild rose, or woodbine’s gadding flowers,</line>
      <line> Weaving gay wreaths beneath some sheltering tree,</line>
      <line>The sense of sorrow he awhile may lose;</line>
      <line>So have I sought thy flowers, fair Poesy!</line>
      <line>So charmed my way with Friendship and the Muse.</line>
      <line>But darker now grows life’s unhappy day,</line>
      <line>Dark with new clouds of evil yet to come,</line>
      <line>Her pencil sickening Fancy throws away,</line>
      <line>And weary Hope reclines upon the tomb;</line>
      <line>And points my wishes to that tranquil shore,</line>
      <line>Where the pale spectre Care pursues no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM LISLE BOWLES</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>At a Village in Scotland</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh North, as thy romantic vales I leave,</line>
      <line>And bid farewell to each retiring hill</line>
      <line>Where thoughtful fancy seems to linger still</line>
      <line>Tracing the broad bright landscape, much I grieve</line>
      <line> That (mingled with the toiling crowd) no more</line>
      <line>I shall return, your varied views to mark –</line>
      <line>Of rocks, amid the sunshine towering dark,</line>
      <line>Of rivers winding wild, and mountains hoar,</line>
      <line>Or castle gleaming on the distant steep.</line>
      <line>Yet not the less I pray your charms may last,</line>
      <line>And many a softened image of the past</line>
      <line>Pensive combine, and bid remembrance keep</line>
      <line>To cheer me with the thought of pleasure flown</line>
      <line>When I am wandering on my way alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM LISLE BOWLES</author>
    <date>1789</date>
    <title>To the River Itchin</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Itchin, when I behold thy banks again,</line>
      <line>Thy crumbling margin, and thy silver breast</line>
      <line>On which the self-same tints still seem to rest,</line>
      <line>Why feels my heart the shivering sense of pain?</line>
      <line> Is it that many a summer’s day has past</line>
      <line>Since in life’s morn I carolled on thy side?</line>
      <line>Is it that oft since then my heart has sighed</line>
      <line>As youth, and hope’s delusive gleams, flew fast?</line>
      <line>Is it that those who circled on thy shore,</line>
      <line>Companions of my youth, now meet no more?</line>
      <line>Whate’er the cause, upon thy banks I bend</line>
      <line>Sorrowing, yet feel such solace at my heart</line>
      <line>As at the meeting of some long-lost friend</line>
      <line>From whom, in happier hours, we wept to part.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1794</date>
    <title>Pantisocracy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No more my visionary soul shall dwell</line>
      <line>On joys that were! No more endure to weigh</line>
      <line>The shame and anguish of the evil day,</line>
      <line>Wisely forgetful! O’er the ocean swell</line>
      <line> Sublime of hope I seek the cottaged dell,</line>
      <line>Where virtue calm with careless step may stray,</line>
      <line>And dancing to the moonlight roundelay</line>
      <line>The wizard passions weave an holy spell.</line>
      <line>Eyes that have ached with sorrow! Ye shall weep</line>
      <line>Tears of doubt-mingled joy, like theirs who start</line>
      <line>From precipices of distempered sleep</line>
      <line>On which the fierce-eyed fiends their revels keep,</line>
      <line>And see the rising sun, and feel it dart</line>
      <line>New rays of pleasance trembling to the heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>To the River Otter</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear native brook! wild streamlet of the west!</line>
      <line>How many various-fated years have past,</line>
      <line>What blissful and what anguished hours, since last</line>
      <line>I skimmed the smooth thin stone along thy breast,</line>
      <line> Numbering its light leaps! Yet so deep impressed</line>
      <line>Sink the sweet scenes of childhood, that mine eyes</line>
      <line>I never shut amid the sunny blaze,</line>
      <line>But straight with all their tints thy waters rise –</line>
      <line>Thy crossing-plank, thy margin’s willowy maze,</line>
      <line>And bedded sand that veined with various dyes</line>
      <line>Gleamed through thy bright transparence to the gaze!</line>
      <line>Visions of childhood! oft have ye beguiled</line>
      <line>Lone manhood’s cares, yet waking fondest sighs:</line>
      <line>Ah, that I were once more a careless child!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Sappho’s Conjectures</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>To Etna’s scorching sands my Phaon flies!</line>
      <line>False youth, can other charms attractive prove?</line>
      <line>Say, can Sicilian loves thy passions move,</line>
      <line>Play round thy heart and fix thy fickle eyes,</line>
      <line> While in despair the Lesbian Sappho dies?</line>
      <line>Has spring for thee a crown of poppies wove,</line>
      <line>Or dost thou languish in the Idalian grove,</line>
      <line>Whose altar kindles, fanned by lovers’ sighs?</line>
      <line>Ah, think that while on Etna’s shores you stray,</line>
      <line>A fire, more fierce than Etna’s, fills my breast;</line>
      <line>Nor deck Sicilian nymphs with garlands gay</line>
      <line>While Sappho’s brows with cypress wreaths are dressed –</line>
      <line>Let one kind word my weary woes repay,</line>
      <line>Or, in eternal slumbers bid them rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Her Address to the Moon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh thou, meek orb, that stealing o’er the dale</line>
      <line>Cheerest with thy modest beams the noon of night,</line>
      <line>On the smooth lake diffusing silvery light,</line>
      <line>Sublimely still, and beautifully pale!</line>
      <line> What can thy cool and placid eye avail,</line>
      <line>Where fierce despair absorbs the mental sight,</line>
      <line>While inbred glooms the vagrant thoughts invite</line>
      <line>To tempt the gulf where howling fiends assail?</line>
      <line>Oh Night, all nature owns thy tempered power,</line>
      <line>Thy solemn pause, thy dews, thy pensive beam;</line>
      <line>Thy sweet breath whispering in the moonlight bower</line>
      <line>While fainting flowerets kiss the wandering stream!</line>
      <line>Yet, vain is every charm, and vain the hour,</line>
      <line>That brings to madding love no soothing dream!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>To Phaon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Canst thou forget, oh idol of my soul,</line>
      <line>Thy Sappho’s voice, her form, her dulcet lyre</line>
      <line>That melting every thought to fond desire</line>
      <line>Bade sweet delirium o’er thy senses roll?</line>
      <line> Canst thou so soon renounce the blest control</line>
      <line>That calmed with pity’s tears love’s raging fire,</line>
      <line>While hope, slow breathing on the trembling wire,</line>
      <line>In every note with soft persuasion stole?</line>
      <line>Oh, sovereign of my heart – return, return!</line>
      <line>For me no spring appears, no summers bloom,</line>
      <line>No sun-beams glitter, and no altars burn!</line>
      <line>The mind’s dark winter of eternal gloom</line>
      <line>Shows midst the waste a solitary urn,</line>
      <line>A blighted laurel, and a mouldering tomb!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLES LAMB</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>When Last I Roved</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When last I roved these winding wood-walks green,</line>
      <line>Green winding walks, and shady pathways sweet,</line>
      <line>Oft-times would Anna seek the silent scene,</line>
      <line>Shrouding her beauties in the lone retreat.</line>
      <line> No more I hear her footsteps in the shade:</line>
      <line>Her image only in these pleasant ways</line>
      <line>Meets me self-wandering, where in happier days</line>
      <line>I held free converse with the fair-haired maid.</line>
      <line>I passed the little cottage which she loved,</line>
      <line>The cottage which did once my all contain!</line>
      <line>It spake of days which ne’er must come again –</line>
      <line>Spake to my heart, and much my heart was moved:</line>
      <line>‘Now fair befall thee, gentle maid!’ said I,</line>
      <line>And from the cottage turned me with a sigh.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>To a Brook Near the Village of Corston</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As thus I bend me o’er thy babbling stream</line>
      <line>And watch thy current, Memory’s hand portrays</line>
      <line>The faint-formed scenes of the departed days,</line>
      <line>Like the far forest by the moon’s pale beam</line>
      <line> Dimly descried, yet lovely. I have worn</line>
      <line>Upon thy banks the live-long hour away</line>
      <line>When sportive childhood wantoned through the day,</line>
      <line>Joyed at the opening splendour of the morn,</line>
      <line>Or, as the twilight darkened, heaved the sigh</line>
      <line>O Thinking of distant home, as down my cheek</line>
      <line>(At the fond thought slow stealing on) would speak</line>
      <line>The silent eloquence of the full eye.</line>
      <line>Dim are the long-past days, yet still they please</line>
      <line>As thy soft sounds, half-heard, borne on the inconstant breeze.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLES LLOYD</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>On the Death of Priscilla Farmer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As o’er the dying embers oft I cower</line>
      <line>When my tired spirits rest, and my heart swells</line>
      <line>Lulled by domestic quiet, Memory dwells</line>
      <line>On that blest tide, when thou the evening hour</line>
      <line> Didst gladden. While upon the accustomed chair</line>
      <line>I look, it seems as if thou still wert there;</line>
      <line>Kirtled in snowy apron, thy dear knees,</line>
      <line>Propt on the fendered hearth, my fancy sees,</line>
      <line>O’er which – exchanging souls – we wont to bend!</line>
      <line>And as I lift my head, thy features send</line>
      <line>A cheering smile to me – but, in its flight</line>
      <line>O’er my rain-pelted sash, a blast of night</line>
      <line>Sweeps surlily! I start, and fain would creep</line>
      <line>To the bleak dwelling where thy cold limbs sleep!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANNA SEWARD</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>By Derwent’s Rapid Stream</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>By Derwent’s rapid stream as oft I strayed</line>
      <line>With infancy’s light step and glances wild,</line>
      <line>And saw vast rocks on steepy mountains piled</line>
      <line>Frown o’er the umbrageous glen, or pleased surveyed</line>
      <line> The cloudy moonshine in the shadowy glade,</line>
      <line>Romantic Nature to the enthusiast child</line>
      <line>Grew dearer far than when serene she smiled</line>
      <line>In uncontrasted loveliness arrayed.</line>
      <line>But oh! in every scene, with sacred sway</line>
      <line>Her graces fire me; from the bloom that spreads</line>
      <line>Resplendent in the lucid morn of May,</line>
      <line>To the green light the little glow-worm sheds</line>
      <line>On mossy banks when midnight glooms prevail,</line>
      <line>And softest silence broods o’er all the dale.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY TIGHE</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>Written at Scarborough</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As musing pensive in my silent home</line>
      <line>I hear far off the sullen ocean’s roar,</line>
      <line>Where the rude wave just sweeps the level shore</line>
      <line>Or bursts upon the rocks with whitening foam,</line>
      <line> I think upon the scenes my life has known –</line>
      <line>On days of sorrow, and some hours of joy;</line>
      <line>Both which alike Time could so soon destroy!</line>
      <line>And now they seem a busy dream alone;</line>
      <line>While on the earth exists no single trace</line>
      <line>Of all that shook my agitated soul,</line>
      <line>As on the beach new waves for ever roll</line>
      <line>And fill their past forgotten brother’s place;</line>
      <line>But I, like the worn sand, exposed remain</line>
      <line>To each new storm which frets the angry main.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>Written at the Close of Spring</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The garlands fade that Spring so lately wove,</line>
      <line>Each simple flower, which she had nursed in dew,</line>
      <line>Anemones, that spangled every grove,</line>
      <line>The primrose wan, and hare-bell, mildly blue.</line>
      <line> No more shall violets linger in the dell,</line>
      <line>Or purple orchis variegate the plain,</line>
      <line>Till Spring again shall call forth every bell,</line>
      <line>And dress with humid hands her wreaths again.</line>
      <line>Ah, poor humanity! so frail, so fair,</line>
      <line>Are the fond visions of thy early day,</line>
      <line>Till tyrant passion, and corrosive care,</line>
      <line>Bid all thy fairy colours fade away!</line>
      <line>Another May new buds and flowers shall bring:</line>
      <line>Ah! why has happiness – no second Spring?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>From the Thirteenth Cantata of Metastasio</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>On thy grey bark, in witness of my flame,</line>
      <line>I carve Miranda’s cypher – beauteous tree!</line>
      <line>Graced with the lovely letters of her name,</line>
      <line>Henceforth be sacred to my love and me!</line>
      <line> Though the tall elm, the oak, and darker pine,</line>
      <line>With broader arms, may noon’s fierce ardours break,</line>
      <line>To shelter me, and her I love, be thine;</line>
      <line>And thine to see her smile and hear her speak.</line>
      <line>No bird, ill-omened, round thy graceful head</line>
      <line>Shall clamour harsh, or wave his heavy wing,</line>
      <line>But fern and flowers arise beneath thy shade,</line>
      <line>Where the wild bees their lullabies shall sing.</line>
      <line>And in thy boughs the murmuring ring-dove rest;</line>
      <line>And there the nightingale shall build her nest.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>To the Earl of Egremont</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wyndham! ’tis not thy blood, though pure it runs</line>
      <line>Through a long line of glorious ancestry,</line>
      <line>Percys and Seymours, Britain’s boasted sons,</line>
      <line>Who trust the honours of their race to thee.</line>
      <line> ’Tis not thy splendid domes (where Science loves</line>
      <line>To touch the canvas, and the bust to raise),</line>
      <line>Thy rich domains, fair fields, and spreading groves –</line>
      <line>’Tis not all these the Muse delights to praise:</line>
      <line>In birth, and wealth, and honours, great thou art!</line>
      <line>But nobler in thy independent mind,</line>
      <line>And in that liberal hand and feeling heart</line>
      <line>Given thee by Heaven – a blessing to mankind!</line>
      <line>Unworthy oft may titled fortune be:</line>
      <line>A soul like thine – is true Nobility!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>I Grieved for Bonaparté</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I grieved for Bonaparté with a vain</line>
      <line>And an unthinking grief – the vital blood</line>
      <line>Of that man’s mind, what can it be? What food</line>
      <line>Fed his first hopes? What knowledge could he gain?</line>
      <line> ’Tis not in battles that from youth we train</line>
      <line>The governor who must be wise and good</line>
      <line>And temper with the sternness of the brain</line>
      <line>Thoughts motherly and meek as womanhood.</line>
      <line>Wisdom doth live with children round her knees:</line>
      <line>Books, leisure, perfect freedom, and the talk</line>
      <line>Man holds with weekday man in the hourly walk</line>
      <line>Of the mind’s business. These are the degrees</line>
      <line>By which true sway doth mount; this is the stalk</line>
      <line>True power doth grow on – and her rights are these.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>With Ships the Sea Was Sprinkled</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With ships the sea was sprinkled far and nigh</line>
      <line>Like stars in heaven, and joyously it showed;</line>
      <line>Some lying fast at anchor in the road,</line>
      <line>Some veering up and down, one knew not why.</line>
      <line> A goodly vessel did I then espy</line>
      <line>Come like a giant from a haven broad,</line>
      <line>And lustily along the bay she strode,</line>
      <line>Her tackling rich, and of apparel high.</line>
      <line>This ship was nought to me, nor I to her,</line>
      <line>Yet I pursued her with a lover’s look –</line>
      <line>This ship to all the rest did I prefer!</line>
      <line>When will she turn, and whither? She will brook</line>
      <line>No tarrying – where she comes the winds must stir! –</line>
      <line>On went she, and due north her journey took.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Westminster Bridge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Earth hath not anything to show more fair!</line>
      <line>Dull would he be of soul who could pass by</line>
      <line>A sight so touching in its majesty.</line>
      <line>This city now doth like a garment wear</line>
      <line> The beauty of the morning: silent, bare,</line>
      <line>Ships, towers, domes, theatres, and temples lie</line>
      <line>Open unto the fields and to the sky,</line>
      <line>All bright and glittering in the smokeless air.</line>
      <line>Never did sun more beautifully steep</line>
      <line>In his first splendour valley, rock or hill;</line>
      <line>Ne’er saw I, never felt, a calm so deep –</line>
      <line>The river glideth at his own sweet will –</line>
      <line>Dear God, the very houses seem asleep,</line>
      <line>And all that mighty heart is lying still!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Milton, Thou Shouldst Be Living at this Hour</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Milton, thou shouldst be living at this hour,</line>
      <line>England hath need of thee! She is a fen</line>
      <line>Of stagnant waters! Altar, sword, and pen,</line>
      <line>Fireside, the heroic wealth of hall and bower,</line>
      <line> Have forfeited their ancient English dower</line>
      <line>Of inward happiness. We are selfish men –</line>
      <line>Oh raise us up, return to us again,</line>
      <line>And give us manners, virtue, freedom, power!</line>
      <line>Thy soul was like a star and dwelt apart;</line>
      <line>Thou hadst a voice whose sound was like the sea –</line>
      <line>Pure as the naked heavens, majestic, free –</line>
      <line>So didst thou travel on life’s common way</line>
      <line>In cheerful godliness. And yet thy heart</line>
      <line>The lowliest duties on itself did lay.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The World Is Too Much with Us</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world is too much with us: late and soon,</line>
      <line>Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers –</line>
      <line>Little we see in Nature that is ours –</line>
      <line>We have given our hearts away, a sordid boon!</line>
      <line> This sea that bares her bosom to the moon,</line>
      <line>The winds that will be howling at all hours</line>
      <line>And are up-gathered now like sleeping flowers;</line>
      <line>For this, for every thing, we are out of tune:</line>
      <line>It moves us not. Great God! I’d rather be</line>
      <line>A pagan suckled in a creed outworn</line>
      <line>So might I, standing on this pleasant lea,</line>
      <line>Have glimpses that would make me less forlorn –</line>
      <line>Have sight of Proteus coming from the sea,</line>
      <line>Or hear old Triton blow his wreathéd horn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Ere We Had Reached the Wished-for Place</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ere we had reached the wished-for place, night fell;</line>
      <line>We were too late at least by one dark hour,</line>
      <line>And nothing could we see of all that power</line>
      <line>Of prospect whereof many thousands tell.</line>
      <line> The western sky did recompense us well</line>
      <line>With Grecian temple, minaret, and bower,</line>
      <line>And in one part a minster with its tower</line>
      <line>Substantially distinct – a place for bell</line>
      <line>Or clock to toll from! Many a glorious pile</line>
      <line>Did we behold, sights that might well repay</line>
      <line>All disappointment – and, as such, the eye</line>
      <line>Delighted in them – but we felt, the while,</line>
      <line>We should forget them. They are of the sky</line>
      <line>And from our earthly memory fade away.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Nuns Fret Not</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nuns fret not at their convent’s narrow room,</line>
      <line>And hermits are contented with their cells,</line>
      <line>And students with their pensive citadels;</line>
      <line>Maids at the wheel, the weaver at his loom,</line>
      <line> Sit blithe and happy; bees that soar for bloom</line>
      <line>High as the highest peak of Furness Fells</line>
      <line>Will murmur by the hour in foxglove bells.</line>
      <line>In truth, the prison unto which we doom</line>
      <line>Ourselves, no prison is; and hence to me,</line>
      <line>In sundry moods, ’twas pastime to be bound</line>
      <line>Within the sonnet’s scanty plot of ground –</line>
      <line>Pleased if some souls (for such there needs must be)</line>
      <line>Who have felt the weight of too much liberty,</line>
      <line>Should find short solace there, as I have found.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Scorn Not the Sonnet</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Scorn not the sonnet! Critic, you have frowned</line>
      <line>Mindless of its just honours. With this key</line>
      <line>Shakespeare unlocked his heart, the melody</line>
      <line>Of this small lute gave ease to Petrarch’s wound;</line>
      <line> A thousand times this pipe did Tasso sound;</line>
      <line>With it Camöens soothed an exile’s grief.</line>
      <line>The sonnet glittered a gay myrtle-leaf</line>
      <line>Amid the cypress with which Dante crowned</line>
      <line>His visionary brow – a glow-worm lamp.</line>
      <line>It cheered mild Spenser, called from Faery-land</line>
      <line>To struggle through dark ways, and, when a damp</line>
      <line>Fell round the path of Milton, in his hand</line>
      <line>The thing became a trumpet, whence he blew</line>
      <line>Soul-animating strains – alas, too few!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY TIGHE</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>To Death</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh thou most terrible, most dreaded power,</line>
      <line>In whatsoever form thou meetst the eye –</line>
      <line>Whether thou biddest thy sudden arrow fly</line>
      <line>In the dread silence of the midnight-hour;</line>
      <line> Or whether, hovering o’er the lingering wretch</line>
      <line>Thy sad cold javelin hangs suspended long,</line>
      <line>While round the couch the weeping kindred throng</line>
      <line>With hope and fear alternately on stretch –</line>
      <line>Oh, say, for me what horrors are prepared?</line>
      <line>Am I now doomed to meet thy fatal arm?</line>
      <line>Or wilt thou first from life steal every charm,</line>
      <line>And bear away each good my soul would guard,</line>
      <line>That thus, deprived of all it loved, my heart</line>
      <line>From life itself contentedly may part?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1814</date>
    <title>Written During the Author’s Imprisonment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Winter has reached thee once again at last,</line>
      <line>And now the rambler, whom thy groves yet please,</line>
      <line>Feels on his house-warm lips the thin air freeze,</line>
      <line>While in his shrugging neck the resolute blast</line>
      <line> Comes edging; and the leaves, in heaps down cast,</line>
      <line>He shuffles with his hastening foot, and sees</line>
      <line>The cold sky whitening through the wiry trees,</line>
      <line>And sighs to think his loitering noons have passed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And do I love thee less, to paint thee so?</line>
      <line>No. This the season is of beauty still,</line>
      <line>Doubled at heart; of smoke, with whirling glee</line>
      <line>Uptumbling ever from the blaze below,</line>
      <line>And home remembered most – and oh, loved hill,</line>
      <line>The second, and the last, away from thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1815</date>
    <title>Written in the Spring that Succeeded Imprisonment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As one who after long and far-spent years</line>
      <line>Comes on his mistress in an hour of sleep,</line>
      <line>And (wondering half that he can silence keep)</line>
      <line>Stands smiling o’er her through a flash of tears</line>
      <line> To see how sweet and self-same she appears,</line>
      <line>Till, at his touch, with little moving creep</line>
      <line>Of joy, she wakes from out her calmness deep,</line>
      <line>And then his heart finds voice, and dances round her ears –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So I, first coming on my haunts again,</line>
      <line>In pause and stillness of the early prime,</line>
      <line>Stood thinking of the past and present time</line>
      <line>With earnest eyesight, scarcely crossed with pain,</line>
      <line>Till the fresh-moving leaves, and startling birds,</line>
      <line>Loosened my long-suspended breath in words!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>On a Lock of Milton’s Hair</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It lies before me there, and my own breath</line>
      <line>Stirs its thin outer threads, as though beside</line>
      <line>The living head I stood in honoured pride</line>
      <line>Talking of lovely things that conquer death.</line>
      <line> Perhaps he pressed it once, or underneath</line>
      <line>Ran his fine fingers when he leant, blank-eyed,</line>
      <line>And saw in fancy Adam and his bride</line>
      <line>With their rich locks – or his own Delphic wreath!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There seems a love in hair, though it be dead:</line>
      <line>It is the gentlest, yet the strongest thread</line>
      <line>Of our frail plant – a blossom from the tree</line>
      <line>Surviving the proud trunk – as though it said</line>
      <line>‘Patience and gentleness is power. In me</line>
      <line>Behold affectionate eternity!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY BRYAN</author>
    <date>1815</date>
    <title>To My Brother</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh transient sorrows, light as morning dews</line>
      <line>Chased with soon-rising beams –</line>
      <line>Yet oft sick fancy deems</line>
      <line>Portents of ill they came, since care’s worn hues</line>
      <line> O’ercast thy sister’s cheek, where stands a tear</line>
      <line>Unheeded or forgotten now</line>
      <line>Like cold drops on the pallid brow</line>
      <line>Of pain or fear.</line>
      <line>When, when wilt thou return?</line>
      <line>Since thou art far away,</line>
      <line>Each desolated day</line>
      <line>Has brought me much to mourn –</line>
      <line>And oh, my brother, if thou long shouldst roam,</line>
      <line>To her who loves thee best thou never wilt come home!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Sonnet on Chillon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Eternal spirit of the chainless mind!</line>
      <line>Brightest in dungeons, Liberty, thou art,</line>
      <line>For there thy habitation is the heart –</line>
      <line>The heart which love of thee alone can bind!</line>
      <line> And when thy sons to fetters are consigned –</line>
      <line>To fetters, and the damp vault’s dayless gloom –</line>
      <line>Their country conquers with their martyrdom,</line>
      <line>And Freedom’s fame finds wings on every wind.</line>
      <line>Chillon! thy prison is a holy place,</line>
      <line>And thy sad floor an altar – for ’twas trod,</line>
      <line>Until his very steps have left a trace,</line>
      <line>Worn (as if thy cold pavement were a sod)</line>
      <line>By Bonnivard! May none those marks efface –</line>
      <line>For they appeal from tyranny to God!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Sonnet to Lake Leman</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rousseau, Voltaire, our Gibbon, and De Staël!</line>
      <line>Leman, these names are worthy of thy shore –</line>
      <line>Thy shore of names like these! Wert thou no more,</line>
      <line>Their memory thy remembrance would recall!</line>
      <line> To them thy banks were lovely, as to all,</line>
      <line>But they have made them lovelier, for the lore</line>
      <line>Of mighty minds doth hallow in the core</line>
      <line>Of human hearts the ruin of a wall</line>
      <line>Where dwelt the wise and wondrous – but by thee</line>
      <line>How much more, Lake of Beauty, do we feel,</line>
      <line>In sweetly gliding o’er thy crystal sea,</line>
      <line>The wild glow of that not ungentle zeal,</line>
      <line>Which of the heirs of immortality</line>
      <line>Is proud, and makes the breath of glory real!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>On First Looking into Chapman’s Homer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Much have I travelled in the realms of gold,</line>
      <line>And many goodly states and kingdoms seen;</line>
      <line>Round many western islands have I been</line>
      <line>Which bards in fealty to Apollo hold.</line>
      <line> Oft of one wide expanse had I been told</line>
      <line>That deep-browed Homer ruled as his demesne;</line>
      <line>Yet did I never breathe its pure serene</line>
      <line>Till I heard Chapman speak out loud and bold!</line>
      <line>Then felt I like some watcher of the skies</line>
      <line>When a new planet swims into his ken;</line>
      <line>Or like stout Cortez when with eagle eyes</line>
      <line>He stared at the Pacific – and all his men</line>
      <line>Looked at each other with a wild surmise,</line>
      <line>Silent, upon a peak in Darien.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Great Spirits Now on Earth are Sojourning</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Great spirits now on earth are sojourning –</line>
      <line>He of the cloud, the cataract, the lake,</line>
      <line>Who on Helvellyn’s summit, wide awake,</line>
      <line>Catches his freshness from Archangel’s wing;</line>
      <line> He of the rose, the violet, the spring,</line>
      <line>The social smile, the chain for freedom’s sake;</line>
      <line>And lo! – whose steadfastness would never take</line>
      <line>A meaner sound than Raphael’s whispering.</line>
      <line>And other spirits there are, standing apart</line>
      <line>Upon the forehead of the age to come.</line>
      <line>These, these will give the world another heart</line>
      <line>And other pulses. Hear ye not the hum</line>
      <line>Of mighty workings? –</line>
      <line>Listen awhile ye nations, and be dumb!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>To Mrs Reynolds’ Cat</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cat, who has past thy grand climacteric,</line>
      <line>How many mice and rats hast in thy days</line>
      <line>Destroyed? How many titbits stolen? Gaze</line>
      <line>With those bright languid segments green, and prick</line>
      <line> Those velvet ears – but prithee do not stick</line>
      <line>Thy latent talons in me, and upraise</line>
      <line>Thy gentle mew, and tell me all the frays</line>
      <line>Of fish and mice, and rats and tender chick.</line>
      <line>Nay, look not down, nor lick thy dainty wrists –</line>
      <line>For all the wheezy asthma, and for all</line>
      <line>Thy tail’s tip is nicked off, and though the fists</line>
      <line>Of many a maid have given thee many a maul,</line>
      <line>Still is that fur as soft as when the lists</line>
      <line>In youth thou enteredst on glass-bottled wall!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>On Sitting Down to Read ‘King Lear’ Once Again</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh golden-tongued Romance, with serene lute!</line>
      <line>Fair pluméd syren, Queen of far-away!</line>
      <line>Leave melodizing on this wintry day –</line>
      <line>Shut up thine olden pages, and be mute.</line>
      <line> Adieu, for, once again, the fierce dispute</line>
      <line>Betwixt damnation and impassioned clay</line>
      <line>Must I burn through – once more humbly assay</line>
      <line>The bitter-sweet of this Shakespearean fruit.</line>
      <line>Chief poet! and ye clouds of Albion</line>
      <line>(Begetters of our deep eternal theme),</line>
      <line>When through the old oak forest I am gone,</line>
      <line>Let me not wander in a barren dream,</line>
      <line>But, when I am consuméd in the fire,</line>
      <line>Give me new phoenix-wings to fly at my desire.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>When I Have Fears that I May Cease to Be</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I have fears that I may cease to be</line>
      <line>Before my pen has gleaned my teeming brain,</line>
      <line>Before high-piléd books, in charactery,</line>
      <line>Hold like rich garners the full ripened grain;</line>
      <line> When I behold, upon the night’s starred face,</line>
      <line>Huge cloudy symbols of a high romance,</line>
      <line>And think that I may never live to trace</line>
      <line>Their shadows, with the magic hand of chance;</line>
      <line>And when I feel, fair creature of an hour,</line>
      <line>That I shall never look upon thee more,</line>
      <line>Never have relish in the fairy power</line>
      <line>Of unreflecting love – then on the shore</line>
      <line>Of the wide world I stand alone, and think</line>
      <line>Till love and fame to nothingness do sink.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Bright Star</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bright star, would I were steadfast as thou art!</line>
      <line>Not in lone splendour hung aloft the night</line>
      <line>And watching with eternal lids apart,</line>
      <line>Like Nature’s patient sleepless eremite,</line>
      <line> The moving waters at their priestlike task</line>
      <line>Of pure ablution round earth’s human shores;</line>
      <line>Or gazing on the new soft-fallen mask</line>
      <line>Of snow upon the mountains and the moors.</line>
      <line>No! Yet still steadfast, still unchangeable,</line>
      <line>Pillowed upon my fair Love’s ripening breast</line>
      <line>To feel for ever its soft fall and swell,</line>
      <line>Awake for ever in a sweet unrest –</line>
      <line>Still, still to hear her tender-taken breath,</line>
      <line>And so live ever: or else swoon to death.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>HORACE SMITH</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>In Egypt’s Sandy Silence</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Egypt’s sandy silence, all alone,</line>
      <line>Stands a gigantic leg, which far off throws</line>
      <line>The only shadows that the desert knows.</line>
      <line>‘I am great Ozymandias’, saith the stone,</line>
      <line> ‘The King of Kings – This mighty city shows</line>
      <line>The wonders of my hand!’ The city’s gone,</line>
      <line>Nought but the leg remaining to disclose</line>
      <line>The site of this forgotten Babylon.</line>
      <line>We wonder, and some hunter may express</line>
      <line>Wonder like ours, when through the wilderness</line>
      <line>Where London stood, holding the wolf in chase,</line>
      <line>He meets some fragment huge, and stops to guess</line>
      <line>What powerful but unrecorded race</line>
      <line>Once dwelt in that annihilated place.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>Ozymandias</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I met a traveller from an antique land</line>
      <line>Who said: ‘Two vast and trunkless legs of stone</line>
      <line>Stand in the desert. Near them on the sand,</line>
      <line>Half sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown,</line>
      <line> And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,</line>
      <line>Tell that its sculptor well those passions read</line>
      <line>Which yet survive (stamped on these lifeless things)</line>
      <line>The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed.</line>
      <line>And on the pedestal these words appear:</line>
      <line>“My name is Ozymandias, King of Kings;</line>
      <line>Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!”</line>
      <line>Nothing beside remains. Round the decay</line>
      <line>Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare</line>
      <line>The lone and level sands stretch far away.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Lift Not the Painted Veil</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lift not the painted veil which those who live</line>
      <line>Call life! Though unreal shapes be pictured there,</line>
      <line>And it but mimic all we would believe</line>
      <line>With colours idly spread, behind, lurk Fear</line>
      <line> And Hope, twin destinies, who ever weave</line>
      <line>Their shadows o’er the chasm, sightless and drear.</line>
      <line>I knew one who had lifted it: he sought</line>
      <line>(For his lost heart was tender) things to love,</line>
      <line>But found them not, alas – nor was there aught</line>
      <line>The world contains, the which he could approve.</line>
      <line>Through the unheeding many he did move,</line>
      <line>A splendour among shadows, a bright blot</line>
      <line>Upon this gloomy scene, a spirit that strove</line>
      <line>For truth, and like the Preacher found it not.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>Give Me the Gloomy Walk</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Give me the gloomy walk in summer-time</line>
      <line>That intersects the woods where Nature weaves</line>
      <line>Her bowers at will (that, close-encumbered, climb</line>
      <line>Dark overhead their many-mingling leaves),</line>
      <line> While curious anxiousness the bosom heaves</line>
      <line>The hidden beauties of the shade to find</line>
      <line>That in the negligence of summer lives;</line>
      <line>Each herb, leaf, noting of peculiar kind,</line>
      <line>And many a flower and many a nameless weed,</line>
      <line>Where eye scarce marks ’em ere they’re run to seed –</line>
      <line>And where the mossy stump invites to rest,</line>
      <line>And woodbines up the hazel’s stem proceed,</line>
      <line>Drop down and muse within one’s sheltered nest</line>
      <line>Or from one’s pocket take a book and read.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>A Wish</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be where I may when death brings in his bill</line>
      <line>Demanding payment for life’s lingering debt –</line>
      <line>Or in my native village nestling still,</line>
      <line>Or tracing scenes I’ve never known as yet –</line>
      <line> Oh let one wish (go where it will) be mine:</line>
      <line>To turn me back and wander home to die,</line>
      <line>’Mong nearest friends my latest breath resign,</line>
      <line>And in my churchyard wi’ my kindred lie,</line>
      <line>Neath the thick shade’s sycamores decay –</line>
      <line>Its broad leaves trembling to the breeze of day –</line>
      <line>To see its shadow o’er my ashes wave!</line>
      <line>How soothing will it be, while, hovering near,</line>
      <line>My unseen spirit haunts its daisied grave</line>
      <line>Pausing on scenes that life once loved so dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>The River Duddon: Afterthought</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I thought of thee, my partner and my guide,</line>
      <line>As being past away. Vain sympathies –</line>
      <line>For backward, Duddon, as I cast my eyes,</line>
      <line>I see what was, and is, and will abide.</line>
      <line> Still glides the stream, and shall forever glide</line>
      <line>(The form remains, the function never dies),</line>
      <line>While we, the brave, the mighty, and the wise –</line>
      <line>We men, who in our morn of youth defied</line>
      <line>The elements – must vanish. Be it so!</line>
      <line>Enough if something from our hands have power</line>
      <line>To live, and act, and serve the future hour;</line>
      <line>And if, as toward the silent tomb we go,</line>
      <line>Through love, through hope, and faith’s transcendent dower</line>
      <line>We feel that we are greater than we know.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>To Nature</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It may indeed be fantasy, when I</line>
      <line>Essay to draw from all created things</line>
      <line>Deep, heartfelt, inward joy that closely clings,</line>
      <line>And trace in leaves and flowers that round me lie</line>
      <line> Lessons of love and earnest piety.</line>
      <line>So let it be! And if the wide world rings</line>
      <line>In mock of this belief, it brings</line>
      <line>Nor fear, nor grief, nor vain perplexity.</line>
      <line>So will I build my altar in the fields,</line>
      <line>And the blue sky my fretted dome shall be,</line>
      <line>And the sweet fragrance that the wild-flower yields</line>
      <line>Shall be the incense I will yield to thee –</line>
      <line>Thee only, God! and thou shall not despise</line>
      <line>Even me, the priest of this poor sacrifice.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>Written in Keats’ ‘Endymion’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw pale Dian, sitting by the brink</line>
      <line>Of silver falls, the overflow of fountains</line>
      <line>From cloudy steeps; and I grew sad to think</line>
      <line>Endymion’s foot was silent on those mountains,</line>
      <line> And he but a hushed name, that Silence keeps</line>
      <line>In dear remembrance – lonely, and forlorn,</line>
      <line>Singing it to herself until she weeps</line>
      <line>Tears that perchance still glisten in the morn!</line>
      <line>And as I mused, in dull imaginings,</line>
      <line>There came a flash of garments, and I knew</line>
      <line>The awful Muse by her harmonious wings</line>
      <line>Charming the air to music as she flew.</line>
      <line>Anon there rose an echo through the vale</line>
      <line>Gave back Endymion in a dreamlike tale!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>HARTLEY COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>Long Time a Child</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Long time a child, and still a child when years</line>
      <line>Had painted manhood on my cheek, was I;</line>
      <line>For yet I lived like one not born to die –</line>
      <line>A thriftless prodigal of smiles and tears,</line>
      <line> No hope I needed, and I knew no fears.</line>
      <line>But sleep, though sweet, is only sleep; and waking,</line>
      <line>I waked to sleep no more, at once o’ertaking</line>
      <line>The vanguard of my age, with all arrears</line>
      <line>Of duty on my back. Nor child, nor man,</line>
      <line>Nor youth, nor sage, I find my head is grey,</line>
      <line>For I have lost the race I never ran!</line>
      <line>A rathe December blights my lagging May,</line>
      <line>And still I am a child, though I be old –</line>
      <line>Time is my debtor for my years untold.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1834</date>
    <title>To a Distant Scene</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still are the cowslips from thy bosom springing,</line>
      <line>Oh far-off, grassy dell? And dost thou see,</line>
      <line>When southern winds first wake their vernal singing,</line>
      <line>The star-gleam of the wood anemone?</line>
      <line> Doth the shy ring-dove haunt thee yet, the bee</line>
      <line>Hang on thy flowers as when I breathed farewell</line>
      <line>To their wild blooms? And, round my beechen tree,</line>
      <line>Still, in green softness, doth the moss-bank swell?</line>
      <line>Oh, strange illusion! by the fond heart wrought,</line>
      <line>Whose own warm life suffuses Nature’s.</line>
      <line>My being’s tide of many-coloured thought</line>
      <line>Hath passed from thee; and now, rich, leafy place,</line>
      <line>I paint thee oft, scarce consciously, a scene</line>
      <line>Silent, forsaken, dim, shadowed by what hath been.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>Be Frank with Me</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be frank with me, and I accept my lot;</line>
      <line>But deal not with me as a grieving child,</line>
      <line>Who for the loss of that which he hath not</line>
      <line>Is by a show of kindness thus beguiled!</line>
      <line> Raise not for me, from its enshrouded tomb,</line>
      <line>The ghostly likeness of a hope deceased;</line>
      <line>Nor think to cheat the darkness of my doom</line>
      <line>By wavering doubts how far thou art released.</line>
      <line>This dressing pity in the garb of love,</line>
      <line>This effort of the heart to seem the same,</line>
      <line>These sighs and lingerings (which nothing prove</line>
      <line>But that thou leavest me with a kind of shame),</line>
      <line>Remind me more, by their most vain deceit,</line>
      <line>Of the dear loss of all which thou dost counterfeit.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>The Castle of Chillon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair lake, thy lovely and thy haunted shore</line>
      <line>Hath only echoes for the poet’s lute;</line>
      <line>None may tread there save with unsandalled foot,</line>
      <line>Submissive to the great who went before,</line>
      <line> Filled with the mighty memories of yore.</line>
      <line>And yet how mournful are the records there –</line>
      <line>Captivity, and exile, and despair,</line>
      <line>Did they endure who now endure no more.</line>
      <line>The patriot, the woman, and the bard,</line>
      <line>Whose names thy winds and waters bear along;</line>
      <line>What did the world bestow for their reward</line>
      <line>But suffering, sorrow, bitterness, and wrong?</line>
      <line>Genius, a hard and weary lot is thine –</line>
      <line>Thy heart thy fuel, and the grave thy shrine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1783</date>
    <title>Fair Elenor</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The bell struck one and shook the silent tower;</line>
      <line>The graves gave up their dead – fair Elenor</line>
      <line>Walked by the castle gate, and lookéd in.</line>
      <line>A hollow groan ran through the dreary vaults!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She shrieked aloud, and sunk upon the steps</line>
      <line>On the cold stone her pale cheek. Sickly smells</line>
      <line>Of death issue as from a sepulchre,</line>
      <line>And all is silent but the sighing vaults.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Chill death withdraws his hand, and she revives!</line>
      <line>Amazed, she finds herself upon her feet,</line>
      <line>And, like a ghost, through narrow passages</line>
      <line>Walking, feeling the cold walls with her hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fancy returns, and now she thinks of bones,</line>
      <line>And grinning skulls, and corruptible death,</line>
      <line> Wrapped in his shroud; and now fancies she hears</line>
      <line>Deep sighs and sees pale sickly ghosts gliding.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length, no fancy – but reality –</line>
      <line>Distracts her. A rushing sound, and the feet</line>
      <line>Of one that fled, approaches! Ellen stood</line>
      <line>Like a dumb statue, froze to stone with fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wretch approaches, crying: ‘The deed is done!</line>
      <line>Take this, and send it by whom thou wilt send.</line>
      <line>It is my life – send it to Elenor –</line>
      <line>He’s dead, and howling after me for blood!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Take this!’ he cried, and thrust into her arms</line>
      <line>A wet napkin, wrapped about – then rushed</line>
      <line>Past, howling. She received into her arms</line>
      <line>Pale death, and followed on the wings of fear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They passed swift through the outer gate. The wretch,</line>
      <line>Howling, leaped o’er the wall into the moat,</line>
      <line>Stifling in mud. Fair Ellen passed the bridge,</line>
      <line>And heard a gloomy voice cry, ‘Is it done?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As the deer wounded, Ellen flew over</line>
      <line>The pathless plain! As the arrows that fly</line>
      <line> By night, destruction flies and strikes in darkness!</line>
      <line>She fled from fear, till at her house arrived.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her maids await her. On her bed she falls –</line>
      <line>That bed of joy, where erst her lord hath pressed.</line>
      <line>‘Ah, woman’s fear!’ she cried: ‘Ah, curséd duke!</line>
      <line>Ah, my dear lord! Ah, wretched Elenor!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My lord was like a flower upon the brows</line>
      <line>Of lusty May! Ah, life as frail as a flower!</line>
      <line>Oh ghastly Death, withdraw thy cruel hand –</line>
      <line>Seekest thou that flower to deck thy horrid temples?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> My lord was like a star in the highest heaven,</line>
      <line>Drawn down to earth by spells and wickedness;</line>
      <line>My lord was like the opening eyes of day,</line>
      <line>When western winds creep softly o’er the flowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But he is darkened – like the summer’s noon,</line>
      <line>Clouded – fallen like the stately tree cut down!</line>
      <line>The breath of heaven dwelt among his leaves.</line>
      <line>Oh Elenor, weak woman, filled with woe!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus having spoke, she raised up her head</line>
      <line>And saw the bloody napkin by her side,</line>
      <line> Which in her arms she brought – and now, tenfold</line>
      <line>More terrified, saw it unfold itself!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her eyes were fixed. The bloody cloth unfolds,</line>
      <line>Disclosing to her sight the murdered head</line>
      <line>Of her dear lord, all ghastly pale, clotted</line>
      <line>With gory blood. It groaned, and thus it spake:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O Elenor, behold thy husband’s head,</line>
      <line>Who, sleeping on the stones of yonder tower,</line>
      <line>Was reft of life by the accurséd Duke!</line>
      <line>A hiréd villain turned my sleep to death.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Oh Elenor, beware the curséd Duke –</line>
      <line>Oh give him not thy hand, now I am dead.</line>
      <line>He seeks thy love, who (coward in the night)</line>
      <line>Hiréd a villain to bereave my life.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She sat with dead cold limbs, stiffened to stone;</line>
      <line>She took the gory head up in her arms;</line>
      <line>She kisséd the pale lips; she had no tears to shed;</line>
      <line>She hugged it to her breast – and groaned her last!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>HELEN MARIA WILLIAMS</author>
    <date>1786</date>
    <title>Part of an Irregular Fragment Found in a Dark Passage of the Tower</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rise, winds of night! Relentless tempests rise!</line>
      <line>Rush from the troubled clouds, and o’er me roll –</line>
      <line>In this chill pause a deeper horror lies,</line>
      <line>A wilder fear appals my shuddering soul!</line>
      <line> ’Twas on this day, this hour accurst,</line>
      <line>That Nature, starting from repose,</line>
      <line>Heard the dire shrieks of murder burst –</line>
      <line>From infant innocence they rose,</line>
      <line>And shook these solemn towers!</line>
      <line>I shuddering pass that fatal room,</line>
      <line>For ages wrapped in central gloom –</line>
      <line>I shuddering pass that iron door</line>
      <line>Which Fate perchance unlocks no more:</line>
      <line>Death, smeared with blood, o’er the dark portal lowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> How fearfully my step resounds</line>
      <line>Along these onely bounds!</line>
      <line>Spare, savage blast, the taper’s quivering fires –</line>
      <line>Deep in these gathering shades its flame expires.</line>
      <line>Ye host of Heaven! the door recedes –</line>
      <line>It mocks my grasp – what unseen hands</line>
      <line>Have burst its iron bands!</line>
      <line>No mortal force this gate unbarred</line>
      <line>(Where danger lives, which terrors guard) –</line>
      <line>Dread powers! its screaming hinges close</line>
      <line> On this dread scene of impious deeds –</line>
      <line>My feet are fixed! Dismay has bound</line>
      <line>My step on this polluted ground –</line>
      <line>But lo! the pitying moon a line of light</line>
      <line>Athwart the horrid darkness dimly throws,</line>
      <line>And from yon grated window chases night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye visions that before me roll,</line>
      <line>That freeze my blood, that shake my soul!</line>
      <line>Are ye the phantoms of a dream?</line>
      <line>Pale spectres! are ye what ye seem?</line>
      <line> They glide more near –</line>
      <line>Their forms unfold!</line>
      <line>Fixed are their eyes, on me they bend –</line>
      <line>Their glaring look is cold!</line>
      <line>And hark! I hear</line>
      <line>Sounds that the throbbing pulse of life suspend...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But whence arose yon solemn call?</line>
      <line>Yon bloody phantom waves his hand,</line>
      <line>And beckons me to deeper gloom –</line>
      <line>Rest, troubled form, I come!</line>
      <line>Some unknown power my step impels</line>
      <line>To Horror’s secret cells...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1790</date>
    <title>Tam O’ Shanter</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When chapman billies leave the street,</line>
      <line>And drouthy neebors neebors meet;</line>
      <line>As market-days are wearing late,</line>
      <line>An’ folk begin to tak the gate;</line>
      <line> While we sit bousing at the nappy,</line>
      <line>An’ getting fou and unco happy,</line>
      <line>We think na on the lang Scots miles,</line>
      <line>The mosses, waters, slaps, and styles,</line>
      <line>That lie between us and our hame,</line>
      <line>Whare sits our sulky, sullen dame,</line>
      <line>Gathering her brows like gathering storm,</line>
      <line>Nursing her wrath to keep it warm!</line>
      <line>This truth fand honest Tam o’ Shanter,</line>
      <line>As he frae Ayr ae night did canter –</line>
      <line> Auld Ayr, wham ne’er a town surpasses,</line>
      <line>For honest men and bonnie lasses.</line>
      <line>Oh Tam, hadst thou but been sae wise</line>
      <line>As taen thy ain wife Kate’s advice!</line>
      <line>She tauld thee weel thou was a skellum,</line>
      <line>A blethering, blustering, drunken blellum –</line>
      <line>That frae November till October,</line>
      <line>Ae market-day thou was nae sober;</line>
      <line>That ilka melder wi’ the miller,</line>
      <line>Thou sat as lang as thou had siller;</line>
      <line> That ev’ry naig was caed a shoe on,</line>
      <line>The smith and thee gat roaring fou on;</line>
      <line>That at the Lord’s house, even on Sunday,</line>
      <line>Thou drank wi’ Kirkton Jean till Monday.</line>
      <line>She prophesied, that, late or soon,</line>
      <line>Thou would be found deep drowned in Doon,</line>
      <line>Or catched wi’ warlocks in the mirk</line>
      <line>By Alloway’s auld, haunted kirk.</line>
      <line>Ah! gentle dames, it gars me greet</line>
      <line>To think how monie counsels sweet,</line>
      <line> How monie lengthened, sage advices</line>
      <line>The husband frae the wife despises!</line>
      <line>But to our tale! Ae market-night,</line>
      <line>Tam had got planted unco right,</line>
      <line>Fast by an ingle, bleezing finely,</line>
      <line>Wi’ reaming swats, that drank divinely</line>
      <line>And at his elbow Souter Johnie,</line>
      <line>His ancient, trusty, drouthy cronie:</line>
      <line>(Tam loved him like a very brither –</line>
      <line>They had been fou for weeks thegither).</line>
      <line> The night drave on wi’ sangs and clatter,</line>
      <line>And ay the ale was growing better!</line>
      <line>The landlady and Tam grew gracious</line>
      <line>Wi’ secret favours, sweet and precious;</line>
      <line>The Souter tauld his queerest stories;</line>
      <line>The landlord’s laugh was ready chorus;</line>
      <line>The storm without might rair and rustle,</line>
      <line>Tam did na mind the storm a whistle.</line>
      <line>Care, mad to see a man sae happy,</line>
      <line>E’en drowned himsel amang the nappy!</line>
      <line> As bees flee hame wi’ lades o’ treasure,</line>
      <line>The minutes winged their way wi’ pleasure –</line>
      <line>Kings may be blest, but Tam was glorious,</line>
      <line>O’er a’ the ills o’ life victorious!</line>
      <line>But pleasures are like poppies spread –</line>
      <line>You seize the flower, its bloom is shed –</line>
      <line>Or like the snow falls in the river,</line>
      <line>A moment white, then melts for ever;</line>
      <line>Or like the borealis race,</line>
      <line>That flit ere you can point their place;</line>
      <line> Or like the rainbow’s lovely form</line>
      <line>Evanishing amid the storm.</line>
      <line>Nae man can tether time or tide –</line>
      <line>The hour approaches Tam maun ride –</line>
      <line>That hour, o’ night’s black arch the key-stane,</line>
      <line>That dreary hour Tam mounts his beast in,</line>
      <line>And sic a night he taks the road in</line>
      <line>As ne’er poor sinner was abroad in.</line>
      <line>The wind blew as ’twad blawn its last;</line>
      <line>The rattling showers rose on the blast;</line>
      <line> The speedy gleams the darkness swallowed;</line>
      <line>Loud, deep, and lang the thunder bellowed –</line>
      <line>That night, a child might understand,</line>
      <line>The Deil had business on his hand!</line>
      <line>Weel mounted on his grey mare Meg</line>
      <line>(Better never lifted leg)</line>
      <line>Tam skelpit on through dub and mire,</line>
      <line>Despising wind, and rain, and fire;</line>
      <line>Whiles holding fast his guid blue bonnet,</line>
      <line>Whiles crooning o’er some auld Scots sonnet,</line>
      <line> Whiles glow’ring round wi’ prudent cares,</line>
      <line>Lest bogles catch him unawares!</line>
      <line>Kirk-Alloway was drawing nigh,</line>
      <line>Whare ghaists and houlets nightly cry.</line>
      <line>By this time he was cross the ford,</line>
      <line>Whare in the snaw the chapman smoored;</line>
      <line>And past the birks and meikle stane,</line>
      <line>Whare drunken Charlie brak’s neck-bane;</line>
      <line>And through the whins, and by the cairn,</line>
      <line>Whare hunters fand the murdered bairn;</line>
      <line> And near the thorn, aboon the well,</line>
      <line>Whare Mungo’s mither hanged hersel.</line>
      <line>Before him Doon pours all his floods;</line>
      <line>The doubling storm roars through the woods;</line>
      <line>The lightning’s flash from pole to pole;</line>
      <line>Near and more near the thunders roll –</line>
      <line>When, glimmering through the groaning trees,</line>
      <line>Kirk-Alloway seemed in a bleeze:</line>
      <line>Through ilka bore the beams were glancing,</line>
      <line>And loud resounded mirth and dancing.</line>
      <line>Inspiring bold John Barleycorn,</line>
      <line>What dangers thou canst make us scorn!</line>
      <line>Wi’ tippenny, we fear nae evil;</line>
      <line>Wi’ usquabae, we’ll face the Devil!</line>
      <line>The swats sae reamed in Tammie’s noddle,</line>
      <line>Fair play, he cared na deils a boddle.</line>
      <line>But Maggie stood, right sair astonished,</line>
      <line>Till, by the heel and hand admonished,</line>
      <line>She ventured forward on the light,</line>
      <line>And, wow, Tam saw an unco sight! –</line>
      <line> Warlocks and witches in a dance –</line>
      <line>Nae cotillion, brent new frae France,</line>
      <line>But hornpipes, jigs, strathspeys and reels,</line>
      <line>Put life and mettle in their heels.</line>
      <line>A winnock-bunker in the east,</line>
      <line>There sat Auld Nick, in shape o’ beast</line>
      <line>(A tousie tyke, black, grim, and large) –</line>
      <line>To gie them music was his charge.</line>
      <line>He screwed the pipes and gart them skirl,</line>
      <line>Till roof and rafters a’ did dirl.</line>
      <line> Coffins stood round, like open presses,</line>
      <line>That shawed the dead in their last dresses;</line>
      <line>And, by some devilish cantraip sleight,</line>
      <line>Each in its cauld hand held a light –</line>
      <line>By which heroic Tam was able</line>
      <line>To note upon the haly table,</line>
      <line>A murderer’s banes, in gibbet-airns;</line>
      <line>Twa span-lang, wee, unchristened bairns;</line>
      <line>A thief new-cutted frae a rape</line>
      <line>(Wi’ his last gasp his gab did gape);</line>
      <line> Five tomahawks wi’ bluid red-rusted;</line>
      <line>Five scymitars wi’ murder crusted;</line>
      <line>A garter which a babe had strangled;</line>
      <line>A knife a father’s throat had mangled,</line>
      <line>Whom his ain son o’ life bereft –</line>
      <line>The grey-hairs yet stack to the heft! –</line>
      <line>Wi’ mair of horrible and awefu’,</line>
      <line>Which even to name wad be unlawfu’.</line>
      <line>As Tammie glowred, amazed and curious,</line>
      <line>The mirth and fun grew fast and furious;</line>
      <line> The piper loud and louder blew,</line>
      <line>The dancers quick and quicker flew,</line>
      <line>They reeled, they set, they crossed, they cleekit.</line>
      <line>Till ilka carlin swat and reekit,</line>
      <line>And coost her duddies to the wark,</line>
      <line>And linket at it in her sark!</line>
      <line>Now Tam, oh Tam – had thae been queans,</line>
      <line>A’ plump and strapping in their teens –</line>
      <line>Their sarks, instead o’ creeshie flannen,</line>
      <line>Been snaw-white seventeen-hunder linen,</line>
      <line> Thir breeks o’ mine (my only pair</line>
      <line>That ance were plush, o’ guid blue hair),</line>
      <line>I wad hae gi’en them off my hurdies</line>
      <line>For ae blink o’ the bonnie burdies!</line>
      <line>But withered beldams, auld and droll,</line>
      <line>Rigwoodie hags wad spean a foal,</line>
      <line>Louping and flinging on a crummock,</line>
      <line>I wonder did na turn thy stomach!</line>
      <line>But Tam kend what was what fu’ brawlie:</line>
      <line>There was ae winsome wench and wawlie</line>
      <line> That night enlisted in the core,</line>
      <line>Lang after kend on Carrick shore –</line>
      <line>For monie a beast to dead she shot,</line>
      <line>An’ perished monie a bonnie boat,</line>
      <line>And shook baith meikle corn and bear,</line>
      <line>And kept the country-side in fear!</line>
      <line>Her cutty sark, o’ Paisley harn,</line>
      <line>That while a lassie she had worn,</line>
      <line>In longitude though sorely scanty,</line>
      <line>It was her best, and she was vauntie.</line>
      <line> Ah, little kend thy reverend grannie,</line>
      <line>That sark she coft for her wee Nannie,</line>
      <line>Wi’ twa pund Scots (’twas a’ her riches),</line>
      <line>Wad ever graced a dance of witches!</line>
      <line>But here my Muse her wing maun cour,</line>
      <line>Sic flights are far beyond her power –</line>
      <line>To sing how Nannie lap and flang</line>
      <line>(A souple jade she was and strang),</line>
      <line>And how Tam stood like ane bewitched,</line>
      <line>And thought his very een enriched!</line>
      <line> Even Satan glowred, and fidged fu’ fain,</line>
      <line>And hotched and blew wi’ might and main;</line>
      <line>Till – first ae caper, syne anither –</line>
      <line>Tam tint his reason a’ thegither,</line>
      <line>And roars out: ’Weel done, Cutty-sark!’</line>
      <line>And in an instant all was dark;</line>
      <line>And scarcely had he Maggie rallied,</line>
      <line>When out the hellish legion sallied.</line>
      <line>As bees bizz out wi’ angry fyke,</line>
      <line>When plundering herds assail their byke;</line>
      <line> As open pussie’s mortal foes,</line>
      <line>When, pop! she starts before their nose;</line>
      <line>As eager runs the market-crowd,</line>
      <line>When ‘Catch the thief!’ resounds aloud –</line>
      <line>So Maggie runs; the witches follow,</line>
      <line>Wi’ monie an eldritch skriech and hollo!</line>
      <line>Ah, Tam! Ah, Tam! thou’ll get thy fairin –</line>
      <line>In hell they’ll roast thee like a herrin!</line>
      <line>In vain thy Kate awaits thy comin –</line>
      <line>Kate soon will be a woefu’ woman!</line>
      <line>Now, do thy speedy utmost, Meg,</line>
      <line>And win the key-stane of the brig;</line>
      <line>There, at them thou thy tail may toss,</line>
      <line>A running stream they dare na cross!</line>
      <line>But ere the key-stane she could make,</line>
      <line>The fient a tail she had to shake –</line>
      <line>For Nannie, far before the rest,</line>
      <line>Hard upon noble Maggie prest,</line>
      <line>And flew at Tam wi’ furious ettle!</line>
      <line>But little wist she Maggie’s mettle –</line>
      <line> Ae spring brought off her master hale,</line>
      <line>But left behind her ain grey tail:</line>
      <line>The carlin claught her by the rump,</line>
      <line>And left poor Maggie scarce a stump!</line>
      <line>Now, wha this tale o’ truth shall read,</line>
      <line>Ilk man, and mother’s son, take heed:</line>
      <line>Whene’er to drink you are inclined,</line>
      <line>Or cutty sarks run in your mind,</line>
      <line>Think, ye may buy the joys o’er dear –</line>
      <line>Remember Tam o’ Shanter’s mare!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>GOTTFRIED BÜRGER (trans. WILLIAM TAYLOR)</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Lenora</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>At break of day, with frightful dreams</line>
      <line>Lenora struggled sore:</line>
      <line>‘My William, art thou slaine’, say’d she,</line>
      <line>‘Or dost thou love no more?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He went abroade with Richard’s host,</line>
      <line>The Paynim foes to quell;</line>
      <line>But he no word to her had writt,</line>
      <line>An he were sick or well.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With sowne of trump, and beat of drum,</line>
      <line>His fellow-soldyers come –</line>
      <line>Their helmes bydeckt with oaken boughs,</line>
      <line>They seeke their long’d-for home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And ev’ry roade and ev’ry lane</line>
      <line>Was full of old and young,</line>
      <line> To gaze at the rejoicing band,</line>
      <line>To hail with gladsome toung.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Thank God!’ their wives and children saide,</line>
      <line>‘Welcome!’ the brides did saye;</line>
      <line>But greete or kiss Lenora gave</line>
      <line>To none upon that daye!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She askte of all the passing traine</line>
      <line>For him she wisht to see,</line>
      <line>But none of all the passing traine</line>
      <line>Could tell if livéd hee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And when the soldyers all were bye</line>
      <line>She tore her raven haire,</line>
      <line>And cast herself upon the growne</line>
      <line>In furious despaire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
