      <line>Her mother ran and lyfte her up,</line>
      <line>And claspéd in her arme:</line>
      <line>‘My child, my child, what dost thou ail?</line>
      <line>God shield thy life from harm!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O mother, mother, William’s gone!</line>
      <line>What’s all besyde to me?</line>
      <line> There is no mercye, sure, above –</line>
      <line>All, all were spar’d but hee!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Kneel downe, thy paternoster saye,</line>
      <line>’Twill calm thy troubled spright!</line>
      <line>The Lord is wyse, the Lord is good;</line>
      <line>What hee hath done is right.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O mother, mother, say not so!</line>
      <line>Most cruel is my fate –</line>
      <line>I prayde, and prayde, but watte avayl’d?</line>
      <line>’Tis now, alas! too late.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Our Heavenly Father, if we praye,</line>
      <line>Will help a suff’ring childe –</line>
      <line>Go take the holy sacrament,</line>
      <line>So shall thy grief grow milde.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O mother, what I feel within</line>
      <line>No sacrament can staye –</line>
      <line>No sacrament can teche the dead</line>
      <line>To bear the sight of daye!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘May be, among the heathen folk</line>
      <line>Thy William false doth prove,</line>
      <line>And puts away his faith and troth,</line>
      <line>And takes another love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then wherefore sorrow for his loss?</line>
      <line>Thy moans are all in vain:</line>
      <line>And when his soul and body parte,</line>
      <line>His falsehode brings him paine.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O mother, mother! gone is gone –</line>
      <line>My hope is all forlorne –</line>
      <line>The grave mie onlye safeguarde is:</line>
      <line>O, had I ne’er been borne!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Go out, go out, my lampe of life –</line>
      <line>In grislie darkness die!</line>
      <line>There is no mercye, sure, above –</line>
      <line>For ever let me die.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Almighty God! O do not judge</line>
      <line>My poor unhappy childe;</line>
      <line>She knows not what her lips pronounce,</line>
      <line>Her anguish makes her wilde.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My girl, forget thine earthly woe,</line>
      <line>And think on God and bliss;</line>
      <line> For so, at least, shall not thy soule</line>
      <line>Its heavenly bridegroom miss.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O mother, mother! what is blisse,</line>
      <line>And what the fiendis celle?</line>
      <line>With him ’tis Heaven any where,</line>
      <line>Without my William, Helle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Go out, go out, my lamp of life –</line>
      <line>In endless darkness die!</line>
      <line>Without him I must loathe the earth,</line>
      <line>Without him scorne the skye.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And so despaire did rave and rage</line>
      <line>Athwarte her boiling veins;</line>
      <line>Against the providence of Heaven</line>
      <line>She hurlde her impious strains.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She beet her breaste, and wrung her hands,</line>
      <line>And rollde her tearlesse eye,</line>
      <line>From rise of morne, till the pale stars</line>
      <line>Again did freeke the skye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When harke! abroade she hearde the trampe</line>
      <line>Of nimble-hooféd steed;</line>
      <line> She hearde a knighte with clank alighte,</line>
      <line>And climb the staire in speede.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And soon she herde a tinkling hande,</line>
      <line>That twirléd at the pin;</line>
      <line>And thro’ her door, that open’d not,</line>
      <line>These words were breathed in:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What ho! what ho! thy dore undoe –</line>
      <line>Art watching or asleepe?</line>
      <line>My love, dost yet remember mee,</line>
      <line>And dost thou laugh or weep?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Ah! William here so late at night!</line>
      <line>Oh! I have watchte and wak’d –</line>
      <line>Whence dost thou come? For thy return</line>
      <line>My herte has sorely ak’d!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘At midnight only we may ride –</line>
      <line>I come o’er land and sea –</line>
      <line>I mounted late, but soone I go!</line>
      <line>Aryse, and come with me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O William, enter first my bowre,</line>
      <line>And give me one embrace!</line>
      <line> The blasts athwarte the hawthorne hiss –</line>
      <line>Awayte a little space.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The blasts athwarte the hawthorn hiss,</line>
      <line>I may not harboure here –</line>
      <line>My spurre is sharpe, my courser pawes,</line>
      <line>My houre of flighte is nere.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All as thou lyest upon thy couch,</line>
      <line>Aryse, and mounte behinde –</line>
      <line>To-night we’le ride a thousand miles,</line>
      <line>The bridal bed to finde!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘How, ride to-night a thousand miles?</line>
      <line>Thy love thou dost bemocke –</line>
      <line>Eleven is the stroke that still</line>
      <line>Rings on within the clocke.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Looke up! the moone is bright, and we</line>
      <line>Outstride the earthlie men –</line>
      <line>I’ll take thee to the bridal bed</line>
      <line>And night shall end but then.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And where is, then, thy house and home,</line>
      <line>And where thy bridal bed?’</line>
      <line> ‘’Tis narrow, silent, chilly, dark –</line>
      <line>Far hence I rest my head!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And is there any room for mee,</line>
      <line>Wherein that I may creepe?’</line>
      <line>‘There’s room enough for thee and mee,</line>
      <line>Wherein that wee may sleepe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All as thou ly’st upon thy couch,</line>
      <line>Aryse, no longer stop –</line>
      <line>The wedding-guests thy coming waite,</line>
      <line>The chamber dore is ope!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> All in her sarke, as there she lay,</line>
      <line>Upon his horse she sprung;</line>
      <line>And with her lily hands so pale</line>
      <line>About her William clung.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And hurry-skurry forth they go,</line>
      <line>Unheeding wet or dry;</line>
      <line>And horse and rider snort and blow,</line>
      <line>And sparkling pebbles fly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How swift the flood, the mead, the wood,</line>
      <line>Aright, aleft, are gone!</line>
      <line> The bridges thunder as they pass,</line>
      <line>But earthlie sowne is none.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tramp, tramp, across the land they speede;</line>
      <line>Splash, splash, across the see –</line>
      <line>‘Hurrah! the dead can ride apace;</line>
      <line>Dost feare to ride with mee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moone is bryghte, and blue the nyghte –</line>
      <line>Dost quake the blast to stem?</line>
      <line>Dost shudder, mayde, to seeke the dead?’</line>
      <line>‘No, no, but what of them?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> How glumlie sownes yon dirgye song!</line>
      <line>Night-ravens flappe the wing!</line>
      <line>What knell doth slowlie toll ding-dong –</line>
      <line>The psalmes of death who sing?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It creeps, the swarthie funeral-traine,</line>
      <line>The corse is onn the beere;</line>
      <line>Like croke of todes from lonely moores,</line>
      <line>The chaunte doth meet the eere.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Go, bear her corse when midnight’s past,</line>
      <line>With song, and fear, and wayle;</line>
      <line> I’ve gott my wife, I take her home,</line>
      <line>My howre of wedlocke hayl!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lead forth, O clarke, the chaunting quire,</line>
      <line>To swell our nuptial song:</line>
      <line>Come, preaste, and reade the blessing soone –</line>
      <line>For bed, for bed we long!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They heede his calle, and husht the sowne –</line>
      <line>The biere was seene no more –</line>
      <line>And followde him ore feeld and flood</line>
      <line>Yet faster than before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Halloo! halloo! away they goe,</line>
      <line>Unheeding wet or drye;</line>
      <line>And horse and rider snort and blowe,</line>
      <line>And sparkling pebbles flye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How swifte the hill, how swifte the dale,</line>
      <line>Aright, aleft, are gone!</line>
      <line>By hedge and tree, by thorpe and towne,</line>
      <line>They gallop, gallop on.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tramp, tramp, across the land they speede,</line>
      <line>Splash, splash, across the see –</line>
      <line> ‘Hurrah! the dead can ride apace,</line>
      <line>Dost fear to ride with mee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look up, look up, an airy crewe</line>
      <line>In roundel daunces reele;</line>
      <line>The moone is bryghte, and blue the nyghte,</line>
      <line>Mayst dimlie see them wheele.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come to, come to, ye gostlie crew,</line>
      <line>Come to, and follow mee,</line>
      <line>And daunce for us the wedding-daunce,</line>
      <line>When we in bed shall be!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And brush, brush, brush, the ghostlie crew</line>
      <line>Come wheeling ore their heads,</line>
      <line>All rustling like the wither’d leaves</line>
      <line>That wyde the wirlwind spreads.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Halloo! halloo away they go,</line>
      <line>Unheeding wet or dry;</line>
      <line>And horse and rider snort and blowe,</line>
      <line>And sparkling pebbles flye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all that in the moonshyne lay,</line>
      <line>Behynde them fled afar;</line>
      <line> And backwarde scudded overhead</line>
      <line>The sky and every star.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tramp, tramp, across the lande they speede,</line>
      <line>Splash, splash, across the see:</line>
      <line>‘Hurrah! the dead can ride apace –</line>
      <line>Dost fear to ride with mee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I weene the cock prepares to crowe,</line>
      <line>The sand will soone be runne,</line>
      <line>I snuffe the earlye morning aire –</line>
      <line>Downe, downe, our work is done!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The dead, the dead, can ryde apace</line>
      <line>(Oure wed-bed here is fit),</line>
      <line>Oure race is ridde, oure journey ore,</line>
      <line>Oure endlesse union knit!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lo! an yren-grated gate</line>
      <line>Soon biggens to their viewe –</line>
      <line>He crackte his whyppe: the clangynge boltes,</line>
      <line>The doores asunder flewe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They pass, and ’twas on graves they trode –</line>
      <line>‘’Tis hither we are bounde!’ –</line>
      <line> And many a tombstone gostlie white</line>
      <line>Lay inn the moonshyne round.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when hee from his steede alytte,</line>
      <line>His armour, black as cinder,</line>
      <line>Did moulder, moulder all awaye,</line>
      <line>As were it made of tinder.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His head became a naked scull –</line>
      <line>Nor haire nor eyne had hee –</line>
      <line>His body grew a skeleton,</line>
      <line>Whylome so blythe of blee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And att his drye and boney heele</line>
      <line>No spur was left to be;</line>
      <line>And inn his witherde hande you might</line>
      <line>The scythe and houre-glasse see.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lo! his steede did thin to smoke,</line>
      <line>And charnel fires outbreathe;</line>
      <line>And pal’d, and bleach’d, then vanish’d quite</line>
      <line>The mayde from underneathe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And hollow howlings hung in aire,</line>
      <line>And shrekes from vaults arose –.</line>
      <line> Then knew the mayde she mighte no more</line>
      <line>Her living eyes unclose!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But onwarde to the Judgement-seat,</line>
      <line>Thro’ myste and moonlighte dreare,</line>
      <line>The gostlie crewe their flyghte persewe,</line>
      <line>And hollow inn her eare:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Be patient! tho’ thyne herte should breke,</line>
      <line>Arrayne not Heven’s decree –</line>
      <line>Thou nowe art of thie bodie refte,</line>
      <line>Thie soule forgiven bee!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>GOTTFRIED BÜRGER (trans. WILLIAM TAYLOR)</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>The Lass of Fair Wone</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beside the parson’s bower of yew</line>
      <line>Why strays a troubled spright,</line>
      <line>That peaks and pines, and dimly shines</line>
      <line>Thro’ curtains of the night?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Why steals along the pond of toads</line>
      <line>A gliding fire so blue,</line>
      <line>That lights a spot where grows no grass,</line>
      <line>Where falls no rain nor dew?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The parson’s daughter once was good,</line>
      <line>And gentle as the dove,</line>
      <line>And young and fair – and many came</line>
      <line>To win the damsel’s love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>High o’er the hamlet, from the hill</line>
      <line>Beyond the winding stream,</line>
      <line> The windows of a stately house</line>
      <line>In sheen of evening gleam.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There dwelt, in riot, rout, and roar,</line>
      <line>A lord so frank and free,</line>
      <line>That oft, with inward joy of heart,</line>
      <line>The maid beheld his glee –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Whether he met the dawning day</line>
      <line>In hunting trim so fine,</line>
      <line>Or tapers, sparkling from his hall,</line>
      <line>Beshone the midnight wine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He sent the maid his picture, girt</line>
      <line>With diamond, pearl, and gold,</line>
      <line>And silken-paper, sweet with musk,</line>
      <line>This gentle message told:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Let go thy sweethearts, one and all!</line>
      <line>Shalt thou be basely woo’d,</line>
      <line>That worthy art to gain the heart</line>
      <line>Of youths of noble blood?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The tale I would to thee bewray,</line>
      <line>In secret must be said:</line>
      <line> At midnight-hour I’ll seek thy bower –</line>
      <line>Fair lass, be not afraid!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the amorous nightingale</line>
      <line>Sings sweetly to his mate,</line>
      <line>I’ll pipe my quail-call from the field –</line>
      <line>Be kind, nor make me wait.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In cap and mantle clad he came,</line>
      <line>At night, with lonely tread,</line>
      <line>Unseen, and silent as a mist,</line>
      <line>And hush’d the dogs with bread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And when the amorous nightingale</line>
      <line>Sung sweetly to his mate,</line>
      <line>She heard his quail-call in the field,</line>
      <line>And, ah, ne’er made him wait!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The words he whisper’d were so soft</line>
      <line>They won her ear and heart –</line>
      <line>How soon will she who loves believe!</line>
      <line>How deep a lover’s art!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No lure, no soothing guise, he spar’d,</line>
      <line>To banish virtuous shame;</line>
      <line> He call’d on holy God above,</line>
      <line>As witness to his flame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He clasp’d her to his breast, and swore</line>
      <line>To be for ever true:</line>
      <line>‘O yield thee to my wishful arms,</line>
      <line>Thy choice thou shalt not rue!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And while she strove, he drew her on,</line>
      <line>And led her to the bower,</line>
      <line>So still, so dim – and round about</line>
      <line>Sweet smelt the beans in flower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> There beat her heart, and heav’d her breast,</line>
      <line>And pleaded every sense –</line>
      <line>And there the glowing breath of lust</line>
      <line>Did blast her innocence!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when the fragrant beans began</line>
      <line>Their sallow blooms to shed,</line>
      <line>Her sparkling eyes their lustre lost;</line>
      <line>Her cheek, its roses fled:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when she saw the pods increase,</line>
      <line>The ruddier cherries strain,</line>
      <line> She felt her silken robe grow tight,</line>
      <line>Her waist new weight sustain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the mowers went afield,</line>
      <line>The yellow corn to ted,</line>
      <line>She felt her burden stir within,</line>
      <line>And shook with tender dread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the winds of autumn hist</line>
      <line>Along the stubble-field;</line>
      <line>Then could the damsel’s piteous plight</line>
      <line>No longer be conceal’d.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Her sire, a harsh and angry man,</line>
      <line>With furious voice revil’d:</line>
      <line>‘Hence from my sight! I’ll none of thee –</line>
      <line>I harbour not thy child!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And fast, amid her fluttering hair,</line>
      <line>With clenchéd fist he gripes,</line>
      <line>And seiz’d a leathern thong, and lash’d</line>
      <line>Her side with sounding stripes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her lily skin, so soft and white,</line>
      <line>He ribb’d with bloody wales,</line>
      <line> And thrust her out – tho’ black the night,</line>
      <line>Tho’ sleet and storm assails.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up the harsh rock, on flinty paths,</line>
      <line>The maiden had to roam –</line>
      <line>On tottering feet she grop’d her way,</line>
      <line>And sought her lover’s home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘A mother thou has made of me,</line>
      <line>Before thou mad’st a wife:</line>
      <line>For this, upon my tender breast,</line>
      <line>These livid stripes are rife –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Behold!’ And then, with bitter sobs,</line>
      <line>She sank upon the floor:</line>
      <line>‘Make good the evil thou has wrought –</line>
      <line>My injur’d name restore!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Poor soul! I’ll have thee hous’d and nurs’d!</line>
      <line>Thy terrors I lament,</line>
      <line>Stay here – we’ll have some further talk –</line>
      <line>The old one shall repent.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I have no time to rest and wait –</line>
      <line>That saves not my good name –</line>
      <line> If thou with honest soul hast sworn,</line>
      <line>O leave me not to shame;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But at the holy altar be</line>
      <line>Our union sanctified:</line>
      <line>Before the people and the priest</line>
      <line>Receive me for thy bride.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Unequal matches must not blot</line>
      <line>The honours of my line –</line>
      <line>Art thou of wealth or rank for me</line>
      <line>To harbour thee as mine?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> What’s fit and fair I’ll do for thee:</line>
      <line>Shalt yet retain my love –</line>
      <line>Shalt wed my huntsman – and we’ll then</line>
      <line>Our former transports prove.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Thy wicked soul, hard-hearted man,</line>
      <line>May pangs in Hell await –</line>
      <line>Sure, if not suited for thy bride,</line>
      <line>I was not for thy mate!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go, seek a spouse of nobler blood,</line>
      <line>Nor God’s just judgements dread!</line>
      <line> So shall, ere long, some base-born wretch</line>
      <line>Defile thy marriage-bed –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, traitor, feel how wretched they</line>
      <line>In hopeless shame immerst –</line>
      <line>Then smite thy forehead on the wall,</line>
      <line>While horrid curses burst!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Roll thy dry eyes in wild despair –</line>
      <line>Unsooth’d thy grinning woe!’</line>
      <line>Thro’ thy pale temples fire the ball,</line>
      <line>And sink to fiends below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Collected then she started up</line>
      <line>And thro’ the hissing sleet,</line>
      <line>Thro’ thorn and briar, thro’ flood and mire,</line>
      <line>She fled with bleeding feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Where now’, she cry’d, ‘my gracious God!</line>
      <line>What refuge have I left?’</line>
      <line>And reach’d the garden of her home,</line>
      <line>Of hope in man bereft.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On hand and foot she feebly crawl’d</line>
      <line>Beneath the bower unblest,</line>
      <line> Where withering leaves and gathering snow</line>
      <line>Prepar’d her only rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There rending pains and darting throes</line>
      <line>Assail’d her shuddering frame;</line>
      <line>And from her womb a lovely boy</line>
      <line>With wail and weeping came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forth from her hair a silver pin</line>
      <line>With hasty hand she drew,</line>
      <line>And prest against its tender heart,</line>
      <line>And the sweet babe she slew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Erst when the act of blood was done,</line>
      <line>Her soul its guilt abhorr’d:</line>
      <line>‘My Jesus! what has been my deed?</line>
      <line>Have mercy on me, Lord!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With bloody nails, beside the pond,</line>
      <line>Its shallow grave she tore:</line>
      <line>‘There rest in God – there shame and want</line>
      <line>Thou can’st not suffer more!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Me vengeance waits! My poor, poor child,</line>
      <line>Thy wound shall bleed afresh,</line>
      <line> When ravens from the gallows tear</line>
      <line>Thy mother’s mould’ring flesh!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hard by the bower her gibbet stands;</line>
      <line>Her skull is still to show –</line>
      <line>It seems to eye the barren grave,</line>
      <line>Three spans in length below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That is the spot where grows no grass,</line>
      <line>Where falls no rain nor dew,</line>
      <line>Whence steals along the pond of toads</line>
      <line>A hovering fire so blue!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And nightly, when the ravens come,</line>
      <line>Her ghost is seen to glide;</line>
      <line>Pursues and tries to quench the flame,</line>
      <line>And pines the pool beside.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MATTHEW ‘MONK’ LEWIS</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Alonzo the Brave and the Fair Imogine</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A warrior so bold and a virgin so bright</line>
      <line>Conversed, as they sat on the green;</line>
      <line>They gazed on each other with tender delight –</line>
      <line>Alonzo the Brave was the name of the knight,</line>
      <line> The maid’s was the Fair Imogine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And, oh!’ said the youth, ‘since to-morrow I go</line>
      <line>To fight in a far-distant land,</line>
      <line>Your tears for my absence soon leaving to flow,</line>
      <line>Some other will court you, and you will bestow</line>
      <line>On a wealthier suitor your hand!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh hush these suspicions’, Fair Imogine said,</line>
      <line>‘Offensive to love and to me!</line>
      <line>For, if you be living, or if you be dead,</line>
      <line>I swear by the Virgin, that none in your stead</line>
      <line> Shall husband of Imogine be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if e’er for another my heart should decide,</line>
      <line>Forgetting Alonzo the Brave,</line>
      <line>God grant that, to punish my falsehood and pride,</line>
      <line>Your ghost at the marriage may sit by my side –</line>
      <line>May tax me with perjury, claim me as bride,</line>
      <line>And bear me away to the grave!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To Palestine hastened the hero so bold,</line>
      <line>His love she lamented him sore –</line>
      <line>But scarce had a twelvemonth elapsed when, behold,</line>
      <line> A Baron all covered with jewels and gold</line>
      <line>Arrived at Fair Imogine’s door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His treasure, his presents, his spacious domain,</line>
      <line>Soon made her untrue to her vows:</line>
      <line>He dazzled her eyes, he bewildered her brain,</line>
      <line>He caught her affections so light and so vain –</line>
      <line>And carried her home as his spouse,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now had the marriage been blest by the priest;</line>
      <line>The revelry now was begun;</line>
      <line>The tables they groaned with the weight of the feast –</line>
      <line> Nor yet had the laughter and merriment ceased,</line>
      <line>When the bell of the Castle tolled one!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then first with amazement Fair Imogine found</line>
      <line>That a stranger was placed by her side:</line>
      <line>His air was terrific; he uttered no sound;</line>
      <line>He spoke not, he moved not, he looked not around,</line>
      <line>But earnestly gazed on the bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His vizor was closed, and gigantic his height;</line>
      <line>His armour was sable to view;</line>
      <line>All pleasure and laughter were hushed at his sight;</line>
      <line> The dogs, as they eyed him, drew back in affright;</line>
      <line>The lights in the chamber burnt blue!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His presence all bosoms appeared to dismay;</line>
      <line>The guests sat in silence and fear;</line>
      <line>At length spoke the bride, while she trembled: ‘I pray</line>
      <line>Sir Knight, that your helmet aside you would lay,</line>
      <line>And deign to partake of our cheer.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lady is silent, the stranger complies –</line>
      <line>His vizor he slowly unclosed –</line>
      <line>Oh, then what a sight met Fair Imogine’s eyes!</line>
      <line> What words can express her dismay and surprise</line>
      <line>When a skeleton’s head was exposed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All present then uttered a terrified shout –</line>
      <line>All turned with disgust from the scene –</line>
      <line>The worms they crept in, and the worms they crept out,</line>
      <line>And sported his eyes and his temples about,</line>
      <line>While the spectre addressed Imogine:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Behold me, thou false one! Behold me!’ he cried,</line>
      <line>‘Remember Alonzo the Brave!</line>
      <line>God grants that, to punish thy falsehood and pride,</line>
      <line> My ghost at thy marriage should sit by thy side –</line>
      <line>Should tax thee with perjury, claim thee as bride,</line>
      <line>And bear thee away to the grave!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus saying, his arms round the lady he wound,</line>
      <line>While loudly she shrieked in dismay,</line>
      <line>Then sank with his prey through the wide-yawning ground –</line>
      <line>Nor ever again was Fair Imogine found,</line>
      <line>Or the spectre who bore her away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not long lived the Baron, and none since that time</line>
      <line>To inhabit the Castle presume;</line>
      <line> For chronicles tell that, by order sublime,</line>
      <line>There Imogine suffers the pain of her crime,</line>
      <line>And mourns her deplorable doom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At midnight four times in each year does her sprite,</line>
      <line>When mortals in slumber are bound,</line>
      <line>Arrayed in her bridal apparel of white,</line>
      <line>Appear in the hall with that skeleton-knight,</line>
      <line>And shriek as he whirls her around.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While they drink out of skulls newly torn from the grave,</line>
      <line>Dancing round them pale spectres are seen!</line>
      <line> Their liquor is blood, and this horrible stave</line>
      <line>They howl: ‘To the health of Alonzo the Brave,</line>
      <line>And his consort, the False Imogine!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Thorn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is a thorn, it looks so old</line>
      <line>In truth you’d find it hard to say</line>
      <line>How it could ever have been young,</line>
      <line>It looks so old and grey.</line>
      <line> Not higher than a two years’ child</line>
      <line>It stands erect, this agéd thorn.</line>
      <line>No leaves it has, no thorny points;</line>
      <line>It is a mass of knotted joints,</line>
      <line>A wretched thing forlorn.</line>
      <line>It stands erect, and like a stone</line>
      <line>With lichens it is overgrown.</line>
      <line>Like rock or stone, it is o’ergrown</line>
      <line>With lichens to the very top,</line>
      <line>And hung with heavy tufts of moss,</line>
      <line> A melancholy crop.</line>
      <line>Up from the earth these mosses creep,</line>
      <line>And this poor thorn they clasp it round</line>
      <line>So close you’d say that they were bent</line>
      <line>With plain and manifest intent</line>
      <line>To drag it to the ground,</line>
      <line>And all had joined in one endeavour</line>
      <line>To bury this poor thorn for ever.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>High on a mountain’s highest ridge</line>
      <line>(Where oft the stormy winter gale</line>
      <line> Cuts like a scythe, while through the clouds</line>
      <line>It sweeps from vale to vale),</line>
      <line>Not five yards from the mountain-path</line>
      <line>This thorn you on your left espy;</line>
      <line>And to the left, three yards beyond,</line>
      <line>You see a little muddy pond</line>
      <line>Of water, never dry.</line>
      <line>I’ve measured it from side to side:</line>
      <line>’Tis three feet long and two feet wide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And close beside this agéd thorn</line>
      <line> There is a fresh and lovely sight</line>
      <line>A beauteous heap, a hill of moss,</line>
      <line>Just half a foot in height.</line>
      <line>All lovely colours there you see,</line>
      <line>All colours that were ever seen,</line>
      <line>And mossy network too is there,</line>
      <line>As if by hand of lady fair</line>
      <line>The work had woven been –</line>
      <line>And cups, the darlings of the eye,</line>
      <line>So deep is their vermilion dye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ah me, what lovely tints are there</line>
      <line>Of olive-green and scarlet bright,</line>
      <line>In spikes, in branches, and in stars,</line>
      <line>Green, red, and pearly white!</line>
      <line>This heap of earth o’ergrown with moss,</line>
      <line>Which close beside the thorn you see</line>
      <line>So fresh in all its beauteous dyes,</line>
      <line>Is like an infant’s grave in size –</line>
      <line>As like as like can be –</line>
      <line>But never, never, anywhere</line>
      <line> An infant’s grave was half so fair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now would you see this agéd thorn,</line>
      <line>This pond and beauteous hill of moss,</line>
      <line>You must take care and choose your time</line>
      <line>The mountain when to cross.</line>
      <line>For oft there sits, between the heap</line>
      <line>That’s like an infant’s grave in size</line>
      <line>And that same pond of which I spoke,</line>
      <line>A woman in a scarlet cloak,</line>
      <line>And to herself she cries,</line>
      <line> “Oh misery! Oh misery!</line>
      <line>Oh woe is me, oh misery!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At all times of the day and night</line>
      <line>This wretched woman thither goes,</line>
      <line>And she is known to every star,</line>
      <line>And every wind that blows.</line>
      <line>And there beside the thorn she sits</line>
      <line>When the blue daylight’s in the skies,</line>
      <line>And when the whirlwind’s on the hill,</line>
      <line>Or frosty air is keen and still,</line>
      <line> And to herself she cries,</line>
      <line>“Oh misery! Oh misery!</line>
      <line>Oh woe is me, oh misery!”’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Now wherefore thus, by day and night,</line>
      <line>In rain, in tempest, and in snow,</line>
      <line>Thus to the dreary mountain-top</line>
      <line>Does this poor woman go?</line>
      <line>And why sits she beside the thorn</line>
      <line>When the blue daylight’s in the sky,</line>
      <line>Or when the whirlwind’s on the hill,</line>
      <line> Or frosty air is keen and still,</line>
      <line>And wherefore does she cry –</line>
      <line>Oh wherefore, wherefore, tell me why,</line>
      <line>Does she repeat that doleful cry?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I cannot tell, I wish I could,</line>
      <line>For the true reason no one knows;</line>
      <line>But if you’d gladly view the spot,</line>
      <line>The spot to which she goes –</line>
      <line>The heap that’s like an infant’s grave,</line>
      <line>The pond and thorn, so old and grey –</line>
      <line> Pass by her door (’tis seldom shut)</line>
      <line>And if you see her in her hut,</line>
      <line>Then to the spot away!</line>
      <line>I never heard of such as dare</line>
      <line>Approach the spot when she is there!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘But wherefore to the mountain-top</line>
      <line>Can this unhappy woman go,</line>
      <line>Whatever star is in the skies,</line>
      <line>Whatever wind may blow?’</line>
      <line>‘Nay, rack your brain, ’tis all in vain!</line>
      <line>I’ll tell you everything I know –</line>
      <line>But to the thorn, and to the pond</line>
      <line>Which is a little step beyond,</line>
      <line>I wish that you would go:</line>
      <line>Perhaps when you are at the place</line>
      <line>You something of her tale may trace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll give you the best help I can:</line>
      <line>Before you up the mountain go,</line>
      <line>Up to the dreary mountain-top,</line>
      <line>I’ll tell you all I know.</line>
      <line> ’Tis now some two-and-twenty years</line>
      <line>Since she (her name is Martha Ray)</line>
      <line>Gave with a maiden’s true good will</line>
      <line>Her company to Stephen Hill,</line>
      <line>And she was blithe and gay –</line>
      <line>And she was happy, happy still</line>
      <line>Whene’er she thought of Stephen Hill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And they had fixed the wedding-day –</line>
      <line>The morning that must wed them both –</line>
      <line>But Stephen to another maid</line>
      <line> Had sworn another oath,</line>
      <line>And with this other maid to church</line>
      <line>Unthinking Stephen went.</line>
      <line>Poor Martha, on that woeful day</line>
      <line>A cruel, cruel fire, they say,</line>
      <line>Into her bones was sent –</line>
      <line>It dried her body like a cinder,</line>
      <line>And almost turned her brain to tinder!</line>
      <line>They say, full six months after this,</line>
      <line>While yet the summer-leaves were green,</line>
      <line> She to the mountain-top would go,</line>
      <line>And there was often seen.</line>
      <line>’Tis said a child was in her womb,</line>
      <line>As now to any eye was plain:</line>
      <line>She was with child and she was mad –</line>
      <line>Yet often she was sober sad</line>
      <line>From her exceeding pain.</line>
      <line>Oh me, ten thousand times I’d rather</line>
      <line>That he had died, that cruel father!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sad case for such a brain to hold</line>
      <line> Communion with a stirring child –</line>
      <line>Sad case, as you may think, for one</line>
      <line>Who had a brain so wild!</line>
      <line>Last Christmas when we talked of this,</line>
      <line>Old Farmer Simpson did maintain</line>
      <line>That in her womb the infant wrought</line>
      <line>About its mother’s heart, and brought</line>
      <line>Her senses back again;</line>
      <line>And when at last her time drew near,</line>
      <line>Her looks were calm, her senses clear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> No more I know, I wish I did,</line>
      <line>And I would tell it all to you –</line>
      <line>For what became of this poor child</line>
      <line>There’s none that ever knew;</line>
      <line>And if a child was born or no,</line>
      <line>There’s no one that could ever tell;</line>
      <line>And if’twas born alive or dead,</line>
      <line>There’s no one knows, as I have said –</line>
      <line>But some remember well</line>
      <line>That Martha Ray about this time</line>
      <line> Would up the mountain often climb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all that winter, when at night</line>
      <line>The wind blew from the mountain-peak,</line>
      <line>’Twas worth your while, though in the dark,</line>
      <line>The churchyard-path to seek;</line>
      <line>For many a time and oft were heard</line>
      <line>Cries coming from the mountain-head.</line>
      <line>Some plainly living voices were,</line>
      <line>And others (I’ve heard many swear)</line>
      <line>Were voices of the dead –</line>
      <line> I cannot think, whate’er they say,</line>
      <line>They had to do with Martha Ray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But that she goes to this old thorn,</line>
      <line>The thorn which I’ve described to you,</line>
      <line>And there sits in a scarlet cloak,</line>
      <line>I will be sworn is true.</line>
      <line>For one day with my telescope,</line>
      <line>To view the ocean wide and bright</line>
      <line>(When to this country first I came,</line>
      <line>Ere I had heard of Martha’s name),</line>
      <line> I climbed the mountain’s height;</line>
      <line>A storm came on, and I could see</line>
      <line>No object higher than my knee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas mist and rain, and storm and rain!</line>
      <line>No screen, no fence, could I discover –</line>
      <line>And then the wind, in faith it was</line>
      <line>A wind full ten times over!</line>
      <line>I looked around, I thought I saw</line>
      <line>A jutting crag, and off I ran</line>
      <line>Head-foremost through the driving rain</line>
      <line> The shelter of the crag to gain,</line>
      <line>And, as I am a man,</line>
      <line>Instead of jutting crag I found</line>
      <line>A woman seated on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I did not speak – I saw her face –</line>
      <line>Her face it was enough for me!</line>
      <line>I turned about and heard her cry,</line>
      <line>“Oh misery! Oh misery!”</line>
      <line>And there she sits, until the moon</line>
      <line>Through half the clear blue sky will go;</line>
      <line>And when the little breezes make</line>
      <line>The waters of the pond to shake</line>
      <line>(As all the country know),</line>
      <line>She shudders, and you hear her cry,</line>
      <line>“Oh misery! Oh misery!”’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘But what’s the thorn, and what’s the pond,</line>
      <line>And what’s the hill of moss to her?</line>
      <line>And what’s the creeping breeze that comes</line>
      <line>The little pond to stir?’</line>
      <line>‘I cannot tell, but some will say</line>
      <line> She hanged her baby on the tree;</line>
      <line>Some say she drowned it in the pond,</line>
      <line>Which is a little step beyond;</line>
      <line>But all and each agree</line>
      <line>The little babe was buried there,</line>
      <line>Beneath that hill of moss so fair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve heard the scarlet moss is red</line>
      <line>With drops of that poor infant’s blood –</line>
      <line>But kill a new-born infant thus,</line>
      <line>I do not think she could!</line>
      <line> Some say, if to the pond you go</line>
      <line>And fix on it a steady view,</line>
      <line>The shadow of a babe you trace,</line>
      <line>A baby and a baby’s face,</line>
      <line>And that it looks at you –</line>
      <line>Whene’er you look on it, ’tis plain</line>
      <line>The baby looks at you again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And some had sworn an oath that she</line>
      <line>Should be to public justice brought;</line>
      <line>And for the little infant’s bones</line>
      <line> With spades they would have sought.</line>
      <line>But then the beauteous hill of moss</line>
      <line>Before their eyes began to stir,</line>
      <line>And for full fifty yards around</line>
      <line>The grass it shook upon the ground –</line>
      <line>But all do still aver</line>
      <line>The little babe is buried there,</line>
      <line>Beneath that hill of moss so fair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot tell how this may be,</line>
      <line>But plain it is the thorn is bound</line>
      <line> With heavy tufts of moss that strive</line>
      <line>To drag it to the ground.</line>
      <line>And this I know, full many a time</line>
      <line>When she was on the mountain high,</line>
      <line>By day, and in the silent night</line>
      <line>When all the stars shone clear and bright,</line>
      <line>That I have heard her cry,</line>
      <line>“Oh misery! Oh misery!</line>
      <line>Oh woe is me, oh misery!”’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Christabel, Part I</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis the middle of night by the Castle-clock,</line>
      <line>And the owls have awakened the crowing cock:</line>
      <line>Tu-whit! Tu-whoo!</line>
      <line>And hark, again! the crowing cock,</line>
      <line> How drowsily it crew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sir Leoline, the Baron rich,</line>
      <line>Hath a toothless mastiff bitch;</line>
      <line>From her kennel beneath the rock</line>
      <line>She makes answer to the clock,</line>
      <line>Four for the quarters, and twelve for the hour –</line>
      <line>Ever and aye, moonshine or shower,</line>
      <line>Sixteen short howls, not over loud</line>
      <line>(Some say, she sees my Lady’s shroud).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is the night chilly and dark?</line>
      <line> The night is chilly, but not dark.</line>
      <line>The thin grey cloud is spread on high –</line>
      <line>It covers but not hides the sky.</line>
      <line>The moon is behind, and at the full,</line>
      <line>And yet she looks both small and dull.</line>
      <line>The night is chill, the cloud is grey –</line>
      <line>’Tis a month before the month of May,</line>
      <line>And the spring comes slowly up this way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lovely lady, Christabel,</line>
      <line>Whom her father loves so well,</line>
      <line> What makes her in the wood so late,</line>
      <line>A furlong from the Castle-gate?</line>
      <line>She had dreams all yesternight</line>
      <line>Of her own betrothéd knight –</line>
      <line>Dreams that made her moan and leap</line>
      <line>As on her bed she lay in sleep –</line>
      <line>And she in the midnight-wood will pray</line>
      <line>For the weal of her lover that’s far away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She stole along, she nothing spoke,</line>
      <line>The breezes they were still also,</line>
      <line>And naught was green upon the oak</line>
      <line>But moss and rarest mistletoe;</line>
      <line> She kneels beneath the huge oak-tree,</line>
      <line>And in silence prayeth she.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lady leaps up suddenly,</line>
      <line>The lovely lady, Christabel!</line>
      <line>It moaned as near, as near can be,</line>
      <line>But what it is she cannot tell –</line>
      <line>On the other side it seems to be,</line>
      <line>Of the huge, broad-breasted, old oak-tree!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The night is chill; the forest bare;</line>
      <line>Is it the wind that moaneth bleak?</line>
      <line> There is not wind enough in the air</line>
      <line>To move away the ringlet-curl</line>
      <line>From the lovely lady’s cheek –</line>
      <line>There is not wind enough to twirl</line>
      <line>The one red leaf, the last of its clan,</line>
      <line>That dances as often as dance it can,</line>
      <line>Hanging so light, and hanging so high,</line>
      <line>On the topmost twig that looks up at the sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hush, beating heart of Christabel –</line>
      <line>Jesu, Maria, shield her well!</line>
      <line> She folded her arms beneath her cloak,</line>
      <line>And stole to the other side of the oak.</line>
      <line>What sees she there?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There she sees a damsel bright,</line>
      <line>Drest in a silken robe of white;</line>
      <line>Her neck, her feet, her arms, bare,</line>
      <line>And the jewels disordered in her hair.</line>
      <line>I guess, ’twas frightful there to see</line>
      <line>A lady so richly clad as she –</line>
      <line>Beautiful exceedingly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Mary mother, save me now!’</line>
      <line>Said Christabel, ‘and who art thou?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lady strange made answer meet,</line>
      <line>And her voice was faint and sweet:</line>
      <line>‘Have pity on my sore distress –</line>
      <line>I scarce can speak for weariness –</line>
      <line>Stretch forth thy hand, and have no fear!’</line>
      <line>Said Christabel, ‘How camest thou here?’</line>
      <line>And the lady, whose voice was faint and sweet,</line>
      <line>Did thus pursue her answer meet:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘My sire is of a noble line,</line>
      <line>And my name is Geraldine;</line>
      <line>Five warriors seized me yestermorn,</line>
      <line>Me, even me, a maid forlorn –</line>
      <line>They choked my cries with force and fright,</line>
      <line>And tied me on a palfrey white.</line>
      <line>The palfrey was as fleet as wind,</line>
      <line>And they rode furiously behind.</line>
      <line>They spurred amain, their steeds were white –</line>
      <line>And once we crossed the shade of night.</line>
      <line> As sure as Heaven shall rescue me,</line>
      <line>I have no thought what men they be;</line>
      <line>Nor do I know how long it is</line>
      <line>(For I have lain in fits, I wis)</line>
      <line>Since one, the tallest of the five,</line>
      <line>Took me from the palfrey’s back,</line>
      <line>A weary woman, scarce alive.</line>
      <line>Some muttered words his comrades spoke:</line>
      <line>He placed me underneath this oak,</line>
      <line>He swore they would return with haste –</line>
      <line> Whither they went I cannot tell.</line>
      <line>I thought I heard, some minutes past,</line>
      <line>Sounds as of a castle-bell.</line>
      <line>Stretch forth thy hand (thus ended she),</line>
      <line>And help a wretched maid to flee.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Christabel stretched forth her hand,</line>
      <line>And comforted fair Geraldine,</line>
      <line>Saying that she should command</line>
      <line>The service of Sir Leoline,</line>
      <line>And straight be convoyed, free from thrall,</line>
      <line>Back to her noble father’s hall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So up she rose, and forth they passed</line>
      <line>With hurrying steps, yet nothing fast.</line>
      <line>Her lucky stars the lady blest,</line>
      <line>And Christabel she sweetly said:</line>
      <line>‘All our household are at rest,</line>
      <line>Each one sleeping in his bed;</line>
      <line>Sir Leoline is weak in health,</line>
      <line>And may not well awakened be,</line>
      <line>So to my room we’ll creep in stealth,</line>
      <line> And you tonight must sleep with me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They crossed the moat, and Christabel</line>
      <line>Took the key that fitted well;</line>
      <line>A little door she opened straight,</line>
      <line>All in the middle of the gate –</line>
      <line>The gate that was ironed within and without,</line>
      <line>Where an army in battle-array had marched out.</line>
      <line>The lady sank, belike through pain,</line>
      <line>And Christabel with might and main</line>
      <line>Lifted her up, a weary weight,</line>
      <line> Over the threshold of the gate –</line>
      <line>Then the lady rose again,</line>
      <line>And moved as she were not in pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So free from danger, free from fear,</line>
      <line>They crossed the court – right glad they were!</line>
      <line>And Christabel devoutly cried</line>
      <line>To the lady by her side,</line>
      <line>‘Praise we the Virgin all divine</line>
      <line>Who hath rescued thee from thy distress!’</line>
      <line>‘Alas, alas!’ said Geraldine,</line>
      <line> ‘I cannot speak for weariness.’</line>
      <line>So free from danger, free from fear,</line>
      <line>They crossed the court – right glad they were!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Outside her kennel, the mastiff old</line>
      <line>Lay fast asleep, in moonshine cold.</line>
      <line>The mastiff old did not awake,</line>
      <line>Yet she an angry moan did make!</line>
      <line>And what can ail the mastiff bitch?</line>
      <line>Never till now she uttered yell</line>
      <line>Beneath the eye of Christabel –</line>
      <line> Perhaps it is the owlet’s scritch,</line>
      <line>For what can ail the mastiff bitch?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They passed the hall, that echoes still,</line>
      <line>Pass as lightly as you will!</line>
      <line>The brands were flat, the brands were dying,</line>
      <line>Amid their own white ashes lying;</line>
      <line>But when the lady passed there came</line>
      <line>A tongue of light, a fit of flame,</line>
      <line>And Christabel saw the lady’s eye –</line>
      <line>And nothing else saw she thereby,</line>
      <line> Save the boss of the shield of Sir Leoline tall,</line>
      <line>Which hung in a murky old niche in the wall.</line>
      <line>‘Oh softly tread’, said Christabel,</line>
      <line>‘My father seldom sleepeth well.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet Christabel her feet she bares,</line>
      <line>And they are creeping up the stairs</line>
      <line>(Now in glimmer, and now in gloom),</line>
      <line>And now they pass the Baron’s room,</line>
      <line>As still as death, with stifled breath!</line>
      <line>And now have reached her chamber-door,</line>
      <line> And now with eager feet press down</line>
      <line>The rushes of her chamber-floor.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moon shines dim in the open air,</line>
      <line>And not a moonbeam enters here;</line>
      <line>But they without its light can see</line>
      <line>The chamber carved so curiously –</line>
      <line>Carved with figures strange and sweet,</line>
      <line>All made out of the carver’s brain,</line>
      <line>For a lady’s chamber meet:</line>
      <line>The lamp with twofold silver chain</line>
      <line> Is fastened to an angel’s feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The silver lamp burns dead and dim;</line>
      <line>But Christabel the lamp will trim –</line>
      <line>She trimmed the lamp, and made it bright,</line>
      <line>And left it swinging to and fro,</line>
      <line>While Geraldine, in wretched plight,</line>
      <line>Sank down upon the floor below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh weary lady, Geraldine,</line>
      <line>I pray you, drink this cordial wine!</line>
      <line>It is a wine of virtuous powers –</line>
      <line> My mother made it of wild flowers.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And will your mother pity me,</line>
      <line>Who am a maiden most forlorn?’</line>
      <line>Christabel answered: ‘Woe is me!</line>
      <line>She died the hour that I was born.</line>
      <line>I have heard the gray-haired friar tell</line>
      <line>How on her deathbed she did say</line>
      <line>That she should hear the Castle-bell</line>
      <line>Strike twelve upon my wedding-day –</line>
      <line>Oh mother dear, that thou wert here!’</line>
      <line> ‘I would’, said Geraldine, ‘she were!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But soon with altered voice, said she,</line>
      <line>’Off, wandering mother! Peak and pine!</line>
      <line>I have power to bid thee flee.’</line>
      <line>Alas, what ails poor Geraldine?</line>
      <line>Why stares she with unsettled eye?</line>
      <line>Can she the bodiless dead espy?</line>
      <line>And why with hollow voice cries she,</line>
      <line>’Off, woman, off! This hour is mine –</line>
      <line>Though thou her guardian spirit be,</line>
      <line>Off, woman, off! – ’tis given to me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Christabel knelt by the lady’s side,</line>
      <line>And raised to Heaven her eyes so blue –</line>
      <line>‘Alas!’ said she, ‘this ghastly ride,</line>
      <line>Dear lady, it hath wildered you!’</line>
      <line>The lady wiped her moist cold brow,</line>
      <line>And faintly said, ‘’Tis over now!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Again the wild-flower wine she drank:</line>
      <line>Her fair large eyes ’gan glitter bright,</line>
      <line>And from the floor whereon she sank</line>
      <line> The lofty lady stood upright –</line>
      <line>She was most beautiful to see,</line>
      <line>Like a lady of a far countree!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus the lofty lady spake –</line>
      <line>‘All they who live in the upper sky,</line>
      <line>Do love you, holy Christabel!</line>
      <line>And you love them, and for their sake</line>
      <line>And for the good which me befel,</line>
      <line>Even I in my degree will try,</line>
      <line>Fair maiden, to requite you well.</line>
      <line> But now unrobe yourself, for I</line>
      <line>Must pray, ere yet in bed I lie.’</line>
      <line>Quoth Christabel, ‘So let it be!</line>
      <line>And as the lady bade, did she.</line>
      <line>Her gentle limbs did she undress,</line>
      <line>And lay down in her loveliness.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But through her brain, of weal and woe</line>
      <line>So many thoughts moved to and fro</line>
      <line>That vain it were her lids to close;</line>
      <line>So half-way from the bed she rose,</line>
      <line> And on her elbow did recline</line>
      <line>To look at the lady Geraldine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beneath the lamp the lady bowed,</line>
      <line>And slowly rolled her eyes around;</line>
      <line>Then, drawing in her breath aloud</line>
      <line>Like one that shuddered, she unbound</line>
      <line>The cincture from beneath her breast.</line>
      <line>Her silken robe and inner vest</line>
      <line>Dropt to her feet, and, full in view,</line>
      <line>Behold her bosom and half her side –</line>
      <line> A sight to dream of, not to tell!</line>
      <line>And she is to sleep with Christabel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet Geraldine nor speaks nor stirs;</line>
      <line>Ah! what a stricken look was hers!</line>
      <line>Deep from within she seems half-way</line>
      <line>To lift some weight with sick assay,</line>
      <line>And eyes the maid and seeks delay –</line>
      <line>Then suddenly, as one defied,</line>
      <line>Collects herself in scorn and pride,</line>
      <line>And lay down by the maiden’s side!</line>
      <line>And in her arms the maid she took,</line>
      <line>Ah wel-a-day!</line>
      <line>And with low voice and doleful look</line>
      <line>These words did say:</line>
      <line>‘In the touch of this bosom there worketh a spell,</line>
      <line>Which is lord of thy utterance, Christabel!</line>
      <line> Thou knowest to-night, and wilt know to-morrow,</line>
      <line>This mark of my shame, this seal of my sorrow;</line>
      <line>But vainly thou warrest,</line>
      <line>For this is alone in</line>
      <line>Thy power to declare,</line>
      <line>That in the dim forest</line>
      <line>Thou heardst a low moaning,</line>
      <line>And foundst a bright lady, surpassingly fair;</line>
      <line>And didst bring her home with thee in love and in charity,</line>
      <line>To shield her and shelter her from the damp air.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>The Old Woman of Berkeley</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The raven croaked as she sat at her meal</line>
      <line>And the Old Woman knew what she said,</line>
      <line>And she grew pale at the raven’s tale</line>
      <line>And sickened and went to her bed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Now fetch me my children, and fetch them with speed’,</line>
      <line>The Old Woman of Berkeley said –</line>
      <line>‘The Monk, my son, and my daughter the Nun,</line>
      <line>Bid them hasten, or I shall be dead.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Monk, her son, and her daughter the Nun</line>
      <line>Their way to Berkeley went,</line>
      <line>And they have brought, with pious thought,</line>
      <line>The holy sacrament.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Old Woman shrieked as they entered the door,</line>
      <line>And she cried with a voice of despair:</line>
      <line> ‘Now take away the sacrament,</line>
      <line>For its presence I cannot bear!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her lip it trembled with agony,</line>
      <line>The sweat ran down her brow:</line>
      <line>‘I have tortures in store for evermore,</line>
      <line>But spare me, my children, now!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away they sent the sacrament,</line>
      <line>The fit it left her weak,</line>
      <line>She looked at her children with ghastly eyes</line>
      <line>And faintly struggled to speak:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘All kinds of sin I have rioted in,</line>
      <line>And the Judgment now must be –</line>
      <line>But I secured my children’s souls,</line>
      <line>Oh, pray, my children, for me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have ’nointed myself with infants’ fat –</line>
      <line>The fiends have been my slaves –</line>
      <line>From sleeping babes I have sucked the breath,</line>
      <line>And, breaking by charms the sleep of death,</line>
      <line>I have called the dead from their graves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the Devil will fetch me now in fire,</line>
      <line> My witchcrafts to atone;</line>
      <line>And I who have troubled the dead man’s grave</line>
      <line>Shall never have rest in my own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bless, I entreat, my winding-sheet,</line>
      <line>My children, I beg of you;</line>
      <line>And with holy water sprinkle my shroud –</line>
      <line>And sprinkle my coffin too!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And let me be chained in my coffin of stone,</line>
      <line>And fasten it strong, I implore,</line>
      <line>With iron bars – and with three chains</line>
      <line> Chain it to the church-floor!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And bless the chains, and sprinkle them,</line>
      <line>And let fifty priests stand round,</line>
      <line>Who night and day the mass may say</line>
      <line>When I lie on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And see that fifty choristers</line>
      <line>Beside the bier attend me,</line>
      <line>And day and night by the taper’s light</line>
      <line>With holy hymns defend me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the church-bells all, both great and small,</line>
      <line> Be tolled by night and day,</line>
      <line>To drive from thence the fiends who come</line>
      <line>To bear my body away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And ever have the church-door barred,</line>
      <line>After the Evensong –</line>
      <line>And I beseech you, children dear,</line>
      <line>Let the bars and bolts be strong.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And let this be three days and nights,</line>
      <line>My wretched corpse to save –</line>
      <line>Till the fourth morning keep me safe,</line>
      <line> And then I may rest in my grave.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Old Woman of Berkeley laid her down,</line>
      <line>And her eyes grew deadly dim;</line>
      <line>Short came her breath, and the struggle of death</line>
      <line>Did loosen every limb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They blessed the Old Woman’s winding-sheet</line>
      <line>With rites and prayers due;</line>
      <line>With holy water they sprinkled her shroud,</line>
      <line>And they sprinkled her coffin too.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And they chained her in her coffin of stone,</line>
      <line> And with iron barred it down,</line>
      <line>And in the church with three strong chains</line>
      <line>They chained it to the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And they blessed the chains and sprinkled them,</line>
      <line>And fifty priests stood round</line>
      <line>By night and day the mass to say</line>
      <line>Where she lay on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And fifty sacred choristers</line>
      <line>Beside the bier attend her,</line>
      <line>Who day and night, by tapers’ light,</line>
      <line> Should with holy hymns defend her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To see the priests and choristers</line>
      <line>It was a goodly sight,</line>
      <line>Each holding (as it were a staff)</line>
      <line>A taper burning bright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the church-bells all, both loud and small,</line>
      <line>Did toll so loud and long;</line>
      <line>And they have barred the church-door hard,</line>
      <line>After the Evensong.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the first night, the tapers’ light</line>
      <line> Burnt steadily and clear;</line>
      <line>But they, without, an hideous rout</line>
      <line>Of angry fiends could hear –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A hideous roar at the church-door</line>
      <line>Like a long thunder-peal –</line>
      <line>And the priests they prayed, and the choristers sung,</line>
      <line>Louder in fearful zeal!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Loud tolled the bell, the priests prayed well,</line>
      <line>The tapers they burnt bright;</line>
      <line>The Monk her son, and her daughter the Nun,</line>
      <line>They told their beads all night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cock he crew, the fiends they flew</line>
      <line>From the voice of the morning away;</line>
      <line>Then undisturbed the choristers sing,</line>
      <line>And the fifty priests they pray:</line>
      <line>As they had sung and prayed all night,</line>
      <line>They prayed and sung all day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The second night the taper’s light</line>
      <line>Burnt dismally and blue,</line>
      <line>And everyone saw his neighbour’s face</line>
      <line> Like a dead man’s face to view.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And yells and cries, without, arise</line>
      <line>That the stoutest heart might shock,</line>
      <line>And a deafening roaring, like a cataract pouring</line>
      <line>Over a mountain-rock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Monk and Nun they told their beads</line>
      <line>As fast as they could tell,</line>
      <line>And aye as louder grew the noise</line>
      <line>The faster went the bell!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Louder and louder the choristers sung</line>
      <line> As they trembled more and more;</line>
      <line>And the priests, as they prayed to Heaven for aid,</line>
      <line>They smote their breasts full sore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cock he crew, the fiends they flew</line>
      <line>From the voice of the morning away;</line>
      <line>Then undisturbed the choristers sing,</line>
      <line>And the fifty priests they pray:</line>
      <line>As they had sung and prayed all night,</line>
      <line>They prayed and sung all day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The third night came, and the tapers’ flame</line>
      <line> A frightful stench did make,</line>
      <line>And they burnt as though they had been dipped</line>
      <line>In the burning brimstone lake!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the loud commotion, like the rushing of ocean,</line>
      <line>Grew momently more and more;</line>
      <line>And strokes as of a battering-ram</line>
      <line>Did shake the strong church-door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The bellmen, they for very fear</line>
      <line>Could toll the bell no longer;</line>
      <line>And still as louder grew the strokes,</line>
      <line> Their fear it grew the stronger.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Monk and Nun forgot their beads –</line>
      <line>They fell on the ground in dismay –</line>
      <line>There was not a single saint in Heaven</line>
      <line>To whom they did not pray!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the choristers’ song, which late was so strong,</line>
      <line>Faltered with consternation,</line>
      <line>For the church did rock as an earthquake-shock</line>
      <line>Uplifted its foundation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And a sound was heard like the trumpet-blast</line>
      <line> That shall one day wake the dead;</line>
      <line>The strong church-door could bear no more,</line>
      <line>And the bolts and the bars they fled;</line>
      <line>And the tapers’ light was extinguished quite</line>
      <line>And the choristers faintly sung;</line>
      <line>And the priests dismayed, panted and prayed,</line>
      <line>And on all saints in Heaven for aid</line>
      <line>They called with trembling tongue!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in He came with eyes of flame,</line>
      <line>The Devil to fetch the dead,</line>
      <line> And all the church with his presence glowed</line>
      <line>Like a fiery furnace red.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He laid his hand on the iron chains,</line>
      <line>And like flax they mouldered asunder,</line>
      <line>And the coffin-lid, which was barred so firm,</line>
      <line>He burst with his voice of thunder.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he bade the old Woman of Berkeley rise,</line>
      <line>And come with her master away –</line>
      <line>A cold sweat started on that cold corpse</line>
      <line>At the voice she was forced to obey!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She rose on her feet in her winding-sheet,</line>
      <line>Her dead flesh quivered with fear,</line>
      <line>And a groan like that which the Old Woman gave</line>
      <line>Never did mortal hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She followed her Master to the church-door –</line>
      <line>There stood a black horse there,</line>
      <line>His breath was red like furnace-smoke,</line>
      <line>His eyes like a meteor’s glare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Devil he flung her on the horse,</line>
      <line>And he leapt up before,</line>
      <line> And away like the lightning’s speed they went,</line>
      <line>And she was seen no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They saw her no more, but her cries</line>
      <line>For four miles round they could hear,</line>
      <line>And children at rest at their mother’s breast</line>
      <line>Started, and screamed with fear!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1800</date>
    <title>The Haunted Beach</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upon a lonely desert beach</line>
      <line>Where the white foam was scattered,</line>
      <line>A little shed upreared its head</line>
      <line>Though lofty barks were shattered.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The sea-weeds gathering near the door</line>
      <line>A sombre path displayed;</line>
      <line>And, all around, the deafening roar</line>
      <line>Re-echoed on the chalky shore,</line>
      <line>By the green billows made.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Above a jutting cliff was seen</line>
      <line>Where sea-birds hovered, craving;</line>
      <line>And all around the crags were bound</line>
      <line>With weeds – for ever waving.</line>
      <line>And here and there, a cavern wide</line>
      <line> Its shadowy jaws displayed;</line>
      <line>And near the sands, at ebb of tide,</line>
      <line>A shivered mast was seen to ride</line>
      <line>Where the green billows strayed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And often, while the moaning wind</line>
      <line>Stole o’er the summer ocean,</line>
      <line>The moonlight scene was all serene,</line>
      <line>The waters scarce in motion;</line>
      <line>Then, while the smoothly slanting sand</line>
      <line>The tall cliff wrapped in shade,</line>
      <line> The fisherman beheld a band</line>
      <line>Of spectres gliding hand in hand –</line>
      <line>Where the green billows played.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And pale their faces were as snow,</line>
      <line>And sullenly they wandered;</line>
      <line>And to the skies with hollow eyes</line>
      <line>They looked as though they pondered.</line>
      <line>And sometimes, from their hammock-shroud,</line>
      <line>They dismal howlings made,</line>
      <line>And while the blast blew strong and loud</line>
      <line> The clear moon marked the ghastly crowd,</line>
      <line>Where the green billows played!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then above the haunted hut</line>
      <line>The curlews screaming hovered;</line>
      <line>And the low door, with furious roar,</line>
      <line>The frothy breakers covered.</line>
      <line>For in the fisherman’s lone shed</line>
      <line>A murdered man was laid,</line>
      <line>With ten wide gashes in his head,</line>
      <line>And deep was made his sandy bed</line>
      <line> Where the green billows played.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A shipwrecked mariner was he,</line>
      <line>Doomed from his home to sever,</line>
      <line>Who swore to be through wind and sea</line>
      <line>Firm and undaunted ever!</line>
      <line>And when the wave resistless rolled,</line>
      <line>About his arm he made</line>
      <line>A packet rich of Spanish gold,</line>
      <line>And, like a British sailor bold,</line>
      <line>Plunged where the billows played!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The spectre band, his messmates brave,</line>
      <line>Sunk in the yawning ocean,</line>
      <line>While to the mast he lashed him fast,</line>
      <line>And braved the storm’s commotion.</line>
      <line>The winter moon upon the sand</line>
      <line>A silvery carpet made,</line>
      <line>And marked the sailor reach the land,</line>
      <line>And marked his murderer wash his hand</line>
      <line>Where the green billows played.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And since that hour the fisherman</line>
      <line> Has toiled and toiled in vain;</line>
      <line>For all the night the moony light</line>
      <line>Gleams on the spectered main!</line>
      <line>And when the skies are veiled in gloom,</line>
      <line>The murderer’s liquid way</line>
      <line>Bounds o’er the deeply yawning tomb,</line>
      <line>And flashing fires the sands illume,</line>
      <line>Where the green billows play!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full thirty years his task has been,</line>
      <line>Day after day more weary;</line>
      <line> For Heaven designed his guilty mind</line>
      <line>Should dwell on prospects dreary.</line>
      <line>Bound by a strong and mystic chain,</line>
      <line>He has not power to stray;</line>
      <line>But destined misery to sustain,</line>
      <line>He wastes, in solitude and pain,</line>
      <line>A loathsome life away.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WALTER SCOTT</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>From The Lay of the Last Minstrel</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>If thou wouldst view fair Melrose aright,</line>
      <line>Go visit it by the pale moon-light;</line>
      <line>For the gay beams of lightsome day</line>
      <line>Gild, but to flout, the ruins grey.</line>
      <line> When the broken arches are black in night,</line>
      <line>And each shafted oriel glimmers white;</line>
      <line>When the cold light’s uncertain shower</line>
      <line>Streams on the ruined central tower;</line>
      <line>When buttress and buttress, alternately,</line>
      <line>Seem framed of ebon and ivory;</line>
      <line>When silver edges the imagery,</line>
      <line>And the scrolls that teach thee to live and die;</line>
      <line>When distant Tweed is heard to rave,</line>
      <line>And the owlet to hoot o’er the dead man’s grave;</line>
      <line> Then go – but go alone the while –</line>
      <line>Then view St David’s ruined pile;</line>
      <line>And, home returning, soothly swear,</line>
      <line>Was never scene so sad and fair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Short halt did Deloraine make there;</line>
      <line>Little recked he of the scene so fair.</line>
      <line>With dagger’s hilt, on the wicket strong,</line>
      <line>He struck full loud, and struck full long.</line>
      <line>The porter hurried to the gate –</line>
      <line>‘Who knocks so loud, and knocks so late?’</line>
      <line> ‘From Branksome I’, the warrior cried;</line>
      <line>And strait the wicket opened wide:</line>
      <line>For Branksome’s chiefs had in battle stood,</line>
      <line>To fence the rights of fair Melrose;</line>
      <line>And lands and livings, many a rood,</line>
      <line>Had gifted the shrine for their souls’ repose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bold Deloraine his errand said;</line>
      <line>The porter bent his humble head;</line>
      <line>With torch in hand, and foot unshod,</line>
      <line>And noiseless step, the path he trod;</line>
      <line> The archéd cloisters, far and wide,</line>
      <line>Rang to the warrior’s clanking stride;</line>
      <line>Till, stooping low his lofty crest,</line>
      <line>He entered the cell of the ancient priest,</line>
      <line>And lifted his barréd aventayle,</line>
      <line>To hail the Monk of St Mary’s aisle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The Ladye of Branksome greets thee by me –</line>
      <line>Says that the fated hour is come,</line>
      <line>And that to-night I shall watch with thee,</line>
      <line>To win the treasure of the tomb.’</line>
      <line> From sackcloth couch the Monk arose,</line>
      <line>With toil his stiffened limbs he reared</line>
      <line>(A hundred years had flung their snows</line>
      <line>On his thin locks and floating beard),</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And strangely on the knight looked he,</line>
      <line>And his blue eyes gleamed wild and wide:</line>
      <line>‘And, darest thou, warrior, seek to see</line>
      <line>What Heaven and Hell alike would hide ?</line>
      <line>My breast, in belt of iron pent,</line>
      <line>With shirt of hair and scourge of thorn,</line>
