      <line> For threescore years, in penance spent,</line>
      <line>My knees those flinty stones have worn –</line>
      <line>Yet all too little to atone</line>
      <line>For knowing what should ne’er be known.</line>
      <line>Wouldst thou thy every future year</line>
      <line>In ceaseless prayer and penance drie,</line>
      <line>Yet wait thy latter end with fear? –</line>
      <line>Then, daring warrior, follow me !’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Penance, father, will I none!</line>
      <line>Prayer know I hardly one –</line>
      <line> For mass or prayer can I rarely tarry,</line>
      <line>Save to patter an Avé Mary</line>
      <line>When I ride on a Border foray –</line>
      <line>Other prayer can I none</line>
      <line>So speed me my errand, and let me be gone.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Again on the Knight looked the Churchman old</line>
      <line>And again he sighed heavily;</line>
      <line>For he had himself been a warrior bold,</line>
      <line>And fought in Spain and Italy.</line>
      <line>And he thought on the days that were long since bye,</line>
      <line> When his limbs were strong, and his courage was high;</line>
      <line>Now, slow and faint, he led the way,</line>
      <line>Where, cloistered round, the garden lay;</line>
      <line>The pillared arches were over their head,</line>
      <line>And beneath their feet were the bones of the dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spreading herbs and flowerets bright,</line>
      <line>Glistened with the dew of night;</line>
      <line>Nor herb nor floweret glistened there,</line>
      <line>But was carved in the cloister arches as fair.</line>
      <line>The Monk gazed long on the lovely moon,</line>
      <line> Then into the night he lookéd forth;</line>
      <line>And red and bright the streamers light</line>
      <line>Were dancing in the glowing north.</line>
      <line>So had he seen, in fair Castile,</line>
      <line>The youth in glittering squadrons start;</line>
      <line>Sudden the flying jennet wheel,</line>
      <line>And hurl the unexpected dart.</line>
      <line>He knew, by the streamers that shot so bright,</line>
      <line>That spirits were riding the northern light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By a steel-clenchéd postern-door,</line>
      <line> They entered now the chancel tall;</line>
      <line>The darkened roof rose high aloof</line>
      <line>On pillars lofty, and light, and small;</line>
      <line>The keystone, that locked each ribbéd aisle,</line>
      <line>Was a fleur-de-lys, or a quatre-feuille;</line>
      <line>The corbells were carved grotesque and grim;</line>
      <line>And the pillars, with clustered shafts so trim,</line>
      <line>With plinth and with capital flourished around,</line>
      <line>Seemed bundles of lances which garlands had bound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full many a scutcheon and banner riven</line>
      <line>Shook to the cold night-wind of heaven,</line>
      <line>Around the screenéd altar’s pale;</line>
      <line>And there the dying lamps did burn,</line>
      <line>Before thy low and lonely urn,</line>
      <line>Oh gallant chief of Otterburne,</line>
      <line>And thine, dark knight of Liddesdale!</line>
      <line>Oh fading honours of the dead!</line>
      <line>Oh high ambition, lowly laid!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moon on the east oriel shone,</line>
      <line>Through slender shafts of shapely stone,</line>
      <line> By foliaged tracery combined;</line>
      <line>Thou wouldst have thought some fairy’s hand,</line>
      <line>’Twixt poplars straight, the osier wand,</line>
      <line>In many a freakish knot, had twined –</line>
      <line>Then framed a spell, when the work was done,</line>
      <line>And changed the willow-wreaths to stone.</line>
      <line>The silver light, so pale and faint,</line>
      <line>Shewed many a prophet and many a saint,</line>
      <line>Whose image on the glass was dyed;</line>
      <line>Full in the midst, his cross of red</line>
      <line> Triumphant Michael brandishéd,</line>
      <line>And trampled the apostate’s pride.</line>
      <line>The moonbeam kissed the holy pane,</line>
      <line>And threw on the pavement a bloody stain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They sate them down on a marble stone</line>
      <line>(A Scottish monarch slept below);</line>
      <line>Thus spoke the Monk, in solemn tone:</line>
      <line>‘I was not always a man of woe,</line>
      <line>For Paynim countries I have trod</line>
      <line>And fought beneath the cross of God –</line>
      <line> Now, strange to my eyes thine arms appear,</line>
      <line>And their iron clang sounds strange to my ear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In these far climes, it was my lot</line>
      <line>To meet the wondrous Michael Scott;</line>
      <line>A wizard of such dreaded fame,</line>
      <line>That when, in Salamanca’s cave,</line>
      <line>Him listed his magic wand to wave,</line>
      <line>The bells would ring in Notre Dame!</line>
      <line>Some of his skill he taught to me;</line>
      <line>And, warrior, I could say to thee</line>
      <line> The words that clove Eildon hills in three,</line>
      <line>And bridled the Tweed with a curb of stone;</line>
      <line>But to speak them were a deadly sin;</line>
      <line>And for having but thought them my heart within,</line>
      <line>A treble penance must be done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When Michael lay on his dying-bed,</line>
      <line>His conscience was awakenéd;</line>
      <line>He bethought him of his sinful deed,</line>
      <line>And he gave me a sign to come with speed:</line>
      <line>I was in Spain when the morning rose,</line>
      <line> But I stood by his bed ere evening close!</line>
      <line>The words may not again be said</line>
      <line>That he spoke to me, on death-bed laid;</line>
      <line>They would rend this Abbaye’s massy nave,</line>
      <line>And pile it in heaps above his grave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I swore to bury his mighty book,</line>
      <line>That never mortal might therein look;</line>
      <line>And never to tell where it was hid,</line>
      <line>Save at his chief of Branksome’s need –</line>
      <line>And when that need was past and o’er,</line>
      <line> Again the volume to restore.</line>
      <line>I buried him on St Michael’s night,</line>
      <line>When the bell tolled one, and the moon was bright;</line>
      <line>And I dug his chamber among the dead,</line>
      <line>Where the floor of the chancel was stainéd red,</line>
      <line>That his patron’s cross might over him wave,</line>
      <line>And scare the fiends from the wizard’s grave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was a night of woe and dread,</line>
      <line>When Michael in the tomb I laid!</line>
      <line>Strange sounds along the chancel past;</line>
      <line> The banners waved without a blast!’</line>
      <line>(Still spoke the Monk, when the bell tolled one –</line>
      <line>I tell you, that a braver man</line>
      <line>Than William of Deloraine, good at need,</line>
      <line>Against a foe ne’er spurred a steed;</line>
      <line>Yet somewhat was he chilled with dread,</line>
      <line>And his hair did bristle upon his head.)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Lo, warrior, now the cross of red</line>
      <line>Points to the grave of the mighty dead;</line>
      <line>Within it burns a wondrous light,</line>
      <line> To chase the spirits that love the night:</line>
      <line>That lamp shall burn unquenchably,</line>
      <line>Until the eternal doom shall be.’</line>
      <line>Slow moved the Monk to the broad flagstone,</line>
      <line>Which the bloody cross was traced upon:</line>
      <line>He pointed to a secret nook;</line>
      <line>A bar from thence the warrior took;</line>
      <line>And the Monk made a sign with his withered hand,</line>
      <line>The grave’s huge portal to expand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With beating heart to the task he went</line>
      <line> (His sinewy frame o’er the gravestone bent),</line>
      <line>With bar of iron heaved amain,</line>
      <line>Till the toil-drops fell from his brows like rain!</line>
      <line>It was by dint of passing strength</line>
      <line>That he moved the massy stone at length.</line>
      <line>I would you had been there to see</line>
      <line>How the light broke forth so gloriously –</line>
      <line>Streamed upward to the chancel roof,</line>
      <line>And through the galleries far aloof!</line>
      <line>No earthly flame blazed e’er so bright:</line>
      <line>It shone like Heaven’s own blesséd light,</line>
      <line>And, issuing from the tomb,</line>
      <line>Shewed the Monk’s cowl and visage pale,</line>
      <line>Danced on the dark-browed Warrior’s mail,</line>
      <line>And kissed his waving plume.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Before their eyes the wizard lay</line>
      <line>As if he had not been dead a day,</line>
      <line>His hoary beard in silver rolled</line>
      <line>(He seemed some seventy winters old),</line>
      <line>A palmer’s amice wrapped him round,</line>
      <line> With a wrought Spanish baldric bound,</line>
      <line>Like a pilgrim from beyond the sea;</line>
      <line>His left hand held his book of might,</line>
      <line>A silver cross was in his right;</line>
      <line>The lamp was placed beside his knee.</line>
      <line>High and majestic was his look,</line>
      <line>At which the fellest fiends had shook,</line>
      <line>And all unruffled was his face –</line>
      <line>They trusted his soul had gotten grace!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Often had William of Deloraine</line>
      <line> Rode through the battle’s bloody plain,</line>
      <line>And trampled down the warriors slain,</line>
      <line>And neither known remorse or awe;</line>
      <line>Yet now remorse and awe he owned:</line>
      <line>His breath came thick, his head swam round,</line>
      <line>When this strange scene of death he saw!</line>
      <line>Bewildered and unnerved he stood,</line>
      <line>And the priest prayed fervently and loud –</line>
      <line>With eyes averted prayéd he,</line>
      <line>He might not endure the sight to see</line>
      <line> Of the man he had loved so brotherly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the priest his death-prayer had prayed,</line>
      <line>Thus unto Deloraine he said:</line>
      <line>‘Now speed thee what thou hast to do,</line>
      <line>Or, warrior, we may dearly rue;</line>
      <line>For those thou mayest not look upon</line>
      <line>Are gathering fast round the yawning stone!’</line>
      <line>Then Deloraine, in terror, took</line>
      <line>From the cold hand the mighty book,</line>
      <line>With iron clasped and with iron bound –</line>
      <line> He thought as he took it the dead man frowned,</line>
      <line>But the glare of the sepulchral light</line>
      <line>Perchance had dazzled the warrior’s sight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the huge stone sunk o’er the tomb</line>
      <line>The night returned, in double gloom,</line>
      <line>For the moon had gone down and the stars were few,</line>
      <line>And, as the Knight and Priest withdrew,</line>
      <line>With wavering steps and dizzy brain,</line>
      <line>They hardly might the postern gain.</line>
      <line>’Tis said, as through the aisles they passed</line>
      <line> They heard strange noises on the blast;</line>
      <line>And through the cloister-galleries small,</line>
      <line>Which at mid-height thread the chancel-wall,</line>
      <line>Loud sobs, and laughter louder, ran –</line>
      <line>And voices unlike the voice of man,</line>
      <line>As if the fiends kept holiday</line>
      <line>Because these spells were brought today.</line>
      <line>I cannot tell how the truth may be,</line>
      <line>I say the tale as ’twas said to me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Now hie thee hence’, the father said,</line>
      <line> ‘And when we are on death-bed laid,</line>
      <line>O may our dear Ladye, and sweet St John,</line>
      <line>Forgive our souls for the deed we have done!’</line>
      <line>The Monk returned him to his cell,</line>
      <line>And many a prayer and penance sped –</line>
      <line>When the Convent met at the noontide-bell,</line>
      <line>The Monk of St Mary’s aisle was dead...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JAMES HOGG</author>
    <date>1807</date>
    <title>The Wife of Crowle</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And aye she sat by the cheek of the grate,</line>
      <line>Pretending to shape and to sew;</line>
      <line>But she looked at all that entered the hall</line>
      <line>As if she would look them through.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Her hands she rung, and at times she sung</line>
      <line>Some wild airs for the dead;</line>
      <line>Then ’gan to tell a crazy tale –</line>
      <line>She told it for a meed:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I once had a son, but now he is gone –</line>
      <line>They tore my son from me –</line>
      <line>His life-blood streamed where the cormorant screamed,</line>
      <line>On the wild rocks girt by the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So hard his lone bed, and unpillowed his head,</line>
      <line>For the dark-sea cave is his urn;</line>
      <line> The cliff-flowers weep o’er his slumbers so deep,</line>
      <line>And the dead-lights over him burn.</line>
      <line>Say what can restore the form that’s no more,</line>
      <line>Or illumine the death-set eye?</line>
      <line>Yes, a wild mother’s tears, and a wild mother’s prayers,</line>
      <line>A spirit may force from the sky!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the sun had rose high, and the season gone by,</line>
      <line>My yearnings continued the same:</line>
      <line>I prayed to Heaven both morning and even</line>
      <line>To send me my son – till he came!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> One evening late by the chimney I sate:</line>
      <line>I dreamed of the times that were gone –</line>
      <line>Of its chirrup so eerie the cricket was weary,</line>
      <line>All silent I sate and alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fire burnt bright, and I saw by the light</line>
      <line>My own son enter the hall;</line>
      <line>A white birchen wand he held in his hand,</line>
      <line>But no shadow had he on the wall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He looked at the flame, as forward he came,</line>
      <line>All steadfast, and looked not away;</line>
      <line> His motion was still as mist on the hill,</line>
      <line>And his colour like cold-white clay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I knew him full well – but the tones of the bell</line>
      <line>Which quavered as midnight it rung</line>
      <line>So stunned me I strove, but I could not move</line>
      <line>My hand, my foot, nor my tongue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Blood-drops in a shower then fell on the floor</line>
      <line>From the roof, and they fell upon me:</line>
      <line>No water their stain could wash out again –</line>
      <line>Those blood-drops still may you see!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> His form still grew, and the flame burnt blue,</line>
      <line>I stretched out my arms to embrace;</line>
      <line>But he turned his dead eye, so hollow and dry,</line>
      <line>And so wistfully gazed in my face,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That my head whirled round, and the walls and the ground</line>
      <line>All darkened – no more could I see –</line>
      <line>But each finger’s point, and each finger’s joint,</line>
      <line>Grew thick as the joint of my knee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wakened ere day, but my son was away,</line>
      <line>No word to me had he said;</line>
      <line> Though my blood was boiling, and my heart recoiling,</line>
      <line>To see him again still I prayed –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And often he has come to my lonely home,</line>
      <line>In guise that might adamant melt:</line>
      <line>He has offered his hand with expression so bland,</line>
      <line>But that hand could never be felt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve oft seen him glide so close by my side,</line>
      <line>On his grave-cloth the seams I could trace:</line>
      <line>The blood from a wound trickled down to the ground,</line>
      <line>And a napkin was over his face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> So oft have I seen that death-like mien</line>
      <line>It has somewhat bewildered my brain;</line>
      <line>Yet though chilled with affright at the terrible sight,</line>
      <line>I long still to see it again!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>GEORGE CRABBE</author>
    <date>1810</date>
    <title>Peter Grimes</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Peter Grimes made fishing his employ</line>
      <line>(His wife he cabined with him and his boy)</line>
      <line>And seemed that life laborious to enjoy:</line>
      <line>To town came quiet Peter with his fish,</line>
      <line> And had of all a civil word and wish.</line>
      <line>He left his trade upon the Sabbath-day,</line>
      <line>And took young Peter in his hand to pray;</line>
      <line>But soon the stubborn boy from care broke loose,</line>
      <line>At first refused, then added his abuse.</line>
      <line>His father’s love he scorned, his power defied,</line>
      <line>But being drunk, wept sorely when he died.</line>
      <line>Yes, then he wept, and to his mind there came</line>
      <line>Much of his conduct, and he felt the shame –</line>
      <line>How he had oft the good old man reviled,</line>
      <line> And never paid the duty of a child;</line>
      <line>How, when the father in his Bible read,</line>
      <line>He in contempt and anger left the shed.</line>
      <line>‘It is the word of life’, the parent cried!</line>
      <line>‘This is the life itself’, the boy replied.</line>
      <line>And, while old Peter in amazement stood,</line>
      <line>Gave the hot spirit to his boiling blood;</line>
      <line>How he, with oath and furious speech, began</line>
      <line>To prove his freedom and assert the man;</line>
      <line>And when the parent checked his impious rage,</line>
      <line> How he had cursed the tyranny of age –</line>
      <line>Nay, once had dealt the sacrilegious blow</line>
      <line>On his bare head, and laid his parent low.</line>
      <line>The father groaned, ‘If thou art old’, said he,</line>
      <line>And hast a son, thou wilt remember me:</line>
      <line>Thy mother left me in a happy time,</line>
      <line>Thou killedst not her! Heaven spares the double crime.’</line>
      <line>On an inn-settle, in his maudlin grief,</line>
      <line>This he revolved, and drank for his relief.</line>
      <line>Now lived the youth in freedom, but debarred</line>
      <line> From constant pleasure, and he thought it hard –</line>
      <line>Hard that he could not every wish obey,</line>
      <line>But must awhile relinquish ale and play –</line>
      <line>Hard that he could not to his cards attend,</line>
      <line>But must acquire the money he would spend!</line>
      <line>With greedy eye he looked on all he saw</line>
      <line>(He knew not justice, and he laughed at law),</line>
      <line>On all he marked he stretched his ready hand –</line>
      <line>He fished by water and he filched by land!</line>
      <line>Oft in the night has Peter dropped his oar,</line>
      <line> Fled from his boat, and sought for prey on shore;</line>
      <line>Oft up the hedgerow glided, on his back</line>
      <line>Bearing the orchard’s produce in a sack,</line>
      <line>Or farm-yard load, tugged fiercely from the stack.</line>
      <line>And as these wrongs to greater numbers rose,</line>
      <line>The more he looked on all men as his foes.</line>
      <line>He built a mud-walled hovel, where he kept</line>
      <line>His various wealth, and there he oft-times slept;</line>
      <line>But no success could please his cruel soul:</line>
      <line>He wished for one to trouble and control –</line>
      <line> He wanted some obedient boy to stand</line>
      <line>And bear the blow of his outrageous hand,</line>
      <line>And hoped to find in some propitious hour</line>
      <line>A feeling creature subject to his power.</line>
      <line>Peter had heard there were in London then</line>
      <line>(Still have they being!) workhouse clearing-men,</line>
      <line>Who, undisturbed by feelings just or kind,</line>
      <line>Would parish-boys to needy tradesmen bind:</line>
      <line>They in their want a trifling sum would take,</line>
      <line>And toiling slaves of piteous orphans make.</line>
      <line> Such Peter sought, and when a lad was found,</line>
      <line>The sum was dealt him, and the slave was bound.</line>
      <line>Some few in town observed in Peter’s trap</line>
      <line>A boy, with jacket blue and woollen cap;</line>
      <line>But none enquired how Peter used the rope,</line>
      <line>Or what the bruise that made the stripling stoop;</line>
      <line>None could the ridges on his back behold,</line>
      <line>None sought him shivering in the winter’s cold;</line>
      <line>None put the question, ‘Peter, dost thou give</line>
      <line>The boy his food? What, man, the lad must live!</line>
      <line> Consider, Peter, let the child have bread,</line>
      <line>He’ll serve thee better if he’s stroked and fed.’</line>
      <line>None reasoned thus, and some, on hearing cries,</line>
      <line>Said calmly, ‘Grimes is at his exercise.’</line>
      <line>Pinned, beaten, cold, pinched, threatened and abused,</line>
      <line>His efforts punished and his food refused,</line>
      <line>Awake tormented (soon aroused from sleep),</line>
      <line>Struck if he wept, and yet compelled to weep,</line>
      <line>The trembling boy dropped down and strove to pray,</line>
      <line>Received a blow, and trembling turned away,</line>
      <line> Or sobbed and hid his piteous face – while he,</line>
      <line>The savage master, grinned in horrid glee!</line>
      <line>He’d now the power he ever loved to show,</line>
      <line>A feeling being subject to his blow.</line>
      <line>Thus lived the lad, in hunger, peril, pain,</line>
      <line>His tears despised, his supplications vain.</line>
      <line>Compelled by fear to lie, by need to steal,</line>
      <line>His bed uneasy and unblest his meal,</line>
      <line>For three sad years the boy his tortures bore,</line>
      <line>And then his pains and trials were no more.</line>
      <line> ‘How died he, Peter?’ when the people said,</line>
      <line>He growled, ‘I found him lifeless in his bed’ –</line>
      <line>Then tried for softer tone, and sighed, ‘Poor Sam is dead.’</line>
      <line>Yet murmurs were there, and some questions asked –</line>
      <line>How he was fed, how punished, and how tasked?</line>
      <line>Much they suspected, but they little proved,</line>
      <line>And Peter passed untroubled and unmoved.</line>
      <line>Another boy with equal ease was found,</line>
      <line>The money granted, and the victim bound –</line>
      <line>And what his fate? One night it chanced he fell</line>
      <line>From the boat’s mast and perished in her well,</line>
      <line>Where fish were living kept, and where the boy,</line>
      <line>So reasoned men, could not himself destroy.</line>
      <line>‘Yes, so it was’, said Peter. ‘In his play</line>
      <line>(For he was idle both by night and day)</line>
      <line>He climbed the mainmast and then fell below’ –</line>
      <line>Then showed his corpse, and pointed to the blow.</line>
      <line>What said the jury? They were long in doubt,</line>
      <line>But sturdy Peter faced the matter out;</line>
      <line>So they dismissed him, saying at the time,</line>
      <line> ‘Keep fast your hatchway when you’ve boys who climb.’</line>
      <line>This hit the conscience, and he coloured more</line>
      <line>Than for the closest questions put before.</line>
      <line>Thus all his fears the verdict set aside,</line>
      <line>And at the slave-shop Peter still applied.</line>
      <line>Then came a boy of manners soft and mild –</line>
      <line>Our seamen’s wives with grief beheld the child;</line>
      <line>All thought (the poor themselves) that he was one</line>
      <line>Of gentle blood, some noble sinner’s son,</line>
      <line>Who had, belike, deceived some humble maid,</line>
      <line> Whom he had first seduced and then betrayed.</line>
      <line>However this, he seemed a gracious lad,</line>
      <line>In grief submissive and with patience sad.</line>
      <line>Passive he laboured, till his slender frame</line>
      <line>Bent with his loads, and he at length was lame –</line>
      <line>Strange that a frame so weak could bear so long</line>
      <line>The grossest insult and the foulest wrong,</line>
      <line>But there were causes: in the town they gave</line>
      <line>Fire, food, and comfort, to the gentle slave;</line>
      <line>And though stern Peter, with a cruel hand</line>
      <line> And knotted rope, enforced the rude command,</line>
      <line>Yet he considered what he’d lately felt,</line>
      <line>And his vile blows with selfish pity dealt.</line>
      <line>One day such draughts the cruel fisher made,</line>
      <line>He could not vend them in his borough-trade,</line>
      <line>But sailed for London-mart. The boy was ill,</line>
      <line>But ever humbled to his master’s will,</line>
      <line>And on the river, where they smoothly sailed,</line>
      <line>He strove with terror and awhile prevailed –</line>
      <line>But new to danger on the angry sea,</line>
      <line> He clung affrightened to his master’s knee.</line>
      <line>The boat grew leaky and the wind was strong,</line>
      <line>Rough was the passage and the time was long;</line>
      <line>His liquor failed, and Peter’s wrath arose –</line>
      <line>No more is known, the rest we must suppose</line>
      <line>Or learn of Peter. Peter says he spied</line>
      <line>The stripling’s danger and for harbour tried –</line>
      <line>Meantime the fish, and then the apprentice, died.’</line>
      <line>The pitying women raised a clamour round</line>
      <line>And weeping said, ‘Thou hast thy ‘prentice drowned.’</line>
      <line> Now the stern man was summoned to the hall</line>
      <line>To tell his tale before the burghers all –</line>
      <line>He gave the account, professed the lad he loved,</line>
      <line>And kept his brazen features all unmoved.</line>
      <line>The mayor himself with tone severe replied:</line>
      <line>‘Henceforth with thee shall never boy abide.</line>
      <line>Hire thee a freeman, whom thou durst not beat,</line>
      <line>But who in thy despite will sleep and eat!</line>
      <line>Free thou art now – again shouldst thou appear,</line>
      <line>Thou’lt find thy sentence, like thy soul, severe.’</line>
      <line> Alas for Peter! Not a helping hand</line>
      <line>(So was he hated) could he now command –</line>
      <line>Alone he rowed his boat, alone he cast</line>
      <line>His nets beside, or made his anchor fast.</line>
      <line>To hold a rope, or hear a curse, was none –</line>
      <line>He toiled and railed, he groaned and swore, alone.</line>
      <line>Thus by himself compelled to live each day,</line>
      <line>To wait for certain hours the tide’s delay,</line>
      <line>At the same time the same dull views to see:</line>
      <line>The bounding marsh-bank and the blighted tree;</line>
      <line> The water only, when the tides were high,</line>
      <line>When low, the mud half-covered and half-dry;</line>
      <line>The sun-burnt tar that blisters on the planks,</line>
      <line>And bank-side stakes in their uneven ranks;</line>
      <line>Heaps of entangled weeds that slowly float,</line>
      <line>As the tide rolls by the impeded boat.</line>
      <line>When tides were neap, and, in the sultry day,</line>
      <line>Through the tall bounding mud-banks made their way,</line>
      <line>Which on each side rose swelling, and below</line>
      <line>The dark warm flood ran silently and slow,</line>
      <line> There anchoring, Peter chose from man to hide,</line>
      <line>There hang his head, and view the lazy tide</line>
      <line>In its hot slimy channel slowly glide.</line>
      <line>Where the small eels, that left the deeper way</line>
      <line>For the warm shore, within the shallows play –</line>
      <line>Where gaping mussels, left upon the mud,</line>
      <line>Slope their slow passage to the fallen flood –</line>
      <line>Here dull and hopeless he’d lie down and trace</line>
      <line>How sidelong crabs had scrawled their crooked race,</line>
      <line>Or sadly listen to the tuneless cry</line>
      <line> Of fishing gull or clanging golden-eye.</line>
      <line>What time the sea-birds to the marsh would come,</line>
      <line>And the loud bittern, from the bullrush home,</line>
      <line>Gave from the salt-ditch side the bellowing boom,</line>
      <line>He nursed the feelings these dull scenes produce</line>
      <line>And loved to stop beside the opening sluice</line>
      <line>Where the small stream, confined in narrow bound,</line>
      <line>Ran with a dull, unvaried, saddening sound –</line>
      <line>Where all presented to the eye or ear</line>
      <line>Oppressed the soul with misery, grief, and fear.</line>
      <line>Besides these objects, there were places three</line>
      <line>Which Peter seemed with certain dread to see:</line>
      <line>When he drew near them he would turn from each,</line>
      <line>And loudly whistle till he passed the reach.</line>
      <line>A change of scene to him brought no relief:</line>
      <line>In town, ’twas plain, men took him for a thief;</line>
      <line>The sailors’ wives would stop him in the street</line>
      <line>And say, ‘Now, Peter, thou’st no boy to beat!’</line>
      <line>Infants at play, when they perceived him, ran,</line>
      <line>Warning each other – ‘That’s the wicked man!’</line>
      <line> He growled an oath, and in an angry tone</line>
      <line>Cursed the whole place, and wished to be alone.</line>
      <line>Alone he was, the same dull scenes in view,</line>
      <line>And still more gloomy in his sight they grew.</line>
      <line>Though man he hated, yet, employed alone</line>
      <line>At bootless labour, he would swear and groan,</line>
      <line>Cursing the shoals that glided by the spot</line>
      <line>And gulls that caught them when his arts could not.</line>
      <line>Cold nervous tremblings shook his sturdy frame,</line>
      <line>And strange disease (he couldn’t say the name);</line>
      <line> Wild were his dreams, and oft he rose in fright,</line>
      <line>Waked by his view of horrors in the night –</line>
      <line>Horrors that would the sternest minds amaze,</line>
      <line>Horrors that demons might be proud to raise.</line>
      <line>And though he felt forsaken, grieved at heart</line>
      <line>To think he lived from all mankind apart,</line>
      <line>Yet, if a man approached, in terrors he would start.</line>
      <line>A winter passed since Peter saw the town,</line>
      <line>And summer lodgers were again come down;</line>
      <line>These, idly curious, with their glasses spied</line>
      <line> The ships in bay (as anchored for the tide</line>
      <line>The river’s craft) the bustle of the quay –</line>
      <line>And seaport views, which landsmen love to see.</line>
      <line>One, up the river, had a man and boat</line>
      <line>Seen day by day, now anchored, now afloat.</line>
      <line>Fisher he seemed, yet used no net nor hook;</line>
      <line>Of sea-fowl swimming by no heed he took,</line>
      <line>But on the gliding waves still fixed his lazy look.</line>
      <line>At certain stations he would view the stream,</line>
      <line>As if he stood bewildered in a dream,</line>
      <line> Or that some power had chained him for a time</line>
      <line>To feel a curse or meditate on crime.</line>
      <line>This known, some curious, some in pity, went,</line>
      <line>And others questioned: ‘Wretch, dost thou repent?’</line>
      <line>He heard, he trembled, and in fear resigned</line>
      <line>His boat. New terror filled his restless mind;</line>
      <line>Furious he grew, and up the country ran,</line>
      <line>And there they seized him – a distempered man.</line>
      <line>Him we received, and to a parish-bed,</line>
      <line>Followed and cursed, the groaning man was led.</line>
      <line> Here when they saw him, whom they used to shun –</line>
      <line>A lost, lone man, so harassed and undone –</line>
      <line>Our gentle females (ever prompt to feel)</line>
      <line>Perceived compassion on their anger steal.</line>
      <line>His crimes they could not from their memories blot,</line>
      <line>But they were grieved, and trembled at his lot.</line>
      <line>A priest too came, to whom his words are told –</line>
      <line>And all the signs they shuddered to behold.</line>
      <line>‘Look! look!’ they cried ‘his limbs with horror shake,</line>
      <line>And as he grinds his teeth, what noise they make!</line>
      <line> How glare his angry eyes, and yet he’s not awake!</line>
      <line>See what cold drops upon his forehead stand,</line>
      <line>And how he clenches that broad bony hand!’</line>
      <line>The priest attending found he spoke at times</line>
      <line>As one alluding to his fears and crimes:</line>
      <line>‘It was the fall’, he muttered, ‘I can show</line>
      <line>The manner how – I never struck a blow.’</line>
      <line>And then aloud, ‘Unhand me, free my chain.</line>
      <line>On oath he fell – it struck him to the brain.</line>
      <line>Why ask my father? That old man will swear</line>
      <line> Against my life – besides, he wasn’t there.</line>
      <line>What, all agreed? Am I to die to-day?</line>
      <line>My Lord, in mercy give me time to pray.’</line>
      <line>Then as they watched him, calmer he became,</line>
      <line>And grew so weak he couldn’t move his frame,</line>
      <line>But murmuring spake–while they could see and hear</line>
      <line>The start of terror and the groan of fear –</line>
      <line>See the large dew-beads on his forehead rise,</line>
      <line>And the cold death-drop glaze his sunken eyes.</line>
      <line>Nor yet he died, but with unwonted force</line>
      <line> Seemed with some fancied being to discourse.</line>
      <line>He knew not us, or with accustomed art</line>
      <line>He hid the knowledge, yet exposed his heart –</line>
      <line>’Twas part confession and the rest defence,</line>
      <line>A madman’s tale, with gleams of waking sense.</line>
      <line>‘I’ll tell you all’, he said, ‘the very day</line>
      <line>When the old man first placed them in my way –</line>
      <line>My father’s spirit – he who always tried</line>
      <line>To give me trouble, when he lived and died:</line>
      <line>When he was gone he could not be content</line>
      <line> To see my days in painful labour spent,</line>
      <line>But would appoint his meetings, and he made</line>
      <line>Me watch at these, and so neglect my trade.</line>
      <line>’Twas one hot noon, all silent, still, serene,</line>
      <line>No living being had I lately seen;</line>
      <line>I paddled up and down and dipped my net,</line>
      <line>But (such his pleasure) I could nothing get –</line>
      <line>A father’s pleasure, when his toil was done,</line>
      <line>To plague and torture thus an only son!</line>
      <line>And so I sat and looked upon the stream,</line>
      <line>How it ran on, and felt as in a dream –</line>
      <line>But dream it was not. No! I fixed my eyes</line>
      <line>On the mid stream and saw the spirits rise –</line>
      <line>I saw my father on the water stand</line>
      <line>And hold a thin pale boy in either hand,</line>
      <line>And there they glided ghastly on the top</line>
      <line>Of the salt flood, and never touched a drop.</line>
      <line>I would have struck them, but they knew the intent</line>
      <line>And smiled upon the oar, and down they went.</line>
      <line>Now, from that day, whenever I began</line>
      <line> To dip my net, there stood the hard old man –</line>
      <line>He and those boys! I humbled me and prayed</line>
      <line>They would be gone – they heeded not, but stayed.</line>
      <line>Nor could I turn, nor would the boat go by,</line>
      <line>But, gazing on the spirits, there was I –</line>
      <line>They bade me leap to death, but I was loath to die.</line>
      <line>And every day, as sure as day arose,</line>
      <line>Would these three spirits meet me ere the close;</line>
      <line>To hear and mark them daily was my doom,</line>
      <line>And “Come” they said, with weak sad voices, “Come!”</line>
      <line> To row away, with all my strength I tried,</line>
      <line>But there were they, hard by me in the tide,</line>
      <line>The three unbodied forms – and “Come”, still “Come” they cried!</line>
      <line>Fathers should pity – but this old man shook</line>
      <line>His hoary locks, and froze me by a look!</line>
      <line>Thrice, when I struck them, through the water came</line>
      <line>A hollow groan, that weakened all my frame:</line>
      <line>“Father”, said I, “have mercy!” He replied</line>
      <line>I know not what – the angry spirit lied!</line>
      <line>“Didst thou not draw thy knife?” said he. ’Twas true,</line>
      <line> But I had pity and my arm withdrew –</line>
      <line>He cried for mercy, which I kindly gave,</line>
      <line>But he has no compassion in his grave.</line>
      <line>There were three places, where they ever rose</line>
      <line>(The whole long river has not such as those),</line>
      <line>Places accurst, where if a man remain</line>
      <line>He’ll see the things which strike him to the brain –</line>
      <line>And there they made me on my paddle lean</line>
      <line>And look at them for hours. Accurséd scene,</line>
      <line>When they would glide to that smooth eddy-space,</line>
      <line> Then bid me leap and join them in the place –</line>
      <line>And at my groans each little villain-sprite</line>
      <line>Enjoyed my pains and vanished in delight!</line>
      <line>In one fierce summer-day, when my poor brain</line>
      <line>Was burning hot, and cruel was my pain,</line>
      <line>Then came this father-foe – and there he stood</line>
      <line>With his two boys again, upon the flood.</line>
      <line>There was more mischief in their eyes, more glee</line>
      <line>In their pale faces when they glared at me!</line>
      <line>Still did they force me on the oar to rest,</line>
      <line> And when they saw me fainting and oppressed,</line>
      <line>He, with his hand – the old man – scooped the flood,</line>
      <line>And there came flame about him mixed with blood!</line>
      <line>He bade me stoop and look upon the place,</line>
      <line>Then flung the hot-red liquor in my face!</line>
      <line>Burning it blazed, and then I roared for pain –</line>
      <line>I thought the demons would have turned my brain.</line>
      <line>Still there they stood, and forced me to behold</line>
      <line>A place of horrors (they cannot be told) –</line>
      <line>Where the flood opened, there I heard the shriek</line>
      <line> Of tortured guilt, no earthly tongue can speak:</line>
      <line>“All days alike, for ever!” did they say,</line>
      <line>“And unremitted torments every day!”</line>
      <line>Yes, so they said.’ But here he ceased, and gazed</line>
      <line>On all around, affrightened and amazed.</line>
      <line>And still he tried to speak, and looked in dread</line>
      <line>Of frightened females gathering round his bed –</line>
      <line>Then dropped exhausted, and appeared at rest,</line>
      <line>Till the strong foe the vital powers possessed;</line>
      <line>Then with an inward, broken voice he cried,</line>
      <line> ‘Again they come!’ and muttered as he died.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Darkness</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I had a dream, which was not all a dream:</line>
      <line>The bright sun was extinguished, and the stars</line>
      <line>Did wander darkling in the eternal space,</line>
      <line>Rayless and pathless, and the icy Earth</line>
      <line> Swung blind and blackening in the moonless air!</line>
      <line>Morn came, and went, and came – and brought no day.</line>
      <line>And men forgot their passions in the dread</line>
      <line>Of this their desolation; and all hearts</line>
      <line>Were chilled into a selfish prayer for light.</line>
      <line>And they did live by watchfires – and the thrones,</line>
      <line>The palaces of crownéd kings, the huts,</line>
      <line>The habitations of all things which dwell,</line>
      <line>Were burnt for beacons. Cities were consumed,</line>
      <line>And men were gathered round their blazing homes</line>
      <line> To look once more into each other’s face.</line>
      <line>Happy were those who dwelt within the eye</line>
      <line>Of the volcanos, and their mountain-torch!</line>
      <line>A fearful hope was all the World contained –</line>
      <line>Forests were set on fire, but hour by hour</line>
      <line>They fell and faded, and the crackling trunks</line>
      <line>Extinguished with a crash, and all was black.</line>
      <line>The brows of men by the despairing light</line>
      <line>Wore an unearthly aspect, as by fits</line>
      <line>The flashes fell upon them. Some lay down</line>
      <line> And hid their eyes and wept; and some did rest</line>
      <line>Their chins upon their clenchéd hands, and smiled;</line>
      <line>And others hurried to and fro, and fed</line>
      <line>Their funeral-piles with fuel, and lookéd up</line>
      <line>With mad disquietude on the dull sky,</line>
      <line>The pall of a past World – and then again</line>
      <line>With curses cast them down upon the dust,</line>
      <line>And gnashed their teeth and howled. The wild birds shrieked</line>
      <line>And, terrified, did flutter on the ground,</line>
      <line>And flap their useless wings; the wildest brutes</line>
      <line> Came tame and tremulous; and vipers crawled</line>
      <line>And twined themselves among the multitude,</line>
      <line>Hissing, but stingless – they were slain for food!</line>
      <line>And War, which for a moment was no more,</line>
      <line>Did glut himself again: a meal was bought</line>
      <line>With blood, and each sat sullenly apart</line>
      <line>Gorging himself in gloom. No love was left.</line>
      <line>All earth was but one thought, and that was death,</line>
      <line>Immediate and inglorious – and the pang</line>
      <line>Of famine fed upon all entrails! Men</line>
      <line> Died, and their bones were tombless as their flesh.</line>
      <line>The meagre by the meagre were devoured.</line>
      <line>Even dogs assailed their masters – all save one,</line>
      <line>And he was faithful to a corse, and kept</line>
      <line>The birds and beasts and famished men at bay,</line>
      <line>Till hunger clung them, or the dropping dead</line>
      <line>Lured their lank jaws – himself sought out no food,</line>
      <line>But with a piteous and perpetual moan,</line>
      <line>And a quick desolate cry, licking the hand</line>
      <line>Which answered not with a caress, he died.</line>
      <line> The crowd was famished by degrees; but two</line>
      <line>Of an enormous city did survive,</line>
      <line>And they were enemies. They met beside</line>
      <line>The dying embers of an altar-place</line>
      <line>Where had been heaped a mass of holy things</line>
      <line>For an unholy usage; they raked up,</line>
      <line>And shivering scraped with their cold skeleton hands,</line>
      <line>The feeble ashes, and their feeble breath</line>
      <line>Blew for a little life, and made a flame</line>
      <line>Which was a mockery. Then they lifted up</line>
      <line> Their eyes as it grew lighter, and beheld</line>
      <line>Each other’s aspects – saw, and shrieked, and died –</line>
      <line>Even of their mutual hideousness they died,</line>
      <line>Unknowing who he was upon whose brow</line>
      <line>Famine had written fiend!</line>
      <line>The world was void:</line>
      <line>The populous and the powerful was a lump,</line>
      <line>Seasonless, herbless, treeless, manless, lifeless –</line>
      <line>A lump of death – a chaos of hard clay!</line>
      <line>The rivers, lakes, and ocean all stood still,</line>
      <line>And nothing stirred within their silent depths.</line>
      <line> Ships, sailorless, lay rotting on the sea,</line>
      <line>And their masts fell down piecemeal – as they dropped</line>
      <line>They slept on the abyss without a surge.</line>
      <line>The waves were dead; the tides were in their grave</line>
      <line>(The Moon, their mistress, had expired before);</line>
      <line>The winds were withered in the stagnant air,</line>
      <line>And the clouds perished – Darkness had no need</line>
      <line>Of aid from them – She was the Universe!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>La Belle Dame Sans Merci</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh, what can ail thee, knight-at-arms,</line>
      <line>Alone and palely loitering?</line>
      <line>The sedge is withered from the lake,</line>
      <line>And no birds sing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh, what can ail thee, knight-at-arms,</line>
      <line>So haggard and so woe-begone?</line>
      <line>The squirrel’s granary is full,</line>
      <line>And the harvest’s done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I see a lily on thy brow,</line>
      <line>With anguish moist and fever-dew,</line>
      <line>And on thy cheek a fading rose</line>
      <line>Fast withereth too.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I met a lady in the meads</line>
      <line>Full beautiful, a fairy’s child;</line>
      <line> Her hair was long, her foot was light,</line>
      <line>And her eyes were wild.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I made a garland for her head,</line>
      <line>And bracelets too, and fragrant zone;</line>
      <line>She looked at me as she did love,</line>
      <line>And made sweet moan.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I set her on my pacing steed,</line>
      <line>And nothing else saw all day long;</line>
      <line>For sidelong would she bend, and sing</line>
      <line>A fairy’s song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She found me roots of relish sweet,</line>
      <line>And honey wild, and manna-dew;</line>
      <line>And sure in language strange she said,</line>
      <line>‘I love thee true.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She took me to her elfin grot,</line>
      <line>And there she wept, and sighed full sore,</line>
      <line>And there I shut her wild wild eyes</line>
      <line>With kisses four.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And there she lulléd me asleep</line>
      <line>And there I dreamed, ah woe betide!</line>
      <line> The latest dream I ever dreamed</line>
      <line>On the cold hill side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw pale kings, and princes too,</line>
      <line>Pale warriors – death-pale were they all –</line>
      <line>Who cried: ‘La belle Dame sans merci</line>
      <line>Thee hath in thrall!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw their starved lips in the gloam</line>
      <line>With horrid warning gapéd wide,</line>
      <line>And I awoke, and found me here</line>
      <line>On the cold hill’s side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And this is why I sojourn here</line>
      <line>Alone and palely loitering,</line>
      <line>Though the sedge is withered from the lake,</line>
      <line>And no birds sing.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>from Superstition’s Dream</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>That time was come, or seemed as it was come,</line>
      <line>When death no longer makes the grave its home,</line>
      <line> When waking spirits leave their earthly rest</line>
      <line>To mix forever with the damned or blest,</line>
      <line>When years in drowsy thousands counted by</line>
      <line>Then hung on minutes with their destiny,</line>
      <line>When life in terror drops its draining glass</line>
      <line>And all that’s mortal like to shadows pass</line>
      <line>As ’neath approaching tempests sinks the sun,</line>
      <line>When time shall leave eternity begun.</line>
      <line>Life swooned in terror at that hour’s dread birth</line>
      <line>And as in ague, shook the fearful earth,</line>
      <line> And shuddering Nature seemed herself to shun</line>
      <line>While trembling conscience felt the deed was done!</line>
      <line>A gloomy sadness round the sky was cast,</line>
      <line>And clouds seemed hurrying with unusual haste –</line>
      <line>Winds urged them forward like to restless ships,</line>
      <line>And light dim faded with its last eclipse,</line>
      <line>While Agitation turned a straining eye,</line>
      <line>And Hope stood watching like a bird to fly,</line>
      <line>And cringing Nature (like a child in dread)</line>
      <line>Clung to her fading garments till she fled,</line>
      <line> And awful sights began to be revealed</line>
      <line>Which Death’s dark dungeons had so long concealed!</line>
      <line>Each grave its doomsday prisoner resigned,</line>
      <line>And burst in noises like an hollow wind,</line>
      <line>And spirits (mingling with the living then)</line>
      <line>Thrilled fearful voices with the cries of men,</line>
      <line>And, flying furious, grinning deep despair</line>
      <line>Shaped dismal shadows on the troubled air,</line>
      <line>And lightning shot its flashes as they came</line>
      <line>And passing clouds seemed kindling into flame</line>
      <line> And strong, and, stronger came the sulphury smell</line>
      <line>While demons followed in the breath of Hell,</line>
      <line>Grinning in mockery as the doomed complained –</line>
      <line>Losing their pains in seeing others pained!</line>
      <line>Fierce raged destruction sweeping o’er the land</line>
      <line>And the last counted moment seemed at hand;</line>
      <line>As scales near equal hang the earnest eyes</line>
      <line>In doubtful balance which shall fall or rise,</line>
      <line>So in the moment of that crashing blast</line>
      <line>Eyes hearts and hopes paused trembling for the last,</line>
      <line> And sudden thunder-claps with yawing rents</line>
      <line>Gashed the frail garment of the elements</line>
      <line>And bursting whirlwinds, winged in purple flame,</line>
      <line>And lightning’s flash in stronger terrors came</line>
      <line>Burning all life and Nature where they fell</line>
      <line>And leaving earth as desolate as Hell.</line>
      <line>The pleasant hues of fields and woods was past</line>
      <line>And Nature’s beauties had enjoyed their last:</line>
      <line>The coloured flower, the green of field and tree,</line>
      <line>What they had been forever ceased to be;</line>
      <line> Grass shriveled brown in miserable hues</line>
      <line>And showers of fire dried up the hissing dews;</line>
      <line>Leaves crumbled ashes to the air’s hot breath,</line>
      <line>And all awaited universal death...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS CAMPBELL</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>The Last Man</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All worldly shapes shall melt in gloom,</line>
      <line>The Sun himself die,</line>
      <line>Before this mortal shall assume</line>
      <line>Its Immortality!</line>
      <line> I saw a vision in my sleep</line>
      <line>That gave my spirit strength to sweep</line>
      <line>Adown the gulf of Time!</line>
      <line>I saw the last of human mould</line>
      <line>That shall Creations’s death behold.</line>
      <line>As Adam saw her prime!</line>
      <line>The Sun’s eye had a sickly glare,</line>
      <line>The Earth with age was wan,</line>
      <line>The skeletons of nations were</line>
      <line>Around that lonely man!</line>
      <line> Some had expired in fight – the brands</line>
      <line>Still rusted in their bony hands;</line>
      <line>In plague and famine some!</line>
      <line>Earth’s cities had no sound nor tread;</line>
      <line>And ships were drifting with the dead</line>
      <line>To shores where all was dumb!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet, prophet-like, that lone one stood</line>
      <line>With dauntless words and high,</line>
      <line>That shook the sere leaves from the wood</line>
      <line>As if a storm passed by,</line>
      <line> Saying, ‘We are twins in death, proud Sun!</line>
      <line>Thy face is cold, thy race is run,</line>
      <line>’Tis Mercy bids thee go;</line>
      <line>For thou ten thousand thousand years</line>
      <line>Hast seen the tide of human tears,</line>
      <line>That shall no longer flow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What though beneath thee man put forth</line>
      <line>His pomp, his pride, his skill,</line>
      <line>And arts that made fire, flood, and earth</line>
      <line>The vassals of his will?</line>
      <line> Yet mourn I not thy parted sway,</line>
      <line>Thou dim discrownéd king of day:</line>
      <line>For all those trophied arts</line>
      <line>And triumphs that beneath thee sprang</line>
      <line>Healed not a passion or a pang</line>
      <line>Entailed on human hearts.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go, let oblivion’s curtain fall</line>
      <line>Upon the stage of men,</line>
      <line>Nor with thy rising beams recall</line>
      <line>Life’s tragedy again.</line>
      <line> Its piteous pageants bring not back,</line>
      <line>Nor waken flesh upon the rack</line>
      <line>Of pain anew to writhe –</line>
      <line>Stretched in disease’s shapes abhorred,</line>
      <line>Or mown in battle by the sword</line>
      <line>Like grass beneath the scythe.</line>
      <line>Even I am weary in yon skies</line>
      <line>To watch thy fading fire;</line>
      <line>Test of all sumless agonies,</line>
      <line>Behold not me expire!</line>
      <line> My lips that speak thy dirge of death –</line>
      <line>Their rounded gasp and gargling breath</line>
      <line>To see thou shalt not boast;</line>
      <line>The eclipse of Nature spreads my pall –</line>
      <line>The majesty of Darkness shall</line>
      <line>Receive my parting ghost!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This spirit shall return to Him</line>
      <line>That gave its heavenly spark;</line>
      <line>Yet think not, Sun, it shall be dim</line>
      <line>When thou thyself are dark!</line>
      <line> No! it shall live again, and shine</line>
      <line>In bliss unknown to beams of thine,</line>
      <line>By Him recalled to breath</line>
      <line>Who captive led captivity,</line>
      <line>Who robbed the grave of Victory,</line>
      <line>And took the sting from Death!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go, Sun, while Mercy holds me up</line>
      <line>On Nature’s awful waste</line>
      <line>To drink this last and bitter cup</line>
      <line>Of grief that man shall taste –</line>
      <line> Go, tell the night that hides thy face</line>
      <line>Thou saw’st the last of Adam’s race</line>
      <line>On Earth’s sepulchral clod</line>
      <line>The darkening universe defy</line>
      <line>To quench his immortality</line>
      <line>Or shake his trust in God!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1826</date>
    <title>The Last Man</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas in the year two thousand and one,</line>
      <line>A pleasant morning of May,</line>
      <line>I sat on the gallows-tree all alone,</line>
      <line>A chanting a merry lay –</line>
      <line> To think how the pest had spared my life</line>
      <line>To sing with the larks that day!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When up the heath came a jolly knave,</line>
      <line>Like a scarecrow all in rags;</line>
      <line>It made me crow to see his old duds</line>
      <line>All abroad in the winds like flags –</line>
      <line>So up he came to the timbers’ foot</line>
      <line>And pitched down his greasy bags.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Good Lord, how blithe the old beggar was</line>
      <line>At pulling out his scraps –</line>
      <line> The very sight of his broken orts</line>
      <line>Made a work in his wrinkled chaps!</line>
      <line>‘Come down’, says he, ‘you Newgate-bird,</line>
      <line>And have a taste of my snaps!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then down the rope, like a tar from the mast,</line>
      <line>I slided, and by him stood;</line>
      <line>But I wished myself on the gallows again</line>
      <line>When I smelt that beggar’s food –</line>
      <line>A foul beef-bone, and a mouldy crust –</line>
      <line>‘Oh’, quoth he, ‘the Heavens are good!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then, after this grace, he cast him down:</line>
      <line>Says I, ‘You’ll get sweeter air</line>
      <line>A pace or two off, on the windward side’ –</line>
      <line>For the felons’ bones lay there!</line>
      <line>But he only laughed at the empty skulls,</line>
      <line>And offered them part of his fare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I never harmed them, and they won’t harm me –</line>
      <line>Let the proud and the rich be cravens!’</line>
      <line>I did not like that strange beggar-man,</line>
      <line>He looked up so at the Heaven –</line>
      <line> Anon he shook out his empty old poke:</line>
      <line>‘There’s the crumbs’, saith he, ‘for the ravens!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It made me angry to see his face,</line>
      <line>It had such a jesting look;</line>
      <line>But while I made up my mind to speak,</line>
      <line>A small case-bottle he took:</line>
      <line>Quoth he, ‘Though I gather the green watercress,</line>
      <line>My drink is not of the brook!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full manners-like he tendered the dram –</line>
      <line>Oh it came of a dainty cask –</line>
      <line> But whenever it came to his turn to pull:</line>
      <line>‘Your leave, good sir, I must ask;</line>
      <line>But I always wipe the brim with my sleeve</line>
      <line>When a hangman sups at my flask!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then he laughed so loudly and long,</line>
      <line>The churl was quite out of breath –</line>
      <line>I thought the very Old One was come</line>
      <line>To mock me before my death,</line>
      <line>And wished I had buried the dead men’s bones</line>
      <line>That were lying about the heath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But the beggar gave me a jolly clap:</line>
      <line>‘Come, let us pledge each other,</line>
      <line>For all the wide world is dead beside’</line>
      <line>And we are brother and brother –</line>
      <line>I’ve a yearning for thee in my heart</line>
      <line>As if we had come from one mother.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve a yearning for thee in my heart</line>
      <line>That almost makes me weep,</line>
      <line>For as I passed from town to town</line>
      <line>The folks were all stone-asleep,</line>
      <line> But when I saw thee sitting aloft</line>
      <line>It made me both laugh and leap!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now a curse (I thought) be on his love,</line>
      <line>And a curse be on his mirth,</line>
      <line>An’ it were not for that beggar-man</line>
      <line>I’d be the King of the Earth –</line>
      <line>But I promised myself an hour should come</line>
      <line>To make him rue his birth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So down we sat and boused again</line>
      <line>Till the sun was in mid-sky,</line>
      <line> When, just as the gentle west wind came,</line>
      <line>We hearkened a dismal cry:</line>
      <line>‘Up, up on the tree’, quoth the beggar-man,</line>
      <line>‘Till those horrible dogs go by!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lo, from the forest’s far-off skirts</line>
      <line>They came all yelling for gore,</line>
      <line>A hundred hounds all yelling at once,</line>
      <line>And a panting hart before –</line>
      <line>Till he sunk down at the gallows’ foot,</line>
      <line>And there his haunches they tore!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> His haunches they tore, without a horn</line>
      <line>To tell when the chase was done,</line>
      <line>And there was not a scarlet coat</line>
      <line>To flaunt it in the sun –</line>
      <line>I turned and looked at the beggar-man,</line>
      <line>And his tears dropped one by one.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And with curses sore he chid the hounds,</line>
      <line>Till the last dropped out of sight –</line>
      <line>Anon saith he, ‘Let’s down again,</line>
      <line>And ramble for our delight,</line>
      <line> For the world’s all free, and we may choose</line>
      <line>A right cozy barn for tonight!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With that he set up his staff on end</line>
      <line>And it fell with the point due west;</line>
      <line>So we fared that way to a city great</line>
      <line>Where the folks had died of the pest –</line>
      <line>It was fine to enter in house and hall</line>
      <line>Wherever it liked me best!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For the porters all were stiff and cold,</line>
      <line>And could not lift their heads;</line>
      <line>And when we came where their masters lay,</line>
      <line>The rats leapt out of the beds –</line>
      <line>The grandest palaces in the land</line>
      <line>Were as free as workhouse-sheds.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the beggar-man made a mumping face,</line>
      <line>And knocked at every gate:</line>
      <line>It made me curse to hear how he whined,</line>
      <line>So our fellowship turned to hate,</line>
      <line>And I bade him walk the world by himself,</line>
      <line>For I scorned so humble a mate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> So he turned right, and I turned left,</line>
      <line>As if we had never met,</line>
      <line>And I chose a fair stone-house for myself,</line>
      <line>For the city was all to let –</line>
      <line>And for three brave holydays drank my fill</line>
      <line>Of the choicest I could get!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And because my jerkin was coarse and worn</line>
      <line>I got me a properer vest;</line>
      <line>It was purple velvet, stitched over with gold,</line>
      <line>And a shining star at the breast –</line>
      <line> ’Twas enough to fetch old Joan from her grave,</line>
      <line>To see me so purely dressed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Joan was dead, and under the mould,</line>
      <line>And every buxom lass –</line>
      <line>In vane I watched at the window-pane</line>
      <line>For a Christian soul to pass,</line>
      <line>But sheep and kine wandered up the street</line>
      <line>And browsed on the new-come grass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When lo, I spied the old beggar-man,</line>
      <line>And lustily he did sing;</line>
      <line> His rags were lapped in a scarlet cloak,</line>
      <line>And a crown he had, like a king –</line>
      <line>So he stepped right up before my gate</line>
      <line>And danced me a saucy fling!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Heaven mend us all – but within my mind</line>
      <line>I had killed him then and there</line>
      <line>To see him lording so braggart-like</line>
      <line>That was born to his beggar’s fare –</line>
      <line>And now he had stolen the royal crown</line>
      <line>His betters were meant to wear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But God forbid that a thief should die</line>
      <line>Without his share of the laws!</line>
      <line>So I nimbly whipped my tackle out</line>
      <line>And soon tied up his claws –</line>
      <line>I was judge myself, and jury, and all,</line>
      <line>And solemnly tried the cause.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the beggar-man would not plead, but cried</line>
      <line>Like a babe without its corals,</line>
      <line>For he knew how hard it is apt to go</line>
      <line>When the law and a thief have quarrels –</line>
      <line> There was not a Christian soul alive</line>
      <line>To speak a word for his morals!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh how gaily I doffed my costly gear</line>
      <line>And put on my workday clothes –</line>
      <line>I was tired of such long Sunday life,</line>
      <line>And was never one of the sloths;</line>
      <line>But the beggar-man grumbled a weary deal,</line>
      <line>And made many crooked mouths.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So I hauled him off to the gallows’ foot,</line>
      <line>And blinded him in his bags;</line>
      <line> ’Twas a weary job to heave him up</line>
      <line>(For a doomed man always lags),</line>
      <line>But by ten of the clock he was off his legs</line>
      <line>In the wind and airing his rags!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So there he hung, and there I stood</line>
      <line>The LAST MAN left alive,</line>
      <line>To have my own will of all the earth:</line>
      <line>Quoth I, ‘Now I shall thrive!’</line>
      <line>But when was ever honey made</line>
      <line>With one bee in a hive?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> My conscience began to gnaw my heart</line>
      <line>Before the day was done,</line>
      <line>For other men’s lives had all gone out</line>
      <line>Like candles in the sun –</line>
      <line>But it seemed as if I had broke at last</line>
      <line>A thousand necks in one!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So I went and cut his body down</line>
      <line>To bury it decently</line>
      <line>(God send there were any soul alive</line>
      <line>To do the same by me),</line>
      <line> But the wild dogs came with a terrible speed,</line>
      <line>And bayed me up the tree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My sight was like a drunkard’s sight,</line>
      <line>And my head began to swim,</line>
      <line>To see their jaws all white with foam</line>
      <line>Like the ravenous ocean’s brim –</line>
      <line>But when the wild dogs trotted away</line>
      <line>Their jaws were bloody and grim!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their jaws were bloody and grim, good Lord,</line>
      <line>But the beggar-man, where was he?</line>
      <line> There was nought of him but some ribbons of rags</line>
      <line>Below the gallows-tree –</line>
      <line>I know the Devil, when I am dead,</line>
      <line>Will send his hounds for me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve buried my babies one by one,</line>
      <line>And dug the deep hole for Joan,</line>
      <line>And covered the faces of kith and kin,</line>
      <line>And felt the old churchyard-stone</line>
      <line>Go cold to my heart, full many a time –</line>
      <line>But I never felt so lone!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For the lion and Adam were company,</line>
      <line>And the tiger him beguiled;</line>
      <line>But the simple kind are foes to my life,</line>
      <line>And the household brutes are wild.</line>
      <line>If the veriest cur would lick my hand,</line>
      <line>I could love it like a child!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the beggar-man’s ghost besets my dreams</line>
      <line>At night, to make me madder,</line>
      <line>And my wretched conscience within my breast</line>
      <line>Is stinging like an adder –</line>
      <line> I sigh when I pass the gallows’ foot,</line>
      <line>And look at the rope and ladder!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For hanging looks sweet – but alas, in vain</line>
      <line>My desperate fancy begs;</line>
      <line>I must turn my cup of sorrows quite up,</line>
      <line>And drink it to the dregs,</line>
      <line>For there is not another man alive</line>
      <line>In the world, to pull my legs!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1784</date>
    <title>Old Corruption</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When Old Corruption first begun,</line>
      <line>Adorned in yellow vest,</line>
      <line>He committed on Flesh a whoredom –</line>
      <line>Oh, what a wicked beast!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> From them a callow babe did spring,</line>
      <line>And Old Corruption smiled</line>
      <line>To think his race could never end,</line>
      <line>For now he had a child.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He called him Surgery, and fed</line>
      <line>The babe with his own milk,</line>
      <line>For Flesh and he could ne’er agree –</line>
      <line>She would not let him suck.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And this he always kept in mind,</line>
      <line>And formed a crooked knife,</line>
      <line> And ran about with bloody hands</line>
      <line>To seek his mother’s life;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And as he ran to seek his mother</line>
      <line>He met with a dead woman –</line>
      <line>He fell in love, and married her:</line>
      <line>A deed which is not common.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She soon grew pregnant, and brought forth</line>
      <line>Scurvy and Spotted Fever;</line>
      <line>The father grinned and skipped about,</line>
      <line>And said, ‘I’m made for ever –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For now I have procured these imps,</line>
      <line>I’ll try experiments!’</line>
      <line>With that he tied poor Scurvy down</line>
      <line>And stopped up all its vents,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the child began to swell</line>
      <line>He shouted out aloud,</line>
      <line>‘I’ve found the dropsy out – and soon</line>
      <line>Shall do the world more good!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He took up Fever by the neck,</line>
      <line>And cut out all its spots –</line>
      <line> And through the holes which he had made</line>
      <line>He first discovered guts!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1784</date>
    <title>Lo, the Bat</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lo, the bat with leathern wing,</line>
      <line>Winking and blinking,</line>
      <line>Winking and blinking,</line>
      <line>Winking and blinking</line>
      <line> Like Doctor Johnson.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh ho!’ said Doctor Johnson</line>
      <line>To Scipio Africanus,</line>
      <line>‘If you don’t own me a philosopher</line>
      <line>I’ll kick your Roman anus!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Ah ha!’ to Doctor Johnson</line>
      <line>Said Scipio Africanus,</line>
      <line>‘Lift up my Roman petticoat,</line>
      <line>And kiss my Roman anus!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1784</date>
    <title>Village Cricket</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh I say, you Joe,</line>
      <line>Throw us the ball!</line>
      <line>I’ve a good mind to go</line>
      <line>And leave you all.</line>
      <line> I never saw such a bowler –</line>
      <line>To bowl the ball in a tansey,</line>
      <line>And to clean it with my handkercher</line>
      <line>Without saying a word!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That Bill’s a foolish fellow –</line>
      <line>He has given me a black eye!</line>
      <line>He does not know how to handle a bat</line>
      <line>Any more than a dog or a cat:</line>
      <line>He has knocked down the wicket</line>
      <line>And broke the stumps,</line>
      <line> And runs without shoes to save his pumps!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1786</date>
    <title>Holy Willie’s Prayer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh thou that in the heavens does dwell,</line>
      <line>Wha, as it pleases best thysel,</line>
      <line>Sends ane to Heaven and ten to Hell,</line>
      <line>A’ for thy glory –</line>
      <line> And no for ony gude or ill</line>
      <line>They’ve done before thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I bless and praise thy matchless might,</line>
      <line>When thousands thou hast left in night,</line>
      <line>That I am here before thy sight,</line>
      <line>For gifts and grace,</line>
      <line>A burning and a shining light</line>
      <line>To a’ this place!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What was I, or my generation,</line>
      <line>That should get such exaltation?</line>
      <line> I, wha deserved most just damnation</line>
      <line>For broken laws</line>
      <line>Sax thousand years ere my creation,</line>
      <line>Through Adam’s cause!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When from my mother’s womb I fell,</line>
      <line>Thou might hae plunged me deep in Hell,</line>
      <line>To gnash my gooms, and weep, and wail,</line>
      <line>In burning lakes,</line>
      <line>Where damnéd devils roar and yell</line>
      <line>Chained to their stakes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet I am here, a chosen sample,</line>
      <line>To show thy grace is green and ample:</line>
      <line>I’m here, a pillar of thy temple</line>
      <line>Strong as a rock,</line>
      <line>A guide, a ruler and example</line>
      <line>To a’ thy flock!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Lord thou kens what zeal I bear,</line>
      <line>When drinkers drink, and swearers swear,</line>
      <line>And singin’ there and dancin’ here,</line>
      <line>Wi’ great an’ sma’;</line>
      <line> For I am keepet by thy fear,</line>
      <line>Free frae them a’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But yet, oh Lord (confess I must),</line>
      <line>At times I’m fashed wi’ fleshly lust;</line>
      <line>And sometimes too, in warldly trust</line>
      <line>Vile self gets in!</line>
      <line>But thou remembers we are dust,</line>
      <line>Defiled wi’ sin!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Lord – yestreen – thou kens – wi’ Meg –</line>
      <line>Thy pardon I sincerely beg!</line>
      <line> Oh may’t ne’er be a living plague,</line>
      <line>To my dishonour,</line>
      <line>And I’ll never lift a lawless leg</line>
      <line>Again upon her!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Besides, I farther maun avow,</line>
      <line>Wi’ Leezi’s lass, three times – I trow –</line>
      <line>But Lord, that friday I was fou</line>
      <line>When I cam near her;</line>
      <line>Or else, thou kens, thy servant true</line>
      <line>Wad never steer her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Maybe thou lets this fleshly thorn</line>
      <line>Buffet thy servant even and morn,</line>
      <line>Lest he over proud and high should turn,</line>
      <line>That he’s sae gifted;</line>
      <line>If sae, thy hand maun even be borne</line>
      <line>Until thou lift it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lord bless thy chosen in this place –</line>
      <line>For here thou has a chosen race –</line>
      <line>But God, confound their stubborn face,</line>
      <line>And blast their name,</line>
      <line> Wha bring thy rulers to disgrace</line>
      <line>And open shame!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lord mind Gaun Hamilton’s deserts!</line>
      <line>He drinks, and swears, and plays at cartes,</line>
      <line>Yet has sae mony taking arts</line>
      <line>Wi’ great and sma’,</line>
      <line>Frae God’s ain priest the people’s hearts</line>
      <line>He steals awa.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when we chastened him therefore,</line>
      <line>Thou kens how he bred sic a splore,</line>
      <line> And set the warld in a roar</line>
      <line>O’ laughin’ at us:</line>
      <line>Curse thou his basket and his store,</line>
      <line>Kail and potatoes!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lord hear my earnest cry and prayer</line>
      <line>Against that Presbytry of Ayr!</line>
      <line>Thy strong right hand, Lord, make it bare</line>
      <line>Upon their heads!</line>
      <line>Lord visit them, and dinna spare,</line>
      <line>For their misdeeds!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh Lord my God, that glib-tongued Aiken!</line>
      <line>My very heart and flesh are quaking</line>
      <line>To think how I sat, sweating, shaking,</line>
      <line>And pissed wi’ dread,</line>
      <line>While Auld wi’ hingin lip gaed sneaking</line>
      <line>And hid his head!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lord, in thy day o’ vengeance try him!</line>
      <line>Lord visit him that did employ him!</line>
