      <line>And pass not in thy mercy by them,</line>
      <line>Nor hear their prayer;</line>
      <line> But for thy people’s sake destroy them,</line>
      <line>And dinna spare!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Lord, remember me and mine</line>
      <line>Wi’ mercies temporal and divine!</line>
      <line>That I for grace and gear may shine,</line>
      <line>Excelled by nane!</line>
      <line>And a’ the glory shall be thine!</line>
      <line>Amen! Amen!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1795</date>
    <title>January,1795</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pavement slippery, people sneezing;</line>
      <line>Lords in ermine, beggars freezing;</line>
      <line>Titled gluttons dainties carving,</line>
      <line>Genius in a garret starving!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Lofty mansions, warm and spacious;</line>
      <line>Courtiers cringing and voracious;</line>
      <line>Misers scarce the wretched heeding;</line>
      <line>Gallant soldiers fighting, bleeding.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wives who laugh at passive spouses;</line>
      <line>Theatres and meeting-houses;</line>
      <line>Balls, where simpering misses languish;</line>
      <line>Hospitals, and groans of anguish.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Arts and sciences bewailing;</line>
      <line>Commerce drooping, credit failing;</line>
      <line> Placemen mocking subjects loyal;</line>
      <line>Separations, weddings royal.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Authors who can’t earn a dinner;</line>
      <line>Many a subtle rogue a winner;</line>
      <line>Fugitives for shelter seeking;</line>
      <line>Misers hoarding, tradesmen breaking.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Taste and talents quite deserted;</line>
      <line>All the laws of truth perverted;</line>
      <line>Arrogance o’er merit soaring –</line>
      <line>Merit silently deploring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ladies gambling night and morning;</line>
      <line>Fools the works of genius scorning;</line>
      <line>Ancient dames for girls mistaken,</line>
      <line>Youthful damsels quite forsaken.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some in luxury, delighting</line>
      <line>More in talking than in fighting;</line>
      <line>Lovers old, and beaux decrepid,</line>
      <line>Lordlings empty and insipid.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poets, painters and musicians;</line>
      <line>Lawyers, doctors, politicians;</line>
      <line> Pamphlets, newspapers and odes,</line>
      <line>Seeking fame by different roads.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gallant souls with empty purses;</line>
      <line>Generals only fit for nurses;</line>
      <line>Schoolboys smit with martial spirit</line>
      <line>Taking place of martial merit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Honest men who can’t get places,</line>
      <line>Knaves who show unblushing faces –</line>
      <line>Ruin hastened, peace retarded,</line>
      <line>Candour spurned and art rewarded.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>The Idiot Boy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis eight o’clock, a clear March night,</line>
      <line>The moon is up, the sky is blue,</line>
      <line>The owlet in the moonlight air</line>
      <line>He shouts from nobody knows where,</line>
      <line> He lengthens out his lonely shout,</line>
      <line>Halloo! Halloo! A long halloo!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why bustle thus about your door,</line>
      <line>What means this bustle, Betty Foy?</line>
      <line>Why are you in this mighty fret?</line>
      <line>And why on horseback have you set</line>
      <line>Him whom you love, your idiot boy?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beneath the moon that shines so bright,</line>
      <line>Till she is tired, let Betty Foy</line>
      <line>With girth and stirrup fiddle-faddle –</line>
      <line> But wherefore set upon a saddle</line>
      <line>Him whom she loves, her idiot boy?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s scarce a soul that’s out of bed;</line>
      <line>Good Betty, put him down again!</line>
      <line>His lips with joy they burr at you,</line>
      <line>But Betty, what has he to do</line>
      <line>With stirrup, saddle, or with rein?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world will say ’tis very idle,</line>
      <line>Bethink you of the time of night!</line>
      <line>There’s not a mother, no not one,</line>
      <line> But when she hears what you have done,</line>
      <line>Oh Betty she’ll be in a fright!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Betty’s bent on her intent,</line>
      <line>For her good neighbour, Susan Gale</line>
      <line>(Old Susan, she who dwells alone)</line>
      <line>Is sick, and makes a piteous moan</line>
      <line>As if her very life would fail.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s not a house within a mile,</line>
      <line>No hand to help them in distress;</line>
      <line>Old Susan lies abed in pain,</line>
      <line> And sorely puzzled are the twain,</line>
      <line>For what she ails they cannot guess.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty’s husband’s at the wood</line>
      <line>Where by the week he doth abide,</line>
      <line>A woodman in the distant vale;</line>
      <line>There’s none to help poor Susan Gale –</line>
      <line>What must be done, what will betide?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty from the lane has fetched</line>
      <line>Her pony that is mild and good</line>
      <line>Whether he be in joy or pain,</line>
      <line> Feeding at will along the lane</line>
      <line>Or bringing faggots from the wood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he is all in travelling trim,</line>
      <line>And by the moonlight Betty Foy</line>
      <line>Has up upon the saddle set –</line>
      <line>The like was never heard of yet –</line>
      <line>Him whom she loves, her idiot boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he must post without delay</line>
      <line>Across the bridge that’s in the dale,</line>
      <line>And by the church, and o’er the down,</line>
      <line> To bring a doctor from the town,</line>
      <line>Or she will die, old Susan Gale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is no need of boot or spur,</line>
      <line>There is no need of whip or wand,</line>
      <line>For Johnny has his holly-bough,</line>
      <line>And with a hurly-burly now</line>
      <line>He shakes the green bough in his hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty o’er and o’er has told</line>
      <line>The boy who is her best delight,</line>
      <line>Both what to follow, what to shun,</line>
      <line> What do, and what to leave undone,</line>
      <line>How turn to left, and how to right.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty’s most especial charge</line>
      <line>Was, ‘Johnny! Johnny! mind that you</line>
      <line>Come home again, nor stop at all,</line>
      <line>Come home again, whate’er befall,</line>
      <line>My Johnny do, I pray you do.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To this did Johnny answer make</line>
      <line>Both with his head and with his hand,</line>
      <line>And proudly shook the bridle too;</line>
      <line> And then, his words were not a few,</line>
      <line>Which Betty well could understand!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now that Johnny is just going,</line>
      <line>Though Betty’s in a mighty flurry,</line>
      <line>She gently pats the pony’s side</line>
      <line>On which her idiot boy must ride,</line>
      <line>And seems no longer in a hurry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when the pony moved his legs,</line>
      <line>Oh, then for the poor idiot boy! –</line>
      <line>For joy he cannot hold the bridle,</line>
      <line> For joy his head and heels are idle,</line>
      <line>He’s idle all for very joy!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And while the pony moves his legs,</line>
      <line>In Johnny’s left hand you may see</line>
      <line>The green bough’s motionless and dead;</line>
      <line>The moon that shines above his head</line>
      <line>Is not more still and mute than he.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His heart it was so full of glee</line>
      <line>That till full fifty yards were gone</line>
      <line>He quite forgot his holly whip</line>
      <line> And all his skill in horsemanship –</line>
      <line>Oh happy, happy, happy John!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty’s standing at the door,</line>
      <line>And Betty’s face with joy o’erflows –</line>
      <line>Proud of herself, and proud of him,</line>
      <line>OO She sees him in his travelling trim,</line>
      <line>How quietly her Johnny goes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The silence of her idiot boy,</line>
      <line>What hopes it sends to Betty’s heart!</line>
      <line>He’s at the guide-post – he turns right,</line>
      <line>She watches till he’s out of sight,</line>
      <line>And Betty will not then depart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Burr, burr – now Johnny’s lips they burr,</line>
      <line>As loud as any mill, or near it!</line>
      <line>Meek as a lamb the pony moves,</line>
      <line>And Johnny makes the noise he loves,</line>
      <line>And Betty listens, glad to hear it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away she hies to Susan Gale,</line>
      <line>And Johnny’s in a merry tune;</line>
      <line>The owlets hoot, the owlets curr,</line>
      <line> And Johnny’s lips they burr, burr, burr,</line>
      <line>And on he goes beneath the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His steed and he right well agree,</line>
      <line>For of this pony there’s a rumour</line>
      <line>That should he lose his eyes and ears,</line>
      <line>And should he live a thousand years,</line>
      <line>He never will be out of humour.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But then he is a horse that thinks,</line>
      <line>And when he thinks his pace is slack!</line>
      <line>Now, though he knows poor Johnny well,</line>
      <line> Yet for his life he cannot tell</line>
      <line>What he has got upon his back.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So through the moonlight lanes they go,</line>
      <line>And far into the moonlight dale,</line>
      <line>And by the church, and o’er the down,</line>
      <line>To bring a doctor from the town,</line>
      <line>To comfort poor old Susan Gale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty, now at Susan’s side,</line>
      <line>Is in the middle of her story,</line>
      <line>What comfort Johnny soon will bring–</line>
      <line> With many a most diverting thing</line>
      <line>Of Johnny’s wit and Johnny’s glory.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty’s still at Susan’s side –</line>
      <line>By this time she’s not quite so flurried;</line>
      <line>Demure with porringer and plate</line>
      <line>She sits, as if in Susan’s fate</line>
      <line>Her life and soul were buried.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Betty, poor good woman, she</line>
      <line>(You plainly in her face may read it)</line>
      <line>Could lend out of that moment’s store</line>
      <line> Five years of happiness or more,</line>
      <line>To any that might need it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But yet I guess that now and then</line>
      <line>With Betty all was not so well;</line>
      <line>And to the road she turns her ears,</line>
      <line>And thence full many a sound she hears</line>
      <line>Which she to Susan will not tell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Susan moans, poor Susan groans,</line>
      <line>‘As sure as there’s a moon in heaven’,</line>
      <line>Cries Betty, ‘he’ll be back again!</line>
      <line> They’ll both be here, ’tis almost ten –</line>
      <line>They’ll both be here before eleven.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Susan moans, poor Susan groans,</line>
      <line>The clock gives warning for eleven –</line>
      <line>’Tis on the stroke! ‘If Johnny’s near’,</line>
      <line>Quoth Betty, ‘he will soon be here,</line>
      <line>As sure as there’s a moon in heaven.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The clock is on the stroke of twelve</line>
      <line>And Johnny is not yet in sight;</line>
      <line>The moon’s in heaven, as Betty sees,</line>
      <line> But Betty is not quite at ease –</line>
      <line>And Susan has a dreadful night!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty, half an hour ago,</line>
      <line>On Johnny vile reflections cast,</line>
      <line>‘A little idle sauntering thing!’</line>
      <line>With other names, an endless string,</line>
      <line>But now that time is gone and past.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty’s drooping at the heart,</line>
      <line>That happy time all past and gone,</line>
      <line>‘How can it be he is so late?</line>
      <line> The doctor he has made him wait –</line>
      <line>Susan, they’ll both be here anon.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Susan’s growing worse and worse,</line>
      <line>And Betty’s in a sad quandary –</line>
      <line>And then there’s nobody to say</line>
      <line>If she must go or she must stay;</line>
      <line>She’s in a sad quandary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The clock is on the stroke of one,</line>
      <line>But neither doctor nor his guide</line>
      <line>Appear along the moonlight road;</line>
      <line> There’s neither horse nor man abroad,</line>
      <line>And Betty’s still at Susan’s side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Susan she begins to fear</line>
      <line>Of sad mischances not a few:</line>
      <line>That Johnny may perhaps be drowned,</line>
      <line>Or lost perhaps, and never found –</line>
      <line>Which they must both forever rue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She prefaced half a hint of this</line>
      <line>With, ‘God forbid it should be true!’</line>
      <line>At the first word that Susan said</line>
      <line> Cried Betty, rising from the bed,</line>
      <line>‘Susan, I’d gladly stay with you!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I must be gone, I must away!</line>
      <line>Consider, Johnny’s but half-wise;</line>
      <line>Susan, we must take care of him.</line>
      <line>If he is hurt in life or limb’ –</line>
      <line>‘Oh God forbid!’ poor Susan cries.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What can I do?’ says Betty, going,</line>
      <line>‘What can I do to ease your pain?</line>
      <line>Good Susan tell me, and I’ll stay;</line>
      <line>I fear you’re in a dreadful way,</line>
      <line>But I shall soon be back again.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Good Betty go, good Betty go,</line>
      <line>There’s nothing that can ease my pain’</line>
      <line>Then off she hies, but with a prayer</line>
      <line>That God poor Susan’s life would spare,</line>
      <line>Till she comes back again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So through the moonlight lane she goes,</line>
      <line>And far into the moonlight dale;</line>
      <line>And how she ran, and how she walked,</line>
      <line> And all that to herself she talked,</line>
      <line>Would surely be a tedious tale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In high and low, above, below,</line>
      <line>In great and small, in round and square,</line>
      <line>In tree and tower, was Johnny seen –</line>
      <line>In bush and brake, in black and green,</line>
      <line>’Twas Johnny, Johnny, everywhere.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She’s past the bridge that’s in the dale,</line>
      <line>And now the thought torments her sore,</line>
      <line>Johnny perhaps his horse forsook</line>
      <line> To hunt the moon that’s in the brook,</line>
      <line>And never will be heard of more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now she’s high upon the down,</line>
      <line>Alone amid a prospect wide;</line>
      <line>There’s neither Johnny nor his horse</line>
      <line>Among the fern or in the gorse;</line>
      <line>There’s neither doctor nor his guide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh saints, what is become of him?</line>
      <line>Perhaps he’s climbed into an oak,</line>
      <line>Where he will stay till he is dead;</line>
      <line> Or sadly he has been misled,</line>
      <line>And joined the wandering gypsy-folk.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or him that wicked pony’s carried</line>
      <line>To the dark cave, the goblins’ hall,</line>
      <line>Or in the castle he’s pursuing,</line>
      <line>Among the ghosts, his own undoing;</line>
      <line>Or playing with the waterfall.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At poor old Susan then she railed</line>
      <line>While to the town she posts away,</line>
      <line>‘If Susan had not been so ill,</line>
      <line> Alas, I should have had him still,</line>
      <line>My Johnny, till my dying day.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Betty, in this sad distemper,</line>
      <line>The doctor’s self would hardly spare;</line>
      <line>Unworthy things she talked and wild –</line>
      <line>Even he, of cattle the most mild,</line>
      <line>The pony had his share.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now she’s got into the town,</line>
      <line>And to the doctor’s door she hies;</line>
      <line>’Tis silence all on every side –</line>
      <line> The town so long, the town so wide,</line>
      <line>Is silent as the skies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now she’s at the doctor’s door,</line>
      <line>She lifts the knocker, rap, rap, rap;</line>
      <line>The doctor at the casement shows</line>
      <line>His glimmering eyes that peep and doze,</line>
      <line>And one hand rubs his old nightcap.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh doctor, doctor, where’s my Johnny?’</line>
      <line>‘I’m here, what is’t you want with me?’</line>
      <line>‘Oh sir, you know I’m Betty Foy,</line>
      <line> And I have lost my poor dear boy!</line>
      <line>You know him, him you often see –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He’s not so wise as some folks be.’</line>
      <line>‘The Devil take his wisdom!’ said</line>
      <line>The doctor, looking somewhat grim;</line>
      <line>‘What, woman, should I know of him?’</line>
      <line>And, grumbling, he went back to bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh woe is me! Oh woe is me!</line>
      <line>Here will I die, here will I die;</line>
      <line>I thought to find my Johnny here,</line>
      <line> But he is neither far nor near –</line>
      <line>Oh what a wretched mother I!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She stops, she stands, she looks about,</line>
      <line>Which way to turn she cannot tell.</line>
      <line>Poor Betty! It would ease her pain</line>
      <line>If she had heart to knock again;</line>
      <line>The clock strikes three – a dismal knell!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then up along the town she hies,</line>
      <line>No wonder if her senses fail,</line>
      <line>This piteous news so much it shocked her,</line>
      <line> She quite forgot to send the doctor,</line>
      <line>To comfort poor old Susan Gale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now she’s high upon the down,</line>
      <line>And she can see a mile of road,</line>
      <line>‘Oh cruel! I’m almost three-score –</line>
      <line>Such night as this was ne’er before,</line>
      <line>There’s not a single soul abroad.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She listens, but she cannot hear</line>
      <line>The foot of horse, the voice of man;</line>
      <line>The streams with softest sound are flowing,</line>
      <line> The grass you almost hear it growing –</line>
      <line>You hear it now if e’er you can.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The owlets through the long blue night</line>
      <line>Are shouting to each other still –</line>
      <line>Fond lovers, yet not quite hob-nob,</line>
      <line>They lengthen out the tremulous sob</line>
      <line>That echoes far from hill to hill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Betty now has lost all hope,</line>
      <line>Her thoughts are bent on deadly sin;</line>
      <line>A green-grown pond she just has passed,</line>
      <line>And from the brink she hurries fast,</line>
      <line>Lest she should drown herself therein.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now she sits her down and weeps –</line>
      <line>Such tears she never shed before –</line>
      <line>‘Oh dear, dear pony! My sweet joy!</line>
      <line>Oh carry back my idiot boy,</line>
      <line>And we will ne’er o’erload thee more!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A thought is come into her head:</line>
      <line>‘The pony he is mild and good,</line>
      <line>And we have always used him well;</line>
      <line> Perhaps he’s gone along the dell</line>
      <line>And carried Johnny to the wood.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then up she springs as if on wings,</line>
      <line>She thinks no more of deadly sin –</line>
      <line>If Betty fifty ponds should see,</line>
      <line>The last of all her thoughts would be</line>
      <line>To drown herself therein.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh reader, now that I might tell</line>
      <line>What Johnny and his horse are doing!</line>
      <line>What they’ve been doing all this time –</line>
      <line> Oh could I put it into rhyme,</line>
      <line>A most delightful tale pursuing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perhaps (and no unlikely thought!)</line>
      <line>He with his pony now doth roam</line>
      <line>The cliffs and peaks so high that are,</line>
      <line>To lay his hands upon a star,</line>
      <line>And in his pocket bring it home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perhaps he’s turned himself about,</line>
      <line>His face unto his horse’s tail,</line>
      <line>And still and mute, in wonder lost,</line>
      <line> All like a silent horseman-ghost</line>
      <line>He travels on along the vale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now perhaps he’s hunting sheep,</line>
      <line>A fierce and dreadful hunter he!</line>
      <line>Yon valley, that’s so trim and green,</line>
      <line>In five months’ time, should he be seen,</line>
      <line>A desert wilderness will be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perhaps, with head and heels on fire</line>
      <line>And like the very soul of evil,</line>
      <line>He’s galloping away, away,</line>
      <line> And so he’ll gallop on for aye,</line>
      <line>The bane of all that dread the Devil.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I to the Muses have been bound,</line>
      <line>These fourteen years, by strong indentures;</line>
      <line>Oh gentle Muses, let me tell</line>
      <line>But half of what to him befell,</line>
      <line>For sure he met with strange adventures!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh gentle Muses, is this kind?</line>
      <line>Why will ye thus my suit repel?</line>
      <line>Why of your further aid bereave me?</line>
      <line> And can ye thus unfriended leave me,</line>
      <line>Ye Muses, whom I love so well?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who’s yon, that near the waterfall</line>
      <line>Which thunders down with headlong force</line>
      <line>Beneath the moon, yet shining fair,</line>
      <line>As careless as if nothing were,</line>
      <line>Sits upright on a feeding horse?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unto his horse, that’s feeding free,</line>
      <line>He seems, I think, the rein to give;</line>
      <line>Of moon or stars he takes no heed</line>
      <line> (Of such we in romances read) –</line>
      <line>’Tis Johnny, Johnny, as I live!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that’s the very pony too!</line>
      <line>Where is she, where is Betty Foy?</line>
      <line>She hardly can sustain her fears –</line>
      <line>The roaring waterfall she hears,</line>
      <line>And cannot find her idiot boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your pony’s worth his weight in gold;</line>
      <line>Then calm your terrors, Betty Foy!</line>
      <line>She’s coming from among the trees,</line>
      <line> And now, all full in view, she sees</line>
      <line>Him whom she loves, her idiot boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Betty sees the pony too!</line>
      <line>Why stand you thus good Betty Foy?</line>
      <line>It is no goblin, ’tis no ghost,</line>
      <line>’Tis he whom you so long have lost,</line>
      <line>He whom you love, your idiot boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She looks again – her arms are up –</line>
      <line>She screams – she cannot move for joy!</line>
      <line>She darts as with a torrent’s force,</line>
      <line> She almost has o’erturned the horse,</line>
      <line>And fast she holds her idiot boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Johnny burrs and laughs aloud –</line>
      <line>Whether in cunning or in joy</line>
      <line>I cannot tell, but while he laughs</line>
      <line>Betty a drunken pleasure quaffs</line>
      <line>To hear again her idiot boy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now she’s at the pony’s tail,</line>
      <line>And now she’s at the pony’s head,</line>
      <line>On that side now, and now on this;</line>
      <line> And, almost stifled with her bliss,</line>
      <line>A few sad tears does Betty shed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She kisses o’er and o’er again</line>
      <line>Him whom she loves, her idiot boy;</line>
      <line>She’s happy here, she’s happy there,</line>
      <line>She is uneasy everywhere –</line>
      <line>Her limbs are all alive with joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She pats the pony, where or when</line>
      <line>She knows not, happy Betty Foy!</line>
      <line>The little pony glad may be,</line>
      <line>But he is milder far than she,</line>
      <line>You hardly can perceive his joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh Johnny, never mind the doctor!</line>
      <line>You’ve done your best, and that is all.’</line>
      <line>She took the reins, when this was said,</line>
      <line>And gently turned the pony’s head</line>
      <line>From the loud waterfall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By this the stars were almost gone;</line>
      <line>The moon was setting on the hill,</line>
      <line>So pale you scarcely looked at her;</line>
      <line> The little birds began to stir,</line>
      <line>Though yet their tongues were still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pony, Betty, and her boy,</line>
      <line>Wind slowly through the woody dale:</line>
      <line>And who is she, betimes abroad,</line>
      <line>That hobbles up the steep rough road –</line>
      <line>Who is it, but old Susan Gale?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Long Susan lay deep lost in thought,</line>
      <line>And many dreadful fears beset her,</line>
      <line>Both for her messenger and nurse;</line>
      <line> And as her mind grew worse and worse,</line>
      <line>Her body it grew better.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She turned, she tossed herself, in bed –</line>
      <line>On all sides doubts and terrors met her;</line>
      <line>Point after point did she discuss,</line>
      <line>And while her mind was fighting thus,</line>
      <line>Her body still grew better.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Alas, what is become of them?</line>
      <line>These fears can never be endured –</line>
      <line>I’ll to the wood.’ The word scarce said,</line>
      <line> Did Susan rise up from her bed,</line>
      <line>As if by magic cured.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away she posts up hill and down,</line>
      <line>And to the wood at length is come;</line>
      <line>She spies her friends, she shouts a greeting –</line>
      <line>Oh me, it is a merry meeting</line>
      <line>As ever was in Christendom!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The owls have hardly sung their last</line>
      <line>While our four travellers homeward wend;</line>
      <line>The owls have hooted all night long –</line>
      <line> And with the owls began my song,</line>
      <line>And with the owls must end.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For while they all were travelling home,</line>
      <line>Cried Betty, ‘Tell us Johnny, do,</line>
      <line>Where all this long night you have been,</line>
      <line>What you have heard, what you have seen,</line>
      <line>And Johnny, mind you tell us true.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now Johnny all night long had heard</line>
      <line>The owls in tuneful concert strive;</line>
      <line>No doubt too he the moon had seen,</line>
      <line> For in the moonlight he had been</line>
      <line>From eight o’clock till five.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus to Betty’s question, he</line>
      <line>Made answer, like a traveller bold</line>
      <line>(His very words I give to you):</line>
      <line>‘The cocks did crow to-whoo, to-whoo,</line>
      <line>And the sun did shine so cold.’</line>
      <line>Thus answered Johnny in his glory,</line>
      <line>And that was all his travel’s story.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>from Peter Bell</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it some party, in a parlour</line>
      <line>Crammed (just as they on earth were crammed),</line>
      <line>Some sipping punch, some sipping tea,</line>
      <line>But as you by their faces see,</line>
      <line> All silent and all damned?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis no such thing, I do assure you,</line>
      <line>Which Peter sees in the clear flood.</line>
      <line>It is no ugly apprehension</line>
      <line>Of eyes and ears, ’tis no invention –</line>
      <line>It is a thing of flesh and blood...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now poor Peter is convinced,</line>
      <line>While still he holds the ass’s head,</line>
      <line>That ’tis a fiend with visage wan,</line>
      <line>A live man-fiend, a living man,</line>
      <line> That’s lying in the river-bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He looks, he looks, he looks again,</line>
      <line>He sees a motion, hears a groan;</line>
      <line>His eyes will burst, his heart will break,</line>
      <line>He gives a loud and dreadful shriek,</line>
      <line>And back he falls just like a stone...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He lifts his head, he sees his staff,</line>
      <line>He touches – ’tis to him a treasure!</line>
      <line>To find that he is not in Hell,</line>
      <line>As you’ll suppose to Peter Bell</line>
      <line> Doth give a sweet and languid pleasure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And while upon his side he lies,</line>
      <line>His head upon his elbow raised,</line>
      <line>Almost you’d say as in a dream</line>
      <line>His eyes are settling on the stream</line>
      <line>Where he before had gazed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No dimple now disturbs the stream;</line>
      <line>In Peter’s brain there is no riot;</line>
      <line>His eye upon the stream he fixes,</line>
      <line>And with the sight no terror mixes,</line>
      <line>His heart is calm and quiet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Quoth he, ‘That is a dead man’s face</line>
      <line>Among the shadows of the trees!</line>
      <line>Those are no doubt a dead man’s knuckles,</line>
      <line>And there you see his brass shoe-buckles.</line>
      <line>And there his breeches’ knees.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At last he rises from his side,</line>
      <line>And sits upright upon the ground,</line>
      <line>And o’er the stream he hangs his nose</line>
      <line>And points his staff as you’d suppose</line>
      <line> The river’s depth to sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This sees the ass, while on the grass</line>
      <line>Close by the river’s brink he lies,</line>
      <line>And straight with a transition tragic,</line>
      <line>That seems just like the touch of magic,</line>
      <line>Up from the ground the ass doth rise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At this friend Peter round him looks,</line>
      <line>And sees the poor and patient creature</line>
      <line>Close to him, in his uncouth way</line>
      <line>Expressing all the joy he may</line>
      <line> In every limb and feature.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His meagre bones all shake with joy,</line>
      <line>And close by Peter’s side he stands;</line>
      <line>While Peter o’er the river bends,</line>
      <line>The little ass his neck extends</line>
      <line>And fondly licks his hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such life is in the ass’s eyes,</line>
      <line>Such life is in his limbs and ears,</line>
      <line>That Peter Bell, if he had been</line>
      <line>The veriest coward ever seen,</line>
      <line> Must now have thrown aside his fears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With caution Peter eyes the stream</line>
      <line>(The sapling deep and deeper goes);</line>
      <line>‘The body is no doubt’, quoth he,</line>
      <line>‘The thing which it appears to be –</line>
      <line>It moves not, neither limbs, nor clothes.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The ass looks on, and to his work</line>
      <line>Is Peter quietly resigned:</line>
      <line>He touches here, he touches there,</line>
      <line>And now among the dead man’s hair</line>
      <line> His sapling Peter has entwined.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He pulls, and pulls, and pulls again,</line>
      <line>And he whom the poor ass had lost –</line>
      <line>The man who had been four days dead –</line>
      <line>Head-foremost from the river’s bed</line>
      <line>Uprises like a ghost!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>We Are Seven</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A simple child, dear brother Jim,</line>
      <line>That lightly draws its breath,</line>
      <line>And feels its life in every limb,</line>
      <line>What should it know of death?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I met a little cottage-girl–</line>
      <line>She was eight years old, she said –</line>
      <line>Her hair was thick with many a curl</line>
      <line>That clustered round her head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She had a rustic, woodland air,</line>
      <line>And she was wildly clad;</line>
      <line>Her eyes were fair, and very fair –</line>
      <line>Her beauty made me glad.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sisters and brothers, little maid,</line>
      <line>How many may you be?’</line>
      <line> ‘How many? Seven in all’, she said,</line>
      <line>And wondering looked at me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And where are they, I pray you tell?’</line>
      <line>She answered, ‘Seven are we,</line>
      <line>And two of us at Conway dwell,</line>
      <line>And two are gone to sea;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Two of us in the churchyard lie,</line>
      <line>My sister and my brother;</line>
      <line>And in the churchyard-cottage, I</line>
      <line>Dwell near them with my mother.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘You say that two at Conway dwell,</line>
      <line>And two are gone to sea,</line>
      <line>Yet you are seven – I pray you tell,</line>
      <line>Sweet maid, how this may be?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then did the little maid reply,</line>
      <line>‘Seven boys and girls are we –</line>
      <line>Two of us in the churchyard lie,</line>
      <line>Beneath the churchyard-tree.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You run about, my little maid,</line>
      <line>Your limbs they are alive;</line>
      <line> If two are in the churchyard laid,</line>
      <line>Then ye are only five.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Their graves are green, they may be seen’,</line>
      <line>The little maid replied,</line>
      <line>‘Twelve steps or more from my mother’s door,</line>
      <line>And they are side by side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My stockings there I often knit,</line>
      <line>My kerchief there I hem,</line>
      <line>And there upon the ground I sit,</line>
      <line>I sit and sing to them.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And often after sunset, sir,</line>
      <line>When it is light and fair,</line>
      <line>I take my little porringer</line>
      <line>And eat my supper there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The first that died was little Jane;</line>
      <line>In bed she moaning lay,</line>
      <line>Till God released her of her pain,</line>
      <line>And then she went away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So in the churchyard she was laid,</line>
      <line>And all the summer dry</line>
      <line> Together round her grave we played,</line>
      <line>My brother John and I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the ground was white with snow</line>
      <line>And I could run and slide,</line>
      <line>My brother John was forced to go,</line>
      <line>And he lies by her side.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How many are you then’, said I,</line>
      <line>‘If they two are in Heaven?’</line>
      <line>The little maiden did reply,</line>
      <line>‘Oh master, we are seven!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘But they are dead, those two are dead –</line>
      <line>Their spirits are in Heaven!’</line>
      <line>’Twas throwing words away, for still</line>
      <line>The little maid would have her will,</line>
      <line>And said, ‘Nay, we are seven!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY AND SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>The Devil’s Thoughts</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>From his brimstone bed at break of day</line>
      <line>A walking the Devil is gone,</line>
      <line>To visit his snug little farm the Earth,</line>
      <line>And see how his stock went on.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Over the hill and over the dale,</line>
      <line>And he went over the plain,</line>
      <line>And backward and forward he swished his long tail</line>
      <line>As a gentleman swishes his cane.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He saw a lawyer killing a viper</line>
      <line>On the dunghill beside his stable;</line>
      <line>‘Oh, oh!’, quoth he, for it put him in mind</line>
      <line>Of the story of Cain and Abel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An apothecary on a white horse</line>
      <line>Rode by on his vocation,</line>
      <line> And the Devil thought of his old friend</line>
      <line>Death in the Revelation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He went into a rich bookseller’s shop,</line>
      <line>Quoth he, ‘We are both of one college!</line>
      <line>For I sat myself, like a cormorant, once</line>
      <line>Upon the tree of knowledge.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He saw a turnkey in a trice</line>
      <line>Hand-cuff a troublesome blade;</line>
      <line>‘Nimbly,’ quoth he, ‘the fingers move</line>
      <line>If a man is but used to his trade.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He saw the same turnkey unfettering a man,</line>
      <line>With but little expedition,</line>
      <line>And he laughed for he thought of the long debates</line>
      <line>On the Slave-trade abolition.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As he went through [Cold-Bath] fields he looked</line>
      <line>At a solitary cell;</line>
      <line>And the Devil was pleased, for it gave him a hint</line>
      <line>For improving the prisons of Hell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He past a cottage with a double coach-house,</line>
      <line>A cottage of gentility;</line>
      <line> And he grinned at the sight, for his favourite vice</line>
      <line>Is pride that apes humility.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He saw a pig right rapidly</line>
      <line>Adown the river float,</line>
      <line>The pig swam well, but every stroke</line>
      <line>Was cutting his own throat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Nicholas grinned and swished his tail</line>
      <line>For joy and admiration;</line>
      <line>And he thought of his daughter, Victory,</line>
      <line>And his darling babe, Taxation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He met an old acquaintance</line>
      <line>Just by the Methodist meeting –</line>
      <line>She held a consecrated flag,</line>
      <line>And the Devil nods a greeting.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She tipped him the wink, then frowned and cried,</line>
      <line>‘Avaunt! my name’s Religion’,</line>
      <line>And turned to Mr. W[ilberforce]</line>
      <line>And leered like a love-sick pigeon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>General [Gascoigne]’s burning face</line>
      <line>He saw with consternation,</line>
      <line> And back to Hell his way did take,</line>
      <line>For the Devil thought by a slight mistake</line>
      <line>It was general conflagration.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>GEORGE CRABBE</author>
    <date>1812</date>
    <title>Procrastination</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love will expire – the gay, the happy dream</line>
      <line>Will turn to scorn, indifference, or esteem.</line>
      <line>Some favoured pairs, in this exchange, are blest,</line>
      <line>Nor sigh for raptures in a state of rest;</line>
      <line> Others, ill-matched, with minds unpaired, repent</line>
      <line>At once the deed, and know no more content –</line>
      <line>From joy to anguish they in haste decline,</line>
      <line>And, with their fondness, their esteem resign.</line>
      <line>More luckless still their fate, who are the prey</line>
      <line>Of long-protracted hope and dull delay:</line>
      <line>Mid plans of bliss the heavy hours pass on,</line>
      <line>Till love is withered, and till joy is gone.</line>
      <line>This gentle flame two youthful hearts possessed,</line>
      <line>The sweet disturber of unenvied rest:</line>
      <line> The prudent Dinah was the maid beloved,</line>
      <line>And the kind Rupert was the swain approved.</line>
      <line>A wealthy aunt her gentle niece sustained,</line>
      <line>He, with a father, at his desk remained –</line>
      <line>The youthful couple, to their vows sincere,</line>
      <line>Thus loved expectant, year succeeding year,</line>
      <line>With pleasant views and hopes, but not a prospect near.</line>
      <line>Rupert some comfort in his station saw,</line>
      <line>But the poor virgin lived in dread and awe;</line>
      <line>Upon her anxious looks the widow smiled,</line>
      <line> And bade her wait, ‘for she was yet a child’.</line>
      <line>She for her neighbour had a due respect,</line>
      <line>Nor would his son encourage or reject;</line>
      <line>And thus the pair, with expectations vain,</line>
      <line>Beheld the seasons change and change again.</line>
      <line>Meantime the nymph her tender tales perused,</line>
      <line>Where cruel aunts impatient girls refused –</line>
      <line>While hers, though teasing, boasted to be kind,</line>
      <line>And she, resenting, to be all resigned!</line>
      <line>The dame was sick, and when the youth applied</line>
      <line> For her consent, she groaned, and coughed, and cried,</line>
      <line>Talked of departing, and again her breath</line>
      <line>Drew hard, and coughed, and talked again of death:</line>
      <line>‘Here you may live, my Dinah – here the boy</line>
      <line>And you together my estate enjoy!’</line>
      <line>Thus to the lovers was her mind expressed,</line>
      <line>Till they forbore to urge the fond request.</line>
      <line>Servant, and nurse, and comforter, and friend,</line>
      <line>Dinah had still some duty to attend –</line>
      <line>But yet their walk, when Rupert’s evening call</line>
      <line> Obtained an hour, made sweet amends for all.</line>
      <line>So long they now each other’s thoughts had known,</line>
      <line>That nothing seemed exclusively their own;</line>
      <line>But with the common wish, the mutual fear,</line>
      <line>They now had travelled to their thirtieth year.</line>
      <line>At length a prospect opened – but alas!</line>
      <line>Long time must yet, before the union, pass:</line>
      <line>Rupert was called, in other clime, to increase</line>
      <line>Another’s wealth, and toil for future peace.</line>
      <line>Loath were the lovers; but the aunt declared</line>
      <line> ’Twas fortune’s call, and they must be prepared:</line>
      <line>‘You now are young, and for this brief delay,</line>
      <line>And Dinah’s care, what I bequeath will pay –</line>
      <line>All will be yours! Nay, love, suppress that sigh!</line>
      <line>The kind must suffer, and the best must die!’</line>
      <line>Then came the cough, and strong the signs it gave</line>
      <line>Of holding long contention with the grave.</line>
      <line>The lovers parted with a gloomy view,</line>
      <line>And little comfort, but that both were true;</line>
      <line>He for uncertain duties doomed to steer,</line>
      <line> While hers remained too certain and severe.</line>
      <line>Letters arrived, and Rupert fairly told</line>
      <line>His cares were many, and his hopes were cold:</line>
      <line>The view more clouded, that was never fair,</line>
      <line>And love alone preserved him from despair –</line>
      <line>In other letters brighter hopes he drew,</line>
      <line>His friends were kind, and he believed them true!</line>
      <line>When the sage widow Dinah’s grief descried,</line>
      <line>She wondered much why one so happy sighed,</line>
      <line>Then bade her see how her poor aunt sustained</line>
      <line> The ills of life, nor murmured nor complained.</line>
      <line>To vary pleasures, from the lady’s chest</line>
      <line>Were drawn the pearly string and tabby vest,</line>
      <line>Beads, jewels, laces, all their value shown,</line>
      <line>With the kind notice – ‘They will be your own!’</line>
      <line>This hope, these comforts, cherished day by day,</line>
      <line>To Dinah’s bosom made a gradual way,</line>
      <line>Till love of treasure had as large a part</line>
      <line>As love of Rupert, in the virgin’s heart.</line>
      <line>Whether it be that tender passions fail,</line>
      <line> From their own nature, while the strong prevail;</line>
      <line>Or whether avarice, like the poison-tree,</line>
      <line>Kills all beside it, and alone will be –</line>
      <line>Whatever cause prevailed, the pleasure grew</line>
      <line>In Dinah’s soul: she loved the hoards to view;</line>
      <line>With lively joy those comforts she surveyed,</line>
      <line>And love grew languid in the careful maid.</line>
      <line>Now the grave niece partook the widow’s cares,</line>
      <line>Looked to the great, and ruled the small affairs;</line>
      <line>Saw cleaned the plate, arranged the china-show,</line>
      <line> And felt her passion for a shilling grow:</line>
      <line>The indulgent aunt increased the maid’s delight,</line>
      <line>By placing tokens of her wealth in sight;</line>
      <line>She loved the value of her bonds to tell,</line>
      <line>And spake of stocks, and how they rose and fell.</line>
      <line>This passion grew, and gained at length such sway</line>
      <line>That other passions shrank to make it way;</line>
      <line>Romantic notions now the heart forsook,</line>
      <line>She read but seldom, and she changed her book;</line>
      <line>And for the verses she was wont to send,</line>
      <line>Short was her prose – and she was Rupert’s friend.</line>
      <line>Seldom she wrote, and then the widow’s cough,</line>
      <line>And constant call, excused her breaking off;</line>
      <line>Who, now oppressed, no longer took the air,</line>
      <line>But sat and dozed upon an easy chair.</line>
      <line>The cautious doctor saw the case was clear,</line>
      <line>But judged it best to have companions near;</line>
      <line>They came, they reasoned, they prescribed – at last,</line>
      <line>Like honest men, they said their hopes were past!</line>
      <line>Then came a priest – ’tis comfort to reflect,</line>
      <line> When all is over, there was no neglect!</line>
      <line>And all was over: by her husband’s bones</line>
      <line>The widow rests beneath the sculptured stones</line>
      <line>That yet record their fondness and their fame;</line>
      <line>While all they left, the virgin’s care became –</line>
      <line>Stock, bonds, and buildings! It disturbed her rest</line>
      <line>To think what load of troubles she possessed;</line>
      <line>Yet, if a trouble, she resolved to take</line>
      <line>The important duty for the donor’s sake!</line>
      <line>She too was heiress to the widow’s taste,</line>
      <line> Her love of hoarding, and her dread of waste.</line>
      <line>Sometimes the past would on her mind intrude,</line>
      <line>And then a conflict full of care ensued:</line>
      <line>The thoughts of Rupert on her mind would press –</line>
      <line>His worth she knew, but doubted his success –</line>
      <line>Of old she saw him heedless: what the boy</line>
      <line>Forbore to save, the man would not enjoy.</line>
      <line>Oft had he lost the chance that care would seize,</line>
      <line>Willing to live, but more to live at ease –</line>
      <line>Yet could she not a broken vow defend,</line>
      <line> And Heaven, perhaps, might yet enrich her friend!</line>
      <line>Month after month was passed, and all were spent</line>
      <line>In quiet comfort and in rich content:</line>
      <line>Miseries there were, and woes the world around,</line>
      <line>But these had not her pleasant dwelling found;</line>
      <line>She knew that mothers grieved, and widows wept,</line>
      <line>And she was sorry, said her prayers, and slept!</line>
      <line>Thus passed the seasons, and to Dinah’s board</line>
      <line>Gave what the seasons to the rich afford;</line>
      <line>For she indulged – nor was her heart so small,</line>
      <line> That one strong passion should engross it all!</line>
      <line>A love of splendour now with avarice strove,</line>
      <line>And oft appeared to be the stronger love:</line>
      <line>A secret pleasure filled the Widow’s breast</line>
      <line>When she reflected on the hoards possessed,</line>
      <line>But livelier joy inspired the ambitious Maid</line>
      <line>When she the purchase of those hoards displayed.</line>
      <line>In small but splendid room she loved to see</line>
      <line>That all was placed in view and harmony;</line>
      <line>There, as with eager glance she looked around,</line>
      <line> She much delight in every object found;</line>
      <line>While books devout were near her – to destroy,</line>
      <line>Should it arise, an overflow of joy!</line>
      <line>Within that fair apartment guests might see</line>
      <line>The comforts culled for wealth by vanity:</line>
      <line>Around the room an Indian paper blazed,</line>
      <line>With lively tint and figures boldly raised;</line>
      <line>Silky and soft upon the floor below,</line>
      <line>The elastic carpet rose with crimson glow.</line>
      <line>All things around implied both cost and care –</line>
      <line> What met the eye was elegant or rare!</line>
      <line>Some curious trifles round the room were laid,</line>
      <line>By hope presented to the wealthy maid;</line>
      <line>Within a costly case of varnished wood,</line>
      <line>In level rows, her polished volumes stood</line>
      <line>(Shown as a favour to a chosen few,</line>
      <line>To prove what beauty for a book could do);</line>
      <line>A silver urn with curious work was fraught,</line>
      <line>A silver lamp from Grecian pattern wrought;</line>
      <line>Above her head, all gorgeous to behold,</line>
      <line> A timepiece stood on feet of burnished gold.</line>
      <line>A stag’s-head crest adorned the pictured case –</line>
      <line>Through the pure crystal shone the enamelled face –</line>
      <line>And while on brilliants moved the hands of steel,</line>
      <line>It clicked from prayer to prayer, from meal to meal.</line>
      <line>Here as the lady sat, a friendly pair</line>
      <line>Stepped in to admire the view, and took their chair –</line>
      <line>They then related how the young and gay</line>
      <line>Were thoughtless wandering in the broad highway,</line>
      <line>How tender damsels sailed in tilted boats</line>
      <line> And laughed with wicked men in scarlet coats,</line>
      <line>And how we live in such degenerate times</line>
      <line>That men conceal their wants, and show their crimes,</line>
      <line>While vicious deeds are screened by fashion’s name,</line>
      <line>And what was once our pride is now our shame.</line>
      <line>Dinah was musing, as her friends discoursed,</line>
      <line>When these last words a sudden entrance forced</line>
      <line>Upon her mind – and ‘what was once her pride</line>
      <line>And now her shame’ some painful views supplied.</line>
      <line>Thoughts of the past within her bosom pressed,</line>
      <line> And there a change was felt, and was confessed.</line>
      <line>While thus the virgin strove with secret pain,</line>
      <line>Her mind was wandering o’er the troubled main –</line>
      <line>Still she was silent, nothing seemed to see,</line>
      <line>But sat and sighed in pensive reverie.</line>
      <line>OO The friends prepared new subjects to begin –</line>
      <line>When tall Susannah, maiden starch, stalked in!</line>
      <line>Not in her ancient mode, sedate and slow,</line>
      <line>As when she came, the mind she knew, to know;</line>
      <line>Nor as, when listening half an hour before,</line>
      <line>She twice or thrice tapped gently at the door;</line>
      <line>But, all decorum cast in wrath aside,</line>
      <line>‘I think the devil’s in the man!’ she cried –</line>
      <line>‘A huge tall sailor, with his tawny cheek,</line>
      <line>And pitted face, will with my lady speak!</line>
      <line>He grinned an ugly smile, and said he knew,</line>
      <line>Please you, my lady, ’twould be joy to you –</line>
      <line>What must I answer?’ Trembling and distressed</line>
      <line>Sank the pale Dinah by her fears oppressed,</line>
      <line>When, thus alarmed, and brooking no delay,</line>
      <line>Swift to her room the stranger made his way.</line>
      <line> ‘Revive, my love’, said he, ‘I’ve done thee harm –</line>
      <line>Give me thy pardon!’ and he looked alarm.</line>
      <line>Meantime the prudent Dinah had contrived</line>
      <line>Her soul to question, and she then revived.</line>
      <line>‘See, my good friend’ – and then she raised her head –</line>
      <line>‘The bloom of life, the strength of youth is fled!</line>
      <line>Living we die – to us the world is dead!</line>
      <line>We parted blest with health, and I am now</line>
      <line>Age-struck and feeble – so I find art thou:</line>
      <line>Thine eye is sunken, furrowed is thy face,</line>
      <line> And downward lookst thou. So we run our race –</line>
      <line>And happier they whose race is nearly run,</line>
      <line>Their troubles over, and their duties done!’</line>
      <line>‘True, lady, true – we are not girl and boy,</line>
      <line>But time has left us something to enjoy.’</line>
      <line>‘What! thou hast learned my fortune? Yes, I live</line>
      <line>To feel how poor the comforts wealth can give!</line>
      <line>Thou too perhaps art wealthy – but our fate</line>
      <line>Still mocks our wishes! Wealth is come too late.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘To me, nor late nor early! I am come</line>
      <line> Poor as I left thee to my native home –</line>
      <line>Nor yet’, said Rupert, ‘will I grieve. ’Tis mine</line>
      <line>To share thy comforts, and the glory thine:</line>
      <line>For thou wilt gladly take that generous part</line>
      <line>That both exalts and gratifies the heart;</line>
      <line>While mine rejoices –’ ‘Heavens!’ returned the maid,</line>
      <line>‘This talk to one so withered and decayed?</line>
      <line>No! all my care is now to fit my mind</line>
      <line>For other spousal, and to die resigned.</line>
      <line>As friend and neighbour, I shall hope to see</line>
      <line> These noble views, this pious love, in thee –</line>
      <line>That we together may the change await</line>
      <line>(Guides and spectators in each other’s fate),</line>
      <line>When, fellow-pilgrims, we shall daily crave</line>
      <line>The mutual prayer that arms us for the grave!’</line>
      <line>Half angry, half in doubt, the lover gazed</line>
      <line>On the meek maiden, by her speech amazed:</line>
      <line>‘Dinah’, said he, ‘dost thou respect thy vows?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What spousal meanest thou? Thou art Rupert’s spouse!</line>
      <line>The chance is mine to take, and thine to give –</line>
      <line> But, trifling this, if we together live.</line>
      <line>Can I believe that after all the past,</line>
      <line>Our vows, our loves, thou wilt be false at last?</line>
      <line>Something thou hast – I know not what – in view:</line>
      <line>I find thee pious – let me find thee true!’</line>
      <line>‘Ah, cruel this – but do, my friend, depart,</line>
      <line>And to its feelings leave my wounded heart!’</line>
      <line>‘Nay, speak at once – and Dinah, let me know,</line>
      <line>Meanest thou to take me, now I’m wrecked, in tow?</line>
      <line>Be fair; nor longer keep me in the dark –</line>
      <line> Am I forsaken for a trimmer spark?</line>
      <line>Heaven’s spouse thou art not; nor can I believe</line>
      <line>That God accepts her who will man deceive!</line>
      <line>True I am shattered – I have service seen,</line>
      <line>And service done, and have in trouble been!</line>
      <line>My cheek (it shames me not) has lost its red,</line>
      <line>And the brown buff is o’er my features spread.</line>
      <line>Perchance my speech is rude, for I among</line>
      <line>The untamed have been, in temper and in tongue –</line>
      <line>Have been trepanned, have lived in toil and care,</line>
      <line> And wrought for wealth I was not doomed to share.</line>
      <line>It touched me deeply, for I felt a pride</line>
      <line>In gaining riches for my destined bride!</line>
      <line>Speak then my fate. For these my sorrows past,</line>
      <line>Time lost, youth fled, hope wearied, and at last</line>
      <line>This doubt of thee (a childish thing to tell,</line>
      <line>But certain truth) – my very throat they swell;</line>
      <line>They stop the breath, and but for shame could I</line>
      <line>Give way to weakness, and with passion cry.</line>
      <line>These are unmanly struggles, but I feel</line>
      <line> This hour must end them – and perhaps will heal.’</line>
      <line>Here Dinah sighed, as if afraid to speak,</line>
      <line>And then repeated – they were frail and weak;</line>
      <line>His soul she loved, and hoped he had the grace</line>
      <line>To fix his thoughts upon a better place.</line>
      <line>She ceased. With steady glance, as if to see</line>
      <line>The very root of this hypocrisy,</line>
      <line>He her small fingers moulded in his hard</line>
      <line>And bronzed broad hand – then told her his regard,</line>
      <line>His best respect were gone, but love had still</line>
      <line> Hold in his heart, and governed yet the will,</line>
      <line>Or he would curse her. Saying this, he threw</line>
      <line>The hand in scorn away, and bade adieu</line>
      <line>To every lingering hope, with every care in view.</line>
      <line>Proud and indignant, suffering, sick, and poor,</line>
      <line>He grieved unseen, and spoke of love no more –</line>
      <line>Till all he felt in indignation died,</line>
      <line>As hers had sunk in avarice and pride.</line>
      <line>In health declining, as in mind distressed,</line>
      <line>To some in power his troubles he confessed,</line>
      <line>And shares a parish-gift. At prayers he sees</line>
      <line>The pious Dinah dropped upon her knees;</line>
      <line>Thence as she walks the street with stately air</line>
      <line>As chance directs, oft meet the parted pair.</line>
      <line>When he, with thickset coat of badge-man’s blue,</line>
      <line>Moves near her shaded silk of changeful hue;</line>
      <line>When his thin locks of gray approach her braid</line>
      <line>(A costly purchase made in beauty’s aid);</line>
      <line>When his frank air, and his unstudied pace,</line>
      <line>Are seen with her soft manner, air, and grace,</line>
      <line> And his plain artless look with her sharp meaning face;</line>
      <line>It might some wonder in a stranger move,</line>
      <line>How these together could have talked of love.</line>
      <line>Behold them now! See there a tradesman stands,</line>
      <line>And humbly hearkens to some fresh commands.</line>
      <line>He moves to speak, she interrupts him: ‘Stay!’</line>
      <line>Her air expresses – ‘Hark to what I say!’</line>
      <line>Ten paces off, poor Rupert on a seat</line>
      <line>Has taken refuge from the noonday heat,</line>
      <line>His eyes on her intent, as if to find</line>
      <line> What were the movements of that subtle mind.</line>
      <line>How still, how earnest is he! It appears</line>
      <line>His thoughts are wandering through his earlier years –</line>
      <line>Through years of fruitless labour, to the day</line>
      <line>When all his earthly prospects died away:</line>
      <line>‘Had I’, he thinks, ‘been wealthier of the two,</line>
      <line>Would she have found me so unkind, untrue?</line>
      <line>Or knows not man when poor, what man when rich will do?</line>
      <line>Yes, yes! I feel that I had faithful proved,</line>
      <line>And should have soothed and raised her, blest and loved!’</line>
      <line> But Dinah moves – she had observed before,</line>
      <line>The pensive Rupert at an humble door.</line>
      <line>Some thoughts of pity raised by his distress,</line>
      <line>Some feeling touch of ancient tenderness;</line>
      <line>Religion, duty, urged the maid to speak,</line>
      <line>In terms of kindness to a man so weak;</line>
      <line>But pride forbade – and to return would prove</line>
      <line>She felt the shame of his neglected love.</line>
      <line>Nor wrapped in silence could she pass, afraid</line>
      <line>Each eye should see her, and each heart upbraid.</line>
      <line> One way remained – the way the Levite took,</line>
      <line>Who without mercy could on misery look</line>
      <line>(A way perceived by craft, approved by pride),</line>
      <line>She crossed and passed him on the other side.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JAMES SMITH</author>
    <date>1812</date>
    <title>The Baby’s Debut, by W. W.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My brother Jack was nine in May,</line>
      <line>And I was eight on New Year’s Day;</line>
      <line>So in Kate Wilson’s shop</line>
      <line>Papa (he’s my papa and Jack’s)</line>
      <line> Bought me, last week, a doll of wax,</line>
      <line>And brother Jack a top.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jack’s in the pouts, and this it is –</line>
      <line>He thinks mine came to more than his;</line>
      <line>So to my drawer he goes,</line>
      <line>Takes out the doll, and, O, my stars!</line>
      <line>He pokes her head between the bars,</line>
      <line>And melts off half her nose!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Quite cross, a bit of string I beg,</line>
      <line>And tie it to his peg-top’s peg,</line>
      <line> And bang, with might and main,</line>
      <line>Its head against the parlour-door:</line>
      <line>Off flies the head, and hits the floor,</line>
      <line>And breaks a window-pane.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This made him cry with rage and spite:</line>
      <line>Well, let him cry, it serves him right.</line>
      <line>A pretty thing, forsooth!</line>
      <line>If he’s to melt, all scalding hot,</line>
      <line>Half my doll’s nose, and I am not</line>
      <line>To draw his peg-top’s tooth!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Aunt Hannah heard the window break,</line>
      <line>And cried, “O naughty Nancy Lake,</line>
      <line>Thus to distress your aunt:</line>
      <line>No Drury-Lane for you to-day!”</line>
      <line>And while papa said, “Pooh, she may!”</line>
      <line>Mamma said, “No, she shan’t!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, after many a sad reproach,</line>
      <line>They got into a hackney coach,</line>
      <line>And trotted down the street.</line>
      <line>I saw them go: one horse was blind,</line>
      <line> The tails of both hung down behind,</line>
      <line>Their shoes were on their feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The chaise in which poor brother Bill</line>
      <line>Used to be drawn to Pentonville,</line>
      <line>Stood in the lumber-room:</line>
      <line>I wiped the dust from off the top,</line>
      <line>While Molly mopped it with a mop,</line>
      <line>And brushed it with a broom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My uncle’s porter, Samuel Hughes,</line>
      <line>Came in at six to black the shoes</line>
      <line> (I always talk to Sam);</line>
      <line>So what does he, but takes, and drags</line>
      <line>Me in the chaise along the flags,</line>
      <line>And leaves me where I am.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My father’s walls are made of brick,</line>
      <line>But not so tall and not so thick</line>
      <line>As these; and, goodness me!</line>
      <line>My father’s beams are made of wood,</line>
      <line>But never, never half so good</line>
      <line>As those that now I see.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> What a large floor! ’tis like a town!</line>
      <line>The carpet when they lay it down,</line>
      <line>Won’t hide it, I’ll be bound;</line>
      <line>And there’s a row of lamps! – my eye!</line>
      <line>How they do blaze! I wonder why</line>
      <line>They keep them on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At first I caught hold of the wing,</line>
      <line>And kept away; but Mr. Thingumbob,</line>
      <line>the prompter man,</line>
      <line>Gave with his hand my chaise a shove,</line>
      <line> And said, “Go on, my pretty love;</line>
      <line>Speak to ’em, little Nan.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You’ve only got to curtsy, whisper,</line>
      <line>hold your chin up, laugh, and lisp,</line>
      <line>And then you’re sure to take:</line>
      <line>I’ve known the day when brats, not quite</line>
      <line>Thirteen, got fifty pounds a-night;</line>
      <line>Then why not Nancy Lake?”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But while I’m speaking, where’s papa?</line>
      <line>And where’s my aunt? and where’s mamma?</line>
      <line> Where’s Jack? Oh, there they sit!</line>
      <line>They smile, they nod; I’ll go my ways,</line>
      <line>And order round poor Billy’s chaise,</line>
      <line>To join them in the pit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now, good gentle-folks, I go</line>
      <line>To join mamma, and see the show;</line>
      <line>So, bidding you adieu,</line>
      <line>I curtsy, like a pretty miss,</line>
      <line>And if you’ll blow to me,</line>
      <line>I’ll blow a kiss to you.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JAMES HOGG</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>from James Rigg</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>On Tuesday morn, at half past six o’clock,</line>
      <line>I rose and dressed myself, and having shut</line>
      <line>The door o’ the bedroom still and leisurely,</line>
      <line>I walked down stairs. When at the outer door</line>
      <line> I firmly grasped the key, that ere night-fall</line>
      <line>Had turned the lock into its wonted niche</line>
      <line>Within the brazen implement, that shone</line>
      <line>With no unseemly splendour – mellowed light</line>
      <line>Elicited by touch of careful hand</line>
      <line>On the brown lintel – and the obedient door</line>
      <line>(As at a potent necromancer’s touch)</line>
      <line>Into the air receded suddenly,</line>
      <line>And gave wide prospect of the sparkling lake,</line>
      <line>Just then emerging from the snow-white mist</line>
      <line> Like angel’s veil slow-folded up to Heaven.</line>
      <line>And lo! a vision bright and beautiful</line>
      <line>Sheds a refulgent glory o’er the sand –</line>
      <line>The sand and glory of my avenue,</line>
      <line>For, standing silent by the kitchen-door</line>
      <line>(Tinged by the morning sun, and in its own</line>
      <line>Brown natural hide most lovely, two long ears</line>
      <line>Upstretching perpendicularly, then</line>
      <line>With the horizon levelled – to my gaze</line>
      <line>Superb as horn of fabled unicorn –</line>
      <line> Each in its own proportions grander far</line>
      <line>Than the frontal glory of that wandering beast,</line>
      <line>Child of the desert), lo! a beauteous ass,</line>
      <line>With panniers hanging silent at each side,</line>
      <line>Silent as cage of bird whose song is mute –</line>
      <line>Though silent yet not empty – filled with bread,</line>
      <line>The staff of life, the means by which the soul</line>
      <line>(By fate obedient to the powers of sense)</line>
      <line>Renews its faded vigour, and keeps up</line>
      <line>A proud communion with the external heavens.</line>
      <line> Fastened to a ring it stood, while at its head</line>
      <line>A boy of six years old, an angel bright,</line>
      <line>Patted its neck, and to its mouth applied</line>
      <line>The harmless thistle that his hand had plucked</line>
      <line>From the wild common, melancholy crop!</line>
      <line>Not undelightful was that simple sight,</line>
      <line>For I at once did recognize that ass</line>
      <line>To be the property of one James Rigg...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JAMES HOGG</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Isabelle</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Can there be a moon in heaven tonight,</line>
      <line>That the hill and gray cloud seem so light?</line>
      <line>The air is whitened by some spell,</line>
      <line>For there is no moon, I know it well;</line>
      <line> On this third day the sages say –</line>
      <line>’Tis wonderful how well they know! –</line>
      <line>The moon is journeying far away,</line>
      <line>Bright somewhere in a heaven below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is a strange and lovely night,</line>
      <line>A grayish pale, but not white!</line>
      <line>Is it rain, or is it dew,</line>
      <line>That falls so thick I see its hue?</line>
      <line>In rays it follows, one, two, three,</line>
      <line>Down the air so merrily;</line>
      <line> Said Isabelle, ‘So let it be!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why does the Lady Isabelle</line>
      <line>Sit in the damp and dewy dell</line>
      <line>Counting the racks of drizzly rain?</line>
      <line>And how often the rail cries over again,</line>
      <line>For she’s harping, harping, in the brake,</line>
      <line>‘Craik, craik, craik, craik’ –</line>
      <line>Ten times nine, and thrice eleven;</line>
      <line>That last call was an hundred and seven!</line>
      <line>‘Craik, craik, the hour is near!’</line>
      <line> Let it come, I have no fear –</line>
      <line>Yet it is a dreadful work, I wis,</line>
      <line>Such doings in a night like this!</line>
      <line>Sounds the river harsh and loud?</line>
      <line>The stream sounds harsh, but not loud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a cloud that seems to hover</line>
      <line>By western hill the churchyard over –</line>
      <line>What is it like? ’Tis like a whale!</line>
      <line>’Tis like a shark with half the tail –</line>
      <line>Not half, but a third and more –</line>
      <line> Now ’tis a wolf, and now a boar;</line>
      <line>Its face is raised, it cometh here –</line>
      <line>Let it come, there is no fear!</line>
      <line>There’s two for Heaven, and ten for Hell –</line>
      <line>‘Let it come, ’tis well, ’tis well!’</line>
      <line>Said the Lady Isabelle.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN HOOKHAM FRERE</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>Whistlecraft (Canto III)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I’ve a proposal here from Mr Murray –</line>
      <line>He offers handsomely, the money down –</line>
      <line>My dear, you might recover from your flurry</line>
      <line>In a nice airy lodging out of town,</line>
      <line> At Croyden, Epsom, anywhere in Surrey –</line>
      <line>If every stanza brings us in a crown,</line>
      <line>I think that I might venture to bespeak</line>
      <line>A bedroom and front parlour for next week.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tell me, my dear Thalia, what you think –</line>
      <line>Your nerves have undergone a sudden shock,</line>
      <line>Your poor dear spirits have begun to sink –</line>
      <line>On Banstead Downs you’d muster a new stock,</line>
      <line>And I’d be sure to keep away from drink</line>
      <line>And always go to bed by twelve o’clock!</line>
      <line> We’ll travel down there in the morning stages:</line>
      <line>Our verses shall go down to distant ages.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And here in town we’ll breakfast on hot rolls,</line>
      <line>And you shall have a better shawl to wear –</line>
      <line>These pantaloons of mine are chafed in holes,</line>
      <line>By Monday next I’ll compass a new pair –</line>
      <line>Come now, fling up the cinders, fetch the coals,</line>
      <line>And take away the things you hung to air;</line>
      <line>Set out the tea-things, and bid Phoebe bring</line>
      <line>The kettle up – Arms and the Monks I sing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Some ten miles off an ancient Abbey stood</line>
      <line>Amidst the mountains, near a noble stream –</line>
      <line>A level eminence, enshrined with wood,</line>
      <line>Sloped to the river’s bank and southern beam.</line>
      <line>Within were fifty friars fat and good,</line>
      <line>Of goodly persons, and of good esteem,</line>
      <line>That passed an easy, exemplary life,</line>
      <line>Remote from want and care and worldly strife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Between the Monks and Giants there subsisted</line>
      <line>In the first Abbot’s lifetime much respect;</line>
      <line> The Giants let them settle where they listed –</line>
      <line>The Giants were a tolerating sect!</line>
      <line>A poor lame Giant once the Monks assisted:</line>
      <line>Old and abandoned, dying with neglect,</line>
      <line>The Prior found him, cured his broken bone,</line>
      <line>And very kindly cut him for the stone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This seemed a glorious, golden opportunity</line>
      <line>To civilize the whole gigantic race;</line>
      <line>To draw them to pay tithes and dwell in unity;</line>
      <line>The Giant’s valley was a fertile place,</line>
      <line> And might have much enriched the whole community</line>
      <line>Had the old Giant lived a longer space –</line>
      <line>But he relapsed, and though all means were tried,</line>
      <line>They could but just baptize him – when he died.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I believe the Giants never knew</line>
      <line>Of the kind treatment that befell their mate</line>
      <line>(He broke down all at once, and all the crew</line>
      <line>Had taken leave, and left him to his fate),</line>
      <line>And though the Monks exposed him full in view,</line>
      <line>Propped on his crutches at the garden-gate</line>
      <line> To prove their cure, and show that all was right,</line>
      <line>It happened that no Giants came in sight…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In castles and in courts Ambition dwells,</line>
      <line>But not in castles or in courts alone;</line>
      <line> She breathed a wish, throughout those sacred cells,</line>
      <line>For bells of larger size, and louder tone.</line>
      <line>Giants abominate the sound of bells,</line>
      <line>And soon the fierce antipathy was shown –</line>
      <line>The tinkling and the jingling and the clangour</line>
      <line>Roused their irrational gigantic anger!</line>
    </stanza>
