    <stanza>
      <line>Unhappy mortals, ever blind to fate!</line>
      <line>Unhappy Monks, you see no danger nigh!</line>
      <line>Exulting in their sound and size and weight,</line>
      <line>From morn till noon the merry peal you ply:</line>
      <line> The belfry rocks, your bosoms are elate,</line>
      <line>Your spirits with the ropes and pulleys fly –</line>
      <line>Tired, but transported, panting, pulling, hauling,</line>
      <line>Ramping and stamping, overjoyed and bawling.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Meanwhile the solemn mountains that surrounded</line>
      <line>The silent valley where the Convent lay,</line>
      <line>With tintinabular uproar were astounded,</line>
      <line>When the first peal burst forth at break of day:</line>
      <line>Feeling their granite ears severely wounded,</line>
      <line>They scarce knew what to think, or what to say,</line>
      <line> And – though large mountains commonly conceal</line>
      <line>Their sentiments, dissembling what they feel –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet Cader-Gibbrish from his cloudy throne</line>
      <line>To huge Loblommon gave an intimation</line>
      <line>Of this strange rumour, with an awful tone</line>
      <line>Thundering his deep surprise and indignation.</line>
      <line>The lesser hills, in language of their own,</line>
      <line>Discussed the topic by reverberation,</line>
      <line>Discoursing with their echoes all day long –</line>
      <line>Their only conversation was, ‘ding-dong’!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Those giant-mountains inwardly were moved,</line>
      <line>But never made an outward change of place:</line>
      <line>Not so the mountain-giants – as behoved</line>
      <line>A more alert and locomotive race –</line>
      <line>Hearing a clatter which they disapproved,</line>
      <line>They ran straight forward to besiege the place</line>
      <line>With a discordant universal yell,</line>
      <line>Like house-dog howling at a dinner-bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>Old Meg She Was a Gypsy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Meg she was a gypsy,</line>
      <line>And lived upon the moors,</line>
      <line>Her bed it was the brown heath-turf,</line>
      <line>And her house was out-of-doors.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Her apples were swart blackberries,</line>
      <line>Her currants pods o’ broom,</line>
      <line>Her wine was dew of the white wild rose,</line>
      <line>Her book a churchyard tomb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her brothers were the craggy hills,</line>
      <line>Her sisters larchen trees –</line>
      <line>Alone with her great family</line>
      <line>She lived as she did please.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No breakfast had she many a morn,</line>
      <line>No dinner many a noon,</line>
      <line> And ‘stead of supper she would stare</line>
      <line>Full hard against the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For every morn, of woodbine fresh</line>
      <line>She made a garlanding,</line>
      <line>And every night the dark glen yew</line>
      <line>She wove – and she would sing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And with her fingers old and brown</line>
      <line>She plaited mats o’ rushes,</line>
      <line>And gave them to the cottagers</line>
      <line>She met among the bushes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Old Meg she was brave as Margaret Queen</line>
      <line>And tall as Amazon,</line>
      <line>An old red blanket-cloak she wore,</line>
      <line>A chip-hat had she on –</line>
      <line>God rest her agéd bones somewhere,</line>
      <line>She died full long agone!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Peter Bell the Third (IV)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lo, Peter in Hell’s Grosvenor Square,</line>
      <line>A footman in the Devil’s service!</line>
      <line>And the misjudging world would swear</line>
      <line>That every man in service there</line>
      <line> To virtue would prefer vice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Peter, though now damned, was not</line>
      <line>What Peter was before damnation:</line>
      <line>Men oftentimes prepare a lot</line>
      <line>Which, ere it finds them, is not what</line>
      <line>Suits with their genuine station.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All things that Peter saw and felt</line>
      <line>Had a peculiar aspect to him;</line>
      <line>And when they came within the belt</line>
      <line>Of his own nature, seemed to melt,</line>
      <line> Like cloud to cloud, into him.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so the outward world uniting</line>
      <line>To that within him, he became</line>
      <line>Considerably uninviting</line>
      <line>To those who, meditation slighting,</line>
      <line>Were moulded in a different frame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he scorned them, and they scorned him!</line>
      <line>And he scorned all they did – and they</line>
      <line>Did all that men of their own trim</line>
      <line>Are wont to do to please their whim,</line>
      <line> Drinking, lying, swearing, play.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such were his fellow-servants – thus</line>
      <line>His virtue, like our own, was built</line>
      <line>Too much on that indignant fuss</line>
      <line>Hypocrite pride stirs up in us</line>
      <line>To bully one another’s guilt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had a mind which was somehow</line>
      <line>At once circumference and centre</line>
      <line>Of all he might or feel or know –</line>
      <line>Nothing went ever out, although</line>
      <line> Something did ever enter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had as much imagination</line>
      <line>As a pint-pot – he never could</line>
      <line>Fancy another situation,</line>
      <line>From which to dart his contemplation,</line>
      <line>Than that wherein he stood!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet his was individual mind,</line>
      <line>And new created all he saw</line>
      <line>In a new manner, and refined</line>
      <line>Those new creations, and combined</line>
      <line> Them, by a master-spirit’s law.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus, though unimaginative,</line>
      <line>An apprehension clear, intense,</line>
      <line>Of his mind’s work, had made alive</line>
      <line>The things it wrought on – I believe</line>
      <line>Wakening a sort of thought in sense.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But from the first ’twas Peter’s drift</line>
      <line>To be a kind of moral eunuch,</line>
      <line>He touched the hem of Nature’s shift,</line>
      <line>Felt faint – and never dared uplift</line>
      <line> The closest, all-concealing tunic!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She laughed the while, with an arch smile,</line>
      <line>And kissed him with a sister’s kiss,</line>
      <line>And said: ‘My best Diogenes,</line>
      <line>I love you well, but, if you please,</line>
      <line>Tempt not again my deepest bliss!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis you are cold – for I, not coy,</line>
      <line>Yield love for love, frank, warm, and true;</line>
      <line>And Burns, a Scottish peasant-boy –</line>
      <line>His errors prove it – knew my joy</line>
      <line> More, learnéd friend, than you...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Don Juan (I)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> Young Juan now was sixteen years of age,</line>
      <line>Tall, handsome, slender, but well knit; he seemed</line>
      <line>Active, though not so sprightly, as a page;</line>
      <line>And everybody but his mother deemed</line>
      <line>Him almost man; but she flew in a rage</line>
      <line>And bit her lips (for else she might have screamed)</line>
      <line>If any said so, for to be precocious</line>
      <line>Was in her eyes a thing the most atrocious.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Amongst her numerous acquaintance, all</line>
      <line>Selected for discretion and devotion,</line>
      <line> There was the Donna Julia, whom to call</line>
      <line>Pretty were but to give a feeble notion</line>
      <line>Of many charms in her as natural</line>
      <line>As sweetness to the flower, or salt to ocean,</line>
      <line>Her zone to Venus, or his bow to Cupid</line>
      <line>(But this last simile is trite and stupid).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The darkness of her oriental eye</line>
      <line>Accorded with her Moorish origin.</line>
      <line>Her blood was not all Spanish, by the by</line>
      <line>(In Spain, you know, this is a sort of sin):</line>
      <line> When proud Grenada fell, and, forced to fly,</line>
      <line>Boabdil wept, of Donna Julia’s kin</line>
      <line>Some went to Africa, some stayed in Spain –</line>
      <line>Her great great grandmamma chose to remain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She married (I forget the pedigree)</line>
      <line>With an hidalgo, who transmitted down</line>
      <line>His blood less noble than such blood should be;</line>
      <line>At such alliances his sires would frown,</line>
      <line>In that point so precise in each degree</line>
      <line>That they bred in and in, as might be shown,</line>
      <line> Marrying their cousins – nay, their aunts and nieces,</line>
      <line>Which always spoils the breed, if it increases.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This heathenish cross restored the breed again,</line>
      <line>Ruined its blood, but much improved its flesh;</line>
      <line>For, from a root the ugliest in old Spain</line>
      <line>Sprung up a branch as beautiful as fresh;</line>
      <line>The sons no more were short, the daughters plain –</line>
      <line>But there’s a rumour which I fain would hush:</line>
      <line>’Tis said that Donna Julia’s grandmamma</line>
      <line>Produced her Don more heirs at love than law.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> However this might be, the race went on</line>
      <line>Improving still through every generation,</line>
      <line>Until it centered in an only son,</line>
      <line>Who left an only daughter; my narration</line>
      <line>May have suggested that this single one</line>
      <line>Could be but Julia (whom on this occasion</line>
      <line>I shall have much to speak about), and she</line>
      <line>Was married, charming, chaste, and twenty-three.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her eye (I’m very fond of handsome eyes)</line>
      <line>Was large and dark, suppressing half its fire</line>
      <line> Until she spoke, then through its soft disguise</line>
      <line>Flashed an expression more of pride than ire,</line>
      <line>And love than either; and there would arise</line>
      <line>A something in them which was not desire,</line>
      <line>But would have been, perhaps, but for the soul</line>
      <line>Which struggled through and chastened down the whole.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her glossy hair was clustered o’er a brow</line>
      <line>Bright with intelligence, and fair and smooth;</line>
      <line>Her eyebrow’s shape was like the aerial bow,</line>
      <line>Her cheek all purple with the beam of youth,</line>
      <line> Mounting, at times, to a transparent glow,</line>
      <line>As if her veins ran lightning; she, in sooth,</line>
      <line>Possessed an air and grace by no means common,</line>
      <line>Her stature tall – I hate a dumpy woman.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wedded she was some years, and to a man</line>
      <line>Of fifty – and such husbands are in plenty –</line>
      <line>And yet, I think, instead of such a ONE</line>
      <line>’Twere better to have TWO of five and twenty,</line>
      <line>Especially in countries near the sun:</line>
      <line>And now I think on’t, mi vien in mente,</line>
      <line> Ladies even of the most uneasy virtue</line>
      <line>Prefer a spouse whose age is short of thirty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis a sad thing, I cannot choose but say,</line>
      <line>And all the fault of that indecent sun</line>
      <line>Who cannot leave alone our helpless clay</line>
      <line>But will keep baking, broiling, burning on,</line>
      <line>That howsoever people fast and pray</line>
      <line>The flesh is frail, and so the soul undone:</line>
      <line>What men call gallantry, and gods adultery,</line>
      <line>Is much more common where the climate’s sultry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Happy the nations of the moral north!</line>
      <line>Where all is virtue, and the winter season</line>
      <line>Sends sin, without a rag on, shivering forth</line>
      <line>(’Twas snow that brought St Anthony to reason);</line>
      <line>Where juries cast up what a wife is worth</line>
      <line>By laying whate’er sum, in mulct, they please on</line>
      <line>The lover, who must pay a handsome price</line>
      <line>Because it is a marketable vice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alfonso was the name of Julia’s lord,</line>
      <line>A man well looking for his years, and who</line>
      <line> Was neither much beloved, nor yet abhorred;</line>
      <line>They lived together as most people do,</line>
      <line>Suffering each other’s foibles by accord,</line>
      <line>And not exactly either one or two;</line>
      <line>Yet he was jealous, though he did not show it,</line>
      <line>For jealousy dislikes the world to know it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Julia was – yet I never could see why –</line>
      <line>With Donna Inez quite a favourite friend;</line>
      <line>Between their tastes there was small sympathy,</line>
      <line>For not a line had Julia ever penned.</line>
      <line> Some people whisper (but, no doubt, they lie,</line>
      <line>For malice still imputes some private end)</line>
      <line>That Inez had, ere Don Alfonso’s marriage,</line>
      <line>Forgot with him her very prudent carriage;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that, still keeping up the old connection,</line>
      <line>Which time had lately rendered much more chaste,</line>
      <line>She took his lady also in affection.</line>
      <line>And certainly this course was much the best:</line>
      <line>She flattered Julia with her sage protection,</line>
      <line>And complimented Don Alfonso’s taste;</line>
      <line> And if she could not (who can?) silence scandal,</line>
      <line>At least she left it a more slender handle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I can’t tell whether Julia saw the affair</line>
      <line>With other people’s eyes, or if her own</line>
      <line>Discoveries made, but none could be aware</line>
      <line>Of this, at least no symptom e’er was shown;</line>
      <line>Perhaps she did not know, or did not care,</line>
      <line>Indifferent from the first, or callous grown:</line>
      <line>I’m really puzzled what to think or say,</line>
      <line>She kept her counsel in so close a way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Juan she saw, and, as a pretty child,</line>
      <line>Caressed him often, such a thing might be</line>
      <line>Quite innocently done, and harmless styled,</line>
      <line>When she had twenty years, and thirteen he;</line>
      <line>But I am not so sure I should have smiled</line>
      <line>When he was sixteen, Julia twenty-three,</line>
      <line>These few short years make wondrous alterations,</line>
      <line>Particularly amongst sun-burnt nations.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Whate’er the cause might be, they had become</line>
      <line>Changed; for the dame grew distant, the youth shy,</line>
      <line> Their looks cast down, their greetings almost dumb,</line>
      <line>And much embarrassment in either eye.</line>
      <line>There surely will be little doubt with some</line>
      <line>That Donna Julia knew the reason why,</line>
      <line>But as for Juan, he had no more notion</line>
      <line>Than he who never saw the sea of ocean.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet Julia’s very coldness still was kind,</line>
      <line>And tremulously gentle her small hand</line>
      <line>Withdrew itself from his, but left behind</line>
      <line>A little pressure, thrilling, and so bland</line>
      <line> And slight, so very slight, that to the mind</line>
      <line>’Twas but a doubt; but ne’er magician’s wand</line>
      <line>Wrought change with all Armida’s fairy art</line>
      <line>Like what this light touch left on Juan’s heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if she met him, though she smiled no more,</line>
      <line>She looked a sadness sweeter than her smile,</line>
      <line>As if her heart had deeper thoughts in store</line>
      <line>She must not own, but cherished more the while</line>
      <line>For that compression in its burning core.</line>
      <line>Even innocence itself has many a wile,</line>
      <line> And will not dare to trust itself with truth –</line>
      <line>And love is taught hypocrisy from youth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But passion most dissembles yet betrays</line>
      <line>Even by its darkness; as the blackest sky</line>
      <line>Foretells the heaviest tempest, it displays</line>
      <line>Its workings through the vainly guarded eye,</line>
      <line>And in whatever aspect it arrays</line>
      <line>Itself, ’tis still the same hypocrisy;</line>
      <line>Coldness or anger, even disdain or hate,</line>
      <line>Are masks it often wears, and still too late.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then there were sighs, the deeper for suppression,</line>
      <line>And stolen glances, sweeter for the theft,</line>
      <line>And burning blushes, though for no transgression,</line>
      <line>Tremblings when met, and restlessness when left;</line>
      <line>All these are little preludes to possession,</line>
      <line>Of which young passion cannot be bereft,</line>
      <line>And merely tend to show how greatly love is</line>
      <line>Embarrassed at first starting with a novice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Julia’s heart was in an awkward state;</line>
      <line>She felt it going, and resolved to make</line>
      <line> The noblest efforts for herself and mate,</line>
      <line>For honour’s, pride’s, religion’s, virtue’s sake;</line>
      <line>Her resolutions were most truly great,</line>
      <line>And almost might have made a Tarquin quake;</line>
      <line>She prayed the Virgin Mary for her grace,</line>
      <line>As being the best judge of a lady’s case.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She vowed she never would see Juan more,</line>
      <line>And next day paid a visit to his mother,</line>
      <line>And looked extremely at the opening door,</line>
      <line>Which, by the Virgin’s grace, let in another;</line>
      <line>Grateful she was, and yet a little sore –</line>
      <line>Again it opens, it can be no other,</line>
      <line>’Tis surely Juan now – No! I’m afraid</line>
      <line>That night the Virgin was no further prayed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She now determined that a virtuous woman</line>
      <line>Should rather face and overcome temptation,</line>
      <line>That flight was base and dastardly, and no man</line>
      <line>Should ever give her heart the least sensation;</line>
      <line>That is to say, a thought beyond the common</line>
      <line>Preference that we must feel upon occasion</line>
      <line> For people who are pleasanter than others –</line>
      <line>But then they only seem so many brothers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And even if by chance (and who can tell –</line>
      <line>The devil’s so very sly) she should discover</line>
      <line>That all within was not so very well,</line>
      <line>And, if still free, that such or such a lover</line>
      <line>Might please perhaps, a virtuous wife can quell</line>
      <line>Such thoughts, and be the better when they’re over.</line>
      <line>And if the man should ask, ’tis but denial:</line>
      <line>I recommend young ladies to make trial.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And then there are such things as love divine,</line>
      <line>Bright and immaculate, unmixed and pure,</line>
      <line>Such as the angels think so very fine,</line>
      <line>And matrons, who would be no less secure,</line>
      <line>Platonic, perfect, ‘just such love as mine’:</line>
      <line>Thus Julia said – and thought so, to be sure –</line>
      <line>And so I’d have her think, were I the man</line>
      <line>On whom her reveries celestial ran.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such love is innocent, and may exist</line>
      <line>Between young persons without any danger –</line>
      <line> A hand may first, and then a lip be kissed –</line>
      <line>For my part, to such doings I’m a stranger,</line>
      <line>But hear these freedoms form the utmost list</line>
      <line>Of all o’er which such love may be a ranger:</line>
      <line>If people go beyond, ’tis quite a crime,</line>
      <line>But not my fault – I tell them all in time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love, then, but love within its proper limits,</line>
      <line>Was Julia’s innocent determination</line>
      <line>In young Don Juan’s favour. And to him, its</line>
      <line>Exertion might be useful on occasion,</line>
      <line> And (lighted at too pure a shrine to dim its</line>
      <line>Etherial lustre) with what sweet persuasion</line>
      <line>He might be taught, by love and her together –</line>
      <line>I really don’t know what, nor Julia either!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fraught with this fine intention, and well fenced</line>
      <line>In mail of proof (her purity of soul),</line>
      <line>She, for the future, of her strength convinced,</line>
      <line>And that her honour was a rock, or mole,</line>
      <line>Exceeding sagely from that hour dispensed</line>
      <line>With any kind of troublesome control –</line>
      <line> But whether Julia to the task was equal</line>
      <line>Is that which must be mentioned in the sequel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her plan she deemed both innocent and feasible,</line>
      <line>And, surely, with a stripling of sixteen</line>
      <line>Not scandal’s fangs could fix on much that’s seizable,</line>
      <line>Or if they did so, satisfied to mean</line>
      <line>Nothing but what was good, her breast was peaceable –</line>
      <line>A quiet conscience makes one so serene!</line>
      <line>Christians have burnt each other, quite persuaded</line>
      <line>That all the Apostles would have done as they did.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And if in the mean time her husband died –</line>
      <line>But Heaven forbid that such a thought should cross</line>
      <line>Her brain, though in a dream – and then she sighed –</line>
      <line>Never could she survive that common loss! –</line>
      <line>But just suppose that moment should betide,</line>
      <line>I only say suppose it, inter nos</line>
      <line>(This should be entre nous, for Julia thought</line>
      <line>In French, but then the rhyme would go for nought),</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I only say suppose this supposition:</line>
      <line>Juan being then grown up to man’s estate</line>
      <line> Would fully suit a widow of condition,</line>
      <line>Even seven years hence it would not be too late;</line>
      <line>And in the interim (to pursue this vision)</line>
      <line>The mischief, after all, could not be great,</line>
      <line>For he would learn the rudiments of love –</line>
      <line>I mean the seraph way of those above.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So much for Julia. Now we’ll turn to Juan,</line>
      <line>Poor little fellow, he had no idea</line>
      <line>Of his own case, and never hit the true one;</line>
      <line>In feelings quick as Ovid’s Miss Medea,</line>
      <line> He puzzled over what he found a new one,</line>
      <line>But not as yet imagined it could be a</line>
      <line>Thing quite in course, and not at all alarming,</line>
      <line>Which, with a little patience, might grow charming.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Silent and pensive, idle, restless, slow,</line>
      <line>His home deserted for the lonely wood,</line>
      <line>Tormented with a wound he could not know,</line>
      <line>His, like all deep grief, plunged in solitude:</line>
      <line>I’m fond myself of solitude or so,</line>
      <line>But then, I beg it may be understood,</line>
      <line> By solitude I mean a sultan’s, not</line>
      <line>A hermit’s, with a harem for a grot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh Love! in such a wilderness as this,</line>
      <line>Where transport and security entwine,</line>
      <line>Here is the empire of thy perfect bliss,</line>
      <line>And here thou art a god indeed divine.’</line>
      <line>The bard I quote from does not sing amiss,</line>
      <line>With the exception of the second line,</line>
      <line>For that same twining ‘transport and security’</line>
      <line>Are twisted to a phrase of some obscurity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The poet meant, no doubt, and thus appeals</line>
      <line>To the good sense and senses of mankind,</line>
      <line>The very thing which everybody feels,</line>
      <line>As all have found on trial, or may find,</line>
      <line>That no one likes to be disturbed at meals</line>
      <line>Or love! I won’t say more about ‘entwined’</line>
      <line>Or ‘transport’, as we knew all that before,</line>
      <line>But beg ‘security’ will bolt the door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Young Juan wandered by the glassy brooks</line>
      <line>Thinking unutterable things; he threw</line>
      <line> Himself at length within the leafy nooks</line>
      <line>Where the wild branch of the cork forest grew;</line>
      <line>There poets find materials for their books,</line>
      <line>And every now and then we read them through,</line>
      <line>So that their plan and prosody are eligible,</line>
      <line>Unless, like Wordsworth, they prove unintelligible.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He, Juan (and not Wordsworth) so pursued</line>
      <line>His self-communion with his own high soul</line>
      <line>Until his mighty heart, in its great mood,</line>
      <line>Had mitigated part, though not the whole</line>
      <line> Of its disease; he did the best he could</line>
      <line>With things not very subject to control,</line>
      <line>And turned, without perceiving his condition,</line>
      <line>Like Coleridge, into a metaphysician.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He thought about himself, and the whole earth,</line>
      <line>Of man the wonderful, and of the stars,</line>
      <line>And how the deuce they ever could have birth;</line>
      <line>And then he thought of earthquakes, and of wars,</line>
      <line>How many miles the moon might have in girth,</line>
      <line>Of air-balloons, and of the many bars</line>
      <line> To perfect knowledge of the boundless skies –</line>
      <line>And then he thought of Donna Julia’s eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In thoughts like these true wisdom may discern</line>
      <line>Longings sublime, and aspirations high,</line>
      <line>Which some are born with, but the most part learn</line>
      <line>To plague themselves withal, they know not why:</line>
      <line>’Twas strange that one so young should thus concern</line>
      <line>His brain about the action of the sky;</line>
      <line>If you think ’twas philosophy that this did,</line>
      <line>I can’t help thinking puberty assisted.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He pored upon the leaves, and on the flowers,</line>
      <line>And heard a voice in all the winds; and then</line>
      <line>He thought of wood nymphs and immortal bowers,</line>
      <line>And how the goddesses came down to men:</line>
      <line>He missed the pathway, he forgot the hours,</line>
      <line>And when he looked upon his watch again,</line>
      <line>He found how much old Time had been a winner –</line>
      <line>He also found that he had lost his dinner.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sometimes he turned to gaze upon his book,</line>
      <line>Boscan, or Garcilasso – by the wind</line>
      <line> Even as the page is rustled while we look,</line>
      <line>So by the poesy of his own mind</line>
      <line>Over the mystic leaf his soul was shook,</line>
      <line>As if ’twere one whereon magicians bind</line>
      <line>Their spells, and give them to the passing gale,</line>
      <line>According to some good old woman’s tale.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus would he while his lonely hours away</line>
      <line>Dissatisfied, nor knowing what he wanted;</line>
      <line>Nor glowing reverie, nor poet’s lay,</line>
      <line>Could yield his spirit that for which it panted,</line>
      <line> A bosom whereon he his head might lay,</line>
      <line>And hear the heart beat with the love it granted,</line>
      <line>With – several other things, which I forget,</line>
      <line>Or which, at least, I need not mention yet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Those lonely walks, and lengthening reveries,</line>
      <line>Could not escape the gentle Julia’s eyes;</line>
      <line>She saw that Juan was not at his ease;</line>
      <line>But that which chiefly may, and must, surprise</line>
      <line>Is, that the Donna Inez did not tease</line>
      <line>Her only son with question or surmise;</line>
      <line> Whether it was she did not see, or would not,</line>
      <line>Or, like all very clever people, could not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This may seem strange, but yet ’tis very common;</line>
      <line>For instance, gentlemen, whose ladies take</line>
      <line>Leave to o’erstep the written rights of woman</line>
      <line>And break the – which commandment is’t they break</line>
      <line>(I have forgot the number, and think no man</line>
      <line>Should rashly quote, for fear of a mistake) –</line>
      <line>I say, when these same gentlemen are jealous,</line>
      <line>They make some blunder, which their ladies tell us.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A real husband always is suspicious,</line>
      <line>But still no less suspects in the wrong place,</line>
      <line>Jealous of some one who had no such wishes,</line>
      <line>Or pandering blindly to his own disgrace</line>
      <line>By harbouring some dear friend extremely vicious –</line>
      <line>The last indeed’s infallibly the case:</line>
      <line>And when the spouse and friend are gone off wholly,</line>
      <line>He wonders at their vice, and not his folly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus parents also are at times short-sighted;</line>
      <line>Though watchful as the lynx, they ne’er discover,</line>
      <line> The while the wicked world beholds delighted,</line>
      <line>Young Hopeful’s mistress, or Miss Fanny’s lover,</line>
      <line>Till some confounded escapade has blighted</line>
      <line>The plan of twenty years, and all is over;</line>
      <line>And then the mother cries, the father swears,</line>
      <line>And wonders why the devil he got heirs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Inez was so anxious, and so clear</line>
      <line>Of sight, that I must think, on this occasion,</line>
      <line>She had some other motive much more near</line>
      <line>For leaving Juan to his new temptation;</line>
      <line>But what that motive was, I shan’t say here;</line>
      <line>Perhaps to finish Juan’s education,</line>
      <line>Perhaps to open Don Alfonso’s eyes,</line>
      <line>In case he thought his wife too great a prize.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was upon a day, a summer’s day –</line>
      <line>Summer’s indeed a very dangerous season,</line>
      <line>And so is spring about the end of May –</line>
      <line>The sun, no doubt, is the prevailing reason;</line>
      <line>But whatsoe’er the cause is, one may say,</line>
      <line>And stand convicted of more truth than treason,</line>
      <line> That there are months which nature grows more merry in:</line>
      <line>March has its hares, and May must have its heroine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas on a summer’s day – the sixth of June –</line>
      <line>I like to be particular in dates,</line>
      <line>Not only of the age, and year, but moon;</line>
      <line>They are a sort of post-house, where the Fates</line>
      <line>Change horses, making history change its tune,</line>
      <line>Then spur away o’er empires and o’er states,</line>
      <line>Leaving at last not much besides chronology,</line>
      <line>Excepting the post-obits of theology.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ’Twas on the sixth of June, about the hour</line>
      <line>Of half-past six – perhaps still nearer seven –</line>
      <line>When Julia sat within as pretty a bower</line>
      <line>As e’er held houri in that heathenish heaven</line>
      <line>Described by Mahomet, and Anacreon Moore,</line>
      <line>To whom the lyre and laurels have been given,</line>
      <line>With all the trophies of triumphant song –</line>
      <line>He won them well, and may he wear them long!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She sat, but not alone; I know not well</line>
      <line>How this same interview had taken place,</line>
      <line> And even if I knew, I should not tell –</line>
      <line>People should hold their tongues in any case –</line>
      <line>No matter how or why the thing befell,</line>
      <line>But there were she and Juan, face to face.</line>
      <line>When two such faces are so, ’twould be wise,</line>
      <line>But very difficult, to shut their eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How beautiful she looked! Her conscious heart</line>
      <line>Glowed in her cheek, and yet she felt no wrong.</line>
      <line>Oh Love, how perfect is thy mystic art,</line>
      <line>Strengthening the weak, and trampling on the strong,</line>
      <line> How self-deceitful is the sagest part</line>
      <line>Of mortals whom thy lure hath led along –</line>
      <line>The precipice she stood on was immense,</line>
      <line>So was her creed in her own innocence.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She thought of her own strength, and Juan’s youth,</line>
      <line>And of the folly of all prudish fears,</line>
      <line>Victorious virtue, and domestic truth,</line>
      <line>And then of Don Alfonso’s fifty years:</line>
      <line>I wish these last had not occurred, in sooth,</line>
      <line>Because that number rarely much endears,</line>
      <line> And through all climes, the snowy and the sunny,</line>
      <line>Sounds ill in love, whate’er it may in money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When people say, ‘I’ve told you fifty times’,</line>
      <line>They mean to scold, and very often do;</line>
      <line>When poets say, ‘I’ve written fifty rhymes’,</line>
      <line>They make you dread that they’ll recite them too;</line>
      <line>In gangs of fifty, thieves commit their crimes;</line>
      <line>At fifty love for love is rare, ’tis true,</line>
      <line>But then, no doubt, it equally as true is,</line>
      <line>A good deal may be bought for fifty Louis.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Julia had honour, virtue, truth, and love</line>
      <line>For Don Alfonso; and she inly swore,</line>
      <line>By all the vows below to powers above,</line>
      <line>She never would disgrace the ring she wore,</line>
      <line>Nor leave a wish which wisdom might reprove;</line>
      <line>And while she pondered this, besides much more,</line>
      <line>One hand on Juan’s carelessly was thrown,</line>
      <line>Quite by mistake – she thought it was her own;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unconsciously she leaned upon the other,</line>
      <line>Which played within the tangles of her hair;</line>
      <line> And to contend with thoughts she could not smother,</line>
      <line>She seemed by the distraction of her air.</line>
      <line>’Twas surely very wrong in Juan’s mother</line>
      <line>To leave together this imprudent pair –</line>
      <line>She who for many years had watched her son so:</line>
      <line>I’m very certain mine would not have done so.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The hand which still held Juan’s, by degrees</line>
      <line>Gently, but palpably confirmed its grasp,</line>
      <line>As if it said ‘Detain me, if you please’;</line>
      <line>Yet there’s no doubt she only meant to clasp</line>
      <line> His fingers with a pure Platonic squeeze;</line>
      <line>She would have shrunk as from a toad, or asp,</line>
      <line>Had she imagined such a thing could rouse</line>
      <line>A feeling dangerous to a prudent spouse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot know what Juan thought of this,</line>
      <line>But what he did, is much what you would do;</line>
      <line>His young lip thanked it with a grateful kiss,</line>
      <line>And then, abashed at its own joy, withdrew</line>
      <line>In deep despair, lest he had done amiss,</line>
      <line>Love is so very timid when ’tis new:</line>
      <line> She blushed, and frowned not, but she strove to speak,</line>
      <line>And held her tongue, her voice was grown so weak.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun set, and up rose the yellow moon –</line>
      <line>The devil’s in the moon for mischief – they</line>
      <line>Who called her chaste, methinks, began too soon</line>
      <line>Their nomenclature; there is not a day,</line>
      <line>The longest, not the twenty-first of June,</line>
      <line>Sees half the business in a wicked way</line>
      <line>On which three single hours of moonshine smile.</line>
      <line>And then she looks so modest all the while!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a dangerous silence in that hour,</line>
      <line>A stillness, which leaves room for the full soul</line>
      <line>To open all itself, without the power</line>
      <line>Of calling wholly back its self-control;</line>
      <line>The silver light which, hallowing tree and tower,</line>
      <line>Sheds beauty and deep softness o’er the whole,</line>
      <line>Breathes also to the heart, and o’er it throws</line>
      <line>A loving languor, which is not repose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Julia sat with Juan, half embraced</line>
      <line>And half retiring from the glowing arm,</line>
      <line> Which trembled like the bosom where ’twas placed;</line>
      <line>Yet still she must have thought there was no harm,</line>
      <line>Or else ’twere easy to withdraw her waist;</line>
      <line>But then the situation had its charm,</line>
      <line>And then – God knows what next – I can’t go on;</line>
      <line>I’m almost sorry that I e’er begun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Plato! Plato! You have paved the way,</line>
      <line>With your confounded fantasies, to more</line>
      <line>Immoral conduct by the fancied sway</line>
      <line>Your system feigns o’er the controlless core</line>
      <line> Of human hearts, than all the long array</line>
      <line>Of poets and romancers. You’re a bore,</line>
      <line>A charlatan, a coxcomb – and have been,</line>
      <line>At best, no better than a go-between!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Julia’s voice was lost, except in sighs,</line>
      <line>Until too late for useful conversation;</line>
      <line>The tears were gushing from her gentle eyes,</line>
      <line>I wish, indeed, they had not had occasion,</line>
      <line>But who, alas, can love, and then be wise?</line>
      <line>Not that remorse did not oppose temptation,</line>
      <line> A little still she strove, and much repented,</line>
      <line>And whispering ‘I will ne’er consent’ – consented…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Man’s a phenomenon, one knows not what,</line>
      <line>And wonderful beyond all wondrous measure;</line>
      <line>’Tis pity though, in this sublime world, that</line>
      <line>Pleasure’s a sin, and sometimes sin’s a pleasure!</line>
      <line>Few mortals know what end they would be at,</line>
      <line>But whether glory, power, or love, or treasure,</line>
      <line>The path is through perplexing ways, and when</line>
      <line>The goal is gained, we die, you know – and then?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What then? I do not know. No more do you –</line>
      <line>And so good night! Return we to our story:</line>
      <line>’Twas in November, when fine days are few,</line>
      <line>And the far mountains wax a little hoary</line>
      <line>And clap a white cape on their mantles blue,</line>
      <line>And the sea dashes round the promontory,</line>
      <line>And the wild breaker boils against the rock,</line>
      <line>And sober suns must set at five O’clock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas, as the watchmen say, a cloudy night;</line>
      <line>No moon, no stars, the wind was low or loud</line>
      <line>By gusts, and many a sparkling hearth was bright</line>
      <line>With the piled wood, round which the family crowd;</line>
      <line>There’s something cheerful in that sort of light,</line>
      <line>Even as a summer sky’s without a cloud:</line>
      <line>I’m fond of fire, and crickets, and all that,</line>
      <line>A lobster salad, and champagne, and chat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas midnight, Donna Julia was in bed</line>
      <line>(Sleeping, most probably), when at her door</line>
      <line>Arose a clatter might awake the dead,</line>
      <line>If they had never been awoke before –</line>
      <line>And that they have been so we all have read,</line>
      <line>And are to be so, at the least, once more!</line>
      <line>The door was fastened, but with voice and fist</line>
      <line>First knocks were heard, then ‘Madam – Madam – hist!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For God’s sake, Madam – Madam – here’s my master,</line>
      <line>With more than half the city at his back –</line>
      <line>Was ever heard of such a curst disaster!</line>
      <line>’Tis not my fault – I kept good watch. Alack!</line>
      <line>Do, pray undo the bolt a little faster –</line>
      <line>They’re on the stair just now, and in a crack</line>
      <line>Will all be here! Perhaps he yet may fly –</line>
      <line>Surely the window’s not so very high?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By this time Don Alfonso was arrived,</line>
      <line>With torches, friends, and servants in great number;</line>
      <line>The major part of them had long been wived,</line>
      <line>And therefore paused not to disturb the slumber</line>
      <line>Of any wicked woman, who contrived</line>
      <line>By stealth her husband’s temples to encumber:</line>
      <line>Examples of this kind are so contagious,</line>
      <line>Were one not punished, all would be outrageous!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I can’t tell how, or why, or what suspicion</line>
      <line>Could enter into Don Alfonso’s head;</line>
      <line>But for a cavalier of his condition</line>
      <line>It surely was exceedingly ill-bred,</line>
      <line>Without a word of previous admonition,</line>
      <line>To hold a levée round his lady’s bed,</line>
      <line>And summon lackeys, armed with fire and sword,</line>
      <line>To prove himself the thing he most abhorred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Donna Julia! starting as from sleep,</line>
      <line>(Mind, that I do not say, she had not slept)</line>
      <line> Began at once to scream, and yawn, and weep;</line>
      <line>Her maid Antonia, who was an adept,</line>
      <line>Contrived to fling the bedclothes in a heap,</line>
      <line>As if she had just now from out them crept:</line>
      <line>I can’t tell why she should take all this trouble</line>
      <line>To prove her mistress had been sleeping double.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Julia mistress, and Antonia maid,</line>
      <line>Appeared like two poor harmless women, who,</line>
      <line>Of goblins, but still more of men, afraid,</line>
      <line>Had thought one man might be deterred by two,</line>
      <line> And therefore side by side were gently laid</line>
      <line>Until the hours of absence should run through</line>
      <line>And truant husband should return, and say</line>
      <line>‘My dear, I was the first who came away.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now Julia found at length a voice, and cried</line>
      <line>‘In heaven’s name, Don Alfonso, what d’ye mean?</line>
      <line>Has madness seized you? Would that I had died</line>
      <line>Ere such a monster’s victim I had been!</line>
      <line>What may this midnight violence betide,</line>
      <line>A sudden fit of drunkenness or spleen?</line>
      <line> Dare you suspect me, whom the thought would kill?</line>
      <line>Search, then, the room!’ Alfonso said, ‘I will.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He searched, they searched, and rummaged everywhere,</line>
      <line>Closet and clothes-press, chest and window-seat,</line>
      <line>And found much linen, lace, and several pair</line>
      <line>Of stockings, slippers, brushes, combs, complete,</line>
      <line>With other articles of ladies fair,</line>
      <line>To keep them beautiful, or leave them neat:</line>
      <line>Arras they pricked, and curtains, with their swords,</line>
      <line>And wounded several shutters, and some boards.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Under the bed they searched, and there they found –</line>
      <line>No matter what – it was not that they sought!</line>
      <line>They opened windows, gazing if the ground</line>
      <line>Had signs or footmarks, but the earth said nought;</line>
      <line>And then they stared each others’ faces round:</line>
      <line>’Tis odd, not one of all these seekers thought</line>
      <line>(And seems to me almost a sort of blunder),</line>
      <line>Of looking in the bed as well as under.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>During this inquisition Julia’s tongue</line>
      <line>Was not asleep: ‘Yes, search and search’, she cried,</line>
      <line> ‘Insult on insult heap, and wrong on wrong!</line>
      <line>It was for this that I became a bride!</line>
      <line>For this in silence I have suffered long</line>
      <line>A husband like Alfonso at my side;</line>
      <line>But now I’ll bear no more, nor here remain,</line>
      <line>If there be law, or lawyers, in all Spain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Yes, Don Alfonso! – husband now no more</line>
      <line>(If ever you indeed deserved the name),</line>
      <line>Is’t worthy of your years? You have threescore –</line>
      <line>Fifty, or sixty, it is all the same!</line>
      <line> Is’t wise or fitting causeless to explore</line>
      <line>For facts against a virtuous woman’s fame?</line>
      <line>Ungrateful, perjured, barbarous Don Alfonso,</line>
      <line>How dare you think your lady would go on so?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it for this I have disdained to hold</line>
      <line>The common privileges of my sex? –</line>
      <line>That I have chosen a confessor so old</line>
      <line>And deaf, that any other it would vex,</line>
      <line>And never once he has had cause to scold,</line>
      <line>But found my very innocence perplex</line>
      <line> So much, he always doubted I was married –</line>
      <line>How sorry you will be when I’ve miscarried!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Was it for this that no cortejo ere</line>
      <line>I yet have chosen from out the youth of Seville?</line>
      <line>Is it for this I scarce went anywhere,</line>
      <line>Except to bull-fights, mass, play, rout, and revel?</line>
      <line>Is it for this, whate’er my suitors were,</line>
      <line>I favoured none-nay, was almost uncivil?</line>
      <line>Is it for this that General Count O’Reilly,</line>
      <line>Who took Algiers, declares I used him vilely?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Did not the Italian Musico Cazzani</line>
      <line>Sing at my heart six months at least in vain?</line>
      <line>Did not his countryman, Count Corniani,</line>
      <line>Call me the only virtuous wife in Spain?</line>
      <line>Were there not also Russians, English, many?</line>
      <line>The Count Strongstroganoff I put in pain,</line>
      <line>And Lord Mount Coffeehouse, the Irish peer,</line>
      <line>Who killed himself for love (with wine) last year.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Have I not had two bishops at my feet?</line>
      <line>The Duke of Ichar, and Don Fernan Nunez,</line>
      <line> And is it thus a faithful wife you treat?</line>
      <line>I wonder in what quarter now the moon is!</line>
      <line>I praise your vast forbearance not to beat</line>
      <line>Me also, since the time so opportune is –</line>
      <line>Oh, valiant man! with sword drawn and cocked trigger,</line>
      <line>Now, tell me, don’t you cut a pretty figure?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Was it for this you took your sudden journey,</line>
      <line>Under pretence of business indispensable</line>
      <line>With that sublime of rascals your attorney,</line>
      <line>Whom I see standing there, and looking sensible</line>
      <line>Of having played the fool? Though both I spurn, he</line>
      <line>Deserves the worst, his conduct’s less defensible,</line>
      <line>Because, no doubt, ’twas for his dirty fee,</line>
      <line>And not from any love to you nor me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If he comes here to take a deposition,</line>
      <line>By all means let the gentleman proceed;</line>
      <line>You’ve made the apartment in a fit condition –</line>
      <line>There’s pen and ink for you, sir, when you need –</line>
      <line>Let every thing be noted with precision,</line>
      <line>I would not you for nothing should be fee’d!</line>
      <line> But, as my maid’s undressed, pray turn your spies out.’</line>
      <line>‘Oh!’ sobbed Antonia, ‘I could tear their eyes out.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is the closet, there the toilette, there</line>
      <line>The anti-chamber – search them under, over!</line>
      <line>There is the sofa, there the great armchair,</line>
      <line>The chimney (which would really hold a lover).</line>
      <line>I wish to sleep, and beg you will take care</line>
      <line>And make no further noise, till you discover</line>
      <line>The secret cavern of this lurking treasure –</line>
      <line>And when ’tis found, let me, too, have that pleasure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And now, Hidalgo! now that you have thrown</line>
      <line>Doubt upon me, confusion over all,</line>
      <line>Pray have the courtesy to make it known</line>
      <line>Who is the man you search for? How d’ye call</line>
      <line>Him? What’s his lineage? Let him but be shown!</line>
      <line>I hope he’s young and handsome – is he tall?</line>
      <line>Tell me – and be assured that since you stain</line>
      <line>My honour thus, it shall not be in vain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At least, perhaps, he has not sixty years!</line>
      <line>At that age he would be too old for slaughter,</line>
      <line> Or for so young a husband’s jealous fears –</line>
      <line>Antonia! let me have a glass of water –</line>
      <line>I am ashamed of having shed these tears,</line>
      <line>They are unworthy of my father’s daughter;</line>
      <line>My mother dreamed not in my natal hour</line>
      <line>That I should fall into a monster’s power!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perhaps ’tis of Antonia you are jealous,</line>
      <line>You saw that she was sleeping by my side</line>
      <line>When you broke in upon us with your fellows!</line>
      <line>Look where you please – we’ve nothing, sir, to hide –</line>
      <line> Only another time, I trust, you’ll tell us,</line>
      <line>Or for the sake of decency abide</line>
      <line>A moment at the door, that we may be</line>
      <line>Dressed to receive so much good company!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now, sir, I have done, and say no more!</line>
      <line>The little I have said may serve to show</line>
      <line>The guileless heart in silence may grieve o’er</line>
      <line>The wrongs to whose exposure it is slow –</line>
      <line>I leave you to your conscience as before,</line>
      <line>’Twill one day ask you why you used me so.</line>
      <line> God grant you feel not then the bitterest grief –</line>
      <line>Antonia! where’s my pocket-handkerchief?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She ceased, and turned upon her pillow. Pale</line>
      <line>She lay, her dark eyes flashing through their tears,</line>
      <line>Like skies that rain and lighten – as a veil,</line>
      <line>Waved and o’ershading her wan cheek, appears</line>
      <line>Her streaming hair. The black curls strive, but fail,</line>
      <line>To hide the glossy shoulder, which uprears</line>
      <line>Its snow through all – her soft lips lie apart,</line>
      <line>And louder than her breathing beats her heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The Señor Don Alfonso stood confused;</line>
      <line>Antonia bustled round the ransacked room,</line>
      <line>And, turning up her nose, with looks abused</line>
      <line>Her master, and his myrmidons, of whom</line>
      <line>Not one, except the attorney, was amused –</line>
      <line>He, like Achates, faithful to the tomb,</line>
      <line>So there were quarrels, cared not for the cause,</line>
      <line>Knowing they must be settled by the laws.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With prying snub-nose, and small eyes, he stood,</line>
      <line>Following Antonia’s motions here and there,</line>
      <line> With much suspicion in his attitude.</line>
      <line>For reputations he had little care –</line>
      <line>So that a suit or action were made good –</line>
      <line>Small pity had he for the young and fair,</line>
      <line>And ne’er believed in negatives, till these</line>
      <line>Were proved by competent false witnesses.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Don Alfonso stood with downcast looks,</line>
      <line>And, truth to say, he made a foolish figure;</line>
      <line>When, after searching in five hundred nooks,</line>
      <line>And treating a young wife with so much rigour,</line>
      <line> He gained no point, except some self-rebukes,</line>
      <line>Added to those his lady with such vigour</line>
      <line>Had poured upon him for the last half-hour,</line>
      <line>Quick, thick, and heavy – as a thunder-shower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At first he tried to hammer an excuse,</line>
      <line>To which the sole reply were tears, and sobs,</line>
      <line>And indications of hysterics, whose</line>
      <line>Prologue is always certain throes, and throbs,</line>
      <line>Gasps, and whatever else the owners choose –</line>
      <line>Alfonso saw his wife, and thought of Job’s!</line>
      <line> He saw too, in perspective, her relations,</line>
      <line>And then he tried to muster all his patience.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stood in act to speak, or rather stammer,</line>
      <line>But sage Antonia cut him short before</line>
      <line>The anvil of his speech received the hammer,</line>
      <line>With ‘Pray sir, leave the room, and say no more,</line>
      <line>Or madam dies!’ Alfonso muttered ‘Damn her’,</line>
      <line>But nothing else, the time of words was o’er –</line>
      <line>He cast a rueful look or two, and did</line>
      <line>(He knew not wherefore) that which he was bid.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With him retired his posse comitatus,</line>
      <line>The attorney last, who lingered near the door</line>
      <line>Reluctantly, still tarrying there as late as</line>
      <line>Antonia let him – not a little sore</line>
      <line>At this most strange and unexplained ‘hiatus’</line>
      <line>In Don Alfonso’s facts, which just now wore</line>
      <line>An awkward look. As he revolved the case</line>
      <line>The door was fastened in his legal face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No sooner was it bolted, than – oh shame!</line>
      <line>Oh sin! oh sorrow! and oh womankind!</line>
      <line> How can you do such things and keep your fame,</line>
      <line>Unless this world, and t’other too, be blind?</line>
      <line>Nothing so dear as an unfilched good name!</line>
      <line>But to proceed (for there is more behind) –</line>
      <line>With much heart-felt reluctance be it said,</line>
      <line>Young Juan slipped, half-smothered, from the bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had been hid – I don’t pretend to say</line>
      <line>How, nor can I indeed describe the where</line>
      <line>(Young, slender, and packed easily, he lay,</line>
      <line>No doubt, in little compass, round or square) –</line>
      <line> But pity him I neither must nor may</line>
      <line>His suffocation by that pretty pair:</line>
      <line>’Twere better, sure, to die so, than be shut</line>
      <line>With maudlin Clarence in his Malmsey butt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, secondly, I pity not, because</line>
      <line>He had no business to commit a sin,</line>
      <line>Forbid by heavenly, fined by human laws –</line>
      <line>At least ’twas rather early to begin!</line>
      <line>But at sixteen the conscience rarely gnaws</line>
      <line>So much as when we call our old debts in</line>
      <line> At sixty years, and draw the accounts of evil,</line>
      <line>And find a deucéd balance with the Devil!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of his position I can give no notion –</line>
      <line>’Tis written in the Hebrew Chronicle,</line>
      <line>How the physicians, leaving pill and potion,</line>
      <line>Prescribed, by way of blister, a young belle,</line>
      <line>When old King David’s blood grew dull in motion,</line>
      <line>And that the medicine answered very well.</line>
      <line>Perhaps ’twas in a different way applied,</line>
      <line>For David lived, but Juan nearly died!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> What’s to be done? Alfonso will be back</line>
      <line>The moment he has sent his fools away.</line>
      <line>Antonia’s skill was put upon the rack,</line>
      <line>But no device could be brought into play –</line>
      <line>And how to parry the renewed attack?</line>
      <line>Besides, it wanted but few hours of day:</line>
      <line>Antonia puzzled; Julia did not speak,</line>
      <line>But pressed her bloodless lip to Juan’s cheek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He turned his lip to hers, and with his hand</line>
      <line>Called back the tangles of her wandering hair;</line>
      <line> Even then their love they could not all command,</line>
      <line>And half forgot their danger and despair:</line>
      <line>Antonia’s patience now was at a stand –</line>
      <line>‘Come, come, ’tis no time now for fooling there!’</line>
      <line>She whispered, in great wrath – ‘I must deposit</line>
      <line>This pretty gentleman within the closet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pray, keep your nonsense for some luckier night!</line>
      <line>Who can have put my master in this mood?</line>
      <line>What will become on’t? I’m in such a fright –</line>
      <line>The devil’s in the urchin, and no good!</line>
      <line> Is this a time for giggling – this a plight?</line>
      <line>Why, don’t you know that it may end in blood?</line>
      <line>You’ll lose your life, and I shall lose my place,</line>
      <line>My mistress, all – for that half-girlish face!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had it but been for a stout cavalier</line>
      <line>Of twenty-five or thirty (come, make haste),</line>
      <line>But for a child, what piece of work is here!</line>
      <line>I really, madam, wonder at your taste</line>
      <line>(Come, sir, get in) – my Master must be near!</line>
      <line>There, for the present, at the least he’s fast,</line>
      <line> And, if we can but till the morning keep</line>
      <line>Our counsel – Juan, mind, you must not sleep!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, Don Alfonso entering, but alone,</line>
      <line>Closed the oration of the trusty maid:</line>
      <line>She loitered, and he told her to be gone,</line>
      <line>An order somewhat sullenly obeyed;</line>
      <line>However, present remedy was none,</line>
      <line>And no great good seemed answered if she stayed:</line>
      <line>Regarding both with slow and sidelong view,</line>
      <line>She snuffed the candle, curtsied, and withdrew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Alfonso paused a minute, then begun</line>
      <line>Some strange excuses for his late proceeding –</line>
      <line>He would not justify what he had done,</line>
      <line>To say the best, it was extreme ill-breeding;</line>
      <line>But there were ample reasons for it (none</line>
      <line>Of which he specified in this his pleading) –</line>
      <line>His speech was a fine sample, on the whole,</line>
      <line>Of rhetoric, which the learn’d call rigmarole.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Julia said nought; though all the while there rose</line>
      <line>A ready answer, which at once enables</line>
      <line> A matron who her husband’s foible knows,</line>
      <line>By a few timely words to turn the tables,</line>
      <line>Which if it does not silence still must pose –</line>
      <line>Even if it should comprise a pack of fables:</line>
      <line>’Tis to retort with firmness, and when he</line>
      <line>OO Suspects with one, do you reproach with three.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Julia, in fact, had tolerable grounds</line>
      <line>(Alfonso’s loves with Inez were well known);</line>
      <line>But whether ’twas that one’s own guilt confounds –</line>
      <line>But that can’t be, as has been often shown</line>
      <line>A lady with apologies abounds –</line>
      <line>It might be that her silence sprang alone</line>
      <line>From delicacy to Don Juan’s ear,</line>
      <line>To whom she knew his mother’s fame was dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There might be one more motive (which makes two):</line>
      <line>Alfonso ne’er to Juan had alluded –</line>
      <line>Mentioned his jealousy, but never who</line>
      <line>Had been the happy lover he concluded</line>
      <line>Concealed amongst his premises (’tis true,</line>
      <line>His mind the more o’er this its mystery brooded) –</line>
      <line> To speak of Inez now were, one may say,</line>
      <line>Like throwing Juan in Alfonso’s way!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A hint, in tender cases, is enough;</line>
      <line>Silence is best, besides there is a tact</line>
      <line>(That modern phrase appears to me sad stuff,</line>
      <line>But it will serve to keep my verse compact)</line>
      <line>Which keeps, when pushed by questions rather rough,</line>
      <line>A lady always distant from the fact –</line>
      <line>The charming creatures lie with such a grace,</line>
      <line>There’s nothing so becoming to the face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> They blush, and we believe them; at least I</line>
      <line>Have always done so! ’Tis of no great use,</line>
      <line>In any case, attempting a reply,</line>
      <line>For then their eloquence grows quite profuse –</line>
      <line>And when at length they’re out of breath, they sigh,</line>
      <line>And cast their languid eyes down, and let loose</line>
      <line>A tear or two, and then we make it up:</line>
      <line>And then – and then – and then – sit down and sup.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alfonso closed his speech, and begged her pardon,</line>
      <line>Which Julia half withheld, and then half granted,</line>
      <line> And laid conditions, he thought very hard, on –</line>
      <line>Denying several little things he wanted!</line>
      <line>He stood like Adam lingering near his garden,</line>
      <line>With useless penitence perplexed and haunted,</line>
      <line>Beseeching she no further would refuse –</line>
      <line>When lo! he stumbled o’er a pair of shoes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A pair of shoes – what then? Not much, if they</line>
      <line>Are such as fit with lady’s feet – but these</line>
      <line>(No one can tell how much I grieve to say)</line>
      <line>Were masculine! To see them, and to seize,</line>
      <line> Was but a moment’s act! Ah, well-a-day –</line>
      <line>My teeth begin to chatter, my veins freeze –</line>
      <line>Alfonso first examined well their fashion,</line>
      <line>And then flew out into another passion.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He left the room for his relinquished sword,</line>
      <line>And Julia instant to the closet flew.</line>
      <line>‘Fly, Juan, fly! for Heaven’s sake! Not a word –</line>
      <line>The door is open – you may yet slip through</line>
      <line>The passage you so often have explored –</line>
      <line>Here is the garden-key! Fly – fly – Adieu!</line>
      <line> Haste – haste! – I hear Alfonso’s hurrying feet!</line>
      <line>Day has not broke – there’s no one in the street.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>None can say that this was not good advice,</line>
      <line>The only mischief was, it came too late</line>
      <line>(Of all experience ’tis the usual price,</line>
      <line>A sort of income-tax laid on by fate) –</line>
      <line>Juan had reached the room-door in a trice,</line>
      <line>And might have done so by the garden-gate,</line>
      <line>But met Alfonso in his dressing-gown,</line>
      <line>Who threatened death – so Juan knocked him down.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Dire was the scuffle, and out went the light,</line>
      <line>Antonia cried out ‘Rape!’ and Julia ‘Fire!’</line>
      <line>But not a servant stirred to aid the fight.</line>
      <line>Alfonso, pummelled to his heart’s desire,</line>
      <line>Swore lustily he’d be revenged this night –</line>
      <line>And Juan, too, blasphemed an octave higher!</line>
      <line>His blood was up – though young, he was a tartar,</line>
      <line>And not at all disposed to prove a martyr!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alfonso’s sword had dropped ere he could draw it,</line>
      <line>And they continued battling hand to hand,</line>
      <line> For Juan very luckily ne’er saw it!</line>
      <line>His temper not being under great command,</line>
      <line>If at that moment he had chanced to claw it,</line>
      <line>Alfonso’s days had not been in the land</line>
      <line>Much longer. Think of husbands’, lovers’, lives!</line>
      <line>And how ye may be doubly widows–wives!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alfonso grappled to detain the foe,</line>
      <line>And Juan throttled him to get away,</line>
      <line>And blood (’twas from the nose) began to flow;</line>
      <line>At last, as they more faintly wrestling lay,</line>
      <line> Juan contrived to give an awkward blow,</line>
      <line>And then his only garment quite gave way –</line>
      <line>He fled, like Joseph, leaving it! but there,</line>
      <line>I doubt, all likeness ends between the pair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lights came at length, and men, and maids, who found</line>
      <line>An awkward spectacle their eyes before:</line>
      <line>Antonia in hysterics, Julia swooned,</line>
      <line>Alfonso leaning, breathless, by the door;</line>
      <line>Some half-torn drapery scattered on the ground,</line>
      <line>Some blood, and several footsteps, but no more –</line>
      <line> Juan the gate gained, turned the key about,</line>
      <line>And liking not the inside, locked the out!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>The Cataract of Lodore</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How does the Water,</line>
      <line>Come down at Lodore?’</line>
      <line>My little boy asked me</line>
      <line>Thus, once on a time;</line>
      <line> And moreover he tasked me</line>
      <line>To tell him in rhyme!</line>
      <line>Anon at the word,</line>
      <line>There first came one daughter</line>
      <line>And then came another,</line>
      <line>To second and third</line>
      <line>The request of their brother,</line>
      <line>And to hear how the Water</line>
      <line>Comes down at Lodore,</line>
      <line>With its rush and its roar,</line>
      <line> As many a time</line>
      <line>They had seen it before.</line>
      <line>So I told them in rhyme,</line>
      <line>For of rhymes I had store;</line>
      <line>And ’twas in my vocation</line>
      <line>For their recreation</line>
      <line>That so I should sing;</line>
      <line>Because I was Laureate</line>
      <line>To them and the King.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From its sources which well</line>
      <line> In the tarn on the fell;</line>
      <line>From its fountains</line>
      <line>In the mountains,</line>
      <line>It’s rills and it’s gills;</line>
      <line>Through moss and through brake,</line>
      <line>It runs and it creeps</line>
      <line>For awhile, till it sleeps</line>
      <line>In its own little lake.</line>
      <line>And thence at departing,</line>
      <line>Awakening and starting,</line>
      <line> It runs through the reeds</line>
      <line>And away it proceeds,</line>
      <line>Through meadow and glade,</line>
      <line>In sun and in shade,</line>
      <line>And through the wood-shelter,</line>
      <line>Among crags in its flurry,</line>
      <line>Helter-skelter,</line>
      <line>Hurry-scurry!</line>
      <line>Here it comes sparkling,</line>
      <line>And there it lies darkling;</line>
      <line> Now smoking and frothing</line>
      <line>It’s tumult and wrath in,</line>
      <line>Till in this rapid race</line>
      <line>On which it is bent,</line>
      <line>It reaches the place</line>
      <line>Of its steep descent.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Cataract strong</line>
      <line>Then plunges along,</line>
      <line>Striking and raging</line>
      <line>As if a war waging</line>
      <line> Its caverns and rocks among:</line>
      <line>Rising and leaping,</line>
      <line>Sinking and creeping,</line>
      <line>Swelling and sweeping,</line>
      <line>Showering and springing,</line>
      <line>Flying and flinging,</line>
      <line>Writhing and ringing,</line>
      <line>Eddying and whisking,</line>
      <line>Spouting and frisking,</line>
      <line>Turning and twisting,</line>
      <line> Around and around</line>
      <line>With endless rebound;</line>
      <line>Smiting and fighting,</line>
      <line>A sight to delight in;</line>
      <line>Confounding, astounding,</line>
      <line>Dizzying and deafening the ear with its sound!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Collecting, projecting,</line>
      <line>Receding and speeding,</line>
      <line>And shocking and rocking,</line>
      <line>And darting and parting,</line>
      <line> And threading and spreading,</line>
      <line>And whizzing and hissing,</line>
      <line>And dripping and skipping,</line>
      <line>And hitting and splitting,</line>
      <line>And shining and twining,</line>
      <line>And rattling and battling,</line>
      <line>And shaking and quaking,</line>
      <line>And pouring and roaring,</line>
      <line>And waving and raving,</line>
      <line>And tossing and crossing,</line>
      <line> And flowing and going,</line>
      <line>And running and stunning,</line>
      <line>And foaming and roaming,</line>
      <line>And dinning and spinning,</line>
      <line>And dropping and hopping,</line>
      <line>And working and jerking,</line>
      <line>And guggling and struggling,</line>
      <line>And heaving and cleaving,</line>
      <line>And moaning and groaning;</line>
      <line>And glittering and frittering,</line>
      <line> And gathering and feathering,</line>
      <line>And whitening and brightening,</line>
      <line>And quivering and shivering,</line>
      <line>And hurrying and skurrying,</line>
      <line>And thundering and floundering;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dividing and gliding and sliding,</line>
      <line>And falling and brawling and sprawling,</line>
      <line>And driving and riving and striving,</line>
      <line>And sprinkling and twinkling and wrinkling,</line>
      <line>And sounding and bounding and rounding,</line>
      <line>And bubbling and troubling and doubling,</line>
      <line>And grumbling and rumbling and tumbling,</line>
      <line>And clattering and battering and shattering;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Retreating and beating and meeting and sheeting,</line>
      <line>Delaying and straying and playing and spraying,</line>
      <line>Advancing and prancing and glancing and dancing,</line>
      <line>Recoiling, turmoiling and toiling and boiling,</line>
      <line>And gleaming and streaming and steaming and beaming,</line>
      <line>And rushing and flushing and brushing and gushing,</line>
      <line>And flapping and rapping and clapping and slapping</line>
      <line> And curling and whirling and purling and twirling,</line>
      <line>And thumping and plumping and bumping and jumping,</line>
      <line>And dashing and flashing and splashing and clashing;</line>
      <line>And so never ending, but always descending,</line>
      <line>Sounds and motions for ever and ever are blending,</line>
      <line>All at once and all o’er, with a mighty uproar –</line>
      <line>And this way the Water comes down at Lodore.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS LOVE PEACOCK</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>The Legend of Manor Hall</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Farmer Wall, of Manor Hall,</line>
      <line>To market drove his wain:</line>
      <line>Along the road it went, well stowed</line>
      <line>With sacks of golden grain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> His station he took, but in vain did he look</line>
      <line>For a customer all the morn,</line>
      <line>Though the farmers all, save Farmer Wall,</line>
      <line>They sold off all their corn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then home he went, sore discontent,</line>
      <line>And many an oath he swore,</line>
      <line>And he kicked up rows with his children and spouse</line>
      <line>When they met him at the door!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Next market-day he drove away</line>
      <line>To the town his loaded wain:</line>
      <line> The farmers all, save Farmer Wall,</line>
      <line>They sold off all their grain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No bidder he found, and he stood astound</line>
      <line>At the close of the market-day,</line>
      <line>When the market was done, and the chapmen were gone</line>
      <line>Each man his several way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stalked by his load along the road,</line>
      <line>His face with wrath was red;</line>
      <line>His arms he tossed, like a good man crossed</line>
      <line>In seeking his daily bread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> His face was red, and fierce was his tread,</line>
      <line>And with lusty voice cried he,</line>
      <line>‘My corn I’ll sell to the Devil of Hell,</line>
      <line>If he’ll my chapman be!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>These words he spoke just under an oak</line>
      <line>Seven hundred winters old;</line>
      <line>And he straight was aware of a man sitting there</line>
      <line>On the roots and grassy mould.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The roots rose high, o’er the greensward dry,</line>
      <line>And the grass around was green</line>
      <line> Save just the space of the stranger’s place,</line>
      <line>Where it seemed as a fire had been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All scorched was the spot, as gypsy-pot</line>
      <line>Had swung and bubbled there:</line>
      <line>The grass was marred, the roots were charred,</line>
      <line>And the ivy-stems were bare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The stranger sprung up: to the farmer he flung</line>
      <line>A loud and friendly hail,</line>
      <line>And he said, ‘I see well thou hast corn to sell –</line>
      <line>And I’ll buy it on the nail!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The twain in a trice agreed on the price;</line>
      <line>The stranger his earnest paid,</line>
      <line>And with horses and wain to come for the grain</line>
      <line>His own appointment made.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The farmer cracked his whip and tracked</line>
      <line>His way right merrily on;</line>
      <line>He struck up a song as he trudged along</line>
