      <line>For joy that his job was done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His children fair he danced in the air –</line>
      <line>His heart with joy was big –</line>
      <line> He kissed his wife, he seized a knife,</line>
      <line>He slew a sucking-pig!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The faggots burned, the porkling turned</line>
      <line>And crackled before the fire,</line>
      <line>And an odour arose that was sweet in the nose</line>
      <line>Of a passing ghostly friar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He tirled the pin, he entered in,</line>
      <line>He sat down at the board;</line>
      <line>The pig he blest, when he saw it well dressed,</line>
      <line>And the humming ale outpoured.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The friar laughed, the friar quaffed,</line>
      <line>He chirped like a bird in May;</line>
      <line>The farmer told how his corn he had sold</line>
      <line>As he journeyed home that day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The friar he quaffed, but no longer he laughed,</line>
      <line>He changed from red to pale;</line>
      <line>‘Oh hapless elf, ’tis the Fiend himself</line>
      <line>To whom thou hast made thy sale!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The friar he quaffed, he took a deep draught,</line>
      <line>He crossed himself amain:</line>
      <line> ‘Oh slave of pelf, ’tis the Devil himself</line>
      <line>To whom thou has sold thy grain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And sure as the day, he’ll fetch thee away</line>
      <line>With the corn which thou hast sold,</line>
      <line>If thou let him pay o’er one tester more</line>
      <line>Than thy settled price in gold.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The farmer gave vent to a loud lament,</line>
      <line>The wife to a long outcry;</line>
      <line>Their relish for pig and ale had flown,</line>
      <line>The friar alone picked every bone</line>
      <line> And drained the flagon dry!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The friar was gone, the morning dawn</line>
      <line>Appeared, and the stranger’s wain</line>
      <line>Came to the hour, with six-horse power,</line>
      <line>To fetch the purchased grain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The horses were black – on their dewy track</line>
      <line>Light steam from the ground upcurled;</line>
      <line>Long wreaths of smoke from their nostrils broke,</line>
      <line>And their tails like torches whirled!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>More dark and grim, in face and limb,</line>
      <line> Seemed the stranger than before,</line>
      <line>As his empty wain, with steeds thrice twain,</line>
      <line>Drew up at the farmer’s door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the stranger’s face was a sly grimace</line>
      <line>As he seized the sacks of grain</line>
      <line>And, one by one, till left were none,</line>
      <line>He tossed them on the wain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And slyly he leered as his hand upreared</line>
      <line>A purse of costly mould,</line>
      <line>Where bright and fresh through a silver mesh</line>
      <line>Shone forth the glittering gold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The farmer held out his right hand stout,</line>
      <line>And drew it back with dread;</line>
      <line>For in fancy he heard each warning word</line>
      <line>The supping friar had said.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His eye was set on the silver net,</line>
      <line>His thoughts were in fearful strife</line>
      <line>When, sudden as fate, the glittering bait</line>
      <line>Was snatched by his loving wife!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, swift as thought, the stranger caught</line>
      <line> The farmer his waist around,</line>
      <line>And at once the twain and the loaded wain</line>
      <line>Sank through the rifted ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The gable-end wall of Manor Hall</line>
      <line>Fell in ruins on the place –</line>
      <line>That stone-heap old the tale has told</line>
      <line>To each succeeding race.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wife gave a cry that rent the sky</line>
      <line>At her goodman’s downward flight;</line>
      <line>But she held the purse fast, and a glance she cast</line>
      <line> To see that all was right!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas the Fiend’s full-pay for her goodman gray,</line>
      <line>And the gold was good and true;</line>
      <line>Which made her declare that ‘his dealings were fair,</line>
      <line>To give the Devil his due!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She wore the black pall for Farmer Wall,</line>
      <line>From her fond embraces riven –</line>
      <line>But she won the vows of a younger spouse</line>
      <line>With the gold which the Fiend had given!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, farmers, beware of the oaths you swear</line>
      <line> When you cannot sell your corn,</line>
      <line>Lest to bid and buy a stranger be nigh,</line>
      <line>With hidden tail and horn!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And with good heed the moral a-read</line>
      <line>Which is of this tale the pith:</line>
      <line>If your corn you sell to the Fiend of Hell</line>
      <line>You may sell yourself therewith.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if by mishap you fall in the trap,</line>
      <line>Would you bring the fiend to shame,</line>
      <line>Lest the tempting prize should dazzle her eyes,</line>
      <line> Lock up your frugal dame!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1826</date>
    <title>Mary’s Ghost</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas in the middle of the night,</line>
      <line>To sleep young William tried,</line>
      <line>When Mary’s ghost came stealing in</line>
      <line>And stood at his bedside:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh William dear, oh William dear,</line>
      <line>My rest eternal ceases –</line>
      <line>Alas, my everlasting peace</line>
      <line>Is broken into pieces!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I thought the last of all my cares</line>
      <line>Would end with my last minute;</line>
      <line>But though I went to my long home,</line>
      <line>I didn’t stay long in it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The body-snatchers they have come,</line>
      <line>And made a snatch at me –</line>
      <line> It’s very hard them kind of men</line>
      <line>Won’t let a body be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You thought that I was buried deep,</line>
      <line>Quite decent like and chary,</line>
      <line>But from her grave in Mary-bone</line>
      <line>They’ve come and boned your Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The arm that used to take your arm</line>
      <line>Is took to Doctor Vyse;</line>
      <line>And both my legs are gone to walk</line>
      <line>The hospital at Guy’s.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I vowed that you should have my hand,</line>
      <line>But fate gives us denial;</line>
      <line>You’ll find it there at Doctor Bell’s</line>
      <line>In spirits and a phial.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As for my feet, the little feet</line>
      <line>You used to call so pretty,</line>
      <line>There’s one, I know, in Bedford Row,</line>
      <line>The tother’s in the City.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I can’t tell where my head is gone,</line>
      <line>But Doctor Carpue can;</line>
      <line> As for my trunk, it’s all packed up</line>
      <line>To go by Pickford’s van!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wish you’d go to Mister P.</line>
      <line>And save me such a ride –</line>
      <line>I don’t half like the outside place</line>
      <line>They’ve took for my inside.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cock it crows – I must be gone!</line>
      <line>My William I must part!</line>
      <line>But I’ll be yours in death, although</line>
      <line>Sir Astley has my heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Don’t go to weep upon my grave,</line>
      <line>And think that there I be;</line>
      <line>They haven’t left an atom there</line>
      <line>Of my anatomy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>First Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, I know that you once were my lover,</line>
      <line>But that sort of thing has an end,</line>
      <line>And though love and its transports are over,</line>
      <line>You know you can still be – my friend:</line>
      <line> I was young, too, and foolish, remember</line>
      <line>(Did you ever hear John Hardy sing?) –</line>
      <line>It was then the fifteenth of November,</line>
      <line>And this is the end of the spring!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You complain that you are not well-treated</line>
      <line>By my suddenly altering so;</line>
      <line>Can I help it? – you’re very conceited,</line>
      <line>If you think yourself equal to Joe.</line>
      <line>Don’t kneel at my feet, I implore you;</line>
      <line>Don’t write on the drawings you bring;</line>
      <line> Don’t ask me to say, ‘I adore you,’</line>
      <line>For, indeed, it is now no such thing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I confess, when at Bognor we parted,</line>
      <line>I swore that I worshipped you then –</line>
      <line>That I was a maid broken-hearted,</line>
      <line>And you the most charming of men.</line>
      <line>I confess, when I read your first letter,</line>
      <line>I blotted your name with a tear –</line>
      <line>But, oh! I was young – knew no better,</line>
      <line>Could I tell that I’d meet Hardy here?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> How dull you are grown! How you worry,</line>
      <line>Repeating my vows to be true –</line>
      <line>If I said so, I told you a story,</line>
      <line>For I love Hardy better than you!</line>
      <line>Yes! my fond heart has fixed on another</line>
      <line>(I sigh so whenever he’s gone),</line>
      <line>I shall always love you – as a brother,</line>
      <line>But my heart is John Hardy’s alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM COWPER</author>
    <date>1788</date>
    <title>Sweet Meat Has Sour Sauce, or The Slave Trader in the Dumps</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A trader I am to the African shore,</line>
      <line>But since that my trading is like to be o’er</line>
      <line>I’ll sing you a song which you ne’er heard before,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line> Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I first heard the news it gave me a shock</line>
      <line>Much like what they call an electrical knock,</line>
      <line>And now I am going to sell off my stock</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis a curious assortment of dainty regales</line>
      <line>To tickle the negroes with when the ship sails –</line>
      <line>Fine chains for the neck, and a cat with nine tails,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line> Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here’s supple-jack plenty, and store of rattan</line>
      <line>That will wind itself round the sides of a man</line>
      <line>As close as a hoop round a bucket or can,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here’s padlocks and bolts and screws for the thumbs</line>
      <line>That squeeze them so lovingly till the blood comes,</line>
      <line>They sweeten the temper like comfits or plums</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line> Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When a negro his head from his victuals withdraws</line>
      <line>And clenches his teeth and thrusts out his paws,</line>
      <line>Here’s a notable engine to open his jaws –</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus, going to market, we kindly prepare</line>
      <line>A pretty black cargo of African ware</line>
      <line>For what they must meet with when they get there,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line> Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twould do your heart good to see ’em below</line>
      <line>Lie flat on their backs all the way as we go</line>
      <line>Like sprats on a gridiron, scores in a row!</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But ah, if in vain I have studied an art</line>
      <line>So gainful to me (all boasting apart),</line>
      <line>I think it will break my compassionate heart –</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line> Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For oh, how it enters my soul like an awl:</line>
      <line>This pity (which some people self-pity call)</line>
      <line>Is sure the most heart-piercing pity of all!</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So this is my song – as I told you before –</line>
      <line>Come buy off my stock, for I must no more</line>
      <line>Carry Caesars and Pompeys to Sugar-cane Shore,</line>
      <line>Which nobody can deny, deny,</line>
      <line> Which nobody can deny!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>HANNAH MORE</author>
    <date>1788</date>
    <title>from Slavery: A Poem</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No; they have heads to think, and hearts to feel,</line>
      <line>And souls to act, with firm though erring zeal;</line>
      <line>For they have keen affections, kind desires,</line>
      <line>Love strong as death, and active patriot fires;</line>
      <line>All the rude energy, the fervid flame</line>
      <line>Of high-souled passion and ingenuous shame –</line>
      <line>Strong but luxuriant virtues boldly shoot</line>
      <line>From the wild vigour of a savage root!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Nor weak their sense of honour’s proud control</line>
      <line>(For pride is virtue in a pagan soul):</line>
      <line>A sense of worth, a conscience of desert,</line>
      <line>A high, unbroken haughtiness of heart –</line>
      <line>That self-same stuff which erst proud empires swayed,</line>
      <line>Of which the conquerors of the world were made.</line>
      <line>Capricious fate of man! That very pride</line>
      <line>In Afric scourged, in Rome was deified...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Whene’er to Afric’s shores I turn my eyes,</line>
      <line>Horrors of deepest, deadliest guilt arise:</line>
      <line>I see (by more than fancy’s mirror shown)</line>
      <line>The burning village and the blazing town –</line>
      <line>See the dire victim torn from social life,</line>
      <line>The shrieking babe, the agonizing wife!</line>
      <line>She, wretch forlorn, is dragged by hostile hands,</line>
      <line>To distant tyrants sold, in distant lands!</line>
      <line>Transmitted miseries and successive chains</line>
      <line>The sole sad heritage her child obtains!</line>
      <line>Even this last wretched boon their foes deny:</line>
      <line>To weep together, or together die.</line>
      <line>By felon hands, by one relentless stroke,</line>
      <line>See the fond links of feeling nature broke!</line>
      <line>The fibres twisting round a parent’s heart,</line>
      <line>Torn from their grasp, and bleeding as they part.</line>
      <line>Hold, murderers, hold! Nor aggravate distress –</line>
      <line>Respect the passions you yourselves possess –</line>
      <line>Even you, of ruffian heart and ruthless hand,</line>
      <line>Love your own offspring, love your native land.</line>
      <line> Ah, leave them holy Freedom’s cheering smile,</line>
      <line>The Heaven-taught fondness for the parent soil!</line>
      <line>Revere affections mingled with our frame –</line>
      <line>In every nature, every clime the same!</line>
      <line>In all, these feelings equal sway maintain,</line>
      <line>In all, the love of home and freedom reign,</line>
      <line>And Tempe’s vale and parched Angola’s sand</line>
      <line>One equal fondness of their sons command.</line>
      <line>The unconquered savage laughs at pain and toil,</line>
      <line>Basking in Freedom’s beams which gild his native soil...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thou, white savage, whether lust of gold</line>
      <line>Or lust of conquest ruled thee uncontrolled –</line>
      <line>Hero or robber – by whatever name</line>
      <line>Thou plead thy impious claim to wealth or fame:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Whether inferior mischiefs be thy boast</line>
      <line>(A petty tyrant rifling Gambia’s coast),</line>
      <line>Or bolder carnage track thy crimson way</line>
      <line>(Kings dispossessed, and provinces thy prey),</line>
      <line>Panting to tame wide Earth’s remotest bound –</line>
      <line>All Cortez murdered, all Columbus found –</line>
      <line>O’er plundered realms to reign, detested lord,</line>
      <line>Make millions wretched, and thyself abhorred;</line>
      <line>In reason’s eye, in wisdom’s fair account,</line>
      <line>Your sum of glory boasts a like amount –</line>
      <line> The means may differ, but the end’s the same:</line>
      <line>Conquest is pillage with a nobler name!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANN YEARSLEY</author>
    <date>1788</date>
    <title>Death of Luco (from On the Inhumanity of the Slave Trade)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun had reached</line>
      <line>His zenith. Pausing faintly, Luco stood</line>
      <line> Leaning upon his hoe, while memory brought,</line>
      <line>In piteous imagery, his agéd father,</line>
      <line>His poor fond mother, and his faithful maid.</line>
      <line>The mental group in wildest motion set</line>
      <line>Fruitless imagination – fury, grief,</line>
      <line>Alternate shame, the sense of insult, all</line>
      <line>Conspire to aid the inward storm! Yet words</line>
      <line>Were no relief: he stood in silent woe.</line>
      <line>Gorgon, remorseless Christian, saw the slave</line>
      <line>Stand musing mid the ranks and, stealing soft</line>
      <line> Behind the studious Luco, struck his cheek</line>
      <line>With a too-heavy whip that reached his eye,</line>
      <line>Making it dark for ever. Luco turned</line>
      <line>In strongest agony, and with his hoe</line>
      <line>Struck the rude Christian on the forehead. Pride,</line>
      <line>With hateful malice, seized on Gorgon’s soul</line>
      <line>(By nature fierce), while Luco sought the beach</line>
      <line>And plunged beneath the wave. But near him lay</line>
      <line>A planter’s barge, whose seamen grasped his hair,</line>
      <line>Dragging to life a wretch who wished to die.</line>
      <line> Rumour now spreads the tale, while Gorgon’s breath</line>
      <line>Envenomed aids her blast. Imputed crimes</line>
      <line>Oppose the plea of Luco, till he scorns</line>
      <line>Even a just defence, and stands prepared.</line>
      <line>The planters, conscious that to fear alone</line>
      <line>They owe their cruel power, resolve to blend</line>
      <line>New torment with the pangs of death, and hold</line>
      <line>Their victim high in dreadful view to fright</line>
      <line>The wretched number left. Luco is chained</line>
      <line>To a huge tree, his fellow-slaves are ranged</line>
      <line> To share the horrid sight; fuel is placed</line>
      <line>In an increasing train, some paces back,</line>
      <line>To kindle slowly, and approach the youth,</line>
      <line>With more than native terror.</line>
      <line>See, it burns!</line>
      <line>He gazes on the growing flame, and calls</line>
      <line>For ‘Water, water!’ The small boon’s denied.</line>
      <line>E’en Christians throng each other to behold</line>
      <line>The different alterations of his face</line>
      <line>As the hot death approaches. (Oh shame, shame</line>
      <line>Upon the followers of Jesus! Shame</line>
      <line> On him that dares avow a God!) He writhes,</line>
      <line>While down his breast glide the unpitied tears,</line>
      <line>And in their sockets strain their scorchéd balls.</line>
      <line>‘Burn, burn me quick! I cannot die!’ he cries,</line>
      <line>‘Bring fire more close!’ The planters heed him not,</line>
      <line>But still prolonging Luco’s torture, threat</line>
      <line>Their trembling slaves around...</line>
      <line>Gracious God!</line>
      <line>Why thus in mercy let thy whirlwinds sleep</line>
      <line>O’er a vile race of Christians, who profane</line>
      <line>Thy glorious attributes? Sweep them from Earth,</line>
      <line>Or check their cruel power! The savage tribes</line>
      <line>Are angels when compared to brutes like these.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANNA LAETITIA BARBAULD</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>On the Expected General Rising of the French Nation in 1792</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rise, mighty nation, in thy strength,</line>
      <line>And deal thy dreadful vengeance round –</line>
      <line>Let thy great spirit, roused at length,</line>
      <line>Strike hordes of despots to the ground!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Devoted land, thy mangled breast</line>
      <line>Eager the royal vultures tear!</line>
      <line>By friends betrayed, by foes oppressed –</line>
      <line>And Virtue struggles with Despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The tocsin sounds! Arise, arise!</line>
      <line>Stern o’er each breast let Country reign –</line>
      <line>Nor virgin’s plighted hand, nor sighs,</line>
      <line>Must now the ardent youth detain:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor must the hind who tills thy soil</line>
      <line>The ripened vintage stay to press,</line>
      <line> Till Rapture crown the flowing bowl,</line>
      <line>And Freedom boast of full success.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Briareus-like extend thy hands,</line>
      <line>That every hand may crush a foe –</line>
      <line>In millions pour thy generous bands,</line>
      <line>And end a warfare by a blow!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then wash with sad repentant tears</line>
      <line>Each deed that clouds thy glory’s page,</line>
      <line>Each frenzied start impelled by fears,</line>
      <line>Each transient burst of headlong rage!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then fold in thy relenting arms</line>
      <line>Thy wretched outcasts where they roam;</line>
      <line>From pining want and war’s alarms,</line>
      <line>Oh call the child of misery home!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then build the tomb – oh not alone</line>
      <line>Of him who bled in Freedom’s cause:</line>
      <line>With equal eye the martyr own</line>
      <line>Of faith revered and ancient laws.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then be thy tide of glory stayed!</line>
      <line>Then be thy conquering banners furled!</line>
      <line> Obey the laws thyself hast made,</line>
      <line>And rise the model of the world!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>HELEN MARIA WILLIAMS</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>France 1792</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Delightful land – ah, now with general voice</line>
      <line>Thy village sons and daughters may rejoice…</line>
      <line>For now on Gallia’s plains the peasant knows</line>
      <line>Those equal rights impartial Heaven bestows.</line>
      <line>He now, by Freedom’s ray illumined, taught</line>
      <line>Some self-respect, some energy of thought,</line>
      <line>Discerns the blessings that to all belong,</line>
      <line>And lives to guard his humble shed from wrong.</line>
      <line>Auspicious Liberty! in vain thy foes</line>
      <line>Deride thy ardour, and thy force oppose;</line>
      <line> In vain refuse to mark thy spreading light,</line>
      <line>While, like the mole they hide their heads in night,</line>
      <line>Or hope their eloquence with taper-ray</line>
      <line>Can dim the blaze of philosophic day –</line>
      <line>Those reasoners who pretend that each abuse,</line>
      <line>Sanctioned by precedent, has some blest use!</line>
      <line>Does then some chemic power to Time belong,</line>
      <line>Extracting by some process right from wrong?</line>
      <line>Must feudal governments for ever last</line>
      <line>(Those gothic piles, the works of ages past) –</line>
      <line> Nor may obtrusive Reason boldly scan,</line>
      <line>Far less reform, the rude misshapen plan:</line>
      <line>The winding labyrinths, the hostile towers</line>
      <line>(Whence danger threatens, and where horror lowers),</line>
      <line>The jealous drawbridge, and the moat profound,</line>
      <line>The lonely dungeon in the caverned ground,</line>
      <line>The sullen dome above those central caves</line>
      <line>Where lives one despot, and a host of slaves?</line>
      <line>Ah, Freedom, on this renovated shore</line>
      <line>That fabric frights the moral world no more!</line>
      <line> Shook to its basis by thy powerful spell,</line>
      <line>Its triple walls in massy fragments fell;</line>
      <line>While, rising from the hideous wreck, appears</line>
      <line>The temple thy firm arm sublimely rears –</line>
      <line>Of fair proportions, and of simple grace,</line>
      <line>A mansion worthy of the human race.</line>
      <line>For me, the witness of those scenes, whose birth</line>
      <line>Forms a new era in the storied earth,</line>
      <line>Oft, while with glowing breast those scenes I view,</line>
      <line>They lead, ah friend beloved, my thoughts to you!</line>
      <line> Ah, still each fine emotion they impart</line>
      <line>With your idea mingles in my heart –</line>
      <line>You, whose warm bosom, whose expanded mind,</line>
      <line>Have shared this glorious triumph of mankind –</line>
      <line>You, whom I oft have heard, with generous zeal,</line>
      <line>With all that truth can urge or pity feel,</line>
      <line>Refute the pompous argument, that tried</line>
      <line>The common cause of millions to deride...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1794</date>
    <title>from The Female Vagrant</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Four years each day with daily bread was blest,</line>
      <line>By constant toil and constant prayer supplied.</line>
      <line>Three lovely infants lay within my breast,</line>
      <line>And often, viewing their sweet smiles, I sighed</line>
      <line>And knew not why. My happy father died</line>
      <line>Just as the children’s meal began to fail,</line>
      <line> For War the nations to the field defied:</line>
      <line>The loom stood still unwatched, the idle gale</line>
      <line>Wooed in deserted shrouds the unregarding sail.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How changed at once: for Labour’s cheerful hum,</line>
      <line>Silence and fears and Misery’s weeping train.</line>
      <line>But soon with proud parade the noisy drum</line>
      <line>Beat round to sweep the streets of want and pain!</line>
      <line>My husband’s arms now only served to strain</line>
      <line>Me and his children, hungering in his view.</line>
      <line>He could not beg. My prayers and tears were vain!</line>
      <line>To join those miserable men he flew –</line>
      <line>We reached the western world a poor devoted crew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh dreadful price of being – to resign</line>
      <line>All that is dear in being! Better far</line>
      <line>In Want’s most lonely cave till death to pine</line>
      <line>Unseen, unheard, unwatched by any star.</line>
      <line>Better before proud Fortune’s sumptuous car</line>
      <line>Obvious our dying bodies to obtrude,</line>
      <line>Than dog-like, wading at the heels of War,</line>
      <line>Protract a curst existence with the brood</line>
      <line> That lap, their very nourishment, their brother’s blood!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pains and plagues that on our heads came down</line>
      <line>(Disease and famine, agony and fear,</line>
      <line>In wood or wilderness, in camp or town),</line>
      <line>It would thy brain unsettle even to hear!</line>
      <line>All perished, all, in one remorseless year –</line>
      <line>Husband and children, one by one, by sword</line>
      <line>And scourge of fiery fever. Every tear</line>
      <line>Dried up, despairing, desolate, on board</line>
      <line>A British ship I waked, as from a trance restored…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Peaceful as this immeasurable plain</line>
      <line>By these extended beams of dawn impressed,</line>
      <line>In the calm sunshine slept the glittering main.</line>
      <line> The very ocean has its hour of rest</line>
      <line>Ungranted to the human mourner’s breast.</line>
      <line>Remote from man and storms of mortal care,</line>
      <line>With wings which did the world of waves invest,</line>
      <line>The spirit of God diffused through balmy air</line>
      <line>Quiet that might have healed, if aught could heal, despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, how unlike each smell, each sight and sound,</line>
      <line>That late the stupor of my spirit broke!</line>
      <line>Of noisome hospitals the groan profound,</line>
      <line>The mine’s dire earthquake, the bomb’s thunder-stroke,</line>
      <line> Heart-sickening Famine’s grim despairing look;</line>
      <line>The midnight flames in thundering deluge spread;</line>
      <line>The storméd town’s expiring shriek that woke</line>
      <line>Far round the grisly phantoms of the dead –</line>
      <line>And, pale with ghastly light, the victor’s human head!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some mighty gulf of separation passed,</line>
      <line>I seemed transported to another world –</line>
      <line>A dream resigned with pain when from the mast</line>
      <line>The impatient mariner the sail unfurled</line>
      <line>And, whistling, called the wind that hardly curled</line>
      <line> The silent seas. The pleasant thoughts of home</line>
      <line>With tears his weather-beaten cheek impearled:</line>
      <line>For me, farthest from earthly port to roam</line>
      <line>Was best – my only wish to shun where man might come.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And oft, robbed of my perfect mind, I thought</line>
      <line>At last my feet a resting-place had found.</line>
      <line>“Here will I weep in peace”, so Fancy wrought,</line>
      <line>“Roaming the illimitable waters round –</line>
      <line>Here gaze, of every friend but Death disowned,</line>
      <line>All day my ready tomb the ocean-flood.”</line>
      <line> To break my dream the vessel reached its bound,</line>
      <line>And homeless near a thousand homes I stood,</line>
      <line>And near a thousand tables pined and wanted food.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1795</date>
    <title>For A’ That, and A’ That</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is there, for honest Poverty</line>
      <line>That hings his head, and a’ that?</line>
      <line>The coward-slave, we pass him by,</line>
      <line>We dare be poor for a’ that!</line>
      <line> For a’ that, and a’ that</line>
      <line>(Our toils obscure, and a’ that),</line>
      <line>The rank is but the guinea’s stamp,</line>
      <line>The Man’s the gowd for a’ that!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What though on hamely fare we dine,</line>
      <line>Wear hoddin grey, and a’ that –</line>
      <line>Gie fools their silks and knaves their wine,</line>
      <line>A man’s a man for a’ that!</line>
      <line>For a’ that, and a’ that,</line>
      <line>Their tinsel show, and a’ that,</line>
      <line> The honest man, though e’er sae poor,</line>
      <line>Is king o’ men for a’ that.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye see yon birkie ca’d a lord,</line>
      <line>Wha struts, and stares, and a’ that,</line>
      <line>Though hundreds worship at his word,</line>
      <line>He’s but a coof for a’ that!</line>
      <line>For a’ that and a’ that</line>
      <line>(His ribband, star, and a’ that),</line>
      <line>The man of independent mind,</line>
      <line>He looks and laughs at a’ that!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A prince can mak a belted knight –</line>
      <line>A marquis, duke, and a’ that –</line>
      <line>But an honest man’s aboun his might:</line>
      <line>Gude faith, he mauna fa’ that!</line>
      <line>For a’ that, and a’ that</line>
      <line>(Their dignities, and a’ that),</line>
      <line>The pith o’ sense, and pride o’ worth,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Are higher rank than a’ that!</line>
      <line>Then let us pray that come it may,</line>
      <line>As come it will for a’ that,</line>
      <line> That sense and worth, o’er a’ the earth</line>
      <line>Shall bear the gree, and a’ that –</line>
      <line>For a’ that, and a’ that,</line>
      <line>Its comin yet for a’ that,</line>
      <line>That man to man, the warld o’er,</line>
      <line>Shall brothers be, for a’ that!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>Poems on the Slave Trade</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>High in the air exposed the slave is hung</line>
      <line>To all the birds of heaven, their living food!</line>
      <line>He groans not, though – awakened by that fierce sun –</line>
      <line>New torturers live to drink their parent blood!</line>
      <line> He groans not, though the gorging vulture tear</line>
      <line>The quivering fibre! Hither gaze, oh ye</line>
      <line>Who tore this man from peace and liberty –</line>
      <line>Gaze hither, ye who weigh with scrupulous care</line>
      <line>The right and prudent – for beyond the grave</line>
      <line>There is another world! And call to mind,</line>
      <line>Ere your decrees proclaim to all mankind</line>
      <line>Murder is legalized, that there the slave</line>
      <line>Before the Eternal, ‘thunder-tongued shall plead</line>
      <line>Against the deep damnation of your deed’!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>France: An Ode</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye clouds, that far above me float and pause,</line>
      <line>Whose pathless march no mortal may control!</line>
      <line>Ye ocean-waves, that whereso’er ye roll,</line>
      <line>Yield homage only to eternal laws!</line>
      <line> Ye woods, that listen to the night-bird’s singing,</line>
      <line>Midway the smooth and perilous slope reclined,</line>
      <line>Save where your own imperious branches swinging</line>
      <line>Have made a solemn music of the wind,</line>
      <line>Where (like a man beloved of God)</line>
      <line>Through glooms which never woodman trod</line>
      <line>How oft, pursuing fancies holy,</line>
      <line>My moonlight way o’er flowering weeds I wound</line>
      <line>Inspired, beyond the guess of folly,</line>
      <line>By each rude shape and wild unconquerable sound!</line>
      <line> Oh ye loud waves, and oh ye forests high,</line>
      <line>And oh ye clouds that far above me soared –</line>
      <line>Thou rising sun, thou blue rejoicing sky,</line>
      <line>Yea, every thing that is, and will be, free –</line>
      <line>Bear witness for me, whereso’er ye be,</line>
      <line>With what deep worship I have still adored</line>
      <line>The spirit of divinest Liberty!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When France in wrath her giant-limbs upreared,</line>
      <line>And, with an oath which smote air, earth and sea,</line>
      <line>Stamped her strong foot and said she would be free,</line>
      <line> Bear witness for me how I hoped and feared –</line>
      <line>With what a joy my lofty gratulation</line>
      <line>Unawed I sang, amid a slavish band –</line>
      <line>And when to whelm the disenchanted nation</line>
      <line>(Like fiends embattled by a wizard’s wand)</line>
      <line>The Monarchs marched in evil day,</line>
      <line>And Britain joined the dire array,</line>
      <line>Though dear her shores and circling ocean;</line>
      <line>Though many friendships, many youthful loves,</line>
      <line>Had swoln the patriot emotion</line>
      <line> And flung a magic light o’er all her hills and groves;</line>
      <line>Yet still my voice, unaltered, sang defeat</line>
      <line>To all that braved the tyrant-quelling lance –</line>
      <line>And shame (too long delayed) and vain retreat!</line>
      <line>For ne’er, oh Liberty, with partial aim</line>
      <line>I dimmed thy light or damped thy holy flame,</line>
      <line>But blest the paeans of delivered France,</line>
      <line>And hung my head, and wept at Britain’s name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And what’, I said, ‘though Blasphemy’s loud scream</line>
      <line>With that sweet music of deliverance strove –</line>
      <line> Though all the fierce and drunken passions wove</line>
      <line>A dance more wild that e’er was maniac’s dream!</line>
      <line>Ye storms that round the dawning East assembled,</line>
      <line>The sun was rising, though ye hid his light!’</line>
      <line>And when (to soothe my soul, that hoped and trembled)</line>
      <line>The dissonance ceased, and all seemed calm and bright;</line>
      <line>When France her front, deep-scarred and gory,</line>
      <line>Concealed with clustering wreaths of glory;</line>
      <line>When, insupportably advancing,</line>
      <line>Her arm made mockery of the warrior’s ramp;</line>
      <line> While, timid looks of fury glancing,</line>
      <line>Domestic treason (crushed beneath her fatal stamp)</line>
      <line>Writhed like a wounded dragon in his gore;</line>
      <line>Then I reproached my fears that would not flee –</line>
      <line>‘And soon’, I said, ‘shall Wisdom teach her lore</line>
      <line>In the low huts of them that toil and groan!</line>
      <line>And, conquering by her happiness alone,</line>
      <line>Shall France compel the nations to be free.</line>
      <line>Till Love and Joy look round, and call the Earth their own.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forgive me, Freedom – oh forgive those dreams!</line>
      <line> I hear thy voice, I hear thy loud lament,</line>
      <line>From bleak Helvetia’s icy caverns sent –</line>
      <line>I hear thy groans upon her bloodstained streams!</line>
      <line>Heroes, that for thy peaceful country perished –</line>
      <line>And ye that, fleeing, spot your mountain-snows</line>
      <line>With bleeding wounds – forgive me that I cherished</line>
      <line>One thought that ever blest your cruel foes!</line>
      <line>To scatter rage, and traitorous guilt,</line>
      <line>Where Peace her jealous home had built;</line>
      <line>A patriot-race to disinherit</line>
      <line> Of all that made their stormy wilds so dear;</line>
      <line>And with inexpiable spirit</line>
      <line>To taint the bloodless freedom of the mountaineer –</line>
      <line>Oh France, that mockest Heaven, adulterous, blind,</line>
      <line>And patriot only in pernicious toils!</line>
      <line>Are these thy boasts, champion of human kind?</line>
      <line>To mix with Kings in the low lust of sway,</line>
      <line>Yell in the hunt, and share the murderous prey,</line>
      <line>To insult the shrine of Liberty with spoils</line>
      <line>From freemen torn – to tempt, and to betray?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The sensual and the dark rebel in vain,</line>
      <line>Slaves by their own compulsion! In mad game</line>
      <line>They burst their manacles, and wear the name</line>
      <line>Of Freedom graven on a heavier chain!</line>
      <line>Oh Liberty, with profitless endeavour</line>
      <line>Have I pursued thee many a weary hour</line>
      <line>But thou nor swellst the victor’s strain, nor ever</line>
      <line>Didst breathe thy soul in forms of human power.</line>
      <line>Alike, from all, howe’er they praise thee</line>
      <line>(Nor prayer, nor boastful name delays thee) –</line>
      <line> Alike from Priestcraft’s harpy minions</line>
      <line>And factious Blasphemy’s obscener slaves</line>
      <line>Thou speedest on thy subtle pinions,</line>
      <line>The guide of homeless winds, and playmate of the waves!</line>
      <line>And there I felt thee – on the sea-cliff’s verge,</line>
      <line>OWhose pines, scarce travelled by the breeze above,</line>
      <line>Had made one murmur with the distant surge.</line>
      <line>Yes, while I stood and gazed, my temples bare,</line>
      <line>And shot my being through earth, sea and air,</line>
      <line>Possessing all things with intensest love,</line>
      <line>Oh Liberty, my spirit found thee there!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>from Fears in Solitude</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We, this whole people, have been clamorous</line>
      <line>For war and bloodshed, animating sports</line>
      <line>The which we pay for, as a thing to talk of,</line>
      <line>Spectators and not combatants!…</line>
      <line>Boys and girls,</line>
      <line>And women, that would groan to see a child</line>
      <line>Pull off an insect’s leg, all read of war,</line>
      <line>The best amusement for our morning meal!</line>
      <line>The poor wretch, who has learnt his only prayers</line>
      <line>From curses, who knows scarcely words enough</line>
      <line>To ask a blessing of his heavenly Father,</line>
      <line>Becomes a fluent phraseman, absolute</line>
      <line>And technical in victories and defeats,</line>
      <line>And all our dainty terms for fratricide,</line>
      <line>Terms which we trundle smoothly o’er our tongues</line>
      <line>Like mere abstractions, empty sounds to which</line>
      <line>We join no feeling and attach no form –</line>
      <line>As if the soldier died without a wound;</line>
      <line> As if the fibres of this godlike frame</line>
      <line>Were gored without a pang; as if the wretch,</line>
      <line>Who fell in battle doing bloody deeds,</line>
      <line>Passed off to Heaven, translated and not killed;</line>
      <line>As though he had no wife to pine for him,</line>
      <line>No God to judge him!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT SOUTHEY</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>The Battle of Blenheim</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was a summer evening,</line>
      <line>Old Kaspar’s work was done,</line>
      <line>And he before his cottage door</line>
      <line>Was sitting in the sun,</line>
      <line> And by him sported on the green</line>
      <line>His little grandchild Wilhelmine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She saw her brother Peterkin</line>
      <line>Roll something large and round</line>
      <line>That he beside the rivulet</line>
      <line>In playing there had found;</line>
      <line>He came to ask what he had found</line>
      <line>That was so large, and smooth, and round.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Kaspar took it from the boy</line>
      <line>Who stood expectant by,</line>
      <line> And then the old man shook his head</line>
      <line>And with a natural sigh,</line>
      <line>‘’Tis some poor fellow’s skull’, said he,</line>
      <line>‘Who fell in the great victory.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I find them in the garden for</line>
      <line>There’s many here about,</line>
      <line>And often when I go to plough</line>
      <line>The ploughshare turns them out –</line>
      <line>For many thousand men’, said he,</line>
      <line>‘Were slain in the great victory.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘Now tell us what ’twas all about’,</line>
      <line>Young Peterkin he cries,</line>
      <line>And little Wilhelmine looks up</line>
      <line>With wonder-waiting eyes,</line>
      <line>‘Now tell us all about the war</line>
      <line>And what they killed each other for.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It was the English’, Kaspar cried,</line>
      <line>‘That put the French to rout,</line>
      <line>But what they killed each other for</line>
      <line>I could not well make out.</line>
      <line> But everybody said’, quoth he,</line>
      <line>‘That ’twas a famous victory.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My father lived at Blenheim then,</line>
      <line>Yon little stream hard by –</line>
      <line>They burnt his dwelling to the ground</line>
      <line>And he was forced to fly;</line>
      <line>So with his wife and child he fled,</line>
      <line>Nor had he where to rest his head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With fire and sword the country round</line>
      <line>Was wasted far and wide,</line>
      <line> And many a childing mother then</line>
      <line>And new-born infant died.</line>
      <line>But things like that, you know, must be</line>
      <line>At every famous victory.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say it was a shocking sight</line>
      <line>After the field was won,</line>
      <line>For many thousand bodies here</line>
      <line>Lay rotting in the sun –</line>
      <line>But things like that you know must be</line>
      <line>After a famous victory.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Great praise the Duke of Marlborough won,</line>
      <line>And our good Prince Eugene.’</line>
      <line>‘Why ’twas a very wicked thing!’</line>
      <line>Said little Wilhelmine.</line>
      <line>‘Nay, nay, my little girl’, quoth he,</line>
      <line>‘It was a famous victory,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And everybody praised the Duke</line>
      <line>Who such a fight did win.’</line>
      <line>‘But what good came of it at last?’</line>
      <line>Quoth little Peterkin.</line>
      <line> ‘Why that I cannot tell’, said he,</line>
      <line>‘But ’twas a famous victory!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BLOOMFIELD</author>
    <date>1801</date>
    <title>The Farmer’s Boy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, ere sweet Summer bids its long adieu,</line>
      <line>And winds blow keen where late the blossoms grew,</line>
      <line>The bustling day and jovial night must come,</line>
      <line>The long-accustomed feast of Harvest Home...</line>
      <line>Behold the round oak table’s massy frame</line>
      <line>Bestride the kitchen-floor! The careful dame</line>
      <line>And generous host invite their friends around,</line>
      <line>While all that cleared the crop, or tilled the ground,</line>
      <line>Are guests by right of custom – old and young..</line>
      <line>Such were the days – of days long past I sing –</line>
      <line>When pride gave place to mirth without a sting,</line>
      <line> Ere tyrant customs strength sufficient bore</line>
      <line>To violate the feelings of the poor,</line>
      <line>To leave them distanced in the madding race</line>
      <line>Where’er refinement shows its hated face –</line>
      <line>Not causeless hated: ’tis the peasant’s curse,</line>
      <line>That hourly makes his wretched station worse,</line>
      <line>Destroys life’s intercourse, the social plan</line>
      <line>That rank to rank cements, as man to man.</line>
      <line>Wealth flows round him, Fashion lordly reigns;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet poverty is his, and mental pains.</line>
      <line>Methinks I hear the mourner thus impart</line>
      <line> The stifled murmurs of his wounded heart:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Whence comes this change, ungracious, irksome, cold?</line>
      <line>Whence the new grandeur that mine eyes behold,</line>
      <line>The widening distance that I darkly see?</line>
      <line>Has Wealth done this? Then Wealth’s a foe to me,</line>
      <line>Foe to our rights...</line>
      <line>Our annual feast, when Earth her plenty yields,</line>
      <line>O When crowned with boughs the last load quits the fields</line>
      <line>The aspect still of ancient joy puts on –</line>
      <line>The aspect only, with the substance gone.</line>
      <line>Where unaffected Freedom charmed the soul,</line>
      <line>The separate table and the costly bowl,</line>
      <line> Cool as the blast that checks the budding Spring,</line>
      <line>A mockery of gladness round them fling...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor reigns that joy, when hand in hand they join,</line>
      <line>That good old Master felt in shaking mine.</line>
      <line>Heaven bless his memory – bless his honoured name! –</line>
      <line>The poor will speak his lasting worthy fame.</line>
      <line> To souls fair-purposed, strength and guidance give –</line>
      <line>In pity to us, still let goodness live –</line>
      <line>Let Labour have its due! My cot shall be</line>
      <line>From chilling want and guilty murmurs free!</line>
      <line>Let Labour have its due – then peace is mine,</line>
      <line>And never, never shall my heart repine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>On the Extinction of the Venetian Republic</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Once did she hold the gorgeous East in fee,</line>
      <line>And was the safeguard of the West – the worth</line>
      <line>Of Venice did not fall below her birth,</line>
      <line>Venice, the eldest child of Liberty!</line>
      <line> She was a maiden-city, bright and free,</line>
      <line>No guile seduced, no force could violate;</line>
      <line>And when she took unto herself a mate,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She must espouse the everlasting sea.</line>
      <line>And what if she had seen those glories fade,</line>
      <line>Those titles vanish, and that strength decay?</line>
      <line>Yet shall some tribute of regret be paid</line>
      <line>When her long life hath reached its final day:</line>
      <line>Men are we, and must grieve when even the shade</line>
      <line>Of that which once was great is passed away.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>To Toussaint L’Ouverture</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Toussaint – the most unhappy man of men! –</line>
      <line>Whether the rural milkmaid by her cow</line>
      <line>Sing in thy hearing, or thou liest now</line>
      <line>Alone in some deep dungeon’s earless den,</line>
      <line> Oh miserable chieftain, where and when</line>
      <line>Wilt thou find patience? Yet die not! Do thou</line>
      <line>Wear rather in thy bonds a cheerful brow;</line>
      <line>Though fallen thyself, never to rise again,</line>
      <line>Live, and take comfort! Thou hast left behind</line>
      <line>Powers that will work for thee – air, earth, and skies –</line>
      <line>There’s not a breathing of the common wind</line>
      <line>That will forget thee! Thou hast great allies:</line>
      <line>Thy friends are exultations, agonies,</line>
      <line>And love, and man’s unconquerable mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>We Had a Fellow-Passenger</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We had a fellow-passenger who came</line>
      <line>From Calais with us, gaudy in array –</line>
      <line>A negro woman, like a lady gay,</line>
      <line>Yet silent as a woman fearing blame.</line>
      <line> Dejected, meek – yea, pitiably tame –</line>
      <line>She sat, from notice turning not away,</line>
      <line>But on our proffered kindness still did lay</line>
      <line>A weight of languid speech, or at the same</line>
      <line>Was silent, motionless in eyes and face.</line>
      <line>She was a negro woman driven from France,</line>
      <line>Rejected like all others of that race,</line>
      <line>Not one of whom may now find footing there.</line>
      <line>This the poor outcast did to us declare,</line>
      <line>Nor murmured at the unfeeling ordinance.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>‘Golden Hours’: Calais and the Rhone (from Prelude, VI)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas a time when Europe was rejoiced,</line>
      <line>France standing on the top of golden hours,</line>
      <line>And human nature seeming born again.</line>
      <line> Bound, as I said, to the Alps, it was our lot</line>
      <line>To land at Calais on the very eve</line>
      <line>Of that great Federal Day; and there we saw,</line>
      <line>In a mean city and among a few,</line>
      <line>How bright a face is worn when joy of one</line>
      <line>Is joy of tens of millions!</line>
      <line>Southward thence</line>
      <line>We took our way, direct through hamlets, towns,</line>
      <line>Gaudy with relics of that festival,</line>
      <line>Flowers left to wither on triumphal arcs</line>
      <line>And window-garlands. On the public roads</line>
      <line> (And once three days successively through paths</line>
      <line>By which our toilsome journey was abridged)</line>
      <line>Among sequestered villages we walked,</line>
      <line>And found benevolence and blessedness</line>
      <line>Spread like a fragrance everywhere…</line>
      <line>Unhoused beneath the evening star we saw</line>
      <line>Dances of liberty, and in late hours</line>
      <line>Of darkness, dances in the open air.</line>
      <line>Among the vine-clad hills of Burgundy,</line>
      <line>Upon the bosom of the gentle Soane</line>
      <line> We glided forward with the flowing stream.</line>
      <line>Swift Rhone, thou wert the wings on which we cut</line>
      <line>Between thy lofty rocks! Enchanting show</line>
      <line>Those woods and farms and orchards did present,</line>
      <line>And single cottages and lurking towns –</line>
      <line>Reach after reach, procession without end</line>
      <line>Of deep and stately vales. A lonely pair</line>
      <line>Of Englishmen we were, and sailed along</line>
      <line>Clustered together with a merry crowd</line>
      <line>Of those emancipated, with a host</line>
      <line> Of travellers, chiefly delegates returning</line>
      <line>From the great spousals newly solemnized</line>
      <line>In their chief city, in the sight of Heaven.</line>
      <line>Like bees they swarmed – gaudy and gay as bees!</line>
      <line>Some vapoured in the unruliness of joy,</line>
      <line>And flourished with their swords as if to fight</line>
      <line>The saucy air! In this blithe company</line>
      <line>We landed, took with them our evening meal,</line>
      <line>Guests welcome almost as the angels were</line>
      <line>To Abraham of old. The supper done,</line>
      <line>With flowing cups elate, and happy thoughts,</line>
      <line>We rose at signal given, and formed a ring</line>
      <line>And hand in hand danced round and round the board.</line>
      <line>All hearts were open, every tongue was loud</line>
      <line>With amity and glee. We bore a name</line>
      <line>Honoured in France, the name of Englishmen,</line>
      <line>And hospitably did they give us hail</line>
      <line>As their forerunners in a glorious course –</line>
      <line>And round and round the board they danced again!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>A Tourist’s Unconcern: Paris (from Prelude, IX)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Through Paris lay my readiest path, and there</line>
      <line>I sojourned a few days and visited</line>
      <line>In haste each spot of old and recent fame –</line>
      <line>The latter chiefly – from the Field of Mars</line>
      <line>Down to the suburbs of St Antony,</line>
      <line> And from Mont Martyr southward to the Dome</line>
      <line>Of Genevieve. In both her clamorous halls</line>
      <line>(The National Synod and the Jacobins)</line>
      <line>I saw the revolutionary power</line>
      <line>Toss like a ship at anchor, rocked by storms;</line>
      <line>The Arcades I traversed in the Palace huge</line>
      <line>Of Orleans, coasted round and round the line</line>
      <line>Of tavern, brothel, gaming-house and shop –</line>
      <line>Great rendezvous of worst and best, the walk</line>
      <line>Of all who had a purpose, or had not!</line>
      <line> I stared, and listened with a stranger’s ears</line>
      <line>To hawkers and haranguers (hubbub wild!)</line>
      <line>And hissing factionists with ardent eyes,</line>
      <line>In knots, or pairs, or single – ant-like swarms</line>
      <line>Of builders and subverters, every face</line>
      <line>That hope or apprehension could put on:</line>
      <line>Joy, anger and vexation, in the midst</line>
      <line>Of gaiety and dissolute idleness.</line>
      <line>Where silent zephyrs sported with the dust</line>
      <line>Of the Bastille I sat in the open sun</line>
      <line> And from the rubbish gathered up a stone,</line>
      <line>And pocketed the relic in the guise</line>
      <line>Of an enthusiast; yet, in honest truth</line>
      <line>Though not without some strong incumbencies,</line>
      <line>And glad – could living man be otherwise? –</line>
      <line>I looked for something which I could not find,</line>
      <line>Affecting more emotion than I felt.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>Among Royalists: Blois (from Prelude IX)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A knot of military officers</line>
      <line>That to a regiment appertained which then</line>
      <line>Was stationed in the city were the chief</line>
      <line>Of my associates; some of these wore swords</line>
      <line>Which had been seasoned in the wars, and all</line>
      <line>Were men well-born – at least, laid claim to such</line>
      <line>Distinction, as the chivalry of France.</line>
      <line>In age and temper differing, they had yet</line>
      <line> One spirit ruling in them all – alike</line>
      <line>(Save only one, hereafter to be named)</line>
      <line>Were bent upon undoing what was done!</line>
      <line>This was their rest, and only hope; therewith</line>
      <line>No fear had they of bad becoming worse,</line>
      <line>For worst to them had come – nor would have stirred,</line>
      <line>Or deemed it worth a moment’s while to stir,</line>
      <line>In any thing, save only if the act</line>
      <line>Looked thitherward.</line>
      <line>One, reckoning by years,</line>
      <line>Was in the prime of manhood, and erewhile</line>
      <line> He had sat lord in many tender hearts,</line>
      <line>Though heedless of such honours now, and changed:</line>
      <line>His temper was quite mastered by the times,</line>
      <line>And they had blighted him, had eat away</line>
      <line>The beauty of his person, doing wrong</line>
      <line>Alike to body and to mind. His port,</line>
      <line>Which once had been erect and open, now</line>
      <line>Was stooping and contracted, and a face</line>
      <line>By nature lovely in itself, expressed,</line>
      <line>As much as any that was ever seen,</line>
      <line> A ravage out of season, made by thoughts</line>
      <line>Unhealthy and vexatious. At the hour,</line>
      <line>The most important of each day, in which</line>
      <line>The public news was read, the fever came,</line>
      <line>A punctual visitant, to shake this man,</line>
      <line>Disarmed his voice and fanned his yellow cheek</line>
      <line>Into a thousand colours, While he read,</line>
      <line>Or mused, his sword was haunted by his touch</line>
      <line>Continually, like an uneasy place</line>
      <line>In his own body.</line>
      <line>’Twas in truth an hour</line>
      <line> Of universal ferment – mildest men</line>
      <line>Were agitated, and commotions, strife</line>
      <line>Of passions and opinion, filled the walls</line>
      <line>Of peaceful houses with unquiet sounds!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>‘A Patriot’: Blois (Prelude IX)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Among that band of officers was one,</line>
      <line> Already hinted at, of other mould –</line>
      <line>A patriot, thence rejected by the rest,</line>
      <line>And with an oriental loathing spurned</line>
      <line>As of a different caste. A meeker man</line>
      <line>Than this lived never, or a more benign…</line>
      <line>And when we chanced</line>
      <line>One day to meet a hunger-bitten girl</line>
      <line>Who crept along fitting her languid self</line>
      <line>Unto a heifer’s motion – by a cord</line>
      <line> Tied to her arm, and picking thus from the lane</line>
      <line>Its sustenance, while the girl with her two hands</line>
      <line>Was busy knitting in a heartless mood</line>
      <line>Of solitude – and at the sight my friend</line>
      <line>In agitation said, ‘’Tis against that</line>
      <line>Which we are fighting!’ I with him believed</line>
      <line>Devoutly that a spirit was abroad</line>
      <line>Which could not be withstood; that poverty,</line>
      <line>At least like this, would in a little time</line>
      <line>Be found no more; that we should see the Earth</line>
      <line> Unthwarted in her wish to recompense</line>
      <line>The industrious and the lowly child of toil,</line>
      <line>All institutes for ever blotted out</line>
      <line>That legalized exclusion, empty pomp</line>
      <line>Abolished, sensual state and cruel power</line>
      <line>(Whether by edict of the one or few),</line>
      <line>And finally, as sum and crown of all,</line>
      <line>Should see the people having a strong hand</line>
      <line>In making their own laws – whence better days</line>
      <line>To all mankind!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>‘Sleep No More’: Paris (from Prelude X)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The state, as if to stamp the final seal</line>
      <line> On her security, and to the world</line>
      <line>Show what she was, a high and fearless soul –</line>
      <line>Or rather in a spirit of thanks to those</line>
      <line>Who had stirred up her slackening faculties</line>
      <line>To a new transition – had assumed with joy</line>
      <line>The body and the venerable name</line>
      <line>Of a republic. Lamentable crimes,</line>
      <line>’Tis true, had gone before this hour, the work</line>
      <line>Of massacre, in which the senseless sword</line>
      <line>Was prayed to as a judge. But these were past,</line>
      <line> Earth free from them for ever (as was thought),</line>
      <line>Ephemeral monsters, to be seen but once –</line>
      <line>Things that could only show themselves, and die!</line>
      <line>This was the time in which, inflamed with hope,</line>
      <line>To Paris I returned. Again I ranged,</line>
      <line>More eagerly than I had done before,</line>
      <line>Through the wide city – and in progress passed</line>
      <line>The prison where the unhappy monarch lay,</line>
      <line>Associate with his children and his wife</line>
      <line>In bondage, and the Palace, lately stormed</line>
      <line> With roar of canon and a numerous host.</line>
      <line>I crossed (a black and empty area then)</line>
      <line>The Square of the Carroussel, few weeks back</line>
      <line>Heaped up with dead and dying – upon these</line>
      <line>And other sights looking as doth a man</line>
      <line>Upon a volume whose contents he knows</line>
      <line>Are memorable but from him locked up,</line>
      <line>Being written in a tongue he cannot read,</line>
      <line>So that he questions the mute leaves with pain</line>
      <line>And half upbraids their silence.</line>
      <line>But that night,</line>
      <line> When on my bed I lay, I was most moved</line>
      <line>And felt most deeply in what world I was.</line>
      <line>My room was high and lonely, near the roof</line>
      <line>Of a large mansion or hotel, a spot</line>
      <line>That would have pleased me in more quiet times –</line>
      <line>Nor was it wholly without pleasure then.</line>
      <line>With unextinguished taper I kept watch,</line>
      <line>Reading at intervals. The fear gone by</line>
      <line>Pressed on me almost like a fear to come.</line>
      <line>I thought of those September massacres,</line>
      <line> Divided from me by a little month,</line>
      <line>And felt and touched them, a substantial dread</line>
      <line>(The rest was conjured up from tragic fictions</line>
      <line>And mournful calendars of true history,</line>
      <line>Remembrances and dim admonishments):</line>
      <line>‘The horse is taught his manage, and the wind</line>
      <line>Of heaven wheels round and treads in his own steps!</line>
      <line>Year follows year, the tide returns again,</line>
      <line>Day follows day: all things have second birth –</line>
      <line>The earthquake is not satisfied at once!’</line>
      <line> And in such way I wrought upon myself</line>
      <line>Until I seemed to hear a voice that cried</line>
      <line>To the whole city, ‘Sleep no more!’ To this</line>
      <line>Add comments of a calmer mind, from which</line>
      <line>I could not gather full security,</line>
      <line>But at the best it seemed a place of fear</line>
      <line>Unfit for the repose of night,</line>
      <line>Defenceless as a place where tigers roam.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>War and Alienation: London and Wales (from Prelude X)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When to my native land</line>
      <line>(After a whole year’s absence) I returned</line>
      <line>I found the air yet busy with the stir</line>
      <line>Of a contention which had been raised up</line>
      <line>Against the traffickers in negro blood –</line>
      <line>An effort which, though baffled, nevertheless</line>
      <line>Had called back old forgotten principles</line>
      <line>Dismissed from service, had diffused some truths,</line>
      <line>And more of virtuous feeling, through the heart</line>
      <line>Of the English people…</line>
      <line>For me that strife had ne’er</line>
      <line>Fastened on my affections – nor did now</line>
      <line>Its unsuccessful issue much excite</line>
      <line>My sorrow, having laid this faith to heart</line>
      <line>That if France prospered good men would not long</line>
      <line>Pay fruitless worship to humanity,</line>
      <line>And this most rotten branch of human shame</line>
      <line> (Object, it seemed, of a superfluous pains)</line>
      <line>Would fall together with its parent tree.</line>
      <line>Such was my then belief – that there was one,</line>
      <line>And only one, solicitude for all!</line>
      <line>And now the strength of Britain was put forth</line>
      <line>In league with the confederated host;</line>
      <line>Not in my single self alone I found,</line>
      <line>But in the minds of all ingenuous youth,</line>
      <line>Change and subversion from that hour. No shock</line>
      <line>Given to my moral nature had I known</line>
      <line> Down to that moment – neither lapse,</line>
      <line>Nor turn of sentiment, that might be named</line>
      <line>A revolution, save at this one time!</line>
      <line>All else was progress on the self-same path</line>
      <line>On which, with a diversity of pace,</line>
      <line>I had been travelling – this, a stride at once</line>
      <line>Into another region.</line>
      <line>True it is</line>
      <line>’Twas not concealed with what ungracious eyes</line>
      <line>Our native rulers from the very first</line>
      <line>Had looked upon regenerated France,</line>
      <line> Nor had I doubted that this day would come;</line>
      <line>But in such contemplation I had thought</line>
      <line>Of general interests only, beyond this</line>
      <line>Had never once foretasted the event.</line>
      <line>Now I had other business, for I felt</line>
      <line>The ravage of this most unnatural strife</line>
      <line>In my own heart. There it lay like a weight,</line>
      <line>At enmity with all the tenderest springs</line>
      <line>Of my enjoyments.</line>
      <line>I who with the breeze</line>
      <line>Had played, a green leaf on the blesséd tree</line>
      <line> Of my beloved country (nor had wished</line>
      <line>For happier fortune than to wither there),</line>
      <line>Now from my pleasant station was cut off,</line>
      <line>And tossed about in whirlwinds. I rejoiced –</line>
      <line>Yea, afterwards, truth painful to record,</line>
      <line>Exulted in the triumph of my soul,</line>
      <line>When Englishmen by thousands were o’erthrown,</line>
      <line>Left without glory on the field, or driven,</line>
      <line>Brave hearts, to shameful flight.</line>
      <line>It was a grief –</line>
      <line>Grief call it not, ’twas anything but that –</line>
      <line> A conflict of sensations without name,</line>
      <line>Of which he only who may love the sight</line>
      <line>Of a village-steeple as I do can judge,</line>
      <line>When in the congregation, bending all</line>
      <line>To their great Father, prayers were offered up</line>
      <line>Or praises for our country’s victories,</line>
      <line>And, mid the simple worshippers perchance</line>
      <line>I only, like an uninvited guest</line>
      <line>Whom no one owned, sat silent – shall I add</line>
      <line>Fed on the day of vengeance yet to come!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>‘Eternal Justice’: Morecambe Sands (Prelude X)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Friend, few happier moments have been mine</line>
      <line>Through my whole life than that when first I heard</line>
      <line>That this foul tribe of Moloch was o’erthrown</line>
      <line>And their chief regent levelled with the dust!</line>
      <line>The day was one which haply may deserve</line>
      <line>A separate chronicle. Having gone abroad</line>
      <line>From a small village where I tarried then,</line>
      <line>To the same far-secluded privacy</line>
      <line>I was returning. Over the smooth sands</line>
      <line> Of Levens’ ample estuary lay</line>
      <line>My journey, and beneath a genial sun…</line>
      <line> Without me and within as I advanced</line>
      <line>All that I saw, or felt, or communed with,</line>
      <line>Was gentleness and peace. Upon a small</line>
      <line>And rocky island near, a fragment stood –</line>
      <line>Itself like a sea-rock – of what had been</line>
      <line>A Romish chapel, where in ancient times</line>
      <line>Masses were said at the hour which suited those</line>
      <line>Who crossed the sands with ebb of morning tide.</line>
      <line>Not far from this still ruin all the plain</line>
      <line>Was spotted with a variegated crowd</line>
      <line> Of coaches, wains, and travellers (horse, and foot),</line>
      <line>Wading beneath the conduct of their guide</line>
      <line>In loose procession through the shallow stream</line>
      <line>Of inland-water – the great sea meanwhile</line>
      <line>Was at safe distance, far retired.</line>
      <line>I paused</line>
      <line>Unwilling to proceed, the scene appeared</line>
      <line>So gay and cheerful – when, a traveller</line>
      <line>Chancing to pass, I carelessly enquired</line>
      <line>If any news were stirring. He replied</line>
      <line>(In the familiar language of the day)</line>
      <line> That Robespierre was dead. Nor was a doubt,</line>
      <line>On further question, left within my mind,</line>
      <line>But that the tidings were substantial truth –</line>
      <line>That he and his supporters all were fallen.</line>
      <line>Great was my glee of spirit, great my joy</line>
      <line>In vengeance, and eternal justice, thus</line>
      <line>Made manifest. ‘Come now, ye golden times’,</line>
      <line>Said I, forth-breathing on those open sands</line>
      <line>A hymn of triumph, ‘as the morning comes</line>
      <line>Out of the bosom of the night, come ye!</line>
      <line> Thus far our trust is verified: behold,</line>
      <line>They who with clumsy desperation brought</line>
      <line>Rivers of blood, and preached that nothing else</line>
      <line>Could cleanse the Augean stable, by the might</line>
      <line>Of their own helper have been swept away!</line>
      <line>Their madness is declared and visible –</line>
      <line>Elsewhere will safety now be sought, and earth</line>
      <line>March firmly towards righteousness and peace.’</line>
      <line>Then schemes I framed more calmly when and how</line>
      <line>The madding factions might be tranquillized,</line>
      <line> And (through hardships manifold and long)</line>
      <line>The mighty renovation would proceed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1813</date>
    <title>From Helpstone</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thou far-fled pasture, long evanished scene,</line>
      <line>Where Nature’s freedom spread the flowery green –</line>
      <line>Where golden kingcups opened into view,</line>
      <line>Where silver daisies charmed the raptured view,</line>
      <line>And tottering (hid among those brighter gems)</line>
      <line>Where silver grasses bent their tiny stems,</line>
      <line>Where the pale lilac mean and lowly grew</line>
      <line>Courting in vain each gazer’s heedless view,</line>
      <line>While cowslips, sweetest flowers upon the plain,</line>
      <line>Seemingly bowed to shun the hand in vain,</line>
      <line>Where lowing oxen roamed to feed at large</line>
      <line>And bleating there the shepherd’s woolly charge</line>
      <line>Whose constant calls thy echoing valleys cheered,</line>
      <line>Thy scenes adorned and rural life endeared –</line>
      <line>No calls of hunger pity’s feelings wound,</line>
      <line>’Twas wanton plenty raised the joyful sound!</line>
      <line>Thy grass in plenty gave the wished supply</line>
      <line>Ere sultry suns had waked the troubling fly</line>
      <line>Then blest retiring (by thy bounty fed)</line>
      <line>They sought thy shades and found an easy bed.</line>
      <line> But now, alas, those scenes exist no more,</line>
      <line>The pride of life with thee (like mine) is o’er:</line>
      <line>Thy pleasing spots, to which fond memory clings,</line>
      <line>Sweet cooling shades and soft refreshing springs –</line>
      <line>And though Fate’s pleased to lay their beauties by</line>
      <line>In a dark corner of obscurity,</line>
      <line>As fair and sweet they bloomed thy plains among</line>
      <line>As blooms those Edens by the poets sung,</line>
      <line>Now all laid waste by Desolation’s hand</line>
      <line>Whose curséd weapons levels half the land!</line>
      <line> Oh who could see my dear green willows fall,</line>
      <line>What feeling heart but dropped a tear for all!</line>
      <line>Accurséd Wealth, o’erbounding human laws,</line>
      <line>Of every evil thou remains the cause:</line>
      <line>Victims of want, those wretches such as me,</line>
      <line>Too truly lay their wretchedness to thee!</line>
      <line>Thou art the bar that keeps from being fed,</line>
      <line>And thine our loss of labour and of bread –</line>
      <line>Thou art the cause that levels every tree,</line>
      <line>And woods bow down to clear a way for thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>From Lamentations of Round-Oak Waters</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look backward on the days of yore</line>
      <line>Upon my injured brook,</line>
      <line>In fancy con its beauties o’er,</line>
      <line>How it had used to look –</line>
      <line>Oh then what trees my banks did crown,</line>
      <line>What willows flourished here –</line>
      <line>Hard as the axe that cut them down</line>
      <line>The senseless wretches were!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But sweating slaves I do not blame</line>
      <line>(Those slaves by wealth decreed),</line>
      <line>No, I should hurt their harmless name</line>
      <line>To brand ’em with the deed:</line>
      <line>Although their aching hands did wield</line>
      <line>The axe that gave the blow,</line>
