      <line>Yet ’twas not them that owned the field,</line>
      <line>Nor planned its overthrow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, no, the foes that hurt my field</line>
      <line>Hurts these poor moilers too,</line>
      <line> And thy own bosom knows and feels</line>
      <line>Enough to prove it true –</line>
      <line>And oh, poor souls, they may complain,</line>
      <line>But their complaining’s all:</line>
      <line>The injured worms that turn again,</line>
      <line>But turn again to fall!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their foes and mine are lawless foes,</line>
      <line>And laws themselves they hold</line>
      <line>Which clipt-winged Justice can’t oppose,</line>
      <line>But forcéd yields to Gold!</line>
      <line> These are the foes of mine and me,</line>
      <line>These all our ruin planned,</line>
      <line>Although they never felled a tree</line>
      <line>Or took a tool in hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah cruel foes, with plenty blest,</line>
      <line>So hankering after more,</line>
      <line>To lay the greens and pastures waste</line>
      <line>Which profited before –</line>
      <line>Poor greedy souls, what would they have,</line>
      <line>Beyond their plenty given?</line>
      <line> Will riches keep ’em from the grave,</line>
      <line>Or buy them rest in Heaven?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1814</date>
    <title>from The St James’s Phenomenon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Good people all attend now,</line>
      <line>And I’ll tell ye of such a monster</line>
      <line>As shall make your eyes</line>
      <line>Be double their size</line>
      <line> And the hats that ye have on stir!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’m aware there’ve been before this</line>
      <line>As pretty frights as may be –</line>
      <line>Two sisters in one,</line>
      <line>And babes like a tun,</line>
      <line>And much worse things than they be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For I’ve heard of an unlegged body</line>
      <line>That went about on castors,</line>
      <line>And a head that would come</line>
      <line>Bolt into a room</line>
      <line> And cry, ‘How now, my masters?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Lord! all these were handsome</line>
      <line>To the one I’m going to mention –</line>
      <line>To whom a shark</line>
      <line>Is a perfect spark,</line>
      <line>And an ogre deserves a pension.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hard by St James’s Palace</line>
      <line>You may see this Prince of Shockings;</line>
      <line>But not before three,</line>
      <line>For at one, d’ye see,</line>
      <line> He begins to put on his stockings!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His head, or else what should be</line>
      <line>In the place that’s on his shoulders,</line>
      <line>Is nothing but hair,</line>
      <line>Frizzled here and there</line>
      <line>To the terror of all beholders!...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of his fingers a tailor tells me</line>
      <line>(For one here and there the truth picks)</line>
      <line>That the right, when they span,</line>
      <line>Are a lady’s fan,</line>
      <line>And the left a start of toothpicks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His organs of digestion</line>
      <line>Make a noise like the wheels of mangles;</line>
      <line>His tongue’s a skin,</line>
      <line>And hollow within,</line>
      <line> And his teeth are dice at angles...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>N.B. Behave respectful;</line>
      <line>For if he thinks you flout him,</line>
      <line>He’s got a big</line>
      <line>Old judges’ wig</line>
      <line> Wherewith he lays about him!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>Napoleon’s Farewell</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell to the land where the gloom of my glory</line>
      <line>Arose and o’ershadowed the Earth with her name –</line>
      <line>She abandons me now, but the page of her story,</line>
      <line>The brightest, or blackest, is filled with my fame!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I have warred with a world which vanquished me only</line>
      <line>When the meteor of conquest allured me too far;</line>
      <line>I have coped with the nations which dread me, thus lonely,</line>
      <line>The last single captive to millions in war!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell to thee, France! When thy diadem crowned me,</line>
      <line>I made thee the gem and the wonder of Earth,</line>
      <line>But thy weakness decrees I should leave as I found thee,</line>
      <line>Decayed in thy glory, and sunk in thy worth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell to thee, France! But when Liberty rallies</line>
      <line>Once more in thy regions, remember me then!</line>
      <line> The violet still grows in the depth of thy valleys –</line>
      <line>Though withered, thy tears will unfold it again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet yet, I may baffle the hosts that surround us,</line>
      <line>And yet may thy heart leap awake to my voice –</line>
      <line>There are links which must break in the chain that has bound us,</line>
      <line>Then turn thee and call on the Chief of thy choice!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>The Mask of Anarchy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I lay asleep in Italy</line>
      <line>There came a voice from over the sea,</line>
      <line>And with great power it forth led me</line>
      <line>To walk in the visions of poesy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I met Murder on the way –</line>
      <line>He had a mask like Castlereagh –</line>
      <line>Very smooth he looked, yet grim;</line>
      <line>Seven blood-hounds followed him:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All were fat, and well they might</line>
      <line>Be in admirable plight,</line>
      <line>For one by one, and two by two,</line>
      <line>He tossed them human hearts to chew</line>
      <line>Which from his wide cloak he drew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Next came Fraud, and he had on,</line>
      <line> Like Eldon, an ermined gown –</line>
      <line>His big tears (for he wept well)</line>
      <line>Turned to millstones as they fell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the little children, who</line>
      <line>Round his feet played to and fro,</line>
      <line>Thinking every tear a gem,</line>
      <line>Had their brains knocked out by them.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Clothed with the bible, as with light,</line>
      <line>And the shadows of the night,</line>
      <line>Like Sidmouth, next, Hypocrisy</line>
      <line> On a crocodile rode by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And many more Destructions played</line>
      <line>In this ghastly masquerade,</line>
      <line>All disguised, even to the eyes,</line>
      <line>Like bishops, lawyers, peers, or spies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Last came Anarchy: he rode</line>
      <line>On a white horse, splashed with blood;</line>
      <line>He was pale even to the lips,</line>
      <line>Like Death in the Apocalypse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he wore a kingly crown;</line>
      <line> And in his grasp a sceptre shone;</line>
      <line>On his brow this mark I saw –</line>
      <line>‘I am God, and King, and Law!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With a pace stately and fast,</line>
      <line>Over English land he passed,</line>
      <line>Trampling to a mire of blood</line>
      <line>The adoring multitude.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And a mighty troop around,</line>
      <line>With their trampling shook the ground,</line>
      <line>Waving each a bloody sword</line>
      <line> For the service of their Lord.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And with glorious triumph, they</line>
      <line>Rode through England proud and gay,</line>
      <line>Drunk as with intoxication</line>
      <line>On the wine of desolation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O’er fields and towns, from sea to sea,</line>
      <line>Passed the Pageant swift and free,</line>
      <line>Tearing up, and trampling down;</line>
      <line>Till they came to London town.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And each dweller, panic-stricken,</line>
      <line> Felt his heart with terror sicken</line>
      <line>Hearing the tempestuous cry</line>
      <line>Of the triumph of Anarchy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For with pomp to meet him came</line>
      <line>Clothed in arms like blood and flame</line>
      <line>The hired murderers, who did sing</line>
      <line>‘Thou art God, and Law, and King!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We have waited, weak and lone,</line>
      <line>For thy coming, Mighty One!</line>
      <line>Our purses are empty, our swords are cold –</line>
      <line> Give us glory, and blood, and gold.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lawyers and priests, a motley crowd,</line>
      <line>To the earth their pale brows bowed;</line>
      <line>Like a prayer not over loud</line>
      <line>Whispering, ‘Thou art Law and God!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then all cried with one accord,</line>
      <line>‘Thou art King, and God, and Lord!</line>
      <line>Anarchy, to thee we bow,</line>
      <line>Be thy name made holy now!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Anarchy, the skeleton,</line>
      <line> Bowed and grinned to every one,</line>
      <line>As well as if his education</line>
      <line>Had cost ten millions to the nation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For he knew the palaces</line>
      <line>Of our Kings were rightly his;</line>
      <line>His the sceptre, crown, and globe,</line>
      <line>And the gold-inwoven robe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So he sent his slaves before</line>
      <line>To seize upon the Bank and Tower,</line>
      <line>And was proceeding with intent</line>
      <line> To meet his pensioned Parliament</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When one fled past, a manic maid,</line>
      <line>And her name was Hope, she said:</line>
      <line>But she looked more like Despair,</line>
      <line>And she cried out in the air:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My father Time is weak and grey</line>
      <line>With waiting for a better day;</line>
      <line>See how idiot-like he stands,</line>
      <line>Fumbling with his palsied hands!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He has had child after child,</line>
      <line> And the dust of death is piled</line>
      <line>Over every one but me –</line>
      <line>Misery, oh, misery!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then she lay down in the street,</line>
      <line>Right before the horses’ feet,</line>
      <line>Expecting, with a patient eye,</line>
      <line>Murder, Fraud, and Anarchy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When between her and her foes</line>
      <line>A mist, a light, an image rose,</line>
      <line>Small at first, and weak, and frail</line>
      <line>Like the vapour of a vale,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till as clouds grow on the blast,</line>
      <line>Like tower-crowned giants striding fast,</line>
      <line>And glare with lightnings as they fly,</line>
      <line>And speak in thunder to the sky,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It grew – a shape arrayed in mail</line>
      <line>Brighter than the viper’s scale,</line>
      <line>And upborne on wings whose grain</line>
      <line>Was as the light of sunny rain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On its helm, seen far away,</line>
      <line> A planet, like the morning’s, lay;</line>
      <line>And those plumes its light rained through</line>
      <line>Like a shower of crimson dew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With step as soft as wind it passed</line>
      <line>O’er the heads of men – so fast</line>
      <line>That they knew the presence there,</line>
      <line>And looked – but all was empty air!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As flowers beneath May’s footstep waken,</line>
      <line>As stars from Night’s loose hair are shaken,</line>
      <line>As waves arise when loud winds call,</line>
      <line> Thoughts sprung where’er that step did fall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the prostrate multitude</line>
      <line>Looked, and ankle-deep in blood,</line>
      <line>Hope, that maiden most serene,</line>
      <line>Was walking with a quiet mien;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Anarchy, the ghastly birth,</line>
      <line>Lay, dead earth upon the earth –</line>
      <line>The horse of Death, tameless as wind,</line>
      <line>Fled, and with his hoofs did grind</line>
      <line>To dust the murderers thronged behind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A rushing light of clouds and splendour,</line>
      <line>A sense awakening and yet tender,</line>
      <line>Was heard and felt – and at its close</line>
      <line>These words of joy and fear arose</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As if their own indignant Earth</line>
      <line>Which gave the sons of England birth</line>
      <line>Had felt their blood upon her brow,</line>
      <line>And, shuddering with a mother’s throe,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had turnéd every drop of blood</line>
      <line>By which her face had been bedewed</line>
      <line> To an accent unwithstood –</line>
      <line>As if her heart had cried aloud:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Men of England, heirs of glory,</line>
      <line>Heroes of unwritten story,</line>
      <line>Nurslings of one mighty Mother,</line>
      <line>Hopes of her and one another,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rise like Lions after slumber</line>
      <line>In unvanquishable number,</line>
      <line>Shake your chains to earth like dew</line>
      <line>Which in sleep had fallen on you –</line>
      <line> Ye are many, they are few!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is Freedom? Ye can tell</line>
      <line>That which slavery is, too well –</line>
      <line>For its very name has grown</line>
      <line>To an echo of your own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis to work and have such pay</line>
      <line>As just keeps life from day to day</line>
      <line>In your limbs – as in a cell</line>
      <line>For the tyrants’ use to dwell –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So that ye for them are made,</line>
      <line> Loom, and plough, and sword, and spade,</line>
      <line>With or without your own will bent</line>
      <line>To their defence and nourishment!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis to see your children weak,</line>
      <line>With their mothers pine and peak</line>
      <line>When the winter winds are bleak –</line>
      <line>They are dying whilst I speak!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis to hunger for such diet</line>
      <line>As the rich man in his riot</line>
      <line>Casts to the fat dogs that lie</line>
      <line> Surfeiting beneath his eye!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis to let the ghost of gold</line>
      <line>Take from toil a thousandfold</line>
      <line>More than e’er its substance could</line>
      <line>In the tyrannies of old –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Paper coin! – that forgery</line>
      <line>Of the title-deeds, which ye</line>
      <line>Hold to something of the worth</line>
      <line>Of the inheritance of Earth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis to be a slave in soul</line>
      <line> And to hold no strong control</line>
      <line>Over your own wills, but be</line>
      <line>All that others make of ye –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And at length when ye complain</line>
      <line>With a murmur weak and vain</line>
      <line>’Tis to see the tyrant’s crew</line>
      <line>Ride over your wives and you –</line>
      <line>Blood is on the grass like dew!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then it is to feel revenge</line>
      <line>Fiercely thirsting to exchange</line>
      <line> Blood for blood – and wrong for wrong!</line>
      <line>Do not thus when ye are strong.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Birds find rest in narrow nest</line>
      <line>When weary of their wingéd quest;</line>
      <line>Beasts find fare in woody lair</line>
      <line>When storm and snow are in the air;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Asses, swine, have litter spread</line>
      <line>And with fitting food are fed;</line>
      <line>All things have a home but one –</line>
      <line>Thou, oh Englishman, hast none!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>'This is Slavery – savage men,</line>
      <line>Or wild beasts within a den,</line>
      <line>Would endure not as ye do –</line>
      <line>But such ills they never knew!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What art thou Freedom? Oh, could slaves</line>
      <line>Answer from their living graves</line>
      <line>This demand! Tyrants would flee</line>
      <line>Like a dream’s dim imagery –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art not, as impostors say,</line>
      <line>A shadow soon to pass away,</line>
      <line> A superstition, and a name</line>
      <line>Echoing from the cave of Fame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For the labourer thou art bread,</line>
      <line>And a comely table spread</line>
      <line>From his daily labour come</line>
      <line>In a neat and happy home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art clothes, and fire, and food</line>
      <line>For the trampled multitude –</line>
      <line>No, in countries that are free</line>
      <line>Such starvation cannot be</line>
      <line> As in England now we see!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To the rich thou art a check,</line>
      <line>When his foot is on the neck</line>
      <line>Of his victim, thou dost make</line>
      <line>That he treads upon a snake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art justice: ne’er for gold</line>
      <line>May thy righteous laws be sold</line>
      <line>As laws are in England – thou</line>
      <line>Shieldst alike the high and low.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art wisdom: freemen never</line>
      <line> Dream that God will damn for ever</line>
      <line>All who think those things untrue.</line>
      <line>Of which priests make such ado.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art peace: never by thee</line>
      <line>Would blood and treasure wasted be</line>
      <line>As tyrants wasted them, when all</line>
      <line>Leagued to quench thy flame in Gaul</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What if English toil and blood</line>
      <line>Was poured forth even as a flood?</line>
      <line>It availed, oh, Liberty,</line>
      <line> To dim, but not extinguish thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art Love: the rich have kissed</line>
      <line>Thy feet, and like him following Christ,</line>
      <line>Give their substance to the free</line>
      <line>And through the rough world follow thee –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or turn their wealth to arms, and make</line>
      <line>War for thy beloved sake</line>
      <line>On wealth, and war, and fraud – whence they</line>
      <line>Drew the power which is their prey.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Science, poetry, and thought</line>
      <line> Are thy lamps; they make the lot</line>
      <line>Of the dwellers in a cot</line>
      <line>So serene, they curse it not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spirit, patience, gentleness,</line>
      <line>All that can adorn and bless,</line>
      <line>Art thou – let deeds, not words, express</line>
      <line>Thine exceeding loveliness!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let a great Assembly be</line>
      <line>Of the fearless and the free</line>
      <line>On some spot of English ground</line>
      <line> Where the plains stretch wide around!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the blue sky overhead,</line>
      <line>The green earth on which ye tread –</line>
      <line>All that must eternal be –</line>
      <line>Witness the solemnity!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From the corners uttermost</line>
      <line>Of the bounds of English coast;</line>
      <line>From every hut, village, and town</line>
      <line>Where those who live and suffer moan</line>
      <line>For others’ misery or their own;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> From the workhouse and the prison</line>
      <line>Where pale as corpses newly risen,</line>
      <line>Women, children, young and old</line>
      <line>Groan for pain, and weep for cold;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From the haunts of daily life</line>
      <line>Where is waged the daily strife</line>
      <line>With common wants and common cares</line>
      <line>Which sows the human heart with tares;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lastly from the palaces</line>
      <line>Where the murmur of distress</line>
      <line> Echoes, like the distant sound</line>
      <line>Of a wind alive around</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Those prison halls of wealth and fashion,</line>
      <line>Where some few feel such compassion</line>
      <line>For those who groan, and toil, and wail</line>
      <line>As must make their brethren pale –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye who suffer woes untold,</line>
      <line>Or to feel, or to behold</line>
      <line>Your lost country bought and sold</line>
      <line>With a price of blood and gold –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Let a vast assembly be,</line>
      <line>And with great solemnity</line>
      <line>Declare with measured words that ye</line>
      <line>Are, as God has made ye, free!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be your strong and simple words</line>
      <line>Keen to wound as sharpened swords,</line>
      <line>And wide as targes let them be,</line>
      <line>With their shade to cover ye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the tyrants pour around</line>
      <line>With a quick and startling sound,</line>
      <line>Like the loosening of a sea,</line>
      <line>Troops of armed emblazonry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the charged artillery drive</line>
      <line>Till the dead air seems alive</line>
      <line>With the clash of clanging wheels,</line>
      <line>And the tramp of horses’ heels!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the fixéd bayonet</line>
      <line>Gleam with sharp desire to wet</line>
      <line>Its bright point in English blood,</line>
      <line>Looking keen as one for food!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Let the horsemen’s scimitars</line>
      <line>Wheel and flash, like sphereless stars</line>
      <line>Thirsting to eclipse their burning</line>
      <line>In a sea of death and mourning!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Stand ye calm and resolute,</line>
      <line>Like a forest close and mute,</line>
      <line>With folded arms and looks which are</line>
      <line>Weapons of unvanquished war,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And let Panic, who outspeeds</line>
      <line>The career of arméd steeds</line>
      <line> Pass, a disregarded shade</line>
      <line>Through your phalanx undismayed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the laws of your own land,</line>
      <line>Good or ill, between ye stand</line>
      <line>Hand to hand, and foot to foot,</line>
      <line>Arbiters of the dispute!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The old laws of England – they</line>
      <line>Whose reverend heads with age are grey,</line>
      <line>Children of a wiser day,</line>
      <line>And whose solemn voice must be</line>
      <line> Thine own echo – Liberty!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On those who first should violate</line>
      <line>Such sacred heralds in their state</line>
      <line>Rest the blood that must ensue,</line>
      <line>And it will not rest on you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if then the tyrants dare,</line>
      <line>Let them ride among you there,</line>
      <line>Slash, and stab, and maim, and hew –</line>
      <line>What they like, that let them do.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With folded arms and steady eyes,</line>
      <line> And little fear, and less surprise,</line>
      <line>Look upon them as they slay</line>
      <line>Till their rage has died away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then they will return with shame</line>
      <line>To the place from which they came,</line>
      <line>And the blood thus shed will speak</line>
      <line>In hot blushes on their cheek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Every woman in the land</line>
      <line>Will point at them as they stand –</line>
      <line>They will hardly dare to greet</line>
      <line> Their acquaintance in the street!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the bold, true warriors</line>
      <line>Who have hugged Danger in wars</line>
      <line>Will turn to those who would be free,</line>
      <line>Ashamed of such base company.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that slaughter to the Nation</line>
      <line>Shall steam up like inspiration –</line>
      <line>Eloquent, oracular –</line>
      <line>A volcano heard afar!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And these words shall then become</line>
      <line> Like Oppression’s thundered doom</line>
      <line>Ringing through each heart and brain,</line>
      <line>Heard again – again – again:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Rise like lions after slumber</line>
      <line>In unvanquishable number!</line>
      <line>Shake your chains to earth like dew</line>
      <line>Which in sleep had fallen on you –</line>
      <line>Ye are many, they are few!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>England in 1819</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>An old, mad, blind, despised, and dying king!</line>
      <line>Princes, the dregs of their dull race, who flow</line>
      <line>Through public scorn – mud from a muddy spring!</line>
      <line>Rulers who neither see, nor feel, nor know,</line>
      <line> But leech-like to their fainting country cling,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till they drop, blind in blood, without a blow!</line>
      <line>A people starved and stabbed in the untilled field!</line>
      <line>An army, which liberticide and prey</line>
      <line>Makes as a two-edged sword to all who wield!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Golden and sanguine laws which tempt and slay!</line>
      <line>Religion, Christless, Godless – a book sealed!</line>
      <line>A senate, time’s worst statute unrepealed! –</line>
      <line>Are graves, from which a glorious phantom may</line>
      <line>Burst, to illumine our tempestuous day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>from The Vision of Judgment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Saint Peter sat by the celestial gate,</line>
      <line>And nodded o’er his keys – when, lo! there came</line>
      <line> A wondrous noise he had not heard of late,</line>
      <line>A rushing sound of wind, and stream, and flame,</line>
      <line>In short, a roar of things extremely great,</line>
      <line>Which would have made all save a saint exclaim;</line>
      <line>But he, with first a start and then a wink,</line>
      <line>Said, ‘There’s another star gone out, I think!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But ere he could return to his repose,</line>
      <line>A cherub flapped his right wing o’er his eyes –</line>
      <line>At which Saint Peter yawned, and rubbed his nose.</line>
      <line>‘Saint Porter’, said the angel, ‘prithee rise’</line>
      <line> (Waving a goodly wing, which glowed as glows</line>
      <line>An earthly peacock’s tale, with heavenly dyes);</line>
      <line>To which the saint replied, ‘Well, what’s the matter?</line>
      <line>Is Lucifer come back, with all this clatter?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘No’, quoth the cherub, ‘George the Third is dead!’</line>
      <line>‘And who is George the Third?’ replied the apostle –</line>
      <line>‘What George? what Third?’ ‘The King of England’, said</line>
      <line>The angel. ‘Well he won’t find kings to jostle</line>
      <line>Him on his way! But does he wear his head?</line>
      <line>Because the last we saw here had a tussle,</line>
      <line> And ne’er would have got into Heaven’s good graces,</line>
      <line>Had he not flung his head in all our faces!’...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While thus they spake, the angelic caravan,</line>
      <line>Arriving like a rush of mighty wind</line>
      <line>Cleaving the fields of space, as doth the swan</line>
      <line>Some silver stream (say, Ganges, Nile, or Inde,</line>
      <line>Or Thames, or Tweed), and mid them an old man</line>
      <line>With an old soul, and both extremely blind,</line>
      <line>Halted before the gate, and in his shroud</line>
      <line>Seated their fellow traveller on a cloud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> But bringing up the rear of this bright host</line>
      <line>A Spirit of a different aspect waved</line>
      <line>His wings, like thunder-clouds above some coast</line>
      <line>Whose barren beach with frequent wrecks is paved.</line>
      <line>His brow was like the deep when tempest-tossed –</line>
      <line>Fierce and unfathomable thoughts engraved</line>
      <line>Eternal wrath on his immortal face,</line>
      <line>And where he gazed a gloom pervaded space.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As he drew near he gazed upon the gate,</line>
      <line>Ne’er to be entered more by him or Sin,</line>
      <line> With such a glance of supernatural hate</line>
      <line>As made Saint Peter wish himself within –</line>
      <line>He pottered with his keys at a great rate,</line>
      <line>And sweated through his apostolic skin</line>
      <line>(Of course his perspiration was but ichor,</line>
      <line>Or some such other spiritual liquor).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The very cherubs huddled all together,</line>
      <line>Like birds when soars the falcon, and they felt</line>
      <line>A tingling to the tip of every feather,</line>
      <line>And formed a circle like Orion’s Belt</line>
      <line>Around their poor old charge – who scarce knew whither</line>
      <line>His guards had led him, though they gently dealt</line>
      <line>With royal manes (for by many stories,</line>
      <line>And true, we learn the angels all are Tories.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As things were in this posture, the gate flew</line>
      <line>Asunder, and the flashing of its hinges</line>
      <line>Flung over space an universal hue</line>
      <line>Of many-coloured flame, until its tinges</line>
      <line>Reached even our speck of Earth, and made a new</line>
      <line>Aurora Borealis spread its fringes</line>
      <line> O’er the North Pole – the same seen, when ice-bound,</line>
      <line>By Captain Parry’s crew in Melville Sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And from the gate thrown open issued beaming</line>
      <line>A beautiful and mighty Thing of Light,</line>
      <line>Radiant with glory, like a banner streaming</line>
      <line>Victorious from some world-o’erthrowing fight</line>
      <line>(My poor comparisons must needs be teeming</line>
      <line>With earthly likenesses, for here the night</line>
      <line>Of clay obscures our best conceptions – saving</line>
      <line>Joanna Southcote, and Bob Southey raving)...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Michael flew forth in glory and in good,</line>
      <line>A goodly work of Him from whom all glory</line>
      <line> And good arise! The portal passed, he stood,</line>
      <line>Before him the young cherubs and saints hoary</line>
      <line>(I say ‘young’, begging to be understood</line>
      <line>By looks, not years, and should be very sorry</line>
      <line>To state they were not older than Saint Peter,</line>
      <line>But merely that they seemed a little sweeter).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cherubs and the saints bowed down before</line>
      <line>That archangelic Hierarch, the first</line>
      <line>Of essences angelical, who wore</line>
      <line>The aspect of a god – but this ne’er nursed</line>
      <line> Pride in his heavenly bosom, in whose core</line>
      <line>No thought save for his Maker’s service durst</line>
      <line>Intrude: however glorified and high,</line>
      <line>He knew him but the Viceroy of the sky!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He and the sombre silent Spirit met</line>
      <line>(They knew each other both for good and ill),</line>
      <line>Such was their power that neither could forget</line>
      <line>His former friend and future foe – but still</line>
      <line>There was a high immortal proud regret</line>
      <line>In either’s eye, as if ’twere less their will</line>
      <line> Than destiny to make the eternal years</line>
      <line>Their date of war, and their champ clos the spheres...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Archangel bowed, not like a modern beau</line>
      <line>But with a graceful oriental bend,</line>
      <line>Pressing one radiant arm just where below</line>
      <line>The heart in good men is supposed to tend.</line>
      <line> He turned as to an equal, not too low,</line>
      <line>But kindly: Satan met his ancient friend</line>
      <line>With more hauteur, as might an old Castilian</line>
      <line>Poor noble meet a mushroom-rich civilian.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He merely bent his diabolic brow</line>
      <line>An instant – and then, raising it, he stood</line>
      <line>In act to assert his right or wrong, and show</line>
      <line>Cause why King George by no means could or should</line>
      <line>Make out a case to be exempt from woe</line>
      <line>Eternal more than other kings endued</line>
      <line> With better sense and hearts, whom history mentions,</line>
      <line>Who long have ‘paved Hell with their good intentions’!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Michael began: ‘What wouldst thou with this man,</line>
      <line>Now dead, and brought before the Lord? What ill</line>
      <line>Hath he wrought since his mortal race began,</line>
      <line>That thou canst claim him? Speak – and do thy will,</line>
      <line>If it be just! If in this earthly span</line>
      <line>He hath been greatly failing to fulfil</line>
      <line>His duties as a king and mortal, say,</line>
      <line>And he is thine. If not, let him have way.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Michael’, replied the Price of Air, ‘even here,</line>
      <line>Before the gate of Him thou servest, must</line>
      <line>I claim my subject – and will make appear</line>
      <line>That as he was my worshipper in dust</line>
      <line>So shall he be in spirit! Although dear</line>
      <line>To thee and thine because nor wine, nor lust,</line>
      <line>Were of his weaknesses, yet on the throne</line>
      <line>He reigned o’er millions to serve me alone!...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The New World shook him off, the Old yet groans</line>
      <line>Beneath what he and his prepared, if not</line>
      <line>Completed. He leaves heirs on many thrones</line>
      <line>To all his vices – without (what begot</line>
      <line>Compassion for him) his tame virtues! Drones</line>
      <line>Who sleep, or despots who have now forgot</line>
      <line> A lesson which shall be retaught them, wake</line>
      <line>Upon the thrones of Earth – but let them quake!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Five millions of the primitive, who hold</line>
      <line>The faith which makes thee great on earth, implored</line>
      <line>A part of that vast all they held of old –</line>
      <line>Freedom to worship! Not alone your Lord,</line>
      <line>Michael, but you, and you Saint Peter – cold</line>
      <line>Must be your souls if ye have not abhorred</line>
      <line>The foe to Catholic participation</line>
      <line>In all the license of a Christian nation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> True he allowed them to pray God – but, as</line>
      <line>A consequence of prayer, refused the law</line>
      <line>Which would have placed them upon the same base</line>
      <line>With those who did not hold the Saints in awe.’</line>
      <line>But here Saint Peter started from his place</line>
      <line>And cried, ‘You may the prisoner withdraw!</line>
      <line>Ere Heaven shall ope her portals to this Guelph</line>
      <line>While I am guard, may I be damned myself!’...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Satan turned and waved his swarthy hand,</line>
      <line>Which stirred with its electric qualities</line>
      <line>Clouds farther off than we can understand</line>
      <line>(Although we find him sometimes in our skies).</line>
      <line>Infernal thunder shook both sea and land</line>
      <line>In all the planets, and Hell’s batteries</line>
      <line> Let off the artillery which Milton mentions</line>
      <line>As one of Satan’s most sublime inventions!...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upon the verge of space, about the size</line>
      <line>Of half-a-crown, a little speck appeared</line>
      <line>(I’ve seen a something like it in the skies</line>
      <line>In the Aegean, ere a squall); it neared,</line>
      <line>And, growing bigger, took another guise.</line>
      <line>Like an aërial ship it tacked and steered –</line>
      <line> Or was steered (I am doubtful of the grammar</line>
      <line>Of the last phrase, which makes the stanza stammer!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But take your choice) – and then it grew a cloud –</line>
      <line>And so it was! A cloud of witnesses!</line>
      <line>But such a cloud! No land ere saw a crowd</line>
      <line>Of locusts numerous as the heavens saw these.</line>
      <line>They shadowed with their myriads space; their loud</line>
      <line>And frequent cries were like those of wild geese</line>
      <line>(If nations may be likened to a goose),</line>
      <line>And realized the phrase of ‘Hell broke loose’!...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A merry, cockeyed, curious-looking sprite</line>
      <line>Upon the instant started from the throng,</line>
      <line>Dressed in a fashion now forgotten quite –</line>
      <line>For all the fashions of the flesh stick long</line>
      <line> By people in the next world, where unite</line>
      <line>All the costumes since Adam’s (right or wrong),</line>
      <line>From Eve’s fig-leaf down to the petticoat,</line>
      <line>Almost as scanty, of days less remote.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The spirit looked around upon the crowds</line>
      <line>Assembled, and exclaimed: ‘My friends of all</line>
      <line>The spheres, we shall catch cold among these clouds,</line>
      <line>So let’s to business! Why this general call?</line>
      <line>If those are freeholders I see in shrouds,</line>
      <line>And ’tis for an election that they bawl,</line>
      <line> Behold a candidate with unturned coat!</line>
      <line>Saint Peter, may I count upon your vote?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sir’, replied Michael, ‘you mistake – these things</line>
      <line>Are from a former life, and what we do</line>
      <line>Above is more august. To judge of kings</line>
      <line>Is this tribunal met: so now you know!’</line>
      <line>‘Then I presume those gentlemen with wings’,</line>
      <line>Said Wilkes, ‘are cherubs – and that soul below</line>
      <line>Looks much like George the Third, but to my mind</line>
      <line>A good deal older. Bless me! is he blind?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> ‘He is what you behold him, and his doom</line>
      <line>Depends upon his deeds’, the Angel said:</line>
      <line>‘If you have aught to arraign in him, the tomb</line>
      <line>Gives license to the humblest beggar’s head</line>
      <line>To lift itself above the loftiest.’ ‘Some’,</line>
      <line>Said Wilkes, ‘don’t wait to see them laid in lead,</line>
      <line>For such a liberty – and I, for one,</line>
      <line>Have told them what I thought beneath the sun!'...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length, with jostling, elbowing, and the aid</line>
      <line>Of cherubim appointed to the post,</line>
      <line> The devil Asmodeus to the circle made</line>
      <line>His way (and looked as if his journey cost</line>
      <line>Some trouble). When his burden down he laid,</line>
      <line>‘What’s this?’ cried Michael, ‘Why, ’tis not a ghost!’</line>
      <line>‘I know it’, quoth the incubus, ‘but he</line>
      <line>Shall be one if you leave the affair to me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Confound the renegado! I have sprained</line>
      <line>My left wing, he’s so heavy – one would think</line>
      <line>Some of his works about his neck were chained.</line>
      <line>But to the point! While hovering o’er the brink</line>
      <line> Of Skiddaw (where as usual it still rained),</line>
      <line>I saw a taper far below me wink,</line>
      <line>And, stooping, caught this fellow at a libel –</line>
      <line>No less on history, than the Holy Bible!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The former is the Devil’s scripture, and</line>
      <line>The latter yours, good Michael – so the affair</line>
      <line>Belongs to all of us, you understand.</line>
      <line>I snatched him up just as you see him there,</line>
      <line>And brought him off for sentence out of hand!</line>
      <line>I’ve scarcely been ten minutes in the air –</line>
      <line> At least, a quarter it can hardly be –</line>
      <line>I daresay his wife is still at tea!'...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The varlet was not an ill-favoured knave:</line>
      <line>A good deal like a vulture in the face,</line>
      <line>With a hook-nose and a hawk’s eye, which gave</line>
      <line>A smart and sharper-looking sort of grace</line>
      <line>To his whole aspect, which, though rather grave,</line>
      <line>Was by no means so ugly as his case!</line>
      <line>But that, indeed, was hopeless as can be,</line>
      <line>Quite a poetic felony de se.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Michael blew his trump, and stilled the noise</line>
      <line>With one still greater – as is yet the mode</line>
      <line> On Earth besides (except some grumbling voice,</line>
      <line>Which now and then will make a slight inroad</line>
      <line>Upon a decorous silence, few will twice</line>
      <line>Lift up their lungs when fairly overcrowed) –</line>
      <line>And now the Bard could plead his own bad cause,</line>
      <line>With all the attitudes of self-applause!...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had written praises of a regicide:</line>
      <line>He had written praises of all kings whatever!</line>
      <line>He had written for republics far and wide,</line>
      <line>And then against them, bitterer than ever.</line>
      <line>For pantisocracy he once had cried</line>
      <line>Aloud (a scheme less moral than ’twas clever),</line>
      <line> Then grew a hearty anti-jacobin –</line>
      <line>Had turned his coat, and would have turned his skin!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had sung against all battles, and again</line>
      <line>In their high praise and glory. He had called</line>
      <line>Reviewing ‘the ungentle craft’, and then</line>
      <line>Became as base a critic as e’er crawled –</line>
      <line>Fed, paid, and pampered by the very men</line>
      <line>By whom his muse and morals had been mauled.</line>
      <line>He had written much blank verse, and blanker prose,</line>
      <line>And more of both than anybody knows!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> He had written Wesley’s Life – here turning round</line>
      <line>To Satan, ‘Sir, I’m ready to write yours,</line>
      <line>In two octavo volumes, nicely bound,</line>
      <line>With Notes and Preface, all that most allures</line>
      <line>The pious purchaser! And there’s no ground</line>
      <line>For fear, for I can choose my own reviewers –</line>
      <line>So let me have the proper documents</line>
      <line>That I may add you to my other Saints.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Satan bowed and was silent. ‘Well, if you,</line>
      <line>With amiable modesty, decline</line>
      <line> My offer, what says Michael? There are few</line>
      <line>Whose Memoirs could be rendered more divine!</line>
      <line>Mine is a pen of all work – not so new</line>
      <line>As it was once, but I would make you shine</line>
      <line>Like your own trumpet! By the way, my own</line>
      <line>Has more of brass in it, and is as well blown.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, talking about trumpets, here’s my Vision!</line>
      <line>Now you shall judge – all people – yes! You shall</line>
      <line>Judge with my judgment, and by my decision</line>
      <line>Be guided who shall enter Heaven, or fall!</line>
      <line>I settle all these things by intuition</line>
      <line>(Times present, past, to come – Heaven, Hell, and all),</line>
      <line>Like King Alfonso. When I thus see double</line>
      <line>I save the Deity some worlds of trouble!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He ceased, and drew forth an MS – and no</line>
      <line>Persuasion on the part of devils, saints,</line>
      <line>Or angels, now could stop the torrent – so</line>
      <line>He read the first three lines of the Contents;</line>
      <line>But at the fourth, the whole spiritual show</line>
      <line>Had vanished, with variety of scents,</line>
      <line> Ambrosial and sulphureous, as they sprang</line>
      <line>Like lightning off from his ‘melodious twang’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Those grand heroics acted as a spell:</line>
      <line>The angels stopped their ears, and plied their pinions;</line>
      <line>The devils ran howling, deafened, down to Hell;</line>
      <line>The ghosts fled, gibbering, for their own dominions</line>
      <line>(For ’tis not yet decided where they dwell,</line>
      <line>And I leave every man to his opinions);</line>
      <line>Michael took refuge in his trump – but lo!</line>
      <line>His teeth were set on edge, he could not blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Saint Peter, who has hitherto been known</line>
      <line>For an impetuous saint, upraised his keys,</line>
      <line>And at the fifth line knocked the poet down,</line>
      <line>Who fell like Phaeton, but more at ease,</line>
      <line>Into his lake – for there he did not drown,</line>
      <line>A different web being by the Destinies</line>
      <line>Woven for the Laureate’s final wreath, whene’er</line>
      <line>Reform shall happen either here or there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He first sank to the bottom (like his Works),</line>
      <line>But soon rose to the surface (like himself),</line>
      <line> For all corrupted things are buoyed like corks</line>
      <line>By their own rottenness, light as an elf</line>
      <line>Or wisp that flits o’er a morass! He lurks,</line>
      <line>It may be, still (like dull books on a shelf)</line>
      <line>In his own den, to scrawl some Life or Vision –</line>
      <line>As Welborn says, ‘the devil turned precisian’!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As for the rest (to come to the conclusion</line>
      <line>Of this true dream), the telescope is gone</line>
      <line>Which kept my optics free from all delusion,</line>
      <line>And showed me what I in my turn have shown.</line>
      <line> All I saw farther, in the last confusion,</line>
      <line>Was that King George slipped into Heaven, for one,</line>
      <line>And when the tumult dwindled to a calm</line>
      <line>I left him practising the hundredth psalm.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>Ode to H. Bodkin Esq., Secretary to the Society for the Suppression of Mendicity</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hail King of Shreds and Patches; hail</line>
      <line>Disperser of the poor!</line>
      <line>Thou dog in office, set to bark</line>
      <line>All beggars from the door!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Great overseer of overseers,</line>
      <line>And dealer in old rags,</line>
      <line>Thy public duty never fails,</line>
      <line>Thy ardour never flags!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, when I take my walks abroad,</line>
      <line>How many poor I miss!</line>
      <line>(Had Doctor Watts walked nowadays,</line>
      <line>He would have written this.)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So well the vagrant-catchers prowl,</line>
      <line>So clear thy caution keeps</line>
      <line> The path – oh Bodkin, sure thou hast</line>
      <line>The eye that never sleeps!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No Belisarius pleads for alms,</line>
      <line>No Benbow lacketh legs:</line>
      <line>The pious man in black is now</line>
      <line>The only man that begs!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Street-Handels are disorganized,</line>
      <line>Disbanded every band –</line>
      <line>The silent scraper at the door</line>
      <line>Is scarce allowed to stand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The sweeper brushes with his broom,</line>
      <line>The carstairs with his chalk</line>
      <line>Retires, the cripple leaves his stand –</line>
      <line>But cannot sell his walk!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The old wall-blind resigns the wall,</line>
      <line>The camels hide their humps,</line>
      <line>The witherington without a leg</line>
      <line>Mayn’t beg upon his stumps!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poor Jack is gone, that used to doff</line>
      <line>His battered, tattered hat,</line>
      <line> And show his dangled sleeve – alas,</line>
      <line>There seemed no arm in that!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, was it such a sin to air</line>
      <line>His true-blue naval rags,</line>
      <line>Glory’s own trophy, like St Paul,</line>
      <line>Hung round with holy flags!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou knowest best! I meditate,</line>
      <line>My Bodkin, no offence!</line>
      <line>Let us, henceforth, but guard our pounds,</line>
      <line>Thou dost protect our pence!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Well art thou pointed ’gainst the poor,</line>
      <line>For, when the beggar-crew</line>
      <line>Bring their petitions, thou art paid</line>
      <line>Of course to run ’em through!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Doubtless thou art what Hamlet meant –</line>
      <line>To wretches the last friend –</line>
      <line>What ills can mortals have they can’t</line>
      <line>With a bare Bodkin end?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>The Factory</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There rests a shade above yon town,</line>
      <line>A dark funereal shroud –</line>
      <line>’Tis not the tempest hurrying down,</line>
      <line>’Tis not a summer cloud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The smoke that rises on the air</line>
      <line>Is as a type and sign,</line>
      <line>A shadow flung by the despair</line>
      <line>Within those streets of thine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That smoke shuts out the cheerful day,</line>
      <line>The sunset’s purple hues,</line>
      <line>The moonlight’s pure and purple ray,</line>
      <line>The morning’s pearly dews.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such is the moral atmosphere</line>
      <line>Around thy daily life:</line>
      <line> Heavy with care and pale with fear,</line>
      <line>With future tumult rife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There rises on the morning wind</line>
      <line>A low appealing cry –</line>
      <line>A thousand children are resigned</line>
      <line>To sicken and to die!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We read of Moloch’s sacrifice,</line>
      <line>We sicken at the name,</line>
      <line>And seem to hear the infant cries –</line>
      <line>And yet we do the same!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And worse – ’twas but a moment’s pain</line>
      <line>The heathen altar gave,</line>
      <line>But we give years – our idol, Gain,</line>
      <line>Demands a living grave!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How precious is the little one</line>
      <line>Before his mother’s sight,</line>
      <line>With bright hair dancing in the sun,</line>
      <line>And eyes of azure light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sleeps as rosy as the south</line>
      <line>(For summer-days are long),</line>
      <line> A prayer upon the little mouth,</line>
      <line>Lulled by his nurse’s song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love is around him, and his hours</line>
      <line>Are innocent and free:</line>
      <line>His mind essays its early powers</line>
      <line>Beside his mother’s knee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When after-years of trouble come,</line>
      <line>Such as await man’s prime,</line>
      <line>How will he think of that dear home</line>
      <line>And childhood’s lovely time!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And such should childhood ever be –</line>
      <line>The fairy well – to bring</line>
      <line>To life’s worn, weary memory</line>
      <line>The freshness of its spring!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But here the order is reversed</line>
      <line>And infancy, like age,</line>
      <line>Knows of existence but its worst –</line>
      <line>One dull and darkened page,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Written with tears, and stamped with toil,</line>
      <line>Crushed from its earliest hour,</line>
      <line> Weeds darkening on the bitter soil</line>
      <line>That never knew a flower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look on yon child! It droops the head,</line>
      <line>Its knees are bowed with pain;</line>
      <line>It mutters from its wretched bed,</line>
      <line>‘Oh let me sleep again!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas ’tis time – the mother’s eyes</line>
      <line>Turn mournfully away –</line>
      <line>Alas, ’tis time the child must rise,</line>
      <line>And yet it is not day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The lantern’s lit – she hurries forth –</line>
      <line>The spare cloak’s scanty fold</line>
      <line>Scare screens her from the snowy north;</line>
      <line>The child is pale and cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And wearily the little hands</line>
      <line>Their task accustomed ply,</line>
      <line>While daily some, mid those pale bands,</line>
      <line>Droop, sicken, pine, and die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Good God, to think upon a child</line>
      <line>That has no childish days,</line>
      <line> No careless play, no frolics wild,</line>
      <line>No words of prayer and praise!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Man from the cradle – ’tis too soon</line>
      <line>To earn their daily bread,</line>
      <line>And heap the heat and toil of noon</line>
      <line>Upon an infant’s head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To labour ere their strength be come,</line>
      <line>Or starve – is such the doom</line>
      <line>That makes of many an English home</line>
      <line>One long and living tomb?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Is there no pity from above –</line>
      <line>No mercy in those skies –</line>
      <line>Hath then the heart of man no love</line>
      <line>To spare such sacrifice?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh England, though thy tribute waves</line>
      <line>Proclaim thee great and free,</line>
      <line>While those small children pine like slaves</line>
      <line>There is a curse on thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1836</date>
    <title>from A Voice from the Factories</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fondly familiar is the look she gives</line>
      <line>As he returns who forth so lately went,</line>
      <line>For they together pass their happy lives!</line>
      <line>And many a tranquil evening have they spent</line>
      <line>Since, blushing, ignorantly innocent,</line>
      <line>She vowed, with downcast eyes and changeful hue,</line>
      <line>To love him only. Love fulfilled hath lent</line>
      <line>Its deep repose; and when he meets her view</line>
      <line>Her soft look only says, ‘I trust – and I am true!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Scattered like flowers the rosy children play,</line>
      <line>Or round her chair a busy crowd they press,</line>
      <line>But at the father’s coming, start away</line>
      <line>With playful struggle for his loved caress,</line>
      <line>And jealous of the one he first may bless.</line>
      <line>To each a welcoming word is fondly said:</line>
      <line>He bends and kisses some; lifts up the less;</line>
      <line>Admires the little cheek, so round and red,</line>
      <line> Or smoothes with tender hand the curled and shining head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, let us pause, and gaze upon them now!</line>
      <line>Is there not one beloved and lovely boy</line>
      <line>With Mirth’s bright seal upon his open brow,</line>
      <line>And sweet fond eyes, brimful of love and joy –</line>
      <line>He, whom no measure of delight can cloy,</line>
      <line>The daring and the darling of the set –</line>
      <line>He who, though pleased with every passing toy</line>
      <line>(Thoughtless and buoyant to excess), could yet</line>
      <line>Never a gentle word or kindly deed forget.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And one, more fragile than the rest, for whom,</line>
      <line>As for the weak bird in a crowded nest,</line>
      <line>Are needed all the fostering care of home</line>
      <line>And the soft comfort of the brooding breast –</line>
      <line>One who hath oft the couch of sickness prest</line>
      <line>On whom the mother looks, as it goes by,</line>
      <line>With tenderness intense, and fear supprest,</line>
      <line>While the soft patience of her active eye</line>
      <line>Blends with ‘God’s will be done’, ‘God grant thou mayst not die!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And is there not the elder of the band,</line>
      <line> She with the gentle smile and smooth bright hair,</line>
      <line>Waiting, some paces back, content to stand</line>
      <line>Till these of love’s caresses have their share;</line>
      <line>Knowing how soon his fond parental care</line>
      <line>Shall seek his violet in her shady nook?</line>
      <line>Patient she stands, demure, and brightly fair,</line>
      <line>Copying the meekness of her mother’s look,</line>
      <line>And clasping in her hand the favourite storybook.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wake, dreamer – choose! To labour life away,</line>
      <line>Which of these precious little ones shall go</line>
      <line> (Debarred of summer-light and cheerful play)</line>
      <line>To that receptacle for dreary woe,</line>
      <line>The Factory Mill? Shall he, in whom the glow</line>
      <line>Of life shines bright, whose free limbs’ vigorous tread</line>
      <line>Warns us how much of beauty that we know</line>
      <line>Would fade when he became dispirited</line>
      <line>And pined with sickened heart, and bowed his fainting head?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or shall the quiet little one, whose voice</line>
      <line>So rarely mingles in their sounds of glee,</line>
      <line>Whose life can bid no living thing rejoice,</line>
      <line> But rather is a long anxiety –</line>
      <line>Shall he go forth to toil? – and keep the free</line>
      <line>Frank boy, whose merry shouts and restless grace</line>
      <line>Would leave all eyes that used his face to see</line>
      <line>Wistfully gazing towards that vacant space</line>
      <line>Which makes their fireside seem a lone and dreary place.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or, sparing these, send her whose simplest words</line>
      <line>Have power to charm, whose warbled, childish song,</line>
      <line>Fluent and clear and bird-like, strikes the chords</line>
      <line>Of sympathy among the listening throng –</line>
      <line> Whose spirits light, and steps that dance along,</line>
      <line>Instinctive modesty and grace restrain –</line>
      <line>The fair young innocent who knows no wrong,</line>
      <line>Whose slender wrists scarce hold the silken skein</line>
      <line>Which the glad mother winds – shall she endure this pain?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away! The thought – the thought alone – brings tears!</line>
      <line>They labour, they, the darlings of our lives,</line>
      <line>The flowers and sunbeams of our fleeting years,</line>
      <line>From whom alone our happiness derives</line>
      <line>A lasting strength, which every shock survives –</line>
      <line> The green young trees beneath whose arching boughs</line>
      <line>(When failing energy no longer strives)</line>
      <line>Our wearied age shall find a cool repose –</line>
      <line>They toil in torture? No. The painful picture close!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye shudder – nor behold the vision more!</line>
      <line>Oh, fathers! is there then one law for these,</line>
      <line>And one for the pale children of the poor –</line>
      <line>That to their agony your hearts can freeze,</line>
      <line>Deny their pain, their toil, their slow disease,</line>
      <line>And deem with false complaining they encroach</line>
      <line> Upon your time and thought? Is yours the ease</line>
      <line>Which misery vainly struggles to approach,</line>
      <line>Whirling unthinking by in Luxury’s gilded coach?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Examine and decide. Watch through his day</line>
      <line>One of these little ones! The sun hath shone</line>
      <line>An hour, and by the ruddy morning’s ray</line>
      <line>(The last and least) he saunters on alone.</line>
      <line>See where, still pausing on the threshold-stone</line>
      <line>He stands, as loath to lose the bracing wind –</line>
      <line>With wistful wandering glances backward thrown</line>
      <line> On all the light and glory left behind,</line>
      <line>And sighs to think that he must darkly be confined.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Enter with him. The stranger who surveys</line>
      <line>The little natives of that dreary place</line>
      <line>(Where squalid suffering meets his shrinking gaze),</line>
      <line>Used to the glory of a young child’s face,</line>
      <line>Its changeful light, its coloured sparkling grace</line>
      <line>(Gleams of Heaven’s sunshine on our shadowed Earth),</line>
      <line>Starts at each visage, wan, and bold, and base,</line>
      <line>Whose smiles have neither innocence nor mirth –</line>
      <line>And comprehends the sin, original from birth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There the pale orphan, whose unequal strength</line>
      <line>Loathes the incessant toil it must pursue,</line>
      <line>Pines for the cool sweet evening’s twilight length,</line>
      <line>The sunny play-hour and the morning’s dew –</line>
      <line>Worn with its cheerless life’s monotonous hue,</line>
      <line>Bowed down and faint and stupefied it stands,</line>
      <line>Each half-seen object reeling in its view,</line>
      <line>While its hot, trembling, languid little hands</line>
      <line>Mechanically heed the Taskmaster’s commands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> There, sounds of wailing grief and painful blows</line>
      <line>Offend the ear, and startle it from rest</line>
      <line>(While the lungs gasp what air the place bestows),</line>
      <line>Or misery’s joyless vice, the ribald jest,</line>
      <line>Breaks the sick silence. Staring at the guest</line>
      <line>Who comes to view their labour, they beguile</line>
      <line>The unwatched moment: whispers half-supprest,</line>
      <line>And mutterings low, their faded lips defile –</line>
      <line>While gleams from face to face a strange and sullen smile.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>These then are his companions! He, too young</line>
      <line> To share their base and saddening merriment,</line>
      <line>Sits by, his little head in silence hung,</line>
      <line>His limbs cramped up, his body weakly bent,</line>
      <line>Toiling obedient till long hours so spent</line>
      <line>Produce exhaustion’s slumber, dull and deep.</line>
      <line>The Watcher’s stroke – bold – sudden – violent!</line>
      <line>Urges him from that lethargy of sleep,</line>
      <line>And bids him wake to life – to labour, and to weep!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE and Catherine Blake</author>
    <date>1783</date>
    <title>I Love the Jocund Dance</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love the jocund dance,</line>
      <line>The softly-breathing song,</line>
      <line>Where innocent eyes do glance,</line>
      <line>And where lisps the maiden’s tongue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I love the laughing vale,</line>
      <line>I love the echoing hill,</line>
      <line>Where mirth does never fail,</line>
      <line>And the jolly swain laughs his fill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love the pleasant cot,</line>
      <line>I love the innocent bower.</line>
      <line>Where white and brown is our lot,</line>
      <line>Or fruit in the midday hour.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love the oaken seat</line>
      <line>Beneath the oaken tree,</line>
      <line> Where all the old villagers meet,</line>
      <line>And laugh our sports to see.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love our neighbours all,</line>
      <line>But, Kitty, I better love thee;</line>
      <line>And love them I ever shall;</line>
      <line>But thou art all to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS<</author>
    <date>1785</date>
    <title>A Poet’s Welcome to his Love-begotten Daughter</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou’s welcome, wean! Mishanter fa’ me</line>
      <line>If thoughts o’ thee, or yet thy Mamie,</line>
      <line>Shall ever daunton me or awe me,</line>
      <line>My bonnie lady,</line>
      <line> Or if I blush when thou shalt ca’ me</line>
      <line>Tyta, or Daddie!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tho’ now they ca’ me fornicator,</line>
      <line>And tease my name in kintra clatter,</line>
      <line>The mair they talk, I’m kend the better;</line>
      <line>E’en let them clash!</line>
      <line>An auld wife’s tongue’s a feckless matter</line>
      <line>To gie ane fash!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Welcome, my bonnie, sweet, wee dochter!</line>
      <line>Tho’ ye come here a wee unsought for,</line>
      <line> And tho’ your comin I hae fought for,</line>
      <line>Baith Kirk and Queir,</line>
      <line>Yet by my faith, ye’re no unwrought for,</line>
      <line>That I shall swear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wee image o’ my bonnie Betty,</line>
      <line>As fatherly I kiss and daut thee,</line>
      <line>As dear and near my heart I set thee,</line>
      <line>Wi’ as gude will</line>
      <line>As a’ the priests had seen me get thee</line>
      <line>That’s out o’ Hell!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Sweet fruit o’ monie a merry dint,</line>
      <line>My funny toil is no a’ tint;</line>
      <line>Tho’ ye come to the warld askent,</line>
      <line>Which fools may scoff at,</line>
      <line>In my last plack your part’s be in’t,</line>
      <line>The better half o’t!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tho’ I should be the waur bestead,</line>
      <line>Thou’s be as braw and bienly clad,</line>
      <line>And thy young years as nicely bred</line>
      <line>Wi’ education,</line>
      <line> As ony brat o’ wedlock’s bed,</line>
      <line>In a’ thy station –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For if thou be, what I wad hae thee,</line>
      <line>And tak the counsel I shall gie thee,</line>
      <line>I’ll never rue my trouble wi’ thee,</line>
      <line>The cost nor shame o’t,</line>
      <line>But be a loving Father to thee,</line>
      <line>And brag the name o’t!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS and Agnes Craif McLehose</author>
    <date>1787</date>
    <title>Ae Fond Kiss</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ae fond kiss, and then we sever –</line>
      <line>Ae fareweel, and then for ever!</line>
      <line>Deep in heart-wrung tears I’ll pledge thee,</line>
      <line>Warring sighs and groans I’ll wage thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Who shall say that Fortune grieves him,</line>
      <line>While the star of hope she leaves him:</line>
      <line>Me, nae chearful twinkle lights me –</line>
      <line>Dark despair around benights me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll ne’er blame my partial fancy,</line>
      <line>Naething could resist my Nancy:</line>
      <line>But to see her, was to love her –</line>
      <line>Love but her, and love for ever!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had we never loved sae kindly,</line>
      <line>Had we never loved sae blindly –</line>
      <line> Never met, or never parted –</line>
      <line>We had ne’er been broken hearted!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fare-thee-weel, thou first and fairest!</line>
      <line>Fare-thee-weel, thou best and dearest!</line>
      <line>Thine be ilka joy and treasure,</line>
      <line>Peace, enjoyment, love and pleasure!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ae fond kiss, and then we sever,</line>
      <line>Ae fareweel – alas, for ever!</line>
      <line>Deep in heart-wrung tears I’ll pledge thee,</line>
      <line>Warring sighs and groans I’ll wage thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS and Jean Armour</author>
    <date>1788</date>
    <title>I Love My Jean</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of a’ the airts the wind can blaw,</line>
      <line>I dearly like the west;</line>
      <line>For there the bonny lassie lives,</line>
      <line>The lassie I lo’e best:</line>
      <line> There’s wild-woods grow, and rivers row,</line>
      <line>And mony a hill between;</line>
      <line>But day and night my fancy’s flight</line>
      <line>Is ever wi’ my Jean!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I see her in the dewy flowers,</line>
      <line>I see her sweet and fair;</line>
      <line>I hear her in the tunefu’ birds,</line>
      <line>I hear her charm the air –</line>
      <line>There’s not a bonny flower that springs</line>
      <line>By fountain, shaw, or green;</line>
      <line> There’s not a bonny bird that sings,</line>
      <line>But minds me o’ my Jean!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS and Mary Campbell</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Highland Mary</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye banks and braes and streams around</line>
      <line>The Castle o’ Montgomery,</line>
      <line>Green be your woods, and fair your flowers,</line>
      <line>Your waters never drumlie!</line>
      <line> There Simmer first unfald her robes,</line>
      <line>And there the langest tarry,</line>
      <line>For there I took the last fareweel</line>
      <line>O’ my sweet Highland Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How sweetly bloomed the gay green birk,</line>
      <line>How rich the hawthorn’s blossom,</line>
      <line>As underneath their fragrant shade</line>
      <line>I clasped her to my bosom!</line>
      <line>The golden hours, on angel-wings,</line>
      <line>Flew o’er me and my dearie –</line>
      <line> For dear to me as light and life</line>
      <line>Was my sweet Highland Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wi’ mony a vow, and lock’d embrace,</line>
      <line>Our parting was fu’ tender,</line>
      <line>And pledging aft to meet again,</line>
      <line>We tore oursels asunder –</line>
      <line>But oh, fell Death’s untimely frost</line>
      <line>That nipt my flower sae early,</line>
      <line>Now green’s the sod, and cauld’s the clay,</line>
      <line>That wraps my Highland Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> O pale, pale now those rosy lips</line>
      <line>I aft hae kiss’d sae fondly,</line>
      <line>And clos’d for ay the sparkling glance</line>
      <line>That dwelt on me sae kindly!</line>
      <line>And mouldering now in silent dust</line>
      <line>That heart that lo’ed me dearly,</line>
      <line>But still within my bosom’s core</line>
      <line>Shall live my Highland Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLOTTE SMITH</author>
    <date>1788</date>
    <title>To My Children</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O’erwhelmed with sorrow, and sustaining long</line>
      <line>‘The proud man’s contumely, the oppressor’s wrong’,</line>
      <line>Languid despondency and vain regret,</line>
      <line>Must my exhausted spirit struggle yet?</line>
      <line> Yes! Robbed, myself, of all that fortune gave,</line>
      <line>Even of all hope (but shelter in the grave),</line>
      <line>Still shall the plaintive lyre essay its powers</line>
      <line>To dress the Cave of Care with Fancy’s flowers –</line>
      <line>Maternal love the fiend Despair withstand,</line>
      <line>Still animate the heart and guide the hand.</line>
      <line>May you, dear objects of my anxious care,</line>
      <line>Escape the evils I was born to bear,</line>
      <line>Round my devoted head while tempests roll!</line>
      <line>Yet there, where I have treasured up my soul,</line>
      <line> May the soft rays of dawning hope impart</line>
      <line>Reviving patience to my fainting heart –</line>
      <line>And when its sharp solicitudes shall cease,</line>
      <line>May I be conscious in the realms of peace</line>
      <line>That every tear which swells my children’s eyes,</line>
      <line>From sorrows past, not present ills arise.</line>
      <line>Then, with some friend who loves to share your pain</line>
      <line>(For ’tis my boast that some such friends remain),</line>
      <line>By filial grief, and fond remembrance prest,</line>
      <line>You’ll seek the spot where all my sorrows rest,</line>
      <line> Recall my hapless days in sad review</line>
      <line>(The long calamities I bore for you),</line>
      <line>And – with an happier fate – resolve to prove</line>
      <line>How well you merited your mother’s love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1792</date>
    <title>Written Between Dover and Calais, July 1792</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bounding billow, cease thy motion –</line>
      <line>Bear me not so swiftly o’er!</line>
      <line>Cease thy roaring, foamy ocean!</line>
      <line>I will tempt thy rage no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ah! within my bosom beating,</line>
      <line>Varying passions wildly reign.</line>
      <line>Love, with proud resentment meeting,</line>
      <line>Throbs by turns of joy and pain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Joy, that far from foes I wander,</line>
      <line>Where their arts can reach no more;</line>
      <line>Pain, that woman’s heart grows fonder</line>
      <line>When the dream of bliss is o’er!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love, by fickle fancy banished,</line>
      <line>Spurned by hope, indignant flies!</line>
      <line> Yet, when love and hope are vanished,</line>
      <line>Restless Memory never dies!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Far I go, where fate shall lead me,</line>
      <line>Far across the troubled deep,</line>
      <line>Where no stranger’s ear shall heed me,</line>
      <line>Where no eye for me shall weep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Proud has been my fatal passion!</line>
      <line>Proud my injured heart shall be!</line>
      <line>While each thought and inclination</line>
      <line>Proves that heart was formed for thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Not one sigh shall tell my story,</line>
      <line>Not one tear my cheek shall stain!</line>
      <line>Silent grief shall be my glory,</line>
      <line>Grief that stoops not to complain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the bosom, prone to ranging,</line>
