      <line>Still, by ranging, seek a cure –</line>
      <line>Mine disdains the thought of changing,</line>
      <line>Proudly destined to endure!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet ere far from all I treasured,</line>
      <line>Tarleton, ere I bid adieu,</line>
      <line> Ere my days of pain are measured,</line>
      <line>Take the song that’s still thy due!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet believe no servile passions</line>
      <line>Seek to charm thy wandering mind;</line>
      <line>Well I know thy inclinations,</line>
      <line>Wavering as the passing wind!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have loved thee, dearly loved thee,</line>
      <line>Through an age of worldly woe!</line>
      <line>How ungrateful I have proved thee,</line>
      <line>Let my mournful exile show!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ten long years of anxious sorrow,</line>
      <line>Hour by hour I counted o’er;</line>
      <line>Looking forward till tomorrow,</line>
      <line>Every day I loved thee more!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Power and splendour could not charm me;</line>
      <line>I no joy in wealth could see;</line>
      <line>Nor could threats or fears alarm me –</line>
      <line>Save the fear of losing thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the storms of fortune pressed thee,</line>
      <line>I have sighed to hear thee sigh!</line>
      <line> Or when sorrows dire distressed thee,</line>
      <line>I have bid those sorrows fly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Often hast thou smiling told me</line>
      <line>Wealth and power were trifling things,</line>
      <line>While Love, smiling to behold me,</line>
      <line>Mocked cold Time’s destructive wings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When with thee, what ills could harm me?</line>
      <line>Thou could every pang assuage!</line>
      <line>Now, alas! what hope shall charm me?</line>
      <line>Every moment seems an age!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Fare thee well, ungrateful rover!</line>
      <line>Welcome Gallia’s hostile shore;</line>
      <line>Now the breezes waft me over;</line>
      <line>Now we part – to meet no more!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM COWPER and Mary Unwin</author>
    <date>1793</date>
    <title>To Mary</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The twentieth year is well-nigh past</line>
      <line>Since first our sky was overcast –</line>
      <line>Ah would that this might be the last,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thy spirits have a fainter flow,</line>
      <line>I see thee daily weaker grow –</line>
      <line>’Twas my distress that brought thee low,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy needles, once a shining store</line>
      <line>(For my sake restless heretofore),</line>
      <line>Now rust disused, and shine no more,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For though thou gladly wouldst fulfil</line>
      <line>The same kind office for me still,</line>
      <line> Thy sight now seconds not thy will,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But well thou playedst the housewife’s part,</line>
      <line>And all thy threads with magic art</line>
      <line>Have wound themselves about this heart,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy indistinct expressions seem</line>
      <line>Like language uttered in a dream;</line>
      <line>Yet me they charm, whate’er the theme,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thy silver locks, once auburn bright,</line>
      <line>Are still more lovely in my sight</line>
      <line>Than golden beams of orient light,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For could I view nor them, nor thee,</line>
      <line>What sight worth seeing could I see?</line>
      <line>The sun would rise in vain for me,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Partakers of the sad decline,</line>
      <line>Thy hands their little force resign;</line>
      <line> Yet, gently prest, press gently mine,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then I feel that still I hold</line>
      <line>A richer store ten-thousandfold</line>
      <line>Than misers fancy in their gold,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such feebleness of limbs thou prov’st</line>
      <line>That now, at every step, thou mov’st</line>
      <line>Upheld by two! But still thou lov’st,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And still to love, though prest with ill,</line>
      <line>In wintry age to feel no chill,</line>
      <line>With me is to be lovely still,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But ah, by constant heed I know</line>
      <line>How oft the sadness that I show</line>
      <line>Transforms thy smiles to looks of woe,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And should my future lot be cast</line>
      <line>With much resemblance to the past,</line>
      <line> Thy worn-out heart will break at last,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CHARLES LAMB</author>
    <date>1795</date>
    <title>To Mary Ann Lamb, the Author’s Best Friend and Sister</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>If from my lips some angry accents fell,</line>
      <line>Peevish complaint, or harsh reproof unkind,</line>
      <line>’Twas but the error of a sickly mind</line>
      <line>And troubled thoughts, clouding the purer well,</line>
      <line> And waters clear, of Reason! And for me,</line>
      <line>Let this my verse the poor atonement be –</line>
      <line>My verse, which thou to praise wert e’er inclined</line>
      <line>Too highly, and with a painful eye to see</line>
      <line>No blemish. Thou to me didst ever show</line>
      <line>Kindest affection, and wouldst oft-times lend</line>
      <line>An ear to the desponding love-sick lay,</line>
      <line>Weeping my sorrows with me, who repay</line>
      <line>But ill the mighty debt of love I owe,</line>
      <line>Mary, to thee, my sister, and my friend.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1796</date>
    <title>Composed on a Journey Homeward, the Author Having Received Intelligence of the Birth of a Son</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oft o’er my brain does that strange fancy roll</line>
      <line>Which makes the present (while the flesh doth last)</line>
      <line>Seem a mere semblance of some unknown past,</line>
      <line>Mixed with such feelings as perplex the soul</line>
      <line> Self-questioned in her sleep. And some have said</line>
      <line>We lived ere yet this fleshly robe we wore.</line>
      <line>Oh my sweet baby! when I reach the door,</line>
      <line>If heavy looks should tell me thou wert dead</line>
      <line>(As sometimes, through excess of hope, I fear),</line>
      <line>I think that I should struggle to believe</line>
      <line>Thou wert a spirit, to this nether sphere</line>
      <line>Sentenced for some more venial crime to grieve –</line>
      <line>Didst scream, then spring to meet Heaven’s quick reprieve,</line>
      <line>While we wept idly o’er thy little bier!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>Letter to Sara Hutchinson</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, if the bard was weatherwise, who made</line>
      <line>The grand old Ballad of Sir Patrick Spens,</line>
      <line>This night, so tranquil now, will not go hence</line>
      <line>Unroused by winds, that ply a busier trade</line>
      <line> Than that which moulds yon clouds in lazy flakes,</line>
      <line>Or the dull sobbing draught, that drones and rakes</line>
      <line>Upon the strings of this Eolian lute,</line>
      <line>Which better far were mute.</line>
      <line>For lo! the new moon, winter-bright</line>
      <line>And overspread with phantom light –</line>
      <line>With swimming phantom light o’erspread</line>
      <line>But rimmed and circled with a silver thread –</line>
      <line>I see the old moon in her lap, foretelling</line>
      <line>The coming on of rain and squally blast!</line>
      <line> Oh Sara, that the gust even now were swelling,</line>
      <line>And the slant night-shower driving loud and fast!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A grief without a pang, void, dark, and drear,</line>
      <line>A stifling, drowsy, unimpassioned grief</line>
      <line>That finds no natural outlet, no relief</line>
      <line>In word, or sigh, or tear –</line>
      <line>This, Sara, well thou knowst,</line>
      <line>Is that sore evil which I dread the most,</line>
      <line>And oftenest suffer! In this heartless mood,</line>
      <line>To other thoughts by yonder throstle wooed,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> That pipes within the larch-tree, not unseen</line>
      <line>(The larch, which pushes out in tassels green</line>
      <line>Its bundled leafits), wooed to mild delights</line>
      <line>By all the tender sounds and gentle sights</line>
      <line>Of this sweet primrose-month – and vainly wooed!</line>
      <line>Oh dearest Sara, in this heartless mood</line>
      <line>All this long eve, so balmy and serene,</line>
      <line>Have I been gazing on the western sky</line>
      <line>And its peculiar tint of yellow-green;</line>
      <line>And still I gaze and with how blank an eye!</line>
      <line> And those thin clouds above, in flakes and bars,</line>
      <line>That give away their motion to the stars;</line>
      <line>Those stars, that glide behind them, or between,</line>
      <line>Now sparkling, now bedimmed, but always seen;</line>
      <line>Yon crescent moon, as fixed as if it grew</line>
      <line>In its own cloudless, starless lake of blue –</line>
      <line>A boat becalmed, dear William’s sky-canoe!</line>
      <line>I see them all, so excellently fair!</line>
      <line>I see, not feel, how beautiful they are.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My genial spirits fail –</line>
      <line> And what can these avail</line>
      <line>To lift the smothering weight from off my breast?</line>
      <line>It were a vain endeavour,</line>
      <line>Though I should gaze for ever</line>
      <line>On that green light which lingers in the west!</line>
      <line>I may not hope from outward forms to win</line>
      <line>The passion and the life whose fountains are within!</line>
      <line>These lifeless shapes, around, below, above,</line>
      <line>Oh what can they impart?</line>
      <line>When even the gentle thought that thou, my love,</line>
      <line> Art gazing now, like me,</line>
      <line>And seest the heaven I see –</line>
      <line>Sweet thought it is, yet feebly stirs my heart!</line>
      <line>Feebly, oh feebly – yet</line>
      <line>(I well remember it)</line>
      <line>In my first dawn of youth that fancy stole</line>
      <line>With many secret yearnings on my soul.</line>
      <line>At eve, sky-gazing in ‘ecstatic fit’,</line>
      <line>Alas (for cloistered in a city-school</line>
      <line>The sky was all I knew of beautiful),</line>
      <line> At the barred window often did I sit,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And oft upon the leaded school-roof lay,</line>
      <line>And to myself would say:</line>
      <line>There does not live the man so stripped of good affections</line>
      <line>As not to love to see a maiden’s quiet eyes</line>
      <line>Upraised and linking on sweet dreams, by dim connections</line>
      <line>To moon, or Evening Star, or glorious western skies –</line>
      <line>While yet a boy, this thought would so pursue me</line>
      <line>That often it became a kind of vision to me!</line>
      <line>Sweet thought, and dear of old</line>
      <line> To hearts of finer mould –</line>
      <line>Ten thousand times by friends and lovers blest!</line>
      <line>I spoke with rash despair,</line>
      <line>And, ere I was aware,</line>
      <line>The weight was somewhat lifted from my breast.</line>
      <line>Oh Sara, in the weather-fended wood –</line>
      <line>Thy loved haunt, where the stock-doves coo at noon –</line>
      <line>I guess, that thou hast stood</line>
      <line>And watched yon crescent, and its ghost-like moon.</line>
      <line>And yet, far rather in my present mood</line>
      <line> I would that thou’dst been sitting all this while</line>
      <line>Upon the sod-built seat of camomile –</line>
      <line>And, though thy robin may have ceased to sing,</line>
      <line>Yet needs for my sake must thou love to hear</line>
      <line>The beehive murmuring near,</line>
      <line>That ever-busy and most quiet thing</line>
      <line>Which I have heard at midnight murmuring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I feel my spirit moved,</line>
      <line>And, wheresoe’er thou be</line>
      <line>Oh Sister, oh beloved,</line>
      <line> Those dear mild eyes that see</line>
      <line>Even now the heaven I see –</line>
      <line>There is a prayer in them – it is for me!</line>
      <line>And I, dear Sara, I am blessing thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was as calm as this, that happy night</line>
      <line>When Mary, thou, and I together were,</line>
      <line>The low decaying fire our only light,</line>
      <line>And listened to the stillness of the air!</line>
      <line>Oh that affectionate and blameless maid,</line>
      <line>Dear Mary – on her lap my head she laid!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her hand was on my brow</line>
      <line>(Even as my own is now),</line>
      <line>And on my cheek I felt thy eye-lash play.</line>
      <line>Such joy I had that I may truly say,</line>
      <line>My spirit was awe-stricken with the excess</line>
      <line>And trance-like depth of its brief happiness.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah fair remembrances, that so revive</line>
      <line>The heart, and fill it with a living power –</line>
      <line>Where were they, Sara? Or did I not strive</line>
      <line>To win them to me on the fretting hour –</line>
      <line> Then when I wrote thee that complaining scroll</line>
      <line>Which even to bodily sickness bruised thy soul!</line>
      <line>And yet thou blam’st thyself alone – and yet</line>
      <line>Forbidd’st me all regret!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And must I not regret that I distressed</line>
      <line>Thee, best beloved who lovest me the best?</line>
      <line>My better mind had fled I know not whither,</line>
      <line>For oh, was this an absent friend’s employ</line>
      <line>To send from far both pain and sorrow thither</line>
      <line>Where still his blessings should have called down joy!</line>
      <line> I read thy guileless letter o’er again,</line>
      <line>I hear thee of thy blameless self complain,</line>
      <line>And only this I learn (and this, alas, I know),</line>
      <line>That thou art weak and pale with sickness, grief and pain,</line>
      <line>And I – I made thee so!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh for my own sake I regret perforce</line>
      <line>Whatever turns thee, Sara, from the course</line>
      <line>Of calm well-being and a heart at rest!</line>
      <line>When thou, and with thee those whom thou lov’st best,</line>
      <line>Shall dwell together in one happy home,</line>
      <line> One house, the dear abiding home of all,</line>
      <line>I too will crown me with a coronal!</line>
      <line>Nor shall this heart in idle wishes roam</line>
      <line>Morbidly soft!</line>
      <line>No! Let me trust that I shall wear away</line>
      <line>In no inglorious toils the manly day,</line>
      <line>And only now and then, and not too oft,</line>
      <line>Some dear and memorable eve will bless</line>
      <line>Dreaming of all your loves and quietness.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be happy, and I need thee not in sight –</line>
      <line> Peace in thy heart, and quiet in thy dwelling,</line>
      <line>Health in thy limbs, and in thine eyes the light</line>
      <line>Of love, and hope, and honourable feeling.</line>
      <line>Where’er I am, I shall be well content –</line>
      <line>Not near thee, haply shall be more content!</line>
      <line>To all things I prefer the permanent!</line>
      <line>And better seems it for a heart like mine</line>
      <line>Always to know, than sometimes to behold,</line>
      <line>Their happiness and thine;</line>
      <line>For change doth trouble me with pangs untold!</line>
      <line> To see thee, hear thee, feel thee, then to part,</line>
      <line>Oh, it weighs down the heart!</line>
      <line>To visit those I love, as I love thee,</line>
      <line>Mary, and William, and dear Dorothy,</line>
      <line>It is but a temptation to repine –</line>
      <line>The transientness is poison in the wine,</line>
      <line>Eats out the pith of joy, makes all joy hollow,</line>
      <line>All pleasure a dim dream of pain to follow!</line>
      <line>My own peculiar lot, my household life,</line>
      <line>It is, and will remain, indifference or strife –</line>
      <line> While ye are well and happy, ’twould but wrong you</line>
      <line>If I should fondly yearn to be among you.</line>
      <line>Wherefore, oh wherefore, should I wish to be</line>
      <line>A withered branch upon a blossoming tree?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But – let me say it, for I vainly strive</line>
      <line>To beat away the thought – but if thou pined,</line>
      <line>Whate’er the cause, in body or in mind,</line>
      <line>I were the miserablest man alive</line>
      <line>To know it and be absent! Thy delights</line>
      <line>Far off, or near, alike I may partake;</line>
      <line> But oh, to mourn for thee, and to forsake</line>
      <line>All power, all hope of giving comfort to thee –</line>
      <line>To know that thou art weak and worn with pain,</line>
      <line>And not to hear thee, Sara, not to view thee,</line>
      <line>Not sit beside thy bed,</line>
      <line>Not press thy aching head,</line>
      <line>Not bring thee health again</line>
      <line>(At least to hope, to try)</line>
      <line>By this voice, which thou lov’st, and by this earnest eye!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nay, wherefore did I let it haunt my mind,</line>
      <line> The dark distressful dream?</line>
      <line>I turn from it, and listen to the wind</line>
      <line>Which long has raved unnoticed. What a scream</line>
      <line>Of agony, by torture lengthened out,</line>
      <line>That lute sent forth! Oh thou wild storm without!</line>
      <line>agg’d rock, or mountain-pond, or blasted tree,</line>
      <line>Or pine-grove whither woodman never clomb,</line>
      <line>Or lonely house long held the witches’ home,</line>
      <line>Methinks were fitter instruments for thee,</line>
      <line>Mad lutanist, that in this month of showers,</line>
      <line> Of dark brown gardens and of peeping flowers,</line>
      <line>Mak’st Devil’s yule, with worse than wintry song</line>
      <line>The blossoms, buds, and timorous leaves among!</line>
      <line>Thou actor, perfect in all tragic sounds,</line>
      <line>Thou mighty poet, even to frenzy bold!</line>
      <line>What tell’st thou now about?</line>
      <line>’Tis of the rushing of an host in rout –</line>
      <line>And many groans from men with smarting wounds –</line>
      <line>At once they groan with smart, and shudder with the cold!</line>
      <line>’Tis hushed: there is a trance of deepest silence.</line>
      <line>Again! But all that sound, as of a rushing crowd,</line>
      <line>And groans and tremulous shudderings, all are over –</line>
      <line>And it has other sounds, and all less deep, less loud –</line>
      <line>A tale of less affright,</line>
      <line>And tempered with delight,</line>
      <line>As William’s self had made the tender lay:</line>
      <line>’Tis of a little child</line>
      <line>Upon a heathy wild,</line>
      <line>Not far from home, but it has lost its way,</line>
      <line>And now groans low in utter grief and fear,</line>
      <line> And now screams loud, and hopes to make its mother hear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis midnight, and small thoughts have I of sleep –</line>
      <line>Full seldom may my friend such vigils keep –</line>
      <line>Oh breathe she softly in her gentle sleep!</line>
      <line>Cover her, gentle sleep, with wings of healing.</line>
      <line>And be this tempest but a mountain-birth!</line>
      <line>May all the stars hang bright about her dwelling,</line>
      <line>Silent, as though they watched the sleeping earth!</line>
      <line>Healthful and light, my darling, mayst thou rise</line>
      <line>With clear and cheerful eyes –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And of the same good tidings to me send!</line>
      <line>For, oh, belovéd friend,</line>
      <line>I am not the buoyant thing I was of yore</line>
      <line>When, like an own child, I to joy belonged –</line>
      <line>For others mourning oft, myself oft sorely wronged,</line>
      <line>Yet bearing all things then, as if I nothing bore!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, dearest Sara, yes!</line>
      <line>There was a time when, though my path was rough,</line>
      <line>The joy within me dallied with distress,</line>
      <line>And all misfortunes were but as the stuff</line>
      <line> Whence fancy made me dreams of happiness;</line>
      <line>For hope grew round me like the climbing vine,</line>
      <line>And leaves and fruitage, not my own, seemed mine!</line>
      <line>But now ill tidings bow me down to earth –</line>
      <line>Nor care I that they rob me of my mirth,</line>
      <line>But oh, each visitation</line>
      <line>Suspends what nature gave me at my birth,</line>
      <line>My shaping spirit of imagination!</line>
      <line>I speak not now of those habitual ills</line>
      <line>That wear out life, when two unequal minds</line>
      <line> Meet in one house, and two discordant wills;</line>
      <line>This leaves me where it finds,</line>
      <line>Past cure and past complaint – a fate austere,</line>
      <line>Too fixed and hopeless to partake of fear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But thou, dear Sara (dear indeed thou art,</line>
      <line>My comforter! A heart within my heart!),</line>
      <line>Thou, and the few we love, though few ye be,</line>
      <line>Make up a world of hopes and fears for me.</line>
      <line>And if affliction, or distempering pain,</line>
      <line>Or wayward chance befall you, I complain</line>
      <line> Not that I mourn. Oh friends most dear, most true,</line>
      <line>Methinks to weep with you</line>
      <line>Were better far than to rejoice alone –</line>
      <line>But that my coarse domestic life has known</line>
      <line>No habits of heart-nursing sympathy,</line>
      <line>No griefs but such as dull and deaden me,</line>
      <line>No mutual mild enjoyments of its own,</line>
      <line>No hopes of its own vintage – none, oh none,</line>
      <line>Whence, when I mourned for you, my heart might borrow</line>
      <line>Fair forms and living motions for its sorrow.</line>
      <line> For not to think of what I needs must feel,</line>
      <line>But to be still and patient all I can,</line>
      <line>And haply by abstruse research to steal</line>
      <line>From my own nature all the natural man –</line>
      <line>This was my sole resource, my wisest plan!</line>
      <line>And that, which suits a part, infects the whole,</line>
      <line>And now is almost grown the temper of my soul.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My little children are a joy, a love,</line>
      <line>A good gift from above!</line>
      <line>But what is bliss, that still calls up a woe</line>
      <line> And makes it doubly keen,</line>
      <line>Compelling me to feel, as well as know,</line>
      <line>What a most blesséd lot mine might have been.</line>
      <line>Those little angel-children – woe is me! –</line>
      <line>There have been hours, when feeling how they bind</line>
      <line>And pluck out the wing-feathers of my mind,</line>
      <line>Turning my error to necessity, I have half</line>
      <line>Wished they never had been born!</line>
      <line>That, seldom – but sad thoughts they always bring,</line>
      <line>And like the poet’s Philomel I sing</line>
      <line> My love-song with my breast against a thorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With no unthankful spirit I confess</line>
      <line>This clinging grief too, in its turn, awakes</line>
      <line>That love, and father’s joy; but oh, it makes</line>
      <line>The love the greater, and the joy far less!</line>
      <line>These mountains too, these vales, these woods, these lakes,</line>
      <line>Scenes full of beauty and of loftiness</line>
      <line>Where all my life I fondly hoped to live –</line>
      <line>I were sunk low indeed, did they no solace give;</line>
      <line>But oft I seem to feel, and evermore I fear,</line>
      <line> They are not to me now the things, which once they were.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Sara, we receive but what we give,</line>
      <line>And in our life alone does Nature live.</line>
      <line>Ours is her wedding garment, ours her shroud –</line>
      <line>And would we aught behold of higher worth</line>
      <line>Than that inanimate cold world allowed</line>
      <line>To the poor loveless ever-anxious crowd,</line>
      <line>Ah, from the soul itself must issue forth</line>
      <line>A light, a glory, and a luminous cloud</line>
      <line>Enveloping the earth!</line>
      <line>And from the soul itself must there be sent</line>
      <line>A sweet and potent voice, of its own birth,</line>
      <line>Of all sweet sounds the life and element.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh pure of heart, thou needst not ask of me</line>
      <line>What this strong music in the soul may be,</line>
      <line>What and wherein it doth exist,</line>
      <line>This light, this glory, this fair luminous mist,</line>
      <line>This beautiful and beauty-making power!</line>
      <line>Joy, innocent Sara! Joy, that ne’er was given</line>
      <line>Save to the pure, and in their purest hour –</line>
      <line> Joy, Sara, is the spirit and the power</line>
      <line>That, wedding Nature to us, gives in dower</line>
      <line>A new Earth and new Heaven</line>
      <line>Undreamt of by the sensual and the proud!</line>
      <line>Joy is that strong voice, joy that luminous cloud –</line>
      <line>We, we ourselves rejoice!</line>
      <line>And thence flows all that charms or ear or sight –</line>
      <line>All melodies the echoes of that voice,</line>
      <line>All colours a suffusion of that light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sister and friend of my devoutest choice!</line>
      <line> Thou being innocent and full of love,</line>
      <line>And nested with the darlings of thy love,</line>
      <line>And feeling in thy soul, heart, lips, and arms</line>
      <line>Even what the conjugal and mother dove,</line>
      <line>That borrows genial warmth from those she warms,</line>
      <line>Feels in her thrilled wings, blessedly outspread –</line>
      <line>Thou, freed awhile from cares and human dread</line>
      <line>By the immenseness of the good and fair</line>
      <line>Which thou seest everywhere –</line>
      <line>Thus, thus shouldst thou rejoice!</line>
      <line> To thee would all things live from pole to pole,</line>
      <line>Their life the eddying of thy living soul.</line>
      <line>Oh dear! Oh innocent! Oh full of love!</line>
      <line>A very friend! A sister of my choice –</line>
      <line>Oh dear, as light and impulse from above,</line>
      <line>Thus mayst thou ever, evermore rejoice!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Dorothy Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>To My Sister</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is the first mild day of March,</line>
      <line>Each minute sweeter than before;</line>
      <line>The redbreast sings from the tall larch</line>
      <line>That stands beside our door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> There is a blessing in the air</line>
      <line>Which seems a sense of joy to yield</line>
      <line>To the bare trees, and mountains bare,</line>
      <line>And grass in the green field.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My sister – ’tis a wish of mine –</line>
      <line>Now that our morning-meal is done</line>
      <line>Make haste, your morning task resign,</line>
      <line>Come forth and feel the sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Edward will come with you, and pray</line>
      <line>Put on with speed your woodland-dress,</line>
      <line> And bring no book – for this one day</line>
      <line>We’ll give to idleness!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No joyless forms shall regulate</line>
      <line>Our living calendar:</line>
      <line>We from today, my friend, will date</line>
      <line>The opening of the year.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love, now an universal birth,</line>
      <line>From heart to heart is stealing –</line>
      <line>From earth to man, from man to earth –</line>
      <line>It is the hour of feeling!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> One moment now may give us more</line>
      <line>Than fifty years of reason;</line>
      <line>Our minds shall drink at every pore</line>
      <line>The spirit of the season.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some silent laws our hearts may make,</line>
      <line>Which they shall long obey;</line>
      <line>We for the year to come may take</line>
      <line>Our temper from today.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And from the blesséd power that rolls</line>
      <line>About, below, above,</line>
      <line> We’ll frame the measure of our souls –</line>
      <line>They shall be tuned to love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then come, my sister, come I pray,</line>
      <line>With speed put on your woodland-dress,</line>
      <line>And bring no book – for this one day</line>
      <line>We’ll give to idleness.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Dorothy Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1800</date>
    <title>from Home at Grasmere</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mine eyes did ne’er</line>
      <line>Rest on a lovely object, nor my mind</line>
      <line>Take pleasure in the midst of happy thoughts,</line>
      <line>But either she whom now I have, who now</line>
      <line>Divides with me this loved abode, was there</line>
      <line>Or not far off. Where’er my footsteps turned,</line>
      <line>Her voice was like a hidden bird that sang;</line>
      <line>The thought of her was like a flash of light</line>
      <line>Or an unseen companionship, a breath</line>
      <line>Or fragrance independent of the wind…</line>
      <line>The boon is absolute: surpassing grace</line>
      <line>To me hath been vouchsafed. Among the bowers</line>
      <line>Of blissful Eden this was neither given,</line>
      <line> Nor could be given – possession of the good</line>
      <line>Which had been sighed for, ancient thought fulfilled,</line>
      <line>And dear imaginations realized</line>
      <line>Up to their highest measure, yea, and more…</line>
      <line>Long is it since we met to part no more,</line>
      <line>Since I and Emma heard each other’s call</line>
      <line>And were companions once again, like birds</line>
      <line>Which by the intruding fowler had been scared –</line>
      <line> Two of a scattered brood that could not bear</line>
      <line>To live in loneliness! ’Tis long since we,</line>
      <line>Remembering much and hoping more, found means</line>
      <line>To walk abreast, though in a narrow path,</line>
      <line>With undivided steps. Our home was sweet –</line>
      <line>Could it be less? If we were forced to change,</line>
      <line>Our home again was sweet; but still – for youth,</line>
      <line>Strong as it seems and bold, is inly weak</line>
      <line>And diffident – the destiny of life</line>
      <line>Remained unfixed…</line>
      <line>Bleak season was it, turbulent and bleak,</line>
      <line>When hitherward we journeyed, and on foot,</line>
      <line>Through bursts of sunshine and through flying snows,</line>
      <line>Paced the long vales. How long they were, and yet</line>
      <line>How fast that length of way was left behind –</line>
      <line>Wensley’s long vale and Sedbergh’s naked heights.</line>
      <line>The frosty wind, as if to make amends</line>
      <line> For its keen breath, was aiding to our course</line>
      <line>And drove us onward like two ships at sea!</line>
      <line>Stern was the face of Nature; we rejoiced</line>
      <line>In that stern countenance, for our souls had there</line>
      <line>A feeling of their strength. The naked trees,</line>
      <line>The icy brooks, as on we passed, appeared</line>
      <line>To question us. ‘Whence come ye? To what end?’</line>
      <line>They seemed to say. ‘What would ye?’ said the shower,</line>
      <line>‘Wild wanderers, whither through my dark domain?’</line>
      <line>The sunbeam said, ‘Be happy’. They were moved –</line>
      <line> All things were moved – they round us as we went,</line>
      <line>We in the midst of them.</line>
      <line>And when the trance</line>
      <line>Came to us as we stood by Hart-Leap Well,</line>
      <line>The intimation of the milder day</line>
      <line>Which is to come, the fairer world than this,</line>
      <line>And raised us up, dejected as we were</line>
      <line>Among the records of that doleful place</line>
      <line>By sorrow for the hunted beast who there</line>
      <line>Had yielded up his breath – the awful trance,</line>
      <line>The vision of humanity and of God</line>
      <line> The mourner, God the sufferer, when the heart</line>
      <line>Of his poor creatures suffers wrongfully –</line>
      <line>Both in the sadness and the joy we found</line>
      <line>A promise and an earnest that we twain,</line>
      <line>A pair seceding from the common world,</line>
      <line>Might in that hallowed spot to which our steps</line>
      <line>Were tending, in that individual nook,</line>
      <line>Might even thus early for ourselves secure,</line>
      <line>And in the midst of these unhappy times,</line>
      <line>A portion of the blessedness which love</line>
      <line> And knowledge will, we trust, hereafter give</line>
      <line>To all the vales of earth and all mankind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Dorothy Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>To a Butterfly</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Stay near me, do not take thy flight!</line>
      <line>A little longer stay in sight –</line>
      <line>Much reading do I find in thee,</line>
      <line>Historian of my infancy.</line>
      <line> Float near me, do not yet depart!</line>
      <line>Dead times revive in thee;</line>
      <line>Thou bringest (gay creature, as thou art)</line>
      <line>A solemn image to my heart:</line>
      <line>My father’s family.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh pleasant, pleasant were the days,</line>
      <line>The time when in our childish plays</line>
      <line>My sister Emmeline and I</line>
      <line>Together chased the butterfly.</line>
      <line>A very hunter, I did rush</line>
      <line> Upon the prey – with leaps and springs</line>
      <line>I followed on from brake to bush –</line>
      <line>But she, God love her, feared to brush</line>
      <line>The dust from off its wings!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Dorothy Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>The Sparrow’s Nest</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look, five blue eggs are gleaming there!</line>
      <line>Few visions have I seen more fair,</line>
      <line>Nor many prospects of delight</line>
      <line>More pleasing than that simple sight.</line>
      <line> I started, seeming to espy</line>
      <line>The home and sheltered bed,</line>
      <line>The sparrow’s dwelling, which hard by</line>
      <line>My father’s house in wet or dry,</line>
      <line>My sister Emmeline and I</line>
      <line>Together visited.</line>
      <line>She looked at it as if she feared it –</line>
      <line>Still wishing, dreading to be near it –</line>
      <line>Such heart was in her, being then</line>
      <line>A little prattler among men.</line>
      <line> The blessing of my later years</line>
      <line>Was with me when a boy:</line>
      <line>She gave me eyes, she gave me ears,</line>
      <line>And humble cares, and delicate fears,</line>
      <line>A heart, the fountain of sweet tears,</line>
      <line>And love, and thought, and joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Dorothy Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>‘Child of My Parents’ (1805 Prelude XIII)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Child of my parents, sister of my soul,</line>
      <line>Elsewhere have strains of gratitude been breathed</line>
      <line>To thee for all the early tenderness</line>
      <line>Which I from thee imbibed. And true it is</line>
      <line> That later seasons owed to thee no less;</line>
      <line>For, spite of thy sweet influence and the touch</line>
      <line>Of other kindred hands that opened out</line>
      <line>The springs of tender thought in infancy,</line>
      <line>And spite of all which singly I had watched</line>
      <line>Of elegance, and each minuter charm</line>
      <line>In Nature and in life, still to the last –</line>
      <line>Even to the very going-out of youth,</line>
      <line>The period which our story now has reached –</line>
      <line>I too exclusively esteemed that love,</line>
      <line> And sought that beauty, which (as Milton sings)</line>
      <line>Has terror in it. Thou didst soften down</line>
      <line>This over-sternness; but for thee, sweet friend,</line>
      <line>My soul, too reckless of mild grace, had been</line>
      <line>Far longer what by nature it was framed –</line>
      <line>Longer retained its countenance severe –</line>
      <line>A rock with torrents roaring, with the clouds</line>
      <line>Familiar, and a favourite of the stars;</line>
      <line>But thou didst plant its crevices with flowers,</line>
      <line>Hang it with shrubs that twinkle in the breeze,</line>
      <line> And teach the little birds to build their nests</line>
      <line>And warble in its chambers.</line>
      <line>At a time</line>
      <line>When Nature, destined to remain so long</line>
      <line>Foremost in my affections, had fallen back</line>
      <line>Into second place, well pleased to be</line>
      <line>A handmaid to a nobler than herself –</line>
      <line>When every day brought with it some new sense</line>
      <line>Of exquisite regard for common things,</line>
      <line>And all the earth was budding with these gifts</line>
      <line>Of more refined humanity – thy breath,</line>
      <line> Dear sister, was a kind of gentler spring</line>
      <line>That went before my steps.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Caroline (Vallon) Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>It Is a Beauteous Evening</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is a beauteous evening, calm and free:</line>
      <line>The holy time is quiet as a nun</line>
      <line>Breathless with adoration; the broad sun</line>
      <line>Is sinking down in its tranquillity;</line>
      <line> The gentleness of heaven is on the sea.</line>
      <line>Listen, the mighty being is awake</line>
      <line>And doth with his eternal motion make</line>
      <line>A sound like thunder – everlastingly!</line>
      <line>Dear child, dear girl, that walkest with me here,</line>
      <line>If thou appearst untouched by solemn thought</line>
      <line>Thy nature is not therefore less divine:</line>
      <line>Thou liest in Abraham’s bosom all the year,</line>
      <line>And worshipst at the temple’s inner shrine,</line>
      <line>God being with thee when we know it not.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Mary Wordsworth (née Hutchinson)</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>She Was a Phantom of Delight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She was a phantom of delight</line>
      <line>When first she gleamed upon my sight;</line>
      <line>A lovely apparition, sent</line>
      <line>To be a moment’s ornament;</line>
      <line> Her eyes as stars of twilights fair;</line>
      <line>Like twilights, too, her dusky hair;</line>
      <line>But all things else about her drawn</line>
      <line>From May-time and the cheerful dawn;</line>
      <line>A dancing shape, an image gay,</line>
      <line>To haunt, to startle, and way-lay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw her upon nearer view,</line>
      <line>A spirit, yet a woman too!</line>
      <line>Her household motions light and free,</line>
      <line>And steps of virgin liberty;</line>
      <line> A countenance in which did meet</line>
      <line>Sweet records, promises as sweet;</line>
      <line>A creature not too bright or good</line>
      <line>For human nature’s daily food;</line>
      <line>For transient sorrows, simple wiles,</line>
      <line>Praise, blame, love, kisses, tears, and smiles.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now I see with eye serene</line>
      <line>The very pulse of the machine;</line>
      <line>A being breathing thoughtful breath;</line>
      <line>A traveller betwixt life and death;</line>
      <line> The reason firm, the temperate will,</line>
      <line>Endurance, foresight, strength and skill;</line>
      <line>A perfect woman; nobly planned,</line>
      <line>To warn, to comfort, and command;</line>
      <line>And yet a spirit still, and bright</line>
      <line>With something of an angel light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Mary Wordsworth (née Hutchinson)</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>‘Another Maid There Was’ (1805 Prelude VI, XI)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Another maid there was, who also breathed</line>
      <line>A gladness o’er that season, then to me</line>
      <line> By her exulting outside look of youth</line>
      <line>And placid under-countenance first endeared –</line>
      <line>That other spirit, Coleridge, who is now</line>
      <line>So near to us, that meek confiding heart</line>
      <line>So reverenced by us both...</line>
      <line> Methought such charm</line>
      <line>Of sweetness did her presence breathe around</line>
      <line>That all the trees, and all the silent hills,</line>
      <line>And everything she looked on, should have had</line>
      <line>An intimation how she bore herself</line>
      <line>Towards them and to all creatures. God delights</line>
      <line>In such a being, for her common thoughts</line>
      <line>Are piety, her life is blessedness.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth and Catharine Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1814</date>
    <title>Surprised by Joy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Surprised by joy, impatient as the wind,</line>
      <line>I wished to share the transport – oh, with whom</line>
      <line>But thee, long-buried in the silent tomb,</line>
      <line>That spot which no vicissitude can find?</line>
      <line> Love, faithful love, recalled thee to my mind –</line>
      <line>But how could I forget thee? Through what power</line>
      <line>Even for the least division of an hour</line>
      <line>Have I been so beguiled as to be blind</line>
      <line>To my most grievous loss? That thought’s return</line>
      <line>Was the worst pang that sorrow ever bore –</line>
      <line>Save one, one only, when I stood forlorn,</line>
      <line>Knowing my heart’s best treasure was no more,</line>
      <line>That neither present time, nor years unborn,</line>
      <line>Could to my sight that heavenly face restore.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY and Harriet Shelley (née Westbrook)</author>
    <date>1812</date>
    <title>To Harriet</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Whose is the love that, gleaming through the world,</line>
      <line>Wards off the poisonous arrow of its scorn?</line>
      <line>Whose is the warm and partial praise,</line>
      <line>Virtue’s most sweet reward?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Beneath whose looks did my reviving soul</line>
      <line>Riper in truth and virtuous daring grow?</line>
      <line>Whose eyes have I gazed fondly on,</line>
      <line>And loved mankind the more?</line>
      <line>Harriet, on thine! Thou wert my purer mind,</line>
      <line>Thou wert the inspiration of my song;</line>
      <line>Thine are these early wilding flowers,</line>
      <line>Though garlanded by me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then press into thy breast this pledge of love,</line>
      <line>And know (though time may change, and years may roll)</line>
      <line> Each flowret gathered in my heart</line>
      <line>It consecrates to thine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY and Mary Shelley (née Godwin)</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>from Dedication to Laon and Cythna</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>So now my summer task is ended, Mary,</line>
      <line>And I return to thee, mine own heart’s home,</line>
      <line>As to his Queen, some victor-knight of Fairy,</line>
      <line>Earning bright spoils for her enchanted dome.</line>
      <line> Nor thou disdain that ere my fame become</line>
      <line>A star among the stars of mortal night</line>
      <line>(If it indeed may cleave its natal gloom),</line>
      <line>Its doubtful promise thus I would unite</line>
      <line>With thy belovéd name, thou child of love and light!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The toil which stole from thee so many an hour</line>
      <line>Is ended – and the fruit is at thy feet!</line>
      <line>No longer where the woods, to frame a bower,</line>
      <line>With interlacéd branches mix and meet,</line>
      <line>Or where, with sound like many voices sweet,</line>
      <line> Waterfalls leap among wild islands green</line>
      <line>(Which framed for my lone boat a lone retreat</line>
      <line>Of moss-grown trees and weeds), shall I be seen,</line>
      <line>But beside thee, where still my heart has ever been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thoughts of great deeds were mine, dear friend, when first</line>
      <line>The clouds which wrap this world from youth did pass.</line>
      <line>I do remember well the hour which burst</line>
      <line>My spirit’s sleep. A fresh May-dawn it was</line>
      <line>When I walked forth upon the glittering grass,</line>
      <line>And wept – I knew not why – until there rose</line>
      <line> From the near school-room voices that, alas,</line>
      <line>Were but one echo from a world of woes,</line>
      <line>The harsh and grating strife of tyrants and of foes.</line>
      <line>And then I clasped my hands and looked around –</line>
      <line>But none was near to mock my streaming eyes,</line>
      <line>Which poured their warm drops on the sunny ground –</line>
      <line>So without shame I spoke: ‘I will be wise,</line>
      <line>And just, and free, and mild, if in me lies</line>
      <line>Such power, for I grow weary to behold</line>
      <line>The selfish and the strong still tyrannize</line>
      <line> Without reproach or check.’ I then controlled</line>
      <line>My tears, my heart grew calm, and I was meek and bold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And from that hour did I with earnest thought</line>
      <line>Heap knowledge from forbidden mines or lore,</line>
      <line>Yet nothing that my tyrants knew or taught</line>
      <line>I cared to learn, but from that secret store</line>
      <line>Wrought linkéd armour for my soul, before</line>
      <line>It might walk forth to war among mankind!</line>
      <line>Thus power and hope were strengthened more and more</line>
      <line>Within me, till there came upon my mind</line>
      <line> A sense of loneliness, a thirst with which I pined...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And what art thou? I know, but dare not speak –</line>
      <line>Time may interpret to his silent years!</line>
      <line>Yet in the paleness of thy thoughtful cheek,</line>
      <line>And in the light thine ample forehead wears,</line>
      <line> And in thy sweetest smiles, and in thy tears,</line>
      <line>And in thy gentle speech, a prophecy</line>
      <line>Is whispered to subdue my fondest fears.</line>
      <line>And through thine eyes – even in thy soul – I see</line>
      <line>A lamp of vestal fire burning internally.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say that thou wert lovely from thy birth</line>
      <line>(Of glorious parents) thou aspiring child!</line>
      <line>I wonder not, for one then left this Earth</line>
      <line>Whose life was like a setting planet mild</line>
      <line>Which clothed thee in the radiance undefiled</line>
      <line>Of its departing glory. Still her fame</line>
      <line>Shines on thee, through the tempests dark and wild</line>
      <line>Which shake these latter days – and thou canst claim</line>
      <line>The shelter from thy sire of an immortal name!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One voice came forth from many a mighty spirit,</line>
      <line>Which was the echo of three thousand years,</line>
      <line>And the tumultuous world stood mute to hear it</line>
      <line>As some lone man who in a desert hears</line>
      <line>The music of his home! Unwonted fears</line>
      <line>Fell on the pale oppressors of our race,</line>
      <line> And Faith, and Custom, and low-thoughted cares,</line>
      <line>Like thunder-stricken dragons, for a space</line>
      <line>Left the torn human heart, their food and dwelling-place.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Truth’s deathless voice pauses among mankind!</line>
      <line>If there must be no response to my cry –</line>
      <line>If men must rise and stamp, with fury blind,</line>
      <line>On his pure name who loves them – thou and I,</line>
      <line>Sweet friend, can look from our tranquility</line>
      <line>Like lamps into the world’s tempestuous night,</line>
      <line>Two tranquil stars, while clouds are passing by</line>
      <line> Which wrap them from the foundering seaman’s sight,</line>
      <line>That burn from year to year with unextinguished light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY and Teresa [Emilia] Viviani</author>
    <date>1821</date>
    <title>Epipsychidion</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My song, I fear that thou wilt find but few</line>
      <line>Who fitly shall conceive thy reasoning,</line>
      <line>Of such hard matter dost thou entertain;</line>
      <line>Whence, if by misadventure chance should bring</line>
      <line>Thee to base company (as chance may do),</line>
      <line>Quite unaware of what thou dost contain,</line>
      <line>I prithee, comfort thy sweet self again,</line>
      <line>My last delight! Tell them that they are dull,</line>
      <line>And bid them own that thou art beautiful.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet spirit! sister of that orphan one</line>
      <line>Whose empire is the name thou weepest on,</line>
      <line>In my heart’s temple I suspend to thee</line>
      <line>These votive wreaths of withered memory.</line>
      <line> Poor captive bird! – who from thy narrow cage</line>
      <line>Pourest such music that it might assuage</line>
      <line>The rugged hearts of those who prisoned thee,</line>
      <line>Were they not deaf to all sweet melody –</line>
      <line>This song shall be thy rose. Its petals pale</line>
      <line>Are dead indeed, my adored nightingale,</line>
      <line>But soft and fragrant is the faded blossom,</line>
      <line>And it has no thorn left to wound thy bosom.</line>
      <line>High spirit-wingéd heart! who dost for ever</line>
      <line>Beat thine unfeeling bars with vain endeavour,</line>
      <line> Till those bright plumes of thought (in which arrayed</line>
      <line>It over-soared this low and worldly shade)</line>
      <line>Lie shattered, and thy panting, wounded breast</line>
      <line>Stains with dear blood its unmaternal nest.</line>
      <line>I weep vain tears: blood would less bitter be,</line>
      <line>Yet poured forth gladlier, could it profit thee.</line>
      <line>Seraph of Heaven! too gentle to be human,</line>
      <line>Veiling beneath that radiant form of woman</line>
      <line>All that is insupportable in thee</line>
      <line>Of light, and love, and immortality.</line>
      <line> Sweet benediction in the eternal curse!</line>
      <line>Veiled glory of this lampless universe!</line>
      <line>Thou moon beyond the clouds! Thou living form</line>
      <line>Among the dead! Thou star above the storm!</line>
      <line>Thou wonder, and thou beauty, and thou terror!</line>
      <line>Thou harmony of Nature’s art! Thou mirror</line>
      <line>In whom, as in the splendour of the sun,</line>
      <line>All shapes look glorious which thou gazest on!</line>
      <line>Aye, even the dim words which obscure thee now</line>
      <line>Flash, lightning-like, with unaccustomed glow.</line>
      <line> I pray thee that thou blot from this sad song</line>
      <line>All of its much mortality and wrong</line>
      <line>With those clear drops, which start like sacred dew</line>
      <line>From the twin lights thy sweet soul darkens through,</line>
      <line>Weeping, till sorrow becomes ecstasy –</line>
      <line>Then smile on it, so that it may not die.</line>
      <line>I never thought before my death to see</line>
      <line>Youth’s vision thus made perfect. Emily,</line>
      <line>I love thee; though the world by no thin name</line>
      <line>Will hide that love from its unvalued shame.</line>
      <line> Would we two had been twins of the same mother!</line>
      <line>Or that the name my heart lent to another</line>
      <line>Could be a sister’s bond for her and thee,</line>
      <line>Blending two beams of one eternity!</line>
      <line>Yet were one lawful and the other true,</line>
      <line>These names, though dear, could paint not (as is due)</line>
      <line>How beyond refuge I am thine. Ah me,</line>
      <line>I am not thine – I am a part of thee!</line>
      <line>Sweet lamp! my moth-like muse has burned its wings</line>
      <line>Or, like a dying swan who soars and sings,</line>
      <line> Young Love should teach Time, in his own grey style,</line>
      <line>All that thou art. Art thou not void of guile,</line>
      <line>A lovely soul formed to be blest and bless,</line>
      <line>A well of sealed and secret happiness,</line>
      <line>Whose waters like blithe light and music are,</line>
      <line>Vanquishing dissonance and gloom? A star</line>
      <line>Which moves not in the moving heavens, alone?</line>
      <line>A smile amid dark frowns? A gentle tone</line>
      <line>Amid rude voices? A belovéd light,</line>
      <line>A solitude, a refuge, a delight?</line>
      <line> A lute, which those whom Love has taught to play</line>
      <line>Make music on, to soothe the roughest day</line>
      <line>And lull fond grief asleep? A buried treasure?</line>
      <line>A cradle of young thoughts of wingless pleasure?</line>
      <line>A violet-shrouded grave of woe? I measure</line>
      <line>The world of fancies, seeking one like thee,</line>
      <line>And find – alas! mine own infirmity.</line>
      <line>She met me, stranger, upon life’s rough way,</line>
      <line>And lured me towards sweet death – as night by day,</line>
      <line>Winter by spring, or sorrow by swift hope,</line>
      <line> Led into light, life, peace. An antelope,</line>
      <line>In the suspended impulse of its lightness,</line>
      <line>Were less aethereally light. The brightness</line>
      <line>Of her divinest presence trembles through</line>
      <line>Her limbs as underneath a cloud of dew,</line>
      <line>Embodied in the windless heaven of June</line>
      <line>Amid the splendour-wingéd stars, the Moon</line>
      <line>Burns, inextinguishably beautiful –</line>
      <line>And from her lips, as from a hyacinth full</line>
      <line>Of honey-dew, a liquid murmur drops</line>
      <line> Killing the sense with passion, sweet as stops</line>
      <line>Of planetary music heard in trance.</line>
      <line>In her mild lights the starry spirits dance,</line>
      <line>The sunbeams of those wells which ever leap</line>
      <line>Under the lightnings of the soul – too deep</line>
      <line>For the brief fathom-line of thought or sense.</line>
      <line>The glory of her being, issuing thence,</line>
      <line>Stains the dead, blank, cold air with a warm shade</line>
      <line>Of unentangled intermixture, made</line>
      <line>By Love, of light and motion – one intense</line>
      <line> Diffusion, one serene omnipresence,</line>
      <line>Whose flowing outlines mingle in their flowing,</line>
      <line>Around her cheeks and utmost fingers glowing</line>
      <line>With the unintermitted blood, which there</line>
      <line>Quivers (as in a fleece of snow-like air</line>
      <line>The crimson pulse of living morning quiver)</line>
      <line>Continuously prolonged, and ending never,</line>
      <line>Till they are lost, and in that beauty furled</line>
      <line>Which penetrates and clasps and fills the world,</line>
      <line>Scarce visible from extreme loveliness.</line>
      <line>Warm fragrance seems to fall from her light dress</line>
      <line>And her loose hair, and where some heavy tress</line>
      <line>The air of her own speed has disentwined,</line>
      <line>The sweetness seems to satiate the faint wind;</line>
      <line>And in the soul a wild odour is felt,</line>
      <line>Beyond the sense, like fiery dews that melt</line>
      <line>Into the bosom of a frozen bud.</line>
      <line>See where she stands! a mortal shape indued</line>
      <line>With love and life and light and deity,</line>
      <line>And motion which may change but cannot die –</line>
      <line> An image of some bright eternity;</line>
      <line>A shadow of some golden dream; a splendour</line>
      <line>Leaving the third sphere pilotless; a tender</line>
      <line>Reflection of the eternal moon of love</line>
      <line>Under whose motions life’s dull billows move;</line>
      <line>A metaphor of spring and youth and morning;</line>
      <line>A vision like incarnate April, warning,</line>
      <line>With smiles and tears, frost the anatomy</line>
      <line>Into his summer grave.</line>
      <line>Ah, woe is me!</line>
      <line>What have I dared? Where am I lifted? How</line>
      <line> Shall I descend, and perish not? I know</line>
      <line>That love makes all things equal: I have heard</line>
      <line>By mine own heart this joyous truth averred:</line>
      <line>The spirit of the worm beneath the sod,</line>
      <line>In love and worship, blends itself with God.</line>
      <line>Spouse! sister! angel! pilot of the fate</line>
      <line>Whose course has been so starless! Oh too late</line>
      <line>Belovéd! Oh too soon adored, by me!</line>
      <line>For in the fields of immortality</line>
      <line>My spirit should at first have worshipped thine,</line>
      <line> A divine presence in a place divine –</line>
      <line>Or should have moved beside it on this earth,</line>
      <line>A shadow of that substance, from its birth –</line>
      <line>But not as now. I love thee – yes, I feel</line>
      <line>That on the fountain of my heart a seal</line>
      <line>Is set, to keep its waters pure and bright</line>
      <line>For thee, since in those tears thou hast delight.</line>
      <line>We – are we not formed, as notes of music are,</line>
      <line>For one another, though dissimilar? –</line>
      <line>Such difference without discord, as can make</line>
      <line> Those sweetest sounds, in which all spirits shake</line>
      <line>As trembling leaves in a continuous air?</line>
      <line>Thy wisdom speaks in me, and bids me dare</line>
      <line>Beacon the rocks on which high hearts are wrecked.</line>
      <line>I never was attached to that great sect,</line>
      <line>Whose doctrine is, that each one should select</line>
      <line>Out of the crowd a mistress or a friend,</line>
      <line>And all the rest, though fair and wise, commend</line>
      <line>To cold oblivion – though it is in the code</line>
      <line>Of modern morals, and the beaten road</line>
      <line> Which those poor slaves with weary footsteps tread,</line>
      <line>Who travel to their home among the dead</line>
      <line>By the broad highway of the world, and so</line>
      <line>With one chained friend, perhaps a jealous foe,</line>
      <line>The dreariest and the longest journey go.</line>
      <line>True love in this differs from gold and clay,</line>
      <line>That to divide is not to take away.</line>
      <line>Love is like understanding, that grows bright</line>
      <line>Gazing on many truths; ’tis like thy light,</line>
      <line>Imagination! which from earth and sky,</line>
      <line> And from the depths of human fantasy,</line>
      <line>As from a thousand prisms and mirrors, fills</line>
      <line>The universe with glorious beams, and kills</line>
      <line>Error, the worm, with many a sun-like arrow</line>
      <line>Of its reverberated lightning. Narrow</line>
      <line>The heart that loves, the brain that contemplates,</line>
      <line>The life that wears, the spirit that creates</line>
      <line>One object and one form, and builds thereby</line>
      <line>A sepulchre for its eternity.</line>
      <line>Mind from its object differs most in this:</line>
      <line> Evil from good; misery from happiness;</line>
      <line>The baser from the nobler; the impure</line>
      <line>And frail, from what is clear and must endure.</line>
      <line>If you divide suffering and dross, you may</line>
      <line>Diminish till it is consumed away;</line>
      <line>If you divide pleasure and love and thought,</line>
      <line>Each part exceeds the whole; and we know not</line>
      <line>How much, while any yet remains unshared,</line>
      <line>Of pleasure may be gained, of sorrow spared.</line>
      <line>This truth is that deep well, whence sages draw</line>
      <line> The unenvied light of hope; the eternal law</line>
      <line>By which those live, to whom this world of life</line>
      <line>Is as a garden ravaged, and whose strife</line>
      <line>Tills for the promise of a later birth</line>
      <line>The wilderness of this Elysian earth.</line>
      <line>There was a being whom my spirit oft</line>
      <line>Met on its visioned wanderings, far aloft,</line>
      <line>In the clear golden prime of my youth’s dawn,</line>
      <line>Upon the fairy isles of sunny lawn,</line>
      <line>Amid the enchanted mountains and the caves</line>
      <line> Of divine sleep, and on the air-like waves</line>
      <line>Of wonder-level dream, whose tremulous floor</line>
      <line>Paved her light steps. On an imagined shore,</line>
      <line>Under the gray beak of some promontory,</line>
      <line>She met me, robed in such exceeding glory,</line>
      <line>That I beheld her not. In solitudes</line>
      <line>Her voice came to me through the whispering woods,</line>
      <line>And from the fountains, and the odours deep</line>
      <line>Of flowers, which, like lips murmuring in their sleep</line>
      <line>Of the sweet kisses which had lulled them there,</line>
      <line>Breathed but of her to the enamoured air;</line>
      <line>And from the breezes whether low or loud,</line>
      <line>And from the rain of every passing cloud,</line>
      <line>And from the singing of the summer-birds,</line>
      <line>And from all sounds, all silence. In the words</line>
      <line>Of antique verse and high romance – in form,</line>
      <line>Sound, colour – in whatever checks that storm</line>
      <line>Which with the shattered present chokes the past;</line>
      <line>And in that best philosophy, whose taste</line>
      <line>Makes this cold common Hell, our life, a doom</line>
      <line> As glorious as a fiery martyrdom;</line>
      <line>Her spirit was the harmony of truth.</line>
      <line>Then, from the caverns of my dreamy youth</line>
      <line>I sprang, as one sandalled with plumes of fire,</line>
      <line>And towards the lodestar of my one desire,</line>
      <line>I flitted, like a dizzy moth, whose flight</line>
      <line>Is as a dead leaf’s in the owlet-light,</line>
      <line>When it would seek in Hesper’s setting sphere</line>
      <line>A radiant death, a fiery sepulchre,</line>
      <line>As if it were a lamp of earthly flame.</line>
      <line> But she, whom prayers or tears then could not tame,</line>
      <line>Passed, like a god throned on a wingéd planet</line>
      <line>Whose burning plumes to tenfold swiftness fan it,</line>
      <line>Into the dreary cone of our life’s shade;</line>
      <line>And as a man with mighty loss dismayed,</line>
      <line>I would have followed, though the grave between</line>
      <line>Yawned like a gulf whose spectres are unseen –</line>
      <line>When a voice said: ‘Oh thou of hearts the weakest,</line>
      <line>The phantom is beside thee whom thou seekest.’</line>
      <line>Then I – ‘Where?’ The world’s echo answered ‘where?’</line>
      <line> And in that silence, and in my despair,</line>
      <line>I questioned every tongueless wind that flew</line>
      <line>Over my tower of mourning, if it knew</line>
      <line>Whither ’twas fled, this soul out of my soul;</line>
      <line>And murmured names and spells which have control</line>
      <line>Over the sightless tyrants of our fate;</line>
      <line>But neither prayer nor verse could dissipate</line>
      <line>The night which closed on her; nor uncreate</line>
      <line>That world within this chaos, mine and me,</line>
      <line>Of which she was the veiled divinity –</line>
      <line> The world I say of thoughts that worshipped her.</line>
      <line>And therefore I went forth, with hope and fear</line>
      <line>And every gentle passion sick to death,</line>
      <line>Feeding my course with expectation’s breath,</line>
      <line>Into the wintry forest of our life.</line>
      <line>And struggling through its error with vain strife,</line>
      <line>And stumbling in my weakness and my haste,</line>
      <line>And half bewildered by new forms, I passed,</line>
      <line>Seeking among those untaught foresters</line>
      <line>If I could find one form resembling hers,</line>
      <line> In which she might have masked herself from me.</line>
      <line>There, one whose voice was venomed melody</line>
      <line>Sat by a well, under blue nightshade bowers;</line>
      <line>The breath of her false mouth was like faint flowers,</line>
      <line>Her touch was as electric poison – flame</line>
      <line>Out of her looks into my vitals came,</line>
      <line>And from her living cheeks and bosom flew</line>
      <line>A killing air, which pierced like honey-dew</line>
      <line>Into the core of my green heart, and lay</line>
      <line>Upon its leaves; until, as hair grown gray</line>
      <line> O’er a young brow, they hid its unblown prime</line>
      <line>With ruins of unseasonable time.</line>
      <line>In many mortal forms I rashly sought</line>
      <line>The shadow of that idol of my thought.</line>
      <line>And some were fair – but beauty dies away;</line>
      <line>Others were wise – but honeyed words betray;</line>
      <line>And one was true – oh! why not true to me?</line>
      <line>Then, as a hunted deer that could not flee,</line>
      <line>I turned upon my thoughts, and stood at bay,</line>
      <line>Wounded and weak and panting. The cold day</line>
      <line> Trembled, for pity of my strife and pain –</line>
      <line>When, like a noonday dawn, there shone again</line>
      <line>Deliverance! One stood on my path who seemed</line>
      <line>As like the glorious shape which I had dreamed</line>
      <line>As is the Moon (whose changes ever run</line>
      <line>Into themselves) to the eternal Sun,</line>
      <line>The cold chaste Moon, the Queen of Heaven’s bright isles,</line>
      <line>Who makes all beautiful on which she smiles –</line>
      <line>That wandering shrine of soft yet icy flame</line>
      <line>Which ever is transformed, yet still the same,</line>
      <line> And warms not but illumines. Young and fair</line>
      <line>As the descended spirit of that sphere,</line>
      <line>She hid me, as the Moon may hide the night</line>
      <line>From its own darkness, until all was bright</line>
      <line>Between the heaven and earth of my calm mind,</line>
      <line>And, as a cloud charioted by the wind,</line>
      <line>She led me to a cave in that wild place,</line>
      <line>And sat beside me, with her downward face</line>
      <line>Illumining my slumbers, like the Moon</line>
      <line>Waxing and waning o’er Endymion.</line>
      <line> And I was laid asleep, spirit and limb,</line>
      <line>And all my being became bright or dim</line>
      <line>As the Moon’s image in a summer sea,</line>
      <line>According as she smiled or frowned on me –</line>
      <line>And there I lay, within a chaste cold bed.</line>
      <line>Alas, I then was nor alive nor dead –</line>
      <line>For at her silver voice came Death and Life,</line>
      <line>Unmindful each of their accustomed strife,</line>
      <line>Masked like twin babes, a sister and a brother,</line>
      <line>The wandering hopes of one abandoned mother,</line>
      <line>And through the cavern without wings they flew,</line>
      <line>And cried, ‘Away, he is not of our crew!’</line>
      <line>I wept, and though it be a dream, I weep.</line>
      <line>What storms then shook the ocean of my sleep,</line>
      <line>Blotting that Moon, whose pale and waning lips</line>
      <line>Then shrank as in the sickness of eclipse;</line>
      <line>And how my soul was as a lampless sea,</line>
      <line>And who was then its Tempest; and when she,</line>
      <line>The Planet of that hour, was quenched, what frost</line>
      <line>Crept o’er those waters, till from coast to coast</line>
      <line> The moving billows of my being fell</line>
      <line>Into a death of ice, immovable;</line>
      <line>And then, what earthquakes made it gape and split,</line>
      <line>(The white Moon smiling all the while on it)</line>
      <line>These words conceal – if not, each word would be</line>
      <line>The key of staunchless tears. Weep not for me!</line>
      <line>At length, into the obscure forest came</line>
      <line>The Vision I had sought through grief and shame.</line>
      <line>Athwart that wintry wilderness of thorns</line>
      <line>Flashed from her motion splendour like the morn’s,</line>
      <line> And from her presence life was radiated</line>
      <line>Through the gray earth and branches bare and dead,</line>
      <line>So that her way was paved, and roofed above</line>
      <line>With flowers as soft as thoughts of budding love,</line>
      <line>And music from her respiration spread</line>
      <line>Like light. All other sounds were penetrated</line>
      <line>By the small, still, sweet spirit of that sound,</line>
      <line>So that the savage winds hung mute around;</line>
      <line>And odours warm and fresh fell from her hair</line>
      <line>Dissolving the dull cold in the frore air.</line>
      <line> Soft as an incarnation of the sun,</line>
      <line>When light is changed to love, this glorious one</line>
      <line>Floated into the cavern where I lay,</line>
      <line>And called my spirit, and the dreaming clay</line>
      <line>Was lifted by the thing that dreamed below</line>
      <line>As smoke by fire, and in her beauty’s glow</line>
      <line>I stood, and felt the dawn of my long night</line>
      <line>Was penetrating me with living light:</line>
      <line>I knew it was the Vision veiled from me</line>
      <line>So many years – that it was Emily.</line>
      <line> Twin spheres of light who rule this passive earth,</line>
      <line>This world of love, this me, and into birth</line>
      <line>Awaken all its fruits and flowers, and dart</line>
      <line>Magnetic might into its central heart;</line>
      <line>And lift its billows and its mists, and guide</line>
      <line>By everlasting laws, each wind and tide</line>
      <line>To its fit cloud, and its appointed cave;</line>
      <line>And lull its storms, each in the craggy grave</line>
      <line>Which was its cradle, luring to faint bowers</line>
      <line>The armies of the rainbow-wingéd showers;</line>
      <line> And, as those married lights, which from the towers</line>
      <line>Of heaven look forth and fold the wandering globe</line>
      <line>In liquid sleep and splendour, as a robe,</line>
      <line>And all their many-mingled influence blend,</line>
      <line>(If equal, yet unlike) to one sweet end –</line>
      <line>So ye, bright regents, with alternate sway</line>
      <line>Govern my sphere of being, night and day!</line>
      <line>Thou, not disdaining even a borrowed might;</line>
      <line>Thou, not eclipsing a remoter light;</line>
      <line>And, through the shadow of the seasons three,</line>
      <line> From spring to autumn’s sere maturity,</line>
      <line>Light it into the winter of the tomb,</line>
      <line>Where it may ripen to a brighter bloom.</line>
      <line>Thou too, oh Comet beautiful and fierce,</line>
      <line>Who drew the heart of this frail universe</line>
      <line>Towards thine own, till, wrecked in that convulsion,</line>
      <line>Alternating attraction and repulsion,</line>
      <line>Thine went astray and that was rent in twain,</line>
      <line>Oh, float into our azure heaven again!</line>
      <line>Be there love’s folding-star at thy return;</line>
      <line> The living sun will feed thee from its urn</line>
      <line>Of golden fire; the moon will veil her horn</line>
      <line>In thy last smiles; adoring even and morn</line>
      <line>Will worship thee with incense of calm breath</line>
      <line>And lights and shadows. As the star of death</line>
      <line>And birth is worshipped by those sisters wild</line>
      <line>Called Hope and Fear – upon the heart are piled</line>
      <line>Their offerings – of this sacrifice divine</line>
      <line>A world shall be the altar.</line>
      <line>Lady mine,</line>
      <line>Scorn not these flowers of thought, the fading birth</line>
      <line> Which from its heart of hearts that plant puts forth</line>
      <line>Whose fruit, made perfect by thy sunny eyes,</line>
      <line>Will be as of the trees of Paradise.</line>
      <line>The day is come, and thou wilt fly with me.</line>
      <line>To whatsoe’er of dull mortality</line>
      <line>Is mine, remain a vestal sister still;</line>
      <line>To the intense, the deep, the imperishable,</line>
      <line>Not mine but me, henceforth be thou united</line>
      <line>Even as a bride, delighting and delighted.</line>
      <line>The hour is come – the destined star has risen</line>
      <line> Which shall descend upon a vacant prison.</line>
      <line>The walls are high, the gates are strong, thick set</line>
      <line>The sentinels – but true love never yet</line>
      <line>Was thus constrained. It overleaps all fence –</line>
      <line>Like lightning, with invisible violence</line>
      <line>Piercing its continents; like Heaven’s free breath,</line>
      <line>Which he who grasps can hold not; like Death,</line>
      <line>Who rides upon a thought, and makes his way</line>
      <line>Through temple, tower, and palace, and the array</line>
      <line>Of arms. More strength has love than he or they;</line>
      <line>For it can burst his charnel, and make free</line>
      <line>The limbs in chains, the heart in agony,</line>
      <line>The soul in dust and chaos.</line>
      <line>Emily,</line>
      <line>A ship is floating in the harbour now,</line>
      <line>A wind is hovering o’er the mountain’s brow;</line>
      <line>There is a path on the sea’s azure floor –</line>
      <line>No keel has ever ploughed that path before!</line>
      <line>The halcyons brood around the foamless isles;</line>
      <line>The treacherous ocean has forsworn its wiles;</line>
      <line>The merry mariners are bold and free –</line>
      <line> Say, my heart’s sister, wilt thou sail with me?</line>
      <line>Our bark is as an albatross, whose nest</line>
      <line>Is a far Eden of the purple east;</line>
      <line>And we between her wings will sit, while night,</line>
      <line>And day, and storm, and calm, pursue their flight,</line>
      <line>Our ministers, along the boundless sea,</line>
      <line>Treading each other’s heels, unheededly.</line>
      <line>It is an isle under Ionian skies,</line>
      <line>Beautiful as a wreck of Paradise,</line>
