      <line>And, for the harbours are not safe and good,</line>
      <line> This land would have remained a solitude</line>
      <line>But for some pastoral people native there,</line>
      <line>Who from the Elysian, clear, and golden air</line>
      <line>Draw the last spirit of the age of gold,</line>
      <line>Simple and spirited, innocent and bold.</line>
      <line>The blue Aegean girds this chosen home,</line>
      <line>With ever-changing sound and light and foam,</line>
      <line>Kissing the sifted sands, and caverns hoar –</line>
      <line>And all the winds wandering along the shore</line>
      <line>Undulate with the undulating tide.</line>
      <line> There are thick woods where sylvan forms abide;</line>
      <line>And many a fountain, rivulet, and pond,</line>
      <line>As clear as elemental diamond,</line>
      <line>Or serene morning air; and, far beyond,</line>
      <line>The mossy tracks made by the goats and deer</line>
      <line>(Which the rough shepherd treads but once a year)</line>
      <line>Pierce into glades, caverns, and bowers, and halls</line>
      <line>Built round with ivy, which, the waterfalls</line>
      <line>Illumining, with sound that never fails</line>
      <line>Accompany the noonday nightingales,</line>
      <line> And all the place is peopled with sweet airs.</line>
      <line>The light clear element which the isle wears</line>
      <line>Is heavy with the scent of lemon-flowers,</line>
      <line>Which floats like mist, laden with unseen showers,</line>
      <line>And falls upon the eyelids like faint sleep;</line>
      <line>And from the moss violets and jonquils peep,</line>
      <line>And dart their arrowy odour through the brain</line>
      <line>Till you might faint with that delicious pain.</line>
      <line>And every motion, odour, beam, and tone,</line>
      <line>With that deep music is in unison</line>
      <line> Which is a soul within the soul – they seem</line>
      <line>Like echoes of an antenatal dream.</line>
      <line>It is an isle ’twixt heaven, air, earth, and sea,</line>
      <line>Cradled, and hung in clear tranquillity;</line>
      <line>Bright as that wandering Eden, Lucifer,</line>
      <line>Washed by the soft blue oceans of young air.</line>
      <line>It is a favoured place. Famine or blight,</line>
      <line>Pestilence, war and earthquake, never light</line>
      <line>Upon its mountain-peaks – blind vultures, they</line>
      <line>Sail onward far upon their fatal way!</line>
      <line> The wingéd storms, chanting their thunder-psalm</line>
      <line>To other lands, leave azure chasms of calm</line>
      <line>Over this isle, or weep themselves in dew,</line>
      <line>From which its fields and woods ever renew</line>
      <line>Their green and golden immortality.</line>
      <line>And from the sea there rise, and from the sky</line>
      <line>There fall, clear exhalations, soft and bright,</line>
      <line>Veil after veil, each hiding some delight,</line>
      <line>Which sun or moon or zephyr draw aside,</line>
      <line>Till the isle’s beauty, like a naked bride</line>
      <line> Glowing at once with love and loveliness,</line>
      <line>Blushes and trembles at its own excess!</line>
      <line>Yet, like a buried lamp, a soul no less</line>
      <line>Burns in the heart of this delicious isle,</line>
      <line>An atom of the Eternal, whose own smile</line>
      <line>Unfolds itself, and may be felt, not seen</line>
      <line>O’er the gray rocks, blue waves, and forests green,</line>
      <line>Filling their bare and void interstices.</line>
      <line>But the chief marvel of the wilderness</line>
      <line>Is a lone dwelling, built by whom or how</line>
      <line> None of the rustic island-people know:</line>
      <line>’Tis not a tower of strength, though with its height</line>
      <line>It overtops the woods; but, for delight,</line>
      <line>Some wise and tender ocean-king, ere crime</line>
      <line>Had been invented, in the world’s young prime,</line>
      <line>Reared it, a wonder of that simple time,</line>
      <line>An envy of the isles, a pleasure-house</line>
      <line>Made sacred to his sister and his spouse.</line>
      <line>It scarce seems now a wreck of human art,</line>
      <line>But, as it were titanic; in the heart</line>
      <line> Of earth having assumed its form, then grown</line>
      <line>Out of the mountains, from the living stone,</line>
      <line>Lifting itself in caverns light and high –</line>
      <line>For all the antique and learnéd imagery</line>
      <line>Has been erased, and in the place of it</line>
      <line>The ivy and the wild-vine interknit</line>
      <line>The volumes of their many-twining stems.</line>
      <line>Parasite flowers illume with dewy gems</line>
      <line>The lampless halls, and when they fade, the sky</line>
      <line>Peeps through their winter-woof of tracery</line>
      <line>With moonlight patches, or star atoms keen,</line>
      <line>Or fragments of the day’s intense serene,</line>
      <line>Working mosaic on their Parian floors.</line>
      <line>And, day and night, aloof, from the high towers</line>
      <line>And terraces, the earth and ocean seem</line>
      <line>To sleep in one another’s arms, and dream</line>
      <line>Of waves, flowers, clouds, woods, rocks, and all that we</line>
      <line>Read in their smiles, and call reality.</line>
      <line>This isle and house are mine, and I have vowed</line>
      <line>Thee to be lady of the solitude –</line>
      <line> And I have fitted up some chambers there</line>
      <line>Looking towards the golden eastern air,</line>
      <line>And level with the living winds, which flow</line>
      <line>Like waves above the living waves below.</line>
      <line>I have sent books and music there, and all</line>
      <line>Those instruments with which high spirits call</line>
      <line>The future from its cradle, and the past</line>
      <line>Out of its grave, and make the present last</line>
      <line>In thoughts and joys which sleep, but cannot die,</line>
      <line>Folded within their own eternity.</line>
      <line> Our simple life wants little, and true taste</line>
      <line>Hires not the pale drudge, luxury, to waste</line>
      <line>The scene it would adorn – and therefore, still,</line>
      <line>Nature with all her children haunts the hill.</line>
      <line>The ring-dove, in the embowering ivy, yet</line>
      <line>Keeps up her love-lament, and the owls flit</line>
      <line>Round the evening tower, and the young stars glance</line>
      <line>Between the quick bats in their twilight dance;</line>
      <line>The spotted deer bask in the fresh moonlight</line>
      <line>Before our gate, and the slow, silent night</line>
      <line> Is measured by the pants of their calm sleep.</line>
      <line>Be this our home in life, and when years heap</line>
      <line>Their withered hours, like leaves, on our decay,</line>
      <line>Let us become the overhanging day,</line>
      <line>The living soul of this Elysian isle,</line>
      <line>Conscious, inseparable, one.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile</line>
      <line>We two will rise, and sit, and walk together,</line>
      <line>Under the roof of blue Ionian weather,</line>
      <line>And wander in the meadows, or ascend</line>
      <line>The mossy mountains, where the blue heavens bend</line>
      <line> With lightest winds, to touch their paramour;</line>
      <line>Or linger where the pebble-paven shore,</line>
      <line>Under the quick, faint kisses of the sea</line>
      <line>Trembles and sparkles as with ecstasy,</line>
      <line>Possessing and possessed by all that is</line>
      <line>Within that calm circumference of bliss,</line>
      <line>And by each other, till to love and live</line>
      <line>Be one; or, at the noontide hour, arrive</line>
      <line>Where some old cavern hoar seems yet to keep</line>
      <line>The moonlight of the expiréd night asleep,</line>
      <line> Through which the awakened day can never peep –</line>
      <line>A veil for our seclusion, close as night’s,</line>
      <line>Where secure sleep may kill thine innocent lights –</line>
      <line>Sleep, the fresh dew of languid love, the rain</line>
      <line>Whose drops quench kisses till they burn again!</line>
      <line>And we will talk, until thought’s melody</line>
      <line>Become too sweet for utterance, and it die</line>
      <line>In words, to live again in looks, which dart</line>
      <line>With thrilling tone into the voiceless heart,</line>
      <line>Harmonizing silence without a sound.</line>
      <line> Our breath shall intermix, our bosoms bound,</line>
      <line>And our veins beat together, and our lips</line>
      <line>With other eloquence than words eclipse</line>
      <line>The soul that burns between them – and the wells</line>
      <line>Which boil under our being’s inmost cells,</line>
      <line>The fountains of our deepest life, shall be</line>
      <line>Confused in passion’s golden purity,</line>
      <line>As mountain-springs under the morning sun.</line>
      <line>We shall become the same, we shall be one</line>
      <line>Spirit within two frames! – oh, wherefore two? –</line>
      <line> One passion in twin-hearts, which grows and grew,</line>
      <line>Till like two meteors of expanding flame,</line>
      <line>Those spheres instinct with it become the same,</line>
      <line>Touch, mingle, are transfigured – ever still</line>
      <line>Burning, yet ever inconsumable;</line>
      <line>In one another’s substance finding food,</line>
      <line>Like flames too pure and light and unimbued</line>
      <line>To nourish their bright lives with baser prey,</line>
      <line>Which point to Heaven and cannot pass away:</line>
      <line>One hope within two wills, one will beneath</line>
      <line> Two overshadowing minds, one life, one death,</line>
      <line>One Heaven, one Hell, one immortality,</line>
      <line>And one annihilation. Woe is me!</line>
      <line>The wingéd words on which my soul would pierce</line>
      <line>Into the height of love’s rare universe,</line>
      <line>Are chains of lead around its flight of fire –</line>
      <line>I pant, I sink, I tremble, I expire!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Weak verses, go, kneel at your Sovereign’s feet,</line>
      <line>And say: ‘We are the masters of thy slave;</line>
      <line>What wouldést thou with us and ours and thine?’</line>
      <line> Then call your sisters from oblivion’s cave,</line>
      <line>All singing loud: ‘Love’s very pain is sweet,</line>
      <line>But its reward is in the world divine</line>
      <line>Which, if not here, it builds beyond the grave.</line>
      <line>So shall ye live when I am there. Then haste</line>
      <line>Over the hearts of men, until ye meet</line>
      <line>Marina, Vanna, Primus and the rest,</line>
      <line>And bid them love each other and be blest:</line>
      <line>And leave the troop which errs, and which reproves,</line>
      <line>And come and be my guest – for I am Love’s!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY and Jane Williams</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>To Jane with a Guitar</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ariel to Miranda – Take</line>
      <line>This slave of music for the sake</line>
      <line>Of him who is the slave of thee,</line>
      <line>And teach it all the harmony</line>
      <line> In which thou canst, and only thou,</line>
      <line>Make the delighted spirit glow</line>
      <line>Till joy denies itself again</line>
      <line>And, too intense, is turned to pain –</line>
      <line>For by permission and command</line>
      <line>Of thine own Prince Ferdinand</line>
      <line>Poor Ariel sends this silent token</line>
      <line>Of more than ever can be spoken –</line>
      <line>Your guardian-spirit Ariel, who</line>
      <line>From life to life must still pursue</line>
      <line> Your happiness, for thus alone</line>
      <line>Can Ariel ever find his own.</line>
      <line>From Prospero’s enchanted cell,</line>
      <line>As the mighty verses tell,</line>
      <line>To the throne of Naples he</line>
      <line>Lit you o’er the trackless sea,</line>
      <line>Flitting on, your prow before,</line>
      <line>Like a living meteor.</line>
      <line>When you die, the silent Moon</line>
      <line>In her interlunar swoon</line>
      <line> Is not sadder in her cell</line>
      <line>Than deserted Ariel:</line>
      <line>When you live again on Earth,</line>
      <line>Like an unseen star of birth</line>
      <line>Ariel guides you o’er the sea</line>
      <line>Of life from your nativity!</line>
      <line>Many changes have been rung</line>
      <line>Since Ferdinand and you begun</line>
      <line>Your course of love, and Ariel still</line>
      <line>Has tracked your steps and served your will.</line>
      <line> Now, in a humbler, happier lot,</line>
      <line>This is all remembered not,</line>
      <line>And now, alas, the poor sprite is</line>
      <line>Imprisoned for some fault of his</line>
      <line>In a body like a grave –</line>
      <line>From you he only dares to crave</line>
      <line>For his service and his sorrow</line>
      <line>A smile today, a song tomorrow!</line>
      <line>The artist who this idol wrought</line>
      <line>To echo all harmonious thought</line>
      <line> Felled a tree, while on the steep</line>
      <line>The woods were in their winter sleep,</line>
      <line>Rocked in that repose divine</line>
      <line>On the wind-swept Apennine</line>
      <line>(And dreaming, some, of autumn past,</line>
      <line>And some of spring approaching fast,</line>
      <line>And some of April buds and showers,</line>
      <line>And some of songs in July bowers,</line>
      <line>And all, of love), and so this tree –</line>
      <line>Oh that such our death may be! –</line>
      <line> Died in sleep, and felt no pain,</line>
      <line>To live in happier form again,</line>
      <line>From which, beneath heaven’s fairest star,</line>
      <line>The artist wrought this loved guitar,</line>
      <line>And taught it justly to reply</line>
      <line>To all who question skilfully</line>
      <line>In language gentle as their own,</line>
      <line>Whispering in enamoured tone</line>
      <line>Sweet oracles of woods and dells</line>
      <line>And summer-winds in sylvan cells –</line>
      <line> For it had learnt all harmonies</line>
      <line>Of the plains and of the skies,</line>
      <line>Of the forests and the mountains,</line>
      <line>And the many-voicéd fountains:</line>
      <line>The clearest echoes of the hills,</line>
      <line>The softest notes of falling rills,</line>
      <line>The melodies of birds and bees,</line>
      <line>The murmuring of summer-seas,</line>
      <line>And pattering rain, and breathing dew,</line>
      <line>And airs of evening.</line>
      <line>And it knew</line>
      <line> That seldom-heard mysterious sound,</line>
      <line>Which, driven, on its diurnal round</line>
      <line>As it floats through boundless day,</line>
      <line>Our world enkindles on its way –</line>
      <line>All this it knows, but will not tell</line>
      <line>To those who cannot question well</line>
      <line>The spirit that inhabits it.</line>
      <line>It talks according to the wit</line>
      <line>Of its companions, and no more</line>
      <line>Is heard than has been felt before</line>
      <line> By those who tempt it to betray</line>
      <line>These secrets of an elder day –</line>
      <line>But sweetly, as it answers, will</line>
      <line>Flatter hands of perfect skill:</line>
      <line>It keeps its highest holiest tone</line>
      <line>For our belovéd Jane alone!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY and Jane Williams</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>To Jane: The Stars Were Twinkling</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The keen stars were twinkling</line>
      <line>And the fair moon was rising among them,</line>
      <line>Dear Jane –</line>
      <line>The guitar was tinkling</line>
      <line> But the notes were not sweet till you sung them</line>
      <line>Again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As the moon’s soft splendour</line>
      <line>O’er the faint cold starlight of heaven</line>
      <line>Is thrown,</line>
      <line>So your voice most tender</line>
      <line>To the strings without soul had then given</line>
      <line>Its own.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The stars will awaken,</line>
      <line>Though the moon sleep a full hour later</line>
      <line> Tonight –</line>
      <line>No leaf will be shaken</line>
      <line>While the dews of your melody scatter</line>
      <line>Delight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the sound overpowers</line>
      <line>Sing again, with your dear voice revealing</line>
      <line>A tone</line>
      <line>Of some world far from ours</line>
      <line>Where music and moonlight and feeling</line>
      <line>Are one.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON and Lady Frances Webster</author>
    <date>1815</date>
    <title>When We Two Parted</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When we two parted</line>
      <line>In silence and tears,</line>
      <line>Half broken-hearted,</line>
      <line>To sever for years,</line>
      <line> Pale grew thy cheek and cold,</line>
      <line>Colder thy kiss –</line>
      <line>Truly that hour foretold</line>
      <line>Sorrow to this!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dew of the morning</line>
      <line>Sunk chill on my brow,</line>
      <line>It felt like the warning</line>
      <line>Of what I feel now.</line>
      <line>Thy vows are all broken,</line>
      <line>And light is thy fame:</line>
      <line> I hear thy name spoken,</line>
      <line>And share in its shame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They name thee before me,</line>
      <line>A knell in mine ear,</line>
      <line>A shudder comes o’er me –</line>
      <line>Why wert thou so dear?</line>
      <line>They know not I knew thee,</line>
      <line>Who knew thee too well:</line>
      <line>Long, long shall I rue thee,</line>
      <line>Too deeply to tell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> In secret we met –</line>
      <line>In silence I grieve</line>
      <line>That thy heart could forget,</line>
      <line>Thy spirit deceive!</line>
      <line>If I should meet thee</line>
      <line>After long years,</line>
      <line>How should I greet thee?</line>
      <line>With silence and tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON and Lady Byron</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Fare Thee Well</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fare thee well! and if for ever,</line>
      <line>Still for ever, fare thee well!</line>
      <line>E’en though unforgiving, never</line>
      <line>’Gainst thee shall my heart rebel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Would that breast were bared before thee</line>
      <line>Where thy head so oft hath lain,</line>
      <line>While that placid sleep came o’er thee</line>
      <line>Which thou ne’er canst know again –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Would that breast, by thee glanced over,</line>
      <line>Every inmost thought could show!</line>
      <line>Then thou wouldst at last discover</line>
      <line>’Twas not well to spurn it so.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the world for this commend thee,</line>
      <line>Though it smile upon the blow,</line>
      <line> Even its praises must offend thee,</line>
      <line>Founded on another’s woe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though my many faults defaced me,</line>
      <line>Could no other arm be found</line>
      <line>Than the one which once embraced me,</line>
      <line>To inflict a cureless wound?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet, oh yet, thyself deceive not –</line>
      <line>Love may sink by slow decay,</line>
      <line>But by sudden wrench, believe not</line>
      <line>Hearts can thus be torn away!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Still thine own its life retaineth –</line>
      <line>Still must mine, though bleeding, beat!</line>
      <line>And the undying thought which paineth</line>
      <line>Is – that we no more may meet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>These are words of deeper sorrow</line>
      <line>Than the wail above the dead:</line>
      <line>Both shall live – but every morrow</line>
      <line>Wake us from a widowed bed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when thou wouldst solace gather,</line>
      <line>When our child’s first accents flow,</line>
      <line> Wilt thou teach her to say ‘Father!’</line>
      <line>Though his care she must forego?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When her little hands shall press thee,</line>
      <line>When her lip to thine is prest,</line>
      <line>Think of him whose prayer shall bless thee –</line>
      <line>Think of him thy love had blest!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Should her lineaments resemble</line>
      <line>Those thou never more mayst see,</line>
      <line>Then thy heart will softly tremble</line>
      <line>With a pulse yet true to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> All my faults perchance thou knowest,</line>
      <line>All my madness, none can know,</line>
      <line>All my hopes (where’er thou goest)</line>
      <line>Wither – yet with thee they go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Every feeling hath been shaken!</line>
      <line>Pride – which not a world could bow –</line>
      <line>Bows to thee! By thee forsaken,</line>
      <line>Even my soul forsakes me now.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But ’tis done – all words are idle –</line>
      <line>Words from me are vainer still!</line>
      <line> But the thoughts we cannot bridle</line>
      <line>Force their way without the will.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fare thee well! thus disunited,</line>
      <line>Torn from every nearer tie,</line>
      <line>Seared in heart – and lone – and blighted,</line>
      <line>More than this I scarce can die.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON and Augusta Leigh</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Stanzas to Augusta</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When all around grew drear and dark,</line>
      <line>And reason half withheld her ray,</line>
      <line>And hope but shed a dying spark</line>
      <line>Which more misled my lonely way –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> In that deep midnight of the mind,</line>
      <line>And that internal strife of heart,</line>
      <line>When, dreading to be deemed too kind,</line>
      <line>The weak despair – the cold depart!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When Fortune changed, and Love fled far,</line>
      <line>And Hatred’s shafts flew thick and fast,</line>
      <line>Thou wert the solitary star</line>
      <line>Which rose and set not to the last.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, blest be thine unbroken light!</line>
      <line>That watched me as a seraph’s eye,</line>
      <line> And stood between me and the night,</line>
      <line>For ever shining sweetly nigh.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the cloud upon us came,</line>
      <line>Which strove to blacken o’er thy ray –</line>
      <line>Then purer spread its gentle flame,</line>
      <line>And dashed the darkness all away!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still may thy spirit dwell on mine,</line>
      <line>And teach it what to brave or brook:</line>
      <line>There’s more in one soft word of thine</line>
      <line>Than in the world’s defied rebuke.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thou stoodst as stands a lovely tree,</line>
      <line>That still unbroke, though gently bent,</line>
      <line>Still waves with fond fidelity</line>
      <line>Its boughs above a monument.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The winds might rend, the skies might pour,</line>
      <line>But there thou wert – and still wouldst be</line>
      <line>Devoted in the stormiest hour</line>
      <line>To shed thy weeping leaves o’er me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But thou and thine shall know no blight,</line>
      <line>Whatever fate on me may fall;</line>
      <line> For Heaven in sunshine will requite</line>
      <line>The kind – and thee the most of all!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then let the ties of baffled love</line>
      <line>Be broken – thine will never break!</line>
      <line>Thy heart can feel, but will not move;</line>
      <line>Thy soul, though soft, will never shake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And these, when all was lost beside,</line>
      <line>Were found and still are fixed, in thee –</line>
      <line>And bearing still a breast so tried,</line>
      <line>Earth is no desert – e’en to me!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON and Augusta Leigh</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>Stanzas to Augusta</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the day of my destiny’s over,</line>
      <line>And the star of my fate hath declined,</line>
      <line>Thy soft heart refused to discover</line>
      <line>The faults which so many could find;</line>
      <line> Though thy soul with my grief was acquainted,</line>
      <line>It shrunk not to share it with me,</line>
      <line>And the love which my spirit hath painted</line>
      <line>It never hath found but in thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then when Nature around me is smiling,</line>
      <line>The last smile which answers to mine,</line>
      <line>I do not believe it beguiling,</line>
      <line>Because it reminds me of thine;</line>
      <line>And when winds are at war with the ocean,</line>
      <line>As the breasts I believed in with me,</line>
      <line> If their billows excite an emotion,</line>
      <line>It is that they bear me from thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the rock of my last hope is shivered,</line>
      <line>And its fragments are sunk in the wave,</line>
      <line>Though I feel that my soul is delivered</line>
      <line>To pain – it shall not be its slave!</line>
      <line>There is many a pang to pursue me</line>
      <line>(They may crush, but they shall not contemn),</line>
      <line>They may torture, but shall not subdue me –</line>
      <line>’Tis of thee that I think – not of them!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Though human, thou didst not deceive me,</line>
      <line>Though woman, thou didst not forsake,</line>
      <line>Though loved, thou forborest to grieve me,</line>
      <line>Though slandered, thou never couldst shake;</line>
      <line>Though trusted, thou didst not disclaim me,</line>
      <line>Though parted, it was not to fly,</line>
      <line>Though watchful, ’twas not to defame me,</line>
      <line>Nor, mute, that the world might belie!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet I blame not the world, nor despise it,</line>
      <line>Nor the war of the many with one;</line>
      <line> If my soul was not fitted to prize it,</line>
      <line>’Twas folly not sooner to shun –</line>
      <line>And if dearly that error hath cost me,</line>
      <line>And more than I once could foresee,</line>
      <line>I have found that, whatever it lost me,</line>
      <line>It could not deprive me of thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From the wreck of the past, which hath perished,</line>
      <line>Thus much I at least may recall,</line>
      <line>It hath taught me that what I most cherished</line>
      <line>Deserved to be dearest of all:</line>
      <line> In the desert a fountain is springing,</line>
      <line>In the wide waste there still is a tree,</line>
      <line>And a bird in the solitude singing,</line>
      <line>Which speaks to my spirit of thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON and the Countess Guiccioli</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>Stanzas to the River Po</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>River, that rollest by the ancient walls</line>
      <line>Where dwells the lady of my love, when she</line>
      <line>Walks by thy brink, and there perchance recalls</line>
      <line>A faint and fleeting memory of me,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> What if thy deep and ample stream should be</line>
      <line>A mirror of my heart, where she may read</line>
      <line>The thousand thoughts I now betray to thee,</line>
      <line>Wild as the wave, and headlong as thy speed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What do I say – a mirror of my heart?</line>
      <line>Are not thy waters sweeping, dark and strong?</line>
      <line>Such as my feelings were, and are, thou art –</line>
      <line>And such as thou art were my passions long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Time may have somewhat tamed them – not for ever!</line>
      <line>Thou overflow’st thy banks, and not for aye</line>
      <line> Thy bosom overboils, congenial river!</line>
      <line>Thy floods subside, and mine have sunk away,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But left long wrecks behind – and now again,</line>
      <line>Borne in our old unchanged career, we move.</line>
      <line>Thou tendest wildly onwards to the main,</line>
      <line>And I – to loving one I should not love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The current I behold will sweep beneath</line>
      <line>Her native walls, and murmur at her feet;</line>
      <line>Her eyes will look on thee when she shall breathe</line>
      <line>The twilight air, unharmed by summer’s heat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> She will look on thee – I have looked on thee,</line>
      <line>Full of that thought! And from that moment, ne’er</line>
      <line>Thy waters could I dream of, name, or see,</line>
      <line>Without the inseparable sigh for her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her bright eyes will be imaged in thy stream –</line>
      <line>Yes, they will meet the wave I gaze on now –</line>
      <line>Mine cannot witness, even in a dream,</line>
      <line>That happy wave repass me in its flow!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wave that bears my tears returns no more –</line>
      <line>Will she return by whom that wave shall sweep?</line>
      <line> Both tread thy banks, both wander on thy shore:</line>
      <line>I by thy source, she by the dark-blue deep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But that which keepeth us apart is not</line>
      <line>Distance, nor depth of wave, nor space of earth,</line>
      <line>But the distraction of a various lot –</line>
      <line>As various as the climates of our birth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A stranger loves the lady of the land,</line>
      <line>Born far beyond the mountains, but his blood</line>
      <line>Is all meridian, as if never fanned</line>
      <line>By that black wind that chills the polar flood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> My blood is all meridian! Were it not,</line>
      <line>I had not left my clime, nor should I be,</line>
      <line>In spite of tortures ne’er to be forgot,</line>
      <line>A slave again of love – at least, of thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis vain to struggle – let me perish young –</line>
      <line>Live as I lived, and love as I have loved!</line>
      <line>To dust if I return, from dust I sprung –</line>
      <line>And then, at least my heart can ne’er be moved.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON and Loukas Chalandritsanos</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>I Watched Thee</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watched thee when the foe was at our side,</line>
      <line>Ready to strike at him – or thee and me,</line>
      <line>Were safety hopeless, rather than divide</line>
      <line>Aught with one loved, save love and liberty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> I watched thee on the breakers, when the rock</line>
      <line>Received our prow and all was storm and fear,</line>
      <line>And bade thee cling to me through every shock –</line>
      <line>This arm would be thy bark, or breast thy bier!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watched thee when the fever glazed thine eyes,</line>
      <line>Yielding my couch – and stretched me on the ground</line>
      <line>When overworn with watching, ne’er to rise</line>
      <line>From thence if thou an early grave hadst found.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The earthquake came, and rocked the quivering wall,</line>
      <line>And men and Nature reeled as if with wine –</line>
      <line> Whom did I seek around the tottering hall?</line>
      <line>For thee! Whose safety first provide for? Thine!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when convulsive throes denied my breath</line>
      <line>The faintest utterance to my fading thought,</line>
      <line>To thee – to thee – e’en in the gasp of death</line>
      <line>My spirit turned, oh! oftener than it ought!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus much and more – and yet thou lovst me not,</line>
      <line>And never wilt! Love dwells not in our will.</line>
      <line>Nor can I blame thee, though it be my lot</line>
      <line>To strongly, wrongly, vainly, love thee still.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS and Fanny Brawne</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>The Day Is Gone</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The day is gone, and all its sweets are gone!</line>
      <line>Sweet voice, sweet lips, soft hand, and softer breast,</line>
      <line>Warm breath, light whisper, tender semitone,</line>
      <line>Bright eyes, accomplished shape, and languorous waist!</line>
      <line> Faded the flower and all its budding charms,</line>
      <line>Faded the sight of beauty from my eyes,</line>
      <line>Faded the shape of beauty from my arms,</line>
      <line>Faded the voice, warmth, whiteness, paradise!</line>
      <line>Vanished unseasonably at shut of eve,</line>
      <line>When the dusk holiday, or holinight,</line>
      <line>Of fragrant-curtained love begins to weave</line>
      <line>The woof of darkness thick for hid delight –</line>
      <line>But as I’ve read Love’s missal through today,</line>
      <line>He’ll let me sleep, seeing I fast and pray.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS and Fanny Brawne</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>I Cry Your Mercy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cry your mercy, pity, love – aye love!</line>
      <line>Merciful love that tantalizes not,</line>
      <line>One-thoughted, never-wandering, guileless love,</line>
      <line>Unmasked, and, being seen, without a blot.</line>
      <line> Oh, let me have thee whole – all, all be mine!</line>
      <line>That shape, that fairness, that sweet minor zest</line>
      <line>Of love, your kiss – those hands, those eyes divine,</line>
      <line>That warm, white, lucent, million-pleasured breast –</line>
      <line>Yourself, your soul! In pity give me all!</line>
      <line>Withhold no atom’s atom, or I die–</line>
      <line>Or, living on perhaps, your wretched thrall,</line>
      <line>Forget, in the mist of idle misery,</line>
      <line>Life’s purposes – the palate of my mind</line>
      <line>Losing its gust, and my ambitions blind!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS and Fanny Brawne</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>Ode to Fanny</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Physician Nature, let my spirit blood!</line>
      <line>Oh ease my heart of verse and let me rest –</line>
      <line>Throw me upon thy tripod till the flood</line>
      <line>Of stifling numbers ebbs from my full breast!</line>
      <line> A theme, a theme – great Nature, give a theme!</line>
      <line>Let me begin my dream:</line>
      <line>I come. I see thee, as thou standest there,</line>
      <line>Beckon me out into the wintry air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah dearest love, sweet home of all my fears</line>
      <line>And hopes, and joys, and panting miseries,</line>
      <line>Tonight (if I may guess) thy beauty wears</line>
      <line>A smile of such delight,</line>
      <line>As brilliant and bright,</line>
      <line>As when, with ravished, aching, vassal eyes,</line>
      <line> Lost in soft amaze</line>
      <line>I gaze, I gaze!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who now, with greedy looks, eats up my feast?</line>
      <line>What stare outfaces now my silver moon?</line>
      <line>Ah, keep that hand unravished at the least</line>
      <line>Let, let, the amorous burn,</line>
      <line>But prithee do not turn</line>
      <line>The current of your heart from me so soon!</line>
      <line>Oh, save (in charity)</line>
      <line>The quickest pulse for me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Save it for me, sweet love! Though music breathe</line>
      <line>Voluptuous visions into the warm air,</line>
      <line>Though swimming through the dance’s dangerous wreath,</line>
      <line>Be like an April day,</line>
      <line>Smiling and cold and gay –</line>
      <line>A temperate lily, temperate as fair,</line>
      <line>Then Heaven, there will be</line>
      <line>A warmer June for me!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Why, this’, you’ll say, my Fanny, ‘is not true!’</line>
      <line>Put your soft hand upon your snowy side</line>
      <line> Where the heart beats – confess, ’tis nothing new!</line>
      <line>Must not a woman be</line>
      <line>A feather on the sea,</line>
      <line>Swayed to and fro by every wind and tide?</line>
      <line>Of as uncertain speed</line>
      <line>As blow-ball from the mead?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know it – and to know it is despair</line>
      <line>To one who loves you as I love, sweet Fanny,</line>
      <line>Whose heart goes fluttering for you everywhere,</line>
      <line>Nor, when away you roam,</line>
      <line> Dare keep its wretched home!</line>
      <line>Love, love alone, has pains severe and many –</line>
      <line>Then, loveliest, keep me free</line>
      <line>From torturing jealousy!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, if you prize my subdued soul above</line>
      <line>The poor, the fading, brief pride of an hour,</line>
      <line>Let none profane my Holy See of love,</line>
      <line>Or with a rude hand break</line>
      <line>The sacramental cake –</line>
      <line>Let none else touch the just new-budded flower!</line>
      <line> If not, may my eyes close,</line>
      <line>Love, on their last repose.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE and Mary Joyce</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>Song (‘Mary leave thy lowly cot’)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mary leave thy lowly cot</line>
      <line>When thy thickest jobs are done,</line>
      <line>When thy friends will miss thee not</line>
      <line>Mary to the pastures run –</line>
      <line> Where we met the other night</line>
      <line>’Neath the bush upon the plain,</line>
      <line>Be it dark or be it light</line>
      <line>Ye may guess we’ll meet again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Should ye go or should ye not</line>
      <line>Never shilly-shally dear,</line>
      <line>Leave your work and leave your cot</line>
      <line>Nothing need ye doubt or fear:</line>
      <line>Chaps may tell ye lies in spite –</line>
      <line>Calling me a roving swain –</line>
      <line> Think what passed the other night,</line>
      <line>Then I’m bound we’ll meet again!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE and Mary Joyce</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>My Mary</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who lives where beggars rarely speed,</line>
      <line>And leads a humdrum life indeed</line>
      <line>As none beside herself would lead?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Who lives where noises never cease,</line>
      <line>And, what wi’ hogs and ducks and geese,</line>
      <line>Can never have a minute’s peace?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who, nearly battled to her chin,</line>
      <line>Bangs down the yard through thick and thin,</line>
      <line>Nor picks a road, nor cares a pin?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who (save in Sunday bib-and-tuck)</line>
      <line>Goes daily, waddling like a duck,</line>
      <line> O’er head and ears in grease and muck?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unused to pattens or to clogs,</line>
      <line>Who takes the swill to serve the hogs,</line>
      <line>And steals the milk for cats and dogs?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who (frost and snow as hard as nails)</line>
      <line>Stands out o’ doors and never fails</line>
      <line>To wash up things and scour the pails?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Who bustles night and day, in short,</line>
      <line>At all catch jobs of every sort</line>
      <line>And gains her Mistress’ favour for’t?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And who is oft repaid wi’ praise</line>
      <line>In doing what her Mistress says</line>
      <line>And yielding to her whimmy ways?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For there’s none apter, I believe,</line>
      <line>At ‘creeping up her Mistress’ sleeve’</line>
      <line> Than this low kindred stump of Eve,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who when the baby’s all beshit</line>
      <line>To please its mamma kisses it,</line>
      <line>And vows no rose on earth’s so sweet!</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when her Mistress isn’t nigh</line>
      <line>Who swears and wishes it would die,</line>
      <line>And pinches it to make it cry?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Oh rank deceit! What soul could think –</line>
      <line>But gently there, revealing ink! –</line>
      <line>At faults of thine this friend must wink,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who (not without a spark o’ pride,</line>
      <line>Though strong as grunters’ bristly hide)</line>
      <line>Does keep her hair in papers tied?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, mimicking the gentry’s way,</line>
      <line>Who strives to speak as fine as they</line>
      <line> And minds but every word they say?</line>
      <line>My Mary</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And who (though’s well bid blind to see</line>
      <line>As her to tell the A from B)</line>
      <line>Thinks herself none o’ low degree?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who prates, and runs o’er silly stuff,</line>
      <line>And ’mong the boys makes sport enough –</line>
      <line>So ugly, silly, droll and rough?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Ugly! Muse, for shame ’o thee,</line>
      <line>What faults art thou a’going to see</line>
      <line>In one that’s lotted out to be?</line>
      <line>My Mary?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But heedless sayings meaneth nought</line>
      <line>Done innocent without a thought –</line>
      <line>We humbly ask thy pardon for’t,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who, low in stature, thick and fat,</line>
      <line>Turns brown from going without a hat</line>
      <line> (Though not a pin the worse for that)?</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who’s laughed at, too, by every whelp</line>
      <line>For failings which they cannot help –</line>
      <line>But silly fools will laugh and chelp,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For though in stature mighty small</line>
      <line>And near as thick as thou art tall,</line>
      <line>That hand made thee that made us all,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And though thy nose hooks down too much,</line>
      <line>And prophesies thy chin to touch,</line>
      <line>I’m not so nice to look at such,</line>
      <line>My Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, no! About thy nose and chin,</line>
      <line>Its hooking out or bending in,</line>
      <line>I never heed nor care a pin,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And though thy skin is brown and rough,</line>
      <line>And formed by Nature hard and tough,</line>
      <line> All suiteth me – so that’s enough,</line>
      <line>My Mary!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN CLARE and Mary Joyce</author>
    <date>1820</date>
    <title>Ballad (‘Mary, fate lent me a moment’)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mary, fate lent me a moment of pleasure</line>
      <line>Just to insure me in ages of pain –</line>
      <line>Just bid me meet thee and wish for the treasure</line>
      <line>To frown back and tell me I wisht it in vain!</line>
      <line> Just like spring sunshine I met with thee, Mary,</line>
      <line>That shines for a moment and cloudeth again;</line>
      <line>But, alas in our love there is one thing contrary</line>
      <line>Fate’s clouds of that moment cleared never again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mary, fond feelings will never forsake me –</line>
      <line>Never again though I’m happy with thee –</line>
      <line>Hope paints the cure that enraptured could make me</line>
      <line>Tho’ fate to torment, vows it never shall be!</line>
      <line>Mary, hope whispers some chance in our favour,</line>
      <line>That still I may gaze on thy beauties once more,</line>
      <line> But Fate’s bonds are on me, that cruel enslaver,</line>
      <line>And love is not lawful to meet as before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mary how sweet when love basked in thy feature,</line>
      <line>Mary how saddened the sighs rose and fell;</line>
      <line>Surely those sighs was the instinct of Nature</line>
      <line>Of future forebodings Fate cared no to tell.</line>
      <line>Mary thy smiles still endear our departure,</line>
      <line>Though they do haunt me in gloomy deform;</line>
      <line>Like waining sunbeams the clouds follow after</line>
      <line>That just give a glance ere they’re lost in the storm.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>The Dreaming Child</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And is there sadness in thy dreams, my boy?</line>
      <line>What should the cloud be made of? Blesséd child!</line>
      <line>Thy spirit, borne upon a breeze of joy,</line>
      <line>All day hath ranged through sunshine, clear, yet mild –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And now thou tremblest! Wherefore? In thy soul</line>
      <line>There lies no past, no future – thou hast heard</line>
      <line>No sound of presage from the distance roll,</line>
      <line>Thy heart bears traces of no arrowy word!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From thee no love hath gone – thy mind’s young eye</line>
      <line>Hath looked not into Death’s, and thence become</line>
      <line>A questioner of mute Eternity,</line>
      <line>A weary searcher for a viewless home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor hath thy sense been quickened unto pain,</line>
      <line>By feverish watching for some step beloved;</line>
      <line> Free are thy thoughts, an ever-changeful train,</line>
      <line>Glancing like dewdrops, and as lightly moved!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet now, on billows of strange passion tossed,</line>
      <line>How art thou wildered in the Cave of Sleep!</line>
      <line>My gentle child, midst what dim phantoms lost,</line>
      <line>Thus in mysterious anguish dost thou weep?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Awake! They sadden me, those early tears,</line>
      <line>First flushings of the strong dark river’s flow,</line>
      <line>That must o’ersweep thy soul with coming years –</line>
      <line>The unfathomable flood of human woe!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Awful to watch, e’en rolling through a dream,</line>
      <line>Forcing wild spray-drops – but from childhood’s eyes!</line>
      <line>Wake, wake! as yet thy life’s transparent stream</line>
      <line>Should wear the tinge of none but summer skies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come from the shadow of those realms unknown,</line>
      <line>Where now thy thoughts dismayed and darkling rove;</line>
      <line>Come to the kindly region all thine own,</line>
      <line>The home, still bright for thee with guardian love,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Happy, fair child, that yet a mother’s voice</line>
      <line>Can win thee back from visionary strife!</line>
      <line> Oh, shall my soul, thus wakened to rejoice,</line>
      <line>Start from the dreamlike wilderness of life?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1830</date>
    <title>Recollections</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you remember all the sunny places</line>
      <line>Where in bright days, long past, we played together?</line>
      <line>Do you remember all the old home faces</line>
      <line>That gathered round the hearth in wintry weather?</line>
      <line> Do you remember all the happy meetings,</line>
      <line>In summer evenings round the open door –</line>
      <line>Kind looks, kind hearts, kind words and tender greetings,</line>
      <line>And clasping hands whose pulses beat no more?</line>
      <line>Do you remember them?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you remember all the merry laughter,</line>
      <line>The voices round the swing in our old garden,</line>
      <line>The dog that when we ran still followed after,</line>
      <line>The teasing frolic sure of speedy pardon?</line>
      <line>We were but children then, young happy creatures,</line>
      <line> And hardly knew how much we had to lose –</line>
      <line>But now the dreamlike memory of those features</line>
      <line>Comes back, and bids my darkened spirit muse:</line>
      <line>Do you remember them?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you remember when we first departed</line>
      <line>From all the old companions who were round us –</line>
      <line>How very soon again we grew light-hearted,</line>
      <line>And talked with smiles of all the links which bound us?</line>
      <line>And after, when our footsteps were returning</line>
      <line>With unfelt weariness o’er hill and plain,</line>
      <line> How our young hearts kept boiling up, and burning,</line>
      <line>To think how soon we’d be at home again!</line>
      <line>Do you remember this?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you remember how the dreams of glory</line>
      <line>Kept fading from us like a fairy treasure –</line>
      <line>How we thought less of being famed in story,</line>
      <line>And more of those to whom our fame gave pleasure?</line>
      <line>Do you remember, in far countries, weeping</line>
      <line>When a light breeze, a flower, hath brought to mind</line>
      <line>Old happy thoughts, which till that hour were sleeping,</line>
      <line> And made us yearn for those we left behind?</line>
      <line>Do you remember this?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you remember when no sound woke gladly,</line>
      <line>But desolate echoes through our home were ringing,</line>
      <line>How for a while we talked – then paused full sadly,</line>
      <line>Because our voices bitter thoughts were bringing?</line>
      <line>Ah me, those days – those days! – my friend, my brother,</line>
      <line>Sit down and let us talk of all our woe,</line>
      <line>For we have nothing left but one another.</line>
      <line>Yet where they went, old playmate, we shall go –</line>
      <line> Let us remember this.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>CAROLINE NORTON</author>
    <date>1836</date>
    <title>The Mother’s Heart</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When first thou camest, gentle, shy, and fond,</line>
      <line>My eldest-born, first hope, and dearest treasure,</line>
      <line>My heart received thee with a joy beyond</line>
      <line>All that it yet had felt of earthly pleasure –</line>
      <line> Nor thought that any love again might be</line>
      <line>So deep and strong as that I felt for thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Faithful and true, with sense beyond thy years</line>
      <line>And natural piety that leaned to Heaven;</line>
      <line>Wrung by a harsh word suddenly to tears,</line>
      <line>Yet patient of rebuke when justly given;</line>
      <line>Obedient, easy to be reconciled,</line>
      <line>And meekly-cheerful – such wert thou, my child!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not willing to be left – still by my side,</line>
      <line>Haunting my walks, while summer-day was dying –</line>
      <line> Nor leaving in thy turn; but pleased to glide</line>
      <line>Through the dark room where I was sadly lying,</line>
      <line>Or, by the couch of pain a sitter meek,</line>
      <line>Watch the dim eye, and kiss the feverish cheek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh boy, of such as thou are oftenest made</line>
      <line>Earth’s fragile idols: like a tender flower</line>
      <line>(No strength in all thy freshness) prone to fade,</line>
      <line>And bending weakly to the thunder-shower –</line>
      <line>Still, round the loved, thy heart found force to bind,</line>
      <line>And clung, like woodbine shaken in the wind!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then thou, my merry love – bold in thy glee,</line>
      <line>Under the bough, or by the firelight dancing –</line>
      <line>With thy sweet temper, and thy spirit free,</line>
      <line>Didst come, as restless as a bird’s wing glancing,</line>
      <line>Full of a wild and irrepressible mirth,</line>
      <line>Like a young sunbeam to the gladdened earth!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thine was the shout! the song! the burst of joy!</line>
      <line>Which sweet from childhood’s rosy lip resoundeth;</line>
      <line>Thine was the eager spirit nought could cloy,</line>
      <line>And the glad heart from which all grief reboundeth;</line>
      <line> And many a mirthful jest and mock reply,</line>
      <line>Lurked in the laughter of thy dark-blue eye!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thine was many an art to win and bless,</line>
      <line>The cold and stern to joy and fondness warming;</line>
      <line>The coaxing smile – the frequent soft caress –</line>
      <line>The earnest tearful prayer all wrath disarming!</line>
      <line>Again my heart a new affection found,</line>
      <line>But thought that love with thee had reached its bound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length thou camest – thou, the last and least –</line>
      <line>Nick-named ‘The Emperor’ by thy laughing brothers</line>
      <line> Because a haughty spirit swelled thy breast,</line>
      <line>And thou didst seek to rule and sway the others,</line>
      <line>Mingling with every playful infant wile</line>
      <line>A mimic majesty that made us smile!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And oh, most like a regal child wert thou!</line>
      <line>An eye of resolute and successful scheming,</line>
      <line>Fair shoulders, curling lip, and dauntless brow –</line>
      <line>Fit for the world’s strife, not for Poet’s dreaming –</line>
      <line>And proud the lifting of thy stately head,</line>
      <line>And the firm bearing of thy conscious tread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Different from both! Yet each succeeding claim,</line>
      <line>I, that all other love had been forswearing,</line>
      <line>Forthwith admitted equal and the same –</line>
      <line>Nor injured either, by this love’s comparing,</line>
      <line>Nor stole a fraction for the newer call,</line>
      <line>But in the Mother’s Heart, found room for all!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>To My Brother</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do you recall the fancies of many years ago,</line>
      <line>When the pulse danced those light measures that again it cannot know?</line>
      <line>Ah, we both of us are altered, and now we talk no more</line>
      <line>Of all the old creations that haunted us of yore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Then any favourite volume was a mine of long delight</line>
      <line>From whence we took our future to fashion as we might.</line>
      <line>We lived again its pages, we were its chiefs and kings,</line>
      <line>As actual, but more pleasant, than what the day now brings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was an August evening, with sunset in the trees,</line>
      <line>When home you brought his Voyages who found the fair South Seas</line>
      <line>We read it till the sunset amid the boughs grew dim –</line>
      <line>All other favourite heroes were nothing beside him!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For weeks he was our idol, we sailed with him at sea,</line>
      <line>And the pond amid the willows the ocean seemed to be.</line>
      <line> The water-lilies growing beneath the morning smile,</line>
      <line>We called the South Sea islands, each flower a different isle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No golden lot that fortune could draw for human life,</line>
      <line>To us seemed like a sailor’s, amid the storm and strife.</line>
      <line>Our talk was of fair vessels that swept before the breeze,</line>
      <line>And new-discovered countries amid the Southern Seas.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within that lonely garden what happy hours went by,</line>
      <line>While we fancied that around us spread foreign sea and sky!</line>
      <line>Ah, the dreaming and the distant no longer haunt the mind –</line>
      <line>We leave, in leaving childhood, life’s fairyland behind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> There is not of that garden a single tree or flower;</line>
      <line>They have ploughed its long green grasses, and cut down the lime-tree bower!</line>
      <line>Where are the guelder-roses whose silver used to bring,</line>
      <line>With the gold of the laburnums, their tribute to the Spring?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They have vanished with the childhood that with their treasures</line>
      <line>played;</line>
      <line>The life that cometh after dwells in a darker shade.</line>
      <line>Yet the name of that sea-captain it cannot but recall</line>
      <line>How much we loved his dangers, and how we mourned his fall!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY SCOTT</author>
    <date>1774</date>
    <title>from The Female Advocate</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fired with the music, Aikin, of thy lays,</line>
      <line>To thee the muse a joyful tribute pays –</line>
      <line>Transported, dwells on that harmonious line</line>
      <line>Where taste and spirit, wit and learning, shine;</line>
      <line>Where Fancy’s hand her richest colouring lends,</line>
      <line>And every shade in just proportion blends.</line>
      <line> How fair, how beauteous to our gazing eyes</line>
      <line>Thy vivid intellectual paintings rise!</line>
      <line>We feel thy feelings, glow with all thy fires,</line>
      <line>Adopt thy thoughts, and pant with thy desires!</line>
      <line>Proceed bright maid, and may thy polished page</line>
      <line>O Refine the manners of a trifling age –</line>
      <line>Thy sex apprize of Pleasure’s treacherous charms,</line>
      <line>And woo them from the siren’s fatal arms –</line>
      <line>Teach them with thee on Fancy’s wing to soar,</line>
      <line>With thee the paths of science to explore,</line>
      <line> With thee the open book of Nature scan,</line>
      <line>Yet nobly scorn the little pride of man.</line>
      <line>Man, seated high on Learning’s awful throne,</line>
      <line>Thinks the fair realms of knowledge his alone;</line>
      <line>But you, ye fair, his Salic Law disclaim!</line>
      <line>Supreme in science shall the tyrant reign</line>
      <line>When every talent all-indulgent Heaven</line>
      <line>In lavish bounty to your share hath given?</line>
      <line>With joy ineffable the muse surveys</line>
      <line>The orient beams of more resplendent days:</line>
      <line> As on she raptured looks to future years,</line>
      <line>What a bright throng to Fancy’s view appears!</line>
      <line>To them see Genius her best gifts impart,</line>
      <line>And science raise a throne in every heart!</line>
      <line>One turns the moral, one the historic page,</line>
      <line>Another glows with all a Shakespeare’s rage!</line>
      <line>With matchless Newton now one soars on high,</line>
      <line>Lost in the boundless wonders of the sky;</line>
      <line>Another now (of curious mind) reveals</line>
      <line>What treasures in her bowels Earth conceals –</line>
      <line> Nature’s minuter works attract her eyes,</line>
      <line>Their laws, their powers, her deep research descries.</line>
      <line>From sense abstracted, some with arduous flight</line>
      <line>Explore the realms of intellectual light –</line>
      <line>With unremitting study seek to find</line>
      <line>How mind on matter, matter acts on mind.</line>
      <line>Alike in Nature, arts and manners, read,</line>
      <line>In every path of knowledge see them tread –</line>
      <line>Whilst men, convinced of female talents, pay</line>
      <line>To female worth the tributary lay!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1785</date>
    <title>Epistle to J. Lapraik, An Old Scotch Bard</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>While briers an’ woodbines budding green,</line>
      <line>An’ paitricks scraichen loud at e’en,</line>
      <line>An’ morning poossie whiddan seen,</line>
      <line>Inspire my muse,</line>
      <line> This freedom, in an unknown frien’,</line>
      <line>I pray excuse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On Fasteneen we had a rockin’,</line>
      <line>To ca’ the crack, and weave our stockin’,</line>
      <line>And there was muckle fun and jokin’</line>
      <line>Ye need na doubt;</line>
      <line>At length we had a hearty yokin’</line>
      <line>At sang-about!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was ae sang, amang the rest</line>
      <line>(Aboon them a’ it pleased me best)</line>
      <line> That some kind husband had addrest</line>
      <line>To some sweet wife:</line>
      <line>It thirled the heart-strings through the breast,</line>
      <line>A’ to the life.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve scarce heard ought described sae weel</line>
      <line>What generous manly bosoms feel –</line>
      <line>Thought I, ‘Can this be Pope, or Steele,</line>
      <line>Or Beattie’s wark?’</line>
      <line>They tald me ’twas an odd kind chiel</line>
      <line>About Muirkirk!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> It pat me fidgean-fain to hear’t,</line>
      <line>An’ sae about him there I spier’t;</line>
      <line>Then a’ that kent him round declare’t</line>
      <line>He had an ingine –</line>
      <line>That nane excelled it, few cam near’t,</line>
      <line>It was sae fine –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That (set him to a pint of ale,</line>
      <line>An’ either douse or merry tale,</line>
      <line>Or rhymes an’ sangs he’d made himsel’,</line>
      <line>Or witty catches),</line>
      <line> ’Tween Inverness and Tiviotdale</line>
      <line>He had few matches!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then up I gat, an’ swoor an aith:</line>
      <line>Though I should pawn my pleugh an’ graith,</line>
      <line>Or die a cadger-pownie’s death,</line>
      <line>At some dyke-back,</line>
      <line>A pint an’ gill I’d gie them baith,</line>
      <line>To hear your crack.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But first an’ foremost, I should tell:</line>
      <line>Amaist as soon as I could spell,</line>
      <line> I to the crambo-jingle fell –</line>
      <line>Though rude an’ rough,</line>
      <line>Yet crooning to a body’s sel,</line>
      <line>Does weel eneugh.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am nae poet, in a sense,</line>
      <line>But just a rhymer like by chance,</line>
      <line>An’ hae to learning nae pretence –</line>
      <line>Yet, what the matter?</line>
      <line>Whene’er my Muse does on me glance,</line>
      <line>I jingle at her!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Your critic-folk may cock their nose,</line>
      <line>And say, ‘How can you e’er propose</line>
      <line>(You wha ken hardly verse frae prose)</line>
      <line>To mak a sang?’</line>
      <line>But by your leaves, my learned foes,</line>
      <line>Ye’re maybe wrang!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What’s a’ your jargon o’ the schools,</line>
      <line>Your Latin names for horns an’ stools;</line>
      <line>If honest Nature made you fools,</line>
      <line>What sairs your grammars?</line>
      <line> Ye’d better taen up spades and shools,</line>
      <line>Or knappin-hammers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A set o’ dull, conceited hashes</line>
      <line>Confuse their brains in colledge-classes!</line>
      <line>They gang in stirks, and come out asses</line>
      <line>(Plain truth to speak),</line>
      <line>An’ syne they think to climb Parnassus</line>
      <line>By dint o’ Greek!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gie me ae spark o’ Nature’s fire,</line>
      <line>That’s a’ the learning I desire;</line>
      <line> Then though I drudge through dub an’ mire</line>
      <line>At pleugh or cart,</line>
      <line>My Muse, though hamely in attire,</line>
      <line>May touch the heart...</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ROBERT BURNS</author>
    <date>1785</date>
    <title>I Am a Bard</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am a bard of no regard</line>
      <line>Wi’ gentle folks an’ a’ that,</line>
      <line>But Homer-like the glowran byke</line>
      <line>Frae town to town I draw that!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> For a’ that, an’ a’ that,</line>
      <line>And twice as muckle’s a’ that,</line>
      <line>I’ve lost but ane, I’ve twa behin’ –</line>
      <line>I’ve wife eneugh for a’ that!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never drank the Muses’ stank,</line>
      <line>Castalia’s burn, an a’ that,</line>
      <line>But there is streams, an’ richly reams –</line>
      <line>My Helicon I ca’ that!</line>
      <line>For a’ that, an a’ that...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Great love I bear to a’ the fair,</line>
      <line>Their humble slave, an’ a’ that –</line>
      <line>But lordly will, I hold it still</line>
      <line>A mortal sin to thraw that!</line>
      <line>For a’ that, an’ a’ that...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> In raptures sweet this hour we meet,</line>
      <line>Wi’ mutual love an’ a’ that,</line>
      <line>But for how lang the flie may stang,</line>
      <line>Let inclination law that!</line>
      <line>For a’ that, an’ a’ that...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their tricks an’ craft hae put me daft,</line>
      <line>They’ve ta’en me in an’ a’ that,</line>
      <line> But clear your decks, and here’s – ‘The Sex!’</line>
      <line>I like the jades for a’ that!</line>
      <line>For ‘a that, an’ a’ that,</line>
      <line>An’ twice as muckle as a’ that,</line>
      <line>My dearest bluid to do them guid,</line>
      <line>They’re welcome till’t for a’ that!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>HELEN MARIA WILLIAMS</author>
    <date>1787</date>
    <title>Sonnet on Reading ‘The Mountain Daisy’ by Burns</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>While soon the ‘garden’s flaunting flowers’ decay</line>
      <line>And (scattered on the earth) neglected lie,</line>
      <line>The mountain daisy, cherished by the ray</line>
      <line>A poet drew from Heaven, shall never die.</line>
      <line> Ah, like that lovely flower the Poet rose</line>
      <line>Mid Penury’s bare soil and bitter gale!</line>
      <line>He felt each storm that on the mountain blows,</line>
      <line>Nor ever knew the shelter of the vale.</line>
      <line>By Genius in her native vigour nursed,</line>
      <line>On Nature with impassioned look he gazed,</line>
      <line>Then through the cloud of adverse fortune burst</line>
      <line>Indignant, and in light unborrowed blazed!</line>
      <line>Scotia, from rude affliction shield thy bard –</line>
      <line>His Heaven-taught numbers, Fate herself will guard.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOANNA BAILLIE</author>
    <date>1790</date>
    <title>From An Address to the Muses</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The youthful poet, pen in hand,</line>
      <line>All by the side of blotted stand,</line>
      <line>In reverie deep, which none may break,</line>
      <line>Sits rubbing of his beardless cheek;</line>
      <line>And well his inspiration knows,</line>
      <line>E’en by the dewy drops that trickle o’er his nose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The tuneful sage of riper fame</line>
      <line>Perceives you not in heated frame,</line>
      <line>But at conclusion of his verse</line>
      <line>(Which still his muttering lips rehearse)</line>
      <line>Oft waves his hand in grateful pride,</line>
      <line>And owns the heavenly power that did his fancy guide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh lovely Sisters! is it true</line>
      <line>That they are all inspired by you?</line>
      <line>And while they write, with magic charmed</line>
      <line>And high enthusiasm warmed,</line>
      <line> We may not question heavenly lays,</line>
      <line>For well I wot, they give you all the praise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh lovely sisters! well it shows</line>
      <line>How wide and far your bounty flows –</line>
      <line>Then why from me withhold your beams?</line>
      <line>Unvisited of heavenly dreams,</line>
      <line>Whene’er I aim at heights sublime,</line>
      <line>Still downward am I called to seek some stubborn rhyme!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No hasty lightning breaks the gloom,</line>
      <line>Nor flashing thoughts unsought-for come,</line>
      <line> Nor fancies wake in time of need –</line>
      <line>I labour much with little speed;</line>
      <line>And when my studied task is done,</line>
      <line>Too well, alas, I mark it for my own!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye are the spirits who preside</line>
      <line>In earth and air and ocean wide,</line>
      <line>In hissing flood and crackling fire,</line>
      <line> In horror dread and tumult dire,</line>
      <line>In stilly calm and stormy wind,</line>
      <line>And rule the answering changes in the human mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>High on the tempest-beaten hill</line>
      <line>Your misty shapes ye shift at will –</line>
      <line>The wild fantastic clouds ye form –</line>
      <line>Your voice is in the midnight storm,</line>
      <line>Whilst in the dark and lonely hour</line>
      <line>Oft starts the boldest heart, and owns your secret power!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1794</date>
    <title>Preface to Europe, A Prophecy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Five windows light the caverned man: through one he breathes the air;</line>
      <line>Through one, hears music of the spheres; through one, the eternal vine</line>
      <line>Flourishes, that he may receive the grapes; through one, can look</line>
      <line>And see small portions of the eternal world that ever groweth;</line>
      <line> Through one, himself pass out what time he please (but he will not,</line>
      <line>For stolen joys are sweet, and bread eaten in secret pleasant).’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So sang a fairy, mocking, as he sat on a streaked tulip</line>
      <line>Thinking none saw him. When he ceased I started from the trees</line>
      <line>And caught him in my hat, as boys knock down a butterfly.</line>
      <line>‘How know you this’, said I, ‘small sir? Where did you learn this song?’</line>
      <line>Seeing himself in my possession, thus he answered me:</line>
      <line>‘My master, I am yours! Command me, for I must obey.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Then tell me, what is the material world – and is it dead?’</line>
      <line>He laughing answered: ‘I will write a book on leaves of flowers,</line>
      <line> If you will feed me on love-thoughts, and give me now and then</line>
      <line>A cup of sparkling poetic fancies. So, when I am tipsy</line>
      <line>I’ll sing to you to this soft lute, and show you all alive</line>
      <line>The world, where every particle of dust breathes forth its joy.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took him home in my warm bosom: as we went along</line>
      <line>Wild flowers I gathered, and he showed me each eternal flower.</line>
      <line>He laughed aloud to see them whimper because they were plucked –</line>
      <line>They hovered round me like a cloud of incense. When I came</line>
      <line>Into my parlour and sat down, and took my pen to write,</line>
      <line>My fairy sat upon the table, and dictated Europe.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1804</date>
    <title>from ‘I Come In Self-Annihilation’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I come in self-annihilation and the grandeur of inspiration</line>
      <line>To cast off rational demonstration by faith in the Saviour,</line>
      <line>To cast off the rotten rags of memory by inspiration,</line>
      <line> To cast off Bacon, Locke and Newton from Albion’s covering,</line>
      <line>To take off his filthy garments, and clothe him with imagination,</line>
      <line>To cast aside from poetry all that is not inspiration,</line>
      <line>That it no longer shall dare to mock with the aspersion of madness</line>
      <line>Cast on the inspired by the tame high finisher of paltry blots</line>
      <line>Indefinite, or paltry rhymes, or paltry harmonies,</line>
      <line>Who creeps into state government like a caterpillar to destroy –</line>
      <line>To cast off the idiot questioner, who is always questioning,</line>
      <line>But never capable of answering; who sits with a sly grin</line>
      <line>Silent plotting when to question, like a thief in a cave;</line>
      <line>Who publishes doubt, and calls it knowledge; whose science is despair,</line>
      <line>Whose pretence to knowledge is envy, whose whole science is</line>
      <line>To destroy the wisdom of ages to gratify ravenous envy</line>
      <line>That rages round him like a wolf day and night without rest.</line>
      <line>He smiles with condescension, he talks of benevolence and virtue</line>
      <line>And those who act with benevolence and virtue they murder time on time!</line>
      <line>These are the destroyers of Jerusalem, these are the murderers</line>
      <line>Of Jesus, who deny the faith and mock at eternal life;</line>
      <line>Who pretend to poetry that they may destroy imagination</line>
      <line>By imitation of nature’s images drawn from remembrance!</line>
      <line> These are the sexual garments, the abomination of desolation</line>
      <line>Hiding the human lineaments as with an ark and curtains,</line>
      <line>Which Jesus rent – and now shall wholly purge away with fire,</line>
      <line>Till generation is swallowed up in regeneration.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>WILLIAM BLAKE</author>
    <date>1807</date>
    <title>from ‘Trembling I Sit’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Trembling I sit day and night. My friends are astonished at me,</line>
      <line>Yet they forgive my wanderings. I rest not from my great task –</line>
      <line>To open the eternal worlds, to open the immortal eyes</line>
      <line>Of Man inwards into the worlds of thought; into Eternity</line>
      <line>Ever expanding in the bosom of God, the human imagination!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>‘Pensive at Eve’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>PENSIVE at eve, on the hard world I mused,</line>
      <line>And my poor heart was sad; so at the MOON</line>
      <line>I gazed, and sighed and sighed – for ah, how soon</line>
      <line>Eve saddens into night! Mine eyes perused</line>
      <line> With tearful vacancy the dampy grass</line>
      <line>That wept and glittered in the paly ray,</line>
      <line>And I did pause me on my lonely way</line>
      <line>And mused me on the wretched ones that pass</line>
      <line>O’er the black heath of sorrow. But alas!</line>
