      <line>Most of myself I thought – when it befell</line>
      <line>That the soothe spirit of the breezy wood</line>
      <line>Breathed in mine ear: ‘All this is very well,</line>
      <line>But much of ONE thing is for NO thing good.’</line>
      <line>Oh my poor heart’s INEXPLICABLE SWELL!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>‘Oh I Do Love Thee’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh I do love thee, meek SIMPLICITY!</line>
      <line>For of thy lays the lulling simpleness</line>
      <line>Goes to my heart, and soothes each small distress,</line>
      <line>Distress though small, yet haply great to me.</line>
      <line> ’Tis true on Lady Fortune’s gentlest pad</line>
      <line>I amble on; and yet I know not why</line>
      <line>So sad I am! But should a friend and I</line>
      <line>Frown, pout, and part, then I am very sad.</line>
      <line>And then with sonnets and with sympathy</line>
      <line>My dreamy bosom’s mystic woes I pall;</line>
      <line>Now on my false friend plaining plaintively,</line>
      <line>Now raving at mankind in general;</line>
      <line>But whether sad or fierce, ’tis simple all,</line>
      <line>All very simple, meek SIMPLICITY!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1797</date>
    <title>‘And This Reft House’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And this reft house is that, the which he built,</line>
      <line>Lamented Jack! and here his malt he piled,</line>
      <line>Cautious in vain! these rats, that squeak so wild,</line>
      <line>Squeak not unconscious of their father’s guilt.</line>
      <line> Did he not see her gleaming through the glade!</line>
      <line>Belike ’twas she, the maiden all forlorn.</line>
      <line>What though she milk no cow with crumpled horn,</line>
      <line>Yet, aye, she haunts the dale where erst she strayed,</line>
      <line>And aye beside her stalks her amorous knight!</line>
      <line>Still on his thighs their wonted brogues are worn,</line>
      <line>And through those brogues, still tattered and betorn,</line>
      <line>His hindward charms gleam an unearthly white.</line>
      <line>Ah! thus through broken clouds, at night’s high Noon</line>
      <line>Peeps in fair fragments forth the full-orbed harvest-moon!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1798</date>
    <title>from the Prologue to Peter Bell</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s something in a flying horse,</line>
      <line>There’s something in a huge balloon,</line>
      <line>But through the clouds I’ll never float</line>
      <line>Until I have a little boat</line>
      <line> In shape just like the crescent moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now I have a little boat</line>
      <line>In shape just like the crescent moon –</line>
      <line>Fast through the clouds my boat can sail,</line>
      <line>But if perchance your faith should fail,</line>
      <line>Look up, and you shall see me soon!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The woods, my friends, are round you roaring,</line>
      <line>The woods are roaring like a sea;</line>
      <line>The noise of danger’s in your ears,</line>
      <line>And you have all a thousand fears</line>
      <line> Both for my little boat and me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up goes my boat between the stars</line>
      <line>Through many a breathless field of light,</line>
      <line>Through many a long blue field of ether,</line>
      <line>Leaving ten thousand stars beneath her –</line>
      <line> Up goes my little boat so bright!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The towns in Saturn are ill-built,</line>
      <line>But Jove has very pretty bowers;</line>
      <line>The evening star is not amiss –</line>
      <line>But what are all of them to this,</line>
      <line>This little earth of ours?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then back again to our green earth!</line>
      <line>What business had I here to roam?</line>
      <line>The world for my remarks and me</line>
      <line>Will not a whit the better be –</line>
      <line> I’ve left my heart at home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that is then the dear green earth</line>
      <line>And that’s the dear Pacific Ocean</line>
      <line>And that is Caucasus so dear,</line>
      <line>To think that I again am here –</line>
      <line>Oh, my poor heart’s commotion!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And there is little Tartary</line>
      <line>And there’s the famous River Dnieper,</line>
      <line>And there, amid the ocean green,</line>
      <line>Is that sweet isle, of isles the Queen –</line>
      <line> Ye fairies, from all evil keep her!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And there’s the town where I was born,</line>
      <line>And that’s the house of Parson Swan.</line>
      <line>My heart is touched, I must avow</line>
      <line>(Consider where I’ve been!), and now</line>
      <line>I feel I am a man.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Never did fifty things at once</line>
      <line>Appear so lovely, never never;</line>
      <line>The woods, how sweetly do they ring –</line>
      <line>To hear the earth’s sweet murmuring</line>
      <line> Thus could I hang for ever.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh shame upon you, cruel shame!</line>
      <line>Was ever such a heartless loon</line>
      <line>In such a lovely boat to sit,</line>
      <line>And make no better use of it? –</line>
      <line>A boat that’s like the crescent moon!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Out, out, and like a brooding hen</line>
      <line>Beside your sooty hearth-stone cower!</line>
      <line>Go creep along the dirt, and pick</line>
      <line>Your way with your good walking-stick,</line>
      <line> Just three good miles an hour.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sure in the breast of full-grown poet</line>
      <line>So faint a heart was ne’er before!</line>
      <line>Come to the poets’ wild delights –</line>
      <line>I have ten thousand lovely sights,</line>
      <line>Ten thousand sights in store.'</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My pretty little form of light,</line>
      <line>My sweet and beautiful canoe,</line>
      <line>Now (though it grieves me to the heart)</line>
      <line>I feel, I feel that we must part –</line>
      <line>I must take leave of you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You are a pretty little barge,</line>
      <line>But while your pleasure you’re pursuing</line>
      <line>Without impediment or let,</line>
      <line>My little barge, you quite forget</line>
      <line>What in the world is doing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a party in the bower,</line>
      <line>Round the stone table in my garden:</line>
      <line>The squire is there, and, as I guess,</line>
      <line>His pretty little daughter Bess,</line>
      <line> With Harry the churchwarden.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They were to come this very evening,</line>
      <line>They know not I have been so far;</line>
      <line>I see them there, in number nine,</line>
      <line>All in the bower of Weymouth pine,</line>
      <line>I see them, there they are.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And there’s the wife of Parson Swan,</line>
      <line>And there’s my good friend Stephen Otter –</line>
      <line>And, ere the light of evening fail,</line>
      <line>To them I must relate the tale</line>
      <line> Of Peter Bell the Potter.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Off flew my pretty little barge</line>
      <line>All in a trance of indignation,</line>
      <line>And I, as well as I was able,</line>
      <line>On two poor legs to my stone table</line>
      <line>Limped on with some vexation.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh here he is!’ cried little Bess</line>
      <line>(She saw me at the garden-door),</line>
      <line>‘Oh here he is!’ cried Mistress Swan –</line>
      <line>And all at once around me ran</line>
      <line> Full nine of them or more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sit down, I beg you would be seated’,</line>
      <line>Said I – no doubt with visage pale –</line>
      <line>‘And if, my friends, it pleases you,</line>
      <line>This instant, without more ado,</line>
      <line>We’ll have the promised tale.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so, though somewhat out of breath,</line>
      <line>With lips, no doubt, and visage pale,</line>
      <line>And sore too from a slight contusion,</line>
      <line>Did I, to cover my confusion,</line>
      <line> Begin the promised tale.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>The Glad Preamble (from Prelude 1850)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, there is blessing in this gentle breeze,</line>
      <line>That blows from the green fields, and from the clouds,</line>
      <line>And from the sky; it beats against my cheek,</line>
      <line>And seems half-conscious of the joy it gives.</line>
      <line> Oh welcome messenger! Oh welcome friend!</line>
      <line>A captive greets thee, coming from a house</line>
      <line>Of bondage, from yon city’s walls set free,</line>
      <line>A prison where he hath been long immured.</line>
      <line>Now I am free, enfranchised and at large,</line>
      <line>May fix my habitation where I will.</line>
      <line>What dwelling shall receive me? In what vale</line>
      <line>Shall be my harbour? Underneath what grove</line>
      <line>Shall I take up my home, and what sweet stream</line>
      <line>Shall with its murmur lull me to my rest?</line>
      <line> The earth is all before me – with a heart</line>
      <line>Joyous, nor scared at its own liberty,</line>
      <line>I look about, and should the guide I choose</line>
      <line>Be nothing better than a wandering cloud</line>
      <line>I cannot miss my way. I breathe again;</line>
      <line>Trances of thought and mountings of the mind</line>
      <line>Come fast upon me. It is shaken off –</line>
      <line>As by miraculous gift ’tis shaken off –</line>
      <line>That burden of my own unnatural self,</line>
      <line>The heavy weight of many a weary day</line>
      <line> Not mine, and such as were not made for me.</line>
      <line>Long months of peace (if such bold word accord</line>
      <line>With any promises of human life),</line>
      <line>Long months of ease and undisturbed delight</line>
      <line>Are mine in prospect. Whither shall I turn,</line>
      <line>By road or pathway, or through open field,</line>
      <line>Or shall a twig, or any floating thing</line>
      <line>Upon the river, point me out my course?</line>
      <line>Enough that I am free, for months to come</line>
      <line>May dedicate myself to chosen tasks –</line>
      <line> May quit the tiresome sea and dwell on shore</line>
      <line>If not a settler on the soil, at least</line>
      <line>To drink wild waters, and to pluck green herbs,</line>
      <line>And gather fruits fresh from their native tree.</line>
      <line>Nay more – if I may trust myself, this hour</line>
      <line>Hath brought a gift that consecrates my joy;</line>
      <line>For I, methought, while the sweet breath of heaven</line>
      <line>Was blowing on my body, felt within</line>
      <line>A corresponding, mild, creative breeze,</line>
      <line>A vital breeze, which travelled gently on</line>
      <line> O’er things which it had made, and is become</line>
      <line>A tempest, a redundant energy,</line>
      <line>Vexing its own creation. ’Tis a power</line>
      <line>That does not come unrecognized, a storm</line>
      <line>Which, breaking up a long continued frost,</line>
      <line>Brings with it vernal promises, the hope</line>
      <line>Of active days, of dignity and thought,</line>
      <line>Of prowess in an honourable field,</line>
      <line>Pure passions, virtue, knowledge and delight,</line>
      <line>The holy life of music and of verse.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>‘A Dedicated Spirit’ (from 1805 Prelude IV)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In a throng,</line>
      <line>A festal company of maids and youths,</line>
      <line>Old men and matrons staid – promiscuous rout,</line>
      <line>A medley of all tempers – I had passed</line>
      <line>The night in dancing, gaiety, and mirth,</line>
      <line>With din of instruments and shuffling feet</line>
      <line>And glancing forms and tapers glittering</line>
      <line>And unaimed prattle flying up and down,</line>
      <line>Spirits upon the stretch, and here and there</line>
      <line> Slight shocks of young love-liking interspersed</line>
      <line>That mounted up like joy into the head</line>
      <line>And tingled through the veins. Ere we retired</line>
      <line>The cock had crowed, the sky was bright with day;</line>
      <line>Two miles I had to walk along the fields</line>
      <line>Before I reached my home. Magnificent</line>
      <line>The morning was, a memorable pomp,</line>
      <line>More glorious than I ever had beheld.</line>
      <line>The sea was laughing at a distance; all</line>
      <line>The solid mountains were as bright as clouds,</line>
      <line> Grain-tinctured, drenched in empyrean light;</line>
      <line>And in the meadows and the lower grounds</line>
      <line>Was all the sweetness of a common dawn –</line>
      <line>Dews, vapours, and the melody of birds,</line>
      <line>And labourers going forth into the fields.</line>
      <line>Ah, need I say, dear friend, that to the brim</line>
      <line>My heart was full? I made no vows, but vows</line>
      <line>Were then made for me: bond unknown to me</line>
      <line>Was given that I should be, else sinning greatly,</line>
      <line>A dedicated spirit. On I walked</line>
      <line> In blessedness, which even yet remains.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1806</date>
    <title>Elegiac Stanzas, Suggested by a Picture of Peele Castle in a Storm, Painted by Sir George Beaumont</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I was thy neighbour once, thou rugged pile –</line>
      <line>Four summer weeks I dwelt in sight of thee –</line>
      <line>I saw thee every day, and all the while</line>
      <line>Thy form was sleeping on a glassy sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> So pure the sky, so quiet was the air!</line>
      <line>So like, so very like, was day to day!</line>
      <line>Whene’er I looked, thy image still was there;</line>
      <line>It trembled, but it never passed away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How perfect was the calm! It seemed no sleep –</line>
      <line>No mood, which season takes away, or brings –</line>
      <line>I could have fancied that the mighty deep</line>
      <line>Was even the gentlest of all gentle things.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! then, if mine had been the painter’s hand –</line>
      <line>To express what then I saw – and add the gleam,</line>
      <line> The light that never was on sea or land,</line>
      <line>The consecration, and the poet’s dream!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I would have planted thee, thou hoary pile,</line>
      <line>Amid a world how different from this,</line>
      <line>Beside a sea that could not cease to smile;</line>
      <line>On tranquil land, beneath a sky of bliss!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou shouldst have seemed a treasure-house, a mine</line>
      <line>Of peaceful years; a chronicle of Heaven –</line>
      <line>Of all the sunbeams that did ever shine</line>
      <line>The very sweetest had to thee been given!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> A picture had it been of lasting ease,</line>
      <line>Elysian quiet, without toil or strife;</line>
      <line>No motion but the moving tide, a breeze,</line>
      <line>Or merely silent Nature’s breathing life.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such, in the fond delusion of my heart,</line>
      <line>Such picture would I at that time have made –</line>
      <line>And seen the soul of truth in every part,</line>
      <line>A faith, a trust, that could not be betrayed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So once it would have been – ’tis so no more!</line>
      <line>I have submitted to a new control:</line>
      <line> A power is gone, which nothing can restore;</line>
      <line>A deep distress hath humanized my soul.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not for a moment could I now behold</line>
      <line>A smiling sea, and be what I have been.</line>
      <line>The feeling of my loss will ne’er be old –</line>
      <line>This, which I know, I speak with mind serene.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, Beaumont, friend (who would have been the friend,</line>
      <line>If he had lived, of him whom I deplore),</line>
      <line>This work of thine I blame not, but commend –</line>
      <line>This sea in anger, and that dismal shore!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O ’tis a passionate work – yet wise and well!</line>
      <line>Well chosen is the spirit that is here:</line>
      <line>That hulk which labours in the deadly swell,</line>
      <line>This rueful sky, this pageantry of fear!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And this huge castle, standing here sublime,</line>
      <line>I love to see the look with which it braves,</line>
      <line>Cased in the unfeeling armour of old time,</line>
      <line>The lightning, the fierce wind, and trampling waves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell, farewell the heart that lives alone,</line>
      <line>Housed in a dream, at distance from the kind!</line>
      <line> Such happiness, wherever it be known,</line>
      <line>Is to be pitied; for ’tis surely blind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But welcome fortitude, and patient cheer,</line>
      <line>And frequent sights of what is to be borne!</line>
      <line>Such sights, or worse, as are before me here –</line>
      <line>Not without hope we suffer and we mourn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>ANNA LAETITIA BARBAULD</author>
    <date>1799</date>
    <title>To Mr Coleridge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Midway the Hill of Science, after steep</line>
      <line>And rugged paths that tire the unpractised feet,</line>
      <line>A grove extends, in tangled mazes wrought,</line>
      <line>And filled with strange enchantment. Dubious shapes</line>
      <line> Flit through dim glades, and lure the eager foot</line>
      <line>Of youthful ardour to eternal chase.</line>
      <line>Dreams hang on every leaf; unearthly forms</line>
      <line>Glide through the gloom, and mystic visions swim</line>
      <line>Before the cheated sense. Athwart the mists,</line>
      <line>Far into vacant space, huge shadows stretch</line>
      <line>And seem realities; while things of life,</line>
      <line>Obvious to sight and touch, all glowing round,</line>
      <line>Fade to the hue of shadows.</line>
      <line>Scruples here,</line>
      <line>With filmy net, most like the autumnal webs</line>
      <line> Of floating gossamer, arrest the foot</line>
      <line>Of generous enterprise, and palsy Hope</line>
      <line>And fair Ambition with the chilling touch</line>
      <line>Of sickly hesitation and blank fear.</line>
      <line>Nor seldom Indolence these lawns among</line>
      <line>Fixes her turf-built seat, and wears the garb</line>
      <line>Of deep philosophy, and museful sits</line>
      <line>In dreamy twilight of the vacant mind,</line>
      <line>Soothed by the whispering shade – for soothing soft</line>
      <line>The shades, and vistas lengthening into air</line>
      <line> With moonbeam-rainbows tinted. Here each mind</line>
      <line>Of finer mould, acute and delicate,</line>
      <line>In its high progress to eternal truth</line>
      <line>Rests for a space in fairy bowers entranced,</line>
      <line>And loves the softened light and tender gloom,</line>
      <line>And (pampered with most insubstantial food)</line>
      <line>Looks down indignant on the grosser world</line>
      <line>And matter’s cumbrous shapings!</line>
      <line>Youth beloved</line>
      <line>Of Science, of the Muse beloved, not here –</line>
      <line>Not in the maze of metaphysic lore</line>
      <line> Build thou thy place of resting! Lightly tread</line>
      <line>The dangerous ground, on noble aims intent,</line>
      <line>And be this Circe of the studious cell</line>
      <line>Enjoyed but still subservient. Active scenes</line>
      <line>Shall soon with healthful spirit brace thy mind,</line>
      <line>And fair exertion (for bright fame sustained,</line>
      <line>For friends, for country) chase each spleen-fed fog</line>
      <line>That blots the wide Creation:</line>
      <line>Now Heaven conduct thee with a parent’s love!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1800</date>
    <title>Ode Inscribed to the Infant Son of S. T. Coleridge, Esq.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet baby boy, accept a stranger’s song;</line>
      <line>An untaught minstrel joys to sing of thee!</line>
      <line>And, all alone, her forest haunts among,</line>
      <line>Courts the wild tone of mazy harmony!</line>
      <line>A stranger’s song, babe of the mountain-wild,</line>
      <line>Greets thee as Inspiration’s darling child!</line>
      <line>Oh may the fine-wrought spirit of thy sire</line>
      <line>Awake thy soul and breathe upon thy lyre!</line>
      <line> And blest, amid thy mountain haunts sublime,</line>
      <line>Be all thy days, thy rosy infant days,</line>
      <line>And may the never-tiring steps of time</line>
      <line>Press lightly on with thee o’er life’s disastrous maze.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye hills, coeval with the birth of time!</line>
      <line>O Bleak summits, linked in chains of rosy light!</line>
      <line>Oh may your wonders many a year invite</line>
      <line>Your native son the breezy path to climb</line>
      <line>Where, in majestic pride of solitude,</line>
      <line>Silent and grand, the hermit thought shall trace,</line>
      <line> Far o’er the wild infinity of space,</line>
      <line>The sombre horrors of the waving wood;</line>
      <line>The misty glen; the river’s winding wave;</line>
      <line>The last deep blush of summer’s lingering day;</line>
      <line>The winter storm that, roaming unconfined,</line>
      <line>Sails on the broad wings of the impetuous wind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, whether on the breezy height</line>
      <line>Where Skiddaw greets the dawn of light,</line>
      <line>Ere the rude sons of labour homage pay</line>
      <line>To summer’s flaming eye or winter’s banner grey;</line>
      <line> Whether Lodore its silver torrent flings</line>
      <line>The mingling wonders of a thousand springs;</line>
      <line>Whether smooth Bassenthwaite, at eve’s still hour,</line>
      <line>Reflects the young moon’s crescent pale,</line>
      <line>Or meditation seeks her silent bower</line>
      <line>Amid the rocks of lonely Borrowdale –</line>
      <line>Still may thy name survive, sweet boy, till Time</line>
      <line>Shall bend to Keswick’s vale thy Skiddaw’s brow sublime!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY ROBINSON</author>
    <date>1800</date>
    <title>To the Poet Coleridge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rapt in the visionary theme,</line>
      <line>Spirit divine, with thee I’ll wander,</line>
      <line>Where the blue, wavy, lucid stream</line>
      <line>Mid forest-glooms shall slow meander!</line>
      <line> With thee I’ll trace the circling bounds</line>
      <line>Of thy new paradise, extended,</line>
      <line>And listen to the varying sounds</line>
      <line>Of winds and foamy torrents blended.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now by the source which labouring heaves</line>
      <line>The mystic fountain, bubbling, panting,</line>
      <line>While gossamer its network weaves</line>
      <line>Adown the blue lawn slanting –</line>
      <line>I’ll mark thy ‘sunny dome’ and view</line>
      <line>Thy ‘caves of ice’, thy fields of dew,</line>
      <line> Thy ever-blooming mead, whose flower</line>
      <line>Waves to the cold breath of the moonlight hour!</line>
      <line>Or when the day-star, peering bright</line>
      <line>On the grey wing of parting night,</line>
      <line>With more than vegetating power</line>
      <line>Throbs, grateful to the burning hour,</line>
      <line>As summer’s whispered sighs unfold</line>
      <line>Her million million buds of gold,</line>
      <line>Then will I climb the breezy bounds</line>
      <line>Of thy new paradise, extended,</line>
      <line> And listen to the different sounds</line>
      <line>Of winds and foamy torrents blended!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spirit divine, with thee I’ll trace</line>
      <line>Imagination’s boundless space!</line>
      <line>With thee, beneath thy ‘sunny dome’</line>
      <line>I’ll listen to the minstrel’s lay</line>
      <line>Hymning the gradual close of day,</line>
      <line>In ‘caves of ice’ enchanted roam,</line>
      <line>Where on the glittering entrance plays</line>
      <line>The moon’s beam with its silvery rays,</line>
      <line> Or when the glassy stream</line>
      <line>That through the deep dell flows</line>
      <line>Flashes the noon’s hot beam –</line>
      <line>The noon’s hot beam that midway shows</line>
      <line>Thy flaming temple, studded o’er</line>
      <line>With all Peruvia’s lustrous store!</line>
      <line>There will I trace the circling bounds</line>
      <line>Of thy new paradise, extended,</line>
      <line>And listen to the awful sounds</line>
      <line>Of winds and foamy torrents blended.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> And now I’ll pause to catch the moan</line>
      <line>Of distant breezes, cavern-pent;</line>
      <line>Now, ere the twilight tints are flown,</line>
      <line>Purpling the landscape far and wide</line>
      <line>On the dark promontory’s side</line>
      <line>I’ll gather wild-flowers dew-besprent</line>
      <line>And weave a crown for thee,</line>
      <line>Genius of Heaven-taught poesy!</line>
      <line>While, opening to my wondering eyes</line>
      <line>Thou bidst a new Creation rise,</line>
      <line> I’ll raptured trace the circling bounds</line>
      <line>Of thy rich paradise, extended,</line>
      <line>And listen to the varying sounds</line>
      <line>Of winds and foamy torrents blended.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now, with lofty tones inviting,</line>
      <line>Thy nymph, her dulcimer swift-smiting,</line>
      <line>Shall wake me in ecstatic measures,</line>
      <line>Far, far removed from mortal pleasures,</line>
      <line>In cadence rich, in cadence strong,</line>
      <line>Proving the wondrous witcheries of song!</line>
      <line> I hear her voice – thy ‘sunny dome’,</line>
      <line>Thy ‘caves of ice’, aloud repeat –</line>
      <line>Vibrations maddening, sweet,</line>
      <line>Calling the visionary wanderer home!</line>
      <line>She sings of thee, oh favoured child</line>
      <line>Of minstrelsy, sublimely wild –</line>
      <line>Of thee whose soul can feel the tone</line>
      <line>Which gives to airy dreams a magic all their own!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1802</date>
    <title>from The Castle of Indolence Stanzas</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With him there often walked in friendly wise,</line>
      <line>Or lay upon the moss by brook or tree,</line>
      <line>A noticeable man with large dark eyes</line>
      <line>And a pale face, that seemed undoubtedly</line>
      <line>As if a blooming face it ought to be!</line>
      <line>Heavy his low-hung lip did oft appear</line>
      <line>(A face divine of heaven-born idiocy);</line>
      <line>Profound his forehead was, though not severe –</line>
      <line> Yet some did think that he had little business here.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, God forfend – his was a lawful right!</line>
      <line>Noisy he was, and gamesome as a boy;</line>
      <line>His limbs would toss about him with delight</line>
      <line>Like branches when strong winds the trees annoy.</line>
      <line>He lacked not implement, device or toy,</line>
      <line>To cheat away the hours that silent were;</line>
      <line>He would have taught you how you might employ</line>
      <line>Yourself, and many did to him repair –</line>
      <line>And certés, not in vain – he had inventions rare!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Instruments had he, playthings for the ear</line>
      <line>(Long blades of grass, plucked round him as he lay,</line>
      <line>These served to catch the wind as it came near);</line>
      <line>Glasses he had with many colours gay –</line>
      <line>Others that did all little things display:</line>
      <line>The beetle with his radiance manifold</line>
      <line>(A mailéd angel on a battle day!)</line>
      <line>And leaves and flowers, and herbage green and gold,</line>
      <line>And all the glorious sights which fairies do behold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He would entice that other man to hear</line>
      <line> His music, and to view his imagery;</line>
      <line>And sooth, these two did love each other dear –</line>
      <line>As far as love in such a place could be!</line>
      <line>There did they lie, from earthly labour free,</line>
      <line>Most happy livers as were ever seen!</line>
      <line>If but a bird, to keep them company,</line>
      <line>Or butterfly sate down, they were, I ween,</line>
      <line>As pleased as if the same had been a Maiden Queen!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1805</date>
    <title>‘A Mind Debarred’ (from 18O5 Prelude VI)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O'er paths and fields</line>
      <line>In all that neighbourhood, through narrow lanes</line>
      <line>Of eglantine and through the shady woods,</line>
      <line>And o’er the Border Beacon and the waste</line>
      <line>Of naked pools and common crags that lay</line>
      <line>Exposed on the bare fell, was scattered love,</line>
      <line> A spirit of pleasure and youth’s golden gleam.</line>
      <line>Oh friend, we had not seen thee at that time,</line>
      <line>And yet a power is on me and a strong</line>
      <line>Confusion, and I seem to plant thee there!</line>
      <line>Far art thou wandered now in search of health</line>
      <line>And milder breezes – melancholy lot –</line>
      <line>But thou art with us, with us in the past,</line>
      <line>The present, with us in the times to come.</line>
      <line>There is no grief, no sorrow, no despair,</line>
      <line>No languor, no dejection, no dismay,</line>
      <line> No absence scarcely can there be, for those</line>
      <line>Who love as we do. Speed thee well! Divide</line>
      <line>Thy pleasure with us; thy returning strength,</line>
      <line>Receive it daily as a joy of ours;</line>
      <line>Share with us thy fresh spirits, whether gift</line>
      <line>Of gales Etesian or of loving thoughts.</line>
      <line>I too have been a wanderer – but alas,</line>
      <line>How different is the fate of different men</line>
      <line>Though twins almost in genius and in mind!</line>
      <line>Unknown unto each other (yea, and breathing</line>
      <line> As if in different elements) we were framed</line>
      <line>To bend at last to the same discipline,</line>
      <line>Predestined if two beings ever were</line>
      <line>To seek the same delights, and have one health,</line>
      <line>One happiness. Throughout this narrative,</line>
      <line>Else sooner ended, I have known full well</line>
      <line>For whom I thus record the birth and growth</line>
      <line>Of gentleness, simplicity, and truth,</line>
      <line>And joyous loves that hallow innocent days</line>
      <line>Of peace and self-command. Of rivers, fields,</line>
      <line> And groves I speak to thee, my friend – to thee</line>
      <line>Who, yet a liveried schoolboy in the depths</line>
      <line>Of the huge city, on the leaded roof</line>
      <line>Of that wide edifice, thy home and school,</line>
      <line>Wast used to lie and gaze upon the clouds</line>
      <line>Moving in heaven, or haply, tired of this,</line>
      <line>To shut thine eyes and by internal light</line>
      <line>See trees, and meadows, and thy native stream,</line>
      <line>Far distant, thus beheld from year to year</line>
      <line>Of thy long exile.</line>
      <line>Nor could I forget</line>
      <line> In this late portion of my argument</line>
      <line>That scarcely had I finally resigned</line>
      <line>My rights among those academic bowers</line>
      <line>When thou wert thither guided. From the heart</line>
      <line>Of London, and from the cloisters there, thou camest,</line>
      <line>And didst sit down in temperance and peace,</line>
      <line>A rigorous student. What a stormy course</line>
      <line>Then followed! Oh, it is a pang that calls</line>
      <line>For utterance to think how small a change</line>
      <line>Of circumstances might to thee have spared</line>
      <line> A world of pain, ripened ten thousand hopes</line>
      <line>For ever withered.</line>
      <line>Through this retrospect</line>
      <line>Of my own college life I still have had</line>
      <line>Thy after-sojourn in the self-same place</line>
      <line>Present before my eyes, have played with times</line>
      <line>(I speak of private business of the thought)</line>
      <line>And accidents as children do with cards,</line>
      <line>Or as a man who when his house is built,</line>
      <line>A frame locked up in wood and stone, doth still</line>
      <line>In impotence of mind by his fireside</line>
      <line>Rebuild it to his liking. I have thought</line>
      <line>Of thee, thy learning, gorgeous eloquence,</line>
      <line>And all the strength and plumage of thy youth,</line>
      <line>Thy subtle speculations, toils abstruse</line>
      <line>Among the schoolmen, and Platonic forms</line>
      <line>Of wild ideal pageantry, shaped out</line>
      <line>From things well-matched or ill, and words for things –</line>
      <line>The self-created sustenance of a mind</line>
      <line>Debarred from Nature’s living images,</line>
      <line>Compelled to be a life unto itself,</line>
      <line> And unrelentingly possessed by thirst</line>
      <line>Of greatness, love, and beauty.</line>
      <line>Not alone,</line>
      <line>Ah, surely not in singleness of heart,</line>
      <line>Should I have seen the light of evening fade</line>
      <line>Upon the silent Cam, if we had met</line>
      <line>Even at that early time. I needs must hope,</line>
      <line>Must feel, must trust, that my maturer age</line>
      <line>And temperature less willing to be moved,</line>
      <line>My calmer habits and more steady voice,</line>
      <line>Would with an influence benign have soothed</line>
      <line> Or chased away the airy wretchedness</line>
      <line>That battened on thy youth. But thou hast trod,</line>
      <line>In watchful meditation thou hast trod,</line>
      <line>A march of glory, which does put to shame</line>
      <line>These vain regrets.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1806</date>
    <title>A Complaint</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a change, and I am poor!</line>
      <line>Your love hath been, nor long ago,</line>
      <line>A fountain at my fond heart’s door,</line>
      <line>Whose only business was to flow –</line>
      <line> And flow it did; not taking heed</line>
      <line>Of its own bounty, or my need.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What happy moments did I count –</line>
      <line>Blest was I then all bliss above!</line>
      <line>Now, for that consecrated fount</line>
      <line>Of murmuring, sparkling, living love,</line>
      <line>What have I? Shall I dare to tell?</line>
      <line>A comfortless and hidden well.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A well of love. It may be deep</line>
      <line>(I trust it is), and never dry –</line>
      <line> What matter, if the waters sleep</line>
      <line>In silence and obscurity?</line>
      <line>Such change, and at the very door</line>
      <line>Of my fond heart, hath made me poor.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>MARY TIGHE</author>
    <date>1803</date>
    <title>‘Dreams of Delight, Farewell’ (Psyche, concluding stanzas)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With fond embrace she clasped her long lost son,</line>
      <line> And gracefully received his lovely bride:</line>
      <line>‘Psyche! thou hardly hast my favour won!’</line>
      <line>With roseate smile her Heavenly parent cried,</line>
      <line>‘Yet hence thy charms immortal, deified,</line>
      <line>With the young Joys, thy future offspring fair,</line>
      <line>Shall bloom for ever at thy lover’s side!</line>
      <line>All-ruling Jove’s high mandate I declare –</line>
      <line>Blest denizen of Heaven, arise its joys to share!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She ceased, and lo! a thousand voices, joined</line>
      <line>In sweetest chorus, Love’s high triumph sing;</line>
      <line> There, with the Graces and the Hours entwined,</line>
      <line>His fairy train their rosy garlands bring,</line>
      <line>Or round their mistress sport on halcyon wing;</line>
      <line>While she enraptured lives in his dear eye,</line>
      <line>And drinks immortal love from that pure spring</line>
      <line>Of never-failing full felicity,</line>
      <line>Bathed in ambrosial showers of bliss eternally!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dreams of delight, farewell – your charms no more</line>
      <line>Shall gild the hours of solitary gloom!</line>
      <line>The page remains, but can the page restore</line>
      <line> The vanished bowers which Fancy taught to bloom?</line>
      <line>Ah, no! her smiles no longer can illume</line>
      <line>The path my Psyche treads no more for me.</line>
      <line>Consigned to dark oblivion’s silent tomb,</line>
      <line>The visionary scenes no more I see,</line>
      <line>Fast from the fading lines the vivid colours flee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1807</date>
    <title>To William Wordsworth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh friend! Oh teacher! God’s great gift to me!</line>
      <line>Into my heart have I received that lay</line>
      <line>More than historic, that prophetic lay,</line>
      <line>Wherein (high theme by thee first sung aright)</line>
      <line> Of the foundations and the building-up</line>
      <line>Of thy own spirit thou hast loved to tell</line>
      <line>What may be told, to the understanding mind</line>
      <line>Revealable – and what within the mind</line>
      <line>May rise enkindled.</line>
      <line>Theme hard as high!</line>
      <line>Of smiles spontaneous and mysterious fears:</line>
      <line>The firstborn they of Reason, and twin-birth.</line>
      <line>Of tides obedient to external force,</line>
      <line>And currents self-determined (as might seem),</line>
      <line>Or by interior power. Of moments awful,</line>
      <line> Now in thy hidden life, and now abroad</line>
      <line>Mid festive crowds (thy brows too garlanded,</line>
      <line>A brother of the feast). Of fancies fair,</line>
      <line>Hyblaean murmurs of poetic thought</line>
      <line>Industrious in its joy, by lilied streams</line>
      <line>Native or outland, lakes and famous hills.</line>
      <line>Of more than fancy: of the hope of man</line>
      <line>Amid the tremor of a realm aglow,</line>
      <line>Where France in all her towns lay vibrating,</line>
      <line>Even as a bark becalmed on sultry seas</line>
      <line> Beneath the voice from Heaven – the bursting crash</line>
      <line>Of Heaven’s immediate thunder, when no cloud</line>
      <line>Is visible, or shadow on the main</line>
      <line>(Ah, soon night rolled on night, and every cloud</line>
      <line>Opened its eye of fire; and Hope aloft</line>
      <line>Now fluttered, and now tossed, upon the storm</line>
      <line>Floating). Of Hope afflicted and struck down –</line>
      <line>Thence summoned homeward, homeward to thy heart,</line>
      <line>Oft from the watchtower of man’s absolute self</line>
      <line>(With light unwaning in her eyes) to look</line>
      <line> Far on, herself a glory to behold,</line>
      <line>The Angel of the Vision! Then – last strain! –</line>
      <line>Of Duty (chosen laws controlling choice),</line>
      <line>Virtue and Love! An Orphic tale indeed,</line>
      <line>A tale divine of high and passionate thoughts</line>
      <line>To their own music chanted.</line>
      <line>Ah great Bard,</line>
      <line>Ere yet that last swell dying awed the air,</line>
      <line>With steadfast ken I viewed thee in the choir</line>
      <line>Of ever-enduring men! The truly great</line>
      <line>Have all one age, and from one visible space</line>
      <line> Shed influence, for they – both power, and act –</line>
      <line>Are permanent, and time is not with them,</line>
      <line>Save as it worketh for them, they in it.</line>
      <line>Nor less a sacred roll than those of old</line>
      <line>(And to be placed, as they, with gradual fame</line>
      <line>Among the archives of mankind), thy work</line>
      <line>Makes audible a linkéd song of truth –</line>
      <line>Of truth profound, a sweet continuous song,</line>
      <line>Not learnt, but native, her own natural notes!</line>
      <line>Dear shall it be to every human heart –</line>
      <line> To me how more than dearest – me, on whom</line>
      <line>Comfort from thee, and utterance of thy love,</line>
      <line>Came with such heights and depths of harmony,</line>
      <line>Such sense of wings uplifting, that the storm</line>
      <line>Scattered and whirled me, till my thoughts</line>
      <line>Became a bodily tumult, and thy faithful hopes</line>
      <line>(Thy hopes of me, my friend, by me unfelt)</line>
      <line>Were troublous to me, almost as a voice</line>
      <line>Familiar once, and more than musical,</line>
      <line>To one cast forth whose hope had seemed to die –</line>
      <line> A wanderer with a worn-out heart,</line>
      <line>Mid strangers pining with untended wounds.</line>
      <line>Oh friend, too well thou knowst of what sad years</line>
      <line>The long suppression had benumbed my soul,</line>
      <line>That even as life returns upon the drowned</line>
      <line>The unusual joy awoke a throng of pains:</line>
      <line>Keen pangs of love (awakening, as a babe,</line>
      <line>Turbulent, with an outcry in the heart),</line>
      <line>And fears self-willed, that shunned the eye of hope,</line>
      <line>And hope that would not know itself from fear –</line>
      <line> Sense of past youth, and manhood come in vain,</line>
      <line>And genius given, and knowledge won in vain;</line>
      <line>And all which I had culled in wood-walks wild,</line>
      <line>And all which patient toil had reared, and all,</line>
      <line>Commune with thee had opened out, but flowers</line>
      <line>Strewed on my corse, and borne upon my bier</line>
      <line>In the same coffin, for the self-same grave.</line>
      <line>That way no more! And ill beseems it me,</line>
      <line>Who came a welcomer, in herald’s guise</line>
      <line>Singing of glory and futurity,</line>
      <line> To wander back on such unhealthful roads</line>
      <line>Plucking the poisons of self-harm! And ill</line>
      <line>Such intertwine beseems triumphal wreathes</line>
      <line>Strewed before thy advancing! Thou too, friend!</line>
      <line>Oh injure not the memory of that hour</line>
      <line>Of thy communion with my nobler mind</line>
      <line>By pity or grief, already felt too long!</line>
      <line>Nor let my words import more blame than needs:</line>
      <line>The tumult rose, and ceased – for peace is nigh</line>
      <line>Where wisdom’s voice has found a listening heart.</line>
      <line> Amid the howl of more that wintry storms</line>
      <line>The halcyon hears the voice of vernal hours</line>
      <line>Already on the wing!</line>
      <line>Eve following eve</line>
      <line>(Dear tranquil time, when the sweet sense of home</line>
      <line>Becomes most sweet) – hours for their own sake hailed,</line>
      <line>And more desired, more precious, for thy song!</line>
      <line>In silence listening, like a devout child,</line>
      <line>My soul lay passive: by thy various strain</line>
      <line>Driven as in surges now, beneath the stars</line>
      <line>(With momentary stars of my own birth –</line>
      <line>Fair constellated foam – still darting off</line>
      <line>Into the darkness), now a tranquil sea</line>
      <line>Outspread and bright, yet swelling to the moon!</line>
      <line>And when, oh friend, my comforter, my guide,</line>
      <line>Strong in thyself and powerful to give strength,</line>
      <line>Thy long sustainéd lay finally closed,</line>
      <line>And thy deep voice had ceased (yet thou thyself</line>
      <line>Wert still before mine eyes, and round us both</line>
      <line>That happy vision of beloved faces –</line>
      <line>All whom I deepliest love, in one room, all),</line>
      <line> Scarce conscious, and yet conscious of its close,</line>
      <line>I sat, my being blended in one thought –</line>
      <line>Thought was it, or aspiration, or resolve? –</line>
      <line>Absorbed, yet hanging still upon the sound.</line>
      <line>And when I rose, I found myself in prayer.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1809</date>
    <title>From English Bards and Scotch Reviewers</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Time was, ere yet in these degenerate days</line>
      <line>Ignoble themes obtained mistaken praise,</line>
      <line>When sense and wit, with poesy allied –</line>
      <line>No fabled graces – flourished side by side,</line>
      <line> From the same fount their inspiration drew,</line>
      <line>And, reared by taste, bloomed fairer as they grew.</line>
      <line>Then in this happy isle a Pope’s pure strain</line>
      <line>Sought the rapt soul to charm, nor sought in vain –</line>
      <line>A polished nation’s praise aspired to claim,</line>
      <line>And raised the people’s, as the poet’s, fame.</line>
      <line>Like him great Dryden poured the tide of song,</line>
      <line>In stream less smooth indeed, yet doubly strong.</line>
      <line>Then Congreve’s scenes could cheer, or Otway’s melt –</line>
      <line>For nature then an English audience felt.</line>
      <line> But why these names, or greater still, retrace,</line>
      <line>When all to feebler bards resign their place?</line>
      <line>Yet to such times our lingering looks are cast,</line>
      <line>When taste and reason with those times are past.</line>
      <line>No, look around, and turn each trifling page,</line>
      <line>Survey the precious works that please the age!</line>
      <line>This truth at least let satire’s self allow,</line>
      <line>No dearth of bards can be complained of now:</line>
      <line>The loaded press beneath her labour groans,</line>
      <line>And printer’s devils shake their weary bones,</line>
      <line> While Southey’s epics cram the creaking shelves,</line>
      <line>And Little’s lyrics shine in hot-pressed twelves!</line>
      <line>Behold in various throngs the scribbling crew,</line>
      <line>For notice eager, pass in long review:</line>
      <line>Each spurs his jaded Pegasus apace,</line>
      <line>And rhyme and blank maintain an equal race;</line>
      <line>Sonnets on sonnets crowd, and ode on ode,</line>
      <line>And Tales of Terror jostle on the road.</line>
      <line>Immeasurable measures move along,</line>
      <line>For simpering Folly loves a varied song</line>
      <line> (To strange, mysterious Dullness still the friend),</line>
      <line>Admires the strain she cannot comprehend!</line>
      <line>Thus Lays of Minstrels – may they be the last! –</line>
      <line>On half-strung harps, whine mournful to the blast…</line>
      <line> With eagle-pinions soaring to the skies,</line>
      <line>Behold the ballad-monger Southey rise –</line>
      <line>To him let Camoëns, Milton, Tasso yield –</line>
      <line>Whose annual strains like armies take the field.</line>
      <line>First in the ranks let Joan of Arc advance,</line>
      <line>The scourge of England and the boast of France!</line>
      <line>Though burnt by wicked Bedford as a witch,</line>
      <line>Behold her statue placed in glory’s niche –</line>
      <line>Her fetters burst, and just released from prison,</line>
      <line>A virgin Phoenix from her ashes risen.</line>
      <line> Next see tremendous Thalaba come on,</line>
      <line>Arabia’s monstrous, wild and wondrous son,</line>
      <line>Domdaniel’s dread destroyer, who o’erthrew</line>
      <line>More mad magicians than the world e’er knew.</line>
      <line>Immortal hero, all thy foes o’ercome,</line>
      <line>For ever reign – the rival of Tom Thumb!</line>
      <line>Since startled metre fled before thy face,</line>
      <line>Well wert thou doomed the last of all thy race,</line>
      <line>Well might triumphant genii bear thee hence,</line>
      <line>Illustrious conqueror of common sense!</line>
      <line>Now, last and greatest, Madoc spreads his sails,</line>
      <line>Cacique in Mexico, and Prince in Wales;</line>
      <line>Tells us strange tales, as other travellers do,</line>
      <line>More old than Mandeville’s, and not so true!</line>
      <line>Oh Southey, Southey, cease thy varied song –</line>
      <line>A bard may chant too often and too long!</line>
      <line>As thou art strong in verse, in mercy spare –</line>
      <line>A fourth, alas, were more than we could bear!</line>
      <line>But if, in spite of all the world can say,</line>
      <line>Thou still will verseward plod thy weary way,</line>
      <line> If still in Berkeley-ballads most uncivil</line>
      <line>Thou wilt devote old women to the Devil</line>
      <line>(The babe unborn thy dread intent may rue),</line>
      <line>‘God help thee’, Southey, and thy readers too!</line>
      <line>Next comes the dull disciple of thy school,</line>
      <line>That mild apostate from poetic rule,</line>
      <line>The simple Wordsworth, framer of a lay</line>
      <line>As soft as evening in his favourite May,</line>
      <line>Who warns his friend ‘to shake off toil and trouble,</line>
      <line>And quit his books, for fear of growing double’;</line>
      <line> Who both by precept and example shows</line>
      <line>That prose is verse, and verse is merely prose,</line>
      <line>Convincing all (by demonstration plain)</line>
      <line>Poetic souls delight in prose insane,</line>
      <line>And Christmas-stories, tortured into rhyme,</line>
      <line>Contain the essence of the true sublime.</line>
      <line>Thus when he tells the tale of Betty Foy,</line>
      <line>The idiot mother of an ‘Idiot Boy’,</line>
      <line>A moon-struck silly lad who lost his way,</line>
      <line>And, like his bard, confounded night with day,</line>
      <line> So close on each pathetic part he dwells,</line>
      <line>And each adventure so sublimely tells,</line>
      <line>That all who view the ‘idiot in his glory’</line>
      <line>Conceive the bard the hero of the story!</line>
      <line>Shall gentle Coleridge pass unnoticed here,</line>
      <line>To turgid ode and tumid stanza dear?</line>
      <line>Though themes of innocence amuse him best,</line>
      <line>Yet still obscurity’s a welcome guest.</line>
      <line>If inspiration should her aid refuse</line>
      <line>To him who takes a pixy for a muse,</line>
      <line> Yet none in lofty numbers can surpass</line>
      <line>The bard who soars to elegize and ass!</line>
      <line>How well the subject suits his noble mind –</line>
      <line>A fellow-feeling makes us wondrous kind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1811</date>
    <title>From Feast of the Poets</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All on a sudden, there rose on the stairs</line>
      <line>A noise as of persons with singular airs,</line>
      <line>You’d have thought ’twas the Bishops or Judges a-coming,</line>
      <line>Or whole court of Aldermen hawing and humming,</line>
      <line>Or Abbot at least, with his ushers before,</line>
      <line>But ’twas only Bob Southey and two or three more.</line>
      <line>As soon as he saw him Apollo seemed pleased,</line>
      <line>But as he had settled it not to be teased</line>
      <line>By all the vain dreamers from bedroom and brook,</line>
      <line>He turned from the rest without even a look!</line>
      <line>For Coleridge had vexed him long since I suppose</line>
      <line> By his idling, and gabbling, and muddling in prose,</line>
      <line>And Wordsworth one day made his very hairs bristle</line>
      <line>By going and changing his harp for a whistle!</line>
      <line>These heroes however, long used to attack,</line>
      <line>Were not by contempt to be so driven back</line>
      <line>But followed the God up, and shifting their place</line>
      <line>Stood full in his presence and looked in his face –</line>
      <line>When one began spouting the cream of orations</line>
      <line>In praise of bombarding his friends and relations,</line>
      <line>And tother some lines he had made on a straw,</line>
      <line> Showing how he had found it and what it was for,</line>
      <line>And how, when ’twas balanced, it stood like a spell!</line>
      <line>And how, when ’twas balanced no longer, it fell!</line>
      <line>A wild thing of scorn he described it to be,</line>
      <line>But he said it was patient to Heaven’s decree –</line>
      <line>Then he gazed upon nothing, and looking forlorn,</line>
      <line>Dropped a natural tear for that wild thing of scorn!</line>
      <line>Apollo half laughed betwixt anger and mirth,</line>
      <line>‘And cried was there ever such trifling on Earth?</line>
      <line>It is not enough that this nonsense, I fear,</line>
      <line> Has hurt the fine head of my friend Robert here,</line>
      <line>But the very best promise bred up in this school</line>
      <line>Must show himself proudest in playing the fool.</line>
      <line>What – think ye a bard’s a mere gossip, who tells</line>
      <line>Of the everyday feelings of everyone else,</line>
      <line>And that poetry lies, not in something select,</line>
      <line>But in gathering the refuse that others reject.</line>
      <line>Must a ballad doled out by a spectacled nurse</line>
      <line>About Two-Shoes or Thumb be your model in verse,</line>
      <line>And your writings, instead of sound fancy and style,</line>
      <line> Look more like the morbid abstractions of bile?</line>
      <line>There is one of you here – ’twas of him that I spoke</line>
      <line>Who, instead of becoming a byeword and joke,</line>
      <line>Should have brought back our fine old pre-eminent way,</line>
      <line>And been the first man at my table today.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LORD BYRON</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>‘’Tis to Create’ (from Childe Harold III)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In my youth’s summer I did sing of one,</line>
      <line>The wandering outlaw of his own dark mind;</line>
      <line>Again I seize the theme, then but begun,</line>
      <line>And bear it with me, as the rushing wind</line>
      <line>Bears the cloud onwards. In that tale I find</line>
      <line>The furrows of long thought, and dried-up tears</line>
      <line> Which, ebbing, leave a sterile track behind,</line>
      <line>O’er which all heavily the journeying years</line>
      <line>Plod the last sands of life – where not a flower appears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Since my young days of passion – joy, or pain –</line>
      <line>Perchance my heart and harp have lost a string,</line>
      <line>And both may jar. It may be that in vain</line>
      <line>I would essay as I have sung to sing;</line>
      <line>Yet, though a dreary strain, to this I cling.</line>
      <line>So that it wean me from the weary dream</line>
      <line>Of selfish grief or gladness – so it fling</line>
      <line> Forgetfulness around me – it shall seem</line>
      <line>To me, though to none else, a not ungrateful theme.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He who, grown agéd in this world of woe,</line>
      <line>In deeds not years piercing the depths of life,</line>
      <line>So that no wonder waits him (nor below</line>
      <line>Can love or sorrow, fame, ambition, strife,</line>
      <line>Cut to his heart again with the keen knife</line>
      <line>Of silent, sharp endurance) – he can tell</line>
      <line>Why thought seeks refuge in lone caves, yet rife</line>
      <line>With airy images, and shapes which dwell</line>
      <line> Still unimpaired, though old, in the soul’s haunted cell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis to create, and in creating live</line>
      <line>A being more intense, that we endow</line>
      <line>With form our fancy, gaining as we give</line>
      <line>The life we image – even as I do now!</line>
      <line>What am I? Nothing. But not so art thou,</line>
      <line>Soul of my thought, with whom I traverse earth,</line>
      <line>Invisible but gazing, as I glow</line>
      <line>Mixed with thy spirit, blended with thy birth,</line>
      <line>And feeling still with thee in my crushed feelings’ dearth.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1816</date>
    <title>To Wordsworth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Poet of Nature, thou hast wept to know</line>
      <line>That things depart which never may return:</line>
      <line>Childhood and youth, friendship and love’s first glow,</line>
      <line>Have fled like sweet dreams, leaving thee to mourn.</line>
      <line> These common woes I feel. One loss is mine</line>
      <line>Which thou too feel’st, yet I alone deplore.</line>
      <line>Thou wert as a lone star, whose light did shine</line>
      <line>On some frail bark in winter’s midnight roar;</line>
      <line>Thou hast, like to a rock-built refuge, stood</line>
      <line>Above the blind and battling multitude;</line>
      <line>In honoured poverty thy voice did weave</line>
      <line>Songs consecrate to truth and liberty –</line>
      <line>Deserting these, thou leavest me to grieve,</line>
      <line>Thus having been, that thou shouldst cease to be.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1817</date>
    <title>Sleep and Poetry</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh for ten years, that I may overwhelm</line>
      <line>Myself in poesy – so I may do the deed</line>
      <line>That my own soul has to itself decreed.</line>
      <line>Then will I pass the countries that I see</line>
      <line>In long perspective, and continually</line>
      <line>Taste their pure fountains. First the realm I’ll pass</line>
      <line>Of Flora, and old Pan: sleep in the grass,</line>
      <line>Feed upon apples red and strawberries,</line>
      <line>And choose each pleasure that my fancy sees –</line>
      <line>Catch the white-handed nymphs in shady places</line>
      <line>To woo sweet kisses from averted faces,</line>
      <line>Play with their fingers, touch their shoulders white</line>
      <line>Into a pretty shrinking with a bite</line>
      <line>As hard as lips can make it, till, agreed,</line>
      <line>A lovely tale of human life we’ll read.</line>
      <line>And one will teach a tame dove how it best</line>
      <line>May fan the cool air gently o’er my rest;</line>
      <line>Another, bending o’er her nimble tread,</line>
      <line>Will set a green robe floating round her head,</line>
      <line> And still will dance with ever varied ease,</line>
      <line>Smiling upon the flowers and the trees;</line>
      <line>Another will entice me on, and on</line>
      <line>Through almond blossoms and rich cinnamon,</line>
      <line>Till in the bosom of a leafy world</line>
      <line>We rest in silence, like two gems upcurled</line>
      <line>In the recesses of a pearly shell.</line>
      <line>And can I ever bid these joys farewell?</line>
      <line>Yes, I must pass them for a nobler life,</line>
      <line>Where I may find the agonies, the strife</line>
      <line> Of human hearts – for lo, I see afar,</line>
      <line>O’ersailing the blue cragginess, a car</line>
      <line>And steeds with streamy manes. The charioteer</line>
      <line>Looks out upon the winds with glorious fear –</line>
      <line>And now the numerous tramplings quiver lightly</line>
      <line>Along a huge cloud’s ridge; and now, with sprightly</line>
      <line>Wheel, downward come they into fresher skies,</line>
      <line>Tipt round with silver from the sun’s bright eyes.</line>
      <line>Still downward with capacious whirl they glide,</line>
      <line>And now I see them on a green hillside</line>
      <line> In breezy rest among the nodding stalks.</line>
      <line>The charioteer with wondrous gesture talks</line>
      <line>To the trees and mountains, and there soon appear</line>
      <line>Shapes of delight, of mystery, and fear,</line>
      <line>Passing along before a dusky space</line>
      <line>Made by some mighty oaks. As they would chase</line>
      <line>Some ever-fleeting music, on they sweep!</line>
      <line>Lo, how they murmur, laugh, and smile, and weep –</line>
      <line>Some with upholden hand and mouth severe;</line>
      <line>Some with their faces muffled to the ear</line>
      <line> Between their arms; some, clear in youthful bloom,</line>
      <line>Go glad and smilingly athwart the gloom;</line>
      <line>Some looking back, and some with upward gaze.</line>
      <line>Yes, thousands in a thousand different ways</line>
      <line>Flit onward: now a lovely wreath of girls</line>
      <line>Dancing their sleek hair into tangled curls –</line>
      <line>And now broad wings! Most awfully intent</line>
      <line>The driver of those steeds is forward bent,</line>
      <line>And seems to listen – oh that I might know</line>
      <line>All that he writes with such a hurrying glow!</line>
      <line> The visions all are fled – the car is fled</line>
      <line>Into the light of Heaven – and in their stead</line>
      <line>A sense of real things comes doubly strong,</line>
      <line>And, like a muddy stream, would bear along</line>
      <line>My soul to nothingness! But I will strive</line>
      <line>Against all doubtings, and will keep alive</line>
      <line>The thought of that same chariot, and the strange</line>
      <line>Journey it went.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>JOHN KEATS</author>
    <date>1819</date>
    <title>from The Fall of Hyperion: A Dream (Canto I)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fanatics have their dreams, wherewith they weave</line>
      <line>A paradise for a sect; the savage too</line>
      <line>From forth the loftiest fashion of his sleep</line>
      <line>Guesses at Heaven – pity these have not</line>
      <line> Traced upon vellum or wild Indian leaf</line>
      <line>The shadows of melodious utterance!</line>
      <line>But bare of laurel they live, dream, and die –</line>
      <line>For poesy alone can tell her dreams –</line>
      <line>With the fine spell of words alone can save</line>
      <line>Imagination from the sable chain</line>
      <line>And dumb enchantment. Who alive can say</line>
      <line>‘Thou art no poet – mayst not tell thy dreams!’</line>
      <line>Since every man whose soul is not a clod</line>
      <line>Hath visions, and would speak, if he had loved,</line>
      <line> And been well nurtured in, his mother tongue.</line>
      <line>Whether the dream now purposed to rehearse</line>
      <line>Be poet’s or fanatic’s will be known</line>
      <line>When this warm scribe my hand is in the grave.</line>
      <line>Methought I stood where trees of every clime,</line>
      <line>Palm, myrtle, oak, and sycamore, and beech,</line>
      <line>With plantain and spice-blossoms, made a screen –</line>
      <line>In neighbourhood of fountains (by the noise</line>
      <line>Soft-showering in my ears), and (by the touch</line>
      <line>Of scent) not far from roses. Turning round</line>
      <line> I saw an arbour with a drooping roof</line>
      <line>Of trellis-vines, and bells, and larger blooms,</line>
      <line>Like floral censers, swinging light in air…</line>
      <line>Then to the west I looked, and saw far off</line>
      <line>An image, huge of feature as a cloud,</line>
      <line>At level of whose feet an altar slept,</line>
      <line>To be approached on either side by steps</line>
      <line>And marble balustrade, and patient travail</line>
      <line>To count with toil the innumerable degrees.</line>
      <line>Towards the altar sober-paced I went,</line>
      <line>Repressing haste as too unholy there,</line>
      <line> And, coming nearer, saw beside the shrine</line>
      <line>One ministering – and there arose a flame.</line>
      <line>When in mid-May the sickening east wind</line>
      <line>Shifts sudden to the south, the small warm rain</line>
      <line>Melts out the frozen incense from all flowers,</line>
      <line>And fills the air with so much pleasant health</line>
      <line>That even the dying man forgets his shroud –</line>
      <line>Even so that lofty sacrificial fire,</line>
      <line>Sending forth Maian incense, spread around</line>
      <line>Forgetfulness of everything but bliss,</line>
      <line>And clouded all the altar with soft smoke</line>
      <line>From whose white fragrant curtains thus I heard</line>
      <line>Language pronounced: ‘If thou canst not ascend</line>
      <line>These steps, die on that marble where thou art!</line>
      <line>Thy flesh, near cousin to the common dust,</line>
      <line>Will parch for lack of nutriment – thy bones</line>
      <line>Will wither in few years, and vanish so</line>
      <line>That not the quickest eye could find a grain</line>
      <line>Of what thou now art on that pavement cold.</line>
      <line>The sands of thy short life are spent this hour,</line>
      <line> And no hand in the universe can turn</line>
      <line>Thy hourglass if these gummed leaves be burnt</line>
      <line>Ere thou canst mount up these immortal steps.’</line>
      <line>I heard, I looked: two senses – both at once</line>
      <line>So fine, so subtle – felt the tyranny</line>
      <line>Of that fierce threat and the hard task proposed.</line>
      <line>Prodigious seemed the toil! The leaves were yet</line>
      <line>Burning, when suddenly a palsied chill</line>
      <line>Struck from the pavéd level up my limbs,</line>
      <line>And was ascending quick to put cold grasp</line>
      <line> Upon those streams that pulse beside the throat –</line>
      <line>I shrieked, and the sharp anguish of my shriek</line>
      <line>Stung my own ears – I strove hard to escape</line>
      <line>The numbness, strove to gain the lowest step!</line>
      <line>Slow, heavy, deadly was my pace. The cold</line>
      <line>Grew stifling, suffocating at the heart,</line>
      <line>And when I clasped my hands I felt them not.</line>
      <line>One minute before death, my iced foot touched</line>
      <line>The lowest stair, and, as it touched, life seemed</line>
      <line>To pour in at the toes – I mounted up,</line>
      <line> As once fair angels on a ladder flew</line>
      <line>From the green turf to Heaven.</line>
      <line>‘Holy Power’,</line>
      <line>Cried I, approaching near the hornéd shrine,</line>
      <line>‘What am I that should so be saved from death?</line>
      <line>What am I that another death come not</line>
      <line>To choke my utterance sacrilegious here?’</line>
      <line>Then said the veiléd shadow: ‘Thou hast felt</line>
      <line>What ’tis to die and live again before</line>
      <line>Thy fated hour. That thou hadst power to do so</line>
      <line>Is thy own safety – thou hast dated on</line>
      <line> Thy doom.’ ‘High Prophetess’, said I, ‘purge off</line>
      <line>Benign, if so it please thee, my mind’s film.’</line>
      <line>‘None can usurp this height’, returned that shade,</line>
      <line>‘But those to whom the miseries of the world</line>
      <line>Are misery, and will not let them rest.</line>
      <line>All else who find a haven in the world</line>
      <line>Where they may thoughtless sleep away their days,</line>
      <line>If by a chance into this fane they come,</line>
      <line>Rot on the pavement where thou rottedst half!’</line>
      <line>‘Are there not thousands in the world’, said I,</line>
      <line> Encouraged by the sooth voice of the shade,</line>
      <line>‘Who love their fellows even to the death,</line>
      <line>Who feel the giant agony of the world,</line>
      <line>And more, like slaves to poor humanity</line>
      <line>Labour for mortal good? I sure should see</line>
      <line>Other men here – but I am here alone.’</line>
      <line>‘Those whom thou spakest of are no visionaries’,</line>
      <line>Rejoined that voice, ‘they are no dreamers weak,</line>
      <line>They seek no wonder but the human face,</line>
      <line>No music but a happy-noted voice!</line>
      <line> They come not here, they have no thought to come –</line>
      <line>And thou art here, for thou art less than they.</line>
      <line>What benefit canst thou do, or all thy tribe,</line>
      <line>To the great world? Thou art a dreaming thing,</line>
      <line>A fever of thyself! Think of the earth –</line>
      <line>What bliss even in hope is there for thee?</line>
      <line>What haven? Every creature hath its home,</line>
      <line>Every sole man hath days of joy and pain,</line>
      <line>Whether his labours be sublime or low:</line>
      <line>The pain alone, the joy alone – distinct.</line>
      <line> Only the dreamer venoms all his days,</line>
      <line>Bearing more woe than all his sins deserve.</line>
      <line>Therefore – that happiness be somewhat shared –</line>
      <line>Such things as thou art are admitted oft</line>
      <line>Into like gardens thou didst pass erewhile,</line>
      <line>And suffered in these temples! For that cause</line>
      <line>Thou standest safe beneath this statue’s knees.’</line>
      <line>‘That I am favoured for unworthiness</line>
      <line>By such propitious parley, medicined</line>
      <line>In sickness not ignoble, I rejoice –</line>
      <line> Aye, and could weep for love of such award.’</line>
      <line>So answered I, continuing, ‘If it please,</line>
      <line>Majestic shadow, tell me: sure not all</line>
      <line>Those melodies sung into the world’s ear</line>
      <line>Are useless – sure a poet is a sage,</line>
      <line>A humanist, physician to all men?</line>
      <line>That I am none I feel – as vultures feel</line>
      <line>They are no birds when eagles are abroad.</line>
      <line>What am I then? Thou spakest of my tribe –</line>
      <line>What tribe?’</line>
      <line>The tall shade veiled in drooping white</line>
      <line> Then spake, so much more earnest that the breath</line>
      <line>Moved the thin linen folds that drooping hung</line>
      <line>About a golden censer from the hand</line>
      <line>Pendent: ‘Art thou not of the dreamer tribe?</line>
      <line>The poet and the dreamer are distinct,</line>
      <line>Diverse, sheer opposite, antipodes!</line>
      <line>The one pours out a balm upon the world,</line>
      <line>The other vexes it.’ Then shouted I,</line>
      <line>Spite of myself, and with a Pythia’s spleen:</line>
      <line>‘Apollo! Faded, far-flown Apollo!</line>
      <line>Where is thy misty pestilence to creep</line>
      <line>Into the dwellings, through the door crannies</line>
      <line>Of all mock lyrists, large self-worshippers</line>
      <line>And careless hectorers in proud bad verse.</line>
      <line>Though I breathe death with them it will be life</line>
      <line>To see them sprawl before me into graves!</line>
      <line>Majestic shadow, tell me where I am –</line>
      <line>Whose altar this? for whom this incense curls?</line>
      <line>What image this whose face I cannot see</line>
      <line>For the broad marble knees? and who thou art,</line>
      <line> Of accent feminine so courteous?’</line>
      <line>Then the tall shade, in drooping linens veiled,</line>
      <line>Spoke out, so much more earnest, that her breath</line>
      <line>Stirred the thin folds of gauze that drooping hung</line>
      <line>About a golden censer from her hand</line>
      <line>Pendent; and by her voice I knew she shed</line>
      <line>Long-treasured tears. ‘This temple, sad and lone,</line>
      <line>Is all spared from the thunder of a war</line>
      <line>Foughten long since by giant hierarchy</line>
      <line>Against rebellion; this old image here,</line>
      <line> Whose carvéd features wrinkled as he fell,</line>
      <line>Is Saturn’s – I, Moneta, left supreme</line>
      <line>Sole priestess of his desolation.’</line>
      <line>I had no words to answer, for my tongue,</line>
      <line>Useless, could find about its rooféd home</line>
      <line>No syllable of a fit majesty</line>
      <line>To make rejoinder to Moneta’s mourn.</line>
      <line>There was a silence, while the altar’s blaze</line>
      <line>Was fainting for sweet food: I looked thereon,</line>
      <line>And on the pavéd floor, where nigh were piled</line>
      <line> Faggots of cinnamon, and many heaps</line>
      <line>Of other crispéd spice-wood – then again</line>
      <line>I looked upon the altar, and its horns</line>
      <line>Whitened with ashes, and its languorous flame –</line>
      <line>And then upon the offerings again.</line>
      <line>And so by turns, till sad Moneta cried,</line>
      <line>‘The sacrifice is done! But not the less</line>
      <line>Will I be kind to thee for thy good will.</line>
      <line>My power, which to me is still a curse,</line>
      <line>Shall be to thee a wonder; for the scenes</line>
      <line> Still swooning vivid through my globéd brain,</line>
      <line>With an electral changing misery,</line>
      <line>Thou shalt with these dull mortal eyes behold,</line>
      <line>Free from all pain – if wonder pain thee not!’</line>
      <line>As near as an immortal’s spheréd words</line>
      <line>Could to a mother’s soften, were these last:</line>
      <line>And yet I had a terror of her robes,</line>
      <line>And chiefly of the veils, that from her brow</line>
      <line>Hung pale, and curtained her in mysteries</line>
      <line>That made my heart too small to hold its blood.</line>
      <line> This saw that Goddess, and with sacred hand</line>
      <line>Parted the veils. Then saw I a wan face,</line>
      <line>Not pined by human sorrows, but bright-blanched</line>
      <line>By an immortal sickness which kills not</line>
      <line>(It works a constant change, which happy death</line>
      <line>Can put no end to). Deathwards progressing</line>
      <line>To no death was that visage! It had past</line>
      <line>The lily and the snow; and beyond these</line>
      <line>I must not think now, though I saw that face –</line>
      <line>But for her eyes I should have fled away!</line>
      <line> They held me back, with a benignant light</line>
      <line>Soft mitigated by divinest lids</line>
      <line>Half-closed, and visionless entire they seemed</line>
      <line>Of all external things. They saw me not,</line>
      <line>But in blank splendour beamed like the mild moon</line>
      <line>Who comforts those she sees not – who knows not</line>
      <line>What eyes are upward cast. As I had found</line>
      <line>A grain of gold upon a mountain’s side,</line>
      <line>And, twinged with avarice, strained out my eyes</line>
      <line>To search its sullen entrails rich with ore,</line>
      <line> So at the view of sad Moneta’s brow</line>
      <line>I asked to see what things the hollow brain</line>
      <line>Behind enwombed – what high tragedy</line>
      <line>In the dark secret chambers of her skull</line>
      <line>Was acting, that could give so dread a stress</line>
      <line>To her cold lips, and fill with such a light</line>
      <line>Her planetary eyes, and touch her voice</line>
      <line>With such a sorrow.</line>
      <line>‘Shade of Memory’,</line>
      <line>Cried I, with act adorant at her feet,</line>
      <line>‘By all the gloom hung round thy fallen house,</line>
      <line> By this last temple, by the golden age,</line>
      <line>By great Apollo, thy dear foster-child,</line>
      <line>And by thyself, forlorn divinity,</line>
      <line>The pale omega of a withered race,</line>
      <line>Let me behold, according as thou saidst,</line>
      <line>What in thy brain so ferments to and fro!’</line>
      <line>No sooner had this conjuration passed</line>
      <line>My devout lips, than side by side we stood</line>
