      <line>(Like a stunt bramble by a solemn pine)</line>
      <line>Deep in the shady sadness of a vale.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1818</date>
    <title>From Julian and Maddalo: A Conversation</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I rode one evening with Count Maddalo</line>
      <line>Upon the bank of land which breaks the flow</line>
      <line>Of Adria towards Venice – a bare strand</line>
      <line>Of hillocks, heaped from ever-shifting sand,</line>
      <line> Matted with thistles and amphibious weeds</line>
      <line>Such as from earth’s embrace the salt ooze breeds,</line>
      <line>Is this – an uninhabitable sea-side</line>
      <line>Which the lone fisher, when his nets are dried,</line>
      <line>Abandons; and no other objects breaks</line>
      <line>The waste, but one dwarf tree and some few stakes</line>
      <line>Broken and unrepaired, and the tide makes</line>
      <line>A narrow space of level sand thereon,</line>
      <line>Where ’twas our wont to ride while day went down.</line>
      <line>This ride was my delight.</line>
      <line>I love all waste</line>
      <line> And solitary places, where we taste</line>
      <line>The pleasure of believing what we see</line>
      <line>Is boundless, as we wish our souls to be –</line>
      <line>And such was this wide ocean, and this shore</line>
      <line>More barren than its billows – and yet more</line>
      <line>Than all, with a remembered friend I love</line>
      <line>To ride as then I rode. For the wind drove</line>
      <line>The living spray along the sunny air</line>
      <line>Into our faces; the blue heavens were bare,</line>
      <line>Stripped to their depths by the awakening north;</line>
      <line> And from the waves sound, like delight, broke forth,</line>
      <line>Harmonizing with solitude, and sent</line>
      <line>Into our hearts aërial merriment!</line>
      <line>So, as we rode, we talked, and the swift thought,</line>
      <line>Winging itself with laughter, lingered not,</line>
      <line>But flew from brain the brain (such glee was ours)</line>
      <line>Charged with light memories of remembered hours,</line>
      <line>None slow enough for sadness – till we came</line>
      <line>Homeward, which always makes the spirit tame.</line>
      <line>This day had been cheerful, but cold, and now</line>
      <line> The sun was sinking, and the wind also.</line>
      <line>Our talk grew somewhat serious, as may be</line>
      <line>Talk interrupted with such raillery</line>
      <line>That mocks itself because it cannot scorn</line>
      <line>The thoughts it would extinguish – ’twas forlorn</line>
      <line>But pleasing, such as once (so poets tell)</line>
      <line>The devils held within the dales of Hell</line>
      <line>Concerning God, free-will, and destiny!</line>
      <line>Of all that Earth has been, or yet may be,</line>
      <line>All that vain men imagine or believe,</line>
      <line> Or hope can paint, or suffering may achieve,</line>
      <line>We descanted, and I (for ever, still,</line>
      <line>Is it not wise to make the best of ill?) –</line>
      <line>Argued against despondency, but pride</line>
      <line>Made my companion take the darker side.</line>
      <line>The sense that he was greater than his kind</line>
      <line>Had struck, methinks, his eagle-spirit blind</line>
      <line>By gazing on its own exceeding light.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile the sun paused ere it should alight,</line>
      <line>Over the horizon of the mountains. Oh</line>
      <line> How beautiful is sunset, when the glow</line>
      <line>Of Heaven descends upon a land like thee,</line>
      <line>Thou paradise of exiles, Italy –</line>
      <line>Thy mountains, seas and vineyards, and the towers</line>
      <line>Of cities they encircle! It was ours</line>
      <line>To stand on thee beholding it; and then,</line>
      <line>Just where we had dismounted, the Count’s men</line>
      <line>Were waiting for us with the gondola.</line>
      <line>As those who pause on some delightful way</line>
      <line>Though bent on pilgrimage, we stood</line>
      <line> Looking upon the evening and the flood</line>
      <line>Which lay between the city and the shore,</line>
      <line>Paved with the image of the sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY</author>
    <date>1822</date>
    <title>From Adonais: An Elegy on the Death of John Keats</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I weep for Adonais – he is dead!</line>
      <line>Oh weep for Adonais – though our tears</line>
      <line>Thaw not the frost which binds so dear a head!</line>
      <line>And thou, sad Hour, selected from all years</line>
      <line> To mourn our loss, rouse thy obscure compeers,</line>
      <line>And teach them thine own sorrow, say: ‘With me</line>
      <line>Died Adonais; till the future dares</line>
      <line>Forget the past, his fate and fame shall be</line>
      <line>An echo and a light unto eternity!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where wert thou, mighty Mother, when he lay –</line>
      <line>When thy Son lay – pierced by the shaft which flies</line>
      <line>In darkness? Where was lorn Urania</line>
      <line>When Adonais died? With veiléd eyes,</line>
      <line>Mid listening Echoes, in her paradise</line>
      <line> She sat while one, with soft enamoured breath,</line>
      <line>Rekindled all the fading melodies</line>
      <line>With which, like flowers that mock the corse beneath,</line>
      <line>He had adorned and hid the coming bulk of death.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh weep for Adonais – he is dead!</line>
      <line>Wake, melancholy Mother, wake and weep!</line>
      <line>Yet wherefore? Quench within their burning bed</line>
      <line>Thy fiery tears, and let thy loud heart keep</line>
      <line>Like his a mute and uncomplaining sleep;</line>
      <line>For he is gone, where all things wise and fair</line>
      <line> Descend; – oh dream not that the amorous deep</line>
      <line>Will yet restore him to the vital air:</line>
      <line>Death feeds on his mute voice, and laughs at our despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Most musical of mourners, weep again!</line>
      <line>Lament anew, Urania! He died,</line>
      <line>Who was the sire of an immortal strain,</line>
      <line>(Blind, old and lonely) when his country’s pride,</line>
      <line>The priest, the slave, and the liberticide,</line>
      <line>Trampled and mocked with many a loathéd rite</line>
      <line>Of lust and blood – he went, unterrified,</line>
      <line> Into the gulf of death – but his clear sprite</line>
      <line>Yet reigns o’er earth, the third among the sons of light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Most musical of mourners, weep anew!</line>
      <line>Not all to that bright station dared to climb –</line>
      <line>And happier they their happiness who knew,</line>
      <line>Whose tapers yet burn through that night of time</line>
      <line>In which suns perished; others more sublime,</line>
      <line>Struck by the envious wrath of man or god,</line>
      <line>Have sunk, extinct in their refulgent prime;</line>
      <line>And some yet live, treading the thorny road,</line>
      <line> Which leads, through toil and hate, to Fame’s serene abode.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But now thy youngest, dearest, one has perished –</line>
      <line>The nursling of thy widowhood, who grew</line>
      <line>Like a pale flower by some sad maiden cherished,</line>
      <line>And fed with true-love tears instead of dew –</line>
      <line>Most musical of mourners, weep anew!</line>
      <line>Thy extreme hope, the loveliest and the last</line>
      <line>(The bloom whose petals, nipped before they blew,</line>
      <line>Died on the promise of the fruit) is waste!</line>
      <line>The broken lily lies – the storm is overpast.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> To that high capital, where kingly Death</line>
      <line>Keeps his pale court in beauty and decay,</line>
      <line>He came; and bought, with price of purest breath,</line>
      <line>A grave among the eternal. Come away!</line>
      <line>Haste, while the vault of blue Italian day</line>
      <line>Is yet his fitting charnel-roof – while still</line>
      <line>He lies, as if in dewy sleep he lay!</line>
      <line>Awake him not – surely he takes his fill</line>
      <line>Of deep and liquid rest, forgetful of all ill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He will awake no more, oh never more!</line>
      <line> Within the twilight chamber spreads apace</line>
      <line>The shadow of white Death, and at the door</line>
      <line>Invisible Corruption waits to trace</line>
      <line>His extreme way to her dim dwelling-place;</line>
      <line>The eternal Hunger sits, but pity and awe</line>
      <line>Soothe her pale rage, nor dares she to deface</line>
      <line>So fair a prey, till darkness, and the law</line>
      <line>Of mortal change, shall fill the grave which is her maw…</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Peace, peace! He is not dead, he doth not sleep –</line>
      <line>He hath awakened from the dream of life –</line>
      <line>’Tis we who, lost in stormy visions, keep</line>
      <line>With phantoms an unprofitable strife,</line>
      <line>And in mad trance strike with our spirit’s knife</line>
      <line>Invulnerable nothings. We decay</line>
      <line>Like corpses in a charnel; fear and grief</line>
      <line>Convulse us and consume us day by day,</line>
      <line>And cold hopes swarm like worms within our living clay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He has outsoared the shadow of our night –</line>
      <line>Envy and calumny and hate and pain,</line>
      <line>And that unrest which men miscall delight,</line>
      <line> Can touch him not and torture not again.</line>
      <line>From the contagion of the world’s slow stain</line>
      <line>He is secure, and now can never mourn</line>
      <line>A heart grown cold, a head grown grey in vain;</line>
      <line>Nor, when the spirit’s self has ceased to burn,</line>
      <line>With sparkless ashes load an unlamented urn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He lives, he wakes! ’Tis Death is dead, not he –</line>
      <line>Mourn not for Adonais. Thou young Dawn,</line>
      <line>Turn all thy dew to splendour, for from thee</line>
      <line>The spirit thou lamentest is not gone.</line>
      <line> Ye caverns and ye forests, cease to moan!</line>
      <line>Cease, ye faint flowers and fountains, and thou air,</line>
      <line>Which like a mourning veil thy scarf hadst thrown</line>
      <line>O’er the abandoned earth, now leave it bare</line>
      <line>Even to the joyous stars which smile on its despair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He is made one with Nature: there is heard</line>
      <line>His voice in all her music, from the moan</line>
      <line>Of thunder, to the song of night’s sweet bird;</line>
      <line>He is a presence to be felt and known</line>
      <line>In darkness and in light, from herb and stone,</line>
      <line> Spreading itself where’er that Power may move</line>
      <line>Which has withdrawn his being to its own –</line>
      <line>Which wields the world with never-wearied love,</line>
      <line>Sustains it from beneath, and kindles it above.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He is a portion of the loveliness</line>
      <line>Which once he made more lovely: he doth bear</line>
      <line>His part, while the one Spirit’s plastic stress</line>
      <line>Sweeps through the dull dense world, compelling there,</line>
      <line>All new successions to the forms they wear –</line>
      <line>Torturing the unwilling dross that checks its flight</line>
      <line> To its own likeness (as each mass may bear)</line>
      <line>And bursting in its beauty and its might</line>
      <line>From trees and beasts and men into the Heaven’s light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The splendours of the firmament of time</line>
      <line>May be eclipsed, but are extinguished not;</line>
      <line>Like stars to their appointed height they climb,</line>
      <line>And death is a low mist which cannot blot</line>
      <line>The brightness it may veil. When lofty thought</line>
      <line>Lifts a young heart above its mortal lair,</line>
      <line>And love and life contend in it for what</line>
      <line> Shall be its earthly doom, the dead live there</line>
      <line>And move like winds of light on dark and stormy air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The inheritors of unfulfilled renown</line>
      <line>Rose from their thrones, built beyond mortal thought,</line>
      <line>Far in the unapparent. Chatterton</line>
      <line>Rose pale, his solemn agony had not</line>
      <line>Yet faded from him; Sidney, as he fought</line>
      <line>And as he fell and as he lived and loved</line>
      <line>Sublimely mild (a spirit without spot)</line>
      <line>Arose; and Lucan, by his death approved –</line>
      <line>Oblivion as they rose shrank like a thing reproved.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And many more, whose names on earth are dark,</line>
      <line>But whose transmitted effluence cannot die</line>
      <line>So long as fire outlives the parent spark,</line>
      <line>Rose, robed in dazzling immortality.</line>
      <line>‘Thou art become as one of us’, they cry,</line>
      <line>‘It was for thee yon kingless sphere has long</line>
      <line>Swung blind in unascended majesty,</line>
      <line>Silent alone amid an heaven of song.</line>
      <line>Assume thy wingéd throne, thou Vesper of our throng!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Who mourns for Adonais? Oh come forth,</line>
      <line>Fond wretch, and know thyself and him aright!</line>
      <line>Clasp with thy panting soul the pendulous earth–</line>
      <line>As from a centre, dart thy spirit’s light</line>
      <line>Beyond all worlds, until its spacious might</line>
      <line>Satiate the void circumference; then shrink</line>
      <line>Even to a point within our day and night,</line>
      <line>And keep thy heart light lest it make thee sink</line>
      <line>When hope has kindled hope, and lured thee to the brink.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or go to Rome, which is the sepulchre,</line>
      <line> Oh, not of him, but of our joy! ’Tis nought</line>
      <line>That ages, empires, and religions there</line>
      <line>Lie buried in the ravage they have wrought;</line>
      <line>For such as he, can lend! They borrow not</line>
      <line>Glory from those who made the world their prey –</line>
      <line>And he is gathered to the kings of thought</line>
      <line>Who waged contention with their time’s decay,</line>
      <line>And of the past are all that cannot pass away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go thou to Rome – at once the paradise,</line>
      <line>The grave, the city, and the wilderness –</line>
      <line> And where its wrecks like shattered mountains rise,</line>
      <line>And flowering weeds and fragrant copses dress</line>
      <line>The bones of Desolation’s nakedness,</line>
      <line>Pass, till the spirit of the spot shall lead</line>
      <line>Thy footsteps to a slope of green access</line>
      <line>Where, like an infant’s smile, over the dead</line>
      <line>A light of laughing flowers along the grass is spread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And grey walls moulder round, on which dull time</line>
      <line>Feeds, like slow fire upon a hoary brand,</line>
      <line>And one keen pyramid with wedge sublime,</line>
      <line> Pavilioning the dust of him who planned</line>
      <line>This refuge for his memory, doth stand</line>
      <line>Like flame transformed to marble; and beneath,</line>
      <line>A field is spread, on which a newer band</line>
      <line>Have pitched in Heaven’s smile their camp of death,</line>
      <line>Welcoming him we lose with scarce extinguished breath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here pause: these graves are all too young as yet</line>
      <line>To have outgrown the sorrow which consigned</line>
      <line>Its charge to each – and if the seal is set,</line>
      <line>Here, on one fountain of a mourning mind,</line>
      <line> Break it not thou! Too surely shalt thou find</line>
      <line>Thine own well full, if thou returnest home,</line>
      <line>Of tears and gall. From the world’s bitter wind</line>
      <line>Seek shelter in the shadow of the tomb –</line>
      <line>What Adonais is, why fear we to become?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The One remains, the many change and pass;</line>
      <line>Heaven’s light forever shines, Earth’s shadows fly;</line>
      <line>Life, like a dome of many-coloured glass,</line>
      <line>Stains the white radiance of Eternity,</line>
      <line>Until Death tramples it to fragments. Die,</line>
      <line> If thou wouldst be with that which thou dost seek!</line>
      <line>Follow where all is fled! Rome’s azure sky,</line>
      <line>Flowers, ruins, statues, music, words, are weak</line>
      <line>The glory they transfuse with fitting truth to speak.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why linger, why turn back, why shrink, my heart?</line>
      <line>Thy hopes are gone before: from all things here</line>
      <line>They have departed, thou shouldst now depart!</line>
      <line>A light is passed from the revolving year,</line>
      <line>And man, and woman – and what still is dear</line>
      <line>Attracts to crush, repels to make thee wither.</line>
      <line> The soft sky smiles, the low wind whispers near:</line>
      <line>’Tis Adonais calls! Oh hasten thither –</line>
      <line>No more let Life divide what Death can join together.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That Light whose smile kindles the universe,</line>
      <line>That Beauty in which all things work and move,</line>
      <line>That Benediction which the eclipsing curse</line>
      <line>Of birth can quench not, that sustaining Love,</line>
      <line>Which through the web of being (blindly wove</line>
      <line>By man and beast and earth and air and sea)</line>
      <line>Burns bright or dim, as each are mirrors of</line>
      <line> The fire for which all thirst – now beams on me,</line>
      <line>Consuming the last clouds of cold mortality.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The breath whose might I have invoked in song</line>
      <line>Descends on me – my spirit’s bark is driven</line>
      <line>Far from the shore, far from the trembling throng</line>
      <line>Whose sails were never to the tempest given.</line>
      <line>The massy earth and spheréd skies are riven!</line>
      <line>I am borne darkly, fearfully, afar,</line>
      <line>Whilst, burning through the inmost veil of Heaven,</line>
      <line>The soul of Adonais like a star</line>
      <line> Beacons from the abode where the Eternal are.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1824</date>
    <title>Sappho’s Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell, my lute, and would that I</line>
      <line>Had never waked thy burning chords!</line>
      <line>Poison has been upon thy sigh,</line>
      <line>And fever has breathed in thy words.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet wherefore, wherefore should I blame</line>
      <line>Thy power, thy spell, my gentlest lute?</line>
      <line>I should have been the wretch I am</line>
      <line>Had every chord of thine been mute.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was my evil star above,</line>
      <line>Not my sweet lute that wrought me wrong;</line>
      <line>It was not song that taught me love,</line>
      <line>But it was love that taught me song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If song be past, and hope undone,</line>
      <line>And pulse, and head, and heart, are flame,</line>
      <line> It is thy work, thou faithless one –</line>
      <line>But no, I will not name thy name!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sun-god! lute, wreath are vowed to thee!</line>
      <line>Long be their light upon my grave,</line>
      <line>My glorious grave – yon deep blue sea;</line>
      <line>I shall sleep calm beneath its wave!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>SAMUEL TAYLOR COLERIDGE</author>
    <date>1825</date>
    <title>Work Without Hope</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All Nature seems at work – slugs leave their lair,</line>
      <line>The bees are stirring, birds are on the wing,</line>
      <line>And Winter, slumbering in the open air,</line>
      <line>Wears on his smiling face a dream of spring!</line>
      <line> And I, the while, the sole unbusy thing,</line>
      <line>Nor honey make, nor pair, nor build, nor sing.</line>
      <line>Yet well I ken the banks where amaranths blow,</line>
      <line>Have traced the fount whence streams of nectar flow.</line>
      <line>Bloom, oh ye amaranths, bloom for whom ye may –</line>
      <line>For me ye bloom not! Glide, rich streams, away!</line>
      <line>With lips unbrightened, wreathless brow, I stroll!</line>
      <line>And would you learn the spells that drowse my soul?</line>
      <line>Work without hope draws nectar in a sieve,</line>
      <line>And hope without an object cannot live.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>THOMAS HOOD</author>
    <date>1827</date>
    <title>False Poets and True</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look how the lark soars upward and is gone,</line>
      <line>Turning a spirit as he nears the sky</line>
      <line>His voice is heard, but body there is none</line>
      <line>To fix the vague excursions of the eye.</line>
      <line> So poets’ songs are with us though they die</line>
      <line>Obscured and hid by death’s oblivious shroud,</line>
      <line>And Earth inherits the rich melody</line>
      <line>Like raining music from the morning cloud.</line>
      <line>Yet, few there be who pipe so sweet and loud</line>
      <line>Their voices reach us through the lapse of space.</line>
      <line>The noisy day is deafened by a crowd</line>
      <line>Of undistinguished birds, a twittering race –</line>
      <line>But only lark and nightingale forlorn</line>
      <line>Fill up the silences of night and morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>The Grave of a Poetess</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I stood beside thy lowly grave,</line>
      <line>Spring odours breathed around,</line>
      <line>And music in the river-wave</line>
      <line>Passed with a lulling sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> All happy things that love the sun</line>
      <line>In the bright air glanced by,</line>
      <line>And a glad murmur seemed to run</line>
      <line>Through the soft azure sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fresh leaves were on the ivy-bough</line>
      <line>That fringed the ruins near;</line>
      <line>Young voices were abroad, but thou</line>
      <line>Their sweetness couldst not hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And mournful grew my heart for thee,</line>
      <line>Thou in whose woman’s mind</line>
      <line> The ray that brightens earth and sea,</line>
      <line>The light of song was shrined –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mournful that thou wert slumbering low</line>
      <line>With a dread curtain drawn</line>
      <line>Between thee and the golden glow</line>
      <line>Of this world’s vernal dawn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Parted from all the song and bloom</line>
      <line>Thou wouldst have loved so well,</line>
      <line>To thee the sunshine round thy tomb</line>
      <line>Was but a broken spell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> The bird, the insect on the wing,</line>
      <line>In their bright reckless play,</line>
      <line>Might feel the flush and life of spring,</line>
      <line>And thou wert past away!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But then, even then, a nobler thought</line>
      <line>O’er my vain sadness came,</line>
      <line>The immortal spirit woke, and wrought</line>
      <line>Within my thrilling frame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Surely on lovelier things, I said,</line>
      <line>Thou must have looked ere now,</line>
      <line> Than all that round our pathway shed</line>
      <line>Odours and hues below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shadows of the tomb are here,</line>
      <line>Yet beautiful is Earth!</line>
      <line>What seest thou then where no dim fear,</line>
      <line>No haunting dream hath birth?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here a vain love to passing flowers</line>
      <line>Thou gavest, but where thou art</line>
      <line>The sway is not with changeful hours:</line>
      <line>There love and death must part.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Thou hast left sorrow in thy song,</line>
      <line>A voice not loud, but deep;</line>
      <line>The glorious bowers of Earth among,</line>
      <line>How often didst thou weep!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where couldst thou fix on mortal ground</line>
      <line>Thy tender thoughts and high?</line>
      <line>Now peace the woman’s heart hath found,</line>
      <line>And joy the poet’s eye.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>Properzia Rossi</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>One dream of passion and of beauty more,</line>
      <line>And in its bright fulfilment let me pour</line>
      <line>My soul away! Let earth retain a trace</line>
      <line>Of that which lit my being, though its race</line>
      <line> Might have been loftier far. Yet one more dream –</line>
      <line>From my deep spirit one victorious gleam</line>
      <line>Ere I depart! For thee alone, for thee,</line>
      <line>May this last work, this farewell triumph be –</line>
      <line>Thou, loved so vainly! I would leave enshrined</line>
      <line>Something immortal of my heart and mind,</line>
      <line>That yet may speak to thee when I am gone,</line>
      <line>Shaking thine inmost bosom with a tone</line>
      <line>Of lost affection – something that may prove</line>
      <line>What she hath been, whose melancholy love</line>
      <line> On thee was lavished: silent pang and tear,</line>
      <line>And fervent song, that gushed when none were near,</line>
      <line>And dream by night, and weary thought by day,</line>
      <line>Stealing the brightness from her life away,</line>
      <line>While thou – awake! Not yet within me die</line>
      <line>Under the burden and the agony</line>
      <line>Of this vain tenderness, my spirit – wake!</line>
      <line>Even for thy sorrowful affection’s sake,</line>
      <line>Live. In thy work breathe out – that he may yet,</line>
      <line>Feeling sad mastery there, perchance regret</line>
      <line> Thine unrequited gift.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It comes – the power</line>
      <line>Within me born flows back – my fruitless dower</line>
      <line>That could not win me love! Yet once again</line>
      <line>I greet it proudly, with its rushing train</line>
      <line>Of glorious images: they throng, they press,</line>
      <line>A sudden joy lights up my loneliness –</line>
      <line>I shall not perish all!</line>
      <line>The bright work grows</line>
      <line>Beneath my hand, unfolding, as a rose,</line>
      <line>Leaf after leaf, to beauty. Line by line,</line>
      <line>I fix my thought, heart, soul, to burn, to shine,</line>
      <line> Through the pale marble’s veins. It grows – and now</line>
      <line>I give my own life’s history to thy brow,</line>
      <line>Forsaken Ariadne! Thou shalt wear</line>
      <line>My form, my lineaments; but oh, more fair,</line>
      <line>Touched into lovelier being by the glow</line>
      <line>Which in me dwells, as by the summer light</line>
      <line>All things are glorified. From thee my woe</line>
      <line>Shall yet look beautiful to meet his sight,</line>
      <line>When I am passed away. Thou art the mould</line>
      <line>Wherein I pour the fervent thoughts, the untold,</line>
      <line> The self-consuming! Speak to him of me,</line>
      <line>Thou, the deserted by the lonely sea,</line>
      <line>With the soft sadness of thine earnest eye –</line>
      <line>Speak to him, lorn one, deeply, mournfully,</line>
      <line>Of all my love and grief! Oh, could I throw</line>
      <line>Into thy frame a voice, a sweet, and low,</line>
      <line>And thrilling voice of song, when he came nigh,</line>
      <line>To send the passion of its melody</line>
      <line>Through his pierced bosom – on its tones to bear</line>
      <line>My life’s deep feeling, as the southern air</line>
      <line> Wafts the faint myrtle’s breath – to rise, to swell,</line>
      <line>To sink away in accents of farewell,</line>
      <line>Winning but one, one gush of tears, whose flow</line>
      <line>Surely my parted spirit yet might know,</line>
      <line>If love be strong as death!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now fair thou art,</line>
      <line>Thou form, whose life is of my burning heart</line>
      <line>Yet all the vision that within me wrought</line>
      <line>I cannot make thee! Oh, I might have given</line>
      <line>Birth to creations of far nobler thought;</line>
      <line>I might have kindled, with the fire of Heaven,</line>
      <line> Things not of such as die! But I have been</line>
      <line>Too much alone. A heart whereon to lean,</line>
      <line>With all these deep affections that o’erflow</line>
      <line>My aching soul and find no shore below;</line>
      <line>An eye to be my star; a voice to bring</line>
      <line>Hope o’er my path like sounds that breathe of spring –</line>
      <line>These are denied me, dreamt of still in vain!</line>
      <line>Therefore my brief aspirings from the chain</line>
      <line>Are ever but as some wild fitful song,</line>
      <line>Rising triumphantly, to die ere long</line>
      <line>In dirge-like echoes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet the world will see</line>
      <line>Little of this, my parting work, in thee.</line>
      <line>Thou shalt have fame! Oh, mockery! Give the reed</line>
      <line>From storms a shelter, give the drooping vine</line>
      <line>Something round which its tendrils may entwine,</line>
      <line>Give the parched flower a rain-drop, and the meed</line>
      <line>Of love’s kind words to woman! Worthless fame!</line>
      <line>That in his bosom wins not for my name</line>
      <line>The abiding place it asked! Yet how my heart,</line>
      <line>In its own fairy-world of song and art,</line>
      <line> Once beat for praise! Are those high longings o’er?</line>
      <line>That which I have been, can I be no more?</line>
      <line>Never, oh never more, though still thy sky</line>
      <line>Be blue as then, my glorious Italy!</line>
      <line>And though the music, whose rich breathings fill</line>
      <line>Thine air with soul, be wandering past me still;</line>
      <line>And though the mantle of thy sunlight streams</line>
      <line>Unchanged on forms instinct with poet-dreams,</line>
      <line>Never, oh never more! Where’er I move,</line>
      <line>The shadow of this broken-hearted love</line>
      <line> Is on me and around. Too well they know,</line>
      <line>Whose life is all within, too soon and well,</line>
      <line>When there the blight hath settled – but I go</line>
      <line>Under the silent wings of peace to dwell.</line>
      <line>From the slow-wasting, from the lonely pain,</line>
      <line>The inward burning of those words, ‘in vain’,</line>
      <line>Seared on the heart, I go. ’Twill soon be past,</line>
      <line>Sunshine, and song, and bright Italian heaven,</line>
      <line>And thou, oh thou, on whom my spirit cast</line>
      <line>Unvalued wealth – who knowst not what was given</line>
      <line>In that devotedness – the sad, and deep,</line>
      <line>And unrepaid! Farewell! If I could weep</line>
      <line>Once, only once, beloved one, on thy breast,</line>
      <line>Pouring my heart forth ere I sink to rest!</line>
      <line>But that were happiness, and unto me</line>
      <line>Earth’s gift is fame. Yet I was formed to be</line>
      <line>So richly blest! With thee to watch the sky,</line>
      <line>Speaking not, feeling but that thou wert nigh;</line>
      <line>With thee to listen, while the tones of song</line>
      <line>Swept even as part of our sweet air along –</line>
      <line> To listen silently! With thee to gaze</line>
      <line>On forms, the deified of olden days,</line>
      <line>This had been joy enough! And, hour by hour,</line>
      <line>From its glad well-springs drinking life and power,</line>
      <line>How had my spirit soared, and made its fame</line>
      <line>A glory for thy brow! Dreams, dreams – the fire</line>
      <line>Burns faint within me. Yet I leave my name</line>
      <line>(As a deep thrill may linger on the lyre</line>
      <line>When its full chords are hushed) awhile to live,</line>
      <line>And one day haply in thy heart revive</line>
      <line> Sad thoughts of me. I leave it with a sound,</line>
      <line>A spell o’er memory, mournfully profound –</line>
      <line>I leave it, on my country’s air to dwell!</line>
      <line>Say proudly yet, ‘’Twas hers who loved me well!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>FELICIA HEMANS</author>
    <date>1828</date>
    <title>To Wordsworth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thine is a strain to read among the hills,</line>
      <line>The old and full of voices; by the source</line>
      <line>Of some free stream, whose gladdening presence fills</line>
      <line>The solitude with sound, for in its course</line>
      <line> Even such is thy deep song, that seems a part</line>
      <line>Of those high scenes, a fountain from their heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or its calm spirit fitly may be taken</line>
      <line>To the still breast in sunny garden-bowers,</line>
      <line>Where vernal winds each tree’s low tones awaken</line>
      <line>And bud and bell with changes mark the hours.</line>
      <line>There let thy thoughts be with me, while the day</line>
      <line>Sinks with a golden and serene decay;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or by some hearth where happy faces meet</line>
      <line>When night hath hushed the woods with all their birds,</line>
      <line> There (from some gentle voice) that lay were sweet</line>
      <line>As antique music linked with household-words,</line>
      <line>While in pleased murmurs woman’s lip might move</line>
      <line>And the raised eye of childhood shine in love;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or where the shadows of dark solemn yews</line>
      <line>Brood silently o’er some lone burial-ground</line>
      <line>Thy voice hath power that brightly might diffuse</line>
      <line>A breath, a kindling as of spring, around</line>
      <line>From its own glow of hope and courage high,</line>
      <line>And steadfast faith’s victorious constancy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> True bard, and holy, thou art even as one</line>
      <line>Who, by some secret gift of soul or eye,</line>
      <line>In every spot beneath the smiling sun</line>
      <line>Sees where the springs of living waters lie –</line>
      <line>Unseen they sleep, till, touched by thee,</line>
      <line>Bright healthful waves flow forth to each glad wanderer free.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>Extempore Effusion Upon the Death of James Hogg</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When first, descending from the moorlands,</line>
      <line>I saw the Stream of Yarrow glide</line>
      <line>Along a bare and open valley,</line>
      <line>The Ettrick Shepherd was my guide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> When last along its banks I wandered,</line>
      <line>Through groves that had begun to shed</line>
      <line>Their golden leaves upon the pathways,</line>
      <line>My steps the Border Minstrel led.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mighty Minstrel breathes no longer,</line>
      <line>Mid mouldering ruins low he lies;</line>
      <line>And death upon the braes of Yarrow,</line>
      <line>Has closed the Shepherd-poet’s eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor has the rolling year twice measured,</line>
      <line>From sign to sign, its steadfast course,</line>
      <line> Since every mortal power of Coleridge</line>
      <line>Was frozen at its marvellous source –</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The rapt one, of the godlike forehead,</line>
      <line>The heaven-eyed creature, sleeps in earth:</line>
      <line>And Lamb, the frolic and the gentle,</line>
      <line>Has vanished from his lonely hearth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like clouds that rake the mountain-summits,</line>
      <line>Or waves that own no curbing hand,</line>
      <line>How fast has brother followed brother,</line>
      <line>From sunshine to the sunless land!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> Yet I, whose lids from infant slumber</line>
      <line>Were earlier raised, remain to hear</line>
      <line>A timid voice, that asks in whispers,</line>
      <line>‘Who next will drop and disappear?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our haughty life is crowned with darkness,</line>
      <line>Like London with its own black wreath,</line>
      <line>On which with thee, oh Crabbe, forth-looking,</line>
      <line>I gazed from Hampstead’s breezy heath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As if but yesterday departed,</line>
      <line>Thou too art gone before – but why,</line>
      <line> O’er ripe fruit, seasonably gathered,</line>
      <line>Should frail survivors heave a sigh?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mourn rather for that holy spirit,</line>
      <line>Sweet as the spring, as ocean deep –</line>
      <line>For her who, ere her summer faded,</line>
      <line>Has sunk into a breathless sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No more of old romantic sorrows,</line>
      <line>For slaughtered youth or love-lorn maid!</line>
      <line>With sharper grief is Yarrow smitten,</line>
      <line>And Ettrick mourns with her their Poet dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1835</date>
    <title>Felicia Hemans</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No more, no more, oh never more returning</line>
      <line>Will thy belovéd presence gladden earth,</line>
      <line>No more wilt thou with sad, yet anxious yearning,</line>
      <line>Cling to those hopes which have no mortal birth.</line>
      <line> Thou art gone from us, and with thee departed</line>
      <line>How many lovely things have vanished too –</line>
      <line>Deep thoughts that, at thy will, to being started,</line>
      <line>And feelings teaching us our own were true!</line>
      <line>Thou hast been round us like a viewless spirit</line>
      <line>Known only by the music on the air:</line>
      <line>The leaf or flowers which thou hast named inherit</line>
      <line>A beauty known but from thy breathing there,</line>
      <line>For thou didst on them fling thy strong emotion –</line>
      <line>The likeness from itself the fond heart gave,</line>
      <line> As planets from afar look down on ocean</line>
      <line>And give their own sweet image to the wave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thou didst bring from foreign lands their treasures:</line>
      <line>As floats thy various melody along,</line>
      <line>We know the softness of Italian measures</line>
      <line>And the grave cadence of Castilian song.</line>
      <line>A general bond of union is the poet:</line>
      <line>By its immortal verse is language known,</line>
      <line>And for the sake of song do others know it –</line>
      <line>One glorious poet makes the world his own!</line>
      <line> And thou, how far thy gentle sway extended</line>
      <line>The heart’s sweet empire over land and sea:</line>
      <line>Many a stranger and far flower was blended</line>
      <line>In the soft wreath that glory bound for thee.</line>
      <line>The echoes of the Susquehanna’s waters</line>
      <line>Paused in the pinewoods words of thine to hear,</line>
      <line>And to the wide Atlantic’s younger daughters</line>
      <line>Thy name was lovely and thy song was dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Was not this purchased all too dearly? Never</line>
      <line>Can fame atone for all that fame hath cost.</line>
      <line> We see the goal, but know not the endeavour,</line>
      <line>Nor what fond hopes have on the way been lost.</line>
      <line>What do we know of the unquiet pillow</line>
      <line>By the worn cheek and tearful eyelid pressed,</line>
      <line>When thoughts chase thoughts like the tumultuous billow</line>
      <line>Whose very light and foam reveals unrest.</line>
      <line>We say the song is sorrowful, but know not</line>
      <line>What may have left that sorrow on the song:</line>
      <line>However mournful words may be, they show not</line>
      <line>The whole extent of wretchedness and wrong.</line>
      <line> They cannot paint the long sad hours past only</line>
      <line>In vain regrets o’er what we feel we are.</line>
      <line>Alas, the kingdom of the lute is lonely –</line>
      <line>Cold is the worship coming from afar!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet what is mind in woman but revealing</line>
      <line>In sweet clear light the hidden world below,</line>
      <line>By quicker fancies and a keener feeling</line>
      <line>Than those around, the cold and careless, know?</line>
      <line>What is to feel such feeling, but to culture</line>
      <line>A soil whence pain will never more depart –</line>
      <line> The fable of Prometheus and the vulture</line>
      <line>Reveals the poet’s and the woman’s heart!</line>
      <line>Unkindly are they judged, unkindly treated</line>
      <line>By careless tongues and by ungenerous words,</line>
      <line>While cruel sneer and hard reproach repeated</line>
      <line>Jar the fine music of the spirit’s chords.</line>
      <line>Wert thou not weary, thou whose soothing numbers</line>
      <line>Gave other lips the joy thine own had not?</line>
      <line>Didst thou not welcome thankfully the slumbers</line>
      <line>Which closed around thy mourning human lot?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> What on this earth could answer thy requiring</line>
      <line>For earnest faith, for love (the deep and true),</line>
      <line>The beautiful, which was thy soul’s desiring</line>
      <line>But only from thyself its being drew!</line>
      <line>How is the warm and loving heart requited</line>
      <line>In this harsh world, where it awhile must dwell,</line>
      <line>Its best affections wronged, betrayed and slighted –</line>
      <line>Such is the doom of those who love too well.</line>
      <line>Better the weary dove should close its pinion,</line>
      <line>Fold up its golden wings and be at peace!</line>
      <line> Enter oh lady that serene dominion</line>
      <line>Where earthly cares and earthly sorrows cease.</line>
      <line>Fame’s troubled hour has cleared, and now, replying,</line>
      <line>A thousand hearts their music ask of thine:</line>
      <line>Sleep, with a light – the lovely and undying –</line>
      <line>Around thy grave! A grave which is a shrine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>LETITIA ELIZABETH LANDON</author>
    <date>1837</date>
    <title>The Poet’s Lot</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The poet’s lovely faith creates</line>
      <line>The beauty he believes;</line>
      <line>The light which on his footsteps waits,</line>
      <line>He from himself receives.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line> His lot may be a weary lot,</line>
      <line>His thrall a heavy thrall,</line>
      <line>And cares and griefs the crowd know not,</line>
      <line>His heart may know them all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But still he hath a mighty dower,</line>
      <line>The loveliness that throws</line>
      <line>Over the common thought and hour</line>
      <line>The beauty of the rose.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>A Crocodile</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hard by the lilied Nile I saw</line>
      <line>A duskish river-dragon stretched along,</line>
      <line>The brown habergeon of his limbs enamelled</line>
      <line>With sanguine almandines and rainy pearl:</line>
      <line>And on his back there lay a young one sleeping,</line>
      <line>No bigger than a mouse; with eyes like beads,</line>
      <line>And a small fragment of its speckled egg</line>
      <line>Remaining on its harmless, pulpy snout;</line>
      <line>A thing to laugh at, as it gaped to catch</line>
      <line>The baulking merry flies. In the iron jaws</line>
      <line>Of the great devil-beast, like a pale soul</line>
      <line>Fluttering in rocky hell, lightsomely flew</line>
      <line>A snowy trochilus, with roseate beak</line>
      <line>Tearing the hairy leeches from his throat.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>Death Sweet</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it not sweet to die? for, what is death,</line>
      <line>But sighing that we ne’er may sigh again,</line>
      <line>Getting a length beyond our tedious selves;</line>
      <line>But trampling the last tear from poisonous sorrow,</line>
      <line>Spilling our woes, crushing our frozen hopes,</line>
      <line>And passing like an incense out of man?</line>
      <line>Then, if the body felt, what were its sense,</line>
      <line>Turning to daisies gently in the grave,</line>
      <line>If not the soul’s most delicate delight</line>
      <line>When it does filtrate, through the pores of thought,</line>
      <line>In love and the enamelled flowers of song?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>Hymn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And many voices marshalled in one hymn</line>
      <line>Wound through the night, whose still, translucent moments</line>
      <line>Lay on each side their breath; and the hymn passed</line>
      <line>Its long, harmonious populace of words</line>
      <line>Between the silvery silences, as when</line>
      <line>The slaves of Egypt, like a wind between</line>
      <line>The head and trunk of a dismembered king</line>
      <line>On a strewn plank, with blood and footsteps sealed,</line>
      <line>Vallied the unaccustomed sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>Humble Beginnings</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why, Rome was naked once, a bastard smudge,</line>
      <line>Tumbled on straw, the den-fellow of whelps,</line>
      <line>Fattened on roots, and, when athirst for milk,</line>
      <line>He crept beneath and drank the swagging udder</line>
      <line>Of Tyber’s brave she-wolf; and Heaven’s Judea</line>
      <line>Was folded in a pannier.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>Sonnet: To Tartar, a Terrier Beauty</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Snowdrop of dogs, with ear of brownest dye,</line>
      <line>Like the last orphan leaf of naked tree</line>
      <line>Which shudders in bleak autumn; though by thee,</line>
      <line>Of hearing careless and untutored eye,</line>
      <line>Not understood articulate speech of men,</line>
      <line>Nor marked the artificial mind of books,</line>
      <line>—The mortal’s voice eternized by the pen,—</line>
      <line>Yet hast thou thought and language all unknown</line>
      <line>To Babel’s scholars; oft intensest looks,</line>
      <line>Long scrutiny o’er some dark-veined stone</line>
      <line>Dost thou bestow, learning dead mysteries</line>
      <line>Of the world’s birth-day, oft in eager tone</line>
      <line>With quick-tailed fellows handiest prompt replies,</line>
      <line>Solicitudes canine, four-footed amities.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1823</date>
    <title>A Lake</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A lake</line>
      <line>Is a river curled and asleep like a snake.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1825</date>
    <title>Song by Isbrand</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Squats on a toad-stool under a tree</line>
      <line>A bodiless childfuli of life in the gloom,</line>
      <line>Crying with frog voice, ‘What shall I be?</line>
      <line>Poor unborn ghost, for my mother killed me</line>
      <line>Scarcely alive in her wicked womb.</line>
      <line>What shall I be? shall I creep to the egg</line>
      <line>That’s cracking asunder yonder by Nile,</line>
      <line>And with eighteen toes,</line>
      <line>And a snuff-taking nose,</line>
      <line>Make an Egyptian crocodile?</line>
      <line>Sing, “Catch a mummy by the leg</line>
      <line>And crunch him with an upper jaw,</line>
      <line>Wagging tail and clenching claw;</line>
      <line>Take a bill-full from my craw,</line>
      <line>Neighbour raven, caw, O caw,</line>
      <line>Grunt, my crocky, pretty maw!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Swine, shall I be one? ’Tis a dear dog;</line>
      <line>But for a smile, and kiss, and pout,</line>
      <line>I much prefer your black-lipped snout,</line>
      <line>Little, gruntless, fairy hog,</line>
      <line>Godson of the hawthorn hedge.</line>
      <line>For, when Ringwood snuffs me out,</line>
      <line>And ’gins my tender paunch to grapple,</line>
      <line>Sing, “ ’Twixt your ancles visage wedge,</line>
      <line>And roll up like an apple.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Serpent Lucifer, how do you do?</line>
      <line>Of your worms and your snakes I’d be one or two</line>
      <line>For in this dear planet of wool and of leather</line>
      <line>’Tis pleasant to need no shirt, breeches or shoe,</line>
      <line>And have arm, leg, and belly together.</line>
      <line>Then aches your head, or are you lazy?</line>
      <line>Sing, “Round your neck your belly wrap,</line>
      <line>Tail-a-top, and make your cap</line>
      <line>Any bee and daisy.”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I’ll not be a fool, like the nightingale</line>
      <line>Who sits up all midnight without any ale,</line>
      <line>Making a noise with his nose;</line>
      <line>Nor a camel, although ’tis a beautiful back;</line>
      <line>Nor a duck, notwithstanding the music of quack</line>
      <line>And the webby, mud-patting toes.</line>
      <line>I’ll be a new bird with the head of an ass,</line>
      <line>Two pigs’ feet, two men’s feet, and two of a hen;</line>
      <line>Devil-winged; dragon-bellied; grave-jawed, because grass</line>
      <line>Is a beard that’s soon shaved, and grows seldom again</line>
      <line>Before it is summer; so cow all the rest;</line>
      <line>The new Dodo is finished. O! come to my nest.’</line>
      <line>(Act III, scene iii)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1825</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We have bathed, where none have seen us,</line>
      <line>In the lake and in the fountain,</line>
      <line>Underneath the charmed statue</line>
      <line>Of the timid, bending Venus,</line>
      <line>When the water-nymphs were counting</line>
      <line>In the waves the stars of night,</line>
      <line>And those maidens started at you,</line>
      <line>Your limbs shone through so soft and bright.</line>
      <line>But no secrets dare we tell,</line>
      <line>For thy slaves unlace thee,</line>
      <line>And he, who shall embrace thee,</line>
      <line>Waits to try thy beauty’s spell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We have crowned thee queen of women,</line>
      <line>Since love’s love, the rose, hath kept her</line>
      <line>Court within thy lips and blushes,</line>
      <line>And thine eye, in beauty' swimming,</line>
      <line>Kissing, we rendered up the sceptre,</line>
      <line>At whose touch the startled soul</line>
      <line>Like an ocean bounds and gushes,</line>
      <line>And spirits bend at thy controul.</line>
      <line>But no secrets dare we tell,</line>
      <line>For thy slaves unlace thee,</line>
      <line>And he, who shall embrace thee,</line>
      <line>Is at hand, and so farewell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Lovell Beddoes</author>
    <date>1825</date>
    <title>Dirge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We do lie beneath the grass</line>
      <line>In the moonlight, in the shade</line>
      <line>Of the yew-tree. They that pass</line>
      <line>Hear us not. We are afraid</line>
      <line>They would envy our delight,</line>
      <line>In our graves by glow-worm night.</line>
      <line>Come follow us, and smile as we;</line>
      <line>We sail to the rock in the ancient waves,</line>
      <line>Where the snow falls by thousands into the sea,</line>
      <line>And the drowned and the shipwrecked have happy graves.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1833</date>
    <title>St Simeon Stylites</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>St Simeon Stylites</line>
      <line>Altho’ I be the basest of mankind,</line>
      <line>From scalp to sole one slough and crust of sin,</line>
      <line>Unfit for earth, unfit for heaven, scarce meet</line>
      <line>For troops of devils, mad with blasphemy,</line>
      <line>I will not cease to grasp the hope I hold</line>
      <line>Of saintdom, and to clamour, mourn and sob,</line>
      <line>Battering the gates of heaven with storms of prayer,</line>
      <line>Have mercy, Lord, and take away my sin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let this avail, just, dreadful, mighty God,</line>
      <line>This not be all in vain, that thrice ten years,</line>
      <line>Thrice multiplied by superhuman pangs,</line>
      <line>In hungers and in thirsts, fevers and cold,</line>
      <line>In coughs, aches, stitches, ulcerous throes and cramps,</line>
      <line>A sign betwixt the meadow and the cloud,</line>
      <line>Patient on this tall pillar I have borne</line>
      <line>Rain, wind, frost, heat, hail, damp, and sleet, and snow;</line>
      <line>And I had hoped that ere this period closed</line>
      <line>Thou wouldst have caught me up into thy rest,</line>
      <line>Denying not these weather-beaten limbs</line>
      <line>The meed of saints, the white robe and the palm.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O take the meaning, Lord: I do not breathe,</line>
      <line>Not whisper, any murmur of complaint.</line>
      <line>Pain heap’d ten-hundred-fold to this, were still</line>
      <line>Less burthen, by ten-hundred-fold, to bear,</line>
      <line>Than were those lead-like tons of sin that crush’d</line>
      <line>My spirit flat before thee.</line>
      <line>O Lord, Lord,</line>
      <line>Thou knowest I bore this better at the first,</line>
      <line>For I was strong and hale of body then;</line>
      <line>And tho’ my teeth, which now are dropt away,</line>
      <line>Would chatter with the cold, and all my beard</line>
      <line>Was tagg’d with icy fringes in the moon,</line>
      <line>I drown’d the whoopings of the owl with sound</line>
      <line>Of pious hymns and psalms, and sometimes saw</line>
      <line>An angel stand and watch me, as I sang.</line>
      <line>Now am I feeble grown; my end draws nigh;</line>
      <line>I hope my end draws nigh: half deaf I am,</line>
      <line>So that I scarce can hear the people hum</line>
      <line>About the column’s base, and almost blind,</line>
      <line>And scarce can recognise the fields I know;</line>
      <line>And both my thighs are rotted with the dew;</line>
      <line>Yet cease I not to clamour and to cry,</line>
      <line>While my stiff spine can hold my weary head,</line>
      <line>Till all my limbs drop piecemeal from the stone,</line>
      <line>Have mercy, mercy: take away my sin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Jesus, if thou wilt not save my soul,</line>
      <line>Who may be saved? who is it may be saved?</line>
      <line>Who may be made a saint, if I fail here?</line>
      <line>Show me the man hath suffer’d more than I.</line>
      <line>For did not all thy martyrs die one death?</line>
      <line>For either they were stoned, or crucified,</line>
      <line>Or burn’d in fire, or boil’d in oil, or sawn</line>
      <line>In twain beneath the ribs; but I die here</line>
      <line>To-day, and whole years long, a life of death.</line>
      <line>Bear witness, if I could have found a way</line>
      <line>(And heedfully I sifted all my thought)</line>
      <line>More slowly-painful to subdue this home</line>
      <line>Of sin, my flesh, which I despise and hate,</line>
      <line>I had not stinted practice, O my God.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For not alone this pillar-punishment,</line>
      <line>Not this alone I bore: but while I lived</line>
      <line>In the white convent down the valley there,</line>
      <line>For many weeks about my loins I wore</line>
      <line>The rope that haled the buckets from the well,</line>
      <line>Twisted as tight as I could knot the noose;</line>
      <line>And spake not of it to a single soul,</line>
      <line>Until the ulcer, eating thro’ my skin,</line>
      <line>Betray’d my secret penance, so that all</line>
      <line>My brethren marvell’d greatly. More than this</line>
      <line>I bore, whereof, O God, thou knowest all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Three winters, that my soul might grow to thee,</line>
      <line>I lived up there on yonder mountain side.</line>
      <line>My right leg chain’d into the crag, I lay</line>
      <line>Pent in a roofless close of ragged stones;</line>
      <line>Inswathed sometimes in wandering mist, and twice</line>
      <line>Black’d with thy branding thunder, and sometimes</line>
      <line>Sucking the damps for drink, and eating not,</line>
      <line>Except the spare chance-gift of those that came</line>
      <line>To touch my body and be heal’d, and live:</line>
      <line>And they say then that I work’d miracles,</line>
      <line>Whereof my fame is loud amongst mankind,</line>
      <line>Cured lameness, palsies, cancers. Thou, O God,</line>
      <line>Knowest alone whether this was or no.</line>
      <line>Have mercy, mercy! cover all my sin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, that I might be more alone with thee,</line>
      <line>Three years I lived upon a pillar, high</line>
      <line>Six cubits, and three years on one of twelve;</line>
      <line>And twice three years I crouch’d on one that rose</line>
      <line>Twenty by measure; last of all, I grew</line>
      <line>Twice ten long weary weary years to this,</line>
      <line>That numbers forty cubits from the soil.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I think that I have borne as much as this—</line>
      <line>Or else I dream—and for so long a time,</line>
      <line>If I may measure time by yon slow light,</line>
      <line>And this high dial, which my sorrow crowns—</line>
      <line>So much—even so.</line>
      <line>And yet I know not well,</line>
      <line>For that the evil ones come here, and say,</line>
      <line>‘Fall down, O Simeon: thou hast suffer’d long</line>
      <line>For ages and for ages!’ then they prate</line>
      <line>Of penances I cannot have gone thro’,</line>
      <line>Perplexing me with lies; and oft I fall,</line>
      <line>Maybe for months, in such blind lethargies</line>
      <line>That Heaven, and Earth, and Time are choked.</line>
      <line>But yet</line>
      <line>Bethink thee, Lord, while thou and all the saints</line>
      <line>Enjoy themselves in heaven, and men on earth</line>
      <line>House in the shade of comfortable roofs,</line>
      <line>Sit with their wives by fires, eat wholesome food,</line>
      <line>And wear warm clothes, and even beasts have stalls,</line>
      <line>I, ’tween the spring and downfall of the light,</line>
      <line>Bow down one thousand and two hundred times,</line>
      <line>To Christ, the Virgin Mother, and the saints;</line>
      <line>Or in the night, after a little sleep,</line>
      <line>I wake: the chill stars sparkle; I am wet</line>
      <line>With drenching dews, or stiff with crackling frost.</line>
      <line>I wear an undress’d goatskin on my back;</line>
      <line>A grazing iron collar grinds my neck;</line>
      <line>And in my weak, lean arms I lift the cross,</line>
      <line>And strive and wrestle with thee till I die:</line>
      <line>O mercy, mercy! wash away my sin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Lord, thou knowest what a man I am;</line>
      <line>A sinful man, conceived and born in sin:</line>
      <line>’Tis their own doing; this is none of mine;</line>
      <line>Lay it not to me. Am I to blame for this,</line>
      <line>That here come those that worship me? Ha! ha!</line>
      <line>They think that I am somewhat. What am I?</line>
      <line>The silly people take me for a saint,</line>
      <line>And bring me offerings of fruit and flowers:</line>
      <line>And I, in truth (thou wilt bear witness here)</line>
      <line>Have all in all endured as much, and more</line>
      <line>Than many just and holy men, whose names</line>
      <line>Are register’d and calendar’d for saints.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Good people, you do ill to kneel to me.</line>
      <line>What is it I can have done to merit this?</line>
      <line>I am a sinner viler than you all.</line>
      <line>It may be I have wrought some miracles,</line>
      <line>And cured some halt and maim’d; but what of that?</line>
      <line>It may be, no one, even among the saints,</line>
      <line>May match his pains with mine; but what of that?</line>
      <line>Yet do not rise; for you may look on me,</line>
      <line>And in your looking you may kneel to God.</line>
      <line>Speak! is there any of you halt or maim’d?</line>
      <line>I think you know I have some power with Heaven</line>
      <line>From my long penance: let him speak his wish.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, I can heal him. Power goes forth from me.</line>
      <line>They say that they are heal’d. Ah, hark! they shout</line>
      <line>‘St Simeon Stylites.’ Why, if so,</line>
      <line>God reaps a harvest in me. O my soul,</line>
      <line>God reaps a harvest in thee. If this be,</line>
      <line>Can I work miracles and not be saved?</line>
      <line>This is not told of any. They were saints.</line>
      <line>It cannot be but that I shall be saved;</line>
      <line>Yea, crown’d a saint. They shout, ‘Behold a saint!’</line>
      <line>And lower voices saint me from above.</line>
      <line>Courage, St Simeon! This dull chrysalis</line>
      <line>Cracks into shining wings, and hope ere death</line>
      <line>Spreads more and more and more, that God hath now</line>
      <line>Sponged and made blank of crimeful record all</line>
      <line>My mortal archives.</line>
      <line>O my sons, my sons,</line>
      <line>I, Simeon of the pillar, by surname</line>
      <line>Stylites, among men; I, Simeon,</line>
      <line>The watcher on the column till the end;</line>
      <line>I, Simeon, whose brain the sunshine bakes;</line>
      <line>I, whose bald brows in silent hours become</line>
      <line>Unnaturally hoar with rime, do now</line>
      <line>From my high nest of penance here proclaim</line>
      <line>That Pontius and Iscariot by my side</line>
      <line>Show’d like fair seraphs. On the coals I lay,</line>
      <line>A vessel full of sin: all hell beneath</line>
      <line>Made me boil over. Devils pluck’d my sleeve,</line>
      <line>Abaddon and Asmodeus caught at me.</line>
      <line>I smote them with the cross; they swarm’d again.</line>
      <line>In bed like monstrous apes they crush’d my chest:</line>
      <line>They flapp’d my light out as I read: I saw</line>
      <line>Their faces grow between me and my book;</line>
      <line>With colt-like whinny and with hoggish whine</line>
      <line>They burst my prayer. Yet this way was left,</line>
      <line>And by this way I ’scaped them. Mortify</line>
      <line>Your flesh, like me, with scourges and with thorns;</line>
      <line>Smite, shrink not, spare not. If it may be, fast</line>
      <line>Whole Lents, and pray. I hardly, with slow steps,</line>
      <line>With slow, faint steps, and much exceeding pain,</line>
      <line>Have scrambled past those pits of fire, that still</line>
      <line>Sing in mine ears. But yield not me the praise:</line>
      <line>God only thro’ his bounty hath thought fit,</line>
      <line>Among the powers and princes of this world,</line>
      <line>To make me an example to mankind,</line>
      <line>Which few can reach to. Yet I do not say</line>
      <line>But that a time may come—yea, even now,</line>
      <line>Now, now, his footsteps smite the threshold stairs</line>
      <line>Of life—I say, that time is at the doors</line>
      <line>When you may worship me without reproach;</line>
      <line>For I will leave my relics in your land,</line>
      <line>And you may carve a shrine about my dust,</line>
      <line>And burn a fragrant lamp before my bones,</line>
      <line>When I am gather’d to the glorious saints.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While I spake then, a sting of shrewdest pain</line>
      <line>Ran shrivelling thro’ me, and a cloudlike change,</line>
      <line>In passing, with a grosser him made thick</line>
      <line>These heavy, horny eyes. The end! the end!</line>
      <line>Surely the end! What’s here? a shape, a shade,</line>
      <line>A flash of light. Is that the angel there</line>
      <line>That holds a crown? Come, blessed brother, come.</line>
      <line>I know thy glittering face. I waited long;</line>
      <line>My brows are ready. What! deny it now?</line>
      <line>Nay, draw, draw, draw nigh. So I clutch it. Christ!</line>
      <line>’Tis gone: ’tis here again; the crown! the crown!</line>
      <line>So now ’tis fitted on and grows to me,</line>
      <line>And from it melt the dews of Paradise,</line>
      <line>Sweet! sweet! spikenard, and balm, and frankincense.</line>
      <line>Ah! let me not be fool’d, sweet saints: I trust</line>
      <line>That I am whole, and clean, and meet for Heaven.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Speak, if there be a priest, a man of God,</line>
      <line>Among you there, and let him presently</line>
      <line>Approach, and lean a ladder on the shaft,</line>
      <line>And climbing up into my airy home,</line>
      <line>Deliver me the blessed sacrament;</line>
      <line>For by the warning of the Holy Ghost,</line>
      <line>I prophesy that I shall die to-night,</line>
      <line>A quarter before twelve.</line>
      <line>But thou, O Lord,</line>
      <line>Aid all this foolish people; let them take</line>
      <line>Example, pattern: lead them to thy light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1833</date>
    <title>Ulysses</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It little profits that an idle king,</line>
      <line>By this still hearth, among these barren crags,</line>
      <line>Match’d with an aged wife, I mete and dole</line>
      <line>Unequal laws unto a savage race,</line>
      <line>That hoard, and sleep, and feed, and know not me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot rest from travel: I will drink</line>
      <line>Life to the lees: all times I have enjoy’d</line>
      <line>Greatly, have suffer’d greatly, both with those</line>
      <line>That loved me, and alone; on shore, and when</line>
      <line>Thro’ scudding drifts the rainy Hyades</line>
      <line>Vext the dim sea: I am become a name;</line>
      <line>For always roaming with a hungry heart</line>
      <line>Much have I seen and known; cities of men</line>
      <line>And manners, climates, councils, governments,</line>
      <line>Myself not least, but honour’d of them all;</line>
      <line>And drunk delight of battle with my peers,</line>
      <line>Far on the ringing plains of windy Troy.</line>
      <line>I am a part of all that I have met;</line>
      <line>Yet all experience is an arch wherethro’</line>
      <line>Gleams that untravell’d world, whose margin fades</line>
      <line>For ever and for ever when I move.</line>
      <line>How dull it is to pause, to make an end,</line>
      <line>To rust unburnish’d, not to shine in use!</line>
      <line>As tho’ to breathe were life. Life piled on life</line>
      <line>Were all too little, and of one to me</line>
      <line>Little remains: but every hour is saved</line>
      <line>From that eternal silence, something more,</line>
      <line>A bringer of new things; and vile it were</line>
      <line>For some three suns to store and hoard myself,</line>
      <line>And this gray spirit yearning in desire</line>
      <line>To follow knowledge like a sinking star,</line>
      <line>Beyond the utmost bound of human thought.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This is my son, mine own Telemachus,</line>
      <line>To whom I leave the sceptre and the isle—</line>
      <line>Well-loved of me, discerning to fulfil</line>
      <line>This labour, by slow prudence to make mild</line>
      <line>A rugged people, and thro’ soft degrees</line>
      <line>Subdue them to the useful and the good.</line>
      <line>Most blameless is he, centred in the sphere</line>
      <line>Of common duties, decent not to fail</line>
      <line>In offices of tenderness, and pay</line>
      <line>Meet adoration to my household gods,</line>
      <line>When I am gone. He works his work, I mine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There lies the port; the vessel puffs her sail:</line>
      <line>There gloom the dark broad seas. My mariners,</line>
      <line>Souls that have toil’d, and wrought, and thought with me—</line>
      <line>That ever with a frolic welcome took</line>
      <line>The thunder and the sunshine, and opposed</line>
      <line>Free hearts, free foreheads — you and I are old;</line>
      <line>Old age hath yet his honour and his toil;</line>
      <line>Death closes all: but something ere the end,</line>
      <line>Some work of noble note, may yet be done,</line>
      <line>Not unbecoming men that strove with Gods.</line>
      <line>The lights begin to twinkle from the rocks:</line>
      <line>The long day wanes: the slow moon climbs: the deep</line>
      <line>Moans round with many voices. Come, my friends,</line>
      <line>’Tis not too late to seek a newer world.</line>
      <line>Push off, and sitting well in order smite</line>
      <line>The sounding furrows; for my purpose holds</line>
      <line>To sail beyond the sunset, and the baths</line>
      <line>Of all the western stars, until I die.</line>
      <line>It may be that the gulfs will wash us down:</line>
      <line>It may be we shall touch the Happy Isles,</line>
      <line>And see the great Achilles, whom we knew.</line>
      <line>Tho’ much is taken, much abides; and tho’</line>
      <line>We are not now that strength which in old days</line>
      <line>Moved earth and heaven; that which we are, we are;</line>
      <line>One equal temper of heroic hearts,</line>
      <line>Made weak by time and fate, but strong in will</line>
      <line>To strive, to seek, to find, and not to yield.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1834</date>
    <title>Morte dArthur</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>So all day long the noise of batlle roll’d</line>
      <line>Among the mountains by the winter sea;</line>
      <line>Until King Arthur’s table, man by man,</line>
      <line>Had fallen in Lyonnesse about their Lord,</line>
      <line>King Arthur: then, because his wound was deep,</line>
      <line>The bold Sir Bedivere uplifted him,</line>
      <line>Sir Bedivere, the last of all his knights,</line>
      <line>And bore him to a chapel nigh the field,</line>
      <line>A broken chancel with a broken cross,</line>
      <line>That stood on a dark strait of barren land.</line>
      <line>On one side lay the Ocean, and on one</line>
      <line>Lay a great water, and the moon was full.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then spake King Arthur to Sir Bedivere:</line>
      <line>‘The sequel of to-day unsolders all</line>
      <line>The goodliest fellowship of famous knights</line>
      <line>Whereof this world holds record. Such a sleep</line>
      <line>They sleep—the men I loved. I think that we</line>
      <line>Shall never more, at any future time,</line>
      <line>Delight our souls with talk of knightly deeds,</line>
      <line>Walking about the gardens and the halls</line>
      <line>Of Camelot, as in the days that were.</line>
      <line>I perish by this people which I made,—</line>
      <line>Tho’ Merlin sware that I should come again</line>
      <line>To rule once more—but let what will be, be,</line>
      <line>I am so deeply smitten thro’ the helm</line>
      <line>That without help I cannot last till morn.</line>
      <line>Thou therefore take my brand Excalibur,</line>
      <line>Which was my pride: for thou rememberest how</line>
      <line>In those old days, one summer noon, an arm</line>
      <line>Rose up from out the bosom of the lake,</line>
      <line>Clothed in white samite, mystic, wonderful,</line>
      <line>Holding the sword—and how I row’d across</line>
      <line>And took it, and have worn it, like a king:</line>
      <line>And, wheresoever I am sung or told</line>
      <line>In aftertime, this also shall be known:</line>
      <line>But now delay not: take Excalibur,</line>
      <line>And fling him far into the middle mere:</line>
      <line>Watch what thou seest, and lightly bring me word.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To him replied the bold Sir Bedivere:</line>
      <line>‘It is not meet, Sir King, to leave thee thus,</line>
      <line>Aidless, alone, and smitten thro’ the helm.</line>
      <line>A little thing may harm a wounded man.</line>
      <line>Yet I thy hest will all perform at full,</line>
      <line>Watch what I see, and lightly bring thee word.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So saying, from the ruin’d shrine he stept</line>
      <line>And in the moon athwart the place of tombs,</line>
      <line>Where lay the mighty bones of ancient men,</line>
      <line>Old knights, and over them the sea-wind sang</line>
      <line>Shrill, chill, with flakes of foam. He, stepping down</line>
      <line>By zig-zag paths, and juts of pointed rock,</line>
      <line>Came on the shining levels of the lake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There drew he forth the brand Excalibur,</line>
      <line>And o’er him, drawing it, the winter moon,</line>
      <line>Brightening the skirts of a long cloud, ran forth</line>
      <line>And sparkled keen with frost against the hilt:</line>
      <line>For all the haft twinkled with diamond sparks,</line>
      <line>Myriads of topaz-lights, and jacinth-work</line>
      <line>Of subtlest jewellery. He gazed so long</line>
      <line>That both his eyes were dazzled, as he stood,</line>
      <line>This way and that dividing the swift mind,</line>
      <line>In act to throw: but at the last it seem’d</line>
      <line>Better to leave Excalibur conceal’d</line>
      <line>There in the many-knotted waterflags,</line>
      <line>That whistled stiff and dry about the marge.</line>
      <line>So strode he back slow to the wounded King.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then spake King Arthur to Sir Bedivere:</line>
      <line>‘Hast thou perform’d my mission which I gave?</line>
      <line>What is it thou hast seen? or what hast heard?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And answer made the bold Sir Bedivere:</line>
      <line>‘I heard the ripple washing in the reeds,</line>
      <line>And the wild water lapping on the crag.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To whom replied King Arthur, faint and pale:</line>
      <line>‘Thou hast betray’d thy nature and thy name,</line>
      <line>Not rendering true answer, as beseem’d</line>
      <line>Thy fealty, nor like a noble knight:</line>
      <line>For surer sign had follow’d, either hand,</line>
      <line>Or voice, or else a motion of the mere.</line>
      <line>This is a shameful thing for men to lie.</line>
      <line>Yet now, I charge thee, quickly go again</line>
      <line>As thou art lief and dear, and do the thing</line>
      <line>I bad thee, watch, and lightly bring me word.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then went Sir Bedivere the second time</line>
      <line>Across the ridge, and paced beside the mere,</line>
      <line>Counting the dewy pebbles, fix’d in thought;</line>
      <line>But when he saw the wonder of the hilt,</line>
