      <line>How curiously and strangely chased, he smote</line>
      <line>His palms together, and he cried aloud,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And if indeed I cast the brand away,</line>
      <line>Surely a precious thing, one worthy note,</line>
      <line>Should thus be lost for ever from the earth,</line>
      <line>Which might have pleased the eyes of many men.</line>
      <line>What good should follow this, if this were done?</line>
      <line>What harm, undone? deep harm to disobey,</line>
      <line>Seeing obedience is the bond of rule.</line>
      <line>Were it well to obey then, if a king demand</line>
      <line>An act unprofitable, against himself?</line>
      <line>The King is sick, and knows not what he does.</line>
      <line>What record, or what relic of my lord</line>
      <line>Should be to aftertime, but empty breath</line>
      <line>And rumours of a doubt? but were this kept,</line>
      <line>Stored in some treasure-house of mighty kings,</line>
      <line>Some one might show it at a joust of arms,</line>
      <line>Saying, “King Arthur’s sword, Excalibur,</line>
      <line>Wrought by the lonely maiden of the Lake.</line>
      <line>Nine years she wrought it, sitting in the deeps</line>
      <line>Upon the hidden bases of the hills.”</line>
      <line>So might some old man speak in the aftertime</line>
      <line>To all the people, winning reverence.</line>
      <line>But now much honour and much fame were lost.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So spake he, clouded with his own conceit,</line>
      <line>And hid Excalibur the second time,</line>
      <line>And so strode back slow to the wounded King.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then spoke King Arthur, breathing heavily:</line>
      <line>‘What is it thou hast seen? or what hast heard?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And answer made the bold Sir Bedivere:</line>
      <line>‘I heard the water lapping on the crag,</line>
      <line>And the long ripple washing in the reeds.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To whom replied King Arthur, much in wrath:</line>
      <line>‘Ah, miserable and unkind, untrue,</line>
      <line>Unknightly, traitor-hearted! Woe is me!</line>
      <line>Authority forgets a dying king,</line>
      <line>Laid widow’d of the power in his eye</line>
      <line>That bow’d the will. I see thee what thou art,</line>
      <line>For thou, the latest-left of all my knights,</line>
      <line>In whom should meet the offices of all,</line>
      <line>Thou wouldst betray me for the precious hilt;</line>
      <line>Either from lust of gold, or like a girl</line>
      <line>Valuing the giddy pleasure of the eyes.</line>
      <line>Yet, for a man may fail in duty twice,</line>
      <line>And the third time may prosper, get thee hence:</line>
      <line>But, if thou spare to fling Excalibur,</line>
      <line>I will arise and slay thee with my hands.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then quickly rose Sir Bedivere, and ran,</line>
      <line>And, leaping down the ridges lightly, plunged</line>
      <line>Among the bulrush-beds, and clutch’d the sword,</line>
      <line>And strongly wheel’d and threw it. The great brand</line>
      <line>Made lightnings in the splendour of the moon,</line>
      <line>And flashing round and round, and whirl’d in an arch,</line>
      <line>Shot like a streamer of the northern morn,</line>
      <line>Seen where the moving isles of winter shock</line>
      <line>By night, with noises of the northern sea.</line>
      <line>So flash’d and fell the brand Excalibur:</line>
      <line>But ere he dipt the surface, rose an arm</line>
      <line>Clothed in white samite, mystic, wonderful,</line>
      <line>And caught him by the hilt, and brandish’d him</line>
      <line>Three times, and drew him under in the mere.</line>
      <line>And lightly went the other to the King.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then spoke King Arthur, drawing thicker breath:</line>
      <line>‘Now see I by thine eyes that this is done.</line>
      <line>Speak out: what is it thou hast heard, or seen?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And answer made the bold Sir Bedivere:</line>
      <line>‘Sir King, I closed mine eyelids, lest the gems</line>
      <line>Should blind my purpose, for I never saw,</line>
      <line>Nor shall see, here or elsewhere, till I die,</line>
      <line>Not tho’ I live three lives of mortal men,</line>
      <line>So great a miracle as yonder hilt.</line>
      <line>Then with both hands I flung him, wheeling him;</line>
      <line>But when I look’d again, behold an arm,</line>
      <line>Clothed in white samite, mystic, wonderful,</line>
      <line>That caught him by the hilt, and brandish’d him</line>
      <line>Three times, and drew him under in the mere.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And answer made King Arthur, breathing hard:</line>
      <line>‘My end draws nigh; ’tis time that I were gone.</line>
      <line>Make broad thy shoulders to receive my weight,</line>
      <line>And bear me to the margin; yet I fear</line>
      <line>My wound hath taken cold, and I shall die.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So saying, from the pavement he half rose,</line>
      <line>Slowly, with pain, reclining on his arm,</line>
      <line>And looking wistfully with wide blue eyes</line>
      <line>As in a picture. Him Sir Bedivere</line>
      <line>Remorsefully regarded thro’ his tears,</line>
      <line>And would have spoken, but he found not words,</line>
      <line>Then took with care, and kneeling on one knee,</line>
      <line>O’er both his shoulders drew the languid hands,</line>
      <line>And rising bore him thro’ the place of tombs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, as he walk’d, King Arthur panted hard,</line>
      <line>Like one that feels a nightmare on his bed</line>
      <line>When all the house is mute. So sigh’d the King,</line>
      <line>Muttering and murmuring at his ear, ‘Quick, quick!</line>
      <line>I fear it is too late, and I shall die.’</line>
      <line>But the other swiftly strode from ridge to ridge,</line>
      <line>Clothed with his breath, and looking, as he walk’d,</line>
      <line>Larger than human on the frozen hills.</line>
      <line>He heard the deep behind him, and a cry</line>
      <line>Before. His own thought drove him, like a goad.</line>
      <line>Dry clash’d his harness in the icy caves</line>
      <line>And barren chasms, and all to left and right</line>
      <line>The bare black cliff clang’d round him, as he based</line>
      <line>His feet on juts of slippery crag that rang</line>
      <line>Sharp-smitten with the dint of armed heels—</line>
      <line>And on a sudden, lo! the level lake,</line>
      <line>And the long glories of the winter moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then saw they how there hove a dusky barge,</line>
      <line>Dark as a funeral scarf from stem to stern,</line>
      <line>Beneath them; and descending they were ware</line>
      <line>That all the decks were dense with stately forms</line>
      <line>Black-stoled, black-hooded, like a dream — by these</line>
      <line>Three Queens with crowns of gold — and from them rose</line>
      <line>A cry that shiver’d to the tingling stars,</line>
      <line>And, as it were one voice, an agony</line>
      <line>Of lamentation, like a wind, that shrills</line>
      <line>All night in a waste land, where no one comes,</line>
      <line>Or hath come, since the making of the world.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then murmur’d Arthur, ‘Place me in the barge,’</line>
      <line>And to the barge they came. There those three Queens</line>
      <line>Put forth their hands, and took the King, and wept.</line>
      <line>But she, that rose the tallest of them all</line>
      <line>And fairest, laid his head upon her lap,</line>
      <line>And loosed the shatter’d casque, and chafed his hands,</line>
      <line>And call’d him by his name, complaining loud,</line>
      <line>And dropping bitter tears against his brow</line>
      <line>Striped with dark blood: for all his face was white</line>
      <line>And colourless, and like the wither’d moon</line>
      <line>Smote by the fresh beam of the springing east;</line>
      <line>And all his greaves and cuisses dash’d with drops</line>
      <line>Of onset; and the light and lustrous curls—</line>
      <line>That made his forehead like a rising sun</line>
      <line>High from the dais-throne — were parch’d with dust;</line>
      <line>Or, clotted into points and hanging loose,</line>
      <line>Mix’d with the knightly growth that fringed his lips.</line>
      <line>So like a shatter’d column lay the King;</line>
      <line>Not like that Arthur who, with lance in rest,</line>
      <line>From spur to plume a star of tournament,</line>
      <line>Shot thro’ the lists at Camelot, and charged</line>
      <line>Before the eyes of ladies and of kings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then loudly cried the bold Sir Bedivere,</line>
      <line>‘Ah! my Lord Arthur, whither shall I go?</line>
      <line>Where shall I hide my forehead and my eyes?</line>
      <line>For now I see the true old times are dead,</line>
      <line>When every morning brought a noble chance,</line>
      <line>And every chance brought out a noble knight.</line>
      <line>Such times have been not since the light that led</line>
      <line>The holy Elders with the gift of myrrh.</line>
      <line>But now the whole round table is dissolved</line>
      <line>Which was an image of the mighty world;</line>
      <line>And I, the last, go forth companionless,</line>
      <line>And the days darken round me, and the years,</line>
      <line>Among new men, strange faces, other minds.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And slowly answered Arthur from the barge:</line>
      <line>‘The old order changeth, yielding place to new,</line>
      <line>And God fulfils Himself in many ways,</line>
      <line>Lest one good custom should corrupt the world.</line>
      <line>Comfort thyself: what comfort is in me?</line>
      <line>I have lived my life, and that which I have done</line>
      <line>May He within Himself make pure! but thou,</line>
      <line>If thou shouldst never see my face again,</line>
      <line>Pray for my soul. More things are wrought by prayer</line>
      <line>Than this world dreams of. Wherefore, let thy voice</line>
      <line>Rise like a fountain for me night and day.</line>
      <line>For what are men better than sheep or goats</line>
      <line>That nourish a blind life within the brain,</line>
      <line>If, knowing God, they lift not hands of prayer</line>
      <line>Both for themselves and those who call them friend?</line>
      <line>For so the whole round earth is every way</line>
      <line>Bound by gold chains about the feet of God.</line>
      <line>But now farewell. I am going a long way</line>
      <line>With these thou seest—if indeed I go—</line>
      <line>(For all my mind is clouded with a doubt)</line>
      <line>To the island-valley of Avilion;</line>
      <line>Where falls not hail, or rain, or any snow,</line>
      <line>Nor ever wind blows loudly; but it lies</line>
      <line>Deep-meadow’d, happy, fair with orchard-lawns</line>
      <line>And bowery hollows crown’d with summer sea,</line>
      <line>Where I will heal me of my grievous wound.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So said he, and the barge with oar and sail</line>
      <line>Moved from the brink, like some full-breasted swan</line>
      <line>That, fluting a wild carol ere her death,</line>
      <line>Ruffles her pure cold plume, and takes the flood</line>
      <line>With swarthy webs. Long stood Sir Bedivere</line>
      <line>Revolving many memories, till the hull</line>
      <line>Look’d one black dot against the verge of dawn,</line>
      <line>And on the mere the wailing died away.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1833</date>
    <title>The Eagle</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He clasps the crag with crooked hands;</line>
      <line>Close to the sun in lonely lands,</line>
      <line>Ring’d with the azure world, he stands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wrinkled sea beneath him crawls;</line>
      <line>He watches from his mountain walls,</line>
      <line>And like a thunderbolt he falls.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1834</date>
    <title>Break, break, break,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Break, break, break,</line>
      <line>On thy cold gray stones, O Sea!</line>
      <line>And I would that my tongue could utter</line>
      <line>The thoughts that arise in me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O well for the fisherman’s boy,</line>
      <line>That he shouts with his sister at play!</line>
      <line>O well for the sailor lad,</line>
      <line>That he sings in his boat on the bay!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the stately ships go on</line>
      <line>To their haven under the hill;</line>
      <line>But O for the touch of a vanish’d hand,</line>
      <line>And the sound of a voice that is still!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Break, break, break,</line>
      <line>At the foot of thy crags, O Sea!</line>
      <line>But the tender grace of a day that is dead</line>
      <line>Will never come back to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>Audley Court</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The Bull, the Fleece are cramm’d, and not a room</line>
      <line>For love or money. Let us picnic there</line>
      <line>At Audley Court.’</line>
      <line>I spoke, while Audley feast</line>
      <line>Humm’d like a hive all round the narrow quay,</line>
      <line>To Francis, with a basket on his arm,</line>
      <line>To Francis just alighted from the boat,</line>
      <line>And breathing of the sea. ‘With all my heart,’</line>
      <line>Said Francis. Then we shoulder’d thro’ the swarm,</line>
      <line>And rounded by the stillness of the beach</line>
      <line>To where the bay runs up its latest horn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We left the dying ebb that faintly lipp’d</line>
      <line>The flat red granite; so by many a sweep</line>
      <line>Of meadow smooth from aftermath we reach’d</line>
      <line>The griffin-guarded gates, and pass’d thro’ all</line>
      <line>The pillar’d dusk of sounding sycamores,</line>
      <line>And cross’d the garden to the gardener’s lodge,</line>
      <line>With all its casements bedded, and its walls</line>
      <line>And chimneys muffled in the leafy vine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There, on a slope of orchard, Francis laid</line>
      <line>A damask napkin wrought with horse and hound,</line>
      <line>Brought out a dusky loaf that smelt of home,</line>
      <line>And, half-cut-down, a pasty costly-made,</line>
      <line>Where quail and pigeon, lark and leveret lay,</line>
      <line>Like fossils of the rock, with golden yolks</line>
      <line>Imbedded and injellied; last, with these,</line>
      <line>A flask of cider from his father’s vats,</line>
      <line>Prime, which I knew; and so we sat and eat</line>
      <line>And talk’d old matters over; who was dead,</line>
      <line>Who married, who was like to be, and how</line>
      <line>The races went, and who would rent the hall:</line>
      <line>Then touch’d upon the game, how scarce it was</line>
      <line>This season; glancing thence, discuss’d the farm,</line>
      <line>The four-held system, and the price of grain;</line>
      <line>And struck upon the corn-laws, where we split,</line>
      <line>And came again together on the king</line>
      <line>With heated faces; till he laugh’d aloud;</line>
      <line>And, while the blackbird on the pippin hung</line>
      <line>To hear him, clapt his hand in mine and sang—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oh! who would fight and march and countermarch,</line>
      <line>Be shot for sixpence in a battle-held,</line>
      <line>And shovell’d up into some bloody trench</line>
      <line>Where no one knows? but let me live my life.</line>
      <line>‘Oh! who would cast and balance at a desk,</line>
      <line>Perch’d like a crow upon a three-legg’d stool,</line>
      <line>Till all his juice is dried, and all his joints</line>
      <line>Are full of chalk? but let me live my life.</line>
      <line>‘Who’d serve the state? for if I carved my name</line>
      <line>Upon the cliffs that guard my native land,</line>
      <line>I might as well have traced it in the sands;</line>
      <line>The sea wastes all: but let me live my life.</line>
      <line>‘Oh! who would love? I woo’d a woman once,</line>
      <line>But she was sharper than an eastern wind,</line>
      <line>And all my heart turn’d from her, as a thorn</line>
      <line>Turns from the sea; but let me live my life.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sang his song, and I replied with mine:</line>
      <line>I found it in a volume, all of songs,</line>
      <line>Knock’d down to me, when old Sir Robert’s pride,</line>
      <line>His books—the more the pity, so I said—</line>
      <line>Came to the hammer here in March—and this—</line>
      <line>I set the words, and added names I knew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sleep, Ellen Aubrey, sleep, and dream of me:</line>
      <line>Sleep, Ellen, folded in thy sister’s arm,</line>
      <line>And sleeping, haply dream her arm is mine.</line>
      <line>‘Sleep, Ellen, folded in Emilia’s arm;</line>
      <line>Emilia, fairer than all else but thou,</line>
      <line>For thou art fairer than all else that is.</line>
      <line>‘Sleep, breathing health and peace upon her breast:</line>
      <line>Sleep, breathing love and trust against her lip:</line>
      <line>I go to-night: I come to-morrow morn.</line>
      <line>‘I go, but I return: I would I were</line>
      <line>The pilot of the darkness and the dream.</line>
      <line>Sleep, Ellen Aubrey, love, and dream of me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So sang we each to either, Francis Hale,</line>
      <line>The farmer’s son, who lived across the bay,</line>
      <line>My friend; and I, that having wherewithal,</line>
      <line>And in the fallow leisure of my life</line>
      <line>A rolling stone of here and everywhere,</line>
      <line>Did what I would; but ere the night we rose</line>
      <line>And saunter’d home beneath a moon, that, just</line>
      <line>In crescent, dimly rain’d about the leaf</line>
      <line>Twilights of airy silver, till we reach’d</line>
      <line>The limit of the hills; and as we sank</line>
      <line>From rock to rock upon the glooming quay,</line>
      <line>The town was hush’d beneath us: lower down</line>
      <line>The bay was oily calm; the harbour-buoy,</line>
      <line>Sole star of phosphorescence in the calm,</line>
      <line>With one green sparkle ever and anon</line>
      <line>Dipt by itself, and we were glad at heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1857</date>
    <title>from The Princess I</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now sleeps the crimson petal, now the white;</line>
      <line>Nor waves the cypress in the palace walk;</line>
      <line>Nor winks the gold fin in the porphyry font:</line>
      <line>The fire-fly wakens: waken thou with me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now droops the milkwhite peacock like a ghost,</line>
      <line>And like a ghost she glimmers on to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now lies the Earth all Danae to the stars,</line>
      <line>And all thy heart lies open unto me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now slides the silent meteor on, and leaves</line>
      <line>A shining furrow, as thy thoughts in me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now folds the lily all her sweetness up,</line>
      <line>And slips into the bosom of the lake:</line>
      <line>So fold thyself, my dearest, thou, and slip</line>
      <line>Into my bosom and be lost in me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>from The Princess II</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come down, O maid, from yonder mountain height:</line>
      <line>What pleasure lives in height (the shepherd sang)</line>
      <line>In height and cold, the splendour of the hills?</line>
      <line>But cease to move so near the Heavens, and cease</line>
      <line>To glide a sunbeam by the blasted Pine,</line>
      <line>To sit a star upon the sparkling spire;</line>
      <line>And come, for Love is of the valley, come,</line>
      <line>For Love is of the valley, come thou down</line>
      <line>And find him; by the happy threshold, he,</line>
      <line>Or hand in hand with Plenty in the maize,</line>
      <line>Or red with spirted purple of the vats,</line>
      <line>Of foxlike in the vine; nor cares to walk</line>
      <line>With Death and Morning on the silver horns,</line>
      <line>Nor wilt thou snare him in the white ravine,</line>
      <line>Nor find him dropt upon the firths of ice,</line>
      <line>That huddling slant in furrow-cloven falls</line>
      <line>To roll the torrent out of dusky doors:</line>
      <line>But follow; let the torrent dance thee down</line>
      <line>To find him in the valley; let the wild</line>
      <line>Lean-headed Eagles yelp alone, and leave</line>
      <line>The monstrous ledges there to slope, and spill</line>
      <line>Their thousand wreaths of dangling water-smoke,</line>
      <line>That like a broken purpose waste in air:</line>
      <line>So waste not thou; but come; for all the vales</line>
      <line>Await thee; azure pillars of the hearth</line>
      <line>Arise to thee; the children call, and I</line>
      <line>Thy shepherd pipe, and sweet is every sound,</line>
      <line>Sweeter thy voice, but every sound is sweet;</line>
      <line>Myriads of rivulets hurrying thro’ the lawn,</line>
      <line>The moan of doves in immemorial elms,</line>
      <line>And murmuring of innumerable bees.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam II</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Yew, which graspest at the stones</line>
      <line>That name the under-lying dead,</line>
      <line>Thy fibres net the dreamless head,</line>
      <line>Thy roots are wrapt about the bones.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The seasons bring the flower again,</line>
      <line>And bring the firstling to the flock;</line>
      <line>And in the dusk of thee, the clock</line>
      <line>Beats out the little lives of men.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O not for thee the glow, the bloom,</line>
      <line>Who changest not in any gale,</line>
      <line>Nor branding summer suns avail</line>
      <line>To touch thy thousand years of gloom:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And gazing on thee, sullen tree,</line>
      <line>Sick for thy stubborn hardihood,</line>
      <line>I seem to fail from out my blood</line>
      <line>And grow incorporate into thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam VII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dark house, by which once more I stand</line>
      <line>Here in the long unlovely street,</line>
      <line>Doors, where my heart was used to beat</line>
      <line>So quickly, waiting for a hand,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A hand that can be clasp’d no more—</line>
      <line>Behold me, for I cannot sleep,</line>
      <line>And like a guilty thing I creep</line>
      <line>At earliest morning to the door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He is not here; but far away</line>
      <line>The noise of life begins again,</line>
      <line>And ghastly thro’ the drizzling rain</line>
      <line>On the bald street breaks the blank day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam XI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Calm is the morn without a sound,</line>
      <line>Calm as to suit a calmer grief,</line>
      <line>And only thro’ the faded leaf</line>
      <line>The chestnut pattering to the ground:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Calm and deep peace on this high wold,</line>
      <line>And on these dews that drench the furze,</line>
      <line>And all the silvery gossamers</line>
      <line>That twinkle into green and gold:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Calm and still light on yon great plain</line>
      <line>That sweeps with all its autumn bowers,</line>
      <line>And crowded farms and lessening towers,</line>
      <line>To mingle with the bounding main:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Calm and deep peace in this wide air,</line>
      <line>These leaves that redden to the fall;</line>
      <line>And in my heart, if calm at all,</line>
      <line>If any calm, a calm despair:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Calm on the seas, and silver sleep,</line>
      <line>And waves that sway themselves in rest,</line>
      <line>And dead calm in that noble breast</line>
      <line>Which heaves but with the heaving deep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam L</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be near me when my light is low,</line>
      <line>When the blood creeps, and the nerves prick</line>
      <line>And tingle; and the heart is sick,</line>
      <line>And all the wheels of Being slow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be near me when the sensuous frame</line>
      <line>Is rack’d with pangs that conquer trust;</line>
      <line>And Time, a maniac scattering dust,</line>
      <line>And Life, a Fury slinging flame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be near me when my faith is dry,</line>
      <line>And men the flies of latter spring,</line>
      <line>That lay their eggs, and sting and sing</line>
      <line>And weave their petty cells and die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be near me when I fade away,</line>
      <line>To point the term of human strife,</line>
      <line>And on the low dark verge of life</line>
      <line>The twilight of eternal day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam LIV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh yet we trust that somehow good</line>
      <line>Will be the final goal of ill,</line>
      <line>To pangs of nature, sins of will,</line>
      <line>Defects of doubt, and taints of blood;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That nothing walks with aimless feet;</line>
      <line>That not one life shall be destroy’d,</line>
      <line>Or cast as rubbish to the void,</line>
      <line>When God hath made the pile complete;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That not a worm is cloven in vain;</line>
      <line>That not a moth with vain desire</line>
      <line>Is shrivelPd in a fruitless fire,</line>
      <line>Or but subserves another’s gain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Behold, we know not anything;</line>
      <line>I can but trust that good shall fall</line>
      <line>At last—far off—at last, to all,</line>
      <line>And every winter change to spring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So runs my dream: but what am I?</line>
      <line>An infant crying in the night:</line>
      <line>An infant crying for the light:</line>
      <line>And with no language but a cry.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam LV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wish, that of the living whole</line>
      <line>No life may fail beyond the grave,</line>
      <line>Derives it not from what we have</line>
      <line>The likest God within the soul?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Are God and Nature then at strife,</line>
      <line>That Nature lends such evil dreams?</line>
      <line>So careful of the type she seems,</line>
      <line>So careless of the single life;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That I, considering everywhere</line>
      <line>Her secret meaning in her deeds,</line>
      <line>And finding that of fifty seeds</line>
      <line>She often brings but one to bear,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I falter where I firmly trod,</line>
      <line>And falling with my weight of cares</line>
      <line>Upon the great world’s altar-stairs</line>
      <line>That slope thro’ darkness up to God,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>1 stretch lame hands of faith, and grope,</line>
      <line>And gather dust and chaff, and call</line>
      <line>To what I feel is Lord of all,</line>
      <line>And faintly trust the larger hope.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam LVI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘So careful of the type?’ but no.</line>
      <line>From scarped cliff and quarried stone</line>
      <line>She cries, ‘A thousand types are gone</line>
      <line>I care for nothing, all shall go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Thou makest thine appeal to me:</line>
      <line>I bring to life, I bring to death:</line>
      <line>The spirit does but mean the breath:</line>
      <line>I know no more.’ And he, shall he,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Man, her last work, who seem’d so fair,</line>
      <line>Such splendid purpose in his eyes,</line>
      <line>Who roll’d the psalm to wintry skies,</line>
      <line>Who built him fanes of fruitless prayer,</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam LXX</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who trusted God was love indeed</line>
      <line>And love Creation’s final law—</line>
      <line>Tho’ Nature, red in tooth and claw</line>
      <line>With ravine, shriek’d against his creed—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who loved, who suffer’d countless ills,</line>
      <line>Who battled for the True, the Just,</line>
      <line>Be blown about the desert dust,</line>
      <line>Or seal’d within the iron hills?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No more? A monster then, a dream,</line>
      <line>A discord. Dragons of the prime,</line>
      <line>That tare each other in their slime,</line>
      <line>Were mellow music match’d with him.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O life as futile, then, as frail!</line>
      <line>O for thy voice to soothe and bless!</line>
      <line>What hope of answer, or redress?</line>
      <line>Behind the veil, behind the veil.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam LXX</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot see the features right,</line>
      <line>When on the gloom I strive to paint</line>
      <line>The face I know; the hues are faint</line>
      <line>And mix with hollow masks of night;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cloud-towers by ghostly masons wrought,</line>
      <line>A gulf that ever shuts and gapes,</line>
      <line>A hand that points, and palled shapes</line>
      <line>In shadowy thoroughfares of thought;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And crowds that stream from yawning doors,</line>
      <line>And shoals of pucker’d faces drive;</line>
      <line>Dark bulks that tumble half alive,</line>
      <line>And lazy lengths on boundless shores;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till all at once beyond the will</line>
      <line>I hear a wizard music roll,</line>
      <line>And thro’ a lattice on the soul</line>
      <line>Looks thy fair face and makes it still.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam LXXXIII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dip down upon the northern shore,</line>
      <line>O sweet new-year delaying long;</line>
      <line>Thou doest expectant nature wrong;</line>
      <line>Delaying long, delay no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What stays thee from the clouded noons,</line>
      <line>Thy sweetness from its proper place?</line>
      <line>Can trouble live with April days,</line>
      <line>Or sadness in the summer moons?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bring orchis, bring the foxglove spire,</line>
      <line>The little speedwell’s darling blue,</line>
      <line>Deep tulips dash’d with fiery dew,</line>
      <line>Laburnums, dropping-wells of fire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O thou, new-year, delaying long,</line>
      <line>Delayest the sorrow in my blood,</line>
      <line>That longs to burst a frozen bud</line>
      <line>And flood a fresher throat with song.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam XCV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>By night we linger’d on the lawn,</line>
      <line>For underfoot the herb was dry;</line>
      <line>And genial warmth; and o’er the sky</line>
      <line>The silvery haze of summer drawn;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And calm that let the tapers burn</line>
      <line>Unwavering: not a cricket chirr’d:</line>
      <line>The brook alone far-off was heard,</line>
      <line>And on the board the fluttering urn:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And bats went round in fragrant skies,</line>
      <line>And wheel’d or lit the filmy shapes</line>
      <line>That haunt the dusk, with ermine capes</line>
      <line>And woolly breasts and beaded eyes;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While now we sang old songs that peal’d</line>
      <line>From knoll to knoll, where, couch’d at ease,</line>
      <line>The white kine glimmer’d, and the trees</line>
      <line>Laid their dark arms about the field.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when those others, one by one,</line>
      <line>Withdrew themselves from me and night,</line>
      <line>And in the house light after light</line>
      <line>Went out, and I was all alone,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A hunger seized my heart; I read</line>
      <line>Of that glad year which once had been,</line>
      <line>In those fall’n leaves which kept their green,</line>
      <line>The noble letters of the dead:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And strangely on the silence broke</line>
      <line>The silent-speaking words, and strange</line>
      <line>Was love’s dumb cry defying change</line>
      <line>To test his worth; and strangely spoke</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The faith, the vigour, bold to dwell</line>
      <line>On doubts that drive the coward back,</line>
      <line>And keen thro’ wordy snares to track</line>
      <line>Suggestion to her inmost cell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So word by word, and line by line,</line>
      <line>The dead man touch’d me from the past,</line>
      <line>And all at once it seem’d at last</line>
      <line>The living soul was flash’d on mine,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And mine in this was wound, and whirl’d</line>
      <line>About empyreal heights of thought,</line>
      <line>And came on that which is, and caught</line>
      <line>The deep pulsations of the world,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Æonian music measuring out</line>
      <line>The steps of Time — the shocks of Chance—</line>
      <line>The blows of Death. At length my trance</line>
      <line>Was cancell’d, stricken thro’ with doubt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Vague words! but ah, how hard to frame</line>
      <line>In matter-moulded forms of speech,</line>
      <line>Or ev’n for intellect to reach</line>
      <line>Thro’ memory that which I became:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till now the doubtful dusk reveal’d</line>
      <line>The knolls once more where, couch’d at ease,</line>
      <line>The white kine glimmer’d, and the trees</line>
      <line>Laid their dark arms about the field:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And suck’d from out the distant gloom</line>
      <line>A breeze began to tremble o’er</line>
      <line>The large leaves of the sycamore,</line>
      <line>And fluctuate all the still perfume,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And gathering freshlier overhead,</line>
      <line>Rock’d the full-foliaged elms, and swung</line>
      <line>The heavy-folded rose, and flung</line>
      <line>The lilies to and fro, and said</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The dawn, the dawn,’ and died away;</line>
      <line>And East and West, without a breath,</line>
      <line>Mixt their dim lights, like life and death,</line>
      <line>To broaden into boundless day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam CXV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now fades the last long streak of snow,</line>
      <line>Now burgeons every maze of quick</line>
      <line>About the flowering squares, and thick</line>
      <line>By ashen roots the violets blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now rings the woodland loud and long,</line>
      <line>The distance takes a lovelier hue,</line>
      <line>And drown’d in yonder living blue</line>
      <line>The lark becomes a sightless song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now dance the lights on lawn and lea,</line>
      <line>The flocks are whiter down the vale,</line>
      <line>And milkier ever}' milky sail</line>
      <line>On winding stream or distant sea;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where now the seamew pipes, or dives</line>
      <line>In yonder greening gleam, and fly</line>
      <line>The happy birds, that change their sky</line>
      <line>To build and brood; that live their lives</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From land to land; and in my breast</line>
      <line>Spring wakens too; and my regret</line>
      <line>Becomes an April violet,</line>
      <line>And buds and blossoms like the rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from In Memoriam CXXIII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There rolls the deep where grew the tree.</line>
      <line>O earth, what changes hast thou seen!</line>
      <line>There where the long street roars, hath been</line>
      <line>The stillness of the central sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The hills are shadows, and they flow</line>
      <line>From form to form, and nothing stands;</line>
      <line>They melt like mist, the solid lands,</line>
      <line>Like clouds they shape themselves and go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But in my spirit will I dwell,</line>
      <line>And dream my dream, and hold it true;</line>
      <line>For tho’ my lips may breathe adieu,</line>
      <line>I cannot think the thing farewell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>The Daisy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O love, what hours were thine and mine,</line>
      <line>In lands of palm and southern pine;</line>
      <line>In lands of palm, of orange-blossom,</line>
      <line>Of olive, aloe, and maize and vine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What Roman strength Turbia show’d</line>
      <line>In ruin, by the mountain road;</line>
      <line>How like a gem, beneath, the city</line>
      <line>Of little Monaco, basking, glow’d.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How richly down the rocky dell</line>
      <line>The torrent vineyard streaming fell</line>
      <line>To meet the sun and sunny waters,</line>
      <line>That only heaved with a summer swell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What slender campanili grew</line>
      <line>By bays, the peacock’s neck in hue;</line>
      <line>Where, here and there, on sandy beaches</line>
      <line>A milky-bell’d amaryllis blew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How young Columbus seem’d to rove,</line>
      <line>Yet present in his natal grove,</line>
      <line>Now watching high on mountain cornice,</line>
      <line>And steering, now, from a purple cove,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now pacing mute by ocean’s rim;</line>
      <line>Till, in a narrow street and dim,</line>
      <line>I stay’d the wheels at Cogoletto,</line>
      <line>And drank, and loyally drank to him.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor knew we well what pleased us most,</line>
      <line>Not the dipt palm of which they boast;</line>
      <line>But distant colour, happy hamlet,</line>
      <line>A moulder’d citadel on the coast,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or tower, or high hill-convent, seen</line>
      <line>A light amid its olives green;</line>
      <line>Or olive-hoary cape in ocean;</line>
      <line>Or rosy blossom in hot ravine,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where oleanders flush’d the bed</line>
      <line>Of silent torrents, gravel-spread;</line>
      <line>And, crossing, oft we saw the glisten</line>
      <line>Of ice, far up on a mountain head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We loved that hall, tho’ white and cold,</line>
      <line>Those niched shapes of noble mould,</line>
      <line>A princely people’s awful princes,</line>
      <line>The grave, severe Genovese of old.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At Florence too what golden hours,</line>
      <line>In those long galleries, were ours;</line>
      <line>What drives about the fresh Cascine,</line>
      <line>Or walks in Boboli’s ducal bowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In bright vignettes, and each complete,</line>
      <line>Of tower or duomo, sunny-sweet,</line>
      <line>Or palace, how the city glitter’d,</line>
      <line>Thro’ cypress avenues, at our feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when we crost the Lombard plain</line>
      <line>Remember what a plague of rain;</line>
      <line>Of rain at Reggio, rain at Parma;</line>
      <line>At Lodi, rain, Piacenza, rain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And stern and sad (so rare the smiles</line>
      <line>Of sunlight) look’d the Lombard piles;</line>
      <line>Porch-pillars on the lion resting,</line>
      <line>And sombre, old, colonnaded aisles.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Milan, O the chanting quires,</line>
      <line>The giant windows’ blazon’d fires,</line>
      <line>The height, the space, the gloom, the glory!</line>
      <line>A mount of marble, a hundred spires!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I climb’d the roofs at break of day;</line>
      <line>Sun-smitten Alps before me lay.</line>
      <line>I stood among the silent statues,</line>
      <line>And statued pinnacles, mute as they.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How faintly-flush’d, how phantom-fair,</line>
      <line>Was Monte Rosa, hanging there</line>
      <line>A thousand shadowy-pencill’d valleys</line>
      <line>And snowy dells in a golden air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Remember how we came at last</line>
      <line>To Como; shower and storm and blast</line>
      <line>Had blown the lake beyond his limit,</line>
      <line>And all was flooded; and how we past</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From Como, when the light was gray,</line>
      <line>And in my head, for half the day,</line>
      <line>The rich Virgilian rustic measure</line>
      <line>Of Lari Maxume, all the way,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like ballad-burthen music, kept,</line>
      <line>As on The Lariano crept</line>
      <line>To that fair port below the castle</line>
      <line>Of Queen Theodolind, where we slept;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or hardly slept, but watch’d awake</line>
      <line>A cypress in the moonlight shake,</line>
      <line>The moonlight touching o’er a terrace</line>
      <line>One tall Agave above the lake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What more? we took our last adieu,</line>
      <line>And up the snowy Splugen drew,</line>
      <line>But ere we reach’d the highest summit</line>
      <line>I pluck’d a daisy, I gave it you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It told of England then to me,</line>
      <line>And now it tells of Italy.</line>
      <line>O love, we two shall go no longer</line>
      <line>To lands of summer across the sea;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So dear a life your arms enfold</line>
      <line>Whose crying is a cry for gold:</line>
      <line>Yet here to-night in this dark city,</line>
      <line>When ill and weary, alone and cold,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I found, tho’ crush’d to hard and dry,</line>
      <line>This nurseling of another sky</line>
      <line>Still in the little book you lent me,</line>
      <line>And where you tenderly laid it by:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I forgot the clouded Forth,</line>
      <line>The gloom that saddens Heaven and Earth,</line>
      <line>The bitter east, the misty summer</line>
      <line>And gray metropolis of the North.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perchance, to lull the throbs of pain,</line>
      <line>Perchance, to charm a vacant brain,</line>
      <line>Perchance, to dream you still beside me,</line>
      <line>My fancy fled to the South again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>To the Rev. F. D. Maurice</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, when no graver cares employ,</line>
      <line>Godfather, come and see your boy:</line>
      <line>Your presence will be sun in winter,</line>
      <line>Making the little one leap for joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For, being of that honest few,</line>
      <line>Who give the Fiend himself his due,</line>
      <line>Should eighty-thousand college-councils</line>
      <line>Thunder ‘Anathema,’ friend, at you;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Should all our churchmen foam in spite</line>
      <line>At you, so careful of the right,</line>
      <line>Yet one lay-hearth would give you welcome</line>
      <line>(Take it and come) to the Isle of Wight;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where, far from noise and smoke of town,</line>
      <line>I watch the twilight falling brown</line>
      <line>All round a careless-order’d garden</line>
      <line>Close to the ridge of a noble down.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You’ll have no scandal while you dine,</line>
      <line>But honest talk and wholesome wine,</line>
      <line>And only hear the magpie gossip</line>
      <line>Garrulous under a roof of pine:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For groves of pine on either hand,</line>
      <line>To break the blast of winter, stand;</line>
      <line>And further on, the hoary Channel</line>
      <line>Tumbles a billow on chalk and sand;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where, if below the milky steep</line>
      <line>Some ship of battle slowly creep,</line>
      <line>And on thro’ zones of light and shadow</line>
      <line>Glimmer away to the lonely deep,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We might discuss the Northern sin</line>
      <line>Which made a selfish war begin;</line>
      <line>Dispute the claims, arrange the chances;</line>
      <line>Emperor, Ottoman, which shall win:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or whether war’s avenging rod</line>
      <line>Shall lash all Europe into blood;</line>
      <line>Till you should turn to dearer matters,</line>
      <line>Dear to the man that is dear to God;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How best to help the slender store,</line>
      <line>How mend the dwellings, of the poor;</line>
      <line>How gain in life, as life advances,</line>
      <line>Valour and charity more and more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, Maurice, come: the lawn as yet</line>
      <line>Is hoar with rime, or spongy-wet;</line>
      <line>But when the wreath of March has blossom’d,</line>
      <line>Crocus, anemone, violet,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or later, pay one visit here,</line>
      <line>For those are few we hold as dear;</line>
      <line>Nor pay but one, but come for many,</line>
      <line>Many and many a happy year.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>The Charge of the Light Brigade</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Half a league, half a league,</line>
      <line>Half a league onward,</line>
      <line>All in the valley of Death</line>
      <line>Rode the six hundred.</line>
      <line>‘Forward, the Light Brigade!</line>
      <line>Charge for the guns!’ he said:</line>
      <line>Into the valley of Death</line>
      <line>Rode the six hundred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Forward, the Light Brigade!’</line>
      <line>Was there a man dismay’d?</line>
      <line>Not tho’ the soldier knew</line>
      <line>Some one had blunder’d:</line>
      <line>Their’s not to make reply,</line>
      <line>Their’s not to reason why,</line>
      <line>Their’s but to do and die:</line>
      <line>Into the valley of Death</line>
      <line>Rode the six hundred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cannon to right of them,</line>
      <line>Cannon to left of them,</line>
      <line>Cannon in front of them</line>
      <line>Volley’d and thunder’d;</line>
      <line>Storm’d at with shot and shell,</line>
      <line>Boldly they rode and well,</line>
      <line>Into the jaws of Death,</line>
      <line>Into the mouth of Hell</line>
      <line>Rode the six hundred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Flash’d all their sabres bare,</line>
      <line>Flash’d as they turn’d in air</line>
      <line>Sabring the gunners there,</line>
      <line>Charging an army, while</line>
      <line>All the world wonder’d:</line>
      <line>Plunged in the battery-smoke</line>
      <line>Right thro’ the line they broke;</line>
      <line>Cossack and Russian</line>
      <line>Reel’d from the sabre-stroke</line>
      <line>Shatter’d and sunder’d.</line>
      <line>Then they rode back, but not</line>
      <line>Not the six hundred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cannon to right of them,</line>
      <line>Cannon to left of them,</line>
      <line>Cannon behind them</line>
      <line>Volley’d and thunder’d;</line>
      <line>Storm’d at with shot and shell,</line>
      <line>While horse and hero fell,</line>
      <line>They that had fought so well</line>
      <line>Came thro’ the jaws of Death,</line>
      <line>Back from the mouth of Hell,</line>
      <line>All that was left of them,</line>
      <line>Left of six hundred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When can their glory fade?</line>
      <line>O the wild charge they made!</line>
      <line>All the world wonder’d.</line>
      <line>Honour the charge they made!</line>
      <line>Honour the Light Brigade,</line>
      <line>Noble six hundred!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>from Maud I.xi</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O let the solid ground</line>
      <line>Not fail beneath my feet</line>
      <line>Before my life has found</line>
      <line>What some have found so sweet;</line>
      <line>Then let come what come may,</line>
      <line>What matter if I go mad,</line>
      <line>I shall have had my day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the sweet heavens endure,</line>
      <line>Not close and darken above me</line>
      <line>Before I am quite quite sure</line>
      <line>That there is one to love me;</line>
      <line>Then let come what come may</line>
      <line>To a life that has been so sad,</line>
      <line>I shall have had my day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>from Maud I.xviii</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have led her home, my love, my only friend.</line>
      <line>There is none like her, none.</line>
      <line>And never yet so warmly ran my blood</line>
      <line>And sweetly, on and on</line>
      <line>Calming itself to the long-wish’d-for end,</line>
      <line>Full to the banks, close on the promised good.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>None like her, none.</line>
      <line>Just now the dry-tongued laurels’ pattering talk</line>
      <line>Seem’d her light foot along the garden walk,</line>
      <line>And shook my heart to think she comes once more;</line>
      <line>But even then I heard her close the door,</line>
      <line>The gates of Heaven are closed, and she is gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is none like her, none.</line>
      <line>Nor will be when our summers have deceased.</line>
      <line>O, art thou sighing for Lebanon</line>
      <line>In the long breeze that streams to thy delicious East,</line>
      <line>Sighing for Lebanon,</line>
      <line>Dark cedar, tho’ thy limbs have here increased,</line>
      <line>Upon a pastoral slope as fair,</line>
      <line>And looking to the South, and fed</line>
      <line>With honey’d rain and delicate air,</line>
      <line>And haunted by the starry head</line>
      <line>Of her whose gentle will has changed my fate,</line>
      <line>And made my life a perfumed altar-flame;</line>
      <line>And over whom thy darkness must have spread</line>
      <line>With such delight as theirs of old, thy great</line>
      <line>Forefathers of the thornless garden, there</line>
      <line>Shadowing the snow-limb’d Eve from whom she came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here will I lie, while these long branches sway,</line>
      <line>And you fair stars that crown a happy day</line>
      <line>Go in and out as if at merry play,</line>
      <line>Who am no more so all forlorn,</line>
      <line>As when it seem’d far better to be born</line>
      <line>To labour and the mattock-harden’d hand,</line>
      <line>Than nursed at ease and brought to understand</line>
      <line>A sad astrology, the boundless plan</line>
      <line>That makes you tyrants in your iron skies,</line>
      <line>Innumerable, pitiless, passionless eyes,</line>
      <line>Cold fires, yet with power to burn and brand</line>
      <line>His nothingness into man.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But now shine on, and what care I,</line>
      <line>Who in this stormy gulf have found a pearl</line>
      <line>The countercharm of space and hollow sky,</line>
      <line>And do accept my madness, and would die</line>
      <line>To save from some slight shame one simple girl.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Would die; for sullen-seeming Death may give</line>
      <line>More life to Love than is or ever was</line>
      <line>In our low world, where yet ’tis sweet to live.</line>
      <line>Let no one ask me how it came to pass;</line>
      <line>It seems that I am happy, that to me</line>
      <line>A livelier emerald twinkles in the grass,</line>
      <line>A purer sapphire melts into the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not die; but live a life of truest breath,</line>
      <line>And teach true life to fight with mortal wrongs.</line>
      <line>O, why should Love, like men in drinking-songs,</line>
      <line>Spice his fair banquet with the dust of death?</line>
      <line>Make answer, Maud my bliss,</line>
      <line>Maud made my Maud by that long loving kiss,</line>
      <line>Life of my life, wilt thou not answer this?</line>
      <line>‘The dusky strand of Death inwoven here</line>
      <line>With dear Love’s tie, makes Love himself more dear.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is that enchanted moan only the swell</line>
      <line>Of the long waves that roll in yonder bay?</line>
      <line>And hark the clock within, the silver knell</line>
      <line>Of twelve sweet hours that past in bridal white,</line>
      <line>And died to live, long as my pulses play;</line>
      <line>But now by this my love has closed her sight</line>
      <line>And given false death her hand, and stol’n away</line>
      <line>To dreamful wastes where footless fancies dwell</line>
      <line>Among the fragments of the golden day. 70</line>
      <line>May nothing there her maiden grace affright!</line>
      <line>Dear heart, I feel with thee the drowsy spell.</line>
      <line>My bride to be, my evermore delight,</line>
      <line>My own heart’s heart, my ownest own, farewell;</line>
      <line>It is but for a little space I go:</line>
      <line>And ye meanwhile far over moor and fell</line>
      <line>Beat to the noiseless music of the night!</line>
      <line>Has our whole earth gone nearer to the glow</line>
      <line>Of your soft splendours that you look so bright?</line>
      <line>I have climb’d nearer out of lonely Hell. 80</line>
      <line>Beat, happy stars, timing with things below,</line>
      <line>Beat with my heart more blest than heart can tell,</line>
      <line>Blest, but for some dark undercurrent woe</line>
      <line>That seems to draw — but it shall not be so:</line>
      <line>Let all be well, be well.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>from Maud I.xxii</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come into the garden, Maud,</line>
      <line>For the black bat, night, has flown,</line>
      <line>Come into the garden, Maud,</line>
      <line>I am here at the gate alone;</line>
      <line>And the woodbine spices are wafted abroad,</line>
      <line>And the musk of the rose is blown.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For a breeze of morning moves,</line>
      <line>And the planet of Love is on high,</line>
      <line>Beginning to faint in the light that she loves</line>
      <line>On a bed of daffodil sky,</line>
      <line>To faint in the light of the sun she loves,</line>
      <line>To faint in his light, and to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All night have the roses heard</line>
      <line>The flute, violin, bassoon;</line>
      <line>All night has the casement jessamine stirr’d</line>
      <line>To the dancers dancing in tune;</line>
      <line>Till a silence fell with the waking bird,</line>
      <line>And a hush with the setting moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said to the lily, ‘There is but one</line>
      <line>With whom she has heart to be gay.</line>
      <line>When will the dancers leave her alone?</line>
      <line>She is weary of dance and play.’</line>
      <line>Now half to the setting moon are gone,</line>
      <line>And half to the rising day;</line>
      <line>Low on the sand and loud on the stone</line>
      <line>The last wheel echoes away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said to the rose, ‘The brief night goes</line>
      <line>In babble and revel and wine.</line>
      <line>O young lord-lover, what sighs are those,</line>
      <line>For one that will never be thine?</line>
      <line>But mine, but mine,’ so I sware to the rose,</line>
      <line>‘For ever and ever, mine.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the soul of the rose went into my blood,</line>
      <line>As the music clash’d in the hall;</line>
      <line>And long by the garden lake I stood,</line>
      <line>For I heard your rivulet fall</line>
      <line>From the lake to the meadow and on to the wood,</line>
      <line>Our wood, that is dearer than all;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From the meadow your walks have left so sweet</line>
      <line>That whenever a March-wind sighs</line>
      <line>He sets the jewel-print of your feet</line>
      <line>In violets blue as your eyes,</line>
      <line>To the woody hollows in which we meet</line>
      <line>And the valleys of Paradise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The slender acacia would not shake</line>
      <line>One long milk-bloom on the tree;</line>
      <line>The white lake-blossom fell into the lake</line>
      <line>As the pimpernel dozed on the lea;</line>
      <line>But the rose was awake all night for your sake,</line>
      <line>Knowing your promise to me;</line>
      <line>The lilies and roses were all awake,</line>
      <line>They sigh’d for the dawn and thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Queen rose of the rosebud garden of girls,</line>
      <line>Come hither, the dances are done,</line>
      <line>In gloss of satin and glimmer of pearls,</line>
      <line>Queen lily and rose in one;</line>
      <line>Shine out, little head, sunning over with curls,</line>
      <line>To the flowers, and be their sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There has fallen a splendid tear</line>
      <line>From the passion-flower at the gate.</line>
      <line>She is coming, my dove, my dear;</line>
      <line>She is coming, my life, my fate;</line>
      <line>The red rose cries, ‘She is near, she is near;’</line>
      <line>And the white rose weeps, ‘She is late;’</line>
      <line>The larkspur listens, ‘I hear, I hear;’</line>
      <line>And the lily whispers, ‘I wait.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She is coming, my own, my sweet;</line>
      <line>Were it ever so airy a tread,</line>
      <line>My heart would hear her and beat,</line>
      <line>Were it earth in an earthy bed; 70</line>
      <line>My dust would hear her and beat,</line>
      <line>Had I lain for a century dead;</line>
      <line>Would start and tremble under her feet,</line>
      <line>And blossom in purple and red.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>from Maud II.iv</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O that ’twere possible</line>
      <line>After long grief and pain</line>
      <line>To find the arms of my true love</line>
      <line>Round me once again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I was wont to meet her</line>
      <line>InThe silent woody places</line>
      <line>By the home that gave me birth,</line>
      <line>We stood tranced in long embraces</line>
      <line>Mixt with kisses sweeter sweeter</line>
      <line>Than anything on earth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A shadow flits before me,</line>
      <line>Not thou, but like to thee:</line>
      <line>Ah Christ, that it were possible</line>
      <line>For one short hour to see</line>
      <line>The souls we loved, that they might tell us</line>
      <line>What and where they be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It leads me forth at evening,</line>
      <line>It lightly winds and steals</line>
      <line>In a cold white robe before me,</line>
      <line>When all my spirit reels</line>
      <line>At the shouts, the leagues of lights,</line>
      <line>And the roaring of the wheels.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Half the night I waste in sighs,</line>
      <line>Half in dreams I sorrow after</line>
      <line>The delight of early skies;</line>
      <line>In a wakeful doze I sorrow</line>
      <line>For the hand, the lips, the eyes,</line>
      <line>For the meeting of the morrow,</line>
      <line>The delight of happy laughter,</line>
      <line>The delight of low replies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis a morning pure and sweet,</line>
      <line>And a dewy splendour falls</line>
      <line>On the little flower that clings</line>
      <line>To the turrets and the walls;</line>
      <line>’Tis a morning pure and sweet,</line>
      <line>And the light and shadow fleet;</line>
      <line>She is walking in the meadow,</line>
      <line>And the woodland echo rings;</line>
      <line>In a moment we shall meet;</line>
      <line>She is singing in the meadow</line>
      <line>And the rivulet at her feet</line>
      <line>Ripples on in light and shadow</line>
      <line>To the ballad that she sings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do I hear her sing as of old,</line>
      <line>My bird with the shining head,</line>
      <line>My own dove with the tender eye?</line>
      <line>But there rings on a sudden a passionate cry,</line>
      <line>There is some one dying or dead,</line>
      <line>And a sullen thunder is roll’d;</line>
      <line>For a tumult shakes the city,</line>
      <line>And I wake, my dream is fled;</line>
      <line>In the shuddering dawn, behold,</line>
      <line>Without knowledge, without pity,</line>
      <line>By the curtains of my bed</line>
      <line>That abiding phantom cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Get thee hence, nor come again,</line>
      <line>Mix not memory with doubt,</line>
      <line>Pass, thou deathlike type of pain,</line>
      <line>Pass and cease to move about!</line>
      <line>’Tis the blot upon the brain</line>
      <line>That will show itself without.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then I rise, the eavedrops falls,</line>
      <line>And the yellow vapours choke</line>
      <line>The great city sounding wide;</line>
      <line>The day comes, a dull red ball</line>
      <line>Wrapt in drifts of lurid smoke</line>
      <line>On the misty river-tide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thro’ the hubbub of the market</line>
      <line>I steal, a wasted frame,</line>
      <line>It crosses here, it crosses there,</line>
      <line>Thro’ all that crowd confused and loud,</line>
      <line>The shadow still the same;</line>
      <line>And on my heavy eyelids</line>
      <line>My anguish hangs like shame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas for her that met me,</line>
      <line>That heard me softly call,</line>
      <line>Came glimmering thro’ the laurels</line>
      <line>At the quiet evenfall,</line>
      <line>In the garden by the turrets</line>
      <line>Of the old manorial hall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Would the happy spirit descend,</line>
      <line>From the realms of light and song,</line>
      <line>In the chamber or the street,</line>
      <line>As she looks among the blest,</line>
      <line>Should I fear to greet my friend</line>
      <line>Or to say ‘Forgive the wrong,’</line>
      <line>Or to ask her, ‘Take me, sweet,</line>
      <line>To the regions of thy rest’?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the broad light glares and beats,</line>
      <line>And the shadow flits and fleets</line>
      <line>And will not let me be;</line>
      <line>And I loathe the squares and streets,</line>
      <line>And the faces that one meets,</line>
      <line>Hearts with no love for me:</line>
      <line>Always I long to creep</line>
      <line>Into some still cavern deep,</line>
      <line>There to weep, and weep, and weep</line>
      <line>My whole soul out to thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>from Idylls of the King: Merlin and Vivien</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Love, if Love be Love, if Love be ours,</line>
      <line>Faith and unfaith can ne’er be equal powers:</line>
      <line>Unfaith in aught is want of faith in all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is the little rift within the lute,</line>
      <line>That by and by will make the music mute,</line>
      <line>And ever widening slowly silence all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The little rift within the lover’s lute</line>
      <line>Or little pitted speck in garner’d fruit,</line>
      <line>That rotting inward slowly moulders all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is not worth the keeping: let it go:</line>
      <line>But shall it? answer, darling, answer, no.</line>
      <line>And trust me not at all or all in all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1860</date>
    <title>Tithonus</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The woods decay, the woods decay and fall,</line>
      <line>The vapours weep their burthen to the ground,</line>
      <line>Man comes and tills the field and lies beneath,</line>
      <line>And after many a summer dies the swan.</line>
      <line>Me only cruel immortality</line>
      <line>Consumes: I wither slowly in thine arms,</line>
      <line>Here at the quiet limit of the world,</line>
      <line>A white-hair’d shadow roaming like a dream</line>
      <line>The ever-silent spaces of the East,</line>
      <line>Far-folded mists, and gleaming halls of morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas! for this gray shadow, once a man—</line>
      <line>So glorious in his beauty and thy choice,</line>
      <line>Who madest him thy chosen, that he seem’d</line>
      <line>To his great heart none other than a God!</line>
      <line>I ask’d thee, ‘Give me immortality.’</line>
      <line>Then didst thou grant mine asking with a smile,</line>
      <line>Like wealthy men, who care not how they give.</line>
      <line>But thy strong Hours indignant work’d their wills,</line>
      <line>And beat me down and marr’d and wasted me,</line>
      <line>And tho’ they could not end me, left me maim’d</line>
      <line>To dwell in presence of immortal youth,</line>
      <line>Immortal age beside immortal youth,</line>
      <line>And all I was, in ashes. Can thy love,</line>
      <line>Thy beauty, make amends, tho’ even now,</line>
      <line>Close over us, the silver star, thy guide,</line>
      <line>Shines in those tremulous eyes that fill with tears</line>
      <line>To hear me? Let me go: take back thy gift:</line>
      <line>Why should a man desire in any way</line>
      <line>To vary from the kindly race of men</line>
      <line>Or pass beyond the goal of ordinance</line>
      <line>Where all should pause, as is most meet for all?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A soft air fans the cloud apart; there comes</line>
      <line>A glimpse of that dark world where I was born.</line>
      <line>Once more the old mysterious glimmer steals</line>
      <line>From thy pure brows, and from thy shoulders pure,</line>
      <line>And bosom beating with a heart renew’d.</line>
      <line>Thy cheek begins to redden thro’ the gloom,</line>
      <line>Thy sweet eyes brighten slowly close to mine,</line>
      <line>Ere yet they blind the stars, and the wild team</line>
      <line>Which love thee, yearning for thy yoke, arise,</line>
      <line>And shake the darkness from their loosen’d manes,</line>
      <line>And beat the twilight into flakes of fire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lo! ever thus thou growest beautiful</line>
      <line>In silence, then before thine answer given</line>
      <line>Departest, and thy tears are on my cheek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why wilt thou ever scare me with thy tears,</line>
      <line>And make me tremble lest a saying learnt,</line>
      <line>In days far-off, on that dark earth, be true?</line>
      <line>‘The Gods themselves cannot recall their gifts.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ay me! ay me! with what another heart</line>
      <line>In days far-off, and with what other eyes</line>
      <line>I used to watch—if I be he that watch’d—</line>
      <line>The lucid outline forming round thee; saw</line>
      <line>The dim curls kindle into sunny rings;</line>
      <line>Changed with thy mystic change, and felt my blood</line>
      <line>Glow with the glow that slowly crimson’d all</line>
      <line>Thy presence and thy portals, while I lay,</line>
      <line>Mouth, forehead, eyelids, growing dewy-warm</line>
      <line>With kisses balmier than half-opening buds</line>
      <line>Of April, and could hear the lips that kiss’d</line>
      <line>Whispering I knew not what of wild and sweet,</line>
      <line>Like that strange song I heard Apollo sing,</line>
      <line>While Ilion like a mist rose into towers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet hold me not for ever in thine East:</line>
      <line>How can my nature longer mix with thine?</line>
      <line>Coldly thy rosy shadows bathe me, cold</line>
      <line>Are all thy lights, and cold my wrinkled feet</line>
      <line>Upon thy glimmering thresholds, when the steam</line>
      <line>Floats up from those dim fields about the homes</line>
      <line>Of happy men that have the power to die,</line>
      <line>And grassy barrows of the happier dead.</line>
      <line>Release me, and restore me to the ground;</line>
      <line>Thou seest all things, thou wilt see my grave:</line>
      <line>Thou wilt renew thy beauty morn by morn;</line>
      <line>I earth in earth forget these empty courts,</line>
      <line>And thee returning on thy silver wheels.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>Northern Farmer. New Style</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dosn’t thou ’ear my ’erse’s legs, as they canters awaay?</line>
      <line>Proputty, proputty, proputty—that’s what I ’ears ’em saay.</line>
      <line>Proputty, proputty, proputty—Sam, thou’s an ass for thy paai'ns:</line>
      <line>Theer’s moor sense i’ one o’ ’is legs nor in all thy braains.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Woa—theer’s a craw to pluck wi’ tha, Sam: yon’s parson’s ’ouse—</line>
      <line>Dosn’t thou knaw that a man mun be eather a man or a mouse?</line>
      <line>Time to think on it then; for thou’ll be twenty to weeak.</line>
      <line>Proputty, proputty—woa then woa—let ma ’ear mysen speak.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Me an’ thy muther, Sammy, ’as bean a-talkin’ o’ thee;</line>
      <line>Thou’s bean talkin’ to muther, an’ she bean a tellin’ it me.</line>
      <line>Thou’ll not marry for munny—thou’s sweet upo’ parson’s lass—</line>
      <line>Noa—thou’ll marry for luw—an’ we boath on us thinks tha an ass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Seea’d her todaay goa by—Saaint’s daay—they was ringing the bells.</line>
      <line>She’s a beauty thou thinks—an’ soa is scoors o’ gells,</line>
      <line>Them as ’as munny an’ all—wot’s a beauty?—the flower as blaws.</line>
      <line>But proputty, proputty sticks, an’ proputty, proputty graws.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do’ant be stunt: taake time: I knaws what maakes tha sa mad.</line>
      <line>Warn’t I craazed fur the lasses mysen when I wur a lad?</line>
      <line>But I knaw’d a Quaaker feller as often ’as towd ma this:</line>
      <line>‘Doant thou marry for munny, but goa wheer munny is!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ I went wheer munny war: an’ thy muther coom to ’and,</line>
      <line>Wi’ lots 0’ munny laaid by, an’ a nicetish bit o’ land.</line>
      <line>Maaybe she warn’t a beauty:—I niver giv it a thowt—</line>
      <line>But warn’t she as good to cuddle an’ kiss as a lass as ’ant nowt?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Parson’s lass ’ant nowt, an’ she weant ’a nowt when ’e’s dead,</line>
      <line>Mun be a guvness, lad, or summut, and addle her bread:</line>
      <line>Why? fur ’e’s nobbut a curate, an’ weant niver git hissen clear,</line>
      <line>An’ ’e maade the bed as ’e ligs on afoor ’e coom’d to the shere.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An thin ’e coom’d to the parish wi’ lots 0’ Varsity debt,</line>
      <line>Stook to his taail they did, an’ ’e ’ant got shut on ’em yet.</line>
      <line>An’ ’e ligs on ’is back i’ the grip, wi’ noan to lend ’im a shuw,</line>
      <line>Woorse nor a far-welter’d yowe: fur, Sammy, ’e married fur luw.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Luvv? what’s luw? thou can luw thy lass an’ ’er munny too,</line>
      <line>Maakin’ ’em goa togither as they’ve good right to do.</line>
      <line>Could’n I luw thy muther by cause o’ ’er munny laaid by?</line>
      <line>Naay—fur I luw’d ’er a vast sight moor fur it: reason why.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ay an’ thy muther says thou wants to marry the lass,</line>
      <line>Cooms of a gentleman burn: an’ we boath on us thinks tha an ass.</line>
      <line>Woa then, proputty, wiltha?—an ass as near as mays nowt—</line>
      <line>Woa then, wiltha? dangtha!—the bees is as fell as owt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Break me a bit o’ the esh for his ’ead lad, out o’ the fence!</line>
      <line>Gentleman burn! what’s gentleman burn? is it shillins an’ pence?</line>
      <line>Proputty, proputty’s ivrything ’ere, an’, Sammy, Pm blest</line>
      <line>If it isn’t the saame oop yonder, fur them as ’as it’s the best.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tis’n them as ’as munny as breaks into ’ouses an’ steals,</line>
      <line>Them as ’as coats to their backs an’ taakes their regular meals.</line>
      <line>Noa, but it’s them as niver knaws wheer a meal’s to be ’ad.</line>
      <line>Taake my word for it, Sammy, the poor in a loomp is bad.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Them or thir feythers, tha sees, mun ’a bean a laazy lot,</line>
      <line>Fur work mun ’a gone to the gittin’ whiniver munny was got.</line>
      <line>Feyther ’ad ammost nowt; leastways ’is munny was ’id.</line>
      <line>But ’e tued an’ moil’d ’issen dead, an ’e died a good un, ’e did.</line>
