    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look thou theer wheer Wrigglesby beck cooms out by the ’ill!</line>
      <line>Feyther run oop to the farm, an’ I runs oop to the mill;</line>
      <line>An’ I’ll run oop to the brig, an’ that thou’ll live to see;</line>
      <line>And if thou marries a good un I’ll leave the land to thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thim’s my noations, Sammy, wheerby I means to stick;</line>
      <line>But if thou marries a bad un, I’ll leave the land to Dick.—</line>
      <line>Coom oop, proputty, proputty—that’s what I ’ears ’im saay—</line>
      <line>Proputty, proputty, proputty—canter an’ canter awaay.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1883</date>
    <title>To E. FitzGerald</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old Fitz, who from your suburb grange,</line>
      <line>Where once I tarried for a while,</line>
      <line>Glance at the wheeling Orb of change,</line>
      <line>And greet it with a kindly smile;</line>
      <line>Whom yet I see as there you sit</line>
      <line>Beneath your sheltering garden-tree,</line>
      <line>And while your doves about you flit,</line>
      <line>And plant on shoulder, hand and knee,</line>
      <line>Or on your head their rosy feet,</line>
      <line>As if they knew your diet spares</line>
      <line>Whatever moved in that full sheet</line>
      <line>Let down to Peter at his prayers;</line>
      <line>Who live on milk and meal and grass;</line>
      <line>And once for ten long weeks I tried</line>
      <line>Your table of Pythagoras,</line>
      <line>And seem’d at first ‘a thing enskied’</line>
      <line>(As Shakespeare has it) airy-light</line>
      <line>To float above the ways of men,</line>
      <line>Then fell from that half-spiritual height</line>
      <line>Chill’d, till I tasted flesh again</line>
      <line>One night when earth was winter-black,</line>
      <line>And all the heavens flash’d in frost;</line>
      <line>And on me, half-asleep, came back</line>
      <line>That wholesome heat the blood had lost,</line>
      <line>And set me climbing icy capes</line>
      <line>And glaciers, over which there roll’d</line>
      <line>To meet me long-arm’d vines with grapes</line>
      <line>Of Eshcol hugeness; for the cold</line>
      <line>Without, and warmth within me, wrought</line>
      <line>To mould the dream; but none can say</line>
      <line>That Lenten fare makes Lenten thought,</line>
      <line>Who reads your golden Eastern lay,</line>
      <line>Than which I know no version done</line>
      <line>In English more divinely well;</line>
      <line>A planet equal to the sun</line>
      <line>Which cast it, that large infidel</line>
      <line>Your Omar; and your Omar drew</line>
      <line>Full-handed plaudits from our best</line>
      <line>In modern letters, and from two,</line>
      <line>Old friends outvaluing all the rest,</line>
      <line>Two voices heard on earth no more;</line>
      <line>But we old friends are still alive,</line>
      <line>And I am nearing seventy-four,</line>
      <line>While you have touch’d at seventy-five,</line>
      <line>And so I send a birthday line</line>
      <line>Of greeting; and my son, who dipt</line>
      <line>In some forgotten book of mine</line>
      <line>With sallow scraps of manuscript,</line>
      <line>And dating many a year ago,</line>
      <line>Has hit on this, which you will take</line>
      <line>My Fitz, and welcome, as I know</line>
      <line>Less for its own than for the sake</line>
      <line>Of one recalling gracious times,</line>
      <line>When, in our younger London days,</line>
      <line>You found some merit in my rhymes,</line>
      <line>And I more pleasure in your praise.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alfred Tennyson</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>Crossing the Bar</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sunset and evening star,</line>
      <line>And one clear call for me!</line>
      <line>And may there be no moaning of the bar,</line>
      <line>When I put out to sea,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But such a tide as moving seems asleep,</line>
      <line>Too full for sound and foam,</line>
      <line>When that which drew from out the boundless deep</line>
      <line>Turns again home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Twilight and evening bell,</line>
      <line>And after that the dark!</line>
      <line>And may there be no sadness of farewell,</line>
      <line>When I embark;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For tho’ from out our bourne of Time and Place</line>
      <line>The flood may bear me far,</line>
      <line>I hope to see my Pilot face to face</line>
      <line>When I have crost the bar.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1837</date>
    <title>Long neglect has worn away</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Long neglect has worn away</line>
      <line>Half the sweet enchanting smile;</line>
      <line>Time has turned the bloom to grey;</line>
      <line>Mould and damp the face defile.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But that lock of silky hair,</line>
      <line>Still beneath the picture twined,</line>
      <line>Tells what once those features were,</line>
      <line>Paints their image on the mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair the hand that traced that line,</line>
      <line>‘Dearest, ever deem me true’;</line>
      <line>Swiftly flew the fingers fine</line>
      <line>When the pen that motto drew.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1837</date>
    <title>The night is darkening round me,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The night is darkening round me,</line>
      <line>The wild winds coldly blow;</line>
      <line>But a tyrant spell has bound me</line>
      <line>And I cannot, cannot go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The giant trees are bending</line>
      <line>Their bare boughs weighed with snow,</line>
      <line>And the storm is fast descending</line>
      <line>And yet I cannot go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Clouds beyond clouds above me,</line>
      <line>Wastes beyond wastes below;</line>
      <line>But nothing drear can move me;</line>
      <line>I will not, cannot go.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>All hushed and still within the house;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All hushed and still within the house;</line>
      <line>Without — all wind and driving rain;</line>
      <line>But something whispers to my mind,</line>
      <line>Through rain and through the wailing wind,</line>
      <line>Never again.</line>
      <line>Never again? Why not again?</line>
      <line>Memory has power as real as thine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>It’s over now; I’ve known it all;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It’s over now; I’ve known it all;</line>
      <line>I’ll hide it in my heart no more,</line>
      <line>But back again that night recall,</line>
      <line>And think the fearful vision o’er.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The evening sun, in cloudless shine,</line>
      <line>Had pass’d from summer’s heaven divine;</line>
      <line>And dark the shades of twilight grew,</line>
      <line>And stars were in the depth of blue;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in the heath on mountains far</line>
      <line>From human eye and human care,</line>
      <line>With thoughtful heart and tearful eye</line>
      <line>I sadly watched that solemn sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>It will not shine again;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It will not shine again;</line>
      <line>Its sad course is done;</line>
      <line>I have seen the last ray wane</line>
      <line>Of the cold, bright sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>O COME with me, thus ran the song,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O COME with me, thus ran the song,</line>
      <line>The moon is bright in Autumn’s sky,</line>
      <line>And thou hast toiled and laboured long</line>
      <line>With aching head and weary eye.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>O Dream, where art thou now?</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Dream, where art thou now?</line>
      <line>Long years have past away</line>
      <line>Since last, from off thine angel brow</line>
      <line>I saw the light decay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas, alas for me</line>
      <line>Thou wert so bright and fair,</line>
      <line>I could not think thy memory</line>
      <line>Would yield me nought but care!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun-beam and the storm,</line>
      <line>The summer-eve divine,</line>
      <line>The silent night of solemn calm,</line>
      <line>The full moon’s cloudless shine,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Were once entwined with thee,</line>
      <line>But now with weary pain,</line>
      <line>Lost vision! ’tis enough for me—</line>
      <line>Thou canst not shine again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>How still, how happy! Those are words</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How still, how happy! Those are words</line>
      <line>That once would scarce agree together;</line>
      <line>I loved the plashing of the surge,</line>
      <line>The changing heaven, the breezy weather,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>More than smooth seas and cloudless skies</line>
      <line>And solemn, soothing, softened airs</line>
      <line>That in the forest woke no sighs</line>
      <line>And from the green spray shook no tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How still, how happy! Now I feel</line>
      <line>Where silence dwells is sweeter far</line>
      <line>Than laughing mirth’s most joyous swell</line>
      <line>However pure its raptures are.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, sit down on this sunny stone:</line>
      <line>’Tis wintry light o’er flowerless moors—</line>
      <line>But sit—for we are all alone</line>
      <line>And clear expand heaven’s breathless shores.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I could think in the withered grass</line>
      <line>Spring’s budding wreaths we might discern;</line>
      <line>The violet’s eye might shyly flash</line>
      <line>And young leaves shoot among the fern.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is but thought—full many a night</line>
      <line>The snow shall clothe those hills afar</line>
      <line>And storms shall add a drearier blight</line>
      <line>And winds shall wage a wilder war,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Before the lark may herald in</line>
      <line>Fresh foliage twined with blossoms fair</line>
      <line>And summer days again begin</line>
      <line>Their glory-haloed crown to wear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet my heart loves December’s smile</line>
      <line>As much as July’s golden beam;</line>
      <line>Then let us sit and watch the while</line>
      <line>The blue ice curdling on the stream.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1839</date>
    <title>What winter floods, what showers of spring</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What winter floods, what showers of spring</line>
      <line>Have drenched the grass by night and day;</line>
      <line>And yet, beneath, that spectre ring,</line>
      <line>Unmoved and undiscovered lay</line>
      <line>A mute remembrancer of crime,</line>
      <line>Long lost, concealed, forgot for years,</line>
      <line>It comes at last to cancel time,</line>
      <line>And waken unavailing tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1839</date>
    <title>I KNOW not how it falls on me,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I KNOW not how it falls on me,</line>
      <line>This summer evening, hushed and lone;</line>
      <line>Yet the faint wind comes soothingly</line>
      <line>With something of an olden tone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forgive me if I’ve shunned so long</line>
      <line>Your gentle greeting, earth and air!</line>
      <line>But sorrow withers even the strong,</line>
      <line>And who can fight against despair?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1839</date>
    <title>She dried her tears, and they did smile</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She dried her tears, and they did smile</line>
      <line>To see her cheeks’ returning glow;</line>
      <line>Nor did discern how all the while</line>
      <line>That full heart throbbed to overflow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With that sweet look and lively tone,</line>
      <line>And bright eye shining all the day,</line>
      <line>They could not guess, at midnight lone</line>
      <line>How she would weep the time away.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1839</date>
    <title>Mild the mist upon the hill,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mild the mist upon the hill,</line>
      <line>Telling not of storms to-morrow;</line>
      <line>No; the day has wept its fill,</line>
      <line>Spent its store of silent sorrow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, I’m gone back to the days of youth,</line>
      <line>I am a child once more;</line>
      <line>And ’neath my father’s sheltering roof.</line>
      <line>And near the old hall door,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watch this cloudy evening fall,</line>
      <line>After a day of rain:</line>
      <line>Blue mists, sweet mists of summer pall</line>
      <line>The horizon’s mountain-chain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The damp stands in the long, green grass</line>
      <line>As thick as morning’s tears;</line>
      <line>And dreamy scents of fragrance pass</line>
      <line>That breathe of other years.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1840</date>
    <title>It is too late to call thee now:</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is too late to call thee now:</line>
      <line>I will not nurse that dream again;</line>
      <line>For every joy that lit my brow</line>
      <line>Would bring its after-storm of pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Besides, the mist is half withdrawn;</line>
      <line>The barren mountain-side lies bare;</line>
      <line>And sunshine and awaking morn</line>
      <line>Paint no more golden visions there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet, ever in my grateful breast,</line>
      <line>Thy darling shade shall cherished be;</line>
      <line>For God alone doth know how blest</line>
      <line>My early years have been in thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1843</date>
    <title>Had there been falsehood in my breast</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had there been falsehood in my breast</line>
      <line>No thorns had marred my road,</line>
      <line>This spirit had not lost its rest,</line>
      <line>These tears had never flowed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1844</date>
    <title>Come, walk with me;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, walk with me;</line>
      <line>There’s only thee</line>
      <line>To bless my spirit now;</line>
      <line>We used to love on winter nights</line>
      <line>To wander through the snow.</line>
      <line>Can we not woo back old delights?</line>
      <line>The clouds rush dark and wild;</line>
      <line>They fleck with shade our mountain heights</line>
      <line>The same as long ago,</line>
      <line>And on the horizon rest at last</line>
      <line>In looming masses piled;</line>
      <line>While moonbeams flash and fly so fast</line>
      <line>We scarce can say they smiled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, walk with me — come, walk with me;</line>
      <line>We were not once so few;</line>
      <line>But Death has stolen our company</line>
      <line>As sunshine steals the dew:</line>
      <line>He took them one by one, and we</line>
      <line>Are left, the only two;</line>
      <line>So closer would my feelings twine,</line>
      <line>Because they have no stay but thine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Nay, call me not; it may not be;</line>
      <line>Is human love so true?</line>
      <line>Can Friendship’s flower droop on for years</line>
      <line>And then revive anew?</line>
      <line>No; though the soil be wet with tears,</line>
      <line>How fair soe’er it grew;</line>
      <line>The vital sap once perished</line>
      <line>Will never flow again;</line>
      <line>And surer than that dwelling dread,</line>
      <line>The narrow dungeon of the dead,</line>
      <line>Time parts the hearts of men.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>Cold in the earth, and the deep snow piled above thee!</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cold in the earth, and the deep snow piled above thee!</line>
      <line>Far, far removed, cold in the dreary grave!</line>
      <line>Have I forgot, my Only Love, to love thee,</line>
      <line>Severed at last by Time’s all-wearing wave?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, when alone, do my thoughts no longer hover</line>
      <line>Over the mountains on Angora’s shore;</line>
      <line>Resting their wings where heath and fern-leaves cover</line>
      <line>That noble heart for ever, ever more?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cold in the earth, and fifteen wild Decembers</line>
      <line>From those brown hills have melted into spring—</line>
      <line>Faithful indeed is the spirit that remembers</line>
      <line>After such years of change and suffering!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet Love of youth, forgive if I forget thee</line>
      <line>While the World’s tide is bearing me along:</line>
      <line>Sterner desires and darker hopes beset me,</line>
      <line>Hopes which obscure but cannot do thee wrong.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No other Sun has lightened up my heaven;</line>
      <line>No other Star has ever shone for me:</line>
      <line>All my life’s bliss from thy dear life was given—</line>
      <line>All my life’s bliss is in the grave with thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when the days of golden dreams had perished</line>
      <line>And even Despair was powerless to destroy,</line>
      <line>Then did I learn how existence could be cherished,</line>
      <line>Strengthened and fed without the aid of joy;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then did I check the tears of useless passion,</line>
      <line>Weaned my young soul from yearning after thine;</line>
      <line>Sternly denied its burning wish to hasten</line>
      <line>Down to that tomb already more than mine!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And even yet, I dare not let it languish,</line>
      <line>Dare not indulge in Memory’s rapturous pain;</line>
      <line>Once drinking deep of that divinest anguish,</line>
      <line>How could I seek the empty world again?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>The Prisoner</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the dungeon-crypts, idly did I stray,</line>
      <line>Reckless of the lives wasting there away;</line>
      <line>‘Draw the ponderous bars! open, Warder stern!’</line>
      <line>He dared not say me nay—the hinges harshly turn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Our guests are darkly lodged,’ I whisper’d, gazing through</line>
      <line>The vault, whose grated eye showed heaven more grey than blue;</line>
      <line>(This was when glad spring laughed in awaking pride;)</line>
      <line>‘Aye, darkly lodged enough!’ returned my sullen guide.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, God forgive my youth; forgive my careless tongue;</line>
      <line>I scoffed, as the chill chains on the damp flag-stones rung:</line>
      <line>‘Confined in triple walls, art thou so much to fear,</line>
      <line>That we must bind thee down and clench thy fetters here?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The captive raised her face, it was as soft and mild</line>
      <line>As sculptured marble saint, or slumbering unwean’d child;</line>
      <line>It was so soft and mild, it was so sweet and fair,</line>
      <line>Pain could not trace a line, nor grief a shadow there!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The captive raised her hand and pressed it to her brow;</line>
      <line>‘I have been struck,’ she said, ‘and I am suffering now;</line>
      <line>Yet these are little worth, your bolts and irons strong,</line>
      <line>And, were they forged in steel, they could not hold me long.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hoarse laughed the jailor grim: ‘Shall I be won to hear;</line>
      <line>Dost think, fond, dreaming wretch, that / shall grant thy prayer?</line>
      <line>Or, better still, wilt melt my master’s heart with groans?</line>
      <line>Ah! sooner might the sun thaw down these granite stones.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My master’s voice is low, his aspect bland and kind,</line>
      <line>But hard as hardest flint, the soul that lurks behind;</line>
      <line>And I am rough and rude, yet not more rough to see</line>
      <line>Than is the hidden ghost that has its home in me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>About her lips there played a smile of almost scorn,</line>
      <line>‘My friend,’ she gently said, ‘you have not heard me mourn;</line>
      <line>When you my kindred’s lives, my lost life, can restore,</line>
      <line>Then may I weep and sue,—but never, friend, before!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still, let my tyrants know, I am not doomed to wear</line>
      <line>Year after year in gloom, and desolate despair;</line>
      <line>A messenger of Hope, comes every night to me,</line>
      <line>And offers for short life, eternal liberty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He comes with western winds, with evening’s wandering airs,</line>
      <line>With that clear dusk of heaven that brings the thickest stars.</line>
      <line>Winds take a pensive tone, and stars a tender fire,</line>
      <line>And visions rise, and change, that kill me with desire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Desire for nothing known in my maturer years,</line>
      <line>When Joy grew mad with awe, at counting future tears.</line>
      <line>When, if my spirit’s sky was full of flashes warm,</line>
      <line>I knew not whence they came, from sun, or thunder storm.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, first, a hush of peace—a soundless calm descends;</line>
      <line>The struggle of distress, and fierce impatience ends.</line>
      <line>Mute music soothes my breast, unuttered harmony,</line>
      <line>That I could never dream, till Earth was lost to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then dawns the Invisible; the Unseen its truth reveals;</line>
      <line>My outward sense is gone, my inward essence feels:</line>
      <line>Its wings are almost free—its home, its harbour found,</line>
      <line>Measuring the gulph, it stoops, and dares the final bound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, dreadful is the check—intense the agony—</line>
      <line>When the ear begins to hear, and the eye begins to see;</line>
      <line>When the pulse begins to throb, the brain to think again,</line>
      <line>The soul to feel the flesh, and the flesh to feel the chain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet I would lose no sting, would wish no torture less,</line>
      <line>The more that anguish racks, the earlier it will bless;</line>
      <line>And robed in fires of hell, or bright with heavenly shine,</line>
      <line>If it but herald death, the vision is divine!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She ceased to speak, and we, unanswering, turned to go—</line>
      <line>We had no further power to work the captive woe:</line>
      <line>Her cheek, her gleaming eye, declared that man had given</line>
      <line>A sentence, unapproved, and overruled by Heaven.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Emily Jane Bronte and Charlotte Bronte</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>The Visionary</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Silent is the house: all are laid asleep:</line>
      <line>One alone looks out o’er the snow-wreaths deep;</line>
      <line>Watching every cloud, dreading every breeze</line>
      <line>That whirls the wildering drift, and bends the groaning trees.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cheerful is the hearth, soft the matted floor;</line>
      <line>Not one shivering gust creeps through pane or door;</line>
      <line>The little lamp burns straight, its rays shoot strong and far:</line>
      <line>I trim it well, to be the wanderer’s guiding-star.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Frown, my haughty sire! chide, my angry dame;</line>
      <line>Set your slaves to spy; threaten me with shame:</line>
      <line>But neither sire nor dame, nor prying serf shall know,</line>
      <line>What angel nightly tracks that waste of frozen snow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What I love shall come like visitant of air,</line>
      <line>Safe in secret power from lurking human snare;</line>
      <line>What loves me, no word of mine shall e’er betray,</line>
      <line>Though for faith unstained my life must forfeit pay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Burn, then, little lamp; glimmer straight and clear—</line>
      <line>Hush! a rustling wing stirs, methinks, the air:</line>
      <line>He for whom I wait, thus ever comes to me;</line>
      <line>Strange Power! I trust thy might; trust thou my constancy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1838</date>
    <title>Rondeau</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jenny kissed me when we met,</line>
      <line>Jumping from the chair she sat in;</line>
      <line>Time, you thief, who love to get</line>
      <line>Sweets into your list, put that in:</line>
      <line>Say I’m weary, say I’m sad,</line>
      <line>Say that health and wealth have missed me,</line>
      <line>Say I’m growing old, but add,</line>
      <line>Jenny kissed me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Leigh Hunt</author>
    <date>1852</date>
    <title>On the Death of His Son Vincent</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Waking at morn, with the accustomed sigh</line>
      <line>For what no morn could ever bring me more,</line>
      <line>And again sighing, while collecting strength</line>
      <line>To meet the pangs that waited me, like one</line>
      <line>Whose sleep the rack hath watched: I tried to feel</line>
      <line>How good for me had been strange griefs of old,</line>
      <line>That for long days, months, years, inured my wits</line>
      <line>To bear the dreadful burden of one thought.</line>
      <line>One thought with woful need turned many ways,</line>
      <line>Which, shunned at first, and scaring me, as wounds 10</line>
      <line>Thrusting in wound, became, oh! almost clasped</line>
      <line>And blest, as saviours from the one dire pang</line>
      <line>That mocked the will to move it.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1839</date>
    <title>How to Read Me</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>T o turn my volume o’er nor find</line>
      <line>To chide or discommend</line>
      <line>Some vestige of a wandering mind,</line>
      <line>Sweet unsuspicious friend!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Believe that all were loved like you,</line>
      <line>With love from blame exempt,</line>
      <line>Believe that all my griefs were true</line>
      <line>And all my joys were dreamt.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>Twenty years hence my eyes may grow</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Twenty years hence my eyes may grow</line>
      <line>If not quite dim, yet rather so,</line>
      <line>Still yours from others they shall know</line>
      <line>Twenty years hence.</line>
      <line>Twenty years hence tho’ it may hap</line>
      <line>That I be call’d to take a nap</line>
      <line>In a cool cell where thunder-clap</line>
      <line>Was never heard.</line>
      <line>There breathe but o’er my arch of grass</line>
      <line>A not too sadly sigh’d Alas,</line>
      <line>And I shall catch, ere you can pass,</line>
      <line>That winged word.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>Dying Speech of an Old Philosopher</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I strove with none, for none was worth my strife:</line>
      <line>Nature I loved, and, next to Nature, Art:</line>
      <line>I warm’d both hands before the fire of Life;</line>
      <line>It sinks; and I am ready to depart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>Age</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Death, tho I see him not, is near</line>
      <line>And grudges me my eightieth year.</line>
      <line>Now, I would give him all these last</line>
      <line>For one that fifty have run past.</line>
      <line>Ah! he strikes all things, all alike,</line>
      <line>But bargains: those he will not strike.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1858</date>
    <title>Pigmies and Cranes</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I live among the Pigmies and the Cranes,</line>
      <line>Nor care a straw who loses or who gains.</line>
      <line>Peel doffs the harness, Russell puts it on,</line>
      <line>The late Sir Robert is the live Lord John,</line>
      <line>Close in the corner sits the abler man,</line>
      <line>But show me the more tricky if you can.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1858</date>
    <title>La Promessa Sposa</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep, my sweet girl! and all the sleep</line>
      <line>You take away from others, keep:</line>
      <line>A night, no distant one, will come</line>
      <line>When those you took their slumbers from,</line>
      <line>Generous, ungenerous, will confess</line>
      <line>Their joy that you have slumber’d less,</line>
      <line>And envy more than they condemn</line>
      <line>The rival who avenges them.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Walter Savage Landor</author>
    <date>1863</date>
    <title>Memory</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mother of the Muses, we are taught,</line>
      <line>Is Memory: she has left me; they remain,</line>
      <line>And shake my shoulder, urging me to sing</line>
      <line>About the summer days, my loves of old.</line>
      <line>Alas! alas! is all I can reply.</line>
      <line>Memory has left with me that name alone,</line>
      <line>Harmonious name, which other bards may sing,</line>
      <line>But her bright image in my darkest hour</line>
      <line>Comes back, in vain comes back, call’d or uncall’d.</line>
      <line>Forgotten are the names of visitors</line>
      <line>Ready to press my hand but yesterday;</line>
      <line>Forgotten are the names of earlier friends</line>
      <line>Whose genial converse and glad countenance</line>
      <line>Are fresh as ever to mine ear and eye;</line>
      <line>To these, when I have written, and besought</line>
      <line>Remembrance of me, the word Dear alone</line>
      <line>Hangs on the upper verge, and waits in vain.</line>
      <line>A blessing wert thou, O oblivion,</line>
      <line>If thy stream carried only weeds away,</line>
      <line>But vernal and autumnal flowers alike</line>
      <line>It hurries down to wither on the strand.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Winthrop Mackworth Praed</author>
    <date>1839</date>
    <title>To Helen</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dearest, I did not think four years ago,</line>
      <line>When through your veil I saw your tears shine,</line>
      <line>Caught your clear whisper, exquisitely low,</line>
      <line>And felt your soft hand tremble into mine,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That in so brief, so very brief a space,</line>
      <line>The all-seeing Ruler of our lot in life,</line>
      <line>Would lay on you, so full of light, hope, grace,</line>
      <line>The darker, sadder duties of the wife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fears, hopes and frequent toil, and constant care</line>
      <line>For this poor frame, by sickness sore bested;</line>
      <line>The daily tendance on the fractious chair,</line>
      <line>The nightly vigil by the restless bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet not unwelcomed must this morn arise,</line>
      <line>Though in less sullied beams it might have shone.</line>
      <line>Strength of these weak hands, light of these dim eyes,</line>
      <line>In sickness as in health, bless you, my Own!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hood</author>
    <date>1840</date>
    <title>from Miss Kilmansegg and her Precious Leg (Her Christening)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though Shakespeare asks us, ‘What’s in a name?’</line>
      <line>(As if cognomens were much the same),</line>
      <line>There’s really a very great scope in it.</line>
      <line>A name?—why, wasn’t there Doctor Dodd,</line>
      <line>That servant at once of Mammon and God,</line>
      <line>Who found four thousand pounds and odd,</line>
      <line>A prison—a cart—and a rope in it?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A name?—if the party had a voice,</line>
      <line>What mortal would be a Bugg by choice,</line>
      <line>As a Hogg, a Grubb, or a Chubb rejoice,</line>
      <line>Or any such nauseous blazon?</line>
      <line>Not to mention many a vulgar name,</line>
      <line>That would make a doorplate blush for shame,</line>
      <line>If doorplates were not so brazen!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A name?—it has more than nominal worth,</line>
      <line>And belongs to good or bad luck at birth—</line>
      <line>As dames of a certain degree know,</line>
      <line>In spite of his Page’s hat and hose,</line>
      <line>His Page’s jacket, and buttons in rows,</line>
      <line>Bob only sounds like a page of prose</line>
      <line>Till turn’d into Rupertino.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now to christen the infant Kilmansegg,</line>
      <line>For days and days it was quite a plague,</line>
      <line>To hunt the list in the Lexicon:</line>
      <line>And scores were tried like coin by the ring,</line>
      <line>Ere names were found just the proper thing</line>
      <line>For a minor rich as a Mexican.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then cards were sent, the presence to beg</line>
      <line>Of all the kin of Kilmansegg,</line>
      <line>White, yellow, and brown relations:</line>
      <line>Brothers, Wardens of City Halls,</line>
      <line>And Uncles—rich as three Golden Balls</line>
      <line>From taking pledges of nations.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nephews, whom Fortune seem’d to bewitch,</line>
      <line>Rising in life like rockets—</line>
      <line>Nieces whose dowries knew no hitch—</line>
      <line>Aunts as certain of dying rich</line>
      <line>As candles in golden sockets—</line>
      <line>Cousins German and cousins’ sons,</line>
      <line>All thriving and opulent—some had tons</line>
      <line>Of Kentish hops in their pockets!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For money had stuck to the race thro’ life</line>
      <line>(As it did to the bushel when cash so rife</line>
      <line>Posed Ali Baba’s brother’s wife)—</line>
      <line>And down to the Cousins and Cozlings,</line>
      <line>The fortunate brood of the Kilmanseggs,</line>
      <line>As if they had come out of golden eggs</line>
      <line>Were all as wealthy as ‘Goslings.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It would fill a Court Gazette to name</line>
      <line>What East and West End people came</line>
      <line>To the rite of Christianity:</line>
      <line>The lofty Lord and the titled Dame,</line>
      <line>All di’monds, plumes, and urbanity:</line>
      <line>His Lordship the May’r with his golden chain,</line>
      <line>And two Gold Sticks, and the Sheriffs twain,</line>
      <line>Nine foreign Counts, and other great men</line>
      <line>With their orders and stars, to help M or N</line>
      <line>To renounce all pomp and vanity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To paint the maternal Kilmansegg,</line>
      <line>The pen of an Eastern Poet would beg,</line>
      <line>And need an elaborate sonnet;</line>
      <line>How she sparkled with gems whenever she stirr’d,</line>
      <line>And her head niddle-noddled at every word,</line>
      <line>And seem’d so happy, a Paradise Bird</line>
      <line>Had nidificated upon it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Sir Jacob the Father strutted and bow’d,</line>
      <line>And smiled to himself, and laugh’d aloud,</line>
      <line>To think of his heiress and daughter—</line>
      <line>And then in his pockets he made a grope,</line>
      <line>And then, in the fulness of joy and hope,</line>
      <line>Seem’d washing his hands with invisible soap,</line>
      <line>In imperceptible water.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had roll’d in money like pigs in mud,</line>
      <line>Till it seem’d to have enter’d into his blood</line>
      <line>By some occult projection:</line>
      <line>And his cheeks, instead of a healthy hue,</line>
      <line>As yellow as any guinea grew,</line>
      <line>Making the common phrase seem true</line>
      <line>About a rich complexion.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now came the Nurse, and during a pause,</line>
      <line>Her dead-leaf satin would fitly cause</line>
      <line>A very autumnal rustle—</line>
      <line>So full of figure, so full of fuss,</line>
      <line>As she carried about the babe to buss,</line>
      <line>She seem’d to be nothing but bustle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A wealthy Nabob was Godpapa,</line>
      <line>And an Indian Begum was Godmamma,</line>
      <line>Whose jewels a Queen might covet—</line>
      <line>And the Priest was a vicar, and Dean withal</line>
      <line>Of that Temple we see with a Golden Ball,</line>
      <line>And a Golden Cross above it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Font was a bowl of American gold,</line>
      <line>Won by Raleigh in days of old,</line>
      <line>In spite of Spanish bravado;</line>
      <line>And the Book of Pray’r was so over-run</line>
      <line>With gilt devices, it shone in the sun,</line>
      <line>Like a copy—a presentation one—</line>
      <line>Of Humboldt’s ‘El Dorado.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gold! and gold! and nothing but gold!</line>
      <line>The same auriferous shine behold i0o</line>
      <line>Wherever the eye could settle!</line>
      <line>On the walls—the sideboard—the ceiling-skv—</line>
      <line>On the gorgeous footmen standing by,</line>
      <line>In coats to delight a miner’s eye,</line>
      <line>With seams of the precious metal.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gold! and gold! and besides the gold,</line>
      <line>The very robe of the infant told</line>
      <line>A tale of wealth in every fold;</line>
      <line>It lapp’d her like a vapour!</line>
      <line>So fine! so thin! the mind at a loss no</line>
      <line>Could compare it to nothing, except a cross</line>
      <line>Of cobwebs with bank-note paper.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then her pearls—’twas a perfect sight, forsooth,</line>
      <line>To see them, like ‘the dew of her youth,’</line>
      <line>In such a plentiful sprinkle.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile, the Vicar read through the form,</line>
      <line>And gave her another, not overwarm,</line>
      <line>That made her little eyes twinkle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the babe was cross’d, and bless’d amain,</line>
      <line>But instead of the Kate, or Ann, or Jane,</line>
      <line>Which the humbler female endorses,</line>
      <line>Instead of one name, as some people prefix,</line>
      <line>Kilmansegg went at the tails of six,</line>
      <line>Like a carriage of state with its horses.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, then the kisses she got and hugs!</line>
      <line>The golden mugs and the golden jugs,</line>
      <line>That lent fresh rays to the midges!</line>
      <line>The golden knives, and the golden spoons,</line>
      <line>The gems that sparkled like fairy boons,</line>
      <line>It was one of the Kilmanseggs’ own saloons,</line>
      <line>But looked like Rundell and Bridge’s!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gold! and gold! the new and old!</line>
      <line>The company ate and drank from gold,</line>
      <line>They revell’d, they sang, and were merry;</line>
      <line>And one of the Gold Sticks rose from his chair,</line>
      <line>And toasted ‘the Lass with the golden hair’</line>
      <line>In a bumper of golden Sherry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gold! still gold! it rain’d on the Nurse,</line>
      <line>Who, unlike Danae, was none the worse;</line>
      <line>There was nothing but guineas glistening!</line>
      <line>Fifty were given to Doctor James</line>
      <line>For calling the little Baby names,</line>
      <line>And for saying, Amen!</line>
      <line>The Clerk had ten,</line>
      <line>And that was the end of the Christening.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hood</author>
    <date>1840</date>
    <title>from Miss Kilmansegg and her Precious Leg (Her Precious Leg)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘As the twig is bent, the tree’s inclined,’</line>
      <line>Is an adage often recall’d to mind,</line>
      <line>Referring to juvenile bias:</line>
      <line>And never so well is the verity seen,</line>
      <line>As when to the weak, warp’d side we lean,</line>
      <line>While Life’s tempests and hurricanes try us.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Even thus with Miss K. and her broken limb,</line>
      <line>By a very, very remarkable whim,</line>
      <line>She show’d her early tuition:</line>
      <line>While the buds of character came into blow</line>
      <line>With a certain tinge that served to show</line>
      <line>The nursery culture long ago,</line>
      <line>As the graft is known by fruition!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For the King’s Physician, who nursed the case,</line>
      <line>His verdict gave with an awful face,</line>
      <line>And three others concurr’d to egg it:</line>
      <line>That the Patient to give old Death the slip,</line>
      <line>Like the Pope, instead of a personal trip,</line>
      <line>Must send her Leg as a Legate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The limb was doom’d—it couldn’t be saved!</line>
      <line>And like other people the patient behaved,</line>
      <line>Nay, bravely that cruel parting braved,</line>
      <line>Which makes some persons so falter;</line>
      <line>They rather would part without a groan,</line>
      <line>With the flesh of their flesh, and bone of their bone,</line>
      <line>They obtained at St George’s altar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when it came to fitting the stump</line>
      <line>With a proxy limb—then flatly and plump</line>
      <line>She spoke, in the spirit olden;</line>
      <line>She couldn’t—she shouldn’t—she wouldn’t have wood!</line>
      <line>Nor a leg of cork, if she never stood,</line>
      <line>And she swore an oath, or something as good,</line>
      <line>The proxy limb should be golden!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A wooden leg! what, a sort of peg,</line>
      <line>For your common Jockeys and Jennies!</line>
      <line>No, no, her mother might worry and plague—</line>
      <line>Weep, go down on her knees, and beg,</line>
      <line>But nothing would move Miss Kilmansegg!</line>
      <line>She could—she would have a Golden Leg,</line>
      <line>If it cost ten thousand guineas!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wood indeed, in Forest or Park,</line>
      <line>With its sylvan honours and feudal bark,</line>
      <line>Is an aristocratical article;</line>
      <line>But split and sawn, and hack’d about town,</line>
      <line>Serving all needs of pauper or clown,</line>
      <line>Trod on! staggered on! Wood cut down</line>
      <line>Is vulgar—fibre and particle!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And Cork!—when the noble Cork Tree shades</line>
      <line>A lovely group of Castilian maids,</line>
      <line>’Tis a thing for a song or sonnet!—</line>
      <line>But cork, as it stops the bottle of gin,</line>
      <line>Or bungs the beer—the small beer!—in—</line>
      <line>It pierced her heart like a corking-pin,</line>
      <line>To think of standing upon it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A Leg of Gold—solid gold throughout,</line>
      <line>Nothing else, whether slim or stout,</line>
      <line>Should ever support her, God willing!</line>
      <line>She must—she could—she would have her whim,</line>
      <line>Her father, she turned a deaf ear to him—</line>
      <line>He might kill her—she didn’t mind killing!</line>
      <line>He was welcome to cut off her other limb—</line>
      <line>He might cut her all off with a shilling!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All other promised gifts were in vain,</line>
      <line>Golden Girdle, or Golden Chain,</line>
      <line>She writhed with impatience more than pain,</line>
      <line>And uttered ‘pshaws!’ and ‘pishes!’</line>
      <line>But a Leg of Gold! as she lay in bed,</line>
      <line>It danced before her—it ran in her head!</line>
      <line>It jump’d with her dearest wishes!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Gold—gold—gold! Oh, let it be gold!’</line>
      <line>Asleep or awake that tale she told,</line>
      <line>And when she grew delirious:</line>
      <line>Till her parents resolved to grant her wish,</line>
      <line>If they melted down plate, and goblet, and dish,</line>
      <line>The case was getting so serious.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So a Leg was made in a comely mould,</line>
      <line>Of Gold, fine virgin glittering gold,</line>
      <line>As solid as man could make it—</line>
      <line>Solid in foot, and calf, and shank,</line>
      <line>A prodigious sum of money it sank;</line>
      <line>In fact ’twas a Branch of the family Bank,</line>
      <line>And no easy matter to break it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All sterling metal—not half-and-half,</line>
      <line>The Goldsmith’s mark was stamped on the calf—</line>
      <line>’Twas pure as from Mexican barter!</line>
      <line>And to make it more costly, just over the knee—</line>
      <line>Where another ligature used to be,</line>
      <line>Was a circle of Jewels, worth shillings to see,</line>
      <line>A new-fangled Badge of the Garter!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas a splendid, brilliant, beautiful Leg,</line>
      <line>Fit for the Court of Scander-Beg,</line>
      <line>That Precious Leg of Miss Kilmansegg!</line>
      <line>For, thanks to parental bounty,</line>
      <line>Secure from Mortification’s touch,</line>
      <line>She stood on a Member that cost as much</line>
      <line>As a Member for all the County!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hood</author>
    <date>1840</date>
    <title>from Mrs Kilmansegg and her Precious Leg (Her Death)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis a stern and startling thing to think</line>
      <line>How often mortality stands on the brink</line>
      <line>Of its grave without any misgiving:</line>
      <line>And yet in this slippery world of strife,</line>
      <line>In the stir of human bustle so rife,</line>
      <line>There are daily sounds to tell us that Life</line>
      <line>Is dying, and Death is living!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ay, Beauty the Girl, and Love the Boy,</line>
      <line>Bright as they are with hope and joy,</line>
      <line>How their souls would sadden instanter,</line>
      <line>To remember that one of those wedding-bells,</line>
      <line>That ring so merrily through the dells,</line>
      <line>Is the same that knells</line>
      <line>Our last farewells,</line>
      <line>Only broken into a canter!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But breath and blood set doom at nought—</line>
      <line>How little the wretched Countess thought,</line>
      <line>When at night she unloos’d her sandal,</line>
      <line>That the Fates had woven her burial-cloth,</line>
      <line>And that Death, in the shape of a Death’s Head Moth,</line>
      <line>Was fluttering round her candle!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As she look’d at her clock of or-molu,</line>
      <line>For the hours she had gone so wearily through</line>
      <line>At the end of a day of trial—</line>
      <line>How little she saw in her pride of prime</line>
      <line>The Dart of Death in the Hand of Time—</line>
      <line>That hand which mov’d on the dial!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As she went with her taper up the stair,</line>
      <line>How little her swollen eye was aware</line>
      <line>That the shadow which follow’d was double!</line>
      <line>Or when she clos’d her chamber door,</line>
      <line>It was shutting out, and for evermore,</line>
      <line>The world—and its worldly trouble.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Little she dreamt, as she laid aside</line>
      <line>Her jewels—after one glance of pride—</line>
      <line>They were solemn bequests to Vanity—</line>
      <line>Or when her robe she began to doff,</line>
      <line>That she stood so near to the putting off</line>
      <line>Of the flesh that clothes humanity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when she quench’d the taper’s light,</line>
      <line>How little she thought as the smoke took flight,</line>
      <line>That her day was done—and merg’d in a night</line>
      <line>Of dreams and duration uncertain—</line>
      <line>Or, along with her own,</line>
      <line>That a hand of bone</line>
      <line>Was closing mortality’s curtain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But life is sweet, and mortality blind,</line>
      <line>And youth is hopeful, and Fate is kind</line>
      <line>In concealing the day of sorrow;</line>
      <line>And enough is the present tense of toil—</line>
      <line>For this world is, to all, a stiffish soil—</line>
      <line>And the mind flies back with a glad recoil</line>
      <line>From the debts not due till tomorrow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wherefore else does the Spirit fly</line>
      <line>And bid its daily cares good-bye,</line>
      <line>Along with its daily clothing?</line>
      <line>Just as the Felon condemn’d to die—</line>
      <line>With a very natural loathing—</line>
      <line>Leaving the Sheriff to dream of ropes,</line>
      <line>From his gloomy cell in a vision elopes,</line>
      <line>To caper on sunny greens and slopes,</line>
      <line>Instead of the dance upon nothing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus, even thus, the Countess slept,</line>
      <line>While Death still nearer and nearer crept,</line>
      <line>Like the Thane who smote the sleeping—</line>
      <line>But her mind was busy with early joys,</line>
      <line>Her golden treasures and golden toys,</line>
      <line>That flash’d a bright</line>
      <line>And golden light</line>
      <line>Under lids still red with weeping.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The golden doll that she used to hug!</line>
      <line>Her coral of gold, and the golden mug!</line>
      <line>Her godfather’s golden presents!</line>
      <line>The golden service she had at her meals,</line>
      <line>The golden watch, and chain, and seals,</line>
      <line>Her golden scissors, and thread, and reels,</line>
      <line>And her golden fishes and pheasants!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The golden guineas in silken purse—</line>
      <line>And the Golden Legends she heard from her nurse,</line>
      <line>Of the Mayor in his gilded carriage—</line>
      <line>And London streets that were pav’d with gold—</line>
      <line>And the Golden Eggs that were laid of old—</line>
      <line>With each golden thing</line>
      <line>To the golden ring</line>
      <line>At her own auriferous Marriage!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And still the golden light of the sun</line>
      <line>Through her golden dream appear’d to run,</line>
      <line>Though the night that roar’d without was one</line>
      <line>To terrify seamen or gipsies—</line>
      <line>While the moon, as if in malicious mirth,</line>
      <line>Kept peeping down at the ruffled earth,</line>
      <line>As though she enjoyed the tempest’s birth,</line>
      <line>In revenge of her old eclipses.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But vainly, vainly, the thunder fell,</line>
      <line>For the soul of the sleeper was under a spell</line>
      <line>That Time had lately embitter’d—</line>
      <line>The Count, as once at her feet he knelt—</line>
      <line>That Foot which now he wanted to melt!</line>
      <line>But—hush!—’twas a stir at her pillow she felt—</line>
      <line>And some object before her glitter’d.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas the Golden Leg!—she knew its gleam!</line>
      <line>And up she started, and tried to scream,—</line>
      <line>But ev’n in the moment she started—</line>
      <line>Down came the limb with a frightful smash,</line>
      <line>And, lost in the universal flash</line>
      <line>That her eyeballs made at so mortal a crash,</line>
      <line>The Spark, called Vital, departed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gold, still gold! hard, yellow, and cold,</line>
      <line>For gold she had lived, and she died for gold—</line>
      <line>By a golden weapon—not oaken; no</line>
      <line>In the morning they found her all alone—</line>
      <line>Stiff, and bloody, and cold as stone—</line>
      <line>But her Leg, the Golden Leg, was gone,</line>
      <line>And the ‘Golden Bowl was broken!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gold, still gold! it haunted her yet—</line>
      <line>At the Golden Lion the Inquest met—</line>
      <line>Its foreman, a carver and gilder—</line>
      <line>And the jury debated from twelve till three</line>
      <line>What the Verdict ought to be,</line>
      <line>And they brought it in as Felo de Se,</line>
      <line>‘Because her own Leg had killed her!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1840</date>
    <title>Uncle an’Aunt</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How happy uncle us’d to be</line>
      <line>O’ zummer time, when aunt an’ he</line>
      <line>O’ Zunday evenens, earm in earm,</line>
      <line>Did walk about their tiny farm,</line>
      <line>While birds did zing an’ gnats did zwarm,</line>
      <line>Drough grass a’most above their knees,</line>
      <line>An’ roun’ by hedges an’ by trees</line>
      <line>Wi’ leafy boughs a-swayen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His hat wer broad, his cwoat wer brown,</line>
      <line>Wi’ two long flaps a-hangen down;</line>
      <line>An’ vrom his knee went down a blue</line>
      <line>Knit stocken to his buckled shoe;</line>
      <line>An’ aunt did pull her gown-tail drough</line>
      <line>Her pocket-hole, to keep en neat,</line>
      <line>As she mid walk, or teake a seat</line>
      <line>By leafy boughs a-swayen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ vu’st they’d goo to zee their lots</line>
      <line>O’ pot-earbs in the gearden plots;</line>
      <line>An’ he, i’-may-be, by the hatch,</line>
      <line>Would zee aunt’s vowls upon a patch</line>
      <line>O’ zeeds, an’ vow if he could catch</line>
      <line>Em wi’ his gun, they shoudden vlee</line>
      <line>Noo mwore into their roosten tree,</line>
      <line>Wi’ leafy boughs a-swayen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ then vrom gearden they did pass</line>
      <line>Drough orcha’d out to zee the grass,</line>
      <line>An’ if the apple-blooth, so white,</line>
      <line>Mid be at all a-touch’d wi’ blight;</line>
      <line>An’ uncle, happy at the zight,</line>
      <line>Did guess what cider there mid be</line>
      <line>In all the orcha’d, tree wi’ tree,</line>
      <line>Wi’ tutties all a-swayen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ then they stump’d along vrom there</line>
      <line>A-vield, to zee the cows an’ meare;</line>
      <line>An’ she, when uncle come in zight,</line>
      <line>Look’d up, an’ prick’d her ears upright,</line>
      <line>An’ whicker’d out wi’ all her might;</line>
      <line>An’ he, a-chucklen, went to zee</line>
      <line>The cows below the sheady tree,</line>
      <line>Wi’ leafy boughs a-swayen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ last ov all, they went to know</line>
      <line>How vast the grass in mead did grow;</line>
      <line>An’ then aunt zaid ’twer time to goo</line>
      <line>In hwome,—a-holden up her shoe,</line>
      <line>To show how wet he wer wi’ dew.</line>
      <line>An’ zoo they toddled hwome to rest,</line>
      <line>Lik’ doves a-vlee-en to their nest,</line>
      <line>In leafy boughs a-swayen.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1841</date>
    <title>Polly Be-En Upzides Wi’ Tom</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! yesterday, d’ye know, I voun’</line>
      <line>Tom Dumpy’s cwoat an’ smock-frock, down</line>
      <line>Below the pollard out in groun’;</line>
      <line>An’ zoo I slyly stole</line>
      <line>An’ took the smock-frock up, an’ tack’d</line>
      <line>The sleeves an’ collar up, an’ pack’d</line>
      <line>Zome nice sharp stwones, all fresh a-crack’d,</line>
      <line>’Ithin each pocket-hole.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ in the evenen, when he shut</line>
      <line>Off work, an’ come an’ donn’d his cwoat,</line>
      <line>Their edges gi’ed en sich a cut,</line>
      <line>How we did stan’ an’ laugh!</line>
      <line>An’ when the smock-frock I’d a-zow’d</line>
      <line>Kept back his head an’ hands, he drow’d</line>
      <line>Hizzelf about, an’ teav’d, an’ blow’d,</line>
      <line>Lik’ any up-tied calf.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then in a veag away he flung</line>
      <line>His frock, an’ after me he sprung,</line>
      <line>An’ mutter’d out sich dreats, an’ wrung</line>
      <line>His vist up sich a size!</line>
      <line>But I, a-runnen, turn’d an’ drow’d</line>
      <line>Some doust, a-pick’d up vrom the road,</line>
      <line>Back at en wi’ the wind, that blow’d</line>
      <line>It right into his eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ he did blink, an’ vow he’d catch</line>
      <line>Me zomehow yet, an’ be my match.</line>
      <line>But I wer nearly down to hatch</line>
      <line>Avore he got vur on;</line>
      <line>An’ up in chammer, nearly dead</line>
      <line>Wi’ runnen, lik’ a cat I vied,</line>
      <line>An’ out o’ window put my head</line>
      <line>To zee if he wer gon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ there he wer, a-prowlen roun’</line>
      <line>Upon the green; an’ I look’d down</line>
      <line>An’ told en that I hoped he voun’</line>
      <line>He mussen think to peck</line>
      <line>Upon a body zoo, nor whip</line>
      <line>The meare to drow me off, nor tip</line>
      <line>Me out o’ cart agean, nor slip</line>
      <line>Cut hoss-heair down my neck.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1841</date>
    <title>The Vaices that Be Gone</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When evenen sheades o’ trees do hide</line>
      <line>A body by the hedge’s zide,</line>
      <line>An’ twitt’ren birds, wi’ playsome flight,</line>
      <line>Do vlee to roost at comen night,</line>
      <line>Then I do saunter out o’ zight</line>
      <line>In orcha’d, where the pleace woonce rung</line>
      <line>Wi’ laughs a-laugh’d an’ zongs a-zung</line>
      <line>By vaices that be gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s still the tree that bore our swing,</line>
      <line>An’ others where the birds did zing;</line>
      <line>But long-leav’d docks do overgrow</line>
      <line>The groun’ we trampled beare below,</line>
      <line>Wi’ merry skippens to an’ fro</line>
      <line>Bezide the banks, where Jim did zit</line>
      <line>A-playen o’ the clarinit</line>
      <line>To vaices that be gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How mother, when we us’d to stun</line>
      <line>Her head wi’ all our naisy fun,</line>
      <line>Did wish us all a-gone vrom home:</line>
      <line>An’ now that zome be dead, an’ zome</line>
      <line>A-gone, an’ all the pleace is dum’,</line>
      <line>How she do wish, wi’ useless tears,</line>
      <line>To have agean about her ears</line>
      <line>The vaices that be gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Vor all the maidens an’ the bwoys</line>
      <line>But I, be marri’d off all woys,</line>
      <line>Or dead an’ gone; but I do bide</line>
      <line>At hwome, alwone, at mother’s zide,</line>
      <line>An’ often, at the evenen-tide,</line>
      <line>I still do saunter out, wi’ tears,</line>
      <line>Down drough the orcha’d, where my ears</line>
      <line>Do miss the vaices gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>My Orchard in Linden Lea</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’ITHIN the woodlands, flow’ry gleiided,</line>
      <line>By the woak tree’s mossy moot,</line>
      <line>The sheenen grass-bleades, timber-sheaded,</line>
      <line>Now do quiver under voot;</line>
      <line>An’ birds do whissle over head,</line>
      <line>An’ water’s bubblen in its bed,</line>
      <line>An’ there vor me the apple tree</line>
      <line>Do lean down low in Linden Lea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When leaves that leately wer a-springen</line>
      <line>Now do feade ’ithin the copse,</line>
      <line>An’ painted birds do hush their zingen</line>
      <line>Up upon the timber’s tops;</line>
      <line>An’ brown-leav’d fruit’s a-turnen red,</line>
      <line>In cloudless zunsheen, over head,</line>
      <line>Wi’ fruit vor me, the apple tree</line>
      <line>Do lean down low in Linden Lea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let other vo’k meake money vaster</line>
      <line>In the air 0’ dark-room’d towns,</line>
      <line>I don’t dread a peevish measter;</line>
      <line>Though noo man do heed my frowns,</line>
      <line>I be free to goo abrode,</line>
      <line>Or teake ageiin my homeward road</line>
      <line>To where, vor me, the apple tree</line>
      <line>Do lean down low in Linden Lea.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1857</date>
    <title>False Friends-Like</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I wer still a bwoy, an’ mother’s pride,</line>
      <line>A bigger bwoy spoke up to me so kind-like,</line>
      <line>‘If you do like, I’ll treat ye wi’ a ride</line>
      <line>In thease wheel-barrow here.’ Zoo I wer blind-like</line>
      <line>To what he had a-worken in his mind-like,</line>
      <line>An’ mounted vor a passenger inside;</line>
      <line>An’ comen to a puddle, perty wide,</line>
      <line>He tipp’d me in, a-grinnen back behind-like.</line>
      <line>Zoo when a man do come to me so thick-like,</line>
      <line>An’ sheake my hand, where woonce he pass’d me by,</line>
      <line>An’ tell me he would do me this or that,</line>
      <line>I can’t help thinken o’ the big bwoy’s trick-like.</line>
      <line>An’ then, vor all I can but wag my hat</line>
      <line>An’ thank en, I do veel a little shy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1858</date>
    <title>Childhood</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Aye, at that time our days wer but vew,</line>
      <line>An’ our lim’s wer but small, an’ a-growen;</line>
      <line>An’ then the feair worold wer new,</line>
      <line>An’ life wer all hopevul an’ gay;</line>
      <line>An’ the times 0’ the sprouten o’ leaves,</line>
      <line>An’ the cheak-burnen seasons o’ mowen,</line>
      <line>An’ binden o’ red-headed sheaves,</line>
      <line>Wer all welcome seasons o’ jay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the housen seem’d high, that be low,</line>
      <line>An’ the brook did seem wide that is narrow,</line>
      <line>An’ time, that do vlee, did goo slow,</line>
      <line>An’ veelens now feeble wer strong,</line>
      <line>An’ our worold did end wi’ the neames</line>
      <line>Ov the Sha’sbury Hill or Bulbarrow;</line>
      <line>An’ life did seem only the geames</line>
      <line>That we play’d as the days rolled along.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the rivers, an’ high-timber’d lands,</line>
      <line>An’ the zilvery hills, 'ithout buyen,</line>
      <line>Did seem to come into our hands</line>
      <line>Vrom others that own’d em avore;</line>
      <line>An’ all zickness, an’ sorrow, an’ need,</line>
      <line>Seem’d to die wi’ the wold vo’k a-dyen,</line>
      <line>An’ leave us vor ever a-freed</line>
      <line>Vrom evils our vorefathers bore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But happy be childern the while</line>
      <line>They have elders a-liven to love em,</line>
      <line>An’ teake all the wearisome tweil</line>
      <line>That zome hands or others mus’ do;</line>
      <line>Like the low-headed shrubs that be warm,</line>
      <line>In the lewth o’ the trees up above em,</line>
      <line>A-screen’d vrom the cwold blowen storm</line>
      <line>That the timber avore em must rue.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1859</date>
    <title>Light or Sheade</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A Maytide’s evenen wer a-dyen,</line>
      <line>Under moonsheen, into night,</line>
      <line>Wi’ a streamen wind a-sighen</line>
      <line>By the thorns a-bloomen white,</line>
      <line>Where in sheade, a-zinken deeply,</line>
      <line>Wer a nook, all dark but lew,</line>
      <line>By a bank, a-risen steeply,</line>
      <line>Not to let the win’ come drough.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Should my love goo out, a-showen</line>
      <line>All her smiles, in open light;</line>
      <line>Or, in lewth, wi’ wind a-blowen,</line>
      <line>Stay in darkness, dim to zight?</line>
      <line>Stay in sheade 0’ bank or wallen,</line>
      <line>In the warmth, if not in light;</line>
      <line>Words alwone vrom her a-vallen,</line>
      <line>Would be jay vor all the night.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1859</date>
    <title>Slow to Come, Quick A-Gone</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! there’s a house that I do know</line>
      <line>Besouth o’ yonder trees,</line>
      <line>Where northern winds can hardly blow</line>
      <line>But in a softest breeze.</line>
      <line>An’ there woonce sounded zongs an’ teales</line>
      <line>Vrom va'ice o’ maid or youth,</line>
      <line>An’ sweeter than the nightengeale’s</line>
      <line>Above the copses lewth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How swiftly there did run the brooks,</line>
      <line>How swift wer winds in flight,</line>
      <line>How swiftly to their roost the rooks</line>
      <line>Did vlee o’er head at night;</line>
      <line>Though slow did seem to us the peace</line>
      <line>O’ comen days a-head,</line>
      <line>That now do seem as in a reace</line>
      <line>Wi’ air-birds to ha’ vied.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1859</date>
    <title>The Turnstile</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! sad wer we as we did peace</line>
      <line>The wold church road, wi’ downcast feace,</line>
      <line>The while the bells, that mwoan’d so deep</line>
      <line>Above our child a-left asleep,</line>
      <line>Wer now a-zingen all alive</line>
      <line>Wi’ tother bells to meake the vive.</line>
      <line>But up at woone pleace we come by,</line>
      <line>’Twer hard to keep woone’s two eyes dry:</line>
      <line>On Stean-cliff road, ’ithin the drong,</line>
      <line>Up where, as vo’k do pass along,</line>
      <line>The turnen stile, a-painted white,</line>
      <line>Do sheen by day an’ show by night.</line>
      <line>Vor always there, as we did goo</line>
      <line>To church, thik stile did let us drough,</line>
      <line>Wi’ spreaden earms that wheel’d to guide</line>
      <line>Us each in turn to tother zide.</line>
      <line>An’ vu’st ov all the train he took</line>
      <line>My wife, wi’ winsome gait an’ look;</line>
      <line>An’ then zent on my little maid,</line>
      <line>A-skippen onward, overjay’d</line>
      <line>To reach agean the pleace o’ pride,</line>
      <line>Her comely mother’s left han’ zide.</line>
      <line>An’ then, a-wheelen roun’, he took</line>
      <line>On me, ’ithin his third white nook.</line>
      <line>An’ in the fourth, a-sheaken wild,</line>
      <line>He zent us on our giddy child.</line>
      <line>But eesterday he guided slow</line>
      <line>My downcast Jenny, vull o’ woe,</line>
      <line>An’ then my little maid in black,</line>
      <line>A-walken softly on her track;</line>
      <line>An’ after he’d a-turn’d agean,</line>
      <line>To let me goo along the leane,</line>
      <line>He had noo little bwoy to vill</line>
      <line>His last white earms, an’ they stood still.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>The Rwose in the Dark</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In zummer, leate at evenen tide,</line>
      <line>I zot to spend a moonless hour</line>
      <line>’Ithin the window, wi’ the zide</line>
      <line>A-bound wi’ rwoses out in flow’r,</line>
      <line>Bezide the bow’r, vorsook o’ birds,</line>
      <line>An’ listen’d to my true-love’s words.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A-risen to her comely height,</line>
      <line>She push’d the swingen ceasement round;</line>
      <line>And I could hear, beyond my zight,</line>
      <line>The win’-blow’d beech-tree softly sound,</line>
      <line>On higher ground, a-swayen slow,</line>
      <line>On drough my happy hour below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ tho’ the darkness then did hide</line>
      <line>The dewy rwose’s blushen bloom,</line>
      <line>He still did cast sweet air inside</line>
      <line>To Jeane, a-chatten in the room;</line>
      <line>An’ though the gloom did hide her feace,</line>
      <line>Her words did bind me to the pleace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ there, while she, wi’ runnen tongue,</line>
      <line>Did talk unzeen ’ithin the hall,</line>
      <line>I thought her like the rwose that flung</line>
      <line>His sweetness vrom his darken’d ball,</line>
      <line>’Ithout the wall, an’ sweet’s the zight</line>
      <line>Ov her bright feace by mornen light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>The Zilver- Weed</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The zilver-weed upon the green,</line>
      <line>Out where my sons an’ daughters play’d,</line>
      <line>Had never time to bloom between</line>
      <line>The litty steps o’ bwoy an’ maid.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But rwose-trees down along the wall,</line>
      <line>That then wer all the maidens’ ceare,</line>
      <line>An’ all a-trimm’d an’ train’d, did bear</line>
      <line>Their bloomen buds vrom Spring to Fall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But now the zilver leaves do show</line>
      <line>To zummer day their goolden crown,</line>
      <line>Wi’ noo swift shoe-zoles’ litty blow,</line>
      <line>In merry play to beat em down.</line>
      <line>An’ where vor years zome busy hand</line>
      <line>Did train the rwoses wide an’ high;</line>
      <line>Now woone by woone the trees do die,</line>
      <line>An’ vew of all the row do stand.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>Lwonesomeness</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I do zew, wi’ nimble hand,</line>
      <line>In here avore the window’s light,</line>
      <line>How still do all the housegear stand</line>
      <line>Around my lwonesome zight.</line>
      <line>How still do all the housegear stand</line>
      <line>Since Willie now’ve a-left the land.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The rwose-tree’s window-sheaden bow</line>
      <line>Do hang in leaf, an’ win’-blow’d flow’rs</line>
      <line>Avore my lwonesome eyes do show</line>
      <line>Thease bright November hours.</line>
      <line>Avore my lwonesome eyes do show</line>
      <line>Wi’ nwone but I to zee em blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sheades o’ leafy buds, avore</line>
      <line>The peanes, do sheake upon the glass,</line>
      <line>An’ stir in light upon the vloor,</line>
      <line>Where now vew veet do pass.</line>
      <line>An’ stir in light upon the vloor</line>
      <line>Where there’s a-stirren nothen mwore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This win’ mid dreve upon the main,</line>
      <line>My brother’s ship, a-plowen foam,</line>
      <line>But not bring mother, cwold, nor rain,</line>
      <line>At her now happy hwome.</line>
      <line>But not bring mother, cwold, nor rain,</line>
      <line>Where she is out o’ pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Zoo now that I’m a-mwopen dumb,</line>
      <line>A-keepen father’s house, do you</line>
      <line>Come oPen wi’ your work vrom hwome,</line>
      <line>Vor company. Now do.</line>
      <line>Come ofen wi’ your work vrom hwome,</line>
      <line>Up here a while. Do come.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Leaves A-Vallen</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There the ash-tree leaves do vail</line>
      <line>In the wind a-blowen cwolder,</line>
      <line>An’ my childern, tall or small,</line>
      <line>Since last Fall be woone year wolder;</line>
      <line>Woone year wolder, woone year dearer,</line>
      <line>Till when they do leave my he’th,</line>
      <line>I shall be noo mwore a hearer</line>
      <line>O’ their va'ices or their me’th.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There dead ash leaves be a-toss’d</line>
      <line>In the wind, a-blowen stronger,</line>
      <line>An’ our life-time, since we lost</line>
      <line>Souls we lov’d, is woone year longer;</line>
      <line>Woone year longer, woone year wider,</line>
      <line>Vrom the friends that death ha’ took,</line>
      <line>As the hours do teake the rider</line>
      <line>Vrom the hand that last he shook.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No. If he do ride at night</line>
      <line>Vrom the zide the zun went under,</line>
      <line>Woone hour vrom his western light</line>
      <line>Needen meake woone hour asunder;</line>
      <line>Woone hour onward, woone hour nigher</line>
      <line>To the hopevul eastern skies,</line>
      <line>Where his mornen rim o’ vier</line>
      <line>Soon ageiin shall meet his eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Leaves be now a-scatter’d round</line>
      <line>In the wind, a-blowen bleaker,</line>
      <line>An’ if we do walk the ground,</line>
      <line>Wi’ our life-strangth woone year weaker;</line>
      <line>Woone year weaker, woone year nigher</line>
      <line>To the pleace where we shall vind</line>
      <line>Woone that’s deathless vor the dier,</line>
      <line>Voremost they that dropp’d behind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Jay A-Pass’d</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When leaves, in evenen winds, do vlee,</line>
      <line>Where mornen air did strip the tree,</line>
