      <line>The mind can wait vor boughs in spring</line>
      <line>To cool the elem-sheaded ring.</line>
      <line>Where orcha’d blooth’s white sceales do vail</line>
      <line>Mid come the apple’s blushen ball.</line>
      <line>Our hopes be new, as time do goo,</line>
      <line>A-measur’d by the zun on high,</line>
      <line>Avore our jays do pass us by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When ice did melt below the zun,</line>
      <line>An’ weaves along the stream did run,</line>
      <line>I hoped in May’s bright froth to roll,</line>
      <line>Lik’ jess’my in a lily’s bowl.</line>
      <line>Or, if I lost my loose-bow’d swing,</line>
      <line>My wrigglen kite mid pull my string,</line>
      <line>An’ when noo ball did rise an’ vail,</line>
      <line>Zome other geame wud still be nigh,</line>
      <line>Avore my jays all pass’d me by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I look’d, as childhood pass’d along,</line>
      <line>To walk, in leater years, man-strong,</line>
      <line>An’ look’d agean, in manhood’s pride,</line>
      <line>To manhood’s sweetest chai'ce, a bride:</line>
      <line>An’ then to childern, that mid come</line>
      <line>To meake my house a dearer hwome.</line>
      <line>But now my mind do look behind</line>
      <line>Vor jays; an’ wonder, wi’ a sigh,</line>
      <line>When ’twer my jays all pass’d me by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wer it when, woonce, I miss’d a call</line>
      <line>To rise, an’ seem’d to have a vall?</line>
      <line>Or when myJeane to my hands left</line>
      <line>Her vew bright keys, a dolevul heft?</line>
      <line>Or when avore the door I stood,</line>
      <line>To watch a child a-gone vor good?</line>
      <line>Or where zome crowd did laugh aloud;</line>
      <line>Or when the leaves did spring, or die?</line>
      <line>When did my jay all pass me by?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>The Vierzide Chairs</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though days do gain upon the night,</line>
      <line>An’ birds do teake a leater flight,</line>
      <line>’Tis cwold enough to spread our hands</line>
      <line>Oonce now an’ then to glowen brands.</line>
      <line>Zoo now we two, a-left alwone,</line>
      <line>Can meake a quiet hour our own,</line>
      <line>Let’s teake, a-zitten feace to feace,</line>
      <line>Our pleaces by the vier pleace,</line>
      <line>Where you shall have the window view</line>
      <line>Outside, an’ I can look on you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When oonce I brought ye hwome my bride,</line>
      <line>In yollow glow o’ zummer tide,</line>
      <line>I wanted you to teake a chair</line>
      <line>At that zide o’ the vier, there,</line>
      <line>And have the ground an’ sky in zight</line>
      <line>Wi’ feace toward the window light;</line>
      <line>While I back here should have my brow</line>
      <line>In sheade, an’ zit where I do now,</line>
      <line>That you mid zee the land outside,</line>
      <line>If I could look on you, my bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ there the water-pool do spread,</line>
      <line>Wi’ swayen elems over head,</line>
      <line>An’ there’s the knap where we did rove</line>
      <line>At dusk, along the high-tree’d grove,</line>
      <line>The while the wind did whisper down</line>
      <line>Our whisper’d words; an’ there’s the crown</line>
      <line>Ov Duncliffe hill, wi’ wid’nen sheades</line>
      <line>Ov wood a-cast on slopen gleades:</line>
      <line>Zoo you injoy the green an’ blue</line>
      <line>Without, an’ I will look on you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ there’s the copse, where we did all</line>
      <line>Goo out a-nutten in the fall,</line>
      <line>That now would meake, a-quiv’ren black,</line>
      <line>But little lewth behind your back;</line>
      <line>An’ there’s the tower, near the door,</line>
      <line>That we at dusk did meet avore</line>
      <line>As we did gather on the green,</line>
      <line>An’ you did zee, an’ wer a-zeen:</line>
      <line>All wold zights welcomer than new,</line>
      <line>A-look’d on as I look’d on you.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>All Still</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why call it dead, wi’ life a-vled,</line>
      <line>On land wi’ lively birds on wing,</line>
      <line>An’ rooks on high, an’ blackbirds nigh</line>
      <line>The wheelen zwallows in a ring,</line>
      <line>An’ vish to zwim, where streams do roam</line>
      <line>By bridge an’ rock a-beat to foam?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bezides the rock an’ boughless stock</line>
      <line>There’s little dead as I can zee.</line>
      <line>I don’t bemwoan a stock or stwone,</line>
      <line>But life that seem’d all life to me;</line>
      <line>Where oone sweet va'fce noo mwore can come</line>
      <line>Agean, the pleace is ever dumb.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>The Vield Path</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here once did sound sweet words, a-spoke</line>
      <line>In wind that swum</line>
      <line>Where ivy clomb,</line>
      <line>About the ribby woak;</line>
      <line>An’ still the words, though now a-gone,</line>
      <line>Be dear to me, that linger on.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ here, as comely vo’k did pass,</line>
      <line>Their sheades did slide</line>
      <line>Below their zide,</line>
      <line>Along the flow’ry grass,</line>
      <line>An’ though the sheades be all a-gone,</line>
      <line>Still dear’s the ground they veil upon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But could they come where then they stroll’d,</line>
      <line>However young</line>
      <line>Mid sound their tongue,</line>
      <line>Their sheades would show em wold;</line>
      <line>But dear, though they be all a-gone,</line>
      <line>Be sheades o’ trees that linger on.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O ashen poles, a-sheenen tall!</line>
      <line>You be too young</line>
      <line>To have a-sprung</line>
      <line>In days when I wer small;</line>
      <line>But you, broad woak, wi’ ribby rind,</line>
      <line>Wer here so long as I can mind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1873</date>
    <title>Seasons and Times</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Awhile in the dead of the winter,</line>
      <line>The wind hurries keen through the sunshine,</line>
      <line>But finds no more leaves that may linger</line>
      <line>On tree-boughs to strew on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Long streaks of bright snow-drift, bank-shaded,</line>
      <line>Yet lie on the slopes, under hedges;</line>
      <line>But still all the road out to Thorndon</line>
      <line>Would not wet a shoe on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The days, though the cold seems to strengthen,</line>
      <line>Outlengthen their span, and the evening</line>
      <line>Seeks later and later its westing,</line>
      <line>To cast its dim hue on the ground,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till tree-heads shall thicken their shadow</line>
      <line>With leaves of a glittering greenness,</line>
      <line>And daisies shall fold up their blossoms</line>
      <line>At evening, in dew on the ground;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then, in the plum-warding garden,</line>
      <line>Or shadowy orchard, the house-man</line>
      <line>Shall smile at his fruit, really blushing,</line>
      <line>Where sunheat shoots through on the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What season do you feel the fairest—</line>
      <line>The season of sowing or growing,</line>
      <line>Or season of mowing and ripeness,</line>
      <line>When hay may lie new on the ground?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And like you the glittering morning,</line>
      <line>Or short-shaded noon, or the coming</line>
      <line>Of slant-lighted evening, or moonlight,</line>
      <line>When footsteps are few on the ground?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>When We That Now Ha’ Childem Wer Childern</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! where the hedge athirt the hill</line>
      <line>Wi’ high-grown boughs did grow,</line>
      <line>An’ ashes’ limbs wer wide a-spread,</line>
      <line>Wi’ up-grown tips, up over head,</line>
      <line>And out an’ in, wi’ broken brink,</line>
      <line>The brook did run below</line>
      <line>.</line>
      <line>Out there in wind a-driven dry</line>
      <line>Down drove we then did goo,</line>
      <line>Where vrost wer still a-ling’ren white,</line>
      <line>In sheades a-screen’d vrom noontide light,</line>
      <line>A-heastenen hwome avore the night</line>
      <line>Should hide our path vrom view.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As you did skim, wi’ litty tips</line>
      <line>O’ tooes, the ground so fleet,</line>
      <line>A-gath’ren in the wind so strong,</line>
      <line>Behind your frock a-gone along,</line>
      <line>The ruddy leaves, a-lifted up,</line>
      <line>Did leap behind your veet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But now, agean, a-treaden trim</line>
      <line>Our track, the seame wold way,</line>
      <line>We bwoth do walk wi’ slower gait</line>
      <line>On veet a-bearen vull-grown waight,</line>
      <line>An’ leave our litty childern’s tooes</line>
      <line>To leap an’ run in play.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>Walken Hwome at Night</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>You then vor me meade up your mind</line>
      <line>To leave your rights o’ hwome behind,</line>
      <line>Your width o’ teable-rim an’ bit</line>
      <line>O’ virezide vloor, where you did zit,</line>
      <line>An’ all your walks by stiles an geates</line>
      <line>O’ summer vields wi’ maiden meates,</line>
      <line>To guide vor me my house, though small,</line>
      <line>A-reckon’d, all my house mid be.</line>
      <line>Come, hood your head; the wind is keen.</line>
      <line>Come this zide, here. I’ll be your screen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The clothes your mother put ye on</line>
      <line>Be now a-worn all out an’ gone,</line>
      <line>An’ you do wear vrom top to tooe</line>
      <line>What my true love ha’ bought ye new,</line>
      <line>That now in comely sheape’s a-shown,</line>
      <line>My own a-decken ov my own;</line>
      <line>An’ oh! ov all that I’ve a-got,</line>
      <line>Vor your sweet lot a half is small.</line>
      <line>Come, hood your head; wrap up, now do.</line>
      <line>Walk clwose to me. I’ll keep ye lew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ now when we be out to spend</line>
      <line>A vrosty night wi’ zome wold friend,</line>
      <line>An’ ringen clocks to tell at last</line>
      <line>The evenen hour’s a-gone too vast,</line>
      <line>Noo vorked roads, to left an’ right,</line>
      <line>Do sunder us vor night or light;</line>
      <line>But all my woe’s vor you to veel,</line>
      <line>An’ all my weal’s vor you to know.</line>
      <line>Come, hood your head. You can’t zee out?</line>
      <line>I’ll lead ye right, you needen doubt.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>Which Road?</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still green on the limbs o’ the woak wer the leaves,</line>
      <line>Where the black slooe did grow, a-meal’d over wi’ grey,</line>
      <line>Though leazes, a-burnt, wer wi’ bennets a-brown’d,</line>
      <line>An’ the stubble o’ wheat wer a-witheren white,</line>
      <line>While sooner the zunlight did zink vrom the zight,</line>
      <line>An’ longer did linger the dim-roaded night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But bright wer the day-light a-dryen the dew,</line>
      <line>As foam wer a-villen the pool in its vail,</line>
      <line>An’ a-sheenen did climb, by the chalk o’ the cliff,</line>
      <line>The white road a-voun’ steep to the waweary step,</line>
      <line>Where along by the knap, wi’ a high-beaten breast,</line>
      <line>Went the maid an’ the chap to the feast in their best.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There hosses went by wi’ their neck in a bow,</line>
      <line>An’ did toss up their nose over outspringen knees;</line>
      <line>An’ the ox, heairyhided, wi’ low-swingen head;</line>
      <line>An’ the sheep, little knee’d, wi’ a quick-dippen nod;</line>
      <line>An’ a maid, wi’ her head a-borne on in a proud</line>
      <line>Gait o’ walken, so smooth as an air-zwimmin cloud.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>Shop o’ Meat-Weare</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A-zellen meat-weare I shall get noo meat,</line>
      <line>I mussen keep a shop 0’ weares to eat.</line>
      <line>I have zome goods, but I do hardly think</line>
      <line>They be a-zwold so vast as they do shrink.</line>
      <line>I have zome goods, but zomehow all my stocks</line>
      <line>Do weaste away lik’ camphor in a box.</line>
      <line>Hand after han’ do come, and slily clips</line>
      <line>A bit an’ bit to veed zome peair o’ lips.</line>
      <line>You vo’k in house don’t wait vor gain o’ treade,</line>
      <line>But teake the store avore the gain’s a-meade.</line>
      <line>I had zome aggs, an’ I do miss zome aggs,</line>
      <line>An’ I don’t think they went ’ithout zome lags.</line>
      <line>I had zome aggs, an’ zome ha’ left my store,</line>
      <line>But I don’t think they travell’d out o’ door.</line>
      <line>I ha’n’t a-got zome aggs that oonce wer mine,</line>
      <line>But I don’t think they brought me any cwein.</line>
      <line>I bought zome aggs, as I do know vull well;</line>
      <line>I bought zome aggs, but now ha’ nwone to zell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Barnes</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>The Stwonen Steps</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The as e stwonen steps a-zet so true</line>
      <line>Wi’ top on top, a voot each wide,</line>
      <line>Did always dim’ the slopen zide</line>
      <line>O’ thease steep ledge, vor me an’ you.</line>
      <line>Had men a-built the steps avore</line>
      <line>The mossy arch ov our wold door?</line>
      <line>Wer thease wold steairs a-laid by man</line>
      <line>Avore the bridge’s arched span?</line>
      <line>Had vo’k a-put the stwones down here</line>
      <line>Avore they piled the churches speer?</line>
      <line>Ah! who do know how long agoo</line>
      <line>The steps vu’st bore a shoe?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An’ here bezide the slopen hump,</line>
      <line>Vrom stwone to stwone, a-lyen flat,</line>
      <line>The childern’s little veet do pat,</line>
      <line>An’ men-vo’k’s heavy zoles do clump.</line>
      <line>Ah! which the last shall beat a shoe</line>
      <line>On thease grey stwones: shall I or you?</line>
      <line>Which little boy 0’ mine shall dim’</line>
      <line>The steps the last, my John or Jim?</line>
      <line>Which maid, child-quick or woman-slow,</line>
      <line>Shall walk the last thease stwones in row?</line>
      <line>Who can ever tell us who</line>
      <line>The last shall come or goo?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The road do lead below the blocks</line>
      <line>To yonder springhead’s stwonen cove,</line>
      <line>An’ Squier’s house, an elem grove,</line>
      <line>An’ mill bezide the foamy rocks.</line>
      <line>An’ aye, thease well-wore blocks o’ stwone</line>
      <line>Wer here when I vu’st run alwone;</line>
      <line>The stwonen steairs wer here avore</line>
      <line>My father put a voot to vloor.</line>
      <line>’Twer up the steps that gramfer come</line>
      <line>To court poor grammer at her hwome.</line>
      <line>But who can ever tell what peairs</line>
      <line>O’ veet trod vu’st the steairs?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Clarence Mangan</author>
    <date>1840</date>
    <title>Twenty Golden Years Ago</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O, the rain, the weary, dreary rain,</line>
      <line>How it plashes on the window-sill!</line>
      <line>Night, I guess too, must be on the wane,</line>
      <line>Strass and Gass around are grown so still.</line>
      <line>Here I sit, with coffee in my cup—</line>
      <line>Ah! ’twas rarely I beheld it flow</line>
      <line>In the taverns where I loved to sup</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Twenty years ago, alas!—but stay,</line>
      <line>On my life, ’tis half-past twelve o’clock!</line>
      <line>After all, the hours do slip away—</line>
      <line>Come, here goes to burn another block!</line>
      <line>For the night, or morn, is wet and cold,</line>
      <line>And my fire is dwindling rather low:—</line>
      <line>I had fire enough, when young and bold,</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear! I don’t feel well at all, somehow:</line>
      <line>Few in Weimar dream how bad I am;</line>
      <line>Floods of tears grow common with me now,</line>
      <line>High-Dutch floods, that Reason cannot dam.</line>
      <line>Doctors think I’ll neither live nor thrive</line>
      <line>If I mope at home so—I don’t know—</line>
      <line>Am I living now? I was alive</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wifeless, friendless, flagonless, alone,</line>
      <line>Not quite bookless, though, unless I chuse,</line>
      <line>Left with nought to do, except to groan,</line>
      <line>Not a soul to woo, except the Muse—</line>
      <line>O! this, this is hard for me to bear,</line>
      <line>Me, who whilome lived so much en haul,</line>
      <line>Me, who broke all hearts like chinaware</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>P’rhaps ’tis better:—Time’s defacing waves</line>
      <line>Long have quenched the radiance of my brow—</line>
      <line>They who curse me nightly from their graves</line>
      <line>Scarce could love me were they living now;</line>
      <line>But my loneliness hath darker ills—</line>
      <line>Such dun-duns as Conscience, Thought and Co.,</line>
      <line>Awful Gorgons! worse than tailors’ bills</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Did I paint a fifth of what I feel,</line>
      <line>O, how plaintive you would ween I was!</line>
      <line>But I won’t, albeit I have a deal</line>
      <line>More to wail about than Kerner has!</line>
      <line>Kerner’s tears are wept for withered flowers,</line>
      <line>Mine for withered hopes; my Scroll of Woe</line>
      <line>Dates, alas! from Youth’s deserted bowers,</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet may Deutschland’s bardlings flourish long!</line>
      <line>Me, I tweak no beak among them;—hawks</line>
      <line>Must not pounce on hawks; besides, in song</line>
      <line>I could once beat all of them by chalks.</line>
      <line>Though you find me, as I near my goal,</line>
      <line>Sentimentalising like Rousseau,</line>
      <line>Oh! I had a grand Byronian soul</line>
      <line>Twenty golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tick-tick, tick-tick!—Not a sound save Time’s,</line>
      <line>And the windgust, as it drives the rain—</line>
      <line>Tortured torturer of reluctant rhymes,</line>
      <line>Go to bed, and rest thine aching brain!</line>
      <line>Sleep!—no more the dupe of hopes or schemes;</line>
      <line>Soon thou sleepest where the thistles blow—</line>
      <line>Curious anticlimax to thy dreams</line>
      <line>Twenty' golden years ago!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Clarence Mangan</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>Siberia</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Siberia’s wastes</line>
      <line>The Ice-wind’s breath</line>
      <line>Woundeth like the toothed steel;</line>
      <line>Lost Siberia doth reveal</line>
      <line>Only blight and death.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Blight and death alone.</line>
      <line>No Summer shines.</line>
      <line>Night is interblent with Day.</line>
      <line>In Siberia’s wastes alway</line>
      <line>The blood blackens, the heart pines.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Siberia’s wastes</line>
      <line>No tears are shed,</line>
      <line>For they freeze within the brain.</line>
      <line>Nought is felt but dullest pain,</line>
      <line>Pain acute, yet dead;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pain as in a dream,</line>
      <line>When years go by</line>
      <line>Funeral-paced, yet fugitive,</line>
      <line>When man lives, and doth not live,</line>
      <line>Doth not live—nor die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Siberia’s wastes</line>
      <line>Are sands and rocks.</line>
      <line>Nothing blooms of green or soft,</line>
      <line>But the snow-peaks rise aloft</line>
      <line>And the gaunt ice-blocks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the exile there</line>
      <line>Is one with those;</line>
      <line>They are part, and he is part,</line>
      <line>For the sands are in his heart,</line>
      <line>And the killing snows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Therefore, in those wastes</line>
      <line>None curse the Czar.</line>
      <line>Each man’s tongue is cloven by</line>
      <line>The North Blast, that heweth nigh</line>
      <line>With sharp scymitar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And such doom each drees,</line>
      <line>Till, hunger-gnawn,</line>
      <line>And cold-slain, he at length sinks there,</line>
      <line>Yet scarce more a corpse than ere</line>
      <line>His last breath was drawn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Anonymous</author>
    <date>1841</date>
    <title>A New Song on the Birth of the Prince of Wales</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s a pretty fuss and bother both in country and in town,</line>
      <line>Since we have got a present, and an heir unto the Crown,</line>
      <line>A little Prince of Wales so charming and so sly,</line>
      <line>And the ladies shout with wonder, What a pretty little boy!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He must have a little musket, a trumpet and a kite,</line>
      <line>A little penny rattle, and silver sword so bright,</line>
      <line>A little cap and feather with scarlet coat so smart,</line>
      <line>And a pretty little hobby horse to ride about the park.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Prince Albert he will often take the young Prince on his lap,</line>
      <line>And fondle him so lovingly, while he stirs about the pap,</line>
      <line>He will pin on his flannel before he takes his nap,</line>
      <line>Then dress him out so stylish with his little clouts and cap.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He must have a dandy suit to strut about the town,</line>
      <line>John Bull must rake together six or seven thousand pound,</line>
      <line>You’d laugh to see his daddy, at night he homeward runs,</line>
      <line>With some peppermint or lollipops, sweet cakes and sugar plums.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He will want a little fiddle, and a little German flute,</line>
      <line>A little pair of stockings and a pretty pair of boots,</line>
      <line>With a handsome pair of spurs, and a golden headed cane,</line>
      <line>And a stick of barley sugar, as long as Drury Lane.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An old maid ran through the palace, which did the nobs surprize,</line>
      <line>Bawling out, he’s got his daddy’s mouth, his mammy’s nose and eyes,</line>
      <line>He will be as like his daddy as a frigate to a ship,</line>
      <line>If he’d only got mustachios upon his upper lip.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now to get these little niceties the taxes must be rose,</line>
      <line>For the little Prince of Wales wants so many suits of clothes,</line>
      <line>So they must tax the frying pan, the windows and the doors,</line>
      <line>The bedsteads and the tables, kitchen pokers, and the floors.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Miller</author>
    <date>1841</date>
    <title>Wee Willie Winkie rins through the town,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wee Willie Winkie rins through the town,</line>
      <line>Up stairs and doon stairs in his nicht-gown,</line>
      <line>Tirling at the window, crying at the lock,</line>
      <line>Are the weans in their bed, for it’s now ten o’clock?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hey, Willie Winkie, are ye coming ben?</line>
      <line>The cat’s singing grey thrums to the sleeping hen,</line>
      <line>The dog’s spelder’d on the floor, and disna gi’e a cheep,</line>
      <line>But here’s a waukrife laddie! that winna fa’ asleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Onything but sleep, you rogue! glow’ring like the moon,</line>
      <line>Rattling in an airn jug wi’ an airn spoon,</line>
      <line>Rumbling, tumbling round about, crawing like a cock,</line>
      <line>Skirling like a kenna-what, wauk’ning sleeping fock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hey, Willie Winkie—the wean’s in a creel!</line>
      <line>Wambling aff a bodie’s knee like a very eel,</line>
      <line>Rugging at the cat’s lug, and raveling a’ her thrums—</line>
      <line>Hey, Willie Winkie—see, there he comes!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wearied is the mither that has a stoorie wean,</line>
      <line>A wee stumpie stoussie, that canna rin his lane,</line>
      <line>That has a battle aye wi’ sleep before he'll close an ee—</line>
      <line>But a kiss frae aff his rosy lips gi’es strength anew to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Dickens</author>
    <date>1841</date>
    <title>The Fine Old English Gentleman</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll sing you a new ballad, and I’ll warrant it first-rate,</line>
      <line>Of the days of that old gentleman who had that old estate;</line>
      <line>When they spent the public money at a bountiful old rate</line>
      <line>On ev’ry mistress, pimp, and scamp, at ev’ry noble gate,</line>
      <line>In the fine old English Tory times;</line>
      <line>Soon may they come again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The good old laws were garnished well with gibbets, whips, and chains,</line>
      <line>With fine old English penalties, and fine old English pains,</line>
      <line>With rebel heads, and seas of blood once hot in rebel veins;</line>
      <line>For all these things were requisite to guard the rich old gains</line>
      <line>Of the fine old English Tory times;</line>
      <line>Soon may they come again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This brave old code, like Argus, had a hundred watchful eyes,</line>
      <line>And ev’ry English peasant had his good old English spies,</line>
      <line>To tempt his starving discontent with fine old English lies,</line>
      <line>Then call the good old Yeomanry to stop his peevish cries,</line>
      <line>In the fine old English Tory times;</line>
      <line>Soon may they come again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The good old times for cutting throats that cried out in their need,</line>
      <line>The good old times for hunting men who held their fathers’ creed,</line>
      <line>The good old times when William Pitt, as all good men agreed,</line>
      <line>Came down direct from Paradise at more than railroad speed. . . .</line>
      <line>Oh the fine old English Tory times;</line>
      <line>When will they come again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In those rare days, the press was seldom known to snarl or bark,</line>
      <line>But sweetly sang of men in pow’r, like any tuneful lark;</line>
      <line>Grave judges, too, to all their evil deeds were in the dark;</line>
      <line>And not a man in twenty score knew how to make his mark.</line>
      <line>Oh the fine old English Tory times;</line>
      <line>Soon may they come again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Those were the days for taxes, and for war’s infernal din;</line>
      <line>For scarcity of bread, that fine old dowagers might win;</line>
      <line>For shutting men of letters up, through iron bars to grin,</line>
      <line>Because they didn’t think the Prince was altogether thin,</line>
      <line>In the fine old English Tory times;</line>
      <line>Soon may they come again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Tolerance, though slow in flight, is strong-wing’d in the main;</line>
      <line>That night must come on these fine days, in course of time was plain;</line>
      <line>The pure old spirit struggled, but its struggles were in vain;</line>
      <line>A nation’s grip was on it, and it died in choking pain,</line>
      <line>With the fine old English Tory days,</line>
      <line>All of the olden time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The bright old day now dawns again; the cry runs through the land,</line>
      <line>In England there shall be dear bread—in Ireland, sword and brand;</line>
      <line>And poverty, and ignorance, shall swell the rich and grand,</line>
      <line>So, rally round the rulers with the gentle iron hand,</line>
      <line>Of the fine old English Tory days;</line>
      <line>Hail to the coming time!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1842</date>
    <title>The most alluring clouds that mount the sky</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The most alluring clouds that mount the sky</line>
      <line>Owe to a troubled element their forms,</line>
      <line>Their hues to sunset. If with raptured eye</line>
      <line>We watch their splendor, shall we covet storms,</line>
      <line>And wish the Lord of day his slow decline</line>
      <line>Would hasten, that such pomp may float on high?</line>
      <line>Behold, already they forget to shine,</line>
      <line>Dissolve—and leave to him who gazed a sigh.</line>
      <line>Not loth to thank each moment for its boon</line>
      <line>Of pure delight, come whensoe’er it may,</line>
      <line>Peace let us seek—to stedfast things attune</line>
      <line>Calm expectations, leaving to the gay</line>
      <line>And volatile their love of transient bowers,</line>
      <line>The house that cannot pass away be ours.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Wordsworth</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>The unremitting voice of nightly streams</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The unremitting voice of nightly streams</line>
      <line>That wastes so oft, we think, its tuneful powers,</line>
      <line>If neither soothing to the worm that gleams</line>
      <line>Through dewy grass, nor small birds hushed in bowers,</line>
      <line>Nor unto silent leaves and drowsy flowers,—</line>
      <line>That voice of unpretending harmony</line>
      <line>(For who what is shall measure by what seems</line>
      <line>To be, or not to be,</line>
      <line>Or tax high Heaven with prodigality?)</line>
      <line>Wants not a healing influence that can creep</line>
      <line>Into the human breast, and mix with sleep</line>
      <line>To regulate the motion of our dreams</line>
      <line>For kindly issues—as though every clime</line>
      <line>Was felt near murmuring brooks in earliest time;</line>
      <line>As, at this day, the rudest swains who dwell</line>
      <line>Where torrents roar, or hear the tinkling knell</line>
      <line>Of water-breaks, with grateful heart could tell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Barrett Browning</author>
    <date>1842</date>
    <title>Grief</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I tell you, hopeless grief is passionless;</line>
      <line>That only men incredulous of despair,</line>
      <line>Half-taught in anguish, through the midnight air</line>
      <line>Beat upward to God’s throne in loud access</line>
      <line>Of shrieking and reproach. Full desertness,</line>
      <line>In souls as countries, lieth silent-bare</line>
      <line>Under the blanching, vertical eye-glare</line>
      <line>Of the absolute Heavens. Deep-hearted man, express</line>
      <line>Grief for thy Dead in silence like to death—</line>
      <line>Most like a monumental statue set</line>
      <line>In everlasting watch and moveless woe</line>
      <line>Till itself crumble to the dust beneath.</line>
      <line>Touch it; the marble eyelids are not wet:</line>
      <line>If it could weep, it could arise and go.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Barrett Browning</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>Sonnet XXIV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let the world’s sharpness, like a clasping knife,</line>
      <line>Shut in upon itself and do no harm</line>
      <line>In this close hand of Love, now soft and warm,</line>
      <line>And let us hear no sound of human strife</line>
      <line>After the click of the shutting. Life to life—</line>
      <line>I lean upon thee, Dear, without alarm,</line>
      <line>And feel as safe as guarded by a charm</line>
      <line>Against the stab of worldlings, who if rife</line>
      <line>Are weak to injure. Very whitely still</line>
      <line>The lilies of our lives may reassure</line>
      <line>Their blossoms from their roots, accessible</line>
      <line>Alone to heavenly dews that drop not fewer,</line>
      <line>Growing straight, out of man’s reach, on the hill.</line>
      <line>God only, who made us rich, can make us poor.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Barrett Browning</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>from Aurora Leigh</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of writing many books there is no end;</line>
      <line>And I who have written much in prose and verse</line>
      <line>For others’ uses, will write now for mine,—</line>
      <line>Will write my story for my better self,</line>
      <line>As when you paint your portrait for a friend,</line>
      <line>Who keeps it in a drawer and looks at it</line>
      <line>Long after he has ceased to love you, just</line>
      <line>To hold together what he was and is.</line>
      <line>I, writing thus, am still what men call young;</line>
      <line>I have not so far left the coasts of life</line>
      <line>To travel inward, that I cannot hear</line>
      <line>That murmur of the outer Infinite</line>
      <line>Which unweaned babies smile at in their sleep</line>
      <line>When wondered at for smiling; not so far,</line>
      <line>But still I catch my mother at her post</line>
      <line>Beside the nursery door, with finger up,</line>
      <line>‘Hush, hush—here’s too much noise!’ while her sweet eyes</line>
      <line>Leap forward, taking part against her word</line>
      <line>In the child’s riot. Still I sit and feel</line>
      <line>My father’s slow hand, when she had left us both,</line>
      <line>Stroke out my childish curls across his knee,</line>
      <line>And hear Assunta’s daily jest (she knew</line>
      <line>He liked it better than a better jest)</line>
      <line>Inquire how many golden scudi went</line>
      <line>To make such ringlets. O my father’s hand,</line>
      <line>Stroke heavily, heavily the poor hair down,</line>
      <line>Draw, press the child’s head closer to thy knee!</line>
      <line>I’m still too young, too young, to sit alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I write. My mother was a Florentine,</line>
      <line>Whose rare blue eyes were shut from seeing me</line>
      <line>When scarcely I was four years old, my life</line>
      <line>A poor spark snatched up from a failing lamp</line>
      <line>Which went out therefore. She was weak and frail;</line>
      <line>She could not bear the joy of giving life,</line>
      <line>The mother’s rapture slew her. If her kiss</line>
      <line>Had left a longer weight upon my lips</line>
      <line>It might have steadied the uneasy breath,</line>
      <line>And reconciled and fraternised my soul</line>
      <line>With the new order. As it was, indeed,</line>
      <line>I felt a mother-want about the world,</line>
      <line>And still went seeking, like a bleating lamb</line>
      <line>Left out at night in shutting up the fold,—</line>
      <line>As restless as a nest-deserted bird</line>
      <line>Grown chill through something being away, though what</line>
      <line>It knows not. I, Aurora Leigh, was born</line>
      <line>To make my father sadder, and myself</line>
      <line>Not overjoyous, truly. Women know</line>
      <line>The way to rear up children (to be just),</line>
      <line>They know a simple, merry, tender knack</line>
      <line>Of tying sashes, fitting baby-shoes,</line>
      <line>And stringing pretty words that make no sense,</line>
      <line>And kissing full sense into empty words,</line>
      <line>Which things are corals to cut life upon,</line>
      <line>Although such trifles: children learn by such,</line>
      <line>Love’s holy earnest in a pretty play</line>
      <line>And get not over-early solemnised,</line>
      <line>But seeing, as in a rose-bush, Love’s Divine</line>
      <line>Which burns and hurts not,—not a single bloom,—</line>
      <line>Become aware and unafraid of Love.</line>
      <line>Such good do mothers. Fathers love as well</line>
      <line>—Mine did, I know,—but still with heavier brains,</line>
      <line>And wills more consciously responsible,</line>
      <line>And not as wisely, since less foolishly;</line>
      <line>So mothers have God’s license to be missed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My father was an austere Englishman,</line>
      <line>Who, after a dry lifetime spent at home</line>
      <line>In college-learning, law, and parish talk,</line>
      <line>Was flooded with a passion unaware,</line>
      <line>His whole provisioned and complacent past</line>
      <line>Drowned out from him that moment. As he stood</line>
      <line>In Florence, where he had come to spend a month</line>
      <line>And note the secret of Da Vinci’s drains,</line>
      <line>He musing somewhat absently perhaps</line>
      <line>Some English question . . . whether men should pay</line>
      <line>The unpopular but necessary tax</line>
      <line>With left or right hand—in the alien sun</line>
      <line>In that great square of the Santissima</line>
      <line>There drifted past him (scarcely marked enough</line>
      <line>To move his comfortable island scorn)</line>
      <line>A train of priestly banners, cross and psalm,</line>
      <line>The white-veiled rose-crowned maidens holding up</line>
      <line>Tall tapers, weighty for such wrists, aslant</line>
      <line>To the blue luminous tremor of the air,</line>
      <line>And letting drop the white wax as they went</line>
      <line>To eat the bishop’s wafer at the church;</line>
      <line>From which long trail of chanting priests and girls,</line>
      <line>A face flashed like a cymbal on his face</line>
      <line>And shook with silent clangour brain and heart,</line>
      <line>Transfiguring him to music. Thus, even thus,</line>
      <line>He too received his sacramental gift</line>
      <line>With eucharistic meanings; for he loved.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus beloved, she died. I’ve heard it said</line>
      <line>That but to see him in the first surprise</line>
      <line>Of widower and father, nursing me,</line>
      <line>Unmothered little child of four years old,</line>
      <line>His large man’s hands afraid to touch my curls,</line>
      <line>As if the gold would tarnish,—his grave lips</line>
      <line>Contriving such a miserable smile</line>
      <line>As if he knew needs must, or I should die,</line>
      <line>And yet ’twas hard,—would almost make the stones 100</line>
      <line>Cry out for pity. There’s a verse he set</line>
      <line>In Santa Croce to her memory,—</line>
      <line>‘Weep for an infant too young to weep much</line>
      <line>When death removed this mother’—stops the mirth</line>
      <line>To-day on women’s faces when they walk</line>
      <line>With rosy children hanging on their gowns,</line>
      <line>Under the cloister to escape the sun</line>
      <line>That scorches in the piazza. After which</line>
      <line>He left our Florence and made haste to hide</line>
      <line>Himself, his prattling child, and silent grief,</line>
      <line>Among the mountains above Pelago;</line>
      <line>Because unmothered babes, he thought, had need</line>
      <line>Of mother nature more than others use,</line>
      <line>And Pan’s white goats, with udders warm and full</line>
      <line>Of mystic contemplations, come to feed</line>
      <line>Poor milkless lips of orphans like his own—</line>
      <line>Such scholar-scraps he talked, I’ve heard from friends,</line>
      <line>For even prosaic men who wear grief long</line>
      <line>Will get to wear it as a hat aside</line>
      <line>With a flower stuck in’t. Father, then, and child,</line>
      <line>We lived among the mountains many years,</line>
      <line>God’s silence on the outside of the house,</line>
      <line>And we who did not speak too loud within,</line>
      <line>And old Assunta to make up the fire,</line>
      <line>Crossing herself whene’er a sudden flame</line>
      <line>Which lightened from the firewood, made alive</line>
      <line>That picture of my mother on the wall.</line>
      <line>The painter drew it after she was dead,</line>
      <line>And when the face was finished, throat and hands,</line>
      <line>Fler cameriera carried him, in hate</line>
      <line>Of the English-fashioned shroud, the last brocade</line>
      <line>She dressed in at the Pitti; ‘he should paint</line>
      <line>No sadder thing than that,’ she swore, ‘to wrong</line>
      <line>Her poor signora.’ Therefore very strange</line>
      <line>The effect was. I, a little child, would crouch</line>
      <line>For hours upon the floor with knees drawn up,</line>
      <line>And gaze across them, half in terror, half</line>
      <line>In adoration, at the picture there,—</line>
      <line>That swan-like supernatural white life</line>
      <line>Just sailing upward from the red stiff silk</line>
      <line>Which seemed to have no part in it nor power</line>
      <line>To keep it from quite breaking out of bounds.</line>
      <line>For hours I sat and stared. Assunta’s awe</line>
      <line>And my poor father’s melancholy eyes</line>
      <line>Still pointed that way. That way went my thoughts</line>
      <line>When wandering beyond sight. And as I grew</line>
      <line>In years, I mixed, confused, unconsciously,</line>
      <line>Whatever I last read or heard or dreamed,</line>
      <line>Abhorrent, admirable, beautiful,</line>
      <line>Pathetical, or ghastly, or grotesque,</line>
      <line>With still that face . . . which did not therefore change,</line>
      <line>But kept the mystic level of all forms,</line>
      <line>Hates, fears, and admirations, was by turns</line>
      <line>Ghost, fiend, and angel, fairy, witch, and sprite,</line>
      <line>A dauntless Muse who eyes a dreadful Fate,</line>
      <line>A loving Psyche who loses sight of Love,</line>
      <line>A still Medusa with mild milky brows</line>
      <line>All curdled and all clothed upon with snakes</line>
      <line>Whose slime falls fast as sweat will; or anon</line>
      <line>Our Lady of the Passion, stabbed with swords</line>
      <line>Where the Babe sucked; or Lamia in her first</line>
      <line>Moonlighted pallor, ere she shrunk and blinked</line>
      <line>And shuddering wriggled down to the unclean;</line>
      <line>Or my own mother, leaving her last smile</line>
      <line>In her last kiss upon the baby-mouth</line>
      <line>My father pushed down on the bed for that,—</line>
      <line>Or my dead mother, without smile or kiss,</line>
      <line>Buried at Florence. All which images,</line>
      <line>Concentred on the picture, glassed themselves</line>
      <line>Before my meditative childhood, as</line>
      <line>The incoherencies of change and death</line>
      <line>Are represented fully, mixed and merged,</line>
      <line>In the smooth fair mystery of perpetual Life.</line>
      <line>And while I stared away my childish wits</line>
      <line>Upon my mother’s picture (ah, poor child!),</line>
      <line>My father, who through love had suddenly</line>
      <line>Thrown off the old conventions, broken loose</line>
      <line>From chin-bands of the soul, like Lazarus,</line>
      <line>Yet had no time to learn to talk and walk</line>
      <line>Or grow anew familiar with the sun,—</line>
      <line>Who had reached to freedom, not to action, lived,</line>
      <line>But lived as one entranced, with thoughts, not aims,</line>
      <line>Whom love had unmade from a common man</line>
      <line>But not completed to an uncommon man,—</line>
      <line>My father taught me what he had learnt the best</line>
      <line>Before he died and left me,—grief and love.</line>
      <line>And, seeing we had books among the hills,</line>
      <line>Strong words of counselling souls confederate</line>
      <line>With vocal pines and waters,—out of books</line>
      <line>He taught me all the ignorance of men,</line>
      <line>And how God laughs in heaven when any man</line>
      <line>Says ‘Here I’m learned; this, I understand;</line>
      <line>In that, I am never caught at fault or doubt.’</line>
      <line>He sent the schools to school, demonstrating</line>
      <line>A fool will pass for such through one mistake,</line>
      <line>While a philosopher will pass for such,</line>
      <line>Through said mistakes being ventured in the gross</line>
      <line>And heaped up to a system.</line>
      <line>I am like,</line>
      <line>They tell me, my dear father. Broader brows</line>
      <line>Howbeit, upon a slenderer undergrowth</line>
      <line>Of delicate features,—paler, near as grave;</line>
      <line>But then my mother’s smile breaks up the whole,</line>
      <line>And makes it better sometimes than itself.</line>
      <line>So, nine full years, our days were hid with God</line>
      <line>Among his mountains: I was just thirteen,</line>
      <line>Still growing like the plants from unseen roots</line>
      <line>In tongue-tied Springs,—and suddenly awoke</line>
      <line>To full life and life’s needs and agonies</line>
      <line>With an intense, strong, struggling heart beside</line>
      <line>A stone-dead father. Life, struck sharp on death,</line>
      <line>Makes awful lightning. His last word was ‘Love—’</line>
      <line>‘Love, my child, love, love!’—(then he had done with grief)</line>
      <line>‘Love, my child.’ Ere I answered he was gone,</line>
      <line>And none was left to love in all the world.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There, ended childhood. What succeeded next</line>
      <line>I recollect as, after fevers, men</line>
      <line>Thread back the passage of delirium,</line>
      <line>Missing the turn still, baffled by the door;</line>
      <line>Smooth endless days, notched here and there with knives,</line>
      <line>A weary, wormy darkness, spurred i’ the flank</line>
      <line>With flame, that it should eat and end itself</line>
      <line>Like some tormented scorpion. Then at last</line>
      <line>I do remember clearly how there came</line>
      <line>A stranger with authority, not right</line>
      <line>(I thought not), who commanded, caught me up</line>
      <line>From old Assunta’s neck; how, with a shriek,</line>
      <line>She let me go,—while I, with ears too full</line>
      <line>Of my father’s silence to shriek back a word,</line>
      <line>In all a child’s astonishment at grief</line>
      <line>Stared at the wharf-edge where she stood and moaned,</line>
      <line>My poor Assunta, where she stood and moaned!</line>
      <line>The white walls, the blue hills, my Italy,</line>
      <line>Drawn backward from the shuddering steamer-deck,</line>
      <line>Like one in anger drawing back her skirts</line>
      <line>Which suppliants catch at. Then the bitter sea</line>
      <line>Inexorably pushed between us both</line>
      <line>And, sweeping up the ship with my despair,</line>
      <line>Threw us out as a pasture to the stars.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ten nights and days we voyaged on the deep;</line>
      <line>Ten nights and days without the common face</line>
      <line>Of any day or night; the moon and sun</line>
      <line>Cut off from the green reconciling earth,</line>
      <line>To starve into a blind ferocity</line>
      <line>And glare unnatural; the very sky</line>
      <line>(Dropping its bell-net down upon the sea,</line>
      <line>As if no human heart should ’scape alive)</line>
      <line>Bedraggled with the desolating salt,</line>
      <line>Until it seemed no more that holy heaven</line>
      <line>To which my father went. All new and strange;</line>
      <line>The universe turned stranger, for a child.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, land!—then, England! oh, the frosty cliffs</line>
      <line>Looked cold upon me. Could I find a home</line>
      <line>Among those mean red houses through the fog?</line>
      <line>And when I heard my father’s language first</line>
      <line>From alien lips which had no kiss for mine</line>
      <line>I wept aloud, then laughed, then wept, then wept,</line>
      <line>And some one near me said the child was mad</line>
      <line>Through much sea-sickness. The train swept us on:</line>
      <line>Was this my father’s England? the great isle?</line>
      <line>The ground seemed cut up from the fellowship</line>
      <line>Of verdure, field from field, as man from man;</line>
      <line>The skies themselves looked low and positive,</line>
      <line>As almost you could touch them with a hand,</line>
      <line>And dared to do it they were so far off</line>
      <line>From God’s celestial crystals; all things blurred</line>
      <line>And dull and vague. Did Shakespeare and his mates</line>
      <line>Absorb the light here?—not a hill or stone</line>
      <line>With heart to strike a radiant colour up</line>
      <line>Or active outline on the indifferent air.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I think I see my father’s sister stand</line>
      <line>Upon the hall-step of her country-house</line>
      <line>To give me welcome. She stood straight and calm,</line>
      <line>Her somewhat narrow forehead braided tight</line>
      <line>As if for taming accidental thoughts</line>
      <line>From possible pulses; brown hair pricked with gray</line>
      <line>By frigid use of life (she was not old,</line>
      <line>Although my father’s elder by a year),</line>
      <line>A nose drawn sharply, yet in delicate lines;</line>
      <line>A close mild mouth, a little soured about</line>
      <line>The ends, through speaking unrequited loves</line>
      <line>Or peradventure niggardly half-truths;</line>
      <line>Eyes of no colour,—once they might have smiled,</line>
      <line>But never, never have forgot themselves</line>
      <line>In smiling; cheeks, in which was yet a rose</line>
      <line>Of perished summers, like a rose in a book,</line>
      <line>Kept more for ruth than pleasure,—if past bloom,</line>
      <line>Past fading also.</line>
      <line>She had lived, we’ll say,</line>
      <line>A harmless life, she called a virtuous life,</line>
      <line>A quiet life, which was not life at all</line>
      <line>(But that, she had not lived enough to know),</line>
      <line>Between the vicar and the county squires,</line>
      <line>The lord-lieutenant looking down sometimes</line>
      <line>From the empyrean to assure their souls</line>
      <line>Against chance vulgarisms, and, in the abyss,</line>
      <line>The apothecary, looked on once a year</line>
      <line>To prove their soundness of humility.</line>
      <line>The poor-club exercised her Christian gifts</line>
      <line>Of knitting stockings, stitching petticoats,</line>
      <line>Because we are of one flesh, after all,</line>
      <line>And need one flannel (with a proper sense</line>
      <line>Of difference in the quality)—and still</line>
      <line>The book-club, guarded from your modern trick</line>
      <line>Of shaking dangerous questions from the crease,</line>
      <line>Preserved her intellectual. She had lived</line>
      <line>A sort of cage-bird life, born in a cage,</line>
      <line>Accounting that to leap from perch to perch</line>
      <line>Was act and joy enough for any bird.</line>
      <line>Dear heaven, how silly are the things that live</line>
      <line>In thickets, and eat berries!</line>
      <line>I, alas,</line>
      <line>A wild bird scarcely fledged, was brought to her cage,</line>
      <line>And she was there to meet me. Very kind.</line>
      <line>Bring the clean water, give out the fresh seed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She stood upon the steps to welcome me,</line>
      <line>Calm, in black garb. I clung about her neck,—</line>
      <line>Young babes, who catch at every shred of wool</line>
      <line>To draw the new light closer, catch and cling</line>
      <line>Less blindly. In my ears my father’s word</line>
      <line>Hummed ignorantly, as the sea in shells,</line>
      <line>‘Love, love, my child.’ She, black there with my grief,</line>
      <line>Might feel my love—she was his sister once—</line>
      <line>I clung to her. A moment she seemed moved,</line>
      <line>Kissed me with cold lips, suffered me to cling,</line>
      <line>And drew me feebly through the hall into</line>
      <line>The room she sat in.</line>
      <line>There, with some strange spasm</line>
      <line>Of pain and passion, she wrung loose my hands</line>
      <line>Imperiously, and held me at arm’s length,</line>
      <line>And with two grey-steel naked-bladed eyes</line>
      <line>Searched through my face,—ay, stabbed it through and through,</line>
      <line>Through brows and cheeks and chin, as if to find</line>
      <line>A wicked murderer in my innocent face,</line>
      <line>If not here, there perhaps. Then, drawing breath,</line>
      <line>She struggled for her ordinary calm—</line>
      <line>And missed it rather,—told me not to shrink,</line>
      <line>As if she had told me not to lie or swear,—</line>
      <line>‘She loved my father and would love me too</line>
      <line>As long as I deserved it.’ Very kind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I understood her meaning afterward;</line>
      <line>She thought to find my mother in my face,</line>
      <line>And questioned it for that. For she, my aunt,</line>
      <line>Had loved my father truly, as she could,</line>
      <line>And hated, with the gall of gentle souls,</line>
      <line>My Tuscan mother who had fooled away</line>
      <line>A wise man from wise courses, a good man</line>
      <line>From obvious duties, and, depriving her,</line>
      <line>His sister, of the household precedence,</line>
      <line>Had wronged his tenants, robbed his native land,</line>
      <line>And made him mad, alike by life and death,</line>
      <line>In love and sorrow. She had pored for years</line>
      <line>What sort of woman could be suitable</line>
      <line>To her sort of hate, to entertain it with,</line>
      <line>And so, her very curiosity</line>
      <line>Became hate too, and all the idealism</line>
      <line>She ever used in life was used for hate,</line>
      <line>Till hate, so nourished, did exceed at last</line>
      <line>The love from which it grew, in strength and heat,</line>
      <line>And wrinkled her smooth conscience with a sense</line>
      <line>Of disputable virtue (say not, sin)</line>
      <line>When Christian doctrine was enforced at church.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thus my father’s sister was to me</line>
      <line>My mother’s hater. From that day she did</line>
      <line>Her duty to me (I appreciate it</line>
      <line>In her own word as spoken to herself),</line>
      <line>Her duty, in large measure, well pressed out</line>
      <line>But measured always. She was generous, bland,</line>
      <line>More courteous than was tender, gave me still</line>
      <line>The first place,—as if fearful that God’s saints</line>
      <line>Would look down suddenly and say ‘Herein</line>
      <line>You missed a point, I think, through lack of love.’</line>
      <line>Alas, a mother never is afraid</line>
      <line>Of speaking angerly to any child,</line>
      <line>Since love, she knows, is justified of love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I, I was a good child on the whole,</line>
      <line>A meek and manageable child. Why not?</line>
      <line>I did not live, to have the faults of life:</line>
      <line>There seemed more true life in my father’s grave</line>
      <line>Than in all England. Since that threw me off</line>
      <line>Who fain would cleave (his latest will, they say,</line>
      <line>Consigned me to his land), I only thought</line>
      <line>Of lying quiet there where I was thrown</line>
      <line>Like sea-weed on the rocks, and suffering her</line>
      <line>To prick me to a pattern with her pin,</line>
      <line>Fibre from fibre, delicate leaf from leaf,</line>
      <line>And dry out from my drowned anatomy</line>
      <line>The last sea-salt left in me.</line>
      <line>So it was.</line>
      <line>I broke the copious curls upon my head</line>
      <line>In braids, because she liked smooth-ordered hair.</line>
      <line>I left off saying my sweet Tuscan words</line>
      <line>Which still at any stirring of the heart</line>
      <line>Came up to float across the English phrase</line>
      <line>As lilies {Bene or Che che), because</line>
      <line>She liked my father’s child to speak his tongue.</line>
      <line>I learnt the collects and the cathecism,</line>
      <line>The creeds, from Athanasius back to Nice,</line>
      <line>The Articles, the Tracts against the times</line>
      <line>(By no means Buonaventure’s ‘Prick of Love’),</line>
      <line>And various popular synopses of</line>
      <line>Inhuman doctrines never taught by John,</line>
      <line>Because she liked instructed piety.</line>
      <line>I learnt my complement of classic French</line>
      <line>(Kept pure of Balzac and neologism)</line>
      <line>And German also, since she liked a range</line>
      <line>Of liberal education,—tongues, not books.</line>
      <line>I learnt a little algebra, a little</line>
      <line>Of the mathematics,—brushed with extreme flounce</line>
      <line>The circle of the sciences, because</line>
      <line>She misliked women who are frivolous.</line>
      <line>I learnt the royal genealogies</line>
      <line>Of Oviedo, the internal laws</line>
      <line>Of the Burmese empire,—by how many feet</line>
      <line>Mount Chimborazo outsoars Teneriffe.</line>
      <line>What navigable river joins itself</line>
      <line>To Lara, and what census of the year five</line>
      <line>Was taken at Klagenfurt,—because she liked</line>
      <line>A general insight into useful facts.</line>
      <line>I learnt much music,—such as would have been</line>
      <line>As quite impossible in Johnson’s day</line>
      <line>As still it might be wished—fine sleights of hand</line>
      <line>And unimagined fingering, shuffling off</line>
      <line>The hearer’s soul through hurricanes of notes</line>
      <line>To a noisy Tophet; and I drew ... costumes</line>
      <line>From French engravings, nereids neatly draped</line>
      <line>(With smirks of simmering godship): I washed in</line>
      <line>Landscapes from nature (rather say, washed out).</line>
      <line>I danced the polka and Cellarius,</line>
      <line>Spun glass, stuffed birds, and modelled flowers in wax,</line>
      <line>Because she liked accomplishments in girls.</line>
      <line>I read a score of books on womanhood</line>
      <line>To prove, if women do not think at all,</line>
      <line>They may teach thinking (to a maiden aunt</line>
      <line>Or else the author),—books that boldly assert</line>
      <line>Their right of comprehending husband’s talk</line>
      <line>When not too deep, and even of answering</line>
      <line>With pretty ‘may it please you,’ or ‘so it is,’—</line>
      <line>Their rapid insight and fine aptitude,</line>
      <line>Particular worth and general missionariness,</line>
      <line>As long as they keep quiet by the fire</line>
      <line>And never say ‘no’ when the world says ‘ay’,</line>
      <line>For that is fatal,—their angelic reach</line>
      <line>Of virtue, chiefly used to sit and darn,</line>
      <line>And fatten household sinners,—their, in brief,</line>
      <line>Potential faculty in everything</line>
      <line>Of abdicating power in it: she owned</line>
      <line>She liked a woman to be womanly,</line>
      <line>And English women, she thanked God and sighed</line>
      <line>(Some people always sigh in thanking God)</line>
      <line>Were models to the universe. And last</line>
      <line>I learnt cross-stitch, because she did not like</line>
      <line>To see me wear the night with empty hands</line>
      <line>A-doing nothing. So, my shepherdess</line>
      <line>Was something after all (the pastoral saints</line>
      <line>Be praised for’t), leaning lovelorn with pink eyes</line>
      <line>To match her shoes, when I mistook the silks;</line>
      <line>Her head uncrushed by that round weight of hat</line>
      <line>So strangely similar to the tortoise-shell</line>
      <line>Which slew the tragic poet.</line>
      <line>By the way,</line>
      <line>The works of women are symbolical.</line>
      <line>We sew, sew, prick our fingers, dull our sight,</line>
      <line>Producing what? A pair of slippers, sir,</line>
      <line>To put on when you’re weary—or a stool</line>
      <line>To stumble over and vex you .. . ‘curse that stool!’</line>
      <line>Or else at best, a cushion, where you lean</line>
      <line>And sleep, and dream of something we are not</line>
      <line>But would be for your sake. Alas, alas!</line>
      <line>This hurts most, this—that, after all, we are paid</line>
      <line>The worth of our work, perhaps.</line>
      <line>In looking down</line>
      <line>Those years of education (to return)</line>
      <line>I wonder if Brinvilliers suffered more</line>
      <line>In the water-torture . . . flood succeeding flood</line>
      <line>To drench the incapable throat and split the veins . . .</line>
      <line>Than I did. Certain of your feebler souls</line>
      <line>Go out in such a process; many pine</line>
      <line>To a sick, inodorous light; my own endured:</line>
      <line>I had relations in the Unseen, and drew</line>
      <line>The elemental nutriment and heat</line>
      <line>From nature, as earth feels the sun at nights,</line>
      <line>Or as a babe sucks surely in the dark.</line>
      <line>I kept the life thrust on me, on the outside</line>
      <line>Of the inner life with all its ample room</line>
      <line>For heart and lungs, for will and intellect,</line>
      <line>Inviolable by conventions. God,</line>
      <line>I thank thee for that grace of thine!</line>
      <line>At first</line>
      <line>I felt no life which was not patience,—did</line>
      <line>The thing she bade me, without heed to a thing</line>
      <line>Beyond it, sat in just the chair she placed,</line>
      <line>With back against the window, to exclude</line>
      <line>The sight of the great lime-tree on the lawn,</line>
      <line>Which seemed to have come on purpose from the woods</line>
      <line>To bring the house a message,—ay, and walked</line>
      <line>Demurely in her carpeted low rooms,</line>
      <line>As if I should not, hearkening my own steps,</line>
      <line>Misdoubt I was alive. I read her books,</line>
      <line>Was civil to her cousin, Romney Leigh,</line>
      <line>Gave ear to her vicar, tea to her visitors,</line>
      <line>And heard them whisper, when I changed a cup</line>
      <line>(I blushed for joy at that),—‘The Italian child,</line>
      <line>For all her blue eyes and her quiet ways,</line>
      <line>Thrives ill in England: she is paler yet</line>
      <line>Than when we came the last time; she will die.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Will die.’ My cousin, Romney Leigh, blushed too,</line>
      <line>With sudden anger, and approaching me</line>
      <line>Said low between his teeth, ‘You’re wicked now?</line>
      <line>You wish to die and leave the world a-dusk</line>
      <line>For others, with your naughty light blown out?’</line>
      <line>I looked into his face defyingly;</line>
      <line>He might have known that, being what I was,</line>
      <line>’Twas natural to like to get away</line>
      <line>As far as dead folk can: and then indeed</line>
      <line>Some people make no trouble when they die.</line>
      <line>He turned and went abruptly, slammed the door,</line>
      <line>And shut his dog out.</line>
      <line>Romney, Romney Leigh.</line>
      <line>I have not named my cousin hitherto,</line>
      <line>And yet I used him as a sort of friend;</line>
      <line>My elder by few years, but cold and shy</line>
      <line>And absent . .. tender, when he thought of it,</line>
      <line>Which scarcely was imperative, grave betimes,</line>
      <line>As well as early master of Leigh Hall,</line>
      <line>Whereof the nightmare sat upon his youth,</line>
      <line>Repressing all its seasonable delights,</line>
      <line>And agonising with a ghastly sense</line>
      <line>Of universal hideous want and wrong</line>
      <line>To incriminate possession. When he came</line>
      <line>From college to the country, very oft</line>
      <line>He crossed the hill on visits to my aunt,</line>
      <line>With gifts of blue grapes from the hothouses,</line>
      <line>A book in one hand,—mere statistics (if</line>
      <line>I chanced to lift the cover), count of all</line>
      <line>The goats whose beards grow sprouting down toward hell</line>
      <line>Against God’s separative judgment-hour.</line>
      <line>And she, she almost loved him,—even allowed</line>
      <line>That sometimes he should seem to sigh my way;</line>
      <line>It made him easier to be pitiful,</line>
      <line>And sighing was his gift. So, undisturbed,</line>
      <line>At whiles she let him shut my music up</line>
      <line>And push my needles down, and lead me out</line>
      <line>To see in that south angle of the house</line>
      <line>The figs grow black as if by a Tuscan rock,</line>
      <line>On some light pretext. She would turn her head</line>
      <line>At other moments, go to fetch a thing,</line>
      <line>And leave me breath enough to speak with him,</line>
      <line>For his sake; it was simple.</line>
      <line>Sometimes too</line>
      <line>He would have saved me utterly, it seemed,</line>
      <line>He stood and looked so.</line>
      <line>Once, he stood so near,</line>
      <line>He dropped a sudden hand upon my head</line>
      <line>Bent down on woman’s work, as soft as rain—</line>
      <line>But then I rose and shook it off as fire,</line>
      <line>The stranger’s touch that took my father’s place</line>
      <line>Yet dared seem soft.</line>
      <line>I used him for a friend</line>
      <line>Before I ever knew him for a friend.</line>
      <line>’Twas better, ’twas worse also, afterward:</line>
      <line>We came so close, we saw our differences</line>
      <line>Too intimately. Always Romney Leigh</line>
      <line>Was looking for the worms, I for the gods.</line>
      <line>A godlike nature his; the gods look down,</line>
      <line>Incurious of themselves; and certainly</line>
      <line>’Tis well I should remember, how, those days,</line>
      <line>I was a worm too, and he looked on me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little by his act perhaps, yet more</line>
      <line>By something in me, surely not my will,</line>
      <line>I did not die. But slowly, as one in swoon,</line>
      <line>To whom life creeps back in the form of death,</line>
      <line>With a sense of separation, a blind pain</line>
      <line>Of blank obstruction, and a roar i’ the ears</line>
      <line>Of visionary chariots which retreat</line>
      <line>As earth grows clearer . . . slowly, by degrees;</line>
      <line>I woke, rose up . . . where was I? in the world;</line>
      <line>For uses therefore I must count worth while.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Barrett Browning</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>The Best Thing in the World</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What’s the best thing in the world?</line>
      <line>June-rose, by May-dew impearled;</line>
      <line>Sweet south-wind, that means no rain;</line>
      <line>Truth, not cruel to a friend;</line>
      <line>Pleasure, not in haste to end;</line>
      <line>Beauty, not self-decked and curled</line>
      <line>Till its pride is over-plain;</line>
      <line>Light, that never makes you wink;</line>
      <line>Memory', that gives no pain;</line>
      <line>Love, when, so, you’re loved again.</line>
      <line>What’s the best thing in the world?</line>
      <line>—Something out of it, I think.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Barrett Browning</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>‘Died...'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What shall we add now? He is dead.</line>
      <line>And I who praise and you who blame,</line>
      <line>With wash of words across his name,</line>
      <line>Find suddenly declared instead—</line>
      <line>‘On Sunday, third of August, dead.'</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Which stops the whole we talked to-day.</line>
      <line>I quickened to a plausive glance</line>
      <line>At his large general tolerance</line>
      <line>By common people’s narrow way,</line>
      <line>Stopped short in praising. Dead, they say.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And you, who had just put in a sort</line>
      <line>Of cold deduction—‘rather, large</line>
      <line>Through weakness of the continent marge,</line>
      <line>Than greatness of the thing contained’—</line>
      <line>Broke off. Dead!—there, you stood restrained.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As if we had talked in following one</line>
      <line>Up some long gallery. ‘Would you choose</line>
      <line>An air like that? The gait is loose—</line>
      <line>Or noble.’ Sudden in the sun</line>
      <line>An oubliette winks. Where is he? Gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dead. Man’s ‘I was’ by God’s T am’—</line>
      <line>All hero-worship comes to that.</line>
      <line>High heart, high thought, high fame, as flat</line>
      <line>As a gravestone. Bring your facet jam—</line>
      <line>The epitaph’s an epigram.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dead. There’s an answer to arrest</line>
      <line>All carping. Dust’s his natural place?</line>
      <line>He’ll let the flies buzz round his face</line>
      <line>And, though you slander, not protest?</line>
      <line>—From such an one, exact the Best?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Opinions gold or brass are null.</line>
      <line>We chuck our flattery or abuse,</line>
      <line>Called Caesar’s due, as Charon’s dues,</line>
      <line>I’ the teeth of some dead sage or fool,</line>
      <line>To mend the grinning of a skull.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be abstinent in praise and blame.</line>
      <line>The man’s still mortal, who stands first,</line>
      <line>And mortal only, if last and worst.</line>
      <line>Then slowly lift so frail a fame,</line>
      <line>Or softly drop so poor a shame.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1842</date>
    <title>My Last Duchess</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>That’s my last Duchess painted on the wall,</line>
      <line>Looking as if she were alive. I call</line>
      <line>That piece a wonder, now: Fra Pandolf’s hands</line>
      <line>Worked busily a day, and there she stands.</line>
      <line>Will’t please you sit and look at her? I said</line>
      <line>‘Fra Pandolf by design, for never read</line>
      <line>Strangers like you that pictured countenance,</line>
      <line>The depth and passion of its earnest glance,</line>
      <line>But to myself they turned (since none puts by</line>
      <line>The curtain I have drawn for you, but I)</line>
      <line>And seemed as they would ask me, if they durst,</line>
      <line>How such a glance came there; so, not the first</line>
      <line>Are you to turn and ask thus. Sir, ’t was not</line>
      <line>Her husband’s presence only, called that spot</line>
      <line>Of joy into the Duchess’ cheek: perhaps</line>
      <line>Fra Pandolf chanced to say ‘Her mantle laps</line>
      <line>‘Over my lady’s wrist too much,’ or ‘Paint</line>
      <line>‘Must never hope to reproduce the faint</line>
      <line>‘Half-flush that dies along her throat:’ such stuff</line>
      <line>Was courtesy, she thought, and cause enough</line>
      <line>For calling up that spot of joy. She had</line>
      <line>A heart—how shall I say?—too soon made glad,</line>
      <line>Too easily impressed; she liked whate’er</line>
      <line>She looked on, and her looks went everywhere.</line>
      <line>Sir, ’t was all one! My favour at her breast,</line>
      <line>The dropping of the daylight in the West,</line>
      <line>The bough of cherries some officious fool</line>
      <line>Broke in the orchard for her, the white mule</line>
      <line>She rode with round the terrace—all and each</line>
      <line>Would draw from her alike the approving speech,</line>
      <line>Or blush, at least. She thanked men,—good! but thanked</line>
      <line>Somehow—I know not how—as if she ranked</line>
      <line>My gift of a nine-hundred-years-old name</line>
      <line>With anybody’s gift. Who’d stoop to blame</line>
      <line>This sort of trifling? Even had you skill</line>
      <line>In speech—(which I have not)—to make your will</line>
      <line>Quite clear to such an one, and say, ‘Just this</line>
      <line>‘Or that in you disgusts me; here you miss,</line>
      <line>‘Or there exceed the mark’—and if she let</line>
      <line>Herself be lessoned so, nor plainly set</line>
      <line>Her wits to yours, forsooth, and made excuse,</line>
      <line>—E’en then would be some stooping; and I choose</line>
      <line>Never to stoop. Oh sir, she smiled, no doubt,</line>
      <line>Whene’er I passed her; but who passed without</line>
      <line>Much the same smile? This grew; I gave commands;</line>
      <line>Then all smiles stopped together. There she stands</line>
      <line>As if alive. Will’t please you rise? We’ll meet</line>
      <line>The company below, then. I repeat,</line>
      <line>The Count your master’s known munificence</line>
      <line>Is ample warrant that no just pretence</line>
      <line>Of mine for dowry will be disallowed;</line>
      <line>Though his fair daughter’s self, as I avowed</line>
      <line>At starting, is my object. Nay, we’ll go</line>
      <line>Together down, sir. Notice Neptune, though,</line>
      <line>Taming a sea-horse, thought a rarity,</line>
      <line>Which Claus of Innsbruck cast in bronze for me!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1842</date>
    <title>Soliloquy of the Spanish Cloister</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gr-r-r—there go, my heart’s abhorrence!</line>
      <line>Water your damned flower-pots, do!</line>
      <line>If hate killed men, Brother Lawrence,</line>
      <line>God’s blood, would not mine kill you!</line>
      <line>What? your myrtle-bush wants trimming?</line>
      <line>Oh, that rose has prior claims—</line>
      <line>Needs its leaden vase filled brimming?</line>
      <line>Hell dry you up with its flames!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At the meal we sit together:</line>
      <line>Salve tibi! I must hear</line>
      <line>Wise talk of the kind of weather,</line>
      <line>Sort of season, time of year:</line>
      <line>Not a plenteous cork-crop: scarcely</line>
      <line>Dare we hope oak-galls, I doubt:</line>
      <line>What’s the Latin name for ‘parsley’?</line>
      <line>What’s the Greek name for Swine’s Snout?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Whew! We’ll have our platter burnished,</line>
      <line>Laid with care on our own shelf!</line>
      <line>With a fire-new spoon we’re furnished,</line>
      <line>And a goblet for ourself,</line>
      <line>Rinsed like something sacrificial</line>
      <line>Ere’t is fit to touch our chaps—</line>
      <line>Marked with L. for our initial!</line>
      <line>(He-he! There his lily snaps!)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Saint, forsooth! While brown Dolores</line>
      <line>Squats outside the Convent bank</line>
      <line>With Sanchicha, telling stories,</line>
      <line>Steeping tresses in the tank,</line>
      <line>Blue-black, lustrous, thick like horsehairs,</line>
      <line>—Can’t I see his dead eye glow,</line>
      <line>Bright as’t were a Barbary corsair’s?</line>
