      <line>(That is, if he’d let it show!)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When he finishes refection,</line>
      <line>Knife and fork he never lays</line>
      <line>Cross-wise, to my recollection,</line>
      <line>As do I, in Jesu’s praise.</line>
      <line>I the Trinity illustrate,</line>
      <line>Drinking watered orange-pulp—</line>
      <line>In three sips the Arian frustrate;</line>
      <line>While he drains his at one gulp.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, those melons? If he’s able</line>
      <line>We’re to have a feast! so nice!</line>
      <line>One goes to the Abbot’s table,</line>
      <line>All of us get each a slice.</line>
      <line>How go on your flowers? None double?</line>
      <line>Not one fruit-sort can you spy?</line>
      <line>Strange!—And I, too, at such trouble,</line>
      <line>Keep them close-nipped on the sly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s a great text in Galatians,</line>
      <line>Once you trip on it, entails</line>
      <line>Twenty-nine distinct damnations,</line>
      <line>One sure, if another fails:</line>
      <line>If I trip him just a-dying,</line>
      <line>Sure of heaven as sure can be,</line>
      <line>Spin him round and send him flying</line>
      <line>Off to hell, a Manichee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or, my scrofulous French novel</line>
      <line>On grey paper with blunt type!</line>
      <line>Simply glance at it, you grovel</line>
      <line>Hand and foot in Belial’s gripe:</line>
      <line>If I double down its pages</line>
      <line>At the woeful sixteenth print,</line>
      <line>When he gathers his greengages,</line>
      <line>Ope a sieve and slip it in’t?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or, there’s Satan!—one might venture</line>
      <line>Pledge one’s soul to him, yet leave</line>
      <line>Such a flaw in the indenture</line>
      <line>As he’d miss till, past retrieve,</line>
      <line>Blasted lay that rose-acacia</line>
      <line>We’re so proud of! Hy, Zy, Hine . . .</line>
      <line>’St, there’s Vespers! Plena gratia</line>
      <line>Ave, Virgo! Gr-r-r—you swine!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>The Bishop Orders His Tomb at Saint Praxed’s Church</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Vanity, saith the preacher, vanity!</line>
      <line>Draw round my bed: is Anselm keeping back?</line>
      <line>Nephews—sons mine ... ah God, I know not! Well—</line>
      <line>She, men would have to be your mother once,</line>
      <line>Old Gandolf envied me, so fair she was!</line>
      <line>What’s done is done, and she is dead beside,</line>
      <line>Dead long ago, and I am Bishop since,</line>
      <line>And as she died so must we die ourselves,</line>
      <line>And thence ye may perceive the world’s a dream.</line>
      <line>Life, how and what is it? As here I lie</line>
      <line>In this state-chamber, dying by degrees,</line>
      <line>Hours and long hours in the dead night, I ask</line>
      <line>‘Do I live, am I dead?’ Peace, peace seems all.</line>
      <line>Saint Praxed’s ever was the church for peace;</line>
      <line>And so, about this tomb of mine. I fought</line>
      <line>With tooth and nail to save my niche, ye know:</line>
      <line>—Old Gandolf cozened me, despite my care;</line>
      <line>Shrewd was that snatch from out the corner South</line>
      <line>He graced his carrion with, God curse the same!</line>
      <line>Yet still my niche is not so cramped but thence</line>
      <line>One sees the pulpit o’ the epistle-side,</line>
      <line>And somewhat of the choir, those silent seats,</line>
      <line>And up into the aery dome where live</line>
      <line>The angels, and a sunbeam’s sure to lurk:</line>
      <line>And I shall fill my slab of basalt there,</line>
      <line>And ’neath my tabernacle take my rest,</line>
      <line>With those nine columns round me, two and two,</line>
      <line>The odd one at my feet where Anselm stands:</line>
      <line>Peach-blossom marble all, the rare, the ripe</line>
      <line>As fresh-poured red wine of a mighty pulse.</line>
      <line>—Old Gandolf with his paltry onion-stone,</line>
      <line>Put me where I may look at him! True peach,</line>
      <line>Rosy and flawless: how I earned the prize!</line>
      <line>Draw close: that conflagration of my church</line>
      <line>—What then? So much was saved if aught were missed!</line>
      <line>My sons, ye would not be my death? Go dig</line>
      <line>The white-grape vineyard where the oil-press stood,</line>
      <line>Drop water gently till the surface sink,</line>
      <line>And if ye find ... Ah God, I know not, I! ...</line>
      <line>Bedded in store of rotten fig-leaves soft,</line>
      <line>And corded up in a tight olive-frail,</line>
      <line>Some lump, ah God, of lapis lazuli,</line>
      <line>Big as a Jew’s head cut off at the nape,</line>
      <line>Blue as a vein o’er the Madonna’s breast . ..</line>
      <line>Sons, all have I bequeathed you, villas, all,</line>
      <line>That brave Frascati villa with its bath,</line>
      <line>So, let the blue lump poise between my knees,</line>
      <line>Like God the Father’s globe on both his hands</line>
      <line>Ye worship in the Jesu Church so gay,</line>
      <line>For Gandolf shall not choose but see and burst!</line>
      <line>Swift as a weaver’s shuttle fleet our years:</line>
      <line>Man goeth to the grave, and where is he?</line>
      <line>Did I say basalt for my slab, sons? Black—</line>
      <line>’T was ever antique-black I meant! How else</line>
      <line>Shall ye contrast my frieze to come beneath?</line>
      <line>The bas-relief in bronze ye promised me,</line>
      <line>Those Pans and Nymphs ye wot of, and perchance</line>
      <line>Some tripod, thyrsus, with a vase or so,</line>
      <line>The Saviour at his sermon on the mount,</line>
      <line>Saint Praxed in a glory, and one Pan</line>
      <line>Ready to twitch the Nymph’s last garment off,</line>
      <line>And Moses with the tables . . . but I know</line>
      <line>Ye mark me not! What do they whisper thee,</line>
      <line>Child of my bowels, Anselm? Ah, ye hope</line>
      <line>To revel down my villas while I gasp</line>
      <line>Bricked o’er with beggar’s mouldy travertine</line>
      <line>Which Gandolf from his tomb-top chuckles at!</line>
      <line>Nay, boys, ye love me—all of jasper, then!</line>
      <line>’T is jasper ye stand pledged to, lest I grieve.</line>
      <line>My bath must needs be left behind, alas!</line>
      <line>One block, pure green as a pistachio-nut,</line>
      <line>There’s plenty jasper somewhere in the world—</line>
      <line>And have I not Saint Praxed’s ear to pray</line>
      <line>Horses for ye, and brown Greek manuscripts,</line>
      <line>And mistresses with great smooth marbly limbs?</line>
      <line>—That’s if ye carve my epitaph aright,</line>
      <line>Choice Latin, picked phrase, Tully’s every word,</line>
      <line>No gaudy ware like Gandolf s second line—</line>
      <line>Tully, my masters? Ulpian serves his need!</line>
      <line>And then how I shall lie through centuries,</line>
      <line>And hear the blessed mutter of the mass,</line>
      <line>And see God made and eaten all day long,</line>
      <line>And feel the steady candle-flame, and taste</line>
      <line>Good strong thick stupefying incense-smoke!</line>
      <line>For as I lie here, hours of the dead night,</line>
      <line>Dying in state and by such slow degrees,</line>
      <line>I fold my arms as if they clasped a crook,</line>
      <line>And stretch my feet forth straight as stone can point,</line>
      <line>And let the bedclothes, for a mortcloth, drop</line>
      <line>Into great laps and folds of sculptor’s-work:</line>
      <line>And as yon tapers dwindle, and strange thoughts</line>
      <line>Grow, with a certain humming in my ears,</line>
      <line>About the life before I lived this life,</line>
      <line>And this life too, popes, cardinals and priests,</line>
      <line>Saint Praxed at his sermon on the mount,</line>
      <line>Your tall pale mother with her talking eyes,</line>
      <line>And new-found agate urns as fresh as day,</line>
      <line>And marble’s language, Latin pure, discreet,</line>
      <line>—Aha, elucescebat quoth our friend?</line>
      <line>No Tully, said I, Ulpian at the best!</line>
      <line>Evil and brief hath been my pilgrimage.</line>
      <line>All lapis, all, sons! Else I give the Pope</line>
      <line>My villas! Will ye ever eat my heart?</line>
      <line>Ever your eyes were as a lizard’s quick,</line>
      <line>They glitter like your mother’s for my soul,</line>
      <line>Or ye would heighten my impoverished frieze,</line>
      <line>Piece out its starved design, and fill my vase</line>
      <line>With grapes, and add a vizor and a Term,</line>
      <line>And to the tripod ye would tie a lynx</line>
      <line>That in his struggle throws the thyrsus down,</line>
      <line>To comfort me on my entablature</line>
      <line>Whereon I am to lie till I must ask</line>
      <line>‘Do I live, am I dead?’ There, leave me, there!</line>
      <line>For ye have stabbed me with ingratitude</line>
      <line>To death—ye wish it—God, ye wish it! Stone—</line>
      <line>Gritstone, a-crumble! Clammy squares which sweat</line>
      <line>As if the corpse they keep were oozing through—</line>
      <line>And no more lapis to delight the world!</line>
      <line>Well go! I bless ye. Fewer tapers there,</line>
      <line>But in a row: and, going, turn your backs</line>
      <line>—Ay, like departing altar-ministrants,</line>
      <line>And leave me in my church, the church for peace,</line>
      <line>That I may watch at leisure if he leers—</line>
      <line>Old Gandolf, at me, from his onion-stone,</line>
      <line>As still he envied me, so fair she was!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>Home-Thoughts, from Abroad</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, to be in England,</line>
      <line>Now that April’s there,</line>
      <line>And whoever wakes in England</line>
      <line>Sees, some morning, unaware,</line>
      <line>That the lowest boughs and the brushwood sheaf</line>
      <line>Round the elm-tree bole are in tiny leaf,</line>
      <line>While the chaffinch sings on the orchard bough</line>
      <line>In England—now!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And after April, when May follows,</line>
      <line>And the whitethroat builds, and all the swallows!</line>
      <line>Hark, where my blossomed pear-tree in the hedge</line>
      <line>Leans to the field and scatters on the clover</line>
      <line>Blossoms and dewdrops—at the bent spray’s edge—</line>
      <line>That’s the wise thrush; he sings each song twice over,</line>
      <line>Lest you should think he never could recapture</line>
      <line>The first fine careless rapture!</line>
      <line>And though the fields look rough with hoary dew</line>
      <line>All will be gay when noontide wakes anew</line>
      <line>The buttercups, the little children’s dower</line>
      <line>—Far brighter than this gaudy melon-flower!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>Meeting at Night</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The grey sea and the long black land;</line>
      <line>And the yellow half-moon large and low;</line>
      <line>And the startled little waves that leap</line>
      <line>In fiery ringlets from their sleep,</line>
      <line>As I gain the cove with pushing prow,</line>
      <line>And quench its speed i’ the slushy sand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then a mile of warm sea-scented beach;</line>
      <line>Three fields to cross till a farm appears;</line>
      <line>A tap at the pane, the quick sharp scratch</line>
      <line>And blue spurt of a lighted match,</line>
      <line>And a voice less loud, thro’ its joys and fears,</line>
      <line>Than the two hearts beating each to each!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1851</date>
    <title>Memorabilia</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, did you once see Shelley plain,</line>
      <line>And did he stop and speak to you</line>
      <line>And did you speak to him again?</line>
      <line>How strange it seems and new!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But you were living before that,</line>
      <line>And also you are living after;</line>
      <line>And the memory I started at—</line>
      <line>My starting moves your laughter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I crossed a moor, with a name of its own</line>
      <line>And a certain use in the world no doubt,</line>
      <line>Yet a hand’s-breadth of it shines alone</line>
      <line>’Mid the blank miles round about:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For there I picked up on the heather</line>
      <line>And there I put inside my breast</line>
      <line>A moulted feather, an eagle-feather!</line>
      <line>Well, I forget the rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>Andrea del Sarto</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>But do not let us quarrel any more,</line>
      <line>No, my Lucrezia; bear with me for once:</line>
      <line>Sit down and all shall happen as you wish.</line>
      <line>You turn your face, but does it bring your heart?</line>
      <line>I’ll work then for your friend’s friend, never fear,</line>
      <line>Treat his own subject after his own way,</line>
      <line>Fix his own time, accept too his own price,</line>
      <line>And shut the money into this small hand</line>
      <line>When next it takes mine. Will it? tenderly?</line>
      <line>Oh, I’ll content him,—but to-morrow, Love!</line>
      <line>I often am much wearier than you think,</line>
      <line>This evening more than usual, and it seems</line>
      <line>As if—forgive now—should you let me sit</line>
      <line>Here by the window with your hand in mine</line>
      <line>And look a half-hour forth on Fiesole,</line>
      <line>Both of one mind, as married people use,</line>
      <line>Quietly, quietly the evening through,</line>
      <line>I might get up to-morrow to my work</line>
      <line>Cheerful and fresh as ever. Let us try.</line>
      <line>To-morrow, how you shall be glad for this!</line>
      <line>Your soft hand is a woman of itself,</line>
      <line>And mine the man’s bared breast she curls inside.</line>
      <line>Don’t count the time lost, neither; you must serve</line>
      <line>For each of the five pictures we require:</line>
      <line>It saves a model. So! keep looking so—</line>
      <line>My serpentining beauty, rounds on rounds!</line>
      <line>—How could you ever prick those perfect ears,</line>
      <line>Even to put the pearl there! oh, so sweet—</line>
      <line>My face, my moon, my everybody’s moon,</line>
      <line>Which everybody looks on and calls his,</line>
      <line>And, I suppose, is looked on by in turn,</line>
      <line>While she looks—no one’s: very dear, no less.</line>
      <line>You smile? why, there’s my picture ready made,</line>
      <line>There’s what we painters call our harmony!</line>
      <line>A common greyness silvers everything,—</line>
      <line>All in a twilight, you and I alike</line>
      <line>—You, at the point of your first pride in me</line>
      <line>(That’s gone you know),—but I, at every point;</line>
      <line>My youth, my hope, my art, being all toned down</line>
      <line>To yonder sober pleasant Fiesole.</line>
      <line>There’s the bell clinking from the chapel-top;</line>
      <line>That length of convent-wall across the way</line>
      <line>Holds the trees safer, huddled more inside;</line>
      <line>The last monk leaves the garden; days decrease,</line>
      <line>And autumn grows, autumn in everything.</line>
      <line>Eh? the whole seems to fall into a shape</line>
      <line>As if I saw alike my work and self</line>
      <line>And all that I was born to be and do,</line>
      <line>A twilight-piece. Love, we are in God’s hand.</line>
      <line>How strange now, looks the life he makes us lead;</line>
      <line>So free we seem, so fettered fast we are!</line>
      <line>I feel he laid the fetter: let it lie!</line>
      <line>This chamber for example—turn your head—</line>
      <line>All that’s behind us! You don’t understand</line>
      <line>Nor care to understand about my art,</line>
      <line>But you can hear at least when people speak:</line>
      <line>And that cartoon, the second from the door</line>
      <line>—It is the thing, Love! so such things should be—</line>
      <line>Behold Madonna!—I am bold to say.</line>
      <line>1 can do with my pencil what I know,</line>
      <line>What I see, what at bottom of my heart</line>
      <line>I wish for, if I ever wish so deep—</line>
      <line>Do easily, too—what I say, perfectly,</line>
      <line>I do not boast, perhaps: yourself are judge,</line>
      <line>Who listened to the Legate’s talk last week,</line>
      <line>And just as much they used to say in France.</line>
      <line>At any rate’t is easy, all of it!</line>
      <line>No sketches first, no studies, that’s long past:</line>
      <line>I do what many dream of, all their lives,</line>
      <line>—Dream? strive to do, and agonize to do,</line>
      <line>And fail in doing. I could count twenty such</line>
      <line>On twice your fingers, and not leave this town,</line>
      <line>Who strive—you don’t know how the others strive</line>
      <line>To paint a little thing like that you smeared</line>
      <line>Carelessly passing with your robes afloat,—</line>
      <line>Yet do much less, so much less, Someone says,</line>
      <line>(I know his name, no matter)—so much less!</line>
      <line>Well, less is more, Lucrezia: I am judged.</line>
      <line>There burns a truer light of God in them,</line>
      <line>In their vexed beating stuffed and stopped-up brain,</line>
      <line>Heart, or whate’er else, than goes on to prompt</line>
      <line>This low-pulsed forthright craftsman’s hand of mine.</line>
      <line>Their works drop groundward, but themselves, I know,</line>
      <line>Reach many a time a heaven that’s shut to me,</line>
      <line>Enter and take their place there sure enough,</line>
      <line>Though they come back and cannot tell the world.</line>
      <line>My works are nearer heaven, but I sit here.</line>
      <line>The sudden blood of these men! at a word—</line>
      <line>Praise them, it boils, or blame them, it boils too.</line>
      <line>I, painting from myself and to myself,</line>
      <line>Know what I do, am unmoved by men’s blame</line>
      <line>Or their praise either. Somebody remarks</line>
      <line>Morello’s outline there is wrongly traced,</line>
      <line>His hue mistaken; what of that? or else,</line>
      <line>Rightly traced and well ordered; what of that?</line>
      <line>Speak as they please, what does the mountain care?</line>
      <line>Ah, but a man’s reach should exceed his grasp,</line>
      <line>Or what’s a heaven for? All is silver-grey</line>
      <line>Placid and perfect with my art: the worse!</line>
      <line>I know both what I want and what might gain,</line>
      <line>And yet how profitless to know, to sigh</line>
      <line>‘Had I been two, another and myself,</line>
      <line>‘Our head would have o’erlooked the world!’ No doubt.</line>
      <line>Yonder’s a work now, of that famous youth</line>
      <line>The Urbinate who died five years ago.</line>
      <line>(’T is copied, George Vasari sent it me.)</line>
      <line>Well, I can fancy how he did it all,</line>
      <line>Pouring his soul, with kings and popes to see,</line>
      <line>Reaching, that heaven might so replenish him,</line>
      <line>Above and through his art—for it gives way;</line>
      <line>That arm is wrongly put—and there again—</line>
      <line>A fault to pardon in the drawing’s lines,</line>
      <line>Its body, so to speak: its soul is right,</line>
      <line>He means right—that, a child may understand.</line>
      <line>Still, what an arm! and I could alter it:</line>
      <line>But all the play, the insight and the stretch—</line>
      <line>Out of me, out of me! And wherefore out?</line>
      <line>Had you enjoined them on me, given me soul,</line>
      <line>We might have risen to Rafael, I and you!</line>
      <line>Nay, Love, you did give all I asked, I think—</line>
      <line>More than I merit, yes, by many times.</line>
      <line>But had you—oh, with the same perfect brow,</line>
      <line>And perfect eyes, and more than perfect mouth,</line>
      <line>And the low voice my soul hears, as a bird</line>
      <line>The fowler’s pipe, and follows to the snare—</line>
      <line>Had you, with these the same, but brought a mind!</line>
      <line>Some women do so. Had the mouth there urged</line>
      <line>‘God and the glory! never care for gain.</line>
      <line>‘The present by the future, what is that?</line>
      <line>‘Live for fame, side by side with Agnolo!</line>
      <line>‘Rafael is waiting: up to God, all three!’</line>
      <line>I might have done it for you. So it seems:</line>
      <line>Perhaps not. All is as God over-rules.</line>
      <line>Beside, incentives come from the soul’s self;</line>
      <line>The rest avail not. Why do I need you?</line>
      <line>What wife had Rafael, or has Agnolo?</line>
      <line>In this world, who can do a thing, will not;</line>
      <line>And who would do it, cannot, I perceive:</line>
      <line>Yet the will’s somewhat—somewhat, too, the power—</line>
      <line>And thus we half-men struggle. At the end,</line>
      <line>God, I conclude, compensates, punishes.</line>
      <line>’T is safer for me, if the award be strict,</line>
      <line>That I am something underrated here,</line>
      <line>Poor this long while, despised, to speak the truth.</line>
      <line>I dared not, do you know, leave home all day,</line>
      <line>For fear of chancing on the Paris lords.</line>
      <line>The best is when they pass and look aside;</line>
      <line>But they speak sometimes; I must bear it all.</line>
      <line>Well may they speak! That Francis, that first time,</line>
      <line>And that long festal year at Fontainebleau!</line>
      <line>I surely then could sometimes leave the ground,</line>
      <line>Put on the glory, Rafael’s daily wear,</line>
      <line>In that humane great monarch’s golden look,—</line>
      <line>One finger in his beard or twisted curl</line>
      <line>Over his mouth’s good mark that made the smile,</line>
      <line>One arm about my shoulder, round my neck,</line>
      <line>The jingle of his gold chain in my ear,</line>
      <line>I painting proudly with his breath on me,</line>
      <line>All his court round him, seeing with his eyes,</line>
      <line>Such frank French eyes, and such a fire of souls</line>
      <line>Profuse, my hand kept plying by those hearts,—</line>
      <line>And, best of all, this, this, this face beyond,</line>
      <line>This in the background, waiting on my work,</line>
      <line>To crown the issue with a last reward!</line>
      <line>A good time, was it not, my kingly days?</line>
      <line>And had you not grown restless . . . but I know—</line>
      <line>’T is done and past; ’t was right, my instinct said;</line>
      <line>Too live the life grew, golden and not grey,</line>
      <line>And I’m the weak-eyed bat no sun should tempt</line>
      <line>Out of the grange whose four walls make his world.</line>
      <line>Flow could it end in any other way?</line>
      <line>You called me, and I came home to your heart.</line>
      <line>The triumph was—to reach and stay there; since</line>
      <line>I reached it ere the triumph, what is lost?</line>
      <line>Let my hands frame your face in your hair’s gold,</line>
      <line>You beautiful Lucrezia that are mine!</line>
      <line>‘Rafael did this, Andrea painted that;</line>
      <line>‘The Roman’s is the better when you pray,</line>
      <line>‘But still the other’s Virgin was his wife—’</line>
      <line>Men will excuse me. I am glad to judge</line>
      <line>Both pictures in your presence; clearer grows</line>
      <line>My better fortune, I resolve to think.</line>
      <line>For do you know, Lucrezia, as God lives,</line>
      <line>Said one day Agnolo, his very self,</line>
      <line>To Rafael ... I have known it all these years ...</line>
      <line>(When the young man was flaming out his thoughts</line>
      <line>Upon a palace-wall for Rome to see,</line>
      <line>Too lifted up in heart because of it)</line>
      <line>‘Friend, there’s a certain sorry little scrub</line>
      <line>‘Goes up and down our Florence, none cares how,</line>
      <line>‘Who, were he set to plan and execute</line>
      <line>‘As you are, pricked on by your popes and kings,</line>
      <line>‘Would bring the sweat into that brow of yours!’</line>
      <line>To Rafael’s!—And indeed the arm is wrong.</line>
      <line>I hardly dare ... yet, only you to see,</line>
      <line>Give the chalk here—quick, thus the line should go!</line>
      <line>Ay, but the soul! he’s Rafael! rub it out!</line>
      <line>Still, all I care for, if he spoke the truth,</line>
      <line>(What he? why, who but Michel Agnolo?</line>
      <line>Do you forget already words like those?)</line>
      <line>If really there was such a chance, so lost,—</line>
      <line>Is, whether you’re—not grateful—but more pleased.</line>
      <line>Well, let me think so. And you smile indeed!</line>
      <line>This hour has been an hour! Another smile?</line>
      <line>If you would sit thus by me every night</line>
      <line>I should work better, do you comprehend?</line>
      <line>I mean that I should earn more, give you more.</line>
      <line>See, it is settled dusk now; there’s a star;</line>
      <line>Morello’s gone, the watch-lights show the wall,</line>
      <line>The cue-owls speak the name we call them by.</line>
      <line>Come from the window, love,—come in, at last,</line>
      <line>Inside the melancholy little house</line>
      <line>We built to be so gay with. God is just.</line>
      <line>King Francis may forgive me: oft at nights</line>
      <line>When I look up from painting, eyes tired out,</line>
      <line>The walls become illumined, brick from brick</line>
      <line>Distinct, instead of mortar, fierce bright gold,</line>
      <line>That gold of his I did cement them with!</line>
      <line>Let us but love each other. Must you go?</line>
      <line>That Cousin here again? he waits outside?</line>
      <line>Must see you—you, and not with me? Those loans?</line>
      <line>More gaming debts to pay? you smiled for that?</line>
      <line>Well, let smiles buy me! have you more to spend?</line>
      <line>While hand and eye and something of a heart</line>
      <line>Are left me, work’s my ware, and what’s it worth?</line>
      <line>I’ll pay my fancy. Only let me sit</line>
      <line>The grey remainder of the evening out,</line>
      <line>Idle, you call it, and muse perfectly</line>
      <line>How I could paint, were I but back in France,</line>
      <line>One picture, just one more—the Virgin’s face,</line>
      <line>Not yours this time! I want you at my side</line>
      <line>To hear them—that is, Michel Agnolo—</line>
      <line>Judge all I do and tell you of its worth.</line>
      <line>Will you? To-morrow, satisfy your friend.</line>
      <line>I take the subjects for his corridor,</line>
      <line>Finish the portrait out of hand—there, there,</line>
      <line>And throw him in another thing or two</line>
      <line>If he demurs; the whole should prove enough</line>
      <line>To pay for this same Cousin’s freak. Beside,</line>
      <line>What’s better and what’s all I care about,</line>
      <line>Get you the thirteen scudi for the ruff!</line>
      <line>Love, does that please you? Ah, but what does he,</line>
      <line>The Cousin! what does he to please you more?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am grown peaceful as old age to-night.</line>
      <line>I regret little, I would change still less.</line>
      <line>Since there my past life lies, why alter it?</line>
      <line>The very wrong to Francis!—it is true</line>
      <line>I took his coin, was tempted and complied,</line>
      <line>And built this house and sinned, and all is said.</line>
      <line>My father and my mother died of want.</line>
      <line>Well, had I riches of my own? you see</line>
      <line>How one gets rich! Let each one bear his lot.</line>
      <line>They were born poor, lived poor, and poor they died:</line>
      <line>And I have laboured somewhat in my time</line>
      <line>And not been paid profusely. Some good son</line>
      <line>Paint my two hundred pictures—let him try!</line>
      <line>No doubt, there’s something strikes a balance. Yes,</line>
      <line>You loved me quite enough, it seems to-night.</line>
      <line>This must suffice me here. What would one have?</line>
      <line>In heaven, perhaps, new chances, one more chance—</line>
      <line>Four great walls in the New Jerusalem,</line>
      <line>Meted on each side by the angel’s reed,</line>
      <line>For Leonard, Rafael, Agnolo and me</line>
      <line>To cover—the three first without a wife,</line>
      <line>While I have mine! So—still they overcome</line>
      <line>Because there’s still Lucrezia,—as I choose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Again the Cousin’s whistle! Go, my Love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Two in the Campagna</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wonder do you feel to-day</line>
      <line>As I have felt since, hand in hand,</line>
      <line>We sat down on the grass, to stray</line>
      <line>In spirit better through the land,</line>
      <line>This morn of Rome and May?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For me, I touched a thought, I know,</line>
      <line>Has tantalized me many times,</line>
      <line>(Like turns of thread the spiders throw</line>
      <line>Mocking across our path) for rhymes</line>
      <line>To catch at and let go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Help me to hold it! First it left</line>
      <line>The yellowing fennel, run to seed</line>
      <line>There, branching from the brickwork’s cleft,</line>
      <line>Some old tomb’s ruin: yonder weed</line>
      <line>Took up the floating weft,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where one small orange cup amassed</line>
      <line>Five beetles,—blind and green they grope</line>
      <line>Among the honey-meal: and last,</line>
      <line>Everywhere on the grassy slope</line>
      <line>I traced it. Hold it fast!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The champaign with its endless fleece</line>
      <line>Of feathery grasses everywhere!</line>
      <line>Silence and passion, joy and peace,</line>
      <line>An everlasting wash of air—</line>
      <line>Rome’s ghost since her decease.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such life here, through such lengths of hours,</line>
      <line>Such miracles performed in play,</line>
      <line>Such primal naked forms of flowers,</line>
      <line>Such letting nature have her way</line>
      <line>While heaven looks from its towers!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How say you? Let us, O my dove,</line>
      <line>Let us be unashamed of soul,</line>
      <line>As earth lies bare to heaven above!</line>
      <line>How is it under our control</line>
      <line>To love or not to love?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I would that you were all to me,</line>
      <line>You that are just so much, no more.</line>
      <line>Nor yours nor mine, nor slave nor free!</line>
      <line>Where does the fault lie? What the core</line>
      <line>O’ the wound, since wound must be?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I would I could adopt your will,</line>
      <line>See with your eyes, and set my heart</line>
      <line>Beating by yours, and drink my fill</line>
      <line>At your soul’s springs,—your part my part</line>
      <line>In life, for good and ill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No. I yearn upward, touch you close,</line>
      <line>Then stand away. I kiss your cheek,</line>
      <line>Catch your soul’s warmth,—I pluck the rose</line>
      <line>And love it more than tongue can speak—</line>
      <line>Then the good minute goes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Already how am I so far</line>
      <line>Out of that minute? Must I go</line>
      <line>Still like the thistle-ball, no bar,</line>
      <line>Onward, whenever light winds blow</line>
      <line>Fixed by no friendly star?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Just when I seemed about to learn!</line>
      <line>Where is the thread now? Off again!</line>
      <line>The old trick! Only I discern—</line>
      <line>Infinite passion, and the pain</line>
      <line>Of finite hearts that yearn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>Love in a Life</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Room after room,</line>
      <line>I hunt the house through</line>
      <line>We inhabit together.</line>
      <line>Heart, fear nothing, for, heart, thou shalt find her—</line>
      <line>Next time, herself!—not the trouble behind her</line>
      <line>Left in the curtain, the couch’s perfume!</line>
      <line>As she brushed it, the cornice-wreath blossomed anew:</line>
      <line>Yon looking-glass gleamed at the wave of her feather.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet the day wears,</line>
      <line>And door succeeds door;</line>
      <line>I try the fresh fortune—</line>
      <line>Range the wide house from the wing to the centre.</line>
      <line>Still the same chance! she goes out as I enter.</line>
      <line>Spend my whole day in the quest,—who cares?</line>
      <line>But’t is twilight, you see,—with such suites to explore,</line>
      <line>Such closets to search, such alcoves to importune!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>A Toccata of Galuppi’s</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Galuppi, Baldassaro, this is very sad to find!</line>
      <line>I can hardly misconceive you; it would prove me deaf and blind;</line>
      <line>But although I take your meaning, ’t is with such a heavy mind!</line>
      <line>Here you come with your old music, and here’s all the good it brings.</line>
      <line>What, they lived once thus at Venice where the merchants were the kings,</line>
      <line>Where Saint Mark’s is, where the Doges used to wed the sea with rings?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ay, because the sea’s the street there; and’t is arched by ... what you call</line>
      <line>. . Shylock’s bridge with houses on it, where they kept the carnival:</line>
      <line>I was never out of England—it’s as if I saw it all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Did young people take their pleasure when the sea was warm in May?</line>
      <line>Balls and masks begun at midnight, burning ever to midday,</line>
      <line>When they made up fresh adventures for the morrow, do you say?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Was a lady such a lady, cheeks so round and lips so red,—</line>
      <line>On her neck the small face buoyant, like a bell-flower on its bed,</line>
      <line>O’er the breast’s superb abundance where a man might base his head?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, and it was graceful of them—they’d break talk off and afford</line>
      <line>—She, to bite her mask’s black velvet—he, to finger on his sword,</line>
      <line>While you sat and played Toccatas, stately at the clavichord?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What? Those lesser thirds so plaintive, sixths diminished, sigh on sigh,</line>
      <line>Told them something? Those suspensions, those solutions—‘Must we die?’</line>
      <line>Those commiserating sevenths—‘Life might last! we can but try!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Were you happy?’—‘Yes’—‘And are you still as happy?’—‘Yes. And you?’</line>
      <line>—‘Then, more kisses!’—‘Did / stop them, when a million seemed so few?’</line>
      <line>Hark, the dominant’s persistence till it must be answered to!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, an octave struck the answer. Oh, they praised you, I dare say!</line>
      <line>‘Brave Galuppi! that was music! good alike at grave and gay!</line>
      <line>‘I can always leave off talking when I hear a master play!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then they left you for their pleasure: till in due time, one by one,</line>
      <line>Some with lives that came to nothing, some with deeds as well undone,</line>
      <line>Death stepped tacitly and took them where they never see the sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when I sit down to reason, think to take my stand nor swerve,</line>
      <line>While I triumph o’er a secret wrung from nature’s close reserve,</line>
      <line>In you come with your cold music till I creep thro’ every nerve.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, you, like a ghosdy cricket, creaking where a house was burned:</line>
      <line>‘Dust and ashes, dead and done with, Venice spent what Venice earned.</line>
      <line>‘The soul, doubtless, is immortal—where a soul can be discerned.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Yours for instance: you know physics, something of geology,</line>
      <line>‘Mathematics are your pastime; souls shall rise in their degree;</line>
      <line>‘Butterflies may dread extinction,—you’ll not die, it cannot be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘As for Venice and her people, merely born to bloom and drop,</line>
      <line>‘Here on earth they bore their fruitage, mirth and folly were the crop:</line>
      <line>‘What of soul was left, I wonder, when the kissing had to stop?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Dust and ashes!’ So you creak it, and I want the heart to scold.</line>
      <line>Dear dead women, with such hair, too—what’s become of all the gold</line>
      <line>Used to hang and brush their bosoms? I feel chilly and grown old.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>‘Childe Roland to the Dark Tower Came’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My first thought was, he lied in every word,</line>
      <line>That hoary cripple, with malicious eye</line>
      <line>Askance to watch the working of his lie</line>
      <line>On mine, and mouth scarce able to afford</line>
      <line>Suppression of the glee, that pursed and scored</line>
      <line>Its edge, at one more victim gained thereby.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What else should he be set for, with his staff?</line>
      <line>Wfiat, save to waylay with his lies, ensnare</line>
      <line>All travellers who might find him posted there,</line>
      <line>And ask the road? I guessed what skull-like laugh</line>
      <line>Would break, what crutch ’gin write my epitaph</line>
      <line>For pastime in the dusty thoroughfare,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If at his counsel I should turn aside</line>
      <line>Into that ominous tract which, all agree,</line>
      <line>Hides the Dark Tower. Yet acquiescingly</line>
      <line>I did turn as he pointed: neither pride</line>
      <line>Nor hope rekindling at the end descried,</line>
      <line>So much as gladness that some end might be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For, what with my whole world-wide wandering,</line>
      <line>What with my search drawn out thro’ years, my hope</line>
      <line>Dwindled into a ghost not fit to cope</line>
      <line>With that obstreperous joy success would bring,—</line>
      <line>I hardly tried now to rebuke the spring</line>
      <line>My heart made, finding failure in its scope.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As when a sick man very near to death</line>
      <line>Seems dead indeed, and feels begin and end</line>
      <line>The tears and takes the farewell of each friend,</line>
      <line>And hears one bid the other go, draw breath</line>
      <line>Freelier outside, (‘since all is o’er,’ he saith,</line>
      <line>‘And the blow fallen no grieving can amend;’)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While some discuss if near the other graves</line>
      <line>Be room enough for this, and when a day</line>
      <line>Suits best for carrying the corpse away,</line>
      <line>With care about the banners, scarves and staves:</line>
      <line>And still the man hears all, and only craves</line>
      <line>He may not shame such tender love and stay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus, I had so long suffered in this quest,</line>
      <line>Heard failure prophesied so oft, been writ</line>
      <line>So many times among ‘The Band’—to wit,</line>
      <line>The knights who to the Dark Tower’s search addressed</line>
      <line>Their steps—that just to fail as they, seemed best,</line>
      <line>And all the doubt was now—should I be fit?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, quiet as despair, I turned from him,</line>
      <line>That hateful cripple, out of his highway</line>
      <line>Into the path he pointed. All the day</line>
      <line>Had been a dreary one at best, and dim</line>
      <line>Was settling to its close, yet shot one grim</line>
      <line>Red leer to see the plain catch its estray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For mark! no sooner was I fairly found</line>
      <line>Pledged to the plain, after a pace or two,</line>
      <line>Than, pausing to throw backward a last view</line>
      <line>O’er the safe road, ’t was gone; grey plain all round:</line>
      <line>Nothing but plain to the horizon’s bound.</line>
      <line>I might go on; nought else remained to do.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, on I went. I think I never saw</line>
      <line>Such starved ignoble nature; nothing throve:</line>
      <line>For flowers—as well expect a cedar grove!</line>
      <line>But cockle, spurge, according to their law</line>
      <line>Might propagate their kind, with none to awe,</line>
      <line>You’d think; a burr had been a treasure-trove.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No! penury, inertness and grimace,</line>
      <line>In some strange sort, were the land’s portion. ‘See</line>
      <line>‘Or shut your eyes,’ said Nature peevishly,</line>
      <line>‘It nothing skills: I cannot help my case:</line>
      <line>"T is the Last Judgment’s fire must cure this place,</line>
      <line>‘Calcine its clods and set my prisoners free.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If there pushed any ragged thistle-stalk</line>
      <line>Above its mates, the head was chopped; the bents</line>
      <line>Were jealous else. What made those holes and rents</line>
      <line>In the dock’s harsh swarth leaves, bruised as to baulk</line>
      <line>All hope of greenness? ’t is a brute must walk</line>
      <line>Pashing their life out, with a brute’s intents.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As for the grass, it grew as scant as hair</line>
      <line>In leprosy; thin dry blades pricked the mud</line>
      <line>Which underneath looked kneaded up with blood.</line>
      <line>One stiff blind horse, his every bone a-stare,</line>
      <line>Stood stupefied, however he came there:</line>
      <line>Thrust out past service from the devil’s stud!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alive? he might be dead for aught I know,</line>
      <line>With that red gaunt and colloped neck a-strain,</line>
      <line>And shut eyes underneath the rusty mane;</line>
      <line>Seldom went such grotesqueness with such woe;</line>
      <line>I never saw a brute I hated so;</line>
      <line>He must be wicked to deserve such pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I shut my eyes and turned them on my heart.</line>
      <line>As a man calls for wine before he fights,</line>
      <line>I asked one draught of earlier, happier sights,</line>
      <line>Ere fitly I could hope to play my part.</line>
      <line>Think first, fight afterwards—the soldier’s art:</line>
      <line>One taste of the old time sets all to rights.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not it! I fancied Cuthbert’s reddening face</line>
      <line>Beneath its garniture of curly gold,</line>
      <line>Dear fellow, till I almost felt him fold</line>
      <line>An arm in mine to fix me to the place,</line>
      <line>That way he used. Alas, one night’s disgrace!</line>
      <line>Out went my heart’s new fire and left it cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Giles then, the soul of honour—there he stands</line>
      <line>Frank as ten years ago when knighted first.</line>
      <line>What honest man should dare (he said) he durst.</line>
      <line>Good—but the scene shifts—faugh! what hangman-hands</line>
      <line>Pin to his breast a parchment? His own bands</line>
      <line>Read it. Poor traitor, spit upon and curst!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Better this present than a past like that;</line>
      <line>Back therefore to my darkening path again!</line>
      <line>No sound, no sight as far as eye could strain.</line>
      <line>Will the night send a howlet or a bat?</line>
      <line>I asked: when something on the dismal flat</line>
      <line>Came to arrest my thoughts and change their train.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A sudden little river crossed my path</line>
      <line>As unexpected as a serpent comes.</line>
      <line>No sluggish tide congenial to the glooms;</line>
      <line>This, as it frothed by, might have been a bath</line>
      <line>For the fiend’s glowing hoof—to see the wrath</line>
      <line>Of its black eddy bespate with flakes and spumes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So petty yet so spiteful! All along,</line>
      <line>Low scrubby alders kneeled down over it;</line>
      <line>Drenched willows flung them headlong in a fit</line>
      <line>Of mute despair, a suicidal throng:</line>
      <line>The river which had done them all the wrong,</line>
      <line>Whate’er that was, rolled by, deterred no whit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Which, while I forded,—good saints, how I feared</line>
      <line>To set my foot upon a dead man’s cheek,</line>
      <line>Each step, or feel the spear I thrust to seek</line>
      <line>For hollows, tangled in his hair or beard!</line>
      <line>—It may have been a water-rat I speared,</line>
      <line>But, ugh! it sounded like a baby’s shriek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Glad was I when I reached the other bank.</line>
      <line>Now for a better country. Vain presage!</line>
      <line>Who were the strugglers, what war did they wage,</line>
      <line>Whose savage trample thus could pad the dank</line>
      <line>Soil to a plash? Toads in a poisoned tank,</line>
      <line>Or wild cats in a red-hot iron cage—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fight must so have seemed in that fell cirque.</line>
      <line>What penned them there, with all the plain to choose?</line>
      <line>No foot-print leading to that horrid mews,</line>
      <line>None out of it. Mad brewage set to work</line>
      <line>Their brains, no doubt, like galley-slaves the Turk</line>
      <line>Pits for his pastime, Christians against Jews.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And more than that—a furlong on—why, there!</line>
      <line>What bad use was that engine for, that wheel,</line>
      <line>Or brake, not wheel—that harrow fit to reel</line>
      <line>Men’s bodies out like silk? with all the air</line>
      <line>Of Tophet’s tool, on earth left unaware,</line>
      <line>Or brought to sharpen its rusty teeth of steel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then came a bit of stubbed ground, once a wood,</line>
      <line>Next a marsh, it would seem, and now mere earth</line>
      <line>Desperate and done with; (so a fool finds mirth,</line>
      <line>Makes a thing and then mars it, till his mood</line>
      <line>Changes and off he goes!) within a rood—</line>
      <line>Bog, clay and rubble, sand and stark black dearth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now blotches rankling, coloured gay and grim,</line>
      <line>Now patches where some leanness of the soil’s</line>
      <line>Broke into moss or substances like boils;</line>
      <line>Then came some palsied oak, a cleft in him</line>
      <line>Like a distorted mouth that splits its rim</line>
      <line>Gaping at death, and dies while it recoils.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And just as far as ever from the end!</line>
      <line>Nought in the distance but the evening, nought</line>
      <line>To point my footstep further! At the thought,</line>
      <line>A great black bird, Apollyon’s bosom-friend,</line>
      <line>Sailed past, nor beat his wide wing dragon-penned</line>
      <line>That brushed my cap—perchance the guide I sought.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For, looking up, aware I somehow grew,</line>
      <line>’Spite of the dusk, the plain had given place</line>
      <line>All round to mountains—with such name to grace</line>
      <line>Mere ugly heights and heaps now stolen in view.</line>
      <line>How thus they had surprised me,—solve it, you!</line>
      <line>How to get from them was no clearer case.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet half I seemed to recognize some trick</line>
      <line>Of mischief happened to me, God knows when—</line>
      <line>In a bad dream perhaps. Here ended, then,</line>
      <line>Progress this way. When, in the very nick</line>
      <line>Of giving up, one time more, came a click</line>
      <line>As when a trap shuts—you’re inside the den!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Burningly it came on me all at once,</line>
      <line>This was the place! those two hills on the right,</line>
      <line>Crouched like two bulls locked horn in horn in light;</line>
      <line>While to the left, a tall scalped mountain ... Dunce,</line>
      <line>Dotard, a-dozing at the very nonce,</line>
      <line>After a life spent training for the sight!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What in the midst lay but the Tower itself?</line>
      <line>The round squat turret, blind as the fool’s heart,</line>
      <line>Built of brown stone, without a counterpart</line>
      <line>In the whole world. The tempest’s mocking elf</line>
      <line>Points to the shipman thus the unseen shelf</line>
      <line>He strikes on, only when the timbers start.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not see? because of night perhaps?—why, day</line>
      <line>Came back again for that! before it left,</line>
      <line>The dying sunset kindled through a cleft:</line>
      <line>The hills, like giants at a hunting, lay,</line>
      <line>Chin upon hand, to see the game at bay,—</line>
      <line>‘Now stab and end the creature—to the heft!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not hear? when noise was everywhere! it tolled</line>
      <line>Increasing like a bell. Names in my ears</line>
      <line>Of all the lost adventurers my peers,—</line>
      <line>How such a one was strong, and such was bold,</line>
      <line>And such was fortunate, yet each of old</line>
      <line>Lost, lost! one moment knelled the woe of years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There they stood, ranged along the hill-sides, met</line>
      <line>To view the last of me, a living frame</line>
      <line>For one more picture! in a sheet of flame</line>
      <line>I saw them and I knew them all. And yet</line>
      <line>Dauntless the slug-horn to my lips I set,</line>
      <line>And blew. ‘Childe Roland to the Dark Tower came.'</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>A Grammarian’s Funeral</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us begin and carry up this corpse,</line>
      <line>Singing together.</line>
      <line>Leave we the common crofts, the vulgar thorpes</line>
      <line>Each in its tether</line>
      <line>Sleeping safe on the bosom of the plain,</line>
      <line>Cared-for till cock-crow:</line>
      <line>Look out if yonder be not day again</line>
      <line>Rimming the rock-row!</line>
      <line>That’s the appropriate country: there, man’s thought,</line>
      <line>Rarer, intenser,</line>
      <line>Self-gathered for an outbreak, as it ought,</line>
      <line>Chafes in the censer.</line>
      <line>Leave we the unlettered plain its herd and crop;</line>
      <line>Seek we sepulture</line>
      <line>On a tall mountain, citied to the top,</line>
      <line>Crowded with culture!</line>
      <line>All the peaks soar, but one the rest excels;</line>
      <line>Clouds overcome it;</line>
      <line>No! yonder sparkle is the citadel’s</line>
      <line>Circling its summit.</line>
      <line>Thither our path lies; wind we up the heights:</line>
      <line>Wait ye the warning?</line>
      <line>Our low life was the level’s and the night’s;</line>
      <line>He’s for the morning.</line>
      <line>Step to a tune, square chests, erect each head,</line>
      <line>’Ware the beholders!</line>
      <line>This is our master, famous calm and dead,</line>
      <line>Borne on our shoulders.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep, crop and herd! sleep, darkling thorpe and croft,</line>
      <line>Safe from the weather!</line>
      <line>He, whom we convoy to his grave aloft,</line>
      <line>Singing together,</line>
      <line>He was a man born with thy face and throat,</line>
      <line>Lyric Apollo!</line>
      <line>Long he lived nameless: how should spring take note</line>
      <line>Winter would follow?</line>
      <line>Till lo, the little touch, and youth was gone!</line>
      <line>Cramped and diminished,</line>
      <line>Moaned he, ‘New measures, other feet anon!</line>
      <line>‘My dance is finished?’</line>
      <line>No, that’s the world’s way: (keep the mountain-side,</line>
      <line>Make for the city!)</line>
      <line>He knew the signal, and stepped on with pride</line>
      <line>Over men’s pity;</line>
      <line>Left play for work, and grappled with the world</line>
      <line>Bent on escaping:</line>
      <line>‘What’s in the scroll,’ quoth he, ‘thou keepest furled?</line>
      <line>‘Show me their shaping,</line>
      <line>‘Theirs who most studied man, the bard and sage,—</line>
      <line>‘Give!’—So, he gowned him,</line>
      <line>Straight got by heart that book to its last page:</line>
      <line>Learned, we found him.</line>
      <line>Yea, but we found him bald too, eyes like lead,</line>
      <line>Accents uncertain:</line>
      <line>‘Time to taste life,’ another would have said,</line>
      <line>‘Up with the curtain!’</line>
      <line>This man said rather, ‘Actual life comes next?</line>
      <line>‘Patience a moment!</line>
      <line>‘Grant I have mastered learning’s crabbed text,</line>
      <line>‘Still there’s the comment.</line>
      <line>‘Let me know all! Prate not of most or least,</line>
      <line>‘Painful or easy!</line>
      <line>‘Even to the crumbs I’d fain eat up the feast,</line>
      <line>‘Ay, nor feel queasy.’</line>
      <line>Oh, such a life as he resolved to live,</line>
      <line>When he had learned it,</line>
      <line>When he had gathered all books had to give!</line>
      <line>Sooner, he spurned it.</line>
      <line>Image the whole, then execute the parts—</line>
      <line>Fancy the fabric</line>
      <line>Quite, ere you build, ere steel strike fire from quartz,</line>
      <line>Ere mortar dab brick!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(Here’s the town-gate reached: there’s the market-place</line>
      <line>Gaping before us.)</line>
      <line>Yea, this in him was the peculiar grace</line>
      <line>(Hearten our chorus!)</line>
      <line>That before living he’d learn how to live—</line>
      <line>No end to learning:</line>
      <line>Earn the means first—God surely will contrive</line>
      <line>Use for our earning.</line>
      <line>Others mistrust and say, ‘But time escapes:</line>
      <line>‘Live now or never!’</line>
      <line>He said, ‘What’s time? Leave Now for dogs and apes!</line>
      <line>‘Man has Forever.’</line>
      <line>Back to his book then: deeper drooped his head:</line>
      <line>Calculus racked him:</line>
      <line>Leaden before, his eyes grew dross of lead:</line>
      <line>Tussis attacked him.</line>
      <line>‘Now, master, take a little rest!’—not he!</line>
      <line>(Caution redoubled,</line>
      <line>Step two abreast, the way winds narrowly!)</line>
      <line>Not a whit troubled</line>
      <line>Back to his studies, fresher than at first,</line>
      <line>Fierce as a dragon</line>
      <line>He (soul-hydroptic with a sacred thirst)</line>
      <line>Sucked at the flagon.</line>
      <line>Oh, if we draw a circle premature,</line>
      <line>Heedless of far gain,</line>
      <line>Greedy for quick returns of profit, sure</line>
      <line>Bad is our bargain!</line>
      <line>Was it not great? did not he throw on God,</line>
      <line>(He loves the burthen)—</line>
      <line>God’s task to make the heavenly period</line>
      <line>Perfect the earthen?</line>
      <line>Did not he magnify the mind, show clear</line>
      <line>Just what it all meant?</line>
      <line>He would not discount life, as fools do here,</line>
      <line>Paid by instalment.</line>
      <line>He ventured neck or nothing—heaven’s success</line>
      <line>Found, or earth’s failure: no</line>
      <line>‘Wilt thou trust death or not?’ He answered ‘Yes:</line>
      <line>‘Hence with life’s pale lure!’</line>
      <line>That low man seeks a little thing to do,</line>
      <line>Sees it and does it:</line>
      <line>This high man, with a great thing to pursue,</line>
      <line>Dies ere he knows it.</line>
      <line>That low man goes on adding one to one,</line>
      <line>His hundred’s soon hit:</line>
      <line>This high man, aiming at a million,</line>
      <line>Misses an unit.</line>
      <line>That, has the world here—should he need the next,</line>
      <line>Let the world mind him!</line>
      <line>This, throws himself on God, and unperplexed</line>
      <line>Seeking shall find him.</line>
      <line>So, with the throttling hands of death at strife,</line>
      <line>Ground he at grammar;</line>
      <line>Still, thro’ the rattle, parts of speech were rife:</line>
      <line>While he could stammer</line>
      <line>He settled Hoti’s business—let it be!—</line>
      <line>Properly based Oun—</line>
      <line>Gave us the doctrine of the enclitic De,</line>
      <line>Dead from the waist down.</line>
      <line>Well, here’s the platform, here’s the proper place:</line>
      <line>Hail to your purlieus,</line>
      <line>All ye highfliers of the feathered race,</line>
      <line>Swallows and curlews!</line>
      <line>Here’s the top-peak; the multitude below</line>
      <line>Live, for they can, there:</line>
      <line>This man decided not to Live but Know—</line>
      <line>Bury this man there?</line>
      <line>Here—here’s his place, where meteors shoot, clouds form,</line>
      <line>Lightnings are loosened,</line>
      <line>Stars come and go! Let joy break with the storm,</line>
      <line>Peace let the dew send!</line>
      <line>Lofty designs must close in like effects:</line>
      <line>Loftily lying,</line>
      <line>Leave him—still loftier than the world suspects,</line>
      <line>Living and dying.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1860</date>
    <title>Confessions</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is he buzzing in my ears?</line>
      <line>‘Now that I come to die,</line>
      <line>‘Do I view the world as a vale of tears?’</line>
      <line>Ah, reverend sir, not I!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What I viewed there once, what I view again</line>
      <line>Where the physic bottles stand</line>
      <line>On the table’s edge,—is a suburb lane,</line>
      <line>With a wall to my bedside hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That lane sloped, much as the bottles do,</line>
      <line>From a house you could descry</line>
      <line>O’er the garden-wall: is the curtain blue</line>
      <line>Or green to a healthy eye?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To mine, it serves for the old June weather</line>
      <line>Blue above lane and wall;</line>
      <line>And that farthest bottle labelled ‘Ether’</line>
      <line>Is the house o’ertopping all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At a terrace, somewhere near the stopper,</line>
      <line>There watched for me, one June,</line>
      <line>A girl: I know, sir, it’s improper,</line>
      <line>My poor mind’s out of tune.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Only, there was a way . . . you crept</line>
      <line>Close by the side, to dodge</line>
      <line>Eyes in the house, two eyes except:</line>
      <line>They styled their house ‘The Lodge’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What right had a lounger up their lane?</line>
      <line>But, by creeping very close,</line>
      <line>With the good wall’s help,—their eyes might strain</line>
      <line>And stretch themselves to Oes,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet never catch her and me together,</line>
      <line>As she left the attic, there,</line>
      <line>By the rim of the bottle labelled ‘Ether’,</line>
      <line>And stole from stair to stair,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And stood by the rose-wreathed gate. Alas,</line>
      <line>We loved, sir—used to meet:</line>
      <line>How sad and bad and mad it was—</line>
      <line>But then, how it was sweet!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1860</date>
    <title>Youth and Art</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It once might have been, once only:</line>
      <line>We lodged in a street together,</line>
      <line>You, a sparrow on the housetop lonely,</line>
      <line>I, a lone she-bird of his feather.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your trade was with sticks and clay,</line>
      <line>You thumbed, thrust, patted and polished,</line>
      <line>Then laughed ‘They will see some day</line>
      <line>‘Smith made, and Gibson demolished.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My business was song, song, song;</line>
      <line>I chirped, cheeped, trilled and twittered,</line>
      <line>‘Kate Brown’s on the boards ere long,</line>
      <line>‘And Grisi’s existence embittered!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I earned no more by a warble</line>
      <line>Than you by a sketch in plaster;</line>
      <line>You wanted a piece of marble,</line>
      <line>I needed a music-master.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We studied hard in our styles,</line>
      <line>Chipped each at a crust like Hindoos,</line>
      <line>For air looked out on the tiles,</line>
      <line>For fun watched each other’s windows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You lounged, like a boy of the South,</line>
      <line>Cap and blouse—nay, a bit of beard too;</line>
      <line>Or you got it, rubbing your mouth</line>
      <line>With fingers the clay adhered to.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I—soon managed to find</line>
      <line>Weak points in the flower-fence facing,</line>
      <line>Was forced to put up a blind</line>
      <line>And be safe in my corset-lacing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No harm! It was not my fault</line>
      <line>If you never turned your eye’s tail up</line>
      <line>As I shook upon E in alt,</line>
      <line>Or ran the chromatic scale up:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For spring bade the sparrows pair,</line>
      <line>And the boys and girls gave guesses,</line>
      <line>And stalls in our street looked rare</line>
      <line>With bulrush and watercresses.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why did you not pinch a flower</line>
      <line>In a pellet of clay and fling it?</line>
      <line>Why did not I put a power</line>
      <line>Of thanks in a look, or sing it?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I did look, sharp as a lynx,</line>
      <line>(And yet the memory rankles)</line>
      <line>When models arrived, some minx</line>
      <line>Tripped up-stairs, she and her ankles.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But I think I gave you as good!</line>
      <line>‘That foreign fellow,—who can know</line>
      <line>‘How she pays, in a playful mood,</line>
      <line>‘For his tuning her that piano?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Could you say so, and never say</line>
      <line>‘Suppose we join hands and fortunes,</line>
      <line>‘And I fetch her from over the way,</line>
      <line>‘Her, piano, and long tunes and short tunes?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, no: you would not be rash,</line>
      <line>Nor I rasher and something over:</line>
      <line>You’ve to settle yet Gibson’s hash,</line>
      <line>And Grisi yet lives in clover.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But you meet the Prince at the Board,</line>
      <line>I’m queen myself at bals-pare,</line>
      <line>I’ve married a rich old lord,</line>
      <line>And you’re dubbed knight and an R.A.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each life unfulfilled, you see;</line>
      <line>It hangs still, patchy and scrappy:</line>
      <line>We have not sighed deep, laughed free,</line>
      <line>Starved, feasted, despaired,—been happy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And nobody calls you a dunce,</line>
      <line>And people suppose me clever:</line>
      <line>This could but have happened once,</line>
      <line>And we missed it, lost it for ever.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Caliban upon Setebos; or, Natural Theology in the Island</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>[’Will sprawl, now that the heat of day is best,</line>
      <line>Flat on his belly in the pit’s much mire,</line>
      <line>With elbows wide, fists clenched to prop his chin.</line>
      <line>And, while he kicks both feet in the cool slush,</line>
      <line>And feels about his spine small eft-things course,</line>
      <line>Run in and out each arm, and make him laugh:</line>
      <line>And while above his head a pompion-plant,</line>
      <line>Coating the cave-top as a brow its eye,</line>
      <line>Creeps down to touch and tickle hair and beard,</line>
      <line>And now a flower drops with a bee inside,</line>
      <line>And now a fruit to snap at, catch and crunch,—</line>
      <line>He looks out o’er yon sea which sunbeams cross</line>
      <line>And recross till they weave a spider-web</line>
      <line>(Meshes of fire, some great fish breaks at times)</line>
      <line>And talks to his own self, howe’er he please,</line>
      <line>Touching that other, whom his dam called God.</line>
      <line>Because to talk about Him, vexes—ha,</line>
      <line>Could He but know! and time to vex is now,</line>
      <line>When talk is safer than in winter-time.</line>
      <line>Moreover Prosper and Miranda sleep</line>
      <line>In confidence he drudges at their task,</line>
      <line>And it is good to cheat the pair, and gibe,</line>
      <line>Letting the rank tongue blossom into speech.]</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Setebos, Setebos, and Setebos!</line>
      <line>’Thinketh, He dwelleth i’ the cold o’ the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Thinketh He made it, with the sun to match,</line>
      <line>But not the stars; the stars came otherwise;</line>
      <line>Only made clouds, winds, meteors, such as that:</line>
      <line>Also this isle, what lives and grows thereon,</line>
      <line>And snaky sea which rounds and ends the same.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>'Thinketh, it came of being ill at ease:</line>
      <line>He hated that He cannot change His cold,</line>
      <line>Nor cure its ache. ’Hath spied an icy fish</line>
      <line>That longed to ’scape the rock-stream where she lived,</line>
      <line>And thaw herself within the lukewarm brine</line>
      <line>O’ the lazy sea her stream thrusts far amid,</line>
      <line>A crystal spike ’twixt two warm walls of wave;</line>
      <line>Only, she ever sickened, found repulse</line>
      <line>At the other kind of water, not her life,</line>
      <line>(Green-dense and dim-delicious, bred o’ the sun)</line>
      <line>Flounced back from bliss she was not born to breathe,</line>
      <line>And in her old bounds buried her despair,</line>
      <line>Hating and loving warmth alike: so He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Thinketh, He made thereat the sun, this isle,</line>
      <line>Trees and the fowls here, beast and creeping thing.</line>
      <line>Yon otter, sleek-wet, black, lithe as a leech;</line>
      <line>Yon auk, one fire-eye in a ball of foam,</line>
      <line>That floats and feeds; a certain badger brown</line>
      <line>He hath watched hunt with that slant white-wedge eye</line>
      <line>By moonlight; and the pie with the long tongue</line>
      <line>That pricks deep into oakwarts for a worm,</line>
      <line>And says a plain word when she finds her prize,</line>
      <line>But will not eat the ants; the ants themselves</line>
      <line>That build a wall of seeds and settled stalks</line>
      <line>About their hole—He made all these and more,</line>
      <line>Made all we see, and us, in spite: how else?</line>
      <line>He could not, Himself, make a second self</line>
      <line>To be His mate; as well have made Himself:</line>
      <line>He would not make what he mislikes or slights,</line>
      <line>An eyesore to Him, or not worth His pains:</line>
      <line>But did, in envy, listlessness or sport,</line>
      <line>Make what Himself would fain, in a manner, be—</line>
      <line>Weaker in most points, stronger in a few,</line>
      <line>Worthy, and yet mere playthings all the while,</line>
      <line>Things He admires and mocks too,—that is it.</line>
      <line>Because, so brave, so better though they be,</line>
      <line>It nothing skills if He begin to plague.</line>
      <line>Look now, I melt a gourd-fruit into mash,</line>
      <line>Add honeycomb and pods, I have perceived,</line>
      <line>Which bite like finches when they bill and kiss,—</line>
      <line>Then, when froth rises bladdery, drink up all,</line>
      <line>Quick, quick, till maggots scamper through my brain;</line>
      <line>Last, throw me on my back i’ the seeded thyme,</line>
      <line>And wanton, wishing I were born a bird.</line>
      <line>Put case, unable to be what I wish,</line>
      <line>I yet could make a live bird out of clay:</line>
      <line>Would not I take clay, pinch my Caliban</line>
      <line>Able to fly?—for, there, see, he hath wings,</line>
      <line>And great comb like the hoopoe’s to admire,</line>
      <line>And there, a sting to do his foes offence,</line>
      <line>There, and I will that he begin to live,</line>
      <line>Fly to yon rock-top, nip me off the horns</line>
      <line>Of grigs high up that make the merry din,</line>
      <line>Saucy through their veined wings, and mind me not.</line>
      <line>In which feat, if his leg snapped, brittle clay,</line>
      <line>And he lay stupid-like,—why, I should laugh;</line>
      <line>And if he, spying me, should fall to weep,</line>
      <line>Beseech me to be good, repair his wrong,</line>
      <line>Bid his poor leg smart less or grow again,—</line>
      <line>Well, as the chance were, this might take or else</line>
      <line>Not take my fancy: I might hear his cry,</line>
      <line>And give the mankin three sound legs for one,</line>
      <line>Or pluck the other off, leave him like an egg,</line>
      <line>And lessoned he was mine and merely clay.</line>
      <line>Were this no pleasure, lying in the thyme,</line>
      <line>Drinking the mash, with brain become alive,</line>
      <line>Making and marring clay at will? So He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Thinketh, such shows nor right nor wrong in Him,</line>
      <line>Nor kind, nor cruel: He is strong and Lord.</line>
      <line>’Am strong myself compared to yonder crabs</line>
      <line>That march now from the mountain to the sea,</line>
      <line>’Let twenty pass, and stone the twenty-first,</line>
      <line>Loving not, hating not, just choosing so.</line>
      <line>’Say, the first straggler that boasts purple spots</line>
      <line>Shall join the file, one pincer twisted off;</line>
      <line>’Say, this bruised fellow shall receive a worm,</line>
      <line>And two worms he whose nippers end in red;</line>
      <line>As it likes me each time, I do: so He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well then, ’supposeth He is good i’ the main,</line>
      <line>Placable if His mind and ways were guessed,</line>
      <line>But rougher than His handiwork, be sure!</line>
      <line>Oh, He hath made things worthier than Himself,</line>
      <line>And envieth that, so helped, such things do more</line>
      <line>Than He who made them! What consoles but this?</line>
      <line>That they, unless through Him, do nought at all,</line>
      <line>And must submit: what other use in things?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Hath cut a pipe of pithless elder joint</line>
      <line>That, blown through, gives exact the scream o’ the jay</line>
      <line>When from her wing you twitch the feathers blue:</line>
      <line>Sound this, and little birds that hate the jay</line>
      <line>Flock within stone’s throw, glad their foe is hurt:</line>
      <line>Put case such pipe could prattle and boast forsooth</line>
      <line>‘I catch the birds, I am the crafty thing,</line>
      <line>‘I make the cry my maker cannot make</line>
      <line>‘With his great round mouth; he must blow through mine!’</line>
      <line>Would not I smash it with my foot? So He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But wherefore rough, why cold and ill at ease?</line>
      <line>Aha, that is a question! Ask, for that,</line>
      <line>What knows,—the something over Setebos</line>
      <line>That made Him, or He, may be, found and fought, 1</line>
      <line>Worsted, drove off and did to nothing, perchance.</line>
      <line>There may be something quiet o’er His head,</line>
      <line>Out of His reach, that feels nor joy nor grief,</line>
      <line>Since both derive from weakness in some way.</line>
      <line>I joy because the quails come; would not joy</line>
      <line>Could I bring quails here when I have a mind:</line>
      <line>This Quiet, all it hath a mind to, doth.</line>
      <line>’Esteemeth stars the outposts of its couch,</line>
      <line>But never spends much thought nor care that way.</line>
      <line>It may look up, work up,—the worse for those</line>
      <line>It works on! ’Careth but for Setebos</line>
      <line>The many-handed as a cuttle-fish,</line>
      <line>Who, making Himself feared through what He does,</line>
      <line>Looks up, first, and perceives he cannot soar</line>
      <line>To what is quiet and hath happy life;</line>
      <line>Next looks down here, and out of very spite</line>
      <line>Makes this a bauble-world to ape yon real,</line>
      <line>These good things to match those as hips do grapes.</line>
      <line>’T is solace making baubles, ay, and sport.</line>
      <line>Himself peeped late, eyed Prosper at his books</line>
      <line>Careless and lofty, lord now of the isle:</line>
      <line>Vexed, ’stitched a book of broad leaves, arrow-shaped,</line>
      <line>Wrote thereon, he knows what, prodigious words;</line>
      <line>Has peeled a wand and called it by a name;</line>
      <line>Weareth at whiles for an enchanter’s robe</line>
      <line>The eyed skin of a supple oncelot;</line>
      <line>And hath an ounce sleeker than youngling mole,</line>
      <line>A four-legged serpent he makes cower and couch,</line>
      <line>Now snarl, now hold its breath and mind his eye,</line>
      <line>And saith she is Miranda and my wife:</line>
      <line>’Keeps for his Ariel a tall pouch-bill crane</line>
      <line>He bids go wade for fish and straight disgorge;</line>
      <line>Also a sea-beast, lumpish, which he snared,</line>
      <line>Blinded the eyes of, and brought somewhat tame,</line>
      <line>And split its toe-webs, and now pens the drudge</line>
      <line>In a hole o’ the rock and calls him Caliban;</line>
      <line>A bitter heart that bides its time and bites.</line>
      <line>’Plays thus at being Prosper in a way,</line>
      <line>Taketh his mirth with make-believes: so He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His dam held that the Quiet made all things</line>
      <line>Which Setebos vexed only: ’holds not so.</line>
      <line>Who made them weak, meant weakness He might vex.</line>
      <line>Had He meant other, while His hand was in,</line>
      <line>Why not make horny eyes no thorn could prick,</line>
      <line>Or plate my scalp with bone against the snow,</line>
      <line>Or overscale my flesh ’neath joint and joint,</line>
      <line>Like an ore’s armour? Ay,—so spoil His sport!</line>
      <line>He is the One now: only He doth all.</line>
      <line>’Saith, He may like, perchance, what profits Him.</line>
