      <line>Ay, himself loves what does him good; but why?</line>
      <line>’Gets good no otherwise. This blinded beast</line>
      <line>Loves whoso places flesh-meat on his nose,</line>
      <line>But, had he eyes, would want no help, but hate</line>
      <line>Or love, just as it liked him: He hath eyes.</line>
      <line>Also it pleaseth Setebos to work,</line>
      <line>Use all His hands, and exercise much craft,</line>
      <line>By no means for the love of what is worked.</line>
      <line>’Tasteth, himself, no finer good i’ the world</line>
      <line>When all goes right, in this safe summer-time,</line>
      <line>And he wants little, hungers, aches not much,</line>
      <line>Than trying what to do with wit and strength.</line>
      <line>’Falls to make something: ’piled yon pile of turfs,</line>
      <line>And squared and stuck there squares of soft white chalk,</line>
      <line>And, with a fish-tooth, scratched a moon on each,</line>
      <line>And set up endwise certain spikes of tree,</line>
      <line>And crowned the whole with a sloth’s skull a-top,</line>
      <line>Found dead i’ the woods, too hard for one to kill.</line>
      <line>No use at all i’ the work, for work’s sole sake;</line>
      <line>’Shall some day knock it down again: so He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Saith He is terrible: watch His feats in proof!</line>
      <line>One hurricane will spoil six good months’ hope.</line>
      <line>He hath a spite against me, that I know,</line>
      <line>Just as He favours Prosper, who knows why?</line>
      <line>So it is, all the same, as well I find.</line>
      <line>’Wove wattles half the winter, fenced them firm</line>
      <line>With stone and stake to stop she-tortoises</line>
      <line>Crawling to lay their eggs here: well, one wave,</line>
      <line>Feeling the foot of Him upon its neck,</line>
      <line>Gaped as a snake does, lolled out its large tongue,</line>
      <line>And licked the whole labour flat: so much for spite.</line>
      <line>’Saw a ball flame down late (yonder it lies)</line>
      <line>Where, half an hour before, I slept i’ the shade:</line>
      <line>Often they scatter sparkles: there is force!</line>
      <line>’Dug up a newt He may have envied once</line>
      <line>And turned to stone, shut up inside a stone.</line>
      <line>Please Him and hinder this?—What Prosper does?</line>
      <line>Aha, if He would tell me how! Not He!</line>
      <line>There is the sport: discover how or die!</line>
      <line>All need not die, for of the things o’ the isle</line>
      <line>Some flee afar, some dive, some run up trees;</line>
      <line>Those at His mercy,—why, they please Him most</line>
      <line>When . .. when . .. well, never try the same way twice!</line>
      <line>Repeat what act has pleased, He may grow wroth.</line>
      <line>You must not know His ways, and play Him off,</line>
      <line>Sure of the issue. ’Doth the like himself:</line>
      <line>’Spareth a squirrel that it nothing fears</line>
      <line>But steals the nut from underneath my thumb,</line>
      <line>And when I threat, bites stoutly in defence:</line>
      <line>’Spareth an urchin that contrariwise,</line>
      <line>Curls up into a ball, pretending death</line>
      <line>For fright at my approach: the two ways please.</line>
      <line>But what would move my choler more than this,</line>
      <line>That either creature counted on its life</line>
      <line>To-morrow and next day and all days to come,</line>
      <line>Saying, forsooth, in the inmost of its heart,</line>
      <line>‘Because he did so yesterday with me,</line>
      <line>‘And otherwise with such another brute,</line>
      <line>‘So must he do henceforth and always.’—Ay?</line>
      <line>Would teach the reasoning couple what ‘must’ means!</line>
      <line>’Doth as he likes, or wherefore Lord? So He.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Conceiveth all things will continue thus,</line>
      <line>And we shall have to live in fear of Him</line>
      <line>So long as He lives, keeps His strength: no change,</line>
      <line>If He have done His best, make no new world</line>
      <line>To please Him more, so leave off watching this,—</line>
      <line>If He surprise not even the Quiet’s self</line>
      <line>Some strange day,—or, suppose, grow into it</line>
      <line>As grubs grow butterflies: else, here are we,</line>
      <line>And there is He, and nowhere help at all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Believeth with the life, the pain shall stop.</line>
      <line>His dam held different, that after death</line>
      <line>He both plagued enemies and feasted friends:</line>
      <line>Idly! He doth His worst in this our life,</line>
      <line>Giving just respite lest we die through pain,</line>
      <line>Saving last pain for worst,—with which, an end.</line>
      <line>Meanwhile, the best way to escape His ire</line>
      <line>Is, not to seem too happy. ’Sees, himself,</line>
      <line>Yonder two flies, with purple films and pink,</line>
      <line>Bask on the pompion-bell above: kills both.</line>
      <line>’Sees two black painful beetles roll their ball</line>
      <line>On head and tail as if to save their lives:</line>
      <line>Moves them the stick away they strive to clear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Even so, ’would have Him misconceive, suppose</line>
      <line>This Caliban strives hard and ails no less,</line>
      <line>And always, above all else, envies Him;</line>
      <line>Wherefore he mainly dances on dark nights,</line>
      <line>Moans in the sun, gets under holes to laugh,</line>
      <line>And never speaks his mind save housed as now:</line>
      <line>Outside, ’groans, curses. If He caught me here,</line>
      <line>O’erheard this speech, and asked ‘What chucklest at?’</line>
      <line>’Would, to appease Him, cut a finger off,</line>
      <line>Or of my three kid yearlings burn the best,</line>
      <line>Or let the toothsome apples rot on tree,</line>
      <line>Or push my tame beast for the ore to taste:</line>
      <line>While myself lit a fire, and made a song</line>
      <line>And sung it, ‘ What I hate, be consecrate</line>
      <line>‘To celebrate Thee and Thy state, no mate</line>
      <line>‘'For Thee; what see for envy in poor me?'</line>
      <line>Hoping the while, since evils sometimes mend,</line>
      <line>Warts rub away and sores are cured with slime,</line>
      <line>That some strange day, will either the Quiet catch</line>
      <line>And conquer Setebos, or likelier He</line>
      <line>Decrepit may doze, doze, as good as die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>[What, what? A curtain o’er the world at once!</line>
      <line>Crickets stop hissing; not a bird—or, yes,</line>
      <line>There scuds His raven that has told Him all!</line>
      <line>It was fool’s play, this prattling! Ha! The wind</line>
      <line>Shoulders the pillared dust, death’s house o’ the move,</line>
      <line>And fast invading fires begin! White blaze—</line>
      <line>A tree’s head snaps—and there, there, there, there, there,</line>
      <line>His thunder follows! Fool to gibe at Him!</line>
      <line>Lo! ’Lieth flat and loveth Setebos!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Maketh his teeth meet through his upper lip,</line>
      <line>Will let those quails fly, will not eat this month</line>
      <line>One little mess of whelks, so he may ’scape!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>[Rhyme for a Child Viewing a Naked Venus in a Painting of‘The Judgement of Paris']</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He gazed and gazed and gazed and gazed,</line>
      <line>Amazed, amazed, amazed, amazed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>Never the Time and the Place</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Never the time and the place</line>
      <line>And the loved one all together!</line>
      <line>This path—how soft to pace!</line>
      <line>This May—what magic weather!</line>
      <line>Where is the loved one’s face?</line>
      <line>In a dream that loved one’s face meets mine,</line>
      <line>But the house is narrow, the place is bleak</line>
      <line>Where, outside, rain and wind combine</line>
      <line>With a furtive ear, if I strive to speak,</line>
      <line>With a hostile eye at my flushing cheek,</line>
      <line>With a malice that marks each word, each sign!</line>
      <line>O enemy sly and serpentine,</line>
      <line>Uncoil thee from the waking man!</line>
      <line>Do I hold the Past</line>
      <line>Thus firm and fast</line>
      <line>Yet doubt if the Future hold I can?</line>
      <line>This path so soft to pace shall lead</line>
      <line>Thro’ the magic of May to herself indeed!</line>
      <line>Or narrow if needs the house must be,</line>
      <line>Outside are the storms and strangers: we—</line>
      <line>Oh, close, safe, warm sleep I and she,</line>
      <line>—I and she!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>Development</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My Father was a scholar and knew Greek.</line>
      <line>When I was five years old, I asked him once</line>
      <line>‘What do you read about?’</line>
      <line>‘The siege of Troy.’</line>
      <line>‘What is a siege and what is Troy?’</line>
      <line>Whereat</line>
      <line>He piled up chairs and tables for a town,</line>
      <line>Set me a-top for Priam, called our cat</line>
      <line>—Helen, enticed away from home (he said)</line>
      <line>By wicked Paris, who couched somewhere close</line>
      <line>Under the footstool, being cowardly,</line>
      <line>But whom—since she was worth the pains, poor puss—</line>
      <line>Towzer and Tray,—our dogs, the Atreidai,—sought</line>
      <line>By taking Troy to get possession of</line>
      <line>—Always when great Achilles ceased to sulk,</line>
      <line>(My pony in the stable)—forth would prance</line>
      <line>And put to flight Hector—our page-boy’s self.</line>
      <line>This taught me who was who and what was what:</line>
      <line>So far I rightly understood the case</line>
      <line>At five years old: a huge delight it proved</line>
      <line>And still proves—thanks to that instructor sage</line>
      <line>My Father, who knew better than turn straight</line>
      <line>Learning’s full flare on weak-eyed ignorance,</line>
      <line>Or, worse yet, leave weak eyes to grow sand-blind,</line>
      <line>Content with darkness and vacuity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It happened, two or three years afterward,</line>
      <line>That—I and playmates playing at Troy’s Siege—</line>
      <line>My Father came upon our make-believe.</line>
      <line>‘How would you like to read yourself the tale</line>
      <line>Properly told, of which I gave you first</line>
      <line>Merely such notion as a boy could bear?</line>
      <line>Pope, now, would give you the precise account</line>
      <line>Of what, some day, by dint of scholarship,</line>
      <line>You’ll hear—who knows?—from Homer’s very mouth.</line>
      <line>Learn Greek by all means, read the “Blind Old Man,</line>
      <line>Sweetest of Singers”—tuphlos which means “blind,”</line>
      <line>Hedistos which means “sweetest,” Time enough!</line>
      <line>Try, anyhow, to master him some day;</line>
      <line>Until when, take what serves for substitute,</line>
      <line>Read Pope, by all means!’</line>
      <line>So I ran through Pope,</line>
      <line>Enjoyed the tale—what history so true?</line>
      <line>Also attacked my Primer, duly drudged,</line>
      <line>Grew fitter thus for what was promised next—</line>
      <line>The very thing itself, the actual words,</line>
      <line>When I could turn—say, Buttmann to account.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Time passed, I ripened somewhat: one fine day,</line>
      <line>‘Quite ready for the Iliad, nothing less?</line>
      <line>There’s Heine, where the big books block the shelf:</line>
      <line>Don’t skip a word, thumb well the Lexicon!’</line>
      <line>I thumbed well and skipped nowise till I learned</line>
      <line>Who was who, what was what, from Homer’s tongue,</line>
      <line>And there an end of learning. Had you asked</line>
      <line>The all-accomplished scholar, twelve years old,</line>
      <line>‘Who was it wrote the Iliad?’—what a laugh!</line>
      <line>‘Why, Homer, all the world knows: of his life</line>
      <line>Doubtless some facts exist: it’s everywhere:</line>
      <line>We have not settled, though, his place of birth:</line>
      <line>He begged, for certain, and was blind beside:</line>
      <line>Seven cities claimed him—Scio, with best right,</line>
      <line>Thinks Byron. What he wrote? Those Hymns we have.</line>
      <line>Then there’s the “Battle of the Frogs and Mice,”</line>
      <line>That’s all—unless they dig “Margites” up</line>
      <line>(I’d like that) nothing more remains to know.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus did youth spend a comfortable time;</line>
      <line>Until—‘What’s this the Germans say is fact</line>
      <line>That Wolf found out first? It’s unpleasant work</line>
      <line>Their chop and change, unsettling one’s belief:</line>
      <line>All the same, while we live, we learn, that’s sure.’</line>
      <line>So, I bent brow o’er Prolegomena.</line>
      <line>And, after Wolf, a dozen of his like</line>
      <line>Proved there was never any Troy at all,</line>
      <line>Neither Besiegers nor Besieged,—nay, worse,—</line>
      <line>No actual Homer, no authentic text,</line>
      <line>No warrant for the fiction I, as fact,</line>
      <line>Had treasured in my heart and soul so long—</line>
      <line>Ay, mark you! and as fact held still, still hold,</line>
      <line>Spite of new knowledge, in my heart of hearts</line>
      <line>And soul of souls, fact’s essence freed and fixed</line>
      <line>From accidental fancy’s guardian sheath.</line>
      <line>Assuredly thenceforward—thank my stars!—</line>
      <line>However it got there, deprive who could—</line>
      <line>Wring from the shrine my precious tenantry,</line>
      <line>Helen, Ulysses, Hector and his Spouse,</line>
      <line>Achilles and his Friend?—though Wolf—ah, Wolf!</line>
      <line>Why must he needs come doubting, spoil a dream?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But then ‘No dream’s worth waking’—Browning says:</line>
      <line>And here’s the reason why I tell thus much.</line>
      <line>I, now mature man, you anticipate,</line>
      <line>May blame my Father justifiably</line>
      <line>For letting me dream out my nonage thus,</line>
      <line>And only by such slow and sure degrees</line>
      <line>Permitting me to sift the grain from chaff,</line>
      <line>Get truth and falsehood known and named as such.</line>
      <line>Why did he ever let me dream at all,</line>
      <line>Not bid me taste the story in its strength?</line>
      <line>Suppose my childhood was scarce qualified</line>
      <line>To rightly understand mythology,</line>
      <line>Silence at least was in his power to keep:</line>
      <line>I might have—somehow—correspondingly—</line>
      <line>Well, who knows by what method, gained my gains,</line>
      <line>Been taught, by forthrights not meanderings,</line>
      <line>My aim should be to loathe, like Peleus’ son,</line>
      <line>A lie as Hell’s Gate, love my wedded wife,</line>
      <line>Like Hector, and so on with all the rest.</line>
      <line>Could not I have excogitated this</line>
      <line>Without believing such men really were?</line>
      <line>That is—he might have put into my hand</line>
      <line>The ‘Ethics’? In translation, if you please,</line>
      <line>Exact, no pretty lying that improves,</line>
      <line>To suit the modern taste: no more, no less—</line>
      <line>The ‘Ethics’: ’t is a treatise I find hard</line>
      <line>To read aright now that my hair is grey,</line>
      <line>And I can manage the original.</line>
      <line>At five years old—how ill had fared its leaves!</line>
      <line>Now, growing double o’er the Stagirite,</line>
      <line>At least I soil no page with bread and milk,</line>
      <line>Nor crumple, dogsear and deface—boys’ way.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Browning</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>Inapprehensiveness</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We two stood simply friend-like side by side,</line>
      <line>Viewing a twilight country far and wide,</line>
      <line>Till she at length broke silence. ‘How it towers</line>
      <line>Yonder, the ruin o’er this vale of ours!</line>
      <line>The West’s faint flare behind it so relieves</line>
      <line>Its rugged outline—sight perhaps deceives,</line>
      <line>Or I could almost fancy that I see</line>
      <line>A branch wave plain—belike some wind-sown tree</line>
      <line>Chance-rooted where a missing turret was.</line>
      <line>What would I give for the perspective glass</line>
      <line>At home, to make out if’t is really so!</line>
      <line>Has Ruskin noticed here at Asolo</line>
      <line>That certain weed-growths on the ravaged wall</line>
      <line>Seem’ .. . something that I could not say at all,</line>
      <line>My thought being rather—as absorbed she sent</line>
      <line>Look onward after look from eyes distent</line>
      <line>With longing to reach Heaven’s gate left ajar—</line>
      <line>‘Oh, fancies that might be, oh, facts that are!</line>
      <line>What of a wilding? By you stands, and may</line>
      <line>So stand unnoticed till the Judgment Day,</line>
      <line>One who, if once aware that your regard</line>
      <line>Claimed what his heart holds,—woke, as from its sward</line>
      <line>The flower, the dormant passion, so to speak—</line>
      <line>Then what a rush of life would startling wreak</line>
      <line>Revenge on your inapprehensive stare</line>
      <line>While, from the ruin and the West’s faint flare,</line>
      <line>You let your eyes meet mine, touch what you term</line>
      <line>Quietude—that’s an universe in germ—</line>
      <line>The dormant passion needing but a look</line>
      <line>To burst into immense life!’</line>
      <line>‘No, the book</line>
      <line>Which noticed how the wall-growths wave’ said she</line>
      <line>‘Was not by Ruskin.’</line>
      <line>I said ‘Vernon Lee?’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ebenezer Jones</author>
    <date>1843</date>
    <title>High Summer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never wholly feel that summer is high,</line>
      <line>However green the trees, or loud the birds,</line>
      <line>However movelessly eye-winking herds</line>
      <line>Stand in field ponds, or under large trees lie,</line>
      <line>Till I do climb all cultured pastures by,</line>
      <line>That hedged by hedgerows studiously fretted trim,</line>
      <line>Smile like a lady’s face with lace laced prim,</line>
      <line>And on some moor or hill that seeks the sky</line>
      <line>Lonely and nakedly,—utterly lie down,</line>
      <line>And feel the sunshine throbbing on body and limb,</line>
      <line>My drowsy brain in pleasant drunkenness swim,</line>
      <line>Each rising thought sink back and dreamily drown,</line>
      <line>Smiles creep o’er my face, and smother my lips, and cloy,</line>
      <line>Each muscle sink to itself, and separately enjoy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ebenezer Jones</author>
    <date>1843</date>
    <title>Whimper of Awakening Passion</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your hands made a tent o’er mine eyes,</line>
      <line>As low in your lap I was lain,</line>
      <line>Perhaps half from yourself to disguise</line>
      <line>The prayer that they could not restrain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You sang, and your voice through me waved</line>
      <line>Such rapture, I heard myself say,</line>
      <line>‘Oh here is the heaven I have craved,</line>
      <line>Never hence will I wander astray.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I lay in your lap your limbs gave</line>
      <line>Such beautiful smooth rest to me,</line>
      <line>I told you that thus to be slave</line>
      <line>I would never consent to be free.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But now mine eyes under their tent</line>
      <line>Think such distance from yours, love, is wrong;</line>
      <line>And my mouth wants your mouth to be sent</line>
      <line>Down to him, all undrest, love, of song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh I fear if your beautiful limbs</line>
      <line>Still to have me their slave feel inclined,</line>
      <line>You must either prevent all these whims,</line>
      <line>Or a way, love, to humour them find.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ebenezer Jones</author>
    <date>1843</date>
    <title>Eyeing the Eyes of One’s Mistress</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When down the crowded aisle my wandering eyes</line>
      <line>’Lighted on thine fix’d scanningly on my face,</line>
      <line>They struck not passion fire, but in their place</line>
      <line>Did settlingly fix themselves, contemplative-wise,</line>
      <line>Thine eyes to fathom;—for as one that lies</line>
      <line>On mountain side where thick-leaved branches vein</line>
      <line>’Twixt him and the sun, and gazes o’er the plain</line>
      <line>That wide beneath him variedly amplifies;</line>
      <line>I think my being was elevatedly lain</line>
      <line>On its own thought, and in thy being gazing</line>
      <line>With tranquil speculation, that did gain</line>
      <line>Singular delight: thus mine eyes thine appraising,</line>
      <line>By dial reckoning, only a moment spent;</line>
      <line>Whole ages by the heart’s right measurement.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when thine eyelids bent into thy gaze</line>
      <line>Nearing regard and instigating light;</line>
      <line>Their lashes narrowing o’er the dewy blaze</line>
      <line>That suddenly thine eyes did appetite;</line>
      <line>Narrowing as if thou feared’st to invite</line>
      <line>Too utterly, but truly that their motion</line>
      <line>Caressingly closing faindy, might excite</line>
      <line>My tranquil gaze to passionate devotion;—</line>
      <line>Then suddenly seemed I an infinite life;</line>
      <line>Infinitely falling down before thy shrine;</line>
      <line>Infinitely praying thy descent; the strife</line>
      <line>Of the aisle’s crowd seem’d gone; thine eyes and mine,</line>
      <line>Devouring distance, into each other grew;</line>
      <line>While thine unfeigning lids gloriously upward flew.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1844</date>
    <title>Love’s Pains</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This love, I canna’ bear it,</line>
      <line>It cheats me night and day;</line>
      <line>This love, I canna’ wear it,</line>
      <line>It takes my peace away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This love, wa’ once a flower;</line>
      <line>But now it is a thorn,—</line>
      <line>The joy o’ evening hour,</line>
      <line>Turn’d to a pain e’re morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This love, it wa’ a bud,</line>
      <line>And a secret known to me;</line>
      <line>Like a flower within a wood;</line>
      <line>Like a nest within a tree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This love, wrong understood,</line>
      <line>Oft’ turned my joy to pain;</line>
      <line>I tried to throw away the bud,</line>
      <line>But the blossom would remain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1844</date>
    <title>I’ve Had Many an Aching Pain</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve had many an aching pain,</line>
      <line>A for sake o’ somebody:</line>
      <line>I have talked, but o’ in vain,</line>
      <line>When I thought o’ somebody.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nought could please me any where,</line>
      <line>I could heed nor smile, nor tear;</line>
      <line>And yet I sighed, for half a year!</line>
      <line>And that for sake o’ somebody.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She was like the lily fair,</line>
      <line>The rose it blushed, for somebody;</line>
      <line>Her neck was white, her cheek was rare,</line>
      <line>I wot it smiled on somebody;—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here’s good luck to somebody;</line>
      <line>And best o’ health for somebody;</line>
      <line>The dearest thought I keep mysell,</line>
      <line>I keep for sake o’ somebody.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1844</date>
    <title>Stanzas</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Black absence hides upon the past</line>
      <line>I quite forget thy face</line>
      <line>And memory like the angry blast</line>
      <line>Will love’s last smile erace</line>
      <line>I try to think of what has been</line>
      <line>But all is blank to me</line>
      <line>And other faces pass between</line>
      <line>My early love and thee</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I try to trace thy memory now</line>
      <line>And only find thy name</line>
      <line>Those inky lashes on thy brow</line>
      <line>Black hair, and eyes the same</line>
      <line>Thy round pale face of snowy dyes</line>
      <line>There’s nothing paints thee there</line>
      <line>A darkness comes before my eyes</line>
      <line>For nothing seems so fair</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I knew thy name so sweet and young</line>
      <line>’Twas music to my ears</line>
      <line>A silent word upon my tongue</line>
      <line>A hidden thought for years</line>
      <line>Dark hair and lashes swarthy too</line>
      <line>Arched on thy forehead pale</line>
      <line>All else is vanished from my view</line>
      <line>Like voices on the gale</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1844</date>
    <title>A Vision</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I lost the love, of heaven above;</line>
      <line>I spurn’d the lust, of earth below;</line>
      <line>I felt the sweets of fancied love,—</line>
      <line>And hell itself my only foe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I lost earths joys, but felt the glow,</line>
      <line>Of heaven’s flame abound in me:</line>
      <line>’Till loveliness, and I did grow,</line>
      <line>The bard of immortality.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loved, but woman fell away;</line>
      <line>I hid me, from her faded fame:</line>
      <line>I snatch’d the sun’s eternal ray,—</line>
      <line>And wrote ’till earth was but a name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In every language upon earth,</line>
      <line>On every shore, o’er every sea;</line>
      <line>I gave my name immortal birth,</line>
      <line>And kep’t my spirit with the free.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>The thunder mutters louder & more loud</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With quicker motion hay folks ply the rake</line>
      <line>Ready to burst slow sails the pitch black cloud</line>
      <line>& all the gang a bigger haycock make</line>
      <line>To sit beneath—the woodland winds awake</line>
      <line>The drops so large wet all thro’ in an hour</line>
      <line>A tiney flood runs down the leaning rake</line>
      <line>In the sweet hay yet dry the hay folks cower</line>
      <line>& some beneath the waggon shun the shower</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>The Old Year</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Old Year’s gone away</line>
      <line>To nothingness and night</line>
      <line>We cannot find him all the day</line>
      <line>Nor hear him in the night</line>
      <line>He left no footstep mark or place</line>
      <line>In either shade or sun</line>
      <line>Tho’ last year he’d a neighbours face</line>
      <line>In this he’s known by none</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All nothing every where</line>
      <line>Mists we on mornings see</line>
      <line>They have more substance when they’re here</line>
      <line>And more of form than he</line>
      <line>He was a friend by every fire</line>
      <line>In every cot and hall</line>
      <line>A guest to every hearts desire</line>
      <line>And now he’s nought at all</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Old papers thrown away</line>
      <line>Or garments cast aside</line>
      <line>E’en the talk of yesterday</line>
      <line>Are things identified</line>
      <line>But time once torn away</line>
      <line>No voices can recall</line>
      <line>The eve of new years day</line>
      <line>Left the old one lost to all</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>'I Am'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am—yet what I am, none cares or knows;</line>
      <line>My friends forsake me like a memory lost:—</line>
      <line>I am the self-consumer of my woes;—</line>
      <line>They rise and vanish in oblivion’s host,</line>
      <line>Like shadows in love’s frenzied stifled throes:—</line>
      <line>And yet I am, and live—like vapours tost</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Into the nothingness of scorn and noise,—</line>
      <line>Into the living sea of waking dreams,</line>
      <line>Where there is neither sense of life or joys,</line>
      <line>But the vast shipwreck of my lifes esteems;</line>
      <line>Even the dearest, that I love the best</line>
      <line>Are strange—nay, rather stranger than the rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I long for scenes, where man hath never trod</line>
      <line>A place where woman never smiled or wept</line>
      <line>There to abide with my Creator, God;</line>
      <line>And sleep as I in childhood, sweetly slept,</line>
      <line>Untroubling, and untroubled where I lie,</line>
      <line>The grass below—above the vaulted sky.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1847</date>
    <title>The Winters Spring</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The winter comes I walk alone</line>
      <line>I want no birds to sing</line>
      <line>To those who keep their hearts their own</line>
      <line>The winter is the Spring</line>
      <line>No flowers to please—no bees to hum</line>
      <line>The coming Springs already come</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never want the Christmas rose</line>
      <line>To come before its time</line>
      <line>The seasons each as God bestows</line>
      <line>Are simple and sublime</line>
      <line>I love to see the snow storm hing</line>
      <line>’Tis but the winter garb of Spring</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never want the grass to bloom</line>
      <line>The snow-storm’s best in white</line>
      <line>I love to see the tempest come</line>
      <line>And love its piercing light</line>
      <line>The dazzled eyes that love to cling</line>
      <line>O’er snow white meadows sees the Spring</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I love the snow the crimpling snow</line>
      <line>That hangs on every thing</line>
      <line>It covers every thing below</line>
      <line>Like white doves brooding wing</line>
      <line>A landscape to the aching sight</line>
      <line>A vast expance of dazzling light</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is the foliage of the woods</line>
      <line>That winter’s bring—The dress</line>
      <line>White easter of the year in bud</line>
      <line>That makes the winter Spring</line>
      <line>The frost and snow his poseys bring</line>
      <line>Natures white spirits of the Spring</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1847</date>
    <title>Hesperus</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hesperus the day is gone</line>
      <line>Soft falls the silent dew</line>
      <line>A tear is now on many a flower</line>
      <line>And heaven lives in you</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hesperus the evening mild</line>
      <line>Falls round us soft and sweet</line>
      <line>’Tis like the breathings of a child</line>
      <line>When day and evening meet</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hesperus the closing flower</line>
      <line>Sleeps on the dewy ground</line>
      <line>While dews fall in a silent shower</line>
      <line>And heaven breathes around</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hesperus thy twinkling ray</line>
      <line>Beams in the blue of heaven</line>
      <line>And tells the traveller on his way</line>
      <line>That earth shall be forgiven</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1848</date>
    <title>An Invite to Eternity</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wilt thou go with me sweet maid</line>
      <line>Say maiden wilt thou go with me</line>
      <line>Through the valley depths of shade</line>
      <line>Of night and dark obscurity</line>
      <line>Where the path hath lost its way</line>
      <line>Where the sun forgets the day</line>
      <line>Where there’s nor life nor light to see</line>
      <line>Sweet maiden wilt thou go with me</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where stones will turn to flooding streams</line>
      <line>Where plains will rise like ocean waves</line>
      <line>Where life will fade like visioned dreams</line>
      <line>And mountains darken into caves</line>
      <line>Say maiden wilt thou go with me</line>
      <line>Through this sad non-identity</line>
      <line>Where parents live and are forgot</line>
      <line>And sisters live and know us not</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Say maiden wilt thou go with me</line>
      <line>In this strange death of life to be</line>
      <line>To live in death and be the same</line>
      <line>Without this life, or home, or name</line>
      <line>At once to be, & not to be</line>
      <line>That was, and is not—yet to see</line>
      <line>Things pass like shadows—and the sky</line>
      <line>Above, below, around us lie</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The land of shadows wilt thou trace</line>
      <line>And look—nor know each others face</line>
      <line>The present mixed with reasons gone</line>
      <line>And past, and present all as one</line>
      <line>Say maiden can thy life be led</line>
      <line>To join the living with the dead</line>
      <line>Then trace thy footsteps on with me</line>
      <line>We’re wed to one eternity</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1848</date>
    <title>The Shepherd Boy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fly or beetle on their track</line>
      <line>Are things that know no sin</line>
      <line>And when they whemble on their back</line>
      <line>What terror they seem in</line>
      <line>The shepherd boy wi’ bits o’ bents</line>
      <line>Will turn them up again</line>
      <line>And start them where they nimbly went</line>
      <line>Along the grassy plain</line>
      <line>And such the shepherd boy is found</line>
      <line>While lying on the sun crackt ground</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lady-bird that seldom stops</line>
      <line>From climbing all the day</line>
      <line>Climbs up the rushes tassle tops</line>
      <line>Spreads wings and flies away</line>
      <line>He sees them—lying on the grass</line>
      <line>Musing the whole day long</line>
      <line>And clears the way to let them pass</line>
      <line>And sings a nameless song</line>
      <line>He watches pismires on the hill</line>
      <line>Always busy never still</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sees the traveller beetle run</line>
      <line>Where thick the grass wood weaves</line>
      <line>To hide the black-snail from the sun</line>
      <line>He props up plantain leaves</line>
      <line>The lady-cows have got a house</line>
      <line>Within the cowslip pip</line>
      <line>The spider weaving for his spouse</line>
      <line>On threads will often slip</line>
      <line>So looks and lyes the shepherd boy</line>
      <line>The summer long his whole employ—</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Evening</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis evening, the black snail has got on his track,</line>
      <line>And gone to its nest is the wren;—</line>
      <line>And the packman snail too, with his home on his back;</line>
      <line>Clings on the bowed bents like a wen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shepherd has made a rude mark with his foot,</line>
      <line>Where his shaddow reached when he first came;</line>
      <line>And it just touched the tree where his secret love cut,</line>
      <line>Two letters that stand for love’s name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The evening comes in with the wishes of love;—</line>
      <line>And the shepherd he looks on the flowers;—</line>
      <line>And thinks who would praise the soft song of the dove,</line>
      <line>And meet joy in these dewfalling hours.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For nature is love, and the wishers of love;</line>
      <line>When nothing can hear or intrude;</line>
      <line>It hides from the eagle, and joins with the dove:</line>
      <line>In beautiful green solitude.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Sonnet: 'I am’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I feel I am;—I only know I am,</line>
      <line>And plod upon the earth, as dull and void:</line>
      <line>Earth’s prison chilled my body with its dram</line>
      <line>Of dullness, and my soaring thoughts destroyed,</line>
      <line>I fled to solitudes from passions dream,</line>
      <line>But strife persued—I only know, I am,</line>
      <line>I was a being created in the race</line>
      <line>Of men disdaining bounds of place and time:—</line>
      <line>A spirit that could travel o’er the space</line>
      <line>Of earth and heaven,—like a thought sublime,</line>
      <line>Tracing creation, like my maker, free,—</line>
      <line>A soul unshackled—like eternity,</line>
      <line>Spurning earth’s vain and soul debasing thrall</line>
      <line>But now I only know I am,—that’s all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Stanzas</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The passing of a dream</line>
      <line>Are the thoughts I have to day</line>
      <line>Cloud shadows they all seem</line>
      <line>And pass as soon away</line>
      <line>Their meaning and their shade</line>
      <line>I cannot well define</line>
      <line>The little left unsaid</line>
      <line>Seems others, and not mine</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here’s a place so dainty dress’t</line>
      <line>That o’er my vision swim</line>
      <line>Like a land in the far west</line>
      <line>But alas my vision’s dim</line>
      <line>The trees are not the trees</line>
      <line>Under which I used to play</line>
      <line>And the flowers they cannot please</line>
      <line>For I am sad to day</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here’s the shumac all on fire</line>
      <line>Like hot coals amid the green</line>
      <line>It might please my heart’s desire</line>
      <line>If elsewhere the place had been</line>
      <line>Here dreams their troubles make</line>
      <line>To a body without pain</line>
      <line>When shall my mind awake</line>
      <line>In its own loved scenes again</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Soft falls the sweet evening</line>
      <line>Bright shines the one star</line>
      <line>The night clouds they’re leaning</line>
      <line>On mountains afar</line>
      <line>The moon in dim brightness</line>
      <line>The fern in its lightness</line>
      <line>Tinge the valley with whiteness</line>
      <line>Both near and afar</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O soft falls the evening</line>
      <line>Around those sweet glens</line>
      <line>The hill’s shadows leaning</line>
      <line>Half over the glen</line>
      <line>There meet me my deary</line>
      <line>I’m lonely and weary</line>
      <line>And nothing can cheer me</line>
      <line>So meet me agen</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The gate it clap’d slightly</line>
      <line>The noise it was small</line>
      <line>The footstep fell lightly</line>
      <line>And she pass’d the stone wall</line>
      <line>And is it my deary</line>
      <line>I’m no longer weary</line>
      <line>But happy and cheery</line>
      <line>For in thee I meet all</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>To Miss B</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Odd rot it what a shame it is</line>
      <line>That love should puzzles grow</line>
      <line>That we the one we seek should miss</line>
      <line>And change from top to toe</line>
      <line>The Gilafers a Gilafer</line>
      <line>And nature owns the plan</line>
      <line>And strange a thing it is to me</line>
      <line>A man cant be a man</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I traced the woods and mountains brow</line>
      <line>And felt as feels a man</line>
      <line>Love pleased me then that puzzles now</line>
      <line>E’en do the best I can</line>
      <line>Nature her same green mantle spread</line>
      <line>And boundless is her span</line>
      <line>The same bright sun is o’er my head</line>
      <line>But I can’t be a man</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The turf is green and fair the sky</line>
      <line>And nature still divine</line>
      <line>And summot lovely fills my eye</line>
      <line>Just like this love of mine</line>
      <line>And though I love—it may not be</line>
      <line>For do the best I can</line>
      <line>Mong such disordered company</line>
      <line>I cannot be a man</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Th[r]ough married ties—affections ties</line>
      <line>And all the ties of love</line>
      <line>I struggled to be just and wise</line>
      <line>But just I cannot prove</line>
      <line>The Bible says that God is love</line>
      <line>I like so wise a plan</line>
      <line>But was it ordered from above</line>
      <line>That love was [not] wi’ man</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This contradiction puzzles me</line>
      <line>And it may puzzle all</line>
      <line>Was Adam thus fore doomed to be</line>
      <line>Our misery by his fall</line>
      <line>Eves fall has been a fall to me</line>
      <line>And do the best I can</line>
      <line>Woman—I neither love nor see</line>
      <line>And cannot be a man</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Hymn to the Creator</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Almighty creator and ruler as well</line>
      <line>Of the earth and the heaven and darkness and hell</line>
      <line>We adore thee—and worship as simple as when</line>
      <line>Adam knelt in the garden the first of all men</line>
      <line>The God of that sun that yet brings the broad day</line>
      <line>When Eve the first flower in the first garden lay</line>
      <line>That mercy that yet ever falls from the sky</line>
      <line>Says that the meanest of beings never shall die</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Almighty creator of all we behold</line>
      <line>The mountains bare rock and the meadows all gold</line>
      <line>The wilderness old and the desert of sand</line>
      <line>Are his in his glory and wild barren land</line>
      <line>To cheer and to cherish in wonder and love</line>
      <line>The earth well as heaven, his dwellings above</line>
      <line>Almighty creator to seek and to save</line>
      <line>We need from the cradle thy help to the grave</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We need thee and fear thee so ought we to fear</line>
      <line>When thou hast no mercy none other will hear</line>
      <line>And mercy thou shewest every day to our land</line>
      <line>In keeping us all as the work of thy hand</line>
      <line>In helping the feeble in seeking the lost</line>
      <line>For man neither springs from a pillar or post</line>
      <line>But breath[e]s from his father eternally yet</line>
      <line>His hell or his heaven in mercy is met</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Almighty creator of heaven and earth</line>
      <line>Creations protector its life and its birth</line>
      <line>In thee all began and in thee all have end</line>
      <line>Our father at first and at last the one friend</line>
      <line>We love and adore thee or ought so to do</line>
      <line>From the sunrise of morning to evenings bright dew</line>
      <line>Through morning and evening and blackest midnight</line>
      <line>Thou’rt our faith in nights darkness and love in morns light</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>There is a charm in Solitude that cheers</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a charm in Solitude that cheers</line>
      <line>A feeling that the world knows nothing of</line>
      <line>A green delight the wounded mind endears</line>
      <line>After the hustling world is broken off</line>
      <line>Whose whole delight was crime at good to scoff</line>
      <line>Green solitude his prison pleasure yields</line>
      <line>The bitch fox heeds him not—birds seem to laugh</line>
      <line>He lives the Crusoe of his lonely fields</line>
      <line>Which dark green oaks his noontide leisure shields</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I went my Sunday mornings rounds</line>
      <line>One pleasant summer day</line>
      <line>And stood i’ the green meadow grounds</line>
      <line>’Mong cocks and swaths 0’ hay</line>
      <line>Up the green rush the Lady bird</line>
      <line>Clomb to its very tops</line>
      <line>And there the crickets songs were heard</line>
      <line>Like organs without stops</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun was climbing up the sky</line>
      <line>A looking glass of gold</line>
      <line>It melts and quivers on the eye</line>
      <line>And blinds us to behold</line>
      <line>Melting and shining to its height</line>
      <line>It shines from pole to pole</line>
      <line>And sliddering down at dewy night</line>
      <line>Goes out a dying coal</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I stood among the swathes and cocks</line>
      <line>How sweet the light did seem</line>
      <line>When a sweet lass with inky locks</line>
      <line>Came tripping by the stream</line>
      <line>Sweet one I said I do prefer</line>
      <line>To ask you why you walk</line>
      <line>’Tis merely for my pleasure sir</line>
      <line>As you stand there to talk</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wind came from the southern sky</line>
      <line>And tokened flying showers</line>
      <line>The busy bee and butterfly</line>
      <line>Her ribbons took for flowers</line>
      <line>The wasp it buzzed about her mouth</line>
      <line>Her lips seemed cherries red</line>
      <line>The wind shook from the balmy south</line>
      <line>The curls about her head</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Young man she said you’l marry me</line>
      <line>And waited for reply</line>
      <line>Why yes my dear but do’nt you see</line>
      <line>Love is the stronger tie</line>
      <line>And then I kissed her lips and cheeks</line>
      <line>And made her merry hearted</line>
      <line>I wed the maid in just three weeks</line>
      <line>From the first day we parted</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>First Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I ne’er was struck before that hour</line>
      <line>With love so sudden and so sweet</line>
      <line>Her face it bloomed like a sweet flower</line>
      <line>And stole my heart away complete</line>
      <line>My face turned pale a deadly pale</line>
      <line>My legs refused to walk away</line>
      <line>And when she looked what could I ail</line>
      <line>My life and all seemed turned to clay</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then my blood rushed to my face</line>
      <line>And took my eyesight quite away</line>
      <line>The trees and bushes round the place</line>
      <line>Seemed midnight at noon day</line>
      <line>I could not see a single thing</line>
      <line>Words from my eyes did start</line>
      <line>They spoke as chords do from the string</line>
      <line>And blood burnt round my heart</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Are flowers the winters choice</line>
      <line>Is love’s bed always snow</line>
      <line>She seemed to hear my silent voice</line>
      <line>Not loves appeals to know 20</line>
      <line>I never saw so sweet a face</line>
      <line>As that I stood before</line>
      <line>My heart has left its dwelling place</line>
      <line>And can return no more—</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I HID my love when young while I</line>
      <line>Coud’nt bear the buzzing of a flye</line>
      <line>I hid my love to my despite</line>
      <line>Till I could not bear to look at light</line>
      <line>I dare not gaze upon her face</line>
      <line>But left her memory in each place</line>
      <line>Where ere I saw a wild flower lye</line>
      <line>I kissed and bade my love good bye</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I met her in the greenest dells</line>
      <line>Where dew drops pearl the wood blue bells</line>
      <line>The lost breeze kissed her bright blue eye</line>
      <line>The Bee kissed and went singing bye</line>
      <line>A sun beam found a passage there</line>
      <line>A gold chain round her neck so fair</line>
      <line>As secret as the wild bees song</line>
      <line>She lay there all the summer long</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hid my love in field and town</line>
      <line>Till e’en the breeze would knock me down</line>
      <line>The Bees seemed singing ballads oe’r</line>
      <line>The flyes buzz turned a Lions roar</line>
      <line>And even silence found a tongue</line>
      <line>To haunt me all the summer long</line>
      <line>The Riddle nature could not prove</line>
      <line>Was nothing else but secret love</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wish I was where I would be</line>
      <line>With love alone to dwell</line>
      <line>Was I but her or she but me</line>
      <line>Then love would all be well</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wish to send my thoughts to her</line>
      <line>As quick as thoughts can fly</line>
      <line>But as the winds the waters stir</line>
      <line>The mirrors change & flye</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Fragment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love’s memories haunt my footsteps still</line>
      <line>Like ceaseless flowings of the river</line>
      <line>Its mystic depths say what can fill?</line>
      <line>Sad disappointment waits for ever</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>The Yellowhammer</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When shall I see the white thorn leaves agen</line>
      <line>And Yellowhammers gath’ring the dry bents</line>
      <line>By the Dyke side on stilly moor or fen</line>
      <line>Feathered wi love and natures good intents</line>
      <line>Rude is the nest this Architect invents</line>
      <line>Rural the place wi cart ruts by dyke side</line>
      <line>Dead grass, horse hair and downy headed bents</line>
      <line>Tied to dead thistles she doth well provide</line>
      <line>Close to a hill 0’ ants where cowslips bloom</line>
      <line>And shed o’er meadows far their sweet perfume</line>
      <line>In early Spring when winds blow chilly cold</line>
      <line>The yellow hammer trailing grass will come</line>
      <line>To fix a place and choose an early home</line>
      <line>With yellow breast and head of solid gold</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mist rauk is hanging</line>
      <line>Over turnip fields green</line>
      <line>The wood gate is banging</line>
      <line>Where hunters are seen</line>
      <line>The brown leaves are dancing</line>
      <line>About on the green</line>
      <line>The horses are prancing</line>
      <line>Where the hounds hurry in</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where Lucy stands knocking</line>
      <line>Her clogs at the gate</line>
      <line>Bright shoes & white stocking</line>
      <line>Are killing of late</line>
      <line>Wi cotton or silk on</line>
      <line>What man could forbear</line>
      <line>Where Lucy sits milking</line>
      <line>To kiss if he dare</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Maples turn yellow</line>
      <line>Hazels crimson & brown</line>
      <line>Oaks still keep their colour</line>
      <line>Popples fade & fall down</line>
      <line>When a milking goes Lucy</line>
      <line>Where woodbramble weaves</line>
      <line>T[he] winds wont excuse ye</line>
      <line>But pelts her wi leaves</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On her new gown and bonnet</line>
      <line>They patter and fall</line>
      <line>Leaving no stain upon it</line>
      <line>They pat and thats all</line>
      <line>Crows quawk & swoop over</line>
      <line>Like chimney sweep crows</line>
      <line>Lucy milks under cover</line>
      <line>Nor sullies her clothes</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Home rambles young Lucy</line>
      <line>With her milk buckets twain</line>
      <line>Oer grass fields were dews be</line>
      <line>And rut brimming lane</line>
      <line>She sings songs till Sunday</line>
      <line>When she offers her vows</line>
      <line>And in drab frock on monday</line>
      <line>Goes milking the cows</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Clare</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>An Anecdote of Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When April & dew brings primroses here</line>
      <line>I think love of you at the Spring o’ the year</line>
      <line>Did I harbour bad words when your garter fell off</line>
      <line>I to stoop was deterred but I stood not to scoff</line>
      <line>A bitt of brown list of small value must be</line>
      <line>But as it lay there ’twas a diamond to me</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ere back you turned to pick it up</line>
      <line>I noticed well the place</line>
      <line>For children there for violets stoop</line>
      <line>With many a rosey face</line>
      <line>I fain would stoop myself you see</line>
      <line>But dare not well presume</line>
      <line>The Blackbird sung out let it be</line>
      <line>The maid was in her bloom</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How beautiful that ancle was</line>
      <line>From which that garter fell</line>
      <line>And lusty was the bonny lass</line>
      <line>Whose name I dare not tell</line>
      <line>I know the colour of her gown</line>
      <line>Her bonnet Ribbon too</line>
      <line>The fairest maiden in the town</line>
      <line>Is she that wears the blue</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though years have gone but when I see</line>
      <line>The green spot where it fell</line>
      <line>The stitchwort flower delighteth me</line>
      <line>There blooming in the dell</line>
      <line>And years may come no winter seers</line>
      <line>The green haunts of the Dove</line>
      <line>Those wild flowers stand the bl[i]ght of years</line>
      <line>Sweet anecdotes of love—</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Ruskin</author>
    <date>1844</date>
    <title>La Madonna dell'Acqua</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Around her shrine no earthly blossoms blow,</line>
      <line>No footsteps fret the pathway to and fro;</line>
      <line>No sign nor record of departed prayer,</line>
      <line>Print of the stone, nor echo of the air;</line>
      <line>Worn by the lip, nor wearied by the knee,—</line>
      <line>Only a deeper silence of the sea:</line>
      <line>For there, in passing, pause the breezes bleak,</line>
      <line>And the foam fades, and all the waves are weak.</line>
      <line>The pulse-like oars in softer fall succeed,</line>
      <line>The black prow falters through the wild seaweed—</line>
      <line>Where, twilight-borne, the minute thunders reach</line>
      <line>Of deep-mouthed surf, that bays by Lido’s beach,</line>
      <line>With intermittent motion traversed far,</line>
      <line>And shattered glancing of the western star,</line>
      <line>Till the faint storm-bird on the heaving flow</line>
      <line>Drops in white circles, silently like snow.</line>
      <line>Not here the ponderous gem, nor pealing note,</line>
      <line>Dim to adorn—insentient to adore—</line>
      <line>But purple-dyed, the mists of evening float,</line>
      <line>In ceaseless incense from the burning floor</line>
      <line>Of ocean, and the gathered gold of heaven</line>
      <line>Laces its sapphire vault, and, early given,</line>
      <line>The white rays of the rushing firmament</line>
      <line>Pierce the blue-quivering night through wreath or rent</line>
      <line>Of cloud inscrutable and motionless,</line>
      <line>Hectic and wan, and moon-companioned cloud!</line>
      <line>Oh! lone Madonna—angel of the deep—</line>
      <line>When the night falls, and deadly winds are loud,</line>
      <line>Will not thy love be with us while we keep</line>
      <line>Our watch upon the waters, and the gaze 30</line>
      <line>Of thy soft eyes, that slumber not, nor sleep?</line>
      <line>Deem not thou, stranger, that such trust is vain;</line>
      <line>Faith walks not on these weary waves alone,</line>
      <line>Though weakness dread, or apathy disdain</line>
      <line>The spot which God has hallowed for His own.</line>
      <line>They sin who pass it lightly—ill divining</line>
      <line>The glory of this place of bitter prayer;</line>
      <line>And hoping against hope, and self-resigning,</line>
      <line>And reach of faith, and wrestling with despair,</line>
      <line>And resurrection of the last distress,</line>
      <line>Into the sense of heaven, when earth is bare,</line>
      <line>And of God’s voice, when man’s is comfortless.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Ruskin</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>The Zodiac Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Horn for weapon, and wool for shield,</line>
      <line>Windy weather and lambs afield.</line>
      <line>Head in the sunshine, hoof in the hay,</line>
      <line>Toss the last of the clouds away.</line>
      <line>Double in leaf and double in light,</line>
      <line>Flowers by day, and stars by night.</line>
      <line>Cancer, Cancer, crooked and black,</line>
      <line>Answer us, answer us—Forward or back?</line>
      <line>Fierce at eve, at morning tame,</line>
      <line>Crest of cloud, and claws of flame.</line>
      <line>Sickle in hand, and sandal on feet,</line>
      <line>Crowned with poppy, and swathed with wheat.</line>
      <line>Libra, Libra, truth is treasure,</line>
      <line>Fair the weight and full the measure.</line>
      <line>Sharp the sting, but grand the grief,</line>
      <line>Shivering bough, and burning leaf.</line>
      <line>Numb the finger: narrow the mark,</line>
      <line>Frost on the feather, and flight in the dark.</line>
      <line>Capricorn, Capricorn,</line>
      <line>Cowardly heart, and crumpled horn.</line>
      <line>Snow to flicker, or rain to fall,</line>
      <line>Down with thy pitcher, and out with it all.</line>
      <line>Fish, little fish, lying head to tail,</line>
      <line>Daisies round the dish and a pearl on every scale.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Babington Macaulay</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>Epitaph on a Jacobite</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>To my true king I offered free from stain</line>
      <line>Courage and faith; vain faith, and courage vain.</line>
      <line>For him, I threw lands, honours, wealth, away,</line>
      <line>And one dear hope, that was more prized than they.</line>
      <line>For him I languished in a foreign clime,</line>
      <line>Grey-haired with sorrow in my manhood’s prime;</line>
      <line>Heard on Lavernia Scargill’s whispering trees,</line>
      <line>And pined by Arno for my lovelier Tees;</line>
      <line>Beheld each night my home in fevered sleep,</line>
      <line>Each morning started from the dream to weep;</line>
      <line>Till God, who saw me tried too sorely, gave</line>
      <line>The resting place I asked, an early grave.</line>
      <line>Oh thou, whom chance leads to this nameless stone,</line>
      <line>From that proud country which was once mine own,</line>
      <line>By those white cliffs I never more must see,</line>
      <line>By that dear language which I spake like thee,</line>
      <line>Forget all feuds, and shed one English tear</line>
      <line>O’er English dust. A broken heart lies here.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>Rales and Regulations</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A short direction</line>
      <line>To avoid dejection,</line>
      <line>By variations</line>
      <line>In occupations,</line>
      <line>And prolongation</line>
      <line>Of relaxation,</line>
      <line>And combinations</line>
      <line>Of recreations,</line>
      <line>And disputation</line>
      <line>On the state of the nation</line>
      <line>In adaptation</line>
      <line>To your station,</line>
      <line>By invitations</line>
      <line>To friends and relations,</line>
      <line>By evitation</line>
      <line>Of amputation,</line>
      <line>By permutation</line>
      <line>In conversation,</line>
      <line>And deep reflection</line>
      <line>You’ll avoid dejection.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Learn well your grammar,</line>
      <line>And never stammer,</line>
      <line>Write well and neatly,</line>
      <line>And sing most sweetly,</line>
      <line>Be enterprising,</line>
      <line>Love early rising,</line>
      <line>Go walk of six miles,</line>
      <line>Have ready quick smiles,</line>
      <line>With lightsome laughter,</line>
      <line>Soft flowing after.</line>
      <line>Drink tea, not coffee;</line>
      <line>Never eat toffy.</line>
      <line>Eat bread with butter.</line>
      <line>Once more, don’t stutter.</line>
      <line>Don’t waste your money,</line>
      <line>Abstain from honey.</line>
      <line>Shut doors behind you,</line>
      <line>(Don’t slam them, mind you.)</line>
      <line>Drink beer, not porter.</line>
      <line>Don’t enter the water</line>
      <line>Till to swim you are able.</line>
      <line>Sit close to the table.</line>
      <line>Take care of a candle.</line>
      <line>Shut a door by the handle,</line>
      <line>Don’t push with your shoulder</line>
      <line>Until you are older.</line>
      <line>Lose not a button.</line>
      <line>Refuse cold mutton.</line>
      <line>Starve your canaries.</line>
      <line>Believe in fairies.</line>
      <line>If you are able,</line>
      <line>Don’t have a stable</line>
      <line>With any mangers.</line>
      <line>Be rude to strangers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Moral: Behave.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>They told me you had been to her,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They told me you had been to her,</line>
      <line>And mentioned me to him:</line>
      <line>She gave me a good character,</line>
      <line>But said I could not swim.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sent them word I had not gone</line>
      <line>(We know it to be true):</line>
      <line>If she should push the matter on,</line>
      <line>What would become of you?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I gave her one, they gave him two,</line>
      <line>You gave us three or more;</line>
      <line>They all returned from him to you,</line>
      <line>Though they were mine before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If I or she should chance to be</line>
      <line>Involved in this affair,</line>
      <line>He trusts to you to set them free,</line>
      <line>Exactly as we were.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My notion was that you had been</line>
      <line>(Before she had this fit)</line>
      <line>An obstacle that came between</line>
      <line>Him, and ourselves, and it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Don’t let him know she liked them best,</line>
      <line>For this must ever be</line>
      <line>A secret, kept from all the rest,</line>
      <line>Between yourself and me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>How doth the little crocodile</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How doth the little crocodile</line>
      <line>Improve his shining tail,</line>
      <line>And pour the waters of the Nile</line>
      <line>On every golden scale!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How cheerfully he seems to grin,</line>
      <line>How neatly spreads his claws,</line>
      <line>And welcomes little fishes in,</line>
      <line>With gently smiling jaws!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>‘You are old, Father William,’ the young man said</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And your hair has become very white;</line>
      <line>And yet you incessantly stand on your head—</line>
      <line>Do you think, at your age, it is right?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘In my youth’, Father William replied to his son,</line>
      <line>‘I feared it might injure the brain;</line>
      <line>But, now that I’m perfectly sure I have none,</line>
      <line>Why, I do it again and again.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You are old,’ said the youth, ‘as I mentioned before,</line>
      <line>And have grown most uncommonly fat;</line>
      <line>Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door—</line>
      <line>Pray, what is the reason of that?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘In my youth’, said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,</line>
      <line>‘I kept all my limbs very supple</line>
      <line>By the use of this ointment—one shilling the box—</line>
      <line>Allow me to sell you a couple?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You are old,’ said the youth, ‘and your jaws are too weak</line>
      <line>For anything tougher than suet;</line>
      <line>Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak—</line>
      <line>Pray, how did you manage to do it?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘In my youth’, said his father, ‘I took to the law,</line>
      <line>And argued each case with my wife;</line>
      <line>And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw</line>
      <line>Has lasted the rest of my life.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You are old,’ said the youth, ‘one would hardly suppose</line>
      <line>That your eye was as steady as ever;</line>
      <line>Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose—</line>
      <line>What made you so awfully clever?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I have answered three questions, and that is enough,’</line>
      <line>Said his father, ‘Don’t give yourself airs!</line>
      <line>Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?</line>
      <line>Be off, or I’ll kick you down-stairs!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>Jabberwocky</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas brillig, and the slithy toves</line>
      <line>Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:</line>
      <line>All mimsy were the borogoves,</line>
      <line>And the mome raths outgrabe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Beware the Jabberwock, my son!</line>
      <line>The jaws that bite, the claws that catch!</line>
      <line>Beware the Jubjub bird, and shun</line>
      <line>The frumious Bandersnatch!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He took his vorpal sword in hand:</line>
      <line>Long time the manxome foe he sought—</line>
      <line>So rested he by the Tumtum tree,</line>
      <line>And stood awhile in thought.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, as in uffish thought he stood,</line>
      <line>The Jabberwock, with eyes of flame,</line>
      <line>Came whiffling through the tulgey wood,</line>
      <line>And burbled as it came!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One, two! One, two! And through and through</line>
      <line>The vorpal blade went snicker-snack!</line>
      <line>He left it dead, and with its head</line>
      <line>He went galumphing back.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And hast thou slain the Jabberwock?</line>
      <line>Come to my arms, my beamish boy!</line>
      <line>O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!’</line>
      <line>He chortled in his joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Twas brillig, and the slithy toves</line>
      <line>Did gyre and gimble in the wabe:</line>
      <line>All mimsy were the borogoves,</line>
      <line>And the mome raths outgrabe.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>The sun was shining on the sea,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun was shining on the sea,</line>
      <line>Shining with all his might:</line>
      <line>He did his very best to make</line>
      <line>The billows smooth and bright—</line>
      <line>And this was odd, because it was</line>
      <line>The middle of the night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moon was shining sulkily,</line>
      <line>Because she thought the sun</line>
      <line>Had got no business to be there</line>
      <line>After the day was done—</line>
      <line>‘It’s very rude of him’, she said,</line>
      <line>‘To come and spoil the fun!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sea was wet as wet could be,</line>
      <line>The sands were dry as dry.</line>
      <line>You could not see a cloud, because</line>
      <line>No cloud was in the sky:</line>
      <line>No birds were flying overhead—</line>
      <line>There were no birds to fly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Walrus and the Carpenter</line>
      <line>Were walking close at hand:</line>
      <line>They wept like anything to see</line>
      <line>Such quantities of sand:</line>
      <line>‘If this were only cleared away,’</line>
      <line>They said, ‘it would be grand!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘If seven maids with seven mops</line>
      <line>Swept it for half a year,</line>
      <line>Do you suppose’, the Walrus said,</line>
      <line>‘That they could get it clear?’</line>
      <line>‘I doubt it,’ said the Carpenter,</line>
      <line>And shed a bitter tear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘O Oysters, come and walk with us!’</line>
      <line>The Walrus did beseech.</line>
      <line>‘A pleasant walk, a pleasant talk,</line>
      <line>Along the briny beach:</line>
      <line>We cannot do with more than four,</line>
      <line>To give a hand to each.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The eldest Oyster looked at him,</line>
      <line>But never a word he said:</line>
      <line>The eldest Oyster winked his eye,</line>
      <line>And shook his heavy head—</line>
      <line>Meaning to say he did not choose</line>
      <line>To leave the oyster-bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But four young Oysters hurried up,</line>
      <line>All eager for the treat:</line>
      <line>Their coats were brushed, their faces washed,</line>
      <line>Their shoes were clean and neat—</line>
      <line>And this was odd, because, you know,</line>
      <line>They hadn’t any feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Four other Oysters followed them,</line>
      <line>And yet another four;</line>
      <line>And thick and fast they came at last,</line>
      <line>And more, and more, and more—</line>
      <line>All hopping through the frothy waves,</line>
      <line>And scrambling to the shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Walrus and the Carpenter</line>
      <line>Walked on a mile or so,</line>
      <line>And then they rested on a rock</line>
      <line>Conveniently low:</line>
      <line>And all the little Oysters stood</line>
      <line>And waited in a row.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The time has come’, the Walrus said,</line>
      <line>‘To talk of many things:</line>
      <line>Of shoes—and ships—and sealing wax—</line>
      <line>Of cabbages—and kings—</line>
      <line>And why the sea is boiling hot—</line>
      <line>And whether pigs have wings.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘But wait a bit,’ the Oysters cried,</line>
      <line>‘Before we have our chat;</line>
      <line>For some of us are out of breath,</line>
      <line>And all of us are fat!’</line>
      <line>‘No hurry!’ said the Carpenter.</line>
      <line>They thanked him much for that.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>‘A loaf of bread’, the Walrus said,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Is what we chiefly need:</line>
      <line>Pepper and vinegar besides</line>
      <line>Are very good indeed—</line>
      <line>Now, if you’re ready, Oysters dear,</line>
      <line>We can begin to feed.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘But not on us!’ the Oysters cried,</line>
      <line>Turning a little blue.</line>
      <line>‘After such kindness, that would be</line>
      <line>A dismal thing to do!’</line>
      <line>‘The night is fine,’ the Walrus said.</line>
      <line>‘Do you admire the view?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It was so kind of you to come!</line>
      <line>And you are very nice!’</line>
      <line>The Carpenter said nothing but</line>
      <line>‘Cut us another slice.</line>
      <line>I wish you were not quite so deaf—</line>
      <line>I’ve had to ask you twice!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It seems a shame’, the Walrus said,</line>
      <line>‘To play them such a trick.</line>
      <line>After we’ve brought them out so far,</line>
      <line>And made them trot so quick!’</line>
      <line>The Carpenter said nothing but</line>
      <line>‘The butter’s spread too thick!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I weep for you,’ the Walrus said:</line>
      <line>‘I deeply sympathize.’</line>
      <line>With sobs and tears he sorted out</line>
      <line>Those of the largest size, 100</line>
      <line>Holding his pocket-handkerchief</line>
      <line>Before his streaming eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Q Oysters,’ said the Carpenter,</line>
      <line>‘You’ve had a pleasant run!</line>
      <line>Shall we be trotting home again?’</line>
      <line>But answer came there none—</line>
      <line>And this was scarcely odd, because</line>
      <line>They’d eaten every one.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>In winter, when the fields are white,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In winter, when the fields are white,</line>
      <line>I sing this song for your delight—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In spring, when woods are getting green,</line>
      <line>I’ll try and tell you what I mean:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In summer, when the days are long,</line>
      <line>Perhaps you’ll understand the song:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In autumn, when the leaves are brown,</line>
      <line>Take pen and ink, and write it down.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I sent a message to the fish:</line>
      <line>I told them ‘This is what I wish.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The little fishes of the sea,</line>
      <line>They sent an answer back to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The little fishes’ answer was</line>
