      <line>‘We cannot do it, Sir, because—’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I sent to them again to say</line>
      <line>‘It will be better to obey’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fishes answered, with a grin,</line>
      <line>‘Why, what a temper you are in!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I told them once, I told them twice:</line>
      <line>They would not listen to advice.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took a kettle large and new,</line>
      <line>Fit for the deed I had to do.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My heart went hop, my heart went thump:</line>
      <line>I filled the kettle at the pump.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then some one came to me and said</line>
      <line>‘The little fishes are in bed.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said to him, I said it plain,</line>
      <line>‘Then you must wake them up again.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said it very loud and clear:</line>
      <line>I went and shouted in his ear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But he was very stiff and proud:</line>
      <line>He said, ‘You needn’t shout so loud!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he was very proud and stiff:</line>
      <line>He said ‘I’d go and wake them, if—’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took a corkscrew from the shelf:</line>
      <line>I went to wake them up myself.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when I found the door was locked,</line>
      <line>I pulled and pushed and kicked and knocked.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when I found the door was shut,</line>
      <line>I tried to turn the handle, but—</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Hunting of the Snark</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Just the place for a Snark!’ the Bellman cried,</line>
      <line>As he landed his crew with care;</line>
      <line>Supporting each man on the top of the tide</line>
      <line>By a finger entwined in his hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Just the place for a Snark! I have said it twice:</line>
      <line>That alone should encourage the crew.</line>
      <line>Just the place for a Snark! I have said it thrice:</line>
      <line>What I tell you three times is true.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The crew was complete: it included a Boots—</line>
      <line>A maker of Bonnets and Hoods—</line>
      <line>A Barrister, brought to arrange their disputes—</line>
      <line>And a Broker, to value their goods.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A Billiard-marker, whose skill was immense,</line>
      <line>Might perhaps have won more than his share—</line>
      <line>But a Banker, engaged at enormous expense,</line>
      <line>Had the whole of their cash in his care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was also a Beaver, that paced on the deck,</line>
      <line>Or would sit making lace in the bow:</line>
      <line>And had often (the Bellman said) saved them from wreck</line>
      <line>Though none of the sailors knew how.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was one who was famed for the number of things</line>
      <line>He forgot when he entered the ship:</line>
      <line>His umbrella, his watch, all his jewels and rings,</line>
      <line>And the clothes he had bought for the trip.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had forty-two boxes, all carefully packed,</line>
      <line>With his name painted clearly on each:</line>
      <line>But, since he omitted to mention the fact,</line>
      <line>They were all left behind on the beach.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The loss of his clothes hardly mattered, because</line>
      <line>He had seven coats on when he came,</line>
      <line>With three pair of boots—but the worst of it was,</line>
      <line>He had wholly forgotten his name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He would answer to ‘Hi’ or to any loud cry,</line>
      <line>Such as ‘Fry me!’ or ‘Fritter my wig!’</line>
      <line>To ‘What-you-may-call-um!’ or ‘What-was-his-name!’</line>
      <line>But especially ‘Thing-um-a-jig!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While, for those who preferred a more forcible word,</line>
      <line>He had different names from these:</line>
      <line>His intimate friends called him ‘Candle-ends’,</line>
      <line>And his enemies ‘Toasted-cheese’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘His form is ungainly—his intellect small—’</line>
      <line>(So the Bellman would often remark)—</line>
      <line>‘But his courage is perfect! And that, after all,</line>
      <line>Is the thing that one needs with a Snark.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He would joke with hyaenas, returning their stare</line>
      <line>With an impudent wag of the head:</line>
      <line>And he once went a walk, paw-in-paw, with a bear,</line>
      <line>‘Just to keep up its spirits,’ he said.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He came as a Baker: but owned, when too late—</line>
      <line>And it drove the poor Bellman half-mad—</line>
      <line>He could only bake Bridecake—for which, I may state,</line>
      <line>No materials were to be had.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The last of the crew needs especial remark,</line>
      <line>Though he looked an incredible dunce:</line>
      <line>He had just one idea—but, that one being ‘Snark’,</line>
      <line>The good Bellman engaged him at once.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He came as a Butcher: but gravely declared,</line>
      <line>When the ship had been sailing a week,</line>
      <line>He could only kill Beavers. The Bellman looked scared,</line>
      <line>And was almost too frightened to speak:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But at length he explained, in a tremulous tone,</line>
      <line>There was only one Beaver on board;</line>
      <line>And that was a tame one he had of his own,</line>
      <line>Whose death would be deeply deplored.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Beaver, who happened to hear the remark,</line>
      <line>Protested, with tears in its eyes,</line>
      <line>That not even the rapture of hunting the Snark</line>
      <line>Could atone for that dismal surprise!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It strongly advised that the Butcher should be</line>
      <line>Conveyed in a separate ship:</line>
      <line>But the Bellman declared that would never agree</line>
      <line>With the plans he had made for the trip:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Navigation was always a difficult art,</line>
      <line>Though with only one ship and one bell:</line>
      <line>And he feared he must really decline, for his part,</line>
      <line>Undertaking another as well.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Beaver’s best course was, no doubt, to procure</line>
      <line>A second-hand dagger-proof coat—</line>
      <line>So the Baker advised it—and next, to insure</line>
      <line>Its life in some Office of note:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This the Baker suggested, and offered for hire</line>
      <line>(On moderate terms), or for sale,</line>
      <line>Two excellent Policies, one Against Fire</line>
      <line>And one Against Damage From Hail.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet still, ever after that sorrowful day,</line>
      <line>Whenever the Butcher was by,</line>
      <line>The Beaver kept looking the opposite way,</line>
      <line>And appeared unaccountably shy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Bellman himself they all praised to the skies—</line>
      <line>Such a carriage, such ease and such grace!</line>
      <line>Such solemnity, too! One could see he was wise,</line>
      <line>The moment one looked in his face!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had bought a large map representing the sea,</line>
      <line>Without the least vestige of land:</line>
      <line>And the crew were much pleased when they found it to be</line>
      <line>A map they could all understand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What’s the good of Mercator’s North Poles and Equators,</line>
      <line>Tropics, Zones, and Meridian Lines?’</line>
      <line>So the Bellman would cry: and the crew would reply</line>
      <line>‘They are merely conventional signs!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Other maps are such shapes, with their islands and capes!</line>
      <line>But we’ve got our brave Captain to thank’</line>
      <line>(So the crew would protest) ‘that he’s bought us the best—</line>
      <line>A perfect and absolute blank!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This was charming, no doubt: but they shortly found out</line>
      <line>That the Captain they trusted so well</line>
      <line>Had only one notion for crossing the ocean,</line>
      <line>And that was to tingle his bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He was thoughtful and grave—but the orders he gave</line>
      <line>Were enough to bewilder a crew.</line>
      <line>When he cried ‘Steer to starboard, but keep her head larboard!’</line>
      <line>What on earth was the helmsman to do?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the bowsprit got mixed with the rudder sometimes:</line>
      <line>A thing, as the Bellman remarked,</line>
      <line>That frequently happens in tropical climes,</line>
      <line>When a vessel is, so to speak, ‘snarked’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the principal failing occurred in the sailing,</line>
      <line>And the Bellman, perplexed and distressed,</line>
      <line>Said he had hoped, at least, when the wind blew due East,</line>
      <line>That the ship would not travel due West!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the danger was past—they had landed at last,</line>
      <line>With their boxes, portmanteaus, and bags:</line>
      <line>Yet at first sight the crew were not pleased with the view</line>
      <line>Which consisted of chasms and crags.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Bellman perceived that their spirits were low,</line>
      <line>And repeated in musical tone</line>
      <line>Some jokes he had kept for a season of woe—</line>
      <line>But the crew would do nothing but groan.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He served out some grog with a liberal hand,</line>
      <line>And bade them sit down on the beach:</line>
      <line>And they could not but own that their Captain looked grand,</line>
      <line>As he stood and delivered his speech.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Friends, Romans, and countrymen, lend me your ears!’</line>
      <line>(They were all of them fond of quotations:</line>
      <line>So they drank to his health, and they gave him three cheers,</line>
      <line>While he served out additional rations).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We have sailed many months, we have sailed many weeks,</line>
      <line>(Four weeks to the month you may mark),</line>
      <line>But never as yet (’tis your Captain who speaks)</line>
      <line>Have we caught the least glimpse of a Snark!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We have sailed many weeks, we have sailed many days,</line>
      <line>(Seven days to the week I allow),</line>
      <line>But a Snark, on the which we might lovingly gaze,</line>
      <line>We have never beheld till now!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Come, listen, my men, while I tell you again</line>
      <line>The five unmistakable marks</line>
      <line>By which you may know, wheresoever you go,</line>
      <line>The warranted genuine Snarks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Let us take them in order. The first is the taste,</line>
      <line>Which is meagre and hollow, but crisp:</line>
      <line>Like a coat that is rather too tight in the waist,</line>
      <line>With a flavour of Will-o’-the-Wisp.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Its habit of getting up late you’ll agree</line>
      <line>That it carries too far, when I say</line>
      <line>That it frequently breakfasts at five-o’clock tea,</line>
      <line>And dines on the following day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The third is its slowness in taking a jest.</line>
      <line>Should you happen to venture on one,</line>
      <line>It will sigh like a thing that is deeply distressed:</line>
      <line>And it always looks grave at a pun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The fourth is its fondness for bathing-machines,</line>
      <line>Which it constantly carries about,</line>
      <line>And believes that they add to the beauty of scenes—</line>
      <line>A sentiment open to doubt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The fifth is ambition. It next will be right</line>
      <line>To describe each particular batch:</line>
      <line>Distinguishing those that have feathers, and bite,</line>
      <line>From those that have whiskers, and scratch.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘For, although common Snarks do no manner of harm,</line>
      <line>Yet I feel it my duty to say</line>
      <line>Some are Boojums—’ The Bellman broke off in alarm,</line>
      <line>For the Baker had fainted away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They roused him with muffins—they roused him with ice—</line>
      <line>They roused him with mustard and cress—</line>
      <line>They roused him with jam and judicious advice—</line>
      <line>They set him conundrums to guess.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When at length he sat up and was able to speak,</line>
      <line>His sad story he offered to tell;</line>
      <line>And the Bellman cried ‘Silence! Not even a shriek!’</line>
      <line>And excitedly tingled his bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was silence supreme! Not a shriek, not a scream,</line>
      <line>Scarcely even a howl or a groan,</line>
      <line>As the man they called ‘Ho!’ told his story of woe</line>
      <line>In an antediluvian tone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My father and mother were honest, though poor—’</line>
      <line>‘Skip all that!’ cried the Bellman in haste.</line>
      <line>‘If it once becomes dark, there’s no chance of a Snark—</line>
      <line>We have hardly a minute to waste!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I skip forty years,’ said the Baker in tears,</line>
      <line>‘And proceed without further remark</line>
      <line>To the day when you took me aboard of your ship</line>
      <line>To help you in hunting the Snark.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘A dear uncle of mine (after whom I was named)</line>
      <line>Remarked, when I bade him farewell—’</line>
      <line>‘Oh, skip your dear uncle!’ the Bellman exclaimed,</line>
      <line>As he angrily tingled his bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He remarked to me then,’ said that mildest of men,</line>
      <line>‘ “If your Snark be a Snark, that is right:</line>
      <line>Fetch it home by all means—you may serve it with greens</line>
      <line>And it’s handy for striking a light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘ “You may seek it with thimbles—and seek it with care—</line>
      <line>You may hunt it with forks and hope;</line>
      <line>You may threaten its life with a railway-share;</line>
      <line>You may charm it with smiles and soap—” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(‘That’s exactly the method,’ the Bellman bold</line>
      <line>In a hasty parenthesis cried,</line>
      <line>‘That’s exactly the way I have always been told</line>
      <line>That the capture of Snarks should be tried!’)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘ “But oh, beamish nephew, beware of the day,</line>
      <line>If your Snark be a Boojum! For then</line>
      <line>You will softly and suddenly vanish away,</line>
      <line>And never be met with again!”</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It is this, it is this that oppresses my soul,</line>
      <line>When I think of my uncle’s last words:</line>
      <line>And my heart is like nothing so much as a bowl</line>
      <line>Brimming over with quivering curds!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It is this, it is this—’ ‘We have had that before!’</line>
      <line>The Bellman indignantly said.</line>
      <line>And the Baker replied ‘Let me say it once more.</line>
      <line>It is this, it is this that I dread!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I engage with the Snark—every night after dark—</line>
      <line>In a dreamy delirious fight:</line>
      <line>I serve it with greens in those shadowy scenes,</line>
      <line>And 1 use it for striking a light:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘But if ever I meet with a Boojum, that day,</line>
      <line>In a moment (of this I am sure),</line>
      <line>I shall softly and suddenly vanish away—</line>
      <line>And the notion I cannot endure!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Bellman looked uffish, and wrinkled his brow.</line>
      <line>‘If only you’d spoken before!</line>
      <line>It’s excessively awkward to mention it now,</line>
      <line>With the Snark, so to speak, at the door!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We should all of us grieve, as you well may believe,</line>
      <line>If you never were met with again—</line>
      <line>But surely, my man, when the voyage began,</line>
      <line>You might have suggested it then?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It’s excessively awkward to mention it now—</line>
      <line>As I think I’ve already remarked.’</line>
      <line>And the man they called ‘Hi!’ replied, with a sigh,</line>
      <line>‘I informed you the day we embarked.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You may charge me with murder—or want of sense—</line>
      <line>(We are all of us weak at times):</line>
      <line>But the slightest approach to a false pretence</line>
      <line>Was never among my crimes!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I said it in Hebrew—I said it in Dutch—</line>
      <line>I said it in German and Greek:</line>
      <line>But I wholly forgot (and it vexes me much)</line>
      <line>That English is what you speak!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>”Tis a pitiful tale,’ said the Bellman, whose face</line>
      <line>Had grown longer at every word:</line>
      <line>‘But, now that you’ve stated the whole of your case,</line>
      <line>More debate would be simply absurd.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The rest of my speech’ (he exclaimed to his men)</line>
      <line>‘You shall hear when I’ve leisure to speak it.</line>
      <line>But the Snark is at hand, let me tell you again!</line>
      <line>’Tis your glorious duty to seek it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘To seek it with thimbles, to seek it with care;</line>
      <line>To pursue it with forks and hope;</line>
      <line>To threaten its life with a railway-share;</line>
      <line>To charm it with smiles and soap!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘For the Snark’s a peculiar creature, that wo’n’t</line>
      <line>Be caught in a commonplace way.</line>
      <line>Do all that you know, and try all that you don’t:</line>
      <line>Not a chance must be wasted to-day!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘For England expects—I forbear to proceed:</line>
      <line>’Tis a maxim tremendous, but trite:</line>
      <line>And you’d best be unpacking the things that you need</line>
      <line>To rig yourselves out for the fight.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the Banker endorsed a blank cheque (which he crossed),</line>
      <line>And changed his loose silver for notes:</line>
      <line>The Baker with care combed his whiskers and hair,</line>
      <line>And shook the dust out of his coats:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Boots and the Broker were sharpening a spade—</line>
      <line>Each working the grindstone in turn:</line>
      <line>But the Beaver went on making lace, and displayed</line>
      <line>No interest in the concern:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the Barrister tried to appeal to its pride,</line>
      <line>And vainly proceeded to cite</line>
      <line>A number of cases, in which making laces</line>
      <line>Had been proved an infringement of right.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The maker of Bonnets ferociously planned</line>
      <line>A novel arrangement of bows:</line>
      <line>While the Billiard-marker with quivering hand</line>
      <line>Was chalking the tip of his nose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the Butcher turned nervous, and dressed himself fine,</line>
      <line>With yellow kid gloves and a ruff—</line>
      <line>Said he felt it exactly like going to dine,</line>
      <line>Which the Bellman declared was all ‘stuff.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Introduce me, now there’s a good fellow,’ he said,</line>
      <line>‘If we happen to meet it together!’</line>
      <line>And the Bellman, sagaciously nodding his head,</line>
      <line>Said ‘That must depend on the weather.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Beaver went simply galumphing about,</line>
      <line>At seeing the Butcher so shy:</line>
      <line>And even the Baker, though stupid and stout,</line>
      <line>Made an effort to wink with one eye.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Be a man!’ said the Bellman in wrath, as he heard</line>
      <line>The Butcher beginning to sob.</line>
      <line>‘Should we meet with a Jubjub, that desperate bird,</line>
      <line>We shall need all our strength for the job!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They sought it with thimbles, they sought it with care;</line>
      <line>They pursued it with forks and hope;</line>
      <line>They threatened its life with a railway-share;</line>
      <line>They charmed it with smiles and soap.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the Butcher contrived an ingenious plan</line>
      <line>For making a separate sally;</line>
      <line>And had fixed on a spot unfrequented by man,</line>
      <line>A dismal and desolate valley.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the very same plan to the Beaver occurred:</line>
      <line>It had chosen the very same place:</line>
      <line>Yet neither betrayed, by a sign or a word,</line>
      <line>The disgust that appeared in his face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each thought he was thinking of nothing but ‘Snark’</line>
      <line>And the glorious work of the day;</line>
      <line>And each tried to pretend that he did not remark</line>
      <line>That the other was going that way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the valley grew narrower and narrower still,</line>
      <line>And the evening got darker and colder,</line>
      <line>Till (merely from nervousness, not from good will)</line>
      <line>They marched along shoulder to shoulder.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then a scream, shrill and high, rent the shuddering sky</line>
      <line>And they knew that some danger was near:</line>
      <line>The Beaver turned pale to the tip of its tail,</line>
      <line>And even the Butcher felt queer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He thought of his childhood, left far behind—</line>
      <line>That blissful and innocent state—</line>
      <line>The sound so exactly recalled to his mind</line>
      <line>A pencil that squeaks on a slate!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘’Tis the voice of the Jubjub!’ he suddenly cried.</line>
      <line>(This man, that they used to call ‘Dunce’.)</line>
      <line>‘As the Bellman would tell you,’ he added with pride,</line>
      <line>‘I have uttered that sentiment once.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘’Tis the note of the Jubjub! Keep count, I entreat.</line>
      <line>You will find I have told it you twice.</line>
      <line>’Tis the song of the Jubjub! The proof is complete.</line>
      <line>If only I’ve stated it thrice.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Beaver had counted with scrupulous care,</line>
      <line>Attending to every word:</line>
      <line>But it fairly lost heart, and outgrabe in despair,</line>
      <line>When the third repetition occurred.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It felt that, in spite of all possible pains,</line>
      <line>It had somehow contrived to lose count,</line>
      <line>And the only thing now was to rack its poor brains</line>
      <line>By reckoning up the amount.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Two added to one—if that could but be done’,</line>
      <line>It said, ‘with one’s fingers and thumbs!’</line>
      <line>Recollecting with tears how, in earlier years,</line>
      <line>It had taken no pains with its sums.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The thing can be done,’ said the Butcher, ‘I think.</line>
      <line>The thing must be done, I am sure.</line>
      <line>The thing shall be done! Bring me paper and ink,</line>
      <line>The best there is time to procure.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Beaver brought paper, portfolio, pens,</line>
      <line>And ink in unfailing supplies:</line>
      <line>While strange creepy creatures came out of their dens,</line>
      <line>And watched them with wondering eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So engrossed was the Butcher, he heeded them not,</line>
      <line>As he wrote with a pen in each hand,</line>
      <line>And explained all the while in a popular style</line>
      <line>Which the Beaver could well understand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Taking Three as the subject to reason about—</line>
      <line>A convenient number to state—</line>
      <line>We add Seven, and Ten, and then multiply out</line>
      <line>By One Thousand diminished by Eight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The result we proceed to divide, as you see,</line>
      <line>By Nine Hundred and Ninety and Two:</line>
      <line>Then subtract Seventeen, and the answer must be</line>
      <line>Exactly and perfectly true.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The method employed I would gladly explain,</line>
      <line>While I have it so clear in my head,</line>
      <line>If I had but the time and you had but the brain—</line>
      <line>But much yet remains to be said.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘In one moment I’ve seen what has hitherto been</line>
      <line>Enveloped in absolute mystery,</line>
      <line>And without extra charge I will give you at large</line>
      <line>A Lesson in Natural History.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In his genial way he proceeded to say</line>
      <line>(Forgetting all laws of propriety,</line>
      <line>And that giving instruction, without introduction,</line>
      <line>Would have caused quite a thrill in Society),</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘As to temper the Jubjub’s a desperate bird.</line>
      <line>Since it lives in perpetual passion:</line>
      <line>Its taste in costume is entirely absurd—</line>
      <line>It is ages ahead of the fashion:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘But it knows any friend it has met once before:</line>
      <line>It never will look at a bribe:</line>
      <line>And in charity-meetings it stands at the door,</line>
      <line>And collects—though it does not subscribe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Its flavour when cooked is more exquisite far</line>
      <line>Than mutton, or oysters, or eggs:</line>
      <line>(Some think it keeps best in an ivory jar,</line>
      <line>And some, in mahogany kegs:)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You boil it in sawdust: you salt it in glue:</line>
      <line>You condense it with locusts and tape:</line>
      <line>Still keeping one principal object in view—</line>
      <line>To preserve its symmetrical shape.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Butcher would gladly have talked till next day,</line>
      <line>But he felt that the Lesson must end,</line>
      <line>And he wept with delight in attempting to say</line>
      <line>He considered the Beaver his friend:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While the Beaver confessed, with affectionate looks</line>
      <line>More eloquent even than tears,</line>
      <line>It had learned in ten minutes far more than all books</line>
      <line>Would have taught it in seventy years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They returned hand-in-hand, and the Bellman, unmanned</line>
      <line>(For a moment) with noble emotion,</line>
      <line>Said ‘This amply repays all the wearisome days</line>
      <line>We have spent on the billowy ocean!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such friends, as the Beaver and Butcher became,</line>
      <line>Have seldom if ever been known;</line>
      <line>In winter or summer, ’twas always the same—</line>
      <line>You could never meet either alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when quarrels arose—as one frequently finds</line>
      <line>Quarrels will, spite of every endeavour—</line>
      <line>The song of the Jubjub recurred to their minds,</line>
      <line>And cemented their friendship for ever!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They sought it with thimbles, they sought it with care;</line>
      <line>They pursued it with forks and hope;</line>
      <line>They threatened its life with a railway-share;</line>
      <line>They charmed it with smiles and soap.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the Barrister, weary of proving in vain</line>
      <line>That the Beaver’s lace-making was wrong,</line>
      <line>Fell asleep, and in dreams saw the creature quite plain</line>
      <line>That his fancy had dwelt on so long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He dreamed that he stood in a shadowy Court,</line>
      <line>Where the Snark, with a glass in its eye,</line>
      <line>Dressed in gown, bands, and wig, was defending a pig</line>
      <line>On the charge of deserting its sty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Witnesses proved, without error or flaw,</line>
      <line>That the sty was deserted when found:</line>
      <line>And the Judge kept explaining the state of the law</line>
      <line>In a soft under-current of sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The indictment had never been clearly expressed,</line>
      <line>And it seemed that the Snark had begun,</line>
      <line>And had spoken three hours, before any one guessed</line>
      <line>What the pig was supposed to have done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Jury had each formed a different view</line>
      <line>(Long before the indictment was read),</line>
      <line>And they all spoke at once, so that none of them knew</line>
      <line>One word that the others had said.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘You must know—’ said the Judge: but the Snark exclaimed ‘Fudge!</line>
      <line>That statute is obsolete quite!</line>
      <line>Let me tell you, my friends, the whole question depends</line>
      <line>On an ancient manorial right.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘In the matter of Treason the pig would appear</line>
      <line>To have aided, but scarcely abetted:</line>
      <line>While the charge of Insolvency fails, it is clear,</line>
      <line>If you grant the plea “never indebted”.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The fact of Desertion I will not dispute:</line>
      <line>But its guilt, as I trust, is removed</line>
      <line>(So far as relates to the costs of this suit)</line>
      <line>By the Alibi which has been proved.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘My poor client’s fate now depends on your votes.’</line>
      <line>Here the speaker sat down in his place,</line>
      <line>And directed the Judge to refer to his notes</line>
      <line>And briefly to sum up the case.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the Judge said he never had summed up before;</line>
      <line>So the Snark undertook it instead,</line>
      <line>And summed it so well that it came to far more</line>
      <line>Than the Witnesses ever had said!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the verdict was called for, the Jury declined,</line>
      <line>As the word was so puzzling to spell;</line>
      <line>But they ventured to hope that the Snark wouldn’t mind</line>
      <line>Undertaking that duty as well.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So the Snark found the verdict, although, as it owned,</line>
      <line>It was spent with the toils of the day:</line>
      <line>When it said the word ‘guilty!’ the Jury all groaned</line>
      <line>And some of them fainted away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the Snark pronounced sentence, the Judge being quite</line>
      <line>Too nervous to utter a word:</line>
      <line>When it rose to its feet, there was silence like night,</line>
      <line>And the fall of a pin might be heard.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Transportation for life’ was the sentence it gave,</line>
      <line>‘And then to be fined forty pound.’</line>
      <line>The Jury all cheered, though the Judge said he feared</line>
      <line>That the phrase was not legally sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But their wild exultation was suddenly checked</line>
      <line>When the jailer informed them, with tears,</line>
      <line>Such a sentence would have not the slightest effect,</line>
      <line>As the pig had been dead for some years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Judge left the Court, looking deeply disgusted</line>
      <line>But the Snark, though a little aghast,</line>
      <line>As the lawyer to whom the defence was intrusted,</line>
      <line>Went bellowing on to the last.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus the Barrister dreamed, while the bellowing seemed</line>
      <line>To grow every moment more clear:</line>
      <line>Till he woke to the knell of a furious bell,</line>
      <line>Which the Bellman rang close at his ear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They sought it with thimbles, they sought it with care;</line>
      <line>They pursued it with forks and hope;</line>
      <line>They threatened its life with a railway-share;</line>
      <line>They charmed it with smiles and soap.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the Banker, inspired with a courage so new</line>
      <line>It was matter for general remark,</line>
      <line>Rushed madly ahead and was lost to their view</line>
      <line>In his zeal to discover the Snark.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But while he was seeking with thimbles and care,</line>
      <line>A Bandersnatch swiftly drew nigh</line>
      <line>And grabbed at the Banker, who shrieked in despair,</line>
      <line>For he knew it was useless to fly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He offered large discount—he offered a cheque</line>
      <line>(Drawn ‘to bearer’) for seven-pounds-ten:</line>
      <line>But the Bandersnatch merely extended its neck</line>
      <line>And grabbed at the Banker again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Without rest or pause—while those frumious jaws</line>
      <line>Went savagely snapping around—</line>
      <line>He skipped and he hopped, and he floundered and flopped,</line>
      <line>Till fainting he fell to the ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Bandersnatch fled as the others appeared</line>
      <line>Led on by that fear-stricken yell:</line>
      <line>And the Bellman remarked ‘It is just as I feared!’</line>
      <line>And solemnly tolled on his bell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He was black in the face, and they scarcely could trace</line>
      <line>The least likeness to what he had been:</line>
      <line>While so great was his fright that his waistcoat turned white—</line>
      <line>A wonderful thing to be seen!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To the horror of all who were present that day,</line>
      <line>He uprose in full evening dress,</line>
      <line>And with senseless grimaces endeavoured to say</line>
      <line>What his tongue could no longer express.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down he sank in a chair—ran his hands through his hair—</line>
      <line>And chanted in mimsiest tones</line>
      <line>Words whose utter inanity proved his insanity,</line>
      <line>While he rattled a couple of bones.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Leave him here to his fate—it is getting so late!’</line>
      <line>The Bellman exclaimed in a fright.</line>
      <line>‘We have lost half the day. Any further delay,</line>
      <line>And we sha’n’t catch a Snark before night!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They sought it with thimbles, they sought it with care;</line>
      <line>They pursued it with forks and hope;</line>
      <line>They threatened its life with a railway-share;</line>
      <line>They charmed it with smiles and soap.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They shuddered to think that the chase might fail,</line>
      <line>And the Beaver, excited at last,</line>
      <line>Went bounding along on the tip of its tail,</line>
      <line>For the daylight was nearly past.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is Thingumbob shouting!’ the Bellman said.</line>
      <line>‘He is shouting like mad, only hark!</line>
      <line>He is waving his hands, he is wagging his head,</line>
      <line>He has certainly found a Snark!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They gazed in delight, while the Butcher exclaimed</line>
      <line>‘He was always a desperate wag!’</line>
      <line>They beheld him—their Baker—their hero unnamed—</line>
      <line>On the top of a neighbouring crag,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Erect and sublime, for one moment of time,</line>
      <line>In the next, that wild figure they saw</line>
      <line>(As if stung by a spasm) plunge into a chasm,</line>
      <line>While they waited and listened in awe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘It’s a Snark!’ was the sound that first came to their ears,</line>
      <line>And seemed almost too good to be true.</line>
      <line>Then followed a torrent of laughter and cheers:</line>
      <line>Then the ominous words ‘It’s a Boo—’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, silence. Some fancied they heard in the air</line>
      <line>A weary and wandering sigh</line>
      <line>That sounded like ‘—jum!’ but the others declare</line>
      <line>It was only a breeze that went by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They hunted till darkness came on, but they found</line>
      <line>Not a button, or feather, or mark,</line>
      <line>By which they could tell that they stood on the ground</line>
      <line>Where the Baker had met with the Snark.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the midst of the word he was trying to say,</line>
      <line>In the midst of his laughter and glee,</line>
      <line>He had softly and suddenly vanished away—</line>
      <line>For the Snark was a Boojum, you see.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>He thought he saw an Elephant,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw an Elephant,</line>
      <line>That practised on a fife:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A letter from his wife.</line>
      <line>“At length I realise”, he said,</line>
      <line>“The bitterness of Life!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw a Buffalo</line>
      <line>Upon the chimney-piece:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>His Sister’s Husband’s Niece.</line>
      <line>“Unless you leave this house”, he said,</line>
      <line>“I’ll send for the Police!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw a Banker’s Clerk</line>
      <line>Descending from the bus:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A Hippopotamus:</line>
      <line>“If this should stay to dine”, he said,</line>
      <line>“There wo’n’t be much for us!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw a Kangaroo</line>
      <line>That worked a coffee-mill:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A Vegetable-Pill.</line>
      <line>“Were I to swallow this”, he said,</line>
      <line>“I should be very ill!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw a Coach-and-Four</line>
      <line>That stood beside his bed:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A Bear without a Head.</line>
      <line>“Poor thing,” he said, “poor silly thing!</line>
      <line>It’s waiting to be fed!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw an Albatross</line>
      <line>That fluttered round the lamp:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A Penny-Postage-Stamp.</line>
      <line>“You’d best be getting home,” he said:</line>
      <line>“The nights are very damp!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw a Garden-Door</line>
      <line>That opened with a key:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A Double Rule of Three:</line>
      <line>“And all its mystery”, he said,</line>
      <line>“Is clear as day to me!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He thought he saw an Argument</line>
      <line>That proved he was the Pope:</line>
      <line>He looked again, and found it was</line>
      <line>A Bar of Mottled Soap.</line>
      <line>“A fact so dread”, he faintly said,</line>
      <line>“Extinguishes all hope!” ’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charlotte Bronte</author>
    <date>1846</date>
    <title>The Autumn day</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Autumn day its course has run—the Autumn evening falls</line>
      <line>Already risen the Autumn moon gleams quiet on these walls</line>
      <line>And Twilight to my lonely house a silent guest is come</line>
      <line>In mask of gloom through every room she passes dusk and dumb</line>
      <line>Her veil is spread, her shadow shed o’er stair and chamber void</line>
      <line>And now I feel her presence steal even to my lone fireside</line>
      <line>Sit silent Nun—sit there and be</line>
      <line>Comrade and Confidant to me</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charlotte Bronte</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>The house was still</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The house was still—the room was still</line>
      <line>’Twas eventide in June</line>
      <line>A caged canary to the sun</line>
      <line>Then setting—trilled a tune</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A free bird on that lilac bush</line>
      <line>Outside the lattice heard</line>
      <line>He listened long—there came a hush</line>
      <line>He dropped an answering word—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The prisoner to the free replied</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charlotte Bronte</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>I now had only to retrace</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I now had only to retrace</line>
      <line>The long and lonely road</line>
      <line>So lately in the rainbow chase</line>
      <line>With fearless ardour trod</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Behind I left the sunshine now</line>
      <line>The evening setting sun,</line>
      <line>Before a storm rolled dark and low</line>
      <line>Some gloomy hills upon</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It came with rain—it came with wind</line>
      <line>With swollen stream it howled</line>
      <line>And night advancing black and blind</line>
      <line>In ebon horror scowled</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lost in the hills—all painfully</line>
      <line>I climbed a heathy peak</line>
      <line>I sought I longed afar to see</line>
      <line>My life’s light’s parting streak</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The West was black as if no day</line>
      <line>Had ever lingered there</line>
      <line>As if no red expiring ray</line>
      <line>Had tinged the enkindled air</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And morning’s portals could not lie</line>
      <line>Where yon dark Orient spread</line>
      <line>The funeral North—the black dark sky</line>
      <line>Alike mourned [ ] dead</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lewis Carroll</author>
    <date>1845</date>
    <title>The Nurse</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Nurse believed the sick man slept</line>
      <line>For motionless he lay</line>
      <line>She rose and from the bed-side crept</line>
      <line>With cautious step away.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charlotte Bronte</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Stanzas</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Often rebuked, yet always back returning</line>
      <line>To those first feelings that were born with me,</line>
      <line>And leaving busy chase of wealth and learning</line>
      <line>For idle dreams of things which cannot be:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To-day, I will seek not the shadowy region;</line>
      <line>Its unsustaining vastness waxes drear;</line>
      <line>And visions rising, legion after legion,</line>
      <line>Bring the unreal world too strangely near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll walk, but not in old heroic traces,</line>
      <line>And not in paths of high morality,</line>
      <line>And not among the half-distinguished faces,</line>
      <line>The clouded forms of long-past history.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll walk where my own nature would be leading:</line>
      <line>It vexes me to choose another guide:</line>
      <line>Where the gray flocks in ferny glens are feeding;</line>
      <line>Where the wild wind blows on the mountain side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What have those lonely mountains worth revealing?</line>
      <line>More glory and more grief than I can tell:</line>
      <line>The earth that wakes one human heart to feeling</line>
      <line>Can centre both the worlds of Heaven and Hell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Edward Lear</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>There was an Old Man</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was an Old Man who supposed,</line>
      <line>That the street door was partially closed;</line>
      <line>But some very large rats, ate his coats and his hats,</line>
      <line>While that futile old gentleman dozed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a Young Lady whose eyes,</line>
      <line>Were unique as to colour and size;</line>
      <line>When she opened them wide, people all turned aside,</line>
      <line>And started away in surprise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was an Old Man on some rocks,</line>
      <line>Who shut his wife up in a box,</line>
      <line>When she said, ‘Let me out,’ he exclaimed, ‘Without doubt,</line>
      <line>You will pass all your life in that box.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was an old man who screamed out</line>
      <line>Whenever they knocked him about;</line>
      <line>So they took off his boots, And fed him with fruits,</line>
      <line>And continued to knock him about.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Edward Lear</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>The Dong with a Luminous Nose</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When awful darkness and silence reign</line>
      <line>Over the great Gromboolian plain,</line>
      <line>Through the long, long wintry nights;—</line>
      <line>When the angry breakers roar</line>
      <line>As they beat on the rocky shore;—</line>
      <line>When Storm-clouds brood on the towering heights</line>
      <line>Of the Hills of the Chankly Bore:—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, through the vast and gloomy dark,</line>
      <line>There moves what seems a fiery spark,</line>
      <line>A lonely spark with silvery rays</line>
      <line>Piercing the coal-black night,—</line>
      <line>A Meteor strange and bright:—</line>
      <line>Hither and thither the vision strays,</line>
      <line>A single lurid light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Slowly it wanders,—pauses,—creeps,—</line>
      <line>Anon it sparkles,—flashes and leaps;</line>
      <line>And ever as onward it gleaming goes</line>
      <line>A light on the Bong-tree stems it throws.</line>
      <line>And those who watch at that midnight hour</line>
      <line>From Hall or Terrace, or lofty Tower,</line>
      <line>Cry, as the wild light passes along,—</line>
      <line>‘The Dong!—the Dong!</line>
      <line>‘The wandering Dong through the forest goes!</line>
      <line>‘The Dong! the Dong!</line>
      <line>‘The Dong with a luminous Nose!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Long years ago</line>
      <line>The Dong was happy and gay,</line>
      <line>Till he fell in love with a Jumbly Girl</line>
      <line>Who came to those shores one day,</line>
      <line>For the Jumblies came in a sieve, they did,—</line>
      <line>Landing at eve near the Zemmery Fidd</line>
      <line>Where the Oblong Oysters grow,</line>
      <line>And the rocks are smooth and gray.</line>
      <line>And all the woods and the valleys rang</line>
      <line>With the Chorus they daily and nightly sang,—</line>
      <line>‘Far and few, far and few,</line>
      <line>Are the lands where the Jumblies live;</line>
      <line>Their heads are green, and their hands are blue</line>
      <line>And they went to sea in a sieve.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Happily, happily passed those days!</line>
      <line>While the cheerful Jumblies staid;</line>
      <line>They danced in circlets all night long,</line>
      <line>To the plaintive pipe of the lively Dong,</line>
      <line>In moonlight, shine, or shade.</line>
      <line>For day and night he was always there</line>
      <line>By the side of the Jumbly Girl so fair,</line>
      <line>With her sky-blue hands, and her sea-green hair.</line>
      <line>Till the morning came of that hateful day</line>
      <line>When the Jumblies sailed in their sieve away,</line>
      <line>And the Dong was left on the cruel shore</line>
      <line>Gazing—gazing for evermore,—</line>
      <line>Ever keeping his weary eyes on</line>
      <line>That pea-green sail on the far horizon,—</line>
      <line>Singing the Jumbly Chorus still</line>
      <line>As he sate all day on the grassy hill,—</line>
      <line>‘Far and few, far and few,</line>
      <line>Are the lands where the Jumblies live;</line>
      <line>Their heads are green, and their hands are blue,</line>
      <line>And they went to sea in a sieve.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when the sun was low in the West,</line>
      <line>The Dong arose and said,—</line>
      <line>—‘What little sense I once possessed</line>
      <line>Has quite gone out of my head!’—</line>
      <line>And since that day he wanders still</line>
      <line>By lake and forest, marsh and hill,</line>
      <line>Singing—‘O somewhere, in valley or plain</line>
      <line>‘Might I find my Jumbly Girl again!</line>
      <line>‘For ever I’ll seek by lake and shore</line>
      <line>‘Till I find my Jumbly Girl once more!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Playing a pipe with silvery squeaks,</line>
      <line>Since then his Jumbly Girl he seeks,</line>
      <line>And because by night he could not see,</line>
      <line>He gathered the bark of the Twangum Tree</line>
      <line>On the flowery plain that grows.</line>
      <line>And he wove him a wondrous Nose,—</line>
      <line>A Nose as strange as a Nose could be!</line>
      <line>Of vast proportions and painted red,</line>
      <line>And tied with cords to the back of his head.</line>
      <line>—In a hollow rounded space it ended</line>
      <line>With a luminous Lamp within suspended,</line>
      <line>All fenced about</line>
      <line>With a bandage stout</line>
      <line>To prevent the wind from blowing it out;—</line>
      <line>And with holes all round to send the light,</line>
      <line>In gleaming rays on the dismal night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now each night, and all night long,</line>
      <line>Over those plains still roams the Dong;</line>
      <line>And above the wail of the Chimp and Snipe</line>
      <line>You may hear the squeak of his plaintive pipe</line>
      <line>While ever he seeks, but seeks in vain</line>
      <line>To meet with his Jumbly Girl again;</line>
      <line>Lonely and wild—all night he goes,—</line>
      <line>The Dong with a luminous Nose!</line>
      <line>And all who watch at the midnight hour,</line>
      <line>From Hall or Terrace, or lofty Tower,</line>
      <line>Cry, as they trace the Meteor bright,</line>
      <line>Moving along through the dreary night,—</line>
      <line>‘This is the hour when forth he goes,</line>
      <line>‘The Dong with a luminous Nose!</line>
      <line>‘Yonder—over the plain he goes;</line>
      <line>‘He goes!</line>
      <line>‘He goes;</line>
      <line>‘The Dong with a luminous Nose!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Edward Lear</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>The New Vestments</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There lived an old man in the Kingdom of Tess,</line>
      <line>Who invented a purely original dress;</line>
      <line>And when it was perfectly made and complete,</line>
      <line>He opened the door, and walked into the street.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By way of a hat, he’d a loaf of Brown Bread,</line>
      <line>In the middle of which he inserted his head;—</line>
      <line>His Shirt was made up of no end of dead Mice,</line>
      <line>The warmth of whose skins was quite fluffy and nice;—</line>
      <line>His Drawers were of Rabbit-skins;—so were his Shoes;—</line>
      <line>His Stockings were skins,—but it is not known whose;—</line>
      <line>His Waistcoat and Trowsers were made of Pork Chops;—</line>
      <line>His Buttons were Jujubes, and Chocolate Drops;—</line>
      <line>His Coat was all Pancakes with Jam for a border,</line>
      <line>And a girdle of Biscuits to keep it in order;</line>
      <line>And he wore over all, as a screen from bad weather,</line>
      <line>A Cloak of green Cabbage-leaves stitched all together.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He had walked a short way, when he heard a great noise,</line>
      <line>Of all sorts of Beasticles, Birdlings, and Boys;—</line>
      <line>And from every long street and dark lane in the town</line>
      <line>Beasts, Birdies, and Boys in a tumult rushed down.</line>
      <line>Two Cows and a half ate his Cabbage-leaf Cloak;—</line>
      <line>Four Apes seized his Girdle, which vanished like smoke;—</line>
      <line>Three Kids ate up half of his Pancaky Coat,—</line>
      <line>And the tails were devour’d by an ancient He Goat;—</line>
      <line>An army of Dogs in a twinkling tore up his</line>
      <line>Pork Waistcoat and Trowsers to give to their Puppies;—</line>
      <line>And while they were growling, and mumbling the Chops,</line>
      <line>Ten Boys prigged the Jujubes and Chocolate Drops.—</line>
      <line>He tried to run back to his house, but in vain,</line>
      <line>For Scores of fat Pigs came again and again;—</line>
      <line>They rushed out of stables and hovels and doors,—</line>
      <line>They tore off his stockings, his shoes, and his drawers;—</line>
      <line>And now from the housetops with screechings descend,</line>
      <line>Striped, spotted, white, black, and gray Cats without end,</line>
      <line>They jumped on his shoulders and knocked off his hat,—</line>
      <line>When Crows, Ducks, and Hens made a mincemeat of that;—</line>
      <line>They speedily flew at his sleeves in a trice,</line>
      <line>And utterly tore up his Shirt of dead Mice;—</line>
      <line>They swallowed the last of his Shirt with a squall,—</line>
      <line>Whereon he ran home with no clothes on at all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he said to himself as he bolted the door,</line>
      <line>‘I will not wear a similar dress any more,</line>
      <line>‘Any more, any more, any more, never more!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Edward Lear</author>
    <date>1879</date>
    <title>'How pleasant to know Mr Lear!'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How pleasant to know Mr Lear!’</line>
      <line>Who has written such volumes of stuff!</line>
      <line>Some think him ill-tempered and queer,</line>
      <line>But a few think him pleasant enough.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His mind is concrete and fastidious,</line>
      <line>His nose is remarkably big;</line>
      <line>Flis visage is more or less hideous,</line>
      <line>His beard it resembles a wig.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He has ears, and two eyes, and ten fingers,</line>
      <line>Leastways if you reckon two thumbs;</line>
      <line>Long ago he was one of the singers,</line>
      <line>But now he is one of the dumbs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sits in a beautiful parlour,</line>
      <line>With hundreds of books on the wall;</line>
      <line>He drinks a great deal of Marsala,</line>
      <line>But never gets tipsy at all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He has many friends, laymen and clerical,</line>
      <line>Old Foss is the name of his cat:</line>
      <line>His body is perfectly spherical,</line>
      <line>He weareth a runcible hat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When he walks in a waterproof white,</line>
      <line>The children run after him so!</line>
      <line>Calling out, ‘He’s come out in his night¬</line>
      <line>gown, that crazy old Englishman, oh!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He weeps by the side of the ocean,</line>
      <line>He weeps on the top of the hill;</line>
      <line>He purchases pancakes and lotion,</line>
      <line>And chocolate shrimps from the mill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He reads but he cannot speak Spanish,</line>
      <line>He cannot abide ginger-beer:</line>
      <line>Ere the days of his pilgrimage vanish,</line>
      <line>How pleasant to know Mr Lear!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Kingsley</author>
    <date>1847</date>
    <title>When I was a greenhorn and young,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And wanted to be and to do,</line>
      <line>I puzzled my brains about choosing my line,</line>
      <line>Till I found out the way that things go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The same piece of clay makes a tile,</line>
      <line>A pitcher, a taw, or a brick:</line>
      <line>Dan Horace knew life; you may cut out a saint,</line>
      <line>Or a bench, from the self-same stick.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The urchin who squalls in a gaol,</line>
      <line>By circumstance turns out a rogue;</line>
      <line>While the castle-bred brat is a senator born,</line>
      <line>Or a saint, if religion’s in vogue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We fall on our legs in this world,</line>
      <line>Blind kittens, tossed in neck and heels:</line>
      <line>’Tis Dame Circumstance licks Nature’s cubs into shape,</line>
      <line>She’s the mill-head, if we are the wheels.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then why puzzle and fret, plot and dream?</line>
      <line>He that’s wise will just follow his nose;</line>
      <line>Contentedly fish, while he swims with the stream;</line>
      <line>’Tis no business of his where it goes.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Kingsley</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>The Invitation</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come away with me, Tom,</line>
      <line>Term and talk are done;</line>
      <line>My poor lads are reaping,</line>
      <line>Busy every one.</line>
      <line>Curates mind the parish,</line>
      <line>Sweepers mind the court;</line>
      <line>We’ll away to Snowdon</line>
      <line>For our ten days’ sport;</line>
      <line>Fish the August evening</line>
      <line>Till the eve is past,</line>
      <line>Whoop like boys, at pounders</line>
      <line>Fairly played and grassed.</line>
      <line>When they cease to dimple,</line>
      <line>Lunge, and swerve, and leap,</line>
      <line>Then up over Siabod,</line>
      <line>Choose our nest, and sleep.</line>
      <line>Up a thousand feet, Tom,</line>
      <line>Round the lion’s head,</line>
      <line>Find soft stones to leeward</line>
      <line>And make up our bed.</line>
      <line>Eat our bread and bacon,</line>
      <line>Smoke the pipe of peace,</line>
      <line>And, ere we be drowsy,</line>
      <line>Give our boots a grease.</line>
      <line>Homer’s heroes did so,</line>
      <line>Why not such as we?</line>
      <line>What are sheets and servants?</line>
      <line>Superfluity!</line>
      <line>Pray for wives and children</line>
      <line>Safe in slumber curled,</line>
      <line>Then to chat till midnight</line>
      <line>O’er this babbling world—</line>
      <line>Of the workmen’s college,</line>
      <line>Of the price of grain,</line>
      <line>Of the tree of knowledge,</line>
      <line>Of the chance of rain;</line>
      <line>If Sir A. goes Romeward,</line>
      <line>If Miss B. sings true,</line>
      <line>If the fleet comes homeward,</line>
      <line>If the mare will do,—</line>
      <line>Anything and everything—</line>
      <line>Up there in the sky</line>
      <line>Angels understand us,</line>
      <line>And no ‘saints’ are by.</line>
      <line>Down, and bathe at day-dawn,</line>
      <line>Tramp from lake to lake,</line>
      <line>Washing brain and heart clean</line>
      <line>Every step we take.</line>
      <line>Leave to Robert Browning</line>
      <line>Beggars, fleas, and vines;</line>
      <line>Leave to mournful Ruskin</line>
      <line>Popish Apennines,</line>
      <line>Dirty Stones of Venice</line>
      <line>And his Gas-lamps Seven—</line>
      <line>We’ve the stones of Snowdon</line>
      <line>And the lamps of heaven.</line>
      <line>Wdiere’s the mighty credit</line>
      <line>In admiring Alps?</line>
      <line>Any goose sees ‘glory’</line>
      <line>In their ‘snowy scalps.’</line>
      <line>Leave such signs and wonders</line>
      <line>For the dullard brain,</line>
      <line>As aesthetic brandy,</line>
      <line>Opium and cayenne.</line>
      <line>Give me Bramshill common</line>
      <line>(St John’s harriers by),</line>
      <line>Or the vale of Windsor,</line>
      <line>England’s golden eye.</line>
      <line>Show me life and progress,</line>
      <line>Beauty, health, and man;</line>
      <line>Houses fair, trim gardens,</line>
      <line>Turn where’er I can.</line>
      <line>Or, if bored with ‘High Art,’</line>
      <line>And such popish stuff,</line>
      <line>One’s poor ear need airing,</line>
      <line>Snowdon’s high enough.</line>
      <line>While we find God’s signet</line>
      <line>Fresh on English ground,</line>
      <line>Why go gallivanting</line>
      <line>With the nations round?</line>
      <line>Though we try no ventures</line>
      <line>Desperate or strange;</line>
      <line>Feed on commonplaces</line>
      <line>In a narrow range;</line>
      <line>Never sought for Franklin</line>
      <line>Round the frozen Capes;</line>
      <line>Even, with Macdougall,</line>
      <line>Bagged our brace of apes;</line>
      <line>Never had our chance, Tom,</line>
      <line>In that black Redan;</line>
      <line>Can’t avenge poor Brereton</line>
      <line>Out in Sakarran;</line>
      <line>Tho’ we earn our bread, Tom,</line>
      <line>By the dirty pen,</line>
      <line>What we can we will be,</line>
      <line>Honest Englishmen.</line>
      <line>Do the work that’s nearest,</line>
      <line>Though it’s dull at w'hiles,</line>
      <line>Helping, when we meet them,</line>
      <line>Lame dogs over stiles;</line>
      <line>See in every hedgerow</line>
      <line>Marks of angels’ feet,</line>
      <line>Epics in each pebble</line>
      <line>Underneath our feet;</line>
      <line>Once a year, like schoolboys,</line>
      <line>Robin-Hooding go,</line>
      <line>Leaving fops and fogies</line>
      <line>A thousand feet below.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1847</date>
    <title>Natura Naturans</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beside me,—in the car,—she sat,</line>
      <line>She spake not, no, nor looked to me:</line>
      <line>From her to me, from me to her,</line>
      <line>What passed so subtly stealthily?</line>
      <line>As rose to rose that by it blows</line>
      <line>Its interchanged aroma flings;</line>
      <line>Or wake to sound of one sweet note</line>
      <line>The virtues of disparted strings.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beside me, nought but this!—but this,</line>
      <line>That influent as within me dwelt</line>
      <line>Her life, mine too within her breast,</line>
      <line>Her brain, her every limb she felt:</line>
      <line>We sat; while o’er and in us, more</line>
      <line>And more, a power unknown prevailed,</line>
      <line>Inhaling, and inhaled,—and still</line>
      <line>’Twas one, inhaling or inhaled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beside me, nought but this;—and passed;</line>
      <line>I passed; and know not to this day</line>
      <line>If gold or jet her girlish hair,</line>
      <line>If black, or brown, or lucid-grey</line>
      <line>Her eye’s young glance: the fickle chance</line>
      <line>That joined us, yet may join again;</line>
      <line>But I no face again could greet</line>
      <line>As hers, whose life was in me then.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As unsuspecting mere a maid</line>
      <line>As, fresh in maidhood’s bloomiest bloom,</line>
      <line>In casual second-class did e’er</line>
      <line>By casual youth her seat assume;</line>
      <line>Or vestal, say, of saintliest clay,</line>
      <line>For once by balmiest airs betrayed</line>
      <line>Unto emotions too too sweet</line>
      <line>To be unlingeringly gainsaid:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unowning then, confusing soon</line>
      <line>With dreamier dreams that o’er the glass</line>
      <line>Of shyly ripening woman-sense</line>
      <line>Reflected, scarce reflected, pass,</line>
      <line>A wife may-be, a mother she</line>
      <line>In Hymen’s shrine recalls not now,</line>
      <line>She first in hour, ah, not profane,</line>
      <line>With me to Hymen learnt to bow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah no!—Yet owned we, fused in one,</line>
      <line>The Power which e’en in stones and earths</line>
      <line>By blind elections felt, in forms</line>
      <line>Organic breeds to myriad births;</line>
      <line>By lichen small on granite wall</line>
      <line>Approved, its faintest feeblest stir</line>
      <line>Slow-spreading, strengthening long, at last</line>
      <line>Vibrated full in me and her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In me and her—sensation strange!</line>
      <line>The lily grew to pendent head,</line>
      <line>To vernal airs and mossy bank</line>
      <line>Its sheeny primrose spangles spread,</line>
      <line>In roof o’er roof of shade sun-proof</line>
      <line>Did cedar strong itself outclimb,</line>
      <line>And altitude of aloe proud</line>
      <line>Aspire in floreal crown sublime;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Flashed flickering forth fantastic flies,</line>
      <line>Big bees their burly bodies swung,</line>
      <line>Rooks roused with civic din the elms,</line>
      <line>And lark its wild reveillez rung;</line>
      <line>In Libyan dell the light gazelle,</line>
      <line>The leopard lithe in Indian glade,</line>
      <line>And dolphin, brightening tropic seas,</line>
      <line>In us were living, leapt and played:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their shells did slow Crustacea build,</line>
      <line>Their gilded skins did snakes renew,</line>
      <line>While mightier spines for loftier kind</line>
      <line>Their types in amplest limbs outgrew;</line>
      <line>Yea, close comprest in human breast,</line>
      <line>What moss, and tree, and livelier thing,</line>
      <line>What Earth, Sun, Star of force possest,</line>
      <line>Lay budding, burgeoning forth for Spring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such sweet preluding sense of old</line>
      <line>Led on in Eden’s sinless place</line>
      <line>The hour when bodies human first</line>
      <line>Combined the primal prime embrace,</line>
      <line>Such genial heat the blissful seat</line>
      <line>In man and woman owned unblamed,</line>
      <line>When, naked both, its garden paths</line>
      <line>They walked unconscious, unashamed:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ere, clouded yet in mistiest dawn,</line>
      <line>Above the horizon dusk and dun,</line>
      <line>One mountain crest with light had tipped</line>
      <line>That Orb that is the Spirit’s Sun;</line>
      <line>Ere dreamed young flowers in vernal showers</line>
      <line>Of fruit to rise the flower above,</line>
      <line>Or ever yet to young Desire</line>
      <line>Was told the mystic name of Love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>Say not the struggle</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Say not the struggle nought availeth,</line>
      <line>The labour and the wounds are vain,</line>
      <line>The enemy faints not, nor faileth,</line>
      <line>And as things have been, things remain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If hopes were dupes, fears may be liars;</line>
      <line>It may be, in yon smoke concealed,</line>
      <line>Your comrades chase e’en now the fliers,</line>
      <line>And, but for you, possess the field.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For while the tired waves, vainly breaking,</line>
      <line>Seem here no painful inch to gain,</line>
      <line>Far back through creeks and inlets making</line>
      <line>Came, silent, flooding in, the main,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And not by eastern windows only,</line>
      <line>When daylight comes, comes in the light,</line>
      <line>In front the sun climbs slow, how slowly,</line>
      <line>But westward, look, the land is bright.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1851</date>
    <title>To spend uncounted years of pain,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Again, again, and yet again,</line>
      <line>In working out in heart and brain</line>
      <line>The problem of our being here;</line>
      <line>To gather facts from far and near,</line>
      <line>Upon the mind to hold them clear,</line>
      <line>And, knowing more may yet appear,</line>
      <line>Unto one’s latest breath to fear</line>
      <line>The premature result to draw—</line>
      <line>Is this the object, end and law,</line>
      <line>And purpose of our being here?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>Amours de Voyage</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Over the great windy waters, and over the clear crested summits,</line>
      <line>Unto the sun and the sky, and unto the perfecter earth,</line>
      <line>Come, let us go,—to a land wherein gods of the old time wandered,</line>
      <line>Where every breath even now changes to ether divine.</line>
      <line>Come, let us go; though withal a voice whisper, ‘The world that we live in,</line>
      <line>Whithersoever we turn, still is the same narrow crib;</line>
      <line>’Tis but to prove limitation, and measure a cord, that we travel;</line>
      <line>Let who would ’scape and be free go to his chamber and think;</line>
      <line>’Tis but to change idle fancies for memories wilfully falser;</line>
      <line>’Tis but to go and have been. ’—Come, little bark! let us go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear Eustatio, I write that you may write me an answer,</line>
      <line>Or at the least to put us again en rapport with each other.</line>
      <line>Rome disappoints me much,—St Peter’s, perhaps, in especial;</line>
      <line>Only the Arch of Titus and view from the Lateran please me:</line>
      <line>This, however, perhaps, is the weather, which truly is horrid.</line>
      <line>Greece must be better, surely; and yet I am feeling so spiteful,</line>
      <line>That I could travel to Athens, to Delphi, and Troy, and Mount Sinai,</line>
      <line>Though but to see with my eyes that these are vanity also.</line>
      <line>Rome disappoints me much; I hardly as yet understand, but</line>
      <line>Rubbishy seems the word that most exactly would suit it.</line>
      <line>All the foolish destructions, and all the sillier savings,</line>
      <line>All the incongruous things of past incompatible ages,</line>
      <line>Seem to be treasured up here to make fools of present and future.</line>
      <line>Would to Heaven the old Goths had made a cleaner sweep of it!</line>
      <line>Would to Heaven some new ones would come and destroy these churches!</line>
      <line>However, one can live in Rome as also in London.</line>
      <line>Rome is better than London, because it is other than London.</line>
      <line>It is a blessing, no doubt, to be rid, at least for a time, of</line>
      <line>All one’s friends and relations,—yourself (forgive me!) included,—</line>
      <line>All the assujettissement of having been what one has been,</line>
      <line>What one thinks one is, or thinks that others suppose one;</line>
      <line>Yet, in despite of all, we turn like fools to the English.</line>
      <line>Vernon has been my fate; who is here the same that you knew him,—</line>
      <line>Making the tour, it seems, with friends of the name of Trevellyn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rome disappoints me still; but I shrink and adapt myself to it.</line>
      <line>Somehow a tyrannous sense of a superincumbent oppression</line>
      <line>Still, wherever I go, accompanies ever, and makes me</line>
      <line>Feel like a tree (shall I say?) buried under a ruin of brick-work.</line>
      <line>Rome, believe me, my friend, is like its own Monte Testaceo,</line>
      <line>Merely a marvellous mass of broken and castaway wine-pots.</line>
      <line>Ye gods! what do I want with this rubbish of ages departed,</line>
      <line>Things that Nature abhors, the experiments that she has failed in?</line>
      <line>What do I find in the Forum? An archway and two or three pillars.</line>
      <line>Well, but St Peter’s? Alas, Bernini has filled it with sculpture!</line>
      <line>No one can cavil, I grant, at the size of the great Coliseum.</line>
      <line>Doubtless the notion of grand and capacious and massive amusement,</line>
      <line>This the old Romans had; but tell me, is this an idea?</line>
      <line>Yet of solidity much, but of splendour little is extant:</line>
      <line>‘Brickwork I found thee, and marble I left thee!’ their Emperor vaunted;</line>
      <line>‘Marble I thought thee, and brickwork I find thee!’ the Tourist may answer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At last, dearest Louisa, I take up my pen to address you.</line>
      <line>Here we are, you see, with the seven-and-seventy boxes,</line>
      <line>Courier, Papa and Mamma, the children, and Mary and Susan:</line>
      <line>Here we all are at Rome, and delighted of course with St Peter’s,</line>
      <line>And very pleasantly lodged in the famous Piazza di Spagna.</line>
      <line>Rome is a wonderful place, but Mary shall tell you about it;</line>
      <line>Not very gay, however; the English are mostly at Naples;</line>
      <line>There are the A.s, we hear, and most of the W. party.</line>
      <line>George, however, is come; did I tell you about his mustachios?</line>
      <line>Dear, I must really stop, for the carriage, they tell me, is waiting.</line>
      <line>Mary will finish; and Susan is writing, they say, to Sophia.</line>
      <line>Adieu, dearest Louise,—evermore your faithful Georgina.</line>
      <line>Who can a Mr Claude be whom George has taken to be with?</line>
      <line>Very stupid, I think, but George says so very clever.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, the Christian faith, as at any rate I understood it,</line>
      <line>With its humiliations and exaltations combining,</line>
      <line>Exaltations sublime, and yet diviner abasements,</line>
      <line>Aspirations from something most shameful here upon earth and</line>
      <line>In our poor selves to something most perfect above in the heavens,—</line>
      <line>No, the Christian faith, as I, at least, understood it,</line>
      <line>Is not here, O Rome, in any of these thy churches;</line>
      <line>Is not here, but in Freiburg, or Rheims, or Westminster Abbey.</line>
      <line>What in thy Dome I find, in all thy recenter efforts,</line>
      <line>Is a something, I think, more rational far, more earthly,</line>
