      <line>Actual, less ideal, devout not in scorn and refusal,</line>
      <line>But in a positive, calm, Stoic-Epicurean acceptance.</line>
      <line>This I begin to detect in St Peter’s and some of the churches,</line>
      <line>Mostly in all that I see of the sixteenth-century masters;</line>
      <line>Overlaid of course with infinite gauds and gewgaws,</line>
      <line>Innocent, playful follies, the toys and trinkets of childhood,</line>
      <line>Forced on maturer years, as the serious one thing needful,</line>
      <line>By the barbarian will of the rigid and ignorant Spaniard.</line>
      <line>Curious work, meantime, re-entering society; how we</line>
      <line>Walk a livelong day, great Heaven, and watch our shadows!</line>
      <line>What our shadows seem, forsooth, we will ourselves be.</line>
      <line>Do I look like that? you think me that: then I am that.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Luther, they say, was unwise; like a half-taught German, he could not</line>
      <line>See that old follies were passing most tranquilly out of remembrance;</line>
      <line>Leo the Tenth was employing all efforts to clear out abuses;</line>
      <line>Jupiter, Juno, and Venus, Fine Arts, and Fine Letters, the Poets,</line>
      <line>Scholars, and Sculptors, and Painters, were quietly clearing away the</line>
      <line>Martyrs, and Virgins, and Saints, or at any rate Thomas Aquinas:</line>
      <line>He must forsooth make a fuss and distend his huge Wittenberg lungs, and</line>
      <line>Bring back Theology once yet again in a flood upon Europe:</line>
      <line>Lo you, for forty days from the windows of heaven it fell; the</line>
      <line>Waters prevail on the earth yet more for a hundred and fifty;</line>
      <line>Are they abating at last? the doves that are sent to explore are</line>
      <line>Wearily fain to return, at the best with a leaflet of promise,—</line>
      <line>Fain to return, as they went, to the wandering wave-tost vessel,—</line>
      <line>Fain to re-enter the roof which covers the clean and the unclean,—</line>
      <line>Luther, they say, was unwise; he didn’t see how things were going;</line>
      <line>Luther was foolish,—but, O great God! what call you Ignatius?</line>
      <line>O my tolerant soul, be still! but you talk of barbarians,</line>
      <line>Alaric, Attila, Genseric;—why, they came, they killed, they</line>
      <line>Ravaged, and went on their way; but these vile, tyrannous Spaniards,</line>
      <line>These are here still,—how long, O ye Heavens, in the country of Dante?</line>
      <line>These, that fanaticized Europe, which now can forget them, release not</line>
      <line>This, their choicest of prey, this Italy; here you see them,—</line>
      <line>Here, with emasculate pupils, and gimcrack churches of Gesu,</line>
      <line>Pseudo-learning and lies, confessional-boxes and postures,—</line>
      <line>Here, with metallic beliefs and regimental devotions,—</line>
      <line>Here, overcrusting with slime, perverting, defacing, debasing,</line>
      <line>Michel Angelo’s dome, that had hung the Pantheon in heaven,</line>
      <line>Raphael’s Joys and Graces, and thy clear stars, Galileo!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Which of three Misses Trevellyn is it that Vernon shall marry</line>
      <line>Is not a thing to be known; for our friend is one of those natures</line>
      <line>Which have their perfect delight in the general tender-domestic,</line>
      <line>So that he trifles with Mary’s shawl, ties Susan’s bonnet,</line>
      <line>Dances with all, but at home is most, they say, with Georgina,</line>
      <line>Who is, however, too silly in my apprehension for Vernon.</line>
      <line>I, as before when I wrote, continue to see them a little;</line>
      <line>Not that I like them much or care a bajocco for Vernon,</line>
      <line>But I am slow at Italian, have not many English acquaintance,</line>
      <line>And I am asked, in short, and am not good at excuses.</line>
      <line>Middle-class people these, bankers very likely, not wholly</line>
      <line>Pure of the taint of the shop; will at table d’hote and restaurant</line>
      <line>Have their shilling’s worth, their penny’s pennyworth even:</line>
      <line>Neither man’s aristocracy this, nor God’s, God knoweth!</line>
      <line>Yet they are fairly descended, they give you to know, well connected;</line>
      <line>Doubtless somewhere in some neighbourhood have, and are careful to keep, some</line>
      <line>Threadbare-genteel relations, who in their turn are enchanted</line>
      <line>Grandly among county people to introduce at assemblies</line>
      <line>To the unpennied cadets our cousins with excellent fortunes.</line>
      <line>Neither man’s aristocracy this, nor God’s, God knoweth!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, what a shame, indeed, to abuse these most worthy people!</line>
      <line>Ah, what a sin to have sneered at their innocent rustic pretensions!</line>
      <line>Is it not laudable really, this reverent worship of station?</line>
      <line>Is it not fitting that wealth should tender this homage to culture?</line>
      <line>Is it not touching to witness these efforts, if little availing,</line>
      <line>Painfully made, to perform the old ritual service of manners?</line>
      <line>Shall not devotion atone for the absence of knowledge? and fervour</line>
      <line>Palliate, cover, the fault of a superstitious observance?</line>
      <line>Dear, dear, what do I say? but, alas! just now, like Iago,</line>
      <line>I can be nothing at all, if it is not critical wholly;</line>
      <line>So in fantastic height, in coxcomb exaltation,</line>
      <line>Here in the Garden I can walk, can freely concede to the Maker</line>
      <line>That the works of his hand are all very good: his creatures,</line>
      <line>Beast of the field and fowl, he brings them before me; I name them;</line>
      <line>That which I name them, they are,—the bird, the beast, and the cattle.</line>
      <line>But for Adam,—alas, poor critical coxcomb Adam!</line>
      <line>But for Adam there is not found an help-meet for him.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, great dome of Agrippa, thou art not Christian! canst not,</line>
      <line>Strip and replaster and daub and do what they will with thee, be so!</line>
      <line>Here underneath the great porch of colossal Corinthian columns,</line>
      <line>Here as I walk, do I dream of the Christian belfries above them?</line>
      <line>Or on a bench as I sit and abide for long hours, till thy whole vast</line>
      <line>Round grows dim as in dreams to my eyes, I repeople thy niches,</line>
      <line>Not with the Martyrs, and Saints, and Confessors, and Virgins, and children,</line>
      <line>But with the mightier forms of an older, austerer worship;</line>
      <line>And I recite to myself, how</line>
      <line>Eager for battle here</line>
      <line>Stood Vulcan, here matronal Juno,</line>
      <line>And with the bow to his shoulder faithful</line>
      <line>He who with pure dew laveth of Castaly</line>
      <line>His flowing locks, who holdeth of Lycia</line>
      <line>The oak forest and the wood that bore him,</line>
      <line>Delos’ and Patara’s own Apollo.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet it is pleasant, I own it, to be in their company; pleasant,</line>
      <line>Whatever else it may be, to abide in the feminine presence.</line>
      <line>Pleasant, but wrong, will you say? But this happy, serene coexistence</line>
      <line>Is to some poor soft souls, I fear, a necessity simple,</line>
      <line>Meat and drink and life, and music, filling with sweetness,</line>
      <line>Thrilling with melody sweet, with harmonies strange overwhelming,</line>
      <line>All the long-silent strings of an awkward, meaningless fabric.</line>
      <line>Yet as for that, I could live, I believe, with children; to have those</line>
      <line>Pure and delicate forms encompassing, moving about you,</line>
      <line>This were enough, I could think; and truly with glad resignation</line>
      <line>Could from the dream of romance, from the fever of flushed adolescence,</line>
      <line>Look to escape and subside into peaceful avuncular functions.</line>
      <line>Nephews and nieces! alas, for as yet I have none! and, moreover,</line>
      <line>Mothers are jealous, I fear me, too often, too rightfully; fathers</line>
      <line>Think they have title exclusive to spoiling their own little darlings;</line>
      <line>And by the law of the land, in despite of Malthusian doctrine,</line>
      <line>No sort of proper provision is made for that most patriotic,</line>
      <line>Most meritorious subject, the childless and bachelor uncle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye, too, marvellous Twain, that erect on. the Monte Cavallo</line>
      <line>Stand by your rearing steeds in the grace of your motionless movement,</line>
      <line>Stand with your upstretched arms and tranquil regardant faces,</line>
      <line>Stand as instinct with life in the might of immutable manhood,—</line>
      <line>O ye mighty and strange, ye ancient divine ones of Hellas,</line>
      <line>Are ye Christian too? to convert and redeem and renew you,</line>
      <line>Will the brief form have sufficed, that a Pope has set up on the apex</line>
      <line>Of the Egyptian stone that o’ertops you, the Christian symbol?</line>
      <line>And ye, silent, supreme in serene and victorious marble,</line>
      <line>Ye that encircle the walls of the stately Vatican chambers,</line>
      <line>Juno and Ceres, Minerva, Apollo, the Muses and Bacchus,</line>
      <line>Ye unto whom far and near come posting the Christian pilgrims,</line>
      <line>Ye that are ranged in the halls of the mystic Christian pontiff,</line>
      <line>Are ye also baptized? are ye of the Kingdom of Heaven?</line>
      <line>Utter, O some one, the word that shall reconcile Ancient and Modern!</line>
      <line>Am I to turn me for this unto thee, great Chapel of Sixtus?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>These are the facts. The uncle, the elder brother, the squire (a</line>
      <line>Little embarrassed, I fancy), resides in a family place in</line>
      <line>Cornwall, of course; ‘Papa is in business,’ Mary informs me;</line>
      <line>He’s a good sensible man, whatever his trade is. The mother</line>
      <line>Is—shall I call it fine?—herself she would tell you refined, and</line>
      <line>Greatly, I fear me, looks down on my bookish and maladroit manners;</line>
      <line>Somewhat affecteth the blue; would talk to me often of poets;</line>
      <line>Quotes, which I hate, Childe Harold; but also appreciates Wordsworth;</line>
      <line>Sometimes adventures on Schiller; and then to religion diverges;</line>
      <line>Questions me much about Oxford; and yet, in her loftiest flights, still</line>
      <line>Grates the fastidious ear with the slightly mercantile accent.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it contemptible, Eustace,—I’m perfectly ready to think so,—</line>
      <line>Is it,—the horrible pleasure of pleasing inferior people?</line>
      <line>I am ashamed my own self; and yet true it is, if disgraceful,</line>
      <line>That for the first time in life I am living and moving with freedom.</line>
      <line>I, who never could talk to the people I meet with my uncle,—</line>
      <line>I, who have always failed,—I, trust me, can suit the Trevellyns;</line>
      <line>I, believe me,—great conquest,—am liked by the country bankers.</line>
      <line>And I am glad to be liked, and like in return very kindly.</line>
      <line>So it proceeds; Laissez faire, laissez alter,—such is the watchword.</line>
      <line>Well, I know there are thousands as pretty and hundreds as pleasant,</line>
      <line>Girls by the dozen as good, and girls in abundance with polish</line>
      <line>Higher and manners more perfect than Susan or Mary Trevellyn.</line>
      <line>Well, I know, after all, it is only juxtaposition,—</line>
      <line>Juxtaposition, in short; and what is juxtaposition?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But I am in for it now,—laissez faire, of a truth, laissez alter.</line>
      <line>Yes, I am going,—I feel it, I feel and cannot recall it,—</line>
      <line>Fusing with this thing and that, entering into all sorts of relations,</line>
      <line>Tying I know not what ties, which, whatever they are, I know one thing,</line>
      <line>Will, and must, woe is me, be one day painfully broken,—</line>
      <line>Broken with painful remorses, with shrinkings of soul, and relentings,</line>
      <line>Foolish delays, more foolish evasions, most foolish renewals.</line>
      <line>But I have made the step, have quitted the ship of Ulysses;</line>
      <line>Quitted the sea and the shore, passed into the magical island;</line>
      <line>Yet on my lips is the moly, medicinal, offered of Hermes.</line>
      <line>I have come into the precinct, the labyrinth closes around me,</line>
      <line>Path into path rounding slyly; I pace slowly on, and the fancy,</line>
      <line>Struggling awhile to sustain the long sequences, weary, bewildered,</line>
      <line>Fain must collapse in despair; I yield, I am lost and know nothing;</line>
      <line>Yet in my bosom unbroken remaineth the clew; I shall use it.</line>
      <line>Lo, with the rope on my loins I descend through the fissure; I sink, yet</line>
      <line>Inly secure in the strength of invisible arms up above me;</line>
      <line>Still, wheresoever I swing, wherever to shore, or to shelf, or</line>
      <line>Floor of cavern untrodden, shell-sprinkled, enchanting, I know I</line>
      <line>Yet shall one time feel the strong cord tighten about me,—</line>
      <line>Feel it relentless, upbear me from spots I would rest in; and though the</line>
      <line>Rope sway wildly, I faint, crags wound me, from crag unto crag re-</line>
      <line>Bounding, or, wide in the void, I die ten deaths, ere the end I</line>
      <line>Yet shall plant firm foot on the broad lofty spaces I quit, shall</line>
      <line>Feel underneath me again the great massy strengths of abstraction,</line>
      <line>Look yet abroad from the height o’er the sea whose salt wave I have tasted.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dearest Louisa,—Inquire, if you please, about Mr Claude-.</line>
      <line>He has been once at R., and remembers meeting the H.s.</line>
      <line>Harriet L., perhaps, may be able to tell you about him.</line>
      <line>It is an awkward youth, but still with very good manners;</line>
      <line>Not without prospects, we hear; and, George says, highly connected.</line>
      <line>Georgy declares it absurd, but Mamma is alarmed, and insists he has</line>
      <line>Taken up strange opinions and may be turning a Papist.</line>
      <line>Certainly once he spoke of a daily service he went to.</line>
      <line>‘Where?’ we asked, and he laughed and answered, ‘At the Pantheon.’</line>
      <line>This was a temple, you know, and now is a Catholic church; and</line>
      <line>Though it is said that Mazzini has sold it for Protestant service,</line>
      <line>Yet I suppose the change can hardly as yet be effected.</line>
      <line>Adieu again,—evermore, my dearest, your loving Georgina.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I AM to tell you, you say, what I think of our last new acquaintance.</line>
      <line>Well, then, I think that George has a very fair right to be jealous.</line>
      <line>I do not like him much, though I do not dislike being with him.</line>
      <line>He is what people call, I suppose, a superior man, and</line>
      <line>Certainly seems so to me; but I think he is frightfully selfish.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alba, thoufindest me still, and, Alba, thou findest me ever,</line>
      <line>Now from the Capitol steps, now over Titus's Arch,</line>
      <line>Herefrom the large grassy spaces that spread from the Lateran portal,</line>
      <line>Towering o'er aqueduct lines lost in perspective between,</line>
      <line>Or from a Vatican window, or bridge, or the high Coliseum,</line>
      <line>Clear by the garlanded line cut of the Flavian ring.</line>
      <line>Beautiful can I not call thee, and yet thou hast power to o’ermaster,</line>
      <line>Power of mere beauty; in dreams, Alba, thou hauntest me still.</line>
      <line>Is it religion? I ask me; or is it a vain superstition?</line>
      <line>Slavery abject and gross? service, too feeble, of truth?</line>
      <line>Is it an idol I bow to, or is it a god that I worship?</line>
      <line>Do I sink back on the old, or do I soar from the mean?</line>
      <line>So through the city I wander and question, unsatisfied ever,</line>
      <line>Reverent so I accept, doubtful because I revere.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it illusion? or does there a spirit from perfecter ages,</line>
      <line>Here, even yet, amid loss, change, and corruption, abide?</line>
      <line>Does there a spirit we know not, though seek, though we find, comprehend not</line>
      <line>Here to entice and confuse, tempt and evade us, abide?</line>
      <line>Lives in the exquisite grace of the column disjointed and single,</line>
      <line>Haunts the rude masses of brick garlanded gayly with vine,</line>
      <line>E'en in the turret fantastic surviving that springs from the ruin,</line>
      <line>E'en in the people itself? is it illusion or not?</line>
      <line>Is it illusion or not that attracteth the pilgrim transalpine,</line>
      <line>Brings him a dullard and dunce hither to pry and to stare?</line>
      <line>Is it illusion or not that allures the barbarian stranger,</line>
      <line>Brings him with gold to the shrine, brings him in arms to the gate?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What do the people say, and what does the government do?—you</line>
      <line>Ask, and I know not at all. Yet fortune will favour your hopes; and</line>
      <line>I, who avoided it all, am fated, it seems, to describe it.</line>
      <line>I, who nor meddle nor make in politics,—I who sincerely</line>
      <line>Put not my trust in leagues nor any suffrage by ballot,</line>
      <line>Never predicted Parisian millenniums, never beheld a</line>
      <line>New Jerusalem coming down dressed like a bride out of heaven</line>
      <line>Right on the Place de la Concorde,—I, nevertheless, let me say it,</line>
      <line>Could in my soul of souls, this day, with the Gaul at the gates, shed</line>
      <line>One true tear for thee, thou poor little Roman republic!</line>
      <line>France, it is foully done! and you, my stupid old England,—</line>
      <line>You, who a twelvemonth ago said nations must choose for themselves, you</line>
      <line>Could not, of course, interfere,—you, now, when a nation has chosen—</line>
      <line>Pardon this folly! The Times will, of course, have announced the occasion,</line>
      <line>Told you the news of to-day; and although it was slightly in error</line>
      <line>When it proclaimed as a fact the Apollo was sold to a Yankee,</line>
      <line>You may believe when it tells you the French are at Civita Vecchia.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dulce it is, and decorum, no doubt, for the country to fall,—to</line>
      <line>Offer one’s blood an oblation to Freedom, and die for the Cause; yet</line>
      <line>Still, individual culture is also something, and no man</line>
      <line>Finds quite distinct the assurance that he of all others is called on,</line>
      <line>Or would be justified, even, in taking away from the world that</line>
      <line>Precious creature, himself. Nature sent him here to abide here;</line>
      <line>Else why sent him at all? Nature wants him still, it is likely.</line>
      <line>On the whole, we are meant to look after ourselves; it is certain</line>
      <line>Each has to eat for himself, digest for himself, and in general</line>
      <line>Care for his own dear life, and see to his own preservation;</line>
      <line>Nature’s intentions, in most things uncertain, in this most plain are decisive;</line>
      <line>These, on the whole, I conjecture the Romans will follow, and I shall.</line>
      <line>So we cling to our rocks like limpets; Ocean may bluster,</line>
      <line>Over and under and round us; we open our shells to imbibe our</line>
      <line>Nourishment, close them again, and are safe, fulfilling the purpose</line>
      <line>Nature intended,—a wise one, of course, and a noble, we doubt not.</line>
      <line>Sweet it may be and decorous, perhaps, for the country to die; but,</line>
      <line>On the whole, we conclude the Romans won’t do it, and I sha’n’t.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will they fight? They say so. And will the French? I can hardly,</line>
      <line>Hardly think so; and yet—He is come, they say, to Palo,</line>
      <line>He is passed from Monterone, at Santa Severa</line>
      <line>He hath laid up his guns. But the Virgin, the Daughter of Roma,</line>
      <line>She hath despised thee and laughed thee to scorn,—the Daughter of Tiber,</line>
      <line>She hath shaken her head and built barricades against thee!</line>
      <line>Will they fight? I believe it. Alas! ’tis ephemeral folly,</line>
      <line>Vain and ephemeral folly, of course, compared with pictures,</line>
      <line>Statues, and antique gems!—Indeed: and yet indeed too,</line>
      <line>Yet methought, in broad day did I dream—tell it not in St James’s,</line>
      <line>Whisper it not in thy courts, O Christ Church!—yet did I, waking,</line>
      <line>Dream of a cadence that sings, Si tombent nos jeunes heros, la</line>
      <line>Terre en produit de nouveaux contre vous tous prets a se battre;</line>
      <line>Dreamt of great indignations and angers transcendental,</line>
      <line>Dreamt of a sword at my side and a battle-horse underneath me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now supposing the French or the Neapolitan soldier</line>
      <line>Should by some evil chance come exploring the Maison Serny</line>
      <line>(Where the family English are all to assembly for safety),</line>
      <line>Am I prepared to lay down my life for the British female?</line>
      <line>Really, who knows? One has bowed and talked, till, little by little,</line>
      <line>All the natural heat has escaped of the chivalrous spirit.</line>
      <line>Oh, one conformed, of course; but one doesn’t die for good manners,</line>
      <line>Stab or shoot, or be shot, by way of graceful attention.</line>
      <line>No, if it should be at all, it should be on the barricades there;</line>
      <line>Should I incarnadine ever this inky pacifical finger,</line>
      <line>Sooner far should it be for this vapour of Italy’s freedom,</line>
      <line>Sooner far by the side of the d-d and dirty plebeians.</line>
      <line>Ah, for a child in the street I could strike; for the full-blown lady—</line>
      <line>Somehow, Eustace, alas! I have not felt the vocation.</line>
      <line>Yet these people of course will expect, as of course, my protection,</line>
      <line>Vernon in radiant arms stand forth for the lovely Georgina,</line>
      <line>And to appear, I suppose, were but common civility. Yes, and</line>
      <line>Truly I do not desire they should either be killed or offended.</line>
      <line>Oh, and of course you will say, ‘When the times comes, you will be ready.’</line>
      <line>Ah, but before it comes, am I to presume it will be so?</line>
      <line>What I cannot feel now, am I to suppose that I shall feel?</line>
      <line>Am I not free to attend for the ripe and indubious instinct?</line>
      <line>Am I forbidden to wait for the clear and lawful perception?</line>
      <line>Is it the calling of man to surrender his knowledge and insight,</line>
      <line>For the mere venture of what may, perhaps, be the virtuous action?</line>
      <line>Must we, walking our earth, discerning a little, and hoping</line>
      <line>Some plain visible task shall yet for our hands be assigned us,—</line>
      <line>Must we abandon the future for fear of omitting the present, 90</line>
      <line>Quit our own fireside hopes at the alien call of a neighbour,</line>
      <line>To the mere possible shadow of Deity offer the victim?</line>
      <line>And is all this, my friend, but a weak and ignoble refining,</line>
      <line>Wholly unworthy the head or the heart of Your Own Correspondent?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, we are fighting at last, it appears. This morning as usual,</line>
      <line>Murray, as usual, in hand, I enter the Caffe Nuovo;</line>
      <line>Seating myself with a sense as it were of a change in the weather,</line>
      <line>Not understanding, however, but thinking mostly of Murray,</line>
      <line>And, for to-day is their day, of the Campidoglio Marbles,</line>
      <line>Caffe-latte! I call to the waiter,—and Non c’ e latte,</line>
      <line>This is the answer he makes me, and this the sign of a battle.</line>
      <line>So I sit; and truly they seem to think any one else more</line>
      <line>Worthy than me of attention. I wait for my milkless nero,</line>
      <line>Free to observe undistracted all sorts and sizes of persons,</line>
      <line>Blending civilian and soldier in strangest costume, coming in, and</line>
      <line>Gulping in hottest haste, still standing, their coffee,—withdrawing</line>
      <line>Eagerly, jangling a sword on the steps, or jogging a musket</line>
      <line>Slung to the shoulder behind. They are fewer, moreover, than usual,</line>
      <line>Much, and silenter far; and so I begin to imagine</line>
      <line>Something is really afloat. Ere I leave, the Caffe is empty,</line>
      <line>Empty too the streets, in all its length the Corso</line>
      <line>Empty, and empty I see to my right and left the Condotti.</line>
      <line>Twelve o’clock, on the Pincian Hill, with lots of English,</line>
      <line>Germans, Americans, French,—the Frenchmen, too, are protected,—</line>
      <line>So we stand in the sun, but afraid of a probable shower;</line>
      <line>So we stand and stare, and see, to the left of St Peter’s,</line>
      <line>Smoke, from the cannon, white,—but that is at intervals only,—</line>
      <line>Black, from a burning house, we suppose, by the Cavalleggieri;</line>
      <line>And we believe we discern some lines of men descending</line>
      <line>Down through the vineyard-slopes, and catch a bayonet gleaming.</line>
      <line>Every ten minutes, however,—in this there is no misconception,—</line>
      <line>Comes a great white puff from behind Michel Angelo’s dome, and</line>
      <line>After a space the report of a real big gun,—not the Frenchman’s?—</line>
      <line>That must be doing some work. And so we watch and conjecture.</line>
      <line>Shortly, an Englishman comes, who says he has been to St Peter’s,</line>
      <line>Seen the Piazza and troops, but that is all he can tell us;</line>
      <line>So we watch and sit, and, indeed, it begins to be tiresome.—</line>
      <line>All this smoke is outside; when it has come to the inside,</line>
      <line>It will be time, perhaps, to descend and retreat to our houses.</line>
      <line>Half past one, or two. The report of small arms frequent,</line>
      <line>Sharp and savage indeed; that cannot all be for nothing:</line>
      <line>So we watch and wonder; but guessing is tiresome, very.</line>
      <line>Weary of wondering, watching, and guessing, and gossiping idly,</line>
      <line>Down I go, and pass through the quiet streets with the knots of</line>
      <line>National Guards patrolling, and flags hanging out at the windows,</line>
      <line>English, American, Danish,—and, after offering to help an</line>
      <line>Irish family moving en masse to the Maison Serny,</line>
      <line>After endeavouring idly to minister balm to the trembling</line>
      <line>Quinquagenarian fears of two lone British spinsters,</line>
      <line>Go to make sure of my dinner before the enemy enter.</line>
      <line>But by this there are signs of stragglers returning; and voices</line>
      <line>Talk, though you don’t believe it, of guns and prisoners taken;</line>
      <line>And on the walls you read the first bulletin of the morning.—</line>
      <line>This is all that I saw, and all I know of the battle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Victory! Victory!—Yes! ah, yes, thou republican Zion,</line>
      <line>Truly the kings of the earth are gathered and gone by together;</line>
      <line>Doubtless they marvelled to witness such things, were astonished, and so forth.</line>
      <line>Victory! Victory! Victory!—Ah, but it is, believe me,</line>
      <line>Easier, easier far, to intone the chant of the martyr</line>
      <line>Than to indite any paean of any victory. Death may</line>
      <line>Sometimes be noble; but life, at the best, will appear an illusion.</line>
      <line>While the great pain is upon us, it is great; when it is over,</line>
      <line>Why, it is over. The smoke of the sacrifice rises to heaven,</line>
      <line>Of a sweet savour, no doubt, to Somebody; but on the altar,</line>
      <line>Lo, there is nothing remaining but ashes and dirt and ill odour.</line>
      <line>So it stands, you perceive; the labial muscles, that swelled with</line>
      <line>Vehement evolution of yesterday Marseillaises,</line>
      <line>Articulations sublime of defiance and scorning, to-day col-</line>
      <line>Lapse and languidly mumble, while men and women and papers</line>
      <line>Scream and re-scream to each other the chorus of Victory. Well, but</line>
      <line>I am thankful they fought, and glad that the Frenchmen were beaten.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, I have seen a man killed! An experience that, among others!</line>
      <line>Yes, I suppose I have; although I can hardly be certain,</line>
      <line>And in a court of justice could never declare I had seen it.</line>
      <line>But a man was killed, I am told, in a place where I saw</line>
      <line>Something; a man was killed, I am told, and I saw something.</line>
      <line>I was returning home from St Peter’s; Murray, as usual,</line>
      <line>Under my arm, I remember; had crossed the St Angelo bridge; and</line>
      <line>Moving towards the Condotti, had got to the first barricade, when</line>
      <line>Gradually, thinking still of St Peter’s, I became conscious</line>
      <line>Of a sensation of movement opposing me,—tendency this way</line>
      <line>(Such as one fancies may be in a stream when the wave of the tide is</line>
      <line>Coming and not yet come,—a sort of poise and retention);</line>
      <line>So I turned, and, before I turned, caught sight of stragglers</line>
      <line>Heading a crowd, it is plain, that is coming behind that corner.</line>
      <line>Looking up, I see windows filled with heads; the Piazza,</line>
      <line>Into which you remember the Ponte St Angelo enters,</line>
      <line>Since I passed, has thickened with curious groups; and now the</line>
      <line>Crowd is coming, has turned, has crossed that last barricade, is</line>
      <line>Here at my side. In the middle they drag at something. What is it?</line>
      <line>Ha! bare swords in the air, held up! There seem to be voices</line>
      <line>Pleading and hands putting back; official, perhaps; but the swords are</line>
      <line>Many, and bare in the air. In the air? They descend; they are smiting</line>
      <line>Hewing, chopping—At what? In the air once more upstretched! And</line>
      <line>Is it blood that’s on them? Yes, certainly blood! Of whom, then?</line>
      <line>Over whom is the cry of this furor of exultation?</line>
      <line>While they are skipping and screaming, and dancing their caps on</line>
      <line>the points of</line>
      <line>Swords and bayonets, I to the outskirts back, and ask a</line>
      <line>Mercantile-seeming by-stander, ‘What is it?’ and he, looking always</line>
      <line>That way, makes me answer, ‘A Priest, who was trying to fly to</line>
      <line>The Neapolitan army,’—and thus explains the proceeding.</line>
      <line>You didn’t see the dead man? No;—I began to be doubtful;</line>
      <line>I was in black myself, and didn’t know what mightn’t happen;—</line>
      <line>But a National Guard close by me, outside of the hubbub,</line>
      <line>Broke his sword with slashing a broad hat covered with dust,—and</line>
      <line>Passing away from the place with Murray under my arm, and</line>
      <line>Stooping, I saw through the legs of the people the legs of a body.</line>
      <line>You are the first, do you know, to whom I have mentioned the matter.</line>
      <line>Whom should I tell it to, else?—these girls?—the Heavens forbid it!—</line>
      <line>Quidnuncs at Monaldini’s?—idlers upon the Pincian?</line>
      <line>If I rightly remember, it happened on that afternoon when</line>
      <line>Word of the nearer approach of a new Neapolitan army</line>
      <line>First was spread. I began to bethink me of Paris Septembers,</line>
      <line>Thought I could fancy the look of the old ’Ninety-two. On that evening</line>
      <line>Three or four, or, it may be, five, of these people were slaughtered.</line>
      <line>Some declare they had, one of them, fired on a sentinel; others</line>
      <line>Say they were only escaping; a Priest, it is currendy stated,</line>
      <line>Stabbed a National Guard on the very Piazza Colonna:</line>
      <line>History, Rumour of Rumours, I leave it to thee to determine!</line>
      <line>But I am thankful to say the government seems to have strength to</line>
      <line>Put it down; it has vanished, at least; the place is most peaceful.</line>
      <line>Through the Trastevere walking last night, at nine of the clock, I</line>
      <line>Found no sort of disorder; I crossed by the Island-bridges,</line>
      <line>So by the narrow streets to the Ponte Rotto, and onwards</line>
      <line>Thence, by the Temple of Vesta, away to the great Coliseum,</line>
      <line>Which at the full of the moon is an object worthy a visit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Only think, dearest Louisa, what fearful scenes we have witnessed!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>George has just seen Garibaldi, dressed up in a long white cloak, on</line>
      <line>Horseback, riding by, with his mounted negro behind him:</line>
      <line>This is a man, you know, who came from America with him,</line>
      <line>Out of the woods, I suppose, and uses a lasso in fighting,</line>
      <line>Which is, I don’t quite know, but a sort of noose, I imagine;</line>
      <line>This he throws on the heads of the enemy’s men in a battle,</line>
      <line>Pulls them into his reach, and then most cruelly kills them:</line>
      <line>Mary does not believe, but we heard it from an Italian.</line>
      <line>Mary allows she was wrong about Mr Claude being selfish;</line>
      <line>He was most useful and kind on the terrible thirtieth of April.</line>
      <line>Do not write here any more; we are starting directly for Florence:</line>
      <line>We should be off to-morrow, if only Papa could get horses;</line>
      <line>All have been seized everywhere for the use of this dreadful Mazzini.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>P.S.</line>
      <line>Mary has seen thus far.—I am really so angry, Louisa,—</line>
      <line>Quite out of patience, my dearest! What can the man be intending!</line>
      <line>I am quite tired; and Mary, who might bring him to in a moment,</line>
      <line>Lets him go on as he likes, and neither will help nor dismiss him.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is most curious to see what a power a few calm words (in</line>
      <line>Merely a brief proclamation) appear to possess on the people.</line>
      <line>Order is perfect, and peace; the city is utterly tranquil;</line>
      <line>And one cannot conceive that this easy and nonchalant crowd, that</line>
      <line>Flows like a quiet stream through street and market-place, entering</line>
      <line>Shady recesses and bays of church, osteria, and caffe,</line>
      <line>Could in a moment be changed to a flood as of molten lava,</line>
      <line>Boil into deadly wrath and wild homicidal delusion.</line>
      <line>Ah, ’tis an excellent race,—and even in old degradation,</line>
      <line>Under a rule that enforces to flattery, lying, and cheating,</line>
      <line>E’en under Pope and Priest, a nice and natural people.</line>
      <line>Oh, could they but be allowed this chance of redemption!—but clearly</line>
      <line>That is not likely to be. Meantime, notwithstanding all journals,</line>
      <line>Honour for once to the tongue and the pen of the eloquent writer!</line>
      <line>Honour to speech! and all honour to thee, thou noble Mazzini!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I AM in love, meantime, you think; no doubt you would think so.</line>
      <line>I am in love, you say; with those letters, of course, you would say so.</line>
      <line>I am in love, you declare. I think not so; yet I grant you</line>
      <line>It is a pleasure, indeed, to converse with this girl. Oh, rare gift,</line>
      <line>Rare felicity, this! she can talk in a rational way, can</line>
      <line>Speak upon subjects that really are matters of mind and of thinking,</line>
      <line>Yet in perfection retain her simplicity; never, one moment,</line>
      <line>Never, however you urge it, however you tempt her, consents to</line>
      <line>Step from ideas and fancies and loving sensations to those vain</line>
      <line>Conscious understandings that vex the minds of man-kind.</line>
      <line>No, though she talk, it is music; her fingers desert not the keys; ’tis</line>
      <line>Song, though you hear in the song the articulate vocables sounded,</line>
      <line>Syllabled singly and sweetly the words of melodious meaning.</line>
      <line>I am in love, you say; I do not think so exactly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There are two different kinds, I believe, of human attraction:</line>
      <line>One which simply disturbs, unsettles, and makes you uneasy,</line>
      <line>And another that poises, retains, and fixes and holds you.</line>
      <line>I have no doubt, for myself, in giving my voice for the latter.</line>
      <line>I do not wish to be moved, but growing where I was growing,</line>
      <line>There more truly to grow, to live where as yet I had languished.</line>
      <line>I do not like being moved: for the will is excited; and action</line>
      <line>Is a most dangerous thing; I tremble for something factitious,</line>
      <line>Some malpractice of heart and illegitimate process;</line>
      <line>We are so prone to these things with our terrible notions of duty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, let me look, let me watch, let m£ wait, unhurried, unprompted!</line>
      <line>Bid me not venture on aught that could alter or end what is present!</line>
      <line>Say not, Time flies, and Occasion, that never returns, is departing!</line>
      <line>Drive me not out, ye ill angels with fiery swords, from my Eden,</line>
      <line>Waiting, and watching, and looking! Let love be its own inspiration!</line>
      <line>Shall not a voice, if a voice there must be, from the airs that environ,</line>
      <line>Yea, from the conscious heavens, without our knowledge or effort,</line>
      <line>Break into audible words? and love be its own inspiration?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wherefore and how I am certain, I hardly can tell; but it is so.</line>
      <line>She doesn’t like me, Eustace; I think she never will like me.</line>
      <line>Is it my fault, as it is my misfortune, my ways are not her ways?</line>
      <line>Is it my fault, that my habits and modes are dissimilar wholly?</line>
      <line>’Tis not her fault, ’tis her nature, her virtue, to misapprehend them:</line>
      <line>’Tis not her fault, ’tis her beautiful nature, not ever to know me.</line>
      <line>Hopeless it seems,—yet I cannot, though hopeless, determine to leave it:</line>
      <line>She goes,—therefore I go; she moves,—I move, not to lose her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, ’tisn’t manly, of course, ’tisn’t manly, this method of wooing;</line>
      <line>’Tisn’t the way very likely to win. For the woman, they tell you,</line>
      <line>Ever prefers the audacious, the wilful, the vehement hero;</line>
      <line>She has no heart for the timid, the sensitive soul; and for knowledge,—</line>
      <line>Knowledge, O ye Gods!—when did they appreciate knowledge?</line>
      <line>Wherefore should they, either? I am sure I do not desire it.</line>
      <line>Ah, and I feel too, Eustace, she cares not a tittle about me!</line>
      <line>(Care about me, indeed! and do I really expect it?)</line>
      <line>But my manner offends; my ways are wholly repugnant;</line>
      <line>Every word that I utter estranges, hurts, and repels her;</line>
      <line>Every moment of bliss that I gain, in her exquisite presence,</line>
      <line>Slowly, surely, withdraws her, removes her, and severs her from me.</line>
      <line>Not that I care very much!—any way, I escape from the boy’s own</line>
      <line>Folly, to which I am prone, of loving where it is easy.</line>
      <line>Not that I mind very much! Why should I? I am not in love, and</line>
      <line>Am prepared, I think, if not by previous habit,</line>
      <line>Yet in the spirit beforehand for this and all that is like it;</line>
      <line>It is an easier matter for us contemplative creatures,</line>
      <line>Us, upon whom the pressure of action is laid so lightly;</line>
      <line>We discontented indeed with things in particular, idle,</line>
      <line>Sickly, complaining, by faith in the vision of things in general,</line>
      <line>Manage to hold on our way without, like others around us,</line>
      <line>Seizing the nearest arm to comfort, help, and support us.</line>
      <line>Yet, after all, my Eustace, I know but little about it.</line>
      <line>All I can say for myself, for present alike and for past, is,</line>
      <line>Mary Trevellyn, Eustace, is certainly worth your acquaintance.</line>
      <line>You couldn’t come, I suppose, as far as Florence, to see her?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To-morrow we’re starting for Florence,</line>
      <line>Truly rejoiced, you may guess, to escape from republican terrors;</line>
      <line>Mr C. and Papa to escort us; we by vettura</line>
      <line>Through Siena, and Georgy to follow and join us by Leghorn.</line>
      <line>Then-Ah, what shall I say, my dearest? I tremble in thinking!</line>
      <line>You will imagine my feelings,—the blending of hope and of sorrow!</line>
      <line>How can I bear to abandon Papa and Mamma and my Sisters?</line>
      <line>Dearest Louisa, indeed it is very alarming; but trust me</line>
      <line>Ever, whatever may change, to remain your loving Georgina.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Do I like Mr Claude any better?’</line>
      <line>I am to tell you,—and, ‘Pray, is it Susan or I that attract him?’</line>
      <line>This he never has told, but Georgina could certainly ask him.</line>
      <line>All I can say for myself is, alas! that he rather repels me.</line>
      <line>There! I think him agreeable, but also a little repulsive.</line>
      <line>So be content, dear Louisa; for one satisfactory marriage</line>
      <line>Surely will do in one year for the family you would establish;</line>
      <line>Neither Susan nor I shall afford you the joy of a second.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mr Claude, you must know, is behaving a little bit better;</line>
      <line>He and Papa are great friends; but he really is too shilly-shally —</line>
      <line>So unlike George! Yet I hope that the matter is going on fairly.</line>
      <line>I shall, however, get George, before he goes, to say something.</line>
      <line>Dearest Louisa, how delightful, to bring young people together!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it to Florence we follow, or are we to tarry yet longer,</line>
      <line>E'en amid clamour of arms, here in the city of old,</line>
      <line>Seeking from clamour of arms in the Past and the Arts to be hidden,</line>
      <line>Vainly 'mid Arts and the Past seeking one life to forget?</line>
      <line>Ah, fair shadow, scarce seen, go forth! for anon he shall follow,—</line>
      <line>He that beheld thee, anon, whither thou leadest, must go!</line>
      <line>Go, and the wise, loving Muse, she also will follow and find thee!</line>
      <line>She, should she linger in Rome, were not dissevered from thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet to the wondrous St Peter's, and yet to the solemn Rotonda,</line>
      <line>Mingling with heroes and gods, yet to the Vatican walls,</line>
      <line>Yet may we go, and recline, while a whole mighty world seems above us</line>
      <line>Gathered and fixed to all time into one roofing supreme;</line>
      <line>Yet may we, thinking on these things, exclude what is meaner around us;</line>
      <line>Yet, at the worst of the worst, books and a chamber remain;</line>
      <line>Yet may we think, and forget, and possess our souls in resistance.—</line>
      <line>Ah, but away from the stir, shouting, and gossip of war,</line>
      <line>Where, upon Apennine slope, with the chestnut the oak-trees immingle,</line>
      <line>Where amid odorous copse bridle-paths wander and wind,</line>
      <line>Where under mulberry-branches the diligent rivulet sparkles,</line>
      <line>Or amid cotton and maize peasants their waterworks ply,</line>
      <line>Where, over fig-tree and orange in tier upon tier still repeated,</line>
      <line>Garden on garden upreared, balconies step to the sky,—</line>
      <line>Ah, that I were, far away from the crowd and the streets of the city,</line>
      <line>Under the vine-trellis laid, 0 my beloved, with thee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why doesn’t Mr Claude come with us? you ask.— We don’t know.</line>
      <line>You should know better than we. He talked of the Vatican marbles;</line>
      <line>But I can’t wholly believe that this was the actual reason,—</line>
      <line>He was so ready before, when we asked him to come and escort us.</line>
      <line>Certainly he is odd, my dear Miss Roper. To change so</line>
      <line>Suddenly, just for a whim, was not quite fair to the party,—</line>
      <line>Not quite right. I declare, I really almost am offended:</line>
      <line>I, his great friend, as you say, have doubtless a title to be so.</line>
      <line>Not that I greatly regret it, for dear Georgina distinctly</line>
      <line>Wishes for nothing so much as to show her adroitness. But, oh, my</line>
      <line>Pen will not write any more;—let us say nothing further about it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, my dear Miss Roper, I certainly called him repulsive;</line>
      <line>So I think him, but cannot be sure I have used the expression</line>
      <line>Quite as your pupil should; yet he does most truly repel me.</line>
      <line>Was it to you I made use of the word? or who was it told you?</line>
      <line>Yes, repulsive; observe, it is but when he talks of ideas,</line>
      <line>That he is quite unaffected, and free, and expansive, and easy;</line>
      <line>I could pronounce him simply a cold intellectual being.—</line>
      <line>When does he make advances?—He thinks that women should woo him;</line>
      <line>Yet, if a girl should do so, would be but alarmed and disgusted.</line>
      <line>She that should love him must look for small love in return,—like the ivy</line>
      <line>On the stone wall, must expect but a rigid and niggard support, and</line>
      <line>E’en to get that must go searching all round with her humble embraces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tell me, my friend, do you think that the grain would sprout in the furrow,</line>
      <line>Did it not truly accept as its summum and ultimum bonum</line>
      <line>That mere common and may-be indifferent soil it is set in?</line>
      <line>Would it have force to develop and open its young cotyledons,</line>
      <line>Could it compare, and reflect, and examine one thing with another?</line>
      <line>Would it endure to accomplish the round of its natural functions,</line>
      <line>Were it endowed with a sense of the general scheme of existence?</line>
      <line>While from Marseilles in the steamer we voyaged to Civita Vecchia,</line>
      <line>Vexed in the squally seas as we lay by Capraja and Elba,</line>
      <line>Standing, uplifted, alone on the heaving poop of the vessel,</line>
      <line>Looking around on the waste of the rushing incurious billows,</line>
      <line>‘This is Nature,’ I said: ‘we are born as it were from her waters,</line>
      <line>Over her billows that buffet and beat us, her offspring uncared-for,</line>
      <line>Casting one single regard of a painful victorious knowledge,</line>
      <line>Into her billows that buffet and beat us we sink and are swallowed.’</line>
      <line>This was the sense in my soul, as I swayed with the poop of the steamer;</line>
      <line>And as unthinking I sat in the hall of the famed Ariadne,</line>
      <line>Lo, it looked at me there from the face of a Triton in marble.</line>
      <line>It is the simpler thought, and I can believe it the truer.</line>
      <line>Let us not talk of growth; we are still in our Aqueous Ages.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell, Politics, utterly! What can I do? I cannot</line>
      <line>Fight, you know; and to talk I am wholly ashamed. And although I</line>
      <line>Gnash my teeth when I look in your French or your English papers,</line>
      <line>What is the good of that? Will swearing, I wonder, mend matters?</line>
      <line>Cursing and scolding repel the assailants? No, it is idle;</line>
      <line>No, whatever befalls, I will hide, will ignore or forget it.</line>
      <line>Let the tail shift for itself; I will bury my head. And what’s the</line>
      <line>Roman Republic to me, or I to the Roman Republic?</line>
      <line>Why not fight?—In the first place, I haven’t so much as a musket.</line>
      <line>In the next, if I had, I shouldn’t know how I should use it.</line>
      <line>In the third, just at present I’m studying ancient marbles.</line>
      <line>In the fourth, I consider I owe my life to my country.</line>
      <line>In the fifth,—I forget, but four good reasons are ample.</line>
      <line>Meantime, pray, let ’em fight, and be killed. I delight in devotion.</line>
      <line>So that I ’list not, hurrah for the glorious army of martyrs!</line>
      <line>Sanguis martyrum semen Ecclesice; though it would seem this</line>
      <line>Church is indeed of the purely Invisible, Kingdom-come kind:</line>
      <line>Militant here on earth! Triumphant, of course, then, elsewhere!</line>
      <line>Ah, good Heaven, but I would I were out far away from the pother!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not, as we read in the words of the olden-time inspiration,</line>
      <line>Are there two several trees in the place we are set to abide in;</line>
      <line>But on the apex most high of the Tree of Life in the Garden,</line>
      <line>Budding, unfolding, and falling, decaying and flowering ever,</line>
      <line>Flowering is set and decaying the transient blossom of Knowledge,—</line>
      <line>Flowering alone, and decaying, the needless, unfruitful blossom.</line>
      <line>Or as the cypress-spires by the fair-flowing stream Hellespontine,</line>
      <line>Which from the mythical tomb of the godlike Protesilaiis</line>
      <line>Rose sympathetic in grief to his lovelorn Laodamia,</line>
      <line>Evermore growing, and, when in their growth to the prospect attaining,</line>
      <line>Over the low sea-banks, of the fatal Ilian city,</line>
      <line>Withering still at the sight which still they upgrow to encounter.</line>
      <line>Ah, but ye that extrude from the ocean your helpless faces,</line>
      <line>Ye over stormy seas leading long and dreary processions,</line>
      <line>Ye, too, brood of the wind, whose coming is whence we discern not,</line>
      <line>Making your nest on the wave, and your bed on the crested billow,</line>
      <line>Skimming rough waters, and crowding wet sands that the tide shall return to,</line>
      <line>Cormorants, ducks, and gulls, fill ye my imagination!</line>
      <line>Let us not talk of growth; we are still in our Aqueous Ages.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dearest Miss Roper,—Alas! we are all at Florence quite safe, and</line>
      <line>You, we hear, are shut up! indeed, it is sadly distressing!</line>
      <line>We were most lucky, they say, to get off when we did from the troubles.</line>
      <line>Now you are really besieged! they tell us it soon will be over;</line>
      <line>Only I hope and trust without any fight in the city.</line>
      <line>Do you see Mr Claude?—I thought he might do something for you.</line>
      <line>I am quite sure on occasion he really would wish to be useful.</line>
      <line>What is he doing? I wonder;—still studying Vatican marbles?</line>
      <line>Letters, I hope, pass through. We trust your brother is better.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Juxtaposition, in fine; and what is juxtaposition?</line>
      <line>Look you, we travel along in the railway-carriage, or steamer,</line>
      <line>And, pour passer le temps, till the tedious journey be ended,</line>
      <line>Lay aside paper or book, to talk with the girl that is next one;</line>
      <line>And, pour passer le temps, with the terminus all but in prospect,</line>
      <line>Talk of eternal ties and marriages made in heaven.</line>
      <line>Ah, did we really accept with a perfect heart the illusion!</line>
      <line>Ah, did we really believe that the Present indeed is the Only!</line>
      <line>Or through all transmutation, all shock and convulsion of passion,</line>
      <line>Feel we could carry undimmed, unextinguished, the light of our knowledge!</line>
      <line>But for his funeral train which the bridegroom sees in the distance,</line>
      <line>Would he so joyfully, think you, fall in with the marriage-procession?</line>
      <line>But for that final discharge, would he dare to enlist in that service?</line>
      <line>But for that certain release, ever sign to that perilous contract?</line>
      <line>But for that exit secure, ever bend to that treacherous doorway?—</line>
      <line>Ah, but the bride, meantime,—do you think she sees it as he does?</line>
      <line>But for the steady fore-sense of a freer and larger existence,</line>
      <line>Think you that man could consent to be circumscribed here into action?</line>
      <line>But for assurance within of a limitless ocean divine, o’er</line>
      <line>Whose great tranquil depths unconscious the wind-tost surface</line>
      <line>Breaks into ripples of trouble that come and change and endure not,—</line>
      <line>But that in this, of a truth, we have our being, and know it,</line>
      <line>Think you we men could submit to live and move as we do here?</line>
      <line>Ah, but the women,—God bless them!—they don’t think at all about it.</line>
      <line>Yet we must eat and drink, as you say. And as limited beings</line>
      <line>Scarcely can hope to attain upon earth to an Actual Abstract,</line>
      <line>Leaving to God contemplation, to His hands knowledge confiding,</line>
      <line>Sure that in us if it perish, in Him it abideth and dies not,</line>
      <line>Let us in His sight accomplish our petty particular doings,—</line>
      <line>Yes, and contented sit down to the victual that He has provided.</line>
      <line>Allah is great, no doubt, and Juxtaposition his prophet.</line>
      <line>Ah, but the women, alas! they don’t look at it in that way.</line>
      <line>Juxtaposition is great;—but, my friend, I fear me, the maiden</line>
      <line>Hardly would thank or acknowledge the lover that sought to obtain her,</line>
      <line>Not as the thing he would wish, but the thing he must even put up with,—</line>
      <line>Hardly would tender her hand to the wooer that candidly told her</line>
      <line>That she is but for a space, an ad-interim solace and pleasure,—</line>
      <line>That in the end she shall yield to a perfect and absolute something,</line>
      <line>Which I then for myself shall behold, and not another,—</line>
      <line>Which, amid fondest endearments, meantime I forget not, forsake not.</line>
      <line>Ah, ye feminine souls, so loving and so exacting,</line>
      <line>Since we cannot escape, must we even submit to deceive you?</line>
      <line>Since, so cruel is truth, sincerity shocks and revolts you,</line>
      <line>Will you have us your slaves to lie to you, flatter and—leave you?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Juxtaposition is great,—but, you tell me, affinity greater.</line>
      <line>Ah, my friend, there are many affinities, greater and lesser,</line>
      <line>Stronger and weaker; and each, by the favour of juxtaposition,</line>
      <line>Potent, efficient, in force,—for a time; but none, let me tell you,</line>
      <line>Save by the law of the land and the ruinous force of the will, ah,</line>
      <line>None, I fear me, at last quite sure to be final and perfect.</line>
      <line>Lo, as I pace in the street, from the peasant-girl to the princess,</line>
      <line>Homo sum, nihil humani a me alienum puto,—</line>
      <line>Vir sum, nihil fceminei,—and e’en to the uttermost circle,</line>
      <line>All that is Nature’s is I, and I all things that are Nature’s.</line>
      <line>Yes, as I walk, I behold, in a luminous, large intuition,</line>
      <line>That I can be and become anything that I meet with or look at:</line>
      <line>I am the ox in the dray, the ass with the garden-stuff panniers;</line>
      <line>I am the dog in the doorway, the kitten that plays in the window,</line>
      <line>On sunny slab of the ruin the furtive and fugitive lizard,</line>
      <line>Swallow above me that twitters, and fly that is buzzing about me;</line>
      <line>Yea, and detect, as I go, by a faint but a faithful assurance,</line>
      <line>E’en from the stones of the street, as from rocks or trees of the forest,</line>
      <line>Something of kindred, a common, though latent vitality, greet me;</line>
      <line>And, to escape from our strivings, mistakings, misgrowths, and perversions,</line>
      <line>Fain could demand to return to that perfect and primitive silence,</line>
      <line>Fain be enfolded and fixed, as of old, in their rigid embraces.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And as I walk on my way, I behold them consorting and coupling;</line>
      <line>Faithful it seemeth, and fond, very fond, very probably faithful;</line>
      <line>All as I go on my way, with a pleasure sincere and unmingled.</line>
      <line>Life is beautiful, Eustace, entrancing, enchanting to look at;</line>
      <line>As are the streets of a city we pace while the carriage is changing,</line>
      <line>As a chamber filled-in with harmonious, exquisite pictures,</line>
      <line>Even so beautiful Earth; and could we eliminate only</line>
      <line>This vile hungering impulse, this demon within us of craving,</line>
      <line>Life were beatitude, living a perfect divine satisfaction.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>MILD monastic faces in quiet collegiate cloisters:</line>
      <line>So let me offer a single and celibatarian phrase, a</line>
      <line>Tribute to those whom perhaps you do not believe I can honour.</line>
      <line>But, from the tumult escaping, ’tis pleasant, of drumming and shouting,</line>
      <line>Hither, oblivious awhile, to withdraw, of the fact or the falsehood,</line>
      <line>And amid placid regards and mildly courteous greetings</line>
      <line>Yield to the calm and composure and gentle abstraction that reign o’er</line>
      <line>Mild monastic faces in quiet collegiate cloisters.</line>
      <line>Terrible word, Obligation! You should not, Eustace, you should not,</line>
      <line>No, you should not have used it. But, O great Heavens! I repel it.</line>
      <line>Oh, I cancel, reject, disavow, and repudiate wholly</line>
      <line>Every debt in this kind, disclaim every claim, and dishonour,</line>
      <line>Yea, my own heart’s own writing, my soul’s own signature! Ah, no!</line>
      <line>I will be free in this; you shall not, none shall, bind me.</line>
      <line>No, my friend, if you wish to be told, it was this above all things,</line>
      <line>This that charmed me, ah, yes, even this, that she held me to nothing.</line>
      <line>No, I could talk as I pleased; come close; fasten ties, as I fancied;</line>
      <line>Bind and engage myself deep;—and lo, on the following morning</line>
      <line>It was all e’en as before, like losings in games played for nothing.</line>
      <line>Yes, when I came, with mean fears in my soul, with a semi-performance</line>
      <line>At the first step breaking down in its pitiful role of evasion,</line>
      <line>When to shuffle I came, to compromise, not meet, engagements,</line>
      <line>Lo, with her calm eyes there she met me and knew nothing of it,—</line>
      <line>Stood unexpecting, unconscious. She spoke not of obligations,</line>
      <line>Knew not of debt,—ah, no, I believe you, for excellent reasons.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>HANG this thinking, at last! what good is it? oh, and what evil!</line>
      <line>Oh, what mischief and pain! like a clock in a sick man’s chamber,</line>
      <line>Ticking and ticking, and still through each covert of slumber pursuing.</line>
      <line>What shall I do to thee, O thou Preserver of Men? Have compassion;</line>
      <line>Be favourable, and hear! Take from me this regal knowledge;</line>
      <line>Let me, contented and mute, with the beasts of the field, my brothers,</line>
      <line>Tranquilly, happily lie,—and eat grass, like Nebuchadnezzar!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tibur is beautiful, too, and the orchard slopes, and the Anio</line>
      <line>Palling, falling yet, to the ancient lyrical cadence;</line>
      <line>Tibur and Anio’s tide; and cool from Lucretilis ever,</line>
      <line>With the Digentian stream, and with the Bandusian fountain,</line>
      <line>Folded in Sabine recesses, the valley and villa of Horace:—</line>
      <line>So not seeing I sung; so seeing and listening say I,</line>
      <line>Here as I sit by the stream, as I gaze at the cell of the Sibyl,</line>
      <line>Here with Albunea’s home and the grove of Tiburnus beside me;</line>
      <line>Tivoli beautiful is, and musical, O Teverone,</line>
      <line>Dashing from mountain to plain, thy parted impetuous waters!</line>
      <line>Tivoli’s waters and rocks; and fair under Monte Gennaro</line>
      <line>(Haunt even yet, I must think, as I wander and gaze, of the shadows,</line>
      <line>Faded and pale, yet immortal, of Faunus, the Nymphs, and the Graces),</line>
      <line>Fair in itself, and yet fairer with human completing creations,</line>
      <line>Folded in Sabine recesses the valley and villa of Horace:—</line>
      <line>So not seeing I sung; so now—Nor seeing, nor hearing,</line>
      <line>Neither by waterfall lulled, nor folded in sylvan embraces,</line>
      <line>Neither by cell of the Sibyl, nor stepping the Monte Gennaro,</line>
      <line>Seated on Anio’s bank, nor sipping Bandusian waters,</line>
      <line>But on Montorio’s height, looking down on the tile-clad streets, the</line>
      <line>Cupolas, crosses, and domes, the bushes and kitchen-gardens,</line>
      <line>Which, by the grace of the Tiber, proclaim themselves Rome of the Romans,—</line>
      <line>But on Montorio’s height, looking forth to the vapoury mountains,</line>
      <line>Cheating the prisoner Hope with illusions of vision and fancy,—</line>
      <line>But on Montorio’s height, with these weary soldiers by me,</line>
      <line>Waiting till Oudinot enter, to reinstate Pope and Tourist.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear Miss Roper,—It seems, George Vernon, before we left Rome, said</line>
      <line>Something to Mr Claude about what they call his attentions.</line>
      <line>Susan, two nights ago, for the first time, heard this from Georgina.</line>
      <line>It is so disagreeable and so annoying to think of!</line>
      <line>If it could only be known, though we may never meet him again, that</line>
      <line>It was all George’s doing, and we were entirely unconscious,</line>
      <line>It would extremely relieve—Your ever affectionate Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here is your letter arrived this moment, just as I wanted.</line>
      <line>So you have seen him,—indeed,—and guessed,—how dreadfully clever!</line>
      <line>What did he really say? and what was your answer exactly?</line>
      <line>Charming!—but wait for a moment, I haven’t read through the letter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, my dearest Miss Roper, do just as you fancy about it.</line>
      <line>If you think it sincerer to tell him I know of it, do so.</line>
      <line>Though I should most extremely dislike it, I know I could manage.</line>
      <line>It is the simplest thing, but surely wholly uncalled for.</line>
      <line>Do as you please; you know I trust implicitly to you.</line>
      <line>Say whatever is right and needful for ending the matter.</line>
      <line>Only don’t tell Mr Claude, what I will tell you as a secret,</line>
      <line>That I should like very well to show him myself I forget it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am to say that the wedding is finally settled for Tuesday.</line>
      <line>Ah, my dear Miss Roper, you surely, surely can manage</line>
      <line>Not to let it appear that I know of that odious matter.</line>
      <line>It would be pleasanter far for myself to treat it exactly</line>
      <line>As if it had not occurred; and I do not think he would like it.</line>
      <line>I must remember to add, that as soon as the wedding is over</line>
      <line>We shall be off, I believe, in a hurry, and travel to Milan,</line>
      <line>There to meet friends of Papa’s, I am told, at the Croce di Malta;</line>
      <line>Then I cannot say whither, but not at present to England.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, on Montorio’s height for a last farewell of the city,—</line>
      <line>So it appears; though then I was quite uncertain about it.</line>
      <line>So, however, it was. And now to explain the proceeding.</line>
      <line>I was to go, as I told you, I think, with the people to Florence.</line>
      <line>Only the day before, the foolish family Vernon</line>
      <line>Made some uneasy remarks, as we walked to our lodging together,</line>
      <line>As to intentions, forsooth, and so forth. I was astounded,</line>
      <line>Horrified quite; and obtaining just then, as it happened, an offer</line>
      <line>(No common favour) of seeing the great Ludovisi collection,</line>
      <line>Why, I made this a pretence, and wrote that they must excuse me.</line>
      <line>How could I go? Great Heaven! to conduct a permitted flirtation</line>
      <line>Under those vulgar eyes, the observed of such observers!</line>
      <line>Well, but I now, by a series of fine diplomatic inquiries,</line>
      <line>Find from a sort of relation, a good and sensible woman,</line>
      <line>Who is remaining at Rome with a brother too ill for removal,</line>
      <line>That it was wholly unsanctioned, unknown,—not, I think, by Georgina:</line>
      <line>She, however, ere this,—and that is the best of the story,—</line>
      <line>She and the Vernon, thank Heaven, are wedded and gone — honey-mooning.</line>
      <line>So—on Montorio’s height for a last farewell of the city.</line>
      <line>Tibur I have not seen, nor the lakes that of old I had dreamt of;</line>
      <line>Tiber I shall not see, nor Anio’s waters, nor deep en-</line>
      <line>Folded in Sabine recesses the valley and villa of Horace;</line>
      <line>Tibur I shall not see;—but something better I shall see.</line>
      <line>Twice I have tried before, and failed in getting the horses;</line>
      <line>Twice I have tried and failed: this time it shall not be a failure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Therefore farewell, ye hills, and ye, ye envineyarded ruins.</line>
      <line>Therefore farewell, ye walls, palaces, pillars, and domes!</line>
      <line>Therefore farewell, far seen, ye peaks of the mythic Albano,</line>
      <line>Seen from Montorio’s height, Tibur and/Esula’s hills!</line>
      <line>Ah, could we once, ere we go, could we stand, while, to ocean descending,</line>
      <line>Sinks o’er the yellow dark plain slowly the yellow broad sun,</line>
      <line>Stand, from the forest emerging at sunset, at once in the champaign,</line>
      <line>Open, but studded with trees, chestnuts umbrageous and old,</line>
      <line>E'en in those fair open fields that incurve to thy beautiful hollow,</line>
      <line>Nerni, imbedded in wood, Nemi, inumed in the hill!—</line>
      <line>Therefore farewell, ye plains, and ye hills, and the City Eternal!</line>
      <line>Therefore farewell! We depart, but to behold you again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Eastward, or Northward, or West? I wander and ask as I wander,</line>
      <line>Weary, yet eager and sure, Where shall I come to my love?</line>
      <line>Whitherward hasten to seek her? Ye daughters of Italy, tell me.</line>
      <line>Graceful and tender and dark, is she consorting with you?</line>
      <line>Thou that out-climbest the torrent, that tendest thy goats to the summit,</line>
      <line>Call to me, child of the Alp, has she been seen on the heights?</line>
      <line>Italy, farewell I bid thee! for whither she leads me, I follow.</line>
      <line>Farewell the vineyard! for I, where I but guess her, must go.</line>
      <line>Weariness welcome, and labour, wherever it be, if at last it</line>
      <line>Bring me in mountain or plain into the sight of my love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gone from Florence; indeed; and that is truly provoking;—</line>
      <line>Gone to Milan, it seems; then I go also to Milan.</line>
      <line>Five days now departed; but they can travel but slowly;—</line>
      <line>I quicker far; and I know, as it happens, the house they will go to.—</line>
      <line>Why, what else should I do? Stay here and look at the pictures,</line>
      <line>Statues, and churches? Alack, I am sick of the statues and pictures!—</line>
      <line>No, to Bologna, Parma, Piacenza, Lodi, and Milan,</line>
      <line>Off go we to-night,—and the Venus go to the Devil!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gone to Como, they said; and I have posted to Como.</line>
      <line>There was a letter left; but the cameriere had lost it.</line>
      <line>Could it have been for me? They came, however, to Como,</line>
      <line>And from Como went by the boat,—perhaps to the Spliigen,—</line>
      <line>Or to the Stelvio, say, and the Tyrol; also it might be</line>
      <line>By Porlezza across to Lugano, and so to the Simplon</line>
      <line>Possibly, or the St Gothard,—or possibly, too, to Baveno,</line>
      <line>Orta, Turin, and elsewhere. Indeed, I am greatly bewildered.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have been up the Spliigen, and on the Stelvio also:</line>
      <line>Neither of these can I find they have followed; in no one inn, and</line>
      <line>This would be odd, have they written their names. I have been to Porlezza;</line>
      <line>There they have not been seen, and therefore not at Lugano.</line>
      <line>What shall I do? Go on through the Tyrol, Switzerland, Deutschland,</line>
      <line>Seeking, an inverse Saul, a kingdom, to find only asses?</line>
      <line>There is a tide, at least in the love affairs of mortals,</line>
      <line>Which, when taken at flood, leads on to the happiest fortune,—</line>
      <line>Leads to the marriage-morn and the orange-flowers and the altar,</line>
      <line>And the long lawful line of crowned joys to crowned joys succeeding.—</line>
      <line>Ah, it has ebbed with me! Ye gods, and when it was flowing,</line>
      <line>Pitiful fool that I was, to stand fiddle-faddling in that way!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have returned and found their names in the book at Como.</line>
      <line>Certain it is I was right, and yet I am also in error.</line>
      <line>Added in feminine hand, I read, By the boat to Bellaggio.—</line>
      <line>So to Bellaggio again, with the words of her writing to aid me.</line>
      <line>Yet at Bellaggio I find no trace, no sort of remembrance.</line>
      <line>So I am here, and wait, and know every hour will remove them.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have but one chance left,—and that is going to Florence.</line>
      <line>But it is cruel to turn. The mountains seem to demand me,—</line>
      <line>Peak and valley from far to beckon and motion me onward.</line>
      <line>Somewhere amid their folds she passes whom fain I would follow;</line>
      <line>Somewhere among those heights she haply calls me to seek her.</line>
      <line>Ah, could I hear her call! could I catch the glimpse of her raiment!</line>
      <line>Turn, however, I must, though it seem I turn to desert her;</line>
      <line>For the sense of the thing is simply to hurry to Florence,</line>
      <line>Where the certainty yet may be learnt, I suppose, from the Ropers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear Miss Roper,—By this you are safely away, we are hoping,</line>
      <line>Many a league from Rome; erelong we trust we shall see you.</line>
      <line>Flow have you travelled? I wonder;—was Mr Claude your companion?</line>
      <line>As for ourselves, we went from Como straight to Lugano;</line>
      <line>So by the Mount St Gothard; we meant to go by Porlezza,</line>
      <line>Taking the steamer, and stopping, as you had advised, at Bellaggio,</line>
      <line>Two or three days or more; but this was suddenly altered,</line>
      <line>After we left the hotel, on the very way to the steamer.</line>
      <line>So we have seen, I fear, not one of the lakes in perfection.</line>
      <line>Well, he is not come; and now, I suppose, he will not come.</line>
      <line>What will you think, meantime?—and yet I must really confess it;—</line>
      <line>What will you say? I wrote him a note. We left in a hurry,</line>
      <line>Went from Milan to Como, three days before we expected.</line>
      <line>But I thought, if he came all the way to Milan, he really</line>
      <line>Ought not to be disappointed; and so I wrote three lines to</line>
      <line>Say I had heard he was coming, desirous of joining our party;—</line>
      <line>If so, then I said, we had started for Como, and meant to</line>
      <line>Cross the St Gothard, and stay, we believed, at Lucerne, for the summer.</line>
      <line>Was it wrong? and why, if it was, has it failed to bring him?</line>
      <line>Did he not think it worth while to come to Milan? He knew (you</line>
      <line>Told him) the house we should go to. Or may it, perhaps, have miscarried?</line>
      <line>Any way, now, I repent, and am heartily vexed that I wrote it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a home on the shore of the Alpine sea, that upswelling</line>
      <line>High up the mountain-sides spreads in the hollow between;</line>
      <line>Wilderness, mountain, and snow from the land of the olive conceal it;</line>
      <line>Under Pilatus’s hill low by its river it lies:</line>
      <line>Italy, utter the word, and the olive and vine will allure not,—</line>
      <line>Wilderness, forest, and snow will not the passage impede;</line>
      <line>Italy, unto thy cities receding, the clew to recover,</line>
      <line>Hither, recovered the clew, shall not the traveller haste?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a city, upbuilt on the quays of the turbulent Amo,</line>
      <line>Under Fiesole’s heights,—thither are we to return?</line>
      <line>There is a city that fringes the curve of the inflowing waters,</line>
      <line>Under the perilous hill fringes the beautiful bay,—</line>
      <line>Parthenope do they call thee?—the Siren, Neapolis, seated</line>
      <line>Under Vesevus’s hill,—are we receding to thee?—</line>
      <line>Sicily, Greece, will invite, and the Orient;—or are we to turn to</line>
      <line>England, which may after all be for its children the best?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So you are really free, and living in quiet at Florence;</line>
      <line>That is delightful news;—you travelled slowly and safely;</line>
      <line>Mr Claude got you out; took rooms at Florence before you;</line>
      <line>Wrote from Milan to say so; had left directly for Milan,</line>
      <line>Hoping to find us soon;—if he could, he would, you are certain.—</line>
      <line>Dear Miss Roper, your letter has made me exceedingly happy.</line>
      <line>You are quite sure, you say, he asked you about our intentions;</line>
      <line>You had not heard as yet of Lucerne, but told him of Como.—</line>
      <line>Well, perhaps he will come;—however, I will not expect it.</line>
      <line>Though you say you are sure,—if he can, he will, you are certain.</line>
      <line>O my dear, many thanks from your ever affectionate Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>ACTION will furnish belief—but will that belief be the true one?</line>
      <line>This is the point, you know. However, it doesn’t much matter.</line>
      <line>What one wants, I suppose, is to predetermine the action,</line>
      <line>So as to make it entail, not a chance-belief, but the true one.</line>
      <line>Out of the question, you say; if a thing isn’t wrong, we may do it.</line>
      <line>Ah! but this wrong, you see—but I do not know that it matters.</line>
