      <line>Eustace, the Ropers are gone, and no one can tell me about them.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pisa, they say they think; and so I follow to Pisa,</line>
      <line>Hither and thither inquiring, I weary of making inquiries;</line>
      <line>I am ashamed, I declare, of asking people about it.—</line>
      <line>Who are your friends? You said you had friends who would certainly know them.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But it is idle, moping, and thinking, and trying to fix her</line>
      <line>Image more and more in, to write the old perfect inscription</line>
      <line>Over and over again upon every page of remembrance.</line>
      <line>I have settled to stay at Florence to wait for your answer.</line>
      <line>Who are your friends? Write quickly and tell me. I wait for your answer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You are at Lucca Baths, you tell me, to stay for the summer;</line>
      <line>Florence was quite too hot; you can’t move further at present.</line>
      <line>Will you not come, do you think, before the summer is over?</line>
      <line>Mr C. got you out with very considerable trouble;</line>
      <line>And he was useful and kind, and seemed so happy to serve you;</line>
      <line>Didn’t stay with you long, but talked very openly to you;</line>
      <line>Made you almost his confessor, without appearing to know it,—</line>
      <line>What about?—and you say you didn’t need his confessions.</line>
      <line>O my dear Miss Roper, I dare not trust what you tell me!</line>
      <line>Will he come, do you think? I am really so sorry for him!</line>
      <line>They didn’t give him my letter at Milan, I feel pretty certain.</line>
      <line>You had told him Bellaggio. We didn’t go to Bellaggio;</line>
      <line>So he would miss our track, and perhaps never come to Lugano,</line>
      <line>Where we were written in full, To Lucerne across the St Gothard.</line>
      <line>But he could write to you;—you would tell him where you were going.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let me, then, bear to forget her. I will not cling to her falsely;</line>
      <line>Nothing factitious or forced shall impair the old happy relation.</line>
      <line>I will let myself go, forget, not try to remember;</line>
      <line>I will walk on my way, accept the chances that meet me,</line>
      <line>Freely encounter the world, imbibe these alien airs, and</line>
      <line>Never ask if new feelings and thoughts are of her or of others.</line>
      <line>Is she not changing, herself—the old image would only delude me.</line>
      <line>I will be bold, too, and change,—if it must be. Yet if in all things,</line>
      <line>Yet if I do but aspire evermore to the Absolute only,</line>
      <line>I shall be doing, I think, somehow, what she will be doing;—</line>
      <line>I shall be thine, O my child, some way, though I know not in what way.</line>
      <line>Let me submit to forget her; I must; I already forget her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Utterly vain is, alas! this attempt at the Absolute,—wholly!</line>
      <line>I, who believed not in her, because I would fain believe nothing,</line>
      <line>Have to believe as I may, with a wilful, unmeaning acceptance.</line>
      <line>I, who refused to enfasten the roots of my floating existence</line>
      <line>In the rich earth, cling now to the hard, naked rock that is left me.—</line>
      <line>Ah! she was worthy, Eustace,—and that, indeed, is my comfort,—</line>
      <line>Worthy a nobler heart than a fool such as I could have given.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, it relieves me to write, though I do not send, and the chance that</line>
      <line>Takes may destroy my fragments. But as men pray, without asking</line>
      <line>Whether One really exist to hear or do anything for them,—</line>
      <line>Simply impelled by the need of the moment to turn to a Being</line>
      <line>In a conception of whom there is freedom from all limitation,—</line>
      <line>So in your image I turn to an ens rationis of friendship.</line>
      <line>Even so write in your name I know not to whom nor in what wise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a time, methought it was but lately departed,</line>
      <line>When, if a thing was denied me, I felt I was bound to attempt it;</line>
      <line>Choice alone should take, and choice alone should surrender.</line>
      <line>There was a time, indeed, when I had not retired thus early,</line>
      <line>Languidly thus, from pursuit of a purpose I once had adopted.</line>
      <line>But it is over, all that! I have slunk from the perilous field in</line>
      <line>Whose wild struggle of forces the prizes of life are contested.</line>
      <line>It is over, all that! I am a coward, and know it.</line>
      <line>Courage in me could be only factitious, unnatural, useless.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Comfort has come to me here in the dreary streets of the city,</line>
      <line>Comfort—how do you think?—with a barrel-organ to bring it.</line>
      <line>Moping along the streets, and cursing my day as I wandered,</line>
      <line>All of a sudden my ear met the sound of an English psalm-tune.</line>
      <line>Comfort me it did, till indeed I was very near crying.</line>
      <line>Ah, there is some great truth, partial, very likely, but needful,</line>
      <line>Lodged, I am strangely sure, in the tones of the English psalm-tune.</line>
      <line>Comfort it was at least; and I must take without question</line>
      <line>Comfort, however it come, in the dreary streets of the city.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What with trusting myself, and seeking support from within me,</line>
      <line>Almost I could believe I had gained a religious assurance,</line>
      <line>Formed in my own poor soul a great moral basis to rest on.</line>
      <line>Ah, but indeed I see, I feel it factitious entirely;</line>
      <line>I refuse, reject, and put it utterly from me;</line>
      <line>I will look straight out, see things, not try to evade them;</line>
      <line>Fact shall be fact for me; and the Truth the Truth as ever,</line>
      <line>Flexible, changeable, vague, and multiform, and doubtful.—</line>
      <line>Off, and depart to the void, thou subtle, fanatical tempter!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I shall behold thee again (is it so?) at a new visitation,</line>
      <line>O ill genius thou! I shall, at my life’s dissolution,</line>
      <line>(When the pulses are weak, and the feeble light of the reason</line>
      <line>Flickers, an unfed flame retiring slow from the socket),</line>
      <line>Low on a sick-bed laid, hear one, as it were, at the doorway,</line>
      <line>And, looking up, see thee, standing by, looking emptily at me;</line>
      <line>I shall entreat thee then, though now I dare to refuse thee,— no</line>
      <line>Pale and pitiful now, but terrible then to the dying.—</line>
      <line>Well, I will see thee again, and while I can, will repel thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rome is fallen, I hear, the gallant Medici taken,</line>
      <line>Noble Manara slain, and Garibaldi has lost il Moro;—</line>
      <line>Rome is fallen; and fallen, or falling, heroical Venice.</line>
      <line>I, meanwhile, for the loss of a single small chit of a girl, sit</line>
      <line>Moping and mourning here,—for her, and myself much smaller.</line>
      <line>Whither depart the souls of the brave that die in the battle,</line>
      <line>Die in the lost, lost fight, for the cause that perishes with them?</line>
      <line>Are they upborne from the field on the slumberous pinions of angels</line>
      <line>Unto a far-off home, where the weary rest from their labour,</line>
      <line>And the deep wounds are healed, and the bitter and burning moisture</line>
      <line>Wiped from the generous eyes? or do they linger, unhappy,</line>
      <line>Pining, and haunting the grave of their by-gone hope and endeavour?</line>
      <line>All declamation, alas! though I talk, I care not for Rome, nor</line>
      <line>Italy; feebly and faintly, and but with the lips, can lament the</line>
      <line>Wreck of the Lombard youth and the victory of the oppressor.</line>
      <line>Whither depart the brave?—God knows; I certainly do not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He has not come as yet; and now I must not expect it.</line>
      <line>You have written you say, to friends at Florence, to see him,</line>
      <line>If he perhaps should return;—but that is surely unlikely.</line>
      <line>Has he not written to you?—he did not know your direction.</line>
      <line>Oh, how strange never once to have told him where you were going!</line>
      <line>Yet if he only wrote to Florence, that would have reached you.</line>
      <line>If what ypu say he said was true, why has he not done so?</line>
      <line>Is he gone back to Rome, do you think, to his Vatican marbles?—</line>
      <line>O my dear Miss Roper, forgive me! do not be angry!—</line>
      <line>You have written to Florence;—your friends would certainly find him.</line>
      <line>Might you not write to him?—but yet it is so little likely!</line>
      <line>I shall expect nothing more.—Ever yours, your affectionate Mary.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot stay at Florence, not even to wait for a letter.</line>
      <line>Galleries only oppress me. Remembrance of hope I had cherished</line>
      <line>(Almost more than as hope, when I passed through Florence the first time)</line>
      <line>Lies like a sword in my soul. I am more a coward than ever,</line>
      <line>Chicken-hearted, past thought. The caffes and waiters distress me.</line>
      <line>All is unkind, and, alas! I am ready for any one’s kindness.</line>
      <line>Oh, I knew it of old, and knew it, I thought, to perfection,</line>
      <line>If there is any one thing in the world to preclude all kindness,</line>
      <line>It is the need of it,—it is this sad, self-defeating dependence.</line>
      <line>Why is this, Eustace? Myself, were I stronger, I think I could tell you.</line>
      <line>But it is odd when it comes. So plumb I the deeps of depression,</line>
      <line>Daily in deeper, and find no support, no will, no purpose.</line>
      <line>All my old strengths are gone. And yet I shall have to do something.</line>
      <line>Ah, the key of our life, that passes all wards, opens all locks,</line>
      <line>Is not I will, but / must. I must,—I must,—and I do it.</line>
      <line>After all, do I know that I really cared so about her?</line>
      <line>Do whatever I will, I cannot call up her image;</line>
      <line>For when I close my eyes, I see, very likely, St Peter’s,</line>
      <line>Or the Pantheon faqade, or Michel Angelo’s figures,</line>
      <line>Or, at a wish, when I please, the Alban hills and the Forum,—</line>
      <line>But that face, those eyes,—ah no, never anything like them;</line>
      <line>Only, try as I will, a sort of featureless outline,</line>
      <line>And a pale blank orb, which no recollection will add to.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>After all perhaps there was something factitious about it:</line>
      <line>I have had pain, it is true; I have wept; and so have the actors.</line>
      <line>At the last moment I have your letter, for which I was waiting.</line>
      <line>I have taken my place, and see no good in inquiries.</line>
      <line>Do nothing more, good Eustace, I pray you. It only will vex me.</line>
      <line>Take no measures. Indeed, should we meet, I could not be certain;</line>
      <line>All might be changed, you know. Or perhaps there was nothing to be changed.</line>
      <line>It is a curious history, this; and yet I foresaw it;</line>
      <line>I could have told it before. The Fates, it is clear, are against us;</line>
      <line>For it is certain enough that I met with the people you mention;</line>
      <line>They were at Florence the day I returned there, and spoke to me even;</line>
      <line>Stayed a week, saw me often; departed, and whither I know not.</line>
      <line>Great is Fate, and is best. I believe in Providence partly.</line>
      <line>What is ordained is right, and all that happens is ordered.</line>
      <line>Ah, no, that isn’t it. But yet I retain my conclusion.</line>
      <line>I will go where I am led, and will not dictate to the chances.</line>
      <line>Do nothing more, I beg. If you love me, forbear interfering.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Shall we come out of it all, some day, as one does from a tunnel?</line>
      <line>Will it be all at once, without our doing or asking,</line>
      <line>We shall behold clear day, the trees and meadows about us,</line>
      <line>And the faces of friends, and the eyes we loved looking at us?</line>
      <line>Who knows? Who can say? It will not do to suppose it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rome will not suit me, Eustace; the priests and soldiers possess it;</line>
      <line>Priests and soldiers;—and, ah! which is worst, the priest or the soldier?</line>
      <line>Politics, farewell, however! For what could I do? with inquiring,</line>
      <line>Talking, collating the journals, go fever my brain about things o’er</line>
      <line>Which I can have no control. No, happen whatever may happen,</line>
      <line>Time, I suppose, will subsist; the earth will revolve on its axis;</line>
      <line>People will travel; the stranger will wander as now in the city;</line>
      <line>Rome will be here, and the Pope the custode of Vatican marbles.</line>
      <line>I have no heart, however, for any marble or fresco;</line>
      <line>I have essayed it in vain; ’tis vain as yet to essay it:</line>
      <line>But I may haply resume some day my studies in this kind;</line>
      <line>Not as the Scripture says, is, I think, the fact. Ere our death-day,</line>
      <line>Faith, I think, does pass, and Fove; but Knowledge abideth.</line>
      <line>Let us seek Knowledge;—the rest must come and go as it happens.</line>
      <line>Knowledge is hard to seek, and harder yet to adhere to.</line>
      <line>Knowledge is painful often; and yet when we know, we are happy.</line>
      <line>Seek it, and leave mere Faith and Love to come with the chances.</line>
      <line>As for Hope,—to-morrow I hope to be starting for Naples.</line>
      <line>Rome will not do, I see, for many very good reasons.</line>
      <line>Eastward, then, I suppose, with the coming of winter, to Egypt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You have heard nothing; of course, I know you can have heard nothing.</line>
      <line>Ah, well, more than once I have broken my purpose, and sometimes,</line>
      <line>Only too often, have looked for the little lake-steamer to bring him.</line>
      <line>But it is only fancy,—I do not really expect it.</line>
      <line>Oh, and you see I know so exactly how he would take it:</line>
      <line>Finding the chances prevail against meeting again, he would banish</line>
      <line>Forthwith every thought of the poor little possible hope, which</line>
      <line>I myself could not help, perhaps, thinking only too much of;</line>
      <line>He would resign himself, and go. I see it exactly.</line>
      <line>So I also submit, although in a different manner.</line>
      <line>Can you not really come? We go very shortly to England.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So go forth to the world, to the good report and the evil?</line>
      <line>Go, little book! thy tale, is it not evil and good?</line>
      <line>Go, and if strangers revile, pass quietly by without answer.</line>
      <line>Go, and if curious friends ask of thy rearing and age,</line>
      <line>Say, 7 am flitting about many years from brain unto brain of</line>
      <line>Feeble and restless youths bom to inglorious days;</line>
      <line>But,’ so finish the word, 'I was writ in a Roman chamber,</line>
      <line>When from Janiculan heights thundered the cannon of France.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>The Latest Decalogue</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou shalt have one God only; who</line>
      <line>Would be at the expense of two?</line>
      <line>No graven images may be</line>
      <line>Worshipped, except the currency:</line>
      <line>Swear not at all; for for thy curse</line>
      <line>Thine enemy is none the worse:</line>
      <line>At church on Sunday to attend</line>
      <line>Will serve to keep the world thy friend:</line>
      <line>Honour thy parents; that is, all</line>
      <line>From whom advancement may befall:</line>
      <line>Thou shalt not kill; but needst not strive</line>
      <line>Officiously to keep alive:</line>
      <line>Do not adultery commit;</line>
      <line>Advantage rarely comes of it:</line>
      <line>Thou shalt not steal; an empty feat,</line>
      <line>When it’s so lucrative to cheat:</line>x
      <line>Bear not false witness; let the lie</line>
      <line>Have time on its own wings to fly:</line>
      <line>Thou shalt not covet; but tradition</line>
      <line>Approves all forms of competition.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sum of all is, thou shalt love,</line>
      <line>If any body, God above:</line>
      <line>At any rate shall never labour</line>
      <line>More than thyself to love thy neighbour.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from Dipsychus I</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I sat at the cafe, I said to myself,</line>
      <line>They may talk as they please about what they call pelf,</line>
      <line>They may sneer as they like about eating and drinking,</line>
      <line>But help it I cannot, I cannot help thinking</line>
      <line>How pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>How pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I sit at my table en grand seigneur,</line>
      <line>And when I have done, throw a crust to the poor;</line>
      <line>Not only the pleasure, one’s self, of good living,</line>
      <line>But also the pleasure of now and then giving.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was but last winter I came up to Town,</line>
      <line>But already I’m getting a little renown;</line>
      <line>I make new acquaintance where’er I appear;</line>
      <line>I am not too shy, and have nothing to fear.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I drive through the streets, and I care not a d—mn;</line>
      <line>The people they stare, and they ask who I am;</line>
      <line>And if I should chance to run over a cad,</line>
      <line>I can pay for the damage if ever so bad.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We stroll to our box and look down on the pit,</line>
      <line>And if it weren’t low should be tempted to spit;</line>
      <line>We loll and we talk until people look up,</line>
      <line>And when it’s half over we go out and sup.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The best of the table and best of the fare—</line>
      <line>And as for the others, the devil may care;</line>
      <line>It isn’t our fault if they dare not afford</line>
      <line>To sup like a prince and be drunk as a lord.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We sit at our tables and tipple champagne;</line>
      <line>Ere one bottle goes, comes another again;</line>
      <line>The waiters they skip and they scuttle about,</line>
      <line>And the landlord attends us so civilly out.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was but last winter I came up to Town,</line>
      <line>But already I’m getting a little renown;</line>
      <line>I get to good houses without much ado,</line>
      <line>Am beginning to see the nobility too.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O dear! what a pity they ever should lose it!</line>
      <line>For they are the gentry that know how to use it;</line>
      <line>So grand and so graceful, such manners, such dinners,</line>
      <line>But yet, after all, it is we are the winners.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus I sat at my table en grand seigneur,</line>
      <line>And when I had done threw a crust to the poor;</line>
      <line>Not only the pleasure, one’s self, of good eating,</line>
      <line>But also the pleasure of now and then treating.</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>So pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They may talk as they please about what they call pelf,</line>
      <line>And how one ought never to think of one’s self,</line>
      <line>And how pleasures of thought surpass eating and drinking—</line>
      <line>My pleasure of thought is the pleasure of thinking</line>
      <line>How pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>How pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A gondola here, and a gondola there,</line>
      <line>’Tis the pleasantest fashion of taking the air.</line>
      <line>To right and to left; stop, turn, and go yonder,</line>
      <line>And let us repeat, o’er the tide as we wander,</line>
      <line>How pleasant it is to have money, heigh ho!</line>
      <line>How pleasant it is to have money.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>from Dypsichus II</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is no God,’ the wicked saith,</line>
      <line>‘And truly it’s a blessing,</line>
      <line>For what he might have done with us</line>
      <line>It’s better only guessing.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is no God,’ a youngster thinks,</line>
      <line>‘Or really, if there may be,</line>
      <line>He surely didn’t mean a man</line>
      <line>Always to be a baby.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There is no God, or if there is,’</line>
      <line>The tradesman thinks, ‘’twere funny</line>
      <line>If he should take it ill in me</line>
      <line>To make a little money.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Whether there be,’ the rich man says,</line>
      <line>‘It matters very little,</line>
      <line>For I and mine, thank somebody,</line>
      <line>Are not in want of victual.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some others, also, to themselves</line>
      <line>Who scarce so much as doubt it,</line>
      <line>Think there is none, when they are well,</line>
      <line>And do not think about it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But country folks who live beneath</line>
      <line>The shadow of the steeple;</line>
      <line>The parson and the parson’s wife,</line>
      <line>And mostly married people;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Youths green and happy in first love,</line>
      <line>So thankful for illusion;</line>
      <line>And men caught out in what the world</line>
      <line>Calls guilt, in first confusion;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And almost every one when age,</line>
      <line>Disease, or sorrows strike him,</line>
      <line>Inclines to think there is a God,</line>
      <line>Or something very like Him.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>I dreamed a dream: I dreamt that I espied,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Upon a stone that was not rolled aside,</line>
      <line>A shadow sitting by a grave—a Shade,</line>
      <line>As thin, as unsubstantial, as of old</line>
      <line>Came, the Greek poet told,</line>
      <line>To lick the life-blood in the trench Ulysses made—</line>
      <line>As pale, as thin, and said:</line>
      <line>‘I am the resurrection of the dead.</line>
      <line>The night is past, the morning is at hand,</line>
      <line>And I must in my proper semblance stand,</line>
      <line>Appear brief space and vanish,—hear me, this is true,</line>
      <line>I am that Jesus whom they slew.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And shadows dim, I dreamed, the dead apostles came,</line>
      <line>And bent their heads for sorrow and for shame—</line>
      <line>Sorrow for their great loss, and shame</line>
      <line>For what they did in that vain name.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in long ranges far behind there seemed</line>
      <line>Pale vapoury angel forms; or was it cloud? that kept</line>
      <line>Strange watch; the women also stood beside and wept.</line>
      <line>And Peter spoke the word:</line>
      <line>‘O my own Lord,</line>
      <line>What is it we must do?</line>
      <line>Is it then all untrue?</line>
      <line>Did we not see, and hear, and handle thee,</line>
      <line>Yea, for whole hours</line>
      <line>Upon the Mount in Galilee,</line>
      <line>On the lake shore, and here at Bethany,</line>
      <line>When thou ascended to thy God and ours?’</line>
      <line>And paler still became the distant cloud,</line>
      <line>The women wept aloud.</line>
      <line>And the Shade answered, ‘What ye say I know not;</line>
      <line>But it is true</line>
      <line>I am that Jesus whom they slew,</line>
      <line>Whom ye have preached, but in what way I know not.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the great World, it chanced, came by that way,</line>
      <line>And stopped, and looked, and spoke to the police,</line>
      <line>And said the thing, for order’s sake and peace,</line>
      <line>Most certainly must be suppressed, the nuisance cease.</line>
      <line>His wife and daughter must have where to pray,</line>
      <line>And whom to pray to, at the least one day</line>
      <line>In seven, and something definite to say.</line>
      <line>Whether the fact so many years ago</line>
      <line>Had, or not, happened, how was he to know?</line>
      <line>Yet he had always heard that it was so.</line>
      <line>As for himself, perhaps it was all one;</line>
      <line>And yet he found it not unpleasant, too,</line>
      <line>On Sunday morning in the roomy pew,</line>
      <line>To see the thing with such decorum done.</line>
      <line>As for himself, perhaps it was all one;</line>
      <line>Yet on one’s death-bed all men always said</line>
      <line>It was a comfortable thing to think upon</line>
      <line>The Atonement and the Resurrection of the dead.</line>
      <line>So the great world as having said his say,</line>
      <line>Unto his country-house pursued his way.</line>
      <line>And on the grave the Shadow sat all day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the poor Pope was sure it must be so,</line>
      <line>Else wherefore did the people kiss his toe?</line>
      <line>The subtle Jesuit cardinal shook his head,</line>
      <line>And mildly looked and said,</line>
      <line>It mattered not a jot</line>
      <line>Whether the thing, indeed, were so or not;</line>
      <line>Religion must be kept up, and the Church preserved,</line>
      <line>And for the people this best served,</line>
      <line>And then he turned, and added most demurely,</line>
      <line>‘Whatever may befall,</line>
      <line>We Catholics need no evidence at all,</line>
      <line>The holy father is infallible, surely!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An English canon heard,</line>
      <line>And [quietly demurred.]</line>
      <line>Religion rests on evidence, of course,</line>
      <line>And on inquiry we must put no force.</line>
      <line>Difficulties still, upon whatever ground,</line>
      <line>Are likely, almost certain, to be found.</line>
      <line>The Theist scheme, the Pantheist, one and all,</line>
      <line>Must with, or e’en before, the Christian fall.</line>
      <line>And till the thing were plainer to our eyes,</line>
      <line>To disturb faith was surely most unwise.</line>
      <line>As for the Shade, who trusted such narrations?</line>
      <line>Except, of course, in ancient revelations.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And dignitaries of the Church came by.</line>
      <line>It had been worth to some of them, they said,</line>
      <line>Some £100,000 a year a head.</line>
      <line>If it fetched so much in the market, truly,</line>
      <line>’Twas not a thing to be given up unduly.</line>
      <line>It had been proved by Butler in one way,</line>
      <line>By Paley better in a later day;</line>
      <line>It had been proved in twenty ways at once,</line>
      <line>By many a doctor plain to any a dunce;</line>
      <line>There was no question but it must be so.</line>
      <line>And the Shade answered, that he did not know;</line>
      <line>He had no reading, and might be deceived,</line>
      <line>But still He was the Christ, as he believed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And women, mild and pure,</line>
      <line>Forth from still homes and village schools did pass,</line>
      <line>And asked, if this indeed were thus, alas,</line>
      <line>What should they teach their children and the poor?</line>
      <line>The Shade replied, he could not know,</line>
      <line>But it was truth, the fact was so.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who had kept all commandments from his youth</line>
      <line>Yet still found one thing lacking—even Truth:</line>
      <line>And the Shade only answered, ‘Go, make haste,</line>
      <line>Enjoy thy great possessions as thou may’st.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Hugh Clough</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>That there are powers above us I admit;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>That there are powers above us I admit;</line>
      <line>It may be true too</line>
      <line>That while we walk the troublous tossing sea,</line>
      <line>That when we see the o’ertopping waves advance,</line>
      <line>And when [we] feel our feet beneath us sink,</line>
      <line>There are who walk beside us; and the cry</line>
      <line>That rises so spontaneous to the lips,</line>
      <line>The ‘Help us or we perish,’ is not nought,</line>
      <line>An evanescent spectrum of disease.</line>
      <line>It may be that in deed and not in fancy,</line>
      <line>A hand that is not ours upstays our steps,</line>
      <line>A voice that is not ours commands the waves,</line>
      <line>Commands the waves, and whispers in our ear,</line>
      <line>O thou of little faith, why didst thou doubt?</line>
      <line>At any rate—</line>
      <line>That there are beings above us, I suppose,</line>
      <line>(Hypothesis the soul of science is),</line>
      <line>And when we lift up holy hands of prayer,</line>
      <line>I will not say they will not give us aid.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1847</date>
    <title>The Blessed Damozel</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The blessed damozel leaned out</line>
      <line>From the gold bar of Heaven;</line>
      <line>Her eyes were deeper than the depth</line>
      <line>Of waters stilled at even;</line>
      <line>She had three lilies in her hand,</line>
      <line>And the stars in her hair were seven.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her robe, ungirt from clasp to hem,</line>
      <line>No wrought flowers did adorn,</line>
      <line>But a white rose of Mary’s gift,</line>
      <line>For service meetly worn;</line>
      <line>Her hair that lay along her back</line>
      <line>Was yellow like ripe corn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Herseemed she scarce had been a day</line>
      <line>One of God’s choristers;</line>
      <line>The wonder was not yet quite gone</line>
      <line>From that still look of hers;</line>
      <line>Albeit, to them she left, her day</line>
      <line>Had counted as ten years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(To one, it is ten years of years.</line>
      <line>. .. Yet now, and in this place,</line>
      <line>Surely she leaned o’er me—her hair</line>
      <line>Fell all about my face . . .</line>
      <line>Nothing: the autumn-fall of leaves.</line>
      <line>The whole year sets apace.)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was the rampart of God’s house</line>
      <line>That she was standing on;</line>
      <line>By God built over the sheer depth</line>
      <line>The which is Space begun;</line>
      <line>So high, that looking downward thence</line>
      <line>She scarce could see the sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It lies in Heaven, across the flood</line>
      <line>Of ether, as a bridge.</line>
      <line>Beneath, the tides of day and night</line>
      <line>With flame and darkness ridge</line>
      <line>The void, as low as where this earth</line>
      <line>Spins like a fretful midge.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Around her, lovers, newly met</line>
      <line>’Mid deathless love’s acclaims,</line>
      <line>Spoke evermore among themselves</line>
      <line>Their heart-remembered names;</line>
      <line>And the souls mounting up to God</line>
      <line>Went by her like thin flames.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And still she bowed herself and stooped</line>
      <line>Out of the circling charm;</line>
      <line>Until her bosom must have made</line>
      <line>The bar she leaned on warm.</line>
      <line>And the lilies lay as if asleep</line>
      <line>Along her bended arm.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From the fixed place of Heaven she saw</line>
      <line>Time like a pulse shake fierce</line>
      <line>Through all the worlds. Her gaze still strove</line>
      <line>Within the gulf to pierce</line>
      <line>Its path; and now she spoke as when</line>
      <line>The stars sang in their spheres.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun was gone now; the curled moon</line>
      <line>Was like a little feather</line>
      <line>Fluttering far down the gulf; and now</line>
      <line>She spoke through the still weather.</line>
      <line>Her voice was like the voice the stars</line>
      <line>Had when they sang together.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(Ah sweet! Even now, in that bird’s song,</line>
      <line>Strove not her accents there,</line>
      <line>Fain to be hearkened? When those bells</line>
      <line>Possessed the mid-day air,</line>
      <line>Strove not her steps to reach my side</line>
      <line>Down all the echoing stair?)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I wish that he were come to me,</line>
      <line>For he will come,’ she said.</line>
      <line>‘Have I not prayed in Heaven?—on earth,</line>
      <line>Lord, Lord, has he not pray’d?</line>
      <line>Are not two prayers a perfect strength?</line>
      <line>And shall I feel afraid?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘When round his head the aureole clings,</line>
      <line>And he is clothed in white,</line>
      <line>I’ll take his hand and go with him</line>
      <line>To the deep wells of light;</line>
      <line>As unto a stream we will step down,</line>
      <line>And bathe there in God’s sight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We two will stand beside that shrine,</line>
      <line>Occult, withheld, untrod,</line>
      <line>Whose lamps are stirred continually</line>
      <line>With prayer sent up to God;</line>
      <line>And see our old prayers, granted, melt</line>
      <line>Each like a little cloud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We two will lie i’ the shadow of</line>
      <line>That living mystic tree</line>
      <line>Within whose secret growth the Dove</line>
      <line>Is sometimes felt to be,</line>
      <line>While every leaf that His plumes touch</line>
      <line>Saith His Name audibly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘And I myself will teach to him,</line>
      <line>I myself, lying so,</line>
      <line>The songs I sing here; which his voice</line>
      <line>Shall pause in, hushed and slow,</line>
      <line>And find some knowledge at each pause,</line>
      <line>Or some new thing to know.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(Alas! we two, we two, thou say’st!</line>
      <line>Yea, one wast thou with me</line>
      <line>That once of old. But shall God lift</line>
      <line>To endless unity</line>
      <line>The soul whose likeness with thy soul</line>
      <line>Was but its love for thee?)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We two,’ she said, ‘will seek the groves</line>
      <line>Where the lady Mary is,</line>
      <line>With her five handmaidens, whose names</line>
      <line>Are five sweet symphonies,</line>
      <line>Cecily, Gertrude, Magdalen,</line>
      <line>Margaret and Rosalys.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Circlewise sit they, with bound locks</line>
      <line>And foreheads garlanded;</line>
      <line>Into the fine cloth white like flame</line>
      <line>Weaving the golden thread,</line>
      <line>To fashion the birth-robes for them</line>
      <line>Who are just born, being dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘He shall fear, haply, and be dumb:</line>
      <line>Then will I lay my cheek</line>
      <line>To his, and tell about our love,</line>
      <line>Not once abashed or weak:</line>
      <line>And the dear Mother will approve</line>
      <line>My pride, and let me speak.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Herself shall bring us, hand in hand,</line>
      <line>To Him round whom all souls</line>
      <line>Kneel, the clear-ranged unnumbered heads</line>
      <line>Bowed with their aureoles:</line>
      <line>And angels meeting us shall sing</line>
      <line>To their citherns and citoles.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There will I ask of Christ the Lord</line>
      <line>Thus much for him and me:—</line>
      <line>Only to live as once on earth</line>
      <line>With Love,—only to be,</line>
      <line>As then awhile, for ever now</line>
      <line>Together, I and he.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She gazed and listened and then said,</line>
      <line>Less sad of speech than mild,—</line>
      <line>‘All this is when he comes.’ She ceased.</line>
      <line>The light thrilled towards her, fill’d</line>
      <line>With angels in strong level flight.</line>
      <line>Her eyes prayed, and she smil’d.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(I saw her smile.) But soon their path</line>
      <line>Was vague in distant spheres:</line>
      <line>And then she cast her arms along</line>
      <line>The golden barriers,</line>
      <line>And laid her face between her hands,</line>
      <line>And wept. (I heard her tears.)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>A Half-Way Pause</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The turn of noontide has begun.</line>
      <line>In the weak breeze the sunshine yields.</line>
      <line>There is a bell upon the fields.</line>
      <line>On the long hedgerow’s tangled run</line>
      <line>A low white cottage intervenes:</line>
      <line>Against the wall a blind man leans,</line>
      <line>And sways his face to have the sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our horses’ hoofs stir in the road,</line>
      <line>Quiet and sharp. Light hath a song</line>
      <line>Whose silence, being heard, seems long.</line>
      <line>The point of noon maketh abode,</line>
      <line>And will not be at once gone through.</line>
      <line>The sky’s deep colour saddens you,</line>
      <line>And the heat weighs a dreamy load.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Autumn Idleness</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This sunlight shames November where he grieves</line>
      <line>In dead red leaves, and will not let him shun</line>
      <line>The day, though bough with bough be over-run.</line>
      <line>But with a blessing every glade receives</line>
      <line>High salutation; while from hillock-eaves</line>
      <line>The deer gaze calling, dappled white and dun,</line>
      <line>As if, being foresters of old, the sun</line>
      <line>Had marked them with the shade of forest-leaves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here dawn to-day unveiled her magic glass;</line>
      <line>Here noon now gives the thirst and takes the dew;</line>
      <line>Till eve bring rest when other good things pass.</line>
      <line>And here the lost hours the lost hours renew</line>
      <line>While I still lead my shadow o’er the grass,</line>
      <line>Nor know, for longing, that which I should do.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Sudden Light</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have been here before,</line>
      <line>But when or how I cannot tell:</line>
      <line>I know the grass beyond the door,</line>
      <line>The sweet, keen smell,</line>
      <line>The sighing sound, the lights around the shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You have been mine before,—</line>
      <line>How long ago I may not know:</line>
      <line>But just when at that swallow’s soar</line>
      <line>Your neck turned so,</line>
      <line>Some veil did fall,—I knew it all of yore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Has this been thus before?</line>
      <line>And shall not thus time’s eddying flight</line>
      <line>Still with our lives our love restore</line>
      <line>In death’s despite,</line>
      <line>And day and night yield one delight once more?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>A Match with the Moon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Weary already, weary miles to-night</line>
      <line>I walked for bed: and so, to get some ease,</line>
      <line>I dogged the flying moon with similes.</line>
      <line>And like a wisp she doubled on my sight</line>
      <line>In ponds; and caught in tree-tops like a kite;</line>
      <line>And in a globe of film all liquorish</line>
      <line>Swam full-faced like a silly silver fish;—</line>
      <line>Last like a bubble shot the welkin’s height</line>
      <line>Where my road turned, and got behind me, and sent</line>
      <line>My wizened shadow craning round at me,</line>
      <line>And jeered, ‘So, step the measure,—one two three!’</line>
      <line>And if I faced on her, looked innocent.</line>
      <line>But just at parting, halfway down a dell,</line>
      <line>She kissed me for good-night. So you’ll not tell.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>The Woodspurge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wind flapped loose, the wind was still,</line>
      <line>Shaken out dead from tree and hill:</line>
      <line>I had walked on at the wind’s will,—</line>
      <line>I sat now, for the wind was still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Between my knees my forehead was,—</line>
      <line>My lips drawn in, said not Alas!</line>
      <line>My hair was over in the grass,</line>
      <line>My naked ears heard the day pass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My eyes, wide open, had the run</line>
      <line>Of some ten weeds to fix upon;</line>
      <line>Among those few, out of the sun,</line>
      <line>The woodspurge flowered, three cups in one.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From perfect grief there need not be</line>
      <line>Wisdom or even memory:</line>
      <line>One thing then learnt remains to me,—</line>
      <line>The woodspurge has a cup of three.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1859</date>
    <title>Even So</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>So it is, my dear.</line>
      <line>All such things touch secret strings</line>
      <line>For heavy hearts to hear.</line>
      <line>So it is, my dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Very like indeed:</line>
      <line>Sea and sky, afar, on high,</line>
      <line>Sand and strewn seaweed,—</line>
      <line>Very like indeed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the sea stands spread</line>
      <line>As one wall with the flat skies,</line>
      <line>Where the lean black craft like flies</line>
      <line>Seem well-nigh stagnated,</line>
      <line>Soon to drop off dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Seemed it so to us</line>
      <line>When I was thine and thou wast mine,</line>
      <line>And all these things were thus,</line>
      <line>But all our world in us?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Could we be so now?</line>
      <line>Not if all beneath heaven’s pall</line>
      <line>Lay dead but I and thou,</line>
      <line>Could we be so now!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>Nuptial Sleep</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nuptial Sleep</line>
      <line>At length their long kiss severed, with sweet smart:</line>
      <line>And as the last slow sudden drops are shed</line>
      <line>From sparkling eaves when all the storm has fled,</line>
      <line>So singly flagged the pulses of each heart.</line>
      <line>Their bosoms sundered, with the opening start</line>
      <line>Of married flowers to either side outspread</line>
      <line>From the knit stem; yet still their mouths, burnt red,</line>
      <line>Fawned on each other where they lay apart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep sank them lower than the tide of dreams,</line>
      <line>And their dreams watched them sink, and slid away.</line>
      <line>Slowly their souls swam up again, through gleams</line>
      <line>Of watered light and dull drowned waifs of day;</line>
      <line>Till from some wonder of new woods and streams</line>
      <line>He woke, and wondered more: for there she lay.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dante Gabriel Rossetti</author>
    <date>1871</date>
    <title>Smithereens</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Uncertain-aged Miss Thereabouts,</line>
      <line>Tough fossil of her teens,</line>
      <line>Has lifted up with saving hand</line>
      <line>The ruined Smithereens.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down the dark steps of debt that hand</line>
      <line>Sped like an angel’s wing,</line>
      <line>Deep-dowered with gold, and for itself</line>
      <line>Brought back a golden ring.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah lovely Lucy Lovandove,</line>
      <line>That ring’s a snake, and means</line>
      <line>Woe without end: therein lies crushed</line>
      <line>Thy heart—to smithereens.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1848</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I am dead, my dearest,</line>
      <line>Sing no sad songs for me;</line>
      <line>Plant thou no roses at my head,</line>
      <line>Nor shady cypress tree:</line>
      <line>Be the green grass above me</line>
      <line>With showers and dewdrops wet;</line>
      <line>And if thou wilt, remember,</line>
      <line>And if thou wilt, forget.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I shall not see the shadows,</line>
      <line>I shall not feel the rain;</line>
      <line>I shall not hear the nightingale</line>
      <line>Sing on, as if in pain:</line>
      <line>And dreaming through the twilight</line>
      <line>That doth not rise nor set,</line>
      <line>Haply I may remember,</line>
      <line>And haply may forget.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh roses for the flush of youth,</line>
      <line>And laurel for the perfect prime;</line>
      <line>But pluck an ivy branch for me</line>
      <line>Grown old before my time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh violets for the grave of youth,</line>
      <line>And bay for those dead in their prime;</line>
      <line>Give me the withered leaves I chose</line>
      <line>Before in the old time.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>Remember</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Remember me when I am gone away,</line>
      <line>Gone far away into the silent land;</line>
      <line>When you can no more hold me by the hand,</line>
      <line>Nor I half turn to go yet turning stay.</line>
      <line>Remember me when no more day by day</line>
      <line>You tell me of our future that you planned:</line>
      <line>Only remember me; you understand</line>
      <line>It will be late to counsel then or pray.</line>
      <line>Yet if you should forget me for a while</line>
      <line>And afterwards remember, do not grieve:</line>
      <line>For if the darkness and corruption leave</line>
      <line>A vestige of the thoughts that once I had,</line>
      <line>Better by far you should forget and smile</line>
      <line>Than that you should remember and be sad.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>One Sea-Side Grave</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unmindful of the roses,</line>
      <line>Unmindful of the thorn,</line>
      <line>A reaper tired reposes</line>
      <line>Among his gathered corn:</line>
      <line>So might I, till the morn!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Cold as the cold Decembers,</line>
      <line>Past as the days that set,</line>
      <line>While only one remembers</line>
      <line>And all the rest forget,—</line>
      <line>But one remembers yet.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Echo</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come to me in the silence of the night;</line>
      <line>Come in the speaking silence of a dream;</line>
      <line>Come with soft rounded cheeks and eyes as bright</line>
      <line>As sunlight on a stream;</line>
      <line>Come back in tears,</line>
      <line>O memory, hope, love of finished years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh dream how sweet, too sweet, too bitter sweet,</line>
      <line>Whose wakening should have been in Paradise,</line>
      <line>Where souls brimfull of love abide and meet;</line>
      <line>Where thirsting longing eyes</line>
      <line>Watch the slow door</line>
      <line>That opening, letting in, lets out no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet come to me in dreams, that I may live</line>
      <line>My very life again tho’ cold in death:</line>
      <line>Come back to me in dreams, that I may give</line>
      <line>Pulse for pulse, breath for breath:</line>
      <line>Speak low, lean low,</line>
      <line>As long ago, my love, how long ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>The Bourne</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Underneath the growing grass,</line>
      <line>Underneath the living flowers,</line>
      <line>Deeper than the sound of showers:</line>
      <line>There we shall not count the hours</line>
      <line>By the shadows as they pass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Youth and health will be but vain,</line>
      <line>Beauty reckoned of no worth:</line>
      <line>There a very little girth</line>
      <line>Can hold round what once the earth</line>
      <line>Seemed too narrow to contain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>From the Antique</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It’s a weary life, it is, she said:—</line>
      <line>Doubly blank in a woman’s lot:</line>
      <line>I wish and I wish I were a man:</line>
      <line>Or, better than any being, were not:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Were nothing at all in all the world,</line>
      <line>Not a body and not a soul:</line>
      <line>Not so much as a grain of dust</line>
      <line>Or drop of water from pole to pole.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still the world would wag on the same,</line>
      <line>Still the seasons go and come:</line>
      <line>Blossoms bloom as in days of old,</line>
      <line>Cherries ripen and wild bees hum.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>None would miss me in all the world,</line>
      <line>How much less would care or weep:</line>
      <line>I should be nothing, while all the rest</line>
      <line>Would wake and weary and fall asleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>May</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot tell you how it was;</line>
      <line>But this I know: it came to pass</line>
      <line>Upon a bright and breezy day</line>
      <line>When May was young; ah pleasant May!</line>
      <line>As yet the poppies were not born</line>
      <line>Between the blades of tender corn;</line>
      <line>The last eggs had not hatched as yet,</line>
      <line>Nor any bird foregone its mate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot tell you what it was;</line>
      <line>But this I know: it did but pass.</line>
      <line>It passed away with sunny May,</line>
      <line>With all sweet things it passed away,</line>
      <line>And left me old, and cold, and grey.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1857</date>
    <title>A Birthday</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My heart is like a singing bird</line>
      <line>Whose nest is in a watered shoot;</line>
      <line>My heart is like an apple tree</line>
      <line>Whose boughs are bent with thickset fruit;</line>
      <line>My heart is like a rainbow shell</line>
      <line>That paddles in a halcyon sea;</line>
      <line>My heart is gladder than all these</line>
      <line>Because my love is come to me.</line>
      <line>Raise me a dais of silk and down;</line>
      <line>Hang it with vair and purple dyes;</line>
      <line>Carve it in doves and pomegranates,</line>
      <line>And peacocks with a hundred eyes;</line>
      <line>Work it in gold and silver grapes,</line>
      <line>In leaves and silver fleurs-de-lys;</line>
      <line>Because the birthday of my life</line>
      <line>Is come, my love is come to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1857</date>
    <title>Winter: My Secret</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I tell my secret? No indeed, not I:</line>
      <line>Perhaps some day, who knows?</line>
      <line>But not today; it froze, and blows, and snows,</line>
      <line>And you’re too curious: fie!</line>
      <line>You want to hear it? well:</line>
      <line>Only, my secret’s mine, and I won’t tell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or, after all, perhaps there’s none:</line>
      <line>Suppose there is no secret after all,</line>
      <line>But only just my fun.</line>
      <line>Today’s a nipping day, a biting day;</line>
      <line>In which one wants a shawl,</line>
      <line>A veil, a cloak, and other wraps:</line>
      <line>I cannot ope to every one who taps,</line>
      <line>And let the draughts come whistling thro’ my hall;</line>
      <line>Come bounding and surrounding me,</line>
      <line>Come buffeting, astounding me,</line>
      <line>Nipping and clipping thro’ my wraps and all.</line>
      <line>I wear my mask for warmth: who ever shows</line>
      <line>His nose to Russian snows</line>
      <line>To be pecked at by every wind that blows?</line>
      <line>You would not peck? I thank you for good will,</line>
      <line>Believe, but leave that truth untested still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spring’s an expansive time: yet I don’t trust</line>
      <line>March with its peck of dust,</line>
      <line>Nor April with its rainbow-crowned brief showers,</line>
      <line>Nor even May, whose flowers</line>
      <line>One frost may wither thro’ the sunless hours.</line>
      <line>Perhaps some languid summer day,</line>
      <line>When drowsy birds sing less and less,</line>
      <line>And golden fruit is ripening to excess,</line>
      <line>If there’s not too much sun nor too much cloud,</line>
      <line>And the warm wind is neither still nor loud,</line>
      <line>Perhaps my secret I may say,</line>
      <line>Or you may guess.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1857</date>
    <title>A Better Resurrection</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have no wit, no words, no tears;</line>
      <line>My heart within me like a stone</line>
      <line>Is numbed too much for hopes or fears;</line>
      <line>Look right, look left, I dwell alone;</line>
      <line>I lift mine eyes, but dimmed with grief</line>
      <line>No everlasting hills I see;</line>
      <line>My life is in the falling leaf:</line>
      <line>O Jesus, quicken me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My life is like a faded leaf,</line>
      <line>My harvest dwindled to a husk;</line>
      <line>Truly my life is void and brief</line>
      <line>And tedious in the barren dusk;</line>
      <line>My life is like a frozen thing,</line>
      <line>No bud nor greenness can I see:</line>
      <line>Yet rise it shall—the sap of Spring;</line>
      <line>O Jesus, rise in me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My life is like a broken bowl,</line>
      <line>A broken bowl that cannot hold</line>
      <line>One drop of water for my soul</line>
      <line>Or cordial in the searching cold;</line>
      <line>Cast in the fire the perished thing,</line>
      <line>Melt and remould it, till it be</line>
      <line>A royal cup for Him my King:</line>
      <line>O Jesus, drink of me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1858</date>
    <title>By the Sea</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why does the sea moan evermore?</line>
      <line>Shut out from heaven it makes its moan,</line>
      <line>It frets against the boundary shore;</line>
      <line>All earth’s full rivers cannot fill</line>
      <line>The sea, that drinking thirsteth still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sheer miracles of loveliness</line>
      <line>Lie hid in its unlooked-on bed:</line>
      <line>Anemones, salt, passionless,</line>
      <line>Blow flower-like; just enough alive</line>
      <line>To blow and multiply and thrive.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Shells quaint with curve, or spot, or spike,</line>
      <line>Encrusted live things argus-eyed,</line>
      <line>All fair alike, yet all unlike,</line>
      <line>Are born without a pang, and die</line>
      <line>Without a pang, and so pass by.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1858</date>
    <title>They lie at rest, our blessed dead;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dews drop cool above their head,</line>
      <line>They knew not when fleet summer fled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Together all, yet each alone;</line>
      <line>Each laid at rest beneath his own</line>
      <line>Smooth turf or white allotted stone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When shall our slumber sink so deep,</line>
      <line>And eyes that wept and eyes that weep</line>
      <line>Weep not in the sufficient sleep?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>God be with you, our great and small,</line>
      <line>Our loves, our best beloved of all,</line>
      <line>Our own beyond the salt sea-wall.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1859</date>
    <title>Goblin Market</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Morning and evening</line>
      <line>Maids heard the goblins cry:</line>
      <line>‘Come buy our orchard fruits,</line>
      <line>Come buy, come buy:</line>
      <line>Apples and quinces,</line>
      <line>Lemons and oranges,</line>
      <line>Plump unpecked cherries,</line>
      <line>Melons and raspberries,</line>
      <line>Bloom-down-cheeked peaches,</line>
      <line>Swart-headed mulberries,</line>
      <line>Wild free-born cranberries,</line>
      <line>Crab-apples, dewberries,</line>
      <line>Pine-apples, blackberries,</line>
      <line>Apricots, strawberries;—</line>
      <line>All ripe together</line>
      <line>In summer weather,—</line>
      <line>Morns that pass by,</line>
      <line>Fair eves that fly;</line>
      <line>Come buy, come buy:</line>
      <line>Our grapes fresh from the vine,</line>
      <line>Pomegranates full and fine,</line>
      <line>Dates and sharp bullaces,</line>
      <line>Rare pears and greengages,</line>
      <line>Damsons and bilberries,</line>
      <line>Taste them and try:</line>
      <line>Currants and gooseberries,</line>
      <line>Bright-fire-like barberries,</line>
      <line>Figs to fill your mouth,</line>
      <line>Citrons from the South,</line>
      <line>Sweet to tongue and sound to eye;</line>
      <line>Come buy, come buy.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Evening by evening</line>
      <line>Among the brookside rushes,</line>
      <line>Laura bowed her head to hear,</line>
      <line>Lizzie veiled her blushes:</line>
      <line>Crouching close together</line>
      <line>In the cooling weather,</line>
      <line>With clasping arms and cautioning lips,</line>
      <line>With tingling cheeks and finger tips.</line>
      <line>‘Lie close,’ Laura said,</line>
      <line>Pricking up her golden head:</line>
      <line>‘We must not look at goblin men,</line>
      <line>We must not buy their fruits:</line>
      <line>Who knows upon what soil they fed</line>
      <line>Their hungry thirsty roots?’</line>
      <line>‘Come buy,’ call the goblins</line>
      <line>Hobbling down the glen.</line>
      <line>‘Oh,’ cried Lizzie, ‘Laura, Laura,</line>
      <line>You should not peep at goblin men.’</line>
      <line>Lizzie covered up her eyes,</line>
      <line>Covered close lest they should look;</line>
      <line>Laura reared her glossy head,</line>
      <line>And whispered like the restless brook:</line>
      <line>‘Look, Lizzie, look, Lizzie,</line>
      <line>Down the glen tramp little men.</line>
      <line>One hauls a basket,</line>
      <line>One bears a plate,</line>
      <line>One lugs a golden dish</line>
      <line>Of many pounds weight.</line>
      <line>How fair the vine must grow</line>
      <line>Whose grapes are so luscious;</line>
      <line>How warm the wind must blow</line>
      <line>Thro’ those fruit bushes.’</line>
      <line>‘No,’ said Lizzie: ‘No, no, no;</line>
      <line>Their offers should not charm us,</line>
      <line>Their evil gifts would harm us.’</line>
      <line>She thrust a dimpled finger</line>
      <line>In each ear, shut eyes and ran:</line>
      <line>Curious Laura chose to linger</line>
      <line>Wondering at each merchant man.</line>
      <line>One had a cat’s face,</line>
      <line>One whisked a tail,</line>
      <line>One tramped at a rat’s pace,</line>
      <line>One crawled like a snail,</line>
      <line>One like a wombat prowled obtuse and furry,</line>
      <line>One like a ratel tumbled hurry skurry.</line>
      <line>She heard a voice like voice of doves</line>
      <line>Cooing all together:</line>
      <line>They sounded kind and full of loves</line>
      <line>In the pleasant weather.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laura stretched her gleaming neck</line>
      <line>Like a rush-imbedded swan,</line>
      <line>Like a lily from the beck,</line>
      <line>Like a moonlit poplar branch,</line>
      <line>Like a vessel at the launch</line>
      <line>When its last restraint is gone.</line>
      <line>Backwards up the mossy glen</line>
      <line>Turned and trooped the goblin men,</line>
      <line>With their shrill repeated cry,</line>
      <line>‘Come buy, come buy.’</line>
      <line>When they reached where Laura was</line>
      <line>They stood stock still upon the moss,</line>
      <line>Leering at each other,</line>
      <line>Brother with queer brother;</line>
      <line>Signalling each other,</line>
      <line>Brother with sly brother.</line>
      <line>One set his basket down,</line>
      <line>One reared his plate;</line>
      <line>One began to weave a crown</line>
      <line>Of tendrils, leaves and rough nuts brown</line>
      <line>(Men sell not such in any town);</line>
      <line>One heaved the golden weight</line>
      <line>Of dish and fruit to offer her:</line>
      <line>‘Come buy, come buy,’ was still their cry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laura stared but did not stir,</line>
      <line>Longed but had no money:</line>
      <line>The whisk-tailed merchant bade her taste</line>
      <line>In tones as smooth as honey,</line>
      <line>The cat-faced purr’d,</line>
      <line>The rat-paced spoke a word</line>
      <line>Of welcome, and the snail-paced even was heard;</line>
      <line>One parrot-voiced and jolly</line>
      <line>Cried ‘Pretty Goblin’ still for ‘Pretty Polly;’—</line>
      <line>One whistled like a bird.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But sweet-tooth Laura spoke in haste:</line>
      <line>‘Good folk, I have no coin;</line>
      <line>To take were to purloin:</line>
      <line>I have no copper in my purse,</line>
      <line>1 have no silver either,</line>
      <line>And all my gold is on the furze</line>
      <line>That shakes in windy weather</line>
      <line>Above the rusty heather.’</line>
      <line>‘You have much gold upon your head,’</line>
      <line>They answered all together:</line>
      <line>‘Buy from us with a golden curl.’</line>
      <line>She clipped a precious golden lock,</line>
      <line>She dropped a tear more rare than pearl,</line>
      <line>Then sucked their fruit globes fair or red</line>
      <line>Sweeter than honey from the rock,</line>
      <line>Stronger than man-rejoicing wine,</line>
      <line>Clearer than water flowed that juice;</line>
      <line>She never tasted such before,</line>
      <line>How should it cloy with length of use?</line>
      <line>She sucked and sucked and sucked the more</line>
      <line>Fruits which that unknown orchard bore;</line>
      <line>She sucked until her lips were sore;</line>
      <line>Then flung the emptied rinds away</line>
      <line>But gathered up one kernel-stone,</line>
      <line>And knew not was it night or day</line>
      <line>As she turned home alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lizzie met her at the gate</line>
      <line>Full of wise upbraidings:</line>
      <line>‘Dear, you should not stay so late,</line>
      <line>Twilight is not good for maidens;</line>
      <line>Should not loiter in the glen</line>
      <line>In the haunts of goblin men.</line>
      <line>Do you not remember Jeanie,</line>
      <line>How she met them in the moonlight,</line>
      <line>Took their gifts both choice and many,</line>
      <line>Ate their fruits and wore their flowers</line>
      <line>Plucked from bowers</line>
      <line>Where summer ripens at all hours?</line>
      <line>But ever in the noonlight</line>
      <line>She pined and pined away;</line>
      <line>Sought them by night and day,</line>
      <line>Found them no more but dwindled and grew grey;</line>
      <line>Then fell with the first snow,</line>
      <line>While to this day no grass will grow</line>
      <line>Where she lies low:</line>
      <line>I planted daisies there a year ago</line>
      <line>That never blow.</line>
      <line>You should not loiter so.’</line>
      <line>‘Nay, hush,’ said Laura:</line>
      <line>‘Nay, hush, my sister:</line>
      <line>I ate and ate my fill,</line>
      <line>Yet my mouth waters still;</line>
      <line>Tomorrow night I will</line>
      <line>Buy more:’ and kissed her:</line>
      <line>‘Have done with sorrow;</line>
      <line>I’ll bring you plums tomorrow</line>
      <line>Fresh on their mother twigs,</line>
      <line>Cherries worth getting;</line>
      <line>You cannot think what figs</line>
      <line>My teeth have met in,</line>
      <line>What melons icy-cold</line>
      <line>Piled on a dish of gold</line>
      <line>Too huge for me to hold,</line>
      <line>What peaches with a velvet nap,</line>
      <line>Pellucid grapes without one seed:</line>
      <line>Odorous indeed must be the mead</line>
      <line>Whereon they grow, and pure the wave they drink</line>
      <line>With lilies at the brink,</line>
      <line>And sugar-sweet their sap.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Golden head by golden head,</line>
      <line>Like two pigeons in one nest</line>
      <line>Folded in each other’s wings,</line>
      <line>They lay down in their curtained bed:</line>
      <line>Like two blossoms on one stem,</line>
      <line>Like two flakes of new-fall’n snow,</line>
      <line>Like two wands of ivory</line>
      <line>Tipped with gold for awful kings.</line>
      <line>Moon and stars gazed in at them,</line>
      <line>Wind sang to them lullaby,</line>
      <line>Lumbering owls forbore to fly,</line>
      <line>Not a bat flapped to and fro</line>
      <line>Round their rest:</line>
      <line>Cheek to cheek and breast to breast</line>
      <line>Locked together in one nest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Early in the morning</line>
      <line>When the first cock crowed his warning,</line>
      <line>Neat like bees, as sweet and busy,</line>
      <line>Laura rose with Lizzie:</line>
      <line>Fetched in honey, milked the cows,</line>
      <line>Aired and set to rights the house,</line>
      <line>Kneaded cakes of whitest wheat,</line>
      <line>Cakes for dainty mouths to eat,</line>
      <line>Next churned butter, whipped up cream,</line>
      <line>Fed their poultry, sat and sewed;</line>
      <line>Talked as modest maidens should:</line>
      <line>Lizzie with an open heart,</line>
      <line>Laura in an absent dream,</line>
      <line>One content, one sick in part;</line>
      <line>One warbling for the mere bright day’s delight,</line>
      <line>One longing for the night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At length slow evening came:</line>
      <line>They went with pitchers to the reedy brook;</line>
      <line>Lizzie most placid in her look,</line>
      <line>Laura most like a leaping flame.</line>
      <line>They drew the gurgling water from its deep;</line>
      <line>Lizzie plucked purple and rich golden flags,</line>
      <line>Then turning homewards said: ‘The sunset flushes</line>
      <line>Those furthest loftiest crags;</line>
      <line>Come, Laura, not another maiden lags,</line>
      <line>No wilful squirrel wags,</line>
      <line>The beasts and birds are fast asleep.’</line>
      <line>But Laura loitered still among the rushes</line>
      <line>And said the bank was steep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And said the hour was early still,</line>
      <line>The dew not fall’n, the wind not chill:</line>
      <line>Listening ever, but not catching</line>
      <line>The customary cry,</line>
      <line>‘Come buy, come buy,’</line>
      <line>With its iterated jingle</line>
      <line>Of sugar-baited words:</line>
      <line>Not for all her watching</line>
      <line>Once discerning even one goblin</line>
      <line>Racing, whisking, tumbling, hobbling;</line>
      <line>Let alone the herds</line>
      <line>That used to tramp along the glen,</line>
      <line>In groups or single,</line>
      <line>Of brisk fruit-merchant men.</line>
      <line>Till Lizzie urged, ‘O Laura, come;</line>
      <line>I hear the fruit-call but I dare not look:</line>
      <line>You should not loiter longer at this brook:</line>
      <line>Come with me home.</line>
      <line>The stars rise, the moon bends her arc,</line>
      <line>Each glowworm winks her spark,</line>
      <line>Let us get home before the night grows dark</line>
      <line>For clouds may gather</line>
      <line>Tho’ this is summer weather,</line>
      <line>Put out the lights and drench us thro’;</line>
      <line>Then if we lost our way what should we do?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laura turned cold as stone</line>
      <line>To find her sister heard that cry alone,</line>
      <line>That goblin cry,</line>
      <line>‘Come buy our fruits, come buy.’</line>
      <line>Must she then buy no more such dainty fruit?</line>
      <line>Must she no more such succous pasture find,</line>
      <line>Gone deaf and blind?</line>
      <line>Her tree of life drooped from the root:</line>
      <line>She said not one word in her heart’s sore ache;</line>
      <line>But peering thro’ the dimness, nought discerning,</line>
      <line>Trudged home, her pitcher dripping all the way;</line>
      <line>So crept to bed, and lay</line>
      <line>Silent till Lizzie slept;</line>
      <line>Then sat up in a passionate yearning,</line>
      <line>And gnashed her teeth for baulked desire, and wept</line>
      <line>As if her heart would break.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Day after day, night after night,</line>
      <line>Laura kept watch in vain</line>
      <line>In sullen silence of exceeding pain.</line>
      <line>She never caught again the goblin cry:</line>
      <line>‘Come buy, come buy;’—</line>
      <line>She never spied the goblin men</line>
      <line>Hawking their fruits along the glen:</line>
      <line>But when the noon waxed bright</line>
      <line>Her hair grew thin and gray;</line>
      <line>She dwindled, as the fair full moon doth turn</line>
      <line>To swift decay and burn</line>
      <line>Her fire away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One day remembering her kernel-stone</line>
      <line>She set it by a wall that faced the south;</line>
      <line>Dewed it with tears, hoped for a root,</line>
      <line>Watched for a waxing shoot,</line>
      <line>But there came none;</line>
      <line>It never saw the sun,</line>
      <line>It never felt the trickling moisture run:</line>
      <line>While with sunk eyes and faded mouth</line>
      <line>She dreamed of melons, as a traveller sees</line>
      <line>False waves in desert drouth</line>
      <line>With shade of leaf-crowned trees,</line>
      <line>And burns the thirstier in the sandful breeze.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She no more swept the house,</line>
      <line>Tended the fowls or cows,</line>
      <line>Fetched honey, kneaded cakes of wheat,</line>
      <line>Brought water from the brook:</line>
      <line>But sat down listless in the chimney-nook</line>
      <line>And would not eat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tender Lizzie could not bear</line>
      <line>To watch her sister’s cankerous care</line>
      <line>Yet not to share.</line>
      <line>She night and morning</line>
      <line>Caught the goblins’ cry:</line>
      <line>‘Come buy our orchard fruits,</line>
      <line>Come buy, come buy:’—</line>
      <line>Beside the brook, along the glen,</line>
      <line>She heard the tramp of goblin men,</line>
      <line>The voice and stir</line>
      <line>Poor Laura could not hear;</line>
      <line>Longed to buy fruit to comfort her,</line>
      <line>But feared to pay too dear.</line>
      <line>She thought of Jeanie in her grave,</line>
      <line>Who should have been a bride;</line>
      <line>But who for joys brides hope to have</line>
      <line>Fell sick and died</line>
      <line>In her gay prime,</line>
      <line>In earliest Winter time,</line>
      <line>With the first glazing rime,</line>
      <line>With the first snow-fall of crisp Winter time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till Laura dwindling</line>
      <line>Seemed knocking at Death’s door:</line>
      <line>Then Lizzie weighed no more</line>
      <line>Better and worse;</line>
      <line>But put a silver penny in her purse,</line>
      <line>Kissed Laura, crossed the heath with clumps of furze</line>
      <line>At twilight, halted by the brook:</line>
      <line>And for the first time in her life</line>
      <line>Began to listen and look.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laughed every goblin</line>
      <line>When they spied her peeping:</line>
      <line>Came towards her hobbling,</line>
      <line>Flying, running, leaping,</line>
      <line>Puffing and blowing,</line>
      <line>Chuckling, clapping, crowing,</line>
      <line>Clucking and gobbling,</line>
      <line>Mopping and mowing,</line>
      <line>Full of airs and graces,</line>
      <line>Pulling wry faces,</line>
      <line>Demure grimaces,</line>
