      <line>Cat-like and rat-like,</line>
      <line>Ratel- and wombat-like,</line>
      <line>Snail-paced in a hurry,</line>
      <line>Parrot-voiced and whistler,</line>
      <line>Helter skelter, hurry skurry,</line>
      <line>Chattering like magpies,</line>
      <line>Fluttering like pigeons,</line>
      <line>Gliding like fishes,—</line>
      <line>Plugged her and kissed her,</line>
      <line>Squeezed and caressed her:</line>
      <line>Stretched up their dishes,</line>
      <line>Panniers, and plates:</line>
      <line>‘Look at our apples</line>
      <line>Russet and dun,</line>
      <line>Bob at our cherries,</line>
      <line>Bite at our peaches,</line>
      <line>Citrons and dates,</line>
      <line>Grapes for the asking,</line>
      <line>Pears red with basking</line>
      <line>Out in the sun,</line>
      <line>Plums on their twigs;</line>
      <line>Pluck them and suck them,</line>
      <line>Pomegranates, figs.’—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Good folk,’ said Lizzie,</line>
      <line>Mindful of Jeanie:</line>
      <line>‘Give me much and many:’—</line>
      <line>Held out her apron,</line>
      <line>Tossed them her penny.</line>
      <line>‘Nay, take a seat with us,</line>
      <line>Honour and eat with us,’</line>
      <line>They answered grinning:</line>
      <line>‘Our feast is but beginning.</line>
      <line>Night yet is early,</line>
      <line>Warm and dew-pearly,</line>
      <line>Wakeful and starry:</line>
      <line>Such fruits as these</line>
      <line>No man can carry;</line>
      <line>Half their bloom would fly,</line>
      <line>Half their dew would dry,</line>
      <line>Half their flavour would pass by.</line>
      <line>Sit down and feast with us,</line>
      <line>Be welcome guest with us,</line>
      <line>Cheer you and rest with us.’—</line>
      <line>‘Thank you,’ said Lizzie: ‘But one waits</line>
      <line>At home alone for me:</line>
      <line>So without further parleying,</line>
      <line>If you will not sell me any</line>
      <line>Of your fruits tho’ much and many,</line>
      <line>Give me back my silver penny</line>
      <line>I tossed you for a fee.’—</line>
      <line>They began to scratch their pates,</line>
      <line>No longer wagging, purring,</line>
      <line>But visibly demurring,</line>
      <line>Grunting and snarling.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One called her proud,</line>
      <line>Cross-grained, uncivil;</line>
      <line>Their tones waxed loud,</line>
      <line>Their looks were evil.</line>
      <line>Lashing their tails</line>
      <line>They trod and hustled her,</line>
      <line>Elbowed and jostled her,</line>
      <line>Clawed with their nails,</line>
      <line>Barking, mewing, hissing, mocking,</line>
      <line>Tore her gown and soiled her stocking,</line>
      <line>Twitched her hair out by the roots,</line>
      <line>Stamped upon her tender feet,</line>
      <line>Held her hands and squeezed their fruits</line>
      <line>Against her mouth to make her eat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>White and golden Lizzie stood,</line>
      <line>Like a lily in a flood,—</line>
      <line>Like a rock of blue-veined stone</line>
      <line>Lashed by tides obstreperously,—</line>
      <line>Like a beacon left alone</line>
      <line>In a hoary roaring sea,</line>
      <line>Sending up a golden fire,—</line>
      <line>Like a fruit-crowned orange-tree</line>
      <line>White with blossoms honey-sweet</line>
      <line>Sore beset by wasp and bee,—</line>
      <line>Like a royal virgin town</line>
      <line>Topped with gilded dome and spire</line>
      <line>Close beleaguered by a fleet</line>
      <line>Mad to tug her standard down.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One may lead a horse to water,</line>
      <line>Twenty cannot make him drink.</line>
      <line>Tho’ the goblins cuffed and caught her,</line>
      <line>Coaxed and fought her,</line>
      <line>Bullied and besought her,</line>
      <line>Scratched her, pinched her black as ink,</line>
      <line>Kicked and knocked her,</line>
      <line>Mauled and mocked her,</line>
      <line>Lizzie uttered not a word;</line>
      <line>Would not open lip from lip</line>
      <line>Lest they should cram a mouthful in:</line>
      <line>But laughed in heart to feel the drip</line>
      <line>Of juice that syrupped all her face,</line>
      <line>And lodged in dimples of her chin,</line>
      <line>And streaked her neck which quaked like curd.</line>
      <line>At last the evil people</line>
      <line>Worn out by her resistance</line>
      <line>Flung back her penny, kicked their fruit</line>
      <line>Along whichever road they took,</line>
      <line>Not leaving root or stone or shoot;</line>
      <line>Some writhed into the ground,</line>
      <line>Some dived into the brook</line>
      <line>With ring and ripple,</line>
      <line>Some scudded on the gale without a sound,</line>
      <line>Some vanished in the distance.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In a smart, ache, tingle,</line>
      <line>Lizzie went her way;</line>
      <line>Knew not was it night or day;</line>
      <line>Sprang up the bank, tore thro’ the furze,</line>
      <line>Threaded copse and dingle,</line>
      <line>And heard her penny jingle</line>
      <line>Bouncing in her purse,</line>
      <line>Its bounce was music to her ear.</line>
      <line>She ran and ran</line>
      <line>As if she feared some goblin man</line>
      <line>Dogged her with gibe or curse</line>
      <line>Or something worse:</line>
      <line>But not one goblin skurried after,</line>
      <line>Nor was she pricked by fear;</line>
      <line>The kind heart made her windy-paced</line>
      <line>That urged her home quite out of breath with haste</line>
      <line>And inward laughter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She cried ‘Laura,’ up the garden,</line>
      <line>‘Did you miss me?</line>
      <line>Come and kiss me.</line>
      <line>Never mind my bruises,</line>
      <line>Hug me, kiss me, suck my juices</line>
      <line>Squeezed from goblin fruits for you,</line>
      <line>Goblin pulp and goblin dew.</line>
      <line>Eat me, drink me, love me;</line>
      <line>Laura, make much of me:</line>
      <line>For your sake I have braved the glen</line>
      <line>And had to do with goblin merchant men.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laura started from her chair,</line>
      <line>Flung her arms up in the air,</line>
      <line>Clutched her hair:</line>
      <line>‘Lizzie, Lizzie, have you tasted</line>
      <line>For my sake the fruit forbidden?</line>
      <line>Must your light like mine be hidden,</line>
      <line>Your young life like mine be wasted,</line>
      <line>Undone in mine undoing</line>
      <line>And ruined in my ruin,</line>
      <line>Thirsty, cankered, goblin-ridden?’—</line>
      <line>She clung about her sister,</line>
      <line>Kissed and kissed and kissed her:</line>
      <line>Tears once again</line>
      <line>Refreshed her shrunken eyes,</line>
      <line>Dropping like rain</line>
      <line>After long sultry drouth;</line>
      <line>Shaking with aguish fear, and pain,</line>
      <line>She kissed and kissed her with a hungry mouth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her lips began to scorch,</line>
      <line>That juice was wormwood to her tongue,</line>
      <line>She loathed the feast:</line>
      <line>Writhing as one possessed she leaped and sung,</line>
      <line>Rent all her robe, and wrung</line>
      <line>Her hands in lamentable haste,</line>
      <line>And beat her breast.</line>
      <line>Her locks streamed like the torch</line>
      <line>Borne by a racer at full speed,</line>
      <line>Or like the mane of horses in their flight,</line>
      <line>Or like an eagle when she stems the light</line>
      <line>Straight toward the sun,</line>
      <line>Or like a caged thing freed,</line>
      <line>Or like a flying flag when armies run.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Swift fire spread thro’ her veins, knocked at her heart,</line>
      <line>Met the fire smouldering there</line>
      <line>And overbore its lesser flame;</line>
      <line>She gorged on bitterness without a name:</line>
      <line>Ah! fool, to choose such part</line>
      <line>Of soul-consuming care!</line>
      <line>Sense failed in the mortal strife:</line>
      <line>Like the watch-tower of a town</line>
      <line>Which an earthquake shatters down,</line>
      <line>Like a lightning-stricken mast,</line>
      <line>Like a wind-uprooted tree</line>
      <line>Spun about,</line>
      <line>Like a foam-topped waterspout</line>
      <line>Cast down headlong in the sea,</line>
      <line>She fell at last;</line>
      <line>Pleasure past and anguish past,</line>
      <line>Is it death or is it life?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Life out of death.</line>
      <line>That night long Lizzie watched by her,</line>
      <line>Counted her pulse’s flagging stir,</line>
      <line>Felt for her breath,</line>
      <line>Held water to her lips, and cooled her face</line>
      <line>With tears and fanning leaves:</line>
      <line>But when the first birds chirped about their eaves,</line>
      <line>And early reapers plodded to the place</line>
      <line>Of golden sheaves,</line>
      <line>And dew-wet grass</line>
      <line>Bowed in the morning winds so brisk to pass,</line>
      <line>And new buds with new day</line>
      <line>Opened of cup-like lilies on the stream,</line>
      <line>Laura awoke as from a dream,</line>
      <line>Laughed in the innocent old way,</line>
      <line>Hugged Lizzie but not twice or thrice;</line>
      <line>Her gleaming locks showed not one thread of grey,</line>
      <line>Her breath was sweet as May</line>
      <line>And light danced in her eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Days, weeks, months, years</line>
      <line>Afterwards, when both were wives</line>
      <line>With children of their own;</line>
      <line>Their mother-hearts beset with fears,</line>
      <line>Their lives bound up in tender lives;</line>
      <line>Laura would call the little ones</line>
      <line>And tell them of her early prime,</line>
      <line>Those pleasant days long gone</line>
      <line>Of not-returning time:</line>
      <line>Would talk about the haunted glen,</line>
      <line>The wicked, quaint fruit-merchant men,</line>
      <line>Their fruits like honey to the throat</line>
      <line>But poison in the blood;</line>
      <line>(Men sell not such in any town:)</line>
      <line>Would tell them how her sister stood</line>
      <line>In deadly peril to do her good,</line>
      <line>And win the fiery antidote:</line>
      <line>Then joining hands to little hands</line>
      <line>Would bid them cling together,</line>
      <line>‘For there is no friend like a sister</line>
      <line>In calm or stormy weather;</line>
      <line>To cheer one on the tedious way,</line>
      <line>To fetch one if one goes astray,</line>
      <line>To lift one if one totters down,</line>
      <line>To strengthen whilst one stands.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>Promises Like Pie-Crust</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Promise me no promises,</line>
      <line>So will I not promise you:</line>
      <line>Keep we both our liberties,</line>
      <line>Never false and never true:</line>
      <line>Let us hold the die uncast,</line>
      <line>Free to come as free to go:</line>
      <line>For I cannot know your past,</line>
      <line>And of mine what can you know?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You, so warm, may once have been</line>
      <line>Warmer towards another one:</line>
      <line>I, so cold, may once have seen</line>
      <line>Sunlight, once have felt the sun:</line>
      <line>Who shall show us if it was</line>
      <line>Thus indeed in time of old?</line>
      <line>Fades the image from the glass,</line>
      <line>And the fortune is not told.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If you promised, you might grieve</line>
      <line>For lost liberty again:</line>
      <line>If I promised, I believe</line>
      <line>I should fret to break the chain.</line>
      <line>Let us be the friends we were,</line>
      <line>Nothing more but nothing less:</line>
      <line>Many thrive on frugal fare</line>
      <line>Who would perish of excess.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1863</date>
    <title>Somewhere or Other</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Somewhere or other there must surely be</line>
      <line>The face not seen, the voice not heard,</line>
      <line>The heart that not yet—never yet—ah me!</line>
      <line>Made answer to my word.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Somewhere or other, may be near or far;</line>
      <line>Past land and sea, clean out of sight;</line>
      <line>Beyond the wandering moon, beyond the star</line>
      <line>That tracks her night by night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Somewhere or other, may be far or near;</line>
      <line>With just a wall, a hedge, between;</line>
      <line>With just the last leaves of the dying year</line>
      <line>Fallen on a turf grown green.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1863</date>
    <title>The Lowest Place</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Give me the lowest place: not that I dare</line>
      <line>Ask for that lowest place, but Thou hast died</line>
      <line>That I might live and share</line>
      <line>Thy glory by Thy side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Give me the lowest place: or if for me</line>
      <line>That lowest place too high, make one more low</line>
      <line>Where I may sit and see</line>
      <line>My God and love Thee so.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>Grown and Flown</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loved my love from green of Spring</line>
      <line>Until sere Autumn’s fall;</line>
      <line>But now that leaves are withering</line>
      <line>How should one love at all?</line>
      <line>One heart’s too small</line>
      <line>For hunger, cold, love, everything.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loved my love on sunny days</line>
      <line>Until late Summer’s wane;</line>
      <line>But now that frost begins to glaze</line>
      <line>How should one love again?</line>
      <line>Nay, love and pain</line>
      <line>Walk wide apart in diverse ways.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loved my love—alas to see</line>
      <line>That this should be, alas!</line>
      <line>I thought that this could scarcely be,</line>
      <line>Yet has it come to pass:</line>
      <line>Sweet sweet love was,</line>
      <line>Now bitter bitter grown to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>A Dirge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why were you born when the snow was falling?</line>
      <line>You should have come to the cuckoo’s calling,</line>
      <line>Or when grapes are green in the cluster,</line>
      <line>Or, at least, when lithe swallows muster</line>
      <line>For their far off flying</line>
      <line>From summer dying.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why did you die when the lambs were cropping?</line>
      <line>You should have died at the apples’ dropping,</line>
      <line>When the grasshopper comes to trouble,</line>
      <line>And the wheat-fields are sodden stubble,</line>
      <line>And all winds go sighing</line>
      <line>For sweet things dying.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>A Christmas Carol</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the bleak mid-winter</line>
      <line>Frosty wind made moan,</line>
      <line>Earth stood hard as iron,</line>
      <line>Water like a stone;</line>
      <line>Snow had fallen, snow on snow,</line>
      <line>Snow on snow,</line>
      <line>In the bleak mid-winter</line>
      <line>Long ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our God, Heaven cannot hold Him</line>
      <line>Nor earth sustain;</line>
      <line>Heaven and earth shall flee away</line>
      <line>When He comes to reign:</line>
      <line>In the bleak mid-winter</line>
      <line>A stable-place sufficed</line>
      <line>The Lord God Almighty</line>
      <line>Jesus Christ.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Enough for Him whom cherubim</line>
      <line>Worship night and day,</line>
      <line>A breastful of milk</line>
      <line>And a mangerful of hay;</line>
      <line>Enough for Him whom angels</line>
      <line>Fall down before,</line>
      <line>The ox and ass and camel</line>
      <line>Which adore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Angels and archangels</line>
      <line>May have gathered there,</line>
      <line>Cherubim and seraphim</line>
      <line>Throng’d the air,</line>
      <line>But only His mother</line>
      <line>In her maiden bliss</line>
      <line>Worshipped the Beloved</line>
      <line>With a kiss.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What can I give Him,</line>
      <line>Poor as I am?</line>
      <line>If I were a shepherd</line>
      <line>I would bring a lamb,</line>
      <line>If I were a wise man</line>
      <line>I would do my part,—</line>
      <line>Yet what I can I give Him,</line>
      <line>Give my heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1881</date>
    <title>‘Summer is Ended’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>T o think that this meaningless thing was ever a rose,</line>
      <line>Scentless, colourless, this!</line>
      <line>Will it ever be thus (who knows?)</line>
      <line>Thus with our bliss,</line>
      <line>If we wait till the close?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tho’ we care not to wait for the end, there comes the end</line>
      <line>Sooner, later, at last,</line>
      <line>Which nothing can mar, nothing mend:</line>
      <line>An end locked fast,</line>
      <line>Bent we cannot re-bend.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>‘Endure hardness'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A cold wind stirs the blackthorn</line>
      <line>To burgeon and to blow,</line>
      <line>Besprinkling half-green hedges</line>
      <line>With flakes and sprays of snow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thro’ coldness and thro’ keenness,</line>
      <line>Dear hearts, take comfort so:</line>
      <line>Somewhere or other doubtless</line>
      <line>These make the blackthorn blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>Lord Jesus, who would think that I am Thine?</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, who would think</line>
      <line>Who sees me ready to turn back or sink,</line>
      <line>That Thou art mine?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot hold Thee fast tho’ Thou art mine:</line>
      <line>Hold Thou me fast,</line>
      <line>So earth shall know at last and heaven at last</line>
      <line>That I am Thine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Christina G. Rossetti</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>A Frog’s Fate</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Contemptuous of his home beyond</line>
      <line>The village and the village-pond,</line>
      <line>A large-souled Frog who spurned each byeway</line>
      <line>Hopped along the imperial highway.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor grunting pig nor barking dog</line>
      <line>Could disconcert so great a Frog.</line>
      <line>The morning dew was lingering yet,</line>
      <line>His sides to cool, his tongue to wet:</line>
      <line>The night-dew, when the night should come,</line>
      <line>A travelled Frog would send him home.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not so, alas! The wayside grass</line>
      <line>Sees him no more: not so, alas!</line>
      <line>A broad-wheeled waggon unawares</line>
      <line>Ran him down, his joys, his cares.</line>
      <line>From dying choke one feeble croak</line>
      <line>The Frog’s perpetual silence broke:—</line>
      <line>‘Ye buoyant Frogs, ye great and small,</line>
      <line>Even I am mortal after all!</line>
      <line>My road to fame turns out a wry way;</line>
      <line>I perish on the hideous highway;</line>
      <line>Oh for my old familiar byeway!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The choking Frog sobbed and was gone;</line>
      <line>The Waggoner strode whistling on.</line>
      <line>Unconscious of the carnage done,</line>
      <line>Whistling that Waggoner strode on—</line>
      <line>Whistling (it may have happened so)</line>
      <line>‘A froggy would a-wooing go.’</line>
      <line>A hypothetic frog trolled he,</line>
      <line>Obtuse to a reality.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O rich and poor, O great and small,</line>
      <line>Such oversights beset us all.</line>
      <line>The mangled Frog abides incog,</line>
      <line>The uninteresting actual frog:</line>
      <line>The hypothetic frog alone</line>
      <line>Is the one frog we dwell upon.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ebenezer Elliott</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Epigram</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Prepare to meet the King of Terrors,’ cried</line>
      <line>To prayerless Want, his plunderer ferret-eyed:</line>
      <line>‘I am the King of Terrors,’ Want replied.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ebenezer Elliott</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Donought would have everything;</line>
      <line>Eat the lark, and use its wing;</line>
      <line>Sip the sweet, and be the sting:</line>
      <line>Donought is the only King.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Donought is an alchemist;</line>
      <line>Hencock is a communist;</line>
      <line>Idle head is heavy fist;</line>
      <line>Will’s a right line—with a twist.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hark! the throstle! what sings he?</line>
      <line>‘Worm, my Beauty, come to me!’</line>
      <line>Yet all lovely things are free:</line>
      <line>‘Chain’d and happy, cannot be.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘See the daisies, how they grow!’</line>
      <line>When they list, the breezes blow:</line>
      <line>Why can’t weary man do so?</line>
      <line>All enjoy, and nothing owe?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Mouth, keep open! Eyes, be shut!’</line>
      <line>Take no care for back or gut:</line>
      <line>Best of women is the slut:</line>
      <line>Hey, for cattle cook’d and cut!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
    </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ebenezer Elliott</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Epigram</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is a communist? One who hath yearnings</line>
      <line>For equal division of unequal earnings:</line>
      <line>Idler, or bungler, or both, he is willing</line>
      <line>To fork out his penny, and pocket your shilling.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1849</date>
    <title>To Marguerite—Continued</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes! in the sea of life enisled,</line>
      <line>With echoing straits between us thrown,</line>
      <line>Dotting the shoreless watery wild,</line>
      <line>We mortal millions live alone.</line>
      <line>The islands feel the enclasping flow,</line>
      <line>And then their endless bounds they know.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when the moon their hollows lights,</line>
      <line>And they are swept by balms of spring,</line>
      <line>And in their glens, on starry nights,</line>
      <line>The nightingales divinely sing;</line>
      <line>And lovely notes, from shore to shore,</line>
      <line>Across the sounds and channels pour—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh! then a longing like despair</line>
      <line>Is to their farthest caverns sent;</line>
      <line>For surely once, they feel, we were</line>
      <line>Parts of a single continent!</line>
      <line>Now round us spreads the watery plain—</line>
      <line>Oh might our marges meet again!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who order’d, that their longing’s fire</line>
      <line>Should be, as soon as kindled, cool’d?</line>
      <line>Who renders vain their deep desire?—</line>
      <line>A God, a God their severance ruled!</line>
      <line>And bade betwixt their shores to be</line>
      <line>The unplumb’d, salt, estranging sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Destiny</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why each is striving, from of old,</line>
      <line>To love more deeply than he can?</line>
      <line>Still would be true, yet still grows cold?</line>
      <line>—Ask of the Powers that sport with man!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They yok’d in him, for endless strife,</line>
      <line>A heart of ice, a soul of fire;</line>
      <line>And hurl’d him on the Field of Life,</line>
      <line>An aimless unallay’d Desire.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1851</date>
    <title>Dover Beach</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sea is calm to-night.</line>
      <line>The tide is full, the moon lies fair</line>
      <line>Upon the straits;—on the French coast the light</line>
      <line>Gleams and is gone; the cliffs of England stand,</line>
      <line>Glimmering and vast, out in the tranquil bay.</line>
      <line>Come to the window, sweet is the night-air!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Only, from the long line of spray</line>
      <line>Where the sea meets the moon-blanch’d land,</line>
      <line>Listen! you hear the grating roar</line>
      <line>Of pebbles which the waves draw back, and fling,</line>
      <line>At their return, up the high strand,</line>
      <line>Begin, and cease, and then again begin,</line>
      <line>With tremulous cadence slow, and bring</line>
      <line>The eternal note of sadness in.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sophocles long ago</line>
      <line>Pleard it on the Tigs an, and it brought</line>
      <line>Into his mind the turbid ebb and flow</line>
      <line>Of human misery; we</line>
      <line>Find also in the sound a thought,</line>
      <line>Flearing it by this distant northern sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Sea of Faith</line>
      <line>Was once, too, at the full, and round earth’s shore</line>
      <line>Lay like the folds of a bright girdle furl’d.</line>
      <line>But now I only hear</line>
      <line>Its melancholy, long, withdrawing roar,</line>
      <line>Retreating, to the breath</line>
      <line>Of the night-wind, down the vast edges drear</line>
      <line>And naked shingles of the world.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, love, let us be true</line>
      <line>To one another! for the world, which seems</line>
      <line>To lie before us like a land of dreams,</line>
      <line>So various, so beautiful, so new,</line>
      <line>Hath really neither joy, nor love, nor light,</line>
      <line>Nor certitude, nor peace, nor help for pain;</line>
      <line>And we are here as on a darkling plain</line>
      <line>Swept with confused alarms of struggle and flight,</line>
      <line>Where ignorant armies clash by night.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>The Scholar-Gipsy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go, for they call you, shepherd, from the hill;</line>
      <line>Go, shepherd, and untie the wattled cotes!</line>
      <line>No longer leave thy wistful flock unfed,</line>
      <line>Nor let thy bawling fellows rack their throats,</line>
      <line>Nor the cropp’d herbage shoot another head.</line>
      <line>But when the fields are still,</line>
      <line>And the tired men and dogs all gone to rest,</line>
      <line>And only the white sheep are sometimes seen</line>
      <line>Cross and recross the strips of moon-blanch’d green,</line>
      <line>Come, shepherd, and again begin the quest!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here, where the reaper was at work of late—</line>
      <line>In this high field’s dark corner, where he leaves</line>
      <line>His coat, his basket, and his earthen cruse,</line>
      <line>And in the sun all morning binds the sheaves,</line>
      <line>Then here, at noon, comes back his stores to use—</line>
      <line>Here will I sit and wait,</line>
      <line>While to my ear from uplands far away</line>
      <line>The bleating of the folded flocks is borne,</line>
      <line>With distant cries of reapers in the corn—</line>
      <line>All the live murmur of a summer’s day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Screen’d is this nook o’er the high, half-reap’d field,</line>
      <line>And here till sun-down, shepherd! will I be.</line>
      <line>Through the thick corn the scarlet poppies peep,</line>
      <line>And round green roots and yellowing stalks I see</line>
      <line>Pale pink convolvulus in tendrils creep;</line>
      <line>And air-swept lindens yield</line>
      <line>Their scent, and rustle down their perfumed showers</line>
      <line>Of bloom on the bent grass where I am laid,</line>
      <line>And bower me from the August sun with shade;</line>
      <line>And the eye travels down to Oxford’s towers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And near me on the grass lies Glanvil’s book—</line>
      <line>Come, let me read the oft-read tale again!</line>
      <line>The story of the Oxford scholar poor,</line>
      <line>Of pregnant parts and quick inventive brain,</line>
      <line>Who, tired of knocking at preferment’s door,</line>
      <line>One summer-morn forsook</line>
      <line>His friends, and went to learn the gipsy-lore,</line>
      <line>And roam’d the world with that wild brotherhood,</line>
      <line>And came, as most men deem’d, to little good,</line>
      <line>But came to Oxford and his friends no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But once, years after, in the country-lanes,</line>
      <line>Two scholars, whom at college erst he knew,</line>
      <line>Met him, and of his way of life enquired;</line>
      <line>Whereat he answer’d, that the gipsy-crew,</line>
      <line>His mates, had arts to rule as they desired</line>
      <line>The workings of men’s brains,</line>
      <line>And they can bind them to what thoughts they will.</line>
      <line>‘And I,’ he said, ‘the secret of their art,</line>
      <line>When fully learn’d, will to the world impart;</line>
      <line>But it needs heaven-sent moments for this skill.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This said, he left them, and return’d no more.—</line>
      <line>But rumours hung about the country-side,</line>
      <line>That the lost Scholar long was seen to stray,</line>
      <line>Seen by rare glimpses, pensive and tongue-tied,</line>
      <line>In hat of antique shape, and cloak of grey,</line>
      <line>The same the gipsies wore.</line>
      <line>Shepherds had met him on the Hurst in spring;</line>
      <line>At some lone alehouse in the Berkshire moors,</line>
      <line>On the warm ingle-bench, the smock-frock’d boors</line>
      <line>Had found him seated at their entering,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, ’mid their drink and clatter, he would fly.</line>
      <line>And I myself seem half to know thy looks,</line>
      <line>And put the shepherds, wanderer! on thy trace;</line>
      <line>And boys who in lone wheatfields scare the rooks</line>
      <line>I ask if thou hast pass’d their quiet place;</line>
      <line>Or in my boat I lie</line>
      <line>Moor’d to the cool bank in the summer-heats,</line>
      <line>’Mid wide grass meadows which the sunshine fills,</line>
      <line>And watch the warm, green-muffled Cumner hills,</line>
      <line>And wonder if thou haunt’st their shy retreats.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For most, I know, thou lov’st retired ground!</line>
      <line>Thee at the ferry Oxford riders blithe,</line>
      <line>Returning home on summer-nights, have met</line>
      <line>Crossing the stripling Thames at Bab-lock-hithe,</line>
      <line>Trailing in the cool stream thy fingers wet,</line>
      <line>As the punt’s rope chops round;</line>
      <line>And leaning backward in a pensive dream,</line>
      <line>And fostering in thy lap a heap of flowers</line>
      <line>Pluck’d in shy fields and distant Wychwood bowers,</line>
      <line>And thine eyes resting on the moonlit stream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then they land, and thou art seen no more!—</line>
      <line>Maidens, who from the distant hamlets come</line>
      <line>To dance around the Fyfield elm in May,</line>
      <line>Oft through the darkening fields have seen thee roam,</line>
      <line>Or cross a stile into the public way.</line>
      <line>Oft thou hast given them store</line>
      <line>Of flowers—the frail-leaf d, white anemony,</line>
      <line>Dark bluebells drench’d with dews of summer eves,</line>
      <line>And purple orchises with spotted leaves—</line>
      <line>But none hath words she can report of thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, above Godstow Bridge, when hay-time’s here</line>
      <line>In June, and many a scythe in sunshine flames,</line>
      <line>Men who through those wide fields of breezy grass</line>
      <line>Where black-wing’d swallows haunt the glittering Thames,</line>
      <line>To bathe in the abandon’d lasher pass,</line>
      <line>Have often pass’d thee near</line>
      <line>Sitting upon the river bank o’ergrown;</line>
      <line>Mark’d thine outlandish garb, thy figure spare,</line>
      <line>Thy dark vague eyes, and soft abstracted air—</line>
      <line>But, when they came from bathing, thou wast gone!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At some lone homestead in the Cumner hills,</line>
      <line>Where at her open door the housewife darns,</line>
      <line>Thou hast been seen, or hanging on a gate</line>
      <line>To watch the threshers in the mossy barns.</line>
      <line>Children, who early range these slopes and late</line>
      <line>For cresses from the rills,</line>
      <line>Have known thee eying, all an April-day,</line>
      <line>The springing pastures and the feeding kine;</line>
      <line>And mark’d thee, when the stars come out and shine,</line>
      <line>Through the long dewy grass move slow away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In autumn, on the skirts of Bagley Wood—</line>
      <line>Where most the gipsies by the turf-edged way</line>
      <line>Pitch their smoked tents, and every bush you see</line>
      <line>With scarlet patches tagg’d and shreds of grey,</line>
      <line>Above the forest-ground called Thessaly—</line>
      <line>The blackbird, picking food,</line>
      <line>Sees thee, nor stops his meal, nor fears at all;</line>
      <line>So often has he known thee past him stray,</line>
      <line>Rapt, twirling in thy hand a wither’d spray,</line>
      <line>And waiting for the spark from heaven to fall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And once, in winter, on the causeway chill</line>
      <line>Where home through flooded fields foot-travellers go,</line>
      <line>Have I not pass’d thee on the wooden bridge,</line>
      <line>Wrapt in thy cloak and battling with the snow,</line>
      <line>Thy face tow’rd Hinksey and its wintry ridge?</line>
      <line>And thou hast climb’d the hill,</line>
      <line>And gain’d the white brow of the Cumner range;</line>
      <line>Turn’d once to watch, while thick the snowflakes fall,</line>
      <line>The line of festal light in Christ-Church hall—</line>
      <line>Then sought thy straw in some sequester’d grange.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But what—I dream! Two hundred years are flown</line>
      <line>Since first thy story ran through Oxford halls,</line>
      <line>And the grave Glanvil did the tale inscribe</line>
      <line>That thou wert wander’d from the studious walls</line>
      <line>To learn strange arts, and join a gipsy-tribe;</line>
      <line>And thou from earth art gone</line>
      <line>Long since, and in some quiet churchyard laid—</line>
      <line>Some country-nook, where o’er thy unknown grave</line>
      <line>Tall grasses and white flowering nettles wave,</line>
      <line>Under a dark, red-fruited yew-tree’s shade.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>—No, no, thou hast not felt the lapse of hours!</line>
      <line>For what wears out the life of mortal men?</line>
      <line>Tis that from change to change their being rolls;</line>
      <line>’Tis that repeated shocks, again, again,</line>
      <line>Exhaust the energy of strongest souls</line>
      <line>And numb the elastic powers.</line>
      <line>Till having used our nerves with bliss and teen,</line>
      <line>And tired upon a thousand schemes our wit,</line>
      <line>To the just-pausing Genius we remit</line>
      <line>Our worn-out life, and are—what we have been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou hast not lived, why should’st thou perish, so?</line>
      <line>Thou hadst one aim, one business, one desire;</line>
      <line>Else wert thou long since number’d with the dead!</line>
      <line>Else hadst thou spent, like other men, thy fire!</line>
      <line>The generations of thy peers are fled,</line>
      <line>And we ourselves shall go;</line>
      <line>But thou possessest an immortal lot,</line>
      <line>And we imagine thee exempt from age</line>
      <line>And living as thou liv’st on Glanvil’s page,</line>
      <line>Because thou hadst—what we, alas! have not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For early didst thou leave the world, with powers</line>
      <line>Fresh, undiverted to the world without,</line>
      <line>Firm to their mark, not spent on other things;</line>
      <line>Free from the sick fatigue, the languid doubt,</line>
      <line>Which much to have tried, in much been baffled, brings.</line>
      <line>O life unlike to ours!</line>
      <line>Who fluctuate idly without term or scope,</line>
      <line>Of whom each strives, nor knows for what he strives,</line>
      <line>And each half lives a hundred different lives;</line>
      <line>Who wait like thee, but not, like thee, in hope.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou waitest for the spark from heaven! and we,</line>
      <line>Light half-believers of our casual creeds,</line>
      <line>Who never deeply felt, nor clearly will’d,</line>
      <line>Whose insight never has borne fruit in deeds,</line>
      <line>Whose vague resolves never have been fulfill’d;</line>
      <line>For whom each year we see</line>
      <line>Breeds new beginnings, disappointments new;</line>
      <line>Who hesitate and falter life away,</line>
      <line>And lose to-morrow the ground won to-day—</line>
      <line>Ah! do not we, wanderer! await it too?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, we await it!—but it still delays,</line>
      <line>And then we suffer! and amongst us one,</line>
      <line>Who most has suffer’d, takes dejectedly</line>
      <line>His seat upon the intellectual throne;</line>
      <line>And all his store of sad experience he</line>
      <line>Lays bare of wretched days;</line>
      <line>Tells us his misery’s birth and growth and signs,</line>
      <line>And how the dying spark of hope was fed,</line>
      <line>And how the breast was soothed, and how the head,</line>
      <line>And all his hourly varied anodynes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This for our wisest! and we others pine,</line>
      <line>And wish the long unhappy dream would end,</line>
      <line>And waive all claim to bliss, and try to bear;</line>
      <line>With close-lipp’d patience for our only friend,</line>
      <line>Sad patience, too near neighbour to despair—</line>
      <line>But none has hope like thine!</line>
      <line>Thou through the fields and through the woods dost stray,</line>
      <line>Roaming the country-side, a truant boy,</line>
      <line>Nursing thy project in unclouded joy,</line>
      <line>And every doubt long blown by time away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O born in days when wits were fresh and clear,</line>
      <line>And life ran gaily as the sparkling Thames;</line>
      <line>Before this strange disease of modern life,</line>
      <line>With its sick hurry, its divided aims,</line>
      <line>Its heads o’ertax’d, its palsied hearts, was rife—</line>
      <line>Fly hence, our contact fear!</line>
      <line>Still fly, plunge deeper in the bowering wood!</line>
      <line>Averse, as Dido did with gesture stern</line>
      <line>From her false friend’s approach in Hades turn,</line>
      <line>Wave us away, and keep thy solitude!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still nursing the unconquerable hope,</line>
      <line>Still clutching the inviolable shade,</line>
      <line>With a free, onward impulse brushing through,</line>
      <line>By night, the silver’d branches of the glade—</line>
      <line>Far on the forest-skirts, where none pursue,</line>
      <line>On some mild pastoral slope</line>
      <line>Emerge, and resting on the moonlit pales</line>
      <line>Freshen thy flowers as in former years</line>
      <line>With dew, or listen with enchanted ears,</line>
      <line>From the dark dingles, to the nightingales!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But fly our paths, our feverish contact fly!</line>
      <line>For strong the infection of our mental strife,</line>
      <line>Which, though it gives no bliss, yet spoils for rest;</line>
      <line>And we should win thee from thy own fair life,</line>
      <line>Like us distracted, and like us unblest.</line>
      <line>Soon, soon thy cheer would die,</line>
      <line>Thy hopes grow timorous, and unfix’d thy powers,</line>
      <line>And thy clear aims be cross and shifting made;</line>
      <line>And then thy glad perennial youth would fade,</line>
      <line>Fade, and grow old at last, and die like ours.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then fly our greetings, fly our speech and smiles!</line>
      <line>—As some grave Tyrian trader, from the sea,</line>
      <line>Descried at sunrise an emerging prow</line>
      <line>Lifting the cool-hair’d creepers stealthily,</line>
      <line>The fringes of a southward-facing brow</line>
      <line>Among the Ægean isles;</line>
      <line>And saw the merry Grecian coaster come,</line>
      <line>Freighted with amber grapes, and Chian wine,</line>
      <line>Green, bursting figs, and tunnies steep’d in brine—</line>
      <line>And knew the intruders on his ancient home,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The young light-hearted masters of the waves—</line>
      <line>And snatch’d his rudder, and shook out more sail;</line>
      <line>And day and night held on indignantly</line>
      <line>O’er the blue Midland waters with the gale,</line>
      <line>Betwixt the Syrtes and soft Sicily,</line>
      <line>To where the Atlantic raves</line>
      <line>Outside the western straits; and unbent sails</line>
      <line>There, where down cloudy cliffs, through sheets of foam,</line>
      <line>Shy traffickers, the dark Iberians come;</line>
      <line>And on the beach undid his corded bales.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>Growing Old</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is it to grow old?</line>
      <line>Is it to lose the glory of the form,</line>
      <line>The lustre of the eye?</line>
      <line>Is it for beauty to forego her wreath?</line>
      <line>—Yes, but not this alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it to feel our strength—</line>
      <line>Not our bloom only, but our strength—decay?</line>
      <line>Is it to feel each limb</line>
      <line>Grow stiffer, every function less exact,</line>
      <line>Each nerve more loosely strung?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, this, and more; but not</line>
      <line>Ah, ’tis not what in youth we dream’d ’twould be!</line>
      <line>’Tis not to have our life</line>
      <line>Mellow’d and soften’d as with sunset-glow,</line>
      <line>A golden day’s decline.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis not to see the world</line>
      <line>As from a height, with rapt prophetic eyes,</line>
      <line>And heart profoundly stirr’d;</line>
      <line>And weep, and feel the fulness of the past,</line>
      <line>The years that are no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is to spend long days</line>
      <line>And not once feel that we were ever young;</line>
      <line>It is to add, immured</line>
      <line>In the hot prison of the present, month</line>
      <line>To month with weary pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is to suffer this,</line>
      <line>And feel but half, and feebly, what we feel.</line>
      <line>Deep in our hidden heart</line>
      <line>Festers the dull remembrance of a change,</line>
      <line>But no emotion—none.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is—last stage of all—</line>
      <line>When we are frozen up within, and quite</line>
      <line>The phantom of ourselves,</line>
      <line>To hear the world applaud the hollow ghost</line>
      <line>Which blamed the living man.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>The Progress of Poesy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Youth rambles on life’s arid mount,</line>
      <line>And strikes the rock, and finds the vein,</line>
      <line>And brings the water from the fount,</line>
      <line>The fount which shall not flow again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The man mature with labour chops</line>
      <line>For the bright stream a channel grand,</line>
      <line>And sees not that the sacred drops</line>
      <line>Ran off and vanish’d out of hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then the old man totters nigh,</line>
      <line>And feebly rakes among the stones.</line>
      <line>The mount is mute, the channel dry;</line>
      <line>And down he lays his weary bones.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>Below the surface-stream, shallow and light,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Below the surface-stream, shallow and light,</line>
      <line>Of what we say we feel—below the stream,</line>
      <line>As light, of what we think we feel—there flows</line>
      <line>With noiseless current strong, obscure and deep,</line>
      <line>The central stream of what we feel indeed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Matthew Arnold</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>Geist’s Grave</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Four years!—and didst thou stay above</line>
      <line>The ground, which hides thee now, but four?</line>
      <line>And all that life, and all that love,</line>
      <line>Were crowded, Geist! into no more?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Only four years those winning ways,</line>
      <line>Which make me for thy presence yearn,</line>
      <line>Call’d us to pet thee or to praise,</line>
      <line>Dear little friend! at every turn?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That loving heart, that patient soul,</line>
      <line>Had they indeed no longer span,</line>
      <line>To run their course, and reach their goal,</line>
      <line>And read their homily to man?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That liquid, melancholy eye,</line>
      <line>From whose pathetic, soul-fed springs</line>
      <line>Seem’d surging the Virgilian cry,</line>
      <line>The sense of tears in mortal things—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That steadfast, mournful strain, consoled</line>
      <line>By spirits gloriously gay,</line>
      <line>And temper of heroic mould—</line>
      <line>What, was four years their whole short day?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, only four!—and not the course</line>
      <line>Of all the centuries yet to come,</line>
      <line>And not the infinite resource</line>
      <line>Of Nature, with her countless sum</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of figures, with her fulness vast</line>
      <line>Of new creation evermore,</line>
      <line>Can ever quite repeat the past,</line>
      <line>Or just thy little self restore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Stern law of every mortal lot!</line>
      <line>Which man, proud man, finds hard to bear,</line>
      <line>And builds himself I know not what</line>
      <line>Of second life I know not where.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But thou, when struck thine hour to go,</line>
      <line>On us, who stood despondent by,</line>
      <line>A meek last glance of love didst throw,</line>
      <line>And humbly lay thee down to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet would we keep thee in our heart—</line>
      <line>Would fix our favourite on the scene,</line>
      <line>Nor let thee utterly depart</line>
      <line>And be as if thou ne’er hadst been.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so there rise these lines of verse</line>
      <line>On lips that rarely form them now;</line>
      <line>While to each other we rehearse:</line>
      <line>Such ways, such arts, such looks hadst thou!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We stroke thy broad brown paws again,</line>
      <line>We bid thee to thy vacant chair,</line>
      <line>We greet thee by the window-pane,</line>
      <line>We hear thy scuffle on the stair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We see the flaps of thy large ears</line>
      <line>Quick raised to ask which way we go;</line>
      <line>Crossing the frozen lake, appears</line>
      <line>Thy small black figure on the snow!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor to us only art thou dear</line>
      <line>Who mourn thee in thine English home;</line>
      <line>Thou hast thine absent master’s tear,</line>
      <line>Dropt by the far Australian foam.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy memory lasts both here and there,</line>
      <line>And thou shalt live as long as we.</line>
      <line>And after that—thou dost not care!</line>
      <line>In us was all the world to thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet, fondly zealous for thy fame,</line>
      <line>Even to a date, beyond our own</line>
      <line>We strive to carry down thy name,</line>
      <line>By mounded turf, and graven stone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We lay thee, close within our reach,</line>
      <line>Here, where the grass is smooth and warm,</line>
      <line>Between the holly and the beech,</line>
      <line>Where oft we watch’d thy couchant form,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Asleep, yet lending half an ear</line>
      <line>To travellers on the Portsmouth road;—</line>
      <line>There build we thee, O guardian dear,</line>
      <line>Mark’d with a stone, thy last abode!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then some, who through this garden pass,</line>
      <line>When we too, like thyself, are clay,</line>
      <line>Shall see thy grave upon the grass,</line>
      <line>And stop before the stone, and say:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>People who lived here long ago</line>
      <line>Did by this stone, it seems, intend</line>
      <line>To name for future times to know</line>
      <line>The dachs-hound, Geist, their little friend.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>A Dream</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I heard the dogs howl in the moonlight night;</line>
      <line>I went to the window to see the sight;</line>
      <line>All the Dead that ever I knew</line>
      <line>Going one by one and two by two.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On they pass’d, and on they pass’d;</line>
      <line>Townsfellows all, from first to last;</line>
      <line>Born in the moonlight of the lane,</line>
      <line>Quench’d in the heavy shadow again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Schoolmates, marching as when we play’d</line>
      <line>At soldiers once—but now more staid;</line>
      <line>Those were the strangest sight to me</line>
      <line>Who were drown’d, I knew, in the awful sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Straight and handsome folk; bent and weak too;</line>
      <line>Some that I loved, and gasp’d to speak to;</line>
      <line>Some but a day in their churchyard bed;</line>
      <line>Some that I had not known were dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A long, long crowd—where each seem’d lonely,</line>
      <line>Yet of them all there was one, one only,</line>
      <line>Raised a head or look’d my way:</line>
      <line>She linger’d a moment,—she might not stay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How long since I saw that fair pale face!</line>
      <line>Ah! Mother dear! might I only place</line>
      <line>My head on thy breast, a moment to rest,</line>
      <line>While thy hand on my tearful cheek were prest!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On, on, a moving bridge they made</line>
      <line>Across the moon-stream, from shade to shade,</line>
      <line>Young and old, women and men;</line>
      <line>Many long-forgot, but remember’d then.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And first there came a bitter laughter;</line>
      <line>A sound of tears the moment after;</line>
      <line>And then a music so lofty and gay,</line>
      <line>That every morning, day by day,</line>
      <line>I strive to recall it if I may.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>The Fairies</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up the airy mountain,</line>
      <line>Down the rushy glen,</line>
      <line>We daren’t go a-hunting</line>
      <line>For fear of little men;</line>
      <line>Wee folk, good folk,</line>
      <line>Trooping all together;</line>
      <line>Green jacket, red cap,</line>
      <line>And white owl’s feather!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down along the rocky shore</line>
      <line>Some make their home,</line>
      <line>They live on crispy pancakes</line>
      <line>Of yellow tide-foam;</line>
      <line>Some in the reeds</line>
      <line>Of the black mountain lake,</line>
      <line>With frogs for their watch-dogs,</line>
      <line>All night awake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>High on the hill-top</line>
      <line>The old King sits;</line>
      <line>He is now so old and gray</line>
      <line>He’s nigh lost his wits.</line>
      <line>With a bridge of white mist</line>
      <line>Columbkill he crosses,</line>
      <line>On his stately journeys</line>
      <line>From Slieveleague to Rosses;</line>
      <line>Or going up with music</line>
      <line>On cold starry nights,</line>
      <line>To sup with the Queen</line>
      <line>Of the gay Northern Lights.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They stole little Bridget</line>
      <line>For seven years long;</line>
      <line>When she came down again</line>
      <line>Her friends were all gone.</line>
      <line>They took her lightly back,</line>
      <line>Between the night and morrow,</line>
      <line>They thought that she was fast asleep,</line>
      <line>But she was dead with sorrow.</line>
      <line>They have kept her ever since</line>
      <line>Deep within the lake,</line>
      <line>On a bed of flag-leaves,</line>
      <line>Watching till she wake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By the craggy hill-side,</line>
      <line>Through the mosses bare,</line>
      <line>They have planted thorn-trees</line>
      <line>For pleasure here and there.</line>
      <line>Is any man so daring</line>
      <line>As dig them up in spite,</line>
      <line>He shall find their sharpest thorns</line>
      <line>In his bed at night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up the airy mountain,</line>
      <line>Down the rushy glen,</line>
      <line>We daren’t go a-hunting</line>
      <line>For fear of little men;</line>
      <line>Wee folk, good folk,</line>
      <line>Trooping all together;</line>
      <line>Green jacket, red cap,</line>
      <line>And white owl’s feather!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>The Witch-Bride</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fair witch crept to a young man’s side,</line>
      <line>And he kiss’d her and took her for his bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But a Shape came in at the dead of night,</line>
      <line>And fill’d the room with snowy light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he saw how in his arms there lay</line>
      <line>A thing more frightful than mouth may say.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he rose in haste, and follow’d the Shape</line>
      <line>Till morning crown’d an eastern cape.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he girded himself, and follow’d still</line>
      <line>When sunset sainted the western hill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, mocking and thwarting, clung to his side,</line>
      <line>Weary day!—the foul Witch-Bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>The Boy from his bedroom-window</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Boy from his bedroom-window</line>
      <line>Look’d over the little town,</line>
      <line>And away to the bleak black upland</line>
      <line>Under a clouded moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moon came forth from her cavern,</line>
      <line>He saw the sudden gleam</line>
      <line>Of a tarn in the swarthy moorland;</line>
      <line>Or perhaps the whole was a dream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For I never could find that water</line>
      <line>In all my walks and rides:</line>
      <line>Far-off, in the Land of Memory,</line>
      <line>That midnight pool abides.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Many fine things had I glimpse of,</line>
      <line>And said, ‘I shall find them one day.’</line>
      <line>Whether within or without me</line>
      <line>They were, I cannot say.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>Four ducks on a pond,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Four ducks on a pond,</line>
      <line>A grass-bank beyond,</line>
      <line>A blue sky of spring,</line>
      <line>White clouds on the wing;</line>
      <line>What a little thing</line>
      <line>To remember for years—</line>
      <line>To remember with tears!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>Everything passes and vanishes;</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Everything passes and vanishes;</line>
      <line>Everything leaves its trace;</line>
      <line>And often you see in a footstep</line>
      <line>What you could not see in a face.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>Writing</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A man who keeps a diary, pays</line>
      <line>Due toll to many tedious days;</line>
      <line>But life becomes eventful—then</line>
      <line>His busy hand forgets the pen.</line>
      <line>Most books, indeed, are records less</line>
      <line>Of fulness than of emptiness.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>An Evening</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A Sunset’s mounded cloud;</line>
      <line>A diamond evening-star;</line>
      <line>Sad blue hills afar;</line>
      <line>Love in his shroud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Scarcely a tear to shed;</line>
      <line>Hardly a word to say;</line>
      <line>The end of a summer day;</line>
      <line>Sweet Love dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>Express</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We move in elephantine row,</line>
      <line>The faces of our friends retire,</line>
      <line>The roof withdraws, and curtsying flow</line>
      <line>The message-bearing lines of wire;</line>
      <line>With doubling, redoubling beat,</line>
      <line>Smoother we run and more fleet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By flow’r-knots, shrubs, and slopes of grass,</line>
      <line>Cut walls of rock with ivy-stains,</line>
      <line>Thro’ winking arches swift we pass,</line>
      <line>And flying, meet the flying trains,</line>
      <line>Whirr—whirr—gone!</line>
      <line>And still we hurry on;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By orchards, kine in pleasant leas,</line>
      <line>A hamlet-lane, a spire, a pond,</line>
      <line>Long hedgerows, counter-changing trees,</line>
      <line>With blue and steady hills beyond;</line>
      <line>(House, platform, post,</line>
      <line>Flash—and are lost!)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Smooth-edged canals, and mills on brooks;</line>
      <line>Old farmsteads, busier than they seem,</line>
      <line>Rose-crusted or of graver looks,</line>
      <line>Rich with old tile and motley beam;</line>
      <line>Clay-cutting, slope, and ridge,</line>
      <line>The hollow rumbling bridge.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gray vapour-surges, whirl’d in the wind</line>
      <line>Of roaring tunnels, dark and long,</line>
      <line>Then sky and landscape unconfined,</line>
      <line>Then streets again where workers throng</line>
      <line>Come—go. The whistle shrill</line>
      <line>Controls us to its will.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Broad vents, and chimneys tall as masts,</line>
      <line>With heavy flags of streaming smoke;</line>
      <line>Brick mazes, fiery furnace-blasts,</line>
      <line>Walls, waggons, gritty heaps of coke;</line>
      <line>Through these our ponderous rank</line>
      <line>Glides in with hiss and clank.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So have we sped our wondrous course</line>
      <line>Amid a peaceful busy land,</line>
      <line>Subdued by long and painful force</line>
      <line>Of planning head and plodding hand.</line>
      <line>How much by labour can</line>
      <line>The feeble race of man!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Allingham</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>No funeral gloom</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No funeral gloom, my dears, when I am gone,</line>
      <line>Corpse-gazing, tears, black raiment, graveyard grimness;</line>
      <line>Think of me as withdrawn into the dimness,</line>
      <line>Yours still, you mine; remember all the best</line>
      <line>Of our past moments, and forget the rest;</line>
      <line>And so, to where I wait, come gently on.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Love at Large</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Whene’er I come where ladies are,</line>
      <line>How sad soever I was before,</line>
      <line>Though like a ship frost-bound and far</line>
      <line>Withheld in ice from the ocean’s roar,</line>
      <line>Third-winter’d in that dreadful dock,</line>
      <line>With stiffen’d cordage, sails decay’d,</line>
      <line>And crew that care for calm and shock</line>
      <line>Alike, too dull to be dismay’d,</line>
      <line>Yet, if I come where ladies are,</line>
      <line>How sad soever I was before,</line>
      <line>Then is my sadness banish’d far,</line>
      <line>And I am like that ship no more;</line>
      <line>Or like that ship if the ice-field splits,</line>
      <line>Burst by the sudden polar Spring,</line>
      <line>And all thank God with their warming wits,</line>
      <line>And kiss each other and dance and sing,</line>
      <line>And hoist fresh sails, that make the breeze</line>
      <line>Blow them along the liquid sea,</line>
      <line>Out of the North, where life did freeze,</line>
      <line>Into the haven where they would be.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>The Kiss</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I saw you take his kiss!’ ‘’Tis true.’</line>
      <line>‘O, modesty!’ "Twas strictly kept:</line>
      <line>‘He thought me asleep; at least, I knew</line>
      <line>‘He thought I thought he thought I slept.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1850</date>
    <title>Constancy rewarded</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I vow’d unvarying faith, and she,</line>
      <line>To whom in full I pay that vow,</line>
      <line>Rewards me with variety</line>
      <line>Which men who change can never know.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Rosy Bosom’d Hours</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A florin to the willing Guard</line>
      <line>Secured, for half the way,</line>
      <line>(He lock’d us in, ah, lucky-starr’d,)</line>
      <line>A curtain’d, front coupe.</line>
      <line>The sparkling sun of August shone;</line>
      <line>The wind was in the West;</line>
      <line>Your gown and all that you had on</line>
      <line>Was what became you best;</line>
      <line>And we were in that seldom mood</line>
      <line>When soul with soul agrees,</line>
      <line>Mingling, like flood with equal flood,</line>
      <line>In agitated ease.</line>
      <line>Far round, each blade of harvest bare</line>
      <line>Its little load of bread;</line>
      <line>Each furlong of that journey fair</line>
      <line>With separate sweetness sped.</line>
      <line>The calm of use was coming o’er</line>
      <line>The wonder of our wealth,</line>
      <line>And now, maybe, ’twas not much more</line>
      <line>Than Eden’s common health.</line>
      <line>We paced the sunny platform, while</line>
      <line>The train at Havant changed:</line>
      <line>What made the people kindly smile,</line>
      <line>Or stare with looks estranged?</line>
      <line>Too radiant for a wife you seem’d,</line>
      <line>Serener than a bride;</line>
      <line>Me happiest born of men I deem’d,</line>
      <line>And show’d perchance my pride.</line>
      <line>I loved that girl, so gaunt and tall,</line>
      <line>Who whispered loud, ‘Sweet Thing!’</line>
      <line>Scanning your figure, slight yet all</line>
      <line>Round as your own gold ring.</line>
      <line>At Salisbury you stray’d alone</line>
      <line>Within the shafted glooms,</line>
      <line>Whilst 1 was by the Verger shown</line>
      <line>The brasses and the tombs.</line>
      <line>At tea we talk’d of matters deep,</line>
      <line>Of joy that never dies;</line>
      <line>We laugh’d, till love was mix’d with sleep</line>
      <line>Within your great sweet eyes.</line>
      <line>The next day, sweet with luck no less</line>
      <line>And sense of sweetness past,</line>
      <line>The full tide of our happiness</line>
      <line>Rose higher than the last.</line>
      <line>At Dawlish, ’mid the pools of brine,</line>
      <line>You stept from rock to rock,</line>
      <line>One hand quick tightening upon mine,</line>
      <line>One holding up your frock.</line>
      <line>On starfish and on weeds alone</line>
      <line>You seem’d intent to be:</line>
      <line>Flash’d those great gleams of hope unknown</line>
      <line>From you, or from the sea?</line>
      <line>Ne’er came before, ah, when again</line>
      <line>Shall come two days like these:</line>
      <line>Such quick delight within the brain,</line>
      <line>Within the heart such peace?</line>
      <line>I thought, indeed, by magic chance,</line>
      <line>A third from Heaven to win,</line>
      <line>But as, at dusk, we reach’d Penzance,</line>
      <line>A drizzling rain set in.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Toys</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My little Son, who look’d from thoughtful eyes</line>
      <line>And moved and spoke in quiet grown-up wise,</line>
      <line>Having my law the seventh time disobey’d,</line>
      <line>I struck him, and dismiss’d</line>
      <line>With hard words and unkiss’d,</line>
      <line>His Mother, who was patient, being dead.</line>
      <line>Then, fearing lest his grief should hinder sleep,</line>
      <line>I visited his bed,</line>
      <line>But found him slumbering deep,</line>
      <line>With darken’d eyelids, and their lashes yet</line>
      <line>From his late sobbing wet.</line>
      <line>And I, with moan,</line>
      <line>Kissing away his tears, left others of my own;</line>
      <line>For, on a table drawn beside his head,</line>
      <line>He had put, within his reach,</line>
      <line>A box of counters and a red-vein’d stone,</line>
      <line>A piece of glass abraded by the beach</line>
      <line>And six or seven shells,</line>
      <line>A bottle with bluebells</line>
      <line>And two French copper coins, ranged there with careful art,</line>
      <line>To comfort his sad heart.</line>
      <line>So when that night I pray’d</line>
      <line>To God, I wept, and said:</line>
      <line>Ah, when at last we lie with tranced breath,</line>
      <line>Not vexing Thee in death,</line>
      <line>And Thou rememberest of what toys</line>
      <line>We made our joys,</line>
      <line>How weakly understood,</line>
      <line>Thy great commanded good,</line>
      <line>Then, fatherly not less</line>
      <line>Than I whom Thou hast moulded from the clay,</line>
      <line>Thou’It leave Thy wrath, and say,</line>
      <line>‘I will be sorry for their childishness.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>Magna est Veritas</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here, in this little Bay,</line>
      <line>Full of tumultuous life and great repose,</line>
      <line>Where, twice a day,</line>
      <line>The purposeless, glad ocean comes and goes,</line>
      <line>Under high cliffs, and far from the huge town,</line>
      <line>I sit me down.</line>
      <line>For want of me the world’s course will not fail:</line>
      <line>When all its work is done, the lie shall rot;</line>
      <line>The truth is great, and shall prevail,</line>
      <line>When none cares whether it prevail or not.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Coventry Patmore</author>
    <date>1878</date>
    <title>Arbor Vitae</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With honeysuckle, over-sweet, festoon’d;</line>
      <line>With bitter ivy bound;</line>
      <line>Terraced with funguses unsound;</line>
      <line>Deform’d with many a boss</line>
      <line>And closed scar, o’ercushion’d deep with moss;</line>
      <line>Bunch’d all about with pagan mistletoe;</line>
      <line>And thick with nests of the hoarse bird</line>
      <line>That talks, but understands not his own word;</line>
      <line>Stands, and so stood a thousand years ago,</line>
      <line>A single tree.</line>
      <line>Thunder has done its worst among its twigs,</line>
      <line>Where the great crest yet blackens, never pruned,</line>
      <line>But in its heart, alway</line>
      <line>Ready to push new verdurous boughs, whene’er</line>
      <line>The rotting saplings near it fall and leave it air,</line>
      <line>Is all antiquity and no decay.</line>
      <line>Rich, though rejected by the forest-pigs,</line>
      <line>Its fruit, beneath whose rough, concealing rind</line>
      <line>They that will break it find</line>
      <line>Heart-succouring savour of each several meat,</line>
      <line>And kernell’d drink of brain-renewing power,</line>
      <line>With bitter condiment and sour,</line>
      <line>And sweet economy of sweet,</line>
      <line>And odours that remind</line>
      <line>Of haunts of childhood and a different day.</line>
      <line>Beside this tree,</line>
      <line>Praising no Gods nor blaming, sans a wish,</line>
      <line>Sits, Tartar-like, the Time’s civility,</line>
      <line>And eats its dead-dog off a golden dish.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ernest Jones</author>
    <date>1852</date>
    <title>The Song of the Low</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We’re low—we’re low—we’re very very low,</line>
      <line>As low as low can be;</line>
      <line>The rich are high—for we make them so—</line>
      <line>And a miserable lot are we!</line>
      <line>And a miserable lot are we! are we!</line>
      <line>And a miserable lot are we!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We plough and sow—we’re so very very low,</line>
      <line>That we delve in the dirty clay,</line>
      <line>Till we bless the plain with the golden grain,</line>
      <line>And the vale with the fragrant hay.</line>
      <line>Our place we know—we’re so very' low,</line>
      <line>’Tis down at the landlords’ feet:</line>
      <line>We’re not too low—the bread to grow,</line>
      <line>But too low the bread to eat.</line>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low, etc.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down, down we go—we’re so very very low,</line>
      <line>To the hell of the deep sunk mines.</line>
      <line>But we gather the proudest gems that glow,</line>
      <line>When the crown of a despot shines;</line>
      <line>And whenever he lacks—upon our backs</line>
      <line>Fresh loads he deigns to lay,</line>
      <line>We’re far too low to vote the tax,</line>
      <line>But not too low to pay.</line>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low, etc.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low—mere rabble, we know,</line>
      <line>But at our plastic power,</line>
      <line>The mould at the lordling’s feet will grow</line>
      <line>Into palace and church and tower—</line>
      <line>Then prostrate fall—in the rich man’s hall,</line>
      <line>And cringe at the rich man’s door,</line>
      <line>We’re not too low to build the wall,</line>
      <line>But too low to tread the floor.</line>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low, etc.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low—we’re very very low,</line>
      <line>Yet from our fingers glide</line>
      <line>The silken flow—and the robes that glow,</line>
      <line>Round the limbs of the sons of pride.</line>
      <line>And what we get—and what we give,</line>
      <line>We know—and we know our share.</line>
      <line>We’re not too low the cloth to weave—</line>
      <line>But too low the cloth to wear.</line>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low, etc.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low—we’re very very low,</line>
      <line>And yet when the trumpets ring,</line>
      <line>The thrust of a poor man’s arm will go</line>
      <line>Through the heart of the proudest king!</line>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low—our place we know,</line>
      <line>We’re only the rank and file,</line>
      <line>We’re not too low—to kill the foe,</line>
      <line>But too low to touch the spoil.</line>
      <line>We’re low, we’re low, etc.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Makepeace Thackeray</author>
    <date>1853</date>
    <title>Sorrows of Werther</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Werther had a love for Charlotte</line>
      <line>Such as words could never utter;</line>
      <line>Would you know how first he met her?</line>
      <line>She was cutting bread-and-butter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Charlotte was a married lady,</line>
      <line>And a moral man was Werther,</line>
      <line>And, for all the wealth of Indies,</line>
      <line>Would do nothing for to hurt her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So he sighed and pined and ogled,</line>
      <line>And his passion boiled and bubbled,</line>
      <line>Till he blew his silly brains out,</line>
      <line>And no more was by it troubled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Charlotte, having seen his body</line>
      <line>Borne before her on a shutter,</line>
      <line>Like a well-conducted person,</line>
      <line>Went on cutting bread-and-butter.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Out of the Frying Pan into the Fire</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I DREAMT one night—it was a horrid dream—</line>
      <line>That I was dead, and made was the division</line>
      <line>Between the innocent flesh and guilty spirit,</line>
      <line>And that the former, with a white sheet wrapt round</line>
