      <line>And nailed up in a box, was to the bottom</line>
      <line>Sunk of a deep and narrow pit, which straight</line>
      <line>Was filled to overheaping with a mixture</line>
      <line>Of damp clay, rotting flesh and mouldering bones,</line>
      <line>And lidded with a weighty stone whereon</line>
      <line>Was writ my name and on what days precise</line>
      <line>I first and last drew breath; while up the latter</line>
      <line>Flew, without help of wings or fins or members,</line>
      <line>By its mere lightness, through the air, to heaven;</line>
      <line>And there being placed before the judgment-seat</line>
      <line>Of its Maker, and most unsatisfactory</line>
      <line>Answer returning to the question:—‘Wherefore</line>
      <line>Wast thou as I made thee?’ was sent down</line>
      <line>Tumbling by its own weight, down down to Hell,</line>
      <line>To sink or swim or wade as best it might,</line>
      <line>In sulphurous fires unquenchable for ever,</line>
      <line>With Socrates and Plato, Aristides</line>
      <line>Falsely surnamed the just, and Zoroaster,</line>
      <line>Titus the good, and Cato and divine</line>
      <line>Homer and Virgil, and so many millions</line>
      <line>And millions more of wrongfully called good</line>
      <line>And wise and virtuous, that for want of sulphur</line>
      <line>And fire and snakes and instruments of torture</line>
      <line>And room in Hell, the Universal Maker</line>
      <line>Was by his own inherent justice forced,</line>
      <line>That guilt might not go scot-free and unpunished,</line>
      <line>To set apart so large a share of Heaven</line>
      <line>For penal colonies and jails and treadmills,</line>
      <line>That mutinies for want of flying-space</line>
      <line>Began t’ arise among the cherubim</line>
      <line>And blessed spirits, and a Proclamation</line>
      <line>Of Martial Law in Heaven was just being read</line>
      <line>When, in a sweat of agony and fear,</line>
      <line>I woke, and found myself in Germany,</line>
      <line>In the close prison of a German bed,</line>
      <line>And at my bedside Mr Oberkellner</line>
      <line>With printed list of questions in his hand:</line>
      <line>My name and age and birthplace and religion,</line>
      <line>Trade or profession, wherefore I had come,</line>
      <line>How long to stay, whither next bound, and so forth;</line>
      <line>All at my peril to be truly answered,</line>
      <line>And upon each a sixpence to the State,</line>
      <line>Which duly paid I should obtain permission</line>
      <line>To stay where I was so long as the State pleased,</line>
      <line>Without being prosecuted as a felon,</line>
      <line>Spy, or disturber of the public peace.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Pain</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Pain, who made thee?’ thus I said once</line>
      <line>To the grim unpitying monster,</line>
      <line>As, one sleepless night, I watched him</line>
      <line>Heating in the fire his pincers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘God Almighty; who dare doubt it?’</line>
      <line>With a hideous grin he answered:</line>
      <line>‘I’m his eldest best-beloved son,</line>
      <line>Cut from my dead mother’s bowels.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Wretch, thou liest;’ shocked and shuddering</line>
      <line>To the monster I replied then;</line>
      <line>‘God is good, and kind, and gracious;</line>
      <line>Never made a thing so ugly.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Tell me then, since thou know’st better,</line>
      <line>Whose 1 am, by whom begotten;’</line>
      <line>‘Hell’s thy birth-place, and the Devil</line>
      <line>Both thy father and thy mother.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Be it so; to me the same ’tis</line>
      <line>Whether I’m God’s son or grandson,</line>
      <line>And to thee not great the difference</line>
      <line>Once thy flesh between my tongs is.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Spare me, spare me, Pain;’ I shrieked out,</line>
      <line>As the red-hot pincers caught me;</line>
      <line>‘Thou art God’s son; aye thou ’rt God’s self;</line>
      <line>Only take thy fingers off me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Old Man</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>At six years old I had before mine eyes</line>
      <line>A picture painted, like the rainbow, bright,</line>
      <line>But far, far off in th’ unapproachable distance.</line>
      <line>With all my childish heart I longed to reach it,</line>
      <line>And strove and strove the livelong day in vain,</line>
      <line>Advancing with slow step some few short yards</line>
      <line>But not perceptibly the distance lessening.</line>
      <line>At threescore years old, when almost within</line>
      <line>Grasp of my outstretched arms the selfsame picture</line>
      <line>With all its beauteous colors painted bright,</line>
      <line>I’m backward from it further borne each day</line>
      <line>By an invisible, compulsive force,</line>
      <line>Gradual but yet so steady, sure, and rapid,</line>
      <line>That at threescore and ten I’ll from the picture</line>
      <line>Be even more distant than I was at six.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Very Old Man</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I well remember how some threescore years</line>
      <line>And ten ago, a helpless babe, I toddled</line>
      <line>From chair to chair about my mother’s chamber,</line>
      <line>Feeling, as ’twere, my way in the new world</line>
      <line>And foolishly afraid of, or, as’t might be,</line>
      <line>Foolishly pleased with, th’ unknown objects round me.</line>
      <line>And now with stiffened joints I sit all day</line>
      <line>In one of those same chairs, as foolishly</line>
      <line>Hoping or fearing something from me hid</line>
      <line>Behind the thick, dark veil which I see hourly</line>
      <line>And minutely on every side round closing</line>
      <line>And from my view all objects shutting out.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Another and another and another</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Another and another and another</line>
      <line>And still another sunset and sunrise,</line>
      <line>The same yet different, different yet the same,</line>
      <line>Seen by me now in my declining years</line>
      <line>As in my early childhood, youth and manhood;</line>
      <line>And by my parents and my parents’ parents,</line>
      <line>And by the parents of my parents’ parents,</line>
      <line>And by their parents counted back for ever,</line>
      <line>Seen, all their lives long, even as now by me;</line>
      <line>And by my children and my children’s children</line>
      <line>And by the children of my children’s children</line>
      <line>And by their children counted on for ever</line>
      <line>Still to be seen as even now seen by me;</line>
      <line>Clear and bright sometimes, sometimes dark and clouded</line>
      <line>But still the same sunsetting and sunrise;</line>
      <line>The same for ever to the never ending</line>
      <line>Line of observers, to the same observer</line>
      <line>Through all the changes of his life the same:</line>
      <line>Sunsetting and sunrising and sunsetting,</line>
      <line>And then again sunrising and sunsetting,</line>
      <line>Sunrising and sunsetting evermore.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>My Stearine Candles</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He’s gone to bed at last, that flaring, glaring,</line>
      <line>Round, red-faced, bold, monopolizing Sun,</line>
      <line>And I may venture from their hiding-place</line>
      <line>To bring my pair of stearine candles forth</line>
      <line>And set them, firmly stayed, upon my table,</line>
      <line>To illuminate and cheer my studious evening.</line>
      <line>Thou hast my praise, Prometheus, for thy theft,</line>
      <line>And, were I to idolatry addicted,</line>
      <line>Shouldst be my God in preference to Buddh,</line>
      <line>Brahma, or Thor, or Odin, or Jove’s self.</line>
      <line>Her of the olive branch I’d hold to thee</line>
      <line>The next in honor, and before her shrine</line>
      <line>In gratitude would keep for ever burning</line>
      <line>A lamp of such Athenian oil as Plato,</line>
      <line>Demosthenes, Pythagoras, and Solon</line>
      <line>Were wont in bed to read by, after midnight.</line>
      <line>The third, last person of my Trinity</line>
      <line>Should be th’ inventor of the stearine candle;</line>
      <line>He that enabled me to sit, the long</line>
      <line>Midwinter nights, in study, by a light</line>
      <line>Which neither flickers nor offends the nostrils,</line>
      <line>Nor from the distance of a thousand miles,</line>
      <line>Or thousand years, or both perhaps, keeps ever</line>
      <line>And anon calling me—like some bold child</line>
      <line>The mother’s hand—to come and snuff and snub it;</line>
      <line>But steady, cleanly, bright and inodorous,</line>
      <line>Than tallow more humane, than wax less costly,</line>
      <line>Gives me just what I want, and asks back nothing.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>Once on a time</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Once on a time a thousand different men</line>
      <line>Together knelt before as many Gods</line>
      <line>Each from the other different as themselves</line>
      <line>Were different each from each, yet didn’t fall out,</line>
      <line>Or cut each others’ throats amidst their prayers—</line>
      <line>‘Stop there! that never happened, or, if it did,</line>
      <line>’Twas by a miracle; or if it happened</line>
      <line>Really and in the way of nature, tell me</line>
      <line>How, where, and when, what kind of men they were,</line>
      <line>What kind of Gods—didn’t even the Gods fall out?’</line>
      <line>Not even the Gods; I’ll tell thee how it was;</line>
      <line>But art thou trusty? canst thou keep the secret?</line>
      <line>‘Yes yes.’ Then in thine ear: the thousand Gods</line>
      <line>Had all the selfsame name; so every God,</line>
      <line>Hearing no name invoked except his own,</line>
      <line>Believed that every man of all the thousand</line>
      <line>Worshipped him only; while each one of all</line>
      <line>The thousand worshippers, hearing no name</line>
      <line>Except his own God’s name invoked, believed</line>
      <line>That every one of all the whole nine hundred</line>
      <line>Ninety and nine worshipped no God but his;</line>
      <line>So all the thousand men together lived</line>
      <line>In love and peace, as holding the same faith,</line>
      <line>And of the thousand Gods not one was jealous.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry James</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Two hundred men and eighteen killed</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Two hundred men and eighteen killed</line>
      <line>For want of a second door!</line>
      <line>Ay, for with two doors, each ton coal</line>
      <line>Had cost one penny more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And what is it else makes England great,</line>
      <line>At home, by land, by sea,</line>
      <line>But her cheap coal, and eye’s tail turned</line>
      <line>Toward strict economy?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But if a slate falls off the roof</line>
      <line>And kills a passer-by,</line>
      <line>Or if a doctor’s dose too strong</line>
      <line>Makes some half-dead man die,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We have coroners and deodands</line>
      <line>And inquests, to no end,</line>
      <line>And every honest Englishman’s</line>
      <line>The hapless sufferer’s friend,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And householder’s or doctor’s foe,</line>
      <line>For he has nought to lose,</line>
      <line>And fain will, if he can, keep out</line>
      <line>Of that poor dead man’s shoes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But if of twice a hundred men,</line>
      <line>And eighteen more, the breath</line>
      <line>Is stopped at once in a coal pit,</line>
      <line>It’s quite a natural death;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For, God be praised! the chance is small</line>
      <line>That either you or I</line>
      <line>Should come, for want of a second door,</line>
      <line>In a coal pit to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Besides, ’twould cost a thousand times</line>
      <line>As much, or something more,</line>
      <line>To make to every pit of coal</line>
      <line>A second, or safety door,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As all the shrouds and coffins cost</line>
      <line>For those who perish now</line>
      <line>For want of a second door, and that’s</line>
      <line>No trifle, you’ll allow;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And trade must live, though now and then</line>
      <line>A man or two may die;</line>
      <line>So merry sing ‘God bless the Queen,’</line>
      <line>And long live you and I;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, Jenny, let each widow have</line>
      <line>A cup of congo strong,</line>
      <line>And every orphan half a cup,</line>
      <line>And so I end my song,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With prayer to God to keep coal cheap,</line>
      <line>Both cheap and plenty too,</line>
      <line>And if the pit’s a whole mile deep,</line>
      <line>What is it to me or you?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For though we’re mortal too, no doubt,</line>
      <line>And Death for us his sithe</line>
      <line>Has ready still, the chance is small</line>
      <line>We ever die of stithe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if we do, our gracious Queen</line>
      <line>Will, sure, a telegram send,</line>
      <line>To say how sore she grieves for us</line>
      <line>And our untimely end;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And out of her own privy purse</line>
      <line>A sovereign down will pay,</line>
      <line>To have us decently interred</line>
      <line>And put out of the way;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And burial service shall for us</line>
      <line>In the churchyard be read,</line>
      <line>And more bells rung and more hymns sung</line>
      <line>Than if we had died in bed:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For such an accident as this</line>
      <line>May never occur again,</line>
      <line>And till it does, one door’s enough</line>
      <line>For pumps, air, coal, and men;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And should it occur—which God forbid!—</line>
      <line>And stifle every soul,</line>
      <line>Remember well, good Christians all,</line>
      <line>Not one whit worse the coal.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Bell Scott</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>A Rhyme of the Sun-Dial</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dial is dark, ’tis but half-past one:</line>
      <line>But the crow is abroad, and the day’s begun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dial is dim, ’tis but half-past two:</line>
      <line>Fit the small foot with its neat first shoe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The light gains fast, it is half-past three:</line>
      <line>Now the blossom appears all over the tree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The gnomon tells it is but half-past four:</line>
      <line>Shut upon him the old school-door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun is strong, it is half-past five:</line>
      <line>Through this and through that let him hustle and strive.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ha, thunder and rain! it is half-past six:</line>
      <line>Hither and thither, go, wander and fix.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shadows are sharp, it is half-past seven:</line>
      <line>The Titan dares to scale even heaven!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The rain soon dries, it is half-past eight:</line>
      <line>Time faster flies, but it is not late!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sky now is clear, it is half-past nine:</line>
      <line>Draw all the threads and make them entwine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Clearer and calmer, ’tis half-past ten:</line>
      <line>Count we the gains? not yet: try again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shadows lengthen, half-past eleven:</line>
      <line>He looks back, alas! let the man be shriven!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mist falls cold, it is half-past twelve:</line>
      <line>Hark, the bell tolls! up, sexton and delve!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Bell Scott</author>
    <date>1854</date>
    <title>Death</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am the one whose thought</line>
      <line>Is as the deed; I have no brother, and</line>
      <line>No father; years</line>
      <line>Have never seen my power begin. A chain</line>
      <line>Doth bind all things to me. In my hand, man,—</line>
      <line>Infinite thinker,—vanishes as doth</line>
      <line>The worm that he creates, as doth the moth</line>
      <line>That it creates, as doth the limb minute</line>
      <line>That stirs upon that moth. My being is</line>
      <line>Inborn with all things, and</line>
      <line>With all things doth expand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But fear me not; I am</line>
      <line>The hoary dust, the shut ear, the profound,</line>
      <line>The deep of night,</line>
      <line>When Nature’s universal heart doth cease</line>
      <line>To beat; communicating nothing; dark</line>
      <line>And tongueless, negative of all things. Yet</line>
      <line>Fear me not, man; I am the blood that flows</line>
      <line>Within thee,—I am change; and it is I</line>
      <line>Creates a joy within thee, when thou feel’st</line>
      <line>Manhood and new untried superior powers</line>
      <line>Rising before thee: I it is can make</line>
      <line>Old things give place</line>
      <line>To thy free race.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All things are born for me.</line>
      <line>His father and his mother,—yet man hates</line>
      <line>Me foolishly.</line>
      <line>An easy spirit and a free lives on,</line>
      <line>But he who fears the ice doth stumble. Walk</line>
      <line>Straight onward peacefully,—I am a friend</line>
      <line>Will pass thee graciously: but grudge and weep</line>
      <line>And cark,—I’ll be a cold chain round thy neck</line>
      <line>Into the grave, each day a link drawn in,</line>
      <line>Untill thy face shall be upon the turf,</line>
      <line>And the hair from thy crown</line>
      <line>Be blown like thistle-down.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Bell Scott</author>
    <date>1875</date>
    <title>The Witch's Ballad</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O, I hae come from far away,</line>
      <line>From a warm land far away,</line>
      <line>A southern land across the sea,</line>
      <line>With sailor-lads about the mast,</line>
      <line>Merry and canny, and kind to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I hae been to yon town,</line>
      <line>To try my luck in yon town;</line>
      <line>Nort, and Mysie, Elspie too.</line>
      <line>Right braw we were to pass the gate,</line>
      <line>Wi’ gowden clasps on girdles blue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mysie smiled wi’ miminy mouth,</line>
      <line>Innocent mouth, miminy mouth;</line>
      <line>Elspie wore her scarlet gown,</line>
      <line>Nort’s grey eyes were unco’ gleg,</line>
      <line>My Castile comb was like a crown.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We walked abreast all up the street,</line>
      <line>Into the market up the street;</line>
      <line>Our hair with marygolds was wound,</line>
      <line>Our bodices with love-knots laced,</line>
      <line>Our merchandise with tansy bound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nort had chickens, I had cocks,</line>
      <line>Gamesome cocks, loud-crowing cocks;</line>
      <line>Mysie ducks, and Elspie drakes,—</line>
      <line>For a wee groat or a pound:</line>
      <line>We lost nae time wi’ gives and takes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lost nae time, for well we knew,</line>
      <line>In our sleeves full well we knew,</line>
      <line>When the gloaming came that night,</line>
      <line>Duck nor drake nor hen nor cock</line>
      <line>Would be found by candle-light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when our chaffering all was done,</line>
      <line>All was paid for, sold and done,</line>
      <line>We drew a glove on ilka hand,</line>
      <line>We sweetly curtsied each to each,</line>
      <line>And deftly danced a saraband.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The market lasses looked and laughed,</line>
      <line>Left their gear and looked and laughed;</line>
      <line>They made as they would join the game,</line>
      <line>But soon their mithers, wild and wud,</line>
      <line>With whack and screech they stopped the same.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sae loud the tongues o’ randies grew,</line>
      <line>The flitin’ and the skirlin’ grew,</line>
      <line>At all the windows in the place,</line>
      <line>Wi’ spoons or knives, wi’ needle or awl,</line>
      <line>Was thrust out every hand and face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And down each stair they thronged anon,</line>
      <line>Gentle, semple, thronged anon;</line>
      <line>Souter and tailor, frowsy Nan,</line>
      <line>The ancient widow young again,</line>
      <line>Simpering behind her fan.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Without a choice, against their will,</line>
      <line>Doited, dazed, against their will,</line>
      <line>The market lassie and her mither,</line>
      <line>The farmer and his husbandman,</line>
      <line>Hand in hand dance a’ thegether.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Slow at first, but faster soon,</line>
      <line>Still increasing wild and fast,</line>
      <line>Hoods and mantles, hats and hose,</line>
      <line>Blindly doffed and cast away,</line>
      <line>Left them naked, heads and toes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They would have torn us limb from limb,</line>
      <line>Dainty limb from dainty limb;</line>
      <line>But never one of them could win</line>
      <line>Across the line that I had drawn</line>
      <line>With bleeding thumb a-widdershin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But there was Jeff the provost’s son,</line>
      <line>Jeff the provost’s only son;</line>
      <line>There was Father Auld himsel’,</line>
      <line>The Lombard frae the hostelry,</line>
      <line>And the lawyer Peter Fell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All goodly men we singled out,</line>
      <line>Waled them well, and singled out,</line>
      <line>And drew them by the left hand in;</line>
      <line>Mysie the priest, and Elspie won</line>
      <line>The Lombard, Nort the lawyer carle,</line>
      <line>I mysel’ the provost’s son.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, with cantrip kisses seven,</line>
      <line>Three times round with kisses seven,</line>
      <line>Warped and woven there spun we,</line>
      <line>Arms and legs and flaming hair,</line>
      <line>Like a whirlwind on the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like the wind that sucks the sea,</line>
      <line>Over and in and on the sea,</line>
      <line>Good sooth it was a mad delight;</line>
      <line>And every man of all the four</line>
      <line>Shut his eyes and laughed outright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laughed as long as they had breath,</line>
      <line>Laughed while they had sense or breath</line>
      <line>And close about us coiled a mist</line>
      <line>Of gnats and midges, wasps and flies,</line>
      <line>Like the whirlwind shaft it rist.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Drawn up I was right off my feet,</line>
      <line>Into the mist and off my feet;</line>
      <line>And, dancing on each chimney-top,</line>
      <line>I saw a thousand darling imps</line>
      <line>Keeping time with skip and hop.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And on the provost’s brave ridge-tile,</line>
      <line>On the provost’s grand ridge-tile,</line>
      <line>The Blackamoor first to master me</line>
      <line>I saw,—I saw that winsome smile,</line>
      <line>The mouth that did my heart beguile,</line>
      <line>And spoke the great Word over me,</line>
      <line>In the land beyond the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I called his name, I called aloud,</line>
      <line>Alas! I called on him aloud;</line>
      <line>And then he filled his hand with stour,</line>
      <line>And threw it towards me in the air;</line>
      <line>My mouse flew out, I lost my pow’r!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My lusty strength, my power, were gone;</line>
      <line>Power was gone, and all was gone.</line>
      <line>He will not let me love him more!</line>
      <line>Of bell and whip and horse’s tail</line>
      <line>He cares not if I find a store.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But I am proud if he is fierce!</line>
      <line>I am as proud as he is fierce;</line>
      <line>I’ll turn about and backward go,</line>
      <line>If I meet again that Blackamoor,</line>
      <line>And he’ll help us then, for he shall know</line>
      <line>I seek another paramour.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And we’ll gang once more to yon town,</line>
      <line>Wi’ better luck to yon town;</line>
      <line>We’ll walk in silk and cramoisie,</line>
      <line>And I shall wed the provost’s son;</line>
      <line>My-lady of the town I’ll be!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For I was born a crowned king’s child,</line>
      <line>Born and nursed a king’s child,</line>
      <line>King 0’ a land ayont the sea,</line>
      <line>Where the Blackamoor kissed me first,</line>
      <line>And taught me art and glamourie.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each one in her wame shall hide</line>
      <line>Her hairy mouse, her wary mouse,</line>
      <line>Fed on madwort and agramie,—</line>
      <line>Wear amber beads between her breasts,</line>
      <line>And blind-worm’s skin about her knee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Lombard shall be Elspie’s man,</line>
      <line>Elspie’s gowden husband-man;</line>
      <line>Nort shall take the lawyer’s hand;</line>
      <line>The priest shall swear another vow:</line>
      <line>We’ll dance again the saraband!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Bell Scott</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>Music</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Listless the silent ladies sit</line>
      <line>About the room so gaily lit;</line>
      <line>Madame Ions likes the cups or ray,</line>
      <line>But thinks it scarce enough to say:</line>
      <line>Mistress Cox is gone astray</line>
      <line>To the night-light in her own nursery,</line>
      <line>Wonders if little Maude was led</line>
      <line>Without long coaxing into bed:</line>
      <line>Miss Jemima Applewhite,</line>
      <line>On a low stool by the fire,</line>
      <line>Concentrates her confused desire,—</line>
      <line>Perhaps will do so all the night,</line>
      <line>On an unused rhyme for ‘scan,’</line>
      <line>And can but find the stiff word man:</line>
      <line>Miss Temple pets the little hound,</line>
      <line>That has a tendency to whine,</line>
      <line>To-night its cushion can’t be found;</line>
      <line>And wonders when they’ll leave the wine</line>
      <line>Few take, but which men still combine</line>
      <line>To linger over when they dine.</line>
      <line>Indeed a frightful interval!</line>
      <line>Madame Ions wants her game,</line>
      <line>Or she must have her usual wink;</line>
      <line>But now satiric Bertha Stahl</line>
      <line>Jumps upon the music-stool,</line>
      <line>And breaks into a sportive flame;</line>
      <line>But what of all things do you think</line>
      <line>She plays, that laughter-loving fool?</line>
      <line>The funeral march, Dead March of Saul!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, Lord of Hosts! their mailed tread,</line>
      <line>Bearing along the mailed dead,</line>
      <line>Makes me bow my stubborn head.</line>
      <line>Never underneath the sun</line>
      <line>With this heart-fathoming march be done;</line>
      <line>Still, Lord of Hosts! to Thee we cry,</line>
      <line>When our great ones, loved ones, die,</line>
      <line>Still some grand lament we crave,</line>
      <line>When we descend into the grave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I turn, afraid that I may weep,—</line>
      <line>Jemima’s pestered wits still ran</line>
      <line>After the unused rhyme for ‘scan,’</line>
      <line>Dear old Ions was asleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Mortimer Collins</author>
    <date>1855</date>
    <title>Lotos Eating</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who would care to pass his life away</line>
      <line>Of the Lotos-land a dreamful denizen—</line>
      <line>Lotos-islands in a waveless bay,</line>
      <line>Sung by Alfred Tennyson?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who would care to be a dull new-comer</line>
      <line>Far across the wild sea’s wide abysses,</line>
      <line>Where, about the earth’s 3000th summer</line>
      <line>Passed divine Ulysses?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rather give me coffee, art, a book,</line>
      <line>From my windows a delicious sea-view,</line>
      <line>Southdown mutton, somebody to cook—</line>
      <line>‘Music?’ I believe you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Strawberry icebergs in the summer time—</line>
      <line>But of elmwood many a massive splinter,</line>
      <line>Good ghost stories, and a classic rhyme,</line>
      <line>For the nights of winter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now and then a friend and some sauterne,</line>
      <line>Now and then a haunch of Highland venison:</line>
      <line>And for Lotos-lands I’ll never yearn</line>
      <line>Maugre Alfred Tennyson.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Mortimer Collins</author>
    <date>1875</date>
    <title>To F. C.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fast falls the snow, O lady mine,</line>
      <line>Sprinkling the lawn with crystals fine,</line>
      <line>But by the gods we won’t repine</line>
      <line>While we’re together,</line>
      <line>We’ll chat and rhyme and kiss and dine,</line>
      <line>Defying weather.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So stir the fire and pour the wine,</line>
      <line>And let those sea-green eyes divine</line>
      <line>Pour their love-madness into mine:</line>
      <line>I don’t care whether</line>
      <line>’Tis snow or sun or rain or shine</line>
      <line>If we’re together.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Shirley Brooks</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>Poem by a Perfectly Furious Academician</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I takes and paints,</line>
      <line>Hears no complaints,</line>
      <line>And sells before I’m dry;</line>
      <line>Till savage Ruskin</line>
      <line>He sticks his tusk in,</line>
      <line>Then nobody will buy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Edward FitzGerald</author>
    <date>1856</date>
    <title>Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Awake! for Morning in the Bowl of Night</line>
      <line>Has flung the Stone that puts the Stars to Flight:</line>
      <line>And Lo! the Hunter of the East has caught</line>
      <line>The Sultan’s Turret in a Noose of Light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dreaming when Dawn’s Left Hand was in the Sky</line>
      <line>I heard a Voice within the Tavern cry,</line>
      <line>‘Awake, my Little ones, and fill the Cup</line>
      <line>‘Before Life’s Liquor in its Cup be dry.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, as the Cock crew, those who stood before</line>
      <line>The Tavern shouted—‘Open then the Door!</line>
      <line>‘You know how little while we have to stay,</line>
      <line>‘And, once departed, may return no more.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now the New Year reviving old Desires,</line>
      <line>The thoughtful Soul to Solitude retires,</line>
      <line>Where the White Hand of Moses on the Bough</line>
      <line>Puts out, and Jesus from the Ground suspires.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Iram indeed is gone with all its Rose,</line>
      <line>And Jamshyd’s Sev’n-ring’d Cup where no one knows;</line>
      <line>But still the Vine her ancient Ruby yields,</line>
      <line>And still a Garden by the Water blows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And David’s Lips are lock’t; but in divine</line>
      <line>High piping Pehlevi, with ‘Wine! Wine! Wine!</line>
      <line>‘Red Wine!’—the Nightingale cries to the Rose</line>
      <line>That yellow Cheek of her’s to’incarnadine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come, fill the Cup, and in the Fire of Spring</line>
      <line>The Winter Garment of Repentance fling:</line>
      <line>The Bird of Time has but a little way</line>
      <line>To fly—and Lo! the Bird is on the Wing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And look—a thousand Blossoms with the Day</line>
      <line>Woke—and a thousand scatter’d into Clay;</line>
      <line>And this first Summer Month that brings the Rose</line>
      <line>Shall take Jamshyd and Kaikobad away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But come with old Khayyam, and leave the Lot</line>
      <line>Of Kaikobad and Kaikhosru forgot:</line>
      <line>Let Rustum lay about him as he will,</line>
      <line>Or Hatim Tai cry Supper—heed them not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With me along some Strip of Herbage strown</line>
      <line>That just divides the desert from the sown,</line>
      <line>Where name of Slave and Sultan scarce is known,</line>
      <line>And pity Sultan Mahmud on his Throne.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here with a Loaf of Bread beneath the Bough,</line>
      <line>A Flask of Wine, a Book of Verse—and Thou</line>
      <line>Beside me singing in the Wilderness—</line>
      <line>And Wilderness is Paradise enow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How sweet is mortal Sovranty!’—think some:</line>
      <line>Others—‘How blest the Paradise to come!’</line>
      <line>Ah, take the Cash in hand and waive the Rest;</line>
      <line>Oh, the brave Music of a distant Drum!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look to the Rose that blows about us—‘Lo,</line>
      <line>‘Laughing,’ she says, ‘into the World I blow:</line>
      <line>‘At once the silken Tassel of my purse</line>
      <line>‘Tear, and its Treasure on the Garden throw.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Worldly Hope men set their Hearts upon</line>
      <line>Turns Ashes—or it prospers; and anon,</line>
      <line>Like Snow upon the Desert’s dusty Face</line>
      <line>Lighting a little Hour or two—is gone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And those who husbanded the Golden Grain,</line>
      <line>And those who flung it to the Winds like Rain,</line>
      <line>Alike to no such aureate Earth are turn’d</line>
      <line>As, buried once, Men want dug up again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Think, in this batter’d Caravanserai</line>
      <line>Whose Doorways are alternate Night and Day,</line>
      <line>How Sultan after Sultan with his Pomp</line>
      <line>Abode his Hour or two, and went his way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say the Lion and the Lizard keep</line>
      <line>The Courts where Jamshyd gloried and drank deep:</line>
      <line>And Bahrain, that great Hunter—the Wild Ass</line>
      <line>Stamps o’er his Head, and he lies fast asleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I sometimes think that never blows so red</line>
      <line>The Rose as where some buried Caesar bled;</line>
      <line>That every Hyacinth the Garden wears</line>
      <line>Dropt in its Lap from some once lovely Head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And this delightful Herb whose tender Green</line>
      <line>Fledges the River’s Lip on which we lean—</line>
      <line>Ah, lean upon it lightly! for who knows</line>
      <line>From what once lovely Lip it springs unseen!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, my Beloved, fill the Cup that clears</line>
      <line>To-day of past Regrets and future Fears—</line>
      <line>To-morrow?—Why, To-morrow I may be</line>
      <line>Myself with Yesterday’s Sev’n Thousand Years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lo! some we loved, the loveliest and best</line>
      <line>That Time and Fate of all their Vintage prest,</line>
      <line>Have drunk their Cup a Round or two before,</line>
      <line>And one by one crept silently to Rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And we, that now make merry in the Room</line>
      <line>They left, and Summer dresses in new Bloom,</line>
      <line>Ourselves must we beneath the Couch of Earth</line>
      <line>Descend, ourselves to make a Couch—for whom?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, make the most of what we yet may spend,</line>
      <line>Before we too into the Dust descend;</line>
      <line>Dust into Dust, and under Dust, to lie,</line>
      <line>Sans Wine, sans Song, sans Singer, and—sans End!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alike for those who for To-day prepare,</line>
      <line>And those that after a To-morrow stare,</line>
      <line>A Muezzin from the Tower of Darkness cries</line>
      <line>‘Fools! your Reward is neither Here nor There!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why, all the Saints and Sages who discuss’d</line>
      <line>Of the Two Worlds so learnedly, are thrust</line>
      <line>Like foolish Prophets forth; their Words to Scorn</line>
      <line>Are scatter’d, and their Mouths are stopt with Dust.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, come with old Khayyam, and leave the Wise</line>
      <line>To talk; one thing is certain, that Life flies;</line>
      <line>One thing is certain, and the Rest is Lies;</line>
      <line>The Flower that once has blown for ever dies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Myself when young did eagerly frequent</line>
      <line>Doctor and Saint, and heard great Argument</line>
      <line>About it and about: but evermore</line>
      <line>Came out by the same Door as in I went.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With them the Seed of Wisdom did I sow,</line>
      <line>And with my own hand labour’d it to grow:</line>
      <line>And this was all the Harvest that I reap’d—</line>
      <line>‘I came like Water, and like Wind I go.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Into this Universe, and why not knowing,</line>
      <line>Nor whence, like Water willy-nilly flowing:</line>
      <line>And out of it, as Wind along the Waste,</line>
      <line>I know not whither, willy-nilly blowing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What, without asking, hither hurried whence?</line>
      <line>And, without asking, whither hurried hence!</line>
      <line>Another and another Cup to drown</line>
      <line>The Memory of this Impertinence!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up from Earth’s Centre through the Seventh Gate</line>
      <line>I rose, and on the Throne of Saturn sate,</line>
      <line>And many Knots unravel’d by the Road;</line>
      <line>But not the Knot of Human Death and Fate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was a Door to which I found no Key:</line>
      <line>There was a Veil past which I could not see:</line>
      <line>Some little Talk awhile of Me and Thee</line>
      <line>There seemed—and then no more of Thee and Me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then to the rolling Heav’n itself I cried,</line>
      <line>Asking, ‘What Lamp had Destiny to guide</line>
      <line>‘Her little Children stumbling in the Dark?’</line>
      <line>And—‘A blind Understanding!’ Heav’n replied.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then to this earthen Bowl did I adjourn</line>
      <line>My Lip the secret Well of Life to learn:</line>
      <line>And Lip to Lip it murmur’d—‘While you live</line>
      <line>‘Drink!—for once dead you never shall return.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I think the Vessel, that with fugitive</line>
      <line>Articulation answer’d, once did live,</line>
      <line>And merry-make; and the cold Lip I kiss’d</line>
      <line>How many Kisses might it take—and give!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For in the Market-place, one Dusk of Day,</line>
      <line>I watch’d the Potter thumping his wet Clay:</line>
      <line>And with its all obliterated Tongue</line>
      <line>It murmur’d—‘Gently, Brother, gently, pray!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, fill the Cup:—what boots it to repeat</line>
      <line>How Time is slipping underneath our Feet:</line>
      <line>Unborn To-morrow, and dead Yesterday,</line>
      <line>Why fret about them if To-day be sweet!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One Moment in Annihilation’s Waste,</line>
      <line>One Moment, of the Well of Life to taste—</line>
      <line>The Stars are setting and the Caravan</line>
      <line>Starts for the Dawn of Nothing—Oh, make haste!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How long, how long, in infinite Pursuit</line>
      <line>Of This and That endeavour and dispute?</line>
      <line>Better be merry with the fruitful Grape</line>
      <line>Than sadden after none, or bitter, Fruit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You know, my Friends, how long since in my House</line>
      <line>For a new Marriage I did make Carouse:</line>
      <line>Divorced old barren Reason from by Bed,</line>
      <line>And took the Daughter of the Vine to Spouse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For ‘Is’ and ‘Is-not’ though with Rule and Line,</line>
      <line>And ‘Up-and-down’ without, I could define,</line>
      <line>I yet in all I only cared to know,</line>
      <line>Was never deep in anything but—Wine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lately, by the Tavern Door agape,</line>
      <line>Came stealing through the Dusk an Angel Shape</line>
      <line>Bearing a Vessel on his Shoulder; and</line>
      <line>He bid me taste of it; and ’twas—the Grape!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Grape that can with Logic absolute</line>
      <line>The Two-and-Seventy jarring Sects confute:</line>
      <line>The subtle Alchemist that in a Trice</line>
      <line>Life’s leaden Metal into Gold transmute.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mighty Mahmud, the victorious Lord,</line>
      <line>That all the misbelieving and black Horde</line>
      <line>Of Fears and Sorrows that infest the Soul</line>
      <line>Scatters and slays with his enchanted Sword.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But leave the Wise to wrangle, and with me</line>
      <line>The Quarrel of the Universe let be:</line>
      <line>And, in some corner of the Hubbub coucht,</line>
      <line>Make Game of that which makes as much of Thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For in and out, above, about, below,</line>
      <line>’Tis nothing but a Magic Shadow-show,</line>
      <line>Play’d in a Box whose Candle is the Sun,</line>
      <line>Round which we Phantom Figures come and go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if the Wine you drink, the Lip you press,</line>
      <line>End in the Nothing all Things end in—Yes—</line>
      <line>Then fancy while Thou art, Thou art but what</line>
      <line>Thou shalt be—Nothing—Thou shalt not be less.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While the Rose blows along the River Brink,</line>
      <line>With old Khayyam the Ruby Vintage drink:</line>
      <line>And when the Angel with his darker Draught</line>
      <line>Draws up to Thee—take that, and do not shrink.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis all a Chequer-board of Nights and Days</line>
      <line>Where Destiny with Men for Pieces plays:</line>
      <line>Hither and thither moves, and mates, and slays,</line>
      <line>And one by one back in the Closet lays.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Ball no Question makes of Ayes and Noes,</line>
      <line>But Right or Left as strikes the Player goes;</line>
      <line>And He that toss’d Thee down into the Field,</line>
      <line>He knows about it all—He knows—HE knows!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ,</line>
      <line>Moves on: nor all thy Piety nor Wit</line>
      <line>Shall lure it back to cancel half a Line,</line>
      <line>Nor all thy Tears wash out a Word of it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that inverted Bowl we call The Sky,</line>
      <line>Whereunder crawling coop’t we live and die,</line>
      <line>Lift not thy hands to It for help—for It</line>
      <line>Rolls impotently on as Thou or I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With Earth’s first Clay They did the Last Man’s knead,</line>
      <line>And then of the Last Harvest sow’d the Seed:</line>
      <line>Yea, the first Morning of Creation wrote</line>
      <line>What the Last Dawn of Reckoning shall read.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I tell Thee this—When, starting from the Goal,</line>
      <line>Over the shoulders of the flaming Foal</line>
      <line>Of Heav’n Parwi'n and Mushtara they flung,</line>
      <line>In my predestin’d Plot of Dust and Soul</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Vine had struck a Fibre; which about</line>
      <line>If clings my Being—let the Sufi flout;</line>
      <line>Of my Base Metal may be filed a Key,</line>
      <line>That shall unlock the Door he howls without.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And this I know: whether the one True Light,</line>
      <line>Kindle to Love, or Wrath consume me quite,</line>
      <line>One Glimpse of It within the Tavern caught</line>
      <line>Better than in the Temple lost outright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh Thou, who didst with Pitfall and with Gin</line>
      <line>Beset the Road I was to wander in,</line>
      <line>Thou wilt not with Predestination round</line>
      <line>Enmesh me, and impute my Fall to Sin?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, Thou, who Man of baser Earth didst make,</line>
      <line>And who with Eden didst devise the Snake;</line>
      <line>For all the Sin wherewith the Face of Man</line>
      <line>Is blacken’d, Man’s Forgiveness give—and take!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Listen again. One Evening at the Close</line>
      <line>Of Ramazan, ere the better Moon arose,</line>
      <line>In that old Potter’s Shop I stood alone</line>
      <line>With the clay Population round in Rows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, strange to tell, among that Earthen Lot</line>
      <line>Some could articulate, while others not:</line>
      <line>And suddenly one more impatient cried—</line>
      <line>‘Who is the Potter, pray, and who the Pot?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then said another—‘Surely not in vain</line>
      <line>‘My Substance from the common Earth was ta’en,</line>
      <line>‘That He who subtly wrought me into Shape</line>
      <line>‘Should stamp me back to common Earth again.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Another said—‘Why, ne’er a peevish Boy,</line>
      <line>‘Would break the Bowl from which he drank in Joy;</line>
      <line>‘Shall He that made the Vessel in pure Love</line>
      <line>‘And Fansy, in an after Rage destroy!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>None answer’d this; but after Silence spake</line>
      <line>A Vessel of a more ungainly Make:</line>
      <line>‘They sneer at me for leaning all awry;</line>
      <line>‘What! did the Hand then of the Potter shake?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Said one—‘Folks of a surly Tapster tell,</line>
      <line>‘And daub his Visage with the Smoke of Hell;</line>
      <line>‘They talk of some strict Testing of us—Pish!</line>
      <line>‘He’s a Good Fellow, and ’twill all be well.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then said another with a long-drawn Sigh,</line>
      <line>‘My Clay with long oblivion is gone dry:</line>
      <line>‘But, fill me with the old familiar Juice,</line>
      <line>‘Methinks I might recover by-and-bye!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So while the Vessels one by one were speaking,</line>
      <line>One spied the little Crescent all were seeking:</line>
      <line>And then they jogg’d each other, ‘Brother! Brother!</line>
      <line>‘Hark to the Porter’s Shoulder-knot a-creaking!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, with the Grape my fading Life provide,</line>
      <line>And wash my Body whence the Life has died,</line>
      <line>And in a Windingsheet of Vine-leaf wrapt,</line>
      <line>So bury me by some sweet Garden-side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That ev’n my buried Ashes such a Snare</line>
      <line>Of Perfume shall fling up into the Air,</line>
      <line>As not a True Believer passing by</line>
      <line>But shall be overtaken unaware.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Indeed the Idols I have loved so long</line>
      <line>Have done my Credit in Men’s Eye much wrong:</line>
      <line>Have drown’d my Honour in a shallow Cup,</line>
      <line>And sold my Reputation for a Song.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Indeed, indeed, Repentance oft before</line>
      <line>I swore—but was I sober when I swore?</line>
      <line>And then and then came Spring, and Rose-in-hand</line>
      <line>My thread-bare Penitence apieces tore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And much as Wine has play’d the Infidel,</line>
      <line>And robb’d me of my Robe of Honour—well,</line>
      <line>I often wonder what the Vintners buy</line>
      <line>One half so precious as the Goods they sell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas, that Spring should vanish with the Rose!</line>
      <line>That Youth’s sweet-scented Manuscript should close!</line>
      <line>The Nightingale that in the Branches sang,</line>
      <line>Ah, whence, and whither flown again, who knows!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah Love! could thou and I with Fate conspire</line>
      <line>To grasp this sorry Scheme of Things entire,</line>
      <line>Would not we shatter it to bits—and then</line>
      <line>Re-mould it nearer to the Heart’s Desire!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, Moon of my Delight who know’st no wane,</line>
      <line>The Moon of Heav’n is rising once again:</line>
      <line>How oft hereafter rising shall she look</line>
      <line>Through this same Garden after me—in vain!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when Thyself with shining Foot shall pass</line>
      <line>Among the Guests Star-scatter’d on the Grass,</line>
      <line>And in thy joyous Errand reach the Spot</line>
      <line>Where I made one—turn down an empty Glass!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Siddal</author>
    <date>1857</date>
    <title>A Silent Wood</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O silent wood, I enter thee</line>
      <line>With a heart so full of misery</line>
      <line>For all the voices from the trees</line>
      <line>And the ferns that cling about my knees.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In thy darkest shadow let me sit</line>
      <line>When the grey owls about thee flit;</line>
      <line>There will I ask of thee a boon,</line>
      <line>That I may not faint or die or swoon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gazing through the gloom like one</line>
      <line>Whose life and hopes are also done,</line>
      <line>Frozen like a thing of stone</line>
      <line>I sit in thy shadow—but not alone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Can God bring back the day when we two stood</line>
      <line>Beneath the clinging trees in that dark wood?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Elizabeth Siddal</author>
    <date>1859</date>
    <title>Dead Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh never weep for love that’s dead</line>
      <line>Since love is seldom true</line>
      <line>But changes his fashion from blue to red,</line>
      <line>From brightest red to blue,</line>
      <line>And love was born to an early death</line>
      <line>And is so seldom true.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then harbour no smile on your bonny face</line>
      <line>To win the deepest sigh.</line>
      <line>The fairest words on truest lips</line>
      <line>Pass on and surely die,</line>
      <line>And you will stand alone, my dear,</line>
      <line>When wintry winds draw nigh.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet, never weep for what cannot be,</line>
      <line>For this God has not given.</line>
      <line>If the merest dream of love were true</line>
      <line>Then, sweet, we should be in heaven,</line>
      <line>And this is only earth, my dear,</line>
      <line>Where true love is not given.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Morris</author>
    <date>1858</date>
    <title>Summer Dawn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pray but one prayer for me ’twixt thy closed lips,</line>
      <line>Think but one thought of me up in the stars.</line>
      <line>The summer night waneth, the morning light slips,</line>
      <line>Faint & grey ’twixt the leaves of the aspen, betwixt the cloud-bars,</line>
      <line>That are patiendy waiting there for the dawn:</line>
      <line>Patient and colourless, though Heaven’s gold</line>
      <line>Waits to float through them along with the sun.</line>
      <line>Far out in the meadows, above the young corn,</line>
      <line>The heavy elms wait, and restless and cold</line>
      <line>The uneasy wind rises; the roses are dun;</line>
      <line>Through the long twilight they pray for the dawn,</line>
      <line>Round the lone house in the midst of the corn.</line>
      <line>Speak but one word to me over the corn,</line>
      <line>Over the tender, bow’d locks of the corn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Morris</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>For the Briar Rose</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fateful slumber floats and flows</line>
      <line>About die tangle of the rose;</line>
      <line>But lo! the fated hand and heart</line>
      <line>To rend the slumbrous curse apart!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The threat of war, the hope of peace,</line>
      <line>The Kingdom’s peril and increase</line>
      <line>Sleep on and bide the latter day,</line>
      <line>When fate shall take her chain away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The maiden pleasance of the land</line>
      <line>Knoweth no stir of voice or hand,</line>
      <line>No cup the sleeping waters fill,</line>
      <line>The restless shuttle lieth still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here lies the hoarded love, the key</line>
      <line>To all the treasure that shall be;</line>
      <line>Come fated hand the gift to take,</line>
      <line>And smite this sleeping world awake.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Morris</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>Another for the Briar Rose</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O treacherous scent, O thorny sight,</line>
      <line>O tangle of world’s wrong and right,</line>
      <line>What art thou ’gainst my armour’s gleam</line>
      <line>But dusky cobwebs of a dream?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beat down, deep sunk from every gleam</line>
      <line>Of hope, they lie and dully dream;</line>
      <line>Men once, but men no more, that Love</line>
      <line>Their waste defeated hearts should move.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here sleeps the world that would not love!</line>
      <line>Let it sleep on, but if He move</line>
      <line>Their hearts in humble wise to wait</line>
      <line>On his new-wakened fair estate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O won at last is never late!</line>
      <line>Thy silence was the voice of fate;</line>
      <line>Thy still hands conquered in the strife;</line>
      <line>Thine eyes were light; thy lips were life.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Morris</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>Pomona</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am the ancient Apple-Queen,</line>
      <line>As once I was so am I now.</line>
      <line>For evermore a hope unseen,</line>
      <line>Betwixt the blossom and the bough.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, where’s the river’s hidden Gold!</line>
      <line>And where the windy grave of Troy?</line>
      <line>Yet come I as I came of old,</line>
      <line>From out the heart of Summer’s joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Morris</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>The End of May</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How the wind howls this morn</line>
      <line>About the end of May,</line>
      <line>And drives June on apace</line>
      <line>To mock the world forlorn</line>
      <line>And the world’s joy passed away</line>
      <line>And my unlonged-for face!</line>
      <line>The world’s joy passed away;</line>
      <line>For no more may I deem</line>
      <line>That any folk are glad</line>
      <line>To see the dawn of day</line>
      <line>Sunder the tangled dream</line>
      <line>Wherein no grief they had.</line>
      <line>Ah, through the tangled dream</line>
      <line>Where others have no grief</line>
      <line>Ever it fares with me</line>
      <line>That fears and treasons stream</line>
      <line>And dumb sleep slays belief</line>
      <line>Whatso therein may be.</line>
      <line>Sleep slayeth all belief</line>
      <line>Until the hopeless light</line>
      <line>Wakes at the birth of June</line>
      <line>More lying tales to weave,</line>
      <line>More love in woe’s despite,</line>
      <line>More hope to perish soon.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Ashe</author>
    <date>1860</date>
    <title>Corpse-Bearing</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I remember, they sent</line>
      <line>Some one to me, who said,</line>
      <line>‘You were his friend while he lived:</line>
      <line>Be so now he is dead.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So I went next day to the house;</line>
      <line>And a woman nodded to me,</line>
      <line>As I sat alone in thought:—</line>
      <line>Said, ‘Sir, would you like to see</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The poor dead body upstairs,</line>
      <line>Before we rivet the lid?’</line>
      <line>But I said, ‘I would rather not:</line>
      <line>For the look would never be hid</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘From my sight, day after day,</line>
      <line>From my soul, year after year.</line>
      <line>Enough to look on the pall:</line>
      <line>Enough to follow the bier.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So the mourners gather’d at last;</line>
      <line>And the poor dead body was put</line>
      <line>In a hearse with mournful plumes,</line>
      <line>And the door of the hearse was shut.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the mourners were all</line>
      <line>In the coaches, ready to start,</line>
      <line>The sorrowing parent came</line>
      <line>To me, and whisper’d apart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He smiled as well as he could;</line>
      <line>And the import of what he said</line>
      <line>Was, that I should bear at the feet,</line>
      <line>And his son would bear at the head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He was ever my friend;</line>
      <line>And I was happy to be</line>
      <line>Of ever so small use still</line>
      <line>To one who had so loved me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, what a weight, O God!</line>
      <line>Was that one coffin to bear!</line>
      <line>Like a coffin of lead!</line>
      <line>And I carry it everywhere</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>About, wherever I go!</line>
      <line>If I lift the slightest thing,</line>
      <line>That requires an effort to lift,</line>
      <line>The effort at once will bring</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The whole weight into my hands,</line>
      <line>And I carry the corpse at the feet;</line>
      <line>And feel as if it would drop,</line>
      <line>And slip out of its winding-sheet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have made a vow in my heart,</line>
      <line>Whatever the friends may say,</line>
      <line>Never to carry a corpse</line>
      <line>Again, to my dying day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Ashe</author>
    <date>1874</date>
    <title>To Two Bereaved</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>You must be sad; for though it is to Heaven,</line>
      <line>’Tis hard to yield a little girl of seven.</line>
      <line>Alas, for me, ’tis hard my grief to rule,</line>
      <line>Who only met her as she went to school;</line>
      <line>Who never heard the little lips so sweet</line>
      <line>Say even ‘Good morning,’ though our eyes would meet</line>
      <line>As whose would fain be friends! How must you sigh,</line>
      <line>Sick for your loss, when even so sad am I,</line>
      <line>Who never clasp’d the small hands any day!</line>
      <line>Fair flowers thrive round the little grave, I pray.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Love Peacock</author>
    <date>1860</date>
    <title>Lave and Age</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I played with you ’mid cowslips blowing,</line>
      <line>When I was six and you were four;</line>
      <line>When garlands weaving, flower-balls throwing,</line>
      <line>Were pleasures soon to please no more.</line>
      <line>Through groves and meads, o’er grass and heather,</line>
      <line>With little playmates, to and fro,</line>
      <line>We wandered hand in hand together;</line>
      <line>But that was sixty years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You grew a lovely roseate maiden,</line>
      <line>And still our early love was strong;</line>
      <line>Still with no care our days were laden,</line>
      <line>They glided joyously along;</line>
      <line>And I did love you, very dearly,</line>
      <line>How dearly words want power to show;</line>
      <line>I thought your heart was touched as nearly;</line>
      <line>But that was fifty years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then other lovers came around you,</line>
      <line>Your beauty grew from year to year,</line>
      <line>And many a splendid circle found you</line>
      <line>The centre of its glittering sphere.</line>
      <line>I saw you then, first vows forsaking,</line>
      <line>On rank and wealth your hand bestow;</line>
      <line>Oh, then I thought my heart was breaking,—</line>
      <line>But that was forty years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I lived on, to wed another:</line>
      <line>No cause she gave me to repine;</line>
      <line>And when I heard you were a mother,</line>
      <line>I did not wish the children mine.</line>
      <line>My own young flock, in fair progression,</line>
      <line>Made up a pleasant Christmas row:</line>
      <line>My joy in them was past expression;—</line>
      <line>But that was thirty years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You grew a matron plump and comely,</line>
      <line>You dwelt in fashion’s brightest blaze;</line>
      <line>My earthly lot was far more homely;</line>
      <line>But I too had my festal days.</line>
      <line>No merrier eyes have ever glistened</line>
      <line>Around the hearth-stone’s wintry glow,</line>
      <line>Than when my youngest child was christened:—</line>
      <line>But that was twenty years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Time passed. My eldest girl was married,</line>
      <line>And I am now a grandsire grey;</line>
      <line>One pet of four years old I’ve carried</line>
      <line>Among the wild-flowered meads to play.</line>
      <line>In our old fields of childish pleasure,</line>
      <line>Where now, as then, the cowslips blow,</line>
      <line>She fills her basket’s ample measure,—</line>
      <line>And that is not ten years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But though first love’s impassioned blindness</line>
      <line>Has passed away in colder light,</line>
      <line>I still have thought of you with kindness,</line>
      <line>And shall do, till our last good-night.</line>
      <line>The ever-rolling silent hours</line>
      <line>Will bring a time we shall not know,</line>
      <line>When our young days of gathering flowers</line>
      <line>Will be an hundred years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Adelaide Anne Procter</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>Envy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He was the first always: Fortune</line>
      <line>Shone bright in his face.</line>
      <line>I fought for years; with no effort</line>
      <line>He conquered the place:</line>
      <line>We ran; my feet were all bleeding,</line>
      <line>But he won the race.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spite of his many successes</line>
      <line>Men loved him the same;</line>
      <line>My one pale ray of good fortune</line>
      <line>Met scoffing and blame.</line>
      <line>When we erred, they gave him pity,</line>
      <line>But me—only shame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My home was still in the shadow,</line>
      <line>His lay in the sun:</line>
      <line>I longed in vain: what he asked for</line>
      <line>It straightway was done.</line>
      <line>Once I staked all my heart’s treasure,</line>
      <line>We played—and he won.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes; and just now I have seen him,</line>
      <line>Cold, smiling, and blest,</line>
      <line>Laid in his coffin. God help me!</line>
      <line>While he is at rest,</line>
      <line>I am cursed still to live:—even</line>
      <line>Death loved him the best.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Richard Watson Dixon</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>Dream</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With camel’s hair I clothed my skin,</line>
      <line>I fed my mouth with honey wild;</line>
      <line>And set me scarlet wool to spin,</line>
      <line>And all my breast with hyssop filled;</line>
      <line>Upon my brow and cheeks and chin</line>
      <line>A bird’s blood spilled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took a broken reed to hold,</line>
      <line>I took a sponge of gall to press;</line>
      <line>I took weak water-weeds to fold</line>
      <line>About my sacrificial dress.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took the grasses of the field,</line>
      <line>The flax was boiled upon my crine;</line>
      <line>And ivy thorn and wild grapes healed</line>
      <line>To make good wine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took my scrip of manna sweet,</line>
      <line>My cruse of water did I bless;</line>
      <line>I took the white dove by the feet,</line>
      <line>And flew into the wilderness.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The tiger came and played;</line>
      <line>Uprose the lion in his mane;</line>
      <line>The jackal’s tawny nose</line>
      <line>And sanguine dripping tongue</line>
      <line>Out of the desert rose</line>
      <line>And plunged its sands among;</line>
      <line>The bear came striding o’er the desert plain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Uprose the horn and eyes</line>
      <line>And quivering flank of the great unicorn,</line>
      <line>And galloped round and round;</line>
      <line>Uprose the gleaming claw</line>
      <line>Of the leviathan, and wound</line>
      <line>In steadfast march did draw</line>
      <line>Its course away beyond the desert’s bourn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I stood within a maze</line>
      <line>Woven round about me by a magic art,</line>
      <line>And ordered circle-wise:</line>
      <line>The bear more near did tread,</line>
      <line>And with two fiery eyes,</line>
      <line>And with a wolfish head,</line>
      <line>Did close the circle round in every part.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With scarlet corded horn,</line>
      <line>With frail wrecked knees and stumbling pace,</line>
      <line>The scapegoat came:</line>
      <line>His eyes took flesh and spirit dread in flame</line>
      <line>At once, and he died looking towards my face.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Richard Watson Dixon</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>The Wizard's Funeral</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>For me, for me, two horses wait,</line>
      <line>Two horses stand before my gate:</line>
      <line>Their vast black plumes on high are cast,</line>
      <line>Their black manes swing in the midnight blast,</line>
      <line>Red sparkles from their eyes fly fast.</line>
      <line>But can they drag the hearse behind,</line>
      <line>Whose black plumes mystify the wind?</line>
      <line>What a thing for this heap of bones and hair!</line>
      <line>Despair, despair!</line>
      <line>Yet think of half the world’s winged shapes</line>
      <line>Which have come to thee wondering:</line>
      <line>At thee the terrible idiot gapes,</line>
      <line>At thee the running devil japes,</line>
      <line>And angels stoop to thee and sing</line>
      <line>From the soft midnight that enwraps</line>
      <line>Their limbs, so gently, sadly fair;—</line>
      <line>Thou seest the stars shine through their hair.</line>
      <line>The blast again, ho, ho, the blast!</line>
      <line>I go to a mansion that shall outlast;</line>
      <line>And the stoled priest who steps before</line>
      <line>Shall turn and welcome me at the door.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Richard Watson Dixon</author>
    <date>1861</date>
    <title>Dawning</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Over the hill I have watched the dawning,</line>
      <line>I have watched the dawn of morning light,</line>
      <line>Because I cannot well sleep by night,</line>
      <line>Every day I have watched the dawning.</line>
      <line>And to-day very early my window shook</line>
      <line>With the cold wind fresh from the ghasdy brook,</line>
      <line>And I left my bed to watch the dawning.</line>
      <line>Very cold was the light, very pale, very still,</line>
      <line>And the wind blew great clouds over the hill</line>
      <line>Towards the wet place of the dying dawning;</line>
      <line>It blew them over towards the east</line>
      <line>In heavier charge as the light increased,</line>
      <line>From the very death of the dying dawning.</line>
      <line>Whence did the clouds come over the hill?</line>
      <line>I cannot tell, for no clouds did fill</line>
      <line>The clear space opposite the dawning</line>
      <line>Right over the hill, long, low, and pearl-grey,</line>
      <line>Set in the wind to live as it may;</line>
      <line>And as the light increased from the dawning,</line>
      <line>The cold, cold brook unto my seeming</line>
      <line>Did intermit its ghastly gleaming</line>
      <line>And ran forth brighter in the dawning.</line>
      <line>The wall-fruit stretched along the wall,</line>
      <line>The pear-tree waved its banners tall;</line>
      <line>Then close beside me in the dawning,</line>
      <line>I saw thy face so stonily grey,</line>
      <line>And the close lips no word did say,</line>
      <line>The eyes confessed not in the dawning.</line>
      <line>I saw a man ride through the light</line>
      <line>Upon the hill-top, out of sight</line>
      <line>Of me and thee and all the dawning.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love I</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>By this he knew she wept with waking eyes:</line>
      <line>That, at his hand’s light quiver by her head,</line>
      <line>The strange low sobs that shook their common bed,</line>
      <line>Were called into her with a sharp surprise,</line>
      <line>And strangled mute, like little gaping snakes,</line>
      <line>Dreadfully venomous to him. She lay</line>
      <line>Stone-still, and the long darkness flowed away</line>
      <line>With muffled pulses. Then, as midnight makes</line>
      <line>Her giant heart of Memory and Tears</line>
      <line>Drink the pale drug of silence, and so beat</line>
      <line>Sleep’s heavy measure, they from head to feet</line>
      <line>Were moveless, looking through their dead black years,</line>
      <line>By vain regret scrawled over the blank wall.</line>
      <line>Like sculptured effigies they might be seen</line>
      <line>Upon their marriage-tomb, the sword between;</line>
      <line>Each wishing for the sword that severs all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love V</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A message from her set his brain aflame.</line>
      <line>A world of household matters filled her mind,</line>
      <line>Wherein he saw hypocrisy designed:</line>
      <line>She treated him as something that is tame,</line>
      <line>And but at other provocation bites.</line>
      <line>Familiar was her shoulder in the glass,</line>
      <line>Through that dark rain: yet it may come to pass</line>
      <line>That a changed eye finds such familiar sights</line>
      <line>More keenly tempting than new loveliness.</line>
      <line>The ‘What has been’ a moment seemed his own:</line>
      <line>The splendours, mysteries, dearer because known,</line>
      <line>Nor less divine: Love’s inmost sacredness,</line>
      <line>Called to him, ‘Come!’—In his restraining start,</line>
      <line>Eyes nurtured to be looked at, scarce could see</line>
      <line>A wave of the great waves of Destiny</line>
      <line>Convulsed at a checked impulse of the heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love VI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It chanced his lips did meet her forehead cool.</line>
      <line>She had no blush, but slanted down her eye.</line>
      <line>Shamed nature, then, confesses love can die:</line>
      <line>And most she punishes the tender fool</line>
      <line>Who will believe what honours her the most!</line>
      <line>Dead! is it dead? She has a pulse, and flow</line>
      <line>Of tears, the price of blood-drops, as I know,</line>
      <line>For whom the midnight sobs around Love’s ghost,</line>
      <line>Since then I heard her, and so will sob on.</line>
      <line>The love is here; it has but changed its aim.</line>
      <line>O bitter barren woman! what’s the name?</line>
      <line>The name, the name, the new name thou hast won?</line>
      <line>Behold me striking the world’s coward stroke!</line>
      <line>That will I not do, though the sting is dire.</line>
      <line>—Beneath the surface this, while by the fire</line>
      <line>They sat, she laughing at a quiet joke.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love VII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She issues radiant from her dressing-room,</line>
      <line>Like one prepared to scale an upper sphere:</line>
      <line>—By stirring up a lower, much I fear!</line>
      <line>How deftly that oiled barber lays his bloom!</line>
      <line>That long-shanked dapper Cupid with frisked curls,</line>
      <line>Can make known women torturingly fair;</line>
      <line>The gold-eyed serpent dwelling in rich hair,</line>
      <line>Awakes beneath his magic whisks and twirls.</line>
      <line>His art can take the eyes from out my head,</line>
      <line>Until I see with eyes of other men;</line>
      <line>While deeper knowledge crouches in its den,</line>
      <line>And sends a spark up:—is it true we are wed?</line>
      <line>Yea! filthiness of body is most vile,</line>
      <line>But faithlessness of heart I do hold worse.</line>
      <line>The former, it were not so great a curse</line>
      <line>To read on the steel-mirror of her smile.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
