    <title>Modern Love IX</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He felt the wild beast in him betweenwhiles</line>
      <line>So masterfully rude, that he would grieve</line>
      <line>To see the helpless delicate thing receive</line>
      <line>His guardianship through certain dark defiles.</line>
      <line>Had he not teeth to rend, and hunger too?</line>
      <line>But still he spared her. Once: ‘Have you no fear?’</line>
      <line>He said: ’twas dusk; she in his grasp; none near.</line>
      <line>She laughed: ‘No, surely; am I not with you?’</line>
      <line>And uttering that soft starry ‘you,’ she leaned</line>
      <line>Her gentle body near him, looking up;</line>
      <line>And from her eyes, as from a poison-cup,</line>
      <line>He drank until the flittering eyelids screened.</line>
      <line>Devilish malignant witch! and oh, young beam</line>
      <line>Of heaven’s circle-glory! Here thy shape</line>
      <line>To squeeze like an intoxicating grape—</line>
      <line>I might, and yet thou goest safe, supreme.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XVI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In our old shipwrecked days there was an hour,</line>
      <line>When in the firelight steadily aglow,</line>
      <line>Joined slackly, we beheld the red chasm grow</line>
      <line>Among the clicking coals. Our library-bower</line>
      <line>That eve was left to us: and hushed we sat</line>
      <line>As lovers to whom Time is whispering.</line>
      <line>From sudden-opened doors we heard them sing:</line>
      <line>The nodding elders mixed good wine with chat.</line>
      <line>Well knew we that Life’s greatest treasure lay</line>
      <line>With us, and of it was our talk. ‘Ah, yes!</line>
      <line>Love dies!’ I said: I never thought it less.</line>
      <line>She yearned to me that sentence to unsay.</line>
      <line>Then when the fire domed blackening, I found</line>
      <line>Her cheek was salt against my kiss, and swift</line>
      <line>Up the sharp scale of sobs her breast did lift:—</line>
      <line>Now am I haunted by that taste! that sound!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XVII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>At dinner, she is hostess, I am host.</line>
      <line>Went the feast ever cheerfuller? She keeps</line>
      <line>The Topic over intellectual deeps</line>
      <line>In buoyancy afloat. They see no ghost.</line>
      <line>With sparkling surface-eyes we ply the ball:</line>
      <line>It is in truth a most contagious game:</line>
      <line>Hiding the Skeleton, shall be its name.</line>
      <line>Such play as this, the devils might appal!</line>
      <line>But here’s the greater wonder; in that we</line>
      <line>Enamoured of an acting nought can tire,</line>
      <line>Each other, like true hypocrites, admire;</line>
      <line>Warm-lighted looks, Love’s ephemerioe,</line>
      <line>Shoot gaily o’er the dishes and the wine.</line>
      <line>We waken envy of our happy lot.</line>
      <line>Fast, sweet, and golden, shows the marriage-knot.</line>
      <line>Dear guests, you now have seen Love’s corpse-light shine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We three are on the cedar-shadowed lawn;</line>
      <line>My friend being third. He who at love once laughed,</line>
      <line>Is in the weak rib by a fatal shaft</line>
      <line>Struck through, and tells his passion’s bashful dawn</line>
      <line>And radiant culmination, glorious crown,</line>
      <line>When ‘this’ she said: went ‘thus’: most wondrous she.</line>
      <line>Our eyes grow white, encountering: that we are three,</line>
      <line>Forgetful; then together we look down.</line>
      <line>But he demands our blessing; is convinced</line>
      <line>That words of wedded lovers must bring good.</line>
      <line>We question; if we dare! or if we should!</line>
      <line>And pat him, with light laugh. We have not winced.</line>
      <line>Next, she has fallen. Fainting points the sign</line>
      <line>To happy things in wedlock. When she wakes,</line>
      <line>She looks the star that thro’ the cedar shakes:</line>
      <line>Her lost moist hand clings mortally to mine.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXIII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis Christmas weather, and a country house</line>
      <line>Receives us: rooms are full: we can but get</line>
      <line>An attic-crib. Such lovers will not fret</line>
      <line>At that, it is half-said. The great carouse</line>
      <line>Knocks hard upon the midnight’s hollow door,</line>
      <line>But when I knock at hers, I see the pit.</line>
      <line>Why did I come here in that dullard fit?</line>
      <line>I enter, and lie couched upon the floor.</line>
      <line>Passing, I caught the coverlet’s quick beat:—</line>
      <line>Come, Shame, burn to my soul! and Pride, and Pain—</line>
      <line>Foul demons that have tortured me, enchain!</line>
      <line>Out in the freezing darkness the lambs bleat.</line>
      <line>The small bird stiffens in the low starlight.</line>
      <line>I know not how, but shuddering as I slept,</line>
      <line>I dreamed a banished angel to me crept:</line>
      <line>My feet were nourished on her breasts all night.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>You like not that French novel? Tell me why.</line>
      <line>You think it quite unnatural. Let us see.</line>
      <line>The actors are, it seems, the usual three:</line>
      <line>Husband, and wife, and lover. She—but fie!</line>
      <line>In England we’ll not hear of it. Edmond,</line>
      <line>The lover, her devout chagrin doth share;</line>
      <line>Blanc-mange and absinthe are his penitent fare,</line>
      <line>Till his pale aspect makes her over-fond:</line>
      <line>So, to preclude fresh sin, he tries rosbif.</line>
      <line>Meantime the husband is no more abused:</line>
      <line>Auguste forgives her ere the tear is used.</line>
      <line>Then hangeth all on one tremendous If:—</line>
      <line>If she will choose between them. She does choose;</line>
      <line>And takes her husband, like a proper wife.</line>
      <line>Unnatural? My dear, these things are life:</line>
      <line>And life, some think, is worthy of the Muse.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXXI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This golden head has wit in it. I live</line>
      <line>Again, and a far higher life, near her.</line>
      <line>Some women like a young philosopher;</line>
      <line>Perchance because he is diminutive.</line>
      <line>For woman’s manly god must not exceed</line>
      <line>Proportions of the natural nursing size.</line>
      <line>Great poets and great sages draw no prize</line>
      <line>With women: but the little lap-dog breed,</line>
      <line>Who can be hugged, or on a mantel-piece</line>
      <line>Perched up for adoration, these obtain</line>
      <line>Her homage. And of this we men are vain?</line>
      <line>Of this! ’Tis ordered for the world’s increase!</line>
      <line>Small flattery! Yet she has that rare gift</line>
      <line>To beauty, Common Sense. I am approved.</line>
      <line>It is not half so nice as being loved,</line>
      <line>And yet I do prefer it. What’s my drift?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXXIV</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Madam would speak with me. So, now it comes:</line>
      <line>The Deluge or else Fire! She’s well; she thanks</line>
      <line>My husbandship. Our chain on silence clanks.</line>
      <line>Time leers between, above his twiddling thumbs.</line>
      <line>Am I quite well? Most excellent in health!</line>
      <line>The journals, too, I diligently peruse.</line>
      <line>Vesuvius is expected to give news:</line>
      <line>Niagara is no noisier. By stealth</line>
      <line>Our eyes dart scrutinizing snakes. She’s glad</line>
      <line>I’m happy, says her quivering under-lip.</line>
      <line>‘And are not you?’ ‘How can I be?’ ‘Take ship!</line>
      <line>For happiness is somewhere to be had.’</line>
      <line>‘Nowhere for me!’ Her voice is barely heard.</line>
      <line>I am not melted, and make no pretence.</line>
      <line>With commonplace I freeze her, tongue and sense.</line>
      <line>Niagara or Vesuvius is deferred.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXXVI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My Lady unto Madam makes her bow.</line>
      <line>The charm of women is, that even while</line>
      <line>You’re probed by them for tears, you yet may smile,</line>
      <line>Nay, laugh outright, as I have done just now.</line>
      <line>The interview was gracious: they anoint</line>
      <line>(To me aside) each other with fine praise:</line>
      <line>Discriminating compliments they raise,</line>
      <line>That hit with wondrous aim on the weak point:</line>
      <line>My Lady’s nose of Nature might complain.</line>
      <line>It is not fashioned aptly to express</line>
      <line>Her character of large-browed steadfastness.</line>
      <line>But Madam says: Thereof she may be vain!</line>
      <line>Now, Madam’s faulty feature is a glazed</line>
      <line>And inaccessible eye, that has soft fires,</line>
      <line>Wide gates, at love-time only. This admires</line>
      <line>My Lady. At the two I stand amazed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XXXVII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Along the garden terrace, under which</line>
      <line>A purple valley (lighted at its edge</line>
      <line>By smoky torch-flame on the long cloud-ledge</line>
      <line>Whereunder dropped the chariot), glimmers rich,</line>
      <line>A quiet company we pace, and wait</line>
      <line>The dinner-bell in prae-digestive calm.</line>
      <line>So sweet up violet banks the Southern balm</line>
      <line>Breathes round, we care not if the bell be late:</line>
      <line>Though here and there grey seniors question Time</line>
      <line>In irritable coughings. With slow foot</line>
      <line>The low rosed moon, the face of Music mute,</line>
      <line>Begins among her silent bars to climb.</line>
      <line>As in and out, in silvery dusk, we thread,</line>
      <line>I hear the laugh of Madam, and discern</line>
      <line>My Lady’s heel before me at each turn.</line>
      <line>Our tragedy, is it alive or dead?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XLII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I AM to follow her. There is much grace</line>
      <line>In women when thus bent on martyrdom.</line>
      <line>They think that dignity of soul may come,</line>
      <line>Perchance, with dignity of body. Base!</line>
      <line>But I was taken by that air of cold</line>
      <line>And statuesque sedateness, when she said</line>
      <line>‘I’m going’; lit a taper, bowed her head,</line>
      <line>And went, as with the stride of Pallas bold.</line>
      <line>Fleshly indifference horrible! The hands</line>
      <line>Of Time now signal: O, she’s safe from me!</line>
      <line>Within those secret walls what do I see?</line>
      <line>Where first she set the taper down she stands:</line>
      <line>Not Pallas: Hebe shamed! Thoughts black as death,</line>
      <line>Like a stirred pool in sunshine break. Her wrists</line>
      <line>I catch: she faltering, as she half resists,</line>
      <line>‘You love...? love...? love...?’ all on an indrawn breath.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love XLVII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We saw the swallows gathering in the sky,</line>
      <line>And in the osier-isle we heard them noise.</line>
      <line>We had not to look back on summer joys,</line>
      <line>Or forward to a summer of bright dye:</line>
      <line>But in the largeness of the evening earth</line>
      <line>Our spirits grew as we went side by side.</line>
      <line>The hour became her husband and my bride.</line>
      <line>Love that had robbed us so, thus blessed our dearth!</line>
      <line>The pilgrims of the year waxed very loud</line>
      <line>In multitudinous chatterings, as the flood</line>
      <line>Full brown came from the West, and like pale blood</line>
      <line>Expanded to the upper crimson cloud.</line>
      <line>Love that had robbed us of immortal things,</line>
      <line>This little moment mercifully gave,</line>
      <line>Where I have seen across the twilight wave</line>
      <line>The swan sail with her young beneath her wings.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Modern Love L</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus piteously Love closed what he begat:</line>
      <line>The union of this ever-diverse pair!</line>
      <line>These two were rapid falcons in a snare,</line>
      <line>Condemned to do the flitting of the bat.</line>
      <line>Lovers beneath the singing sky of May,</line>
      <line>They wandered once; clear as the dew on flowers:</line>
      <line>But they fed not on the advancing hours:</line>
      <line>Their hearts held cravings for the buried day.</line>
      <line>Then each applied to each that fatal knife,</line>
      <line>Deep questioning, which probes to endless dole.</line>
      <line>Ah, what a dusty answer gets the soul</line>
      <line>When hot for certainties in this our life!—</line>
      <line>In tragic hints here see what evermore</line>
      <line>Moves dark as yonder midnight ocean’s force,</line>
      <line>Thundering like ramping hosts of warrior horse,</line>
      <line>To throw that faint thin line upon the shore!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>When I Would Image</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I would image her features,</line>
      <line>Comes up a shrouded head:</line>
      <line>I touch the outlines, shrinking;</line>
      <line>She seems of the wandering dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when love asks for nothing,</line>
      <line>And lies on his bed of snow,</line>
      <line>The face slips under my eyelids,</line>
      <line>All in its living glow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like a dark cathedral city,</line>
      <line>Whose spires, and domes, and towers</line>
      <line>Quiver in violet lightnings,</line>
      <line>My soul basks on for hours.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Meredith</author>
    <date>1883</date>
    <title>Lucifer in Starlight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>On a starred night Prince Lucifer uprose.</line>
      <line>Tired of his dark dominion swung the fiend</line>
      <line>Above the rolling ball in cloud part screened,</line>
      <line>Where sinners hugged their spectre of repose.</line>
      <line>Poor prey to his hot fit of pride were those.</line>
      <line>And now upon his western wing he leaned,</line>
      <line>Now his huge bulk o’er Afric’s sands careened,</line>
      <line>Now the black planet shadowed Arctic snows.</line>
      <line>Soaring through wider zones that pricked his scars</line>
      <line>With memory of the old revolt from Awe,</line>
      <line>He reached a middle height, and at the stars,</line>
      <line>Which are the brain of heaven, he looked, and sank.</line>
      <line>Around the ancient track marched, rank on rank,</line>
      <line>The army of unalterable law.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>J. Stanyan Bigg</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>An Irish Picture</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A smoking swamp before a cottage door;</line>
      <line>A drowned dog bobbing to a soleless shoe;</line>
      <line>A broken wash-tub, with its ragged staves</line>
      <line>Swimming and ducking to a battered hat,</line>
      <line>Whenever the wind stirs the reedy slime;</line>
      <line>A tumbled peat-stack, dripping in the rain;</line>
      <line>A long, lank pig, with dissipated eyes,</line>
      <line>Leading a vagrant life among the moors;</line>
      <line>A rotting paling, and a plot of ground,</line>
      <line>With fifteen cabbage-stalks amid lush weeds;</line>
      <line>A moss-grown pathway, and a worn-out gate,</line>
      <line>Its broken bars down-dangling from the nails;</line>
      <line>A windy cottage, with a leaky thatch,</line>
      <line>And two dim windows set like eyes asquint;</line>
      <line>A bulging doorway, with a drunken lean;</line>
      <line>Two half-nude children dabbling in the mire,</line>
      <line>And scrambling eagerly for bottle-necks;</line>
      <line>A man akimbo at the open door,</line>
      <line>His battered hat slouched o’er his sottish eyes,</line>
      <line>Smoking contented in the falling rain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>Before Parting</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A month or twain to live on honeycomb</line>
      <line>Is pleasant; but one tires of scented time,</line>
      <line>Cold sweet recurrence of accepted rhyme,</line>
      <line>And that strong purple under juice and foam</line>
      <line>Where the wine’s heart has burst;</line>
      <line>Nor feel the latter kisses like the first.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Once yet, this poor one time; I will not pray</line>
      <line>Even to change the bitterness of it,</line>
      <line>The bitter taste ensuing on the sweet,</line>
      <line>To make your tears fall where your soft hair lay</line>
      <line>All blurred and heavy in some perfumed wise</line>
      <line>Over my face and eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And yet who knows what end the scythed wheat</line>
      <line>Makes of its foolish poppies’ mouths of red?</line>
      <line>These were not sown, these are not harvested,</line>
      <line>They grow a month and are cast under feet</line>
      <line>And none has care thereof,</line>
      <line>As none has care of a divided love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know each shadow of your lips by rote,</line>
      <line>Each change of love in eyelids and eyebrows;</line>
      <line>The fashion of fair temples tremulous</line>
      <line>With tender blood, and colour of your throat;</line>
      <line>I know not how love is gone out of this,</line>
      <line>Seeing that all was his.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love’s likeness there endures upon all these:</line>
      <line>But out of these one shall not gather love.</line>
      <line>Day hath not strength nor the night shade enough</line>
      <line>To make love whole and fill his lips with ease,</line>
      <line>As some bee-builded cell</line>
      <line>Feels at filled lips the heavy honey swell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know not how this last month leaves your hair</line>
      <line>Less full of purple colour and hid spice,</line>
      <line>And that luxurious trouble of closed eyes</line>
      <line>Is mixed with meaner shadow and waste care;</line>
      <line>And love, kissed out by pleasure, seems not yet</line>
      <line>Worth patience to regret.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1862</date>
    <title>After Death</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The four boards of the coffin lid</line>
      <line>Heard all the dead man did.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The first curse was in his mouth,</line>
      <line>Made of grave’s mould and deadly drouth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The next curse was in his head,</line>
      <line>Made of God’s work discomfited.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The next curse was in his hands,</line>
      <line>Made out of two grave-bands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The next curse was in his feet,</line>
      <line>Made out of a grave-sheet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I had fair coins red and white,</line>
      <line>And my name was as great light;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I had fair clothes green and red,</line>
      <line>And strong gold bound round my head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But no meat comes in my mouth,</line>
      <line>Now I fare as the worm doth;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And no gold binds in my hair,</line>
      <line>Now I fare as the blind fare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My live thews were of great strength,</line>
      <line>Now am I waxen a span’s length;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My live sides were full of lust,</line>
      <line>Now are they dried with dust.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The first board spake and said:</line>
      <line>‘Is it best eating flesh or bread?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The second answered it:</line>
      <line>‘Is wine or honey the more sweet?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The third board spake and said:</line>
      <line>‘Is red gold worth a girl’s gold head?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fourth made answer thus:</line>
      <line>‘All these things are as one with us.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dead man asked of them:</line>
      <line>‘Is the green land stained brown with flame?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Have they hewn my son for beasts to eat,</line>
      <line>And my wife’s body for beasts’ meat?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Have they boiled my maid in a brass pan,</line>
      <line>And built a gallows to hang my man?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The boards said to him:</line>
      <line>‘This is a lewd thing that ye deem.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your wife has gotten a golden bed,</line>
      <line>All the sheets are sewn with red.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your son has gotten a coat of silk,</line>
      <line>The sleeves are soft as curded milk.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your maid has gotten a kirtle new,</line>
      <line>All the skirt has braids of blue.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your man has gotten both ring and glove,</line>
      <line>Wrought well for eyes to love.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dead man answered thus:</line>
      <line>‘What good gift shall God give us?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The boards answered him anon:</line>
      <line>‘Flesh to feed hell’s worm upon.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>A Leave-Taking</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us go hence, my songs; she will not hear.</line>
      <line>Let us go hence together without fear;</line>
      <line>Keep silence now, for singing-time is over,</line>
      <line>And over all old things and all things dear.</line>
      <line>She loves not you nor me as all we love her.</line>
      <line>Yea, though we sang as angels in her ear,</line>
      <line>She would not hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us rise up and part; she will not know.</line>
      <line>Let us go seaward as the great winds go,</line>
      <line>Full of blown sand and foam; what help is here?</line>
      <line>There is no help, for all these things are so,</line>
      <line>And all the world is bitter as a tear.</line>
      <line>And how these things are, though ye strove to show,</line>
      <line>She would not know.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us go home and hence; she will not weep.</line>
      <line>We gave love many dreams and days to keep,</line>
      <line>Flowers without scent, and fruits that would not grow,</line>
      <line>Saying ‘If thou wilt, thrust in thy sickle and reap.’</line>
      <line>All is reaped now; no grass is left to mow;</line>
      <line>And we that sowed, though all we fell on sleep,</line>
      <line>She would not weep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us go hence and rest; she will not love.</line>
      <line>She shall not hear us if we sing hereof,</line>
      <line>Nor see love’s ways, how sore they are and steep.</line>
      <line>Come hence, let be, lie still; it is enough.</line>
      <line>Love is a barren sea, bitter and deep;</line>
      <line>And though she saw all heaven in flower above,</line>
      <line>She would not love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us give up, go down; she will not care.</line>
      <line>Though all the stars made gold of all the air,</line>
      <line>And the sea moving saw before it move</line>
      <line>One moon-flower making all the foam-flowers fair;</line>
      <line>Though all those waves went over us, and drove</line>
      <line>Deep down the stifling lips and drowning hair,</line>
      <line>She would not care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let us go hence, go hence; she will not see.</line>
      <line>Sing all once more together; surely she,</line>
      <line>She too, remembering days and words that were,</line>
      <line>Will turn a little toward us, sighing; but we,</line>
      <line>We are hence, we are gone, as though we had not been there.</line>
      <line>Nay, and though all men seeing had pity on me,</line>
      <line>She would not see.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>Ilicet</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is an end of joy and sorrow;</line>
      <line>Peace all day long, all night, all morrow,</line>
      <line>But never a time to laugh or weep.</line>
      <line>The end is come of pleasant places,</line>
      <line>The end of tender words and faces,</line>
      <line>The end of all, the poppied sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No place for sound within their hearing,</line>
      <line>No room for hope, no time for fearing,</line>
      <line>No lips to laugh, no lids for tears.</line>
      <line>The old years have run out all their measure;</line>
      <line>No chance of pain, no chance of pleasure,</line>
      <line>No fragment of the broken years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Outside of all the worlds and ages,</line>
      <line>There where the fool is as the sage is,</line>
      <line>There where the slayer is clean of blood,</line>
      <line>No end, no passage, no beginning,</line>
      <line>There where the sinner leaves off sinning,</line>
      <line>There where the good man is not good.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is not one thing with another,</line>
      <line>But Evil saith to Good: My brother,</line>
      <line>My brother, I am one with thee:</line>
      <line>They shall not strive nor cry for ever:</line>
      <line>No man shall choose between them: never</line>
      <line>Shall this thing end and that thing be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wind wherein seas and stars are shaken</line>
      <line>Shall shake them, and they shall not waken;</line>
      <line>None that has lain down shall arise;</line>
      <line>The stones are sealed across their places;</line>
      <line>One shadow is shed on all their faces,</line>
      <line>One blindness cast on all their eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep, is it sleep perchance that covers</line>
      <line>Each face, as each face were his lover’s?</line>
      <line>Farewell; as men that sleep fare well.</line>
      <line>The grave’s mouth laughs unto derision</line>
      <line>Desire and dread and dream and vision,</line>
      <line>Delight of heaven and sorrow of hell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No soul shall tell nor lip shall number</line>
      <line>The names and tribes of you that slumber;</line>
      <line>No memory, no memorial.</line>
      <line>‘Thou knowest’—who shall say thou knowest?</line>
      <line>There is none highest and none lowest:</line>
      <line>An end, an end, an end of all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Good night, good sleep, good rest from sorrow</line>
      <line>To these that shall not have good morrow;</line>
      <line>The gods be gentle to all these.</line>
      <line>Nay, if death be not, how shall they be?</line>
      <line>Nay, is there help in heaven? it may be</line>
      <line>All things and lords of things shall cease.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The stooped urn, filling, dips and flashes;</line>
      <line>The bronzed brims are deep in ashes;</line>
      <line>The pale old lips of death are fed.</line>
      <line>Shall this dust gather flesh hereafter?</line>
      <line>Shall one shed tears or fall to laughter,</line>
      <line>At sight of all these poor old dead?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nay, as thou wilt; these know not of it;</line>
      <line>Thine eyes’ strong weeping shall not profit,</line>
      <line>Thy laughter shall not give thee ease;</line>
      <line>Cry aloud, spare not, cease not crying,</line>
      <line>Sigh, till thou cleave thy sides with sighing,</line>
      <line>Thou shalt not raise up one of these.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Burnt spices flash, and burnt wine hisses,</line>
      <line>The breathing flame’s mouth curls and kisses</line>
      <line>The small dried rows of frankincense;</line>
      <line>All round the sad red blossoms smoulder,</line>
      <line>Flowers coloured like the fire, but colder,</line>
      <line>In sign of sweet things taken hence;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yea, for their sake and in death’s favour</line>
      <line>Things of sweet shape and of sweet savour</line>
      <line>We yield them, spice and flower and wine;</line>
      <line>Yea, costlier things than wine or spices,</line>
      <line>Whereof none knoweth how great the price is,</line>
      <line>And fruit that comes not of the vine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From boy’s pierced throat and girl’s pierced bosom</line>
      <line>Drips, reddening round the blood-red blossom,</line>
      <line>The slow delicious bright soft blood,</line>
      <line>Bathing the spices and the pyre,</line>
      <line>Bathing the flowers and fallen fire,</line>
      <line>Bathing the blossom by the bud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Roses whose lips the flame has deadened</line>
      <line>Drink till the lapping leaves are reddened</line>
      <line>And warm wet inner petals w'eep;</line>
      <line>The flower whereof sick sleep gets leisure,</line>
      <line>Barren of balm and purple pleasure,</line>
      <line>Fumes with no native steam of sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why will ye weep? what do ye weeping?</line>
      <line>For waking folk and people sleeping,</line>
      <line>And sands that fill and sands that fall,</line>
      <line>The days rose-red, the poppied hours,</line>
      <line>Blood, wine, and spice and fire and flowers,</line>
      <line>There is one end of one and all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Shall such an one lend love or borrow?</line>
      <line>Shall these be sorry for thy sorrow?</line>
      <line>Shall these give thanks for words or breath?</line>
      <line>Their hate is as their loving-kindness;</line>
      <line>The frontlet of their brows is blindness,</line>
      <line>The armlet of their arms is death.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lo, for no noise or light of thunder</line>
      <line>Shall these grave-clothes be rent in sunder;</line>
      <line>He that hath taken, shall he give?</line>
      <line>He hath rent them: shall he bind together? 1</line>
      <line>He hath bound them: shall he break the tether?</line>
      <line>He hath slain them: shall he bid them live?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little sorrow, a little pleasure,</line>
      <line>Fate metes us from the dusty measure</line>
      <line>That holds the date of all of us;</line>
      <line>We are born with travail and strong crying,</line>
      <line>And from the birth-day to the dying</line>
      <line>The likeness of our life is thus.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One girds himself to serve another,</line>
      <line>Whose father was the dust, whose mother</line>
      <line>The little dead red worm therein;</line>
      <line>They find no fruit of things they cherish;</line>
      <line>The goodness of a man shall perish,</line>
      <line>It shall be one thing with his sin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In deep wet ways by grey old gardens</line>
      <line>Fed with sharp spring the sweet fruit hardens;</line>
      <line>They know not what fruits wane or grow;</line>
      <line>Red summer burns to the utmost ember;</line>
      <line>They know not, neither can remember,</line>
      <line>The old years and flowers they used to know.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, for their sakes, so trapped and taken,</line>
      <line>For theirs, forgotten and forsaken,</line>
      <line>Watch, sleep not, gird thyself with prayer.</line>
      <line>Nay, where the heart of wrath is broken,</line>
      <line>Where long love ends as a thing spoken,</line>
      <line>How shall thy crying enter there?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though the iron sides of the old world falter,</line>
      <line>The likeness of them shall not alter</line>
      <line>For all the rumour of periods,</line>
      <line>The stars and seasons that come after,</line>
      <line>The tears of latter men, the laughter</line>
      <line>Of the old unalterable gods.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Far up above the years and nations,</line>
      <line>The high gods, clothed and crowned with patience,</line>
      <line>Endure through days of deathlike date;</line>
      <line>They bear the witness of things hidden;</line>
      <line>Before their eyes all life stands chidden,</line>
      <line>As they before the eyes of Fate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not for their love shall Fate retire,</line>
      <line>Nor they relent for our desire,</line>
      <line>Nor the graves open for their call.</line>
      <line>The end is more than joy and anguish,</line>
      <line>Than lives that laugh and lives that languish,</line>
      <line>The poppied sleep, the end of all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>A Match</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>If love were what the rose is,</line>
      <line>And I were like the leaf,</line>
      <line>Our lives would grow together</line>
      <line>In sad or singing weather,</line>
      <line>Blown fields or flowerful closes,</line>
      <line>Green pleasure or grey grief;</line>
      <line>If love were what the rose is,</line>
      <line>And I were like the leaf.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If I were what the words are,</line>
      <line>And love were like the tune,</line>
      <line>With double sound and single</line>
      <line>Delight our lips would mingle,</line>
      <line>With kisses glad as birds are</line>
      <line>That get sweet rain at noon;</line>
      <line>If I were what the words are,</line>
      <line>And love were like the tune.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If you were life, my darling,</line>
      <line>And I your love were death,</line>
      <line>We’d shine and snow together</line>
      <line>Ere March made sweet the weather</line>
      <line>With daffodil and starling</line>
      <line>And hours of fruitful breath;</line>
      <line>If you were life, my darling,</line>
      <line>And I your love were death.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If you were thrall to sorrow,</line>
      <line>And I were page to joy,</line>
      <line>We’d play for lives and seasons</line>
      <line>With loving looks and treasons</line>
      <line>And tears of night and morrow</line>
      <line>And laughs of maid and boy;</line>
      <line>If you were thrall to sorrow,</line>
      <line>And I were page to joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If you were April’s lady,</line>
      <line>And I were lord in May,</line>
      <line>We’d throw with leaves for hours</line>
      <line>And draw for days with flowers,</line>
      <line>Till day like night were shady</line>
      <line>And night were bright like day;</line>
      <line>If you were April’s lady,</line>
      <line>And I were lord in May.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If you were queen of pleasure,</line>
      <line>And I were king of pain,</line>
      <line>We’d hunt down love together,</line>
      <line>Pluck out his flying-feather,</line>
      <line>And teach his feet a measure,</line>
      <line>And find his mouth a rein;</line>
      <line>If you were queen of pleasure,</line>
      <line>And I were king of pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>The Leper</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nothing is better, I well think,</line>
      <line>Than love; the hidden well-water</line>
      <line>Is not so delicate to drink:</line>
      <line>This was well seen of me and her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I served her in a royal house;</line>
      <line>I served her wine and curious meat.</line>
      <line>For will to kiss between her brows,</line>
      <line>I had no heart to sleep or eat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mere scorn God knows she had of me,</line>
      <line>A poor scribe, nowise great or fair,</line>
      <line>Who plucked his clerk’s hood back to see</line>
      <line>Her curled-up lips and amorous hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I vex my head with thinking this.</line>
      <line>Yea, though God always hated me,</line>
      <line>And hates me now that I can kiss</line>
      <line>Her eyes, plait up her hair to see</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How she then wore it on the brows,</line>
      <line>Yet am I glad to have her dead</line>
      <line>Here in this wretched wattled house</line>
      <line>Where I can kiss her eyes and head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nothing is better, I well know,</line>
      <line>Than love; no amber in cold sea</line>
      <line>Or gathered berries under snow:</line>
      <line>That is well seen of her and me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Three thoughts I make my pleasure of:</line>
      <line>First I take heart and think of this:</line>
      <line>That knight’s gold hair she chose to love,</line>
      <line>His mouth she had such will to kiss.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then I remember that sundawn</line>
      <line>I brought him by a privy way</line>
      <line>Out at her lattice, and thereon</line>
      <line>What gracious words she found to say.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>(Cold rushes for such little feet—</line>
      <line>Both feet could lie into my hand.</line>
      <line>A marvel was it of my sweet</line>
      <line>Her upright body could so stand.)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sweet friend, God give you thank and grace;</line>
      <line>Now am I clean and whole of shame,</line>
      <line>Nor shall men burn me in the face</line>
      <line>For my sweet fault that scandals them.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I tell you over word by word.</line>
      <line>She, sitting edgewise on her bed,</line>
      <line>Holding her feet, said thus. The third,</line>
      <line>A sweeter thing than these, I said.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>God, that makes time and ruins it</line>
      <line>And alters not, abiding God,</line>
      <line>Changed with disease her body sweet,</line>
      <line>The body of love wherein she abode.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love is more sweet and comelier</line>
      <line>Than a dove’s throat strained out to sing.</line>
      <line>All they spat out and cursed at her</line>
      <line>And cast her forth for a base thing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They cursed her, seeing how God had wrought</line>
      <line>This curse to plague her, a curse of his.</line>
      <line>Fools were they surely, seeing not</line>
      <line>How sweeter than all sweet she is.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He that had held her by the hair,</line>
      <line>With kissing lips blinding her eyes,</line>
      <line>Felt her bright bosom, strained and bare,</line>
      <line>Sigh under him, with short mad cries</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Out of her throat and sobbing mouth</line>
      <line>And body broken up with love,</line>
      <line>With sweet hot tears his lips were loth</line>
      <line>Her own should taste the savour of,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yea, he inside whose grasp all night</line>
      <line>Her fervent body leapt or lay,</line>
      <line>Stained with sharp kisses red and white,</line>
      <line>Found her a plague to spurn away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hid her in this wattled house,</line>
      <line>I served her water and poor bread.</line>
      <line>For joy to kiss between her brows</line>
      <line>Time upon time I was nigh dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bread failed; we got but well-water</line>
      <line>And gathered grass with dropping seed.</line>
      <line>I had such joy of kissing her,</line>
      <line>I had small care to sleep or feed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sometimes when service made me glad</line>
      <line>The sharp tears leapt between my lids,</line>
      <line>Falling on her, such joy I had</line>
      <line>To do the service God forbids.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I pray you let me be at peace,</line>
      <line>Get hence, make room for me to die.’</line>
      <line>She said that: her poor lip would cease,</line>
      <line>Put up to mine, and turn to cry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said, ‘Bethink yourself how love</line>
      <line>Fared in us twain, what either did;</line>
      <line>Shall I unclothe my soul thereof?</line>
      <line>That I should do this, God forbid.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yea, though God hateth us, he knows</line>
      <line>That hardly in a little thing</line>
      <line>Love faileth of the work it does</line>
      <line>Till it grow ripe for gathering.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Six months, and now my sweet is dead</line>
      <line>A trouble takes me; I know not</line>
      <line>If all were done well, all well said,</line>
      <line>No word or tender deed forgot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Too sweet, for the least part in her,</line>
      <line>To have shed life out by fragments; yet,</line>
      <line>Could the close mouth catch breath and stir,</line>
      <line>I might see something I forget.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Six months, and I sit still and hold</line>
      <line>In two cold palms her cold two feet.</line>
      <line>Her hair, half grey half ruined gold,</line>
      <line>Thrills me and burns me in kissing it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love bites and stings me through, to see</line>
      <line>Her keen face made of sunken bones.</line>
      <line>Her worn-off eyelids madden me,</line>
      <line>That were shot through with purple once.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She said, ‘Be good with me; I grow</line>
      <line>So tired for shame’s sake, I shall die</line>
      <line>If you say nothing:’ even so.</line>
      <line>And she is dead now, and shame put by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yea, and the scorn she had of me</line>
      <line>In the old time, doubtless vexed her then.</line>
      <line>I never should have kissed her. See</line>
      <line>What fools God’s anger makes of men!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She might have loved me a little too,</line>
      <line>Had I been humbler for her sake.</line>
      <line>But that new shame could make love new</line>
      <line>She saw not—yet her shame did make.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took too much upon my love,</line>
      <line>Having for such mean service done</line>
      <line>Her beauty and all the ways thereof,</line>
      <line>Her face and all the sweet thereon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yea, all this while I tended her,</line>
      <line>I know the old love held fast his part:</line>
      <line>I know the old scorn waxed heavier,</line>
      <line>Mixed with sad wonder, in her heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It may be all my love went wrong—</line>
      <line>A scribe’s work writ awry and blurred,</line>
      <line>Scrawled after the blind evensong—</line>
      <line>Spoilt music with no perfect word.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But surely I would fain have done</line>
      <line>All things the best I could. Perchance</line>
      <line>Because I failed, came short of one,</line>
      <line>She kept at heart that other man’s.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am grown blind with all these things:</line>
      <line>It may be now she hath in sight</line>
      <line>Some better knowledge; still there clings</line>
      <line>The old question. Will not God do right?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>The Garden of Proserpine</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here, where the world is quiet;</line>
      <line>Here, where all trouble seems</line>
      <line>Dead winds’ and spent waves’ riot</line>
      <line>In doubtful dreams of dreams;</line>
      <line>I watch the green field growing</line>
      <line>For reaping folk and sowing,</line>
      <line>For harvest-time and mowing,</line>
      <line>A sleepy world of streams.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am tired of tears and laughter,</line>
      <line>And men that laugh and weep;</line>
      <line>Of what may come hereafter</line>
      <line>For men that sow to reap:</line>
      <line>I am weary of days and hours,</line>
      <line>Blown buds of barren flowers,</line>
      <line>Desires and dreams and powers</line>
      <line>And everything but sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here life has death for neighbour,</line>
      <line>And far from eye or ear</line>
      <line>Wan waves and wet winds labour,</line>
      <line>Weak ships and spirits steer;</line>
      <line>They drive adrift, and whither</line>
      <line>They wot not who make thither;</line>
      <line>But no such winds blow hither,</line>
      <line>And no such things grow here.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No growth of moor or coppice,</line>
      <line>No heather-flower or vine,</line>
      <line>But bloomless buds of poppies,</line>
      <line>Green grapes of Proserpine,</line>
      <line>Pale beds of blowing rushes</line>
      <line>Where no leaf blooms or blushes</line>
      <line>Save this whereout she crushes</line>
      <line>For dead men deadly wine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pale, without name or number,</line>
      <line>In fruitless fields of corn,</line>
      <line>They bow themselves and slumber</line>
      <line>All night till light is born;</line>
      <line>And like a soul belated,</line>
      <line>In hell and heaven unmated,</line>
      <line>By cloud and mist abated</line>
      <line>Comes out of darkness morn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though one were strong as seven,</line>
      <line>He too with death shall dwell,</line>
      <line>Nor wake with wings in heaven,</line>
      <line>Nor weep for pains in hell;</line>
      <line>Though one were fair as roses,</line>
      <line>His beauty clouds and closes;</line>
      <line>And well though love reposes,</line>
      <line>In the end it is not well.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pale, beyond porch and portal,</line>
      <line>Crowned with calm leaves, she stands</line>
      <line>Who gathers all things mortal</line>
      <line>With cold immortal hands;</line>
      <line>Her languid lips are sweeter</line>
      <line>Than love’s who fears to greet her</line>
      <line>To men that mix and meet her</line>
      <line>From many times and lands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She waits for each and other,</line>
      <line>She waits for all men born;</line>
      <line>Forgets the earth her mother,</line>
      <line>The life of fruits and corn;</line>
      <line>And spring and seed and swallow</line>
      <line>Take wing for her and follow</line>
      <line>Where summer song rings hollow</line>
      <line>And flowers are put to scorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There go the loves that wither,</line>
      <line>The old loves with wearier wings;</line>
      <line>And all dead years draw thither,</line>
      <line>And all disastrous things;</line>
      <line>Dead dreams of days forsaken,</line>
      <line>Blind buds that snows have shaken,</line>
      <line>Wild leaves that winds have taken,</line>
      <line>Red strays of ruined springs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We are not sure of sorrow,</line>
      <line>And joy was never sure;</line>
      <line>To-day will die to-morrow;</line>
      <line>Time stoops to no man’s lure;</line>
      <line>And love, grown faint and fretful,</line>
      <line>With lips but half regretful</line>
      <line>Sighs, and with eyes forgetful</line>
      <line>Weeps that no loves endure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From too much love of living,</line>
      <line>From hope and fear set free,</line>
      <line>We thank with brief thanksgiving</line>
      <line>Whatever gods may be</line>
      <line>That no life lives for ever;</line>
      <line>That dead men rise up never;</line>
      <line>That even the weariest river</line>
      <line>Winds somewhere safe to sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then star nor sun shall waken,</line>
      <line>Nor any change of light:</line>
      <line>Nor sound of waters shaken,</line>
      <line>Nor any sound or sight:</line>
      <line>Nor wintry leaves nor vernal,</line>
      <line>Nor days nor things diurnal;</line>
      <line>Only the sleep eternal</line>
      <line>In an eternal night.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>Why grudge them lotus-leaf and laurel,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why grudge them lotus-leaf and laurel,</line>
      <line>O toothless mouth or swinish maw,</line>
      <line>Who never grudged you bells and coral,</line>
      <line>Who never grudged you troughs and straw?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lie still in kennel, sleek in stable,</line>
      <line>Good creatures of the stall or sty;</line>
      <line>Shove snouts for crumbs below the table;</line>
      <line>Lie still; and rise not up to lie.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Algernon Charles Swinburne</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>A Forsaken Garden</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In a coign of the cliff between lowland and highland,</line>
      <line>At the sea-down’s edge between windward and lee,</line>
      <line>Walled round with rocks as an inland island,</line>
      <line>The ghost of a garden fronts the sea.</line>
      <line>A girdle of brushwood and thorn encloses</line>
      <line>The steep square slope of the blossomless bed</line>
      <line>Where the weeds that grew green from the graves of its roses</line>
      <line>Now lie dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fields fall southward, abrupt and broken,</line>
      <line>To the low last edge of the long lone land.</line>
      <line>If a step should sound or a word be spoken,</line>
      <line>Would a ghost not rise at the strange guest’s hand?</line>
      <line>So long have the grey bare walks lain guestless,</line>
      <line>Through branches and briars if a man make way,</line>
      <line>He shall find no life but the sea-wind’s, restless</line>
      <line>Night and day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dense hard passage is blind and stifled</line>
      <line>That crawls by a track none turn to climb</line>
      <line>To the strait waste place that the years have rifled</line>
      <line>Of all but the thorns that are touched not of time.</line>
      <line>The thorns he spares when the rose is taken;</line>
      <line>The rocks are left when he wastes the plain.</line>
      <line>The wind that wanders, the weeds wind-shaken,</line>
      <line>These remain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not a flower to be pressed of the foot that falls not;</line>
      <line>As the heart of a dead man the seed-plots are dry;</line>
      <line>From the thicket of thorns whence the nightingale calls not,</line>
      <line>Could she call, there were never a rose to reply.</line>
      <line>Over the meadows that blossom and wither</line>
      <line>Rings but the note of a sea-bird’s song;</line>
      <line>Only the sun and the rain come hither</line>
      <line>All year long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun burns sere and the rain dishevels</line>
      <line>One gaunt bleak blossom of scentless breath.</line>
      <line>Only the wind here hovers and revels</line>
      <line>In a round where life seems barren as death.</line>
      <line>Here there was laughing of old, there was weeping,</line>
      <line>Haply, of lovers none ever will know,</line>
      <line>Whose eyes went seaward a hundred sleeping</line>
      <line>Years ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Heart handfast in heart as they stood, ‘Look thither,’</line>
      <line>Did he whisper? ‘look forth from the flowers to the sea;</line>
      <line>For the foam-flowers endure when the rose-blossoms wither,</line>
      <line>And men that love lightly may die—but we?’</line>
      <line>And the same wind sang and the same waves whitened,</line>
      <line>And or ever the garden’s last petals were shed,</line>
      <line>In the lips that had whispered, the eyes that had lightened,</line>
      <line>Love was dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or they loved their life through, and then went whither?</line>
      <line>And were one to the end—but what end who knows?</line>
      <line>Love deep as the sea as a rose must wither,</line>
      <line>As the rose-red seaweed that mocks the rose.</line>
      <line>Shall the dead take thought for the dead to love them?</line>
      <line>What love was ever as deep as a grave?</line>
      <line>They are loveless now as the grass above them</line>
      <line>Or the wave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All are at one now, roses and lovers,</line>
      <line>Not known of the cliffs and the fields and the sea.</line>
      <line>Not a breath of the time that has been hovers</line>
      <line>In the air now soft with a summer to be.</line>
      <line>Not a breath shall there sweeten the seasons hereafter</line>
      <line>Of the flowers or the lovers that laugh now or weep,</line>
      <line>When as they that are free now of weeping and laughter</line>
      <line>We shall sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here death may deal not again for ever;</line>
      <line>Here change may come not till all change end.</line>
      <line>From the graves they have made they shall rise up never,</line>
      <line>Who have left nought living to ravage and rend.</line>
      <line>Earth, stones, and thorns of the wild ground growing,</line>
      <line>While the sun and the rain live, these shall be;</line>
      <line>Till a last wind’s breath upon all these blowing</line>
      <line>Roll the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till the slow sea rise and the sheer cliff crumble,</line>
      <line>Till terrace and meadow the deep gulfs drink,</line>
      <line>Till the strength of the waves of the high tides humble</line>
      <line>The Helds that lessen, the rocks that shrink,</line>
      <line>Here now in his triumph where all things falter,</line>
      <line>Stretched out on the spoils that his own hand spread,</line>
      <line>As a god self-slain on his own strange altar,</line>
      <line>Death lies dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1863</date>
    <title>Philoctetes</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Silence on silence treads at each low mom.</line>
      <line>Pain and new pain, some glimpse of painless sleep,</line>
      <line>And waking to old anguish and new day:</line>
      <line>Blasted of glory, sundered from my kind:</line>
      <line>My hearth, my realm, the lips that love me, lost:</line>
      <line>So runs it. ’Tis some courage to keep life</line>
      <line>Where life is worthless, and on feeble stay</line>
      <line>To dwell in hope of better till we die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hate this island steep, this seam of beach.</line>
      <line>This ample desolation of gray rock</line>
      <line>Man tills not: and man reaps not, woe is me!</line>
      <line>No voices, save stress-landed mariners</line>
      <line>Leaning in ring with eyebrow-level wrists</line>
      <line>To watch the scummy rack and buzzing waves,</line>
      <line>Toss me a word in pity: stare and pass</line>
      <line>Grinding a clumsy jest or surly sneer.</line>
      <line>Yet in their talk I gather waifs and strays</line>
      <line>Of that great Trojan battle how it goes;</line>
      <line>Of beardless youths who gain down heaven with deeds,</line>
      <line>And all the noise and turmoil of the thing,</line>
      <line>Deed quenching deed, and echo’s swollen boast,</line>
      <line>While I am rotting here and touch no praise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ye have done well to leave me. ’Tis most wise,</line>
      <line>And friendly too, expedient, generous:</line>
      <line>Why this is bounty’s crown; I have deserved</line>
      <line>No less than a sick hound: full thanks for all.</line>
      <line>My kings and comrades, ye are wise and brave,</line>
      <line>As wise as brave, and brave your chiefest voice</line>
      <line>Of foxy Ithaca: ’twas nobly said,</line>
      <line>‘Pack out the carrion on this leeward Isle.</line>
      <line>We need no wounded leaders, no, nor fear.</line>
      <line>His men and ships are needed; they sail on:</line>
      <line>They cannot heal him, and our need is great.’</line>
      <line>Why, man, this is true valour and no theft:</line>
      <line>I could not quit thee, and kings cannot steal.</line>
      <line>But if I meet thy foxship afterdays,</line>
      <line>With half an arm to raise and half a spear,</line>
      <line>I’ll mar that serpent face and false gray smile,</line>
      <line>And leave thy surgy rock without a king.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas, alas, how mean a thing am I</line>
      <line>To rail and threat and bluster like a God.</line>
      <line>The old pain trembles thro’ me marrow-deep,</line>
      <line>A quivering mass of earth, than earth no more,</line>
      <line>Earth gifted with a cunning power of pain,</line>
      <line>Full knowledge of its fall and loathsomeness,</line>
      <line>Craving for enterprize in impotence,</line>
      <line>Some little sleep and all the rest a pain—</line>
      <line>Shall such a thing have pride or hoard revenge?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I loathe the glancing sameness of this brine,</line>
      <line>Its hissing suck of waves, its equal face.</line>
      <line>I loathe the toss of sails, the pass of clouds,</line>
      <line>The white wings curving on the tawny rocks,</line>
      <line>The evening and the dawning and the day.</line>
      <line>We thrive by action, I am chained from all,</line>
      <line>And I forget the pleasure of this earth,</line>
      <line>Of all but pain and slow time dispossess’d.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet is there hope; slow hope yet comfort sure,</line>
      <line>I had forgot it in my wrath and pain.</line>
      <line>Is there no oracle? Troy cannot fall.</line>
      <line>I guard thine arrows, Heracles divine,</line>
      <line>And Troy falls not without them year on year.</line>
      <line>I hoard them as the marrow of my bones,</line>
      <line>Sweet nurses to revenge. Oh, fate is just.</line>
      <line>Ye reap, my kings, wound-harvest and much dead,</line>
      <line>Thinn’d troops, and kingdoms waned to wrack at home,</line>
      <line>And gloomy faces by a gloomy sea,</line>
      <line>And firm-braced Troy before, the sponge of toil,</line>
      <line>And all your warring as an idle dream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I can abide my hour it is so sure,</line>
      <line>I lean on this unstumbling oracle,</line>
      <line>And nourish hope, till worn with many woes</line>
      <line>The haught Kings fall in thinking on the wreck</line>
      <line>They left by Lemnos and the archer hand</line>
      <line>Once fellowless in Hellas. They shall come,</line>
      <line>By Zeus I swear it, they shall come in shame,</line>
      <line>And stand in shame before the man they wrong’d</line>
      <line>And weeded out as refuse. See, they bend,</line>
      <line>Pestilent faces crusted in meek smiles,</line>
      <line>And supple eyes and all the fawn of need:</line>
      <line>And one mouths out on justice, gratitude,</line>
      <line>The cause of Hellas. Then another smooths</line>
      <line>My name with praise, and all the worthy ring</line>
      <line>Lisp sympathy with dew on glassy cheeks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet oracle, thou climax of revenge,</line>
      <line>I will wear out my painful coil in joy,</line>
      <line>Voiceless of all complaining, firm and sure</line>
      <line>The Gods are just, and compensation comes.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1863</date>
    <title>The Power of Interval</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fair girl tripping out to meet her love,</line>
      <line>Trimmed in her best, fresh as a clover bud.</line>
      <line>An old crone leaning at an ember’d fire,</line>
      <line>Short-breath’d in sighs and moaning to herself—</line>
      <line>And all the interval of stealing years</line>
      <line>To make that this, and one by one detach</line>
      <line>Some excellent condition; till Despair</line>
      <line>Faint at the vision, sadly, fiercely blinds</line>
      <line>Her burning eyes on her forgetful hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1870</date>
    <title>The Knight in the Wood</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The thing itself was rough and crudely done,</line>
      <line>Cut in coarse stone, spitefully placed aside</line>
      <line>As merest lumber, where the light was worst</line>
      <line>On a back staircase. Overlooked it lay</line>
      <line>In a great Roman palace crammed with art.</line>
      <line>It had no number in the list of gems,</line>
      <line>Weeded away long since, pushed out and banished,</line>
      <line>Before insipid Guidos over-sweet</line>
      <line>And Dolce’s rose sensationalities,</line>
      <line>And curly chirping angels spruce as birds.</line>
      <line>And yet the motive of this thing ill-hewn</line>
      <line>And hardly seen did touch me. O, indeed,</line>
      <line>The skill-less hand that carved it had belonged</line>
      <line>To a most yearning and bewildered brain:</line>
      <line>There was such desolation in the work;</line>
      <line>And through its utter failure the thing spoke</line>
      <line>With more of human message, heart to heart,</line>
      <line>Than all these faultless, smirking, skin-deep saints,</line>
      <line>In artificial troubles picturesque,</line>
      <line>And martyred sweetly, not one curl awry—</line>
      <line>Listen; a clumsy knight, who rode alone</line>
      <line>Upon a stumbling jade in a great wood</line>
      <line>Belated. The poor beast with head low-bowed</line>
      <line>Snuffing the treacherous ground. The rider leant</line>
      <line>Forward to sound the marish with his lance.</line>
      <line>You saw the place was deadly; that doomed pair,</line>
      <line>The wretched rider and the hide-bound steed,</line>
      <line>Feared to advance, feared to return—That’s all!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1873</date>
    <title>Nuptial Song ‘Sigh, Heart, Break Not ’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sigh, heart, and break not; rest, lark, and wake not!</line>
      <line>Day I hear coming to draw my Love away.</line>
      <line>As mere-waves whisper, and clouds grow crisper,</line>
      <line>Ah, like a rose he will waken up with day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In moon-light lonely, he is my Love only,</line>
      <line>I share with none when Luna rides in grey.</line>
      <line>As dawn-beams quicken, my rivals thicken,</line>
      <line>The light and deed and turmoil of the day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To watch my sleeper to me is sweeter,</line>
      <line>Than any waking words my Love can say;</line>
      <line>In dream he finds me and closer winds me!</line>
      <line>Let him rest by me a little more and stay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, mine eyes, close not: and, tho’ he knows not,</line>
      <line>My lips, on his be tender while you may;</line>
      <line>Ere leaves are shaken, and ring-doves waken,</line>
      <line>And infant buds begin to scent new day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair Darkness, measure thine hours, as treasure</line>
      <line>Shed each one slowly from thine urn, I pray;</line>
      <line>Hoard in and cover each from my lover;</line>
      <line>I cannot lose him yet; dear night, delay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each moment dearer, true-love, lie nearer,</line>
      <line>My hair shall blind thee lest thou see the ray;</line>
      <line>My locks encumber thine ears in slumber,</line>
      <line>Lest any bird dare give thee note of day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He rests so calmly; we lie so warmly;</line>
      <line>Hand within hand, as children after play;—</line>
      <line>In shafted amber on roof and chamber</line>
      <line>Dawn enters; my Love wakens; here is day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1873</date>
    <title>The Churchyard on the Sands</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My Love lies in the gates of foam,</line>
      <line>The last dear wreck of shore;</line>
      <line>The naked sea-marsh binds her home,</line>
      <line>The sand her chamber door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The grey gull flaps the written stones,</line>
      <line>The ox-birds chase the tide;</line>
      <line>And near that narrow field of bones</line>
      <line>Great ships at anchor ride.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Black piers with crust of dripping green,</line>
      <line>One foreland, like a hand,</line>
      <line>O’er intervals of grass between</line>
      <line>Dim lonely dunes of sand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A church of silent weathered looks,</line>
      <line>A breezy reddish tower,</line>
      <line>A yard whose mounded resting-nooks</line>
      <line>Are tinged with sorrel flower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In peace the swallow’s eggs are laid</line>
      <line>Along the belfry walls;</line>
      <line>The tempest does not reach her shade,</line>
      <line>The rain her silent halls.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But sails are sweet in summer sky,</line>
      <line>The lark throws down a lay;</line>
      <line>The long salt levels steam and dry,</line>
      <line>The cloud-heart melts away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But patches of the sea-pink shine,</line>
      <line>The pied crows poise and come;</line>
      <line>The mallow hangs, the bindweeds twine,</line>
      <line>Where her sweet lips are dumb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The passion of the wave is mute;</line>
      <line>No sound or ocean shock;</line>
      <line>No music save the trilling flute</line>
      <line>That marks the curlew flock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But yonder when the wind is keen,</line>
      <line>And rainy air is clear,</line>
      <line>The merchant city’s spires are seen,</line>
      <line>The toil of men grows near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Along the coast-way grind the wheels</line>
      <line>Of endless carts of coal;</line>
      <line>And on the sides of giant keels</line>
      <line>The shipyard hammers roll.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world creeps here upon the shout,</line>
      <line>And stirs my heart in pain;</line>
      <line>The mist descends and blots it out,</line>
      <line>And I am strong again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Strong and alone, my dove, with thee;</line>
      <line>And, tho’ mine eyes be wet,</line>
      <line>There’s nothing in the world to me</line>
      <line>So dear as my regret.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I would not change my sorrow, sweet,</line>
      <line>For others’ nuptial hours;</line>
      <line>I love the daisies at thy feet</line>
      <line>More than their orange flowers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My hand alone shall tend thy tomb</line>
      <line>From leaf-bud to leaf-fall,</line>
      <line>And wreathe around each season’s bloom</line>
      <line>Till autumn ruins all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let snowdrops, early in the year,</line>
      <line>Droop o’er her silent breast;</line>
      <line>And bid the later cowslip rear</line>
      <line>The amber of its crest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come hither, linnets tufted-red,</line>
      <line>Drift by, O wailing tern;</line>
      <line>Set pure vale lilies at her head,</line>
      <line>At her feet lady-fern.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Grow, samphire, at the tidal brink,</line>
      <line>Wave, pansies of the shore,</line>
      <line>To whisper how alone I think</line>
      <line>Of her for evermore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bring blue sea-hollies thorny, keen,</line>
      <line>Long lavender in flower;</line>
      <line>Grey wormwood like a hoary queen,</line>
      <line>Stanch mullein like a tower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O sea-wall mounded long and low,</line>
      <line>Let iron bounds be thine;</line>
      <line>Nor let the salt wave overflow</line>
      <line>That breast I held divine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nor float its sea-weed to her hair,</line>
      <line>Nor dim her eyes with sands:</line>
      <line>No fluted cockle burrow where</line>
      <line>Sleep folds her patient hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tho’ thy crest feel the wild sea’s breath,</line>
      <line>Tho’ tide-weight tear thy root,</line>
      <line>Oh, guard the treasure house, where Death</line>
      <line>Has bound my darling mute.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tho’ cold her pale lips to reward</line>
      <line>With Love’s own mysteries,</line>
      <line>Ah, rob no daisy from her sward,</line>
      <line>Rough gale of eastern seas!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, render sere no silken bent,</line>
      <line>That by her head-stone waves;</line>
      <line>Let noon and golden summer blent</line>
      <line>Pervade these ocean graves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, ah, dear heart, in thy still nest,</line>
      <line>Resign this earth of woes,</line>
      <line>Forget the ardours of the west,</line>
      <line>Neglect the morning glows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep, and forget all things but one,</line>
      <line>Heard in each wave of sea,—</line>
      <line>How lonely all the years will run</line>
      <line>Until I rest by thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Circe</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This the house of Circe, queen of charms—</line>
      <line>A kind of beacon-cauldron poised on high,</line>
      <line>Hooped round with ember-clasping iron bars,</line>
      <line>Sways in her palace porch, and smoulderingly</line>
      <line>Drips out in blots of fire and ruddy stars;</line>
      <line>But out behind that trembling furnace air,</line>
      <line>The lands are ripe and fair,</line>
      <line>Hush are the hills and quiet to the eye.</line>
      <line>The river’s reach goes by</line>
      <line>With lamb and holy tower and squares of corn,</line>
      <line>And shelving interspace</line>
      <line>Of holly bush and thorn,</line>
      <line>And hamlets happy in an Alpine morn,</line>
      <line>And deep-bowered lanes with grace</line>
      <line>Of woodbine newly born.</line>
      <line>But inward o’er the hearth a torch-head stands</line>
      <line>Inverted, slow green flames of fulvous hue,</line>
      <line>Echoed in wave-like shadows over her.</line>
      <line>A censer’s swing-chain set in her fair hands</line>
      <line>Dances up wreaths of intertwisted blue</line>
      <line>In clouds of fragrant frankincense and myrrh.</line>
      <line>A giant tulip head and two pale leaves</line>
      <line>Grew in the midmost of her chamber there,</line>
      <line>A flaunting bloom, naked and undivine,</line>
      <line>Rigid and bare,</line>
      <line>Gaunt as a tawny bond-girl born to shame,</line>
      <line>With freckled cheeks and splotched side serpentine,</line>
      <line>A gipsy among flowers,</line>
      <line>Unmeet for bed or bowers,</line>
      <line>Virginal where pure-handed damsels sleep:</line>
      <line>Let it not breathe a common air with them,</line>
      <line>Lest when the night is deep,</line>
      <line>And all things have their quiet in the moon,</line>
      <line>Some birth of poison from its leaning stem</line>
      <line>Waft in between their slumber-parted lips,</line>
      <line>And they cry out or swoon,</line>
      <line>Deeming some vampire sips,</line>
      <line>Where riper Love may come for nectar boon!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And near this tulip, reared across a loom,</line>
      <line>Hung a fair web of tapestry half done,</line>
      <line>Crowding with folds and fancies half the room:</line>
      <line>Men eyed as gods and damsels still as stone,</line>
      <line>Pressing their brows alone,</line>
      <line>In amethystine robes,</line>
      <line>Or reaching at the polished orchard globes,</line>
      <line>Or rubbing parted love-lips on their rind,</line>
      <line>While the wind</line>
      <line>Sows with sere apple leaves their breast and hair.</line>
      <line>And all the margin there</line>
      <line>Was arabesqued and bordered intricate</line>
      <line>With hairy spider things</line>
      <line>That catch and clamber,</line>
      <line>And salamander in his dripping cave</line>
      <line>Satanic ebon-amber;</line>
      <line>Blind worm, and asp, and eft of cumbrous gait,</line>
      <line>And toads who love rank grasses near a grave,</line>
      <line>And the great goblin moth, who bears</line>
      <line>Between his wings the ruined eyes of death;</line>
      <line>And the enamelled sails</line>
      <line>Of butterflies, who watch the morning’s breath.</line>
      <line>And many an emerald lizard with quick ears</line>
      <line>Asleep in rocky dales.</line>
      <line>And for an outer fringe embroidered small,</line>
      <line>A ring of many locusts, horny-coated,</line>
      <line>A round of chirping tree-frogs merry-throated,</line>
      <line>And sly, fat fishes sailing, watching all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Leicester Warren</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>The Study of a Spider</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>From holy flower to holy flower</line>
      <line>Thou weavest thine unhallowed bower.</line>
      <line>The harmless dewdrops, beaded thin,</line>
      <line>Ripple along thy ropes of sin.</line>
      <line>Thy house a grave, a gulf thy throne</line>
      <line>Affright the fairies every one.</line>
      <line>Thy winding sheets are grey and fell,</line>
      <line>Imprisoning with nets of hell</line>
      <line>The lovely births that winnow by,</line>
      <line>Winged sisters of the rainbow sky:</line>
      <line>Elf-darlings, fluffy, bee-bright things,</line>
      <line>And owl-white moths with mealy wings,</line>
      <line>And tiny flies, as gauzy thin</line>
      <line>As e’er were shut electrum in.</line>
