      <line>These are thy death spoils, insect ghoul,</line>
      <line>With their dear life thy fangs are foul.</line>
      <line>Thou felon anchorite of pain</line>
      <line>Who sittest in a world of slain.</line>
      <line>Hermit, who tunest song unsweet</line>
      <line>To heaving wing and writhing feet.</line>
      <line>A glutton of creation’s sighs,</line>
      <line>Miser of many miseries.</line>
      <line>Toper, whose lonely feasting chair</line>
      <line>Sways in inhospitable air.</line>
      <line>The board is bare, the bloated host</line>
      <line>Drinks to himself toast after toast.</line>
      <line>His lip requires no goblet brink,</line>
      <line>But like a weasel must he drink.</line>
      <line>The vintage is as old as time</line>
      <line>And bright as sunset, pressed and prime.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, venom mouth and shaggy thighs</line>
      <line>And paunch grown sleek with sacrifice,</line>
      <line>Thy dolphin back and shoulders round</line>
      <line>Coarse-hairy, as some goblin hound</line>
      <line>Whom a hag rides to sabbath on,</line>
      <line>While shuddering stars in fear grow wan.</line>
      <line>Thou palace priest of treachery,</line>
      <line>Thou type of selfish lechery,</line>
      <line>I break the toils around thy head</line>
      <line>And from their gibbets take thy dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Stephen Hawker</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>A Croon on Hennacliff</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus said the rushing raven,</line>
      <line>Unto his hungry mate:</line>
      <line>‘Ho! gossip! for Bude Haven:</line>
      <line>There be corpses six or eight.</line>
      <line>Cawk! cawk! the crew and skipper</line>
      <line>Are wallowing in the sea:</line>
      <line>So there’s a savoury supper</line>
      <line>For my old dame and me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Cawk! gaffer! thou art dreaming,</line>
      <line>The shore hath wreckers bold;</line>
      <line>Would rend the yelling seamen,</line>
      <line>From the clutching billows’ hold.</line>
      <line>Cawk! cawk! they’d bound for booty</line>
      <line>Into the dragon’s den:</line>
      <line>And shout, for “death or duty,”</line>
      <line>If the prey were drowning men.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Loud laughed the listening surges,</line>
      <line>At the guess our grandame gave:</line>
      <line>You might call them Boanerges,</line>
      <line>From the thunder of their wave.</line>
      <line>And mockery followed after</line>
      <line>The sea-bird’s jeering brood:</line>
      <line>That filled the skies with laughter,</line>
      <line>From Lundy Light to Bude.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Cawk! cawk!’ then said the raven,</line>
      <line>‘I am fourscore years and ten:</line>
      <line>Yet never in Bude Haven,</line>
      <line>Did I croak for rescued men.—</line>
      <line>They will save the Captain’s girdle,</line>
      <line>And shirt, if shirt there be:</line>
      <line>But leave their blood to curdle,</line>
      <line>For my old dame and me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So said the rushing raven,</line>
      <line>Unto his hungry mate:</line>
      <line>‘Ho! gossip! for Bude Haven:</line>
      <line>There be corpses six or eight.</line>
      <line>Cawk! cawk! the crew and skipper</line>
      <line>Are wallowing in the sea:</line>
      <line>O what a savoury supper</line>
      <line>For my old dame and me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>The Lion’s Skeleton</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How long, O lion, hast thou fleshless lain?</line>
      <line>What rapt thy fierce and thirsty eyes away?</line>
      <line>First came the vulture: worms, heat, wind, and rain</line>
      <line>Ensued, and ardors of the tropic day.</line>
      <line>I know not—if they spared it thee—how long</line>
      <line>The canker sate within thy monstrous mane,</line>
      <line>Till it fell piecemeal, and bestrew’d the plain;</line>
      <line>Or, shredded by the storming sands, was flung</line>
      <line>Again to earth; but now thine ample front,</line>
      <line>Whereon the great frowns gather’d, is laid bare;</line>
      <line>The thunders of thy throat, which erst were wont</line>
      <line>To scare the desert, are no longer there;</line>
      <line>Thy claws remain, but worms, wind, rain, and heat</line>
      <line>Have sifted out the substance of thy feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>A Brilliant Day</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O keen pellucid air! nothing can lurk</line>
      <line>Or disavow itself on this bright day;</line>
      <line>The small rain-plashes shine from far away,</line>
      <line>The tiny emmet glitters at his work;</line>
      <line>The bee looks blithe and gay, and as she plies</line>
      <line>Her task, and moves and sidles round the cup</line>
      <line>Of this spring flower, to drink its honey up,</line>
      <line>Her glassy wings, like oars that dip and rise,</line>
      <line>Gleam momently. Pure-bosom’d, clear of fog,</line>
      <line>The long lake glistens, while the glorious beam</line>
      <line>Bespangles the wet joints and floating leaves</line>
      <line>Of water-plants, whose every point receives</line>
      <line>His light; and jellies of the spawning frog,</line>
      <line>Unmark’d before, like piles of jewels seem!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1868</date>
    <title>On a Vase of Gold-Fish</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The tortured mullet served the Roman’s pride</line>
      <line>By darting round the crystal vase, whose heat</line>
      <line>Ensured his woe and beauty till he died:</line>
      <line>These unharm’d gold-fish yield as rich a treat;</line>
      <line>Seen thus, in parlour-twilight, they appear</line>
      <line>As though the hand of Midas, hovering o’er,</line>
      <line>Wrought on the waters, as his touch drew near,</line>
      <line>And set them glancing with his golden power,</line>
      <line>The flash of transmutation! In their glass</line>
      <line>They float and glitter, by no anguish rackt;</line>
      <line>And, though we see them swelling as they pass,</line>
      <line>’Tis but a painless and phantasmal act,</line>
      <line>The trick of their own bellying walls, which charms</line>
      <line>All eyes—themselves it vexes not, nor harms.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1868</date>
    <title>From Harvest to January</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The hay has long been built into the stack</line>
      <line>And now the grain; anon the hunter’s moon</line>
      <line>Shall wax and wane in cooler skies, and soon</line>
      <line>Again re-orb’d, speed on her wonted track,</line>
      <line>To spend her snowy light upon the rack</line>
      <line>Of dark November, while her brother Sun</line>
      <line>Shall get up later for his eight-hours’ run</line>
      <line>In that cold section of the Zodiac:</line>
      <line>Far from the Lion, from the Virgin far!</line>
      <line>Then onward through the last dim month shall go</line>
      <line>The two great lights, to where the kalendar</line>
      <line>Splits the mid-winter; and the feathery snow</line>
      <line>Ushering another spring, with falling flakes</line>
      <line>Shall nurse the soil for next year’s scythes and rakes.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1873</date>
    <title>Gout and Wings</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pigeons flutter’d fieldward, one and all,</line>
      <line>I saw the swallows wheel, and soar, and dive;</line>
      <line>The little bees hung poised before the hive,</line>
      <line>Even Partlet hoised herself across the wall:</line>
      <line>I felt my earth-bound lot in every limb,</line>
      <line>And, in my envious mood, I half-rebell’d;</line>
      <line>When lo! an insect cross’d the page I held,</line>
      <line>A little helpless minim, slight and slim;</line>
      <line>Ah! sure, there was no room for envy there,</line>
      <line>But gracious aid and condescending care;</line>
      <line>Alas! my pride and pity were misspent,</line>
      <line>The atom knew his strength, and rose in air!</line>
      <line>My gout came tingling back, as off he went,</line>
      <line>A wing was open’d at me everywhere!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>On Seeing a Little Child Spin a Coin of</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alexander the Great</line>
      <line>This is the face of him, whose quick resource</line>
      <line>Of eye and hand subdued Bucephalus,</line>
      <line>And made the shadow of a startled horse</line>
      <line>A foreground for his glory. It is thus</line>
      <line>They hand him down; this coin of Philip’s son</line>
      <line>Recalls his life, his glories, and misdeeds;</line>
      <line>And that abortive court of Babylon,</line>
      <line>Where the world’s throne was left among the reeds.</line>
      <line>His dust is lost among the ancient dead,</line>
      <line>A coin his only presence: he is gone:</line>
      <line>And all but this half mythic image fled—</line>
      <line>A simple child may do him shame and slight;</line>
      <line>’Twixt thumb and finger take the golden head,</line>
      <line>And spin the horns of Ammon out of sight.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>Letty’s Globe</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When Letty had scarce pass’d her third glad year,</line>
      <line>And her young, artless words began to flow,</line>
      <line>One day we gave the child a colour’d sphere</line>
      <line>Of the wide earth, that she might mark and know,</line>
      <line>By tint and outline, all its sea and land.</line>
      <line>She patted all the world; old empires peep’d</line>
      <line>Between her baby fingers; her soft hand</line>
      <line>Was welcome at all frontiers. How she leap’d,</line>
      <line>And laugh’d, and prattled in her world-wide bliss;</line>
      <line>But when we turned her sweet unlearned eye</line>
      <line>On our own isle, she raised a joyous cry,</line>
      <line>‘Oh! yes, I see it, Letty’s home is there!’</line>
      <line>And, while she hid all England with a kiss,</line>
      <line>Bright over Europe fell her golden hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>On Shooting a Swallow in Early Youth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I hoard a little spring of secret tears,</line>
      <line>For thee, poor bird; thy death-blow was my crime:</line>
      <line>From the far past it has flow’d on for years;</line>
      <line>It never dries; it brims at swallow-time.</line>
      <line>No kindly voice within me took thy part,</line>
      <line>Till I stood o’er thy last faint flutterings;</line>
      <line>Since then, methinks, I have a gentler heart,</line>
      <line>And gaze with pity on all wounded wings.</line>
      <line>Full oft the vision of thy fallen head,</line>
      <line>Twittering in highway dust, appeals to me;</line>
      <line>Thy helpless form, as w'hen I struck thee dead,</line>
      <line>Drops out from every swallow-flight I see.</line>
      <line>I would not have thine airy spirit laid,</line>
      <line>I seem to love the little ghost I made.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>Calvus to a Fly</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A H! little fly, alighting fitfully</line>
      <line>In the dim dawn on this bare head of mine,</line>
      <line>Which spreads a white and gleaming track for thee,</line>
      <line>When chairs and dusky wardrobes cease to shine.</line>
      <line>Though thou art irksome, let me not complain;</line>
      <line>Thy foolish passion for my hairless head</line>
      <line>Will spend itself, when these dark hours are sped,</line>
      <line>And thou shalt seek the sunlight on the pane.</line>
      <line>But still beware! thou art on dangerous ground:</line>
      <line>An angry sonnet, or a hasty hand,</line>
      <line>May slander thee, or crush thee: thy shrill sound</line>
      <line>And constant touch may shake my self-command:</line>
      <line>And thou mayst perish in that moment’s spite,</line>
      <line>And die a martyr to thy love of light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Charles Turner</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>A Country Dance</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He has not woo’d, but he has lost his heart.</line>
      <line>That country dance is a sore test for him;</line>
      <line>He thinks her cold; his hopes are faint and dim;</line>
      <line>But though with seeming mirth she takes her part</line>
      <line>In all the dances and the laughter there,</line>
      <line>And though to many a youth, on brief demand,</line>
      <line>She gives a kind assent and courteous hand,</line>
      <line>She loves but him, for him is all her care.</line>
      <line>With jealous heed her lessening voice he hears</line>
      <line>Down that long vista, where she seems to move</line>
      <line>Among fond faces and relays of love,</line>
      <line>And sweet occasion, full of tender fears:</line>
      <line>Down those long lines he watches from above,</line>
      <line>Till with the refluent dance she reappears.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1864</date>
    <title>It was a hard thing</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was a hard thing to undo this knot.</line>
      <line>The rainbow shines, but only in the thought</line>
      <line>Of him that looks. Yet not in that alone,</line>
      <line>For who makes rainbows by invention?</line>
      <line>And many standing round a waterfall</line>
      <line>See one bow each, yet not the same to all,</line>
      <line>But each a hand’s breadth further than the next.</line>
      <line>The sun on falling waters writes the text</line>
      <line>Which yet is in the eye or in the thought.</line>
      <line>It was a hard thing to undo this knot.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>The Habit of Perfection</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Elected Silence, sing to me</line>
      <line>And beat upon my whorled ear,</line>
      <line>Pipe me to pastures still and be</line>
      <line>The music that I care to hear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Shape nothing, lips; be lovely-dumb:</line>
      <line>It is the shut, the curfew sent</line>
      <line>From there where all surrenders come</line>
      <line>Which only makes you eloquent.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be shelled, eyes, with double dark</line>
      <line>And find the uncreated light:</line>
      <line>This ruck and reel which you remark</line>
      <line>Coils, keeps, and teases simple sight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Palate, the hutch of tasty lust,</line>
      <line>Desire not to be rinsed with wine:</line>
      <line>The can must be so sweet, the crust</line>
      <line>So fresh that come in fasts divine!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nostrils, your careless breath that spend</line>
      <line>Upon the stir and keep of pride,</line>
      <line>What relish shall the censers send</line>
      <line>Along the sanctuary side!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O feel-of-primrose hands, O feet</line>
      <line>That want the yield of plushy sward,</line>
      <line>But you shall walk the golden street</line>
      <line>And you unhouse and house the Lord.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, Poverty, be thou the bride</line>
      <line>And now the marriage feast begun,</line>
      <line>And lily-coloured clothes provide</line>
      <line>Your spouse not laboured-at nor spun.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Wreck of the Deutschland</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou mastering me</line>
      <line>God! giver of breath and bread;</line>
      <line>World’s strand, sway of the sea;</line>
      <line>Lord of living and dead;</line>
      <line>Thou hast bound bones and veins in me, fastened me flesh,</line>
      <line>And after it almost unmade, what with dread,</line>
      <line>Thy doing: and dost thou touch me afresh?</line>
      <line>Over again I feel thy finger and find thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I did say yes</line>
      <line>O at lightning and lashed rod;</line>
      <line>Thou heardst me truer than tongue confess</line>
      <line>Thy terror, O Christ, O God;</line>
      <line>Thou knowest the walls, altar and hour and night:</line>
      <line>The swoon of a heart that the sweep and the hurl of thee trod</line>
      <line>Hard down with a horror of height:</line>
      <line>And the midriff astrain with leaning of, laced with fire of stress.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The frown of his face</line>
      <line>Before me, the hurtle of hell</line>
      <line>Behind, where, where was a, where was a place?</line>
      <line>I whirled out wings that spell</line>
      <line>And fled with a fling of the heart to the heart of the Host.</line>
      <line>My heart, but you were dovewinged, I can tell,</line>
      <line>Carrier-witted, I am bold to boast,</line>
      <line>To flash from the flame to the flame then, tower from the grace to the grace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am soft sift</line>
      <line>In an hourglass—at the wall</line>
      <line>Fast, but mined with a motion, a drift,</line>
      <line>And it crowds and it combs to the fall;</line>
      <line>I steady as a water in a well, to a poise, to a pane,</line>
      <line>But roped with, always, all the way down from the tall</line>
      <line>Fells or flanks of the voel, a vein</line>
      <line>Of the gospel proffer, a pressure, a principle, Christ’s gift.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I kiss my hand</line>
      <line>To the stars, lovely-asunder</line>
      <line>Starlight, wafting him out of it; and</line>
      <line>Glow, glory in thunder;</line>
      <line>Kiss my hand to the dappled-with-damson west:</line>
      <line>Since, tho’ he is under the world’s splendour and wonder,</line>
      <line>His mystery must be instressed, stressed;</line>
      <line>For I greet him the days I meet him, and bless when I understand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not out of his bliss</line>
      <line>Springs the stress felt</line>
      <line>Nor first from heaven (and few know this)</line>
      <line>Swings the stroke dealt—</line>
      <line>Stroke and a stress that stars and storms deliver,</line>
      <line>That guilt is hushed by, hearts are flushed by and melt—</line>
      <line>But it rides time like riding a river</line>
      <line>(And here the faithful waver, the faithless fable and miss).</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It dates from day</line>
      <line>Of his going in Galilee;</line>
      <line>Warm-laid grave of a womb-life grey;</line>
      <line>Manger, maiden’s knee;</line>
      <line>The dense and the driven Passion, and frightful sweat:</line>
      <line>Thence the discharge of it, there its swelling to be,</line>
      <line>Though felt before, though in high flood yet—</line>
      <line>What none would have known of it, only the heart, being hard at bay,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is out with it! Oh,</line>
      <line>We lash with the best or worst</line>
      <line>Word last! How a lush-kept plush-capped sloe</line>
      <line>Will, mouthed to flesh-burst,</line>
      <line>Gush!—flush the man, the being with it, sour or sweet,</line>
      <line>Brim, in a flash, full!—Hither then, last or first,</line>
      <line>To hero of Calvary, Christ,’s feet—</line>
      <line>Never ask if meaning it, wanting it, warned of it—men go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be adored among men,</line>
      <line>God, three-numbered form;</line>
      <line>Wring thy rebel, dogged in den,</line>
      <line>Man’s malice, with wrecking and storm.</line>
      <line>Beyond saying sweet, past telling of tongue,</line>
      <line>Thou art lightning and love, I found it, a winter and warm;</line>
      <line>Father and fondler of heart thou hast wrung:</line>
      <line>Hast thy dark descending and most art merciful then.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With an anvil-ding</line>
      <line>And with fire in him forge thy will</line>
      <line>Or rather, rather then, stealing as Spring</line>
      <line>Through him, melt him but master him still:</line>
      <line>Whether at once, as once at a crash Paul,</line>
      <line>Or as Austin, a lingering-out sweet skill,</line>
      <line>Make mercy in all of us, out of us all</line>
      <line>Mastery, but be adored, but be adored King.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Some find me a sword; some</line>
      <line>The flange and the rail; flame,</line>
      <line>Fang, or flood’ goes Death on drum,</line>
      <line>And storms bugle his fame.</line>
      <line>But we dream we are rooted in earth—Dust!</line>
      <line>Flesh falls within sight of us, we, though our flower the same,</line>
      <line>Wave with the meadow, forget that there must</line>
      <line>The sour scythe cringe, and the blear share come.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On Saturday sailed from Bremen,</line>
      <line>American-outward-bound,</line>
      <line>Take settler and seamen, tell men with women,</line>
      <line>Two hundred souls in the round—</line>
      <line>O Father, not under thy feathers nor ever as guessing</line>
      <line>The goal was a shoal, of a fourth the doom to be drowned;</line>
      <line>Yet did the dark side of the bay of thy blessing</line>
      <line>Not vault them, the million of rounds of thv mercv not reeve even them in?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Into the snows she sweeps,</line>
      <line>Hurling the haven behind,</line>
      <line>The Deutschland, on Sunday; and so the sky keeps,</line>
      <line>For the infinite air is unkind,</line>
      <line>And the sea flint-flake, black-backed in the regular blow,</line>
      <line>Sitting Eastnortheast, in cursed quarter, the wind;</line>
      <line>Wiry and white-fiery and whirlwind-swivelled snow</line>
      <line>Spins to the widow-making unchilding unfathering deeps.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She drove in the dark to leeward,</line>
      <line>She struck—not a reef or a rock</line>
      <line>But the combs of a smother of sand: night drew her</line>
      <line>Dead to the Kentish Knock;</line>
      <line>And she beat the bank down with her bows and the ride of her keel:</line>
      <line>The breakers rolled on her beam with ruinous shock;</line>
      <line>And canvas and compass, the whorl and the wheel</line>
      <line>Idle for ever to waft her or wind her with, these she endured.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hope had grown grey hairs,</line>
      <line>Hope had mourning on,</line>
      <line>Trenched with tears, carved with cares,</line>
      <line>Hope was twelve hours gone;</line>
      <line>And frightful a nightfall folded rueful a day</line>
      <line>Nor rescue, only rocket and lightship, shone,</line>
      <line>And lives at last were washing away:</line>
      <line>To the shrouds they took,—they shook in the hurling and horrible airs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One stirred from the rigging to save</line>
      <line>The wild woman-kind below,</line>
      <line>With a rope’s end round the man, handy and brave—</line>
      <line>He was pitched to his death at a blow,</line>
      <line>For all his dreadnought breast and braids of thew:</line>
      <line>They could tell him for hours, dandled the to and fro</line>
      <line>Through the cobbled foam-fleece. What could he do</line>
      <line>With the burl of the fountains of air, buck and the flood of the wave?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They fought with God’s cold—</line>
      <line>And they could not and fell to the deck</line>
      <line>(Crushed them) or water (and drowned them) or rolled</line>
      <line>With the sea-romp over the wreck.</line>
      <line>Night roared, with the heart-break hearing a heart-broke rabble,</line>
      <line>The woman’s wailing, the crying of child without check—</line>
      <line>Till a lioness arose breasting the babble,</line>
      <line>A prophetess towered in the tumult, a virginal tongue told.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, touched in your bower of bone,</line>
      <line>Are you! turned for an exquisite smart,</line>
      <line>Have you! make words break from me here all alone,</line>
      <line>Do you!—mother of being in me, heart. 60</line>
      <line>O unteachably after evil, but uttering truth,</line>
      <line>Why, tears! is it? tears; such a melting, a madrigal start!</line>
      <line>Never-eldering revel and river of youth,</line>
      <line>What can it be, this glee? the good you have there of your own?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sister, a sister calling</line>
      <line>A master, her master and mine!—</line>
      <line>And the inboard seas run swirling and hawling;</line>
      <line>The rash smart sloggering brine</line>
      <line>Blinds her; but she that weather sees one thing, one;</line>
      <line>Has one fetch in her: she rears herself to divine 70</line>
      <line>Ears, and the call of the tall nun</line>
      <line>To the men in the tops and the tackle rode over the storm’s brawling.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She was first of a five and came</line>
      <line>Of a coifed sisterhood.</line>
      <line>(O Deutschland, double a desperate name!</line>
      <line>O world wide of its good!</line>
      <line>But Gertrude, lily, and Luther, are two of a town,</line>
      <line>Christ’s lily and beast of the waste wood:</line>
      <line>From life’s dawn it is drawn down,</line>
      <line>Abel is Cain’s brother and breasts they have sucked the same.)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Loathed for a love men knew in them,</line>
      <line>Banned by the land of their birth,</line>
      <line>Rhine refused them, Thames would ruin them;</line>
      <line>Surf, snow, river and earth</line>
      <line>Gnashed: but thou art above, thou Orion of light;</line>
      <line>Thy unchancelling poising palms were weighing the worth,</line>
      <line>Thou martyr-master: in thy sight</line>
      <line>Storm flakes were scroll-leaved flowers, lily showers—sweet heaven was astrew in them.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Five! the finding and sake</line>
      <line>And cipher of suffering Christ.</line>
      <line>Mark, the mark is of man’s make</line>
      <line>And the word of it Sacrificed.</line>
      <line>But he scores it in scarlet himself on his own bespoken,</line>
      <line>Before-time-taken, dearest prized and priced—</line>
      <line>Stigma, signal, cinquefoil token</line>
      <line>For lettering of the lamb’s fleece, ruddying of the rose-flake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Joy fall to thee, father Francis,</line>
      <line>Drawn to the Life that died;</line>
      <line>With the gnarls of the nails in thee, niche of the lance, his</line>
      <line>Lovescape crucified</line>
      <line>And seal of his seraph-arrival! and these thy daughters</line>
      <line>And five-lived and leaved favour and pride,</line>
      <line>Are sisterly sealed in wild waters,</line>
      <line>To bathe in his fall-gold mercies, to breathe in his all-fire glances.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Away in the loveable west,</line>
      <line>On a pastoral forehead of Wales,</line>
      <line>I was under a roof here, I was at rest,</line>
      <line>And they the prey of the gales;</line>
      <line>She to the black-about air, to the breaker, the thickly</line>
      <line>Falling flakes, to the throng that catches and quails</line>
      <line>Was calling ‘O Christ, Christ, come quickly’:</line>
      <line>The cross to her she calls Christ to her, christens her wild-worst Best.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The majesty! what did she mean?</line>
      <line>Breathe, arch and original Breath.</line>
      <line>Is it love in her of the being as her lover had been?</line>
      <line>Breathe, body of lovely Death.</line>
      <line>They were else-minded then, altogether, the men</line>
      <line>Woke thee with a We are perishing in the weather of Gennesareth.</line>
      <line>Or is it that she cried for the crown then,</line>
      <line>The keener to come at the comfort for feeling the combating keen?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For how to the heart’s cheering</line>
      <line>The down-dugged ground-hugged grey</line>
      <line>Hovers off, the jay-blue heavens appearing</line>
      <line>Of pied and peeled May!</line>
      <line>Blue-beating and hoary-glow height; or night, still higher,</line>
      <line>With belled fire and the moth-soft Milky Way,</line>
      <line>What by your measure is the heaven of desire,</line>
      <line>The treasure never eyesight got, nor was ever guessed what for the hearing?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, but it was not these.</line>
      <line>The jading and jar of the cart,</line>
      <line>Time’s tasking, it is fathers that asking for ease</line>
      <line>Of the sodden-with-its-sorrowing heart,</line>
      <line>Not danger, electrical horror; then further it finds</line>
      <line>The appealing of the Passion is tenderer in prayer apart:</line>
      <line>Other, I gather, in measure her mind’s</line>
      <line>Burden, in wind’s burly and beat of endragoned seas.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But how shall I ... make me room there:</line>
      <line>Reach me a ... Fancy, come faster—</line>
      <line>Strike you the sight of it? look at it loom there,</line>
      <line>Thing that she .. . There then! the Master,</line>
      <line>Ipse, the only one, Christ, King, Head:</line>
      <line>He was to cure the extremity where he had cast her;</line>
      <line>Do, deal, lord it with living and dead;</line>
      <line>Let him ride, her pride, in his triumph, despatch and have done with his doom there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! there was a heart right!</line>
      <line>There was single eye!</line>
      <line>Read the unshapeable shock night</line>
      <line>And knew the who and the why;</line>
      <line>Wording it how but by him that present and past,</line>
      <line>Heaven and earth are word of, worded by?—</line>
      <line>The Simon Peter of a soul! to the blast</line>
      <line>Tarpeian-fast, but a blown beacon of light.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jesu, heart’s light,</line>
      <line>Jesu, maid’s son,</line>
      <line>What was the feast followed the night</line>
      <line>Thou hadst glory of this nun?—</line>
      <line>Feast of the one woman without stain.</line>
      <line>For so conceived, so to conceive thee is done;</line>
      <line>But here was heart-throe, birth of a brain,</line>
      <line>Word, that heard and kept thee and uttered thee outright.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Well, she has thee for the pain, for the</line>
      <line>Patience; but pity of the rest of them!</line>
      <line>Heart, go and bleed at a bitterer vein for the</line>
      <line>Comfortless unconfessed of them—</line>
      <line>No not uncomforted: lovely-felicitous Providence</line>
      <line>Finger of a tender of, O of a feathery delicacy, the breast of the</line>
      <line>Maiden could obey so, be a bell to, ring of it, and</line>
      <line>Startle the poor sheep back! is the shipwrack then a harvest, does</line>
      <line>tempest carry the grain for thee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I admire thee, master of the tides,</line>
      <line>Of the Yore-flood, of the year’s fall;</line>
      <line>The recurb and the recovery of the gulfs sides,</line>
      <line>The girth of it and the wharf of it and the wall;</line>
      <line>Stanching, quenching ocean of a motionable mind;</line>
      <line>Ground of being, and granite of it: past all</line>
      <line>Grasp God, throned behind</line>
      <line>Death with a sovereignty that heeds but hides, bodes but abides;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With a mercy that outrides</line>
      <line>The all of water, an ark</line>
      <line>For the listener; for the lingerer with a love glides</line>
      <line>Lower than death and the dark;</line>
      <line>A vein for the visiting of the past-prayer, pent in prison,</line>
      <line>The-last-breath penitent spirits—the uttermost mark</line>
      <line>Our passion-plunged giant risen,</line>
      <line>The Christ of the Father compassionate, fetched in the storm of his strides.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now burn, new born to the world,</line>
      <line>Double-natured name,</line>
      <line>The heaven-flung, heart-fleshed, maiden-furled</line>
      <line>Miracle-in-Mary-of-flame,</line>
      <line>Mid-numbered he in three of the thunder-throne!</line>
      <line>Not a dooms-day dazzle in his coming nor dark as he came;</line>
      <line>Kind, but royally reclaiming his own;</line>
      <line>A released shower, let flash to the shire, not a lightning of fire hard-hurled.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dame, at our door</line>
      <line>Drowned, and among our shoals,</line>
      <line>Remember us in the roads, the heaven-haven of the reward:</line>
      <line>Our King back, Oh, upon English souls!</line>
      <line>Let him easter in us, be a dayspring to the dimness of us, be a crimson-cresseted east,</line>
      <line>More brightening her, rare-dear Britain, as his reign rolls,</line>
      <line>Pride, rose, prince, hero of us, high-priest,</line>
      <line>Our heart’s charity’s hearth’s fire, our thoughts’ chivalry’s throng’s Lord.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>Moonrise</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I awoke in the Midsummer not-to-call night, in the white and the walk of the morning:</line>
      <line>The moon, dwindled and thinned to the fringe of a fingernail held to the candle,</line>
      <line>Or paring of paradisaical fruit, lovely in waning but lustreless,</line>
      <line>Stepped from the stool, drew back from the barrow, of dark Maenefa the mountain;</line>
      <line>A cusp still clasped him, a fluke yet fanged him, entangled him, not quit utterly.</line>
      <line>This was the prized, the desirable sight,1 unsought, presented so easily,</line>
      <line>Parted me leaf and leaf, divided me, 1 eyelid and eyelid of slumber.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>God’s Grandeur</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world is charged with the grandeur of God.</line>
      <line>It will flame out, like shining from shook foil;</line>
      <line>It gathers to a greatness, like the ooze of oil</line>
      <line>Crushed. Why do men then now not reck his rod?</line>
      <line>Generations have trod, have trod, have trod;</line>
      <line>And all is seared with trade; bleared, smeared with toil;</line>
      <line>And wears man’s smudge and shares man’s smell: the soil</line>
      <line>Is bare now, nor can foot feel, being shod.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And for all this, nature is never spent;</line>
      <line>There lives the dearest freshness deep down things;</line>
      <line>And though the last lights off the black West went</line>
      <line>Oh, morning, at the brown brink eastwards, springs—</line>
      <line>Because the Holy Ghost over the bent</line>
      <line>World broods with warm breast and with ah! bright wings.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>Spring</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nothing is so beautiful as Spring—</line>
      <line>When weeds, in wheels, shoot long and lovely and lush;</line>
      <line>Thrush’s eggs look little low heavens, and thrush</line>
      <line>Through the echoing timber does so rinse and wring</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The ear, it strikes like lightnings to hear him sing;</line>
      <line>The glassy peartree leaves and blooms, they brush</line>
      <line>The descending blue; that blue is all in a rush</line>
      <line>With richness; the racing lambs too have fair their fling.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is all this juice and all this joy?</line>
      <line>A strain of the earth’s sweet being in the beginning</line>
      <line>In Eden garden.—Have, get, before it cloy,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Before it cloud, Christ, lord, and sour with sinning,</line>
      <line>Innocent mind and Mayday in girl and boy,</line>
      <line>Most, O maid’s child, thy choice and worthy the winning.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>In the Valley of the Elwy</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I remember a house where all were good</line>
      <line>To me, God knows, deserving no such thing:</line>
      <line>Comforting smell breathed at very entering,</line>
      <line>Fetched fresh, as I suppose, off some sweet wood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That cordial air made those kind people a hood</line>
      <line>All over, as a bevy of eggs the mothering wing</line>
      <line>Will, or mild nights the new morsels of Spring:</line>
      <line>Why, it seemed of course; seemed of right it should.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lovely the woods, waters, meadows, combes, vales,</line>
      <line>All the air things wear that build this world of Wales;</line>
      <line>Only the inmate does not correspond:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>God, lover of souls, swaying considerate scales,</line>
      <line>Complete thy creature dear O where it fails,</line>
      <line>Being mighty a master, being a father and fond.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>The Windhover:</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I CAUGHT this morning morning’s minion, king-</line>
      <line>dom of daylight’s dauphin, dapple-dawn-drawn Falcon, in his riding</line>
      <line>Of the rolling level underneath him steady air, and striding</line>
      <line>High there, how he rung upon the rein of a wimpling wing</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In his ecstasy! then off, off forth on swing,</line>
      <line>As a skate’s heel sweeps smooth on a bow-bend: the hurl and gliding</line>
      <line>Rebuffed the big wind. My heart in hiding</line>
      <line>Stirred for a bird,—the achieve of, the mastery of the thing!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Brute beauty and valour and act, oh, air, pride, plume, here</line>
      <line>Buckle! and the fire that breaks from thee then, a billion</line>
      <line>Times told lovelier, more dangerous, O my chevalier!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No wonder of it: sheer plod makes plough down sillion</line>
      <line>Shine, and blue-bleak embers, ah my dear,</line>
      <line>Fall, gall themselves, and gash gold-vermilion.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>Pied Beauty</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Glory be to God for dappled things—</line>
      <line>For skies of couple-colour as a brinded cow;</line>
      <line>For rose-moles all in stipple upon trout that swim;</line>
      <line>Fresh-firecoal chestnut-falls; finches’ wings;</line>
      <line>Landscape plotted and pieced—fold, fallow, and plough;</line>
      <line>And all trades, their gear and tackle and trim.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All things counter, original, spare, strange;</line>
      <line>Whatever is fickle, freckled (who knows how?)</line>
      <line>With swift, slow; sweet, sour; adazzle, dim;</line>
      <line>He fathers-forth whose beauty is past change:</line>
      <line>Praise him.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>As kingfishers catch fire</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As kingfishers catch fire, dragonflies draw flame;</line>
      <line>As tumbled over rim in roundy wells</line>
      <line>Stones ring; like each tucked string tells, each hung bell’s</line>
      <line>Bow swung finds tongue to fling out broad its name;</line>
      <line>Each mortal thing does one thing and the same:</line>
      <line>Deals out that being indoors each one dwells;</line>
      <line>Selves—goes its self; myself it speaks and spells,</line>
      <line>Crying What I do is me: for that I came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I say more: the just man justices;</line>
      <line>Keeps grace: that keeps all his goings graces;</line>
      <line>Acts in God’s eye what in God’s eye he is—</line>
      <line>Christ. For Christ plays in ten thousand places,</line>
      <line>Lovely in limbs, and lovely in eyes not his</line>
      <line>To the Father through the features of men’s faces.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>The Leaden Echo and the Golden Echo</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>How to keep—is there any any, is there none such, nowhere known</line>
      <line>some, bow or brooch or braid or brace, lace, latch or catch or key</line>
      <line>to keep</line>
      <line>Back beauty, keep it, beauty, beauty, beauty,... from vanishing away?</line>
      <line>O is there no frowning of these wrinkles, ranked wrinkles deep,</line>
      <line>Down? no waving off of these most mournful messengers, still</line>
      <line>messengers, sad and stealing messengers of grey?—</line>
      <line>No there’s none, there’s none, O no there’s none,</line>
      <line>Nor can you long be, what you now are, called fair,</line>
      <line>Do what you may do, what, do what you may,</line>
      <line>And wisdom is early to despair:</line>
      <line>Be beginning; since, no, nothing can be done</line>
      <line>To keep at bay</line>
      <line>Age and age’s evils, hoar hair,</line>
      <line>Ruck and wrinkle, drooping, dying, death’s worst, winding sheets,</line>
      <line>tombs and worms and tumbling to decay;</line>
      <line>So be beginning, be beginning to despair.</line>
      <line>O there’s none; no no no there’s none:</line>
      <line>Be beginning to despair, to despair,</line>
      <line>Despair, despair, despair, despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spare!</line>
      <line>There is one, yes I have one (Hush there!),</line>
      <line>Only not within seeing of the sun.</line>
      <line>Not within the singeing of the strong sun,</line>
      <line>Tall sun’s tingeing, or treacherous the tainting of the earth’s air,</line>
      <line>Somewhere elsewhere there is ah well where! one,</line>
      <line>One. Yes I can tell such a key, I do know such a place,</line>
      <line>Where whatever’s prized and passes of us, everything that’s fresh and</line>
      <line>fast flying of us, seems to us sweet of us and swiftly away with,</line>
      <line>done away with, undone,</line>
      <line>Undone, done with, soon done with, and yet dearly and dangerously sweet</line>
      <line>Of us, the wimpled-water-dimpled, not-by-morning-matched face,</line>
      <line>The flower of beauty, fleece of beauty, too too apt to, ah! to fleet,</line>
      <line>Never fleets more, fastened with the tenderest truth</line>
      <line>To its own best being and its loveliness of youth: it is an ever¬</line>
      <line>lastingness of, O it is an all youth!</line>
      <line>Come then, your ways and airs and looks, locks, maidengear, gallantry</line>
      <line>and gaiety and grace,</line>
      <line>Winning ways, airs innocent, maiden manners, sweet looks, loose</line>
      <line>locks, long locks, lovelocks, gaygear, going gallant, girlgrace—</line>
      <line>Resign them, sign them, seal them, send them, motion them with</line>
      <line>breath,</line>
      <line>And with sighs soaring, soaring sighs, deliver</line>
      <line>Them; beauty-in-the-ghost, deliver it, early now, long before death</line>
      <line>Give beauty back, beauty, beauty, beauty, back to God, beauty’s self</line>
      <line>and beauty’s giver.</line>
      <line>See; not a hair is, not an eyelash, not the least lash lost; every hair</line>
      <line>Is, hair of the head, numbered.</line>
      <line>Nay, what we had lighthanded left in surly the mere mould</line>
      <line>Will have waked and have waxed and have walked with the wind what</line>
      <line>while we slept,</line>
      <line>This side, that side hurling a heavyheaded hundredfold</line>
      <line>What while we, while we slumbered.</line>
      <line>O then, weary then why should we tread? O why are we so haggard at</line>
      <line>the heart, so care-coiled, care-killed, so fagged, so fashed, so</line>
      <line>cogged, so cumbered,</line>
      <line>When the thing we freely forfeit is kept with fonder a care,</line>
      <line>Fonder a care kept than we could have kept it, kept</line>
      <line>Far with fonder a care (and we, we should have lost it) finer, fonder</line>
      <line>A care kept.—Where kept? do but tell us where kept, where.—</line>
      <line>Yonder.—What high as that! We follow, now we follow.—Yonder, yes</line>
      <line>yonder, yonder,</line>
      <line>Yonder.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1883</date>
    <title>The Blessed Virgin compared to the Air we Breathe</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wild air, world-mothering air,</line>
      <line>Nestling me everywhere,</line>
      <line>That each eyelash or hair</line>
      <line>Girdles; goes home betwixt</line>
      <line>The fleeciest, frailest-flixed</line>
      <line>Snowflake; that’s fairly mixed</line>
      <line>With, riddles, and is rife</line>
      <line>In every least thing’s life;</line>
      <line>This needful, never spent,</line>
      <line>And nursing element;</line>
      <line>My more than meat and drink,</line>
      <line>My meal at every wink;</line>
      <line>This air, which, by life’s law,</line>
      <line>My lung must draw and draw</line>
      <line>Now but to breathe its praise,</line>
      <line>Minds me in many ways</line>
      <line>Of her who not only</line>
      <line>Gave God’s infinity</line>
      <line>Dwindled to infancy</line>
      <line>Welcome in womb and breast,</line>
      <line>Birth, milk, and all the rest</line>
      <line>But mothers each new grace</line>
      <line>That does now reach our race—</line>
      <line>Mary Immaculate,</line>
      <line>Merely a woman, yet</line>
      <line>Whose presence, power is</line>
      <line>Great as no goddess’s</line>
      <line>Was deemed, dreamed; who</line>
      <line>This one work has to do—</line>
      <line>Let all God’s glory through,</line>
      <line>God’s glory which would go</line>
      <line>Through her and from her flow</line>
      <line>Off, and no way but so.</line>
      <line>I say that we are wound</line>
      <line>With mercy round and round</line>
      <line>As if with air: the same</line>
      <line>Is Mary, more by name.</line>
      <line>She, wild web, wondrous robe,</line>
      <line>Mantles the guilty globe,</line>
      <line>Since God has let dispense</line>
      <line>Her prayers his providence:</line>
      <line>Nay, more than almoner,</line>
      <line>The sweet alms’ self is her</line>
      <line>And men are meant to share</line>
      <line>Her life as life does air.</line>
      <line>If I have understood,</line>
      <line>She holds high motherhood</line>
      <line>Towards all our ghostly good</line>
      <line>And plays in grace her part</line>
      <line>About man’s beating heart,</line>
      <line>Laying, like air’s fine flood,</line>
      <line>The deathdance in his blood;</line>
      <line>Yet no part but what will</line>
      <line>Be Christ our Saviour still.</line>
      <line>Of her flesh he took flesh:</line>
      <line>He does take fresh and fresh,</line>
      <line>Though much the mystery how,</line>
      <line>Not flesh but spirit now</line>
      <line>And makes, O marvellous!</line>
      <line>New Nazareths in us,</line>
      <line>Where she shall yet conceive</line>
      <line>Him, morning, noon, and eve;</line>
      <line>New Bethlems, and he born</line>
      <line>There, evening, noon, and morn—</line>
      <line>Bethlem or Nazareth,</line>
      <line>Men here may draw like breath</line>
      <line>More Christ and baffle death;</line>
      <line>Who, born so, comes to be</line>
      <line>New self and nobler me</line>
      <line>In each one and each one</line>
      <line>More makes, when all is done,</line>
      <line>Both God’s and Mary’s Son.</line>
      <line>Again, look overhead</line>
      <line>How air is azured;</line>
      <line>Oh how! Nay do but stand</line>
      <line>Where you can lift your hand</line>
      <line>Skywards: rich, rich it laps</line>
      <line>Round the four fingergaps.</line>
      <line>Yet such a sapphire-shot,</line>
      <line>Charged, steeped sky will not</line>
      <line>Stain light. Yea, mark you this:</line>
      <line>It does no prejudice.</line>
      <line>The glass-blue days are those</line>
      <line>When every colour glows,</line>
      <line>Each shape and shadow shows.</line>
      <line>Blue be it: this blue heaven</line>
      <line>The seven or seven times seven</line>
      <line>Hued sunbeam will transmit</line>
      <line>Perfect, not alter it.</line>
      <line>Or if there does some soft,</line>
      <line>On things aloof, aloft,</line>
      <line>Bloom breathe, that one breath more</line>
      <line>Earth is the fairer for.</line>
      <line>Whereas did air not make</line>
      <line>This bath of blue and slake</line>
      <line>His fire, the sun would shake,</line>
      <line>A blear and blinding ball</line>
      <line>With blackness bound, and all</line>
      <line>The thick stars round him roll</line>
      <line>Flashing like flecks of coal,</line>
      <line>Quartz-fret, or sparks of salt,</line>
      <line>In grimy vasty vault.</line>
      <line>So God was god of old:</line>
      <line>A mother came to mould</line>
      <line>Those limbs like ours which are</line>
      <line>What must make our daystar</line>
      <line>Much dearer to mankind;</line>
      <line>Whose glory bare would blind</line>
      <line>Or less would win man’s mind.</line>
      <line>Through her we may see him</line>
      <line>Made sweeter, not made dim,</line>
      <line>And her hand leaves his light</line>
      <line>Sifted to suit our sight.</line>
      <line>Be thou then, O thou dear</line>
      <line>Mother, my atmosphere;</line>
      <line>My happier world, wherein</line>
      <line>To wend and meet no sin;</line>
      <line>Above me, round me lie</line>
      <line>Fronting my froward eye</line>
      <line>With sweet and scarless sky;</line>
      <line>Stir in my ears, speak there</line>
      <line>Of God’s love, O live air,</line>
      <line>Of patience, penance, prayer:</line>
      <line>World-mothering air, air wild,</line>
      <line>Wound with thee, in thee isled,</line>
      <line>Fold home, fast fold thy child.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1883</date>
    <title>‘The Child is Father to the Man’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The child is father to the man.’</line>
      <line>How can he be? The words are wild.</line>
      <line>Suck any sense from that who can:</line>
      <line>‘The child is father to the man.’</line>
      <line>No; what the poet did write ran,</line>
      <line>‘The man is father to the child.’</line>
      <line>‘The child is father to the man!’</line>
      <line>How can he be? The words are wild.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>Spelt from Sibyl’s Leaves</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Earnest, earthless, equal, attuneable, vaulty, voluminous,...stupendous</line>
      <line>Evening strains to be time’s vast, womb-of-all, home-of-all, hearse- of-all night.</line>
      <line>Her fond yellow hornlight wound to the west, her wild hollow hoarlight hung to the height</line>
      <line>Waste; her earliest stars, earlstars, stars principal, overbend us,</line>
      <line>Fire-featuring heaven. For earth her being has unbound; her dapple is at an end, as-</line>
      <line>tray or aswarm, all throughther, in throngs; self in self steeped and pashed—quite</line>
      <line>Disremembering, dismembering all now. Heart, you round me right</line>
      <line>With: Our evening is over us; our night1 whelms, whelms, and will end us.</line>
      <line>Only the beakleaved boughs dragonish damask the tool-smooth bleak light; black,</line>
      <line>Ever so black on it. Our tale, O our oracle! Let life, waned, ah let life wind</line>
      <line>Off her once skeined stained veined variety upon, all on two spools; part, pen, pack</line>
      <line>Now her all in two flocks, two folds—black, white; right, wrong;</line>
      <line>reckon but, reck but, mind</line>
      <line>But these two; ware of a world where but these two tell, each off the other; of a rack</line>
      <line>Where, selfwrung, selfstrung, sheathe- and shelterless, thoughts against thoughts in groans grind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>No worst, there is none.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>No worst, there is none. Pitched past pitch of grief,</line>
      <line>More pangs will, schooled at forepangs, wilder wring.</line>
      <line>Comforter, where, where is your comforting?</line>
      <line>Mary, mother of us, where is your relief?</line>
      <line>My cries heave, herds-long; huddle in a main, a chief-</line>
      <line>woe, world-sorrow; on an age-old anvil wince and sing—</line>
      <line>Then lull, then leave off. Fury had shrieked ‘No ling-</line>
      <line>ering! Let me be fell: force I must be brief.</line>
      <line>O the mind, mind has mountains; cliffs of fall</line>
      <line>Frightful, sheer, no-man-fathomed. Hold them cheap</line>
      <line>May who ne’er hung there. Nor does long our small</line>
      <line>Durance deal with that steep or deep. Here! creep,</line>
      <line>Wretch, under a comfort serves in a whirlwind: all</line>
      <line>Life death does end and each day dies with sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>To seem the stranger</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>To seem the stranger lies my lot, my life</title>
      <line>Among strangers. Father and mother dear,</line>
      <line>Brothers and sisters are in Christ not near</line>
      <line>And he my peace/my parting, sword and strife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>England, whose honour O all my heart woos, wife</line>
      <line>To my creating thought, would neither hear</line>
      <line>Me, were I pleading, plead nor do I: I wear-</line>
      <line>y of idle a being but by where wars are rife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am in Ireland now; now I am at a third</line>
      <line>Remove. Not but in all removes I can</line>
      <line>Kind love both give and get. Only what word</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wisest my heart breeds dark heaven’s baffling ban</line>
      <line>Bars or hell’s spell thwarts. This to hoard unheard,</line>
      <line>Heard unheeded, leaves me a lonely began.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>I wake and feel the fell of dark, not day.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wake and feel the fell of dark, not day.</line>
      <line>What hours, O what black hours we have spent</line>
      <line>This night! what sights you, heart, saw; ways you went!</line>
      <line>And more must, in yet longer light’s delay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With witness I speak this. But where I say</line>
      <line>Hours I mean years, mean life. And my lament</line>
      <line>Is cries countless, cries like dead letters sent</line>
      <line>To dearest him that lives alas! away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am gall, I am heartburn. God’s most deep decree</line>
      <line>Bitter would have me taste: my taste was me;</line>
      <line>Bones built in me, flesh filled, blood brimmed the curse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Selfyeast of spirit a dull dough sours. I see</line>
      <line>The lost are like this, and their scourge to be</line>
      <line>As I am mine, their sweating selves; but worse.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>Patience, hard thing!</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Patience, hard thing! the hard thing but to pray,</line>
      <line>But bid for, Patience is! Patience who asks</line>
      <line>Wants war, wants wounds; weary his times, his tasks;</line>
      <line>To do without, take tosses, and obey.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rare patience roots in these, and, these away,</line>
      <line>Nowhere. Natural heart’s ivy, Patience masks</line>
      <line>Our ruins of wrecked past purpose. There she basks</line>
      <line>Purple eyes and seas of liquid leaves all day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We hear our hearts grate on themselves: it kills</line>
      <line>To bruise them dearer. Yet the rebellious wills</line>
      <line>Of us we do bid God bend to him even so.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And where is he who more and more distills</line>
      <line>Delicious kindness?—He is patient. Patience fills</line>
      <line>His crisp combs, and that comes those ways we know.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>My own heart</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My own heart let me more have pity on; let</line>
      <line>Me live to my sad self hereafter kind,</line>
      <line>Charitable; not live this tormented mind</line>
      <line>With this tormented mind tormenting yet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cast for comfort I can no more get</line>
      <line>By groping round my comfortless, than blind</line>
      <line>Eyes in their dark can day or thirst can find</line>
      <line>Thirst’s all-in-all in all a world of wet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Soul, self; come, poor Jackself, I do advise</line>
      <line>You, jaded, let be; call off thoughts awhile</line>
      <line>Elsewhere; leave comfort root-room; let joy size</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At God knows when to God knows what; whose smile</line>
      <line>’s not wrung, see you; unforeseen times rather—as skies</line>
      <line>Betweenpie mountains—lights a lovely mile.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerard M. Hopkins</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>Thou are indeed just, Lord</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art indeed just, Lord, if I contend</line>
      <line>With thee; but, sir, so what I plead is just.</line>
      <line>Why do sinners’ ways prosper? and why must</line>
      <line>Disappointment all 1 endeavour end?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wert thou my enemy, O thou my friend,</line>
      <line>How wouldst thou worse, I wonder, than thou dost</line>
      <line>Defeat, thwart me? Oh, the sots and thralls of lust</line>
      <line>Do in spare hours more thrive than I that spend,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sir, life upon thy cause. See, banks and brakes</line>
      <line>Now, leaved how thick! laced they are again</line>
      <line>With fretty chervil, look, and fresh wind shakes</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Them; birds build—but not I build; no, but strain,</line>
      <line>Time’s eunuch, and not breed one work that wakes.</line>
      <line>Mine, O thou lord of life, send my roots rain.</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1889; pub. 1893)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>JOHN HENRY NEWMAN</line>
      <line>from The Dream of Gerontius</line>
      <line>Praise to the Holiest in the height,</line>
      <line>And in the depth be praise:</line>
      <line>In all His words most wonderful;</line>
      <line>Most sure in all His ways!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O loving wisdom of our God!</line>
      <line>When all was sin and shame,</line>
      <line>A second Adam to the fight</line>
      <line>And to the rescue came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>0 wisest love! that flesh and blood</line>
      <line>Which did in Adam fail,</line>
      <line>Should strive afresh against their foe,</line>
      <line>Should strive and should prevail;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that a higher gift than grace</line>
      <line>Should flesh and blood refine,</line>
      <line>God’s Presence and His very Self,</line>
      <line>And Essence all-divine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O generous love! that He who smote</line>
      <line>In man for man the foe,</line>
      <line>The double agony in man</line>
      <line>For man should undergo;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in the garden secretly,</line>
      <line>And on the cross on high,</line>
      <line>Should teach His brethren and inspire</line>
      <line>To suffer and to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Munby</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>The Serving Maid</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When you go out at early morn,</line>
      <line>Your busy hands, sweet drudge, are bare;</line>
      <line>For you must work, and none are there</line>
      <line>To see with scorn—to feel with scorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when the weekly wars begin,</line>
      <line>Your arms are naked to the hilt,</line>
      <line>And many a sturdy pail’s a-tilt</line>
      <line>To sheathe them in—to plunge them in.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For you at least can understand</line>
      <line>That daily work is hard and stern,</line>
      <line>That those who toil for bread must learn</line>
      <line>To bare the hand—to spoil the hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But in the evening, when they dine,</line>
      <line>And you behind each frequent chair</line>
      <line>Are flitting lightly here and there</line>
      <line>To bring them wine—to pour them wine;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh then, from every dainty eye</line>
      <line>That may not so be shock’d or grieved,</line>
      <line>Your hands are hid, your arms are sleeved:</line>
      <line>We ask not why—we tell not why.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah fools! Though you for workday scours,</line>
      <line>And they for show, unveil their charms,</line>
      <line>Love is not bound to snowy arms,</line>
      <line>He thinks of yours—he speaks of yours:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To me his weighted shaft has come;</line>
      <line>Though hand and arm are both unseen,</line>
      <line>Your rosy wrist peeps out between</line>
      <line>And sends it home—and speeds it home.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Munby</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>One Way of Looking at It</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I thought you always knew it well</line>
      <line>(Although indeed you never said so)—</line>
      <line>I thought you knew I dared not tell,</line>
      <line>And that was why you toss’d your head so:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For I have often heard you say</line>
      <line>You hate to see a fellow sighing,</line>
      <line>To hear him stammer all the day,</line>
      <line>And hint mysteriously at dying.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And if I have adored you so,</line>
      <line>I thought you knew I couldn’t help it;</line>
      <line>I could no more escape my woe</line>
      <line>Than Joseph could his empty well-pit.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It wasn’t fair of you at all:</line>
      <line>You moved so light and play’d so neatly,</line>
      <line>And set your foot upon the ball,</line>
      <line>And croquet’d me, I know, completely!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why did you let me look such things,</line>
      <line>And whisper o’er our melting ices,</line>
      <line>If converse with you only brings</line>
      <line>This most objectionable crisis?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wish I had not loved, for then</line>
      <line>Perhaps you would not be offended,</line>
      <line>Nor fling me back my heart again,</line>
      <line>Nor tell me thus that all is ended!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh yes! Sir John’s a charming catch—</line>
      <line>His stud, his balance at his banker’s,</line>
      <line>Unlike himself, are hard to match;</line>
      <line>And I have but one horse at Spanker’s!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He will not house you in some den,</line>
      <line>Served by a footman single-handed—</line>
      <line>He has such store of maids and men</line>
      <line>As your position, love, demanded:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so, I quite approve your choice;</line>
      <line>I won’t regret my wasted wooing;</line>
      <line>I’ll think your sweet soprano voice</line>
      <line>Has warn’d me from my own undoing:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And yet I know, that when too late—</line>
      <line>Just as the spectre came to Priam—</line>
      <line>You’ll learn to rue your splendid fate,</line>
      <line>And wish yourself as free as I am.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Munby</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>Post Mortem</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I lay in my coffin under the sod;</line>
      <line>But the rooks they caw’d, and the sheep they trod</line>
      <line>And munch’d and bleated, and made such a noise—</line>
      <line>What with the feet of the charity boys</line>
      <line>Trampling over the old grave-stones—</line>
      <line>That it loosen’d my inarticulate bones,</line>
      <line>And chased my sleep away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So I turn’d (for the coffin is not so full</line>
      <line>As it was, you know) my aching skull;</line>
      <line>And said to my wife—and it’s not my fault</line>
      <line>If she does lie next to me in the vault—</line>
      <line>Said to her kindly, ‘My love, my dear,</line>
      <line>How do you like these sounds we hear</line>
      <line>Over our heads to-day?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My wife had always a good strong voice;</line>
      <line>But I’m not so sure that I did rejoice</line>
      <line>When I found it as strong as it used to be,</line>
      <line>And so unexpectedly close to me:</line>
      <line>I thought, if her temper should set in,</line>
      <line>Why, the boards between us are very thin,</line>
      <line>And whenever the bearers come one by one</line>
      <line>To deposit the corpse of my eldest son,</line>
      <line>Who is spending the earnings of his papa</line>
      <line>With such sumptuous ease and such great eclat,</line>
      <line>They may think it more pleasant, perhaps, than I did,</line>
      <line>To find that in death we were not divided.</line>
      <line>However, I trusted to time and the worms;</line>
      <line>And I kept myself to the mildest terms</line>
      <line>Of a conjugal How d’ye do.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘John,’ said my wife, ‘you’re a Body, like me;</line>
      <line>At least if you ain’t, why you ought to be;</line>
      <line>And I really don’t think, when I reflect,</line>
      <line>That I ought to pay as much respect</line>
      <line>To a rattling prattling skeleton</line>
      <line>As I did to a man of sixteen stone.</line>
      <line>However (says she), I shall just remark</line>
      <line>That this here place is so cool and dark,</line>
      <line>I’m certain sure, if you hadn’t have spoke,</line>
      <line>My slumber’d never have thus been broke;</line>
      <line>So I wish you’d keep your—voice in your head;</line>
      <line>For I don’t see the good of being dead,</line>
      <line>If one mayn’t be quiet too.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She spoke so clear and she spoke so loud,</line>
      <line>I thank’d my stars that a linen shroud</line>
      <line>And a pair of boards (though they were but thin)</line>
      <line>Kept out some part of that well-known din:</line>
      <line>And, talking of shrouds, the very next word</line>
      <line>That my empty echoing orbits heard</line>
      <line>Was, ‘Gracious me, I can tell by the feel</line>
      <line>That I’m all over rags from head to heel!</line>
      <line>Here’s jobs for needle and thread without ending,</line>
      <line>For there’s ever-so-many holes wants mending!’</line>
      <line>‘My love,’ I ventured to say, ‘I fear</line>
      <line>It’s not much use, your mending ’em here;</line>
      <line>For, as fast as you do, there’s worse than moth,</line>
      <line>And worse than mice, or rats, or both,</line>
      <line>Will eat up the work of your cotton ball</line>
      <line>And leave you never a shroud at all—</line>
      <line>No more than they have to me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, whether it was that she took it ill</line>
      <line>My seeming to question her feminine skill,</line>
      <line>Or whether ’twas simply that we were wedded—</line>
      <line>The very thing happen’d that most I dreaded:</line>
      <line>For, by way of reply, on the coffin-side,</line>
      <line>Just where the planks had started wide,</line>
      <line>There came a blow so straight and true</line>
      <line>That it shook my vertebral column in two;</line>
      <line>And what more might have follow’d I cannot tell,</line>
      <line>But that very minute (’twas just as well)</line>
      <line>The flagstone was lifted overhead,</line>
      <line>And the red-nosed buriers of the dead</line>
      <line>Let down a load on my coffin-plate</line>
      <line>That stunn’d me quite with the shock of its weight.</line>
      <line>’Twas the corpse, of course, of my eldest son,</line>
      <line>Who had injured his brain (a little one)</line>
      <line>By many a spirituous brain-dissolver,</line>
      <line>And finish’d it off with a Colt’s revolver.</line>
      <line>Well—when they had gone and the noise had ceased,</line>
      <line>I look’d for one other attack, at least:</line>
      <line>But, would you believe it? The place was quiet,</line>
      <line>And the worms had resumed their usual diet!</line>
      <line>Nay, everything else was silent too;</line>
      <line>The rooks they neither caw’d nor flew,</line>
      <line>And the sheep slept sound by footstone and head,</line>
      <line>And the charity boys had been whipp’d to bed.</line>
      <line>So I turn’d again, and I said to myself—</line>
      <line>‘Now, as sure as I’m laid on this sordid shelf</line>
      <line>Away from the living that smile or weep,</line>
      <line>I’ll sleep if I can, and let her too sleep:</line>
      <line>And I will not once, for pleasure or pain,</line>
      <line>Unhinge my jaws to speak again,</line>
      <line>No, not if she speaks to me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Sebastian Evans</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>The Fifteen Days of Judgment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Then there shall be signs in Heaven.’—</line>
      <line>Thus much in the text is given,</line>
      <line>Worthy of the sinner’s heeding:</line>
      <line>But the other signs preceding</line>
      <line>Earth’s Last Judgment and destruction,</line>
      <line>And its fiery reconstruction,</line>
      <line>May be drawn from other channels;</line>
      <line>For we read in Hebrew annals</line>
      <line>That there shall be altogether</line>
      <line>Fifteen Judgment days; but whether</line>
      <line>Following or interpolated,</line>
      <line>Jerome saith, is nowhere stated.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the first day, loud upcrashing,</line>
      <line>Shall the shoreless ocean, gnashing</line>
      <line>With a dismal anaclysmal</line>
      <line>Outrush from its deeps abysmal,</line>
      <line>Lifted high by dread supernal,</line>
      <line>Storm the mountain heights eternal!</line>
      <line>Forty cubits of sheer edges,</line>
      <line>Wall-like, o’er the summit-ridges</line>
      <line>Stretching upright forth—a mirror</line>
      <line>For the unutterable terror</line>
      <line>Of the huddled howling nations,</line>
      <line>Smit with sudden desolations,</line>
      <line>Rushing hither, thither, drunken,</line>
      <line>Half their pleasant realms sea-sunken!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the second day, down-pouring,</line>
      <line>Shall the watery walls drop roaring</line>
      <line>From the ruinous precipices</line>
      <line>To the nethermost abysses,</line>
      <line>With a horrible waterquaking</line>
      <line>In the world-wide cataracts, shaking</line>
      <line>Earth’s foundations as they thunder</line>
      <line>To the cavernous darkness under.—</line>
      <line>Surf-plumed steeds of God Almighty,</line>
      <line>Rock and pyramid, forest, city,</line>
      <line>Through the flood-rent valleys scourging,</line>
      <line>Wild in headlong ebb down-surging,</line>
      <line>Down, till eye of man scarce reaches</line>
      <line>Where, within its shrunken beaches,</line>
      <line>Hidden from a world’s amazement,</line>
      <line>Cowers the Deep in self-abasement.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the third day, o’er the seething</line>
      <line>Of the leprous ocean writhing,</line>
      <line>Whale and dragon, ore and kraken,</line>
      <line>And leviathan, forsaken</line>
      <line>His unfathomable eyrie,</line>
      <line>To and fro shall plunge—the dreary</line>
      <line>Dumb death-sickness of creation</line>
      <line>Startling with their ululation.</line>
      <line>Men shall hear the monsters bellow</line>
      <line>Forth their burden, as they wallow;</line>
      <line>But its drift?—Let none demand it!</line>
      <line>God alone shall understand it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the fourth day, blazing redly,</line>
      <line>With a reek pitch-black and deadly,</line>
      <line>A consuming flame shall quiver</line>
      <line>From all seas and every river!</line>
      <line>Every brook and beck and torrent</line>
      <line>Leaping in a fiery current;</line>
      <line>All the moats and meres and fountains</line>
      <line>Lit, like beacons on the mountains;</line>
      <line>Furnace-roar of smolten surges</line>
      <line>Scaring earth’s extremest verges!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the fifth day, Judgment-stricken,</line>
      <line>Every green herb, from the lichen</line>
      <line>To the cedar of the forest,</line>
      <line>Shall sweat blood in anguish sorest!</line>
      <line>On the same, all fowls of heaven</line>
      <line>Into one wide field, fear-driven,</line>
      <line>Shall assemble, cowed and shrinking,</line>
      <line>Neither eating aught, nor drinking;</line>
      <line>Kind with kind, all ranked by feather,</line>
      <line>Doves with doves aghast together,</line>
      <line>Swan with swan in downfal regal,</line>
      <line>Wren with wren, with eagle, eagle!</line>
      <line>Ah! when fowl feel such foreboding,</line>
      <line>What shall be the Sinner’s goading?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the sixth day, through all nations</line>
      <line>Shall be quaking of foundations,</line>
      <line>With a horrible hollow rumbling—</line>
      <line>All that all men builded crumbling</line>
      <line>As the heel of Judgment tramples</line>
      <line>Cot and palace, castles, temples,</line>
      <line>Hall and minster, thorp and city;—</line>
      <line>All men too aghast for pity</line>
      <line>In the crashing and the crushing</line>
      <line>Of that stony stream’s downrushing!—</line>
      <line>And a flame of fiery warning</line>
      <line>Forth from sundown until morning</line>
      <line>With a lurid coruscation</line>
      <line>Shall reveal night’s desolation!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the seventh day, self-shattered,</line>
      <line>Rifting fourfold, scarred and scattered,</line>
      <line>Pounded in the Judgment’s mortars,</line>
      <line>Every stone shall split in quarters!</line>
      <line>Pebble, whinstone, granite sparry,</line>
      <line>Rock and boulder—stones of quarry,</line>
      <line>Shaped or shapeless, all asunder</line>
