      <line>Shivering, split athwart and under;</line>
      <line>And the splinters, each on other,</line>
      <line>Shall make war against his brother,</line>
      <line>Each one grinding each to powder,</line>
      <line>Grinding, gnashing, loud and louder,</line>
      <line>Grinding, gnashing on till even,</line>
      <line>With a dolorous plea to Heaven.</line>
      <line>What the drift?—Let none demand it!</line>
      <line>God alone shall understand it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the eighth, in dire commotion,</line>
      <line>Shall the dry land heave like Ocean,</line>
      <line>Puffed in hills and sucked in hollows,</line>
      <line>Yawning into steep-down swallows—</line>
      <line>Swelling, mountainously lifted,</line>
      <line>Skyward from the plains uplifted—</line>
      <line>With a universal clamour,</line>
      <line>Rattling, roaring through the tremor;</line>
      <line>While, flung headlong, all men living</line>
      <line>Grovel in a wild misgiving!—</line>
      <line>What, O Sinner, shall avail your</line>
      <line>Might in solid Earth’s own failure!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the ninth day all the mountains</line>
      <line>Shall drop bodily, like spent fountains,</line>
      <line>All the cloud-capped pride of pristine</line>
      <line>Peak and pinnacle amethystine</line>
      <line>Toppling, drifting to the level,</line>
      <line>Flooding all the dales with gravel;</line>
      <line>One consummate moment blasting</line>
      <line>All that seems so everlasting—</line>
      <line>All men to the caves for shelter</line>
      <line>Scurrying through the world-wide welter!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the tenth day, hither, thither,</line>
      <line>Herding from their holes together,</line>
      <line>With a glaring of white faces,</line>
      <line>Through the desolate wildernesses</line>
      <line>Men shall o’er that mountain ruin</line>
      <line>Run as from a Death’s pursuing,—</line>
      <line>Each one with suspicious scowling,</line>
      <line>Shrinking from his fellow’s howling—</line>
      <line>For all human speech confounded</line>
      <line>Shall not sound as once it sounded.</line>
      <line>None shall understand his brother—</line>
      <line>Mother child, nor child his mother!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the eleventh day, at dawning,</line>
      <line>Every sepulchre wide yawning</line>
      <line>At the approach of Earth’s Assessor,</line>
      <line>Shall upyield its white possessor;—</line>
      <line>All the skeletons, close-serried,</line>
      <line>O’er the graves where each lay buried,</line>
      <line>Mute upstanding, white and bony,</line>
      <line>With a dreadful ceremony</line>
      <line>Staring from the morn till gloaming</line>
      <line>Eastward for the Judge’s coming;</line>
      <line>Staring on, with sockets eyeless,</line>
      <line>Each one motionless and cryless,</line>
      <line>Save the dry, dead-leaf-like chattering,</line>
      <line>Through that white-branched forest pattering.</line>
      <line>What its drift?—Let none demand it!</line>
      <line>God alone shall understand it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the twelfth, the Planets seven</line>
      <line>And all stars shall drop from Heaven!</line>
      <line>On the same day, scared and trembling,</line>
      <line>All four-footed things assembling,</line>
      <line>Each after his kind in order—</line>
      <line>All the lions in one border,</line>
      <line>Sheep with sheep—not needing shepherd—</line>
      <line>Stag with stag—with leopard, leopard—</line>
      <line>Shall be herded cowed and shrinking,</line>
      <line>Neither earing aught, nor drinking,</line>
      <line>But to Godward bellowing, shrieking,</line>
      <line>Howling, barking, roaring, squeaking;—</line>
      <line>What the drift?—Let none demand it!</line>
      <line>God alone shall understand it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the thirteenth awful morning</line>
      <line>Shall go forth the latest warning,</line>
      <line>With a close to all things mortal,</line>
      <line>For the Judge is at the portal!</line>
      <line>In an agony superhuman,</line>
      <line>Every living man and woman,</line>
      <line>Child and dotard—every breather—</line>
      <line>Shall lie down and die together,</line>
      <line>That all flesh in death’s subjection</line>
      <line>May abide the Resurrection!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>On the fourteenth, morn to even,</line>
      <line>Fire shall feed on Earth and Heaven,</line>
      <line>Through the skies and all they cover,</line>
      <line>Under earth, and on, and over;</line>
      <line>All things ghostly, human, bestial,</line>
      <line>In the crucible celestial</line>
      <line>Tested by the dread purgation</line>
      <line>Of that final conflagration;</line>
      <line>Till the intolerable whiteness</line>
      <line>Dawn, of God’s exceeding brightness</line>
      <line>Through the furnace-flame’s erasure</line>
      <line>Of yon mortal veil of azure!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Last, the fifteenth day shall render</line>
      <line>Earth a more than earthly splendour,</line>
      <line>Once again shall Word be given:</line>
      <line>‘Let there be new Earth, new Heaven!’</line>
      <line>And this fleeting world—this charnel,</line>
      <line>Purified, shall wax eternal!—</line>
      <line>Then all souls shall Michael gather</line>
      <line>At the footstool of the Father,</line>
      <line>Summoning from Earth’s four corners,</line>
      <line>All erst human saints; and scorners,</line>
      <line>And without revenge or pity</line>
      <line>Weigh them in the scales almighty’!—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sinner! Dost thou dread that trial?</line>
      <line>Mark yon shadow on the dial!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>from Art</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Singing is sweet; but be sure of this,</line>
      <line>Lips only sing when they cannot kiss.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Did he ever suspire a tender lay</line>
      <line>While her presence took his breath away?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had his fingers been able to toy with her hair</line>
      <line>Would they then have written the verses fair?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had she let his arm steal round her waist</line>
      <line>Would the lovely portrait yet be traced?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Since he could not embrace it flushed and warm</line>
      <line>He has carved in stone the perfect form.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who gives the fine report of the feast?</line>
      <line>He who got none and enjoyed it least.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Were the wine really slipping down his throat</line>
      <line>Would his song of the wine advance a note?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Will you puff out the music that sways the whirl,</line>
      <line>Or dance and make love with a pretty girl?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who shall the great battle-story write?</line>
      <line>Not the hero down in the thick of the fight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Statues and pictures and verse may be grand,</line>
      <line>But they are not the Life for which they stand.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1865</date>
    <title>Once in a saintly passion</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Once in a saintly passion</line>
      <line>I cried with desperate grief,</line>
      <line>O Lord, my heart is black with guile,</line>
      <line>Of sinners I am chief.</line>
      <line>Then stooped my guardian angel</line>
      <line>And whispered from behind,</line>
      <line>‘Vanity, my little man,</line>
      <line>You’re nothing of the kind.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>Mr MacCall at Cleveland Hall</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mr MacCall at Cleveland Hall,</line>
      <line>Sunday evening—date to fix—</line>
      <line>Fifteenth April, sixty-six,</line>
      <line>Speech reported and redacted</line>
      <line>By a fellow much distracted.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who lectures? No mere scorner;</line>
      <line>Clear-brained, his heart is warm.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She sits at the nearest corner</line>
      <line>Of I will not say what form.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Conflict of Opinions</line>
      <line>In the Present Day, saith Chair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What muff in the British dominions</line>
      <line>Could dispute that she is fair?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mammon-worship is horrid,</line>
      <line>Plutocracy is base.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dark hair from a fine small forehead;</line>
      <line>I catch but the still side face.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We wallow in mere dimension,</line>
      <line>The Big to us is Great.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If she stood at her utmost tension</line>
      <line>She might pass four feet eight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We lay on colour in splashes,</line>
      <line>With a mop, or a broom for brush.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How dark are her long eyelashes!</line>
      <line>How pure is her cheek’s slight flush!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But we have no perception</line>
      <line>For form—the divinest—now.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each curve there is perfection,</line>
      <line>In nostril, chin, and brow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our women are good kind creatures,</line>
      <line>But they cannot dress at all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Does her bonnet grace her features?—</line>
      <line>Clear blue with a black lace fall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Low Church—very low—in the gutter;</line>
      <line>High Church—as ven’son high.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O’er the flower of her face gleams the flutter</line>
      <line>Of a smile like a butterfly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Herder, Wieland, Lessing;</line>
      <line>Bossuet, Montalembert.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fine names, but the name worth guessing</line>
      <line>Is the name of the sweet girl there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The individual; true man;</line>
      <line>Individuality.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A man’s but one half; some woman</line>
      <line>The other half must be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Persistent valour the sternest,</line>
      <line>With love’s most gentle grace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How grand is the eye fixed earnest</line>
      <line>In the half-seen up-turned face!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘How did you like the lecture?</line>
      <line>Was it not beautiful?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I should think she was! ‘I conjecture</line>
      <line>That your brains have been gathering wool!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Chairman was a rare man;</line>
      <line>At every telling point</line>
      <line>He smiled at his post like a jolly host</line>
      <line>Carving rich cuts from the joint;</line>
      <line>Which the name he bore was Richard Moore</line>
      <line>Whom Heaven with grace anoint!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That conflict of opinion</line>
      <line>It had its counterpart</line>
      <line>In conflict for dominion</line>
      <line>Between my head and heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1868</date>
    <title>In the Room</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sun was down, and twilight grey</line>
      <line>Filled half the air; but in the room,</line>
      <line>Whose curtain had been drawn all day,</line>
      <line>The twilight was a dusky gloom:</line>
      <line>Which seemed at first as still as death,</line>
      <line>And void; but was indeed all rife</line>
      <line>With subtle thrills, the pulse and breath</line>
      <line>Of multitudinous lower life.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In their abrupt and headlong way</line>
      <line>Bewildered flies for light had dashed</line>
      <line>Against the curtain all the day,</line>
      <line>And now slept wintrily abashed;</line>
      <line>And nimble mice slept, wearied out</line>
      <line>With such a double night’s uproar;</line>
      <line>But solid beetles crawled about</line>
      <line>The chilly hearth and naked floor.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so throughout the twilight hour</line>
      <line>That vaguely murmurous hush and rest</line>
      <line>There brooded; and beneath its power</line>
      <line>Life throbbing held its throbs supprest:</line>
      <line>Until the thin-voiced mirror sighed,</line>
      <line>I am all blurred with dust and damp,</line>
      <line>So long ago the clear day died,</line>
      <line>So long has gleamed nor fire nor lamp.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Whereon the curtain murmured back,</line>
      <line>Some change is on us, good or ill;</line>
      <line>Behind me and before is black</line>
      <line>As when those human things lie still:</line>
      <line>But I have seen the darkness grow</line>
      <line>As grows the daylight every morn;</line>
      <line>Have felt out there long shine and glow,</line>
      <line>In here long chilly dusk forlorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The cupboard grumbled with a groan,</line>
      <line>Each new day worse starvation brings:</line>
      <line>Since he came here I have not known</line>
      <line>Or sweets or cates or wholesome things:</line>
      <line>But now! a pinch of meal, a crust,</line>
      <line>Throughout the week is all I get.</line>
      <line>I am so empty; it is just</line>
      <line>As when they said we were to let.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is become, then, of our Man?</line>
      <line>The petulant old glass exclaimed;</line>
      <line>If all this time he slumber can,</line>
      <line>He really ought to be ashamed.</line>
      <line>I wish we had our Girl again,</line>
      <line>So gay and busy, bright and fair:</line>
      <line>The girls are better than these men,</line>
      <line>Who only for their dull selves care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It is so many hours ago—</line>
      <line>The lamp and fire were both alight—</line>
      <line>I saw him pacing to and fro,</line>
      <line>Perturbing restlessly the night.</line>
      <line>His face was pale to give one fear,</line>
      <line>His eyes when lifted looked too bright;</line>
      <line>He muttered; what, I could not hear:</line>
      <line>Bad words though; something was not right.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The table said, He wrote so long</line>
      <line>That I grew weary of his weight;</line>
      <line>The pen kept up a cricket song,</line>
      <line>It ran and ran at such a rate:</line>
      <line>And in the longer pauses he</line>
      <line>With both his folded arms downpressed</line>
      <line>And stared as one who does not see,</line>
      <line>Or sank his head upon his breast.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fire-grate said, I am as cold</line>
      <line>As if I never had a blaze;</line>
      <line>The few dead cinders here I hold,</line>
      <line>I held unburned for days and days.</line>
      <line>Last night he made them flare; but still</line>
      <line>What good did all his writing do?</line>
      <line>Among my ashes curl and thrill</line>
      <line>Thin ghosts of all those papers too.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The table answered, Not quite all;</line>
      <line>He saved and folded up one sheet,</line>
      <line>And sealed it fast, and let it fall;</line>
      <line>And here it lies now white and neat.</line>
      <line>Whereon the letter’s whisper came,</line>
      <line>My writing is closed up too well;</line>
      <line>Outside there’s not a single name,</line>
      <line>And who should read me I can’t tell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mirror sneered with scornful spite,</line>
      <line>(That ancient crack which spoiled her looks</line>
      <line>Had marred her temper), Write and write!</line>
      <line>And read those stupid, worn-out books!</line>
      <line>That’s all he does, read, write, and read,</line>
      <line>And smoke that nasty pipe which stinks:</line>
      <line>He never takes the slightest heed</line>
      <line>How any of us feels or thinks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Lucy fifty times a day</line>
      <line>Would come and smile here in my face,</line>
      <line>Adjust a tress that curled astray,</line>
      <line>Or tie a ribbon with more grace:</line>
      <line>She looked so young and fresh and fair,</line>
      <line>She blushed with such a charming bloom,</line>
      <line>It did one good to see her there,</line>
      <line>And brightened all things in the room.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She did not sit hours stark and dumb</line>
      <line>As pale as moonshine by the lamp;</line>
      <line>To lie in bed when day was come,</line>
      <line>And leave us curtained chill and damp.</line>
      <line>She slept away the dreary dark,</line>
      <line>And rose to greet the pleasant morn;</line>
      <line>And sang as gaily as a lark</line>
      <line>While busy as the flies sun-born.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And how she loved us every one;</line>
      <line>And dusted this and mended that,</line>
      <line>With trills and laughs and freaks of fun,</line>
      <line>And tender scoldings in her chat!</line>
      <line>And then her bird, that sang as shrill</line>
      <line>As she sang sweet; her darling flowers</line>
      <line>That grew there in the window-sill,</line>
      <line>Where she would sit at work for hours.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It was not much she ever wrote;</line>
      <line>Her fingers had good work to do;</line>
      <line>Say, once a week a pretty note;</line>
      <line>And very long it took her too.</line>
      <line>And little more she read, I wis;</line>
      <line>Just now and then a pictured sheet,</line>
      <line>Besides those letters she would kiss</line>
      <line>And croon for hours, they were so sweet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She had her friends too, blithe young girls,</line>
      <line>Who whispered, babbled, laughed, caressed,</line>
      <line>And romped and danced with dancing curls,</line>
      <line>And gave our life a joyous zest.</line>
      <line>But with this dullard, glum and sour,</line>
      <line>Not one of all his fellow-men</line>
      <line>Has ever passed a social hour;</line>
      <line>We might be in some wild beast’s den.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This long tirade aroused the bed,</line>
      <line>Who spoke in deep and ponderous bass,</line>
      <line>Befitting that calm life he led,</line>
      <line>As if firm-rooted in his place:</line>
      <line>In broad majestic bulk alone,</line>
      <line>As in thrice venerable age,</line>
      <line>He stood at once the royal throne,</line>
      <line>The monarch, the experienced sage:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know what is and what has been;</line>
      <line>Not anything to me comes strange,</line>
      <line>Who in so many years have seen</line>
      <line>And lived through every kind of change.</line>
      <line>I know when men are good or bad,</line>
      <line>When well or ill, he slowly said;</line>
      <line>When sad or glad, when sane or mad,</line>
      <line>And when they sleep alive or dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At this last word of solemn lore</line>
      <line>A tremor circled through the gloom,</line>
      <line>As if a crash upon the floor</line>
      <line>Had jarred and shaken all the room:</line>
      <line>For nearly all the listening things</line>
      <line>Were old and worn, and knew what curse</line>
      <line>Of violent change death often brings,</line>
      <line>From good to bad, from bad to worse;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They get to know each other well,</line>
      <line>To feel at home and settled down;</line>
      <line>Death bursts among them like a shell,</line>
      <line>And strews them over all the town.</line>
      <line>The bed went on, This man who lies</line>
      <line>Upon me now is stark and cold;</line>
      <line>He will not any more arise,</line>
      <line>And do the things he did of old.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But we shall have short peace or rest;</line>
      <line>For soon up here will come a rout,</line>
      <line>And nail him in a queer long chest,</line>
      <line>And carry him like luggage out.</line>
      <line>They will be muffled all in black,</line>
      <line>And whisper much, and sigh and weep:</line>
      <line>But he will never more come back,</line>
      <line>And some one else in me must sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thereon a little phial shrilled,</line>
      <line>Here empty on the chair I lie: 1</line>
      <line>I heard one say, as I was filled,</line>
      <line>With half of this a man would die.</line>
      <line>The man there drank me with slow breath,</line>
      <line>And murmured, Thus ends barren strife:</line>
      <line>O sweeter, thou cold wine of death,</line>
      <line>Than ever sweet warm wine of life.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One of my cousins long ago,</line>
      <line>A little thing, the mirror said,</line>
      <line>Was carried to a couch to show,</line>
      <line>Whether a man was really dead.</line>
      <line>Two great improvements marked the case:</line>
      <line>He did not blur her with his breath,</line>
      <line>His many-wrinkled, twitching face</line>
      <line>Was smooth old ivory: verdict, Death.—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It lay, the lowest thing there, lulled</line>
      <line>Sweet-sleep-like in corruption’s truce;</line>
      <line>The form whose purpose was annulled,</line>
      <line>While all the other shapes meant use.</line>
      <line>It lay, the he become now it,</line>
      <line>Unconscious of the deep disgrace,</line>
      <line>Unanxious how its parts might flit</line>
      <line>Through what new forms in time and space.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It lay and preached, as dumb things do,</line>
      <line>More powerfully than tongues can prate;</line>
      <line>Though life be torture through and through,</line>
      <line>Man is but weak to plain of fate:</line>
      <line>The drear path crawls on drearier still</line>
      <line>To wounded feet and hopeless breast?</line>
      <line>Well, he can lie down when he will,</line>
      <line>And straight all ends in endless rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And while the black night nothing saw,</line>
      <line>And till the cold morn came at last,</line>
      <line>That old bed held the room in awe</line>
      <line>With tales of its experience vast.</line>
      <line>It thrilled the gloom; it told such tales</line>
      <line>Of human sorrows and delights,</line>
      <line>Of fever moans and infant wails,</line>
      <line>Of births and deaths and bridal nights.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1870</date>
    <title>In a Christian Churchyard</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This field of stones, he said,</line>
      <line>May well call forth a sigh;</line>
      <line>Beneath them lie the dead,</line>
      <line>On them the living lie.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1870</date>
    <title>from The City of Dreadful Night (I)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stood alone within the spacious square</line>
      <line>Declaiming from the central grassy mound,</line>
      <line>With head uncovered and with streaming hair,</line>
      <line>As if large multitudes were gathered round:</line>
      <line>A stalwart shape, the gestures full of might,</line>
      <line>The glances burning with unnatural light:—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: All was black,</line>
      <line>In heaven no single star, on earth no track;</line>
      <line>A brooding hush without a stir or note,</line>
      <line>The air so thick it clotted in my throat;</line>
      <line>And thus for hours; then some enormous things</line>
      <line>Swooped past with savage cries and clanking wings:</line>
      <line>But I strode on austere;</line>
      <line>No hope could have no fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: Eyes of fire</line>
      <line>Glared at me throbbing with a starved desire;</line>
      <line>The hoarse and heavy and carnivorous breath</line>
      <line>Was hot upon me from deep jaws of death;</line>
      <line>Sharp claws, swift talons, fleshless fingers cold</line>
      <line>Plucked at me from the bushes, tried to hold:</line>
      <line>But I strode on austere;</line>
      <line>No hope could have no fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: Lo you, there,</line>
      <line>That hillock burning with a brazen glare;</line>
      <line>Those myriad dusky flames with points a-glow</line>
      <line>Which writhed and hissed and darted to and fro;</line>
      <line>A Sabbath of the Serpents, heaped pell-mell</line>
      <line>For Devil’s roll-call and some fete of Hell:</line>
      <line>Yet I strode on austere;</line>
      <line>No hope could have no fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: Meteors ran</line>
      <line>And crossed their javelins on the black sky-span;</line>
      <line>The zenith opened to a gulf of flame,</line>
      <line>The dreadful thunderbolts jarred earth’s fixed frame;</line>
      <line>The ground all heaved in waves of fire that surged</line>
      <line>And weltered round me sole there unsubmerged:</line>
      <line>Yet I strode on austere;</line>
      <line>No hope could have no fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: Air once more,</line>
      <line>And I was close upon a wild sea-shore;</line>
      <line>Enormous cliffs arose on either hand,</line>
      <line>The deep tide thundered up a league-broad strand;</line>
      <line>White foambelts seethed there, wan spray swept and flew;</line>
      <line>The sky broke, moon and stars and clouds and blue:</line>
      <line>And I strode on austere;</line>
      <line>No hope could have no fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: On the left</line>
      <line>The sun arose and crowned a broad crag-cleft;</line>
      <line>There stopped and burned out black, except a rim,</line>
      <line>A bleeding eyeless socket, red and dim;</line>
      <line>Whereon the moon fell suddenly south-west,</line>
      <line>And stood above the right-hand cliffs at rest:</line>
      <line>Still I strode on austere;</line>
      <line>No hope could have no fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: From the right</line>
      <line>A shape came slowly with a ruddy light;</line>
      <line>A woman with a red lamp in her hand,</line>
      <line>Bareheaded and barefooted on that strand;</line>
      <line>O desolation moving with such grace!</line>
      <line>O anguish with such beauty in thy face!</line>
      <line>I fell as on my bier,</line>
      <line>Hope travailed with such fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: I was twain,</line>
      <line>Two selves distinct that cannot join again;</line>
      <line>One stood apart and knew but could not stir,</line>
      <line>And watched the other stark in swoon and her;</line>
      <line>And she came on, and never turned aside,</line>
      <line>Between such sun and moon and roaring tide:</line>
      <line>And as she came more near</line>
      <line>My soul grew mad with fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: Hell is mild</line>
      <line>And piteous matched with that accursed wild;</line>
      <line>A large black sign was on her breast that bowed,</line>
      <line>A broad black band ran down her snow-white shroud;</line>
      <line>That lamp she held was her own burning heart,</line>
      <line>Whose blood-drops trickled step by step apart:</line>
      <line>The mystery was clear;</line>
      <line>Mad rage had swallowed fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: By the sea</line>
      <line>She knelt and bent above that senseless me;</line>
      <line>Those lamp-drops fell upon my white brow there,</line>
      <line>She tried to cleanse them with her tears and hair;</line>
      <line>She murmured words of pity, love, and woe,</line>
      <line>She heeded not the level rushing flow:</line>
      <line>And mad with rage and fear,</line>
      <line>I stood stonebound so near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came through the desert thus it was,</line>
      <line>As I came through the desert: When the tide</line>
      <line>Swept up to her there kneeling by my side,</line>
      <line>She clasped that corpse-like me, and they were borne</line>
      <line>Away, and this vile me was left forlorn;</line>
      <line>I know the whole sea cannot quench that heart,</line>
      <line>Or cleanse that brow, or wash those two apart:</line>
      <line>They love; their doom is drear,</line>
      <line>Yet they nor hope nor fear;</line>
      <line>But I, what do I here?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Thomson ('B.V.')</author>
    <date>1870</date>
    <title>from The City of Dreadful Night (II)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I wandered in a suburb of the north,</line>
      <line>And reached a spot whence three close lanes led down,</line>
      <line>Beneath thick trees and hedgerows winding forth</line>
      <line>Like deep brook channels, deep and dark and lown:</line>
      <line>The air above was wan with misty light,</line>
      <line>The dull grey south showed one vague blur of white.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I took the left-hand lane and slowly trod</line>
      <line>Its earthen footpath, brushing as I went</line>
      <line>The humid leafage; and my feet were shod</line>
      <line>With heavy languor, and my frame downbent,</line>
      <line>With infinite sleepless weariness outworn,</line>
      <line>So many nights I thus had paced forlorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>After a hundred steps I grew aware</line>
      <line>Of something crawling in the lane below;</line>
      <line>It seemed a wounded creature prostrate there</line>
      <line>That sobbed with pangs in making progress slow,</line>
      <line>The hind limbs stretched to push, the fore limbs then</line>
      <line>To drag; for it would die in its own den.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But coming level with it I discerned</line>
      <line>That it had been a man; for at my tread</line>
      <line>It stopped in its sore travail and half-turned,</line>
      <line>Leaning upon its right, and raised its head,</line>
      <line>And with the left hand twitched back as in ire</line>
      <line>Long grey unreverend locks befouled with mire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A haggard filthy face with bloodshot eyes,</line>
      <line>An infamy for manhood to behold.</line>
      <line>He gasped all trembling, What, you want my prize?</line>
      <line>You leave, to rob me, wine and lust and gold</line>
      <line>And all that men go mad upon, since you</line>
      <line>Have traced my sacred secret of the clue?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You think that I am weak and must submit;</line>
      <line>Yet I but scratch you with this poisoned blade,</line>
      <line>And you are dead as if I clove with it</line>
      <line>That false fierce greedy heart. Betrayed! betrayed!</line>
      <line>I fling this phial if you seek to pass,</line>
      <line>And you are forthwith shrivelled up like grass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then with sudden change, Take thought! take thought!</line>
      <line>Have pity on me! it is mine alone.</line>
      <line>If you could find, it would avail you naught;</line>
      <line>Seek elsewhere on the pathway of your own:</line>
      <line>For who of mortal or immortal race</line>
      <line>The lifetrack of another can retrace?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Did you but know my agony and toil!</line>
      <line>Two lanes diverge up yonder from this lane;</line>
      <line>My thin blood marks the long length of their soil;</line>
      <line>Such clue I left, who sought my clue in vain:</line>
      <line>My hands and knees are worn both flesh and bone;</line>
      <line>I cannot move but with continual moan.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But I am in the very way at last</line>
      <line>To find the long-lost broken golden thread</line>
      <line>Which reunites my present with my past,</line>
      <line>If you but go your own way. And I said,</line>
      <line>I will retire as soon as you have told</line>
      <line>Whereunto leadeth this lost thread of gold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so you know it not! he hissed with scorn;</line>
      <line>I feared you, imbecile! It leads me back</line>
      <line>From this accursed night without a morn,</line>
      <line>And through the deserts which have else no track,</line>
      <line>And through vast wastes of horror-haunted time,</line>
      <line>To Eden innocence in Eden’s clime:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I become a nursling soft and pure,</line>
      <line>An infant cradled on its mother’s knee,</line>
      <line>Without a past, love-cherished and secure;</line>
      <line>Which if it saw this loathsome present Me,</line>
      <line>Would plunge its face into the pillowing breast,</line>
      <line>And scream abhorrence hard to lull to rest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He turned to grope; and I retiring brushed</line>
      <line>Thin shreds of gossamer from off my face,</line>
      <line>And mused, His life would grow, the germ uncrushed;</line>
      <line>He should to antenatal night retrace,</line>
      <line>And hide his elements in that large womb</line>
      <line>Beyond the reach of man-evolving Doom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And even thus, what weary way were planned,</line>
      <line>To seek oblivion through the far-off gate</line>
      <line>Of birth, when that of death is close at hand!</line>
      <line>For this is law, if law there be in Fate:</line>
      <line>What never has been, yet may have its when;</line>
      <line>The thing which has been, never is again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>C. S. Calverley</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>Peace: A Study</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stood, a worn-out City clerk—</line>
      <line>Who’d toiled, and seen no holiday,</line>
      <line>For forty years from dawn to dark—</line>
      <line>Alone beside Caermarthen Bay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He felt the salt spray on his lips;</line>
      <line>Heard children’s voices on the sands;</line>
      <line>Up the sun’s path he saw the ships</line>
      <line>Sail on and on to other lands;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And laughed aloud. Each sight and sound</line>
      <line>To him was joy too deep for tears;</line>
      <line>He sat him on the beach, and bound</line>
      <line>A blue bandana round his ears:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And thought how, posted near his door,</line>
      <line>His own green door on Camden Hill,</line>
      <line>Two bands at least, most likely more,</line>
      <line>Were mingling at their own sweet will</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Verdi with Vance. And at the thought</line>
      <line>He laughed again, and softly drew</line>
      <line>That Morning Herald that he’d bought</line>
      <line>Forth from his breast, and read it through.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>C. S. Calverley</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>Changed</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know not why my soul is racked:</line>
      <line>Why I ne’er smile as was my wont:</line>
      <line>I only know that, as a fact,</line>
      <line>I don’t.</line>
      <line>I used to roam o’er glen and glade</line>
      <line>Buoyant and blithe as other folk:</line>
      <line>And not unfrequently I made</line>
      <line>A joke.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A minstrel’s fire within me burned.</line>
      <line>I’d sing, as one whose heart must break,</line>
      <line>Lay upon lay: I nearly learned</line>
      <line>To shake.</line>
      <line>All day I sang; of love, of fame,</line>
      <line>Of fights our fathers fought of yore,</line>
      <line>Until the thing almost became</line>
      <line>A bore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot sing the old songs now!</line>
      <line>It is not that I deem them low;</line>
      <line>’Tis that I can’t remember how</line>
      <line>They go.</line>
      <line>I could not range the hills till high</line>
      <line>Above me stood the summer moon:</line>
      <line>And as to dancing, I could fly</line>
      <line>As soon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sports, to which with boyish glee</line>
      <line>I sprang erewhile, attract no more;</line>
      <line>Although I am but sixty-three</line>
      <line>Or four.</line>
      <line>Nay, worse than that, I’ve seemed of late</line>
      <line>To shrink from happy boyhood—boys</line>
      <line>Have grown so noisy, and I hate</line>
      <line>A noise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They fright me, when the beech is green,</line>
      <line>By swarming up its stem for eggs:</line>
      <line>They drive their horrid hoops between</line>
      <line>My legs:—</line>
      <line>It’s idle to repine, I know;</line>
      <line>I’ll tell you what I’ll do instead:</line>
      <line>I’ll drink my arrowroot, and go</line>
      <line>To bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>C. S. Calverley</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>Contentment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Friend, there be they on whom mishap</line>
      <line>Or never or so rarely comes,</line>
      <line>That, when they think thereof, they snap</line>
      <line>Derisive thumbs:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And there be they who lightly lose</line>
      <line>Their all, yet feel no aching void;</line>
      <line>Should aught annoy them, they refuse</line>
      <line>To be annoyed:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And fain would I be e’en as these!</line>
      <line>Life is with such all beer and skittles;</line>
      <line>They are not difficult to please</line>
      <line>About their victuals:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The trout, the grouse, the early pea,</line>
      <line>By such, if there, are freely taken;</line>
      <line>If not, they munch with equal glee</line>
      <line>Their bit of bacon:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when they wax a little gay</line>
      <line>And chaff the public after luncheon,</line>
      <line>If they’re confronted with a stray</line>
      <line>Policeman’s truncheon,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They gaze thereat with outstretched necks,</line>
      <line>And laughter which no threats can smother,</line>
      <line>And tell the horror-stricken X</line>
      <line>That he’s another.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In snowtime if they cross a spot</line>
      <line>Where unsuspected boys have slid,</line>
      <line>They fall not down—though they would not</line>
      <line>Mind if they did:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the spring rosebud which they wear</line>
      <line>Breaks short and tumbles from its stem,</line>
      <line>No thought of being angry e’er</line>
      <line>Dawns upon them;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though ’twas Jemima’s hand that placed,</line>
      <line>(As well you ween) at evening’s hour,</line>
      <line>In the loved button-hole that chaste</line>
      <line>And cherished flower.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when they travel, if they find</line>
      <line>That they have left their pocket-compass</line>
      <line>Or Murray or thick boots behind,</line>
      <line>They raise no rumpus,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But plod serenely on without:</line>
      <line>Knowing it’s better to endure</line>
      <line>The evil which beyond all doubt</line>
      <line>You cannot cure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When for that early train they’re late,</line>
      <line>They do not make their woes the text</line>
      <line>Of sermons in the Times, but wait</line>
      <line>On for the next;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And jump inside, and only grin</line>
      <line>Should it appear that that dry wag,</line>
      <line>The guard, omitted to put in</line>
      <line>Their carpet-bag.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>C. S. Calverley</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>‘Forever'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forever; ’tis a single word!</line>
      <line>Our rude forefathers deemed it two:</line>
      <line>Can you imagine so absurd</line>
      <line>A view?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forever! What abysms of woe</line>
      <line>The word reveals, what frenzy, what</line>
      <line>Despair! For ever (printed so)</line>
      <line>Did not.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It looks, ah me! how trite and tame!</line>
      <line>It fails to sadden or appal</line>
      <line>Or solace—it is not the same</line>
      <line>At all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O thou to whom it first occurred</line>
      <line>To solder the disjoined, and dower</line>
      <line>Thy native language with a word</line>
      <line>Of power:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We bless thee! Whether far or near</line>
      <line>Thy dwelling, whether dark or fair</line>
      <line>Thy kingly brow, is neither here</line>
      <line>Nor there.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But in men’s hearts shall be thy throne,</line>
      <line>While the great pulse of England beats.</line>
      <line>Thou coiner of a word unknown</line>
      <line>To Keats!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And nevermore must printer do</line>
      <line>As men did long ago; but run</line>
      <line>‘For’ into ‘ever,’ bidding two</line>
      <line>Be one.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forever! passion-fraught, it throws</line>
      <line>O’er the dim page a gloom, a glamour:</line>
      <line>It’s sweet, it’s strange; and I suppose</line>
      <line>It’s grammar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forever! ’Tis a single word!</line>
      <line>And yet our fathers deemed it two:</line>
      <line>Nor am I confident they erred;</line>
      <line>Are you?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1866</date>
    <title>Her Dilemma</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The two were silent in a sunless church,</line>
      <line>Whose mildewed walls, uneven paving-stones,</line>
      <line>And wasted carvings passed antique research;</line>
      <line>And nothing broke the clock’s dull monotones.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Leaning against a wormy poppy-head,</line>
      <line>So wan and worn that he could scarcely stand,</line>
      <line>—For he was soon to die,—he softly said,</line>
      <line>‘Tell me you love me!’—holding long her hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She would have given a world to breathe ‘yes’ truly,</line>
      <line>So much his life seemed hanging on her mind,</line>
      <line>And hence she lied, her heart persuaded throughly</line>
      <line>’Twas worth her soul to be a moment kind.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But the sad need thereof, his nearing death,</line>
      <line>So mocked humanity that she shamed to prize</line>
      <line>A world conditioned thus, or care for breath</line>
      <line>Where Nature such dilemmas could devise.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>Neutral Tones</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We stood by a pond that winter day,</line>
      <line>And the sun was white, as though chidden of God,</line>
      <line>And a few leaves lay on the starving sod;</line>
      <line>—They had fallen from an ash, and were gray.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your eyes on me were as eyes that rove</line>
      <line>Over tedious riddles of years ago;</line>
      <line>And some words played between us to and fro</line>
      <line>On which lost the more by our love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The smile on your mouth was the deadest thing</line>
      <line>Alive enough to have strength to die;</line>
      <line>And a grin of bitterness swept thereby</line>
      <line>Like an ominous bird a-wing...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Since then, keen lessons that love deceives,</line>
      <line>And wrings with wrong, have shaped to me</line>
      <line>Your face, and the God-curst sun, and a tree,</line>
      <line>And a pond edged with grayish leaves.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>Thoughts of Phena</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Not a line of her writing have I,</line>
      <line>Not a thread of her hair,</line>
      <line>No mark of her late time as dame in her dwelling, whereby</line>
      <line>I may picture her there;</line>
      <line>And in vain do I urge my unsight</line>
      <line>To conceive my lost prize</line>
      <line>At her close, whom I knew when her dreams were upbrimming</line>
      <line>with light,</line>
      <line>And with laughter her eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What scenes spread around her last days,</line>
      <line>Sad, shining, or dim?</line>
      <line>Did her gifts and compassions enray and enarch her sweet ways</line>
      <line>With an aureate nimb?</line>
      <line>Or did life-light decline from her years,</line>
      <line>And mischances control</line>
      <line>Her full day-star; unease, or regret, or forebodings, or fears</line>
      <line>Disennoble her soul?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus I do but the phantom retain</line>
      <line>Of the maiden of yore</line>
      <line>As my relic; yet haply the best of her—fined in my brain</line>
      <line>It may be the more</line>
      <line>That no line of her writing have I,</line>
      <line>Nor a thread of her hair,</line>
      <line>No mark of her late time as dame in her dwelling, whereby</line>
      <line>I may picture her there.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1898</date>
    <title>Friends Beyond</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>William Dewy, Tranter Reuben, Farmer Ledlow late at plough,</line>
      <line>Robert’s kin, and John’s, and Ned’s,</line>
      <line>And the Squire, and Lady Susan, lie in Mellstock churchyard now!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Gone,’ I call them, gone for good, that group of local hearts and heads;</line>
      <line>Yet at mothy curfew-tide,</line>
      <line>And at midnight when the noon-heat breathes it back from walls and leads,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They’ve a way of whispering to me—fellow-wight who yet abide—</line>
      <line>In the muted, measured note</line>
      <line>Of a ripple under archways, or a lone cave’s stillicide:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We have triumphed: this achievement turns the bane to antidote,</line>
      <line>Unsuccesses to success,</line>
      <line>Many thought-worn eves and morrows to a morrow free of thought.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘No more need we corn and clothing, feel of old terrestrial stress;</line>
      <line>Chill detraction stirs no sigh;</line>
      <line>Fear of death has even bygone us: death gave all that we possess.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>W. D.—‘Ye mid burn the old bass-viol that I set such value by.’</line>
      <line>Squire.—‘You may hold the manse in fee,</line>
      <line>You may wed my spouse, may let my children’s memory of me die.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lady S.—‘You may have my rich brocades, my laces; take each household key;</line>
      <line>Ransack coffer, desk, bureau;</line>
      <line>Quiz the few poor treasures hid there, con the letters kept by me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Far.—‘Ye mid zell my favourite heifer, ye mid let the charlock grow,</line>
      <line>Foul the grinterns, give up thrift.’</line>
      <line>Far. Wife.—‘If ye break my best blue china, children, I shan’t care or ho.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All.—‘We’ve no wish to hear the tidings, how the people’s fortunes shift;</line>
      <line>What your daily doings are;</line>
      <line>Who are wedded, born, divided; if your lives beat slow or swift.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Curious not the least are we if our intents you make or mar,</line>
      <line>If you quire to our old tune,</line>
      <line>If the City stage still passes, if the weirs still roar afar.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>—Thus, with very gods’ composure, freed those crosses late and soon</line>
      <line>Which, in life, the Trine allow</line>
      <line>(Why, none witteth), and ignoring all that haps beneath the moon,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>William Dewy, Tranter Reuben, Farmer Ledlow late at plough,</line>
      <line>Robert’s kin, and John’s, and Ned’s,</line>
      <line>And the Squire, and Lady Susan, murmur mildly to me now.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1898</date>
    <title>At an Inn</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When we as strangers sought</line>
      <line>Their catering care,</line>
      <line>Veiled smiles bespoke their thought</line>
      <line>Of what we were.</line>
      <line>They warmed as they opined</line>
      <line>Us more than friends—</line>
      <line>That we had all resigned</line>
      <line>For love’s dear ends.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that swift sympathy</line>
      <line>With living love</line>
      <line>Which quicks the world—maybe</line>
      <line>The spheres above,</line>
      <line>Made them our ministers,</line>
      <line>Moved them to say,</line>
      <line>‘Ah, God, that bliss like theirs</line>
      <line>Would flush our day!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And we were left alone</line>
      <line>As Love’s own pair;</line>
      <line>Yet never the love-light shone</line>
      <line>Between us there!</line>
      <line>But that which chilled the breath</line>
      <line>Of afternoon,</line>
      <line>And palsied unto death</line>
      <line>The pane-fly’s tune.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The kiss their zeal foretold,</line>
      <line>And now deemed come,</line>
      <line>Came not: within his hold</line>
      <line>Love lingered numb.</line>
      <line>Why cast he on our port</line>
      <line>A bloom not ours?</line>
      <line>Why shaped us for his sport</line>
      <line>In after-hours?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>As we seemed we were not</line>
      <line>That day afar,</line>
      <line>And now we seem not what</line>
      <line>We aching are.</line>
      <line>O severing sea and land,</line>
      <line>O laws of men,</line>
      <line>Ere death, once let us stand</line>
      <line>As we stood then!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1898</date>
    <title>'Look into My Glass'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I look into my glass,</line>
      <line>And view my wasting skin,</line>
      <line>And say, ‘Would God it came to pass</line>
      <line>My heart had shrunk as thin!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For then, I, undistrest</line>
      <line>By hearts grown cold to me,</line>
      <line>Could lonely wait my endless rest</line>
      <line>With equanimity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Time, to make me grieve,</line>
      <line>Part steals, lets part abide;</line>
      <line>And shakes this fragile frame at eve</line>
      <line>With throbbings of noontide.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>Drummer Hodge</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They throw in Drummer Hodge, to rest</line>
      <line>Uncoffined—just as found:</line>
      <line>His landmark is a kopje-crest</line>
      <line>That breaks the veldt around;</line>
      <line>And foreign constellations west</line>
      <line>Each night above his mound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Young Hodge the Drummer never knew—</line>
      <line>Fresh from his Wessex home—</line>
      <line>The meaning of the broad Karoo,</line>
      <line>The Bush, the dusty loam,</line>
      <line>And why uprose to nightly view</line>
      <line>Strange stars amid the gloam.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet portion of that unknown plain</line>
      <line>Will Hodge for ever be;</line>
      <line>His homely Northern breast and brain</line>
      <line>Grow to some Southern tree,</line>
      <line>And strange-eyed constellations reign</line>
      <line>His stars eternally.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>A Wife in London</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She sits in the tawny vapour</line>
      <line>That the Thames-side lanes have uprolled,</line>
      <line>Behind whose webby fold on fold</line>
      <line>Like a waning taper</line>
      <line>The street-lamp glimmers cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A messenger’s knock cracks smartly,</line>
      <line>Flashed news is in her hand</line>
      <line>Of meaning it dazes to understand</line>
      <line>Though shaped so shortly:</line>
      <line>He—has fallen—in the far South Land....</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis the morrow; the fog hangs thicker,</line>
      <line>The postman nears and goes:</line>
      <line>A letter is brought whose lines disclose</line>
      <line>By the firelight flicker</line>
      <line>His hand, whom the worm now knows:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fresh—firm—penned in highest feather—</line>
      <line>Page-full of his hoped return,</line>
      <line>And of home-planned jaunts by brake and bum</line>
      <line>In the summer weather,</line>
      <line>And of new love that they would learn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>An August Midnight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A shaded lamp and a waving blind,</line>
      <line>And the beat of a clock from a distant floor:</line>
      <line>On this scene enter—winged, horned, and spined—</line>
      <line>A longlegs, a moth, and a dumbledore;</line>
      <line>While ’mid my page there idly stands</line>
      <line>A sleepy fly, that rubs its hands ...</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thus meet we five, in this still place,</line>
      <line>At this point of time, at this point in space.</line>
      <line>—My guests besmear my new-penned line,</line>
      <line>Or bang at the lamp and fall supine.</line>
      <line>‘God’s humblest, they!’ I muse. Yet why?</line>
      <line>They know Earth-secrets that know not I.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>The Darkling Thrush</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I leant upon a coppice gate</line>
      <line>When Frost was spectre-gray,</line>
      <line>And Winter’s dregs made desolate</line>
      <line>The weakening eye of day.</line>
      <line>The tangled bine-stems scored the sky</line>
      <line>Like strings of broken lyres,</line>
      <line>And all mankind that haunted nigh</line>
      <line>Had sought their household fires.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The land’s sharp features seemed to be</line>
      <line>The Century’s corpse outleant,</line>
      <line>His crypt the cloudy canopy,</line>
      <line>The wind his death-lament.</line>
      <line>The ancient pulse of germ and birth</line>
      <line>Was shrunken hard and dry,</line>
      <line>And every spirit upon earth</line>
      <line>Seemed fervourless as I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At once a voice arose among</line>
      <line>The bleak twigs overhead</line>
      <line>In a full-hearted evensong</line>
      <line>Of joy illimited;</line>
      <line>An aged thrush, frail, gaunt, and small,</line>
      <line>In blast-beruffled plume,</line>
      <line>Had chosen thus to fling his soul</line>
      <line>Upon the growing gloom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So little cause for carolings</line>
      <line>Of such ecstatic sound</line>
      <line>Was written on terrestial things</line>
      <line>Afar or nigh around,</line>
      <line>That I could think there trembled through</line>
      <line>His happy good-night air</line>
      <line>Some blessed Hope, whereof he knew</line>
      <line>And I was unaware.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>Wives in the Sere</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Never a careworn wife but shows,</line>
      <line>If a joy suffuse her,</line>
      <line>Something beautiful to those</line>
      <line>Patient to peruse her,</line>
      <line>Some one charm the world unknows</line>
      <line>Precious to a muser,</line>
      <line>Haply what, ere years were foes,</line>
      <line>Moved her mate to choose her.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, be it a hint of rose</line>
      <line>That an instant hues her,</line>
      <line>Or some early light or pose</line>
      <line>Wherewith thought renews her—</line>
      <line>Seen by him at full, ere woes</line>
      <line>Practised to abuse her—</line>
      <line>Sparely comes it, swiftly goes,</line>
      <line>Time again subdues her.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>The Subalterns</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Poor wanderer,’ said the leaden sky,</line>
      <line>‘I fain would lighten thee,</line>
      <line>But there are laws in force on high</line>
      <line>Which say it must not be.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>—‘I would not freeze thee, shorn one,’ cried</line>
      <line>The North, ‘knew I but how</line>
      <line>To warm my breath, to slack my stride;</line>
      <line>But I am ruled as thou.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>—‘To-morrow I attack thee, wight,’</line>
      <line>Said Sickness. ‘Yet I swear</line>
      <line>I bear thy little ark no spite,</line>
      <line>But am bid enter there.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>—‘Come hither, Son,’ I heard Death say;</line>
      <line>‘I did not will a grave</line>
      <line>Should end thy pilgrimage to-day,</line>
      <line>But I, too, am a slave!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We smiled upon each other then,</line>
      <line>And life to me had less</line>
      <line>Of that fell look it wore ere when</line>
      <line>They owned their passiveness.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>Long Plighted</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it worth while, dear, now,</line>
      <line>To call for bells, and sally forth arrayed</line>
      <line>For marriage-rites—discussed, decried, delayed</line>
      <line>So many years?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it worth while, dear, now,</line>
      <line>To stir desire for old fond purposings,</line>
      <line>By feints that Time still serves for dallyings,</line>
      <line>Though quittance nears?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it worth while, dear, when</line>
      <line>The day being so far spent, so low the sun,</line>
      <line>The undone thing will soon be as the done,</line>
      <line>And smiles as tears?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it worth while, dear, when</line>
      <line>Our cheeks are worn, our early brown is gray;</line>
      <line>When, meet or part we, none says yea or nay,</line>
      <line>Or heeds, or cares?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it worth while, dear, since</line>
      <line>We still can climb old Yell’ham’s wooded mounds</line>
      <line>Together, as each season steals its rounds</line>
      <line>And disappears?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it worth while, dear, since</line>
      <line>As mates in Mellstock churchyard we can lie,</line>
      <line>Till the last crash of all things low and high</line>
      <line>Shall end the spheres?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>A Commonplace Day</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The day is turning ghost,</line>
      <line>And scuttles from the kalendar in fits and furtively,</line>
      <line>To join the anonymous host</line>
      <line>Of those that throng oblivion; ceding his place, maybe,</line>
      <line>To one of like degree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I part the fire-gnawed logs,</line>
      <line>Rake forth the embers, spoil the busy flames, and lay the ends</line>
      <line>Upon the shining dogs;</line>
      <line>Further and further from the nooks the twilight’s stride extends,</line>
      <line>And beamless black impends.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nothing of tiniest worth</line>
      <line>Have I wrought, pondered, planned; no one thing asking blame or praise,</line>
      <line>Since the pale corpse-like birth</line>
      <line>Of this diurnal unit, bearing blanks in all its rays—</line>
      <line>Dullest of dull-hued Days!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wanly upon the panes</line>
      <line>The rain slides as have slid since morn my colourless thoughts; and yet</line>
      <line>Here, while Day’s presence wanes,</line>
      <line>And over him the sepulchre-lid is slowly lowered and set,</line>
      <line>He wakens my regret.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Regret—though nothing dear</line>
      <line>That I wot of, was toward in the wide world at his prime,</line>
      <line>Or bloomed elsewhere than here,</line>
      <line>To die with his decease, and leave a memory sweet, sublime,</line>
      <line>Or mark him out in Time....</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>—Yet, maybe, in some soul,</line>
      <line>In some spot undiscerned on sea or land, some impulse rose,</line>
      <line>Or some intent upstole</line>
      <line>Of that enkindling ardency from whose maturer glows</line>
      <line>The world’s amendment flows;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But which, benumbed at birth</line>
      <line>By momentary chance or wile, has missed its hope to be</line>
      <line>Embodied on the earth;</line>
      <line>And undervoicings of this loss to man’s futurity</line>
      <line>May wake regret in me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>To Lizbie Browne</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>Where are you now?</line>
      <line>In sun, in rain?—</line>
      <line>Or is your brow</line>
      <line>Past joy, past pain,</line>
      <line>Dear Lizbie Browne?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>How you could smile,</line>
      <line>How you could sing!—</line>
      <line>How archly wile</line>
      <line>In glance-giving,</line>
      <line>Sweet Lizbie Browne!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>Who else had hair</line>
      <line>Bay-red as yours,</line>
      <line>Or flesh so fair</line>
      <line>Bred out of doors,</line>
      <line>Sweet Lizbie Browne?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When, Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>You had just begun</line>
      <line>To be endeared</line>
      <line>By stealth to one,</line>
      <line>You disappeared,</line>
      <line>My Lizbie Browne!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ay, Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>So swift your life,</line>
      <line>And mine so slow,</line>
      <line>You were a wife</line>
      <line>Ere I could show</line>
      <line>Love, Lizbie Browne.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still, Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>You won, they said,</line>
      <line>The best of men</line>
      <line>When you were wed....</line>
      <line>Where went you then,</line>
      <line>O Lizbie Browne?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>I should have thought,</line>
      <line>‘Girls ripen fast,’</line>
      <line>And coaxed and caught</line>
      <line>You ere you passed,</line>
      <line>Dear Lizbie Browne!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>I let you slip;</line>
      <line>Shaped not a sign;</line>
      <line>Touched never your lip</line>
      <line>With lip of mine,</line>
      <line>Lost Lizbie Browne!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, Lizbie Browne,</line>
      <line>When on a day</line>
      <line>Men speak of me</line>
      <line>As not, you’ll say,</line>
      <line>‘And who was he?’—</line>
      <line>Yes, Lizbie Browne!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>A Broken Appointment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>You did not come,</line>
      <line>And marching Time drew on, and wore me numb.—</line>
      <line>Yet less for loss of your dear presence there</line>
      <line>Than that I thus found lacking in your make</line>
      <line>That high compassion which can overbear</line>
      <line>Reluctance for pure lovingkindness’ sake</line>
      <line>Grieved I, when, as the hope-hour stroked its sum,</line>
      <line>You did not come.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You love not me,</line>
      <line>And love alone can lend you loyalty;</line>
      <line>—I know and knew it. But, unto the store</line>
      <line>Of human deeds divine in all but name,</line>
      <line>Was it not worth a little hour or more</line>
      <line>To add yet this: Once you, a woman, came</line>
      <line>To soothe a time-torn man; even though it be</line>
      <line>You love not me?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Thomas Hardy</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>The Self-Unseeing</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here is the ancient floor,</line>
      <line>Footworn and hollowed and thin,</line>
      <line>Here was the former door</line>
      <line>Where the dead feet walked in.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She sat here in her chair,</line>
      <line>Smiling into the fire;</line>
      <line>He who played stood there,</line>
      <line>Bowing it higher and higher.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Childlike, I danced in a dream;</line>
      <line>Blessings emblazoned that day;</line>
      <line>Everything glowed with a gleam;</line>
      <line>Yet we were looking away!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dora Greenwell</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>A Scherzo</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>With the wasp at the innermost heart of a peach,</line>
      <line>On a sunny wall out of tip-toe reach,</line>
      <line>With the trout in the darkest summer pool,</line>
      <line>With the fern-seed clinging behind its cool</line>
      <line>Smooth frond, in the chink of an aged tree,</line>
      <line>In the woodbine’s horn with the drunken bee,</line>
      <line>With the mouse in its nest in a furrow old,</line>
      <line>With the chrysalis wrapt in its gauzy fold;</line>
      <line>With things that are hidden, and safe, and bold,</line>
      <line>With things that are timid, and shy, and free,</line>
      <line>Wishing to be;</line>
      <line>With the nut in its shell, with the seed in its pod,</line>
      <line>With the corn as it sprouts in the kindly clod,</line>
      <line>Far down where the secret of beauty shows</line>
      <line>In the bulb of the tulip, before it blows;</line>
      <line>With things that are rooted, and firm, and deep,</line>
      <line>Quiet to lie, and dreamless to sleep;</line>
      <line>With things that are chainless, and tameless, and proud,</line>
      <line>With the fire in the jagged thunder-cloud,</line>
      <line>With the wind in its sleep, with the wind in its waking,</line>
      <line>With the drops that go to the rainbow’s making,</line>
      <line>Wishing to be with the light leaves shaking,</line>
      <line>Or stones on some desolate highway breaking;</line>
      <line>Far up on the hills, where no foot surprises</line>
      <line>The dew as it falls, or the dust as it rises;</line>
      <line>To be couched with the beast in its torrid lair,</line>
      <line>Or drifting on ice with the polar bear,</line>
      <line>With the weaver at work at his quiet loom;</line>
      <line>Anywhere, anywhere, out of this room!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Digby Mackworth Dolben</author>
    <date>1867</date>
    <title>A Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world is young today:</line>
      <line>Forget the gods are old,</line>
      <line>Forget the years of gold</line>
      <line>When all the months were May.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little flower of Love</line>
      <line>Is ours, without a root,</line>
      <line>Without the end of fruit,</line>
      <line>Yet—take the scent thereof.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There may be hope above,</line>
      <line>There may be rest beneath;</line>
      <line>We see them not, but Death</line>
      <line>Is palpable—and Love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W. H. Mallock</author>
    <date>1868</date>
    <title>A Marriage Prospect</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why should I heed their railings? What’s a prude?</line>
      <line>A devil’s scarecrow in the fields of good.</line>
      <line>Let them rail on. I think a wedding-day</line>
      <line>Looks best, as mountains do, some miles away,</line>
      <line>Or squalid fishing-smacks far out to sea,</line>
      <line>Seen lily-sailed in sunshine and blue haze,</line>
      <line>Where the delicious lights are all men chase,</line>
      <line>And no man ever reaches. And so I’m free</line>
      <line>Another six weeks—move in a rich half-light,</line>
      <line>A tenderest compromise of dark and bright,</line>
      <line>A magic season, in short, when eyes that shine</line>
      <line>And lips that whisper with soft words, combine</line>
      <line>The spice of wrong, the conscience-ease of right,</line>
      <line>And deepest sighs come most luxuriously.</line>
      <line>Then too this twilight-time leads not to night</line>
      <line>But sunrise—that at least will gladden me,</line>
      <line>The sunrise of my day of married life,</line>
      <line>Ere bride and bridegroom fade to man and wife:</line>
      <line>And I meanwhile, a short time more, am free—</line>
      <line>Or half free; wherefore let me love my fill</line>
      <line>Of half-loves, ere I consecrate my days,</line>
      <line>In sober, sombre truth, for good and ill,</line>
      <line>To the one worship of a withering face.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W. H. Mallock</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Christmas Thoughts, by a Modern Thinker</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The windows of the church are bright;</line>
      <line>’Tis Christmas Eve; a low wind breathes;</line>
      <line>And girls with happy eyes to-night</line>
      <line>Are hanging up the Christmas wreaths;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And village voices by-and-by</line>
      <line>Will reach my windows through the trees,</line>
      <line>With wild, sweet music: ‘Praise on high</line>
      <line>To God: on earth, good-will and peace.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, happy girls, that hang the wreaths!</line>
      <line>Oh, village fiddlers, happy ye!</line>
      <line>Christmas to you still truly breathes</line>
      <line>Good-will and peace; but not to me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes, gladness is your simple role,</line>
      <line>Ye foolish girls, ye labouring poor;</line>
      <line>But joy would ill beseem my soul—</line>
      <line>To sigh, my part is, and endure.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For once as Rousseau stood, I stand</line>
      <line>Apart, made picturesque by grief—</line>
      <line>One of a small world-weary band,</line>
      <line>The orphans of a dead belief.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Through graveyards lone we love to stray,</line>
      <line>And sadly the sad tombs explore,</line>
      <line>And contradict the texts which say</line>
      <line>That we shall rise once more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our faith is dead, of course; and grief</line>
      <line>Fills its room up; and Christmas pie</line>
      <line>And turkey cannot bring relief</line>
      <line>To such as Obermann and I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, Obermann, and might I pass</line>
      <line>This English Christmas-tide with thee,</line>
      <line>Far by those inland waves whose glass</line>
      <line>Brightens and breaks by Meillerie;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or else amongst the sternest dells</line>
      <line>Alp shags with pine, we’d mix our sighs,</line>
      <line>Mourn at the sound of Christmas bells,</line>
      <line>Sniff at the smell of Christmas pies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But thou art dead; and long, dank grass</line>
      <line>And wet mould cool thy tired, hot brain;</line>
      <line>Thou art lain down, and now, alas!</line>
      <line>Of course you won’t get up again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet, Obermann, ’tis better so;</line>
      <line>For if, sad slumberer, after all</line>
      <line>You were to re-arise, you know</line>
      <line>’Twould make us feel so very small.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Best bear our grief this manlier way,</line>
      <line>And make our grief be balm to grief;</line>
      <line>For if in faith sweet comfort lay,</line>
      <line>There lurks sweet pride in unbelief.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wherefore, remembering this, once more</line>
      <line>Unto my childhood’s church I’ll go,</line>
      <line>And bow my head at that low door</line>
      <line>I passed through standing, long ago.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll sit in the accustomed place,</line>
      <line>And make, while all the unlearned stare,</line>
      <line>A mournful, atheistic face</line>
      <line>At their vain noise of unheard prayer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, while they hymn the heavenly birth</line>
      <line>And angel voices from the skies,</line>
      <line>My thoughts shall go where Weimar’s earth</line>
      <line>For ever darkens Goethe’s eyes;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till sweet girls’ glances from their books</line>
      <line>Shall steal towards me, and they sigh:</line>
      <line>‘How intellectual he looks,</line>
      <line>And yet how wistful! And his eye</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Has that vain look of baffled prayer!’</line>
      <line>And then when church is o’er I’ll run,</line>
      <line>Comb misery into all my hair,</line>
      <line>And go and get my portrait done.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Eliot</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>from Brother and Sister (VI)</title>
