    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our brown canal was endless to my thought;</line>
      <line>And on its banks I sat in dreamy peace,</line>
      <line>Unknowing how the good I loved was wrought,</line>
      <line>Untroubled by the fear that it would cease.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Slowly the barges floated into hew</line>
      <line>Rounding a grassy hill to me sublime</line>
      <line>With some Unknown beyond it, whither flew</line>
      <line>The parting cuckoo toward a fresh spring time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wide-arched bridge, the scented elder-flowers,</line>
      <line>The wondrous watery rings that died too soon,</line>
      <line>The echoes of the quarry, the still hours</line>
      <line>With white robe sweeping-on the shadeless noon,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Were but my growing self, are part of me,</line>
      <line>My present Past, my root of piety.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>from Brother and Sister (VII)</line>
      <line>Those long days measured by my little feet</line>
      <line>Had chronicles which yield me many a text;</line>
      <line>Where irony still finds an image meet</line>
      <line>Of full-grown judgments in this world perplext.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One day my brother left me in high charge,</line>
      <line>To mind the rod, while he went seeking bait,</line>
      <line>And bade me, when I saw a nearing barge,</line>
      <line>Snatch out the line, lest he should come too late.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Proud of the task, I watched with all my might</line>
      <line>For one whole minute, till my eyes grew wide,</line>
      <line>Till sky and earth took on a strange new light</line>
      <line>And seemed a dream-world floating on some tide—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fair pavilioned boat for me alone</line>
      <line>Bearing me onward through the vast unknown.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>from Brother and Sister (VIII)</line>
      <line>But sudden came the barge’s pitch-black prow,</line>
      <line>Nearer and angrier came my brother’s cry,</line>
      <line>And all my soul was quivering fear, when lo!</line>
      <line>Upon the imperilled line, suspended high,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A silver perch! My guilt that won the prey,</line>
      <line>Now turned to merit, had a guerdon rich</line>
      <line>Of hugs and praises, and made merry play,</line>
      <line>Until my triumph reached its highest pitch</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When all at home were told the wondrous feat,</line>
      <line>And how the little sister had fished well.</line>
      <line>In secret, though my fortune tasted sweet,</line>
      <line>I wondered why this happiness befell.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘The little lass had luck,’ the gardener said:</line>
      <line>And so I learned, luck was with glory wed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Augustus Simcox</author>
    <date>1869</date>
    <title>Love's Votary</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Others have pleasantness and praise,</line>
      <line>And wealth; and hand and glove</line>
      <line>They walk with worship all their days,</line>
      <line>But I have only Love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And therefore if Love be a fire,</line>
      <line>Then he shall burn me up;</line>
      <line>If Love be water out of mire,</line>
      <line>Then I will be the cup.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If Love come worn with wayfaring,</line>
      <line>My breast shall be his bed;</line>
      <line>If he come faint and hungering,</line>
      <line>My heart shall be his bread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If Love delight in vassalage,</line>
      <line>Then I will be his thrall,</line>
      <line>Till, when I end my pilgrimage,</line>
      <line>Love give me all for all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1870</date>
    <title>The Well</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I AM a spring—</line>
      <line>Why square me with a kerb?</line>
      <line>Ah, why this measuring</line>
      <line>Of marble limit? Why this accurate vault</line>
      <line>Lest day assault,</line>
      <line>Or any breath disturb?</line>
      <line>And why this regulated flow</line>
      <line>Of what ’tis good to feel, and what to know?</line>
      <line>You have no right</line>
      <line>To take me thus, and bind me to your use,</line>
      <line>Screening me from the flight</line>
      <line>Of all great wings that are beneath the heaven,</line>
      <line>So that to me it is not given</line>
      <line>To hold the image of the awful Zeus,</line>
      <line>Nor any cloud or star</line>
      <line>Emprints me from afar.</line>
      <line>O cruel force,</line>
      <line>That gives me not a chance</line>
      <line>To fill my natural course;</line>
      <line>With mathematic rod</line>
      <line>Economising God;</line>
      <line>Calling me to pre-ordered circumstance</line>
      <line>Nor suffering me to dance</line>
      <line>Over the pleasant gravel,</line>
      <line>With music solacing my travel—</line>
      <line>With music, and the baby buds that toss</line>
      <line>In light, with roots and sippets of the moss!</line>
      <line>A fount, a tank:</line>
      <line>Yet through some sorry grate</line>
      <line>A driblet faulters, till around the flank</line>
      <line>Of burly cliffs it creeps; then, silver-shooting,</line>
      <line>Threads all the patient fluting</line>
      <line>Of quartz, and violet-dappled slate:</line>
      <line>A puny thing, on whose attenuate ripples</line>
      <line>No satyr stoops to see</line>
      <line>His broken effigy,</line>
      <line>No naiad leans the languor of her nipples.</line>
      <line>One faith remains—</line>
      <line>That through what ducts soe’er,</line>
      <line>What metamorphic strains,</line>
      <line>What chymic filt’rings, I shall pass</line>
      <line>To where, O God, Thou lov’st to mass</line>
      <line>Thy rains upon the crags, and dim the sphere.</line>
      <line>So, when night’s heart with keenest silence thrills,</line>
      <line>Take me, and weep me on the desolate hills!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>High overhead</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>High overhead</line>
      <line>My little daughter</line>
      <line>Was going to bed:—</line>
      <line>Below</line>
      <line>In twenty fathoms of black water</line>
      <line>A cod went sulking slow—</line>
      <line>Perceived the light</line>
      <line>That sparkled on the height,</line>
      <line>Then swam</line>
      <line>Up to the filmy level,</line>
      <line>Brought’s eye to bear</line>
      <line>With dull fixed stare,</line>
      <line>Then—‘Damn!’</line>
      <line>He said—and ‘Devil!—</line>
      <line>I thought’—but what he thought who knows?</line>
      <line>One plunge, and off he goes</line>
      <line>East? North?</line>
      <line>Fares forth</line>
      <line>To Lundy? Cardiff? But of that keen probe</line>
      <line>That for an instant pierced the lobe</line>
      <line>Of his sad brain,</line>
      <line>Tickling the phosphor-grit,</line>
      <line>How long will he retain</line>
      <line>One bit?</line>
      <line>And then above</line>
      <line>My little daughter kneels, and says her prayers.</line>
      <line>Quite right!</line>
      <line>My little love—</line>
      <line>Good night!</line>
      <line>Sweet pet!</line>
      <line>Put out the light!</line>
      <line>And so</line>
      <line>I go</line>
      <line>Downstairs—</line>
      <line>And yet—and yet—</line>
      <line>That cod!</line>
      <line>O God!</line>
      <line>O God!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1878</date>
    <title>The Bristol Channel</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sulky old gray brute!</line>
      <line>But when the sunset strokes him,</line>
      <line>Or twilight shadows coax him,</line>
      <line>He gets so silver-milky,</line>
      <line>He turns so soft and silky,</line>
      <line>He’d make a water-spaniel for King Knut.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This sea was Lazarus, all day</line>
      <line>At Dives’ gate he lay,</line>
      <line>And lapped the crumbs.</line>
      <line>Night comes; 10</line>
      <line>The beggar dies—</line>
      <line>Forthwith the Channel, coast to coast,</line>
      <line>Is Abraham’s bosom; and the beggar lies</line>
      <line>A lovely ghost.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1878</date>
    <title>I Bended unto Me</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I bended unto me a bough of May,</line>
      <line>That I might see and smell:</line>
      <line>It bore it in a sort of way,</line>
      <line>It bore it very well.</line>
      <line>But, when I let it backward sway,</line>
      <line>Then it were hard to tell</line>
      <line>With what a toss, with what a swing,</line>
      <line>The dainty thing</line>
      <line>Resumed its proper level,</line>
      <line>And sent me to the devil.</line>
      <line>I know it did—you doubt it?</line>
      <line>I turned, and saw them whispering about it.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1879</date>
    <title>from Roman Women</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Englishwoman on the Pincian,</line>
      <line>I love you not, nor ever can—</line>
      <line>Astounding woman on the Pincian!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I know your mechanism well-adjusted,</line>
      <line>I see your mind and body have been trusted</line>
      <line>To all the proper people:</line>
      <line>I see you straight as is a steeple;</line>
      <line>I see you are not old;</line>
      <line>I see you are a rich man’s daughter;</line>
      <line>I see you know the use of gold,</line>
      <line>But also know the use of soap-and-water;</line>
      <line>And yet I love you not, nor ever can—</line>
      <line>Distinguished woman on the Pincian!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You have no doubt of your preeminence,</line>
      <line>Nor do I make pretence</line>
      <line>To challenge it for my poor little slattern,</line>
      <line>Whose costume dates from Saturn—</line>
      <line>My wall-flower with the long, love-draggled fringes</line>
      <line>But then the controversy hinges</line>
      <line>On higher forms; and you must bear</line>
      <line>Comparisons more noble. Stare, yes, stare—</line>
      <line>I love you not, nor ever can,</line>
      <line>You peerless woman on the Pincian.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No, you’ll not see her on the Pincian,</line>
      <line>My Roman woman, wife of Roman man!</line>
      <line>Elsewhere you may—</line>
      <line>And she is bright as is the day;</line>
      <line>And she is sweet, that honest workman’s wife</line>
      <line>Fulfilled with bounteous life:</line>
      <line>Her body balanced like a spring</line>
      <line>In equipoise of perfect natural grace;</line>
      <line>Her soul unquestioning</line>
      <line>Of ought but genial cares; her face,</line>
      <line>Her frock, her attitude, her pace</line>
      <line>The confluence of absolute harmonies—</line>
      <line>And you, my Lady Margaret,</line>
      <line>Pray what have you to set</line>
      <line>’Gainst splendours such as these?</line>
      <line>No, I don’t love you, and I never can,</line>
      <line>Pretentious woman on the Pincian!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But morals—beautiful serenity</line>
      <line>Of social life, the sugar and the tea,</line>
      <line>The flannels and the soup, the coals,</line>
      <line>The patent recipes for saving souls,</line>
      <line>And other things: the chill dead sneer</line>
      <line>Conventional, the abject fear</line>
      <line>Of form-transgressing freedom—I admit</line>
      <line>That you have these; but love you not a whit</line>
      <line>The more, nor ever can,</line>
      <line>Alarming female on the Pincian!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come out, O woman, from this blindness!</line>
      <line>Rome, too, has women full of loving-kindness,</line>
      <line>Has noble women, perfect in all good</line>
      <line>That makes the glory of great womanhood—</line>
      <line>But they are Women! I have seen them bent</line>
      <line>On gracious errand; seen how goodness lent</line>
      <line>The grave, ineffable charm</line>
      <line>That guards from possibility of harm</line>
      <line>A creature so divinely made,</line>
      <line>So softly swayed</line>
      <line>With native gesture free—</line>
      <line>The melting-point of passionate purity.</line>
      <line>Yes—soup and flannels too,</line>
      <line>And tickets for them—just like you—</line>
      <line>Tracts, books, and all the innumerable channels</line>
      <line>Through which your bounty acts—</line>
      <line>Well—not the tracts,</line>
      <line>But certainly the flannels—</line>
      <line>Her I must love, but you I never can,</line>
      <line>Unlovely woman on the Pincian.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And yet—</line>
      <line>Remarkable woman on the Pincian!—</line>
      <line>We owe a sort of debt</line>
      <line>To you, as having gone with us of old</line>
      <line>To those bleak islands, cold</line>
      <line>And desolate and grim,</line>
      <line>Upon the Ocean’s rim,</line>
      <line>And shared their horrors with us—not that then</line>
      <line>Our poor bewildered ken</line>
      <line>Could catch the further issues, knowing only</line>
      <line>That we were very lonely!</line>
      <line>Ah well, you did us service in your station;</line>
      <line>And how the progress of our civilisation</line>
      <line>Has made you quite so terrible</line>
      <line>It boots not ask; for still</line>
      <line>You gave us stalwart scions,</line>
      <line>Suckled the young sea-lions,</line>
      <line>And smiled infrequent, glacial smiles</line>
      <line>Upon the sulky isles—</line>
      <line>For this and all His mercies—stay at home!</line>
      <line>Here are the passion-flowers!</line>
      <line>Here are the sunny hours!</line>
      <line>O Pincian woman, do not come to Rome!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>A Sermon at Clevedon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go on! Go on!</line>
      <line>Don’t wait for me!</line>
      <line>Isaac was Abraham’s son—</line>
      <line>Yes, certainly—</line>
      <line>And as they clomb Moriah—</line>
      <line>I know! I know!</line>
      <line>A type of the Messiah—</line>
      <line>Just so! just so!</line>
      <line>Perfectly right; and then the ram</line>
      <line>Caught in the—listening? Why of course I am!</line>
      <line>Wherefore, my brethren, that was counted—yes—</line>
      <line>To Abraham for righteousness—</line>
      <line>Exactly, so I said—</line>
      <line>At least—but go a-head!</line>
      <line>Now mark</line>
      <line>The conduct of the Patriarch—</line>
      <line>‘Behold the wood!’</line>
      <line>Isaac exclaimed—By Jove, an Oxford hood!</line>
      <line>'Bui where’—</line>
      <line>What long straight hair!</line>
      <line>1 Where is the lamb?’</line>
      <line>You mean—the ram:</line>
      <line>No, no! I beg your pardon!</line>
      <line>There’s the Churchwarden,</line>
      <line>In the Clerk’s pew—</line>
      <line>Stick tipped with blue—</line>
      <line>Now Justification—</line>
      <line>‘By Faith?’ I fancy; Aye, the old equation;</line>
      <line>Go it, Justice! Go it, Mercy!</line>
      <line>Go it, Douglas! Go it, Percy!</line>
      <line>I back the winner,</line>
      <line>And have a vague conception of the sinner—</line>
      <line>Limbs nude,</line>
      <line>Horatian attitude,</line>
      <line>Nursing his foot in Sublapsarian mood—</line>
      <line>More power</line>
      <line>To you my friend! you’re good for half-an-hour.</line>
      <line>Dry bones! dry bones!</line>
      <line>But in my ear the long-drawn west wind moans,</line>
      <line>Sweet voices seem to murmur from the wave;</line>
      <line>And I can sit, and look upon the stones</line>
      <line>That cover Hallam’s grave.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>T.E. Brown</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>Dartmoor: Sunset at Chagford</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is it ironical, a fool enigma,</line>
      <line>This sunset show?</line>
      <line>The purple stigma,</line>
      <line>Black mountain cut upon a saffron glow—</line>
      <line>Is it a mammoth joke,</line>
      <line>A riddle put for me to guess,</line>
      <line>Which having duly honoured, I may smoke,</line>
      <line>And go to bed,</line>
      <line>And snore,</line>
      <line>Having a soothing consciousness</line>
      <line>Of something red?</line>
      <line>Or is it more?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah, is it, is it more?</line>
      <line>A dole, perhaps?</line>
      <line>The scraps</line>
      <line>Tossed from the table of the revelling gods?—</line>
      <line>What odds!</line>
      <line>I taste them—Lazarus</line>
      <line>Was nourished thus!</line>
      <line>But, all the same, it surely is a cheat—</line>
      <line>Is this the stuff they eat?</line>
      <line>A cheat! a cheat!</line>
      <line>Then let the garbage be—</line>
      <line>Some pig-wash! let it vanish down the sink</line>
      <line>Of night! ’tis not for me.</line>
      <line>I will not drink</line>
      <line>Their draff,</line>
      <line>While, throned on high, they quaff</line>
      <line>The fragrant sconce—</line>
      <line>Has Heaven no cloaca for the nonce?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Say ’tis an anodyne—</line>
      <line>It never shall be mine.</line>
      <line>I want no opiates—</line>
      <line>The best of all their cates</line>
      <line>Were gross to balk the meanest sense;</line>
      <line>I want to be co-equal with their fates;</line>
      <line>I will not be put off with temporal pretence:</line>
      <line>I want to be awake, and know, not stand</line>
      <line>And stare at waving of a conjuror’s hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But is it speech</line>
      <line>Wherewith they strive to reach</line>
      <line>Our poor inadequate souls?</line>
      <line>The round earth rolls;</line>
      <line>I cannot hear it hum—</line>
      <line>The stars are dumb—</line>
      <line>The voices of the world are in my ear</line>
      <line>A sensuous murmur. Nothing speaks</line>
      <line>But man, my fellow—him I hear,</line>
      <line>And understand; but beasts and birds</line>
      <line>And winds and waves are destitute of words.</line>
      <line>What is the alphabet</line>
      <line>The gods have set?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What babbling! what delusion!</line>
      <line>And in these sunset tints</line>
      <line>What gay confusion!</line>
      <line>Man prints</line>
      <line>His meaning, has a letter</line>
      <line>Determinate. I know that it is better</line>
      <line>Than all this cumbrous hieroglyph—</line>
      <line>The For, the If</line>
      <line>Are growth of man’s analysis:</line>
      <line>The gods in bliss</line>
      <line>Scrabble a baby-jargon on the skies</line>
      <line>For us to analyse!</line>
      <line>Cumbrous? nay, idiotic—</line>
      <line>A party-coloured symbolism,</line>
      <line>The fragments of a shivered prism:</line>
      <line>Man gives the swift demotic.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis good to see</line>
      <line>The economy</line>
      <line>Of poor upstriving man!</line>
      <line>Since time began,</line>
      <line>He has been sifting</line>
      <line>The elements; while God, on chaos drifting,</line>
      <line>Sows broadcast all His stuff.</line>
      <line>Lavish enough,</line>
      <line>No doubt; but why this waste?</line>
      <line>See! of these very sunset dyes</line>
      <line>The virgin chaste</line>
      <line>Takes one, and in a harlot’s eyes</line>
      <line>Another rots. They go by billion billions:</line>
      <line>Each blade of grass</line>
      <line>Ignores them as they pass;</line>
      <line>The spiders in their foul pavilions,</line>
      <line>Behold this vulgar gear,</line>
      <line>And sneer;</line>
      <line>Dull frogs</line>
      <line>In bogs</line>
      <line>Catch rosy gleams through rushes,</line>
      <line>And know that night is near;</line>
      <line>Wrong-headed thrushes</line>
      <line>Blow bugles to it;</line>
      <line>And a wrong-headed poet</line>
      <line>Will strut, and strain the cogs</line>
      <line>Of the machine, he blushes</line>
      <line>To call his Muse, and maunder;</line>
      <line>And, marvellous to relate!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>These pseudo-messengers of state</line>
      <line>Will wander</line>
      <line>Where there is no intelligence to meet them,</line>
      <line>Nor even a sensorium to greet them.</line>
      <line>The very finest of them</line>
      <line>Go where there’s nought to love them</line>
      <line>Or notice them: to cairns, to rocks</line>
      <line>Where ravens nurse their young,</line>
      <line>To mica-splints from granite-boulders wrung</line>
      <line>By channels of the marsh, to stocks</line>
      <line>Of old dead willows in a pool as dead.</line>
      <line>Can anything be said</line>
      <line>To these? The leech</line>
      <line>Looks from its muddy lair,</line>
      <line>And sees a silly something in the air—</line>
      <line>Call you this speech?</line>
      <line>O God, if it be speech,</line>
      <line>Speak plainer,</line>
      <line>If Thou would’st teach</line>
      <line>That I shall be a gainer!</line>
      <line>The age of picture-alphabets is gone:</line>
      <line>We are not now so weak;</line>
      <line>We are too old to con</line>
      <line>The horn-book of our youth. Time lags—</line>
      <line>O, rip this obsolete blazon into rags!</line>
      <line>And speak! O, speak!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But, if I be a spectacle</line>
      <line>In Thy great theatre, then do Thy will:</line>
      <line>Arrange Thy instruments with circumspection;</line>
      <line>Summon Thine angels to the vivisection!</line>
      <line>But quick! O, quick!</line>
      <line>For I am sick,</line>
      <line>And very sad.</line>
      <line>Thy pupils will be glad.</line>
      <line>‘See,’ Thou exclaim’st, ‘this ray!</line>
      <line>How permanent upon the retina!</line>
      <line>How odd that purple hue!</line>
      <line>The pineal gland is blue.</line>
      <line>I stick this probe</line>
      <line>In the posterior lobe—</line>
      <line>Behold the cerebellum</line>
      <line>A smoky yellow, like old vellum!</line>
      <line>Students will please observe</line>
      <line>The structure of the optic nerve.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>See! nothing could be finer—</line>
      <line>That film of pink</line>
      <line>Around the hippocampus minor.</line>
      <line>Behold!</line>
      <line>I touch it, and it turns bright gold.</line>
      <line>Again!—as black as ink.</line>
      <line>Another lancet—thanks!</line>
      <line>That’s Manx—</line>
      <line>Yes, the delicate pale sea-green</line>
      <line>Passing into ultra-marine—</line>
      <line>A little blurred—in fact</line>
      <line>This brain seems packed</line>
      <line>With sunsets. Bring</line>
      <line>That battery here; now put your</line>
      <line>Negative pole beneath the suture—</line>
      <line>That’s just the thing.</line>
      <line>Now then the other way—</line>
      <line>I say! I say!</line>
      <line>More chloroform!</line>
      <line>(A little more will do no harm)</line>
      <line>Now this is the most instructive of all</line>
      <line>The phenomena, what in fact we may call</line>
      <line>The most obvious justification</line>
      <line>Of vivisection in general.</line>
      <line>Observe (once! twice!</line>
      <line>That’s very nice)—</line>
      <line>Observe, I say, the incipient relation</line>
      <line>Of a quasi-moral activity</line>
      <line>To this physical agitation!</line>
      <line>Of course, you see....’</line>
      <line>Yes, yes, O God,</line>
      <line>I feel the prod</line>
      <line>Of that dissecting knife.</line>
      <line>Instructive, say the pupil angels, very:</line>
      <line>And some take notes, and some take sandwiches and sherry;</line>
      <line>And some are prying</line>
      <line>Into the very substance of my brain—</line>
      <line>I feel their fingers!</line>
      <line>(My life! my life!)</line>
      <line>Yes, yes! it lingers!</line>
      <line>The sun, the sun—</line>
      <line>Go on! go on!</line>
      <line>Blue, yellow, red!</line>
      <line>But please remember that I am not dead,</line>
      <line>Nor even dying.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Macdonald</author>
    <date>1871</date>
    <title>Winter Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They were parted then at last?</line>
      <line>Was it duty, or force, or fate?</line>
      <line>Or did a worldly blast</line>
      <line>Blow-to the meeting-gate?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An old, short story is this!</line>
      <line>A glance, a trembling, a sigh,</line>
      <line>A gaze in the eyes, a kiss—</line>
      <line>Why will it not go by!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Macdonald</author>
    <date>1871</date>
    <title>Professor Noctutus</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nobody knows the world but me.</line>
      <line>The rest go to bed; I sit up and see.</line>
      <line>I’m a better observer than any of you all,</line>
      <line>For I never look out till the twilight fall,</line>
      <line>And never then without green glasses,</line>
      <line>And that is how my wisdom passes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never think, for that is not fit:</line>
      <line>I observe. I have seen the white moon sit</line>
      <line>On her nest, the sea, like a fluffy owl,</line>
      <line>Hatching the boats and the long-legged fowl!</line>
      <line>When the oysters gape—you may make a note-</line>
      <line>She drops a pearl into every throat.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I can see the wind: can you do that?</line>
      <line>I see the dreams he has in his hat,</line>
      <line>I see him shaking them out as he goes,</line>
      <line>I see them rush in at man’s snoring nose.</line>
      <line>Ten thousand things you could not think,</line>
      <line>I can write down plain with pen and ink!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You know that I know; therefore pull off your hat,</line>
      <line>Whether round and tall, or square and flat:</line>
      <line>You cannot do better than trust in me;</line>
      <line>You may shut your eyes in fact—/ see!</line>
      <line>Lifelong I will lead you, and then, like the owl,</line>
      <line>I will bury you nicely with my spade and showl.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Macdonald</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>The Shortest and Sweetest of Songs</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Come</line>
      <line>Home.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George Macdonald</author>
    <date><1893/date>
    <title>No End of No-Story</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There is a river</line>
      <line>whose waters run asleep</line>
      <line>run run ever</line>
      <line>singing in the shallows</line>
      <line>dumb in the hollows</line>
      <line>sleeping so deep</line>
      <line>and all the swallows</line>
      <line>that dip their feathers</line>
      <line>in the hollows</line>
      <line>or in the shallows</line>
      <line>are the merriest swallows</line>
      <line>and the nests they make</line>
      <line>with the clay they cake</line>
      <line>with the water they shake</line>
      <line>from their wings that rake</line>
      <line>the water out of the shallows</line>
      <line>or out of the hollows</line>
      <line>will hold together</line>
      <line>in any weather</line>
      <line>and the swallows</line>
      <line>are the merriest fellows</line>
      <line>and have the merriest children</line>
      <line>and are built very narrow</line>
      <line>like the head of an arrow</line>
      <line>to cut the air</line>
      <line>and go just where</line>
      <line>the nicest water is flowing</line>
      <line>and the nicest dust is blowing</line>
      <line>and each so narrow</line>
      <line>like the head of an arrow</line>
      <line>is a wonderful barrow</line>
      <line>to carry the mud he makes</line>
      <line>for his children’s sakes</line>
      <line>from the wet water flowing</line>
      <line>and the dry dust blowing</line>
      <line>to build his nest</line>
      <line>for her he loves best</line>
      <line>and the wind cakes it</line>
      <line>the sun bakes it</line>
      <line>into a nest</line>
      <line>for the rest</line>
      <line>of her he loves best</line>
      <line>and all their merry children</line>
      <line>each little fellow</line>
      <line>with a beak as yellow</line>
      <line>as the buttercups growing</line>
      <line>beside the flowing</line>
      <line>of the singing river</line>
      <line>always and ever</line>
      <line>growing and blowing</line>
      <line>as fast as the sheep</line>
      <line>awake or asleep</line>
      <line>crop them and crop</line>
      <line>and cannot stop</line>
      <line>their yellowness blowing</line>
      <line>nor yet the growing</line>
      <line>of the obstinate daisies</line>
      <line>the little white praises</line>
      <line>they grow and they blow</line>
      <line>they spread out their crown</line>
      <line>and they praise the sun</line>
      <line>and when he goes down</line>
      <line>their praising is done</line>
      <line>they fold up their crown</line>
      <line>and sleep every one</line>
      <line>till over the plain</line>
      <line>he is shining amain</line>
      <line>and they’re at it again</line>
      <line>praising and praising</line>
      <line>such low songs raising</line>
      <line>that no one can hear them</line>
      <line>but the sun so near them</line>
      <line>and the sheep that bite them</line>
      <line>but do not fright them</line>
      <line>are the quietest sheep</line>
      <line>awake or asleep</line>
      <line>with the merriest bleat</line>
      <line>and the little lambs</line>
      <line>are the merriest lambs</line>
      <line>forgetting to eat</line>
      <line>for the frolic in their feet</line>
      <line>and the lambs and their dams</line>
      <line>are the whitest sheep</line>
      <line>with the woolliest wool</line>
      <line>for the swallow to pull</line>
      <line>when he makes his nest</line>
      <line>for her he loves best</line>
      <line>and they shine like snow</line>
      <line>in the grasses that grow</line>
      <line>by the singing river</line>
      <line>that sings for ever</line>
      <line>and the sheep and the lambs</line>
      <line>are merry for ever</line>
      <line>because the river</line>
      <line>sings and they drink it</line>
      <line>and the lambs and their dams</line>
      <line>would any one think it</line>
      <line>are bright and white</line>
      <line>because of their diet</line>
      <line>which gladdens them quiet</line>
      <line>for what they bite</line>
      <line>is buttercups yellow</line>
      <line>and daisies white</line>
      <line>and grass as green</line>
      <line>as the river can make it</line>
      <line>with wind as mellow</line>
      <line>to kiss it and shake it</line>
      <line>as never was known</line>
      <line>but here in the hollows</line>
      <line>beside the river</line>
      <line>where all the swallows</line>
      <line>are the merriest fellows</line>
      <line>and the nests they make</line>
      <line>with the clay they cake</line>
      <line>in the sunshine bake</line>
      <line>till they are like bone</line>
      <line>and as dry in the wind</line>
      <line>as a marble stone</line>
      <line>dried in the wind</line>
      <line>the sweetest wind</line>
      <line>that blows by the river</line>
      <line>flowing for ever</line>
      <line>and who shall find</line>
      <line>whence comes the wind</line>
      <line>that blows on the hollows</line>
      <line>and over the shallows</line>
      <line>where dip the swallows</line>
      <line>and comes and goes</line>
      <line>and the sweet life blows</line>
      <line>into the river</line>
      <line>that sings as it flows</line>
      <line>and the sweet life blows</line>
      <line>into the sheep</line>
      <line>awake or asleep</line>
      <line>with the woolliest wool</line>
      <line>and the trailingest tails</line>
      <line>and never fails</line>
      <line>gentle and cool</line>
      <line>to wave the wool</line>
      <line>and to toss the grass</line>
      <line>as the lambs and the sheep</line>
      <line>over it pass</line>
      <line>and tug and bite</line>
      <line>with their teeth so white</line>
      <line>and then with the sweep</line>
      <line>of their trailing tails</line>
      <line>smooth it again</line>
      <line>and it grows amain</line>
      <line>and amain it grows</line>
      <line>and the wind that blows</line>
      <line>tosses the swallows</line>
      <line>over the hollows</line>
      <line>and over the shallows</line>
      <line>and blows the sweet life</line>
      <line>and the joy so rife</line>
      <line>into the swallows</line>
      <line>that skim the shallows</line>
      <line>and have the yellowest children</line>
      <line>and the wind that blows</line>
      <line>is the life of the river</line>
      <line>that flows for ever</line>
      <line>and washes the grasses</line>
      <line>still as it passes</line>
      <line>and feeds the daisies</line>
      <line>the little white praises</line>
      <line>and buttercups sunny</line>
      <line>with butter and honey</line>
      <line>that whiten the sheep</line>
      <line>awake or asleep</line>
      <line>that nibble and bite</line>
      <line>and grow whiter than white</line>
      <line>and merry and quiet</line>
      <line>on such good diet</line>
      <line>watered by the river</line>
      <line>and tossed for ever</line>
      <line>by the wind that tosses</line>
      <line>the wool and the grasses</line>
      <line>and the swallow that crosses</line>
      <line>with all the swallows</line>
      <line>over the shallows</line>
      <line>dipping their wings</line>
      <line>to gather the water</line>
      <line>and bake the cake</line>
      <line>for the wind to make</line>
      <line>as hard as a bone</line>
      <line>and as dry as a stone</line>
      <line>and who shall find</line>
      <line>whence comes the wind</line>
      <line>that blows from behind</line>
      <line>and ripples the river j</line>
      <line>that flows for ever</line>
      <line>and still as it passes</line>
      <line>waves the grasses</line>
      <line>and cools the daisies</line>
      <line>the white sun-praises</line>
      <line>that feed the sheep</line>
      <line>awake or asleep</line>
      <line>and give them their wool</line>
      <line>for the swallows to pull</line>
      <line>a little away</line>
      <line>to mix with the clay</line>
      <line>that cakes to a nest</line>
      <line>for those they love best</line>
      <line>and all the yellow children</line>
      <line>soon to go trying</line>
      <line>their wings at the flying</line>
      <line>over the hollows</line>
      <line>and over the shallows</line>
      <line>with all the swallows</line>
      <line>that do not know</line>
      <line>whence the wind doth blow</line>
      <line>that comes from behind</line>
      <line>a blowing wind</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Frederick Locker-Lampson</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>A Terrible Infant</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I RECOLLECT a nurse call’d Ann</line>
      <line>Who carried me about the grass,</line>
      <line>And one fine day a fine young man</line>
      <line>Came up, and kiss’d the pretty lass.</line>
      <line>She did not make the least objection!</line>
      <line>Thinks I, 'Aha!</line>
      <line>When I can talk I'll tell Mamma.'</line>
      <line>—And that’s my earliest recollection.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Edward Dowden</author>
    <date>1872</date>
    <title>Burdens</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Are sorrows hard to bear,—the ruin</line>
      <line>Of flowers, the rotting of red fruit,</line>
      <line>A love’s decease, a life’s undoing,</line>
      <line>And summer slain, and song-birds mute,</line>
      <line>And skies of snow and bitter air?</line>
      <line>These things, you deem, are hard to bear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But ah the burden, the delight</line>
      <line>Of dreadful joys! Noon opening wide,</line>
      <line>Golden and great; the gulfs of night,</line>
      <line>Fair deaths, and rent veils cast aside,</line>
      <line>Strong soul to strong soul rendered up,</line>
      <line>And silence filling like a cup.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1879</date>
    <title>In Autumn when the woods are red</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And skies are grey and clear,</line>
      <line>The sportsmen seek the wild fowls’ bed</line>
      <line>Or follow down the deer;</line>
      <line>And Cupid hunts by haugh and head,</line>
      <line>By riverside and mere,</line>
      <line>I walk, not seeing where I tread</line>
      <line>And keep my heart with fear,</line>
      <line>Sir, have an eye, on where you tread,</line>
      <line>And keep your heart with fear,</line>
      <line>For something lingers here;</line>
      <line>A touch of April not yet dead,</line>
      <line>In Autumn when the woods are red</line>
      <line>And skies are grey and clear.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1875</date>
    <title>I SAW red evening through the rain,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I saw red evening through the rain,</line>
      <line>Lower above the steaming plain;</line>
      <line>I heard the hour strike small and still,</line>
      <line>From the black belfry on the hill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thought is driven out of doors to-night</line>
      <line>By bitter memory of delight;</line>
      <line>The sharp constraint of finger tips,</line>
      <line>Or the shuddering touch of lips.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I heard the hour strike small and still,</line>
      <line>From the black belfry on the hill.</line>
      <line>Behind me I could still look down</line>
      <line>On the outspread monstrous town.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sharp constraint of finger tips</line>
      <line>Or the shuddering touch of lips,</line>
      <line>And all old memories of delight</line>
      <line>Crowd upon my soul to-night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Behind me I could still look down</line>
      <line>On the outspread feverish town;</line>
      <line>But before me still and grey</line>
      <line>And lonely was the forward way.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1875</date>
    <title>Browning</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Browning makes the verses:</line>
      <line>Your servant the critique.</line>
      <line>Browning wouldn’t sing at all:</line>
      <line>I fancy I could speak.</line>
      <line>Although the book was clever</line>
      <line>(To give the Deil his due)</line>
      <line>I wasn’t pleased with Browning</line>
      <line>Nor he with my review.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1879</date>
    <title>Last night we had a thunderstorm in style.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The wild lightning streaked the airs,</line>
      <line>As though my God fell down a pair of stairs.</line>
      <line>The thunder boomed and bounded all the while;</line>
      <line>All cried and sat by water-side and stile—</line>
      <line>To mop our brow had been our chief of cares.</line>
      <line>I lay in bed with a Voltairean smile,</line>
      <line>The terror of good, simple guilty pairs,</line>
      <line>And made this rondeau in ironic style,</line>
      <line>Last night we had a thunderstorm in style.</line>
      <line>Our God the Father fell down-stairs,</line>
      <line>The stark blue lightning went its flight, the while,</line>
      <line>The very rain you might have heard a mile—</line>
      <line>The strenuous faithful buckled to their prayers.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>Requiem</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Under the wide and starry sky,</line>
      <line>Dig the grave and let me lie.</line>
      <line>Glad did I live and gladly die,</line>
      <line>And I laid me down with a will.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This be the verse you grave for me:</line>
      <line>Here he lies where he longed to be;</line>
      <line>Home is the sailor, home from sea,</line>
      <line>And the hunter home from the hill.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1881</date>
    <title>Pirate Ditty</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fifteen men on the Dead Man’s Chest—</line>
      <line>Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!</line>
      <line>Drink and the devil had done for the rest—</line>
      <line>Yo-ho-ho, and a bottle of rum!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>A Mile an ’ a Bittock</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A mile an’ a bittock, a mile or twa,</line>
      <line>Abiine the burn, ayont the law,</line>
      <line>Davie an’ Donal’ an’ Cherlie an’ a’,</line>
      <line>An’ the mime was shinin’ clearly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ane went hame wi’ the ither, an’ then</line>
      <line>The ither went hame wi’ the ither twa men,</line>
      <line>An’ baith wad return him the service again,</line>
      <line>An’ the mime was shinin’ clearly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The clocks were chappin’ in house an’ ha’,</line>
      <line>Eleeven, twal an’ ane an’ twa;</line>
      <line>An’ the guidman’s face was turnt to the wa’,</line>
      <line>An’ the mime was shinin’ clearly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A wind got up frae affa the sea,</line>
      <line>It blew the stars as dear’s could be,</line>
      <line>It blew in the een of a’ o’ the three,</line>
      <line>An’ the mime was shinin’ clearly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Noo, Davie was first to get sleep in his head,</line>
      <line>‘The best o’ frien’s maun twine,’ he said;</line>
      <line>‘I’m weariet, an’ here I’m awa’ to my bed.’</line>
      <line>An’ the mime was shinin’ clearly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Twa o’ them walkin’ an’ crackin’ their lane,</line>
      <line>The mornin’ licht cam gray an’ plain,</line>
      <line>An’ the birds they yammert on stick an’ stane,</line>
      <line>An’ the mime was shinin’ clearly!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O years ayont, O years awa’,</line>
      <line>My lads, ye’ll mind whate’er befa’—</line>
      <line>My lads, ye’ll mind on the bield o’ the law,</line>
      <line>When the miine was shinin’ clearly.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>Fragment</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou strainest through the mountain fern,</line>
      <line>A most exiguously thin</line>
      <line>Burn.</line>
      <line>For all thy foam, for all thy din,</line>
      <line>Thee shall the pallid lake inurn,</line>
      <line>With well-a-day for Mr Swin-</line>
      <line>Burne!</line>
      <line>Take then this quarto in thy fin</line>
      <line>And, O thou stoker huge and stern,</line>
      <line>The whole affair, outside and in,</line>
      <line>Burn!</line>
      <line>But save the true poetic kin,</line>
      <line>The works of Mr Robert Burn!</line>
      <line>And William Wordsworth upon Tin-</line>
      <line>Tern!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1885</date>
    <title>So live, so love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>So live, so love, so use that fragile hour,</line>
      <line>That when the dark hand of the shining power</line>
      <line>Shall one from other, wife or husband, take,</line>
      <line>The poor survivor may not weep and wake.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>To Mrs Will H. Low</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Even in the bluest noonday of July,</line>
      <line>There could not run the smallest breath of wind</line>
      <line>But all the quarter sounded like a wood;</line>
      <line>And in the chequered silence and above</line>
      <line>The hum of city cabs that sought the Bois,</line>
      <line>Suburban ashes shivered into song.</line>
      <line>A patter and a chatter and a chirp</line>
      <line>And a long dying hiss—it was as though</line>
      <line>Starched old brocaded dames through all the house</line>
      <line>Had trailed a strident skirt, or the whole sky</line>
      <line>Even in a wink had over-brimmed in rain.</line>
      <line>Hark, in these shady parlours, how it talks</line>
      <line>Of the near Autumn, how the smitten ash</line>
      <line>Trembles and augurs floods! O not too long</line>
      <line>In these inconstant latitudes delay,</line>
      <line>O not too late from the unbeloved north</line>
      <line>Trim your escape! For soon shall this low roof</line>
      <line>Resound indeed with rain, soon shall your eyes</line>
      <line>Search the foul garden, search the darkened rooms,</line>
      <line>Nor find one jewel but the blazing log.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1887</date>
    <title>My house, I say.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>MY house, I say. But hark to the sunny doves</line>
      <line>That make my roof the arena of their loves,</line>
      <line>That gyre about the gable all day long</line>
      <line>And fill the chimneys with their murmurous song:</line>
      <line>Our house, they say; and mine, the cat declares</line>
      <line>And spreads his golden fleece upon the chairs;</line>
      <line>And mine the dog, and rises stiff with wrath</line>
      <line>If any alien foot profane the path.</line>
      <line>So too the buck that trimmed my terraces,</line>
      <line>Our whilome gardener, called the garden his;</line>
      <line>Who now, deposed, surveys my plain abode</line>
      <line>And his late kingdom, only from the road.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1887</date>
    <title>It’s an owercome sooth for age an’ youth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It's an overcome sooth for age an' youth</line>
      <line>And it brooks wi’ nae denial,</line>
      <line>That the dearest friends are the auldest friends</line>
      <line>And the young are just on trial.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s a rival bauld wi’ young an’ auld</line>
      <line>And it’s him that has bereft me;</line>
      <line>For the surest friends are the auldest friends</line>
      <line>And the maist o’ mines hae left me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There are kind hearts still, for friends to fill</line>
      <line>And fools to take and break them;</line>
      <line>But the nearest friends are the auldest friends</line>
      <line>And the grave’s the place to seek them.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>Fair Isle</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair Isle at Sea—thy lovely name</line>
      <line>Soft in my ear like music came.</line>
      <line>That sea I loved, and once or twice</line>
      <line>I touched at isles of Paradise.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1894</date>
    <title>As with heaped bees</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As with heaped bees at hiving time</line>
      <line>The boughs are clotted, as (ere prime)</line>
      <line>Heaven swarms with stars, or the city street</line>
      <line>Pullulates with faring feet;</line>
      <line>So swarmed my senses once; that now</line>
      <line>Repose behind my tranquil brow,</line>
      <line>Unsealed, asleep, quiescent, clear;</line>
      <line>Now only the vast shapes I hear</line>
      <line>Hear—and my hearing slowly fills—</line>
      <line>Rivers and winds among the twisting hills,</line>
      <line>And hearken—and my face is lit—</line>
      <line>Life facing; death pursuing it.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The morning drum-call</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The morning drum-call on my eager ear</line>
      <line>Thrills unforgotten yet; the morning dew</line>
      <line>Lies yet undried along my field of noon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But now I pause at whiles in what I do,</line>
      <line>And count the bell, and tremble lest I hear</line>
      <line>(My work untrimmed) the sunset gun too soon.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Louis Stevenson</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>I have trod</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have trod the upward and the downward slope;</line>
      <line>I have endured and done in days before;</line>
      <line>I have longed for all, and bid farewell to hope;</line>
      <line>And I have lived and loved, and closed the door.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Ernest Henley</author>
    <date>1873</date>
    <title>Waiting</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A square, squat room (a cellar on promotion),</line>
      <line>Drab to the soul, drab to the very daylight;</line>
      <line>Plasters astray in unnatural-looking tinware;</line>
      <line>Scissors and lint and apothecary’s jars.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here, on a bench a skeleton would writhe from,</line>
      <line>Angry and sore, I wait to be admitted:</line>
      <line>Wait till my heart is lead upon my stomach,</line>
      <line>While at their ease two dressers do their chores.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One has a probe—it feels to me a crowbar.</line>
      <line>A small boy sniffs and shudders after bluestone.</line>
      <line>A poor old tramp explains his poor old ulcers.</line>
      <line>Life is (I think) a blunder and a shame.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Ernest Henley</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>To W. R.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Madam Life’s a piece in bloom</line>
      <line>Death goes dogging everywhere:</line>
      <line>She’s the tenant of the room,</line>
      <line>He’s the ruffian on the stair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You shall see her as a friend,</line>
      <line>You shall bilk him once and twice;</line>
      <line>But he’ll trap you in the end,</line>
      <line>And he’ll stick you for her price.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With his kneebones at your chest,</line>
      <line>And his knuckles in your throat,</line>
      <line>You would reason—plead—protest!</line>
      <line>Clutching at her petticoat;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But she’s heard it all before,</line>
      <line>Well she knows you’ve had your fun,</line>
      <line>Gingerly she gains the door,</line>
      <line>And your little job is done.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Sydney Dobell</author>
    <date>1875</date>
    <title>Perhaps</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ten heads and twenty hearts! so that this me,</line>
      <line>Having more room and verge, and striking less</line>
      <line>The cage that galls us into consciousness,</line>
      <line>Might drown the rings and ripples of to be</line>
      <line>In the smooth deep of being: plenary</line>
      <line>Round hours; great days, as if two days should press</line>
      <line>Together, and their wine-press’d night accresce</line>
      <line>The next night to so dead a parody</line>
      <line>Of death as cures such living: of these ordain</line>
      <line>My years; of those large years grant me not seven,</line>
      <line>Nor seventy, no, nor only seventy sevens!</line>
      <line>And then, perhaps, I might stand well in even</line>
      <line>This rain of things; down-rain, up-rain, side-rain;</line>
      <line>This rain from Earth and Ocean, air and heaven,</line>
      <line>And from the Heaven within the Heaven of Heavens.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Keary</author>
    <date>1874</date>
    <title>Old Age</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such a wizened creature,</line>
      <line>Sitting alone;</line>
      <line>Every kind of ugliness thrown</line>
      <line>Into each feature.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘I wasn’t always so,’</line>
      <line>Said the wizened</line>
      <line>One; ‘sweet motions unimprisoned</line>
      <line>Were mine long ago.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And again, ‘I shall be—</line>
      <line>At least something</line>
      <line>Out of this outside me, shall wing</line>
      <line>Itself fair and free.’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Philip Bourke Marston</author>
    <date>1875</date>
    <title>After</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little time for laughter,</line>
      <line>A little time to sing,</line>
      <line>A little time to kiss and cling,</line>
      <line>And no more kissing after.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little while for scheming</line>
      <line>Love’s unperfected schemes;</line>
      <line>A little time for golden dreams,</line>
      <line>Then no more any dreaming.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little while ’twas given</line>
      <line>To me to have thy love;</line>
      <line>Now, like a ghost, alone I move</line>
      <line>About a ruined heaven.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little time for speaking,</line>
      <line>Things sweet to say and hear;</line>
      <line>A time to seek, and find thee near,</line>
      <line>Then no more any seeking.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A little time for saying</line>
      <line>Words the heart breaks to say;</line>
      <line>A short, sharp time wherein to pray,</line>
      <line>Then no more need for praying;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But long, long years to weep in,</line>
      <line>And comprehend the whole</line>
      <line>Great grief that desolates the soul,</line>
      <line>And eternity to sleep in.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Louisa S. Guggenberger</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>Afternoon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Purple headland over yonder,</line>
      <line>Fleecy, sun-extinguished moon,</line>
      <line>I am here alone, and ponder</line>
      <line>On the theme of Afternoon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Past has made a groove for Present,</line>
      <line>And what fits it is: no more.</line>
      <line>Waves before the wind are weighty;</line>
      <line>Strongest sea-beats shape the shore.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Just what is is just what can be,</line>
      <line>And the Possible is free;</line>
      <line>’Tis by being, not by effort,</line>
      <line>That the firm cliff juts to sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With an uncontentious calmness</line>
      <line>Drifts the Fact before the ‘Law’;</line>
      <line>So we name the ordered sequence</line>
      <line>We, remembering, foresaw.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And a law is mere procession</line>
      <line>Of the forcible and fit;</line>
      <line>Calm of uncontested Being,</line>
      <line>And our thought that comes of it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the mellow shining daylight</line>
      <line>Lies the Afternoon at ease,</line>
      <line>Little willing ripples answer</line>
      <line>To a drift of casual breeze.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Purple headland to the westward!</line>
      <line>Ebbing tide, and fleecy moon!</line>
      <line>In the ‘line of least resistance’,</line>
      <line>Flows the life of Afternoon.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Louisa S. Guggenberger</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>Twilight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Grey the sky, and growing dimmer.</line>
      <line>And the twilight lulls the sea;</line>
      <line>Half in vagueness, half in glimmer,</line>
      <line>Nature shrouds her mystery.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What have all the hours been spent for?</line>
      <line>Why the on and on of things?</line>
      <line>Why eternity’s procession</line>
      <line>Of the days and evenings?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hours of sunshine, hours of gloaming,</line>
      <line>Wing their unexplaining flight,</line>
      <line>With a measured punctuation</line>
      <line>Of unconsciousness, at night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Just at sunset was translucence,</line>
      <line>When the west was all aflame;</line>
      <line>So I asked the sea a question,</line>
      <line>And an answer nearly came.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Is there nothing but Occurrence?</line>
      <line>Though each detail seem an Act,</line>
      <line>Is that whole we deem so pregnant</line>
      <line>But unemphasized Fact?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or, when dusk is in the hollows</line>
      <line>Of the hill-side and the wave,</line>
      <line>Are things just so much in earnest</line>
      <line>That they cannot but be grave?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nay, the lesson of the Twilight</line>
      <line>Is as simple as ’tis deep;</line>
      <line>Acquiescence, acquiescence,</line>
      <line>And the coming on of sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Louisa S. Guggenberger</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>‘Egoisme a Deux ’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the great universe hung nebulous</line>
      <line>Betwixt the unprevented and the need,</line>
      <line>Was it foreseen that you and I should be?—</line>
      <line>Was it decreed?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>While time leaned onward through eternities,</line>
      <line>Unrippled by a breath and undistraught,</line>
      <line>Lay there at leisure Will that we should breathe?—</line>
      <line>Waited a Thought?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the warm swirl of chaos-elements</line>
      <line>Fashioned the chance that woke to sentient strife,</line>
      <line>Did there a Longing seek, and hasten on</line>
      <line>Our mutual life?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That flux of many accidents but now</line>
      <line>That brought you near and linked your hand in mine,—</line>
      <line>That fused our souls in love’s most final faith,—</line>
      <line>Was it divine?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Louisa S. Guggenberger</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>Love and Language</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love that is alone with love</line>
      <line>Makes solitudes of throngs;</line>
      <line>Then why not songs of silences,—</line>
      <line>Sweet silences of songs?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Parts need words: the perfect whole</line>
      <line>Is silent as the dead;</line>
      <line>When I offered you my soul</line>
      <line>Heard you what I said?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Louisa S. Guggenberger</author>
    <date>1882</date>
    <title>Am I to Lose You?</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Am I to lose you now?’ The words were light;</line>
      <line>You spoke them, hardly seeking a reply,</line>
      <line>That day I bid you quiedy ‘Good-bye,’</line>
      <line>And sought to hide my soul away from sight.</line>
      <line>The question echoed, dear, through many a night,—</line>
      <line>My question, not your own—most wistfully;</line>
      <line>‘Am I to lose him?’—asked my heart of me;</line>
      <line>‘Am I to lose him now, and lose him quite?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And only you can tell me. Do you care</line>
      <line>That sometimes we in quietness should stand</line>
      <line>As fellow-solitudes, hand firm in hand,</line>
      <line>And thought with thought and hope with hope compare?</line>
      <line>What is your answer? Mine must ever be,</line>
      <line>‘I greatly need your friendship: leave it me.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>WILLIAM RENTON</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Renton</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Foal</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The mouse-brown foal that fain had fed</line>
      <line>From off the green his mother crops</line>
      <line>So quietly in her own place,</line>
      <line>Craning in vain and bending, stops,</line>
      <line>Intent upon his match with space,</line>
      <line>And rises beaten by half a head.</line>
      <line>And last he sets himself to slide</line>
      <line>His spidery-slender limbs aside,</line>
      <line>If so be now to reach the mead.—</line>
      <line>He must stride</line>
      <line>Ere he can feed.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Renton</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Shadow of Himself</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>At evening the horse comes down unled</line>
      <line>With pace that is but his second best,</line>
      <line>And with harness only about his head:</line>
      <line>He is half undrest,</line>
      <line>And on his way to bed.</line>
      <line>But he takes his share of the space and the light,</line>
      <line>His brown skin glisters warm and good,</line>
      <line>And his shadow stretches as full a height</line>
      <line>As a horse’s should;</line>
      <line>For on the wall</line>
      <line>As he slouches down</line>
      <line>Stalks a phantom, tall as he is tall</line>
      <line>And black as he is brown;</line>
      <line>With the very gait and the very speed</line>
      <line>Of his Highness shown,</line>
      <line>And I fear me a greed</line>
      <line>That matches his own;</line>
      <line>For if his head should stoop to treat</line>
      <line>With the wayside grasses—in a heat</line>
      <line>There stoops his friend’s,</line>
      <line>And their muzzles meet</line>
      <line>On the very tuft for which he contends.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Renton</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>Crescent Moon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moon had risen an hour or more.</line>
      <line>It was the younger moon, but shorn</line>
      <line>Of those first pointing cusps she wore,</line>
      <line>And bluff with blunted horn;</line>
      <line>But poised upright</line>
      <line>And golden bright,</line>
      <line>Save where there hung a middle haze,</line>
      <line>Soft as the golden air that lies</line>
      <line>Upon the sunset’s closing eyes</line>
      <line>And plays</line>
      <line>Between his glory-golden lids—</line>
      <line>And none forbids.</line>
      <line>And none forbade, as it did seem,</line>
      <line>That this lorn haze should doat and dream</line>
      <line>On such an eve of June</line>
      <line>And cling about the middle moon,</line>
      <line>That scarce was dimmer for such offending.</line>
      <line>But none might stay its soft ascending,</line>
      <line>Till each in turn the veiled old</line>
      <line>Was clear as dew,</line>
      <line>And all the new</line>
      <line>Was dusky gold;</line>
      <line>And last, a wraith,</line>
      <line>Exhaling like the breath</line>
      <line>We breathed upon a golden jar,</line>
      <line>Showed on the tip and went afar—</line>
      <line>Upon the disc a moving spot</line>
      <line>That would be, was, and now was not.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Renton</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>After Nightfall</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ample the air above the western peaks;</line>
      <line>Within the peaks a silence uncompelled.</line>
      <line>It is the hour of abnegation’s self,</line>
      <line>In clear obeisance of the mountain thrones,</line>
      <line>And cloudless self-surrender of the skies:</line>
      <line>The very retrospect of skiey calm,</line>
      <line>And selfless self-approval of the hills.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Renton</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>Moon and Candle-light</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beneath our eaves the moonbeams play,</line>
      <line>Where trumps of white convolvulus</line>
      <line>Lean out askance, and have their say</line>
      <line>Half to the moon and half to us.</line>
      <line>The foam-white tassel nestles still,</line>
      <line>Where the taperlight has laid,</line>
      <line>In its corner by the sill,</line>
      <line>A black tassel for a shade.</line>
      <line>It has laid the shadowy clasp</line>
      <line>Of the high-barred baby-chair</line>
      <line>On the milkwhite casement hasp.</line>
      <line>The moon clasps and holds it there</line>
      <line>With a darker, of her own</line>
      <line>Milkwhite standing casement bar:</line>
      <line>Dusky hands, thus all alone,</line>
      <line>Clasped in each as lovers’ are.</line>
      <line>Through the sea of mellow space,</line>
      <line>Where the moon and candle-light,</line>
      <line>Taking tender heart of grace,</line>
      <line>Mingle hands of holy white,</line>
      <line>The moon looks between the bars</line>
      <line>On the bar-flecked baby-seat,</line>
      <line>Thinks—She!—to wile away the scars.</line>
      <line>The taper smiles on her defeat.</line>
      <line>Smiles, too, a steady shadow down</line>
      <line>Between the fore and hinder stays</line>
      <line>Of the moon’s dais: with a frown</line>
      <line>The table greets the carpet grays.</line>
      <line>The moon turns to hide her smile . .</line>
      <line>Creep up the light two spokes of dust,</line>
      <line>Like light-streaks in a dusty aisle,</line>
      <line>Beneath the chair—midway, are thrust</line>
      <line>On the table shade in black.</line>
      <line>The taper shrugs and hums a tune,</line>
      <line>Two black crutches stumble back</line>
      <line>On the wainscot to the moon.</line>
      <line>... So the shadows make a raft</line>
      <line>Of the chamber gear to-night:</line>
      <line>Play cross-purpose fore and aft</line>
      <line>By the moon and candle-light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Renton</author>
    <date>1876</date>
    <title>The Fork of the Road</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>An utter moorland, high, and wide, and flat;</line>
      <line>A beaten roadway, branching out in grave distaste;</line>
      <line>And weather-beaten and defaced,</line>
      <line>Pricking its ears along the solitary waste—</line>
      <line>A signpost; pointing this way, pointing that.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>R. E. Egerton Warburton</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>Past and Present</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>On four-horse coach, whose luggage pierced the sky,</line>
      <line>Perch’d on back seat, like clerk on office-stool,</line>
      <line>While wintry winds my dangling heels kept cool,</line>
      <line>In Whitney white envelop’d and blue tie,</line>
      <line>Unpillow’d slumber from my half-closed eye</line>
      <line>Scared by the shrill tin horn; when welcome Yule</line>
      <line>Brought holiday season, it was thus from school</line>
      <line>I homeward came some forty years gone by.</line>
      <line>Thus two long days and one long night I rode,</line>
      <line>Stage after stage, till the last change of team</line>
      <line>Stopp’d, splash’d and panting, at my sire’s abode.</line>
      <line>How nowaday from school comes home my son?</line>
      <line>Through duct and tunnel by a puff of steam,</line>
      <line>Shot like a pellet from his own pop-gun.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alice Meynell</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>After a Parting</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Farewell has long been said; I have forgone thee;</line>
      <line>I never name thee even.</line>
      <line>But how shall I learn virtues and yet shun thee?</line>
      <line>For thou art so near Heaven</line>
      <line>That Heavenward meditations pause upon thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou dost beset the path to every shrine;</line>
      <line>My trembling thoughts discern</line>
      <line>Thy goodness in the good for which I pine;</line>
      <line>And, if I turn from but one sin, I turn</line>
      <line>Unto a smile of thine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How shall I thrust thee apart</line>
      <line>Since all my growth tends to thee night and day—</line>
      <line>To thee faith, hope, and art?</line>
      <line>Swift are the currents setting all one way;</line>
      <line>They draw my life, my life, out of my heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alice Meynell</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>Cradle-Song at Twilight</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The child not yet is lulled to rest.</line>
      <line>Too young a nurse, the slender Night</line>
      <line>So laxly holds him to her breast</line>
      <line>That throbs with flight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He plays with her, and will not sleep.</line>
      <line>For other playfellows she sighs;</line>
      <line>An unmaternal fondness keep</line>
      <line>Her alien eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alice Meynell</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The Shepherdess</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She walks—the lady of my delight—</line>
      <line>A shepherdess of sheep.</line>
      <line>Her flocks are thoughts. She keeps them white;</line>
      <line>She guards them from the steep;</line>
      <line>She feeds them on the fragrant height,</line>
      <line>And folds them in for sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She roams maternal hills and bright,</line>
      <line>Dark valleys safe and deep.</line>
      <line>Into that tender breast at night</line>
      <line>The chastest stars may peep.</line>
      <line>She walks—the lady of my delight—</line>
      <line>A shepherdess of sheep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She holds her little thoughts in sight,</line>
      <line>Though gay they run and leap.</line>
      <line>She is so circumspect and right;</line>
      <line>She has her soul to keep.</line>
      <line>She walks—the lady of my delight—</line>
      <line>A shepherdess of sheep.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alice Meynell</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>'I Am the Way ’</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art the Way.</line>
      <line>Hadst Thou been nothing but the goal,</line>
      <line>I cannot say</line>
      <line>If Thou hadst ever met my soul.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I cannot see—</line>
      <line>I, child of process—if there lies</line>
      <line>An end for me,</line>
      <line>Full of repose, full of replies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ll not reproach</line>
      <line>The road that winds, my feet that err.</line>
      <line>Access, Approach</line>
      <line>Art Thou, Time, Way, and Wayfarer.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Alice Meynell</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>The Lady Poverty</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Lady Poverty was fair:</line>
      <line>But she has lost her looks of late,</line>
      <line>With change of times and change of air.</line>
      <line>Ah slattern! she neglects her hair,</line>
      <line>Her gown, her shoes; she keeps no state</line>
      <line>As once when her pure feet were bare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or—almost worse, if worse can be—</line>
      <line>She scolds in parlours, dusts and trims,</line>
      <line>Watches and counts. O is this she</line>
      <line>Whom Francis met, whose step w'as free,</line>
      <line>Who with Obedience carolled hymns,</line>
      <line>In Umbria walked with Chastity?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Where is her ladyhood? Not here,</line>
      <line>Not among modern kinds of men;</line>
      <line>But in the stony fields, where clear</line>
      <line>Through the thin trees the skies appear,</line>
      <line>In delicate spare soil and fen,</line>
      <line>And slender landscape and austere.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Henry Bellyse Baildon</author>
    <date>1877</date>
    <title>A Moth</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A clumsy clot of shadow in the fold</line>
      <line>Of the white blind,—a moth asleep or dead,</line>
      <line>And hooked therein with still, tenacious hold,</line>
      <line>And dusky vans outspread.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Laid on my hand a wonder of dull dyes,</line>
      <line>A sombre miracle of mingled grain,</line>
      <line>Grey etched on grey, faint as faint memories,</line>
      <line>Dim stain invading stain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Each wing-edge scalloped clear as any shell’s,</line>
      <line>With rippled repetitions ebbing in</line>
      <line>Rhyme within rhyme, as when cathedral bells</line>
      <line>Remit their joyous din.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Complete is it of broken laceries,</line>
      <line>A pencilled maze of blending greys,</line>
      <line>Mosaic of symmetric traceries,</line>
      <line>Assorted in sweet ways.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Black velvet grainings upon pearly ash,</line>
      <line>An elf-wrought broidery of hues they stole</line>
      <line>From the black moss-blot, and the lichen-splash,</line>
      <line>From birch or beechen bole.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Strange-headed thing, in ruminative rest</line>
      <line>Stirring its flexile antlers dreamily,</line>
      <line>With great ghoul-eyes and sable-feathered breast,</line>
      <line>In sleep’s security.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘There rest thee, and sleep off thy drowsy fit,</line>
      <line>Till night shall triumph in the dusky glades,</line>
      <line>And mass her conquering glooms, then rise and flit</line>
      <line>A shadow through the shades!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George R. Sims</author>
    <date>1879</date>
    <title>A Garden Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I SCORN the doubts and cares that hurt</line>
      <line>The world and all its mockeries,</line>
      <line>My only care is now to squirt</line>
      <line>The ferns among my rockeries.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In early youth and later life</line>
      <line>I’ve seen an up and seen a down,</line>
      <line>And now I have a loving wife</line>
      <line>To help me peg verbena down.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of joys that come to womankind</line>
      <line>The loom of fate doth weave her few,</line>
      <line>But here are summer joys entwined</line>
      <line>And bound with golden feverfew,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’ve learnt the lessons one and all</line>
      <line>With which the world its sermon stocks,</line>
      <line>Now, heedless of a rise or fall,</line>
      <line>I’ve Brompton and I’ve German stocks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In peace and quiet pass our days,</line>
      <line>With nought to vex our craniums,</line>
      <line>Our middle beds are all ablaze</line>
      <line>With red and white geraniums.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And like a boy I laugh when she,</line>
      <line>In Varden hat and Varden hose,</line>
      <line>Comes slyly up the lawn at me</line>
      <line>To squirt me with the garden hose.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Let him who’d have the peace he needs</line>
