      <line>Give all his worldly mumming up,</line>
      <line>Then dig a garden, plant the seeds,</line>
      <line>And watch the product coming up.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>George R. Sims</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>Undertones</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s a feeling that comes with the daze of joy</line>
      <line>And goes with the knights of grief—</line>
      <line>That stands on the top of a baby buoy,</line>
      <line>And floats with an anchor chief.</line>
      <line>It rides on the back of a noted Bill,</line>
      <line>And fights where your collars fray;</line>
      <line>It whispers in accents loud and shrill—</line>
      <line>To-morrow succeeds to-day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We con the lessons of life betimes</line>
      <line>In the leaves of an open glade;</line>
      <line>The frost on the window writes its rimes,</line>
      <line>We live and we learn be trayed.</line>
      <line>The coals we heat and the apes we were</line>
      <line>Are gone where the Russians sleigh.</line>
      <line>The moral is blown on the well-known air—</line>
      <line>To-morrow succeeds to-day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the busde and jam of the daily strife,</line>
      <line>What matters if men preserve</line>
      <line>The bosom of hope from the butcher’s knife,</line>
      <line>And its train from the pointsman curve?</line>
      <line>Remember the fate of the ready maid</line>
      <line>Who went where the preachers prey;</line>
      <line>Take matter for thought from a new decayed—</line>
      <line>To-morrow succeeds to-day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Jean Ingelow</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>The Long White Seam</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I came round the harbour buoy,</line>
      <line>The lights began to gleam,</line>
      <line>No wave the land-locked water stirred,</line>
      <line>The crags were white as cream;</line>
      <line>And I marked my love by candle-light</line>
      <line>Sewing her long white seam.</line>
      <line>It’s aye sewing ashore, my dear,</line>
      <line>Watch and steer at sea,</line>
      <line>It’s reef and furl, and haul the line,</line>
      <line>Set sail and think of thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I climbed to reach her cottage door;</line>
      <line>O sweetly my love sings!</line>
      <line>Like a shaft of light her voice breaks forth,</line>
      <line>My soul to meet it springs</line>
      <line>As the shining water leaped of old,</line>
      <line>When stirred by angel wings.</line>
      <line>Aye longing to list anew,</line>
      <line>Awake and in my dream,</line>
      <line>But never a song she sang like this,</line>
      <line>Sewing her long white seam.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fair fall the lights, the harbour lights,</line>
      <line>That brought me in to thee,</line>
      <line>And peace drop down on that low roof</line>
      <line>For the sight that I did see,</line>
      <line>And the voice, my dear, that rang so clear</line>
      <line>All for the love of me.</line>
      <line>For O, for O, with brows bent low</line>
      <line>By the candle’s flickering gleam,</line>
      <line>Her wedding gown it was she wrought,</line>
      <line>Sewing the long white seam.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Addington Symonds</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>The Camera Obscura</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Inside the skull the wakeful brain,</line>
      <line>Attuned at birth to joy and pain,</line>
      <line>Dwells for a lifetime; even as one</line>
      <line>Who in a closed tower sees the sun</line>
      <line>Cast faint-hued shadows, dim or clear,</line>
      <line>Upon the darkened disc: now near,</line>
      <line>Now far, they flit; while he, within,</line>
      <line>Surveys the world he may not win:</line>
      <line>Whate’er he sees, he notes; for nought</line>
      <line>Escapes the net of living thought;</line>
      <line>And what he notes, he tells again</line>
      <line>To last and build the brains of men.</line>
      <line>Shades are we; and of shades we weave</line>
      <line>A trifling pleasant make-believe;</line>
      <line>Then pass into the shadowy night,</line>
      <line>Where formless shades blindfold the light.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Bridges</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>London Snow</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When men were all asleep the snow came flying,</line>
      <line>In large white flakes falling on the city brown,</line>
      <line>Stealthily and perpetually settling and loosely lying,</line>
      <line>Hushing the latest traffic of the drowsy town;</line>
      <line>Deadening, muffling, stifling its murmurs failing;</line>
      <line>Lazily and incessantly floating down and down:</line>
      <line>Silently sifting and veiling road, roof and railing;</line>
      <line>Hiding difference, making unevenness even,</line>
      <line>Into angles and crevices softly drifting and sailing.</line>
      <line>All night it fell, and when full inches seven</line>
      <line>It lay in the depth of its uncompacted lightness,</line>
      <line>The clouds blew off from a high and frosty heaven;</line>
      <line>And all woke earlier for the unaccustomed brightness</line>
      <line>Of the winter dawning, the strange unheavenly glare:</line>
      <line>The eye marvelled—marvelled at the dazzling whiteness;</line>
      <line>The ear hearkened to the stillness of the solemn air;</line>
      <line>No sound of wheel rumbling nor of foot falling,</line>
      <line>And the busy morning cries came thin and spare.</line>
      <line>Then boys I heard, as they went to school, calling,</line>
      <line>They gathered up the crystal manna to freeze</line>
      <line>Their tongues with tasting, their hands with snowballing;</line>
      <line>Or rioted in a drift, plunging up to the knees;</line>
      <line>Or peering up from under the white-mossed wonder,</line>
      <line>‘O look at the trees!’ they cried, ‘O look at the trees!’</line>
      <line>With lessened load a few carts creak and blunder,</line>
      <line>Following along the white deserted way,</line>
      <line>A country company long dispersed asunder:</line>
      <line>When now already the sun, in pale display</line>
      <line>Standing by Paul’s high dome, spread forth below</line>
      <line>His sparkling beams, and awoke the stir of the day.</line>
      <line>For now doors open, and war is waged with the snow;</line>
      <line>And trains of sombre men, past tale of number,</line>
      <line>Tread long brown paths, as toward their toil they go:</line>
      <line>But even for them awhile no cares encumber</line>
      <line>Their minds diverted; the daily word is unspoken,</line>
      <line>The daily thoughts of labour and sorrow slumber</line>
      <line>At the sight of the beauty that greets them, for the charm they have broken.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Bridges</author>
    <date>1880</date>
    <title>On a Dead Child</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Perfect little body, without fault or stain on thee,</line>
      <line>With promise of strength and manhood full and fair!</line>
      <line>Though cold and stark and bare,</line>
      <line>The bloom and the charm of life doth awhile remain on thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy mother’s treasure wert thou;—alas! no longer</line>
      <line>To visit her heart with wondrous joy; to be</line>
      <line>Thy father’s pride;—ah, he</line>
      <line>Must gather his faith together, and his strength make stronger.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To me, as I move thee now in the last duty,</line>
      <line>Dost thou with a turn or gesture anon respond;</line>
      <line>Startling my fancy fond</line>
      <line>With a chance attitude of the head, a freak of beauty.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy hand clasps, as ’twas wont, my finger, and holds it:</line>
      <line>But the grasp is the clasp of Death, heartbreaking and stiff;</line>
      <line>Yet feels to my hand as if</line>
      <line>’Twas still thy will, thy pleasure and trust that enfolds it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So I lay thee there, thy sunken eyelids closing,—</line>
      <line>Go lie thou there in thy coffin, thy last little bed!—</line>
      <line>Propping thy wise, sad head,</line>
      <line>Thy firm, pale hands across thy chest disposing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So quiet! doth the change content thee?—Death, whither hath he taken thee?</line>
      <line>To a world, do I think, that rights the disaster of this?</line>
      <line>The vision of which I miss,</line>
      <line>Who weep for the body, and wish but to warm thee and awaken thee?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah! little at best can all our hopes avail us</line>
      <line>To lift this sorrow, or cheer us, when in the dark,</line>
      <line>Unwilling, alone we embark,</line>
      <line>And the things we have seen and have known and have heard of, fail us.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Robert Bridges</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>The evening darkens over.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The evening darkens over.</line>
      <line>After a day so bright</line>
      <line>The windcapt waves discover</line>
      <line>That wild will be the night.</line>
      <line>There’s sound of distant thunder.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The latest sea-birds hover</line>
      <line>Along the cliffs sheer height;</line>
      <line>As in the memory wander</line>
      <line>Last flutterings of delight,</line>
      <line>White wings lost on the white.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s not a ship in sight;</line>
      <line>And as the sun goes under</line>
      <line>Thick clouds conspire to cover</line>
      <line>The moon that should rise yonder.</line>
      <line>Thou art alone, fond lover.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Joseph Skipsey</author>
    <date>1881</date>
    <title>‘Get Up!'</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Get up!’ the caller calls, ‘Get up!’</line>
      <line>And in the dead of night,</line>
      <line>To win the bairns their bite and sup,</line>
      <line>I rise a weary wight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My flannel dudden donn’d, thrice o’er</line>
      <line>My birds are kiss’d, and then</line>
      <line>I with a whistle shut the door,</line>
      <line>I may not ope again.</line>
      <line>(1881)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Joseph Skipsey</author>
    <date>1892</date>
    <title>Not as Wont</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘We’ll meet no more as wont!’ she said;</line>
      <line>And moons went by of keen regret,</line>
      <line>Before once more beneath the shade</line>
      <line>We met, where we so oft had met.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till then in Life’s grim strife I’d kept</line>
      <line>A heart unquelled, an eye unwet;</line>
      <line>But now like any child I wept—</line>
      <line>We’d met, but not as wont we’d met.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Watson</author>
    <date>1881</date>
    <title>An Epitaph</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>His friends he loved. His direst earthly foes—</line>
      <line>Cats—I believe he did but feign to hate.</line>
      <line>My hand will miss the insinuated nose,</line>
      <line>Mine eyes the tail that wagg’d contempt at Fate.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Frederick Stevenson</author>
    <date>1883</date>
    <title>Life and Impellance</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There went most passionately to Life, Impellance,</line>
      <line>And thrilled it with the high perception of divines;</line>
      <line>And through a blight of gloom its request fought for</line>
      <line>Heaven, its hospice, light, investure ante-natal,</line>
      <line>And hope, impact of fathom, lucid suavity.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Frederick Stevenson</author>
    <date>1883</date>
    <title>A Planet of Descendance</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A planet of descendance rent,</line>
      <line>A scatter of an effluence;</line>
      <line>Before the princes of content,</line>
      <line>Angels of deliverance.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>See, methought, the silent hills,</line>
      <line>And the valleys, and the sea;</line>
      <line>There is propent death of skills,</line>
      <line>And invalid’s puissancy.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Eugene Lee-Hamilton</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>Sunken Gold</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In dim green depths rot ingot-laden ships;</line>
      <line>And gold doubloons, that from the drowned hand fell,</line>
      <line>Lie nesded in the ocean-flower’s bell</line>
      <line>With love’s old gifts, once kissed by long-drowned lips.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And round some wrought gold cup the sea-grass whips,</line>
      <line>And hides lost pearls, near pearls still in their shell,</line>
      <line>Where sea-weed forests fill each ocean dell</line>
      <line>And seek dim twilight with their restless tips.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So lie the wasted gifts, the long-lost hopes,</line>
      <line>Beneath the now hushed surface of myself,</line>
      <line>In lonelier depths than where the diver gropes;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They lie deep, deep; but I at times behold</line>
      <line>In doubtful glimpses, on some reefy shelf,</line>
      <line>The gleam of irrecoverable gold.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Eugene Lee-Hamilton</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>Idle Charon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shores of Styx are lone for evermore,</line>
      <line>And not one shadowy form upon the steep</line>
      <line>Looms through the dusk, as far as eyes can sweep,</line>
      <line>To call the ferry over as of yore;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But tintless rushes, all about the shore,</line>
      <line>Have hemmed the old boat in, where, locked in sleep,</line>
      <line>Hoar-bearded Charon lies; while pale weeds creep</line>
      <line>With tightening grasp all round the unused oar.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For in the world of Life strange rumours run</line>
      <line>That now the Soul departs not with the breath,</line>
      <line>But that the Body and the Soul are one;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And in the loved one’s mouth, now, after death,</line>
      <line>The widow puts no obol, nor the son,</line>
      <line>To pay the ferry in the world beneath.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Eugene Lee-Hamilton</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>Noon’s Dream-Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The day is long; the worn Noon dreams.</line>
      <line>He shifts in vain, to ease his pain,</line>
      <line>And through what seems, he hears a song:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A forest song, whose high note seems</line>
      <line>To tell of pain, endured in vain,</line>
      <line>And fills his dreams with things lost long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A dead love seems to thrill that song;</line>
      <line>Hope nursed in vain, years passed in pain,</line>
      <line>Leaves fallen long, a tide that dreams.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then, as he dreams, the shades grow long;</line>
      <line>And, in his pain, he moans in vain,</line>
      <line>While fades the song of what but seems.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Eugene Lee-Hamilton</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>Among the Firs</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>And what a charm is in the rich hot scent</line>
      <line>Of old fir forests heated by the sun,</line>
      <line>Where drops of resin down the rough bark run,</line>
      <line>And needle litter breathes its wonderment.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The old fir forests heated by the sun,</line>
      <line>Their thought shall linger like the lingering scent,</line>
      <line>Their beauty haunt us, and a wonderment</line>
      <line>Of moss, of fern, of cones, of rills that run.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The needle litter breathes a wonderment;</line>
      <line>The crimson crans are sparkling in the sun;</line>
      <line>From tree to tree the scampering squirrels run;</line>
      <line>The hum of insects blends with heat and scent.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The drops of resin down the rough bark run;</line>
      <line>And riper, ever riper, grows the scent;</line>
      <line>But eve has come, to end the wonderment,</line>
      <line>And slowly up the tree trunk climbs the sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Amy Levy</author>
    <date>1884</date>
    <title>Epitaph</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>This is the end of him, here he lies:</line>
      <line>The dust in his throat, the worm in his eyes,</line>
      <line>The mould in his mouth, the turf on his breast;</line>
      <line>This is the end of him, this is best.</line>
      <line>He will never lie on his couch awake,</line>
      <line>Wide-eyed, tearless, till dim daybreak.</line>
      <line>Never again will he smile and smile</line>
      <line>When his heart is breaking all the while.</line>
      <line>He will never stretch out his hands in vain</line>
      <line>Groping and groping—never again.</line>
      <line>Never ask for bread, get a stone instead,</line>
      <line>Never pretend that the stone is bread.</line>
      <line>Never sway and sway ’twixt the false and true,</line>
      <line>Weighing and noting the long hours through.</line>
      <line>Never ache and ache with the chok’d-up sighs;</line>
      <line>This is the end of him, here he lies.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Amy Levy</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>On the Threshold</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>O god, my dream! I dreamed that you were dead;</line>
      <line>Your mother hung above the couch and wept</line>
      <line>Whereon you lay all white, and garlanded</line>
      <line>With blooms of waxen whiteness. I had crept</line>
      <line>Up to your chamber-door, which stood ajar,</line>
      <line>And in the doorway watched you from afar,</line>
      <line>Nor dared advance to kiss your lips and brow.</line>
      <line>I had no part nor lot in you, as now;</line>
      <line>Death had not broken between us the old bar;</line>
      <line>Nor torn from out my heart the old, cold sense</line>
      <line>Of your misprision and my impotence.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A. Mary F. Robinson</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>Auhade Triste</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The last pale rank of poplar-trees</line>
      <line>Begins to glimmer into light,</line>
      <line>With stems and branches faintly white</line>
      <line>Against a heaven one dimly sees</line>
      <line>Beyond the failing night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A point of grey that grows to green</line>
      <line>Fleck’d o’er with rainy yellow bars,—</line>
      <line>A sudden whitening of the stars,</line>
      <line>A pallor where the moon has been,</line>
      <line>A peace the morning mars;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When, lo! a shiver of the breeze</line>
      <line>And all the ruffled birds awake,</line>
      <line>The rustling aspens stir and shake;</line>
      <line>For, pale, beyond the pallid trees,</line>
      <line>The dawn begins to break.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now the air turns cool and wan,</line>
      <line>A drizzling rain begins to fall,</line>
      <line>The sky clouds over with a pall—</line>
      <line>The night, that was for me, is gone;</line>
      <line>The day has come for all.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A. Mary F. Robinson</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>Pallor</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The great white lilies in the grass</line>
      <line>Are pallid as the smile of death;</line>
      <line>For they remember still—alas!—</line>
      <line>The graves they sprang from underneath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The angels up in heaven are pale—</line>
      <line>For all have died, when all is said;</line>
      <line>Nor shall the lutes of Eden avail</line>
      <line>To let them dream they are not dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A. Mary F. Robinson</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>Neurasthenia</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watch the happier people of the house</line>
      <line>Come in and out, and talk, and go their ways;</line>
      <line>I sit and gaze at them; I cannot rouse</line>
      <line>My heavy mind to share their busy days.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watch them glide, like skaters on a stream,</line>
      <line>Across the brilliant surface of the world.</line>
      <line>But I am underneath: they do not dream</line>
      <line>How deep below the eddying flood is whirl’d.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They cannot come to me, nor I to them;</line>
      <line>But, if a mightier arm could reach and save,</line>
      <line>Should I forget the tide I had to stem?</line>
      <line>Should I, like these, ignore the abysmal wave?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yes! in the radixant air how could I know</line>
      <line>How black it is, how fast it is, below?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A. Mary F. Robinson</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>An Orchard at Avignon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The hills are white, but not with snow:</line>
      <line>They are as pale in summer time,</line>
      <line>For herb or grass may never grow</line>
      <line>Upon their slopes of lime.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within the circle of the hills</line>
      <line>A ring, all flowering in a round,</line>
      <line>An orchard-ring of almond fills</line>
      <line>The plot of stony ground.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>More fair than happier trees, I think,</line>
      <line>Grown in well-watered pasture land</line>
      <line>These parched and stunted branches, pink</line>
      <line>Above the stones and sand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O white, austere, ideal place,</line>
      <line>Where very few will care to come,</line>
      <line>Where spring hath lost the waving grace</line>
      <line>She wears for us at home!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Fain would I sit and watch for hours</line>
      <line>The holy whiteness of thy hills,</line>
      <line>Their wreath of pale auroral flowers,</line>
      <line>Their peace the silence fills.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A place of secret peace thou art,</line>
      <line>Such peace as in an hour of pain</line>
      <line>One moment fills the amazed heart,</line>
      <line>And never comes again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Nesbit</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, baby, baby, baby dear,</line>
      <line>We lie alone together here;</line>
      <line>The snowy gown and cap and sheet</line>
      <line>With lavender are fresh and sweet;</line>
      <line>Through half-closed blinds the roses peer</line>
      <line>To see and love you, baby dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We are so tired, we like to lie</line>
      <line>Just doing nothing, you and I,</line>
      <line>Within the darkened quiet room.</line>
      <line>The sun sends dusk rays through the gloom,</line>
      <line>Which is no gloom since you are here,</line>
      <line>My little life, my baby dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Soft sleepy mouth so vaguely pressed</line>
      <line>Against your new-made mother’s breast.</line>
      <line>Soft little hands in mine I fold,</line>
      <line>Soft little feet I kiss and hold,</line>
      <line>Round soft smooth head and tiny ear,</line>
      <line>All mine, my own, my baby dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And he we love is far away!</line>
      <line>But he will come some happy day,</line>
      <line>You need but me, and I can rest</line>
      <line>At peace with you beside me pressed.</line>
      <line>There are no questions, longings vain,</line>
      <line>No murmuring, nor doubt, nor pain,</line>
      <line>Only content and we are here,</line>
      <line>My baby dear.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Nesbit</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>Among His Books</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A silent room—gray with a dusty blight</line>
      <line>Of loneliness;</line>
      <line>A room with not enough of life or light</line>
      <line>Its form to dress.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Books enough though! The groaning sofa bears</line>
      <line>A goodly store—</line>
      <line>Books on the window-seat, and on the chairs,</line>
      <line>And on the floor.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Books of all sorts of soul, all sorts of age,</line>
      <line>All sorts of face—</line>
      <line>Black-letter, vellum, and the flimsy page</line>
      <line>Of commonplace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All bindings, from the cloth whose hue distracts</line>
      <line>One’s weary nerves,</line>
      <line>To yellow parchment, binding rare old tracts</line>
      <line>It serves—deserves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Books on the shelves, and in the cupboard books,</line>
      <line>Worthless and rare—</line>
      <line>Books on the mantelpiece—where’er one looks</line>
      <line>Books everywhere!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Books! books! the only things in life I find</line>
      <line>Not wholly vain.</line>
      <line>Books in my hands—books in my heart enshrined—</line>
      <line>Books in my brain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My friends are they: for children and for wife</line>
      <line>They serve me too;</line>
      <line>For these alone, of all dear things in life,</line>
      <line>Have I found true.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They do not flatter, change, deny, deceive—</line>
      <line>Ah no—not they!</line>
      <line>The same editions which one night you leave</line>
      <line>You find next day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You don’t find railway novels where you left</line>
      <line>Your Elzevirs!</line>
      <line>Your Aldines don’t betray you—leave bereft</line>
      <line>Your lonely years!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And yet this common book of Common Prayer</line>
      <line>My heart prefers,</line>
      <line>Because the names upon the fly-leaf there</line>
      <line>Are mine and hers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It’s a dead flower that makes it open so—</line>
      <line>Forget-me-not—</line>
      <line>The Marriage Service ... well, my dear, you know</line>
      <line>Who first forgot.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Those were the days when in the choir we two</line>
      <line>Sat—used to sing—</line>
      <line>When I believed in God, in love, in you—</line>
      <line>In everything.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Through quiet lanes to church we used to come,</line>
      <line>Happy and good,</line>
      <line>Clasp hands through sermon, and go slowly home</line>
      <line>Down through the wood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Kisses? A certain yellow rose no doubt</line>
      <line>That porch still shows,</line>
      <line>Whenever I hear kisses talked about</line>
      <line>I smell that rose!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No—I don’t blame you—since you only proved</line>
      <line>My choice unwise,</line>
      <line>And taught me books should trusted be and loved,</line>
      <line>Not lips and eyes!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And so I keep your book—your flower—to show</line>
      <line>How much I care</line>
      <line>For the dear memory of what, you know,</line>
      <line>You never were.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Nesbit</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The Gray Folk</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The house, with blind unhappy face,</line>
      <line>Stands lonely in the last year’s corn,</line>
      <line>And in the grayness of the morn</line>
      <line>The gray folk come about the place.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>By many pathways, gliding gray</line>
      <line>They come past meadow, wood, and wold,</line>
      <line>Come by the farm and by the fold</line>
      <line>From the green fields of yesterday.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Past lock and chain and bolt and bar</line>
      <line>They press, to stand about my bed,</line>
      <line>And like the faces of the dead</line>
      <line>I know their hidden faces are.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They will not leave me in the day</line>
      <line>And when night falls they will not go,</line>
      <line>Because I silenced, long ago,</line>
      <line>The only voice that they obey.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Nesbit</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>Love's Guerdons</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dearest, if I almost cease to weep for you,</line>
      <line>Do not doubt I love you just the same;</line>
      <line>’Tis because my life has grown to keep for you</line>
      <line>All the hours that sorrow does not claim.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All the hours when I may steal away to you,</line>
      <line>Where you lie alone through the long day,</line>
      <line>Lean my face against your turf and say to you</line>
      <line>All that there is no one else to say.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do they let you listen—do you lean to me?</line>
      <line>Know now what in life you never knew,</line>
      <line>When I whisper all that you have been to me,</line>
      <line>All that I might never be to you?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear, lie still. No tears but mine are shed for you,</line>
      <line>No one else leaves kisses day by day,</line>
      <line>No one’s heart but mine has beat and bled for you,</line>
      <line>No one else’s flowers push mine away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No one else remembers—do not call to her,</line>
      <line>Not alone she treads the churchyard grass;</line>
      <line>You are nothing now who once were all to her,</line>
      <line>Do not call her—let the strangers pass!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Nesbit</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The Claim</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh! I admit I’m dull and poor,</line>
      <line>And plain and gloomy, as you tell me;</line>
      <line>And dozens flock around your door</line>
      <line>Who in all points but one excel me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You smile on them, on me you frown,</line>
      <line>They worship for the wage you pay;</line>
      <line>I lay life, love, and honour down</line>
      <line>For you to walk on every day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am the only one who sees</line>
      <line>That though such gifts can never move you,</line>
      <line>A meagre price are gifts like these</line>
      <line>For life’s high privilege—to love you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I am the one among your train</line>
      <line>Who sees that loving you is worth</line>
      <line>A thousand times the certain gain</line>
      <line>Of all the heaped-up joys of earth.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And you, who know as well as I,</line>
      <line>What your glass tells you every morning—</line>
      <line>A kindred soul you should descry,</line>
      <line>Dilute with sympathy your scorning.</line>
      <line>At least you should approve the intense</line>
      <line>Love that gives all for you to waste;</line>
      <line>Your other lovers have more sense,</line>
      <line>Admit that I have better taste.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>E. Nesbit</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>Villeggiature</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My window, framed in pear-tree bloom,</line>
      <line>White-curtained shone, and softly lighted:</line>
      <line>So, by the pear-tree, to my room</line>
      <line>Your ghost last night climbed uninvited.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your solid self, long leagues away,</line>
      <line>Deep in dull books, had hardly missed me;</line>
      <line>And yet you found this Romeo’s way,</line>
      <line>And through the blossom climbed and kissed me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watched the still and dewy lawn,</line>
      <line>The pear-tree boughs hung white above you;</line>
      <line>I listened to you till the dawn,</line>
      <line>And half forgot I did not love you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, dear! what pretty things you said,</line>
      <line>What pearls of song you threaded for me!</line>
      <line>I did not—till your ghost had fled—</line>
      <line>Remember how you always bore me!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Rudyard Kipling</author>
    <date>1886</date>
    <title>The Story of Uriah</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jack Barrett went to Quetta</line>
      <line>Because they told him to.</line>
      <line>He left his wife at Simla</line>
      <line>On three-fourths his monthly screw.</line>
      <line>Jack Barrett died at Quetta</line>
      <line>Ere the next month’s pay he drew.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jack Barrett went to Quetta.</line>
      <line>He didn’t understand</line>
      <line>The reason of his transfer</line>
      <line>From the pleasant mountain-land.</line>
      <line>The season was September,</line>
      <line>And it killed him out of hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jack Barrett went to Quetta</line>
      <line>And there gave up the ghost,</line>
      <line>Attempting two men’s duty</line>
      <line>In that very healthy post;</line>
      <line>And Mrs Barrett mourned for him</line>
      <line>Five lively months at most.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Jack Barrett’s bones at Quetta</line>
      <line>Enjoy profound repose;</line>
      <line>But I shouldn’t be astonished</line>
      <line>If now his spirit knows</line>
      <line>The reason of his transfer</line>
      <line>From the Himalayan snows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, when the Last Great Bugle Call</line>
      <line>Adown the Hurnai throbs,</line>
      <line>And the last grim joke is entered</line>
      <line>In the big black Book of Jobs,</line>
      <line>And Quetta graveyards give again</line>
      <line>Their victims to the air,</line>
      <line>I shouldn’t like to be the man</line>
      <line>Who sent Jack Barrett there.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Rudyard Kipling</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>Danny Deever</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What are the bugles blowin’ for?’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>‘To turn you out, to turn you out,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>‘What makes you look so white, so white?’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>‘Pm dreadin’ what I’ve got to watch,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>For they’re hangin’ Danny Deever, you can hear the Dead March play,</line>
      <line>The regiment’s in ’ollow square—they’re hangin’ him to-day;</line>
      <line>They’ve taken of his buttons off an’ cut his stripes away,</line>
      <line>An’ they’re hangin’ Danny Deever in the mornin’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What makes the rear-rank breathe so ’ard?’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>‘It’s bitter cold, it’s bitter cold,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>‘What makes that front-rank man fall down?’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>‘A touch o’ sun, a touch 0’ sun,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>They are hangin’ Danny Deever, they are marchin’ of ’im round,</line>
      <line>They ’ave ’alted Danny Deever by ’is coffin on the ground;</line>
      <line>An’ ’e’ll swing in ’arf a minute for a sneakin’ shootin’ hound—</line>
      <line>O they’re hangin’ Danny Deever in the mornin’!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘’Is cot was right-’and cot to mine,’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>”E’s sleepin’ out an’ far to-night,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>‘I’ve drunk ’is beer a score o’ times,’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>°E’s drinkin’ bitter beer alone,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>They are hangin’ Danny Deever, you must mark ’im to ’is place,</line>
      <line>For ’e shot a comrade sleepin’—you must look ’im in the face;</line>
      <line>Nine ’undred of ’is county an’ the Regiment’s disgrace,</line>
      <line>While they’re hangin’ Danny Deever in the mornin’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘What’s that so black agin the sun?’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>‘It’s Danny fightin’ ’ard for life,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>‘What’s that that whimpers over’ead?’ said Files-on-Parade.</line>
      <line>‘It’s Danny’s soul that’s passin’ now,’ the Colour-Sergeant said.</line>
      <line>For they’re done with Danny Deever, you can ’ear the quickstep play,</line>
      <line>The regiment’s in column, an’ they’re marchin’ us away;</line>
      <line>Ho! the young recruits are shakin’, an’ they’ll want their beer to-day,</line>
      <line>After hangin’ Danny Deever in the mornin’!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Rudyard Kipling</author>
    <date>1892</date>
    <title>Gentlemen-Rankers</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>T o the legion of the lost ones, to the cohort of the damned,</line>
      <line>To my brethren in their sorrow overseas,</line>
      <line>Sings a gentleman of England cleanly bred, machinely crammed,</line>
      <line>And a trooper of the Empress, if you please.</line>
      <line>Yes, a trooper of the forces who has run his own six horses,</line>
      <line>And faith he went the pace and went it blind,</line>
      <line>And the world was more than kin while he held the ready tin,</line>
      <line>But to-day the Sergeant’s something less than kind.</line>
      <line>We’re poor little lambs who’ve lost our way,</line>
      <line>Baa! Baa! Baa!</line>
      <line>We’re little black sheep who’ve gone astray,</line>
      <line>Baa—aa—aa!</line>
      <line>Gendemen-rankers out on the spree,</line>
      <line>Damned from here to Eternity,</line>
      <line>God ha’ mercy on such as we,</line>
      <line>Baa! Yah! Bah!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, it’s sweet to sweat through stables, sweet to empty kitchen slops,</line>
      <line>And it’s sweet to hear the tales the troopers tell,</line>
      <line>To dance with blowzy housemaids at the regimental hops</line>
      <line>And thrash the cad who says you waltz too well.</line>
      <line>Yes, it makes you cock-a-hoop to be ‘Rider’ to your troop,</line>
      <line>And branded with a blasted worsted spur,</line>
      <line>When you envy, O how keenly, one poor Tommy living cleanly</line>
      <line>Who blacks your boots and sometimes calls you ‘Sir’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If the home we never write to, and the oaths we never keep,</line>
      <line>And all we know most distant and most dear,</line>
      <line>Across the snoring barrack-room return to break our sleep,</line>
      <line>Can you blame us if we soak ourselves in beer?</line>
      <line>When the drunken comrade mutters and the great guard-lantern gutters</line>
      <line>And the horror of our fall is written plain,</line>
      <line>Every secret, self-revealing on the aching whitewashed ceiling,</line>
      <line>Do you wonder that we drug ourselves from pain?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We have done with Hope and Honour, we are lost to Love and Truth,</line>
      <line>We are dropping down the ladder rung by rung,</line>
      <line>And the measure of our torment is the measure of our youth.</line>
      <line>God help us, for we knew the worst too young!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Our shame is clean repentance for the crime that brought the sentence,</line>
      <line>Our pride it is to know no spur of pride,</line>
      <line>And the Curse of Reuben holds us till an alien turf enfolds us</line>
      <line>And we die, and none can tell Them where we died.</line>
      <line>We’re poor little lambs who’ve lost our way,</line>
      <line>Baa! Baa! Baa!</line>
      <line>We’re little black sheep who’ve gone astray,</line>
      <line>Baa—aa—aa!</line>
      <line>Gentlemen-rankers out on the spree,</line>
      <line>Damned from here to Eternity,</line>
      <line>God ha’ mercy on such as we,</line>
      <line>Baa! Yah! Bah!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Rudyard Kipling</author>
    <date>1892</date>
    <title>In the Neolithic Age</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the Neolithic Age savage warfare did I wage</line>
      <line>For food and fame and woolly horses’ pelt.</line>
      <line>I was singer to my clan in that dim, red Dawn of Man,</line>
      <line>And I sang of all we fought and feared and felt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yea, I sang as now I sing, when the Prehistoric spring</line>
      <line>Made the piled Biscayan ice-pack split and shove;</line>
      <line>And the troll and gnome and dwerg, and the Gods of Cliff and Berg</line>
      <line>Were about me and beneath me and above.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But a rival of Solutre, told the tribe my style was outre—</line>
      <line>’Neath a tomahawk, of diorite, he fell.</line>
      <line>And I left my views on Art, barbed and tanged, below the heart</line>
      <line>Of a mammothistic etcher at Grenelle.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then I stripped them, scalp from skull, and my hunting-dogs fed full,</line>
      <line>And their teeth I threaded neatly on a thong;</line>
      <line>And I wiped my mouth and said, ‘It is well that they are dead,</line>
      <line>‘For I know my work is right and theirs was wrong’.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But my Totem saw the shame; from his ridgepole-shrine he came,</line>
      <line>And he told me in a vision of the night:—</line>
      <line>‘There are nine and sixty ways of constructing tribal lays,</line>
      <line>‘And every single one of them is right!’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then the silence closed upon me till They put new clothing on me</line>
      <line>Of whiter, weaker flesh and bone more frail;</line>
      <line>And I stepped beneath Time’s finger, once again a tribal singer,</line>
      <line>And a minor poet certified by Traill!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still they skirmish to and fro, men my messmates on the snow,</line>
      <line>When we headed off the aurochs turn for turn;</line>
      <line>When the rich Allobrogenses never kept amanuenses,</line>
      <line>And our only plots were piled in lakes at Berne.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still a cultured Christian age sees us scuffle, squeak, and rage,</line>
      <line>Still we pinch and slap and jabber, scratch and dirk;</line>
      <line>Still we let our business slide—as we dropped the half-dressed hide—</line>
      <line>To show a fellow-savage how to work.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still the world is wondrous large,—seven seas from marge to marge—</line>
      <line>And it holds a vast of various kinds of man;</line>
      <line>And the wildest dreams of Kew are the facts of Khatmandhu,</line>
      <line>And the crimes of Clapham chaste in Martaban.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here’s my wisdom for your use, as I learned it when the moose</line>
      <line>And the reindeer roared where Paris roars to-night:—</line>
      <line>‘There are nine and sixty ways of constructing tribal lays,</line>
      <line>And—every—single—one—of—them—is—right!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Rudyard Kipling</author>
    <date>1897</date>
    <title>The Vampire</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fool there was and he made his prayer</line>
      <line>(Even as you and I!)</line>
      <line>To a rag and a bone and a hank of hair</line>
      <line>(We called her the woman who did not care)</line>
      <line>But the fool he called her his lady fair—</line>
      <line>(Even as you and I!)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, the years we waste and the tears we waste</line>
      <line>And the work of our head and hand</line>
      <line>Belong to the woman who did not know</line>
      <line>(And now we know that she never could know)</line>
      <line>And did not understand!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A fool there was and his goods he spent</line>
      <line>(Even as you and I!)</line>
      <line>Honour and faith and a sure intent</line>
      <line>(And it wasn’t the least what the lady meant)</line>
      <line>But a fool must follow his natural bent</line>
      <line>(Even as you and I!)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, the toil we lost and the spoil we lost</line>
      <line>And the excellent things we planned</line>
      <line>Belong to the woman who didn’t know why</line>
      <line>(And now we know that she never knew why)</line>
      <line>And did not understand!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The fool was stripped to his foolish hide</line>
      <line>(Even as you and I!)</line>
      <line>Which she might have seen when she threw him aside—</line>
      <line>(But it isn’t on record the lady tried)</line>
      <line>So some of him lived but the most of him died—</line>
      <line>(Even as you and I!)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And it isn't the shame and it isn’t the blame</line>
      <line>That stings like a white hot brand— 30</line>
      <line>It's coming to know that she never knew why</line>
      <line>(Seeing, at last, she could never know why)</line>
      <line>And never could understand!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Rudyard Kipling</author>
    <date>1897</date>
    <title>Recessional</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>God of our fathers, known of old,</line>
      <line>Lord of our far-flung battle-line,</line>
      <line>Beneath whose awful Hand we hold</line>
      <line>Dominion over palm and pine—</line>
      <line>Lord God of Hosts, be with us yet,</line>
      <line>Lest we forget—lest we forget!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The tumult and the shouting dies;</line>
      <line>The Captains and the Kings depart:</line>
      <line>Still stands Thine ancient sacrifice,</line>
      <line>An humble and a contrite heart.</line>
      <line>Lord God of Hosts, be with us yet,</line>
      <line>Lest we forget—lest we forget!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Far-called, our navies melt away;</line>
      <line>On dune and headland sinks the fire:</line>
      <line>Lo, all our pomp of yesterday</line>
      <line>Is one with Nineveh and Tyre!</line>
      <line>Judge of the Nations, spare us yet,</line>
      <line>Lest we forget—lest we forget!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If, drunk with sight of power, we loose</line>
      <line>Wild tongues that have not Thee in awe,</line>
      <line>Such boastings as the Gentiles use,</line>
      <line>Or lesser breeds without the Law—</line>
      <line>Lord God of Hosts, be with us yet,</line>
      <line>Lest we forget—lest we forget!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For heathen heart that puts her trust</line>
      <line>In reeking tube and iron shard,</line>
      <line>All valiant dust that builds on dust,</line>
      <line>And guarding, calls not Thee to guard,</line>
      <line>For frantic boast and foolish word—</line>
      <line>Thy mercy on Thy People, Lord!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Canton</author>
    <date>1887</date>
    <title>Day-Dreams</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Broad August burns in milky skies,</line>
      <line>The world is blanched with hazy heat;</line>
      <line>The vast green pasture, even, lies</line>
      <line>Too hot and bright for eyes and feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Amid the grassy levels rears</line>
      <line>The sycamore against the sun</line>
      <line>The dark boughs of a hundred years,</line>
      <line>The emerald foliage of one.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lulled in a dream of shade and sheen,</line>
      <line>Within the clement twilight thrown</line>
      <line>By that great cloud of floating green,</line>
      <line>A horse is standing, still as stone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stirs nor head nor hoof, although</line>
      <line>The grass is fresh beneath the branch;</line>
      <line>His tail alone swings to and fro</line>
      <line>In graceful curves from haunch to haunch.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He stands quite lost, indifferent</line>
      <line>To rack or pasture, trace or rein;</line>
      <line>He feels the vaguely sweet content</line>
      <line>Of perfect sloth in limb and brain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Oscar Wilde</author>
    <date>1887</date>
    <title>Les Ballons</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Against these turbid turquoise skies</line>
      <line>The light and luminous balloons</line>
      <line>Dip and drift like satin moons,</line>
      <line>Drift like silken butterflies;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Reel with every windy gust,</line>
      <line>Rise and reel like dancing girls,</line>
      <line>Float like strange transparent pearls,</line>
      <line>Fall and float like silver dust.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now to the low leaves they cling,</line>
      <line>Each with coy fantastic pose,</line>
      <line>Each a petal of a rose</line>
      <line>Straining at a gossamer string.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then to the tall trees they climb,</line>
      <line>Like thin globes of amethyst,</line>
      <line>Wandering opals keeping tryst</line>
      <line>With the rubies of the lime.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Oscar Wilde</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>Symphony in Yellow</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>An omnibus across the bridge</line>
      <line>Crawls like a yellow butterfly,</line>
      <line>And, here and there, a passer-by</line>
      <line>Shows like a little restless midge.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Big barges full of yellow hay</line>
      <line>Are moved against the shadowy wharf,</line>
      <line>And, like a yellow silken scarf,</line>
      <line>The thick fog hangs along the quay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The yellow leaves begin to fade</line>
      <line>And flutter from the Temple elms,</line>
      <line>And at my feet the pale green Thames</line>
      <line>Lies like a rod of rippled jade.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Oscar Wilde</author>
    <date>1897</date>
    <title>from The Ballad of Reading Gaol (I)</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>He did not wear his scarlet coat,</line>
      <line>For blood and wine are red,</line>
      <line>And blood and wine were on his hands</line>
      <line>When they found him with the dead,</line>
      <line>The poor dead woman whom he loved,</line>
      <line>And murdered in her bed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He walked amongst the Trial Men</line>
      <line>In a suit of shabby gray;</line>
      <line>A cricket cap was on his head,</line>
      <line>And his step seemed light and gay;</line>
      <line>But I never saw a man who looked</line>
      <line>So wistfully at the day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never saw a man who looked</line>
      <line>With such a wistful eye</line>
      <line>Upon that little tent of blue</line>
      <line>Which prisoners call the sky,</line>
      <line>And at every drifting cloud that went</line>
      <line>With sails of silver by.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I walked, with other souls in pain,</line>
      <line>Within another ring,</line>
      <line>And was wondering if the man had done</line>
      <line>A great or little thing,</line>
      <line>When a voice behind me whispered low,</line>
      <line>‘That fellow's got to swing.'</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear Christ! the very prison walls</line>
      <line>Suddenly seemed to reel,</line>
      <line>And the sky above my head became</line>
      <line>Like a casque of scorching steel;</line>
      <line>And, though I was a soul in pain,</line>
      <line>My pain I could not feel.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I only knew what hunted thought</line>
      <line>Quickened his step, and why</line>
      <line>He looked upon the garish day</line>
      <line>With such a wistful eye;</line>
      <line>The man had killed the thing he loved,</line>
      <line>And so he had to die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet each man kills the thing he loves,</line>
      <line>By each let this be heard,</line>
      <line>Some do it with a bitter look,</line>
      <line>Some with a flattering word,</line>
      <line>The coward does it with a kiss,</line>
      <line>The brave man with a sword!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some kill their love when they are young,</line>
      <line>And some when they are old;</line>
      <line>Some strangle with the hands of Lust,</line>
      <line>Some with the hands of Gold:</line>
      <line>The kindest use a knife, because</line>
      <line>The dead so soon grow cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some love too little, some too long,</line>
      <line>Some sell, and others buy;</line>
      <line>Some do the deed with many tears,</line>
      <line>And some without a sigh:</line>
      <line>For each man kills the thing he loves.</line>
      <line>Yet each man does not die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not die a death of shame</line>
      <line>On a day of dark disgrace,</line>
      <line>Nor have a noose about his neck,</line>
      <line>Nor a cloth upon his face,</line>
      <line>Nor drop feet foremost through the floor</line>
      <line>Into an empty space.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not sit with silent men</line>
      <line>Who watch him night and day;</line>
      <line>Who watch him when he tries to weep,</line>
      <line>And when he tries to pray;</line>
      <line>Who watch him lest himself should rob</line>
      <line>The prison of its prey.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not wake at dawn to see</line>
      <line>Dread figures throng his room,</line>
      <line>The shivering Chaplain robed in white,</line>
      <line>The Sheriff stern with gloom,</line>
      <line>And the Governor all in shiny black,</line>
      <line>With the yellow face of Doom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not rise in piteous haste</line>
      <line>To put on convict-clothes,</line>
      <line>While some coarse-mouthed Doctor gloats, and notes</line>
      <line>Each new and nerve-twitched pose,</line>
      <line>Fingering a watch whose little ticks</line>
      <line>Are like horrible hammer-blows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not know that sickening thirst</line>
      <line>That sands one’s throat, before</line>
      <line>The hangman with his gardener’s gloves</line>
      <line>Slips through the padded door,</line>
      <line>And binds one with three leathern thongs,</line>
      <line>That the throat may thirst no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not bend his head to hear</line>
      <line>The Burial Office read,</line>
      <line>Nor, while the terror of his soul</line>
      <line>Tells him he is not dead,</line>
      <line>Cross his own coffin, as he moves</line>
      <line>Into the hideous shed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He does not stare upon the air</line>
      <line>Through a little roof of glass:</line>
      <line>He does not pray with lips of clay</line>
      <line>For his agony to pass;</line>
      <line>Nor feel upon his shuddering cheek</line>
      <line>The kiss of Caiaphas.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In Debtors’ Yard the stones are hard,</line>
      <line>And the dripping wall is high,</line>
      <line>So it was there he took the air</line>
      <line>Beneath the leaden sky,</line>
      <line>And by each side a Warder walked,</line>
      <line>For fear the man might die.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or else he sat with those who watched</line>
      <line>His anguish night and day;</line>
      <line>Who watched him when he rose to weep,</line>
      <line>And when he crouched to pray;</line>
      <line>Who watched him lest himself should rob</line>
      <line>Their scaffold of its prey.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Governor was strong upon</line>
      <line>The Regulations Act:</line>
      <line>The Doctor said that Death was but</line>
      <line>A scientific fact:</line>
      <line>And twice a day the Chaplain called,</line>
      <line>And left a little tract.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And twice a day he smoked his pipe,</line>
      <line>And drank his quart of beer:</line>
      <line>His soul was resolute, and held</line>
      <line>No hiding-place for fear;</line>
      <line>He often said that he was glad</line>
      <line>The hangman’s hands were near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But why he said so strange a thing</line>
      <line>No Warder dared to ask:</line>
      <line>For he to whom a watcher’s doom</line>
      <line>Is given as his task,</line>
      <line>Must set a lock upon his lips,</line>
      <line>And make his face a mask.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or else he might be moved, and try</line>
      <line>To comfort or console:</line>
      <line>And what should Human Pity do</line>
      <line>Pent up in Murderers’ Hole?</line>
      <line>What word of grace in such a place</line>
      <line>Could help a brother’s soul?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With slouch and swing around the ring</line>
      <line>We trod the Fools’ Parade!</line>
      <line>We did not care: we knew we were</line>
      <line>The Devil’s Own Brigade:</line>
      <line>And shaven head and feet of lead</line>
      <line>Make a merry masquerade.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We tore the tarry rope to shreds</line>
      <line>With blunt and bleeding nails;</line>
      <line>We rubbed the doors, and scrubbed the floors,</line>
      <line>And cleaned the shining rails:</line>
      <line>And, rank by rank, we soaped the plank,</line>
      <line>And clattered with the pails.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We sewed the sacks, we broke the stones,</line>
      <line>We turned the dusty drill:</line>
      <line>We banged the tins, and bawled the hymns,</line>
      <line>And sweated on the mill:</line>
      <line>But in the heart of every man</line>
      <line>Terror was lying still.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So still it lay that every day</line>
      <line>Crawled like a weed-clogged wave:</line>
      <line>And we forgot the bitter lot</line>
      <line>That waits for fool and knave,</line>
      <line>Till once, as we tramped in from work,</line>
      <line>We passed an open grave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With yawning mouth the yellow hole</line>
      <line>Gaped for a living thing;</line>
      <line>The very mud cried out for blood</line>
      <line>To the thirsty asphalte ring:</line>
      <line>And we knew that ere one dawn grew fair</line>
      <line>Some prisoner had to swing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Right in we went, with soul intent</line>
      <line>On Death and Dread and Doom:</line>
      <line>The hangman, with his little bag,</line>
      <line>Went shuffling through the gloom:</line>
      <line>And each man trembled as he crept</line>
      <line>Into his numbered tomb.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That night the empty corridors</line>
      <line>Were full of forms of Fear,</line>
      <line>And up and down the iron town</line>
      <line>Stole feet we could not hear,</line>
      <line>And through the bars that hide the stars</line>
      <line>White faces seemed to peer.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He lay as one who lies and dreams</line>
      <line>In a pleasant meadow-land,</line>
      <line>The watchers watched him as he slept,</line>
      <line>And could not understand</line>
      <line>How one could sleep so sweet a sleep</line>
      <line>With a hangman close at hand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But there is no sleep when men must weep</line>
      <line>Who never yet have wept:</line>
      <line>So we—the fool, the fraud, the knave—</line>
      <line>That endless vigil kept,</line>
      <line>And through each brain on hands of pain</line>
      <line>Another’s terror crept.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Alas! it is a fearful thing</line>
      <line>To feel another’s guilt!</line>
      <line>For, right within, the sword of Sin</line>
      <line>Pierced to its poisoned hilt,</line>
      <line>And as molten lead were the tears we shed</line>
      <line>For the blood we had not spilt.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Warders with their shoes of felt</line>
      <line>Crept by each padlocked door,</line>
      <line>And peeped and saw, with eyes of awe,</line>
      <line>Grey figures on the floor,</line>
      <line>And wondered why men knelt to pray</line>
      <line>Who never prayed before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All through the night we knelt and prayed,</line>
      <line>Mad mourners of a corse!</line>
      <line>The troubled plumes of midnight were</line>
      <line>The plumes upon a hearse:</line>
      <line>And bitter wine upon a sponge</line>
      <line>Was the savour of Remorse.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The grey cock crew, the red cock crew,</line>
      <line>But never came the day: no</line>
      <line>And crooked shapes of Terror crouched,</line>
      <line>In the corners where we lay:</line>
      <line>And each evil sprite that walks by night</line>
      <line>Before us seemed to play.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They glided past, they glided fast,</line>
      <line>Like travellers through a mist:</line>
      <line>They mocked the moon in a rigadoon</line>
      <line>Of delicate turn and twist,</line>
      <line>And with formal pace and loathsome grace</line>
      <line>The phantoms kept their tryst.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With mop and mow, we saw them go,</line>
      <line>Slim shadows hand in hand:</line>
      <line>About, about, in ghostly rout</line>
      <line>They trod a saraband:</line>
      <line>And the damned grotesques made arabesques,</line>
      <line>Like the wind upon the sand!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With the pirouettes of marionettes,</line>
      <line>They tripped on pointed tread:</line>
      <line>But with flutes of Fear they filled the ear,</line>
      <line>As their grisly masque they led,</line>
      <line>And loud they sang, and long they sang,</line>
      <line>For they sang to wake the dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Oho!’ they cried, ‘The world is wide,</line>
      <line>But fettered limbs go lame!</line>
      <line>And once, or twice, to throw the dice</line>
      <line>Is a gentlemanly game,</line>
      <line>But he does not win who plays with Sin</line>
      <line>In the secret House of Shame.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No things of air these antics were,</line>
      <line>That frolicked with such glee:</line>
      <line>To men whose lives were held in gyves,</line>
      <line>And whose feet might not go free,</line>
      <line>Ah! wounds of Christ! they were living things,</line>
      <line>Most terrible to see.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Around, around, they waltzed and wound;</line>
      <line>Some wheeled in smirking pairs;</line>
      <line>With the mincing step of a demirep</line>
      <line>Some sidled up the stairs:</line>
      <line>And with subtle sneer, and fawning leer,</line>
      <line>Each helped us at our prayers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The morning wind began to moan,</line>
      <line>But still the night went on:</line>
      <line>Through its giant loom the web of gloom</line>
      <line>Crept till each thread was spun:</line>
      <line>And, as we prayed, we grew afraid</line>
      <line>Of the Justice of the Sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The moaning wind went wandering round</line>
      <line>The weeping prison-wall:</line>
      <line>Till like a wheel of turning steel</line>
      <line>We felt the minutes crawl:</line>
      <line>O moaning wind! what had we done</line>
      <line>To have such a seneschal?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At last I saw the shadowed bars,</line>
      <line>Like a lattice wrought in lead,</line>
      <line>Move right across the whitewashed wall</line>
      <line>That faced my three-plank bed,</line>
      <line>And I knew that somewhere in the world</line>
      <line>God’s dreadful dawn was red.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At six o’clock we cleaned our cells,</line>
      <line>At seven all was still,</line>
      <line>But the sough and swing of a mighty wing</line>
      <line>The prison seemed to fill,</line>
      <line>For the Lord of Death with icy breath</line>
      <line>Had entered in to kill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He did not pass in purple pomp,</line>
      <line>Nor ride a moon-white steed.</line>
      <line>Three yards of cord and a sliding board</line>
      <line>Are all the gallows’ need:</line>
      <line>So with rope of shame the Herald came</line>
      <line>To do the secret deed.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We were as men who through a fen</line>
      <line>Of filthy darkness grope:</line>
      <line>We did not dare to breathe a prayer,</line>
      <line>Or to give our anguish scope:</line>
      <line>Something was dead in each of us,</line>
      <line>And what was dead was Hope.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For Man’s grim Justice goes its way,</line>
      <line>And will not swerve aside:</line>
      <line>It slays the weak, it slays the strong,</line>
      <line>It has a deadly stride:</line>
      <line>With iron heel it slays the strong,</line>
      <line>The monstrous parricide!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We waited for the stroke of eight:</line>
      <line>Each tongue was thick with thirst:</line>
      <line>For the stroke of eight is the stroke of Fate</line>
      <line>That makes a man accursed,</line>
      <line>And Fate will use a running noose</line>
      <line>For the best man and the worst.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We had no other thing to do,</line>
      <line>Save to wait for the sign to come:</line>
      <line>So, like things of stone in a valley lone,</line>
      <line>Quiet we sat and dumb:</line>
      <line>But each man’s heart beat thick and quick,</line>
      <line>Like a madman on a drum!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With sudden shock the prison-clock</line>
      <line>Smote on the shivering air,</line>
      <line>And from all the gaol rose up a wail</line>
      <line>Of impotent despair,</line>
      <line>Like the sound that frightened marshes hear</line>
      <line>From some leper in his lair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And as one sees most fearful things</line>
      <line>In the crystal of a dream,</line>
      <line>We saw the greasy hempen rope</line>
      <line>Hooked to the blackened beam,</line>
      <line>And heard the prayer the hangman’s snare</line>
      <line>Strangled into a scream.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all the woe that moved him so</line>
      <line>That he gave that bitter cry,</line>
      <line>And the wild regrets, and the bloody sweats,</line>
      <line>None knew so well as I:</line>
      <line>For he who lives more lives than one</line>
      <line>More deaths than one must die.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Andrew Land</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>The Last Chance</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within the streams, Pausanias saith,</line>
      <line>That down Cocytus valley flow,</line>
      <line>Girdling the grey domain of Death,</line>
      <line>The spectral fishes come and go;</line>
      <line>The ghosts of trout flit to and fro.</line>
      <line>Persephone, fulfil my wish,</line>
      <line>And grant that in the shades below</line>
      <line>My ghost may land the ghosts of fish.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lionel Johnson</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>Victory</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Down the white steps, into the night, she came;</line>
      <line>Wearing white roses, lit by the full moon:</line>
      <line>And white upon the shadowy lawn she stood,</line>
      <line>Waiting and watching for the dawn’s first flame,</line>
      <line>Over the dark and visionary wood.</line>
      <line>Down the white steps, into the night, she came;</line>
      <line>Wearing white roses, lit by the full moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Night died away: and over the deep wood</line>
      <line>Widened a rosy cloud, a chilly flame:</line>
      <line>The shadowy lawn grew cold, and clear, and white.</line>
      <line>Then down she drew against her eyes her hood,</line>
      <line>To hide away the inexorable light.</line>
      <line>Night died away: and over the deep wood</line>
      <line>Widened a rosy cloud, a chilly flame.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then back she turned, and up the white steps came,</line>
      <line>And looked into a room of burning lights.</line>
      <line>Still slept her loveless husband his brute sleep,</line>
      <line>Beside the comfortless and ashen flame:</line>
      <line>Her lover waited, where the wood was deep.</line>
      <line>She turned not back: but from the white steps came,</line>
      <line>And went into the room of burning lights.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lionel Johnson</author>
    <date>1888</date>
    <title>Lambeth Lyric</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some seven score Bishops late at Lambeth sat,</line>
      <line>Gray-whiskered and respectable debaters:</line>
      <line>Each had on head a well-strung curly hat;</line>
      <line>And each wore gaiters.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And when these prelates at their talk had been</line>
      <line>Long time, they made yet longer proclamation,</line>
      <line>Saying: ‘These creeds are childish! both Nicene,</line>
      <line>And Athanasian.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>True, they were written by the Holy Ghost;</line>
      <line>So, to re-write them were perhaps a pity.</line>
      <line>Refer we their revision to a most</line>
      <line>Select Committee!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In ten years’ time we wise Pan Anglicans</line>
      <line>Once more around this Anglo Catholic table</line>
      <line>Will meet, to prove God’s word more weak than man’s,</line>
      <line>His truth, less stable.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So saying homeward the good Fathers go;</line>
      <line>Up Mississippi some and some up Niger.</line>
      <line>For thine old mantle they have clearly no</line>
      <line>More use, Elijah!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Instead, an apostolic apron girds</line>
      <line>Their loins, which ministerial fingers tie on:</line>
      <line>And Babylon’s songs they sing, new tune and words,</line>
      <line>All over Zion.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Creeds, the Scriptures, all the Faith of old,</line>
      <line>They hack and hew to please each bumptious German,</line>
      <line>Windy and vague as mists and clouds that fold</line>
      <line>Tabour and Hermon.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Happy Establishment in this thine hour!</line>
      <line>Behold thy bishops to their sees retreating!</line>
      <line>‘Have at the Faith!’ each cries: ‘good bye till our</line>
      <line>Next merry meeting!’</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lionel Johnson</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>A Stranger</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her face was like sad things: was like the lights</line>
      <line>Of a great city, seen from far off fields,</line>
      <line>Or seen from sea: sad things, as are the fires</line>
      <line>Lit in a land of furnaces by night:</line>
      <line>Sad things, as are the reaches of a stream</line>
      <line>Flowing beneath a golden moon alone.</line>
      <line>And her clear voice, full of remembrances,</line>
      <line>Came like faint music down the distant air.</line>
      <line>As though she had a spirit of dead joy</line>
      <line>About her, looked the sorrow of her ways:</line>
      <line>If light there be, the dark hills are to climb</line>
      <line>First: and if calm, far over the long sea.</line>
      <line>Fallen from all the world apart she seemed,</line>
      <line>Into a silence and a memory.</line>
      <line>What had the thin hands done, that now they strained</line>
      <line>Together in such passion? And those eyes,</line>
      <line>What saw they long ago, that now they dreamed</line>
      <line>Along the busy streets, blind but to dreams?</line>
      <line>Her white lips mocked the world, and all therein:</line>
      <line>She had known more than this; she wanted not</line>
      <line>This, who had known the past so great a thing.</line>
      <line>Moving about our ways, herself she moved</line>
      <line>In things done, years remembered, places gone.</line>
      <line>Lonely, amid the living crowds, as dead,</line>
      <line>She walked with wonderful and sad regard:</line>
      <line>With us, her passing image: but herself</line>
      <line>Far over the dark hills and the long sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lionel Johnson</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>The Roman Stage</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A man of marble holds the throne,</line>
      <line>With looks composed and resolute:</line>
      <line>Till death, a prince whom princes own,</line>
      <line>Draws near to touch the marble mute.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The play is over: good my friends!</line>
      <line>Murmur the pale lips: your applause!</line>
      <line>With what a grace the actor ends:</line>
      <line>How loyal to dramatic laws!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A brooding beauty on his brow;</line>
      <line>Irony brooding over sin:</line>
      <line>The next imperial actor now</line>
      <line>Bids the satyric piece begin.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Lionel Johnson</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>The Dark Angel</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dark Angel, with thine aching lust</line>
      <line>To rid the world of penitence:</line>
      <line>Malicious Angel, who still dost</line>
      <line>My soul such subtile violence!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Because of thee, no thought, no thing,</line>
      <line>Abides for me undesecrate:</line>
      <line>Dark Angel, ever on the wing,</line>
      <line>Who never reachest me too late!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When music sounds, then changest thou</line>
      <line>Its silvery to a sultry fire:</line>
      <line>Nor will thine envious heart allow</line>
      <line>Delight untortured by desire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Through thee, the gracious Muses turn</line>
      <line>To Furies, O mine Enemy!</line>
      <line>And all the things of beauty burn</line>
      <line>With flames of evil ecstasy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Because of thee, the land of dreams</line>
      <line>Becomes a gathering place of fears:</line>
      <line>Until tormented slumber seems</line>
      <line>One vehemence of useless tears.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When sunlight glows upon the flowers,</line>
      <line>Or ripples down the dancing sea:</line>
      <line>Thou, with thy troop of passionate powers,</line>
      <line>Beleaguerest, bewilderest, me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within the breath of autumn woods,</line>
      <line>Within the winter silences:</line>
      <line>Thy venomous spirit stirs and broods,</line>
      <line>O Master of impieties!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
