      <line>The ardour of red flame is thine,</line>
      <line>And thine the steely soul of ice:</line>
      <line>Thou poisonest the fair design</line>
      <line>Of nature, with unfair device.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Apples of ashes, golden bright;</line>
      <line>Waters of bitterness, how sweet!</line>
      <line>O banquet of a foul delight,</line>
      <line>Prepared by thee, dark Paraclete!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thou art the whisper in the gloom,</line>
      <line>The hinting tone, the haunting laugh:</line>
      <line>Thou art the adorner of my tomb,</line>
      <line>The minstrel of mine epitaph.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I fight thee, in the Holy Name!</line>
      <line>Yet, what thou dost, is what God saith:</line>
      <line>Tempter! should I escape thy flame,</line>
      <line>Thou wilt have helped my soul from Death:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The second Death, that never dies,</line>
      <line>That cannot die, when time is dead:</line>
      <line>Live Death, wherein the lost soul cries,</line>
      <line>Eternally uncomforted.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dark Angel, with thine aching lust!</line>
      <line>Of two defeats, of two despairs:</line>
      <line>Less dread, a change to drifting dust,</line>
      <line>Than thine eternity of cares.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Do what thou wilt, thou shalt not so,</line>
      <line>Dark Angel! triumph over me:</line>
      <line>Lonely, unto the Lone I go;</line>
      <line>Divine, to the Divinity.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerald Massey</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>As proper mode of quenching legal lust,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A Roue takes unto Himself a Wife:</line>
      <line>’Tis Cheaper when the bones begin to rust,</line>
      <line>And there’s no other Woman you can trust;</line>
      <line>But, mind you, in return, Law says you must</line>
      <line>Provide her with the physical means of life:</line>
      <line>And then the blindest beast may wallow and roll;</line>
      <line>The twain are One flesh, never mind the Soul:</line>
      <line>You may not cruelly beat her, but are free</line>
      <line>To violate the life in sanctuary;</line>
      <line>In virgin soil renew old seeds of Crime</line>
      <line>To blast eternity as well as time:</line>
      <line>She must show black and blue, or no divorce</line>
      <line>Is granted by the Law of Physical Force.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerald Massey</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>The Diakka</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>You are the Merry men, dwarfs of soul,</line>
      <line>Who can get your hand through the tiniest hole,</line>
      <line>And make your bells jingle outside of the show;</line>
      <line>Prove there’s life beyond, and on that we go!</line>
      <line>’Tis trying to find that we are more near</line>
      <line>To you than to those we have held more dear,</line>
      <line>But I think they are backing you all the while;</line>
      <line>And down on our efforts benignly may smile</line>
      <line>To see how we strive and are ever unable</line>
      <line>To meet and shake hands with the leg of a table.</line>
      <line>So holloa, boys, ring the bells, let them see how</line>
      <line>You can wake up the world with your row-de-dow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Folk say you are Devils: then act as such!</line>
      <line>Give them a touch of the devil’s clutch.</line>
      <line>In times like ours ’tis a comfort to know</line>
      <line>For certain there may be a devil or so!</line>
      <line>We need them to prove how the lusts of old</line>
      <line>For women or wine, for gore or gold,</line>
      <line>Are not to be quenched with their burning breath</line>
      <line>By the waters of Winter that drown us in death,</line>
      <line>But still live on, all a-crave to be fed</line>
      <line>In the earth-life lived by the homeless dead.</line>
      <line>Holloa, boys, ring the bells, let us see how</line>
      <line>You can wake up the world with your row-de-dow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Many a fathom deep under the ground</line>
      <line>Souls like toads in the rock lie bound,</line>
      <line>Awaiting the resurrection sound</line>
      <line>Of the Crack of doom, for them to be found!</line>
      <line>Nothing short of an earthquake-kick</line>
      <line>Will send them heavenward, make them quick.</line>
      <line>Spirits far off, invisible, mute,</line>
      <line>Can no more reach to the buried root,</line>
      <line>Than we upon earth to the moon can shoot,</line>
      <line>Or open oysters by playing a flute!</line>
      <line>Holloa, boys, ring the bells, show them how</line>
      <line>You can wake up the world with your row-de-dow.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Gerald Massey</author>
    <date>1889</date>
    <title>Womankind</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear things! we would not have you learn too much—</line>
      <line>Your Ignorance is so charming! We’ve a notion</line>
      <line>That greater knowledge might not lend you such</line>
      <line>Sure aid to blind obedience and devotion.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Cosmo Monkouse</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>Any Soul to Any Body</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>S o we must part, my body, you and I</line>
      <line>Who’ve spent so many pleasant years together.</line>
      <line>’Tis sorry work to lose your company</line>
      <line>Who clove to me so close, whate’er the weather,</line>
      <line>From winter unto winter, wet or dry;</line>
      <line>But you have reached the limit of your tether,</line>
      <line>And I must journey on my way alone,</line>
      <line>And leave you quietly beneath a stone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say that you are altogether bad</line>
      <line>(Forgive me, ’tis not my experience),</line>
      <line>And think me very wicked to be sad</line>
      <line>At leaving you, a clod, a prison, whence</line>
      <line>To get quite free I should be very glad.</line>
      <line>Perhaps I may be so, some few days hence,</line>
      <line>But now, methinks, ’twere graceless not to spend</line>
      <line>A tear or two on my departing friend.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now our long partnership is near completed,</line>
      <line>And I look back upon its history;</line>
      <line>I greatly fear I have not always treated</line>
      <line>You with the honesty you showed to me.</line>
      <line>And I must own that you have oft defeated</line>
      <line>Unworthy schemes by your sincerity,</line>
      <line>And by a blush or stammering tongue have tried</line>
      <line>To make me think again before I lied.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis true you’re not so handsome as you were,</line>
      <line>But that’s not your fault and is partly mine.</line>
      <line>You might have lasted longer with more care,</line>
      <line>And still looked something like your first design;</line>
      <line>And even now, with all your wear and tear,</line>
      <line>’Tis pitiful to think I must resign</line>
      <line>You to the friendless grave, the patient prey</line>
      <line>Of all the hungry legions of Decay.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But you must stay, dear body, and I go.</line>
      <line>And I was once so very proud of you:</line>
      <line>You made my mother’s eyes to overflow</line>
      <line>When first she saw you, wonderful and new.</line>
      <line>And now, with all your faults, ’twere hard to find</line>
      <line>A slave more willing or a friend more true.</line>
      <line>Ay—even they who say the worst about you</line>
      <line>Can scarcely tell what I shall do without you.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>Pastel: Masks and Faces</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The light of our cigarettes</line>
      <line>Went and came in the gloom:</line>
      <line>It was dark in the little room.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dark, and then, in the dark,</line>
      <line>Sudden, a flash, a glow,</line>
      <line>And a hand and a ring I know.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then, through the dark, a flush</line>
      <line>Ruddy and vague, the grace</line>
      <line>(A rose!) of her lyric face.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>The Absinthe-Drinker</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Gently I wave the visible world away.</line>
      <line>Far off, I hear a roar, afar yet near,</line>
      <line>Far off and strange, a voice is in my ear,</line>
      <line>And is the voice my own? the words I say</line>
      <line>Fall strangely, like a dream, across the day;</line>
      <line>And the dim sunshine is a dream. How clear,</line>
      <line>New as the world to lovers’ eyes, appear</line>
      <line>The men and women passing on their way!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The world is very fair. The hours are all</line>
      <line>Linked in a dance of mere forgetfulness.</line>
      <line>I am at peace with God and man. O glide,</line>
      <line>Sands of the hour-glass that I count not, fall</line>
      <line>Serenely: scarce I feel your soft caress,</line>
      <line>Rocked on this dreamy and indifferent tide.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>Rain on the Down</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Night, and the down by the sea,</line>
      <line>And the veil of rain on the down;</line>
      <line>And she came through the mist and the rain to me</line>
      <line>From the safe warm lights of the town.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The rain shone in her hair,</line>
      <line>And her face gleamed in the rain;</line>
      <line>And only the night and the rain were there</line>
      <line>As she came to me out of the rain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>During Music</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The music had the heat of blood,</line>
      <line>A passion that no words can reach;</line>
      <line>We sat together, and understood</line>
      <line>Our own heart’s speech.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We had no need of word or sign,</line>
      <line>The music spoke for us, and said</line>
      <line>All that her eyes could read in mine</line>
      <line>Or mine in hers had read.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>At the Cavour</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wine, the red coals, the flaring gas,</line>
      <line>Bring out a brighter tone in cheeks</line>
      <line>That learn at home before the glass</line>
      <line>The flush that eloquently speaks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The blue-grey smoke of cigarettes</line>
      <line>Curls from the lessening ends that glow;</line>
      <line>The men are thinking of the bets,</line>
      <line>The women of the debts, they owe.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then their eyes meet, and in their eyes</line>
      <line>The accustomed smile comes up to call,</line>
      <line>A look half miserably wise,</line>
      <line>Half heedlessly ironical.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>At Dieppe</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The grey-green stretch of sandy grass,</line>
      <line>Indefinitely desolate;</line>
      <line>A sea of lead, a sky of slate;</line>
      <line>Already autumn in the air, alas!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One stark monotony of stone,</line>
      <line>The long hotel, acutely white,</line>
      <line>Against the after-sunset light</line>
      <line>Withers grey-green, and takes the grass’s tone.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Listless and endless it outlies,</line>
      <line>And means, to you and me, no more</line>
      <line>Than any pebble on the shore,</line>
      <line>Or this indifferent moment as it dies.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1894</date>
    <title>Paris</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>My Paris is a land where twilight days</line>
      <line>Merge into violent nights of black and gold;</line>
      <line>Where, it may be, the flower of dawn is cold:</line>
      <line>Ah, but the gold nights, and the scented ways!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Eyelids of women, little curls of hair,</line>
      <line>A little nose curved softly, like a shell,</line>
      <line>A red mouth like a wound, a mocking veil:</line>
      <line>Phantoms, before the dawn, how phantom-fair!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And every woman with beseeching eyes,</line>
      <line>Or with enticing eyes, or amorous,</line>
      <line>Offers herself, a rose, and craves of us</line>
      <line>A rose’s place among our memories.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Arthur Symons</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The Barrel-Organ</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Enigmatical, tremulous,</line>
      <line>Voice of the troubled wires,</line>
      <line>What remembering desires</line>
      <line>Wail to me, wandering thus</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Up through the night with a cry,</line>
      <line>Inarticulate, insane.</line>
      <line>Out of the night of the street and the rain</line>
      <line>Into the rain and the night of the sky?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Inarticulate voice of my heart,</line>
      <line>Rusty, a worn-out thing,</line>
      <line>Harsh with a broken string,</line>
      <line>Mended, and pulled apart,</line>
      <line>All the old tunes played through,</line>
      <line>Fretted by hands that have played,</line>
      <line>Tremulous voice that cries to me out of the shade,</line>
      <line>The voice of my heart is crying in you.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1890</date>
    <title>A Cradle Song</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The angels are bending</line>
      <line>Above your white bed,</line>
      <line>They weary of tending</line>
      <line>The souls of the dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>God smiles in high heaven</line>
      <line>To see you so good,</line>
      <line>The old planets seven</line>
      <line>Grow gay with his mood.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I kiss you and kiss you,</line>
      <line>With arms round my own,</line>
      <line>Ah, how shall I miss you,</line>
      <line>When, dear, you have grown.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1892</date>
    <title>The Pity of Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A pity beyond all telling,</line>
      <line>Is hid in the heart of love;</line>
      <line>The folk who are buying and selling,</line>
      <line>The stars of God where they move,</line>
      <line>The mouse-grey waters on flowing,</line>
      <line>The clouds on their journey above,</line>
      <line>And the cold wet winds ever blowing,</line>
      <line>All threaten the head that I love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>The Sorrow of Love</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The quarrel of the sparrows in the eaves,</line>
      <line>The full round moon and the star-laden sky,</line>
      <line>And the loud song of the ever-singing leaves</line>
      <line>Had hid away earth’s old and weary cry.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And then you came with those red mournful lips,</line>
      <line>And with you came the whole of the world’s tears,</line>
      <line>And all the sorrows of her labouring ships,</line>
      <line>And all burden of her myriad years.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now the sparrows warring in the eaves,</line>
      <line>The crumbling moon, the white stars in the sky,</line>
      <line>And the loud chanting of the unquiet leaves,</line>
      <line>Are shaken with earth’s old and weary cry.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>When You Are Old</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When you are old and grey and full of sleep,</line>
      <line>And nodding by the fire, take down this book,</line>
      <line>And slowly read, and dream of the soft look</line>
      <line>Your eyes had once, and of their shadows deep;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How many loved your moments of glad grace,</line>
      <line>And loved your beauty with love false or true,</line>
      <line>But one man loved tire pilgrim soul in you,</line>
      <line>And loved the sorrows of your changing face;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And bending down beside the glowing bars,</line>
      <line>Murmur, a little sadly, how Love fled</line>
      <line>And paced upon the mountains overhead</line>
      <line>And hid his face amid a crowd of stars.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1892</date>
    <title>Who Goes with Fergus?</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Who will go drive with Fergus now,</line>
      <line>And pierce the deep wood’s woven shade,</line>
      <line>And dance upon the level shore?</line>
      <line>Young man, lift up your russet brow,</line>
      <line>And lift your tender eyelids, maid,</line>
      <line>And brood on hopes and fear no more.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And no more turn aside and brood</line>
      <line>Upon love’s bitter mystery;</line>
      <line>For Fergus rules the brazen cars,</line>
      <line>And rules the shadows of the wood,</line>
      <line>And the white breast of the dim sea</line>
      <line>And all dishevelled wandering stars.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1898</date>
    <title>He Thinks of Those who have Spoken Evil of His Beloved</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Half close your eyelids, loosen your hair,</line>
      <line>And dream about the great and their pride;</line>
      <line>They have spoken against you everywhere,</line>
      <line>But weigh this song with the great and their pride;</line>
      <line>I made it out of a mouthful of air,</line>
      <line>Their children’s children shall say they have lied.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>W.B. Yeats</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had I the heavens’ embroidered cloths,</line>
      <line>Enwrought with golden and silver light,</line>
      <line>The blue and the dim and the dark cloths</line>
      <line>Of night and light and the half-light,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I would spread the cloths under your feet:</line>
      <line>But I, being poor, have only my dreams;</line>
      <line>I have spread my dreams under your feet;</line>
      <line>Tread softly because you tread on my dreams.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>William Cory</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>Hersilia</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I see her stand with arms a-kimbo,</line>
      <line>A blue and blonde sub aureo nimbo;</line>
      <line>She scans her literary limbo,</line>
      <line>The reliques of her teens;</line>
      <line>Things like the chips of broken stilts,</line>
      <line>Or tatters of embroidered quilts,</line>
      <line>Or nosegays tossed away by jilts,</line>
      <line>Notes, ballads, tales, and scenes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Soon will she gambol like a lamb,</line>
      <line>Fenced, but not tethered, near the Cam.</line>
      <line>Maybe she’ll swim where Byron swam,</line>
      <line>And chat beneath the limes,</line>
      <line>Where Arthur, Alfred, Fitz, and Brooks</line>
      <line>Lit thought by one another’s looks,</line>
      <line>Embraced their jests and kicked their books,</line>
      <line>In England’s happier times;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ere magic poets felt the gout,</line>
      <line>Ere Darwin whelmed the Church in doubt,</line>
      <line>Ere Apologia had found out</line>
      <line>The round world must be right;</line>
      <line>When Gladstone, bluest of the blue,</line>
      <line>Read all Augustine’s folios through;</line>
      <line>When France was tame, and no one knew</line>
      <line>We and the Czar would fight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Sixty years since’ (said dear old Scott;</line>
      <line>We’re bound, you know, to quote Sir Wat)</line>
      <line>This isle had not a sweeter spot</line>
      <line>Than Neville’s Court by Granta;</line>
      <line>No Newnham then, no kirtled scribes,</line>
      <line>No Clelia to harangue the tribes,</line>
      <line>No race for girls, no apple bribes</line>
      <line>To tempt an Atalanta.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We males talked fast, we meant to be</line>
      <line>World-betterers all at twenty-three,</line>
      <line>But somehow failed to level thee,</line>
      <line>Oh, battered fort of Edom!</line>
      <line>Into the breach our daughters press,</line>
      <line>Brave patriots in unwarlike dress,</line>
      <line>Adepts at thought-in-idleness,</line>
      <line>Sweet devotees of freedom.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And now it is your turn, fair soul,</line>
      <line>To see the fervent car-wheels roll,</line>
      <line>Your rivals clashing past the goal,</line>
      <line>Some sly Milanion leading.</line>
      <line>Ah! with them may your Genius bring</line>
      <line>Some Celia, some Miss Mannering;</line>
      <line>For youthful friendship is a thing</line>
      <line>More precious than succeeding.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Logie Robertson</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>The Discovery of America</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>All the mill-horses of Europe</line>
      <line>Were plodding round and round;</line>
      <line>All the mills were droning</line>
      <line>The same old sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The drivers were dozing, the millers</line>
      <line>Were deaf—as millers will be;</line>
      <line>When, startling them all, without warning</line>
      <line>Came a great shout from the sea!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It startled them all. The horses,</line>
      <line>Lazily plodding round,</line>
      <line>Started and stopp’d; and the mills dropp’d</line>
      <line>Like a mantle their sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The millers look’d over their shoulders,</line>
      <line>The drivers open’d their eyes:</line>
      <line>A silence, deeper than deafness,</line>
      <line>Had fallen out of the skies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Halloa there!’—this time distinctly</line>
      <line>It rose from the barren sea;</line>
      <line>And Europe, turning in wonder,</line>
      <line>Whisper’d, ‘What can it be?’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Come down, come down to the shore here!’</line>
      <line>And Europe was soon on the sand;—</line>
      <line>It was the great Columbus</line>
      <line>Dragging his prize to land.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>James Logie Robertson</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>A Schule Laddie's Lament on the Lateness o' the Season</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The east wind’s whistlin’ cauld an’ shrill,</line>
      <line>The snaw lies on the Lomont Hill;</line>
      <line>It’s simmer i’ the almanack,</line>
      <line>But when ’ill simmer days be back?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s no’ a bud on tree or buss;</line>
      <line>The craws are at a sair nonplus,—</line>
      <line>Hoo can they big? hoo can they pair?</line>
      <line>Wi’ them sae cauld, and winds sae bare.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>My faither canna saw his seed,—</line>
      <line>The hauf o’ th’ laund’s to ploo, indeed;</line>
      <line>The lambs are deein’, an’ the yowes</line>
      <line>Are trauchled wanderin’ owre the knowes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s no’ a swallow back as yet,</line>
      <line>The robin doesna seek to flit;</line>
      <line>There’s no’ a buckie, nor a bud,</line>
      <line>On ony brae, in ony wud.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It’s no’ a time for barefit feet</line>
      <line>When it may be on-ding o’ sleet.</line>
      <line>The season’s broken a’ oor rules,—</line>
      <line>It’s no’ the time o’ year o’ bools;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It’s no’ the time o’ year o’ peeries.</line>
      <line>I think the year’s gane tapsalteeries!</line>
      <line>The farmers may be bad, nae doot—</line>
      <line>It pits hiz laddies sair aboot.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dollie Radford</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>Soliloquy of a Maiden Aunt</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The ladies bow, and partners set,</line>
      <line>And turn around and pirouette</line>
      <line>And trip the Lancers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But no one seeks my ample chair,</line>
      <line>Or asks me with persuasive air</line>
      <line>To join the dancers.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They greet me, as I sit alone</line>
      <line>Upon my solitary throne,</line>
      <line>And pass politely.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet mine could keep the measured beat,</line>
      <line>As surely as the youngest feet,</line>
      <line>And tread as lightly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>No other maiden had my skill</line>
      <line>In our old homestead on the hill—</line>
      <line>That merry May-time</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When Allan closed the flagging ball,</line>
      <line>And danced with me before them all,</line>
      <line>Until the day-time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Again I laugh, and step alone,</line>
      <line>And curtsey low as on my own</line>
      <line>His strong hand closes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But Allan now seeks staid delight,</line>
      <line>His son there, brought my niece to-night</line>
      <line>These early roses.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Time orders well, we have our Spring,</line>
      <line>Our songs, and may-flower gathering,</line>
      <line>Our love and laughter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And children chatter all the while,</line>
      <line>And leap the brook and climb the stile</line>
      <line>And follow after.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And yet—the step of Allan’s son,</line>
      <line>Is not as light as was the one</line>
      <line>That went before it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And that old lace, I think, falls down</line>
      <line>Less softly on Priscilla’s gown</line>
      <line>Than when I wore it.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>J.K. Stephen</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>England and America</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Republic of the West,</line>
      <line>Enlightened, free, sublime,</line>
      <line>Unquestionably best</line>
      <line>Production of our time.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The telephone is thine,</line>
      <line>And thine the Pullman Car,</line>
      <line>The caucus, the divine</line>
      <line>Intense electric star.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To thee we likewise owe</line>
      <line>The venerable names</line>
      <line>Of Edgar Allan Poe,</line>
      <line>And Mr Henry James.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In short it’s due to thee,</line>
      <line>Thou kind of Western star,</line>
      <line>That we have come to be</line>
      <line>Precisely what we are.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But every now and then,</line>
      <line>It cannot be denied,</line>
      <line>You breed a kind of men</line>
      <line>Who are not dignified,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or courteous or refined,</line>
      <line>Benevolent or wise,</line>
      <line>Or gifted with a mind</line>
      <line>Beyond the common size,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or notable for tact,</line>
      <line>Agreeable to me,</line>
      <line>Or anything, in fact,</line>
      <line>That people ought to be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Britannia rules the waves,</line>
      <line>As I have heard her say;</line>
      <line>She frees whatever slaves</line>
      <line>She meets upon her way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A teeming mother she</line>
      <line>Of Parliaments and Laws;</line>
      <line>Majestic, mighty, free:</line>
      <line>Devoid of common flaws.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For her did Shakspere write</line>
      <line>His admirable plays:</line>
      <line>For her did Nelson fight</line>
      <line>And Wolseley win his bays.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her sturdy common sense</line>
      <line>Is based on solid grounds:</line>
      <line>By saving numerous pence</line>
      <line>She spends effective pounds.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Saxon and the Celt</line>
      <line>She equitably rules;</line>
      <line>Her iron rod is felt</line>
      <line>By countless knaves and fools.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In fact, mankind at large,</line>
      <line>Black, yellow, white and red,</line>
      <line>Is given to her in charge,</line>
      <line>And owns her as a head.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But every here and there—</line>
      <line>Deny it if you can—</line>
      <line>She breeds a vacant stare</line>
      <line>Unworthy of a man:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A look of dull surprise;</line>
      <line>A nerveless idle hand:</line>
      <line>An eye which never tries</line>
      <line>To threaten or command:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In short, a kind of man,</line>
      <line>If man indeed he be,</line>
      <line>As worthy of our ban</line>
      <line>As any that we see:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Unspeakably obtuse,</line>
      <line>Abominably vain,</line>
      <line>Of very little use,</line>
      <line>And execrably plain.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>J.K. Stephen</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>In the Backs</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As I was strolling lonely in the Backs,</line>
      <line>I met a woman whom I did not like.</line>
      <line>I did not like the way the woman walked:</line>
      <line>Loose-hipped, big-boned, disjointed, angular.</line>
      <line>If her anatomy comprised a waist,</line>
      <line>I did not notice it: she had a face</line>
      <line>With eyes and lips adjusted thereunto,</line>
      <line>But round her mouth no pleasing shadows stirred,</line>
      <line>Nor did her eyes invite a second glance.</line>
      <line>Her dress was absolutely colourless,</line>
      <line>Devoid of taste or shape or character;</line>
      <line>Her boots were rather old, and rather large,</line>
      <line>And rather shabby, not precisely matched.</line>
      <line>Her hair was very far from beautiful</line>
      <line>And not abundant: she had such a hat</line>
      <line>As neither merits nor expects remark.</line>
      <line>She was not clever, I am very sure,</line>
      <line>Nor witty nor amusing; well-informed</line>
      <line>She may have been, and kind, perhaps, of heart;</line>
      <line>But gossip was writ plain upon her face.</line>
      <line>And so she stalked her dull unthinking way;</line>
      <line>Or, if she thought of anything, it was</line>
      <line>That such a one had got a second class,</line>
      <line>Or Mrs So-and-So a second child.</line>
      <line>I do not want to see that girl again:</line>
      <line>I do not like her: and I should not mind</line>
      <line>If she were done away with, killed, or ploughed.</line>
      <line>She did not seem to serve a useful end:</line>
      <line>And certainly she was not beautiful.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>J.K. Stephen</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>A Remonstrance</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love is what lacks then: but what does it mean to you</line>
      <line>Where did you hear of it, feel it, or see?</line>
      <line>What has the truth, or the good of it been to you?</line>
      <line>How love some other, yet nohow love me?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If there were any conspicuous fault in me,</line>
      <line>Any defect it were torture to bear,</line>
      <line>Low-lying levels, too deep to exalt, in me,</line>
      <line>Dread possibilities in me to fear:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If I were ugly or old or untractable,</line>
      <line>Mean in my methods or low in my views:</line>
      <line>If I were dull or unpleasant: in fact able</line>
      <line>Neither to please, nor elate, nor amuse:—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That makes you angry, impatient; we’ll take it, then,</line>
      <line>I am a man that to know’s to esteem:</line>
      <line>That’s the admission you make to me: make it then:</line>
      <line>Well why not love me? what’s love but a dream?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Only of course in the sense you bestow on it:</line>
      <line>I have a meaning for love, that is plain:</line>
      <line>Further than passion, and longing, and so on, it</line>
      <line>Means to me liking and liking again:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Liking, and liking, and liking—that’s plain enough;—</line>
      <line>Something depending on qualities then?</line>
      <line>Yes: for they give you both pleasure and pain enough,</line>
      <line>Qualities common in women and men.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Still not a doubt that, the love being brought about,</line>
      <line>Liking made love, there is more that will come:</line>
      <line>All the good qualities ever yet thought about:—</line>
      <line>Yes, they fall short of that excellent sum.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Like a man: like him: and let there be more of it,</line>
      <line>That which he is he’ll be liked for: at last</line>
      <line>Love in a minute will flash—I am sure of it—</line>
      <line>Whether the wedding be future or past.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You who consider it quite immaterial</line>
      <line>Whether the person is worthy or not:</line>
      <line>You who are looking for something ethereal,</line>
      <line>Something celestial, transcending our lot:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You to whom every excellent quality</line>
      <line>Means but a cypher: who hope to behold</line>
      <line>Love at a burst in his mighty totality</line>
      <line>Change all the grey of the world into gold:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You dream a priceless love: I feel a penny one:</line>
      <line>My reason plods, while your fancy can range:—</line>
      <line>Therefore, I ask, since you’ll never love any one,</line>
      <line>Why should you not marry me for a change?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>J.K. Stephen</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>After the Golden Wedding</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She’s not a faultless woman; no!</line>
      <line>She’s not an angel in disguise:</line>
      <line>She has her rivals here below:</line>
      <line>She’s not an unexampled prize:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She does not always see the point</line>
      <line>Of little jests her husband makes:</line>
      <line>And, when the world is out of joint,</line>
      <line>She makes a hundred small mistakes:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>She’s not a miracle of tact:</line>
      <line>Her temper’s not the best I know:</line>
      <line>She’s got her little faults in fact,</line>
      <line>Although I never tell her so.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But this, my wife, is why I hold you</line>
      <line>As good a wife as ever stepped,</line>
      <line>And why I meant it when I told you</line>
      <line>How cordially our feast I kept:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You’ve lived with me these fifty years,</line>
      <line>And all the time you loved me dearly:</line>
      <line>I may have given you cause for tears:</line>
      <line>I may have acted rather queerly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I ceased to love you long ago:</line>
      <line>I loved another for a season:</line>
      <line>As time went on I came to know</line>
      <line>Your worth, my wife: and saw the reason</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Why such a wife as you have been</line>
      <line>Is more than worth the world beside;</line>
      <line>You loved me all the time, my Queen;</line>
      <line>You couldn’t help it if you tried.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You loved me as I once loved you,</line>
      <line>As each loved each beside the altar:</line>
      <line>And whatsoever I might do,</line>
      <line>Your loyal heart could never falter.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, if you sometimes fail me, sweetest,</line>
      <line>And don’t appreciate me, dear,</line>
      <line>No matter: such defects are meetest</line>
      <line>For poor humanity, I fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all’s forgiven, all’s forgot,</line>
      <line>On this our golden wedding day;</line>
      <line>For, see! she loves me: does she not?</line>
      <line>So let the world e’en go its way.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I’m old and nearly useless now,</line>
      <line>Each day a greater weakling proves me:</line>
      <line>There’s compensation anyhow:</line>
      <line>I still possess a wife that loves me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dear worthy husband! good old man!</line>
      <line>Fit hero of a golden marriage:</line>
      <line>I’ll show towards you, if I can,</line>
      <line>An absolutely wifely carriage.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The months or years which your career</line>
      <line>May still comprise before you perish,</line>
      <line>Shall serve to prove that I, my dear,</line>
      <line>Can honour, and obey, and cherish.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Till death us part, as soon he must,</line>
      <line>(And you, my dear, should show the way)</line>
      <line>I hope you’ll always find me just</line>
      <line>The same as on our wedding day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I never loved you, dearest: never!</line>
      <line>Let that be clearly understood:</line>
      <line>I thought you good, and rather clever,</line>
      <line>And found you really rather good.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, what was more, I loved another,</line>
      <line>But couldn’t get him: well, but, then</line>
      <line>You’re just as bad, my erring brother,</line>
      <line>You most impeccable of men:—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Except for this: my love was married</line>
      <line>Some weeks before I married you:</line>
      <line>While you, my amorous dawdler, tarried</line>
      <line>Till we’d been wed a year or two.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You loved me at our wedding: I</line>
      <line>Loved some one else: and after that</line>
      <line>I never cast a loving eye</line>
      <line>On others: you—well, tit for tat!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But after all I made you cheerful:</line>
      <line>Your whims I’ve humoured: saw the point</line>
      <line>Of all your jokes: grew duly tearful,</line>
      <line>When you were sad, yet chose the joint</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>You liked the best of all for dinner,</line>
      <line>And soothed you in your hours of woe:</line>
      <line>Although a miserable sinner,</line>
      <line>I am a good wife, as wives go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I bore with you and took your side,</line>
      <line>And kept my temper all the time:</line>
      <line>I never flirted; never cried,</line>
      <line>Nor ranked it as a heinous crime,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When you preferred another lady,</line>
      <line>Or used improper words to me,</line>
      <line>Or told a story more than shady,</line>
      <line>Or snored and snorted after tea,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Or otherwise gave proofs of being</line>
      <line>A dull and rather vain old man:</line>
      <line>I still succeeded in agreeing</line>
      <line>With all you said, (the safest plan),</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet always strove my point to carry,</line>
      <line>And make you do as I desired:</line>
      <line>I’m glad my people made me marry!</line>
      <line>They hit on just what I required.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had love been wanted—well, I couldn’t</line>
      <line>Have given what I’d not to give;</line>
      <line>Or had a genius asked me! wouldn’t</line>
      <line>The man have suffered? now, we live</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Among our estimable neighbours</line>
      <line>A decent and decorous life:</line>
      <line>I’ve earned by my protracted labours</line>
      <line>The title of a model wife.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But when beneath the turf you’re sleeping,</line>
      <line>And I am sitting here in black,</line>
      <line>Engaged, as they’ll suppose, in weeping,</line>
      <line>I shall not wish to have you back.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A good old couple! kind and wise!</line>
      <line>And oh! what love for one another!</line>
      <line>They’ve won, those two, life’s highest prize,</line>
      <line>Oh! let us copy them, my brother.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Katherine Tynan</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>The Witch</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Witch</line>
      <line>Margaret Grady — I fear she will burn —</line>
      <line>Charmed the butter off my churn;</line>
      <line>’Tis I would know it the wide world over,</line>
      <line>Yellow as saffron, scented with clover.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>At Omagh market the witch displayed it:</line>
      <line>Ill she had gathered, ill she had made it.</line>
      <line>Hid in my cloak’s hood, one glance I threw it,</line>
      <line>Passed on smiling; my troth! I knew it!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sheila, the kindest cow in the parish,</line>
      <line>Mild and silken, and good to cherish,</line>
      <line>Shame her own gold butter should leave her</line>
      <line>To enrich the milk of a low-bred heifer!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I said not Yea or Nay to the mocker,</line>
      <line>But called the fairy-man over from Augher;</line>
      <line>Like a russet he is that’s withered,</line>
      <line>Bent in two with his wisdom gathered.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He touched the butter, he peered and pondered,</line>
      <line>And crooned strange rhymes while I watched and wondered:</line>
      <line>Then he drew me out through the gloaming</line>
      <line>O’er the fields where the mist was coming.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He bewitched me so that I know not</line>
      <line>Where they may grow, where they may grow not;</line>
      <line>Those witch-hazels he plucked and plaited,</line>
      <line>Crooning on while the twigs he mated.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There’s the wreath on the churn-dash yonder.</line>
      <line>All the neighbours view it with wonder;</line>
      <line>And ’spite of Father Tom I avow it</line>
      <line>The yield is doubled since that came to it.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I bless the fairy-man though he be evil;</line>
      <line>Yet fairy-spells come not from the Devil;</line>
      <line>And Margaret Grady—I fear she will burn—</line>
      <line>I do forgive her, with hate and scorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ernest Dowson</author>
    <date>1891</date>
    <title>You would have understood me, had you waited,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>You would have understood me, had you waited,</line>
      <line>I could have loved you, dear! as well as he:</line>
      <line>Had we not been impatient, dear! and fated</line>
      <line>Always to disagree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What is the use of speech? Silence were fitter:</line>
      <line>Lest we should still be wishing things unsaid.</line>
      <line>Though all the words we ever spake were bitter,</line>
      <line>Shall I reproach you dead?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nay, let this earth, your portion, likewise cover</line>
      <line>All the old anger, setting us apart:</line>
      <line>Always, in all, in truth was I your lover;</line>
      <line>Always, I held your heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have met other women who were tender,</line>
      <line>As you were cold, dear! with a grace as rare.</line>
      <line>Think you, I turned to them, or made surrender,</line>
      <line>I who had found you fair?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Had we been patient, dear! ah, had you waited,</line>
      <line>I had fought death for you, better than he:</line>
      <line>But from the very first, dear! we were fated</line>
      <line>Always to disagree.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Late, late, I come to you, now death discloses</line>
      <line>Love that in life was not to be our part:</line>
      <line>On your low lying mound between the roses,</line>
      <line>Sadly I cast my heart.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I would not waken you: nay! this is fitter;</line>
      <line>Death and the darkness give you unto me;</line>
      <line>Here we who loved so, were so cold and bitter,</line>
      <line>Hardly can disagree.</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1891; pub. 1894)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ernest Dowson</author>
    <date></date>
    <title>Terre Promise</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Even now the fragrant darkness of her hair</line>
      <line>Had brushed my cheek; and once, in passing by,</line>
      <line>Her hand upon my hand lay tranquilly:</line>
      <line>What things unspoken trembled in the air!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Always I know, how little severs me</line>
      <line>From mine heart’s country, that is yet so far;</line>
      <line>And must I lean and long across a bar,</line>
      <line>That half a word would shatter utterly?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ah might it be, that just by touch of hand,</line>
      <line>Or speaking silence, shall the barrier fall;</line>
      <line>And she shall pass, with no vain words at all,</line>
      <line>But droop into mine arms, and understand!</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1893; pub. 1896)</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Spleen</line>
      <line>I was not sorrowful, I could not weep,</line>
      <line>And all my memories were put to sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I watched the river grow more white and strange,</line>
      <line>All day till evening I watched it change.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All day till evening I watched the rain</line>
      <line>Beat wearily upon the window pane.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I was not sorrowful, but only tired</line>
      <line>Of everything that ever I desired.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her lips, her eyes, all day became to me</line>
      <line>The shadow of a shadow utterly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All day mine hunger for her heart became</line>
      <line>Oblivion, until the evening came,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And left me sorrowful, inclined to weep,</line>
      <line>With all my memories that could not sleep.</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1896)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Ernest Dowson</author>
    <date></date>
    <title>Vitae summa brevis spem nos vetat incohare longam.</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They are not long, the weeping and the laughter,</line>
      <line>Love and desire and hate:</line>
      <line>I think they have no portion in us after</line>
      <line>We pass the gate.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They are not long, the days of wine and roses:</line>
      <line>Out of a misty dream</line>
      <line>Our path emerges for a while, then closes</line>
      <line>Within a dream.</line>
      <line>(Wr. and pub. 1896)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1892</date>
    <title>Les Demoiselles de Sauve</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beautiful ladies through the orchard pass;</line>
      <line>Bend under crutched-up branches, forked and low;</line>
      <line>Trailing their samet palls o’er dew-drenched grass.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Pale blossoms, looking on proud Jacqueline,</line>
      <line>Blush to the colour of her finger tips,</line>
      <line>And rosy knuckles, laced with yellow lace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>High-crested Berthe discerns, with slant, clinched eyes,</line>
      <line>Amid the leaves pink faces of the skies;</line>
      <line>She locks her plaintive hands Sainte-Margot-wise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ysabeau follows last, with languorous pace;</line>
      <line>Presses, voluptuous, to her bursting lips,</line>
      <line>With backward stoop, a bunch of eglantine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Courtly ladies through the orchard pass;</line>
      <line>Bow low, as in lords’ halls; and springtime grass</line>
      <line>Tangles a snare to catch the tapering toe.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Wings in the Dark</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forth into the warm darkness faring wide—</line>
      <line>More silent momently the silent quay—</line>
      <line>Towards where the ranks of boats rock to the tide,</line>
      <line>Muffling their plaintive gurgling jealously.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With gentle nodding of her gracious snout,</line>
      <line>One greets her master till he step aboard;</line>
      <line>She flaps her wings impatient to get out;</line>
      <line>She runs to plunder, straining every cord.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full-winged and stealthy like a bird of prey,</line>
      <line>All tense the muscles of her seemly flanks;</line>
      <line>She, the coy creature that the idle day</line>
      <line>Sees idly riding in the idle ranks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Backward and forth, over the chosen ground,</line>
      <line>Like a young horse, she drags the heavy trawl</line>
      <line>Content; or speeds her rapturous course unbound,</line>
      <line>And passing fishers through the darkness call,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Deep greeting, in the jargon of the sea.</line>
      <line>Haul upon haul, flounders and soles and dabs,</line>
      <line>And phosphorescent animalculae,</line>
      <line>Sand, sea drift, weeds, thousands of worthless crabs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Darkling upon the mud the fishes grope,</line>
      <line>Cautious to stir, staring with jewel eyes;</line>
      <line>Dogs of the sea, the savage congers mope,</line>
      <line>Winding their sulky march meander-wise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Suddenly all is light and life and flight,</line>
      <line>Upon the sandy bottom, agate strewn.</line>
      <line>The fishers mumble, waiting till the night</line>
      <line>Urge on the clouds, and cover up the moon.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>The Barber</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I dreamed I was a barber; and there went</line>
      <line>Beneath my hand, oh! manes extravagant.</line>
      <line>Beneath my trembling fingers, many a mask</line>
      <line>Of many a pleasant girl. It was my task</line>
      <line>To gild their hair, carefully, strand by strand;</line>
      <line>To paint their eyebrows with a timid hand;</line>
      <line>To draw a bodkin, from a vase of kohl,</line>
      <line>Through the closed lashes; pencils from a bowl</line>
      <line>Of sepia to paint them underneath;</line>
      <line>To blow upon their eyes with a soft breath.</line>
      <line>They lay them back and watched the leaping bands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The dream grew vague. I moulded with my hands</line>
      <line>The mobile breasts, the valley; and the waist</line>
      <line>I touched; and pigments reverently placed</line>
      <line>Upon their thighs in sapient spots and stains,</line>
      <line>Beryls and crysolites and diaphanes,</line>
      <line>And gems whose hot harsh names are never said.</line>
      <line>I was a masseur; and my fingers bled</line>
      <line>With wonder as I touched their awful limbs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Suddenly, in the marble trough, there seems</line>
      <line>O, last of my pale mistresses, Sweetness!</line>
      <line>A twy-lipped scarlet pansie. My caress</line>
      <line>Tinges thy steelgray eyes to violet.</line>
      <line>Adown thy body skips the pit-a-pat</line>
      <line>Of treatment once heard in a hospital</line>
      <line>For plagues that fascinate, but half appal.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, at the sound, the blood of me stood cold.</line>
      <line>The chaste hair ripened into sullen gold.</line>
      <line>The throat, the shoulders, swelled and were uncouth.</line>
      <line>The breasts rose up and offered each a mouth.</line>
      <line>And on the belly pallid blushes crept,</line>
      <line>That maddened me, until I laughed and wept.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Mishka</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mishka is poet among the beasts.</line>
      <line>When roots are rotten, and rivers weep,</line>
      <line>The bear is at play in the land of sleep.</line>
      <line>Though his head be heavy between his fists.</line>
      <line>The bear is poet among the beasts.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Wide and large are the monster’s eyes,</line>
      <line>Nought saying, save one word alone:</line>
      <line>Mishka! Mishka, as turned to stone,</line>
      <line>Hears no word else, nor in anywise</line>
      <line>Can see aught save the monster’s eyes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Honey is under the monster’s lips;</line>
      <line>And Mishka follows into her lair,</line>
      <line>Dragged in the net of her yellow hair,</line>
      <line>Knowing all things when honey drips</line>
      <line>On his tongue like rain, the song of the hips</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of the honey-child, and of each twin mound.</line>
      <line>Mishka! there screamed a far bird-note,</line>
      <line>Deep in the sky, when round his throat</line>
      <line>The triple coil of her hair she wound.</line>
      <line>And stroked his limbs with a humming sound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mishka is white like a hunter’s son;</line>
      <line>For he knows no more of the ancient south</line>
      <line>When the honey-child’s lips are on his mouth,</line>
      <line>When all her kisses are joined in one,</line>
      <line>And his body is bathed in grass and sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shadows lie mauven beneath the trees,</line>
      <line>And purple stains, where the finches pass,</line>
      <line>Leap in the stalks of the deep, rank grass.</line>
      <line>Flutter of wing, and the buzz of bees,</line>
      <line>Deepen the silence, and sweeten ease.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The honey-child is an olive tree,</line>
      <line>The voice of birds and the voice of flowers,</line>
      <line>Each of them all and all the hours,</line>
      <line>The honey-child is a winged bee,</line>
      <line>Her touch is a perfume, a melody.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>The Vines</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Have you seen the listening snake?’</line>
      <line>Bramble clutches for his bride,</line>
      <line>Lately she was by his side,</line>
      <line>Woodbine, with her gummy hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the ground the mottled snake</line>
      <line>Listens for the dawn of day;</line>
      <line>Listens, listening death away,</line>
      <line>Till the day burst winter’s bands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Painted ivy is asleep,</line>
      <line>Stretched upon the bank, all tom,</line>
      <line>Sinewy though she be; love-lorn</line>
      <line>Convolvuluses cease to creep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Bramble clutches for his bride,</line>
      <line>Woodbine, with her gummy hands,</line>
      <line>All his horny claws expands;</line>
      <line>She has withered in his grasp.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘Till the day dawn, till the tide</line>
      <line>Of the winter’s afternoon.’</line>
      <line>‘Who tells dawning?’—‘Listen, soon.’</line>
      <line>Half-born tendrils, grasping, gasp.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Poem</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Geranium, houseleek, laid in oblong beds</line>
      <line>On the trim grass. The daisies’ leprous stain</line>
      <line>Is fresh. Each night the daisies burst again,</line>
      <line>Though every day the gardener crops their heads.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A wistful child, in foul unwholesome shreds,</line>
      <line>Recalls some legend of a daisy chain</line>
      <line>That makes a pretty necklace. She would fain</line>
      <line>Make one, and wear it, if she had some threads.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sun, leprous flowers, foul child. The asphalt burns,</line>
      <line>The garrulous sparrows perch on metal Burns.</line>
      <line>Sing! Sing! they say, and flutter with their wings.</line>
      <line>He does not sing, he only wonders why</line>
      <line>He is sitting there. The sparrows sing. And I</line>
      <line>Yield to the strait allure of simple things.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Spleen</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The roses every one were red,</line>
      <line>And all the ivy leaves were black.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sweet, do not even stir your head,</line>
      <line>Or all of my despairs come back.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sky is too blue, too delicate:</line>
      <line>Too soft the air, too green the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I fear—how long had I to wait!—</line>
      <line>That you will tear yourself from me.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shining box-leaves weary me,</line>
      <line>The varnished holly’s glistening,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The stretch of infinite country;</line>
      <line>So, saving you, does everything.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>Battledore</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sheltered garden sleeps among the tall</line>
      <line>Black poplars which grow round it, next the wall.</line>
      <line>The wall is very high, green grown on red.</line>
      <line>All is within, white convent, chapel, all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Slight supper past, the evening office said,</line>
      <line>Gardening tools locked up, the poultry fed,</line>
      <line>Little is done but lazy chaplets told,</line>
      <line>Weeds plucked, and garden calvaries visited.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some pace and stitch; some read in little, old,</line>
      <line>Worn, heavily bound missals, which they hold</line>
      <line>With both red hands, where lawns are foiled with flowers,</line>
      <line>Lily and Ladybell and Marygold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>This is the least unhushed of evening hours,</line>
      <line>When blessed peace best wears its dearest dowers;</line>
      <line>Quietly grouped are nuns and novices;</line>
      <line>Two tiny ladies play with battledores.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Drunk with the blows, unsteady with the whizz</line>
      <line>Of whirling flight, the shuttlecock seems,</line>
      <line>Alive and fluttering at each new shock.</line>
      <line>Sisters are drawing close by twos and threes.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Asthmatic mother, as the shuttlecock</line>
      <line>Flies straight at her, allows herself to knock</line>
      <line>It onward with her leaf fan, muttering,</line>
      <line>Half as excuse: ’Tis nearly nine o’clock.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>What better warrant for a foolish thing:</line>
      <line>With swift inventiveness the sisters bring</line>
      <line>Whatever light thing strikes; old copybooks</line>
      <line>Fulfil the purpose well. Such fluttering</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Within the convent walls the sober rooks</line>
      <line>Who live among the poplar branches—Sooks!—</line>
      <line>Had seldom seen. Now all the place prevails</line>
      <line>With cries and laughter to its furthest nooks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The novices and nuns catch up their tails,</line>
      <line>Better to bustle, darting till their veils</line>
      <line>Float back and tangle in the merry fuss,</line>
      <line>Till sombre weeds swell out like lusty sails....</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Peace, croaks the mother, Peace, the angelus!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>They say, in other days,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say, in other days,</line>
      <line>When Jove in Heaven, and Pluto ruled in Hell,</line>
      <line>Man, walking in a haze,</line>
      <line>Exceeding good, or did exceeding ill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So, when he came to Dis,</line>
      <line>And man must face his three infernal judges,</line>
      <line>Having greatly done amiss,</line>
      <line>The devils grin, and fellow fellow nudges.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say that many a prince</line>
      <line>Came with such load of crime upon his back,</line>
      <line>That Tartarus would rinse</line>
      <line>His jaws, that Hell would shudder and be black.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>First Abacus would hear the tale</line>
      <line>Against the sinner of his sin,</line>
      <line>And for a pain condemn the pale</line>
      <line>Ghost to the lower court, wherein</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Dread Minos gave a like award,</line>
      <line>And sent him Rhadamanthusward.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There was no pain for man that Hell could reach</line>
      <line>Like this pain. Yet the devils would beseech</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Their master, and entreat the Dreadful One</line>
      <line>To judge as strangely as the thing was done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Pluto judged; that is to say, his face was bare;</line>
      <line>Whereof I may not tell if it were harsh or fair;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But this I may: a man might howl a space</line>
      <line>Of many years who once had seen his face.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>Tobias and the Angel</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tobias, journeying to Ecbatane,</line>
      <line>Takes with him Azarias as he fares,</line>
      <line>Which is an angel, serving unawares,</line>
      <line>To guide and bring him to his house again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Raphael walks mid-picture, sandal-shod;</line>
      <line>Three fingers in three fingers leads the boy;</line>
      <line>Holding sweet speech, the distance to employ;</line>
      <line>The little curly dog sniffs out his road.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tobias, jerkined, belted, simply cloaked,</line>
      <line>With naked shanks, except for limp-legged boots</line>
      <line>Against rough stones or harsh and prickly roots,</line>
      <line>Bareheaded, querulous and wonderlooked.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Glorious archangel, Medicine of God,</line>
      <line>Kind courier, peacock-plumed thy pinions be,</line>
      <line>Sign of thine ancient immortality,</line>
      <line>Folded for fare on mortal stone and sod.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy glory floats and glints twixt hair and wing;</line>
      <line>Thou wearest man’s attention on thy face;</line>
      <line>Though somewhat else Tobias doth half trace</line>
      <line>Therein, whiles thou art wise of trafficking.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Tobias bears his fish, and neatly slung,</line>
      <line>Lest its scales soil, or it should leave a reek;</line>
      <line>Raphael the gall, old Tobit’s eyes being sick,</line>
      <line>By sparrows’ hospitality quick stung.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hard to each hand, Tobias doth not see</line>
      <line>Great Michael, armed and exquisite, alert,</line>
      <line>The prince, the Warrior, lest any hurt;</line>
      <line>Lest Asmodeus lurk to thwart, walks he.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And gentle Gabriel, the ambassador;</line>
      <line>His arm a lily-stalk, with triple bloom,</line>
      <line>And three locked lilies (tidings yet to come).</line>
      <line>One with an angel maketh one of four.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Much sky and little earth complete arrear,</line>
      <line>Tree-fledged and island-strawn, the Tigris, bland,</line>
      <line>Creeps lower. (Pilgrims trudge on mountain land.)</line>
      <line>Flower and thorn and stone are frequent near.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hasting to speed thy marriage, thou and he,</line>
      <line>Tobias, hardly yet at man’s first scope,</line>
      <line>Sprung of staunch kindliness and godly hope,</line>
      <line>Brought up and nourished in captivity.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Forth from the river, come to take thy bath,</line>
      <line>Leaped fleshly passion, eager to devour;</line>
      <line>‘Seize him,’ the angel said; and in that hour</line>
      <line>Slit out his gall, his lust, his bilious wrath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To medicine the gall at bidding turned</line>
      <line>Of him who leadeth thee; the heart laid by;</line>
      <line>The liver too, to purpose presently,</line>
      <line>To fright the demon, being spoiled & burned.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Mark how Tobias, setting out for gain,</line>
      <line>Under the angel guidance halts halfway</line>
      <line>For greater gain; the guide resumes the way,</line>
      <line>Wise and alone, to spare his ward the pain.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He sees in Azarias one of his tribe,</line>
      <line>A man discreet and just, but hired for wages</line>
      <line>To bring him into Media, to Rages;</line>
      <line>Back to the city of Sennacherib.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of Raphael’s work, and how he handled it,</line>
      <line>With fish’s gall how he gave Tobit sight,</line>
      <line>Purgation of the demon-haunted night,</line>
      <line>Is written in the book which Tobit writ.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All things being done, and done exceeding well,</line>
      <line>The guide replied to him, when said Tobias:</line>
      <line>‘Give we the half of gain to Azarias:’</line>
      <line>‘Call me not so, my name is Raphael.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>There liveth no Tobias graced with power</line>
      <line>To take angelic counsel, to uproot</line>
      <line>Swarth lust, meek purity to substitute,</line>
      <line>But meets the angel in the proper hour.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>The Flying Fish</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Myself am Hang the buccaneer,</line>
      <line>whom children love and brave men fear,</line>
      <line>master of courage, come what come,</line>
      <line>master of craft, and called Sea-scum;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>student of wisdom and waterways,</line>
      <line>course of moons and the birth of days;</line>
      <line>to him in whose heart all things be</line>
      <line>I bring my story of the sea.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The same am I as that sleek Hang</line>
      <line>whose pattens along the stone quay clang</line>
      <line>in sailing time, whose pile is high</line>
      <line>on the beach when merchants come to buy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Am he who cumbers his lowly hulk</line>
      <line>with refuse bundles of feeble bulk;</line>
      <line>turns sailor’s eyes to the weather skies;</line>
      <line>bows low to the Master of Merchandise;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>who hoists his sails with the broken slats;</line>
      <line>whose lean crew are scarcely food for his rats;</line>
      <line>am he who creeps from tower-top ken</line>
      <line>and utmost vision of all men:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>ah then, am he who changeth line,</line>
      <line>and which man knoweth that course of mine?</line>
      <line>Am he, sir Sage, who sails to the sea</line>
      <line>where an island and other wonders be.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>After six days we sight the coast,</line>
      <line>and my palace top, should a sailor boast;</line>
      <line>sails rattle down; and then we ride,</line>
      <line>mean junk and proud, by my palace side.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For there lives a junk in that ancient sea</line>
      <line>where the gardens of Hang and his palace be,</line>
      <line>o my fair junk! which once aboard</line>
      <line>the pirate owns no living lord.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Its walls are painted water-green</line>
      <line>like the green sea’s self, both shade and sheen,</line>
      <line>lest any mark it. The pirate’s trade</line>
      <line>is to hover swiftly and make afraid.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Its sails are fashioned of lithe bamboo,</line>
      <line>all painted blue as the sky is blue,</line>
      <line>so it be not seen till the prey be nigh.</line>
      <line>Hang loves not that the same should fly.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In midst of the first a painted sun</line>
      <line>gleams gold like the celestial yon;</line>
      <line>in midst of the second a tender moon,</line>
      <line>that a lover might kiss his flute and swoon;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>or maid touch lute at sight of the third,</line>
      <line>pictured with all the crystal herd;</line>
      <line>so the silly ships are mazed at sight</line>
      <line>of night by day and day by night.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For wind and water a goodlier junk</line>
      <line>than any that ever sailed or sunk;</line>
      <line>which junk was theirs; none fiercer than</line>
      <line>my fathers since the fall of man.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>So cotton rags lays Hang aside:</line>
      <line>lays bare the sailor’s gristly hide;</line>
      <line>and wraps his body in vests of silk;</line>
      <line>ilk is as beautiful as ilk.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Then Hang puts on his ancient mail,</line>
      <line>silver and black, and scale on scale</line>
      <line>like dragons’, which his grandsire bore</line>
      <line>before him, and his grandsire before.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He binds his legs with buskins grim,</line>
      <line>tawny and gold for the pride of him;</line>
      <line>his feet are bare like his who quelled</line>
      <line>the dragon, his feet are feet of eld.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His head is brave with a lacquered casque,</line>
      <line>the donning which is a heavy task;</line>
      <line>its flaps are feathered like Yuen Yin;</line>
      <line>’tis strapped with straps of tiger-skin.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The passions of his fathers whelm</line>
      <line>the heart of Hang when he wears their helm.</line>
      <line>Then Hang grows wrinkled betwixt his eyes;</line>
      <line>he frowns like a devil, devil-wise;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>his eyeballs start; his mask is red</line>
      <line>like his who at last shall judge the dead;</line>
      <line>his nostrils gape; his mouth is the mouth</line>
      <line>of the fish that swims in the torrid south;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>his beard the pirate Hang lets flow;</line>
      <line>he lays his hand on his father’s bow,</line>
      <line>wherewith a cunning man of strength</line>
      <line>might shoot an arrow the vessel’s length.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have another of sun-red lac,</line>
      <line>of a great man’s height, so the string be slack;</line>
      <line>the charge departs with a fiery clang;</line>
      <line>’tis drawn with the foot, the foot of Hang.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such house and harness become me, when</line>
      <line>I wait upon laden merchantmen;</line>
      <line>’Twixt tears and the sea, ’twixt brine and brine,</line>
      <line>they shudder at sight of me and mine.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of the birds that fly in the farthest sea</line>
      <line>six are stranger than others be:</line>
      <line>under its tumble, among the fish,</line>
      <line>six are a marvel passing wish.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>First is a hawk, exceeding great;</line>
      <line>he dwelleth alone; he hath no mate;</line>
      <line>his neck is wound with a yellow ring;</line>
      <line>on his breast is the crest of a former king.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The second bird is exceeding pale,</line>
      <line>from little head to scanty tail;</line>
      <line>she is striped with black on either wing,</line>
      <line>which is rose-lined, like a princely thing.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Though small the bulk of the brilliant third,</line>
      <line>of all blue birds ’tis the bluest bird;</line>
      <line>they fly in bands; and, seen by day,</line>
      <line>by the side of them the sky is grey.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I mind the fifth, I forget the fourth,</line>
      <line>unless that it comes from the east by north.</line>
      <line>The fifth is an orange white-billed duck;</line>
      <line>he diveth for fish, like the god of Luck;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>he hath never a foot on which to stand;</line>
      <line>for water yields and he loves not land.</line>
      <line>This is the end of many words</line>
      <line>save one, concerning marvellous birds.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The great-faced dolphin is first of fish;</line>
      <line>he is devil-eyed and devilish;</line>
      <line>of all the fishes is he most brave,</line>
      <line>he walks the sea like an angry wave.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The second the fishes call their lord;</line>
      <line>himself a bow, his face is a sword;</line>
      <line>his sword is armed with a hundred teeth,</line>
      <line>fifty above and fifty beneath.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The third hath a scarlet suit of mail;</line>
      <line>the fourth is naught but a feeble tail;</line>
      <line>the fifth is a whip with a hundred strands,</line>
      <line>and every arm hath a hundred hands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The last strange fish is the last strange bird;</line>
      <line>Of him no sage hath ever heard;</line>
      <line>he roams the sea in a gleaming horde</line>
      <line>in fear of the dolphin and him of the sword.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He leaps from the sea with a silken swish;</line>
      <line>he beats the air does the flying fish.</line>
      <line>His eyes are round with excess of fright,</line>
      <line>bright as the drops of his pinions’ flight.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
