      <line>In sea and sky he hath no peace;</line>
      <line>for the five strange fish are his enemies;</line>
      <line>and the five strange fowls keep watch for him;</line>
      <line>they know him well by his crystal gleam.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oftwhiles, sir Sage, on my junk’s white deck</line>
      <line>have I seen this fish-bird come to wreck,</line>
      <line>oftwhiles (fair deck) ’twixt bow and poop</line>
      <line>have I seen this piteous sky-fish stoop.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Scaled bird, how his snout and gills dilate,</line>
      <line>all quivering and roseate:</line>
      <line>he pants in crystal and mother-of-pearl</line>
      <line>while his body shrinks and his pinions furl.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His beauty passes like bubbles blown;</line>
      <line>the white bright bird is a fish of stone;</line>
      <line>the bird so fair, for its putrid sake,</line>
      <line>is flung to the dogs in the junk’s white wake.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Have thought, son Pirate, some such must be</line>
      <line>as the beast thou namest in yonder sea;</line>
      <line>else, bring me a symbol from nature’s gear</line>
      <line>of aspiration born of fear.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hast been, my son, to the doctor’s booth</line>
      <line>some day when Hang had a qualm to soothe?</line>
      <line>Hast noted the visible various sign</line>
      <line>Of each flask’s virtue, son of mine?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Rude picture of insect seldom found,</line>
      <line>of plant that thrives in marshy ground,</line>
      <line>goblin of east wind, fog or draught,</line>
      <line>sign of the phial’s potent craft?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis even thus where the drug is sense,</line>
      <line>where wisdom is more than frankincense,</line>
      <line>wit’s grain than a pound of pounded bones,</line>
      <line>where knowledge is redder than ruby stones.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Hast thou marked how poppies are sign of sin?</line>
      <line>how bravery’s mantle is tiger-skin?</line>
      <line>how earth is heavy and dumb with care?</line>
      <line>how song is the speech of all the air?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A tree is the sign most whole and sure</line>
      <line>of aspiration plain and pure;</line>
      <line>of the variation one must wend</line>
      <line>in search of the sign to the sea’s wild end.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Thy fish is the fairest of all that be</line>
      <line>in the throbbing depths of yonder sea.</line>
      <line>He says in his iridescent heart:</line>
      <line>I am gorgeous-eyed and a fish apart;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>my back hath the secret of every shell,</line>
      <line>the Hang of fishes knoweth well;</line>
      <line>scales of my breast are softer still,</line>
      <line>the ugly fishes devise my ill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He prays the Maker of water-things</line>
      <line>not for a sword, but cricket’s wings,</line>
      <line>not to be one of the sons of air,</line>
      <line>to be rid of the water is all his prayer;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>all his hope is a fear-whipped whim;</line>
      <line>all directions are one to him.</line>
      <line>There are seekers of wisdom no less absurd,</line>
      <line>son Hang, than thy fish that would be a bird.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Gray</author>
    <date>1897</date>
    <title>On the South Coast of Cornwall</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>There lives a land beside the western sea</line>
      <line>The sea-salt makes not barren, for its hills</line>
      <line>Laugh even in winter time; the bubbly rills</line>
      <line>Dance down their grades, and fill with melody</line>
      <line>The fishers’ hearts; for these, where’er they be,</line>
      <line>Sing out salt choruses; the land-breeze fills</line>
      <line>Their sweetened lungs with wine which it distils</line>
      <line>From emerald fat field and gorse gold lea.</line>
      <line>Like a thrown net leans out the ample bay.</line>
      <line>The fishers’ huddled cabins crowd and wedge,</line>
      <line>Greedy, against the rugged treacherous edge</line>
      <line>Of their great liquid mine renewed alway.</line>
      <line>The fishers have no thought but of the strong</line>
      <line>Sea, whence their food, their crisp hair, and their song.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Michael Field</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Cyclamens</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>They are terribly white:</line>
      <line>There is snow on the ground,</line>
      <line>And a moon on the snow at night;</line>
      <line>The sky is cut by the winter light;</line>
      <line>Yet I, who have all these things in ken,</line>
      <line>Am struck to the heart by the chiselled white</line>
      <line>Of this handful of cyclamen.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Michael Field</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Noon</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Full summer and at noon; from a waste bed</line>
      <line>Convolvulus, musk-mallow, poppies spread</line>
      <line>The triumph of the sunshine overhead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Blue on refulgent ash-trees lies the heat;</line>
      <line>It tingles on the hedge-rows; the young wheat</line>
      <line>Sleeps, warm in golden verdure, at my feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The pale, sweet grasses of the hayfield blink;</line>
      <line>The heath-moors, as the bees of honey drink,</line>
      <line>Suck the deep bosom of the day. To think</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Of all that beauty by the light defined</line>
      <line>None shares my vision! Sharply on my mind</line>
      <line>Presses the sorrow: fern and flower are blind.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Davidson</author>
    <date>1894</date>
    <title>Thirty Bob a Week</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>I couldn’t touch a stop and turn a screw,</line>
      <line>And set the blooming world a-work for me,</line>
      <line>Like such as cut their teeth—I hope, like you—</line>
      <line>On the handle of a skeleton gold key;</line>
      <line>I cut mine on a leek, which I eat it every week:</line>
      <line>I’m a clerk at thirty bob as you can see.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But I don’t allow it’s luck and all a toss;</line>
      <line>There’s no such thing as being starred and crossed;</line>
      <line>It’s just the power of some to be a boss,</line>
      <line>And the bally power of others to be bossed:</line>
      <line>I face the music, sir; you bet I ain’t a cur;</line>
      <line>Strike me lucky if I don’t believe I’m lost!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For like a mole I journey in the dark,</line>
      <line>A-travelling along the underground</line>
      <line>From my Pillar’d Halls and broad Suburbean Park,</line>
      <line>To come the daily dull official round;</line>
      <line>And home again at night with my pipe all alight,</line>
      <line>A-scheming how to count ten bob a pound.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And it’s often very cold and very wet,</line>
      <line>And my missis stitches towels for a hunks;</line>
      <line>And the Pillar’d Halls is half of it to let—</line>
      <line>Three rooms about the size of travelling trunks.</line>
      <line>And we cough, my wife and I, to dislocate a sigh,</line>
      <line>When the noisy little kids are in their bunks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But you never hear her do a growl or whine,</line>
      <line>For she’s made of flint and roses, very odd;</line>
      <line>And I’ve got to cut my meaning rather fine,</line>
      <line>Or I’d blubber, for I’m made of greens and sod:</line>
      <line>So p’r’aps we are in Hell for all that I can tell,</line>
      <line>And lost and damn’d and served up hot to God.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I ain’t blaspheming, Mr Silver-tongue;</line>
      <line>I’m saying things a bit beyond your art:</line>
      <line>Of all the rummy starts you ever sprung,</line>
      <line>Thirty bob a week’s the rummiest start!</line>
      <line>With your science and your books and your the’ries about spooks,</line>
      <line>Did you ever hear of looking in your heart?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I didn’t mean your pocket, Mr, no:</line>
      <line>I mean that having children and a wife,</line>
      <line>With thirty bob on which to come and go,</line>
      <line>Isn’t dancing to the tabor and the fife:</line>
      <line>When it doesn’t make you drink, by Heaven! it makes you think,</line>
      <line>And notice curious items about life.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I step into my heart and there I meet</line>
      <line>A god-almighty devil singing small,</line>
      <line>Who would like to shout and whistle in the street,</line>
      <line>And squelch the passers flat against the wall;</line>
      <line>If the whole world was a cake he had the power to take,</line>
      <line>He would take it, ask for more, and eat them all.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And I meet a sort of simpleton beside,</line>
      <line>The kind that life is always giving beans;</line>
      <line>With thirty bob a week to keep a bride</line>
      <line>He fell in love and married in his teens:</line>
      <line>At thirty bob he stuck; but he knows it isn’t luck:</line>
      <line>He knows the seas are deeper than tureens.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And the god-almighty devil and the fool</line>
      <line>That meet me in the High Street on the strike,</line>
      <line>When I walk about my heart a-gathering wool,</line>
      <line>Are my good and evil angels if you like.</line>
      <line>And both of them together in every kind of weather</line>
      <line>Ride me like a double-seated bike.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That’s rough a bit and needs its meaning curled.</line>
      <line>But I have a high old hot un in my mind—</line>
      <line>A most engrugious notion of the world,</line>
      <line>That leaves your lightning ’rithmetic behind:</line>
      <line>I give it at a glance when I say ‘There ain’t no chance,</line>
      <line>Nor nothing of the lucky-lottery kind.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And it’s this way that I make it out to be:</line>
      <line>No fathers, mothers, countries, climates—none;</line>
      <line>No Adam was responsible for me,</line>
      <line>Nor society, nor systems, nary one:</line>
      <line>A little sleeping seed, I woke—I did, indeed—</line>
      <line>A million years before the blooming sun.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I woke because I thought the time had come;</line>
      <line>Beyond my will there was no other cause;</line>
      <line>And everywhere I found myself at home,</line>
      <line>Because I chose to be the thing I was;</line>
      <line>And in whatever shape of mollusc or of ape</line>
      <line>I always went according to the laws.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I was the love that chose my mother out;</line>
      <line>I joined two lives and from the union burst;</line>
      <line>My weakness and my strength without a doubt</line>
      <line>Are mine alone for ever from the first:</line>
      <line>It’s just the very same with a difference in the name</line>
      <line>As ‘Thy will be done.’ You say it if you durst!</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>They say it daily up and down the land</line>
      <line>As easy as you take a drink, it’s true;</line>
      <line>But the difficultest go to understand,</line>
      <line>And the difficultest job a man can do,</line>
      <line>Is to come it brave and meek with thirty bob a week,</line>
      <line>And feel that that’s the proper thing for you.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It’s a naked child against a hungry wolf;</line>
      <line>It’s playing bowls upon a splitting wreck;</line>
      <line>It’s walking on a string across a gulf</line>
      <line>With millstones fore-and-aft about your neck;</line>
      <line>But the thing is daily done by many and many a one;</line>
      <line>And we fall, face forward, fighting, on the deck.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>John Davidson</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>A Northern Suburb</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Nature selects the longest way,</line>
      <line>And winds about in tortuous grooves;</line>
      <line>A thousand years the oaks decay;</line>
      <line>The wrinkled glacier hardly moves.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But here the whetted fangs of change</line>
      <line>Daily devour the old demesne—</line>
      <line>The busy farm, the quiet grange,</line>
      <line>The wayside inn, the village green.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In gaudy yellow brick and red,</line>
      <line>With rooting pipes, like creepers rank,</line>
      <line>The shoddy terraces o’erspread</line>
      <line>Meadow, and garth, and daisied bank.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With shelves for rooms the houses crowd,</line>
      <line>Like draughty cupboards in a row—</line>
      <line>Ice-chests when wintry winds are loud,</line>
      <line>Ovens when summer breezes blow.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Roused by the fee’d policeman’s knock,</line>
      <line>And sad that day should come again,</line>
      <line>Under the stars the workmen flock</line>
      <line>In haste to reach the workmen’s train.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For here dwell those who must fulfil</line>
      <line>Dull tasks in uncongenial spheres,</line>
      <line>Who toil through dread of coming ill,</line>
      <line>And not with hope of happier years—</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lowly folk who scarcely dare</line>
      <line>Conceive themselves perhaps misplaced,</line>
      <line>Whose prize for unremitting care</line>
      <line>Is only not to be disgraced.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Mary E. Coleridge</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>An Insincere Wish Addressed to a Beggar</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>We are not near enough to love,</line>
      <line>I can but pity all your woe;</line>
      <line>For wealth has lifted me above,</line>
      <line>And falsehood set you down below.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If you were true, we still might be</line>
      <line>Brothers in something more than name;</line>
      <line>And were I poor, your love to me</line>
      <line>Would make our differing bonds the same.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But golden gates between us stretch,</line>
      <line>Truth opens her forbidding eyes;</line>
      <line>You can’t forget that I am rich,</line>
      <line>Nor I that you are telling lies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Love never comes but at love’s call,</line>
      <line>And pity asks for him in vain;</line>
      <line>Because I cannot give you all,</line>
      <line>You give me nothing back again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And you are right with all your wrong,</line>
      <line>For less than all is nothing too;</line>
      <line>May Heaven beggar me ere long,</line>
      <line>And Truth reveal herself to you!</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Mary E. Coleridge</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>The Nurse's Lament</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The flower is withered on the stem,</line>
      <line>The fruit hath fallen from the bough.</line>
      <line>None knows nor thinks of them.</line>
      <line>There’s no child in the house now.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The bird that sang sings not here.</line>
      <line>Where is the bonny lark?</line>
      <line>When shall I behold my dear?</line>
      <line>The fire is out, the house dark.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Aubrey Beardsley</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The Three Musicians</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Along the path that skirts the wood,</line>
      <line>The three musicians wend their way,</line>
      <line>Pleased with their thoughts, each other’s mood,</line>
      <line>Franz Himmel’s latest roundelay,</line>
      <line>The morning’s work, a new-found theme, their breakfast and the summer day.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>One’s a soprano, lightly frocked</line>
      <line>In cool, white muslin that just shows</line>
      <line>Her brown silk stockings gaily clocked,</line>
      <line>Plump arms and elbows tipped with rose,</line>
      <line>And frills of petticoats and things, and outlines as the warm wind blows.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Beside her a slim, gracious boy</line>
      <line>Hastens to mend her tresses’ fall,</line>
      <line>And dies her favour to enjoy,</line>
      <line>And dies for reclame and recall</line>
      <line>At Paris and St Petersburg, Vienna and St James’s Hall.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The third’s a Polish Pianist</line>
      <line>With big engagements everywhere,</line>
      <line>A light heart and an iron wrist,</line>
      <line>And shocks and shoals of yellow hair,</line>
      <line>And fingers that can trill on sixths and fill beginners with despair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The three musicians stroll along</line>
      <line>And pluck the ears of ripened corn,</line>
      <line>Break into odds and ends of song,</line>
      <line>And mock the woods with Siegfried’s horn,</line>
      <line>And fill the air with Gluck, and fill the tweeded tourist’s soul with scorn.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Polish genius lags behind,</line>
      <line>And, with some poppies in his hand,</line>
      <line>Picks out the strings and wood and wind</line>
      <line>Of an imaginary band,</line>
      <line>Enchanted that for once his men obey his beat and understand.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The charming cantatrice reclines</line>
      <line>And rests a moment where she sees</line>
      <line>Her chateau’s roof that hotly shines</line>
      <line>Amid the dusky summer trees,</line>
      <line>And fans herself, half shuts her eyes, and smoothes the frock about her knees.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The gracious boy is at her feet,</line>
      <line>And weighs his courage with his chance;</line>
      <line>His fears soon melt in noonday heat.</line>
      <line>The tourist gives a furious glance,</line>
      <line>Red as his guide-book grows, moves on, and offers up a prayer for France.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Aubrey Beardsley</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>The Ballad of a Barber</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here is the tale of Carrousel,</line>
      <line>The barber of Meridian Street.</line>
      <line>He cut, and coiffed, and shaved so well,</line>
      <line>That all the world was at his feet.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The King, the Queen, and all the Court,</line>
      <line>To no one else would trust their hair,</line>
      <line>And reigning belles of every sort</line>
      <line>Owed their successes to his care.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>With carriage and with cabriolet</line>
      <line>Daily Meridian Street was blocked,</line>
      <line>Like bees about a bright bouquet</line>
      <line>The beaux about his doorway flocked.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Such was his art he could with ease</line>
      <line>Curl wit into the dullest face;</line>
      <line>Or to a goddess of old Greece</line>
      <line>Add a new wonder and a grace.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>All powders, paints, and subtle dyes,</line>
      <line>And costliest scents that men distil,</line>
      <line>And rare pomades, forgot their price</line>
      <line>And marvelled at his splendid skill.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The curling irons in his hand</line>
      <line>Almost grew quick enough to speak,</line>
      <line>The razor was a magic wand</line>
      <line>That understood the softest cheek.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yet with no pride his heart was moved;</line>
      <line>He was so modest in his ways!</line>
      <line>His dainty task was all he loved,</line>
      <line>And now and then a little praise.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>An equal care he would bestow</line>
      <line>On problems simple or complex;</line>
      <line>And nobody had seen him show</line>
      <line>A preference for either sex.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>How came it then one sunny day,</line>
      <line>Coiffing the daughter of the King,</line>
      <line>He lengthened out the least delay</line>
      <line>And loitered in his hairdressing?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Princess was a pretty child,</line>
      <line>Thirteen years old, or thereabout.</line>
      <line>She was as joyous and as wild</line>
      <line>As spring flowers when the sun is out.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her gold hair fell down to her feet</line>
      <line>And hung about her pretty eyes;</line>
      <line>She was as lyrical and sweet</line>
      <line>As one of Schubert’s melodies.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Three times the barber curled a lock,</line>
      <line>And thrice he straightened it again;</line>
      <line>And twice the irons scorched her frock,</line>
      <line>And twice he stumbled in her train.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>His fingers lost their cunning quite,</line>
      <line>His ivory combs obeyed no more;</line>
      <line>Something or other dimmed his sight,</line>
      <line>And moved mysteriously the floor.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He leant upon the toilet table,</line>
      <line>His fingers fumbled in his breast;</line>
      <line>He felt as foolish as a fable,</line>
      <line>And feeble as a pointless jest.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He snatched a bottle of Cologne,</line>
      <line>And broke the neck between his hands;</line>
      <line>He felt as if he was alone,</line>
      <line>And mighty as a king’s commands.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Princess gave a little scream,</line>
      <line>Carrousel’s cut was sharp and deep;</line>
      <line>He left her softly as a dream</line>
      <line>That leaves a sleeper to his sleep.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>He left the room on pointed feet;</line>
      <line>Smiling that things had gone so well.</line>
      <line>They hanged him in Meridian Street.</line>
      <line>You pray in vain for Carrousel.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL I</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>From Clee to heaven the beacon burns,</line>
      <line>The shires have seen it plain,</line>
      <line>From north and south the sign returns</line>
      <line>And beacons burn again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Look left, look right, the hills are bright,</line>
      <line>The dales are light between,</line>
      <line>Because ’tis fifty years to-night</line>
      <line>That God has saved the Queen.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, when the flame they watch not towers</line>
      <line>About the soil they trod,</line>
      <line>Lads, we’ll remember friends of ours</line>
      <line>Who shared the work with God.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To skies that knit their heartstrings right,</line>
      <line>To fields that bred them brave,</line>
      <line>The saviours come not home to-night:</line>
      <line>Themselves they could not save.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>It dawns in Asia, tombstones show</line>
      <line>And Shropshire names are read;</line>
      <line>And the Nile spills his overflow</line>
      <line>Beside the Severn’s dead.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>We pledge in peace by farm and town</line>
      <line>The Queen they served in war,</line>
      <line>And fire the beacons up and down</line>
      <line>The land they perished for.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>‘God save the Queen’ we living sing,</line>
      <line>From height to height ’tis heard;</line>
      <line>And with the rest your voices ring,</line>
      <line>Lads of the Fifty-third.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh, God will save her, fear you not:</line>
      <line>Be you the men you’ve been,</line>
      <line>Get you the sons your fathers got,</line>
      <line>And God will save the Queen.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL XII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When I watch the living meet,</line>
      <line>And the moving pageant file</line>
      <line>Warm and breathing through the street</line>
      <line>Where I lodge a little while,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If the heats of hate and lust</line>
      <line>In the house of flesh are strong,</line>
      <line>Let me mind the house of dust</line>
      <line>Where my sojourn shall be long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In the nation that is not</line>
      <line>Nothing stands that stood before;</line>
      <line>There revenges are forgot,</line>
      <line>And the hater hates no more;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Lovers lying two and two</line>
      <line>Ask not whom they sleep beside,</line>
      <line>And the bridegroom all night through</line>
      <line>Never turns him to the bride.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL XVI</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>It nods and curtseys and recovers</line>
      <line>When the wind blows above,</line>
      <line>The nettle on the graves of lovers</line>
      <line>That hanged themselves for love.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The nettle nods, the wind blows over,</line>
      <line>The man, he does not move,</line>
      <line>The lover of the grave, the lover</line>
      <line>That hanged himself for love.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL XXX</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Others, I am not the first,</line>
      <line>Have willed more mischief than they durst:</line>
      <line>If in the breathless night I too</line>
      <line>Shiver now, ’tis nothing new.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>More than I, if truth were told,</line>
      <line>Have stood and sweated hot and cold,</line>
      <line>And through their reins in ice and fire</line>
      <line>Fear contended with desire.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Agued once like me were they,</line>
      <line>But I like them shall win my way</line>
      <line>Lastly to the bed of mould</line>
      <line>Where there’s neither heat nor cold.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>But from my grave across my brow</line>
      <line>Plays no wind of healing now,</line>
      <line>And fire and ice within me fight</line>
      <line>Beneath the suffocating night.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL XL</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Into my heart an air that kills</line>
      <line>From yon far country blows:</line>
      <line>What are those blue remembered hills,</line>
      <line>What spires, what farms are those?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>That is the land of lost content,</line>
      <line>I see it shining plain,</line>
      <line>The happy highways where I went</line>
      <line>And cannot come again.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL XLVIII</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Be still, my soul, be still; the arms you bear are brittle,</line>
      <line>Earth and high heaven are fixt of old and founded strong.</line>
      <line>Think rather,—call to thought, if now you grieve a little,</line>
      <line>The days when we had rest, O soul, for they were long.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Men loved unkindness then, but lightless in the quarry</line>
      <line>I slept and saw not; tears fell down, I did not mourn;</line>
      <line>Sweat ran and blood sprang out and I was never sorry:</line>
      <line>Then it was well with me, in days ere I was born.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now, and I muse for why and never find the reason,</line>
      <line>I pace the earth, and drink the air, and feel the sun.</line>
      <line>Be still, be still, my soul; it is but for a season:</line>
      <line>Let us endure an hour and see injustice done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Ay, look: high heaven and earth ail from the prime foundation;</line>
      <line>All thoughts to rive the heart are here, and all are vain:</line>
      <line>Horror and scorn and hate and fear and indignation—</line>
      <line>Oh why did I awake? when shall I sleep again?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>ASL LX</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now hollow fires burn out to black,</line>
      <line>And lights are guttering low:</line>
      <line>Square your shoulders, lift your pack,</line>
      <line>And leave your friends and go.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh never fear, man, nought’s to dread,</line>
      <line>Look not left nor right:</line>
      <line>In all the endless road you tread</line>
      <line>There’s nothing but the night.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1893</date>
    <title>Because I liked you better</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Because I liked you better</line>
      <line>Than suits a man to say,</line>
      <line>It irked you, and I promised</line>
      <line>To throw the thought away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>To put the world between us</line>
      <line>We parted, stiff and dry;</line>
      <line>‘Good-bye’, said you, ‘forget me.’</line>
      <line>‘I will, no fear’, said I.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>If here, where clover whitens</line>
      <line>The dead man’s knoll, you pass,</line>
      <line>And no tall flower to meet you</line>
      <line>Starts in the trefoiled grass,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Halt by the headstone naming</line>
      <line>The heart no longer stirred,</line>
      <line>And say the lad that loved you</line>
      <line>Was one that kept his word.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>Her strong enchantments failing,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Her strong enchantments failing,</line>
      <line>Her towers of fear in wreck,</line>
      <line>Her limbecks dried of poisons</line>
      <line>And the knife at her neck,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The Queen of air and darkness</line>
      <line>Begins to shrill and cry,</line>
      <line>‘O young man, O my slayer,</line>
      <line>To-morrow you shall die.’</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>O Queen of air and darkness,</line>
      <line>I think ’tis truth you say,</line>
      <line>And I shall die to-morrow;</line>
      <line>But you will die to-day.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>Yonder see the morning blink:</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Yonder see the morning blink:</line>
      <line>The sun is up, and up must I,</line>
      <line>To wash and dress and eat and drink</line>
      <line>And look at things and talk and think</line>
      <line>And work, and God knows why.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh often have I washed and dressed</line>
      <line>And what’s to show for all my pain?</line>
      <line>Let me lie abed and rest:</line>
      <line>Ten thousand times I’ve done my best</line>
      <line>And all’s to do again.</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1895; pub. 1922)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1895</date>
    <title>Oh who is that young sinner</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh who is that young sinner with the handcuffs on his wrists?</line>
      <line>And what has he been after that they groan and shake their fists?</line>
      <line>And wherefore is he wearing such a conscience-stricken air?</line>
      <line>Oh they’re taking him to prison for the colour of his hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>’Tis a shame to human nature, such a head of hair as his;</line>
      <line>In the good old time ’twas hanging for the colour that it is;</line>
      <line>Though hanging isn’t bad enough and flaying would be fair</line>
      <line>For the nameless and abominable colour of his hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Oh a deal of pains he’s taken and a pretty price he’s paid</line>
      <line>To hide his poll or dye it of a mentionable shade;</line>
      <line>But they’ve pulled the beggar’s hat off for the world to see and stare,</line>
      <line>And they’re haling him to justice for the colour of his hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Now ’tis oakum for his fingers and the treadmill for his feet</line>
      <line>And the quarry-gang on Portland in the cold and in the heat,</line>
      <line>And between his spells of labour in the time he has to spare</line>
      <line>He can curse the God that made him for the colour of his hair.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>Here dead lie we</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Here dead lie we because we did not choose</line>
      <line>To live and shame the land from which we sprung.</line>
      <line>Life, to be sure, is nothing much to lose,</line>
      <line>But young men think it is, and we were young.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>When the bells justle</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the bells justle in the tower</line>
      <line>The hollow night amid,</line>
      <line>Then on my tongue the taste is sour</line>
      <line>Of all I ever did.</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1895-1900?; pub. 1930)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>The laws of God</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The laws of God, the laws of man,</line>
      <line>He may keep that will and can;</line>
      <line>Not I: let God and man decree</line>
      <line>Laws for themselves and not for me;</line>
      <line>And if my ways are not as theirs</line>
      <line>Let them mind their own affairs.</line>
      <line>Their deeds I judge and much condemn,</line>
      <line>Yet when did I make laws for them?</line>
      <line>Please yourselves, say I, and they</line>
      <line>Need only look the other way.</line>
      <line>But no, they will not; they must still</line>
      <line>Wrest their neighbour to their will,</line>
      <line>And make me dance as they desire</line>
      <line>With jail and gallows and hell-fire.</line>
      <line>And how am I to face the odds</line>
      <line>Of man’s bedevilment and God’s?</line>
      <line>I, a stranger and afraid</line>
      <line>In a world I never made.</line>
      <line>They will be master, right or wrong;</line>
      <line>Though both are foolish, both are strong.</line>
      <line>And since, my soul, we cannot fly</line>
      <line>To Saturn nor to Mercury',</line>
      <line>Keep we must, if keep we can,</line>
      <line>These foreign laws of God and man.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>When the eye of day is shut,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the eye of day is shut,</line>
      <line>And the stars deny their beams,</line>
      <line>And about the forest hut</line>
      <line>Blows the roaring wood of dreams,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>From deep clay, from desert rock,</line>
      <line>From the sunk sands of the main,</line>
      <line>Come not at my door to knock,</line>
      <line>Hearts that loved me not again.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Sleep, be still, turn to your rest</line>
      <line>In the lands where you are laid;</line>
      <line>In far lodgings east and west</line>
      <line>Lie down on the beds you made.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>In gross marl, in blowing dust,</line>
      <line>In the drowned ooze of the sea,</line>
      <line>Where you would not, lie you must,</line>
      <line>Lie you must, and not with me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1901</date>
    <title>Some can gaze and not be sick,</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Some can gaze and not be sick,</line>
      <line>But I could never learn the trick.</line>
      <line>There’s this to say for blood and breath,</line>
      <line>They give a man a taste for death.</line>
      <line>(Wr. 1900-1?; pub. 1937)</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>A.E. Housman</author>
    <date>1900</date>
    <title>The sigh that heaves the grasses</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>The sigh that heaves the grasses</line>
      <line>Whence thou wilt never rise</line>
      <line>Is of the air that passes</line>
      <line>And knows not if it sighs.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The diamond tears adorning</line>
      <line>Thy low mound on the lea,</line>
      <line>Those are the tears of morning,</line>
      <line>That weeps, but not for thee.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Victor Plarr</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>Shadows</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>A SONG of shadows: never glory was</line>
      <line>But it had some soft shadow that would lie</line>
      <line>On wall, on quiet water, on smooth grass,</line>
      <line>Or in the vistas of the phantasy:</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The shadow of the house upon the lawn,</line>
      <line>Upon the house the shadow of the tree,</line>
      <line>And through the moon-steeped hours unto the dawn</line>
      <line>The shadow of thy beauty over me.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Victor Plarr</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>Of Change of Opinions</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As you advance in years you long</line>
      <line>For what you scorned when but a boy:</line>
      <line>Then ’twas the town, now the birds’ song</line>
      <line>Is your obsession and your joy.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And, as you lie and die, maybe</line>
      <line>You will look back, unreconciled</line>
      <line>To that dark hour, and clearly see</line>
      <line>Yourself a little wistful child.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Into the jaws of death you’ll bring</line>
      <line>No virile triumph, wrought with pain;</line>
      <line>But only to the monster fling</line>
      <line>The daydream and the daisy-chain,</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>The lisped word, the gentle touch,</line>
      <line>The wonder, and the mystic thought,</line>
      <line>For old gray Death upon his crutch</line>
      <line>To rake into his Bag of Nought.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Hilaire Belloc</author>
    <date>1896</date>
    <title>The Justice of the Peace</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Distinguish carefully between these two,</line>
      <line>This thing is yours, that other thing is mine.</line>
      <line>You have a shirt, a brimless hat, a shoe</line>
      <line>And half a coat. I am the Lord benign</line>
      <line>Of fifty hundred acres of fat land</line>
      <line>To which I have a right. You understand?</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I have a right because I have, because,</line>
      <line>Because I have—because I have a right.</line>
      <line>Now be quite calm and good, obey the laws,</line>
      <line>Remember your low station, do not fight</line>
      <line>Against the good, because, you know, it pricks</line>
      <line>Whenever the uncleanly demos kicks.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>I do not envy you your hat, your shoe.</line>
      <line>Why should you envy me my small estate?</line>
      <line>It’s fearfully illogical in you</line>
      <line>To fight with economic force and fate.</line>
      <line>Moreover, I have got the upper hand,</line>
      <line>And mean to keep it. Do you understand?</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Francis Thompson</author>
    <date>1897</date>
    <title>The End of It</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>She did not love to love, but hated him</line>
      <line>For making her to love; and so her whim</line>
      <line>From passion taught misprision to begin.</line>
      <line>And all this sin</line>
      <line>Was because love to cast out had no skill</line>
      <line>Self, which was regent still.</line>
      <line>Her own self-will made void her own seifs will.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Frederick Tennyson</author>
    <date>1913</date>
    <title>Old Age</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>As when into the garden paths by night</line>
      <line>One bears a lamp, and with its sickly glare</line>
      <line>Scatters the burnished flowers a-dreaming there,</line>
      <line>Palely they show like spectres in his sight,</line>
      <line>Lovely no more, disfurnished of delight,</line>
      <line>Some folded up and drooping o’er the way,</line>
      <line>Their odours spent, their colour changed to gray,</line>
      <line>Some that stood queen-like in the morning light</line>
      <line>Fallen discrowned: so the low-burning loves</line>
      <line>That tremble in the hearts of aged men</line>
      <line>Cast their own light upon the world that moves</line>
      <line>Around them, and receive it back again.</line>
      <line>Old joys seem dead, old faces without joys;</line>
      <line>Laughter is dead. There is no mirth in boys.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>

  <poem>
    <author>Dora Sigerson Shorter</author>
    <date>1899</date>
    <title>The Wind on the Hills</title>
    <lines>
    <stanza>
      <line>Go not to the hills of Erinn</line>
      <line>When the night winds are about,</line>
      <line>Put up your bar and shutter,</line>
      <line>And so keep the danger out.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>For the good-folk whirl within it,</line>
      <line>And they pull you by the hand,</line>
      <line>And they push you on the shoulder,</line>
      <line>Till you move to their command.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And lo! you have forgotten</line>
      <line>What you have known of tears,</line>
      <line>And you will not remember</line>
      <line>That the world goes full of years;</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>A year there is a lifetime,</line>
      <line>And a second but a day,</line>
      <line>And an older world will meet you</line>
      <line>Each morn you come away.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>Your wife grows old with weeping,</line>
      <line>And your children one by one</line>
      <line>Grow grey with nights of watching,</line>
      <line>Before your dance is done.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And it will chance some morning</line>
      <line>You will come home no more;</line>
      <line>Your wife sees but a withered leaf</line>
      <line>In the wind about the door.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And your children will inherit</line>
      <line>The unrest of the wind,</line>
      <line>They shall seek some face elusive,</line>
      <line>And some land they never find.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>When the wind is loud, they sighing</line>
      <line>Go with hearts unsatisfied,</line>
      <line>For some joy beyond remembrance,</line>
      <line>For some memory denied.</line>
    </stanza>
    <stanza>
      <line>And all your children’s children,</line>
      <line>They cannot sleep or rest,</line>
      <line>When the wind is out in Erinn</line>
      <line>And the sun is in the West.</line>
    </stanza>
    </lines>
  </poem>
</poems>
